title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I miss my neighbors. I feel blessed and fortunate that my house was saved, but this place was more than houses and yards -- it was a community.''

title: Some in Congress Seek Inquiry Over Drug Supply to Canada
description: Twenty-two members of Congress have signed a letter asking Attorney General John Ashcroft to investigate whether the pharmaceutical industry has violated antitrust laws by restricting sales to Canadian wholesalers and pharmacies that export to the United States.

title: Sondheim Guides Two Brothers On a Tour of Life
description: Life unfolds like a road map, neatly creased and popping with place names, in ''Bounce,'' the singing itinerary of a show from Stephen Sondheim that opened on Thursday night at the Kennedy Center.

title: Gathering for '03 World Titles; A Sensational Mix-Up in '76
description: The top players from five continents will converge this weekend on Monte Carlo, where the World Championships will be played over the next two weeks. The last time the contest was played there, in 1976, some bizarre episodes occurred.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: No Apology For Anti-Jewish Remarks
description: A parliamentarian, Martin Hohmann of the conservative Christian Democrats, has refused to apologize for saying that Jews could be described as a ''race of perpetrators'' for their role in the Russian Revolution. In an Oct. 3 speech in Neuhof, his hometown, Mr. Hohmann compared the killings in Russia's violent 1917 revolution, which he said were orchestrated by Jewish Bolsheviks, with the murder of Europe's Jews during the Holocaust. Jewish leaders and members of all Germany's political parties have condemned the remarks, and deputies from Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's Social Democrats have called for Mr. Hohmann's dismissal from Parliament. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Out of the Asylum, Into The Cell
description: A new report by Human Rights Watch has found that American prisons and jails contain three times more mentally ill people than do our psychiatric hospitals. The study confirmed what mental health and corrections experts have long known: incarceration has become the nation's default mental health treatment. And while the report offers good suggestions on how to help those who are incarcerated, a bigger question is what we can do to keep them from ending up behind bars at all.

title: A Top Costume in the City: The Invisible Student
description: Bravery takes many forms in this city, where tigers live in public housing and no self-respecting citizen can be too creative when it comes to self-defense. That is why Josnuel Paulino, a ninth grader at Martin Luther King High School, was so proud of himself yesterday for going to school on Halloween. And why his friend Valerie Nuez was standing on West 66th Street in Manhattan with a packet of ketchup in her jacket pocket.

title: Op-Art
European poll calls Israel a threat to world peace
description: PARIS:  Almost 60 percent of Europeans say that Israel is a larger threat to world peace than North Korea, Iran or Afghanistan, according to a poll scheduled to be made public Monday by the European Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAIMAN, DORIS WEINKLE
description: NAIMAN--Doris Weinkle. Beloved wife of Richard. Dearest mother of Francie, Rachel and Alec. Loving sister-inlaw of Elaine Taibi. Professor Emerita, New York University. Funeral Monday, United Hebrew Community, 201 East Broadway, NYC, 9:30 AM.

title: Orwell's World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REIDY, JOHN
description: REIDY--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Reidy, associated with The Times from 1965 until retiring in 1993.

title: Malaysia Today
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad leaves Malaysia with a strong economy. The following World Bank data highlight the state of his nation:

title: Everlast to Close Plant in Bronx; 100 Workers to Lose Their Jobs
description: Everlast Worldwide Inc., which began producing boxing gloves and punching bags in the South Bronx more than 90 years ago, is moving out of the neighborhood, and 100 jobs will be lost, company officials said yesterday.

title: Oklahoma and Oklahoma State Have Lots to Lose
description: When No. 1 Oklahoma plays host to Oklahoma State today, it is not just the unbeaten Sooners who have everything to lose.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: PRISON FOR EX-OFFICIAL Former Attorney General Dan Morales was sentenced to four years in a federal prison for mail fraud and tax evasion in a case involving Texas' $17 billion settlement with the tobacco industry in 1998. An indictment to which Mr. Morales pleaded guilty last summer said he tried to steer more than a million dollars in unearned legal fees to a Houston lawyer, Marc Murr, who admitted his role in the scheme in October and received a six-month prison term. Mr. Morales, a Democrat, served two terms as Texas attorney general and ran for governor in 2002.

title: Years of Feeding Wall Street Meet Abrupt End at Harry's
description: Harry's Hanover Square, a venerable Financial District restaurant that feted the market's winners and solaced its losers for more than three decades, closed its doors abruptly last night with no plans to reopen anytime soon.

title: The Roles Of Olympic Bidders Addressed
description: Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson, who coordinated Salt Lake City's successful bid for the 2002 Winter Olympics, were either savvy lawbreakers or upright citizens who brought triumph to their state and opportunity to foreign students.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the yen after an industry report showed manufacturing in the Chicago area strengthened. In New York, the dollar settled at 110 yen, up from 108.74 on Thursday.

title: In the Middle East, Dreams and Reality (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Good News at Last, or Is It? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDLOWITZ, MILTON, M.D.
description: MENDLOWITZ--Milton, M.D. October 30, 2003. Dearest husband of Muriel, nee Chertoff. Devoted father of Judith Chertoff Berman, Susan Burnette and Benjamin Mendlowitz. Adored grandfather of nine and great-grandfather. He was a Professor Emeritus at Mount Sinai Hospital where he was affiliated for 65 years as a renouned researcher, teacher and attending physician. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 10 about NBC executives' support for Jay Leno after he introduced Arnold Schwarzenegger's victory speech in California referred incorrectly to the precedent for late-night hosts' public participation in politics. This was not the first such display: Johnny Carson appeared on a nationally televised fund-raiser for Hubert H. Humphrey in 1968.

title: RUSSIAN PREMIER STEPS INTO FRAY ON JAILED TYCOON
description: Russia's prime minister on Friday criticized the freezing of a large block of shares in the Yukos Oil Company, saying he was ''deeply concerned.'' His statement, which followed a warning from President Vladimir V. Putin against ministerial meddling in the case, verged on open defiance and exposed deepening rifts in the Kremlin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACARI, CLAUDIA C. (NEE CORBYONS)
description: MACARI--Claudia C. (nee Corbyons), of Bronx, NY, on October 31, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Leopold M. Loving mother of Robert, Paul, Thomas and Claudette Melton. Funeral Mass Monday, 10 AM, at St. Philip Neri Church, Bronx, NY. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. The family will be present Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: Congressional Unit Analyzes Military Costs in Iraq
description: A new analysis by the Congressional Budget Office suggests that the military costs for the occupation of Iraq could range from $85 billion over four years to $200 billion over 10 years, even if the Pentagon sharply reduces the forces there.

title: Brokerage Firm Is Said to Get Subpoena in Spitzer Inquiry
description: The attorney general of New York has filed a subpoena seeking information from D.C. Capital, a brokerage firm, in connection with his investigation of the mutual fund industry, a person briefed on the matter said yesterday.

title: Grateful for Pell Grant
description: To the Editor:

title: Quarterback Is Rejecting Mark He Feels Is Tainted
description: A week ago, Nate Haasis, the quarterback of a high school football team in Springfield, Ill., became his conference's leader in career passing yardage. Now he is winning praise for requesting that the record be expunged.

title: An Asian Autocrat's Departure
description: It is hard to imagine Malaysia without Mahathir Mohamad. Prime minister for 22 years, Dr. Mahathir has become synonymous with his nation. Other than the weather, little happens in Malaysia beyond his control, and some credit him with the rainfall. But Dr. Mahathir stepped down yesterday. His final days in office were like his two decades of rule, filled with controversy: his scripted departure was marred by an anti-Semitic diatribe at an Islamic leaders' conference. Dr. Mahathir turned over power to a handpicked successor (his earlier choice for heir is still imprisoned on false charges) and left a nation that is prosperous but undemocratic, corrupt and lacking the institutions necessary for enduring success.

title: Miami Looks to Add To Its Winning Streak
description: The Miami Hurricanes will try to take sole possession of second place on the list of longest regular-season winning streaks in college football when they play Virginia Tech in Blacksburg tonight.

title: Unconstitutional Farm Checkoffs
description: One of the major battles in American farming in the past few years concerns the fees collected from farmers to pay for generic advertising like the familiar ''Got Milk?'' and ''Pork: The Other White Meat'' campaigns. The so-called checkoffs are mandated by the federal Agriculture Department but administered by industry groups. The mandatory checkoffs may look small -- 40 cents for every $100 in sales in the case of pork -- but they add up.

title: Gil Nickel, 64, Wine Enthusiast Who Became a Leading Vintner
description: Gil Nickel, a onetime guided-missile expert from Oklahoma who became a prominent wine producer in the Napa Valley, died on Thursday at his home in Oakville, Calif. He was 64.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Inspector Sees Progress
description: The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said investigators were making ''good progress'' in their scrutiny of Iran's nuclear program. The official, Mohamed ElBaradei, said he had been told ''to expect by next week'' a letter from Iran government accepting terms of a protocol that would permit surprise inspections, ''a very positive step forward.'' Iran is under pressure to prove that it is not building nuclear weapons. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Crews Put Weariness Aside In Struggle to Save Homes
description: Members of the strike team, 21 firefighters heading into their eighth straight day of battling the wildfires, made their way through this threatened mountain enclave in the San Bernardino National Forest on Friday using every tool they had to defend the homes from destruction.

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: 12 Nebraska (7-1) at 16 Texas (6-2)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HARTIG, HERBERT
description: HARTIG -- Herbert. 11/1/91. Now you can say it's written in stone. How brillig. Naomi

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report yesterday about the start of a weeklong mission to Afghanistan referred imprecisely to the starting date. The delegation left yesterday for Afghanistan; it is to arrive in Kabul on Sunday.

title: On the Job Today: A Young Worker's View
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Middle East, Dreams and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Seeking Smallpox Defenses

title: Bioterror Researchers Build A More Lethal Mousepox
description: Scientists have created a highly lethal virus in an effort to develop stronger protections against supervirulent forms of smallpox that terrorists might turn on humans, researchers said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAUBARD, SEYMOUR
description: GRAUBARD -- Seymour. North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sy Graubard. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Peter J. Baum, President Stuart Bednoff, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIN, LILLIAN
description: FEIN--Lillian. Devoted sister to Florence Wasserstein and Milton Fein. Passed away on October 29, She will be greatly missed and leaves a void that can never be filled. Services on Sunday at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 10:30AM.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on developments in Iraq misstated the whereabouts of a United Nations spokeswoman who discussed the decision by Secretary General Kofi Annan to withdraw non-Iraqi staff members of the United Nations from the country while security measures were reviewed. The spokeswoman, Marie Okabe, was at headquarters in New York, not in Baghdad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REGOSIN, BERNARD
description: REGOSIN--Bernard. Beloved husband of Felice. Devoted father of Stephanie. Dear brother of Ethel Weiss. Services Sunday, 11 AM at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Spending Bill Nears Passage In the Senate
description: The largest emergency spending bill in the nation's history, pilloried for two months by opponents as too generous to Iraq, is quietly moving toward final Congressional approval on Monday as an almost complete victory for President Bush.

title: Lessons From Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston U. Pays Leader to Quit Before Starting
description: Just one day before he was to take over as the trustees' unanimous choice to lead Boston University, Daniel S. Goldin, the former NASA administrator, agreed to walk away from the presidency of the nation's fourth-largest private university for a reported payment of $1.8 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Religion Journal; A Synagogue Steeped in Harlem History Defies the Odds, but Still Struggles to Survive
description: Whenever Paul Radensky, president of the Old Broadway Synagogue, shuts the lights and locks the sanctuary after Sabbath services, he first raises the decorative curtain covering the Torah ark, to remove it from the reach of rats.

title: Jets Once Again Need Some November Magic
description: Without hesitating and with some pride, Coach Herman Edwards had an instant answer Friday when he was asked about his record with the Jets in November.

title: Lieberman on the Iraq War and Doing What Is Right
description: This 30-second advertisement, ''Doing What's Right,'' is one of two advertisements for Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut being shown on television for the first time this week in New Hampshire. They are Mr. Lieberman's first campaign advertisements of the season. The spots are being shown on broadcast stations that reach New Hampshire voters, but not on the more expensive Boston stations that reach the southern part of the state. The campaign is using local cable systems.

title: Subways Are Noisy, Study Finds, To the Point of Being Harmful
description: Everyone who rides the subways knows they can be irritating during rush hours and sweltering in the summer. But a new report by the City Council says they can also be hazardous to hearing.

title: Friday Night Lights, Camera, Broadcast
description: It used to be that nothing was bigger than the local high school football game between Homecoming rivals. Now, like Troy falling to a gimmick after a decade-long siege, that innocent era officially ended a week ago Friday night, with the first nationally televised high school football game. The contest, between De La Salle of Concord, Calif., and Evangel Christian Academy of Shreveport, La., was the final victory of professionalization, commercialization and, most of all, nationalization over a game that has always been proudly, passionately home-grown.

title: Duncan and San Antonio Are the Knicks' Next Test
description: It is never too early to make winning a habit, the Knicks said at practice Friday. Belaboring the obvious? Yes. Using preventive reinforcement? Perhaps.

title: Valentine May Manage Again in Japan
description: Bobby Valentine, a former manager of the Mets and the Texas Rangers, who spent the past season as an analyst for ESPN, is scheduled to arrive in Japan today to discuss a deal to manage the Chiba Lotte Marines, a team he guided in 1995, Kyodo News reported yesterday. The Marines' deputy owner, Akio Shigemitsu, told Kyodo that he hoped to sign Valentine by tomorrow to a contract of three to five years. Rafael Hermoso

title: Pension Funds Drop Putnam As Manager
description: Several public pension funds and university endowments fired Putnam Investments as their money manager yesterday, bringing total withdrawals from the company to more than $4 billion since it was formally accused of securities fraud on Tuesday.

title: CALIFORNIA AMPLIFIER SAYS EARNINGS WILL AT LEAST DOUBLE
description: California Amplifier, which makes components for wireless and satellite communications, said yesterday that third-quarter per-share earnings would at least double. The news sent its shares 43 percent higher. Profit in the period, which ends Nov. 30, will be 13 to 17 cents a share. Third-quarter sales will be $41 million to $44 million, compared with an Oct. 2 forecast of $30 million to $36 million, the company said. California Amplifier earned 6 cents a share on revenue of $24 million a year earlier. Stock in California Amplifier, which is based in Camarillo, Calif., rose $2.96, to $9.90 a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Entertainment Group
description: The children's entertainment group Cinar, best known for creating Arthur the Aardvark, has agreed to a $143.9 million cash bid from a group led by Michael Hirsh, co-founder of the Teletoon animation channel, in partnership with the private equity arm of Toronto-Dominion Bank. Cinar's founders and controlling shareholders, Ronald Weinberg and Micheline Charest, are barred from any active role in its affairs but have agreed to support the takeover offer. Cinar, based in Montreal, agreed earlier to compensate minority shareholders for losses suffered after a year's worth of revenue was siphoned into an investment firm in the Bahamas. Other lawsuits are pending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BESUNDER, LILLIAN R.
description: BESUNDER--Lillian R. Died October 31. Beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted mother of Jon L. and Rhonda S. Cherished sister of Renee. Funeral services Sunday, November 2nd at the I.J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, N.Y. 800-624-8282

title: Suspect Accused of Trying to Aid North Korea
description: A New Jersey man was arrested Friday on charges that he sent blueprints for specialized valves to a company's office in New York, knowing that the blueprints would be passed on to North Korea, federal prosecutors said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the third-quarter results for the Comcast Corporation misstated the drop in the number of subscribers to its cable phone service. It was 55,000, not 55.6 million.

title: 'Zhivago' Without Hollywood
description: There is a moment when a blurred glimpse of a blond girl in an astrakhan hat peering through a frosted window causes one's heart to leap like Yury Zhivago's. Is it, could it be . . . Julie Christie?

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Taking the Oxymoron Out of 'German Cuisine'
description: YOU could say that Wolfram Siebeck's almost single-handed campaign to transform the way Germans eat began with his discovery that shallots were unavailable in Germany.

title: Good News at Last, or Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS RAISES PROFIT FORECAST
description: Piedmont Natural Gas said yesterday that profit would rise in the fiscal year that begins today after the company added customers in North Carolina and won rate increases there and in Tennessee. Profit will be $2.25 to $2.40 a share, Piedmont said. That compares with the company's 2003 forecast of $2.05 to $2.15. Piedmont plans to sell $200 million in stock and $250 million in debt to finance the purchase of North Carolina gas assets from Progress Energy. That acquisition increased Piedmont's customers by 24 percent, to 920,000, in the Southeast.

title: William Draper, 90, Painter Who Portrayed Presidents
description: William F. Draper, a portrait painter and former combat artist who depicted many of the world's wealthiest and most powerful, died at his home in Manhattan on Sunday. He was 90.

title: In the Middle East, Dreams and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking to the Dead To Protect the Living
description: The home, we like to think, is a haven in a heartless world, a refuge from the dangerous and death-ridden realm beyond its doors. But as Robert Pogue Harrison suggests in ''The Dominion of the Dead,'' an evocative, subtle and occasionally difficult meditation, the home has its origins more as a protection for the dead than as a shelter for the living. ''Human beings housed their dead before they housed themselves,'' he writes, and that housing involved more than just crypts and graves.

title: The Value of Fetuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Good News at Last, or Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, CRISSY
description: STEIN--Crissy. On October 30, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Ephraim. Devoted mother of Margery, Jonathan and Bruce. Cherished grandmother of Peter, Whitney, Mariel, Joshua, Benjamin and Emma. Services Sunday 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: A Plan to Import Drugs Safely
description: The state of Illinois has effectively skewered contentions by the federal Food and Drug Administration that it would be risky to import prescription drugs from Canada to save substantial sums of money. Indeed, an expert panel that visited Canada on behalf of the state has fashioned a plan that should actually make it safer for state employees to purchase drugs from Canada than in this country.

title: G.I. Dies After Clash With Taliban in Southern Afghanistan
description: An American Special Forces soldier has died from wounds sustained during an operation against Taliban guerrillas in southern Afghanistan, the United States military said Friday. He is the third American to die in operations in Afghanistan in less than a week.

title: Halloween Revelers Attack Man, 24
description: A 24-year-old man was stabbed last night in Hollis, Queens, by a group of teenagers who had been engaging in ''Halloween hooliganism,'' the police said.

title: Good News at Last, or Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Chance Justice Is Done? Russia's System Is Questioned
description: Anton V. Drel arrived at the grim Mastrosskaya Tishina prison here last Saturday and signed the papers declaring him the official counsel of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest tycoon. Then a prosecutor presented Mr. Drel with a summons to be questioned as a witness.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Posts Profit
description: The Japanese airline All Nippon Airways earned 20.6 billion yen ($190 million) in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, helped by cost cuts and a one-time gain on its pension plan. The profit followed an 8 billion yen loss in the period last year and came despite a decline in international travel because of the spread of the SARS virus earlier this year. The airline raised its profit target for the full year by 16.7 percent, to 17.5 billion yen ($160 million), because of cost cuts. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Raising Funds
description: The drug maker Elan Corporation said it planned to raise $633.3 million by issuing 35 million new shares and selling $460 million in bonds, but the offers are available only to investors outside the United States because Elan is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The shares will be priced at $4.95 each, and the five-year notes mature at 6.75 percent, after which they can be converted into shares. Since 2002, Elan has raised nearly $1.9 billion by selling noncore assets; it plans to use the new funds to continue paying its $2.3 billion debt, the company said. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Judge Suspends Order On Crosses
description: A judge suspended for now an earlier court order that a crucifix be removed from a school in Ofena, about 90 miles east of Rome, and scheduled a hearing for next month. The earlier order came in response to a lawsuit filed by a local Muslim resident and inflamed many Italians. Pope John Paul II directly addressed the issue in remarks to European Union officials, saying that recognizing a nation's religious heritage ''means recognizing the symbols that set it apart.'' An overwhelming majority of Italians are nominally Roman Catholic. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GANNETT, McLean, Va., publisher of USA Today, said it bought Clipper Magazine, Lancaster, Pa., an independent direct-mail advertising company that reaches about 230 million readers annually. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TORIES' CHOICE NARROWS Michael Howard was virtually assured of succeeding Iain Duncan Smith, the ousted Conservative Party leader, when the final potential contender, Kenneth Clarke, the loser to Mr. Duncan Smith in a runoff election two years ago, said he would not be a candidate this time. Mr. Clarke, former chancellor of the exchequer and the standard bearer of the Tories' liberal wing, threw his backing to Mr. Howard, a former home secretary and traditional right winger, and commended him for saying he would lead the Conservatives "from the center." Barring the entry of a maverick before the deadline for nominations on Thursday, Mr. Howard will become the new leader, and the party will be spared a lengthy and divisive election process involving its 300,000 members. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Car Bursts Through Bushs Security Cordon
description: SOUTHAVEN, Miss., Nov. 1  A driver sped a car through a security cordon Saturday morning toward where President Bush was boarding his limousine after attending a political rally here. Mr. Bush was not harmed.

title: From Noah's Curse to Slavery's Rationale
description: As stories go, this one has all the elements of good soap opera: nudity, sex and dysfunctional families.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 3 Years For Youth Who Sent Threat Parcels
description: A 17-year-old Scottish student was sentenced in Edinburgh High Court to three years in a reform school for sending a letter claiming to having sent ricin poison to Prince William at his university hall and a bottle of aromatherapy eucalyptus oil laced with caustic soda to Cherie Blair, the wife of Prime Minister Tony Blair. The teenager, Paul Smith, admitted sending 44 hoax letters two years ago to the House of Commons, the Scottish Parliament, Scotland Yard, the Home Office and the BBC after being instructed to do so over the Internet by a Scottish anti-English terror group, which was not named. His actions ''could not properly be described in any sense as mere youthful indiscretions or pranks,'' the judge, Lord Kingarth, said. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Democratic Ads Return Fire In Battle Over City Primaries
description: With just three days to go before city voters decide whether to radically change the system for electing local officials, Democrats began mailing out their own literature yesterday urging New Yorkers to vote no on question No. 3.

title: 3 Suits Filed to Block an Abortion Bill That Bush Intends to Sign
description: With President Bush widely expected to sign soon the first federal law prohibiting a specific abortion procedure, opponents filed three suits on Friday seeking to overturn the imminent ban on the grounds that it would be overly broad and unconstitutional.

title: Robert J. Barnes, 86, Leader In Building Este Lauder Brand
description: Robert J. Barnes, a makeup salesman who spent a quarter-century building Este Lauder into one of the best-selling brands in cosmetics, died on Sunday at his home in Monarch Beach, Calif. He was 86.

title: ChevronTexaco Has Its Best Quarter Yet
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation yesterday reported its biggest profit since the 2001 merger that created the company. Earnings exceeded analyst expectations as prices rose and profit margins in oil refining widened.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on developments in Iraq misstated the whereabouts of a United Nations spokeswoman who discussed the decision by Secretary General Kofi Annan to withdraw non-Iraqi staff members of the United Nations from the country while security measures were reviewed. The spokeswoman, Marie Okabe, was at headquarters in New York, not in Baghdad.

title: Putting Schoenberg in Context
description: In its current exhibition, ''Schoenberg, Kandinsky and the Blue Rider,'' the Jewish Museum has brought together a large collection of Arnold Schoenberg's paintings as well as some of his musical manuscripts and some important canvases by Wassily Kandinsky. But an exhibition that includes works by a painter who was far more important as a composer cries out for a musical component.

title: Sports of The Times; Scott Must Keep an Eye On His Back This Year
description: RARE is the coach who leads his team to the N.B.A. finals and begins the next season on the firing line. But the Nets are not your normal franchise, and Byron Scott is not just any coach.

title: Orwell's World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBEL, PAULINE DODGE PRATT
description: WEBEL -- Pauline Dodge Pratt of Glen Head, LI on October 21, 2003. Age 95. Beloved wife of the late Richard K. Webel and the late Frederic R. Pratt. Mother of Robert G. Pratt, Arthur D. Pratt, Polly Brown and Richard C. Webel. Sister of Marshall J. Dodge. Grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of five. Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Sunday, November 2, at 2PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Frederic R. Pratt Memorial Library, C/O Jasper County Chamber of Commerce, Box 1267, Ridgeland, S.C. 29936.

title: NETWORK ASSOCIATES RESTATES RESULTS FOR SIX YEARS
description: Network Associates, the subject of two federal accounting investigations, filed reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday showing restated results since 1998 because of a change in revenue recognition. The restatement moves software and other sales for 1998 through 2000 and books them from 2001 through the first half of this year, the chief financial officer, Stephen C. Richards, said. The revenue was previously booked at the time of the initial sale, he said, though it should have been recorded as services were delivered.

title: Court Approves WorldCom Plan
description: WorldCom won court approval yesterday for a reorganization plan that would allow it to emerge from the largest bankruptcy in history early next year.

title: Daughter Spurs Shift in Gephardt's View on Gays
description: The first hint of the unexpected was in the annual Christmas card from Congress. There, in the photo of Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and his smiling family, stood his daughter Chrissy with her arm around another woman.

title: Fatal Stabbing Linked to Chinatown Bus Business
description: A fight over a Chinatown discount bus route ended in a stabbing death on Thursday night, the police said.

title: Train Derails In Rahway On Its Way To Manhattan
description: A commuter train bound for Manhattan derailed Friday morning, disrupting travel for thousands of passengers on 24 New Jersey Transit and Amtrak trains on the Northeast Corridor line, officials said. It was the third derailment since mid-July of a commuter train headed to New York City from New Jersey.

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: FORMER STATE OFFICIAL IS CONVICTED A former state agriculture commissioner, Meg Scott Phipps, was found guilty of perjury and obstruction of justice. Prosecutors said Ms. Phipps conspired to cover up illegal campaign donations from vendors who wanted to work at the state fair. Her lawyers argued that her aides had kept her in the dark about the payments. Ms. Phipps, the daughter and granddaughter of North Carolina governors, could be sentenced to more than four years in prison. She also faces federal charges. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tories' Choice Narrows
description: Michael Howard was virtually assured of succeeding Iain Duncan Smith, the ousted Conservative Party leader, when the final potential contender, Kenneth Clarke, said he would not be a candidate this time. Mr. Clarke, former chancellor of the exchequer and the standard bearer of the Tories' liberal wing, threw his backing to Mr. Howard, a former home secretary and traditional right winger, and commended him for saying he would lead the Conservatives ''from the center.'' The deadline for nominations is Thursday, and it seems the party will be spared a divisive election process involving its 300,000 members. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Songs That Hurtle Through Urban Pressures
description: ''I don't wanna waste your time,'' were the first words Julian Casablancas of the Strokes sang on Wednesday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, and he meant them. The Strokes take succinctness seriously. Their entire set lasted only an hour, with songs taking about three minutes each.

title: Firsts and Lasts in Mozart and Haydn
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's performance in Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was a felicitous combination of firsts and lasts: the conductor Jane Glover's Carnegie debut, on the one hand, and Mozart's last piano concerto (No. 27) and Haydn's last symphony (No. 104), on the other. Mozart's Symphony No. 29 rounded out a pleasant if somewhat monochromatic program.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Approval For Weapons Incinerator
description: The Arkansas Supreme Court upheld the state's approval for the Army to build a facility to destroy chemical weapons from the Pine Bluff Arsenal. Opponents argued that the state's environmental regulators were not taking into full account the risk of air pollution from the weapons' incineration. Approximately 3,850 tons of chemical weapons, including sarin and mustard gas, are stored at Pine Bluff, according to the ruling. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Judicial Nominees
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Teacher's Pets
description: The Stevenson School is a one-room schoolhouse here in the badlands along the North Dakota-Montana border. It has four students -- and that's assuming that Lexie Russell and Josh Rockeman, both 8, can canoe across the Little Missouri River to get to school.

title: Torre Tells His Boss To Stop Meddling
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre has a message for George Steinbrenner: Be quiet. Or, perhaps more delicately, be supportive. Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, invited Torre to the team's organizational meetings this week in Tampa, Fla. Torre said he used the setting to make a point to his boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNELLER, ADELINE V. (NEE GOLDHAMMER)
description: SCHNELLER -- Adeline V. (nee Goldhammer), on October 28, 2003, in Bethesda, Md., in her 94th year. Longtime resident of NYC and Boca Raton. Beloved wife of Maxwell for 74 years. Devoted mother to Marlene Harte and Joan Knight and their husbands. Adored grandmother to Roger and John Harte and their wives; to Jennifer Dormarunno and Regina Donovan and their husbands. Cherished great-grandmother to Amalia, Penina, Joshua and Rachel Harte and Reid Donovan. Interment Sunday, November 2, at noon, at Mt. Sharon Cemetery in Philadelphia.

title: Calls to Jihad Are Said to Lure Hundreds of Militants Into Iraq
description: Across Europe and the Middle East, young militant Muslim men are answering a call issued by Osama bin Laden and other extremists, and leaving home to join the fight against the American-led occupation in Iraq, according to senior counterterrorism officials based in six countries.

title: What's This? An Actual Judicial Election?
description: Ordinarily, we wouldn't bother to endorse anyone running for State Supreme Court in next Tuesday's election in New York City, and for a very simple reason. Competitive races for the state's top trial court have become so rare that they are practically an endangered species. By and large, these important judgeships go without a fight to the clubhouse favorites awarded a spot on the Democratic Party line, which is normally tantamount to election in this overwhelmingly Democratic town.

title: Clues to an Unfounded Claim Of 3 Deaths in 9/11 Attack
description: It has been one of the enduring mysteries of 9/11: an unfounded claim that a Long Island man and his two young children died when he took them to his office at the World Trade Center. The children would have been the youngest victims.

title: Shotgun in Hand, Kerry Defines His Gun-Control Stance
description: Senator John Kerry blasted away at Howard Dean on Friday, accusing him of currying favor with the National Rifle Association and opposing an assault-weapons ban that Mr. Kerry and other supporters of gun control fought for in the 1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VANAUKEN, CHARLES (VAN)
description: VANAUKEN--Charles (Van). 78, died on October 30, 2003. A talented and creative diamond cutter for over 50 years on 47th Street, NYC. He was a passionate outdoorsman who loved nature. An avid fisherman his entire life. Beloved husband of Estelle, loving father of Mark, Allison, Denise and Jody; son-in-law Roy; daughters-in-law Lily and Carol; adored grandfather of Adam, Michelle, Lindsay, Ethan, Elise and Marci. Service will be held at Wandy Memorial Chapel, 1841 New York Ave, Huntington Station, N.Y. Route 110 north of the Long Island Expressway on Sunday, November 2nd at 1pm, 631-427-7700.

title: California Firefighters Gain Control, With Weather's Aid
description: Aided by wet weather and light winds, firefighters appeared to get the upper hand on Southern California's wildfires on Friday, at least for the day.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Former State Official Is Convicted
description: A former state agriculture commissioner, Meg Scott Phipps, was found guilty of perjury and obstruction of justice. Prosecutors said Ms. Phipps conspired to cover up illegal campaign donations from vendors who wanted to work at the state fair. Her lawyers argued that her aides had kept her in the dark about the payments. Ms. Phipps, the daughter and granddaughter of North Carolina governors, could be sentenced to more than four years in prison. She also faces federal charges. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Sports articles on Tuesday and Wednesday about the National Football League's plans to discipline players found to be using a newly detected steroid known as THG misstated the progress of the investigation into the identity of the steroid's manufacturer. While one American antidoping official said he was ''fairly certain'' THG came from the Bay Area Laboratory Cooperative of Burlingame, Calif., federal investigators have not yet determined the source.

title: High-Tech Daydreamers Investing In Immortality
description: Aubrey de Grey took the stage of the Camden Opera House, tugging at a beard worthy of Methuselah, to tell his listeners that they could triumph over death.

title: Union Raises Questions After Collapse
description: As the investigation began into a parking garage collapse that killed four workers, union leaders asked on Friday if one factor might have been pressure they said their members felt to speed up construction of the $245 million Tropicana casino expansion.

title: Brown Wins First Men's Ivy Title
description: Steve Sundell of Columbia University capped four years of steady improvement by winning the men's individual five-mile race, and Brown University won its first men's team title at the 76th annual Ivy League/Heptagonal cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Sniper Jury Shown Evidence Of a Motive for Shootings
description: Shortly after Jeffrey Hopper was wounded last Oct. 19 in the 12th sniper attack in the Washington area, investigators scouring a wooded area behind the shooting scene in Ashland, Va., discovered a vital piece of evidence.

title: That Alter Ego Can Be a Killer. You Get the Picture, Dorian?
description: Dance-drama is virtually a forgotten art, a thought that comes to mind with ''Dorian,'' Robert Hill's new story ballet inspired by Oscar Wilde's ''Picture of Dorian Gray.'' The only world premiere of American Ballet Theater's season at City Center, it shared the program on Thursday night with ''Petite Mort'' and ''Sechs Tnze,'' two plotless company premieres by a contemporary master, Jiri Kylian.

title: Bank of Japan Sees 2.5% Growth in 2004
description: The Bank of Japan indicated Friday that it expected the economy to continue expanding next year, but it also signaled that it had no plans to raise interest rates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the reorganization of the Archdiocese of New York misstated the number of churches closed in a reorganization by the Archdiocese of Detroit. It was 31, not 33. The article also referred incorrectly to the original plan to close 43 Detroit churches. They represented more than a third of the parishes in the city, not in the archdiocese as a whole.

title: Former Musician Rocks World of Track
description: Willy Cahill, a former coach of the United States Olympic judo team, went to see Victor Conte Jr. on Sept. 3 to pick up his usual order of multivitamins. For nearly 20 years, Cahill had been going to Conte's offices in Burlingame, Calif., and he had grown used to seeing a host of sports luminaries there during his visits.

title: Church Defends Couple Charged With Starving Four Adopted Children
description: After a week's hesitation, the church of the Collingswood couple charged with starving four of their adopted children issued a statement on Friday attacking prosecutors and the state's child welfare agency, saying they had torn apart a ''totally innocent and loving family.''

title: Some Clues to '04, However Faint, Are Set to Emerge
description: With a presidential campaign well under way, leaders of both parties are searching for signs, any signs, of favorable trends for November 2004. For the next two weeks, the best place to look is the South, where three states will hold elections for governor.

title: G.I.'s Battle Guerrillas As Protest Turns Violent
description: Guerrillas and American troops battled for hours here on Friday in an intense firefight after a demonstration in support of Saddam Hussein turned violent.

title: A House Saved, but the Neighborhood Is Lost
description: Bonnie Chase stood in her driveway and gazed at the monstrous destruction of her neighborhood. Where 47 houses once stood, only hers and three others remained intact.

title: Pile of Pennies Is Adding Up To a Scandal In Mutual Funds
description: If you want to steal a lot of money and get away with it, steal a little from a lot of people. They will probably never notice. If they do, they may not think it worth the effort to complain.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide of Weekend yesterday for a recital by the violinist Kyung-Wha Chung tomorrow at the 92nd Street Y has become outdated. The recital was canceled yesterday because of Ms. Chung's illness.

title: In Search Of Back Pay For Heroine Of Civil War
description: Harriet Tubman earned her spot in American history. Born into slavery, she freed herself, then helped free hundreds of others through the Underground Railroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EGAN, HONORABLE MARY
description: EGAN--Honorable Mary, of Stapleton, Staten Island, N.Y. On October 29, 2003. Survived by many cousins and many faithful friends. Funeral from Dongan Hills Virginia Funeral Chapel, 1707 Hylan Blvd, Staten Island, N.Y. on Monday 9:30am. Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Conception RC Church, 10am. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery. Visiting hrs Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm.

title: Israel Limits Holy Site Access; Vandals Deface Rabin Memorial
description: Israel blocked some Palestinian Muslims from reaching a holy site to pray here Friday, while in Tel Aviv vandals defaced a memorial to former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, a day before a ceremony to remember his assassination in 1995.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Protests Over Japanese Students' Skit
description: University students took to the streets in Xian for a second day, shouting anti-Japanese slogans and carrying banners, after some Japanese exchange students put on a risqu skit before a student audience. The presentation was seen as innocent, if in poor taste, by some students and school administrators. But many students saw an insult to China. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Two listings in the Pop and Jazz Guide of Weekend yesterday for Symphony Space in Manhattan misstated the dates. The Indian music concert by Ram Narayan and Family is tonight at 8; it was not last night. The Mediterranean music concert by Tenores di Oniferi, Roberto Corona and Stefano Pinna is tomorrow night at 7, not tonight.

title: Good News at Last, or Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Offer Peace Proposal
description: The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, who have been fighting for a homeland for the country's Tamil minority for 20 years, delivered a power-sharing proposal to the Sri Lankan government via the Norwegian ambassador. The Tigers said they would provide details of the plan today, and government officials said they would respond to it then as well, with the aim of meeting in January. Talks between the Tigers and the government have been suspended since April, but a cease-fire has held since February 2002. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
Lynn S. Beedle, 85, Dies; An Expert on Tall Buildings
description: Lynn S. Beedle, a leader and creative force in the study, design and building of skyscrapers, died on Thursday at his home in Hellertown, Pa. He was 85.

title: Thousand of Subway Riders Stalled by an Electrical Fire
description: An electrical fire on a subway track in Harlem sent smoke billowing through the tunnels yesterday morning and forced the evacuation of a train full of passengers, stalling morning commuting for thousands.

title: In Brooklyn, a Rarity: Judicial Candidates Campaigning
description: The candidate, a woman in a dark suit, stood just inside the turnstiles of the 15th Street station of the F train in Brooklyn yesterday morning, pressing pamphlets into passing hands as countless candidates have done before her.

title: 2 Ironworkers Among Victims: One New, One About to Retire
description: Michael Wittland, a crew foreman helping to build a parking garage at the Tropicana Casino and Resort, was six months from retirement. At 29, Jim Bigelow had just completed his trade training as an ironworker and recently bought his first home with his new family.

title: In Case of the Cellphone Dropsies, Metro-North Asks, 'Can You Pay Us Now?'
description: As if it were not punishment enough to have an arm caught in a train toilet during the evening rush and your name splashed all over the papers the next morning.

title: An Evening's Adventure, With a Cellist and Her Voice
description: If New York concertgoers are eager to know how Zankel Hall intends to distinguish itself from Carnegie Hall's two other auditoriums, the solo cello recital by Maya Beiser on Thursday night provided a mesmerizing answer. Ms. Beiser, a champion of contemporary music with an ardent following, is drawn to composers whose works, often written for her, use video imagery, lighting effects and recorded elements. Zankel Hall proved an ideal environment for Ms. Beiser's multimedia program.

title: RELIANT RESOURCES TO HAVE $1 BILLION WRITE-DOWN
description: Reliant Resources, which sells energy in Texas and 12 other states, said yesterday that it would have $1 billion in third-quarter costs to write down the value of power plants amid a glut of electricity supplies. The loss from continuing operations this year will be about $3.44 a share, Reliant said. That compares with a loss of $1.93 a year earlier. Additional write-downs may be recorded after a review of assets in the fourth quarter, Reliant said. The write-down related mostly to 81 plants Reliant got in the February 2002 acquisition of Orion Power Holdings for $5.3 billion in cash and assumed debt. Stock in Reliant, which is based in Houston, fell 10 cents, to $4.95 a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Unit Acquired
description: A leading European bank, UBS, plans to buy the German private client business of Merrill Lynch. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The private client unit manages assets worth $1.4 billion from offices in Frankfurt and Munich, UBS said. UBS, which is based in Zurich, said the Merrill unit, which has 52 employees, would be integrated into its operations by February.

title: Corrections
description: Sports articles on Tuesday and Wednesday about the National Football League's plans to discipline players found to be using a newly detected steroid known as THG misstated the progress of the investigation into the identity of the steroid's manufacturer. While one American antidoping official said he was ''fairly certain'' THG came from the Bay Area Laboratory Cooperative of Burlingame, Calif., federal investigators have not yet determined the source.

title: Gephardt Beats Clinton
description: Dick Gephardt strides into a family restaurant in Pocahontas, Iowa, and finds two species of mammals waiting for his campaign event, Iowans and reporters.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES. Crude oil climbed on signs that stronger-than-expected recoveries in Europe and the United States will bolster demand. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 64 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $29.11 a barrel.

title: After Martin Goes Down, the Nets Close Out a Rout
description: The night had been perfect, beginning with a ceremony and a standing ovation for last year's accomplishments, the unveiling of the banners for the Atlantic Division and Eastern Conference titles, and a 10-0 run by the Nets to begin the game Friday night against the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCQUARY, JOAN S.
description: McQUARY--Joan S. 81, a resident of Manhattan and Kismet, Fire Island, died on October 31, 2003. She was a graduate of the University of Minnesota and had a long and distinguished career at Columbia University Press. She is survived by Mignon Sauber, her long time companion.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in Business Day yesterday with an article about Richard S. Strong, whom the New York attorney general has accused of improper in-and-out trading in shares of his company's funds, misstated the value of his personal fortune. It is $800 million, not $600 million.

title: Revenge Drives String of Killings in Basra
description: Over the past month, more than a dozen former senior members of Saddam Hussein's government have been shot dead in the streets of this normally peaceful city -- two of them this week alone, both shot in the head at close range.

title: James O'Gara, 85, Editor Of Commonweal Magazine
description: James O'Gara, who led the influential Catholic magazine Commonweal for more than three decades and maintained it as a powerful voice of liberalism in the church, died on Oct. 22 in Catonsville, Md. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAL MOLIN, ARMANDO
description: DAL MOLIN--Armando, 86, Italian-born inventor of the music typewriter, musician, engineer, family man, and avid skier. His business, Music Typographers, of Oyster Bay, NY, engraved most of the music published in the 60's and 70's, earning him numerous Paul Revere Awards and recognition in the Groves Dictionary. He is survived by his wife, Elisabeth, of Shelburne, VT, and their three children and seven grandchildren.

title: A Libertarian Is . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Arrest of Russian Billionaire Captures Attention of Germany
description: The shock waves from last week's arrest of the Russian billionaire Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky have spread widely, but not evenly, through the club of international investors.

title: Mahathir, Malaysia's Autocratic Modernizer, Steps Down
description: Asia's longest-serving leader, Mahathir Mohamad, stepped down Friday, leaving a legacy of a modern Muslim nation that he molded on the back of often autocratic rule and the use of tirades -- often anti-Western and anti-Semitic -- intended to create national cohesiveness.

title: About New York; Sweet Sounds Ease the Pain, Then and Now
description: THE conversation has already sounded every note in the scale of her proud life, from the highs of those younger days in the theater to the lows of a son dying. Now it returns to more notes at the bottom of the scale: a second son seriously ill, again; rent in serious arrears, again. Again.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WorldCom Wins Approval To Exit Bankruptcy

title: Change Brings Controversy In Wheelchair Competition
description: What wheelchair racing needs is a ''little more aggression,'' said Krige Schabort, the defending New York City Marathon men's wheelchair champion. ''Like four or five guys getting to the finish line at the same time.''

title: Seymour Graubard, 92; Fought Anti-Semitism
description: Seymour Graubard, the chairman of the Anti-Defamation League in the 1970's and an outspoken opponent of anti-Semitism and advocate for Soviet Jews, died on Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92.

title: Good News at Last, or Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 23 about recent killings of two journalists at The Togliatti Review, a muckraking newspaper in Russia, misstated the resignation date of its crime editor, Pavel Kaledin, who was quoted as saying it was hard for newspapers to survive in Russia without printing upbeat articles for money. He left in June, not September.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Prison For Ex-Official
description: Former Attorney General Dan Morales was sentenced to four years in a federal prison for mail fraud and tax evasion in a case involving Texas' $17 billion settlement with the tobacco industry in 1998. An indictment to which Mr. Morales pleaded guilty last summer said he tried to steer more than a million dollars in unearned legal fees to a Houston lawyer, Marc Murr, who admitted his role in the scheme in October and received a six-month prison term. Mr. Morales, a Democrat, served two terms as Texas attorney general and ran for governor in 2002. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: POWEREX TO PAY $1.3 MILLION TO SETTLE U.S. ALLEGATIONS
description: Powerex, the electricity-trading unit of the British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority, agreed yesterday to pay $1.3 million to settle allegations that it manipulated California's electricity prices. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's trial staff cleared Powerex of allegations of inappropriate market behavior in 2000 and 2001 and rejected California's claims that the company owed the state $1 billion, Powerex said. Powerex, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, was among about 60 North American electricity companies accused of violating California's power-market rules as prices soared during the state's energy crisis in 2000 and 2001. Powerex said it agreed to the settlement rather than incur an estimated $7.5 million in additional legal costs.

title: Mayor Assails Opposition To City Deal With Snapple
description: A day after a report by New York's comptroller raised serious questions about the bidding process in a deal between the city and Snapple, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his radio program yesterday to denounce the report as a bureaucratic attack on innovation.

title: Good News at Last, or Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit Falls At Fuji Photo
description: The largest maker of film materials in Japan, Fuji Photo Film, said that its profit fell 1.8 percent in the July-September period and that net income was likely to be 11 percent lower than forecast because of the yen's strength against the dollar. Fuji earned 17.8 billion yen ($165 million) in the quarter and now expects to earn 85 billion yen ($780 million) for the full year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNICOL, DORIS (SAMANTHA)
description: McNICOL--Doris (Samantha), 83, of North Palm Beach, FL (formerly of NY and Upper Brookville), died October 30. Beloved mother of Elaine Postley, Janet Barton, Dr. Donald McNicol and Paul McNicol. Loving grandmother of John, Christopher, Scott, William, Katherine Rose and Campbell. Proud great grandmother of Beatrix and Griffin. Also survived by her devoted sisters, Janet Davis and Elaine Egues. Dear friend of Jose Antonio Martinez.

title: The Slate Is Clean at Michigan State
description: Like many students at Michigan State University, Jeff Smoker marks his college years by what he was doing during the annual football showdown with the University of Michigan.

title: Star Pitcher Has Defected From Cuba
description: Maels Rodriguez, a hard-throwing right-hander, and second baseman Yobal Duenas defected from Cuba last Saturday and are seeking asylum in an undisclosed country, following the route of previous Cuban defectors who went on to make millions in major league baseball.

title: An Infuriating Success; Schumer Draws Fire for Tactics Blocking Judicial Nominees
description: When Charles E. Schumer recommended using an extreme tactic the filibuster -- to block some Bush administration nominees for federal judgeships, he put himself in the cross hairs of the president's Republican and conservative allies.

title: NEW MOUNTAIN CAPITAL TO BUY STAKE IN NATIONAL MEDICAL
description: National Medical Health Card Systems, which manages pharmacy benefits for insurers and businesses, said yesterday that a private equity firm, New Mountain Capital, had agreed to buy a 55 percent stake in the company for $80 million. National Medical, based in Port Washington, N.Y., will use about $50 million of the investment to buy back up to 4.5 million shares at $11 a share, 20 percent below Thursday's closing price, $13.75, the company said. New Mountain, based in New York, will receive convertible preferred stock. The company said it would use the rest of the money for acquisitions. National Medical said most of the shares in the purchase would come from its chairman, Bert Brodsky, and his family. Mr. Brodsky is retiring as chairman and will be replaced by New Mountain's chief executive, Steven B. Klinsky.

title: Promising Vote on Global Warming
description: John McCain has failed in his first attempt to persuade his Republican colleagues in the Senate to give the issue of global warming the urgent attention it deserves. By a margin of 55 to 43 on Thursday, the Senate rejected a proposal he sponsored with Joseph Lieberman to impose mandatory caps on the emissions from utilities and other industries that scientists believe are heavily responsible for global warming. But Mr. McCain, as we know, does not give up easily. He started his quest for campaign finance reform in 1995 and prevailed six years later. He promises to be just as tenacious on this issue.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Suit Against Redistricting
description: The Congressional redistricting plan approved by the Legislature last month impermissibly weakens Hispanic voting rights and should be voided, a suit filed in Federal District Court said. The League of United Latin American Citizens, which filed the suit, said the new districts, engineered by Republican majorities in the Texas Senate and House after lengthy protests by Democrats, diluted Hispanic political power by splitting Latino neighborhoods in several major cities, including Dallas. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: How to Help
description: Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund should be sent to 4 Chase Metrotech Center, 7th Floor East, Lockbox 5193, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11245, or any of these organizations:

title: Investment in Technology Is Roaring Softly Back
description: The government's economic report on Thursday showing a surge in business investment in computers and software came as no surprise to the team at Reel FX Creative Studios, a producer of special effects for television commercials and movie studios.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TORIES' CHOICE NARROWS Michael Howard was virtually assured of succeeding Iain Duncan Smith, the ousted Conservative Party leader, when the final potential contender, Kenneth Clarke, said he would not be a candidate this time. Mr. Clarke, former chancellor of the exchequer and the standard bearer of the Tories' liberal wing, threw his backing to Mr. Howard, a former home secretary and traditional right winger, and commended him for saying he would lead the Conservatives "from the center." The deadline for nominations is Thursday, and it seems the party will be spared a divisive election process involving its 300,000 members. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Giants' Primary Target Astray for One Game
description: On any play in a Giants practice, receiver Amani Toomer runs his routes as if they were measured by a precise survey. Every cut has to be perfect, not a step wasted anywhere. He expects to catch every pass, no matter how poorly thrown. When he misses one, for whatever reason, he claps his gloved hands sharply, and occasionally follows with a stream of angry words.

title: Panel Waiting For Iraq Data
description: As a deadline imposed by Republicans and Democrats passed, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee said Friday that the Bush administration had yet to provide all of the information the panel was seeking for its review of intelligence before the war about Iraq's illicit weapons program.

title: Juror Denies Comments In the Trial Of a Mother
description: A juror in the recent trial that found Judith Scruggs guilty of having contributed to her son's suicide took the stand Friday at the judge's request to address comments attributed to him in newspapers that may be grounds for a mistrial.

title: History of Human Error Found in Ferry Accidents
description: A review of 1,500 Coast Guard safety records over the last 25 years shows that Staten Island ferries have been involved in dozens of accidents that injured hundreds and were often attributed to human error -- chiefly what investigators called inattentiveness, poor judgment or negligence by crew members.

title: Bridges' 'Necklace Lights' to Return
description: Strings of ornamental lights on the city's four East River bridges, turned off eight months ago because of budget constraints, will be relighted on Wednesday, using money donated by four local businesses.

title: What's in a Games? Sports ftes abound
description: The inaugural Afro-Asian Games are under way in Hyderabad, India, generating very little interest outside of Hyderabad. But then that's what happens when you launch a new, can-miss product in a glutted market.

title: Oil Companies Stay Course Amid Turmoil In Russia
description: As foreign oil companies watch the fight unfold over Russia's biggest oil concern, Yukos, they say it confirms what they have known for a decade, once the country embarked on its zigzag path to a market economy: Russia, for all its changes, is not like the West, and it will not be for some time to come.

title: Knicks Show Little Fight On Night They Need It
description: The season is only two games old, but the Knicks' issues of effort and passion -- and the lack thereof -- are not new, and they were the only things that resurfaced with a vengeance Saturday night.

title: Diagnosis: Frustration
description: SAY you're critically ill. Your doctor says: ''I can write two prescriptions. One is not proven and may make your condition worse. The second has proven effective in every application. It's your choice.''

title: A Mixed Message On Use of Cellphones
description: What happened to Governor McGreevey's promise to sign a law barring drivers from using hand-held cellphones by the end of January? Last January, that is. And why has the Legislature not given the governor one to sign?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAUBARD, SEYMOUR
description: GRAUBARD--Seymour, 92, died October 29 in Palm Beach of a heart attack. He had had his martini, was having dinner with his daughter and some friends, and collapsed while cheerfully discussing how to defeat President Bush. Such were his last words. A native of New York City and a graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School, he worked in the LaGuardia administration. After the war, he co-founded the law firm presently known as Graubard & Miller and became known for his work in international trade law. Among his many civic activities, he served as the National Chairman of the Anti-Defamation League and the President of the City Club. His wife, Blanche, died last month; he is survived by his daughter, Katherine Graubard, Professor of Biology at the University of Washington in Seattle.

title: Assessing the Record Of a Tarnished Idol
description: LAST Monday night just before 6, my 14-year-old son, Edward, and one of his ninth-grade classmates ran into the den shouting that their school's headmaster had been arrested in a porn sting operation.

title: Great Meals I Have Known
description: There are those who are invited and those who invite. The artist Joe Eula is a little of both. he has been invited Over the years to so many dinners of note by Hosts (Or, in his case, hostesses) that we asked him to recall a few as he does best. And we learn that with the right hostess, all it takes is a little vodka and a thin-skinned tomato.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODIE, SHELDON
description: BRODIE--Sheldon, 77, died peacefully in FL after a long illness. He was a Professor of Clinical Dermatology at NYU Medical School and Chief of Service, Skin & Cancer Unit where he was an attending physician for 40 years. He had a private practice in Beth Page, LI. He loved his work and his patients loved him. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Charlotte and his children Barnett and Martha and her husband Harvey Sepler, grandchildren Aubree and Danny and his sister Barbara Klebanow. He was a paradigm of bravery, tenacity and dignity. We love you and you are an inspiration to us.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday showing the number of bills vetoed by American presidents misstated the number of months served by two presidents. John F. Kennedy was in office for just over 34 months, not 22; Calvin Coolidge served for 67 months, not 63.

title: Sniper
description: The bullet was the color of a new penny. It was less than an inch long and weighed about as much as a wedding ring. It left the muzzle of the rifle at a velocity of around three thousand feet per second, stabilized on its brief journey across the parking lot by six rifling grooves inside the barrel that gave it a clockwise spin.

title: Is the Party Ending For Home Builders?
description: BUOYED by low mortgage rates, the housing market has boomed over the last three years and shares of home-building companies have soared.

title: The Battle Over Teterboro: From Romance to Hostility
description: THE six-passenger plane was heading for Teterboro Airport when it crashed into an oak tree in Gil and Louise Bowman's backyard in Hasbrouck Heights and burst into flames.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUBACK, JEANETTE
description: SCHUBACK--Jeanette. 92, on October 31, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel. Loving mother of Sara and Judith. Cherished grandmother of Richard, Elizabeth, Jesse and Philip. Devoted sister of Ruth and Howard. She was a graduate of NYU and Columbia, and had a long teaching career. Services today at 11:30 AM, Gutterman's, Hackensack, NJ.

title: How to Make an Opera A Riddle: Adapt David Lynch
description: EVER since she was 13, when she first saw ''The Elephant Man,'' Olga Neuwirth, a 35-year-old Austrian composer, has felt an affinity with the filmmaker David Lynch. ''In his films, you are put into a vortex without actually knowing what is going on,'' Ms. Neuwirth said recently from Venice, where she lives. ''So this has always been a part of my thinking.''

title: Fishing and Bickering
description: ''YOU'VE heard of off the beaten track? Well, this is the beaten track,'' John Skinner said as his red Jeep Cherokee slid through a mile-long serpentine trough of sand called Burma Road. It spit the Jeep onto Great Gun Beach near Moriches Inlet, five miles east of the entrance to Smith Point County Park. Mr. Skinner, 42, of Wading River, stopped his vehicle to survey conditions on the beach one recent Saturday morning before sunrise. A southeast wind was whipping the gray sea into uninviting, churning waves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURNER, CHARLES ROSS
description: TURNER--Charles Ross. November 25, 1921-August 26, 2003. Noted American Composer and Pulitzer Prize Finalist died of heart complications. Memorial contributions to the Julliard School.

title: The Neediest Cases; For Homeless, the Gift of Hope
description: Gloria Hernandez tries to be strong for her five children, but strength, like privacy or full stomachs, does not come easily when you and your family live in a shelter for the homeless.

title: Stealing Ideas for Your Garden Is No Crime
description: GARDENERS not only exchange slips and cuttings over the metaphorical fence but also ideas. A visit to any garden is bound to inspire the amateur horticulturist to attempt the same thing, mitigated by the hope that any idea appropriated can be given a twist that makes it one's own.

title: On the Teeming Sidewalks, Nudge, Counternudge
description: I MOVED back to New York in July, after three and half years in the politely repressed kingdom of Connecticut, where you just don't touch people. Not unless there is a reason that both parties, if asked, would call ''good.''

title: Academic Stars: Worth the Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: The A-Z list
description: Argyll patterns: vintage entertaining tips by the late, great duchess.

title: Elissa Gootman, Michael Eichenwald
description: Elissa Gootman, a daughter of Dr. Marilyn Gootman and Dr. Elliot Gootman of Athens, Ga., is to be married there today to Michael Eichenwald, the son of Jeanette and Eduardo Eichenwald of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Ronald D. Gerson is to officiate at Congregation Children of Israel.

title: David Chase, Gerard Cortinez
description: David James Chase and Gerard Isidore Cortinez were married on Thursday at City Hall in Toronto. George McConnachie, a licensed wedding officiant in Ontario, performed the ceremony. Kenneth Page, a friend of Mr. Chase and Mr. Cortinez, took part.

title: The Cruelest Cure
description: I'm sitting in a room with six terrified people. Outside the window we can hear the roar of Boston's rush hour, cars sputtering at intersections, baseball fans shouting in the streets. Out there it is loud, but in here, at the Center for Anxiety and Related Disorders at Boston University, it is as hushed as a hospital, the faces of the patients slick with sweat. The director of the center, the psychologist David H. Barlow, is one of the leading researchers in the field of fear. He isn't here today, but his methods are guiding this therapy group, which is led by two strikingly young-looking graduate students. It seems somehow fitting that this center, the premier institution for the treatment of anxiety, is located smack-dab in the maze of Boston's crooked and crazy streets.

title: The Alien Emperor of 80's London
description: WHEN all 240 pounds and 7 feet of Leigh Bowery barreled into a London nightclub -- crowbarred into an outrageous PVC ensemble that made him look like something between an alien empress and a Regency tart -- it was advisable to step aside. No one got in the way of the man who bestrode London's art, music and fashion subcultures in the late 1980's and early 90's like a colossus in crotchless pants.

title: The Pistol in Dad's Bed
description: THE STUFF OF LIFE

title: U.S. in Second Place in Drug Price Survey
description: U.S. in Second Place

title: The World; New Global Trade Lineup: Haves, Have-Nots, Have-Somes
description: THE end of the cold war did away with the East-West split and made fashionable the notion of a North-South divide. Forget Communism versus capitalism. Now it was rich versus poor. But even as negotiators continue seeking a global trading system that might lift economies in both categories, that idea now appears to be coming apart at the seams.

title: The Iraq War
description: In retrospect, the Iraqis were in a hopeless position before the first shot was fired. The military forces of the United States and the United Kingdom operated according to a professional military ethos that it had taken the West five centuries to develop. The technologies that those forces deployed were frighteningly effective in their lethality and precision, but the chief factor in the victory that occurred in spring 2003 was a combination of training, discipline, and mental preparation at every level that Coalition forces brought to the battlefield.

title: Leaping Dialectics In a Single Bound
description: THE movie ended and the theater emptied, but one man remained in his seat, watching the credits roll. And roll. And roll. The number of visual-effects specialists needed to bring the film, ''X2,'' to the screen -- roughly 200 -- might have provoked a fit of envy in Luca Buvoli, the Italian-born New York artist taking it all in. But Mr. Buvoli quickly shrugged it off.

title: Photo-Op
At Preschool Co-ops, Parents Told to Linger
description: MARGO OHANA opened up the bags of carrots and crackers before efficiently organizing them into baskets, placing them on trays and walking from the kitchen here at the Hastings Co-Op Nursery school to leave them outside the classroom doors as part of her snack duty.

title: It's Not Easy in Greenland, But It's Definitely Cool
description: RUSHING out the door to catch the first of three planes that would take me to Greenland, I grabbed two last items, a flashlight and a sleep mask, and shoved them into my pack. A few days later, the flashlight rolled out of my backpack across the floor of my youth hostel room, and I laughed out loud.

title: Seeds of Problems, in a Doll
description: To the Editor:

title: Trojans Roll and Inch Closer to Title Shot
description: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA 43, WASHINGTON STATE 16

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: A Tunnel to Reduce Truck Traffic Might Add Trucks
description: Peter Keane, the owner of V.I.P. Auto Body on Rust Road in West Maspeth, Queens, looked across the street at the cleared and desolate 40 acres of the old Phelps Dodge copper smelting plant and, beyond it, Newtown Creek. He had heard that the city might build a freight yard there as part of an ambitious plan to link a citywide network of railroad tracks to a proposed tunnel under New York Harbor between Bay Ridge, Brooklyn and either Bayonne or Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDEL, JOAN CLAIRE
description: SEIDEL--Joan Claire. Of Verona, NJ, on October 29, 2003, of a massive heart attack. She was 74 and the beloved wife of Kenneth. Loving mother of Eric and his wife Debra. Dear sister of Rosamund Galston. Cherished grandmother of Eric Jr. and Alexis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAYER, ROSE
description: SAYER--Rose. Died October 30, at the age of 106. Devoted wife of the late Victor. Loving mother of Felice Wiener, Myron, Bertram and Irwin. Beloved mother of the late Zelda Blechner. Cherished grandmother of 14, great grandmother of 20, and great great grandmother of one. She will be missed by all.

title: Vogue Word Watch
description: Remember way back when situations would develop? Forget that antediluvian locution, once used to describe tidings in train or matters in flux. Forget too its short-lived replacement, evolve; that Darwinian verb was taken over by the old New Age lingo and is now going the way of the dodo. To describe how the times they are a changin' -- revealing themselves in magical ways -- today's bureaucratic elite say that events unfold.

title: Beyond the Facade: Searching for Clues to India's History
description: ''TRACES of India: Photography, Architecture, and the Politics of Representation,'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, is the kind of show that repays patient viewing. Immersion might be a better word, for you really need to spend time looking at the show's more than 200 exhibits, reading the brochure and digesting copious wall texts to get a sense of what the curator, Maria Antonella Pelizzari, is trying to say.

title: Corrections
description: An article today on Page 1 of Holiday Movies, Part 2 of Arts & Leisure, about ''The Triplets of Belleville'' and an annotated listing on Page 17 carry an outdated release schedule. After the section had gone to press, the date was changed to Nov. 26 from Nov. 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAIMAN, DORIS WEINKLE
description: NAIMAN--Doris Weinkle. Beloved wife of Richard. Dearest mother of Francie, Rachel and Alec. Loving sister-inlaw of Elaine Taibi. Professor Emerita, New York University. Funeral Monday, United Hebrew Community, 201 East Broadway, NYC, 9:30 AM.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article last Sunday about the arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest man, on charges of fraud and tax evasion referred imprecisely to the precedent. While this was the first jailing of a Russian oligarch on a court order, it was not the first such action of any kind. Vladimir A. Gusinsky, a wealthy media executive, was briefly jailed by prosecutors when he was summoned for questioning in June 2000.

title: Our Lady Of The Flowers
description: When I was 6, my mother enrolled me in ballet class to learn grace and poise. ''It's time for you to be a lady,'' she said. The year was 1982, and for my first lesson, inspired by Olivia Newton-John's video ''Physical,'' I concocted an outfit complete with a button-down shirt knotted above my navel, skimpy track shorts worn over red tights and leg warmers.
