I carried with me a flower I had picked from a pot on a window ledge. My father, who drove me to class, thought that I sweetly intended the bloom for my teacher. I planned to dance with it between my teeth.

title: In the Arrondissements
description: In daytime, dressed-up women filled Paris streets last month. Fewer dressed down, as if they had just washed the car. The fancier look focused on a classic silhouette (right) that imposes a form on the wearer. Jackets, corset-shaped at the waist, were worn with narrow knee-length skirts. Short above-the-knee skirts had extended black-lace hems. Colored stockings, mostly in solid primary colors, were a surprise. One revival was the mid-1960's baby-doll dress with natural shoulders, a signature of Dorothee Bis' boutique (below left).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SACHAROFF, HOWARD
description: SACHAROFF--Howard. Lovingly remembered. Sadly missed. 11/6/02 Rita, Robin, Mitchell, Nhik

title: Too Much
description: Every now and then a study comes along whose chief interest lies in how peculiarly askew its findings seem to be from the common perception of things. Sometimes, of course, the ''surprising new study'' itself turns out to be off in some way. But if the data are fundamentally sound, then what you really want to know is why sensible people hold such a contrary view.

title: No. 5 Seminoles Rout the Irish
description: Chris Rix passed for 327 yards and 3 touchdowns Saturday to help No. 5 Florida State give Notre Dame its second-worst home loss and strengthen its bid for a berth in the national championship game.

title: Richard E. Neustadt, Adviser To 3 Presidents, Is Dead at 84
description: Richard E. Neustadt, the White House adviser, historian and authority on presidential power, died on Friday in England. He was 84.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.H.L.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about the arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest man, on charges of fraud and tax evasion referred imprecisely to the precedent. While this was the first jailing of a Russian oligarch on a court order, it was not the first such action of any kind. Vladimir A. Gusinsky, a wealthy media executive, was briefly jailed by prosecutors when he was summoned for questioning in June 2000.

title: Business People; A Builder and a Painter
description: Fall is a musical time for Victor Elmaleh, the architect and real estate developer who is chairman of World-Wide Holdings. This month, Mr. Elmaleh, a self-taught artist who is also a trained pianist, celebrates his latest venture in the classical world. He painted the watercolor that graces the album cover for ''The Complete Bach Brandenburgs,'' a new recording by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble.

title: F.Y.I.
description: 'Midtown' Doesn't Fly

title: December
description: Dec. 5

title: Sarah Marie Martin, Nicholas Brophy
description: Sarah Marie Martin, a daughter of Karen and James Martin of Houston, was married yesterday to Nicholas Christian Brophy, a son of Lynn and James Brophy of Manasquan, N.J. The Rev. Bill Higgs, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Ocean Club on Paradise Island in the Bahamas.

title: From Barbie to Barbs, A Road Less Traveled
description: Now that I am married and have two kids, I feel the pressure to be cool.

title: The First Ride, 20 Years Later
description: TWENTY years ago, Gerry Holzman, a social studies teacher aspiring to become a full-time woodworker, took a band saw to a block of basswood. Before long, the Islip resident had carved out the beginnings of the Empire State Carousel featuring New York animals, state historical themes and the work of more than 1,000 volunteer carvers and artists.

title: Stealing Ideas for a Garden Is No Crime
description: GARDENERS not only exchange slips and cuttings over the metaphorical fence but also ideas. A visit to any garden is bound to inspire the amateur horticulturist to attempt the same thing, mitigated by the hope that any idea appropriated can be given a twist that makes it one's own.

title: A TAB OF TWO CITIES: ATLANTA, OLD AND NEW
description: BRIGHT, shiny Atlanta with its gleaming skyscrapers, roaring expressways and world-class shopping centers has become the unrivaled capital of the New South, a booming island of modernity anchored in a sea of Southern tradition. And though the New South has much to admire, on a weekend getaway on a $1,000 budget, I found old Atlanta, with its gracious, leafy neighborhoods, its smoky honky-tonk rib joints and an entire district devoted to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., more intriguing.

title: Streetscapes/The Construction of the 1899 Mansion That Was Once at 1030 Fifth Avenue; The Architect and the Client: a Tale for All Ages
description: TOURISTS and New Yorkers frequently gaze in admiration as they pass the mansions of Fifth Avenue, imagining the luxury the homes imply. Little is actually known of how such projects were accomplished, but an unusual trove of correspondence from the architect William Burnet Tuthill to his client James Hooker Hamersley about the mansion they designed in 1899 on the northeast corner of 84th and Fifth -- demolished in 1924 for the present 1030 Fifth Avenue -- shows that all was not easy or pleasant for owner or architect. And in some ways the letters read as if they might have been written today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about ways of evaluating job gains and employment misstated the percentage difference between an estimate of job growth cited by Treasury Secretary John W. Snow and an earlier estimate made by the Bush administration in 2002. Mr. Snow's figure of 200,000 jobs per month was 33 percent lower than the administration's figure of about 300,000, not 50 percent lower.

title: Corrections
description: Achart last Sunday showing the number of bills vetoed by American presidents misstated the number of months served by two presidents. John F. Kennedy was in office for just over 34 months, not 22; Calvin Coolidge served for 67 months, not 63.

title: Tongue Twister (of Sorts): So You Say 'Tornado,' And They Say 'Gustnado'
description: Donald F. Oliver does not care what the National Weather Service says. As far as he is concerned, a tornado ripped through his Orange neighborhood last Monday afternoon, flinging a 100-foot oak tree onto his roof.

title: A Mom-and-Pop Shop for Animation That Married Art and Life
description: LIKE elves puttering in a cottage in some latter-day fairy tale, John and Faith Hubley made films by hand, then carted their wares to market -- and won Oscars for them.

title: Dismantling a Wall Street Club
description: THE chief executive of Merrill Lynch, E. Stanley O'Neal, has never been big on clubs. To Mr. O'Neal, who grew up poor in a small Alabama town as a grandson of a slave, clubs symbolized one thing: exclusion.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Using Stamford's Master Plan to Steer Development
description: THE city of Stamford adopted its latest master plan barely a year ago, but the document has been getting heavy use. It formed the basis for zoning changes that require affordable multifamily housing and is being employed by a number of citizen groups to try to head off or change development proposals that they object to.

title: Electricity Costs and Deregulation
description: Q. Under the New York rent-stabilization laws, an apartment becomes eligible for deregulation when the rent reaches $2,000 and the residents' income exceeds a certain level. Certain apartments have the electricity included in the rent and impose an electric surcharge for each air-conditioning unit. Is this electricity charge included in the computation to see if the $2,000 threshold is reached? . . . Richard Bengloff, Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAND, DAVID L.
description: RAND--David L. On October 29, 2003. 95 years young. Wonderful husband, brother, uncle, cousin and friend to all who asked for his advise and help. He was a great human being. We all loved him. The Rand, Dichter and Rosenthal Families

title: Remembering the Alamo (Whatever Happened)
description: GROWING up, I was a committed ironist. This was not a perfect persona to adopt in San Antonio, Tex., in the 1960's, but back then I styled myself in opposition to my environment. I was a teenager, certain that I had been born in the wrong place, wanting it known, at all times, that I would be moving to Manhattan at the first opportunity. Sunnier kids played football, wrapped houses and drank draft root beer at the Ize Box; I wore black, read Kurt Vonnegut, attended Vietnam War protests and anticipated my acceptance to Sarah Lawrence. At best, I was a fish out of water; at worst, I was an insufferable snob. As my friend and fellow San Antonian Marie Brenner put it, ''To be a Jewish girl in San Antonio in that era was to fall asleep in Texas history class and play Barbra Streisand's 'Color Me Barbra' . . . and dream about moving to New York.''

title: Sleeping Aloft
description: To the Editor: As I have sleep apnea, I was very interested to read ''Flying With Sleep Apnea,'' (Q& A, Oct. 19) about airline travel with CPAP machines.

title: Corrections
description: An article today on Page 1 of Holiday Movies, Part 2 of Arts & Leisure, about ''The Triplets of Belleville'' and an annotated listing on Page 17 carry an outdated release schedule. After the section had gone to press, the date was changed to Nov. 26 from Nov. 21.

title: The Stuff of Life
description: The call comes at eight-thirty on Sunday morning.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Peter Sarsgaard; Round the Loop
description: THE nearly unknown actor Peter Sarsgaard needed the role of Charles Lane in ''Shattered Glass'' as much as Charles Lane, a former policy-wonk editor at The New Republic, needed Mr. Sarsgaard to make him pop fully into the third dimension. The movie, which opened on Friday, centers on how the real Mr. Lane caught a reporter who repeatedly faked stories.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: James Joyce and John Huston's Joyous Gathering
description: ''Why am I feeling this riot of emotions?'' wonders Gabriel Conroy (Donal McCann) near the end of John Huston's last film, ''The Dead'' (1987). Gabriel and his wife, Gretta (Anjelica Huston), have spent the evening -- Jan. 6, 1904, a night when, as the James Joyce story tells us, ''the snow was general all over Ireland'' -- at the Dublin home of his two maiden aunts, who give a small, genteel dinner party every year on that date, the feast of Epiphany. There's been music and wine and dancing and roast goose, and no more talk of politics than is absolutely necessary. And Gabriel's little after-dinner speech, fussed and fretted over, has come off pretty well, on the whole.

title: Michael Jackson's Tutorial in P.R.
description: MICHAEL JACKSON -- ''Everybody loves a star when he's on the top, but no one ever comes around when he starts to drop,'' a young Michael Jackson prophetically sang in ''One More Chance.'' Thirty-three years later, he has a new single also called ''One More Chance.'' The song, a bonus track on his deal-ending greatest hits album for Sony, was written and produced with R. Kelly. (It can be heard at www.michaeljackson.com and on Internet music services like Rhapsody.) Clearly, Mr. Jackson has been watching with special interest as R. Kelly's star has continued to rise despite allegations of misconduct with minors. However, unlike Mr. Kelly's recent radio-conquering hits ''Ignition'' and ''Snake,'' Mr. Jackson's comeback attempt, though it has a nice echo of the Chi-Lites, is too self-conscious to catch on.

title: Saying 'No, Thanks' to Board Memberships
description: So with all those executives raiding, inflating or otherwise tinkering with the corporate cookie jar, and with ''Sue the directors!'' the primal reaction of the aggrieved, the question is: Why would anyone want to sit on a companys board?

title: Labor Board to Hear Waiters' Complaint
description: The National Labor Relations Board has scheduled a hearing on a complaint by a group of waiters against David's Jade Palace Restaurant in Hartsdale, citing violations of the National Labor Relations Act, said Leah Jaffee, supervisory attorney at the board's Manhattan office, which is handling the case.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; From Suburban Office Parks to Korean Mega-Project
description: IT is a bit of a stretch to imagine the geopolitical implications of a real estate development half a world away being discussed in this New Jersey suburb of low-rise office buildings, college campuses and single-family homes.

title: Angela Graham, Jonathan Dahl
description: Angela Maria Montejo Graham, a yoga instructor, was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Dahl, the editor of the Weekend Journal section of The Wall Street Journal. Lisel Burns, the clergy leader at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Green-Wood Historic Chapel in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: NONFICTION | FICTION

title: In This Restaurant Row, A Disservice for Neighbors
description: The attraction of valet parking in places like Little Neck, Bayside and other car-loving parts of Queens is that you can step out of your car and let someone else worry about finding a spot for it. But Charles McBride, who lives on Pembroke Avenue behind several restaurants on Northern Boulevard in Little Neck, wants you to know that as you settle in for a drink, your car often becomes his problem.

title: Shelter's Present Status Due to Its Past Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: Does North Korea's Dear Leader belong in Hollywood -- perhaps as a studio head? Some readers said so. And Robert Downey Jr.'s recovery from drugs prompted others to ask, Is it for real or an act? In Diagnosis, a patient who opted out of medical treatment drew surprising support.

title: Popular Mechanics
description: It's 8:10 p.m. in the bar of the Four Seasons restaurant, its towering windows illuminated from below with dramatic red lights, and Gwen Stefani is making a move. With her sharply cut white pantsuit, pale skin, bright red lips and wavy platinum bob, she's a rock 'n' roll Jean Harlow. Her host, Timothy Schifter, the chief executive of the accessory firm Le Sportsac, is guiding her through the crowd. Guests introduce themselves or wait to be introduced. An eager knot of people that had been clustered around her banquette seems to move with her. During her 27-minute tour of the room, she talks with magazine editors, fashion publicists, downtown stylists and uptown socialites. All eyes are fixed on her. A sociometric star is born.

title: The Nation; Protecting 'Gorbyness,' Marks and All
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV, the last leader of the Soviet empire, wants trademark protection for the birthmark on his forehead and his names -- the formal one as well as Gorby.

title: How Scandal Can Help The Fund Industry
description: ALLIANCE CAPITAL. Janus. Putnam Investments. Strong Funds. Bank One. Bank of America.

title: Chemistry of Alchemy? Sprewell Sounds Off
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 1  The way Allan Houston and Charlie Ward see it, everybody is different off the court. And whether there were cliques formed around off-court interests on last season's Knicks team  as Latrell Sprewell asserted Friday night when he returned to the area for Minnesota's game against the Nets  Ward and Houston believed that they did not disrupt team chemistry on the court.

title: Nets Win First Game Against Ex-Guru
description: As the Nets-Wizards game was about to begin Saturday night, the coaches Byron Scott and Eddie Jordan walked half the distance between their benches, shook hands and headed back to their teams. There were no hugs and no visible animosity, only that polite and professional gesture.

description: if (document.layers) { document.write(" "); } else { document.write(" "); } Journal: var google_hints = "";

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: My family and I stayed at Montauto, the largest of the La Foce houses, a few years ago (''A Villa That Defines Tuscany'' by Mary Tannen, Oct. 5). It should be noted that the pool is perhaps 100 yards from the house. To make matters worse for families with small children, the pool has no shallow end.

title: Pan Am Reunion
description: To the Editor: Corey Kilgannon's article notes that the former Pan Am flight attendants keep in touch via a philanthropic group called World Wings International and meet yearly to reminisce.

title: Love
description: The day she walked the streets of Silk, a chafing wind kept the temperature low and the sun was helpless to move outdoor thermometers more than a few degrees above freezing. Tiles of ice had formed at the shoreline and, inland, the thrown-together houses on Monarch Street whined like puppies. Ice slick gleamed, then disappeared in the early evening shadow, causing the sidewalks she marched along to undermine even an agile tread, let alone one with a faint limp. She should have bent her head and closed her eyes to slits in that weather, but being a stranger, she stared wide-eyed at each house, searching for the address that matched the one in the advertisement: One Monarch Street. Finally she turned into a driveway where Sandler Gibbons stood in his garage door ripping the seam from a sack of Ice-Off. He remembers the crack of her heels on concrete as she approached; the angle of her hip as she stood there, the melon sun behind her, the garage light in her face. He remembers the pleasure of her voice when she asked for directions to the house of women he has known all his life.

title: Nuevo Latino With a Dash of Whimsy
description: I HAVE always found nuevo Latino to be something like California cuisine: a cuisine of assembled foods with a lot of different tastes, both raw and cooked. The emphasis is on fresh ingredients (lots of produce), contrasting textures and colors, and lively flavors (citrus, chilies, cilantro).

title: Athens Taxi Drivers Fight Closer Regulation
description: On Oct. 10, the Athens Hotel Association called on the Greek government to ''prevent the country's taxi drivers from ripping off foreign tourists.''

title: Academic Stars: Worth the Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: There Are Games to Fit Each Style or Substance
description: The inaugural Afro-Asian Games are under way in Hyderabad, India, generating very little interest outside of Hyderabad. But then that's what happens when you launch a can-miss product in a glutted market.

title: European Grand(dad) Tour
description: FOREIGN travel was all but a void in my experience until I retired three years ago. It picked up a year later when my wife, Jan, retired. We have been to Paris, to Rome, and to the Greek Islands. But it was as grandparents that we found ourselves in Portugal this summer, absorbing the principles of successful intergenerational travel while getting, alas, the barest whiff of that fascinating country.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Guatemalan Rebel Tries Her Hand at Democracy
description: Makrina Gudiel gave up her identity to survive.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Sunday with a picture of a drawing by the artist Mark Lombardi misstated the surname of the collector who provided the image. He is Daniel Silverstein, not Silverman.

title: Helping the Economy, One Snip at a Time
description: To loyal patrons of her hair salons, Santa Cruz offers what they desire in cutting, coloring, curling and combing. To New York City officials, Ms. Cruz offers what they desire in jobs and tax revenues.

title: At Sea With MP3's, Boomers Buoy the Struggling Record Industry
description: Beyonc Knowles and 50 Cent have two of the best-selling albums so far this year. Nonetheless, when Borders Books & Music recently redesigned the layouts of the music sections in its more than 420 superstores, the CD's from these and other young hit-makers were booted from prime browsing display space in favor of albums from the likes of Rod Stewart, Sting and Barbra Streisand.

title: The Sobering Life of Robert Downey Jr.
description: Downey was once quoted in a newspaper as saying that the easy part of beating an addiction is stopping -- the hard part is not starting again.

title: Finding No Shortage Of Windmills To Tilt At
description: Stella Harmatiuk, 81, stood on the corner of Manhattan Avenue and Calyer Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on a recent windy morning and smiled beatifically at the people walking down the sidewalk. Until they got close. Then she snapped into candidate mode and accosted them with a pink flier bearing her likeness.

title: Un Joyeux Noel? Non
description: Much has been made lately of the widening gulf -- cultural, political, temperamental -- that separates the United States and France. But ''La Bche,'' Danile Thompson's sly and delicious holiday confection, released in this country three winters ago, before the current geopolitical chill set in, suggests that, at least at the end of December, the two republics still have much in common. The movie, as dry and bubbly as a glass of Veuve Clicquot, as rich and bittersweet as the traditional holiday cake that provides its title, opens with a department-store blast of ''Jingle Bells,'' and even the most chauvinistic American viewer will be gratified to discover how many of our holiday traditions -- at least the ones displayed on screen -- also flourish in France. Music, compulsive consumerism and lavish food, of course, but also sibling rivalry, adultery, repressed family history and something called ''hostile depression,'' which roughly corresponds to what we call seasonal affective disorder. The story, which owes an obvious debt to both Chekhov and Woody Allen, concerns three sisters -- Sabine Azma, Emmanuelle Bart and Charlotte Gainsbourg -- who fight with one another, their newly widowed mother and their father (her first husband), a passionately eccentric Russian violinist. The fact that he is Jewish adds a lovely touch of schmaltz to the Christmas feast; it may also account for the film's welcome doses of tsuris, chutzpah and general mishegas, words that, even in a French movie, should require no translation.

title: Half a Step on Iraqi Security
description: The Bush administration made a smart decision last week to speed the training of an Iraqi civil defense militia to help patrol the seething Sunni Arab area around Baghdad. Yet not even tens of thousands of new civil defense officers can relieve America of its larger military responsibilities in Iraq. Until there is a sovereign Iraqi government with a rebuilt national army, purged of top Baathists and carefully balanced among Sunnis, Shiites and Kurds, substantial international military forces will be needed. And until the United States occupation gives way to an international administration, most of those troops will have to be American.

title: Restoring the Honor of a Composer With a Bum Rap
description: I was going to write about the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli and her latest recording for Decca, ''The Salieri Album,'' and I will, briefly. Not much need be said, really. Ms. Bartoli does much the same here as she did in recent years for Gluck and Vivaldi, shedding light on obscure corners of repertory in imaginative, utterly committed and often gripping performances. Although sheer vocal beauty is sometimes sacrificed to drama (occasionally bordering on melodrama), there is plenty of both. And Salieri is a composer in need of reclamation -- having been scurrilously, if entertainingly, cast as Mozart's murderer in ''Amadeus'' -- and to some extent worthy of it. For all of those reasons, ''The Salieri Album'' is a must for admirers of Ms. Bartoli and for listeners interested in exploring unhackneyed areas of vocal repertory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARNSTEIN, DR. ROBERT LEO
description: ARNSTEIN--Dr. Robert Leo of Hamden, CT, Psychiatristin-Chief Emeritus of the Yale University Health Service, died October 27, 2003, at age 84. Dr. Arnstein is survived by his wife of 56 years, Mary Benjamin Arnstein, and their children, Katharine Arnstein of Brighton, MA, Douglas Arnstein, of San Francisco, CA, Sarah Novack, of Los Angeles, CA, and Anne Arnstein, of Meriden, CT. He is also survived by two grandchildren, Elena Arnstein, of El Cerrito, CA, and Jason Novack, of Los Angeles, CA. Born in New York City, Dr. Arnstein attended the Lincoln School, Deerfield Academy, and Yale University class of 1941 prior to serving in the Army Air Corps from 1941-1946 in Panama. Upon returning from the service, he enrolled in Vassar College to complete his premed studies after which he graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1951. During this period he met Mary Benjamin of New York City and in 1947 they were married. Dr. Arnstein joined Yale University's Department of University Health Division of Student Mental Hygiene in 1955 and was its Chief Psychiatrist from 1960 until his retirement in 1989. He was active in the following professional associations; the American Psychiatric Association, the Group for the Advancement of Psychiatry, and the American College Health Association. Dr. Arnstein served on the boards of the Creative Arts Workshop, the English Speaking Union New Haven Branch, and Fellowship Place. He was also a member of the Executive Council Yale class of 1941, and the Garden Club of New Haven. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Creative Arts Workshop, 80 Audubon Street, New Haven, CT 06510; Fellowship Place 441 Elm Street, New Haven, CT 06511; or the charity of your choice. The family will be receiving visitors Sunday November 2nd from 1:00-4:30 PM at the New Haven Club, 193 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT 06511. Memorial service arrangements are pending and will be announced at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCLEAN, WILLIAM HENRY
description: McLEAN -- William Henry. Born April 15, 1911, in NYC, died of natural causes on Monday, October 27, 2003. Resided in Short Hills, NJ. Husband for 53 years of Vesta Tittmann McLean. Father of William H. McLean Jr. and Eugene B. McLean. Also survived by four grandchildren and a sister Dorothy Baucom. Graduated from Collegiate School, NYC. Graduated from Stevens Institute of Technology in 1931, with a BS in mechanical engineering. Harvard University Master of Science, 1933, MBA 1934, and Doctor of Commercial Science, 1938. He was a member of the faculties of Harvard and Stevens. During WWII he directed the research and development program of the Office of the Quartermaster General for which he was awarded the Legion of Merit. Dr. McLean then began a career that led to executive positions with National Can Company, Dewey & Almy Chemical Company and Merck and Company, Inc. He was president of the Merck Chemical Division and Director of Merck & Co, Ltd, the company's Canadian subsidiary. In 1964 Dr. McLean returned to Stevens and subsequently became Dean of the College, acting President and Trustee. He was a member of Tau Pi and Sigma Xi, national honorary engineering and scientific societies and a licensed professional engineer. The McLean Chemical Sciences Building was named in his honor in 1995. He was a Trustee of Union College and Overlook Hospital, Summit, NJ. He was a founder and first President of the Association of Independent Colleges and Universities of New Jersey. He was also a member of the New Jersey State Board of Higher Education and author of the state's first tuition aid grant program which enabled qualified young people to reduce the financial differential in choosing an independent college. He served on the boards of several major corporations including Digitial Equipment, Ecolabs and National Aviation. His clubs included the Union Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Short Hills Club, of which he was President, St. Louis Country Club, Harvard Club of New York, the Pilgrim Society and the St. Andrews Society of New York. A memorial service will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Union County College Foundation, 1033 Springfield Ave, Cranford, NJ 07016.

title: Father Built Bridges
description: Most children raised under the roof of a famous parent would say that you could do worse than having a renowned bridge-builder for a dad. Still, Margaret Ammann-Durrer, daughter of Othmar Ammann, who designed the George Washington, Bayonne, Triborough, Verrazano-Narrows and Throgs Neck bridges, singles out a specific drawback. ''I was in the seventh grade when the George Washington Bridge opened, and I always despaired the fact that I was supposed to have a good mark in arithmetic,'' she said. Otherwise, growing up in the 1930's in the bridge builder's household in Boonton, alongside two brothers, ''was like living with any daddy that you love -- I had no idea what was going on in his head, but I remember him spending long hours bent over his desk at night.'' In fact, Ammann, perhaps the most respected bridge builder of all time, once compared the George Washington Bridge to a beautiful daughter.

title: Hosts And Hostages
description: Possibly the worst dinner party ever given in Manhattan took place in the winter of 1982. I was not there, thank goodness, but I have heard about it from several people who were. The party was held on the Upper West Side, of course, where so much misguided entertaining took place back then. It featured recorded oud -- yes, oud -- music, hours of it, before the guests were offered more than just a single glass of Champagne. Stronger drinks had been forbidden, on the grounds that they ''corrupt the palate,'' and although hors d'oeuvres were several times promised, they failed to appear. The guests did not sit down until 11, to a meal that consisted, as one of the party recalled, ''mostly of squishy stuff,'' and the evening ended, long after midnight, with the host, who was wearing a caftan -- did I mention that? -- reading from his own poetry. It was snowing. I forgot to mention that, too, and when the guests were finally freed, there were no cabs to be found, so everyone walked home. By the next morning, many were ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWORKIN, WILLIAM
description: DWORKIN--William. October 29, 2003 in New York. He would have been 76 November 9th. He was long active in marketing books on art and architecture, notably at Harry N. Abrams, and then at Rizzoli where he was Vice President for Sales and Associate Editor. He gravitated to publishing out of his love of books. Born in Newark, NJ, he attended Rutgers, Colorado and the University of Chicago. He was an omnivorous reader with a passion for the beautiful and humanizing in the arts, especially classical music. An avid collector of recordings, he was as devoted to film history, having spent his youth in the flickering dark. Secular to his fingertips, he led for over 25 years a Yiddish reading group with wry humor and quiet authority. Dignified, modest, charming of deep feeling and integrity, he is mourned by many friends, his darling cousin Lillian Loewenthal, her husband Leo, and sons Danny and Eben, his nephew David Stamboulis and the family of Eugene Roth, his companion of 33 years who survives him sore at heart. A memorial will be held in December.

Then came two men with a chart and it was clear they were going to build a house. ''You have plenty of land,'' I said to them. ''Please don't build too close to us.'' They assured me they wouldn't, but I knew they would anyway.

title: Our Lady of the Forest
description: The girl's errand in the forest that day was to gather chanterelle mushrooms in a bucket to sell in town at dusk. According to her own account and the accounts of others in the North Fork Campground who would later be questioned by the diocesan committee, by Father Collins of Saint Joseph's of North Fork, by the bishop's representative, and by reporters covering the purported apparitions-including tabloid journalists who treated the story like a visitation by Martians or the birth of a two-headed infant-the girl left her camp before eight o'clock and walked alone into the woods. She wore a sweatshirt with its hood drawn tight. She didn't speak to others of her intentions. Setting out with no direction in mind, she crossed a maple bottom and a copse of alders, traversed a creek on a rotten log, then climbed a ridge into deep rain forest and began searching for mushrooms in earnest.

Nor is it unusual for her roommate, Larissa Powers, to spray her bed with a toxic substance and consider burning all her clothes.

title: Swezey's Made Me Feel at Home
description: FOR those who did not know any better, it looked like just another department store among the strip malls. My husband made fun of me for liking to shop there. Being a Long Island native, he saw Swezey's as a relic and the blue-haired ladies who favored shopping there as hard evidence of this fact. He may have been right, but this well-worn quality is what made me feel so secure and comfortable there. And in a larger sense, Swezey's contributed to my feeling settled in on Long Island.

title: POSTINGS: At Marymount Manhattan College; Goodbye Pool, Hello Offices
description: Past students who have not been on the Marymount Manhattan College campus in the last few months might be in for a surprise the next time they go: the swimming pool on the seventh and eighth floors of the Main Building at 221 East 71st Street, built in 1929 as the clubhouse of the Manhattan Junior League, has been supplanted by offices and a conference room.

title: Living Wills
description: To the Editor:

title: On The Terrace
description: Even when he was a mere student at Parsons School of Design, Narciso Rodriguez was famous.

title: Rivals Attack Dean for Wooing 'Guys With Confederate Flags'
description: Howard Dean's rivals for the Democratic nomination roundly attacked him on Saturday for telling an Iowa newspaper he wanted ''to be the candidate for guys with Confederate flags in their pickup trucks'' in defending his opposition to some gun control legislation.

title: The Watchful Parent, Sentry Over Innocence
description: THE morning after the news broke that the headmaster at Trevor Day, a private school in Manhattan, had been arrested on charges of soliciting sex from teenagers online, tearful parents who gathered there expressed not simply shock, but something closer to betrayal.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; CONGRESS HUNKERS DOWN
description: Members of Congress would like nothing more than to go home for the year, but there is still work to be done. Actually, a lot of work. The Senate this week will try to plow through legislation, including a measure threatening sanctions on Syria and another banning taxes for Internet access. But several big spending bills remain up in the air -- not to mention critical Medicare and energy legislation.

title: Pleasures Big and Small
description: November brings vin nouveau or, in the case of Castello di Borghese, vino novello: new wine.

title: SAN FRANCISCO FOR LESS GOLD
description: SAN FRANCISCO may have swooned, for a while, over the $1,000 tasting menus and college-dropout millionaires of the dot-com boom. But since the economic and tourism slumps, the city not only offers deals to travelers, but its arts scene -- as if awakened from a nap -- seems refreshed and ready for work. Call it the creative upside of the downturn.

title: A Time of Need Is Upon Us
description: As New York City teems once more with a boom-time population of eight million, its signature Dickensian dichotomy brims before our eyes: poverty and homelessness are on the rise even as the streets hum with ambitious newcomers and the average price of a Manhattan apartment rockets toward the million-dollar mark. The city's clashing mix of opulence and opportunity, hard labor and raw daily indigence has rarely been so palpable. Neither has the need for some down-home charity. For all its resilience after the Sept. 11 disaster, the city finds 18 of 100 residents impoverished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TENNENBAUM, MILDRED
description: TENNENBAUM--Mildred. Of Brighton Beach, on October 29, 2003. Passed on quietly. As with everything in life, she did it her way. She is survived by Aileen and Howard Golden, Eugene Messinger and Dr. Barbara Kanal, Alan Wolsky, Michelle Golden, Dana and Lawrence Moses, Ronald Wolsky and Mark Wolsky. Aunt Millie, we already miss you.

title: The Twists and Turns Of the F Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Decoding a Steroid: Hunches, Sweat, Vindication
description: Last June 13, a test tube of clear liquid arrived by overnight mail at the Olympic drug-testing laboratory at the University of California, Los Angeles. The liquid included residue from a syringe that a tipster said contained an undetectable anabolic steroid.

title: Eating Their Words
description: Gossiping over instant coffee in the kitchen is a waste of time; serving five courses on grandmother's Limoges to 30 is a strenuous effort, usually with little return. But discussing ''To the Lighthouse'' while dining on Mrs. Ramsay's boeuf en daube is not only virtuous but will also, in fact, improve your mind. And incidentally, you can wear your new Prada jacket while doing so.

title: Letters
description: Airlines, Setters of Trends

title: Business People; Chairman of Southwest Takes It to His Roots
description: Herbert D. Kelleher has kept a relatively low profile since stepping aside as chief executive of Southwest Airlines two years ago. But Mr. Kelleher, who was a founder of the airline in 1971 and remains as chairman, has never missed a chance to promote it -- and he was at center stage in Philadelphia last week when Southwest announced that it would start service there in 2004.

title: Stacey McArdle, Christopher Danielian
description: Stacey Susanne McArdle, a daughter of Elaine and Edward McArdle of Darnestown, Md., was married yesterday to Christopher John Danielian, a son of Pamela and Ronald Danielian, also of Darnestown. The Rev. Dr. Ruth E. Correll performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Frederick, Md.

title: When Your Brother Is Your Benchmark
description: HOW successful are you? It is a never-ending calculus, and, if you're like me, you started it at a tender age. I remember gauging my stock in the world by how quickly I was chosen to be on a team for a neighborhood game like Red Rover. Yet as painful as these self-assessments can be, they usually offer a lovely little escape hatch: a ''but that's because'' clause. In my case, I may have been one of the last kids chosen for Red Rover, but that's because I was new at the game. Today, I'm not wealthy, but that's because I'm a journalist.

title: Chaney: Silent and Deep
description: LON CHANEY COLLECTION -- (Warner Home Video and Turner Classic Movies) The revered silent-film actor Lon Chaney is best known for ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' (1923) and ''The Phantom of the Opera'' (1925), neither of which is included here. But because they're not horror movies in the classic vein, the three movies in this new DVD package may provide an even better handle on Chaney's artistry; the feature documentary that's also included, produced by the silent-film historian Kevin Brownlow, sheds even more light on the man and his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMERILLO, JOHN
description: CAMERILLO--John, 64. Of Manhattan, N.Y. Passed peacefully on October 8, 2003. He was an Army veteran. He leaves three sisters and two brothers and will be missed.

title: For Auto Executives, Greener Roads After Retirement
description: To the list of auto industry executives who have gone on to smaller things, add Richard O. Schaum's name. Mr. Schaum, who retired in April as executive vice president for product development at Chrysler, has become vice president for vehicle development at WaveCrest Laboratories, a technology start-up that focuses on electric vehicles.

title: Business People; Women Offer Advice: Diversify, Diversify
description: Eight executives, all women and members of corporate boards, have joined forces to help companies find women and minority candidates for director's jobs. They have founded the Directors' Council, based in Phoenix and New York and aimed at increasing the diversity of boards.

title: Ipek Candan, Alexander Snyder
description: Ipek Nicole Candan, the daughter of Ece Ozses of Istanbul and Yavuz Candan of Bodrum, Turkey, was married yesterday to Alexander Lowell Wolff Snyder, the son of Geraldine and Nathan Snyder of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Richard Sobel officiated at the Sagamore hotel at Bolton Landing, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTON, TRUMBULL
description: BARTON--Trumbull. On October 31, 2003, at age 86. The family wishes to extend its profound gratitude to all those for their love and care. Funeral services private.

title: With Bus Cuts Restored, Nassau Budget Is Approved
description: The Nassau County Legislature unanimously approved County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi's $2.29 billion budget for 2004 on Monday after adding $2.4 million to avoid service cutbacks on Long Island Bus.

title: My Mary Sue
description: To the Editor:

title: Residents Want Bicycle Deliverymen To Stop and Spare the Pedestrians
description: It was near midnight on Christmas Day 2000 when Janet Schubert, on her way to a house-sitting job, was hit by a bicycle-riding pizza delivery man speeding through a crosswalk on the Upper East Side. The collision left no lasting physical damage. But it helped bring Ms. Schubert, who was uninterested in politics most of her life, to a City Council candidates' forum nearly two years later.

title: IN CHICAGO, LUXE BY THE LAKE
description: THERE are two conflicting ways to visit a big city on a budget. You can splurge on the grand hotel, tuck in your belt at mealtime and see the show from the third tier; or you can sleep cheaply, order the expensive wine and commandeer the best seats in the house.

title: Canada's Cold War
description: The Way the Crow Flies

title: With California Blazes Out or Down, Firefighters Are Sent Home
description: Thousands of weary firefighters who rushed into Southern California from across the state this week to battle raging wildfires got orders on Saturday to pack up and prepare to return home.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in this section last Sunday about the reclusive Collyer brothers referred incorrectly to another grave in Cypress Hills Cemetery, where the Collyers are buried. The pianist Ignace Jan Paderewski, who died in 1941, is not buried there now; his heart was placed in a crypt there in 1945 but moved in 1986 to the Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa in Doylestown, Pa. A plaque in Cypress Hills still marks the site.

title: Among the Heathens
description: THE SERENITY PRAYER

title: If There's Ever an Unruly Mob
description: IT was an impressive show of force. Westchester County officials were proudly unveiling a police unit that had been newly trained in crowd control. Wearing riot helmets and carrying batons, 18 police officers stomped in unison toward members of the unruly mob, who were played by about two dozen police academy recruits. A few of the recruits really got inspired, yelling, ''Hell, no, we won't go!'' and one even shouted, ''Go home, you pigs!'' though this was met with some dirty looks by his peers.

title: New Malaysian Leader's Style Stirs Optimism
description: The new prime minister of Malaysia, Abdullah Badawi, a consummate diplomat abroad and well connected to the Islamic community at home, cuts an entirely different image from his volatile predecessor, Mahathir Mohamad. Mr. Abdullah is popularly known here as ''Mr. Nice Guy,'' an endearment that could hardly be conferred on Dr. Mahathir.

title: DataBank; Stocks Log Best Week in Almost a Month
description: Stocks had their best week in nearly a month, helped by a merger, healthy earnings reports and the biggest quarterly increase in economic output since the mid-1980's.

title: Motivating Factors
description: Cousin Fred has found religion. He is becoming a tummler.

title: The Sublime Sagami
description: SOMETIMES, there is a defining moment at a restaurant, a moment when the experience coalesces and the rating becomes clear. It happened one night at Sagami. The place was packed and noisy and we had waited a long time for a table. We ordered a raft of appetizers and devoured them. We ordered soup, salad, sashimi and sushi and fried oysters, and we ate all but one last bite of quivery sea urchin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, CHARLOTTE (NEE MALLER)
description: STERN--Charlotte (nee Maller). On October 31, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Judith and Sheldon Katz, Joan and Stuart Kaufman, and Mark and Terrie Stern. Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Services today 11 AM at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Diagnosis
description: Lisa Sanders (Oct. 19) asks a telling question: ''Why would this odd but smart and pleasant woman refuse a treatment that could extend her life and cause virtually no side effects?'' To ''extend'' her life, the woman would need to spend the last remaining months of it enmeshed in the hospital system. Her precious time would be wasted on mind-numbing paperwork and squandered sitting in crowded waiting rooms, her last days spent enduring the invasive jabbing by strangers. A natural death on one's own terms, like natural childbirth, may not be for everyone, but as an end-of-life option it certainly is worthy of medical understanding and respect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, HONORA (HONEY)
description: SHAPIRO--Honora (Honey). Our entire family share with us the deep sadness we are feeling. Honey, we all loved and adored you. You will forever be a song in our hearts. To Barbara, Stephen, Kelly, Lou and all the grandchildren, a light has gone out in our lives. Barbara and Harold

title: CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF
description: WHEN the legendary theater critic Kenneth Tynan saw the 1955 Broadway premiere of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' directed by Elia Kazan, he thought something was amiss. ''It was august, all right, and turbulent, but there were moments of unaccountable wrongness, as if a kazoo had intruded into a string quartet,'' he wrote in an essay for Mademoiselle magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAHLBERG, AUDREY A.
description: DAHLBERG--Audrey A., 82, died October 18, 2003, in Banning, CA. She is survived by her children, Ann L. Dahlberg & Scott E. Dahlberg. She was a homemaker and previously lived in Manhattan, Ridgewood, NJ, and La Jolla, CA.

title: Beatrix Potter's World On View in Toronto
description: ''Peter Rabbit's Garden,'' an exhibition that opened last month at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto, showcases the literature, art and conservation efforts of Beatrix Potter (1866-1943). Curators have gathered rare editions, early merchandise and more than 40 original sketches and watercolors from such beloved books as ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit,'' ''Mrs. Twiggy-Winkle'' and ''Jemima Puddle-Duck.'' A large collection of Potter's letters can be seen in a simultaneous exhibition at the Toronto Reference Library, 789 Yonge Street, (416) 395-5577; admission free.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 12 about investing in the Legg Mason Special Investment Trust misstated its average annual return for the three years ended on Oct. 9. It was 8.1 percent, not 58.1 percent.

title: Fitted and Feminine Give Jeans a Run
description: FOR years, the Los Angeles fashion scene has suffered a bit of the reputation of the starlet: cute and bubbly but insubstantial. At Fashion Week Spring 2004, however, which began last Sunday in Los Angeles, there were signs that jeans, sweatsuits and T-shirts were giving way, at least in some quarters, to femininity and tailoring.

title: Peekskill Redrafts Plan For Peace Officers
description: In response to a recent veto by Gov. George E. Pataki , Peekskill is retooling a proposal to allow the city to designate workers as peace officers to enforce environmental regulations in its 48-square-mile watershed, all of which is in the neighboring towns of Cortlandt and Putnam Valley.

title: A Plan to Build the Best-Protected Bathroom Ever
description: TOURISM promoters believe they can overcome deeply rooted neighborhood objections and move forward with a plan to build what would be Long Island's first true visitors' center after at least three decades of trying.

title: Finally, Ellis Earns Opponents' Attention
description: Jets center Kevin Mawae was sitting in his dorm room with his roommate, Dave Szott, in training camp this summer, ruminating over potential leaders of the defense. Defensive end Shaun Ellis was one player they settled on, an unlikely endorsement considering that Mawae had been on the opposite side of Ellis in a handful of practice scuffles over the last three years.

title: Lessons on the 5:27: 'All Still Kids at Heart'
description: WHEN 14-year-old Kerry Maher began riding the train to private school, her parents were understandably nervous. Her father, John, took her on a couple of practice runs from their home in Redding to the school, Lauralton Hall in Milford.

title: Did Someone Say 50th? Then Invite 250
description: AH, the 50th birthday. A quiet dinner with friends, some low-fat cheesecake, perhaps a nice Cognac before bed.

title: Where Have All The Women Gone?
description: BETSY GOTBAUM presides over City Council meetings from an impressive wooden chair that sits on a large dais in the chambers at City Hall. The room, dressed in dusky oil paintings and gilt trim, is typically ringed by a restless, chattering cloud, equal parts men and women.

title: Light White, At a Right Price
description: Alex Gambal's 2001 Fixin, a vivid chardonnay named for its minor red-wine commune in the Cte de Nuits, is a $19.95 find at the Burgundy Wine Company, 143 West 26th Street.

title: Guy in Skirt Seeks Sensitivity In Brooklyn
description: WANDERING around Brooklyn in a skirt when you are a dude is a complicated affair, fraught with loaded symbols and multiple entendres, but three simple rules will get you a long way:

title: Yale Overpowers Columbia And Stays in Thick of Race
description: IVY LEAGUE

title: Two Villages to Vote On Partner Registries
description: AN increasing number of unmarried couples who want to make their relationships a matter of public record may soon get the chance. In the next 10 days two more Long Island villages are scheduled to vote on virtually identical legislation that would set up domestic partner registries for their residents and employees.

title: BROTHER, CAN YOU SPARE SOME SAND?
description: To help stem the ever-rushing tide of beach erosion, Ocean City officials proposed last week that the Army Corps of Engineers give them some spare sand when it does its periodic beach replenishment program this month. The officials want an extra 50,000 cubic yards of sand to stockpile on the northern end of the island for emergency beach repairs in the three years until the next planned major replenishment, in 2006. The extra cache is paltry next to the amount the corps plans to pump onto the beach - about 1.5 million cubic yards - but Ocean City officials say that tides, floods and other erosion problems aren't scheduled events and that the extra sand would help preserve beaches without waiting for the major replenishment times. A spokesman for the corps said the stockpile was an innovative plan but would require approvals from state and federal governments. Robert Strauss

title: The Great White Wayfarer
description: The child of a test pilot and one of a long line of wanderers, 43-year-old Benedict Allen has spent the last 20 years on a solitary trek across the world's most inhospitable jungles, deserts and Arctic tundra. He thrives on the thin air of high adventure, traveling light, with only a minimum amount of equipment, and almost always alone, with a video camera for companionship. The ''diary'' of his attempt to cross the Bering Strait with a dog team of 10 during one of the coldest Siberian winters in living memory -- ''Ice Dogs'' -- will be shown Nov. 9 on ''National Geographic Ultimate Explorer.'' The noted photographer Bruce Weber has assembled this homage to his eccentric friend.

title: Big 10's End Zone: New York Bars
description: DAVID LEITNER doesn't always stand on chairs in public, banging a cowbell -- Ding Ding dingdingding Ding Ding -- and shouting ''Go Blue!'' at the top of his lungs. Usually, he's just another Manhattan estate-planning lawyer. But when his beloved Michigan Wolverines take the field, or at least the large-screen television at the local sports bar, something comes over him -- and that's when he picks up the cowbell.

title: Deaths in Iraq Take a Steady Toll at Home
description: In the last two weeks, 22 American soldiers have given their lives to the occupation of Iraq, a platoon of 21 men and 1 woman cut down to a stack of photographs by accidents, illness and the rising insurgency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEFILIPPIS, ROBERT
description: DeFILIPPIS--Robert. On November 1, 2003. 56 year member of I.U.O.E. of Local #

title: INSIDE
description: Glimmer of Hope for Miners

title: Page Two: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; 'The World Is More Free and More Peaceful'
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S Rose Garden news conference last Tuesday was so hastily arranged that there was no time for the elegantly printed seat assignments that White House aides usually place on each chair. Instead, someone had unceremoniously scrawled out ABC, NBC and the like on the back of index cards.

title: A Tuesday Night Kind of Place
description: IT was like a scene from ''Sex and the City'' or, more accurately, sex and the suburbs. Hudson's Mill in Massapequa was filled with groups of friends sharing a story, a laugh and a meal. This is not a fancy restaurant where life's milestones are celebrated but a Tuesday night kind of place. In fact, I was there on a Tuesday and it was so full that diners were eating at the bar.

title: A DVD Offers A Chance To Think Inside Cornell's Boxes
description: DON'T all admirers of Joseph Cornell dream of climbing into his mysterious boxes and checking out their contents? Robert Lehrman, a leading collector of Cornell's works, has been able to indulge these fantasies, dismantling boxes in order to ship them to exhibitions and reassembling them upon their return. In his preface to the new book ''Joseph Cornell: Shadowplay Eterniday'' ($60), produced by his Voyager Foundation, he writes, ''I have been able to literally to go inside the box.''

title: Tami Salpeter, Todd Smiler
description: Tami Rachel Salpeter, the daughter of Susan and Jack Salpeter of Coral Springs, Fla., is to be married today in Aventura, Fla., to Todd Jarred Smiler, a son of Barbara and Dennis Smiler of Jericho, N.Y. Rabbi Paul Plotkin is to perform the ceremony at the Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center. Cantor Abraham H. Wolkin, a grandfather of the bridegroom, is to take part in the service.

title: Late With Cellphone Is Still Late
description: To the Editor:

title: Deepti Thomas, Mathew Paulose Jr.
description: Dr. Deepti Thomas, a daughter of Valsamma Thomas and Thomas Samuel of Pelham, N.Y., was married yesterday in Rye, N.Y., to Mathew Paulose Jr., the son of Leela Paulose and Mr. Paulose Sr. of Damascus, Md. The Rev. Dr. Richard E. Murdoch officiated at the Rye Presbyterian Church, with the Rev. Dr. K. A. Abraham, a priest of the Marthoma Syrian Church.

title: Tilt
description: DON QUIXOTE

title: Letters
description: Does North Korea's Dear Leader belong in Hollywood -- perhaps as a studio head? Some readers said so. And Robert Downey Jr.'s recovery from drugs prompted others to ask, Is it for real or an act? In Diagnosis, a patient who opted out of medical treatment drew surprising support.

title: Academic Stars: Worth the Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: Staged Bach Without the Staging
description: IN 2001, as part of Lincoln Center's New Visions series, the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson performed two solo Bach cantatas with the Orchestra of Emmanuel Music in Boston, staged by the director Peter Sellars. Even those who had problems with the starkly dramatic staging concepts had to concede that the performances were exquisite. Now Ms. Hunt Lieberson and Emmanuel Music have recorded the two cantatas, No. 82, ''Ich Habe Genug'' (''I Have Enough''), and No. 199, ''Mein Herze Schwimmt in Blut'' (''My Heart Swims in Blood''), on a Nonesuch CD, which is one the finest Bach recordings to have come along in some time.

title: An Odd Cry Stops Manhattan Traffic: Fore!
description: Many golfers took advantage of yesterday's magnificent late fall weather, but presumably only one man played a round through Midtown Manhattan.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Piano by Laredo

title: Fashionable, but at a Cost?
description: To the Editor:

title: Oui, It's a Cartoon. Non, It's Not for Your Kids.
description: ONCE upon a time, in a land far, far away from the prettified, petrified world of American animation and from the smooth, good-and-evil symmetry of Japanese anime, there lived an artist named Sylvain Chmet. He believed that animation was a genre defiled of late by bad guys, who wanted only to make money and who thought of animators as interchangeable cartoonists-for-hire. So Mr. Chmet created a counterpoise, an exceedingly odd feature-length animation that manages to send up France, America, gastronomy, the Tour de France, consumerism, gangsterism, heroism, professional ambition and heaven knows what else. This is not a film for very young children. On the contrary, says Mr. Chmet, describing the M.O. of the team of animators he directed, ''we really tried to make the film we had always felt deprived of.''

title: The End Of The West?
description: Well, the numbers are in and the numbers don't lie. At the Madrid aid conference, Saudi Arabia pledged $1 billion in new loans and credits for Iraq -- and Germany and France pledged 0 new dollars. Add it all up and the bottom line becomes clear: Saudi Arabia actually cares more about nurturing democracy in Iraq than Germany and France.

title: Tough Call on Tuesday for Suffolk Voters
description: THEY agree that Suffolk County government should be overhauled and taxes curtailed, and that the police department needs to be made more efficient. They agree that an appointed ethics commissioner and tougher ethics rules could help eliminate corruption and cronyism. Both support campaign finance changes and enhanced public transportation. Each promises to make environmental preservation and affordable housing the hallmarks of his administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, SHARON
description: GOLDSTEIN--Sharon. Died on October 28, 2003. Beloved wife of Peter, daughter of Annette Morgenroth. Mother to Joli Rose, sister of Charles and Penny, sister-in-law of Janet, Craig, Debra, Andrew and Elyse; daughter-in-law of Joan and Irv; aunt to Ryan, Seth, Matthew, Daniel, Evan, Simon, Samara, Lauren, Emily and Madison. Friend to many. We will all miss you dearly.

title: December
description: Dec. 5

title: Pack Rats In Our Midst
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Why I Am a Catholic, by Garry Wills. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14.) Even as he offers a lengthy and scathing history of the papal institution, the author explains why he has ''never even considered'' leaving the Roman Catholic Church, arguing that the papacy -- despite its flaws -- remains a symbol of Christian unity that conscientious believers can support while still being in ''loyal opposition'' to the pope. Last year in the Book Review, Jack Miles found this a ''candid, richly informative and perfectly timed book.''

title: Jane Cummins, Kenneth Shidler
description: Jane Alexandra Cummins, the daughter of Janice and Herbert A. Cummins of Livingston, N.J., was married in New York yesterday evening to Kenneth Brian Shidler, the son of Andi Fox of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Alan Shidler of Chicago. Rabbi Barry Friedman officiated at the Princeton Club of New York.

title: In the Ranks, Similarities Between Vietnam and Iraq
description: It is a different war in a different era, fought by a different American Army. Yet the emerging profile of the soldiers, sailors, pilots and other service members dying in Iraq bears a surprising similarity to those who lost their lives in the Vietnam War.

title: E. Hampton Deal Is Restart Of Suffolk Land Program
description: Resuming a long-stalled program to purchase open space, Suffolk County announced last week that it had joined with the Town of East Hampton to buy 57 acres on Three Mile Harbor for $12 million.

title: Business; Look! We Can Drive and Snack at the Same Time
description: CALL it portafuel, cup-holder cuisine or go-grub. Whatever the name, convenience food sells. Ever since the first TV dinners were offered in tin trays, packaged foods have become more portable, and the number of such products is surging.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Julia Jordan Beats the Odds, Then Beats Them Again
description: THE Knicks winning the N.B.A. title. Halley's comet shooting through the sky. An unknown female playwright receiving four New York productions in one year. Some things just don't happen very often, and when they do they can provoke a certain surprise.

title: 2 Hispanic Candidates Battle It Out
description: NO matter what the outcome of voting in Suffolk County on Tuesday, greater representation for the county's Hispanic residents appears certain.

title: Page Two: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; RUSSIA'S WAR WITHIN
description: Back in February, when Russia's economy was booming and little seemed to spoil the ebullience of new riches, President Vladimir V. Putin and Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky appeared together at a meeting of industrialists at the Kremlin.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Bogart
description: 'HIGH SIERRA'; 'TO HAVE AND HAVE NOT' -- (Warner Brothers) The two sides of the Humphrey Bogart persona -- the raging gangster and the cynical idealist who claims not to stick his neck out for anybody (while sticking it out at every turn) -- are epitomized in these releases, both due on Tuesday.

title: U.S. CONSIDERING RECALLING UNITS OF OLD IRAQ ARMY
description: Some American military officers in Iraq are pressing to reconstitute entire units of the former Iraqi Army, which the top United States administrator in Baghdad disbanded in May. They say the change would speed the creation of a new army and stabilize the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAMAN, BARBARA LANE
description: SHAMAN--Barbara Lane. 57, of Seattle, died October 26, 2003. Beloved daughter of Lillian and the late Morris Shaman, of New York. Loyal sister of Ellen and Donna Shaman, loving aunt of Matiah Shaman. Graduated University of Buffalo, '68, Peace Corps Phillipines, 1968-1973. Barbara, a respected electrician, machinist and teacher, was a brave, pioneering woman in the trades.

title: Lara Spingler, Eric Dittmann
description: Lara Nicole Spingler, the daughter of Ellen J. Spingler and Frederick P. Spingler of Watchung, N.J., was married yesterday to Eric William Dittmann, the son of Patricia Hernandez of Stockton, N.J., and William Dittmann of Spring Lake Heights, N.J. The Rev. Louis J. Mazza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Church in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 9
description: Indianapolis Colts (6-1) at Miami Dolphins (5-2)

title: A Ballroom Broadcast, Steeped in Stardust
description: NO company in television is more tied to its past than CBS, nor more conspicuously proud of it.

title: A Mathematician Plays the Stock Market
description: It was early 2000, the market was booming, and my investments in various index funds were doing well but not generating much excitement. Why investments should generate excitement is another issue, but it seemed that many people were genuinely enjoying the active management of their portfolios. So when I received a small and totally unexpected chunk of money, I placed it into what Richard Thaler, a behavioral economist I'll return to later, calls a separate mental account. I considered it, in effect, "mad money."

title: Entrance
description: Then I went indoors. First came the beautiful one, whose

title: Crime
description: A brilliant professional woman without a job is a terrible thing to behold. Patricia Cornwell's dynamic forensic pathologist, Kay Scarpetta, has nothing to do with herself in BLOW FLY (Putnam, $26.95). Booted out of her position as the chief medical examiner of Virginia, Scarpetta is reduced to living in a cottage in Delray Beach and hiring herself out as a consultant. But nothing lights her fire until she receives a message from Jean-Baptiste Chandonne, the monstrous killer she put on death row in an earlier novel, promising to fill her in on the atrocities currently being committed in Baton Rouge by his equally insane twin brother.

title: Investing; In a Land of Giants, Little Funds Find an Audience
description: BERNARD B. KLAWANS, 82, manages the Valley Forge fund out of an office in his home in suburban Philadelphia. title: Surprise Delivery
description: I don't remember the exact moment when it became clear that we needed to go for a fourth. We already had three amazing, healthy boys, and having another baby felt a bit like tempting fate. But my husband, Brian, and I always wanted kids of both sexes, and over the years we became increasingly fixated on having a girl. For months at a time we would dismiss the idea, thinking it was crazy to have another baby and vaguely unethical to be so invested in its sex. But then the old desire for a daughter would come creeping back.

title: Canceling Room Gets Trickier
description: WHEN it comes to imposing cancellation penalties on customers, you have to credit the airline industry for at least having a consistent approach. If you buy a nonrefundable fare on most airlines, it will cost you $100 to cancel or make a change. And despite the ''nonrefundable'' designation, as long as you cancel before the plane leaves, you can usually apply the rest of your fare to a future flight.

title: More From a Deep Vein Of Anti-S.U.V. Sentiment
description: Re ''Parking for S.U.V.'s and Their Necessity'' [letter, Oct. 26]: As a resident of Great Neck for more than 30 years, I have seen many changes to our once lovely and lively village. The incursion of S.U.V.'s into our landscape has brought a never-ending parade of behemoths whose drivers feel entitled to drive how and where they please with no regard for pedestrians or traffic rules. These gas guzzlers would be best served by having their own parking areas, much like compact cars already do. They can then have the joy of backing out between their fellow travelers and can open their humongous doors and let them smash into their neighbor's vehicle! This fair village has become the land of entitlement, sad to say. Let's segregate the S.U.V.'s and they can ''talk'' amongst themselves!

title: In New Proposal, Rebels Seek Territorial Autonomy in Sri Lanka

title: A Bird's-Eye View. Really.
description: 'WINGED MIGRATION' -- (Sony Pictures Classics) The making-of featurette included on the DVD of Jacques Perrin's magnificent 2002 documentary explains the various gizmos that the filmmakers rigged -- motorized gliding parachutes, light aircraft, cameras mounted on assorted robotic devices -- in order to film dozens of species of airborne birds in the course of their yearly migrations.

title: In The Shadow Of The Patriarch
description: My get-away-from-New-York place, my hole-up-and-write place, is an apartment I've kept for the last seven years in Mexico City, in a rundown but sturdy two-story building on a tree-shaded street near a park. The apartment has four large rooms with soft, creaky, dun-hued wooden floors and French windows with disintegrating wood frames and missing panes that let the rain, insects and even birds in. It is furnished with just a bed, bookshelves and two adjoining wooden tables where I work. Here I find concentration and long writing days as I do nowhere else, though that placid routine was turned upside down this summer when Mauricio Montiel rented the apartment next door and it became ''Montiel's Cave,'' where a group of youngish Mexico City writers and journalists gathered regularly at night to talk, over tequila, about books and movies, sometimes until nearly dawn or later. I would drop in to say hello and then find it impossible to leave.

While certainly overstated, it was the word Mr. Doria's friends and allies chose when describing what happened to him this summer.

title: The World of Satyajit Ray
description: 'PATHER PANCHALI'; 'APARAJITO'; 'THE WORLD OF APU' -- (Sony Pictures Classics) Satyajit Ray was an art director at a Calcutta ad agency when he was inspired to make a movie based on Bibhutibhushan Banerjee's autobiographical novel about a Bengali boy, Apu, and his family. That picture, ''Pather Panchali,'' was released in 1955 to great acclaim, but it hadn't come easily: Ray spent all of his earnings and sold his own belongings and his wife's jewelry to complete the film. In doing so, though, he changed the course of movie history. ''Pather Panchali'' and its sequels, ''Aparajito'' (1957) and ''The World of Apu'' (1959), which together trace Apu's journey to adulthood, opened the world of Indian cinema to the West. And for me these three pictures, known as the Apu Trilogy, constitute perhaps the greatest experience the movies have to offer.

A finicky eater, he was on a medically supervised ''diet'' that forbade red meat or chicken but not, somehow, veal and mutton -- or spinach souffls. (Once, when Toklas tried to make a souffl appear ''less nourishing'' by serving it with three different sauces, the artist pronounced her efforts a ''cruel enigma.'')

Apart from sheer greediness, that is: why settle for a small box of candy when you can have a big one? From Sean Connery to Pierce Brosnan, no matter who plays him, 007 represents the ultimate in decadence and sexual magnetism -- and most of us could use just a little more of both.

title: Beneath The Smiles, A Churning Anxiety
description: WE live in a manic-depressive economy, and right now we're in the manic phase. The annual growth rate, 7.2 percent in the third quarter, was spectacular. The Keynesian-style stimulus has been wonderfully effective. But the depressive phase may kick in again soon, as growth slows and millions of employed and unemployed Americans struggle to make up for lost incomes.

title: Franklin Home Is Revived To Reflect the Town's Past
description: A $1 million restoration project that will enable a home owned by a Civil War physician to be opened as a historical museum is expected to be completed next year in Franklin.

title: Another Campaign Season, And He's Heard Enough
description: As election day draws near, the trickle of political mailings has increased to a flood. Few of these items contain anything but negativism, assuming the posture of ''look at what my opponent has done to you.'' Rather than state their great scheme, it remains clouded in mystery lest the electorate become the least bit informed and thereby be able to really judge on merit.

title: Notion Building
description: I read nothing in Matt Bai's article on John Podesta's new think tank (Oct. 12) about focus groups or brainstorming sessions big enough to include people like me. Surely, if the Democratic Party wants to know what might energize its natural constituents, the tent should be large enough for some grass-roots input and ideas. For starters, how about steering the party away from identity politics and toward ''common sense for the common good''? That's a tag line I'd be proud to stick on my bumper.

title: Country Counting
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Who's Counting?'' (Oct. 5) by Judith H. Dobrzynski: For the past two decades my husband and I have kept a large wall map with pins denoting the places to which we have traveled. Friends marvel at all the bright red dots; we lament the wide open spaces yet to explore.

title: How to Make a Building Fly
description: ''WE could have built four or five floors on the vacant parking lot,'' the English architect Will Alsop says of the $30 million building he designed for the Ontario College of Art and Design. ''But there's no magic in that, there's nothing to raise the spirit.'' So he raised the building nine stories on multicolored stilts.

title: Whose Child Is This?
description: Released in 1944 after the censors had held it up for a while, Preston Sturges's Christmas miracle movie is like no other ever made: alternately boisterous and grim, ''The Miracle of Morgan's Creek'' mixes pathos with fits of hysterical slapstick and can leave you genuinely unhinged. Most of the movie is set before Christmas Eve -- precisely nine months before, in fact. That's when Trudy Kockenlocker (Betty Hutton), who wants to do her patriotic bit to buoy the spirits of departing servicemen, goes to a couple of swinging socials with the boys, drinks too much punch, gets conked on the head and maybe marries someone whose name she's not sure of. She doesn't remember what happened, but there's considerable evidence in her expanding waistline that something did. ''I wanted to show what happens to young girls who disregard their parents' advice and who confuse patriotism with promiscuity,'' Preston Sturges wrote, with impish blandness, in his autobiography. Given the virgin birth angle and the triumphal finale -- in which Mussolini and Hitler are driven to madness by American fecundity -- it's more likely that he wanted to make a film in which gleeful blasphemy is so entwined with piety and patriotism that all the moralists could do was gurgle and clutch their chests. (''Some have greatness thrust upon them!'' reads the final crawl.) The miracle is that a mainstream filmmaker could have pulled off such a mixture of sentimentality and subversiveness.

title: The Kid Won't Get Out Of the Picture
description: ON the morning of June 15, the screening room of Robert Evans's Beverly Hills mansion -- a separate structure where over the years he has given debauched parties for friends like Jack Nicholson and Warren Beatty -- burst into flames. Mr. Evans, who had been asleep in his bedroom, crawled out from under his mink bedspread to watch as all his awards and archives, including such treasures as a print of ''Indiscreet'' given him by Cary Grant, went up in flames. ''I haven't set foot there since the fire,'' he says, standing on his patio in a gray cashmere turtleneck, sweatpants and trademark silver bolo tie. He gazes dolefully toward the wreckage. ''My heritage is lost,'' he says. The official cause of the fire was an electrical short. But looking at the charred ruin today, one might sooner suspect a vengeful god with some scores to settle.

Landlocked Spaniards stopped by only in summer or during a week in March, when the Fallas festival fills the streets with building-high sculptures set aflame with much fanfare.

But sitting in his room for three straight days, he was unable to compose a single decent thing. Finally, in frustration, he hurled the guitar, which wasn't even his, onto the bed. It bounced off and hit the radiator.

title: Azzedine Cuisine
description: Shortly before he left London in 1990 to live in Paris, the fashion editor and illustrator Michael Roberts received some advice from Joseph Ettedgui, the founder of the Joseph shops: ''Go see Azzedine.'' He meant, of course, Azzedine Alaa, the Tunisian-born design maverick. Alaa did much to shape the look of the 80's, but his place in the fashion world was (and still is) that of a mother-in-law -- he was at once in the family and outside it. He rarely showed collections when other designers did, and he insisted on living and working under one roof, so that, at any hour, someone was being either fitted or fed. After watching one show crouched on the floor of Alaa's tiny apartment on the Rue de Bellechasse, Roberts says, he felt that ''I was in a cult that I didn't belong to.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Out in Front in Hartford
description: Many great museum collections have been assembled by one man with a plan. At the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn., that man was A. Everett Austin Jr. He served as director of the Wadsworth, the country's oldest art museum, from 1927 to 1944, but it was a series of acquisitions in the early 1930's that made his reputation. As recounted in SURREALISM AND MODERNISM: From the Collection of the Wadsworth Atheneum (Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art/Yale University, $50), it was a fairly radical undertaking. Hartford was a thriving small city back then, but even the larger world had not fully acclimated itself to the strange visions of artists like Salvador Dal, Jean Arp and Ren Magritte. Paul Paret, who teaches art history at the University of Utah, traces the course of modern art to put the museum's works in context. Eric Zafran, the Wadsworth's curator of European painting and sculpture, recounts Austin's remarkable reign. Austin certainly did not build the remarkable collection alone -- he had the help of people like the curator and patron James Thrall Soby, a Hartford native who later headed the painting department of the Museum of Modern Art. But ultimately it was Austin who organized a Picasso retrospective in 1934, the largest in the United States to that date, and who became the first museum director to buy a work by Joseph Cornell. As Zafran tells it, Austin was short-sighted only once -- he neglected to buy Salvador Dal's ''Persistence of Memory'' because the asking price was exorbitant -- $350. Ted Loos

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. The designer Narciso Rodriguez entertains often and for a crowd, so a big table is a must.
