The tables, with matching benches, are available at www.mossonline.com for $2,120 each. Joe D'Urso, who created the penthouse's sleek interiors, also designs furniture. His Odeon Tub chair, shown here, sells for $2,200. To the trade only; (212) 935-3713.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; A CONSECRATION AND A RIFT
description: The Episcopal Church USA will install its first openly gay bishop when the Rev. V. Gene Robinson is consecrated as bishop of New Hampshire today in an ice arena at the University of New Hampshire -- the only local venue large enough to hold the 4,000 participants.

title: Should Public's Money Improve Private Land?
description: TERRY GOOD lives on a piece of property most would envy, a waterfront parcel on Washington Township's private Lake Sterling.

title: As James Soars, Miles Struggles in Cleveland
description: Lost amid the hoopla surrounding the next great thing, LeBron James, have been the struggles of the last great thing, Darius Miles, James's teammate in Cleveland.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some regional editions last Sunday with an article about downtown Mount Kisco, N.Y., misidentified one of two men shown in front of a new store, Elephant's Trunk. The man at the right was Daniel Montroy, the architect, not Rafael Brache, an owner.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: OFF-SEASON, ON TRACK -- Two types of BritRail pass are being reduced by 25 percent through Feb. 28. The passes, which must be bought in the United States, are good on trains in England, Scotland and Wales. The discount applies to the Consecutive Pass (unlimited travel for a minimum of four consecutive days) and the FlexiPass (unlimited travel for 4 to 15 days over a two-month period), in all age categories. Before the discount, a four-day adult FlexiPass, for example, is $189 in standard class, $285 in first class; (877) 677-1066 or www.britrail.net.

title: A Striped Bass, Prepared to Perfection by a Top Chef
description: October, which we all know is the fishingest time of year, can also be as unpredictable as a moody infant. Certainly that was true two weeks ago at Montauk on a Sunday that was, by turns, cloudy, sunny, windy, calm, rough and finally rainy. No doubt this made some difference to the fish, but exactly what difference and how much, only the fish knew, and all we could do was chase our hunches.

title: More From a Deep Vein Of Anti-S.U.V. Sentiment
description: The letter on S.U.V.'s stating that these vehicles are necessary to car-pool several youngsters is ridiculous! I car-pooled in my four-door sedan for many years, taking as many as five children at a time. Taking more than that number of passengers requires at least a mini-van and putting more than five passengers in a S.U.V. puts them in jeopardy. So why are they ''necessary''? In addition to being gas-guzzlers, they pose a danger to those of us who are satisfied with our family sedans. They block the vision of other drivers, whether parked next to them or driving behind them. The only need they fulfill is that of their owners to be ''bigger and better'' than other drivers. They are dangerous and unnecessary and should be outlawed!

title: The Last Emperor
description: Peter Maass (Oct. 19) ends his timely analysis of Kim Jong Il by suggesting that his demise as dictator will come from something unimaginable. O.K., try this: Why not arrange a golden parachute that will land Kim in the C.E.O.'s chair at a major Hollywood studio? Given his interest in cinema, power and spectacle, such an exit might appeal to the North Korean leader. Perhaps the best Washington strategy for removing Kim from the Korean Peninsula will emerge not from the desk of George Bush, Colin Powell or Donald Rumsfeld but rather from the desk of Jack Valenti.

title: The Sobering Life of Robert Downey Jr.
description: I have always admired Robert Downey Jr. as an actor and been fascinated by the way his addictions have played out so publicly. Mim Udovitch did an amazing job of recognizing this fact as well as of giving us a glimpse into his personal life.

title: Soaked!
description: A MATHEMATICIAN PLAYS

title: From Rail To Ruin?
description: Manhattan has secrets. Despite millions of daytime residents and hundreds of skyscrapers, it has places as unexpected and out-of-the way as Emily Dickinson's home in Amherst, Mass. One thinks of Chumley's, a former speakeasy on Bedford Street; of Pomander Walk, a private row of Tudor-style cottages out of sight between 94th and 95th Streets; of Sylvan Terrace, a pedestrian-only passageway to the Morris-Jumel mansion with a set of matched wooden row houses; and of half a hundred other spots unknown to ordinary passersby.

title: In Some Classrooms, English May Unite With Korean
description: More than 1,000 Korean immigrants in New York attend traditional bilingual classes in which they are largely separate from fluent English speakers. But a Korean parents group and Councilman John Liu of Flushing, Queens, want the city's Department of Education to consider another option: a dual-language program in which native English and native Korean speakers share the same classroom and learn both languages.

title: Correction
description: Afront-page article in this section last Sunday about the reclusive Collyer brothers referred incorrectly to another grave in Cypress Hills Cemetery, where the Collyers are buried. The pianist Ignace Jan Paderewski, who died in 1941, is not buried there now; his heart was placed in a crypt there in 1945 but moved in 1986 to the Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa in Doylestown, Pa. A plaque in Cypress Hills still marks the site.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Ditmas Park and Ditmas Park West; Spirited Enclaves With Grand Homes
description: LIKE a lot of residents of a little corner of Flatbush, Brooklyn, known as Ditmas Park and Ditmas Park West, Katleen Felix Ranger and her husband, Pascal, a cosmetics executive, started their housing search in fashionable Park Slope. But after they had looked at a few small, expensive and somewhat noisy brownstone condominium units near Seventh Avenue, a newspaper ad brought them to these unusual enclaves of 100-year-old Victorians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTTMANN, RUTH, M.D.
description: GUTTMANN--Ruth, M.D. The faculty, staff and students of Columbia University Health Sciences Division mourn the loss of our colleague and friend, Dr. Ruth Guttmann. Dr. Guttmann served on the faculty in the Department of Radiology at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons from 1953 until her retirement in 1976. She also served as Director of the Department of Radiotherapy and Nuclear Medicine at the Delafield Hospital from 1963 to 1976. In 1993, Dr. Guttmann established the Thomas S. Zimmer Professorship of Reconstructive Surgery at Columbia in honor of her husband. In 1997, Dr. Guttmann established the George Guttmann Professorship Fund in honor of her father to be used toward creating the George Guttmann Professorship of Craniofacial Surgery at Columbia's School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Dr. Guttmann was a thoughtful, caring and compassionate physician. She will be deeply missed. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice-President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc. Dean, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLEN, PATRICIA
description: MULLEN--Patricia. On October 9, 2003. Teacher, writer, cherished friend. Memorial service Sunday, November 16, 3:00 p.m., at Gilda's Club, 195 West Houston St. (between Sixth Ave and Varick St.). Contributions in Pat's memory may be made to Gilda's Club of NYC.

title: 'Mission Accomplished'
description: To the Editor:

title: With His Wife in Limbo, Husband Can't Move On
description: Michael Schiavo is 6-foot-6, with a scrub-brush mustache and a gold chain bearing the crosses his parents wore. He is a nurse who works the graveyard shift, often pulling into his driveway as his neighbors walk their dogs in the moist Florida dawn. He has a meticulously kept yard, a screened-in pool where his friends sometimes gather, a golden retriever, a girlfriend and a year-old daughter.

title: Blueprint for a Mess
description: On the streets of Baghdad today, Americans do not feel welcome. United States military personnel in the city are hunkered down behind acres of fencing and razor wire inside what was once Saddam Hussein's Republican Palace. When L. Paul Bremer III, head of the Coalition Provisional Authority, leaves the compound, he is always surrounded by bodyguards, carbines at the ready, and G.I.'s on patrol in the city's streets never let their hands stray far from the triggers of their machine guns or M-16 rifles. The official line from the White House and the Pentagon is that things in Baghdad and throughout Iraq are improving. But an average of 35 attacks are mounted each day on American forces inside Iraq by armed resisters of one kind or another, whom American commanders concede are operating with greater and greater sophistication. In the back streets of Sadr City, the impoverished Baghdad suburb where almost two million Shiites live -- and where Bush administration officials and Iraqi exiles once imagined American troops would be welcomed with sweets and flowers -- the mood, when I visited in September, was angry and resentful. In October, the 24-member American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council warned of a deteriorating security situation.

title: Its Mentor vs. Understudy as Scott Encounters Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The Nets were at their best dominating the Minnesota Timberwolves, a team touted as a title contender, in the second quarter on Friday night at Continental Arena. Then, with a 14-point lead, the offense came up empty on one possession.

title: Fashion Choices, In the Eye of a Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Roseanne Spradlin Gives Sex a Realistic Crash and Jiggle
description: ROSEANNE SPRADLIN'S work is gritty, and not because her dancers have been known to wear as little clothing as a stripper at Scores. It is all in the way they move. In her candid pieces, legs splay awkwardly, breasts jiggle and bodies crash to the floor. Sex is treated with more brutality than tenderness. Ms. Spradlin is not fond of giving reality a coat of tasteful varnish.

title: Pack Rats In Our Midst
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy to Burn
description: WHEN the carmakers Nissan, Renault, Hyundai and BMW wanted to investigate the feasibility of using fuel cells to power automobiles, they came to Connecticut.

title: No Politics as Usual With These 2 Running in Louisiana
description: Louisiana voters are used to hearing awful things said about their politicians. The nasty labels over the years have included crook, demagogue, extortionist, swindler, incompetent and Nazi-loving leader of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Don't Revamp Toll Booths; Better to Bulldoze Them
description: To the Editor:

title: A Critics' Feast of Holiday Moments
description: Hostage to the Holiday

title: Habitats/39th Street and Park Avenue; A Designer and a Dentist, At Home in Pearly White
description: TO say that Dr. Michael Bruno, a specialist in cosmetic and reconstructive dentistry, is a perfectionist is to vastly underplay his world view. Dr. Bruno, who lives with his wife, the shoe designer Bettye Muller, in a rigorously designed white lacquer apartment that is uncannily suggestive of a perfect set of new teeth, is driven by the inspiration of three adjectives: efficient, streamlined and continuous, according to Ms. Muller, who has written them down in a notebook.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: EDISON AND THE ELECTRIC CHAIR

title: Revolution Silences MetroStars
description: A misunderstanding between two MetroStars defenders near their goalkeeper resulted in a second-half goal that helped the New England Revolution win, 2-0, Saturday in the opening game of the Major League Soccer playoffs at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLICHT, RHODA
description: BLICHT--Rhoda. The President, Board and staff of the New York Organ Donor Network mourn the passing of Rhoda Blicht. A loving wife, mother and grandmother, Rhoda dedicated her life to saving others through organ donation. She was Founder of the American Liver Foundation, Long Island Chapter, past President of the Greater New York Chapter of the American Liver Foundation, and long-time and active Board member of NYODN. We extend our condolences to her husband Warren, and the entire family at their sudden loss.

title: The Nation; Howard Dean's Internet Push: Where Will it Lead?
description: THESE are good times to be an Internet consultant working in politics. Just ask Ben Green, whose firm, Crossroad Strategies, has handled online duties for clients like Senators John Kerry and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Rebecca Howland, Michael Granne
description: Rebecca Brigadier Howland, the daughter of Jane Howland and Dr. John Howland of Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Aaron Granne, the son of Regina and Martin Granne of Manhattan. The ceremony, which took place at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams, Mass., was led by James R. Dabney, a friend of the bridegroom, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: A Unified Theory Of Nicole Kidman
description: LAST spring, Nicole Kidman completed her transformation from a gifted actress into a movie star, a process all the more mysterious for having occurred in plain sight. She seemed to have been around forever, and then, all of a sudden, there she was: her blue eyes glimmering on the cover of every glossy on the rack; her slender hands clutching an Oscar, her name inscribed at the very top of the Hollywood A-List. In the coming months, she will extend her run as a leading on-screen Quality Lit heroine, appearing in Robert Benton's adaptation of Philip Roth's novel ''The Human Stain'' (which opened Friday) and Anthony Minghella's ''Cold Mountain'' (Dec. 25), based on the best-selling, award winning Civil War novel by Charles Frazier. At this point, those movies may depend more on her than she does on them; her luster will only be enhanced by their success, and is unlikely to be diminished if they fail.

title: Molly Jong-Fast, Matthew Greenfield
description: Molly Miranda Jong-Fast, the daughter of the writer Erica Jong of New York and Jonathan Fast of Cos Cobb, Conn., was married last evening to Matthew Adlai Greenfield, the son of Connie and Stewart Greenfield of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Sarah Reines officiated at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: Stealing Ideas for a Garden Is No Crime
description: Gardeners not only exchange slips and cuttings over the metaphorical fence but also ideas. A visit to any garden is bound to inspire the amateur horticulturist to attempt the same thing, mitigated by the hope that any idea appropriated can be given a twist that makes it one's own.

title: POSTINGS: New Addition to Harvard Club on West 44th Street; Between Two Landmarks, Modern Glass and Limestone
description: The new eight-story glass and limestone addition to the Harvard Club of New York is to be dedicated on Wednesday with tours for members and a ribbon-cutting (crimson, of course).

title: Kenyans Win at New York Marathon
description: The women ran aggressively, the men cautiously. The women were fast, the men slow. But no matter how fast or how slow anyone ran, the Kenyans, as usual, dominated the ING New York City Marathon today.

title: It's Never Too Early To Think About the Beach
description: ''Come early, get five,'' said Mayor Jerome E. Inderweis of Cape May, a Santa-like chortle in his voice. While it may be getting chillier, with leaves turning colors and dropping, Mr. Inderweis and the Cape May City Council are preparing a Christmas present for dedicated beach-goers - cheap early-season beach tags.

title: The Bedford Boys
description: June 6, 1944, 12:30 A.M.: The British troopship, the Empire Javelin , steamed steadily across the English Channel. Among her passengers were thirty-four young men from the small Virginia town of Bedford. They belonged to the 116th Infantry's Company A, a select two-hundred man unit. After twenty months of arduous training, Company A had been chosen from among the 15,000 GIs in the Army of the United States' 29th Division to spearhead the most dangerous and critical American assault of the entire war.

title: The Last Word; Long Story Short
description: In the book business, conventional wisdom has it that short stories don't sell. True, at least once a year a (usually young) author produces a collection to high acclaim and respectable sales. This year, it's Nell Freudenberger's ''Lucky Girls,'' last year it was Adam Haslett's ''You Are Not a Stranger Here'' and before that, it was Jhumpa Lahiri's ''Interpreter of Maladies.'' Nathan Englander's ''For the Relief of Unbearable Urges'' has become a veritable touchstone for every editor trying to persuade his or her employer to take a chance on a book of stories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWD, NADINE, (NEE GOREN)
description: DOWD--Nadine, (nee Goren). Beloved wife of William. Daughter of Bea Goren, and the late Irving B. Goren. Sister of Susan Coseo and Steven Goren. Service November 4 in Fairfield, CT, Speer Funeral Home, 203-259-0824.

title: Jamila Ponton, Alvin Bragg Jr.
description: Jamila Marie Ponton, a daughter of Ocie M. Ponton of Bethel Park, Pa., and the late James A. Ponton, was married yesterday to Alvin Leonard Bragg Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bragg Sr. of New York. The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III performed the ceremony at the Heinz Memorial Chapel in Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTOCK, BETTY
description: WEINSTOCK -- Betty. The Board of Columbia/Barnard Hillel deeply mourns the passing of Betty Weinstock, wife of our devoted Board member, Arthur Weinstock. Our sincere condolences to Arthur and family. May her memory be a blessing. Ruth E. Horowitz Richard E. Kobrin Co-Presidents Earle W. Kazis, Chairman Joanne Ben-Avi Director of Development Charles H. Sheer Director & Jewish Chaplain

title: Hokies Touch Off a Mad Scramble for No. 2
description: They call it Beamer-ball here and it is named for Virginia Tech Coach Frank Beamer and his knack for finding ways to score when his offense seems to disappear. It has transformed the Hokies into an unlikely national power, and Saturday night it undid Miami, a perennial national title contender.

title: Four Comedies and a Collaboration
description: AS with lovers who take a while to warm up to each other, the couple's first meeting promised nothing but mutual dislike. Richard Curtis, auditioning actors for ''Four Weddings and a Funeral,'' felt that Hugh Grant was unreasonably handsome. Mr. Grant was annoyed by the way Mr. Curtis, the film's screenwriter, leaned impassively against a bookshelf and said nothing during his reading.

title: Kitchen Confidential
description: To open the kitchen or not to open? Is it better to put your culinary talents (and your dirty pots, alas) on display for all to see, or is it better to direct your guests to a separate dining room where -- ta-da! -- dinner appears on the table is if by magic? That is the question, although not for me. I have a galley kitchen -- which is by definition open to almost no one -- and when my guests come to dinner, they cluster in the foyer and talk to me while I cook. That is, they talk to my back, and I toss replies over my shoulder. If even one person sidles in to ''help,'' gridlock ensues, and I have to clear the area. But it's better than having my guests huddle in the living room while I miss out on the conversational fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABB, ELAINE (NEE LOEWENTHAL)
description: RABB--Elaine (nee Loewenthal), 76. Wife of the late Irving L. Died in her home September 26. Pre-deceased by son Steven L. and survived by daughter Jo Lee Beaty of Gainsville, Fl and sons David L. of Lone Tree, Co and James L. of Aurora, Il. A memorial celebration is planned in Pompano Beach, Fl February 16, 2004.

title: Not All Teenagers Are Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: The Democrats And Electability
description: To the Editor:

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; MATRIX, THIRD TIME UP
description: The immensely successful Matrix trilogy, written and directed by the brothers Andy and Larry Wachowski, comes to a climax this Wednesday with the release of the final chapter, ''The Matrix Revolutions.'' It's been just a few months since part two, ''The Matrix Reloaded,'' took in some $281 million at the domestic box office, making it the third-highest grossing film of 2003. With the passionate interest fans bring to the Wachowskis' blend of philosophical speculation (the premise: we're all really living in an artificial environment, generated by evil computers) and slam-bang, high-tech action, the concluding installment stands to take in even more. Dave Kehr

title: The Sobering Life of Robert Downey Jr.
description: Robert Downey Jr.'s very public struggle with addiction continues to illustrate the discrimination that less visible people with this chronic illness face on a daily basis (Mim Udovitch, Oct. 19). He can't get work on the new Woody Allen film because it costs too much to insure people with a medical history of addiction, even if they are in recovery. Yet research indicates that the structure and support provided by employment can actually improve treatment outcomes.

title: Diagnosis
description: What part of ''no'' do Lisa Sanders and her colleagues not understand? She seems baffled that a reasonable person might have a legitimate, perhaps better, idea of how she wants to live or end her life than doctors do.

title: The Sobering Life of Robert Downey Jr.
description: Your writer cites, as evidence of Downey's sincerity regarding rehabilitation, his ability to recite two paragraphs by memory from the Alcoholics Anonymous manual, ''something that no one who was just going through the motions could do.'' No one except perhaps a trained professional actor who regularly memorizes reams of dialogue; for an actor, tossing off a couple of paragraphs would be nothing more than a clever parlor trick.

title: Retrofeminist of the Night
description: 'Hi!'

title: The Week in the News: Oct. 26-Nov. 1
description: THE WORLD IS MORE FREE AND MORE PEACEFUL' President BUsh's Rose Garden news conference last Tuesday was so hastily arranged that there was no time for the elegantly printed seat assignments that White House aides usually place on each chair. Instead, someone had unceremoniously scrawled out ABC, NBC and the like on the back of index cards.

title: Graffiti Springing Up On Highway Bridges
description: The Merritt Parkway is famous for its bridges, works of art by George Dunkelberger, a highway architect for the state in the 1930's. What the highway hasn't been known for is graffiti.

title: Randolph Awaits Call on New Yanks Job
description: Willie Randolph is patiently waiting to have a conversation with Manager Joe Torre, a talk that is expected to lead to Randolph, the longtime Yankees third-base coach, being named the team's new bench coach. Torre called Randolph yesterday or Friday, and a person in the discussions about the coaching staff said it was to offer him the chance to succeed Don Zimmer.

title: More Than a Rivalry, an Opportunity
description: Wellington Mara and Woody Johnson were cooped up in a ballroom in downtown Chicago last week, a time zone from the football teams they own and love. It was a business trip, a time to count votes and eat steak at the N.F.L. owners meetings, but each man spent part of it wondering about his less-than-perfect possession.

title: Pack Rats In Our Midst
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigating 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Prices May Be a Better Barometer for Stocks
description: OVER the last 30 years, stock investors could have beaten a buy-and-hold strategy by following a simple market-timing model based on the price of oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AERENSON, MARJORIE
description: AERENSON -- Marjorie, 81, died October 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Bob. Cherished mother of Carol Lucy. Devoted sister to Helen Gurwitt Saltzman, Reis Gurwitt (Lenore) and the late Laurel Gurwitt Chaback. Also survived by Dorothy Rosenberg, Annette and Lee Aerenson, many nieces, nephews, great nieces, great nephews, cousins and friends. Dedicated volunteer and advocate for justice. She will be greatly missed.

title: MONEY POURS IN
description: In the last days before the elections coming on Tuesday, state legislative races were drawing contributions at a record pace, most aimed at giving Democrats control of the evenly divided State Senate. The 120 candidates for Senate and Assembly seats had received a total of $34.7 million as of Oct. 24 and Democrats had raised $3 for every $2 given to Republican candidates, according to reports by the State Election Law Enforcement Commission. Laura Mansnerus

title: The Democrats And Electability
description: To the Editor:

title: The Producers'; The Case Of The Shrinking Blockbuster
description: ON April 19, 2001, at the St. James Theater, everybody who was anybody thought they were witnessing the birth of the next great long-running, crowd-pleasing, bona fide Broadway blockbuster.

title: With a New Stage, Night Life Beckons in White Plains
description: THE White Plains Performing Arts Center is ready for its close-up. Next Saturday the city will throw off its nightly veil and welcome ticket buyers to a new $3.5 million theater, the symbol of a long-anticipated cultural renaissance at the intersection of Mamaroneck Avenue and Main Street.

title: Dorothy Farnan Dies at 84; Author of 'Auden in Love'
description: Dorothy J. Farnan, a high school English teacher whose friendship with the poet W. H. Auden and his companion, Chester Kallman, enabled her to write ''Auden in Love,'' a book about their life together, died on Oct. 23 in her Manhattan apartment. She was 84.

title: I'm Not Darrin
description: I WAS always fascinated by the tube.

title: Anne Kohler, Drew Yurasek
description: Anne Elizabeth Kohler, the daughter of Jane Arsenault of Lincoln, R.I., and Marc Kohler of Cranston, R.I., was married yesterday to Andrew Nicholas Yurasek, the son of Gerry and Andrew M. Yurasek of Jackson, N.J. The Rev. Barry Fleet, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Channing Memorial Church in Newport, R.I.

title: China's Factories Aim to Fill Garages Around the World
description: China, long a nation of pedestrians, cyclists and buses, is undergoing an automobile revolution. Sales of cars, vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles here overtook similar sales in Germany this year, and production surpassed South Korea's.

title: The Nation: Guru Nation; Every Recession and Every Recovery Has a Nostradamus
description: SIGNS of economic spring are all around: stocks are up, profits are surging and companies might even be hiring again.

title: Diagnosis
description: Sometimes we can't come up with a diagnosis despite our best efforts. Or there is no effective treatment for a serious disease. But the most frustrating and challenging situation is the enigmatic patient presented in Sanders's article. The diagnosis is established, a reasonable treatment is at hand and the patient thanks us for our efforts but declines to proceed and drops out of sight. These patients can't be stereotyped by class, sex, income, I.Q., ethnicity, education or any other parameter. They appear out of thin air and disappear just as quickly into the night. They remain enigmas.

title: G.I.'s Double Life in Iraq: Win Friends, Fight Foes
description: In one 24-hour stretch, America's successes and difficulties in this country showed themselves in the figure of Lt. Col. Nate Sassaman.

title: Quadriplegic Historian's Life of the Mind
description: ''SCHOLARSHIP is a lifesaver for me,'' George Jackson said, the air gushing audibly in and out of a ventilator with each breath he took. ''It is a therapy. It keeps my mind going. It keeps me active.''

title: Jana Gold, Richard Kleiman
description: Jana Ilyse Gold and Richard Adam Kleiman were married last evening by Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, PATRICIA F.
description: LEWIS--Patricia F. Suddenly on October 30, 2003. Beloved sister of Dixie. Loving aunt of Leigh. Cherished great-aunt of Abigail and Travis. Devoted friend and mentor to many. A passionate lover of opera and music. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, NYC, on Wednesday 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Thursday 10AM, St. Francis of Assisi Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West 31st Street, NYC 10001.

title: Motorist Breaches Cordon of Security Around President
description: A woman sped a car past a security cordon and, with police chasing her, crashed into the side of a building close to where President Bush had just entered his armored limousine after a speech here on Saturday. Mr. Bush was not hurt, officials said, and his motorcade roared away minutes later.

title: Sports of The Times; A Managerial Memo To Boston: Think Old
description: IN the hours before the Florida Marlins completed their World Series conquest of the Yankees, their manager, 72-year-old Jack McKeon, chuckled as he recalled a casual conversation with the Marlins' owner, Jeffrey Loria, in May.

title: On This Ordinary Block in Brooklyn, The Kurds Are Always in the News
description: In her floor-length striped dress with puffed sleeves, Vera Beaudin Saeedpour seems to belong to a place and time far from today's Brooklyn.

title: A Guru's Advice, In Technicolor
description: TWENTY-ONE years ago, Thomas J. Peters was a little-known consultant at McKinsey & Company with some unconventional ideas about how corporate management should operate. Make what customers want to buy, not what you manufacture best? Heresy. Fraternize with your company's hoi polloi? Unthinkable. Recognize that corporate loyalty is an archaic concept? Nonsense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRUSIN, PAT (NEE FUERST)
description: DRUSIN--Pat (nee Fuerst), peacefully on October 25th. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Harris Drusin and Julie Fidelman. Loving grandmother, mother-in-law, sister and aunt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, STEVEN. ''HOFF.''
description: HOFFMAN--Steven. ''Hoff.'' Never too old to rock-n-roll, but way too young to die. You'll always be with us Doodle. Goodbye, old friend. Scott, Hillary, Remi & Blake Assael

title: Academic Stars: Worth the Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Ogger, Jean-Gabriel Neukomm
description: Dr. Sara Jean Ogger, the grants officer for the New York Council for the Humanities, a private nonprofit organization, in Manhattan, and Jean-Gabriel Neukomm, a Manhattan architect, were married yesterday at Sanctuary Cove, a retreat in Tucson. The Rev. Edward D. Canett, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

title: Looks Are Only Plastic-Deep
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Press Wars in Baghdad; If the News Turns Bad, the Messenger Takes a Hit
description: ''I HAVE come to hate the media,'' a senior aide to L. Paul Bremer III, the head of the occupational authority in Iraq, wrote in a recent e-mail message to family and friends. ''I have worked in politics for a while and I have always, ALWAYS given them the benefit of the doubt. But, I simply cannot continue to sit here and say, 'Oh well, they will turn around eventually and get the story straight.' ''

title: The Diamond Mine May Not Be Forever, but It's a Start
description: As a young man, Willem Hans spent years clocking in miners as they arrived to dig and sift for diamonds at the Alexkor mine, a state-owned colossus on a plot of Atlantic coastline 10 times the size of Manhattan.

title: School Board Candidate Making a Historical Run
description: Laurie Meotti's candidacy for a spot on the Board of Education in Hebron is making state history, but the single mother of two children said her motivation to run for office was simply a desire to be an advocate for all the local students.

title: Misleading Prices
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Airlines Warned Not to Hide Charges'' (Correspondent's Report, Oct. 19): Glad to hear that the Transportation Department is paying attention to misleading pricing tactics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARKMAN, HERBERT B.
description: STARKMAN--Herbert B., 88, of North Miami, FL, on October 30th. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Jeffrey, Steven, James and Valerie. Dear brother of the Hon. Charles B. Starkman and Rosalind Kahn and brother-in-law of Rosemary Starkman and Walter Kahn. Loving uncle and great-uncle. Herbert was the epitome of selflessness, generosity and humor. He served in the U.S. Army 57th Signal Battalion WWII for five years. Decorated Soldier's Medal, Purple Heart, Bronze and Silver Stars for bravery. Honored by ''Crime Watch,'' Miami. Graveside service Monday, November 3, at 1 PM, Beth-El Cemetery, Oradell, NJ.

title: War Studies
description: THE IRAQ WAR

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: FORTY years ago this month, a widely anticipated comedy reached the screen whose title was as formidable as its cast list: IT'S A MAD, MAD, MAD, MAD WORLD (1963). The director, Stanley Kramer, had assembled so many stars that, in the uncut version, it took more than three hours to cram them all in. Jimmy Durante crashes his car along a California road and, before he dies, tells the good Samaritans who come to his aid that a cache of money is buried ''under a big W.'' By today's standards the loot -- $350,000 -- wouldn't make a decent lottery jackpot, but it's enough to set off a mad scramble, with Milton Berle, Buddy Hackett, Ethel Merman, Mickey Rooney and Sid Caesar among those in the hunt. Spencer Tracy, playing a police captain, keeps tabs on them all. The humor may have the sophistication of a Catskills routine (Durante's death is conveyed by a shot of his foot kicking over a bucket), but the old pros play it with an admirable ease -- Friday at 8 p.m. on TCM.

title: Brother-in-Law's Keeper?
description: My feckless brother-in-law spent the past few years engaged in little, and thus has few financial resources. We've refused to lend him money, hoping he'd take some responsibility by finding a job. He recently found out he has cancer; he may live six months or six years. We provide comfort and friendship, but must we offer cash or a place in our home? Given his unruly personality, he'd almost certainly unravel our peace and enjoyment. Anonymous

title: That Silence You Hear Is Chatter About an Arena
description: Mayor Sharpe James, known for his enthusiastic even hyperbolic -- cheerleading when it comes to revitalization efforts in Newark, was at it again this past week. Sort of.

title: Overblown Tax-Credit Tip Brings Lines and Competitors
description: Before the fliers, before the television news story, before a line of hundreds of people materialized and snaked down the block and around the corner, Holy Trinity Beauty Supply Store in Brooklyn was a simple place that sold wigs and makeup.

title: Academic Stars: Worth the Price?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Media Thing
description: AUTUMN OF THE MOGULS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HELD, MARTIN ''ADAM''
description: HELD--Martin ''Adam'' 11/02/ 02. A truly selfless friend who will always be remembered and missed. Bob and Deco

title: Turning Over the Death Card
description: THREE WEEKS IN OCTOBER

description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQ, 6 MONTHS LATER
description: SOLDIERS' SPLIT LIVES -- A half year after President Bush declared major hostilities over in Iraq, soldiers' efforts at democracy building are clashing with tasks like house raids. PAGE 13

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: JUDGMENT RIDGE.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DRAYER, DORIS
description: DRAYER--Doris. My darling Doris, October 31st will be four years since you left. You are never out of my thoughts and will forever be in my memories. Sleep well, my darling. Sonny, Michelle, Joe, Emily, Billy and Caroline

title: Creatures Of Mystery, Some Friendly, Some Not
description: CENTAURS, satyrs, sirens, sphinxes and other fabulous creatures have long been in evidence in the arts of the Mediterranean, Egypt and the Near East. But it was in Greek art of the eighth to the fifth centuries B.C. that we find an unprecedented fascination for such composite beings, says J. Michael Padgett, curator of ''The Centaur's Smile: The Human Animal in Early Greek Art,'' at the Princeton University Art Museum.

title: The Woods Are Full of Them
description: OUR LADY OF THE FOREST

title: The Way the Crow Flies
description: The sun came out after the war and our world went Technicolor. Everyone had the same idea. Let's get married. Let's have kids. Let's be the ones who do it right.

title: Ned Rorem; The Flying Nun; Eileen Atkins; Iraq and Vietnam
description: NED ROREM

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday listing scores for the state's eighth-grade math test omitted those from the Port Chester district. Of 225 students tested, 1.8 percent ranked in Level 1 (the lowest), 7.6 percent in Level 2, 60.4 percent in Level 3, and 30.2 percent in Level 4. The district had a 25-point increase over last year in the number of students meeting at least Level 3. A total of 90.6 percent of the students met standards by reaching Level 3 or Level 4.

title: Fast Food
description: Time may be of the essence, but when you're giving a dinner party, it's not necessarily essential. There is no direct correlation between the time invested in preparations and the success of the evening. In fact, often the reverse is true -- a mere 15 minutes is all it can take to whip up a fabulous party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRURY, PETER ARTHUR III.
description: DRURY--Peter Arthur III. October 25, 2003 in Charleston, SC. Much loved husband of Leila Dryden Drury and father of Robert, Margaret, Deborah and Brean Drury.

title: FOR DEMOCRATS, ECONOMY'S SURGE POSES CHALLENGE
description: For more than two years now, the Democrats seeking the presidency have planned on running a 2004 campaign built around the weak economy and patterned after Bill Clinton's 1992 defeat of President Bush's father.

title: State Building Is Named In Perry Duryea's Honor
description: Perry B. Duryea Jr., the former State Assembly speaker and onetime gubernatorial candidate from Montauk, was praised for his nearly two decades of public service at a ceremony dedicating the Perry B. Duryea Jr. State Office Building in Hauppauge last week.

title: Goodbye, Neo. Hello, Captain Crowe.
description: November

title: The Fine Art of Selling Movies, Italian Style
description: IT'S young Marlon Brando, the Godfather's glower already in place and driblets of blood striping his forehead. He's walking grimly toward the viewer with his arms at his side, his right hand gripping a pistol, his left tensed and grasping at nothing. Slashing diagonally across his body: a monstrous, bloodstained meat hook.

title: The Nation: Sentence Revision; States Seek Ways to Make Executions Error Free
description: GOV. MITT ROMNEY of Massachusetts does not just want a death penalty for his state. He wants an airtight, scientifically unassailable death penalty, one that is all that a death penalty can be.

title: Thanks for Nothing
description: Rewatching ''The Myth of Fingerprints,'' Bart Freundlich's grimly witty 1997 account of a young man's wary return to his WASP family's Thanksgiving, I looked forward to the screaming tantrum thrown by the older sister (Julianne Moore) at dinner. When that didn't happen, I realized I'd confused Ms. Moore's sharp-tongued character with a loudly aggrieved cousin of mine, about whom the less said the better. Happy family holidays may be all alike, but the unhappy ones have a familiar ring as well.

title: The Last Word in Alienation: I Just Don't Remember
description: EVER since Christopher Nolan's tricky rewind-button thriller, ''Memento,'' impressed audiences and (too many) critics a couple of years ago, amnesia has, improbably, emerged as the movies' psychological disorder of choice, eclipsing even the Oscar-winning schizophrenia of ''A Beautiful Mind.'' The amnesia craze has already produced a pair of oddball classics, David Lynch's ''Mulholland Drive'' (2001) and Aki Kaurismaki's ''Man Without a Past'' (2002), as well as a sleek, skillful suspense picture, Doug Liman's ''Bourne Identity,'' which was one of the surprise hits of 2002. In the coming weeks we're in for a full-blown epidemic: Halle Berry will be losing her memory in ''Gothika''; Ben Affleck his in ''Paycheck.'' (Insert your own ''Gigli'' joke here.) In March, Jim Carrey will be similarly afflicted in ''Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.'' And shooting has begun on a remake of John Frankenheimer's ''Manchurian Candidate'' (1962), a political thriller about brainwashing, which is, in its way, the greatest amnesia movie of them all.

title: Q and/A
description: Visiting Darwin's House

title: INVESTING WITH: Robert N. Gensler; T. Rowe Price Media and Telecommunications Fund
description: INVESTORS in media and telecommunications stocks have particular need to think globally, said Robert N. Gensler, manager of the $606 million T. Rowe Price Media and Telecommunications fund.

title: Reality Television Vs. Real Careers
description: IT'S a shame that reality television as we know it didn't exist when I was getting my start as a journalist in the early 1990's.

title: They Love the Lost and Forgotten Melodies
description: IN the 1960's, the world rediscovered the music of the 17th and 18th centuries. At that time, to enjoy this kind of music was to be in the vanguard of musical taste. So-called early music, or period instrument, groups sprung up, with musicians resurrecting forgotten Baroque repertory and bringing them to a wider audience.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; RETAIL'S NEXT BIG THING?
description: Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, will summon its biggest suppliers to its headquarters in Springdale, Ark., on Tuesday to discuss applying the latest in tracking technology, known as RFID(for radio-frequency identification), to packaged foods, beauty products, clothing, sporting goods and other products. The identification tags transmit a digital response when contacted by radio signals from scanning devices.

title: Corrections
description: An essay on Page 1 of Arts & Leisure today about depictions of journalists in movies and on television misstates a traditional term for the press in some copies. It is the fourth estate, not the third.

title: Fierce Fighting and a Kidnapping in Afghanistan
description: Fierce bouts of factional fighting erupted on Friday across Afghanistan, and a Turkish road engineer was reported kidnapped by suspected Taliban fighters, officials said Saturday.

title: For Once, No Letup In Islanders
description: The Islanders turned in one of their maddeningly precise games Saturday against the Anaheim Mighty Ducks, the kind that might compel observers to ask, Why can't these guys do this more often?

title: Personal Business; Little Banks Learn to Compete With Merger Mania
description: THREE years ago, BankAtlantic, a community bank based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., declared its own war of sorts against the big-bank competitors that were swallowing up neighborhood banks throughout its home state.

title: Retracing Their Words
description: One by one, the New York Police Department officers were called to the witness stand by lawyers who said that four officers had shot a man to death unnecessarily. It was no surprise, then, when each of the witnesses said that the shooting, of a troubled man with a hammer, had been justified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUHR, ABRAHAM
description: FUHR--Abraham. Suddenly on October 27, 2003, of Long Beach and Newburgh, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Sheila. Loving father of Edward and Lois, Randi and Paul. Devoted brother and uncle. Adoring grandfather of Reid, Spencer, Sarah and Benjamin. Cherished friend of Janine. He was a gentle and generous man who will be greatly missed by all the people who knew him.

title: Forget Jet Lag: A SuperSonic Relishes Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 1  Months before he made the 5,000-mile trek to Japan, Seattle SuperSonics forward Rashard Lewis had high expectations about playing here.

title: The Day the Firemen Went on Strike
description: AT an early morning fire in a Jamaica, Queens, furniture store, a Fire Department lieutenant runs straight to a telephone booth to call for permission to fight the blaze. Civilians try to put it out, but they have no protective gear. A union official arrives and orders everyone away, while firefighters, dressed in street clothes and bright stocking caps, stand idly by and shout taunts. ''These stupid firemen, they're arguing with each other while this building burns to the ground,'' a bystander says.

title: The Know-It-All
description: We all want and need obsessives from time to time. There is no such thing as ''too much'' expertise when it comes to navigating your sinuses, preparing your income taxes or repairing your car, and I, for one, hope scholarly works on these subjects continue unabated for as long as my obsessives in those areas need them.

title: Page Two: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; A Space Shuttle Rescue, After the Fact
description: IT would have looked a lot like something from a science fiction movie, but there could have been a rescue option for the space shuttle Columbia, which broke apart on Feb. 1, according to a report released last week by the Columbia Accident Investigation Board.

title: Coney Island Brings Forth a Basketball Star. Again.
description: IT was early October. As Sebastian Telfair, better known as Bassy, dribbled a basketball and smiled for the camera, a small crowd gathered to watch. One of the onlookers on this corner in Coney Island, a middle-aged man with several gold teeth and the unmistakable aroma of liquor, started shouting proudly.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Underground Woman
description: FAMILY CIRCLE

title: January
description: Jan. 2

title: Amid Images of Love and Starvation, A More Nuanced Picture Emerges
description: Ever since Raymond and Vanessa Jackson were arrested on Oct. 24 on charges that they were starving their four adopted sons, Joyce Brown, a former neighbor, has been racking her brain. ''You try to remember things that were said, things you saw. Did I miss something?'' she asks.

title: Regina Carter Keeps in Touch With a 260-Year-Old Friend
description: REGINA CARTER has been cheating on her regular violin. So far, she's had two flings with another, older instrument, and she'll be having a third tomorrow night at Alice Tully Hall -- in public, no less. You can't exactly blame her for being disloyal, though. The instrument in question, known to connoisseurs as ''Il Cannone'' (''The Cannon'') because of its big, booming tone, is a priceless 1743 Guarneri belonging to the city of Genoa, Italy, to which it was bequeathed in 1840 by Nicol Paganini, the greatest violin virtuoso in history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, HARRIET G.
description: COHEN--Harriet G. 11/3/83. In cherished loving memory of our dearly beloved mother and grandmother. Always in our hearts. Sadly missed. Richard, Hope, and daughters Lindsey, Ashley and sister-inlaw Lucille

title: Saving Seeds Subjects Farmers to Suits Over Patent
description: Homan McFarling has been farming here all his life, growing mostly soybeans along with a little corn. After each harvest, he puts some seed aside.

title: Online Agencies as Ombudsmen
description: Online travel agencies are no slouches when it comes to customer service. According to the American Customer Satisfaction Index, Web sites like Expedia, Travelocity, Orbitz and others rated 77 out of 100 for the last quarter of 2002, the most recent date this group was rated. That score is higher than many other industries, including banking and retail, and is considerably higher than two industries the e-travel agents serve -- hotels and airlines.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Schwab Thinking Small in Subleasing in Jersey City
description: CHARLES SCHWAB & COMPANY made the decision before the gleaming glass 19-story, 577,000-square-foot office tower built to its specifications on Jersey City's waterfront was even complete: go to Plan B.

title: A Cable Network of Their Own
description: TWENTY-FOUR years ago, ESPN proved that dedicated sports fans would lap up enough games, races, rehash and chatter to fill 24 hours of air time, seven days a week. In the process, it led hordes of sports fans to subscribe to cable for the first time. And by using its growing war chest from subscriber fees to bid against the major networks, ESPN also helped drive up the cost of sports broadcast rights.

title: No Lad Is an Island
description: THE CALLIGRAPHER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALL, BRUCE EDWARD
description: HALL--Bruce Edward. October 31 in Manhattan. Actor, writer, raconteur, Episcopalian. Beloved son of Jane Ann and Herbert of Vero Beach, FL, brother of Amy of Ossining, NY, Judy of Gloucester, MA, and Stephen of Voorhees, NJ. Leaves his dear Andy and countless friends. Service at St. Bartholomew's, Thursday, 4:30 PM. Donations to the Actors Fund, ''Aurora AIDS Initiative,'' 729 7th Ave, NYC, 10019.

title: Elroy Nights
description: Clare and I had been having some disagreements, some differences of opinion, not a lot, but enough so that things between us were up in the air, and we had talked about separating, the way people will, casually, as if it were a step we might take to sort of improve things, to get some space into the marriage, some room to maneuver. Neither of us had big plans; we'd just gotten to the point where we were wondering how we got where we were, why we stayed. With everything else going on-terrorists, war, guys with nine-year-olds buried in their backyards-our problems seemed slight , even to us. But they were ours, which counted for something. We lived on the water in D'Iberville, Mississippi, and things seemed strained; there wasn't any life and death reason we had to be in the same house, under the same roof.

title: The Nation; Home, Sweet Home: Pursuing Dreams in a Land of Fire
description: IF a Hollywood writer produced a script for California's post-recall apocalypse, it couldn't be any more dramatic.

title: A Teen Drama's True Test? Its Adults
description: This week, ''The O.C.'' returns to Fox in all its soapy glory, and viewers will finally find out what happened to good-girl-gone-bad Marissa after her unfortunate overdose in Tijuana, check in on bad-boy-gone-good Ryan as he smolders his way toward true love and find out whether nerdlinger Seth will ever hook up with bitchy proto-soul-mate Summer. Teen spirit will be stinking the place up once again like patchouli at a Phish concert.

title: Showalter Only Looks As Free Agency Nears
description: Texas Manager Buck Showalter flipped through a list of free agents while sitting at his desk last week, reviewing dozens of players and circling those he thought the Rangers should try to sign. Reluctantly, but not surprisingly, Showalter breezed by the marquee players because their potential price tags would make them difficult fits for a team slashing its payroll.

title: A Family With a Knack For Numbers
description: The thing about a long winning streak is that the anticipation seems to run forever, and those involved don't want to do anything to jinx it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERSTEIN, ETHEL B.
description: SILVERSTEIN -- Ethel B. Professor, New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, LI. Survived by husband Benjamin, children Stephen R. Silverstein and Harriet E. Herman, and grandchildren Lauren, Melissa, Jason and Jennifer. Services were held Friday.

title: Supporters Sell Voters New Library In Ossining
description: THE bright red and green button pinned on Edward M. Falcone's shirt says it all: ''Thank You!!''

title: So Much For 'The Front Page'
description: PITY, though not too deeply, the American press. Once the wisecracking truth seekers of ''The Front Page'' and the brave gumshoes of ''All the President's Men,'' the fourth estate has fallen into such cultural disfavor that it risks being renamed the fifth estate, if not the sixth. Hollywood no longer depicts reporters in ruthless pursuit of criminals, high and low. Now they are the criminals.

title: Doctors: Stop Complaining And Get Back to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Courtney Melaine Baron and Blair Gilbert Singer omitted a last line. The final sentence, referring to the bridegroom's father, Brian Singer of Los Angeles, should have read: ''His father retired as the president of Austin Financial Services in Los Angeles.''

title: In This Clash of Church And State, No One Wins
description: FANATICISM, tyranny, unending religious hatreds -- vestiges of the Dark Ages, which swirl around us in our electronically global world -- come to the Metropolitan Opera stage on Thursday in Fromental Halvy's powerful political opera ''La Juive.''

title: Swezey's Closing: A Blow for Riverhead
description: INSIDE Swezey's department store in Riverhead last weekend, the scene was familiar. Customers strolled along the aisles and chatted with longtime employees at the cash registers. But everything else was different: it was the last Saturday Swezey's would be open for business on Main Street.

title: Page Two: Oct. 26-Nov. 1; ECONOMIC NEWS FOR OPTIMISTS
description: Many economists greeted last week's rosy economic news with a chorus of ''Yes, but . . . ''

title: That's Not All, Folks!
description: JOE DANTE, the director of the rambunctious new live-action/animation blend ''Looney Tunes: Back in Action'' (opening Nov. 14), makes movies in which the real world is curiously flat: a canvas to be doodled on by animators and puppeteers, to be crammed with beasties that pop out of the frame like jack-in-the-boxes. His direction of live action is sometimes droopy, his compositions two-dimensional, his stories mere vessels for riffs, cameos and quotations from other movies. But his curlicues are good enough to goose his films to life. Mr. Dante lives through movies, and his movies live through movies, too: even when his films are assembled out of recycled parts, Mr. Dante's antic disposition and fan-boy dreaminess make them spark.

title: Anger and Garbage Pile Up, and the State Sues a Recycler
description: Life is not always easy when you are a 25-foot-tall mountain of garbage. The neighbors grumble about the stink. Government agencies are always on your back. Other businesses complain about what it is like to work near you, a pile of guttered mattresses, twisted vinyl siding and exploded couches.

title: Lovely Day To Watch (Maybe Not Race)
description: The weather forecast for today says temperatures should be in the 60's, an idyllic day for a Sunday stroll or an autumn picnic or watching the 34th annual New York City Marathon. Whether it will be a day of dreams for the 34,000 or so serious and recreational runners who will try to cover the 26 miles 385 yards through all five boroughs remains to be seen.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: George Gershwin

title: At Putnam, The Buck Stays Put In a Pocket
description: EMBARRASSED by state and federal accusations that fund managers at Putnam Investments used inside information to make almost $1 million, the company has promised to return to investors any gains made improperly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDLOWITZ, MILTON, M.D.
description: MENDLOWITZ--Milton, M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of Dr. Mendlowitz, a world recognized physician, scientist, academician and clinician, who served Mount Sinai and medicine for over 70 years. An international authority on the causes and treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular disease, he served as Chief of Mount Sinai's Hypertension Program from 1950 to 1975. He had profound influence on many generations of physicians and students as he patiently gave his time, intelligence and warmth. In 1965, The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Mendlowitz in acknowledgment of his many contributions as a physician, researcher and teacher and the great distinction he brought to Mount Sinai. He will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. William G. Stein, M.D.--Pres. Barry D. Stimmel, M.D.--V.P. Betty Mintz, M.D.--Treas. Elliot Rayfield, M.D.--Sec'y

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's pretty chilling. It's like our worst nightmare was just proved. This might just be the tip of the iceberg.''

title: Clare Crespo, James Chinlund
description: Clare Katherine Crespo, the daughter of Helaine Tuite Moyse and Michael L. Crespo, both of Baton Rouge, La., was married yesterday to James Caleb Chinlund, a son of Dr. Caroline Cross Chinlund and the Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund of New York. The Rev. Patrick L. Smith, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at a house owned by the bride's family in Slidell, La.

title: Business People; For Auto Executives, Greener Roads After Retirement
description: To the list of auto industry executives who have gone on to smaller things, add Richard O. Schaum's name. Mr. Schaum, who retired in April as executive vice president for product development at Chrysler, has become vice president for vehicle development at WaveCrest Laboratories, a technology start-up that focuses on electric vehicles.

title: The Next Best Thing To Your Own
description: IT'S a loverly thought, but facts are facts. A loaf of bread, a jug of wine and thou just don't cut it in the long haul.

title: Appeals Over Primaries Go Out By Mail, by Phone and on Foot
description: Voters across New York City were bombarded with brochures, phone calls and personal visits yesterday, as the political battle over a proposal to eliminate party primaries from citywide elections escalated in the final weekend before the election.

title: Where Rhythm of Life Is Rocked by Violence
description: Almost every sector of life in Baghdad was off kilter on Saturday, usually a normal business day here, because of anonymous warnings that hospitals, schools and other unspecified sites would be the targets of bombings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BESUNDER, LILLIAN R.
description: BESUNDER--Lillian R. Died October 31. Beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted mother of Jon L. and Rhonda S. Cherished sister of Renee. Funeral services Sunday, November 2nd at the I.J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, N.Y. 800-624-8282

title: Renewal And Resistance
description: ON a recent Thursday afternoon, a handful of diners lingered over elegant dishes of poached salmon and shaved fennel in an airy exposed-brick restaurant called Zuppa. Nearby, the Hudson River lapped serenely at the edge of a new apartment building with a 24-hour health club and a swimming pool.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: It's Hello, Bright Lights, Big Chain, And So Long to a General Store
description: It has all the touches of a rural general store: friendly butchers, chatty cashiers and an old man who keeps customers smiling. For nearly 50 years, Charlie Pastor has run University Food Market (it started as a deli) at 115th Street and Broadway in Morningside Heights.

title: QUICK BITE/Ringoes; Grandma Would Be Proud
description: Mincemeat was always the Thanksgiving pie of choice at our house when I was a child, with pumpkin a distant second. Even back then the spicy-sweet goo had spun off its actual meat component, but apples, raisins, dates and other dense fruits remained, as well as the customary splash of brandy or rum. Since then mincemeat has mostly been relegated to the misty realms of nostalgia. Except at Muirhead of Ringoes, an online ordering service that has bravely added mincemeat -- and one featuring green tomatoes, no less -- to its line of fruit butters, mustards and other condiments.

title: Stacey Weiss, Steven Weiser
description: Dr. Stacey Fran Weiss and Steven Elliot Weiser were married last evening by Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Pills, Potions and a Pandora's Box
description: THE plastic tackle box Bill Romanowski carried by his side for years provided him the defined body of a comic-book soldier, a lure and a hook -- as in everyone was drawn to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, MUSIA
description: ZUCKERMAN -- Musia. Passed away peacefully on October 31. Beloved wife of Martin. Loving mother of David. Devoted daughter of the late Joseph and Lea Dimentstein. Cherished niece of Anna Caitak and Masha Sommer and cousin of Doris Martinazzi. Dedicated psychotherapist. Holocaust survivor. Her gentle ways will be missed. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, 11:45 a.m. Shiva will be observed at the Zuckerman residence.

title: Ruling Strikes Transfer Tax From Brookhaven Ballot
description: The Appellate Division of state Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled on Wednesday that a proposition asking Brookhaven Town residents to approve a 2 percent real estate transfer tax was misleadingly worded and must come off Tuesday's town ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUSZECKI, FANNY
description: GRUSZECKI -- Fanny. We have loving thoughts of a fine lady who was so a part of our family. May her memory bring you peace and help you through this time. All of our love -Barbara, Orin, Liz, Rob Jordan and Paula

title: Seafood With a Waterfront View
description: ON my first visit to F.I.S.H., an enormously popular waterfront restaurant on the industrial fringe of this village, I sat on a sunny deck overlooking the narrow Byram River, sipping a glass of chilled Bertani Due Uve. As I watched a great blue heron stalk the far bank, an oyster dredger came chugging up the inlet, its decks piled high with bulging sacks of shellfish. The returning oystermen lent a welcome note of authenticity to the cheerful artifice that is F.I.S.H.

title: Pack Rats In Our Midst
description: To the Editor:

title: The Professorial Provocateur
description: Q: Your new book on American foreign policy, ''Hegemony or Survival: America's Quest for Global Dominance,'' includes a blurb on the jacket that calls you ''arguably the most important intellectual alive.''

title: Europe and U.S. at Odds On Airlines and Privacy
description: TWO years after Congress passed the Aviation and Security Act of 2001, requiring airlines to collect information on their passengers so that Customs officials could check for security threats, Europe is objecting that the amount and the kind of information its airlines are required to supply violate European privacy laws. The trans-Atlantic differences have put Europe's airlines in a bind. If they comply with American requirements, they violate European law; if they don't, they may be penalized by the United States.

title: The Political Big-Game Hunt
description: One way for a lawmaker to unwind from the heavy lifting in Congress is to open a hunting club for selected friends and lobbyists. Representative Billy Tauzin, the chairman of the House energy committee who boasts a dozen trophy deer heads in his office, found the 200-acre duck preserve he opened six years ago on the Maryland shore a rewarding Shangri-La for Capitol buddies and insiders. So the Louisiana Republican is about to open a second private club for even-bigger-game-minded friends and lobbyists on 1,500 acres in south Texas.

title: The Last Resort
description: LOVE

title: Did the Tax Cut Help the Economy?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Faces of Nicole Kidman
description: Nicole Kidman in some of her most remarkable roles.

title: New York City Marathon
description: Kenyans Margaret Okayo and Martin Lel won the elite divisions of the 34th New York City Marathon.

title: Displaced by the Fires
description: A giant, drafty airplane hangar at the San Bernardino Airport in California has turned into a small, chaotic city of the displaced.

title: Almost-Chief of Boston U. Planned a Purge, Some Say
description: Daniel S. Goldin, the former NASA administrator who agreed to walk away from the presidency of Boston University the day before he was to take over, had made it clear in recent weeks that he intended to dismantle the university's leadership. He told officials and trustees he planned to replace many longtime deans and administrators, a top university official said.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Knicks Are Staying Focused Despite Their Slow Start
description: The Knicks let the first game slip through their fingers and into Tracy McGrady's hands at home last Wednesday. They never had a grasp on their second game Saturday night in San Antonio.

title: A Film Dispute Becomes Melodrama
description: The packages traditionally start arriving in November, originating in the marketing and publicity departments of major studios and tiny independent distributors alike. Some contain a single videotape in a generic black plastic case; others a boxed set of shrink-wrapped DVD's in a handsome slipcover adorned with a familiar corporate logo. These discs and tapes are rarely packaged with tantalizing stills or breathless blurbs, like the ones at the video store. Instead, they bear the decorous phrase ''for your consideration'' and a list of the artists -- the stars, the director, the costume designer, the sound editor -- whose work you are invited to consider.

title: People
description: Hollis Rafkin-Sax was named vice chairwoman for United States operations at the New York office of Financial Dynamics. She had been global head for financial communications at Edelman, New York, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc.

title: Time to Stand Pat for an American Who Leads European Broadcaster
description: For years, Harry Evans Sloan was known as an empire builder. These days, Mr. Sloan, 53, an American who is the executive chairman of the European television and radio company SBS Broadcasting, spends more time taming his conquered territories.

title: Baden-Baden Journal; Spoiled Russians. A New Belle poque?
description: Who was the man hanging around the roulette table in the casino in this historic hot-springs resort? He had a black shirt, tie and jacket over black jeans and a two-day stubble, like some of his companions. He looked like a member of the Russian mafia.

title: African Anglicans Vent Anger at Gay Bishop
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 3  Africa's Anglican leaders expressed fury today at the consecration over the weekend of a gay bishop in New Hampshire, renewing their intention to break from the American church and opening up a deep ideological fault line that criss-crossed the world.

title: Russia Is Mostly Unmoved by the Troubles of Its Tycoons
description: In this cinder-block town just outside Moscow, people do not have much sympathy for the jailed oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, and care little about the freezing of shares in his company or the turmoil that has convulsed Russia's financial markets for the past week. They have more pressing concerns, like the sidewalks. Or more precisely, the lack of them.

title: Driver Arrested at Bush Speech Was Under Stress, Friends Say
description: The last time Ann Robison heard from her daughter-in-law, Betina Mixon, Ms. Mixon sounded exhausted from two nights without sleep and deeply troubled over many things -- her brother's hospitalization, her husband's being out of work, her father's death.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about plans by Levi Strauss to stop making blue jeans in San Antonio misstated the location of the original plant. It was on Valencia Street in San Francisco, not in Valencia, Calif.

title: Paying for Superfund
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City's Streets Belong to Kenya
description: Martin Lel and Rodgers Rop are good friends. Lel, 24, and Rop, 27, have trained together in their native Kenya. Lel has won his last three half-marathons, the most recent at the world championships a month ago in Portugal. Rop won the New York City Marathon last November and the Boston Marathon in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHAIKEN, HARRIET HONEY (NEE GOLDMAN)
description: CHAIKEN -- Harriet Honey (nee Goldman). 84, of Columbia, MD, on Thursday, October 30, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Chaiken. Loving mother to Shelly Chaiken, New York, NY, Dr. Marc Chaiken and his wife Bunny, Columbia, MD, and loving grandmother to Jeff, David, Zach and Ben Chaiken. A New York City native, she graduated from Hunter College, NY, in 1939. She spent the next 64 years in Silver Spring, MD, where she was a homemaker, worked for the U.S. government during WWII, and also as a substitute teacher for Prince Georges County. Burial will be private in the King David Memorial Gardens, Falls Church, VA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Howard Hospital Foundation, Attn: Obstetrical Department, 5755 Cedar Lane, Columbia, MD 21044. For information, contact the Witzke Funeral Homes, Inc., of Columbia; 410-992-0680.

title: Congress Approves $87.5 Billion Aid Package for War Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  The Senate today approved an $87.5 billion package for the military and reconstruction campaigns in Iraq and Afghanistan, one day after an attack on an Army helicopter in Iraq left 16 American soldiers dead.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
A Jam Band in an Arena, Cognizant of Geography
description: In an improbable punk-rock tribute, Widespread Panic knocked out three Ramones songs at Madison Square Garden on Friday, its first of two nights there. No matter that the Ramones' pithy songs arose as a reaction to the kind of leisurely jamming that has made Widespread Panic a touring phenomenon since the mid-1980's. As it claimed its arena-size audience in New York, Widespread Panic played New York rock: the Ramones' ''Pet Sematary,'' ''Beat on the Brat'' and ''I Wanna Be Sedated,'' Lou Reed's ''Vicious'' and Talking Heads' ''Life During Wartime.'' John Bell, the band's lead singer and rhythm guitarist, was costumed for Halloween as the Statue of Liberty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, J. B.
description: BROWN--J. B. Of Darien, CT, passed away unexpectedly on November 1, 2003, in Darien, CT. Born May 12, 1966, in Birmingham, MI, he was the son of Vern Brown and Sheila Henderson Brown of Wilmington, NC. Mr. Brown was a principal partner of Hynes, Himmelreich, Glennon & Company of Darien. J.B. was an active member of the Darien Fire Department and will receive the 2003 Rookie of the Year Award posthumously. He was also active with Big Brothers/Big Sisters of America and was a coach for Darien Junior Flag Football. He is survived by his wife, Megan Axthelm Brown of Darien, and his two children, Matthew and Mary. He is also survived by his sister Heather Brown of Wilmington, NC, and his mother-in-law Jill Axthelm of New York City. Friends may call at the Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT, on Tuesday, November 4, 2003, from 5:00 to 9:00 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 374 Middlesex Road, Darien, on Wednesday, November 5, 2003, at 10 AM. Interment is private. Memorial donations may be sent to the Matthew and Mary Brown College Education Fund, c/o Hynes, Himmelreich, Glennon & Company, 30 Old Kings Highway South, P.O. Box 4004, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Attack on U.S. Copter Highlights a Constant Threat Faced by Aircraft in Iraq
description: It is not yet known at what altitude or speed the Chinook hit on Sunday in Iraq was flying, but guerrillas are known to have launched missiles at American planes two or three times a week, and ground fire at helicopters even more often.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Arrested In Stabbing
description: A 15-year-old boy from Queens has been arrested in the stabbing of a 24-year-old man who was attacked on Friday night after he confronted a group of teenagers who his fiance said had pelted his family with eggs. The police said Ajai Jagernauth, 15, of Queens, was arrested on Saturday on charges of attempted murder and assault; he was charged as a juvenile. The victim, Ricky Hosein of Queens, and his family were walking home about 8:30 p.m. Friday when a group of teenagers began throwing eggs at them, said Mr. Hosein's fiance, Adelia Gutierriz, 26. When Mr. Hosein confronted the teenagers, they attacked him, stabbing him in the back, Ms. Gutierriz said. Mr. Hosein remained in the intensive care unit at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
For a Pianist, A Reunion Of Right And Left
description: What speaks to us more movingly than tales of siblings separated in youth and reunited in old age? Rediscovery can be by sheer accident or it can come from investigation and hard work. The idea of lost and found gave Leon Fleisher's piano recital at Carnegie Hall on Friday a ceremonial air, for here was his left hand coming together with a long estranged blood relative: his right.

title: Mars Unit Looks To Merge Marketing
description: The Masterfoods USA division of Mars Inc. is considering consolidating some or all of its media planning and buying assignments, which have combined billings estimated at $350 million and are divided among five agencies.

title: Study Finds That Nitrites in the Body Greatly Aid Blood Flow
description: A common compound in the body previously believed to have no major function has been found to greatly increase blood flow, indicating it has potential as a treatment for illnesses like heart and blood vessel disease and sickle cell anemia, researchers reported on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARKMAN, HERBERT B.
description: STARKMAN--Herbert B. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Loving father, brother, uncle, great-uncle, grandfather and cousin. Graveside service today, 1 PM, Beth-El Cemetery

title: Freeney's Clutch Hit in the Fourth Quarter Sacks Miami
description: COLTS 23, DOLPHINS 17

title: Improving Safety Inside the Honda (and Outside
description: Add safety to the list of attributes that Honda will use to attract future customers.

title: OPENLY GAY MAN IS MADE A BISHOP
description: With the ceremonial laying on of hands by a cluster of bishops, the Rev. V. Gene Robinson was consecrated the next bishop of New Hampshire and the first openly gay prelate in the Episcopal Church U.S.A. on Sunday, laying the groundwork for a split in the American church and a break with fellow Anglican churches abroad.

title: By Pushing Redskins Around, Cowboys Show Who's for Real
description: While Washington Redskins Coach Steve Spurrier was bent over, hands on knees and obviously exasperated, his second-year quarterback was having his left hand examined by trainers after another pummeling. The National Football League is not cooperating with the Redskins' $5 million-a-year coach and his quarterback-propelled offense, and it is beginning to look ugly.

title: Lottery Numbers
Strong Funds' Chairman Resigns His Position
description: Richard S. Strong, the founder of the Strong Mutual Funds, resigned yesterday as chairman of the fund's board of directors, a few days after the New York attorney general said he would take action against Mr. Strong for improper trading of shares.

title: Back to Kabul, With a Queens Accent; Many Immigrants Returning to a Remade Afghanistan, Some to Stay
description: Zikria Nazamy lost almost everything when he fled Afghanistan. Born into a wealthy family with houses in Kabul, Logar, and Kunduz, he left at age 9 with his parents and seven siblings, and spent his adolescent years working the checkout counter in a supermarket in Flushing, Queens.

title: Thomson and TCL in Deal to Form Largest TV Set Maker
description: PARIS, Nov. 3  If you can't beat them, then join them.

title: Religious Leader In Iran Praises Nuclear Pact
description: Iran's supreme religious leader on Sunday lauded the agreement on the country's nuclear program that was reached with the foreign ministers of Germany, Britain and France on Oct. 21 and said it was the right decision.

title: A Writer, Hard-Boiled and Shaped by Murder
description: What good are you to me? The novelist James Ellroy hisses this rebuke, with an expletive thrown in, to the people who loved ''L.A. Confidential,'' the movie, but didn't buy ''L.A. Confidential,'' the book. His book.

title: The Questions on Tomorrow's Ballot
description: New Yorkers will be asked to vote yes or no on five questions on tomorrow's city ballot.

title: Bush Uses Good Economic News for Tax Cut Message
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  President Bush campaigned on the economy and other domestic issues today in Alabama, where he called for permanent tax relief and said the entrepreneurial spirit is "what America's all about."

title: Time to Change Election Rules?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SUBWAY SERVICE RESTORED Subway service on the No. 2 and 3 lines was restored last night after a weekend of disruptions for riders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn that were caused by a track fire in Harlem on Friday. A spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, James Anyansi, said full service resumed on both lines by 9:30 p.m. Crews spent the weekend reinstalling wiring and switches damaged by the fire, at the 110th Street and Lenox Avenue station.

title: The Volatile Notion of a Married Jesus
description: Half a dozen religious leaders joined David Westin, the president of ABC News, and others from the network and the press for lunch on the 22nd floor of ABC building on 66th Street in Manhattan late last week. Mr. Westin wore a sharp suit, as did some members of the clergy; others had dressed casually. Many were diffident. Some were quietly furious.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Jailed Russian Oil Chief Resigns and May Challenge Putin
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3  Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky resigned today as chairman of Russia's richest company, Yukos Oil, even as he defiantly vowed to continue a public  and possibly a political  campaign "to build an open and truly democratic society in Russia."

title: Ambiguous Relationships, Distilled by Israeli Choreographers
description: People kept moving through emotional storms in ''Yossi, Shlomi and Emanuel . . . Three Israeli Choreographers,'' a program presented Saturday night in the Victoria Theater of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here. It featured works to taped musical collages by Yossi Yungman, Shlomi Bitton and Emanuel Gat, three young Israeli choreographers who must surely love restlessness.

description: Today
