title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLAPPER, ARTHUR M.
description: KLAPPER--Arthur M. On November 1, 2003. Survived by wife Arleen (nee Rosenberg) and children Michele S. Klapper, Andrew D. Klapper and his wife Susan L., as well as Judith N. Klapper. Also survived by sister Martha Goldberg and grandchildren Jacob and Joshua. Funeral services to be held today, 12 noon, at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 275 Martling Avenue, Staten Island, NY 10314. Interment to take place at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, Queens. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun. For more information contact Menorah Chapels, 2145 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY 10314.

description: Semiconductor makers have been down so long that they cannot quite believe that things are looking up again.

title: Master Statesman Now His Kin's Fascination
description: Consider how much blood, toil, tears and sweat have gone into books about one Churchill by other Churchills: In the next week, the American versions of new books by two of Winston Churchill's grandchildren will be published -- in all, more than 800 pages weighing three and a half pounds. And both have to do with guess who.

title: A Fresh Mexican Standard-Bearer Emerges
description: The calendar says President Vicente Fox is halfway through his six-year term. But the handwriting on the wall says that it is all but over and that his legacy is likely to be one of unfulfilled pledges and empty promises.

title: Revolt of the Poor in Bolivia
description: The popular protests in Bolivia that forced out President Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada last month are the most recent example of a wave of indigenous power sweeping Latin America. Not since the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors have Latin America's Indians enjoyed the political influence they have today. Sadly, however, the indigenous may not benefit. Leaders of the Bolivia protests, for example, advocate policies that would make the poor worse off.

title: Israel Braces For Walkout Over Changes In Pensions
description: Israeli motorists lined up at gas stations on Sunday as Israel braced for a nationwide strike on Monday to protest the government's planned economic changes.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature

description: An article on Oct. 19 about plans by Levi Strauss to stop making blue jeans in San Antonio misstated the location of the original plant. It was on Valencia Street in San Francisco, not in Valencia, Calif.

title: Time to Change Election Rules?
description: To the Editor:

title: Most TV Spots Sold 3 Months Before Super Bowl
description: Three months before kickoff, CBS has already sold 80 percent of the available commercial time during Super Bowl XXXVIII to advertisers that include newcomers like Procter & Gamble along with mainstays like Anheuser-Busch, General Motors and PepsiCo.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Paid Notice: Deaths   ALBOHER, ALBERT
description: ALBOHER -- Albert. We mourn the loss of Albert, of Bayside, Queens, and Monticello, NY. He passed away peacefully in his sleep on October 31, at the age of 67. Al was President of Albert Alboher Associates and was an avid horse racing fan. He is survived by Ellen Alboher, their two daughters, Lori and Elyse, his sister Vilma and brother Elliott, his beloved granddaughter, Jami Abigail, and his litte grey filly, styled N Misty. Services today, 1:30 PM, at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. Burial at Beth David Cemetery. The family requests that donations be made to support the blind, kidney research or the Make a Wish Foundation in lieu of flowers.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Casino Proposal Splinters A State Used to Consensus
description: Bonnie Bea's Cafe and Gifts is a quiet little shop that sells buttery desserts and ceramic knickknacks, but these days it resounds with impassioned talk about one of the most divisive political battles to hit Maine in years.

title: B. N. Kursunoglu, 81, Physicist Who Led Noted Research Center
description: Behram N. Kursunoglu, a physicist who founded and led the Center for Theoretical Studies, an influential research organization at the University of Miami that drew scientists from around the world, died on Oct. 25 in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 81.

title: Charges Expected In Prudential Inquiry
description: A former branch manager for Prudential Securities in Boston, Robert Shannon, has been told by Massachusetts regulators that he will be charged today with failing to supervise brokers accused of being involved in improper mutual fund trades, his lawyer, Steven Fuller, said Saturday.

title: Despite Positives, More Negatives Are Predicted
description: L. Paul Bremer III, the special American representative for Iraq, has tried to put as positive a face as he can on the current state of affairs here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEARY, MARY ALICE (MIMI)
description: NEARY--Mary Alice (Mimi). Of Upper Montclair, on November 1, 2003. Mother of Lisa Neary and Mary Louise Rubin; sister of Roberta Bennett and A. Frederick Gerstell; and also survived by four grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Wednesday, at 11 AM, at St. Cassian's Church, Upper Montclair. She taught us to appreciate the beauty of life and we will think of her always. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to the NJ Audubon Society, PO Box 693, Bernardsville, NJ 07924. For more information contact Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 973-744-4346.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRETT, PETER
description: BARRETT--Peter. Age 62, on October 29, in New York City, after a long illness. Well known among friends and the New York City press corps as a witty character, avid reader and loyal Red Sox fan. He spent his entire career serving the City of New York. He was most recently employed by the New York City Transit Authority, from which he retired in December, 2002. He will be remembered with great affection by his wife Andrea Green, Bob and Buffy Barrett, and by his many friends and colleagues. Funeral services were private. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Francis's Friends, Inc., 25-02 23rd Ave, Astoria, NY 11105, or your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAINONE, VINCENTIA
description: RAINONE--Vincentia. On November 1, 2003, of Rosedale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Michele. Loving mother of AnnMarie Sessa and Joseph. Cherished grandmother of five and greatgrandmother of nine. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset, with interment to follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: Murder Case Against Durst Is Set to Go To Texas Jury
description: When the police arrested Robert A. Durst two years ago and charged him with killing and dismembering a 71-year-old neighbor, investigators believed they had arrested the kind of penniless drifter who often passes time on Galveston Island in Texas, at the end of Interstate 45.

title: High-Level Talks on Mideast Peace Resume
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 3  More than two months after Israel broke off contacts with the Palestinians, senior leaders from the two sides have resumed behind-the-scenes discussions in an attempt to revive the stalled Middle East peace plan.

title: In Bloomberg, Nonpartisan Fights Party Loyalist
description: Michael R. Bloomberg's push to bring his own version of nonpartisan elections to New York City is shaping up as the most partisan battle yet in the short political career of the Democrat-turned-Republican businessman-turned-mayor.

title: In Haste, the Jets Waste a Chance to Win in Overtime
description: In its chaos, the Jets' botched attempt at a 51-yard field goal in overtime Sunday seemed to sum up their season: head-scratching confusion followed by remorse.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Playoff Makes More Sense Than B.C.S.
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.

title: As Uses Grow, Tiny Materials' Safety Is Hard to Pin Down
description: When researchers fashion nanomaterials so small that their dimensions can be measured in molecules, the unusual and potentially valuable characteristics of those materials tend to show up immediately. But as businesses race to exploit those benefits, investors and policy makers are finding that pinpointing the potential environmental and health impacts of nanotechnology could take years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLASENHEIM, MATTHEW ''MANNY.''
description: BLASENHEIM -- Matthew ''Manny.'' Of Wellington, FL, formerly of Yonkers, on November 1. Beloved husband of Shirley. Father of Peter and Nancy. Grandfather of Alexis, Jon and Michael, and and great-grandfather of eight. Friend of many in the garment center and veteran of World War II.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Martin Goes Over 100
description: The Jets' rushing total of 132 yards was the third best against the Giants this season. Curtis Martin was the first back to run for more than 100 yards against the Giants, with 108. Lynn Zinser

title: Community, of Sorts, Blooms at Shelter for Fire Refugees
description: The wildfires that raged furiously last week through the mountains above this city, engulfing entire towns in flames and forcing more than 60,000 people to flee their homes, were slowly brought under control over the weekend.

description: AN IMPERFECT GOD

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Doug Tuchman, 63, Promoter of Bluegrass
description: Doug Tuchman, a concert promoter and disc jockey who was one of the first to bring bluegrass to New York, died on Oct. 6 in Manhattan. He was 63 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Julie Connelly
description: The reporter answered questions about America's newest labor force as a companion to her article in the Working special section.

title: Paul Calabresi, 73, Who Led Development of Cancer Drugs
description: Dr. Paul Calabresi, a leader in developing and testing drugs to treat Hodgkin's lymphoma, breast cancer and prostate cancer, among other diseases, died Oct. 25 in Providence, R.I. He was 73.

title: Denial Over, Rutgers President Admits Affair in Previous Job
description: After months of denials, the president of Rutgers University acknowledged Sunday that he had had an affair with a subordinate during his seven years as president of the University of Washington, and that it had been a factor in his decision to leave Seattle for New Jersey's state university a year ago.

title: Her Life Is a Mess, but Not Her Hair
description: A widow loses her job in a diner and, to support her two children, deals drugs, then becomes a crystal meth addict and police informer. Happens all the time, and particularly on Lifetime, the cable channel that specializes in women's more extreme struggles.

title: If You Rebuild It, They Can Play
description: As the subway he rides each morning emerges from darkness onto the elevated track along Westchester Avenue in the South Bronx, Jeremy Ocasio said, he sometimes sees other teenagers gape at the startlingly green athletic field he plays football on at the Academy for Careers in Sports, a city high school.

title: Lawyers for Juveniles
description: Forty years ago, in Gideon v. Wainwright, the Supreme Court recognized that criminal defendants have a right to counsel. This principle applies with special force to young defendants, who are least likely to understand their situations, and who are making decisions that could forever change the course of their lives. But the American Bar Association, in new studies, has found that juvenile defendants have woefully inadequate representation.

title: Reuters Will Accept Digital Religious Ads
description: Reuters has reconsidered a decision against accepting advertising from the United Methodist Church for the electronic screens on its American headquarters in Times Square.

title: High School Winners
description: Daniel Periac of Nyack High and Kara McKenna of Suffern High, both in Rockland County, won the annual New York City Marathon High School Invitational, a 2.2-mile run in Central Park held before the marathon yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: GREENWICH: SCHOOL BUS DRIVERS DECLARE STRIKE A union representing school bus drivers for Greenwich Public Schools declared a strike yesterday. The strike was to begin today. T.W.U. Local 100 operates about 100 buses that transport public and parochial students in Greenwich. The union said that its employer, Student Transportation of America, left the bargaining table on Thursday. A union spokesman, Dave Katzman, said high health care costs and too few work days were among the issues in contract negotiations. "The drivers feel they're left with no other option," he said.   (AP)

title: Subtleties of Slam by Bermuda Bowl Contender
description: Play in the World Zonal Championships will begin here on Monday, with 22 countries contesting the Bermuda Bowl for open teams. Italy, which won a different world title a year ago, is favored to win. Fulvio Fantoni and Claudio Nunes, the World Pairs champions, have been recruited to join the regular foursome of Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace.

title: Guatemala's Fictional Democracy
description: In a list of phenomena meant to illustrate how Latin American reality is more fantastic than anything found in fiction, Gabriel Garca Mrquez included in his acceptance speech for the 1982 Nobel Prize a reference to a dictator committing genocide in the name of God. He was speaking of Guatemala's ruler, a vociferous Protestant fundamentalist, Gen. Efran Ros Montt, who that year had taken power in a military coup. During the reign of ''Brother Efran,'' which lasted less than two years, the Guatemalan Army waged a scorched-earth campaign, ostensibly directed against leftist guerrillas, and engaged in hundreds of massacres of rural Mayan Indians.

title: The Helpless Victors
description: Ongoing terrorism in the land of two rivers places the occupying forces before virtually intractable problems. They are unable to find those behind the attacks nor are they receiving the anticipated international aid. Now quickly assembled Iraqi forces are to provide security and order.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTON, TRUMBULL
description: BARTON--Trumbull. On October 31, 2003, at age 86. The family wishes to extend its profound gratitude to all those for their love and care. Funeral services private.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about President Bush's $87 billion request for Iraq and Afghanistan spending referred incorrectly to the number of Congressional Black Caucus members who were likely to vote no. It was 37, not all 39. Two members -- Eleanor Holmes Norton of Washington and Donna M. Christian-Christensen of the Virgin Islands -- are delegates, not full representatives, and thus cannot cast final votes on legislation. (On Oct. 17, when the votes were cast, 32 Black Caucus members voted against the bill, three supported it, and two abstained.)

title: Big Daddy's Ego Defies Death and His Family
description: There's nothing remotely feline about the critter who rules the new revival of ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' which opened last night at the Music Box Theater. As the Southern patriarch Big Daddy in Tennessee Williams's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama of familial lies and loneliness, Ned Beatty brings to mind a rooster bred for cockfighting, just released from his cage and rarin' to ruffle feathers.

title: Music-Sharing Service At M.I.T. Is Shut Down
description: It was hailed as ingenious: a way to listen to music on demand while avoiding the legal battleground of file sharing. Best of all, the music was fully licensed, so there would be no legal trouble.

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Design; Now on Display, Engines Dressed Up to Tell a Story
description: UNDER the hood is the last frontier of automobile design,'' said David Laituri, who was a pioneer in the engine-compartment territory when he was a designer at General Motors.

title: Post-9/11 Detainee Cases On Supreme Court Docket
description: With cases generated by the Bush administration's response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, now reaching the Supreme Court in substantial numbers, the court faces a basic decision apart from the merits of any individual case: whether to become a player in the debate over where to set the balance between individual liberty and national security.

title: Signs of Damage Control in Russia's Oil Scandal
description: President Vladimir V. Putin's new chief of staff criticized prosecutors on Sunday for freezing shares in Yukos, the country's largest oil producer, describing the move as potentially reckless and counterproductive.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Week in Review yesterday described obstacles faced by United States troops in rooting out guerrillas who are attacking them in Iraq. In some editions, the article included a reference to a letter e-mailed to The Times by a public affairs officer of the 82nd Airborne Division. The press officer was quoted as saying, ''It's no secret that the 82nd Airborne Division is a lethal force.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Thursday about a new church in Rome gave an incorrect translation of its name, Dives in Misericordia. It means ''Rich in Mercy,'' not ''Mercy of God.''

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
description: (cont. from page F12)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's clearly a tragic day for America. In a long, hard war, we're going to have tragic days. But they're necessary. They're part of a war that's difficult and complicated.''

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
A Warm Reception From Mother Nature

title: The Big Chill at The Lab
description: A list of nearly 200 scientific researchers has been compiled and given to federal officials by the Traditional Values Coalition, a conservative group that goes wild over gay issues and federal funding of research related to human sexuality.

title: Combs Puts Money Where His Feet Are
description: Bib No. 30972, also known as Sean Combs, also known as P. Diddy, crossed the finish line of the New York City Marathon after 4 hours 14 minutes 54 seconds and raised his arms in triumph. Combs, a hip-hop star, was rushed into a black sports utility vehicle with tinted windows while fans shrieked in delight, then he was whisked to a news conference.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Fit to Be Tied

title: Fidelity Begins Review For a New Agency
description: Fidelity Investments has begun a review for an agency to handle creative duties on its account, which have been handled for the last two years by Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas. Billings were estimated at $75 million.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBLOOM, PHILIP
description: ROSENBLOOM--Philip. Our lives have been and will forever be enriched by our friendship with Phil. Mel and Pearl Zuckerman

title: Bloodlines and Business Intersect for Cable TV Chief
description: The Weather Channel's president, Bill Burke, has television in his genes. His father, Daniel Burke, is the former president of Capital Cities/ABC. Such a pedigree might give the son an instinctive edge in negotiating network access deals with big cable operators -- unless the person on the other side of the table comes from the same gene pool.

title: In Haste, Jets Waste Shot at an Overtime Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 2 — In its chaos, the Jets' botched attempt at a 51-yard field goal in overtime Sunday seemed to sum up their season: head-scratching confusion followed by remorse.

title: The Nets Find That Their System Is a Go
description: During Saturday night's victory over the Washington Wizards, the Nets' Jason Collins threw down an uncharacteristically forceful dunk, then, in a move completely out of character, he turned and flexed while letting out a scream.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
description: (cont. from page F6)

title: Race Becomes More Than an Annual Event
description: Those who live by Bedford Avenue and South Fourth Street in Brooklyn had their 11th-mile welcoming all set for the New York City Marathon runners yesterday. Salsa music blasting from a top-floor window filled the street, volunteers lined up to hand out water and spectators held up signs for the runners.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
File Sharing Pits Copyright Against Free Speech
description: Forbidden files are circulating on the Internet and threats of lawsuits are in the air. Music trading? No, it is the growing controversy over one company's electronic voting systems, and the issues being raised, some legal scholars say, are as fundamental as the sanctity of elections and the right to free speech.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Senator Graham to Retire, Dealing Blow to Democrats
description: Senator Bob Graham of Florida, who recently ended his bid for the White House, announced today that he would not seek re-election to a fourth term.

title: Time to Change Election Rules?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Too Famous To Suffer Unnoticed
description: BECAUSE she is so recognizable, with her thick wraparound shades, Marla Runyan could not suffer anonymously.

title: A Great Day for Spectators Isn't So Great for Runners
description: The calendar may have said November, but it felt more like late September, much to the chagrin of many runners in the New York City Marathon yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Were Seconds From Ruin
description: TICK, tick, tick. Overtime was winding down on Jim Fassel and the Giants yesterday, as was the season and, it can be argued, Fassel's seven-year run as the team's coach. The score was tied, 28-28, and the circumstances of how the Giants arrived in overtime made the prospect of a tie feel like the kiss of sudden death.

title: Robert G. Bartle, 75, Mathematician and Author
description: Robert G. Bartle, a mathematician known for his authoritative texts on real analysis and other areas of advanced mathematics, died on Sept. 18 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 75.

title: Late at Night, That's NBC Crowing
description: Ten years into the deeply personal competition for supremacy in late-night television, NBC has decided the time is finally right to send CBS and its star, David Letterman, a pointed and very public message:

title: The Neediest Cases; Family With a Big Heart Gets a Timely Hand
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Jim and Camille Spannagel were practicing their usual weekend activity: keeping track of their children.

title: Runner Faces a Long Road to Approval
description: Kim Pawalek, a top American distance runner for seven years, is still looking for some respect. She receives it from other runners, but not from her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, ROSE (ZWAN GER)
description: GOLDMAN -- Rose (Zwan ger). 93. Adored wife of the late Alexander B., M.D.; loving mother of Irma Werfel (Laurence) and Robert Goldman, M.D. (Audrey). Beloved grandmother of Beth, Jill, Andrea, Lisa, and great-grandmother of Benjamin, Rebecca, Rise and Janie.

title: Tiniest of Loans Bring Big Payoff, Aid Group Says
description: An organization that promotes small loans for self-employment projects among the world's poorest people plans to announce here on Monday that it is on track to meet its nine-year goal of helping 100 million of the world's poorest families by 2005.

title: Putnams Chief Steps Down Amid Shake-Up in Fund Industry
description: The reverberating scandal rocking the mutual fund industry claimed another victim today, when the Marsh & McLennan Companies , parent of Putnam Investments, said Lawrence J. Lasser had been removed as Putnam's president, chief executive and a director, effective immediately.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Corrections
description: A legend yesterday above a chart with an article about the pace of American military deaths in Iraq referred incorrectly in some copies to the period during which 357 American service members died. That figure covered the full course of the war, through Oct. 31. It was not just for the period from May through October.

title: Death of 2 Babies in Flood Stuns River Region
description: Every person in this little village at the foot of the Catskill Mountains has lost two children, as have their neighbors in Hamden and in Sidney Center.

title: An Iraqi City Looks Suspiciously at U.S. Good-Will Gestures
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Nov. 3  In the epicenter of anti-American hatred, even the most generous of gestures is viewed with a suspicious eye.

title: Giants Keep Fingertip Grasp on the Season
description: Giants cornerback Will Allen coiled into his stance at the left end of the Giants' line, and all he could see was the Jets' snapper's fingertips. Everything slowed down. Giants Stadium, full of agonized fans tolerating their 11th minute of overtime, faded away. Allen heard nothing, saw only those fingertips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, HONORA (HONEY) (NEE RUBEL)
description: SHAPIRO--Honora (Honey) (nee Rubel), pka Honey Sanders, of Los Angeles and New York, died suddenly on October 31st at 75 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Albert Shapiro, loving mother of Barbara, Stephen, Kelly, dear friend to her son-in-law Lou, adoring grandmother of Eli, Eva, Nicolas, Jonathan and Michael, cherished sisterin-law of Harold and Barbara, devoted aunt to Susan, Tony, Patti, Buddy, Karen and Mark. She was the essence of life and happiness, and was adored and loved by everyone who knew her. He wide circle of family and friends are grieving deeply with our loss. Services will be held on Monday, November 3rd, at 12 noon, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long island.

title: Public's Doubt Vs. Bush Vows
description: The political challenge posed to President Bush by the deadly helicopter attack in Iraq on Sunday is this: how to keep public opinion from swinging against him over Iraq while not abandoning his quest to bring a stable democracy to that country.

title: Late Bloomer's Happy Ending
description: Fauja Singh, a 92-year-old Sikh marathoner from Britain, crossed the finish line in darkness, 7 hours 34 minutes after he started.

title: Patents; A device points the way to Mecca and plays calls to prayers.
description: THE Koran requires Muslims to pray five times a day while facing Mecca, the birthplace of the prophet Muhammad. Traditionally muezzins climb the minarets of mosques to call out prayer time, but in the modern world the devout are not always within earshot.

title: Sports Briefing
description: GOLF

title: CROSSING WITH STRANGERS: Children at the Border; Littlest Immigrants, Left in Hands of Smugglers
description: They were barely old enough to cross a street by themselves, much less a border. But there they were, alone on a hot August evening at a United States immigration checkpoint, surrounded by law enforcement officers wearing badges and guns. Eight-year-old Jos Cruz Velzquez held the hand of his brother Sergio, who was 6.

title: Holocaust Museum Tribute Also Serves as a Thread
description: Michel Jeruchim counts himself lucky. His son, Kenneth, understood as a small boy that his father was someone with an incomparable story that demanded his lifelong attention.

title: INSIDE
description: California's Fire Refugees

title: Weather Channel President's Network Faces a 'Very Challenging Time'
description: Bill Burke, a protg of Ted Turner, knows cable television. And he came to know specialized programming in the two years he ran the Resorts Sports Network, a small chain of stations providing snow reports and the like in mountain resorts. So when the opportunity came along last year to take the top job at perhaps the most specialized network in cable television, the Weather Channel, Mr. Burke seemed to be the man for the niche.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DYSTEL, MARION
description: DYSTEL--Marion. Of Rye, NY, passed away on November 2, 2003, at White Plains Hospital due to complications of pneumonia. Born Marion Deitler on February 7, 1915, in Bridgeport, CT, to Louis and Fanny Deitler. She was raised and educated in public schools in Bridgeport, where she met and married her high school sweetheart, Oscar, on October 2, 1938. She served as a volunteer with the American Red Cross during WWII and with the United Hospital in Port Chester and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society Southern New York Chapter. She is survived by her husband of 65 years, Oscar Dystel of Rye. Also surviving are her loving daughter Jane and her husband Steven Schwinder, and her grandchildren Jessica and Zachary, all of New York City. Her son, John, predeceased her in June, 2003. She was also predeceased by her sisters Belle Cone, Jeanne Slachter, and her brothers Leo Deitler and Irving Deitler. Contributions may be made to the John Dystel MS Nursing Fellowship, 50 Main Street, Suite 1000, White Plains, NY 10606.

title: Giants Keep Fingertip Grasp on the Season
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 2  Giants cornerback Will Allen coiled into his stance at the left end of the Giants' line, and all he could see was the Jets' snapper's fingertips. Everything slowed down. Giants Stadium, full of agonized fans tolerating their 11th minute of overtime, faded away. Allen heard nothing, saw only those fingertips.

title: TV for the AARP Set
description: Baby boomers like to say that their tastes in popular culture do not separate them from younger people the way they themselves once stared across the generation gap at their own parents.

title: Iraq War III
description: We thought we won the first Iraq war in 100 hours, but lost the peace to Saddam and his Baathist followers. We thought we won the second Iraq war decisively in one week, but Saddam's murdering class and his imported terrorists chose to run and fight from underground.

title: E-Commerce Report; New advances mean that advertisers are able to quantify the impact of their online marketing campaigns.
description: MARKETERS have long said they would increase their online advertising budgets if Internet sites would do what they promised to do years ago: quantify the effects of an ad campaign on sales, brand awareness and other factors like the consumer's intent to buy.

title: Class, Get in Touch With Your Inner Zappa; A Real Life School of Rock Focuses on Jamming and Performing
description: It was the type of hipper-than-thou crowd not easily impressed. But belting out spot-on renditions of Led Zeppelin and Frank Zappa classics, Paul Green's rock cover band, made up of youths well below the legal drinking age, managed to win over the skeptical tastemakers that flocked to an art-magazine party in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, recently.

title: In Nassau, Vote Is Measure of a Democratic Chief
description: His name will not be on the ballot tomorrow, but Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, is campaigning as if his political career is at stake. It may well be.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Outsize Personalities Riff on Sex, Booze and Politics
description: Pop music would be dreary without large egos, but they have to be tended carefully, and must change significantly every five years or so. Here are three of the current biggest.

title: Pete Rose's Folly, Baseball's Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: Okayo Breaks Her Record By Nearly Two Minutes
description: As Margaret Okayo of Kenya traversed the humpbacked span of the Queensboro Bridge, crossing into Manhattan, she reached at Mile 16 the most alluring and dangerous point on the New York City Marathon course.

title: Ahead by Two in Third, Rangers Let Colorado In
description: Considering that the Rangers have not qualified for the playoffs the last six seasons, one would think they would never become complacent with a lead.

title: College Student Earns Maclay Trophy
description: Matthew Sereni, an equine sciences major at Cal Poly Tech, beat a field of 99 other qualifiers in the ASPCA Equitation Championship at the closing session of the Metropolitan National Horse Show yesterday at Pier 54 in Manhattan. Sereni, 18, collected the Alfred B. Maclay Trophy for his rides on Pinnacle Equine Group's Fareniente. Courtney McKay of Ocala, Fla., finished second, and Randy Sherman of South Pasadena, Calif., placed third. Alex Orr Jr.

title: Family Films Challenge 'Scary' and 'Chainsaw'
description: This was a transition weekend at the box office, with two family films, Disney's animated ''Brother Bear'' and Sony/ Revolution's sports drama ''Radio,'' contending with ''Scary Movie 3'' and ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre'' for the top of the list.

title: Benetton Hires Kurt Andersen to Burnish 'Colors'
description: Colors magazine, Benetton's once-provocative, stylized editorial companion to its often provocative, stylized advertising, has been searching for years to recapture the buzz it had in the mid-1990's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fishers Island: 2 Missing In Crash Of Stunt Plane
description: A single-engine plane that was performing stunts over Long Island Sound crashed just south of Fishers Island about 11:25 a.m. yesterday, and search crews had not found its pilot or passenger by last night, Coast Guard officials said. The crash, a few miles off the coast of New London, Conn., occurred after the aircraft, a Pitts biplane, took off with another stunt plane from Westerly State Airport in Rhode Island, the officials said. The second plane landed safely on Fishers Island. The Coast Guard suspended its search last night after searchers recovered a seat, pieces of a landing gear, a propeller and a wing. Matthew Fleishman, a fisherman who was in the area of the crash, told the Associated Press that the two planes had appeared to be re-enacting a dogfight before one of them hit the water. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Amtrak's Budgetary Crapshoot
description: Washington lawmakers are haggling over next year's budget for passenger rail. They could force Amtrak to shut down, allow it to limp on while deferring important maintenance, or cover its needs. The right choice -- covering its needs -- is clear. But Amtrak is vulnerable because unlike all other intercity transportation, rail does not have a trust fund with a steady stream of public funds.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Judge Orders New Trial For Woman In Killing
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn has ordered Suffolk County prosecutors to release or retry a woman who is serving 25 years to life for killing a man she said had raped her. The federal judge said a ruling by the trial judge had hurt the woman's ability to get a fair trial. The murder trial in 1997 of the woman, Keila Pulinario, attracted attention because Judge Gary J. Weber of Suffolk County Court first said he would permit, and then barred, a defense argument that she suffered from rape trauma syndrome. The syndrome, her lawyers said, made her fearful of being raped again and explained why she fatally shot Imagio Santana in 1995. The federal judge, Jack B. Weinstein, said on Friday that when the trial judge changed his ruling about the defense during the trial, he ''cut the legs off the defense.'' William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Secretary Testifies in Utah
description: Thomas K. Welch, one of the defendants in the Salt Lake City Olympic bribery trial, was "very charismatic and persuasive," said his former secretary, Stephanie Pate, who testified yesterday that she was coaxed into helping the daughters of two International Olympic Committee members set up apartments as part of Utah's campaign to win the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Spitzer to Question Fund Fees in Testimony
description: The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, will say that mutual fund directors should be paying closer attention to the fees charged to shareholders, according to a draft of testimony he plans to make today before a United States Senate panel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Picks Davis's Rival For Council
description: The most heated City Council contest -- the race to succeed the slain Councilman James E. Davis -- drew yet another high-profile political figure yesterday. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins endorsed the Working Families Party candidate over the Democrat, who is Mr. Davis's brother.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fund Fees Are Focus Of Spitzer Testimony

title: German Way To Go Digital: No Dawdling
description: When Sebastian Engel received a letter in the mail last winter warning that he would soon lose his over-the-air analog television service, he reacted like any 26-year-old graduate student with little money and even less interest in the vagaries of TV technology.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Accounts
description: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream, Oakland, Calif., part of Nestl, has expanded its relationship with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, naming the agency to handle the account of Hagen-Dazs, which had been handled by the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $20 million. Goodby, Silverstein also creates campaigns for the Dreyer's ice cream brand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUME, THOMAS
description: HUME--Thomas. Architect, Stamford, CT, died October 31, at 75. He was past President of the Trustees of the Ferguson Library and of Family and Children's Services, both in Stamford. An avid sailor, he was a crew member aboard the 1966 Mallory Cup winner. He is survived by his wife Tulita Mejia Hume; his children, Mary Elise Papke, Connie Hume Rodman, Tony, Emmett Butler, John Linus and Maggie Hume; four sisters, Dorothy Knapp, Brigid O'Brien, Justine and Mary Louise Hume; 10 grandchildren and one step-grandchild. Funeral Mass November 6, 11 AM, St. Clement, 535 Fairfield Ave, Stamford. In lieu of flowers contributions to Friends of the Ferguson Library, 1 Public Library Plaza, Stamford, CT 06901.

title: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 0.95 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 1.04 percent. The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

title: Honors
description: New officers were named at the Family Friendly Programming Forum, a consortium of marketers that distributes seed money to help develop family-oriented television programming. Kaki Hinton, vice president for advertising services at the consumer health care division of Pfizer, becomes chairwoman, succeeding Andrea Alstrup, corporate vice president for advertising at Johnson & Johnson. Bill McCarron, vice president for media and sponsorships at Verizon Communications, becomes chairman, succeeding Brad Simmons, vice president for media services at the United States division of Unilever.

title: Richard E. Neustadt, Historian, Dies at 84; Studied Power and Advised Three Presidents
description: Richard E. Neustadt, the White House adviser, historian and authority on presidential power, died on Friday in England. He was 84.

title: Icelandic Company Says It Has Found Osteoporosis Gene
description: A gene linked to osteoporosis has been identified by Decode Genetics, the Icelandic company that is leading efforts to find the genes that underlie common human diseases.

title: Moss Is Making Jets Forget About Coles
description: One of the Jets' primary concerns before this season was the departure of Chad Pennington's go-to receiver, Laveranues Coles, to Washington. Enter Santana Moss.

title: Bridge of Sighs Is in the Bronx At Willis Avenue
description: It is said that almost anyone can train to run 20 miles. But 26 miles 385 yards? For many runners, the wall, the 20-mile point when energy tends to sag precipitously, defines the marathon. Beyond the wall is a devilish unpredictability: you might sail through the last six miles one year, and be reduced to an agonizing survival shuffle the next. Sailing through is what brings marathoners back for more.

title: Time to Change Election Rules?
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; A cellphone would allow text messages to be sent in handwritten form.
description: CELLPHONES are not what they used to be. In the last few years, many have become hybrids of phones, personal digital assistants, cameras and text message centers. Some people would like to see even more versatility, turning cellphones into a one-man band of added features -- and many of them have won patents for their ideas.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
Congressional Spam Filter
description: When the Senate approved an antispam bill last month, 97 to 0, beleaguered e-mail users may have thought relief was on the way. But industry lobbyists have been working hard to ensure that any law will be full of loopholes. If the bill gets any weaker, it will be worse than none at all, since it would nullify stronger protections at the state level, including a hard-hitting antispam law recently adopted in California.

title: Pennington Plays Well, but Is Feeling Only the Pain
description: Chad Pennington dragged his body across the carpet toward the double doors that lead outside Giants Stadium, limping away from the cruel day as best he could. He had never thrown so many passes in an N.F.L. game, had never even played in overtime before, and now had the look of a man who wanted to forget he had ever been in the building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEU, CHARLOTT (KRAEMER NEU)
description: NEU -- Charlott (Kraemer Neu). Wife of the late Frank Neu, passed away on October 31, at the age of 94. She was an example of great courage which we will never forget.

title: A Warm Reception From Mother Nature
description: (cont. from F7)

title: In Milan, Working to Unfurl a High-Tech Blanket of Fiber
description: The capital of Italy's fashion industry prides itself on the ability to be first to identify a trend. Silvio Scaglia, chief executive and co-founder of e.Biscom, a recent technology start-up, is hoping the same holds true for technology.

title: Mutual Fund Head Resigns From Board
description: Richard S. Strong, the founder of the Strong Mutual Funds, resigned as chairman of the funds' board, a few days after the New York attorney general said he would take action against him for improper trading of shares.

title: Frank A. Pitelka, 87, Zoologist And Behavioral Ecology Expert
description: Frank A. Pitelka, whose studies of wildlife in the Arctic and California helped establish a field of study documenting the way environmental factors affect animal behavior, died Oct. 10 at his daughter's home in Altadena, Calif. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERSON, STANLEY. DEVOTED HUSBAND OF DIANE (NEE GOETZ)
description: PERSON--Stanley. Devoted husband of Diane (nee Goetz). Beloved father of Rabbi Hara Person, U.A.H.C., and Jennifer Person. Cherished grandfather of Lyia, Yonatan and Goldie. Dear brother of Sam, the late Joseph, Frances Kaufmann and Isabel Pershan. Services 12 noon, Tuesday, Gramercy Park Chapels, 157 2nd Avenue, NYC.

title: U.N. to Consider Whether to Ban Some, or All, Forms of Cloning of Human Embryos
description: Trace the lines of science, religion, ethics and politics and eventually they will intersect at one of the most divisive issues currently at play here: human cloning.

title: My Job Prospects (I'm 56)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Better Toomer
description: When Giants receiver Amani Toomer caught a 39-yard pass for a second-quarter touchdown, he lay in the end zone on his back for a moment. The play came at the end of such a long week for Toomer, he wanted to soak it in.

title: Keeping Busy Along the Way
description: Leslie Rogall, 29, loves the New York City Marathon so much that she runs with her cellphone and her digital camera, calling friends and snapping souvenir photos along the course.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about rule changes proposed by the mutual fund industry misstated the views of Mercer Bullard, who heads the shareholder advocacy group Fund Democracy and who plans to propose an oversight board. He said such a board could supplement the Securities and Exchange Commission's regulation of funds, not supplant it.

title: 16 Wounded in Copter Attack Being Treated in Germany
description: LANDSTUHL, Germany, Nov. 3  Sixteen American soldiers hurt in a deadly attack on their helicopter in Iraq on Sunday are being treated at a military hospital here for broken bones, spinal fractures, burns, and other wounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOBLER, WELLS ATHERTON
description: HOBLER--Wells Atherton. 84, on October 30, in St. Louis. Son of the late Atherton W. Hobler, founder and Chairman of Benton and Bowles Advertising. Brother of Edward and Herbert. Pilot, Major, U.S. Army Air Force, WWII. Lived in Bronxville, NY, Stamford, CT, and Princeton, NJ. Princeton graduate, 1941. Beloved husband of Jean Maritz for 48 years in St. Louis. Father of Edward A. Nardi, Peter, Christopher Hobler, Leigh Gerard. Grandfather of six.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCQUARY, JOAN S.
description: McQUARY--Joan S. 81, a resident of Manhattan and Kismet, Fire Island, died on October 31, 2003. She was a graduate of the University of Minnesota and had a long and distinguished career at Columbia University Press. She is survived by Mignon Sauber, her long time companion.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: WOODBRIDGE: 2 MEN SHOT TO DEATH Olga and Alexander Bautin immigrated to New Jersey hoping to spare their sons from serving in the Russian army. One of the sons, 26-year-old Alexey, and a friend were fatally shot on Thursday night. "We saved him from war in Chechnya, and he was killed here," Alexander Bautin told The Star-Ledger of Newark. Alexey Bautin and Sergey Barbashov, 21, of Edison, were shot while sitting in the front seat of Mr. Barbashov's car outside Mr. Bautin's apartment. Detectives were still investigating possible motives and searching for suspects. Mr. Barbashov, a former Middlesex County College student, had hoped to open a business. He sold used cars for an uncle in Bridgeton, authorities said. Mr. Bautin worked full time as a computer programmer.   (AP)

title: Your Kids, My Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPITZER, SYLVIA LINDER
description: SPITZER--Sylvia Linder, on October 28. Survived by her devoted husband, Herman. Beloved wife of the late Frank Linder. Her children, Susan, John and Bill, were enriched through her intelligence, energy and caring. She was an abiding presence for her grandchildren. Her memory will also be cherished by her stepchildren, Andy and Alan and their families; by her son-in-law, and daughters-in-law. As a caring sister Sylvia is remembered by David, Marjorie and sisterin-law, Rosalie. Her love of family and determination to leave the world a better place will sustain us all. Memorial service at 1 p.m., December 1, at Congregation Emanu-El Rye, NY. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to the Anti-Defamation League.

title: 16 G.I.'S ARE KILLED AS MISSILE ATTACK DOWNS U.S. COPTER
description: Guerrillas shot down an American helicopter just outside this city on Sunday in a bold assault that killed 16 soldiers and wounded 20 others. It was the deadliest attack on American troops since the United States invaded Iraq in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREYFUS, KATHRYN
description: DREYFUS -- Kathryn. 103, Hewlett, NY, on November 1, 2003. Wife of the late Emanuel. Mother of Suzanne and the late Bertram Levitan and Robert and Sylvia Dreyfus. Grandmother of Michael, Susan, Richard, Peggy, Nancy, Jay, Sally, Louis, Stephen and the late Kenneth. Adored great-grandmother of 11. Funeral November 5, 11 AM, Temple Sinai, Lawrence, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Oct. 22 about the participation of Evangel Christian Academy of Louisiana in the first high school football game broadcast live on national television misidentified the school in Shreveport, La., for which Denny Duron, chancellor of Evangel, played football. It was Captain Shreve High School, not Woodlawn.

title: Glue and Cable Wire Aid Tenacious Winner
description: The push-rim wheelchair division of the New York City Marathon went just about as Krige Schabort had expected yesterday.

title: Illinois Picks Finalists For Ad Campaigns
description: The Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity in Chicago has named finalists in reviews for its tourism advertising and public relations accounts, with combined billings estimated at $12 million.

title: New Draft Charter Is Unveiled in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov.3  A new draft constitution for Afghanistan was unveiled today and formally presented to the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, at a ceremony on the grounds of the presidential palace.

title: High School Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Service Restored
description: Subway service on the No. 2 and 3 lines was restored last night after a weekend of disruptions for riders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn that were caused by a track fire in Harlem on Friday. A spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, James Anyansi, said full service resumed on both lines by 9:30 p.m. Crews spent the weekend reinstalling wiring and switches damaged by the fire, at the 110th Street and Lenox Avenue station.

title: The Redbirds' Last Ride
description: On Monday, the last of the New York City subway's venerable "redbird" subway trains rumbled from Times Square to Flushing, carrying a retinue of subway buffs, transit officials and bemused commuters.

title: Scenes:  'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'
description: Ned Beatty, Jason Patric and Ashley Judd star in the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof."

title: Scenes:  'Wicked'
description: Kristin Chenoweth, Idina Menzel and Joel Grey star in the new Broadway musical "Wicked."

title: What a Relief!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Folk Meets Baroque At a Haitian Soire
description: It is 1790. Bewigged French colonial society and barefoot black slaves live different lives in Haiti but intermingle nonetheless. Such was the conceit, ingeniously and tastefully presented by Catherine Turocy's New York Baroque Dance Company and Ann Williams's Dallas Black Dance Theater as ''Soire Baroque en Hati'' at Florence Gould Hall on Saturday.

title: Mayor Urges $13.1 Billion For Schools
description: Openly challenging Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature to increase education aid to New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday proposed $13.1 billion in school construction and repairs over five years -- the most ambitious education capital plan in city history -- and demanded that Albany foot more than half of the bill.

title: The Post-Grasso Exchange
description: The New York Stock Exchange is the last major exchange to resist embracing full electronic trading, and its human floor traders -- the so-called specialists, who match buyers and sellers in a given stock -- have been loosely regulated. Critics of the 211-year-old institution are increasingly linking these two facts to the outrageous $187.5 million compensation packages that cost Richard Grasso, its ousted chief executive, his job.

title: Exercise and Setting Ease Alzheimer's Effects
description: For many, a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease can mean life in a dreary nursing home and a treatment centered on powerful antipsychotics to combat the onset of memory loss, dementia and other signs of a mind that is slowly unraveling.

title: From South Africa, Satire That Won't Close Saturday (It's Playing Till Sunday)
description: Theater wants desperately to matter. Theater artists want to be at the center of culture the way they once were. Now movies and television give us our daily entertainment, while pop music gives us live spectacle, packed with confrontation and titillation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORENSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: ORENSTEIN--Abraham. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Abraham Orenstein. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: Report Has Mixed News For Papers
description: The nation's daily newspapers reported their latest six-month circulation figures yesterday, and the results were decidedly mixed. While overall weekday circulation grew slightly, Sunday circulation fell by slightly more compared with the period a year ago, according to an analysis of reports from the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

title: Weighing In on Ending Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention-Getting Decision From a Low-Profile Chief
description: Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the chief executive of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, is not the most visible executive in the insurance industry by a long shot.

title: Sports of The Times; Heads or Tails Is No Way To Determine Overtime
description: WHY does the National Football League persist in waiting until it is embarrassed in a Super Bowl or in a playoff game by its unfair overtime procedure? Why does it persist in allowing a coin toss to determine, in nearly 30 percent of overtime games, which team wins simply because it won the coin toss?

title: The Sunless Sunburn Mystery
description: Sometimes a difficult diagnosis is made, not by performing a large number of lab tests or by a logical analysis of what the patient presents, but by a fortunate association in the physician's mind.

title: Iraq's Economy Is Mostly Stagnant, Propped Up by U.S. Cash and by Hopes of Safer Days
description: The state-owned shoe factory here was once sophisticated enough to make shoes for Bally, the Swiss luxury goods company.

title: Grandmom's Little Health Hazard
description: Women who took care of grandchildren for more than nine hours a week faced a significantly higher risk of developing heart disease, according to a study published in the November issue of The American Journal of Public Health.

title: Let Go, Straphangers. The Ride Is Over.
description: For Edward Murphy, 21, all the hubbub on the No. 7 train to Queens yesterday morning was hard to fathom. Clad in a jacket and tie, he stepped into a subway car at Grand Central Terminal, expecting an uneventful ride to Woodside, where he had a job interview.

title: MetLife Reports 75% Profit Rise
description: MetLife Inc., the life insurer, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 75 percent after the company reduced its losses from corporate bond investments. It said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating a $31 million accounting error found two months ago.

title: Inquiry Is Sought About Deletions In Report on Justice Department
description: Two leading House Democrats asked the Justice Department's inspector general on Monday to investigate the department's decision to delete large parts of a report on employee diversity before releasing it publicly.

title: For Some, Tree Stump in Passaic Is Reason to Believe
description: She is said to have appeared in some pretty strange places in the area -- a grotto in upstate New York, a backyard in Marlboro and a smudgy window in Perth Amboy. But many here believe that on a vacant lot where drugs were once freely traded in this North Jersey city, the Virgin Mary is now appearing in, of all things, the form of a tree stump.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MODNE, ARTHUR
description: MODNE--Arthur. We wish to extend our deepest sympathy to Florence, Leanne, Len, Dara, Dave, Alden, Spencer and Jason. True friends are hard to come by-Arthur, you were one of the best. We will miss you greatly Bernice and Marvin Stephanie and Eric

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: CONJOINED TWINS DEVELOP INFECTION Clarence and Carl Aguirre, the 18-month-old Filipino twins joined at the head, have developed an infection, leading doctors to remove the tissue expanders inserted under their scalps. The expanders, which were inserted on Oct. 20, are used to stretch the skin enough to cover both skulls after their eventual separation. The removal was carried out yesterday in a 45-minute procedure at Children's Hospital at Montefiore in the Bronx. Surgeons said that the infection was not a major setback, and that the expanders would be reinserted. The boys and their mother were expected to return to Blythedale Children's Hospital, a rehabilitation center in Valhalla, N.Y., last night.   Denise Grady (NYT)

title: Mourning and Yao: Two Big Bodies Collide
description: The steepest challenge of Alonzo Mourning's comeback tour measures 7 feet 6 inches with a flat top.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: City Comptroller's Fiscal Report Shows More Reasons for Smiles
description: Higher property and sales taxes, along with increased real estate values, combined with tightfisted budgeting to help New York City end its fiscal year in June in the black, according to a report issued by the city comptroller yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCLEAN, WILLIAM HENRY
description: McLEAN -- William Henry. The Board of Trustees, Headmaster, faculty, staff and the Collegiate School community mourn the loss of this distinguished alumnus and faithful friend of the School and extend condolences to the entire McLean family, including Mr. McLean's wife Vesta T. McLean and sons William H. McLean Jr. and Eugene B. McLean. David B. Forer President, Board of Trustees Kerry P. Brennan Headmaster

title: Novelties That Stick In the Craw Of Your Mind
description: The best novelty hits inspire instant nostalgia. Listeners can look forward to the day when they'll look back and wonder how something so preposterous ever became popular. On Saturday night the bands behind two recent novelty hits came to the Bowery Ballroom.

title: Senate Sends Spending Bill For War Costs To President
description: The Senate gave its final approval on Monday to President Bush's request for $87.5 billion to occupy and rebuild Iraq and Afghanistan, completing Congressional action on the largest emergency spending bill ever sought by a president.

title: Lawyers' Ads Seeking Clients In Ferry Crash
description: Two days after a Staten Island ferry crashed last month, killing 10 passengers and injuring dozens of others, the New York State Bar Association issued an advisory reminding lawyers ''to adhere to the code of professional responsibility'' and refrain from soliciting work or pressuring survivors to sue.

title: Telemarketing Fine Proposed for AT&T
description: The Federal Communications Commission accused AT&T yesterday of making telemarketing pitches to consumers who had asked the company not to call them and the commission proposed fining the company $780,000.

title: Thomson And TCL To Join TV Units
description: If you can't beat them, join them.

title: South African Companies Fill a Void
description: Africa largely missed out on the investment boom of the 1990's and still receives only a tiny portion of the world's foreign direct investment. But while the continent is receiving a shrinking share of global investment from traditional donors like the United States, Britain and France, investment from South Africa, the region's biggest economy, in the rest of the continent has surged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCENTEE, MARIA CONSUELO CORTES, VERGARA
description: McENTEE--Maria Consuelo Cortes-Vergara, died peacefully on November 1, 2003, at her home in Denver after courageously battling a long illness. Connie, as she was known to family and friends, was born in Bogota, Colombia, but grew up in New York City and attended schools in the New York area, including Sacred Heart Villa in Dobbs Ferry, NY. She graduated from the Colegio Nueva Granada in Bogota, Marymount Manhattan College in NYC, and furthered her studies in modern languages at the Sorbonne and the University of Barcelona. In 1980 she moved to the Denver area where she and her husband made their home for the past 23 years. During her career, Connie held positions at several organizations including the American Society of Civil Engineers, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, the Kellogg Corporation, and the Englewood Meridian. She was loved dearly by her family and friends and will be deeply missed. Connie is the daughter of the late Domingo G. Cortes Cuellar and Isabel Vergara de Cortes. She is survived by her husband James J. McEntee, Jr., her two sons, James and Christopher; brothers Hugo (Maria Rosa), Cesar (Marina); sister Nhora; brother-inlaw, Harold A. Comerer; sisters-in-law Christina and Nancy McEntee; nieces and nephews Maria Rosa, Luis Ignacio (Myriam), David Eduardo, Carolina Domenica, Andrea Elisabeth, Meghan, and Michael; grandnephew David; aunt Maria Teresa Vergara and uncle Raymond E. Vergara. Services at Horan & McConaty, Denver, November 4-5, 303-757-1238. Interment Mount Olivet Cemetery, Wheat Ridge, Co.

title: Election Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, RICHARD B.
description: SMITH--Richard B., on November 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Patricia H. Smith. Loving father of Landis, Leslie, Tom, Eliza and step-father of Elizabeth. Devoted grandfather of Eliot, Isobel, Colin, Graham and stepgrandfather of Victoria. Family will receive friends Thursday 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services to be announced.

title: So Few Soldiers, So Much to Do
description: The Bush administration's reaction to the deaths of 16 American soldiers in the downing of a helicopter on Sunday morning was the same as it was to the suicide bombings at police stations and the Red Cross headquarters in Baghdad a week earlier -- and the same as it has been to every other setback the coalition has faced: insistence that there is no need for more American troops beyond the 133,000 now in Iraq.

title: Younger Murdoch to Head Pay TV Company
description: James Murdoch, the 30-year-old son of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, was named chief executive of the British Sky Broadcasting Group on Monday, despite a growing investor outcry about the company's governance.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Accord On Halting Use Of Flame Retardant
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said it had reached an agreement with the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation to phase out two types of a widely used flame retardant, polybrominated diphenyl ether or PBDE, by the end of 2004. Scientists have detected rising levels of the two retardants in wildlife and breast milk of nursing mothers. Following Europe's lead, California in August became the first state to ban the chemicals, the penta and octa forms of PBDE. Great Lakes Chemical, based in Indianapolis, is a main manufacturer of the two chemicals. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Animals Cloned for Food No Longer Draw Collective Yawn
description: The year was 1988. The photo of the three calves was displayed in newspapers and featured in television news. The calves were clones, created from prize Brangus cattle, and made to be eaten in a new business that, the news reports promised, could forever alter the way superior bulls and cows were produced. Nary a word about whether it was safe to eat clones, nary a peep from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, HONORA (HONEY)
description: SHAPIRO--Honora (Honey). The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Honey Shapiro, beloved sister-in-law of Harold and Barbara Shapiro, cherished friends and strong supporters of UJA-Federation. Barbara takes a leadership role both on Long Island and in New York, as chair of the Women's Philanthropic Council and President of the Women's Campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to Harold, Barbara, and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Q & A
description: Ear and Nose Hair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREYFUS, KATHRYN
description: DREYFUS -- Kathryn. We mourn the death of our cherished oldest founding member, our beloved grande dame. Married to the late Manny Dreyfus for 76 years. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Beth Santopolo, President

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Elmsford: Building Workers' Strike Averted
description: Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union announced a tentative contract yesterday and called off a threatened strike by 1,500 janitors, doormen and handymen at more than 500 apartment buildings in Westchester and neighboring counties. The union and the Building and Realty Institute of Westchester and the Mid-Hudson Region initialed an agreement that called for weekly raises of $25 in the contract's first year, $15 in the second and $10 in the third. The Westchester workers average $600 a week. Under the accord, management will make a $5 weekly contribution to each worker's 401(k) plan in the second year and a $10 contribution in the third year. A contract ratification vote is scheduled for Thursday evening. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Canary Wharf Bid
description: The Canary Wharf Group said it had conditionally agreed to a takeover by a consortium led by Morgan Stanley. The bid values Canary Wharf, the London real estate group, at $2.5 billion, topping an offer from the Brascan Group. Shareholders would receive cash and a stake in a new, smaller, publicly traded company. The bidding may not be over as the chairman and founder, Paul D. Reichmann, is still considering an offer, executives close to Mr. Reichmann said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: From the Couch, the Jets Blame the Kicker
description: With their season in tatters and a botched field goal in overtime providing a focal point, the Jets all but wheeled a sofa into their locker room Monday to begin the analysis in the wake of their 31-28 loss to the Giants.

title: Europe Warns of Trade Retaliation Against U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Pascal Lamy, the European Union trade commissioner, said here today that if the United States failed to act quickly to end controversial export subsidies and lift steel tariffs, then trade retaliation by the European Union was "a racing certainty in mid-December."

title: Hope From an African Trouble Spot
description: Sudan, the largest country in Africa, has been at war for 36 of its 47 years. In the last 20 years more than two million people have died. But today there is hope for peace. The government in the north, which is largely Muslim, and the major guerrilla group in the largely Christian and animist south are on the brink of signing a peace agreement. Intense involvement by outside governments, including the Bush administration, made the difference. Continued attention will be crucial to the agreement's success.

title: Diplomatic Tiff Over Ship's Virus
description: Britons have been following the fortunes of a P & O liner, the Aurora, which has been steaming the Mediterranean from crisis to crisis. On Monday, its wanderings provoked the closing of the border between Spain and Gibraltar for the first time in decades (it only lasted 13 hours) and a diplomatic spat with Britain.

title: Assessing A Film That Lost Momentum
description: ''The Human Stain'' had all the right ingredients, or so it seemed. It had a cast with three top-tier actors: Anthony Hopkins, Ed Harris and, most lustrously of all, Nicole Kidman, fresh from her Academy Award-winning performance in ''The Hours.'' It had an Oscar-winning director in Robert Benton. And it had a much-praised literary source in the Philip Roth novel of the same name. Miramax, which had invested $8 million on the $24 million project, was so optimistic about the film as a prime contender in this year's Oscar race that it had planned to open it on 600 screens nationwide, the studio said.

title: Mattingly To Coach Yankees' Hitters
description: Don Mattingly, one of the most beloved Yankees of the past two decades, will return to the team on a full-time basis as the hitting coach. He will be introduced at a news conference at Yankee Stadium today, a person who was involved in the discussions with him said yesterday.

title: Small Schools: What's Lost? What's Gained?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Giuliani, Can't the City Sleep On It?
description: I had just settled in for a late-afternoon nap on Saturday. There I was, drifting off to sleep, when the phone rang. It was Rudolph W. Giuliani calling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, PHYLLIS (NEE FEIN)
description: GILBERT--Phyllis (nee Fein) of Englewood, NJ on November 3. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Erica, Andrea and Steve. Dear sister of Judith Lasser. Doting grandmother of Simon, Alex and Claire. She will be missed by all. Services Wednesday, November 5, at 11:30am (Wien & Wien, Hackensack). For information: 1-800-322-0533.

title: World Cup Schedule Change
description: The United States got an eight-month reprieve and will not begin to play qualifying matches for the 2006 World Cup until August 2004, instead of beginning the long road to Germany early next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLAPPER, ARTHUR
description: KLAPPER--Arthur. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Arthur Klapper, beloved brother of Martha Goldberg. We extend our deepest condolences to Martha and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Arrests of Dissident Iranians Seen as Hard-Line Retaliation
description: The two sons of a prominent dissident cleric, Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, were arrested Monday after they defied a ban on the use of an office, the Iranian Student News Agency reported.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ex-Police Officer Convicted In Ecstasy Case
description: A former city police officer was convicted yesterday of conspiracy to distribute ecstasy after a weeklong trial in federal court in Brooklyn. The former officer, James Vargo, brokered two deals for more than 10,000 ecstasy pills after he was dismissed from the police force in 2000, according to John Curran, an assistant United States attorney who, with Bryan Rose, prosecuted the case. At the time of the deals, Mr. Vargo worked as a bouncer at the nightclub Scores, Mr. Curran said. Mr. Vargo faces a maximum of 20 years in prison, but under federal sentencing guidelines will most likely receive no more than seven years, Mr. Curran said. Mr. Vargo's lawyer, Samuel Gregory, did not return a call seeking comment. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Right Light for Smoother Skin
description: A single session of laser treatment can reduce acne for three months, a study published in The Lancet medical journal has concluded.

title: African Anglican Leaders Outraged Over Gay Bishop in U.S.
description: Africa's Anglican leaders expressed fury on Monday at the consecration of a gay bishop in New Hampshire, renewing their intention to break from the American church and deepening an ideological fault line that crisscrossed the world.

title: Small Schools: What's Lost? What's Gained?
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Turkey Has Not Ruled Out Troops for Iraq, Ambassador Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Turkey's offer of troops for duty in Iraq remains on the table, but no soldiers would be sent without a formal invitation from the American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council, the Turkish ambassador to the United States said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ask Jeeves Names Chief Executive
description: Ask Jeeves Inc., owner of the Ask.com Internet search site, said yesterday that it named Steve Berkowitz, left, as chief executive, succeeding A. George Battle. Mr. Berkowitz, 44, will assume the position in January, Ask Jeeves said in a statement. He had previously been the president of the company, based in Emeryville, Calif. Mr. Battle, 59, has been named executive chairman of the board. Mr. Berkowitz has overseen Ask Jeeves' Web sites for three years. The company turned profitable a year ago because of higher sales of advertising on its sites. Mr. Battle, while supervising Mr. Berkowitz, had also overseen Ask Jeeves's business software division. The company sold that unit in July. Ask Jeeves shares rose 62 cents, to $19.83. They had surged more than elevenfold in the last year through Friday. Mr. Battle is succeeding Garrett Gruener, one of Ask Jeeves's founders, as chairman. Mr. Gruener will remain on the board, the company said.

title: Small Schools: What's Lost? What's Gained?
description: To the Editor:

title: Niedermayer's Short Summer Sets Him Up for Long Haul
description: Devils defenseman Scott Niedermayer entered another short summer vacation with a plan this year. He has played in four Stanley Cup finals in nine years, so he qualifies as an expert on what to do in the off-season.

title: As Population Grows Older, Upstate Towns Face a Crisis
description: In 1998, when Mark Thomas took office as county executive of Chautauqua County, the southwesternmost county in New York State, the county spent $13 million on health care for its poorest residents. Next year the bill is expected to reach $29 million, and the vast majority of that sum, which represents more than half the property taxes the county collects, will pay for medical care for Chautauqua's growing elderly population.

title: The Voice Of an Angel Takes Flight; A Teenager's Album Tops Britain's Classical Charts
description: Hayley Westenra is the stuff of dreams for record companies gloomy over falling sales of classical music. A bright-eyed 16-year-old with an angelic voice, she is close enough to womanhood to secure ample coverage in the girl-obsessed British press. Add to that, her warm soprano voice has just turned her new CD, ''Pure,'' into one of the fastest-selling classical debut albums ever.

title: At Sniper Trial, an Introductory Phase Ends With Arrest Details and a Clinical Phase Begins
description: For several weeks last fall, people watched Whitney Donahue, a supermarket refrigerator repairman, with nervousness bordering on terror. It was his truck, he says: a white Ford Econoline van, similar to the vehicle the police thought the Washington-area sniper was driving.

title: They Will Not Be Moved; A Bastion of Black History Amid S.I. Development
description: There is a certain defiance in the new coat of white paint along the bottom half of the A.M.E. Zion Church in Rossville on Staten Island. All around it, development waits impatiently.

title: Knicks Get Last Laugh On McGrady
description: Tracy McGrady might as well have laughed in his opponents' face. On Monday morning he said the Knicks were prone to folding, citing Orlando's overtime victory in the season opener.

title: Among the Newly Dead, a Soldier Who Was Grieving for His Mother
description: Sgt. Ernest Bucklew was a 5-foot-3-inch coal miner's son who got laid off from a vitamin factory, then joined the Army. For a time, he loved it.

title: A Burden Too Heavy to Put Down
description: Um Haydar was a 25-year-old Iraqi woman whose husband displeased Saddam Hussein's government. After he fled the country in 2000, some members of the Fedayeen Saddam grabbed her from her home and brought her out on the street. There, in front of her children and mother-in-law, two men grabbed her arms while another pulled her head back and beheaded her. Baath Party officials watched the murder, put her head in a plastic bag and took away her children.

title: First Prosecution Witness Called
description: Stephanie Pate, a former secretary of Thomas K. Welch, testified in federal court in Salt Lake City yesterday that five years ago, she released the so-called "Dear Sonia letter" that led to the 2002 Winter Olympics bribery investigation.

title: Picking Up Pieces of a Shattered Program
description: The fresh grave sits on a hill across from campus. Beneath a temporary headstone, sandwiched between wilting roses and browning gardenias, rests a souvenir school key chain.

title: Beating Nature's Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Sri Lankas Leader Suspends Parliament and Deploys Troops
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 4  In a surprise move, Sri Lanka's president suspended parliament, fired three top government ministers and deployed troops at key buildings in the capital of Colombo today, the state-run news media reported. The move sparked a political crisis in the country and fueled fears that a two-year cease-fire between government forces and ethnic Tamil rebels would collapse.

title: RAYTHEON WORKERS ACCEPT LABOR CONTRACT
description: Workers at a Raytheon Company plant in Tucson, Ariz., that makes Tomahawk cruise missiles voted to accept a revised labor contract, averting a strike that was to begin yesterday. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers Local 933, which represents about 2,100 of the plant's 10,000 employees, voted 50.3 percent to 49.7 percent to accept the contract, the union said. Union members had voted on Oct. 26 to strike, subject to a seven-day ''cooling off'' period, after rejecting a proposal that would have increased their share of health insurance premiums. Terms of the revised contract were not immediately available. Raytheon is based in Waltham, Mass.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Opens Challenge To Mugabe Election
description: The High Court, opening a long-delayed challenge to the validity of President Robert Mugabe's re-election victory last spring, heard lawyers for his political opponents charge that the election was ''stifled at birth'' by ballot-box stuffing, voter intimidation and fraudulent election monitoring. Morgan Tsvangirai, who leads the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, attended the opening of the proceeding, which had been delayed for 18 months by government challenges. Mr. Mugabe won 56 percent of the vote. Most foreign observers said the election was not fair. Opposition lawyers filed 200 pages of reports that they said documented election irregularities. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Deep in the Amazon, Vast Questions About the Climate
description: Viewed from the top of a tower 150 feet over an exuberant canopy of green, the vast Amazon jungle appears to be a neatly functioning organism. Trees in immeasurable numbers stretch away to the horizon here, their leaves open to the sun, eager to feed on the light that streams down from the sky and perforates the stifling tropical heat.

title: Corrections
