description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the online circulation by hackers of software from electronic voting systems developed by Diebold Election Systems and Sequoia Voting Systems misattributed a statement about the possibility of Sequoia's submitting its software to a computer security researcher. It was made by Alfie Charles, a Sequoia spokesman, not David Bear, a Diebold spokesman. The article also referred incorrectly to the source of the Sequoia software that was released. The source was a contractor used by one of Sequoia's customers, not one used by the company.

title: Secretary Testifies in Utah
description: Thomas K. Welch, one of the defendants in the Salt Lake City Olympic bribery trial, was ''very charismatic and persuasive,'' said his former secretary, Stephanie Pate, who testified yesterday that she was coaxed into helping the daughters of two International Olympic Committee members set up apartments as part of Utah's campaign to win the 2002 Winter Games.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Conjoined Twins Develop Infection
description: Clarence and Carl Aguirre, the 18-month-old Filipino twins joined at the head, have developed an infection, leading doctors to remove the tissue expanders inserted under their scalps. The expanders, which were inserted on Oct. 20, are used to stretch the skin enough to cover both skulls after their eventual separation. The removal was carried out yesterday in a 45-minute procedure at Children's Hospital at Montefiore in the Bronx. Surgeons said that the infection was not a major setback, and that the expanders would be reinserted. The boys and their mother were expected to return to Blythedale Children's Hospital, a rehabilitation center in Valhalla, N.Y., last night. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: U.N. Putting Two on Leave During Inquiry Into Iraq Bombing
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 4 — Two United Nations officials responsible for security at the Baghdad mission when it was bombed in August will be placed on leave while a team of independent experts determines blame for the security flaws at the mission, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Meet Roslyn Platt, a Customer Of Putnam. She's Not Amused.
description: Last week, Roslyn Platt read in her local paper that Putnam Investments, which manages some of her mutual funds, had become embroiled in an investigation by state and federal securities regulators.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Little Respite for Those Who Share in a Baby's Pain
description: Only 17 months old, Samuel Espinal is already a study in life's often cruel contradictions.

title: Corrections
description: The Shelf Life column in Arts & Ideas on Saturday, about the book ''The Dominion of the Dead'' by Robert Pogue Harrison, misstated the century when the philosopher Giambattista Vico, who also examined death, flourished. It was the 18th century, not the 16th.

title: Study Finds New Drug Acts Quickly on Clogged Arteries
description: Asmall study of heart disease patients testing a hypothesis so improbable that its principal investigator says he gave it a 1 in 10,000 chance of succeeding has found that just a few treatments with an experimental drug reversed what may be the equivalent of years' worth of plaque in coronary arteries.

title: Philip Chu, 83, Architect, Dies; Left Legacy of College Libraries
description: Philip M. Chu, an architect whose work included libraries at Amherst, Barnard and Bryn Mawr Colleges and at Princeton University, died on Oct. 27 at the Arcadia Residence, a home for the elderly in Honolulu. He was 83 and moved to Honolulu with his wife 14 years ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Telecom Profit
description: Italy's largest cellphone company, Telecom Italia Mobile, had net income of 977 million euros ($1.1 billion) in the third quarter after a loss of 43 million euros in the quarter a year earlier. The loss was reported on more than 1 billion euros in write-downs and one-time costs. Sales in the third quarter increased 9.8 percent, to 3.1 billion euros. Operating profit rose 8.6 percent, to 1.1 billion euros. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Giants Try to Straighten A Season Full of Twists
description: There are as many ways to look at the Giants' 4-4 record as there are players in the Giants' locker room, where the one uniting factor is a quote that stays on a dry-erase board in the doorway: ''Keep shoveling.''

title: Pediatricians Urged to Step Up Fight Against Obesity
description: Dr. Richard H. Carmona, the surgeon general, urged pediatricians on Monday to do more to combat childhood obesity, noting that many overweight children became overweight adults.

title: A Wayward Fish and the Artists Who Captured Him
description: Pixar goes underwater, and a blonde tries Washington. Humphrey Bogart climbs the career ladder, the western turns darker and a ''monster'' softer.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Tax Revenue Outlook Brightens
description: State income tax revenue has stabilized after a two-year decline that opened a billion-dollar hole in the state budget. The state, which has no sales tax, relies heavily on income taxes. Michael Kennedy, a state economist, said income tax revenues were up 6.3 percent for the first quarter of the 2004 fiscal year and 12.5 percent in September compared with the previous year. Mr. Kennedy said the figures reflected either an increase in jobs that has not shown up in employment figures or a rise in wages. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: One Recipe for a (Mostly) Emissions-Free Economy
description: Fueling civilization a half-century from now and stemming global warming is a titanic challenge. It is inspiring big ideas, but not nearly enough research to pull them off.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Schwarzenegger Fills 2 Posts
description: Gov.-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger announced his first major appointments, naming as education secretary Richard J. Riordan, the former Los Angeles mayor, and as finance director Donna Arduin, who had been on leave as the budget director in Florida. Ms. Arduin has been auditing the budget for Mr. Schwarzenegger. The appointment of Mr. Riordan was opposed by the California Teachers Association, which wanted the post eliminated because California has an elected superintendent of schools. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Dog on a Hot Tenement Roof

title: U.S. SUBPOENAED NEWMONT MINING ON PERU DISPUTE
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, the world's largest gold producer, said it was subpoenaed in February by the Justice Department for documents related to a shareholder's accusation of bribery in Peru. Peruvian prosecutors found no evidence of wrongdoing in the case, in which the company was accused of paying bribes to win control of the Yanacocha mine, Newmont said in a regulatory filing. The company said it was complying with the request, which involves documents from 1994 through 1999. Newmont, based in Denver, said its motion to dismiss the case was pending.

title: Iraqis Seek Justice, or Vengeance, For Victims of the Killing Fields
description: Until justice is done and Saddam Hussein is dead, Sadri Adab Diwan will carry with him the handwritten accusation that condemned his little sister to death.

title: As the Toll Rises, So Do the Doubts (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMO PAD
description: In a striking illustration of the growing strength of low-fare carriers, domestic passenger traffic at Kennedy International Airport in New York, long considered the gateway to the world, is about to outpace international traffic for the first time since the early 1980's.

title: California Says Fires Are Finally Contained
description: Officials declared the California wildfires tamed on Monday, 10 days after the blazes began their destructive rampage across a wide swath of Southern California.

title: Make Baghdad Pay
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEICHTER, ADRIAN
description: LEICHTER--Adrian, a young, talented artist with a strong and independent spirit who died suddenly of heart failure at age 39. She will be deeply missed by father, Robert; sister, Pamela; brothers, Adam & Christopher; sisters-in-law, Emily and Charlene, family and friends. Private services.

title: Peak Performance and Heavy Traveling, It Seems, Don't Mix
description: This summer, you might have noticed a business traveler at airport security slipping a watch -- or what appeared to be a watch -- off his or her wrist and placing it into the plastic dish. If so, you might have noticed that it was not a real timepiece but a gizmo of the sort Dick Tracy might wear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENZWEIG, MARGARET
description: ROSENZWEIG--Margaret. At 91, of natural causes. Beloved wife of the late Harley. Devoted mother of Elliott and Annmarie Rosenzweig, Bobbi Shmaruk and Rich Rosenberg, Ilene and Donald Kaplan. Dear sister of Marilyn Epstein. Loving grandmother of nine and great grandmother of four. Service 1 PM Wednesday at ''Schwartz Bros.Jeffer'' Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Difficult Days in Iraq
description: Congress gave final approval yesterday to President Bush's request for a further $70 billion in military and civil spending on Iraq, and the United States appears to be settling in for what Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld now acknowledges will be a ''long, hard slog.'' Sunday's missile attack on a military transport helicopter, killing 16 United States soldiers and wounding 20 others, is a grim reminder of how hard this war has already become for a growing number of American families. How long the road ahead now stretches is impossible to say. President Bush has not yet presented any plausible long-term exit strategy. Congress should insist on one before acquiescing to future installments of military spending.

title: As the Toll Rises, So Do the Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Can't Stop Rookie
description: Striker Pat Noonan of the New England Revolution has the MetroStars' number. It is eight -- and counting. Noonan, a rookie from Indiana University, the ninth pick over all in the Major League Soccer draft, continued his scoring spree against the MetroStars when he notched the insurance goal in the Revolution's first-round playoff match Saturday night at Giants Stadium. The return game in the two-game total-goals series is scheduled for Sunday afternoon in Foxboro, Mass.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Damage Award Grows In 1993 Police Shooting
description: A Manhattan jury has added millions of dollars in damages to those awarded in the death of a woman killed by police officers firing at an armed bank robber who was using her as a human shield. In July 1999, a jury awarded $5.7 million, later reduced to $4 million, to the family of Aurea Bonnie Vargas, 41, who was killed in 1993 when the robber took her hostage on Riverside Drive. The robber was also killed. The 1999 jury ruled that the six officers, who fired 29 shots, had acted negligently. On Friday, another Manhattan jury ruled that the police had acted with reckless disregard, a more serious charge, and awarded a further $3 million in damages to Ms. Vargas's estate and $1 million to her brother, Ramon Santiago, who witnessed the shooting. The city did not appeal the first verdict, but lawyers for the city say they will appeal this one. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: New Ranking System for Marathoners
description: If football, basketball, golf, tennis and myriad other sports have ranking systems to help determine who are the best, why not marathon running? After all, the best marathoners do not always race head-on, even in the Olympics or world championships.

title: IN DIE-HARD CITY, G.I.'S ARE ENEMY
description: In the epicenter of anti-American hatred, even the most generous of gestures is viewed with a suspicious eye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERNER, MURIEL (HECHT)
description: SILBERNER--Muriel (Hecht). Beloved wife of Dr. Herbert B. Loving mother of Judy and Joanne. Mother-in-law of Haim Erder. Dear grandmother of Mattan and Michal. Service Tuesday, 1pm, Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ 07039

title: Greenwich School Bus Drivers' Strike Ends Hours After It Began
description: Nearly 100 striking bus drivers agreed on Monday to cut short the strike they had begun just hours earlier in an effort to obtain better health coverage, more paid vacation and something more than the $18 an hour they already get.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bush and Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Look at an Old Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Fishers Island: 2 Plane Crash Victims Identified
description: Two people whose small plane plunged into Long Island Sound on Sunday morning were identified yesterday by the police. They are Edward Rosen, 60, and Ilse Sorensen, 42, both of New London, Conn. The couple were engaged to be married and were flying around Fishers Island in a World War II-era yellow biplane when the plane dropped 500 feet into the water. The couple and friends in two other planes took off together around 11 a.m. from Westerly State Airport in Rhode Island, said Mark Simmons, who was in one of the other planes. Although Mr. Rosen was an experienced stunt pilot, he was not doing any such flying on Sunday, the state police said. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Choices for Election Day
description: Today is Election Day. All the contests are local, so the results will affect everyday lives -- from trash removal and taxes to safe streets, good schools and clean government. For some of the most competitive races and the five questions on the New York City ballot, here are our recommendations, beginning with just this: Vote. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Beating Nature's Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Ways to Save the Planet and Get Healthy, Too
description: As winter weather approaches and November winds start to bite, you might be tempted to think that global warming is a myth. But you would be very wrong.

title: Bronx Gunfire Kills 2
description: Two people were shot dead and a third was wounded when gunfire erupted yesterday in a Bronx playground, the police said.

title: HealthSouth's Former Chief Is Expected To Be Indicted
description: The Justice Department is expected to announce today the indictment of Richard M. Scrushy, the ousted chief executive and founder of HealthSouth, on securities fraud and other charges, government officials and lawyers close to the case said yesterday.

title: Man Says He Was Taken Off List of Witnesses to Shooting
description: A Borough Park artist who saw the police shooting of Gidone Busch testified yesterday that an officer crossed his name off a list of possible witnesses minutes after the incident because the artist said that for no reason, ''you just shot him.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Asbury Park: Springsteen In Surprise Performance
description: Bruce Springsteen made an unexpected appearance at the Stone Pony nightclub on Saturday night, taking part in a benefit for the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. He joined Garland Jeffreys, Joe Grushecky and the Houserockers, Soozie Tyrell, and, at concert's end, the actor Michael J. Fox, who has Parkinson's. When Mr. Grushecky suggested they do ''Murder Incorporated,'' one of Mr. Springsteen's signature songs, the Boss had a problem. ''I don't know the words,'' he said. Mr. Grushecky responded, ''It's O.K., I've written them down.'' A stagehand put a sheet of paper on the stage, but Mr. Springsteen said, ''It's too far away.'' Two fans grabbed the sheet and held it up for him. Joe Brescia (NYT)

title: Surfer on Her Way Up, Brought Down by a Shark
description: She was a member of the ''dawn patrol.'' Every morning before sunrise, Bethany Hamilton, a 13-year-old and one of the country's top female amateur surfers, would follow the pull of the turquoise water and head to a favorite reef, to defy gravity on a wave.

title: Weighing In on Ending Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, DOROTHY C.
description: JOHNSON--Dorothy C., 84, Bronx, NY. Retired educator and businesswoman. President, Johnson Security Bureau. Loving mother of Charles, Sr. and Rev. Suzan Johnson Cook. Funeral Thursday, November 6, 11am. For info Rendall Memorial Presbyterian Church, NYC. 718-537-7268.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pinnacle's Top Executive Resigns
description: Pinnacle Systems Inc., which makes video-editing software, said yesterday that J. Kim Fennel had resigned as chief executive, president and a director. Charles Vaughan, a board member and a partner in private investment firm VLCO Investments, has been named interim chief executive officer and president while the board searches for a permanent successor for Mr. Fennel, Pinnacle said in a statement. Mr. Vaughan, who has held senior management and financial positions at various companies, worked as president of General Electric's General Electric Technical Services unit, as well as vice president for auditing and chief financial officer of G.E.'s international and consumer products sectors, the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., said. Shares of Pinnacle fell 9 cents, to $6.86.

title: Furor Over Anti-Semitism Leads to German Officers Firing
description: BERLIN, Nov. 4  The commander of an elite German special forces army unit was dismissed today after he praised a conservative parliamentarian for a speech that has been widely criticized here as anti-Semitic.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: ACCORD ON HALTING USE OF FLAME RETARDANT The Environmental Protection Agency said it had reached an agreement with the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation to phase out two types of a widely used flame retardant, polybrominated diphenyl ether or PBDE, by the end of 2004. Scientists have detected rising levels of the two retardants in wildlife and breast milk of nursing mothers. Following Europe's lead, California in August became the first state to ban the chemicals, the penta and octa forms of PBDE. Great Lakes Chemical, based in Indianapolis, is a main manufacturer of the two chemicals. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Marathoners (heart) New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Oct. 25 about wildlife destruction in Zimbabwe misstated the location of the Gwayi Valley Conservancy, once home to thousands of impala and hundreds of elephants. It is in the western part of Zimbabwe, not the eastern part.

title: CBS Is Said to Cancel Reagan Mini-Series
description: Under pressure from Republican and conservative groups, CBS is expected to announce as early as today that it is canceling its plans to run a two-part mini-series in November deconstructing the Ronald Reagan presidency, two people close to the decision said last night.

title: Socialist Realism Broke the Promises, but There's the Art
description: Art exhibitions can grow out of long-nourished ambitions or sudden inspiration. ''Dream Factory Communism,'' a show of Stalin-era works at the Schirn Art Gallery here, grew out of a taxi ride.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: An Iceman Close to Home

title: Foul Water and Air Part of Cost Of the Boom in China's Exports
description: The first thing that struck Shen Yunxiang when he descended into the bowels of Hisun Pharmaceutical was the smell, or rather the lack of it. It was as if the sewage system had been scrubbed with ammonia, he said, leaving only a sickly sweet aroma strong enough to overpower the stench of human waste.

title: A 12-Year-Old Nude Model Negotiating Adolescence
description: The ostensible subject of ''Tatjana in Color,'' an adventurous historical drama by Julia Jordan, is the inner life of adolescent girls. Set in 1912 in Neulengbach, a small Austrian town 20 miles from Vienna, it is based on an episode in the life of the artist Egon Schiele, who was jailed for obscenity for using an under-age girl as a nude model.

title: INSIDE
description: Graham Will Leave Senate

title: Sales Fell in October for G.M. and Ford
description: Reporting one of the domestic automobile industry's toughest months yet this year, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company said on Monday that sales fell in October from the month last year.

title: Letters
description: Weighing In on Ending Life

title: A.C.L.U. Suit Challenges State Lobbying Commission
description: Setting up a showdown over free speech, the New York Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit Monday charging that the state's lobbying laws have been unconstitutionally extended to cover grass-roots advocacy.

title: EXTENSIVE FLAWS AT MUTUAL FUNDS CITED AT HEARING
description: The mutual fund industry, plagued by a series of recent scandals, was battered on Monday by new details of widespread trading abuses, the removal of the top executive at a big fund company and the disclosure by federal regulators that the industry faced an imminent wave of government lawsuits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZELNICK, MORRIS
description: ZELNICK--Morris, 89, of Jersey City, NJ on November 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Estelle, father of Robert and Wendy. Loving grandfather of Hillary, Adrienne, Alana, Sarah and David

title: White House Backs Limits On Spending For Medicare
description: The Bush administration joined House Republicans on Monday in pushing a proposal that would force Congress to vote on possible cutbacks in Medicare if the costs of the program, including new drug benefits, grow faster than expected.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Carlos May Testify In Terror Trial
description: Ilich Ramrez Snchez, the terrorist known as Carlos, who is serving a life sentence in France for terrorist activities in Europe in the 1970's and 80's, may testify in a German trial next year, court officials said. A Berlin prosecutor said the French Justice Ministry had authorized Mr. Ramrez's appearance at the trial of a former top associate, Johannes Weinrich, who is charged in 6 cases of murder and 153 cases of attempted murder linked to bomb attacks in France, Germany and Greece from 1975 to 1983. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Research Suggests Therapy Approach
description: When Sidney Guimont's learning disabilities were diagnosed as fetal alcohol syndrome 14 years ago, no therapy was available to help her or others similarly damaged by alcohol.

title: The Democrats And the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Restriction On Oil Shares
description: The Stock Exchange of Thailand imposed an 11-day restriction on trading of shares in the heavily indebted Thai Petrochemical Industry, citing unusual movements in the stock price. The exchange prohibited brokerage firms from allowing clients to buy shares of Thai Petrochemical on credit, known as margin trading. Thai Petrochemical is reportedly nearing a deal with its creditors on obtaining as much as $170 million in working capital to buy crude oil. The company is also completing a plan to restructure its debt. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Weighing In on Ending Life
description: To the Editor:

title: An Option for the Needle-Shy: Spray Flu Vaccine
description: As the season of scratchy throats, stuffy noses and achy muscles arrives, those seeking to protect themselves against flu's miseries have a new option. Instead of an injection, they can receive a painless spritz in each nostril to ward off influenza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROMERO, JONATHAN ED WARDS
description: ROMERO -- Jonathan Ed wards, 65, at home, on October 24, 2003 after a long courageous battle with Multiple System Atrophy. Descendant of early American theologian, Jonathan Edwards, he is survived by his wife, Elaine, sons Jonathan and Gregory, and granddaughter Juliana. Founder and CEO of Sugarland Oil Co. Former Chairman and board member of The Tuxedo Club and Trustee of Berkshire School. Served on the Vestry of St. Mary's in Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, NY. Memorial service November 8 at 11 AM at St. Mary's. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the church in his memory.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FAO INC., King of Prussia, Pa., parent of the F.A.O. Schwarz toy stores, said it had hired an investment banker to help it raise additional capital and would use the money for general corporate purposes and to pay for the installation of boutiques in Saks stores.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, has become outdated. Steve Tyrell's engagement this week was canceled; he has been replaced by Mark Murphy (tonight through Thursday) and Curtis Stigers (Friday through Sunday).

title: Taking a Gamble on the Cosmos
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Subsidizes Companies to Buy Subsidized Cotton
description: Hidden in plain sight, a federal farm subsidy program is paying nearly $1.7 billion to American agribusiness and manufacturers to buy American cotton that is already one of the most highly subsidized crops in the world, according to figures compiled by the program's critics.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Oct. 25 about wildlife destruction in Zimbabwe misstated the location of the Gwayi Valley Conservancy, once home to thousands of impala and hundreds of elephants. It is in the western part of Zimbabwe, not the eastern part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERSON, STANLEY. DEVOTED HUSBAND OF DIANE (NEE GOETZ)
description: PERSON--Stanley. Devoted husband of Diane (nee Goetz). Beloved father of Rabbi Hara Person, U.A.H.C., and Jennifer Person. Cherished grandfather of Liya, Yonatan and Goldi. Dear brother of Sam, the late Joseph, Frances Kaufmann and Isabel Pershan. Services 12 noon, Tuesday, Gramercy Park Chapels, 157 2nd Avenue, NYC.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Prosecutors Won't Seek Death Penalty In Killing
description: The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, left, said he would not seek the death penalty for a Brooklyn man charged with fatally shooting a man in the street. In a statement issued late Friday, Mr. Hynes said that Tyrone Peters, 33, shot Winston Williams on March 31 in East Flatbush five days after Mr. Williams testified against him before a Brooklyn grand jury in a gun possession case. If convicted, Mr. Peters faces a possible sentence of life in prison without parole. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: 'America Will Never Run,' Bush Says of Iraq
description: One day after the deadliest attack against American forces since the fall of Baghdad, President Bush said on Monday that he would not be intimidated by the guerrilla campaign in Iraq and vowed again that the United States would stay there as long as it took to achieve stability.

title: As the Toll Rises, So Do the Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Ringing Warning Bells About Humans' Impact
description: ''Six Modern Plagues, and How We Are Causing Them,'' by Dr. Mark Jerome Walters. Island Press, $22.

title: The Littlest Clotheshorse
description: During the spring 2004 collections in Paris last month, a visit to Colette, the didactically hip boutique on the Right Bank, turned up a curiosity unrivaled by anything that appeared on the runway. There, one spotted a black boucl jacket from the label E2, which had been refashioned from a vintage Chanel and miniaturized to toddler size, the Chanel label still stitched into the back. The demographic for such an item seemed specific and clear: all those 3- and 4-year-olds who, after mornings spent making Play-Doh figurines of Nina Simone, need something special to pluck from their cubbies for lunch at the Crillon.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Borland Names New Executive
description: The Borland Software Corporation, whose programs are used to create computer applications, has named Scott Arnold as chief operating officer and executive vice president to help shape the company's strategy, product development and marketing. Mr. Arnold had worked with software companies the last 15 years at the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, Borland said. Mr. Arnold helped found McKinsey's Silicon Valley office, Borland said. Borland sells programming tools like blocks of software code to clients like Intel and Oracle. Borland missed its third-quarter sales estimate because sales representatives had trouble getting orders for a new package of tools as a single product after the programs had been sold separately, the chief executive, Dale Fuller, said in an interview last month.

title: Defections Lead to a Shake-Up at Putnam
description: Lawrence J. Lasser, the embattled chief executive of Putnam Investments, resigned yesterday, less than a week after federal and state securities regulators sued the mutual fund company and two of its portfolio managers for fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHER, WALTER J., M.D.
description: MAHER--Walter J., M.D., F.A.C.F., 86, on October 29. Former Chief of Ophthalmology at St. Clare's Hospital in New York City. Beloved husband of Jane T. Maher. Memorial Mass Saturday, November 8, 9:30am, St. Denis Church, 90 Union Avenue, Manasquan, NJ. For more information, O'Brien Funeral Home, Wall, NJ. 732-449-6900.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Atari Reports 2nd-Quarter Loss
description: Atari Inc., the publisher of videogame titles like ''Enter the Matrix,'' said yesterday that it had a second-quarter loss as sales fell 45 percent in a traditionally slow time of the year and as it delayed some releases. The net loss for the quarter ended Sept. 30 was $28.7 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with net income of $731,000, or 1 cent, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales at the company, based in New York, fell to $60.6 million from $109.4 million. Atari said it had introduced fewer titles in the second period in order to maximize Christmas sales. Sales are concentrated in the first, third and fourth quarters, the company has said. Atari had the 10th-best-selling game in September, ''Temple of Elemental Evil,'' according to NPD Group's NPD Techworld. For its current third quarter ending Dec. 31, the company expects profit of $28 million to $36 million, or 23 cents to 30 cents a share, on sales of $215 million to $235 million. ''We decided to release less titles during the slow quarter to maximize results into Christmas,'' Bruno Bonnell, the chairman and chief executive, said on a conference call after the report. The shares rose as much as 18 cents to $4.15 in extended trading after the report. They added 11 cents to $3.97 in regular trading.

title: Microsoft To License I.B.M. Chips
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it had licensed I.B.M. microchip technology for use in its Xbox game consoles, a step that could help make I.B.M. the leading chip maker in the video game business.

title: Profit at Kellog Rises
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) - The Kellogg Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 14 percent, topping Wall Street's expectations, on a 7 percent increase in sales. It raised its outlook for the year.

title: A Las Vegas theme for some blue-chip names.
description: DECADES after Elvis Presley warbled ''Viva Las Vegas,'' marketers, agencies and media companies are lustily joining the chorus, flooding the commercial culture with images of gambling and Las Vegas to woo consumers.

title: Prosecutors Seek to Retry Ex-Banker
description: NEW YORK (AP) -- Federal prosecutors said Tuesday they will retry Frank Quattrone, the former star investment banker whose first trial on obstruction-of-justice charges ended in a hung jury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANNEY, BEATRICE LILIENFELD
description: TANNEY--Beatrice Lilienfeld 91. On November 2. Wife of the late Allen D. Tanney, M.D. Survived by Mildred Corning, many good friends including Elizabeth and Gabriel Perdomo who took loving care of her to the end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEARY, MARY ALICE (MIMI)
description: NEARY--Mary Alice (Mimi) of Montclair on November 1, 2003. Beloved mother of Lisa Neary and her husband Geoffrey Whelan and Mary Louise Rubin and her husband John; sister of Roberta Bennett and A. Frederick Gerstell; adored grandmother of Oliver and Eleanor Whelan and Madeleine and Caleb Rubin. A mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Wednesday at 11:00 AM at St. Cassian's Church, Upper Montclair, NJ. Donations may be made to the New Jersey Audubon Society, PO Box 693 Bernardsville, NJ 07924

title: Valentine Is Returning To Japan
description: Holding an overseas grudge is apparently not Bobby Valentine's style, but managing is, and after one year out of uniform Valentine will be back in the dugout in 2004.

title: Government Wants Captain Interviewed
description: Lawyers for the government urged a federal judge yesterday to order Michael J. Gansas, the captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed on Oct. 15, to submit to an interview by federal investigators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOMSY, OLGA
description: HOMSY--Olga, died November 1, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Ernest. Survived by her loving children Joanne, Jackie, Jerry, Teena and Paul, 13 devoted grandchildren, her eight great-grandchildren, and her brother Paul and sister Yvonne. Dignity and grace defined her life. She was a blessing to all. Respects at the McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 3rd Ave, Bayridge, Brooklyn on Tuesday November 4th from 25pm & 7-9pm. Mass at Saint Anselm's Church, 82nd St & 4th Ave, Bayridge, Brooklyn at 11:45am Wednesday, November 5th.

title: This Can't Go On
description: Academic economists often cite Stein's Law, a principle enunciated by the late Herbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Nixon administration. The law comes with various wordings; my favorite is: ''Things that can't go on forever, don't.'' Believe it or not, that's a useful reminder.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline's Profit Grows
description: Ryanair Holdings, the discount airline, reported a 14 percent increase in profit for the six months that ended Sept. 30, to 175.5 million euros ($201.1 million) after taxes, on revenues that rose 28 percent, to 596.4 million euros. Passenger numbers rose 45 percent, to 11.3 million, but the carrier will re-evaluate its Swedish routes, which are doing poorly, the chief executive, Michael O'Leary, above, said. Ryanair said that it had cut its average ticket price by 12 percent and that it would open 13 more routes. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Sharpton Scheduled to Serve As 'Saturday Night Live' Host
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's chances of winning the Democratic presidential nomination may seem slim. But the producers of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' believe his many one-liners at the televised debates have already made him the undisputed king of campaign comedy.

title: ELIZABETH ARDEN TO CUT 10% OF WORKERS IN U.S.
description: The fragrance and skin-care company Elizabeth Arden Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its distribution operations in the United States into a single location and cut about 10 percent of its domestic work force, or about 100 jobs. Under the plan, which is expected to be completed by March, the company's domestic distribution and warehouse operations will move to Roanoke, Va. Elizabeth Arden expects the restructuring to save about $2 million to $4 million in the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, 2005, and about $4 million to $6 million annually in the years following.

title: Front Row
description: Gwen Stefani Joins the Fashion Fray

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHORTALL, KATHLEEN DEADY
description: SHORTALL--Kathleen Deady; on Thursday, October 30, 2003 of Washington, D.C. Beloved mother of John Shortall. Also survived by daughter-in-law Sarah Shortall. She was pre-deceased by husband Thomas Gleason Shortall. Mass of Christian Burial 10am Wednesday, November 5 at St. Agnes Catholic Church, 1914 North Randolph St., Arlington, Va; followed by a reception at the Church Hall. Interment private. Family has requested no flowers. For information Murphy Funeral Home, Arlington, Va.

title: Fiscal Survey Says Hospitals Are Weakest In New York
description: Hospitals in New York State are by far the nation's weakest financially -- so weak that nearly half of them have a hard time raising the money needed to invest in renovated wards, new ambulances and improved computer systems, according to a national analysis released last week.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: ACTIVISTS SEAL SUBWAYS Early-morning commuters in Barcelona found 70 subway entrances nailed shut by anti-globalization activists. Pamphlets left at the sealed subway stops throughout the metropolitan area demanded the release of anti-globalization protesters arrested in Salonica, Greece, in June. Two local youths were arrested.    Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Officer Found Guilty In Homicide
description: A New York City police sergeant accused of causing the death of two people in a drunken driving accident while he was off duty was found guilty yesterday on two counts of criminally negligent homicide. The sergeant, William Miley, 30, was returning from a Long Island bar in May 2001 when his car slammed into another one stopped at a red light. Two passengers in the back seat died. He has been on restricted duty since the accident. It was his second trial: a mistrial was declared in February when jurors were unable to reach a verdict after seven days of deliberations. Sentencing is scheduled for Dec. 3; the sergeant faces up to four years in prison. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Auto Workers Contract
description: Metalworkers at the Ford Motor Company and Mercedes Benz voted to end a strike that for five days has cut Brazil's auto production by as much as a third, but strikers at Volkswagen refused to return to work until they received a better pay offer. Jos Lopez Feijo, leader of the ABC Metalworkers' Union, which called the strike in So Paulo last Tuesday, said workers at Ford and Mercedes voted to accept an offer made late Friday. General Motors had avoided a strike with a negotiated agreement. He did not disclose details of the new offers. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Yukos Expected to Name American as Company's Chief
description: Yukos Oil is expected to announce on Tuesday that Simon G. Kukes, a Russian-born American executive well known in the Russian oil industry, will succeed Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky as chief executive. Mr. Khodorkovsky resigned on Monday, moving to insulate his oil company from his legal troubles.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 369 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: CAMPAIGN TACTICS BEING REVERSED AS EVENTS SHIFT
description: In Iowa on Monday, Howard Dean was talking not about the economy, but about the deadly turmoil in Iraq, and what it would mean for the presidential race.

title: Battle Over Nonpartisan Elections Remains Spirited to the End
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton added her name to the list of Democratic leaders opposing nonpartisan elections, her voice going out yesterday to thousands of New Yorkers, urging them to vote against a referendum on the ballot in today's election.

title: FIRST HEALTH SHARES DROP AFTER PROFIT WARNING
description: The First Health Group, a provider of health-benefits services, cut its 2004 earnings estimate yesterday, setting off a 25 percent decline in its share price. The company, based in Downers Grove, Ill., said it expected flat 2004 earnings, compared with a previous estimate of 15 percent growth. The new estimate of $1.50 to $1.55 a share for 2004 is below Wall Street's expectation of $1.82 a share. First Health said the lowered forecasts were prompted by a loss of customers at its private preferred provider organization business and a decline in projections for corporate accounts, among other factors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUME, THOMAS
description: HUME--Thomas. Architect, Stamford, CT, died October 31, at 75. He was past President of the Trustees of the Ferguson Library and of Family and Children's Services, both in Stamford. An avid sailor, he was a crew member aboard the 1966 Mallory Cup winner. He is survived by his wife Tulita Mejia Hume; his children, Mary Elise Papke, Connie Hume Rodman, Tony, Emmett Butler, John Linus and Maggie Hume; four sisters, Dorothy Knapp, Brigid O'Brien, Justine and Mary Louise Hume; 10 grandchildren and one step-grandchild. Funeral Mass November 6, 11 AM, St. Clement, 535 Fairfield Ave, Stamford. In lieu of flowers contributions to Friends of the Ferguson Library, 1 Public Library Plaza, Stamford, CT 06901.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Airline To Issue Shares
description: Virgin Blue, a discount airline that has won 30 percent of the Australian market in three years, plans to sell about 25 percent of its assets next month in a public offering worth an estimated $400 million Australian dollars ($283 million). The Patrick Corporation, a listed Australian logistics group that shares control with Virgin Group, is expected to wind up with a controlling 45 percent stake, with Virgin Group retaining 30 percent. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Isles Blake Is Hurt
description: Islanders center Jason Blake will be out about two weeks because of a sprained right knee, the team said yesterday. Blake collided with Daniel Alfredsson of the Ottawa Senators during the Islanders' 6-3 victory on Monday night. Blake, with 4 goals and 4 assists in 11 games, will be replaced by Justin Mapletoft, who was called up from the Islanders' affiliate in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Bush Says Iraq Attacks Dont Rise to Level of Major Combat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  President Bush said today that despite the deadly attack on an American helicopter on Sunday, the United States was no longer involved in major combat in Iraq. And he insisted that Saddam Hussein is no longer a danger.

title: Senate Control at Stake in Costly New Jersey Election Fight
description: New Jersey's legislative campaigns drew to a close on Monday with a flurry of negative television advertisements, predictions of low voter turnout and polls suggesting that either party might seize control of the evenly split State Senate.

title: Atomic Agency Chief Urges Global Controls on Nuclear Fuel
description: The director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, citing the growing threat of nuclear terrorism, urged the United Nations on Monday to consider imposing multinational control over the production of nuclear material that could be used in weapons.

title: Money Magazine Appoints New Agency
description: Money Magazine Gives

title: Islanders Finally Make the Senators Feel Unwelcome
description: The Islanders' Jason Wiemer shoved one of those lazy shots from center ice in the second period Monday night, the kind no one ever expects to go in, certainly not with a goaltender present. Ottawa Senators goalie Patrick Lalime crouched to stop the puck, but it somehow squirted by him to give the Islanders a two-goal lead.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Houston; Oil, Yes, but Also Culture and Fine Dining
description: FLAT on its back during the oil bust of the early 1980's, Houston diversified its economy as it rebounded in the 1990's. It is still the energy capital of the world, and the headquarters of ConocoPhillips, the El Paso Corporation, the Halliburton Company and other oil patch giants, but it is also emerging as a center for trade, transport and other industries.

title: Afghans' King Receives Draft Of Constitution
description: A new draft constitution for Afghanistan was unveiled Monday and formally presented to the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, at a ceremony on the grounds of the presidential palace.

title: Market Place; Does anyone want to buy the American Stock Exchange? It is looking for a merger partner.
description: UNABLE to sell the American Stock Exchange, NASD is giving the exchange back to its members. The transaction comes with a dowry, indicating that no one was willing to pay for the exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ULRICH, ROBERT M.
description: ULRICH--Robert M. Died November 1, 2003. A Memorial Service will be held today 6pm, Church of St. Savior, Brooklyn. Contributions to Cabrini Hospice.

title: A New Look at an Old Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Toll Rises, So Do the Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Secrets Spilled Between the Floors
description: Protecting patient confidentiality does not always make it into the elevator, according to a new study that found such lapses to be relatively common.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAVANAGH, CAROLINE PRATT
description: CAVANAGH--Caroline Pratt, 84, of Wilmington, Delaware died on October 31st, 2003. Beloved wife of James B. Cavanagh, mother of Katie C. Maslow, Sheila P. Marshall, James F. Cavanagh, Gary A. Santora. Grandmother of five, great-grandmother of one. Memorial services Wednesday, November 5, 2003 at 10 a.m. at Christ Church, Wilmington. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Children & Families First, 2005 Baynard Blvd, Wilmington, DE 19802.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLORIO, IRIS
description: FLORIO--Iris. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our cherished member, Iris Florio. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Services will be held at Temple Sinai of Roslyn on Tuesday, November 4 2003 at 12pm. Rabbi Michael A. White Carol Weinstock, President

title: PROVIDENT BANKSHARES TO BUY SOUTHERN FINANCIAL
description: The Provident Bankshares Corporation, one of Maryland's largest banks, has agreed to buy Southern Financial Bancorp for $330 million in cash and stock to add branches in the Washington area. Provident will pay 1.0875 shares and $11.125 in cash for each share of Southern Financial, or a total value of $44.50 a share, Provident said. The total price is 19 percent more than Southern Financial's closing price on Friday of $37.27. Southern Financial, based in Warrenton, Va., expects to have $1.5 billion in assets and 33 offices by the first quarter. Provident is the holding company for Provident Bank of Maryland. It has assets of $4.9 billion and 116 offices and is based in Baltimore.

title: As the Toll Rises, So Do the Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Graham to Retire, Dealing Blow to Democrats
description: Senator Bob Graham, a moderate Democrat with a long streak of victories, announced on Monday that he would not seek a fourth term in the United States Senate, adding a new hurdle for Democrats trying to recapture the Senate next year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the gun-control stance of Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, referred incorrectly at one point, in some editions, to the firearm he used on a pheasant hunt in Iowa. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was a shotgun, not a rifle.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about Noah's curse on the descendants of his son Ham and its relation to the concept of race misstated a view of Benjamin Braude, the co-director of Boston College's program in Middle Eastern and Islamic studies. He says that he believes that there was little or no color-based identity in the ancient Near East and in the Hebrew Bible. He does not disagree with that assertion by another scholar, David M. Goldenberg.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If it had been one, I could forgive. If it had been two, I could forgive. But three -- three including this young, innocent girl -- no, I cannot forgive. Someone has to pay for the slaughter.''

title: CEPHALON TO BUY CIMA LABS, BEATING OUT AAIPHARMA
description: Cephalon Inc., which makes drugs to treat neurological disorders, has agreed to buy Cima Labs Inc. for about $515 million to add a technology that allows pills to dissolve quickly in the mouth. Cephalon raised its price from an offer made in August and topped a bid by AaiPharma Inc. by agreeing to pay $34 a share for Cima. AaiPharma said it had received an $11.5 million payment because Cima broke its agreement. With the purchase of Cima, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., Cephalon gains a technology for fast-dissolving pills that patients can take without swallowing. Cima is also developing a competitor to Cephalon's painkiller Actiq.

title: As the Toll Rises, So Do the Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Review Suits on H.M.O. Policies
description: In a case of potentially great significance for managed-care companies and their patients, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether health maintenance organizations can be sued for damages for refusing to cover necessary medical treatment.

title: Severe Copter Injuries Treated in Germany
description: Sixteen American soldiers hurt in a deadly attack on their helicopter in Iraq on Sunday are being treated at a military hospital here for broken bones, spinal fractures, burns and other injuries.

title: Maker of Arm & Hammer Reports Profit Rise
description: By Bloomberg News

title: Letter From the Everglades; On a Silent Landscape, an Environmental War Endures
description: The airboat signs on Highway 41 start just west of Miami, where the stucco sprawl of Little Havana gives way to South Florida's vast, mucky wilderness of saw grass, mangroves and cypress trees.

title: Those Books Look Good? Imagine Reading Them
description: IT doesn't take much solo snooping to deduce that Nancy Bass -- the third-generation owner-operator of the Strand Book Stores, New York City's overflowing repository of the printed page -- keeps her office at the flagship store conspicuously, even suspiciously, bookless.

title: On Web and TV, Parents' Allies Call Child-Starving Claims False
description: Nearly two weeks after Raymond and Vanessa Jackson were arrested on charges of grotesquely starving four adopted boys, the facts behind the case have become the subject of an increasingly contentious war of words, faxes, Web sites and spin in an attempt to shape public opinion.

title: CBS Is Reconsidering Mini-Series on Reagan
description: Under pressure from Republicans and conservative groups, CBS is weighing a decision to scrap a completed four-hour mini-series, ''The Reagans,'' an unflattering portrait of former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, according to a person involved in the production.

title: Some Are More Easily Led Down the Garden Path Than Others
description: American Ballet Theater danced what it called a ''family friendly'' program of works at City Center on Sunday afternoon, pieces chosen to entertain audiences young and old. They were great fun, and were all choreographically good works of their kinds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROCHELLE, THOMAS, ALFRED PETER
description: ROCHELLE - THOMAS -Alfred Peter. Age 88, devoted husband and loving father, passed away peacefully at his home in West Palm Beach, FL, November 1, 2003 with his loving wife, Cathy Maxwell Rochelle-Thomas, by his side. Born in London, England on April 8, 1915, Peter was a proud WWII veteran whose plane was shot down defending England. After the war, Mr. Rochelle-Thomas returned to the family business, J. Rochelle-Thomas Antiques that had been established by his grandfather in England. Eventually Peter moved the business and his family to New York where he became well known and respected for his expertise, collections and knowledge of fine porcelain and art. After retiring to Bermuda, Mr. Rochelle-Thomas returned to Palm Beach to open Palm Beach Antiques, Inc. with his two sons. Mr. Rochelle-Thomas has held several Royal Warrants and was known and respected by many for his knowledge and authority, including Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, and Queen Elizabeth II. He was highly regarded by Christies and Sotheby's auction houses, which came to him often seeking his knowledge and opinions. He was a member of the British Antiques Dealers Association, which had been established by his grandfather, its first president, in 1918. Mr. Rochelle-Thomas is predeceased by, Alfred W. Rochelle - Thomas and David Rochelle-Thomas, his sons with his former wife, Alfreda Rochelle-Thomas, who survives him. He leaves to cherish his memory his wife, Cathy Maxwell RochelleThomas of West Palm Beach; and his daughter Sara Rochelle-Thomas, his grandchildren Emma and Tom and his great grandson, Lewis, all of London. He is predeceased by his former wife, Stella Spurr Rochelle-Thomas and his son, Edward RochelleThomas. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:00 A.M. on Tuesday, November 4, 2003 at St. Ann Catholic Church, West Palm Beach, Fl, followed by a local interment at Our Lady Queen of Peace Catholic Cemetery. For those who wish, donations may be made in the memory of Alfred Peter Rochelle-Thomas to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407. For information, contact the Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bid For Property Company
description: The French real estate unit of the General Electric Company has bid 1.5 billion euros ($1.7 billion) to buy the rival Sophia, challenging a bid from Socit Foncire Lyonnaise. The G.E. unit is offering 41 euros a share, 5.3 percent more than Friday's closing price, the company said. Foncire Lyonnaise bid 38.50 euros a share in cash or five new shares for every four Sophia shares. Buying Sophia would help the G.E. unit expand its 3 billion euros of holdings in France and might help the company save money on taxes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Activists Seal Subways
description: Early-morning commuters in Barcelona found 70 subway entrances nailed shut by anti-globalization activists. Pamphlets left at the sealed subway stops throughout the metropolitan area demanded the release of anti-globalization protesters arrested in Salonica, Greece, in June. Two local youths were arrested. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: London Journal; Royals Beware. Diana's Tell-All Butler Didn't Quite.
description: ''Diana: The Last Secret'' read the teasing headline on The Daily Mirror's front page one day last week, promising ever more sensational revelations about the woman who was Princess of Wales. But dismayingly for those who forked over 32 pence (54 cents) to buy the newspaper, the article revealed only that the secret was too sensational to be revealed.

title: In Resigning Oil Post, Jailed Russian Hints at Political Fight
description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky resigned as chief executive of Russia's richest company, Yukos Oil, on Monday even as he defiantly vowed to continue a public -- and possibly a political -- campaign ''to build an open and truly democratic society in Russia.''

title: Weighing In on Ending Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Conexant To Buy GlobespanVirata
description: Conexant Systems, which makes semiconductors for high-speed modems and cable television set-top boxes, has agreed to buy GlobespanVirata for $969.5 million to add sales of chips for home computer networks. Conexant will pay 1.198 of its common shares for each of GlobespanVirata's, the companies said in a statement yesterday. That equals $7 a share based on Conexant's closing price on Friday, or 14 percent more than GlobespanVirata's close. GlobespanVirata, a money loser, is among the biggest sellers of chips for wireless networking gear. Conexant aims to sell more products for connecting home computers, printers and videogame consoles on wired or wireless networks, saying linkable devices will soon include digital cameras, MP3 music players, televisions and security systems. The combined company, to be based at GlobespanVirata's headquarters in Red Bank, N.J., will employ about 2,400 people and have about $1.2 billion in yearly sales. Shares of GlobespanVirata fell 4 cents, to $6.11. Conexant dropped 63 cents, or 10.8 percent, to $5.21.

title: The Democrats Debate
description: The following is a transcript of a debate of the Democratic Party presidential candidates in Boston, sponsored by CNN and Rock the Vote as recorded by FDCH e-Media, Inc.

title: As Earth Warms, The Hottest Issue Is Energy
description: Suppose that over the next decade or two the forecasts of global warming start to come true. Color has drained from New England's autumns as maple trees die, and the Baltimore oriole can no longer be found south of Buffalo. The Dust Bowl has returned to the Great Plains, and Arctic ice is melting into open water. Upheavals in weather, the environment and life are accelerating around the world.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: SCHWARZENEGGER FILLS 2 POSTS Gov.-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger announced his first major appointments, naming as education secretary Richard J. Riordan, the former Los Angeles mayor, and as finance director Donna Arduin, who had been on leave as the budget director in Florida. Ms. Arduin has been auditing the budget for Mr. Schwarzenegger. The appointment of Mr. Riordan was opposed by the California Teachers Association, which wanted the post eliminated because California has an elected superintendent of schools. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Spending Bill Passes
description: The Senate passed the administration's request for $87.5 billion to spend in Iraq and Afghanistan. It was the biggest emergency spending bill ever sought by a president.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Absolut Company, Stockholm, part of Vin & Sprit A.B., has put up a Web site that plays music meant to offer interpretations of the Absolut vodka bottle. The effort is an extension of the longtime print campaign that shows the bottle rendered by painters, photographers and other artists. The music includes styles described as high-tech soul and an amalgam of jazz, house music, soul and blues. Fitzgerald Communications, New York, created the site (absolut.com/threetracks).

title: Top Executive and Star Designer to Step Down at Gucci
description: PARIS, Nov. 4  The two men who teamed up in the 1990's to transform Gucci from a crippled brand into a luxury goods conglomerate will step down from their jobs next year, Gucci and Pinault Printemps-Redoute, the French retail group, announced today.

title: Budget Compromise Appears Probable for European Union
description: The howls of protest from Europe's smaller countries were all but absent here on Monday as Germany and France, the Continent's troubled economic heavyweights, appeared to have won enough backing to break Europe's budget rules and avoid punishment.

title: Alcohol's Toll On Fetuses: Even Worse Than Thought
description: Thirty years ago, scientists linked prenatal alcohol exposure with a perplexing pattern of birth defects including neurological problems, low birth weight, mental retardation and a set of facial malformations.

title: Taking a Gamble on the Cosmos
description: To the Editor:

title: A MAJOR DONOR LEAVES THE PHILHARMONIC
description: Rita E. Hauser, a longtime trustee, generous supporter of the New York Philharmonic and staunch opponent of its aborted merger with Carnegie Hall, informed board members yesterday that she was resigning. In her letter, Ms. Hauser, who has given millions of dollars to the Philharmonic, said that she had served for more than 25 years and that it was time to step down. Her resignation came on the heels of the failed merger, which she questioned from the start. She also made clear that she was frustrated with the way it was handled by Paul B. Guenther, the chairman of the Philharmonic, arguing that he had failed to involve the entire board adequately in the process. ''I believe the board must engage in a serious rethinking of the orchestra's future directions,'' she wrote in her letter. ''Bold and imaginative leadership is required if the New York Philharmonic is to fulfill its mission in the years ahead.'' Mr. Guenther said yesterday that he agreed with Ms. Hauser's comments and was sorry to lose her. Ms. Hauser's departure, effective Dec. 4, could be a blow to the planned redevelopment of the home of the Philharmonic, Avery Fisher Hall, a project that could cost as much as $250 million. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Palestinians And Israelis Still Speaking, In a Whisper
description: More than two months after Israel broke off contacts with the Palestinians, senior leaders from the two sides have quietly resumed behind-the-scenes discussions in an effort to revive the stalled Middle East peace plan.

title: Blasts Shake U.S. Headquarters in Baghdad, Injuring 4
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 4  Three powerful explosions in rapid succession shook central Baghdad on Tuesday evening in what was apparently a mortar attack on the headquarters of the American civilian authorities here.

title: Hall of Fame Welcomes LaFontaine and Fuhr
description: A series of concussions that left him with migraines, fatigue and depression drove Pat LaFontaine from the National Hockey League five years ago. On Monday night, he was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, along with the former Edmonton Oilers goalie Grant Fuhr, who became its first black member.

title: Editorial Observer; Poet Laureate: Louise Glck and the Public Face of a Private Artist
description: Anyone hearing Louise Glck's reaction when the Library of Congress recently named her as the poet laureate might be forgiven for thinking she was the last person to become America's official poet. ''I have very little taste for public life in the way that they understand it,'' she told The Boston Globe. ''I didn't think I was the sort of person they'd ever look at.''

title: Arafat Extends Term of Emergency Cabinet
description: Yasir Arafat extended the term of the Palestinian emergency cabinet today, an indication that more time may be needed to resolve differences with the prime minister over who will wield authority over security forces.

title: In Mating Games, Spiders May Learn Lessons Faster Than Young Men
description: It is the ''hey there, big boy'' version of the nature-nurture debate: are some gentlewomen born preferring blonds, or do their tastes develop as they age?

title: Consumer Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Food at 35,000 Feet: A Souk of Scents
description: IN a big wide wonderful world of clamoring cuisines, other people's take-out food has joined the long list of new experiences -- some might even say annoyances -- that airplane passengers are learning to put up with.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about British Airways giving one of its Concorde jets to the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum misspelled the surname of the museum's chief executive. He is Col. Tom Tyrrell, not Tyrell.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Adds Directors
description: By Bloomberg News

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mutual Fund Industry Weathers New Storm

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Redback Files For Bankruptcy
description: Redback Networks Inc., which makes equipment used to deliver high-speed Internet service, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday to execute a recovery plan that almost all of its bondholders have agreed to support. Redback listed $591.7 million in assets and $652.9 million in debts in papers filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., has lost money each year since becoming a public company in 1999. Its shares traded at more than $179 in June 2000. Under the company's ''prepackaged'' reorganization plan, holders of the company's $467.5 million in convertible subordinated bonds agreed to exchange their investment for stock in the company, court papers show. Almost all of the voting bondholders approved the plan, which would convert the bonds into about a 95 percent stake in Redback. Redback said with the agreement with its bondholders already in place it might be able to come out of bankruptcy as soon as 60 days. A bankruptcy judge must approve the recovery plan and a $25 million loan that Redback arranged to help finance operations during the debt-restructuring process.

title: The Dirty Business of Cleaning
description: Women who had worked as domestic cleaners were far more likely to suffer from chronic asthma or bronchitis than women who had not, a study done in Spain concludes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUSCHEL, HERBERT
description: MUSCHEL--Herbert, on November 1st, 2003. Creator of TV Guide and Founder of P.R. Newswire. Adored husband of Dollie, brother-in-law of David and Evelyn Cohen. Loving uncle of Deanna and Harriet and great-uncle of Jonathan, Jesse and Sasha. Adoptive father of Pud Magoo. Services Tuesday, 4 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: How's That New Best Seller? Well, the Author's Famous
description: Two weeks from tomorrow at a black-tie gala, the National Book Foundation will bestow on Stephen King a Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters. In that setting Mr. King's latest novel should make an interesting conversation piece. ''Wolves of the Calla'' is the rollicking 714-page fifth installment of a projected seven-volume ''Dark Tower'' fantasy series, illustrated with images not normally associated with distinguished contributions to letters. For instance there's the naked woman in the forest biting the head off a frog.

title: Reintroduced Wolves Dying in Southwest
description: Five years ago, federal biologists began to introduce endangered Mexican gray wolves in remote mountains near the Arizona-New Mexico border, half a century after the end of concerted campaigns to wipe them out. Wolf pairs have been added over the years, with a goal of establishing a population of 100 wild wolves. But now someone is killing them.

title: New York Funds Stop Using Putnam
description: The New York City Employees Retirement System, the police pension fund and the Teachers' Retirement System have decided to stop using Putnam Investments as a fund manager, the city's comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAPGOOD, CYRUS STOW
description: HAPGOOD--Cyrus Stow, 91, of Delray Beach, FL, and Greenwich, CT, died on Sunday, November 2, 2003 in Delray Beach, FL. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, November 5, 2003 11 AM at First Presbyterian Church of Delray Beach. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 W Palmetto Park Rd, Boca Raton, FL 33486

title: Chilling Out
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Adult-Inspired Clothing, for Kids
description: A trend that has children attired as scaled-down adults has been fomenting in the world's shopping capitals in recent years.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: We've Got a Call In To the Cattle

title: KELLOGG PLANS TO CUT PRICES AND OFFER COUPONS
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that it planned to cut prices and increase coupons next year to try to reverse falling sales of its Keebler Chips Deluxe and Fudge Shoppe brands. Kellogg plans to reduce retail prices in 2004 by using such methods as selling two packages of Chips Deluxe for $4 compared with $5 this year, Brad Davidson, president of Kellogg's United States snacks division, said. The company also plans to increase the use of coupons to draw shoppers and to increase advertising of its brands.

title: As Tycoons Slip Overseas, Putin Appears To Lay Siege
description: A lawyer for the embattled Russian oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky said Tuesday that a court in Moscow would decide Nov. 11 whether to release him on bail. Pressure on his company and others continued, with some top executives leaving the country and President Vladimir V. Putin publicly criticizing one businessman.

title: Earnings Rise 55% for Apartment Owner
description: Equity Residential, the largest apartment company in the nation, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 55 percent after it sold some property. Revenue increased less than 1 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Sale Of Nutrition Retailers
description: The Dutch baby food maker Royal Numico said that its shareholders had approved the sale of its subsidiary, the General Nutrition Companies, for $750 million to the private investment firm Apollo Management. Numico, which bought General Nutrition four years ago for $2.5 billion, is trying to shed assets in an attempt to recover from a series of poor investments that have left it heavily in debt. The sale of General Nutrition, which is based in Pittsburgh and operates a chain of vitamin stores, is part of the company's campaign to return to its core business and cut its debt. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Redfish Jump From Fad to Farm
description: Redfish from the Gulf of Mexico were depleted during the Cajun blackening fad of the 1980's, but now their farm-raised cousins are showing up on menus. The Fish Farm in Bacliff, Tex., near Galveston, raises them in ponds on organic feed. Barry and Alex Shurchin, brothers from New York, tasted the fish, liked it and started a company called Redfish Farms to market it in New York. The fish, which has white flesh, a mild flavor and a meaty succulence that suggests wild striped bass, is being sold whole or filleted for $14.99 a pound at Citarella stores. At the Citarella restaurant in Midtown, the chef, Brian Bistrong, sears it in the skin, roasts it briefly and serves it in an Asian-accented broth with mushrooms, above.

title: It's Crunch Time for the Venerable Pippin
description: SINCE the 18th century, pomologists have rated one apple variety as best: New York City's own Newtown Pippin. Revered by the nation's founders, this greenish-yellow lopsided fruit still exemplifies what used to be called high flavor, an almost quaint concept today, when appearance typically trumps taste. Indeed, in this age of fast fruit, the homely and slow-ripening Pippin, the prize of queens and the pride of Queens, faces a precarious future.

title: In Scorched Hills, Tribes Feel Bereft and Forgotten
description: The indigenous people who live in the hills of San Diego County hold to an old philosophy: Fire takes what it wants, floods take what is left and nothing lives long except the mountains.

title: Officials Say U.S. Has No Plans for Iraqi Paramilitary Forces
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 5  Occupying forces here have no plans to use privately controlled Iraqi paramilitary forces to augment Iraq's army and police force, senior American and Iraqi officials said today.

title: Reed Moves to Revamp How Stock Exchange Is Governed
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, proposed significant changes today in how the 211-year old institution is governed, including the creation of a much-smaller, independent board of directors.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Finance Minister Proposed
description: Lawmakers in the opposition Democratic Party of Japan promised to choose Eisuke Sakakibara as the finance minister if they win control of the government in national elections on Sunday. Mr. Sakakibara was known as "Mr. Yen" for his ability to move financial markets when he was vice minister of finance for international affairs in the second half of the 1990's. Polls show the Democratic Party trailing the ruling coalition led by the Liberal Democratic Party. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Report Cites Danger in Overtime for Nurses
description: Many hospitals and nursing homes are endangering patients by allowing or requiring nurses to work more than 12 hours a day, the National Academy of Sciences said on Tuesday.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Teenager With a Voice Has a Vision for the Future
description: When Imani Peterson's grandmother isn't feeling well, Imani gives her something no one else can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOEWY, ROSAMOND E.
description: LOEWY--Rosamond E. Of Manhattan, 82, passed away November 3rd following a lengthy illness. Graduate of Hunter College and Teachers College, Columbia University. Former teacher and guidance counselor in NYC for 35 years. Survivors include her brother Ben, niece Jane and nephew James. Services will be held at Campbells funeral home, 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday, November 6th at 9:30 A.M. Friends may call at the funeral home prior to the service.

title: In the Nazi Darkness, A Call for Light
description: 'Silver Nitrate'

title: Mexican Subtlety
description: PIPIAN -- pumpkin seeds -- figure heavily in certain Mexican dishes, not only contributing their distinctive nuttiness but also acting as a thickening agent in a variety of sauces. I like them best combined with ancho chilies, which are the rich-flavored dried version of the ultramild poblano. (Despite containing a number of anchos, this dish is far from fiery, and may in fact disappoint those who are looking for something along those lines.)

title: Republican Deputy Since 1995 Declares Victory in Mayor's Race
description: Deputy Mayor Phil Amicone, a Republican, defeated a former schools superintendent on Tuesday night in the race to succeed Mayor John Spencer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Deer Park: L.I.R.R. Morning Service Disrupted
description: Service for more than 6,000 commuters on the Long Island Rail Road was disrupted for more than 11 hours yesterday when a signal bridge was knocked down by a freight train on another track. Service on the Ronkonkoma line east of Farmingdale was suspended after 4 a.m. when two cars of a 35-car freight train in Deer Park knocked down the 20-foot-high bridge, which is used for signaling trains to let them know the track is clear. The freight train is owned by the New York & Atlantic railroad. A representative of the Long Island Rail Road said service east from Pennsylvania Station was restored by midafternoon after the two cars were removed from the tracks by cranes. Service west from Ronkonkoma is expected to resume in time for this morning's rush hour. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Pemberton: Bomb Hoax Closes School
description: A high school was closed for most of the school day after someone telephoned the police and claimed three students had brought guns and a bomb to school. The police found nothing, identified the caller as a former student of the school, Christina Spallone, 19, and arrested her. Ms. Spallone, of Brown Mills, was charged with creating a false public alarm and obstruction of justice, said Stephen Emery, the Pemberton chief of police. The police said Ms. Spallone called the principal of Pemberton Township High School at 11:25 a.m. on Monday. The police did not finish inspecting the school until 6 p.m. Detectives found Ms. Spallone on a pay telephone in front of a local convenience store. It was not immediately clear why she made the call. Ms. Spallone was released on Monday on $2,500 bail.

title: Rivals Condemn Dean For Rebel Flag Remark
description: In an emotional, finger-pointing display, Howard Dean was repeatedly rebuked by his Democratic rivals at a debate here on Tuesday night for saying last week that he wanted to be ''the candidate for guys with Confederate flags in their pickup trucks.''

title: Letitia James Wins Seat That Slain Man's Brother Felt Was Rightfully His
description: The brother of a murdered councilman saw the Brooklyn seat slip away yesterday in an election that brought large victories for incumbents across New York City.

title: News Analysis: In Germany, the scent of regret
description: BERLIN:  Considering that the source was the chief of the European Union section of a government-subsidized policy research institute, the admonition was fairly extraordinary: Germany must not fall further into a French trap that was turning the Schroder government away from the country's real interests and potential for leadership in Europe.

title: CBS Cancels 'The Reagans'
description: It is hard to know what CBS was thinking when it decided to order up a less-than-complimentary mini-series about the Reagans at a time when former President Ronald Reagan is failing and his wife, Nancy, is nursing him. And it should have come as no surprise that conservatives, protective of Mr. Reagan's image at all times, would launch one of the fierce assaults that have become so familiar whenever the right wants to scare the media on an ideological question. But having decided to broadcast the program, CBS was wrong to yield to conservative pressure and yank it.

title: What Are Our Options in Iraq? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMPTON, HAROLD ROY
description: HAMPTON--Harold Roy. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mr. Harold Roy Hampton, an esteemed member, and extend to his beloved wife, Gladys and family its deepest sympathy. Brian J. Strum, President Andrew Muhlstock, Secy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DYSTEL, MARION
description: DYSTEL--Marion. Of Rye, NY, passed away on November 2, 2003, at White Plains Hospital due to complications of pneumonia. Born Marion Deitler on February 7, 1915, in Bridgeport, CT, to Louis and Fanny Deitler. She was raised and educated in public schools in Bridgeport, where she met and married her high school sweetheart, Oscar, on October 2, 1938. She served as a volunteer with the American Red Cross during WWII and with the United Hospital in Port Chester and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society Southern New York Chapter. She is survived by her husband of 65 years, Oscar Dystel of Rye. Also surviving are her loving daughter Jane and her husband Steven Schwinder, and her grandchildren Jessica and Zachary, all of New York City. Her son, John, predeceased her in June, 2003. She was also predeceased by her sisters Belle Cone, Jeanne Slachter, and her brothers Leo Deitler and Irving Deitler. Contributions may be made to the John Dystel MS Nursing Fellowship, 50 Main Street, Suite 1000, White Plains, NY 10606.

title: Tumult in Venezuela's Presidential Palace, Seen Up Close
description: ''The Revolution Will Not Be Televised,'' a riveting documentary, is not the movie that the Irish filmmakers Kim Bartley and Donnacha O'Briain envisioned when they traveled to Venezuela to film a portrait of Hugo Chvez, that country's left-wing president. A volatile force in Latin American politics, Mr. Chvez, who was elected president by a landslide in 1998, was shaking up the status quo, having vowed to take control of Venezuela's oil industry and redirect its wealth to benefit the poor.

title: A Fight at the U.N. Over Cloning
description: The Bush administration is campaigning hard at the United Nations for a convention that would ban all forms of human cloning, a position more extreme than it has been able to sell in this country. When the issue comes up for a vote in the General Assembly tomorrow, member states would be wise to ignore the American campaign and instead chart a course that would allow therapeutic cloning, the use of embryonic stem cells in experiments to search for cures for a wide range of diseases.
