This is no time to snuff out promising medical research by imposing rigid moral restraints that are far from universally accepted.

title: Anthony and James Sharing the Spotlight
description: Back then, they were just two kids in the hall, unusually gifted, to be sure, but still far from being described as prodigies, phenoms and sensations. Carmelo Anthony was about to be a senior in high school, LeBron James about to be a junior. They did not know each other, but on that day in Colorado Springs, no one else was around. So they introduced themselves.

title: Law Firms Sue Massachusetts for Tobacco Money
description: BOSTON, Nov. 4  Two law firms that helped Massachusetts win $8.3 billion from a nationwide tobacco settlement faced their former employers in court on Tuesday, claiming they are owed an additional $1.3 billion in legal fees in the case.

title: Battle Royal in Upper Midwest
description: North Dakota Coach Dean Blais compares it to Nebraska versus Oklahoma in football. Minnesota Coach Don Lucia says it is ''probably a little bit like Duke and North Carolina in basketball.''

title: Panel Doubts Finding That Cloned Food Is Safe
description: Just days after the Food and Drug Administration announced preliminary findings that meat and milk from cloned animals were safe to consume, a scientific review panel for the agency said on Tuesday that there was not enough data to support that conclusion and asked for more studies.

title: Profit Rise at Marvel
description: By Bloomberg News

title: Messier Passes Howe on Points List
description: Mark Messier reached a milestone last night that he could have never conceived of 25 seasons ago, when he broke into the National Hockey League.

title: Shifting 'Reagans' To Cable Has CBS Facing New Critics
description: CBS's decision yesterday to drop its mini-series about Ronald and Nancy Reagan, after an impassioned campaign by Republican and conservative groups, roiled the television industry, infuriated some Democrats and liberal groups, and left CBS executives open to criticism they had caved in to political pressure.

title: A Neighborhood Place That Feels Like Home
description: FEW things are as elastic as the idea of the neighborhood restaurant. It stretches in almost any direction to accommodate establishments as diverse as the Chinese takeout joint, the burgers-and-beer pub, the little trattoria, the taqueria. Sushi, Indian, bagels, panini-and-wine bar -- they all line up proudly as local gathering spots. But few epitomize the spirit of the neighborhood restaurant as clearly as Sam's in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: Bush, in California, Tours a Scene of Ruin
description: President Bush got a firsthand look on Tuesday at a slice of the devastation from California's wildfires, viewing the damage from a helicopter and then walking through a neighborhood that had been ravaged.

title: Mutual Fund Misdeeds
description: To the Editor:

title: German General Fired for Backing Slur on Jews
description: The commander of a German special forces army unit was dismissed Tuesday after he praised a conservative member of Parliament for a speech that has been widely criticized here as anti-Semitic.

title: Auction Season Opens With 3 Records
description: Six months ago, Stephen A. Wynn was the biggest buyer at auction. Last night Mr. Wynn, the Las Vegas casino owner, seemed to hit the jackpot as the biggest seller at Christie's when his Modigliani nude brought $26.8 million, a record for the artist at auction.

title: Europe Warns U.S. Is Facing Consequences Over Trade
description: Europe's top trade official said here on Tuesday that the United States could look forward to up to $6 billion of trade sanctions if President Bush failed to lift steel tariffs and Congress did not eliminate overseas tax shelters for American exporters.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Canadian Sent To Syria By U.S. Wants Inquiry
description: Maher Arar, a Canadian citizen who spent a year in a Syrian jail after being deported by the United States as a terrorism suspect, said in Ottawa that he was tortured in Syria in an ordeal he described as ''beyond human imagination.'' Mr. Arar, 33, of Ottawa, was detained at Kennedy Airport en route to Montreal from Tunisia in September 2002 and was later deported to his native Syria, instead of Canada, as he requested. Speaking publicly about his experiences for the first time since being suddenly released last month, Mr. Arar called for a public inquiry into the role that Canada might have played in his detention and deportation. Canada has denied being involved in the decision, but United States officials have said they were acting on information from Canadian law enforcement agencies when they deported Mr. Arar. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police has begun its own investigation. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Suing On Behalf Of A Lizard
description: A coalition of environmental groups led by the Center for Biological Diversity in Tucson is suing Washington over protecting the three-inch-long flat-tailed horned lizard. The coalition cites agriculture and urban sprawl as the primary threats to the lizard habitat in the deserts of southwestern Arizona and southeastern California. It is seeking threatened or endangered status for the lizard. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: France Agrees to Try Harder; Europe Delays Deficit Vote
description: A showdown over France's ballooning budget deficit was averted during meetings among the European Union's finance ministers late Monday and Tuesday, when the tricky question of whether to punish France for breaking budget rules was postponed for three weeks.

title: A Restaurateur Who Bought for Himself
description: WHEN Harry Poulakakos locked the door of his restaurant in Hanover Square for the last time on Friday, he left behind a lot of memories and by his estimate about 60,000 bottles of wine. It was one of New York's best cellars.

title: David Bar-Illan, Ex-Israeli Aide, Dies at 73
description: David Bar-Illan, a concert pianist, editor and media critic who served as chief spokesman for the Israeli government under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, died yesterday in Jerusalem. He was 73.

title: Ferry's Pilot Was Upright, Crewman Says
description: A crew member who was in the pilothouse of the Staten Island ferry that crashed three weeks ago has told investigators that the pilot was standing upright and alone at the controls right up to the moment of impact, city officials said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Israel Says It Is Easing Travel Restrictions on Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 5  Israel announced today that it was easing travel restrictions on Palestinians in the West Bank, a move that appeared timed to help the Palestinian prime minister, who is locked in a running dispute with the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: PATRICIA YEO, below, the chef who severed her ties to Jimmy Haber's AZ and Pazo earlier this year, plans to open her own place, NAGA, at 99 Stanton Street (Ludlow Street) on the Lower East Side in the spring. The food will be Asian-accented.

title: N.F.L. Reinstates Evans After Eight-Game Ban
description: Jets defensive tackle Josh Evans was reinstated by the National Football League late Monday after an eight-game suspension for a third violation of the league's substance abuse policy. Now he must work his way back onto the Jets' roster.

title: Man's Bridge To North Korea Is Seen as Link To Espionage
description: A few months ago, John Choe says, his parents began receiving strange and frightening phone calls at their home on Staten Island. ''Why is your son being paid by the government of North Korea?'' one anonymous caller asked. ''Did you know the F.B.I. is doing surveillance of your son?'' asked another.

title: New Jersey Neglect Case Is Topic on Capitol Hill
description: The accusation that a New Jersey couple systematically starved their four adopted sons will move to Washington on Thursday when a House subcommittee convenes hearings on the allegations.

title: World Cup Schedule Change
description: The United States got an eight-month reprieve and will not begin to play qualifying matches for the 2006 World Cup until August 2004, instead of beginning the long road to Germany early next year.

title: Doing Battle With Those Pests in Your In-Box
description: To the Editor:

title: Big East Is Bulking Up, But Not on Football Field
description: The Big East, rebounding from the defection of three of its members to the Atlantic Coast Conference, ranged to the Midwest and to the South to reconfigure itself yesterday by welcoming Louisville, Cincinnati and South Florida in all sports and DePaul and Marquette in every sport but football.

title: Medical Definitions of Abortion Techniques
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)  Abortion restrictions being signed into law today are creating confusion over just what the ban covers.

title: No Man's Land for Parks, No More; A 13-Project Windfall Where Open Space Is Precious
description: A tough stretch of asphalt in Lower Manhattan -- wrapped and shadowed by the looming loop of a Brooklyn Bridge approach ramp -- will be claimed today as the city's newest parkland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERBER, LEON
description: FERBER--Leon, 96, died on November 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Phyllis for 62 years. Loving father of Paul Ferber, Laurie Ferber Podolsky and her husband, Morris Podolsky. Adoring grandfather of Joshua Podolsky. Funeral service 1PM, Thursday, November 6th at Beth-El Cemetery of Bergen County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMOND, GEORGE
description: HAMOND--George. Died on November 3, age 92. Chief Engineer of Eagle Electric for many years. Long time resident of Great Neck, NY. Husband of Esther. Father of Eugene and Joshua. Grandfather of David and Michael.

title: A California Cheese, Pungent and Smooth, Captures the Crown
description: Redhawk, a Muenster-style cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery in Point Reyes Station, Calif., won the American Cheese Society's grand prize this year. It is astonishingly good: pungent and almost beefy, but smooth-textured. Cowgirl uses organic milk, and though Redhawk is a triple-cream, it has none of the overly intense richness of that category. It is also expensive, normally selling for $28.99 a pound at the Murray's Cheese shops in Greenwich Village and at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Quovadx To Acquire Rogue Wave For $69.7 Million
description: Quovadx Inc., which develops software that allows computers to share information, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Rogue Wave Software Inc. for $69.7 million in cash and stock to add new products and customers. Quovadx said in a statement that it would pay $4.09 and 0.5292 of a common share for each share of Rogue Wave. That values Rogue Wave at $6.83 a share, 20 percent more than Monday's closing price. By buying Rogue Wave, which makes software based on the C++ programming language, Quovadx adds customers in telecommunications and financial services. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter and add to full-year profit, said Quovadx, which is based in Englewood, Colo. Quovadx shares fell 20 cents, to $4.97. Rogue Wave, which is based in Boulder, Colo., rose 95 cents, or about 17 percent, to $6.64.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEISENBERG, SHIRLEY
description: MEISENBERG--Shirley, on November 3. Beloved wife of the late Samuel J. Devoted mother of Norman and Alan. Mother-in-law of Margery Austrager. Adored grandmother of five and great grandmother of eight. Services Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ on Wednesday, November 5, at 2PM. Information: Bernheim-ApterKreitzman, 1-888-351-4414

title: Siloviki Versus Oligarchy
description: Russia today is ruled by Vladimir Putin's siloviki, former K.G.B. men and military officers who have the nation by the throat. That power-hungry mafia (the Russian word is rooted in ''power'') brooks no opposition from either the small band of democratic reformers or the political leftovers from the Yeltsin regime.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Rains Block Repatriation
description: Close to half of 540,000 refugees from Angola's long civil war who have been camped in neighboring nations have returned to the country since May, the office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees said, but most repatriation has stopped because the rainy season has made roads into the country impassable. In Geneva, a spokesman for the office said that about 200,000 refugees had returned, mostly from Zambia. Refugees in Namibia and Congo are continuing to trickle home as well. In total, up to five million Angolans are estimated to have fled their homes during three decades of conflict, which ended last spring. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Doing Battle With Those Pests in Your In-Box
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, PHYLLIS (NEE FEIN)
description: GILBERT--Phyllis (nee Fein) of Englewood, NJ. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Erica, Andrea and mother-in-law of Steve. Dear sister of Judith Lasser. Doting grandmother of Simon, Alex and Claire. She will be missed by all. Services will be held at Wien & Wien, Hackensack, on Wednesday, 11:30am. Contributions may be made to Don Imus Children's Hospital, Hackensack.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: CANADIAN SENT TO SYRIA BY U.S. WANTS INQUIRY Maher Arar, a Canadian citizen who spent a year in a Syrian jail after being deported by the United States as a terrorism suspect, said in Ottawa that he was tortured in Syria in an ordeal he described as "beyond human imagination." Mr. Arar, 33, of Ottawa, was detained at Kennedy Airport en route to Montreal from Tunisia in September 2002 and was later deported to his native Syria, instead of Canada, as he requested. Speaking publicly about his experiences for the first time since being suddenly released last month, Mr. Arar called for a public inquiry into the role that Canada might have played in his detention and deportation. Canada has denied being involved in the decision, but United States officials have said they were acting on information from Canadian law enforcement agencies when they deported Mr. Arar. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police has begun its own investigation.   Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a proposal by the teachers union in New York City to run a charter school gave an outdated reference to a partnership between the teachers union in Miami and Edison Schools, a private management company, to operate 10 charter schools there. The partnership ended before any of the charter schools opened.

title: Death by Optimism
description: On a visit to Saddam's Iraq a year ago, I wrote a column that outraged his government. It described officials burning a Muslim leader's beard and then driving nails through his head.

title: Prescription Drug Bill in Peril, Kennedy Says
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said Tuesday that negotiations on a bill to help elderly people buy prescription drugs were ''on life support,'' in danger of dying within weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, DOROTHY C.
description: JOHNSON--Dorothy C., 84, Bronx, NY. Retired educator and businesswoman. President, Johnson Security Bureau. Loving mother of Charles, Sr. and Rev. Suzan Johnson Cook. Funeral Thursday, November 6, 11am. For info Rendall Memorial Presbyterian Church, NYC. 718-537-7268.

title: Herbert Muschel, 85, Founder Of Service for Corporate News
description: Herbert Muschel, who created PR Newswire, the service that lets companies send press releases to news outlets electronically, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

description: Vadim Valery Filatov, an eye doctor who directed a half-dozen centers for laser-assisted surgery in the New York region, died last Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 39 and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHMIEL, FELIX J.
description: CHMIEL--Felix J. of Fenwick, CT and Tequesta, FL, died November 2, age 77. Felix is survived by his wife Carol and their children, JC, Richard, Robert, Tony, Mimi, and Paul, 14 grandchildren, three brothers and three sisters. He retired after 47 years from U.S. Trust Co., the Senior Estate Planning Attorney in New York and Florida. Graduated from the University of Scranton, St. John's Law School, Masters in Taxation from NYU. Felix taught a paralegal course at NYU School of Continuing Education, was a member of the NY Yacht Club, former Race Committee, Palm Beach Pundits, and Riverbend Golf Club, and served in the United States Navy in WW II. A memorial Mass will be offered Saturday at St. John's Church, Old Saybrook, CT at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa, Ferry Road P.O. Box 2049, Doylestown, PA 18901.

title: Philadelphia Easily Gives Second Term to Its Mayor
description: In an emotional finish to a controversy-ridden campaign, Mayor John F. Street won a second term on Tuesday, beating his Republican opponent, Sam Katz, an executive who lost narrowly to him four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SANOFF, DANNY
description: SANOFF--Danny. Its been one year since you've been gone. We miss you and you will always be remembered. Love, Mom, Lisa, Carmine and Famil

title: To Grandmother's House We Go (With Baggage)
description: When theatergoers talk about a play as a religious experience, they usually just mean that it had charismatic performances or some exciting dance numbers. It's like fashion editors using divine to describe a nice sweater.

title: Democrats Seize Senate And Widen Assembly Gap
description: Democrats tightened their grip on New Jersey government in Tuesday's elections, seizing undisputed control of the State Senate, toppling the state's top Republican elected official, and padding their majority in the General Assembly.

description: McDONNELL -- Morgan F., age 76, of Wayne, IL, passed away at home surrounded by his loving family on November 2, 2003. Son of the late James and Anna McDonnell of New York City and South Hampton. Beloved husband of Anne Ford for 52 years; loving father of Morgan (Kappo), Muffy Haley (Timothy), James (Kim), Peter (Mary), Mary Hull (Edwin), David (Ashlie). Also, survived by 16 grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Visitation Thursday November 6, 2003 at 10:00 AM followed by a memorial mass at 11:00 AM at St. John Neumann Catholic Church at 2900 East Main Street, St. Charles, IL. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to Misericordia Home, 6300 North Ridge Avenue, Chicago, IL 60660.

description: Two United Nations officials in charge of security at the Baghdad mission when it was bombed in August will be put on leave while a team of independent experts determines responsibility for the security flaws at the mission, a United Nations spokesman said Tuesday.

description: Well, maybe youth isn't always wasted on the young. That's the exciting news emanating from the tiny Worth Street Theater in TriBeCa, where ''The Moonlight Room,'' a first play by Tristine Skyler, 32, is announcing the arrival of a precocious talent.

description: ''Hybrid cars will be the future,'' boomed an electronic voice as Japanese men lined up six deep at the Tokyo Motor Show this week to snap photos of a model dressed in hot pants, knee-high boots and a skimpy top as she waved frenetically in front of a Toyota hybrid car.

description: They came from Russia, Poland and Lithuania, and their tales of washing and waxing Wal-Mart's floors for seven nights a week sound much like Pavel's.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Telecom Italia Posts Profit
description: Italy's largest tele-communications company, Telecom Italia, posted net income in the third quarter of 825 million euros ($948 million), a turnaround from a loss of 349 million euros in the quarter last year, when the company's results reflected the effects of write-downs taken by its mobile unit. Telecom Italia benefited in the most recent quarter from a one-time gain of 1.5 billion euros because it was able to recover money that had been put aside to cover an Italian tax that was ruled by the European Union to be illegal. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMYTHE, SHEILA MARY
description: SMYTHE--Sheila Mary. The Manhattanville College community mourns the loss of Sheila Mary Smythe, one of its most dedicated and beloved alumni and volunteer leaders, who died on November 4, 2003. Few individuals have so modestly and selflessly served Manhattanville, helping to lead the college through two decades of growth and change while serving as mentor and guide to countless former students of all ages and faiths. Few individuals have so consistently lived the college's mission, to educate ethically and socially responsible leaders for the global community. Miss Smythe, a graduate of Manhattanville College, served on the college's board of trustees for more then 20 years, beginning in 1981. Twice, she oversaw the college's search for a new president, including in 1994, when president Richard A. Berman, who serves today, was chosen. She twice served as chair of the board, most recently serving as vice-chair, member of the executive committee and academic affairs committees and chair of the trustee affairs committee. In 1981, she received the college's Distinguished Alumni Award and in 1974, the college presented her with an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree in recognition of her professional and personal achievements. In 1997, Manhattanville established the Sheila Mary Smythe Award, given periodically to an esteemed alumnus who has successfully worked to improve society. Over her impressive career Miss Smythe was widely respected for her vision and commitment to education and to health care, and for the strong friendships she made throughout her years of business and community leadership. After serving as president and CEO of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, she became the chief health policy advisor to the Comptroller General of the United States (U.S. General Accounting Office). In 1990, she joined New York Medical College as professor of health policy and economics, and the first dean of the Graduate School of Health Sciences. Since 1995, she also served as executive vice president of the college and president of its Partnership for a Healthy Population. In addition to serving Manhattanville College, Miss Smythe served on the boards of many business and community organizations, including the March of Dimes, Catholic Charities USA and Mutual of America Life Insurance Company. Miss Smythe earned Bachelor of Arts degrees from Manhattanville College and Creighton University, and a Master of Science degree from the Graduate School of Public Health and Administrative Medicine at Columbia University, where she also undertook doctoral studies. Miss Smythe is survived by her niece, Sheila P. Gonley, who graduated from Manhattanville College in 1992 and now lives in England. Manhattanville College has established a Shelia Mary Smythe Memorial Fund. Contributions may be sent in Miss Smythe's name to: Manhattanville College, 2900 Purchase Street, Purchase, New York 10504.

title: Cholesterol Study Offers Hope for a Bold Therapy
description: A small study of heart disease patients testing a hypothesis so improbable its principal investigator says he gave it a one-in-10,000 chance of succeeding has found that just a few treatments with an experimental drug reversed what may be the equivalent of years' worth of plaque in coronary arteries.

title: A Test for Schwarzenegger: Add Muscle to Bare Bones
description: IT made a wonderfully pithy sound bite for the recall election. ''I guarantee I will not raise your taxes,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger said. ''And I guarantee I will not cut education.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, J.B.
description: BROWN--J.B. The Board of Trustees, faculty and Acorn School community mourn the tragic loss of this beloved husband, father, brother and son-in-law. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Brown family including his wife Megan Axthelm Brown, his children Matthew and Mary Brown, his sister Heather Brown and his mother-inlaw Jill Axthelm. The Board of Trustees, The Acorn School

title: What Are Our Options in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the resignation of Lawrence J. Lasser, former chief executive of Putnam Investments, referred incorrectly to shareholderlosses caused by the improper trading of fund managers. Putnam has estimated that managers made $700,000 in improper gains -- not that shareholder losses were $700 million.

title: In Race Shadowed by Scandal, Democrat Keeps Mayor's Office
description: Holding on to his office after one of the hardest-fought campaigns for mayor here in more than a decade, John M. Fabrizi, the Democrat, defeated his Republican challenger, Rick Torres, on Tuesday.

title: The Knicks' Fragile Houston Gets a Day Off From Practice
description: Fresh off their first victory of the season, the Knicks practiced for nearly an hour and a half Tuesday. Guard Allan Houston was the only player whose gray T-shirt was not stained with perspiration at the end of the workout.

title: Assumptions on Adoption
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Key Figures in Gucci's Turnaround Are Quitting
description: The men who turned a creatively exhausted Gucci into one of the fashion world's most dynamic design houses said yesterday that they would leave the company, apparently unwilling to submit to the will of its French owner.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Executive's Viewpoint
description: The new chief executive of Yukos, Simon G. Kukes, said that the company, which is Russia's largest oil producer, plans business as usual, despite the resignation this week of its embattled chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky. ''We don't plan any changes in company behavior, because it is developing normally,'' Mr. Kukes said at a news conference. ''Everything stays intact and we have a strong team.'' He left Russia for the United States in the 1970's, then worked with Phillips Petroleum and Amoco. Mr. Kukes joined Yukos in 1996, left in 1998 to become president of the Russian oil company TNK and brokered its joint venture with BP of Britain this year. He was named the chairman of Yukos last summer. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Editors Note
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday about Iraq's foreign debt should have more fully disclosed the background of its author, Mark Medish. Mr. Medish, an international lawyer and former Treasury official, represents corporations that are owed money by Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Mixed Export Data
description: Southeast Asia's latest trade gauges offer a mixed picture on demand for exports from the United States. A closely watched barometer of manufacturing activity in Singapore rose in October to its highest level in more three years, as faster demand from the United States brightened Singapore's economic prospects. The jump in the purchasing managers' index, compiled by the Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management in Singapore, was the biggest in 18 months. A similar trend is appearing in the Philippines, where the government reported that exports in September rose 2.3 percent, to $3.26 billion, led by a rise in electronics shipments. But exports in Malaysia and Indonesia shrank in September. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: 3 Blasts Seem Aimed at U.S. Compound
description: Three powerful explosions in rapid succession shook central Baghdad on Tuesday evening in what apparently was a mortar attack on the headquarters of the American civilian authorities here.

title: C.I.A. Needs to Learn Arabic, House Committee Leader Says
description: The Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said Tuesday that prewar American intelligence about Iraq had been hampered by significant shortcomings, including what he called the C.I.A.'s unsatisfactory response to Congressional directives to improve its foreign language capacity.

title: S.E.C. Approves Stricter Governance Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved stricter corporate governance standards yesterday for more than 6,000 companies that list their shares on the Nasdaq Stock Market and the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A California Cheese, Pungent and Smooth, Captures the Crown
description: Redhawk, a Muenster-style cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery in Point Reyes Station, Calif., won the American Cheese Society's grand prize this year. It is astonishingly good: pungent and almost beefy, but smooth-textured. Cowgirl uses organic milk, and though Redhawk is a triple-cream, it has none of the overly intense richness of that category. It is also expensive, normally selling for $28.99 a pound at the Murray's Cheese shops in Greenwich Village and at Grand Central Terminal.

title: $1 Million Humanities Prize Goes to a Polish Philosopher
description: The Library of Congress will award the new $1 million Kluge Prize for lifetime contribution to the humanities to a Polish philosopher who provided intellectual backing for the Solidarity union's efforts to jettison communism, library officials said on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEAR, DONALD D., JR.
description: WEAR--Donald D., Jr. Age 56, on Saturday, November 1, 2003 at the Virginia Hospital Center. Husband of Janice J. Wear, father of Christopher D. Wear, brother of Thomas W. Wear, son of Donald D. Wear, Sr., and the late Olga F. Wear. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, November 6th at 3PM at Cherrydale United Methodist Church, 3701 Lorcum Lane, Arlington, Va. Interment private. Contributions may be made to the National Kidney Foundation or UNICEF. For information Murphy Funeral Home, Arlington, VA.

title: Wrapping Up a Trilogy With a Global Assault
description: Like the notion of the matrix itself, the release of ''The Matrix: Revolutions,'' the third installment in the science fiction trilogy conceived by Andy and Larry Wachowski, boggles the mind.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about the future of the American Stock Exchange, referred imprecisely to the market leaders in options trading. While the International Securities Exchange has the largest volume in equity options, the Chicago Board Options Exchange has the largest volume over all if index options are included.

title: Workers Go on Strike at 2 of Manhattan's Most Prestigious Restaurants
description: The ''21'' Club and La Caravelle, two of Manhattan's most venerable restaurants, pride themselves on their sedate atmosphere, but yesterday the scene outside those establishments was anything but sedate as their workers went on strike, and shouted vehemently at anyone heading inside.

title: Private REIT's Move Into Market
description: Investment sales in commercial real estate have been anything but sluggish during the recent economic slowdown, and four companies -- all using similar investment models and ways of raising capital from individual investors -- have been playing leading roles in the transactions, each within its own niche.

title: De Sole and Ford tried to keep control : Era ends at Gucci as top duo resigns
description: PARIS:  In news that shook the fashion world and brought to an end an expansive era in the luxury universe, Tom Ford and Domenico De Sole, the creative and management team behind Gucci Group, announced Tuesday they were leaving the company after failing to reach agreement on renewal of their contracts.

title: Van Gundy Feels at Home, Even if He's Across the River
description: When the public-address announcer introduced Jeff Van Gundy as coach of the Houston Rockets just before Tuesday night's game against the Nets, the sparse crowd gave a mixed reaction that was barely louder than the light chatter filling Continental Arena.

title: About New York; How Green Were His Gills
description: A GOOD seven hours remained before the close of the polls yesterday, but Patrick Hurley, the Republican candidate for the City Council in Woodside and its environs, needed sustenance. With the misty rain outside, it was proving to be a soft day, and a hard one as well.

title: 2 departures are major blow to brand : Gucci is losing its 'dream team'
description: PARIS:  Tom Ford and Domenico De Sole, the creative and management team that turned Gucci into a red-hot brand, announced Tuesday that they would leave the company next year, a decision that shook the fashion world and marked the end of an expansive period in the luxury universe.

title: No Simple Rules For Dealing With Death
description: Last night's episode of ''8 Simple Rules . . . for Dating My Teenage Daughter'' on ABC was taped without a laugh track: the network sitcom equivalent of boots reversed in the stirrups of a riderless horse.

title: Company Said to Develop Substitute for Painkiller
description: A biotechnology company says it has developed a substitute for the widely abused painkiller OxyContin that is resistant to tampering and misuse.

title: Farming in Paradise, Where the Lamb Is King
description: A SMALL pack of male white and chocolate-brown lambs were nudging and shifting, with fleeces tousled by damp weather and heads pitched toward the ground, their focus on the prize: dry, feathery wisps of alfalfa, torn from a hay bale. The alfalfa smelled like sweet tea; their jaws were grinding. It was a special snack on the Allen Sheep Farm, and it was no time to be taking in the view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAVANAGH, CAROLINE PRATT
description: CAVANAGH--Caroline Pratt, 84, of Wilmington, Delaware died on October 31st, 2003. Beloved wife of James B. Cavanagh, mother of Katie C. Maslow, Sheila P. Marshall, James F. Cavanagh, Gary A. Santora. Grandmother of five, great-grandmother of one. Memorial services Wednesday, November 5, 2003 at 10 a.m. at Christ Church, Wilmington. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Children & Families First, 2005 Baynard Blvd, Wilmington, DE 19802.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: 24-Year Term For Drug-Dealing Lottery Winner
description: Jose L. Betancourt, who won millions of dollars in the state lottery, was sentenced to 24 years in prison for cocaine trafficking by a federal judge in Brownsville and was ordered by a jury to return more than $5 million of his winnings because he bought the winning ticket with drug profits. Defense lawyers argued that Mr. Betancourt, 52, bought the ticket from profits from a used-clothing business. Prosecutors countered with evidence that indicated he had sold cocaine for years before hitting the jackpot. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: John Gordon, 82, a Collector of Americana
description: John Gordon, an expert on American folk art who amassed one of the country's finest private collections of pots, whirligigs, weather vanes and paintings, died on Oct. 25 in the Bronx. He was 82 and lived in Manhattan.

title: MORE ON THE VOTE
description: 2 REPUBLICAN GOVERNORS -- Representative Ernie Fletcher was elected in Kentucky and Haley Barbour, former G.O.P. national chairman, won in Mississippi. Page A22.

title: The Supreme Court and Sept. 11
description: In the two years since Sept. 11, the Bush administration and the federal courts have rewritten important areas of the law, scaling back the right to counsel, the ability of prisoners to challenge their confinement and other civil liberties. Through it all, the Supreme Court has been silent, largely because of the time it takes for cases to work their way up. The court will soon have a chance, however, to consider several cases posing the question of how much, if any, our constitutional rights have changed as a result of Sept. 11. It has a duty to step in and stand up for civil liberties.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Oct. 23 about the new anti-doping policy of USA Track & Field referred imprecisely to the number of American track athletes who tested positive for the newly discovered steroid known as THG. (The error was repeated in an editorial on Oct. 31.) While the steroid was found in six urine samples, they came from only four United States track athletes.

title: F.T.C. APPROVES PURCHASE OF KODAK SHARES BY ICAHN
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said that the investor Carl C. Icahn had received clearance from the Federal Trade Commission to buy as much as $500 million worth, or about 7 percent, of the company's outstanding shares. Mr. Icahn is not obligated to purchase the Kodak shares, and government filings do not show that any purchase has occurred. The F.T.C. notified Mr. Icahn on Oct. 29 that it did not see a regulatory reason to prohibit his buying the securities, according to rules that were published on the F.T.C.'s Web site. Mr. Icahn filed to buy as much as $500 million in Kodak shares, a Kodak spokesman said.

title: Network TV officials ponder their own financial whodunit: Where have all the young men gone?
description: AS the case of the missing younger male viewers grows curiouser, as Sherlock Holmes might have put it, the presidents of the entertainment divisions of broadcast network television are weighing in with their worries.

title: . . . Leaves Another Frosty
description: IN theory, all cupcakes should be perfect, since there's really nothing to them. A 10-year-old should be able to handle the assignment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNICOL, DORIS
description: McNICOL--Doris. Sam, as she was known, was born in NYC and graduated from Fordham College. A lifelong lover and collector of American prints and paintings, she died peacefully on October 30, 2003 at home in North Palm Beach, Florida, by the ocean she loved. We will miss her terribly. The Postley Family

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New London: Search Ended For 2 In Plane Crash
description: The Coast Guard yesterday confirmed that it has ended its search for a Connecticut couple missing and presumed dead after their plane crashed into Long Island Sound. On Sunday, the couple -- Edward Rosen, 60 and his fiancee, Ilse Sorensen, 42, both of New London -- were flying on the south side of Fishers Island in a World War II-era biplane when the plane suddenly dropped into the water. A spokesman for the Coast Guard said that crews searched the crash site, where debris was found. Crews used sonar detection equipment but the search was ended at 4:30 p.m. Sunday, owing to the approach of night and the depth of the water, which was several hundred feet or more. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Rivals Rebuke Dean in Debate
description: Howard Dean's Democratic rivals criticized his statement that he wanted the votes of ''guys with Confederate flags'' on their trucks. Page A16.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Livingston's Old Plaza to Make Way for Retail Hub
description: Livingston Manor Shopping Plaza has long been considered a white elephant in the heart of this sprawling suburb. But soon the dowdy 1920's plaza will be bulldozed to make way for a mixed-use development intended to give Livingston a commercial hub it is now missing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The bottom line is that you can't really get your message out for $45 million. You need to be able to spend more.''

title: Turkish Aide Says Troop Offer Is Still Available
description: Turkey's offer to send troops to Iraq remains on the table, but no forces will be sent without a formal invitation from the American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council, the Turkish ambassador to the United States said Tuesday.

title: SVENSKA CELLULOSA TO BUY ALLOYD, PACKAGING MAKER
description: Svenska Cellulosa of Sweden, a leading European tissue maker, agreed to buy the Alloyd Company of the United States for 740 million kronor ($93.9 million). Alloyd, based in DeKalb, Ill., makes packaging boards used to wrap tools, batteries and office equipment, Svenska Cellulosa said. The Swedish company, known as SCA, is struggling to reach its annual sales growth target of as much as 10 percent, including acquisitions, after sales in the first nine months of this year showed a decline from the period in 2002.

title: The Attraction That Is Southern China
description: A state governor in the United States could only dream of attracting a corporate advisory board to match the 21-member roster assembled by a Chinese provincial governor at a three-day annual conference here.

title: Locations: Sweets All Over
description: THE sweet lowdown on some of New York's most notable cupcakes:

title: U.S. Persuades Allies to Halt North Korean Atom Project
description: The Bush administration persuaded its Asian and European allies on Tuesday to suspend a multibillion-dollar project to build two nuclear power reactors in North Korea, in what appeared to be the last step in the dissolution of the 1994 accord that temporarily froze North Korea's nuclear weapons program.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Coup Plotters' Plans
description: A band of white militants known as the Boeremag plotted early last year to topple the government by blowing up power stations around four military bases and executing anyone at the bases who resisted a takeover, an informant testified in the treason trial of 22 South Africans charged in the coup. The informant, Johannes Smit, said in the Pretoria High Court that the plotters equipped themselves with copies of Psalms 20 and 22 and a loyalty oath adapted from a war in 1838 against Zulu natives by white settlers. The 22 men are accused of planning to forcibly march South Africa's 38 million blacks and citizens of Indian descent out of the country should their coup have succeeded. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: UNION CARBIDE WINS SETTLEMENT IN PATENT CASE
description: The Union Carbide unit of Dow Chemical won more than $112 million in damages from a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group for infringing a patent covering chemical catalysts. Jurors in a federal court in Wilmington, Del., concluded Monday that the Shell unit copied processes related to catalysts in the production of ethylene oxide, a component of antifreeze and polyester fibers. An appeals court last year threw out an earlier jury's finding that there was no infringement. A spokeswoman for Shell said the company planned to appeal the decision. While jurors found that Shell copied the process of using catalysts to produce ethylene oxide more efficiently, they concluded that the infringement of the patent was not intentional, a decision that will stop Union Carbide from seeking triple damages.

title: NASA Supporters Seek National Debate on Space Goals
description: After the shuttle Columbia disintegrated on Feb. 1, many supporters of NASA expected a renewed national debate on the goals of the space program. But nine months later, supporters of space exploration and the science program say that the subject appears to be in danger of slipping below the national horizon.

title: One Critics Delight Leaves Another Frosty
description: By ERIC ASIMOV

title: Once Just a Cupcake, These Days a Swell
description: ONE morning in 1996, Allysa Torey and Jennifer Appel, partners who had just opened the Magnolia storefront bakery next to a scruffy bird shop on a sleepy corner of Bleecker Street, made a cake. It was a small cake, so they poured the extra batter into a handy muffin tin. While the breakfast regulars sipped coffee, the first batch of Magnolia cupcakes was baked, frosted and set out on the windowsill.

title: Credit Suisse Has Profit After Year of Big Losses
description: Pursuing a turnaround after a disastrous year, Credit Suisse, Switzerland's No.2 bank behind UBS, posted higher-than-expected third-quarter profits on Tuesday, strengthened by a surge in stock markets and the sale of insurance businesses.

title: Pennington And Short Cross Paths Again
description: It was an otherwise uneventful play in Sunday's game, a reverse that went for only a yard. But Giants linebacker Brandon Short could only laugh as he got up from the turf at Giants Stadium. Jets quarterback Chad Pennington was laughing, too. They patted each other on the helmet and trotted back to their respective huddles.

title: Fans Wonder About Redskins' Fall
description: ''We could talk about a lot of things,'' John Thompson said, ''but the only thing people want to talk about is the Redskins.''

title: Sitting on a Park Bench, Recalling a City Visionary
description: THAT Andrew Haswell Green was some New Yorker.

title: Doing Battle With Those Pests in Your In-Box
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Posted Gains Among Voters After 9/11, Survey Shows
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  The Republican Party, which has lagged behind the Democrat Party in registered voters for much of the last century, has made significant gains across the country and has now pulled virtually even with the Democrats, according to a new portrait of the electorate conducted by the Pew Research Center.

title: GILLETTE SAYS THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT ROSE 18%
description: The Gillette Company said that third-quarter profit climbed 18 percent, helped by sales of a new Mach3 shaver and a weaker United States dollar. Net income rose to $416 million, or 41 cents a share, from $354 million, or 33 cents, in the period a year earlier, Gillette said. Sales rose 11 percent, to $2.41 billion, with about half of the gain coming from a declining dollar. Gillette's introduction of the Mach3Turbo Champion razor fueled a 17 percent sales gain at the shaving division, which is the company's biggest business. Demand for Mach3Turbo shavers in Europe and the Venus razor for women helped increase sales of blades and razors, which generate more than a third of Gillette's revenue and more than half its profit.

title: Intel Claims Breakthrough In Chip Making
description: Researchers for Intel say they have discovered a new material that they believe will permit them to overcome one of the most serious obstacles facing chip makers as they struggle to shrink computer chips to ever smaller dimensions.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Schizophrenic Faces Execution Date
description: Charles L. Singleton, a schizophrenic convicted murderer whose death sentence the Supreme Court declined to review last month, has exhausted all appeals and may be assigned an execution date, Attorney General Mike Beebe said. Mr. Singleton's lawyers had argued that forcing him to take medication was tantamount to making a someone otherwise ineligible for execution sane enough to be put to death. A federal appeals court disagreed, and the Supreme Court declined to accept the case. Mr. Singleton was sentenced to death in 1979. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Mattingly Is Ready to Learn From Torre
description: Don Mattingly was tending to the horses on his farm in Evansville, Ind., eight days ago when the phone rang at his home. His wife, Kim, answered, while their 18-year-old son, Taylor, a Yankees minor leaguer, listened from another room. George Steinbrenner was on the line.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 375 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Donovan to Be Staten Island Prosecutor
description: Daniel M. Donovan Jr. declared victory last night in his bid to become the first Republican elected as Staten Island district attorney; the Democrat, David W. Lehr, conceded shortly before midnight.

title: 7 Who Worked at Prudential Accused in Trading Inquiry
description: Five former Prudential Securities brokers and two former branch managers in Boston were accused yesterday of securities fraud involving improper trading of mutual funds.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Game Price Reduced
description: Sony Computer Entertainment will reduce the price of its PlayStation 2 video game consoles in Japan by 20 percent to generate more sales. Starting Nov. 13, the best-selling games will cost 19,800 yen ($180) and 29,800 yen ($271) for the high-speed machines. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: What Are Our Options in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cashman Allows Pettitte To Test Free-Agent Market
description: The Yankees and Andy Pettitte will not agree on a new contract before Pettitte gauges his value on the free-agent market, General Manager Brian Cashman said yesterday. The Yankees are the only team that can negotiate with Pettitte until Monday, but they have not made an offer even though Pettitte has not formally filed for free agency.

title: Pataki Puts Nonjudge on Court of Appeals
description: Gov. George E. Pataki nominated a Republican trial lawyer from Manhattan on Tuesday to fill a vacancy on the state's highest court.

title: Republicans Win Top Posts In Mississippi and Kentucky
description: The political landscape of the South took yet another Republican turn on Tuesday night as voters in Mississippi unseated a Democratic governor and Kentucky elected its first Republican governor in decades.

title: Report Sees Vast Needs for Energy Capital
description: The world's increasing demand for energy will require total investments of $16 trillion by 2030, most of it needed to maintain and expand the electricity infrastructure, according to a study released on Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: PEMBERTON: BOMB HOAX CLOSES SCHOOL A high school was closed for most of the school day after someone telephoned the police and claimed three students had brought guns and a bomb to school. The police found nothing, identified the caller as a former student of the school, Christina Spallone, 19, and arrested her. Ms. Spallone, of Brown Mills, was charged with creating a false public alarm and obstruction of justice, said Stephen Emery, the Pemberton chief of police. The police said Ms. Spallone called the principal of Pemberton Township High School at 11:25 a.m. on Monday. The police did not finish inspecting the school until 6 p.m. Detectives found Ms. Spallone on a pay telephone in front of a local convenience store. It was not immediately clear why she made the call. Ms. Spallone was released on Monday on $2,500 bail.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tyco, the Conglomerate, Now Suggests That Less Is More
description: Tyco International said yesterday that it would sell its undersea optical fiber communications network, get out of more than 50 smaller businesses, close at least 200 facilities and cut 7,200 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force.

title: What Are Our Options in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Account Of Arms Trafficking Rejected
description: The government said its ambassador to Colombia would not be returning to his post until Colombia's president, lvaro Uribe, offered an explanation for his assertion that rogue Ecuadorean military officers had furnished Colombian leftist rebels with a rocket launcher used in a failed assassination attempt last month. The government recalled the ambassador on Friday, after Mr. Uribe said the weapon used by rebels who tried to kill the president of the Colombian cattlemen's association had come from the Ecuadorean military. Ecuadorean Army officers vigorously denied the charge, and Ecuador's president, Lucio Gutirrez, a former colonel, has supported them, saying Mr. Uribe has shown no proof to back his claim. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Friday about the memoir of Nellie Connally, who was in the presidential car in Dallas with her husband, Gov. John B. Connally, when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1963, misstated the timing of Mr. Connally's switch to the Republican Party. It was in 1973  after, not before, his service as treasury secretary under President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the introduction of a worldwide ranking system for marathon runners misidentified the Kenyan who won the New York City Marathon on Sunday. He was Martin Lel, not Rodgers Rop.

title: Two Coaches Wouldn't Quit In L.I. Case, They Say
description: Two football coaches at the center of the Mepham High School sexual-abuse case said on Tuesday night that they were asked to resign as coaches on Friday but refused to step down.

title: Autumn of the Oligarchs?
description: The two fateful questions of Russian history are, ''What is to be done?'' and ''Who is to blame?'' Now, almost four years into the presidency of Vladimir Putin, who came into office asserting that Russia needs a ''dictatorship of law,'' Russians are asking a new question: ''What is to be done with those who are to blame?''

title: INSIDE
description: A Bold Cholesterol Therapy

title: CALENDAR
description: Cooking School House Calls

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELLINGER, ELEANOR (DE YOUNG)
description: HELLINGER--Eleanor (De Young). On November 3, 2003 at age 84. Mother of Doug, Steve, John, and Bob; grandmother of Danny, Sam, Laura, and Abigail; sister of Stella Donenfeld. She was a lady and a good sport; a woman with warmth, intelligence, compassion, and class. We dearly loved her and she will be sorely missed. Services 12 noon Friday at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, N.Y.

title: The Specter of Paganini Hovering Slyly Over a Performance
description: When Regina Carter became the first jazz musician to play Nicol Paganini's 1743 Guarneri del Ges violin, known as Il Cannone (The Cannon), it was a triumph for jazz. Il Cannone is owned and selectively bestowed on musicians by the city of Genoa, and some traditionalists had insisted that letting anything but classical music be played on the precious instrument would devalue it forever; others pointed out that Paganini himself was an improviser. Ms. Carter played a concert with Il Cannone in Genoa in 2001 and went on to record an album with it.

title: M.L.S. Fines MetroStars Mathis
description: MetroStars striker Clint Mathis was fined $500 yesterday by Major League Soccer "for conduct unbecoming a professional athlete," a result of an altercation with fans at Giants Stadium after last Saturday's playoff loss to the New England Revolution.

title: Coffee Wagon Pulls Up The Wheels On East 9th
description: About three years ago, Nina Berott and Greg Northrop set up a coffee van, the Mud Truck, on Astor Place. Its success and its loyal following led them to do the same on Wall Street. Now they have opened Mudspot, a sliver of a cafe 307 East Ninth Street with restaurant ambitions. A dense espresso served in a little glass tumbler ($1.50) is one of several first-rate coffees, available from morning on. Then there are pastries, panini, soups and, in the evening, tapas to go with beer and wine. Once a month guest chefs prepare four-course dinners that are served in the small back dining room for $40 to $50, including wine poured from oversize bottles. Still, Ms. Berott said, ''there are plenty of people who would rather get their coffee from the truck.''

title: President Signs Bill That Prohibits Type of Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  President Bush signed a law today outlawing a procedure that abortion opponents call "partial-birth abortion," declaring that the measure would benefit "the innocent child" yet unborn.

title: One Critic's Delight . . .
description: EVERYONE likes a cupcake, but nobody wants to marry one.

title: He's an Author. Now Serve Him A Dog's Dinner.
description: COOPER GILLESPIE is not much of a host.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPA, ANTONIO
description: PAPA--Antonio. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Antonio Papa, associated with The Times from May 1954 until retiring in July 1979.

title: How Russian Oil Tycoon Courted Friends in U.S.
description: In early 2001, as George W. Bush's administration moved into the White House, one of Russia's wealthiest men, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, sought a meeting with the new national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. According to a former staff member, National Security Council analysts were asked to perform a background check.

title: Isles' Blake Is Hurt
description: Islanders wing Jason Blake will be out about two weeks because of a sprained right knee, the team said yesterday. Blake collided with Daniel Alfredsson of the Ottawa Senators during the Islanders' 6-3 victory on Monday night. Blake, with 4 goals and 4 assists in 11 games, will be replaced by Justin Mapletoft, who was called up from the Islanders' affiliate in Bridgeport, Conn. Ron Dicker

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: DEER PARK: L.I.R.R. MORNING SERVICE DISRUPTED Service for more than 6,000 commuters on the Long Island Rail Road was disrupted for more than 11 hours yesterday when a signal bridge was knocked down by a freight train on another track. Service on the Ronkonkoma line east of Farmingdale was suspended after 4 a.m. when two cars of a 35-car freight train in Deer Park knocked down the 20-foot-high bridge, which is used for signaling trains to let them know the track is clear. The freight train is owned by the New York & Atlantic railroad. A representative of the Long Island Rail Road said service east from Pennsylvania Station was restored by midafternoon after the two cars were removed from the tracks by cranes. Service west from Ronkonkoma is expected to resume in time for this morning's rush hour.   Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Teenager Held In Embassy Fire
description: Four people were slightly injured at the Turkish Embassy in The Hague after a passer-by threw a bag of flammable material into the building, setting off a small fire. The police denied early reports of a bomb attack, possibly linked to terrorists, saying they had taken a disgruntled 16-year-old suspect into custody. The teenager was discovered at a train station, slightly injured. The authorities said the suspect, whose name and nationality were not released, attacked the embassy after an altercation there earlier in the day. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the fallout from a basketball recruiting scandal at St. Bonaventure University referred incorrectly to the contractual status of the coach who was dismissed last spring and rendered his name incorrectly. The coach was Jan van Breda Kolff, not Van. University officials said they were not negotiating a settlement with him.

title: Recent Plays
description: Much Ado for Love or Money in County Cavan

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ANGOLA: RAINS BLOCK REPATRIATION Close to half of 540,000 refugees from Angola's long civil war who have been camped in neighboring nations have returned to the country since May, the office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees said, but most repatriation has stopped because the rainy season has made roads into the country impassable. In Geneva, a spokesman for the office said that about 200,000 refugees had returned, mostly from Zambia. Refugees in Namibia and Congo are continuing to trickle home as well. In total, up to five million Angolans are estimated to have fled their homes during three decades of conflict, which ended last spring.    Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEDALE, HERBERT
description: ROSEDALE--Herbert, age 71, on November 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Eric, Nancy, Jeff and Mary. Dear brother of Sheila Asroff. Of Counsel, Jenkins & Gilchrist Parker Chapin, LLP. Since 1988, he served as President of American Family Foundation, the leading professional research and education organization in the U.S. for cult related issues. Funeral services will be 1:00 PM Thursday, November 6th at Temple Beth El, 220 S. Bedford Rd., Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to AFF, P.O. Box 2256, Bonita Springs, FL 34133 or to Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester.

title: National Briefing | Washington: School Reopens After Mercury Cleanup
description: Ballou Senior High School, closed for more than a month after mercury stolen from a school laboratory was spread through the building, reopens today. Officials said the school had been certified as clean and safe from mercury contamination by the Environmental Protection Agency and the city's Health Department after a $1 million cleanup. A 16-year-old student was charged last week with stealing the mercury, which can damage brains in high doses. John Files (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France And Ireland Arrest 7 Linked To Real I.R.A.
description: In a joint operation, the police in Dublin and northwestern France arrested seven people suspected of involvement with the Real I.R.A., a paramilitary group that split from the Irish Republican Army and that opposes the Northern Irish peace process. In France, three men and two women from Brittany were arrested after the police found a small cache of weapons and ammunition near the port city of Dieppe. At the same time, two Irishmen in their 20's were arrested in Dublin. The Real I.R.A. killed 29 people in a bombing in 1998 in Omagh, Northern Ireland, but has been less active since the imprisonment of its leader, Michael McKevitt, convicted in August of directing terrorism. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRAPER, WILLIAM F.
description: DRAPER--William F. Like Tolstoy, you ravished your canvas with truth and beauty and gave a meaning to our wars and peace. Francis X. Morrissey, Jr.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: SUING ON BEHALF OF A LIZARD A coalition of environmental groups led by the Center for Biological Diversity in Tucson is suing Washington over protecting the three-inch-long flat-tailed horned lizard. The coalition cites agriculture and urban sprawl as the primary threats to the lizard habitat in the deserts of southwestern Arizona and southeastern California. It is seeking threatened or endangered status for the lizard. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: 2 Men Are Shot Near Nightclub In Midtown, Close to Bryant Park
description: After an argument at a nearby hip-hop club, two men on foot were shot from a car near Bryant Park at 1:30 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The men, each with leg wounds, fled into the park, which the police later closed to search for clues.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Oct. 23 about the new anti-doping policy of USA Track & Field referred imprecisely to the number of American track athletes who tested positive for the newly discovered steroid known as THG. (The error was repeated in an editorial on Oct. 31.) While the steroid was found in six urine samples, they came from only four United States track athletes.

title: Declining Music Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Much Ado for Love Or Money in County Cavan
description: 'The Colleen Bawn'

title: Sports of The Times; Switching Conferences For Prestige and Profit
description: EVERY time I have listened to Mike Tranghese recently, the ominous phrase from the 23rd Psalm comes to mind: ''Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death.''

title: Tucked Away in the West Village, Japan
description: IN New York's vast restaurant sea, Sumile is one of the small, colorful fish that could easily slip through the net. On a dark, quiet block in the West Village, it's a modest, even recessive presence, with only a small menu on a stand outside by way of self-promotion. Passers-by who stop to read it have to look around a bit to locate the front door, a couple of steps down from the sidewalk.

title: F.C.C. Acts Against Pirating of TV Broadcasts
description: Federal regulators approved rules on Tuesday meant to prevent people from copying broadcasts of television shows and movies and widely distributing them on the Internet.

title: Novell to Buy SuSE Linux for $210 Million
description: Novell announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy SuSE Linux of Germany for $210 million, in a deal that shows mainstream software companies are increasingly betting on the free Linux operating system.

title: Issue for Bush: How to Speak Of Casualties?
description: When the Chinook helicopter was shot down on Sunday in Iraq, killing 15 Americans, President Bush let his defense secretary do the talking and stayed out of sight at his ranch. The president has not attended the funeral of any American soldiers killed in action, White House officials say. And with violence in Baghdad dominating the headlines this week, he has used his public appearances to focus on the health of the economy and the wildfires in California.

title: Original Stars Returning to 'Producers,' at a Price
description: Let the schmoozing, begging and finagling begin. Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick are returning to ''The Producers.''

title: Lawyer, Not Ideologue -- Robert Sherlock Smith
description: A son of a novelist and a literary critic in New England, Robert S. Smith started out as a Democrat. But he took a U-turn in 1988, switching to the Republican line two decades after graduating No. 1 in his class at Columbia Law School and landing a high-paying job at a Manhattan law firm.

title: The Game Concludes With Light And Noise
description: ''Everything that has a beginning has an end.'' This sentence appears on the front page of the production notes handed out at press screenings of ''The Matrix Revolutions,'' which opens worldwide today. It is also uttered by the Oracle (Mary Alice) in response to a question from Neo (Keanu Reeves). ''Where is this going?'' he wants to know. ''Where will it end?'' Neo may be the One, but he can hardly be the only One posing such questions. The talk of endings in this, the third and ostensibly final movie in the series, is so insistent that you may wonder whether the Wachowski brothers, who wrote and directed it, felt the need to reassure the audience, and perhaps themselves, that it was really, finally over. There are still a few loose ends that might be spun into future sequels -- ''The Matrix Recycled,'' perhaps, or ''The Matrix Recall Election'' or ''The Matrix Recipe Book and Holiday Menu Planner'' (featuring the Oracle's baking tips) -- but the saga of Neo, which began in 1999 when he was a scruffy hacker who took a red pill, has now by all appearances reached its terminus. The appropriate response is somewhere between ''About time'' (about six hours, depending on what's added for the DVD release) and ''So what?''

title: Prosecutors Ask Judge to Set Another Trial For Ex-Banker
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they planned to try Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse First Boston banker, again after his first trial on charges of obstruction of justice ended in a hung jury last month.

title: Corrections
description: A profile in the special Marathon section on Monday about a top American distance runner who has had to struggle for acceptance from her family for her participation misspelled her surname. She is Kim Pawelek, not Pawalek.

title: A Gay Bishop For Episcopalians
description: To the Editor:

title: Grievances That Can Bring Globalization to Grief
description: A natural resource coveted on the international market was sitting in the ground, and the Bolivian government wanted to exploit it with the help of foreign capital. But after widespread public protests over the terms of the deal, the president was forced to drop it.

title: Washington Talk; The Race According to George McGovern
description: To George McGovern, it all looks very familiar.

title: Group Says Guinea Sold Arms Used on U.S. Embassy in Liberia
description: The cost of befriending the enemy of one's enemy has once again become painfully clear for the United States government: Washington's staunch ally in West Africa, Guinea, supplied mortars to Liberian rebels, who used the gift to shell an American-owned compound in Liberia where thousands had taken refuge during fighting earlier this year, a report to be released Wednesday by Human Rights Watch says.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Turkey: Land Mines Near Syria To Be Cleared
description: Turkey will clear 615,000 land mines along its border with Syria, Deputy Prime Minister Abdullatif Sener announced. The mines, planted from 1957 to 1959, will be destroyed by the military. Turkey joined the international ban on antipersonnel mines in March. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Democrats Keep Hold on Judgeships in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Democratic Party weathered a challenge to its hold on Supreme Court judgeships last night, as the Democratic candidates soundly defeated a slate run by the Working Families Party for the eight available seats on the bench.

title: CITY VOTES DOWN AN EFFORT TO END PARTY PRIMARIES
description: New York City voters overwhelmingly rejected a measure yesterday that would have instituted nonpartisan city elections, voting to forgo changes in a system of selecting municipal officials that has been in place for nearly a century.

title: Democrat to Be Executive, but G.O.P. Holds Legislature
description: State Assemblyman Steve Levy swept to victory yesterday to become the first Democrat elected Suffolk County executive since 1987, according to unofficial returns. But the Republicans increased their majority in the County Legislature by one seat.

title: Aiming Beyond the Pheasants
description: Gun control emerged with a bang in the Democratic presidential primary campaign the other day as Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts blasted a pheasant from the Iowa sky with a shotgun, minutes after attacking the gun control credentials of his rival, former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont. Senator Kerry aimed to have it both ways: he indulged rural voters' fondness for lawful hunting, but he went after Mr. Dean as fair game for having opposed restrictions on military-style assault weapons as a state politician 11 years ago, while now supporting the current federal ban.

title: DEAN CONSIDERS A PLAN TO FORGO PUBLIC FINANCING
description: Howard Dean is planning to poll his supporters in an unusual online survey this week about whether he should become the first Democratic presidential candidate ever to abandon the 30-year-old public-financing system in the primaries.

title: Savard Has Surgery
description: Atlanta Thrashers center Marc Savard will be out for 8 to 10 weeks after having ankle surgery yesterday, leaving the team without one of its top scorers.

title: Ex-Official Is Held in Jail Over Concern He Is Suicidal
description: Russell A. Harding, the former president of the New York City Housing Development Corporation who was indicted in March on embezzlement charges, was arrested on Monday night after his psychiatrist alerted federal court officials that he was in immediate danger of killing himself.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Trade Official Threatens Sanctions

title: In Plea Deal, Man Admits 48 Green River Killings
description: Gary Ridgway, a former truck painter, pleaded guilty today to murdering 48 women in Washington State, so many that "I have a hard time keeping them straight," he said in court.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about the memoir of Nellie Connally, who was in the presidential car in Dallas with her husband, Gov. John B. Connally, when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1963, misstated the timing of Mr. Connally's switch to the Republican Party. It was in 1973 -- after, not before, his service as treasury secretary under President Richard M. Nixon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 'Bloody Sunday' Testimony
description: Martin McGuinness, a former leader of the Irish Republican Army and the chief negotiator for Sinn Fein, its political party, began testifying for the second time at an inquiry into the ''Bloody Sunday'' killing in 1972 of 13 Roman Catholics by British Army paratroopers in Londonderry. Mr. McGuinness, who was education minister in the power-sharing Northern Ireland government, said he became head of the I.R.A. in Londonderry two weeks later, but he refused to disclose details of I.R.A. operations and disputed testimony that he had fired at British soldiers. If the I.R.A. ''had been intending to kill a British soldier, they could have done so quite easily,'' he said. The five-year inquiry, which has called 853 witnesses, recently returned to Northern Ireland after hearing testimony from British soldiers in London. It is expected to conclude early next year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Sri Lanka's President Suspends Parliament and Ousts Officials
description: Sri Lanka's president suspended Parliament, fired three top government ministers and deployed troops at key buildings in Colombo, the capital, on Tuesday, government-run news outlets reported. The move touched off a political crisis in the country and fueled fears that a 20-month cease-fire between government forces and ethnic Tamil rebels would collapse.

title: Former HealthSouth Chief Indicted by U.S.
description: The Justice Department yesterday unveiled an 85-count indictment portraying Richard M. Scrushy as the mastermind of a multibillion-dollar scheme to defraud investors by inflating the profits of HealthSouth, the hospital company he founded and led as chief executive until his ouster earlier this year.

title: What Are Our Options in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Pricing Dispute Hurts McData Results
description: The McData Corporation, a maker of switches for data-storage computer networks, said yesterday that it would fall short of its own estimates for third-quarter revenue by as much as 17 percent because of a pricing dispute with its top customer, the EMC Corporation. Preliminary results showed that sales in the three months ended Friday rose to $93 million to $95 million, from $80.9 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, 2002, before McData changed its fiscal year, the company said. McData, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., had projected sales of $107 million to $112 million. EMC, a maker of computer-data storage systems, had pressed McData for lower prices on switches and had refused to accept delivery of an order, said Steven B. Berg, an analyst for Punk, Ziegel & Company. The dispute prevented some revenue from being recorded in the quarter, McData said. McData's Class A shares fell 40 cents, or 4 percent, to $9.63. A McData spokeswoman, Kathleen Sullivan, declined to say what ended the dispute and led to the sale's completion. An EMC spokesman, Mark Fredrickson, declined to comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, MUSIA
description: ZUCKERMAN--Musia. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Musia Zuckerman. Musia was born in Vilna, Poland in 1938, and narrowly escaped a Nazi forced labor camp. For over a year Musia and her family were hidden by a farmer in the four foot high false attic of a barn. Musia came to New York in 1946. She was member of IPTAR, and a dedicated psychoanalyst. Our condolences to her loving husband, Martin, and son, David.

title: Soho Square Partner Leaves After 3 Months
description: BMW of North America in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., part of BMW, has further narrowed a review for its Western regional creative account by selecting five finalists. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Paterno In Trouble In Happy Valley
description: Joe Paterno remains witty and persuasive. Seventy-six years on this earth and 53 in the coaching business have done nothing to change that. He can claim he has the energy, drive and focus of a much younger man. He can claim that his team is a good one that is bound to get better. He can joke about his situation. Will he step down?

title: Baghdad Scrambled to Offer Deal to U.S. as War Loomed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5  As American soldiers massed on the Iraqi border in March and diplomats argued about war, an influential adviser to the Pentagon received a secret message from a Lebanese-American businessman: Saddam Hussein wanted to make a deal.

title: Too Soon to Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: BSkyB Defends Naming Of Younger Murdoch
description: The tempest surrounding James Murdoch's rise to chief executive of the British Sky Broadcasting Group can be attributed to overheated shareholder activism and longstanding anti-Murdoch sentiment in Britain, a senior member of the company's board said on Tuesday.

title: 2-Party Elections a Foreign Concept in Rural Japan
description: ''Manifesto'' is the buzzword of Japan's political season. Each party must have one. Newspaper headlines squeeze it in.

title: The Famous and the Witty In a Half Century of Chats
description: Television has hundreds of channels and much chatter but little serious conversation. On ''The Open Mind,'' however, which has been on the air for almost 50 years, Richard D. Heffner encourages guests to speak in paragraphs, not sound bites.

title: Warning About Russian Oil Rights Stirs Some Jitters
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 5  A Russian official threw a scare into an already jittery marketplace today, suggesting that licenses to develop the country's natural resources could be reviewed and withdrawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACKERMAN LUBIN, ELSIE
description: ACKERMAN LUBIN--Elsie. Devoted wife, loving mother of Anita Skalka, Sally Calavetta, Bob Ackerman and Rosalie Margolis Druyan, much adored grandmother and dear great grandmother passed away on November 1, 2003 at age 89 with her family by her side. Shiva through today at the Calavetta home.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENDRIHAS DETTMER FRAGKOULAKI, MIRANDA
description: LENDRIHAS DETTMER FRAGKOULAKI -- Miranda. On November 1, 2003, beloved wife of forty-one years of George Lendrihas. Family will receive friends Wednesday 7-9 P.M. and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service Friday 10 A.M. at The Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral. Entombment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, SYLVIA
description: GREENBERG -- Sylvia. Passed away November 3, 2003. Beloved wife of Harry, adored mother to Steven and Neil. Devoted sister to Reva, loving grandmother to Jennifer, Judy and Jane. Services I.J. Morris, Brooklyn, 12:15PM Wednesday, November 5.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Plea For Inquiry On School Network
description: Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, asked Attorney General John Ashcroft to investigate a network of 11 behavior-modification schools for troubled teen-agers, citing accusations of child abuse, human rights violations, deceptive advertising and fraud. The network, the World Wide Association of Specialty Programs of St. George, Utah, oversees programs for more than 2,200 young people in the United States, Mexico and Jamaica. It has attributed suggestions of misconduct to disgruntled customers and staff members. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Yale Names a New Dean of Its Law School
description: Harold Hongju Koh, an expert in human rights and international law, was named the new dean of Yale Law School on Tuesday. He will succeed Anthony Kronman, who is stepping down after 10 years.

title: Senate Rejects Limit on Shared Financial Data
