description: The Senate voted on Tuesday to reject an amendment that would have preserved new rules in California intended to let consumers stop banks, brokerage firms and insurers owned by the same company from swapping customers' financial secrets.

title: 'Spag Bol,' for Italians Real and Imagined
description: JAMIE OLIVER was sitting on a lavender sofa in his living room ruminating over a recipe he would soon make. It would be a variation, he said, on ''spag bol,'' the dish most people, even Italians, call spaghetti bolognese.

title: William Swetland, 90, Actor Who Played Stalwart Men
description: William Swetland, a venerable character actor on Broadway and in regional theater who specialized in stalwart, older characters, died on Friday in Branford, Conn. He was 90.

title: School Districts Struggle With English Fluency Mandate
description: Ten-year-old Claudia Hernandez, the daughter of Mexican immigrants, learned English in the schools here, and after her teacher gave her a dictionary as a gift, she studied at home, too, playing school with her younger brother. Claudia would be the teacher, she recalled, and together they would look up words.

title: Top Officer at 1999 Shooting Says Killing Was Self-Defense
description: The 1999 police shooting in Brooklyn had many of the familiar ingredients of incidents that had inflamed the city over the years: a multitude of bullets, a young man left dead, conflicting accounts of whether it was justified, and talk in the street of a cover-up.

title: Park Avenue Gets Breezy in Winter, So a Cafe Throws Up a Tent
description: For the last few summers, Leslie Ann Nilsson, below, has run Cafe St. Bart's on the terrace at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street. This year, instead of striking her tent, so to speak, she is staying open in the cold weather, with seating for 112 in a fully enclosed and heated all-weather tent that would make Ralph Lauren proud. The tent, made of white plastic, is masked outside with greenery. Inside it has velour and birch bark on the walls, a beamed ceiling, carpets, chandeliers and even a fake fireplace, all designed by Musters & Company, a special events concern. To go with the country-style dcor, the cafe has a harvest menu of dishes like pasta with butternut squash and chicken potpie.

title: Chief of New Jersey State House Loses Race and Party's Hopes
description: John O. Bennett, the Republican co-president of the New Jersey State Senate, lost the battle to save his 24-year political career Tuesday, and with it any chance of his party's keeping its share of power in the Senate.

title: What Are Our Options in Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Truth and Cons
description: To the Editor:

title: A High Price to Pay
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Return to the Stone Age
description: A furniture collection by Guillaume Bardet is a marriage of sculpture and architecture.

title: Tables Doing Double Duty
description: Some alternatives to the conventional dining room.

title: Rethinking the Shoe Box
description: A small house need not be claustrophobic, even in Tokyo, where the average apartment is just 774 square feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUENETTE, ROBERT
description: GUENETTE--Robert. Awardwinning filmmaker and cofounder of RGP, LAMEC and IDA died at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles on October 31 of brain cancer. He was 68. Predeceased by his wife, Frances, he is survived by son Dr. Mark D. Guenette, mother-in-law Basia Gudemann, siblings Sheila Kurtz, Gary, Terry, Bruce and Sharon Atwell, niece Patricia Bylicki and longtime partner Robert Leeburg. Donations in his honor can be made to www.notinourname.net. Services were held November 2 at Mount Sinai Cemetery in Los Angeles. A celebration of his life will take place on November 9.

title: Designing an Identity To Make a Brand Fly
description: ALL-LEATHER seats. Extra legroom. Live satellite television at your seat. Minimalist, whimsical flourishes on the sides of the planes, and oh yeah, low fares.

title: 'The Reagans,' No Longer on CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: In a 'Jam,' Dean Apologizes for Remarks on Rebel Flag
description: Howard Dean apologized yesterday for his recent comments about Southerners who display the Confederate flag, saying, ''I deeply regret the pain that I may have caused.'' He said he would lead the nation in a ''difficult and painful discussion'' about race.

title: After the New York Election
description: New York City residents did the right thing in rejecting Mayor Michael Bloomberg's plan to make local elections nonpartisan. The ballot proposal that would have eliminated party primaries in city elections lost in a landslide. But those who crowed over the margin of victory and the defeat for Mr. Bloomberg curiously missed the larger point. What was true before Tuesday's vote is still true today: the city's electoral system needs a revamping to take power away from political party bosses, lessen corruption and increase voter participation. Mr. Bloomberg and his Charter Revision Commission fell short in defining the means, not the ends.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toymaker's Profit Falls
description: The Bandai Company, maker of the Power Ranger toys, said net profit slipped 4.9 percent, to 6.7 billion yen ($61 million) in the six months ended Sept. 30 because of higher taxes. Sales and operating profits increased in the period, helped by exports. The company kept its profit goal for the year unchanged at 14.2 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: U.N. Panel Puts Off Vote on Measures to Restrict Cloning
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 6  A United Nations committee today postponed a vote on competing resolutions that propose bans on human cloning, one of the most divisive nonpolitical issues among member states.

title: Gains at News Corporation Led by Fox Studios and DVD's
description: The News Corporation, the media giant controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a better-than-expected jump in its financial results for the three months ended Sept. 30, helped by gains at its Fox studios from the robust sales of DVD's that have lifted most Hollywood studios.

title: Critics Mobilize and London Police Brace for Bush's Visit
description: President Bush, who has been shielded from protests in recent travels, arrives in Britain on a state visit in two weeks, and the police here are weighing how to control promised street demonstrations without resorting to crowd control measures that could be seen as curbing free expression.

title: A Couple of Daring, Funny Blokes With a Flair for the Avant-Garde
description: Remember when the British were supposed to be reserved, understated and hypocritical and spoke on television with a BBC accent?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Firefighter Strikes
description: Unofficial strikes by British firefighters spread to several parts of the country in protest of reported changes to pay increases agreed to after stoppages dating to last year. The strikes coincided with Guy Fawkes Day, the annual celebration of the Gunpowder Plot of 1605, when Roman Catholic conspirators, including Fawkes, plotted to blow up Parliament and King James I. Many Britons celebrate by lighting bonfires, burning Fawkes in effigy and setting off fireworks. The fire brigade is usually busy. Striking firefighters said they would respond only to emergency calls. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Forgeries Prompt Grocers To Reject Internet Coupons
description: SEVERAL chain stores are refusing home-printed Internet discount coupons in some states because of what the grocery industry says is a surge in forgeries.

title: Dolls as Role Models, Neither Barbie nor Britney
description: Surrounded by exuberant girls, including her own 8-year-old, a Wisconsin resident named Jean Carter seemed positively thrilled as she paid $650, more than twice what she had planned, at American Girl Place here.

title: PATENT LAWSUIT FILED BY PLAYTEX PRODUCTS IS DISMISSED
description: A Playtex Products patent-infringement lawsuit over tampon applicators against Procter & Gamble has been dismissed. A federal judge threw out the lawsuit yesterday, finding that the Procter & Gamble product was not equivalent to the Playtex device. Judge Thomas M. Rose of Federal District Court in Dayton, Ohio, found that Procter & Gamble's applicator did not contain all the features covered by the Playtex patent. ''Playtex will appeal this ruling and is confident we will prevail,'' a company spokesman, Martin Petersen, said. A Procter & Gamble spokeswoman, Elaine Plummer, said the company was encouraged by the decision. Playtex is based in Westport, Conn. Procter & Gamble is based in Cincinnati.

title: Something Old and New, Both Are Broadway Blues
description: Dominic Moore had not been born when Mark Messier scored his first point in the National Hockey League, on Oct. 13, 1979.

title: Shares Fall on Lower Forecasts From Internet Companies
description: Stocks mostly fell yesterday as disappointing forecasts from the Internet companies Priceline.com and InterActiveCorp added to concern that the market's rally had left many shares expensive.

title: Free Trade Won't Free Cuba
description: According to our state television, the Castro regime was pleased that the United States Senate passed an amendment easing restrictions on American citizens traveling to Cuba. This was no surprise. Just days before the vote, Fidel Castro met here with a group of American travel agents. Both sides are impatient to make business deals in tourism on our island. But how much this would really benefit Cubans outside the top Communist Party leadership remains to be seen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, EDWARD
description: HOFFMAN -- Edward, of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of Sonia. Respected music teacher for more than 35 years. Service private.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Two Arrested In Shooting Deaths
description: The police arrested two teenagers on Tuesday in the shooting deaths of Kristopher Jimenez, 17, and Robert Melendez, 26, near Boston Secor Houses in the Bronx on Monday. The police said the teenagers, Apolinar Roque, 18, and Morlon Henry, 19, approached the victims on bicycles in a playground on Bivona Avenue. Mr. Henry accidentally shot himself in the hand during the attack, the police said. The motive for the shooting is unclear, but the police said the playground was a popular hangout for drug dealers. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Library Disclosure Law
description: Libraries would be required to tell parents who ask what books and videos their children were checking out under a measure passed by the State Senate on Tuesday and expected to be approved by the Assembly next week. The law, sponsored by State Representative Sheryl K. Albers, a Republican from Reedsburg, would apply to all children age 16 and under. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cosmetics Profit Declines
description: The cosmetics maker Shiseido Company said profit in the first six months fell 33.6 percent because of weaker sales and higher costs for its pension plan. Shiseido earned 6.6 billion yen ($61 million) in the half-year as sales fell 0.3 percent. It trimmed its net profit forecast for the year by 8 percent, to 23 billion yen ($209 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Getting Back to Essentials, Beatles Refuse to Let It Be
description: Of all the Beatles recordings, none has a history as fraught as ''Let It Be,'' and on Nov. 18 Capitol Records will add another wrinkle to the story, with the release of ''Let It Be . . . Naked.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cisco Says Strong Results Offer Proof of Recovery

title: INSIDE
description: Dean Regrets Flag Remark

title: Jets' Chrebet Sustains Another Concussion
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet sustained a concussion and was briefly knocked unconscious in Sunday's game against the Giants. Team doctors, concerned that he could be suffering from postconcussion syndrome because he has complained of fatigue and malaise, decided Wednesday to hold him out of Sunday's game against the Oakland Raiders.

title: Big Board Head Offers Detailed Overhaul Plan
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, proposed significant changes yesterday in how the exchange will be governed, including the creation of a stock exchange board that he said would be unencumbered by insider ties and conflicting interests.

title: M.L.S. Fines MetroStars' Mathis
description: MetroStars striker Clint Mathis was fined $500 yesterday by Major League Soccer ''for conduct unbecoming a professional athlete,'' a result of an altercation with fans at Giants Stadium after Saturday's 2-0 playoff loss to the New England Revolution.

title: The Reagans, No Longer on CBS (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Drugs From Canada, and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: For G.O.P., It's a Moment
description: President Bush's signing of the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act on Wednesday was a moment of political triumph for the anti-abortion movement, a reflection of its influence with a Republican-controlled Congress and a Republican president.

title: The Future of Iraq, and Its Occupiers (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: IDX SYSTEMS SAYS IT IS SUBJECT OF FEDERAL INQUIRY
description: The IDX Systems Corporation, a maker of medical software, said yesterday that federal prosecutors were investigating whether the company had made false statements related to an application for a project award from the Commerce Department. The inquiry stems from claims made by an employee, IDX said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. IDX, which is based in Burlington, Vt., said it would cooperate. IDX won a contract from the Commerce Department in 2001 to lead a $9.2 million research venture with four other companies, the filing said. The employee later asserted that IDX ''never had a serious interest in researching the technological solutions described in the proposal,'' the filing said. The company assumes the complaint was ''filed by a disgruntled employee,'' a spokeswoman, Margo Happer, said. ''The government is required by statute to investigate the allegations, which we believe to be without merit.''

title: Camcorders With Tape? How Quaint
description: ''COMPUTERS in the future may weigh no more than 1.5 tons,'' boasted a Popular Mechanics article in 1949. For anyone who has ever lugged a full-featured laptop all the way to Concourse Z, that day can't arrive soon enough.

title: Drugs From Canada, and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Gucci's Choice For Designer Needs Sketches, And Charisma
description: Serge Weinberg, the chief executive of the French retail group Pinault Printemps-Redoute, said on Tuesday that he had no timetable for replacing Tom Ford at Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. As the chattering in the fashion world settled yesterday on a number of candidates, none seemed a clear favorite, meaning that Mr. Weinberg's cool assessment may be the only reliable comment for now.

title: Quixotic Inventions
description: To the Editor:

title: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL SETTLES WHITEHOUSE LAWSUIT
description: Marriott International has reached a settlement with the owner of three hotels in New Orleans that sued the company, accusing it of unfair competition and financial mismanagement, a Marriott spokesman said yesterday. Under the settlement, the owner, Whitehouse Hotel, and a related entity, W.H. Holdings, both of Dallas, dropped their lawsuit against Marriott, the spokesman, Tom Marder, said. Mr. Marder declined to disclose the terms of the settlement but said they were not material to Marriott, which is based in Bethesda, Md. A lawyer for Whitehouse declined to comment. The lawsuit was dismissed on Tuesday. Whitehouse and W.H Holdings sued Marriott in April, asserting that Marriott's management of the former New Orleans Grand Hotel would financially hurt their nearby hotels, the Maison Orleans, the Ritz-Carlton New Orleans and the Iberville Suites. Lynnley Browning (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEDALDI, ROBERT J.
description: TEDALDI--Robert J., formerly of Crestwood, on November 4, 2003. Husband of Dorothea. Father of Ellen, Richard, Barbara, Michael, Eileen, Carole and Mark. Grandfather of 12. Brother of Eugene, Dante and Jane Hale. President of Teaco Construction Corp. and Crestwood Stone Supply. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7 to 9 PM, Thursday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM, Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Saturday, November 8, at 10:00am.

title: Survey Backs Reputation Of Danger in Group Homes
description: Group homes for teenage foster children in New York City have long had a rough reputation, but an in-depth survey of adolescents who have graduated from the homes and of judges, lawyers and caseworkers who have worked with them shows just how dangerous such institutional care can be.

title: Negotiators Resolve Dispute That Jeopardized Energy Bill
description: House and Senate tax writers resolved a dispute on Wednesday that was threatening major energy legislation, opening the way to consideration of a measure intended to stimulate domestic energy production and make the nation's electrical transmission system more dependable.

title: The Future of Iraq, And Its Occupiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Carnegie's Mr. Nice Guy Isn't Mr. Pushover
description: When Carnegie Hall was considering a merger with the New York Philharmonic last summer, a frequent prediction among classical music professionals was that Robert J. Harth, the artistic and executive director of Carnegie Hall, would ultimately be eclipsed by his counterpart Zarin Mehta, executive director of the Philharmonic.

title: A Screening With Stars But a Focus on Politics
description: It sounds like the beginning of a political joke: What do you get when you put Moby, a former White House chief of staff and Katrina vanden Heuvel in the same room?

title: The Future of Iraq, And Its Occupiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Governor Seeks to Toss Out Suit on Feeding Tube
description: Gov. Jeb Bush asked a judge on Wednesday to dismiss a suit seeking to stop him from intervening in the case of a brain-damaged woman whose husband wants her feeding tube removed.

title: Hair Styling, Plus Cancer Education; Brooklyn Health Project Goes Where the Women Are
description: The daily banter at Michou Hair Care goes far beyond hair. It encompasses a new job, an unfaithful boyfriend, a pair of sexy but painful shoes, a coveted day care slot.

title: When Can Drivers Be Halted? Justices Take Up Issue Anew
description: Police roadblocks, and the circumstances under which the police can impede the free movement of drivers whom they have no reason to suspect of a crime, are familiar territory for the Supreme Court. The court has upheld roadblocks to catch drunken drivers and, near the country's borders, illegal immigrants. It has struck down those aimed at finding illegal drugs.

title: School Board Votes to Dismiss 5 Mepham Football Coaches
description: Five football coaches at the center of the Mepham High School sexual abuse scandal will not be allowed to coach the team next year, the Bellmore-Merrick school board said on Wednesday night in a unanimous decision.

title: Sound Engulfs a Room Without Untidy Wires
description: Wiring the left, right and center speakers of a surround-sound system is easy enough because they are at one end of the room. More of a challenge is unobtrusively connecting the speakers along the room's sides. Two new home theater systems, the Niro 1.1 and 1.1 Pro, get around that by putting all five channels' worth of speakers, along with a small subwoofer, into one box.

title: In Traditional Chicago, The Politics of Fitting In
description: AS soon as the film producer Tom Rosenberg finished reading Philip Roth's novel ''The Human Stain,'' about an African-American who passes for white, he wanted to turn it into a movie. But first he called his friend Allison Davis. ''I had to be sure the story was credible,'' Mr. Rosenberg said. ''Allison would know.''

title: Toyota Posts Record $4.8 Billion 6-Month Profit
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest carmaker, posted record profits on Wednesday in the six months through Sept. 30, with sales growing in all of its major markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DYSTEL, MARION
description: DYSTEL--Marion. The Southern New York Chapter of the Multiple Sclerosis Society records with sorrow the passing of Marion Dystel, esteemed Board member and lifetime Trustee. Our heart felt condolences to Oscar Dystel, her husband and soul mate of 65 years, and to the family. Board of Trustees Wayne M. Lopkin, Chair Kathryn A. Coulam, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STIM, JOSEPH D.
description: STIM--Joseph D., 79, of Wantagh, NY, passed away on November 3, 2003, while snorkeling in Hawaii. An extraordinary man who relished peace and provoked thought, Joe served as a paratrooper in World War II, and was awarded the Purple Heart. He graduated from Broooklyn Law School, and practiced law for five decades, respected by his peers, and appreciated by his clients. He was a philosopher who sketched, a learned teacher, a hiker, a playwright, and a gentle man. Dear husband of Bobby for fifty-seven years, loving father of Barbi Jo (Sam Ciofalo), and Richard (Andrea Ross), adored grandfather of Sasha StimVogel. Services to be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Trnpk, Woodbury, NY on Sunday, November 9th at 10 A.M.

title: In Bushs Words: Iraqi Democracy Will Succeed
description: The following is the text of President Bush's remakrs on the 20th Anniversary of The National Endowment For Democracy, as transcribed by FDCH e-Media, Inc.

title: Man Killed by Police Was 'Crazed,' an Officer Who Shot Him Says
description: Gidone Busch was a large, frightening and ''crazed'' figure when he confronted police officers on a Borough Park sidewalk four years ago, one of the officers who shot him testified yesterday.

title: COMPANY SAYS UNIT IT BOUGHT IS BEING INVESTIGATED
description: Curative Health Services, which manages wound-treatment centers, said a pharmacy in Spring Valley, N.Y., that it bought in June is under criminal investigation and the authorities have seized billing records. The company itself is not the focus of the investigation, Curative said. The pharmacy was acquired with a division of the closely held Prescription City for $17.5 million. Curative said that based on information received from investigators, it fired Paul Frank, formerly the largest shareholder of Prescription City, placed another employee on administrative leave and hired outside counsel. Mr. Frank and a company spokesman could not be reached for comment. Separately, Curative said third-quarter net income fell to $1.77 million, or 13 cents a share, from $3.93 million, or 31 cents, in the period a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about a woman who was charged with making a bomb threat against a high school in Pemberton, N.J., misspelled the name of the town where she lives. It is Browns Mills, not Brown Mills.

title: Tarnished but Still Platinum; R. Kelly Is Popular Despite Pornography Charges
description: On a recent afternoon R. Kelly found himself onstage in a small Manhattan nightclub, singing a gorgeous, gentle version of the Sam Cooke classic ''You Send Me.'' When he finished, he looked up from the piano, expecting applause. There was none. This wasn't a concert, after all, it was a photography shoot for a magazine.

title: A New Slogan for Pepsi Without the Joy
description: New Slogan for Pepsi

title: Market Place; The Gucci news looks good for LVMH, but looks can be deceiving.
description: AT first blush, the announcement that Tom Ford and Domenico De Sole will be leaving Gucci at the end of April seems like nothing but good news for Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Gucci's archrival in the luxury goods market.

title: A Classic Tale of Girl Meets Squash
description: SQUASH is not generally one of the vegetables that fire passion in the soul (or in the taste buds). Futtsu Black, a ribbed, flat squash that looks as if someone sat on it, is not likely to arouse the same excitement as say, a ripe, two-pound Brandywine tomato.

title: Death Be Not Loud
description: Who can blame poor President Bush? Look at his terrible dilemma.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: High-Rise Fire Safety
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, responding to a downtown fire that killed six people last month, told the City Council he wanted sprinklers in nearly all high-rise buildings by 2016. Residential buildings and landmarks would be exempt, though they would have to improve fire safety in other ways. The mayor has proposed tax incentives to help offset the cost, which would be in the millions. New commercial and residential buildings higher than 35 feet would be required to install sprinklers under the proposal, which the City Council will vote on within weeks. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBMAN, MARILYN
description: LIEBMAN--Marilyn. On November 4. Dear wife of William. Loving mother of Barbara, Marc, and Daniel. Caring mother-in-law of Anthony, Jody, and six grandchildren. Service Thursday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Streeet and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dominican-Made Powder Remedy Is Poisonous, Health Officials Say
description: A powder sold to Dominicans for years as a remedy for everything from body odor to foot fungus is highly poisonous, health officials warned yesterday, and New York City is trying to persuade botnicas, the herbal medicine shops that cater to Hispanic communities, to stop selling it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Quixotic Inventions

title: Iraq Said to Have Tried to Reach Last-Minute Deal to Avert War
description: As American soldiers massed on the Iraqi border in March and diplomats argued about war, an influential adviser to the Pentagon received a secret message from a Lebanese-American businessman: Saddam Hussein wanted to make a deal.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Gains By G.O.P.
description: The Republican Party, which lagged in registered voters for much of the last century, has made major gains across the country and pulled even with Democrats, a study of the electorate found. Of those surveyed by the Pew Research Center, 34 percent identified themselves as Democrats, 33 percent as Republicans and 33 percent as independents. Republican gains were chiefly among white Protestants, white Roman Catholics and Hispanics and came in swing states like Iowa, Michigan and Minnesota. But opposition to the Iraq war and rising partisan polarization could complicate further gains, the survey found. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Your Social Secretary

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: PREMIER REJECTS DEPORTATION INQUIRY Prime Minister Jean Chrétien rejected calls for a public inquiry into the case of Maher Arar, the Canadian citizen who was deported to Syria by the United States last year on suspicion that he was a terrorist. Mr. Chrétien called the case "deplorable" and blamed the United States, saying that the Canadian government had nothing to do with it. Mr. Arar, of Ottawa, has called for an independent inquiry to clear his name and uncover what role Canada might have played in the decision to detain him at Kennedy Airport and deport him to his native Syria, where, he said, he was tortured. American officials have said they were acting on information from Canadian agencies. Mr. Chretien said a new inquiry was not necessary since the Royal Canadian Mounted Police is conducting one.    Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Quixotic Inventions
description: To the Editor:

title: Short, but the Very Image of a Star
description: HE may have become a political giant this year. But Arnold Schwarzenegger has also shrunk.

title: Drugs From Canada, and the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: The Finer Points Of Moroccan Needlework
description: Isabelle Denamur, a French model-turned-ethnologist, became fascinated with the embroidery of Morocco in the 1970's, while on fashion shoots there. After years of collecting and research, she has written, Ms. Denamur said, ''the book I had always wanted to read.''

title: Economic Scene; With Milton Friedman's ideas now accepted by theorists and policy makers, it's easy to forget how revolutionary they were.
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, I took my first economics class. Like many other college students, I wanted to understand why the economy of our teenage years was such a scary mess, with inflation and rising taxes eroding our parents' paychecks, interest rates soaring and unemployment an ever present threat.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Auto Seller Plans Dividend
description: Astra International of Indonesia said it would pay its first dividend since 1997 as strong demand for its cars helped it recover from $850 million in debt. Astra, about a third of which is owned by Cycle and Carriage of Singapore, was forced to ask creditors late last year to restructure its debt for the second time since the Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998 forced it into default. It said it would pay shareholders 50 rupiah (0.6 cents) a share on Dec. 18. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Truce Effort Comes to Naught, And O'Donnell Suit Resumes
description: After settlement talks between Rosie O'Donnell and her former publishing partner Gruner & Jahr USA broke down over a confidentiality clause on Tuesday, hostilities resumed in full force yesterday in Room 242 of New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: G.O.P. Extends Statehouse Sweeps, but What Do They Mean for '04?
description: Forecast as squeakers, the elections for governor in Mississippi and Kentucky turned out to be anything but on Tuesday, with Republicans comfortably on top. Haley Barbour won here by seven percentage points, defeating a Democratic incumbent, and Representative Ernie Fletcher won by 10 in Kentucky, ending 32 years of Democratic reign there.

title: Microsoft Sets $5 Million Virus Bounty
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it was putting a bounty on the heads of virus writers.

title: A Maverick Assemblyman Becomes the First Democrat in a Decade to Run Suffolk
description: Hours before Steve Levy strode to a lectern to declare political victory as the newly elected Suffolk County executive, he sat at his mother's kitchen table in Holbrook. He sketched out a thank-you list; she mixed an egg cream.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Didn't We Donate That Shirt To Housing Works?

title: Republican and Democratic Panel Leaders Take Feud to the Senate Floor
description: Five months after the Senate Intelligence Committee began its review of prewar intelligence on Iraq, a contentious dispute broke out on the Senate floor on Wednesday as the panel's top Republican and Democrat traded accusations of bad faith.

title: Christabel Bielenberg, Anti-Nazi Memoirist, Dies at 94
description: Christabel Burton Bielenberg, a well-born Englishwoman who wrote a best-selling memoir about saving her German husband, a Nazi resister, from the Gestapo, died on Sunday at the family's home in rural Ireland. She was 94.

title: Ads Aren't All the Browser Tool Is Blocking
description: THE Google toolbar, a thin row of buttons and a query window that sits within the Internet Explorer browser, has become a big hit, with millions of people using it each day. Last summer it attracted even more users when Google added a pop-up blocker to the toolbar's features, effectively filtering the unsolicited advertisements that appear along with many Web pages.

title: Fight Over Tips Prolongs Strike at La Caravelle
description: Striking workers at the ''21'' Club and La Caravelle, two top-drawer Manhattan restaurants, reached a tentative labor contract yesterday, but there was one pesky issue that kept the workers out at La Caravelle: the sommelier's share of the tips.

title: Spain Is Told Its Help in Iraq Will Pay Off
description: Spain's political support of the United States in the war in Iraq will have an economic payoff, the president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, Thomas J. Donohue, told Spanish business leaders here on Wednesday.

title: Campaign Finance System May Be Facing Its Endgame
description: If Howard Dean joins President Bush in declining taxpayer money in the presidential primaries, the move could upend a system that most candidates have used to finance campaigns for almost 30 years, critics and supporters of the program say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARONIN, IRVING S.
description: ARONIN--Irving S., Judge. Beloved husband of Judge Gloria Cohen Aronin. Adored father of Douglas, Heidi and Scott. Doting grandfather of Noah, Chava and Jacob. Service at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Ave (at Ave L), today at 12:30pm.

title: Pettitte and Rodriguez? Imagine
description: The Yankees have said that pitching is their top priority this off-season, but they have taken a passive approach to re-signing Andy Pettitte, who won 21 games last season. Pettitte is waiting until open bidding begins to speak with the Yankees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 4 about revisions in the high school admissions process in New York City misstated the number of students who did not get one of their choices last year. It was 31,000, not 13,000. A letter from the city's Department of Education pointed out the error on Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Meadow: Businessman Held On Drug Charges
description: A former president of the Oyster Bay Chamber of Commerce has been arrested as part of a 10-month federal investigation into a loosely connected cross-country marijuana network, the Nassau County district attorney announced yesterday. Nine people were arrested last month. The former president, Lester Huffer, 57, of Locust Valley, was arrested on Oct. 7, although details were released only yesterday. Rick Hinshaw, a spokesman for the district attorney, said the release was delayed because others were still at large. Mr. Huffer is accused of selling an unspecified quantity of marijuana from his sign shop in Oyster Bay and from his Locust Valley home. If convicted, he faces up to 15 years in prison. He remains in the Nassau County Correctional Facility in $150,000 bail. His lawyer did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Electronic Messages Become A Beacon In the Darkness
description: The night sky over Yamaguchi, Japan, will glow this month with the light from electronic messages transmitted over the Internet. ''Amodal Suspension,'' a public artwork by Rafael Lozano-Hemmer, a Mexican-Canadian electronic artist based in Montreal, allows visitors to the project's Web site (www.amodal.net) to send short text messages that are then beamed into the sky by 20 computer-controlled searchlights at the Yamaguchi Center for Arts and Media. The project, commissioned for the center's opening on Nov.1, will run through Nov.24.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Nuclear Arms Money
description: The Bush administration would get much of the money it sought for new nuclear weapons initiatives under a spending plan approved by House and Senate negotiators who overrode objections that the research could set off a new arms race. Lawmakers working on a spending plan for the Energy Department agreed to provide almost $50 million for research into a new generation of nuclear weapons that the administration says are needed to penetrate underground bunkers. The measure would reduce some elements of the request and put new restrictions on spending. Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bid For Gambling Concern
description: Australia's largest gambling company, Tabcorp Holdings, has offered to buy Tab Ltd., the second biggest, for 1.9 billion Australian dollars ($1.35 billion) in cash and stock. The deal would combine 18,000 slot machines and four casinos and betting shops. Tabcorp offered 23 of its shares and 162 Australian dollars in cash for every 100 Tab shares, the chief executive of Tabcorp, Matthew Slatter, above, said. Tabcorp will assume 364 million Australian dollars of Tab debt.

title: Redskins Owner Backs Spurrier
description: Despite a four-game losing streak that has landed the Washington Redskins in last place in their division, Daniel Snyder, the team's owner, is apparently not disenchanted with his coach, Steve Spurrier.

title: 'Smart' Cards to Speed Service at Football Games
description: The St. Louis Rams football team hopes to provide some relief for the fan who has missed a crucial play while waiting at a concession stand to buy beer or hot dogs: prepaid smart cards and express lines for the people who use them.

title: M.T.A. Agrees To Settle Suits With Manager Of 2 Broadway
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a real estate developer have agreed to settle lawsuits arising from the agency's plan to move to a building in Lower Manhattan -- a plan whose cost tripled to more than $400 million in less than five years.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Ground column in the Business Travel pages on Tuesday, about Houston, misstated the neighborhood for the Houstonian Hotel, Club and Spa. It is in the Galleria area, not the Woodlands.

title: For G.I.'s, a Joyful Trip Home Suddenly Becomes a Painful Ordeal
description: For Sgt. Christopher Nelson, who had never flown in a helicopter, it was going to be a joyful maiden voyage. Strapped in next to one of his buddies, a camera in hand, Sergeant Nelson was headed home to Texas, after seven harrowing months in Iraq.

title: From a Suicide Bomber's Father, No Praise, Just Grief
description: The day after 16-year-old Sabih Abu Saud blew himself up in a West Bank village, with Israeli troops in pursuit, his father Kamal Abu Saud did something extremely unusual -- he declined to eulogize his son as a hero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IDIGORAS, LUIS
description: IDIGORAS--Luis. November 1st, 2003, in New York City. Beloved friend and neighbor. Condolences to his family in Spain.

title: The Future of Iraq, And Its Occupiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, November 05, 2003. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

title: Langenbrunner Helps Devils Win 4th Straight
description: So many pucks flew into the stands Wednesday night that Devils center John Madden said the tiny freezer next to the ice had to be restocked with pucks not once, but twice. That, he said, is a rarity.

title: A Return to the Stone Age With a Look to the Immovable
description: A furniture collection called Mobilier Immobile, by Guillaume Bardet, 31, above, is a marriage of sculpture and architecture. The collection, which includes the Carrara marble daybed, above, giant vases, low table, round-bottom rocking stools, a wide bench where two people can lie down and an undulating sofa, were produced during a nine-month fellowship at the Villa Medici in Rome. When the furniture dealer Yves Gastou saw Mr. Bardet's first designs, he financed the collection and is showing Mr. Bardet's work through Dec. 16. Weighing in at 1 1/2 to 2 tons the larger pieces and 220 pounds to 440 pounds for smaller ones, the designs cost $4,580 to $28,628.

title: Editors' Note
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday about Iraq's foreign debt should have more fully disclosed the background of its author, Mark Medish. Mr. Medish, an international lawyer and former Treasury official, represents corporations that are owed money by Iraq.

title: Russian Markets Jitter Anew At Cabinet Member's Remark
description: A Russian official threw a scare into an already jittery marketplace on Wednesday, suggesting that licenses to develop the country's natural resources could be reviewed and withdrawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABINOR, RUTH GLEEN
description: RABINOR--Ruth Gleen, 87, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on November 5, 2003. Beloved wife of Herb Gleen. Mother of Judith C. Kirschner, Arnold J. Rabinor and Joan E. Rabinor. Mother-in-law of Elliot, Irene and Robert. Grandmother of seven and greatgrandmother of five. Services will be held Friday November 7, 10am, at the Boulevard-Park West Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. 516295-3100. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to American Diabetes Association.

title: Only Motivated Voters Ventured Into the Voting Booth
description: Only a few weeks ago, a Quinnipiac University poll found that a slight majority of New York City voters favored doing away with political party primaries.

title: A Cloud Over Belichick Lifts After the Patriots Win 7 of 8
description: A 5-foot-10, 190-pound sophomore named Bill Belichick handled long-snapping duties at Wesleyan in 1972. By his own admission, Belichick would haphazardly fire the ball over the punter's head. That was probably one reason he made his name in lacrosse and squash.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Interest Rate Raised
description: The Reserve Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter-point, to 5 percent, the first increase since June 2002. The bank raised the rate in response to growing consumer debt and a sharp increase in home loans. In announcing the rate change, the bank said that high demand for credit had increased ''the danger associated with delaying a tightening of policy.'' John Shaw (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I tend to be reflective rather later than sooner. Now, unfortunately, we all know that nobody's personality is perfect. So the things that make me a strong candidate are also my Achilles' heel.''

title: Quick To Buy, Hoping To Sell
description: WHEN Eliot and Jann Zuckerman put their Upper East Side apartment on the market in January, it attracted a seemingly endless stream of lookers.

title: Extent of Ban Is Questioned
description: The abortion ban that President Bush signed into law yesterday is meant to cover a technique used to end a pregnancy that has advanced beyond 18 to 20 weeks. But confusion remains over whether the ban would also cover a more common form of second-trimester abortion.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the consecration of the Rev. V. Gene Robinson, a gay man, as Episcopal bishop of New Hampshire, referred incorrectly to the hometown of Suzanne Filippone, who held a poster saying ''Christianity Is Tolerance.'' The town, South Berwick, is in Maine, not New Hampshire.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hong Kong Computer Maker Posts Loss
description: The Legend Group, Asia's top maker of personal computers, had a lower-than-expected profit in its fiscal second quarter because of losses at its mobile phone unit and price cuts prompted by competition with Dell. Net income rose 2 percent to 261 million Hong Kong dollars ($34 million) in the three months that ended on Sept. 30, from 256 million Hong Kong dollars a year earlier. Sales rose 12 percent but the company's market share in China slipped as other computer makers stepped up sales. Legend, which has its operational headquarters in Beijing, gets more than 90 percent of its revenue from China. Its stock fell 5 percent.

title: Mets Hire High-Tech Pitching Coach
description: Rick Peterson, whose cutting-edge, high-tech training regimen helped make quick stars of three young Oakland Athletics pitchers, was hired yesterday as the Mets' pitching coach.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER TO RETIRE AT TOYS 'R' US
description: Toys ''R'' Us said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Louis Lipschitz, would retire in March after 17 years with the company. A search for a successor is expected to be completed early next year, the company said. Mr. Lipschitz, 58, has been with the company since 1986 and has been chief financial officer since 1993.

title: Final Event Could Answer All Questions
description: For Tiger Woods, winning the PGA Tour money title has become a habit. For Vijay Singh, winning the money title has become a mission.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: GAY-MARRIAGE LAWSUIT IS DISMISSED A Superior Court judge dismissed a lawsuit yesterday brought by seven gay couples who sought to have same-sex unions legally recognized in New Jersey. Lambda Legal, the advocacy group that argued the case for the couples, said it would appeal the ruling. Judge Linda Feinberg said in her opinion that there was nothing in the state's Constitution that guaranteed same-sex unions as a right, and said the appropriate forum to change marriage laws was the Legislature. The lawsuit was filed last year by seven couples who have been in committed relationships for more than 10 years. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Posts Profit
description: France's largest bank, BNP Paribas, posted a 69.3 percent increase in profit in the third quarter, helped by investment gains and a rebound in the markets. Profits rose to 970 million euros ($1.1 billion) from 573 million euros ($659 million) a year earlier. The bank also reported capital gains of 423 million euros, in contrast to a loss of 7 million euros in the third quarter of 2002. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Mayor's Loss in Referendum Emboldens Democrats for '05
description: A day after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suffered a bruising defeat over his proposal for nonpartisan elections, Democratic leaders turned their attention to the mayoral race of 2005, with one Democrat taking the first step toward running.

title: An Unconventional Tradition of Success
description: The tintinnabulations of the Abbey Church tower bells mixed with voices as the only sounds heard on the football practice field. It was on a recent gray late afternoon, and the St. John's College team was running plays in this relatively isolated area in the central part of the state, located amid a forest with the trees nearly bare of leaves.

title: Stifling Patent Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTLIEB, ZELDA
description: GOTTLIEB--Zelda. On November 4, 2003. Loving wife to Alan. Devoted mother of Dale Gottlieb Hudson and Martin Gottlieb. Daughter of Bess Littman. Dear sister of Deborah Markowitz and Harvey Littman. Adored grandmother of Blake and Hill Hudson. Services Friday, November 7, 10AM, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn (Ave M).

title: Senate Debate Due on Hotly Contested Internet Tax Bill
description: A long-delayed federal Internet tax bill that would turn a temporary moratorium on taxes on Internet access into a permanent ban is scheduled for debate today on the floor of the Senate.

title: Terrorists in Kenya Killings Posed as Fishermen, a Report Says
description: The terrorists who attacked an Israeli resort and an airliner along the Kenyan coast last November posed as lobstermen while they smuggled missiles and other weapons from Somalia aboard a wooden boat, according to a United Nations report.

title: Showtime Addresses Concerns On 'Reagans'
description: The Showtime cable network -- which picked up the ''The Reagans'' mini-series after its sister network CBS dropped it amid intense criticism from Republican and conservative groups -- is preparing a panel discussion to follow the broadcast of the television movie.

title: Hollywood Stumbles At Doorstep Of Politics
description: Ronald Reagan was a genius.

title: Canada's Indians Pondering How to Invest Land Payouts
description: Already adept at surviving frigid winters, trapping beaver and hunting caribou and seals, people in aboriginal communities in some of the remotest parts of northern Canada are learning how to manage a multimillion-dollar investment portfolio.

title: Footing the Bill For Computer Lab
description: FOR Nancy Couto, the director of technology for the Armada school district in suburban Detroit, walking into a computer lab at the high school is like stepping back in time. There, beat-up machines still run Windows 95 and barely chug along on 120-megahertz processors and 16 megabytes of memory, a tiny fraction of what even the most basic new desktop comes with these days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMYTHE, SHEILA MARY
description: SMYTHE--Sheila Mary. Suddenly on November 4, 2003. Devoted daughter of Patrick and Molly (nee Gonley) Smythe. Dear friend of Anne E. Schneiders. She is also survived by a loving family in Ireland and England. She was a caring, compassionate woman who was always ready to help anyone in need. At the time of her death, she was Executive Vice President of New York Medical College and Dean of its School of Public Health. She had previously served as President and Chief Operating Officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and as Chief Health Policy Advisor for the U.S. General Accounting Office. Ms. Smythe had a passion for education and public health, with a special interest in children. She served as a member or chair of numerous boards and advisory councils throughout her career, including Manhattanville College, Dominican Academy, the March of Dimes, Catholic Charities USA, the Astor Home for Children, the Dominican Sisters of Hope (Newburgh), the Dominican Sisters of Saint Mary of the Springs (Columbus, OH.), the Visiting Nurse Service of Westchester, and Mutual of America Life Insurance Company. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday and Friday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Resurrection Saturday, November 8th, 10AM, Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave at 66 St. Interment Cedar Hill Cemetery, Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the School of Public Health Scholarship Fund at New York Medical College.

title: Soaring Into the Air With a Boost From a Laser Beam
description: SOMEWHERE, Nikola Tesla is smiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARBER, ETHEL
description: MARBER--Ethel, on November 5, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Al. Loving mother of Susan. Dear sister of the late Frank, Sophie, Bea, Frances and Seymour. She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEDALE, HERBERT
description: ROSEDALE -- Herbert. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Jenkins and Gilchrist Parker Chapin deeply mourn the passing of our beloved and esteemed partner, Herbert Rosedale. In addition to providing the firms' clients with exemplary service for more than 46 years, Herb was an attorney whose deep compassion for others drove him to devote countless hours of pro bono service to victims of cults. Although he will be sorely missed, his legacy will live on through the many young attorneys he mentored over the years in whom he instilled the values that endeared him to his partners, his clients and all who had the privilege of knowing him. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Ethel, and his entire family. Services will be held on Thursday, November 6th at 1:00 PM at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester.

title: 26 Years After Launching, Voyager Is at Crucial Border
description: Twenty-six years and more than eight billion miles from Earth, the durable Voyager 1 spacecraft has journeyed a greater distance than any other human-made object, but scientists are not sure exactly what it has encountered at the far frontier of the solar system.

title: Free Tutoring Is Reaching More Students In the System
description: One-third more poor children in substandard New York City public schools will receive free tutoring this year than last, the Department of Education said yesterday. The department and its critics attributed the increase to improved outreach to eligible families with earlier notification, clearer correspondence and help from new parent coordinators.

title: Illness as an Inspiration
description: Some budding entrepreneurs find inspiration in business classes, in how-to books or in larger-than-life chief executives. As strange as it may seem, Jeff Margolis, chief executive of the TriZetto Group, a company in Newport Beach, Calif., that provides information-technology software and services to health care organizations, found inspiration in a disorder that has afflicted him since he was 19.

title: French Doctor Expected to Be Charged in Assisted Suicide Case
description: In a surprising twist to a euthanasia case that has captivated the nation, the head doctor of the intensive care ward where a French paraplegic, Vincent Humbert, died six weeks ago is expected to be charged with premeditated murder for injecting Mr. Humbert with poison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, MARIELLA
description: WOLF--Mariella. The K.S. Giniger Company mourns the loss of its longtime London representative and dear friend. Our sincere condolences to her many friends and loved ones.

title: Bush Signs Ban On a Procedure For Abortions
description: President Bush signed legislation on Wednesday to outlaw the procedure whose opponents call it partial-birth abortion. The president said the nation ''owes its children a different and better welcome.''

title: Jones Looking for Another Title
description: Roy Jones Jr., the only reigning heavyweight titleholder to move down in weight to gain a title, arrived in Las Vegas yesterday morning for his fight Saturday against Antonio Tarver, who replaced him as the light-heavyweight champion.

title: Iraqis at the Wheel
description: For the past six weeks the news from Iraq has felt like the movie ''Groundhog Day.'' I get up each morning, fire up my Internet and read that a roadside bomb has killed another U.S. soldier. I search for any good news, but rarely find it. Lord knows, we desperately need a new movie, and not ''Apocalypse Now.'' The movie we need is the Iraqi version of ''Mr. Chips Goes to Baghdad.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASE, KENNETH
description: KASE--Kenneth, attorney. On November 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Sandra. Devoted father of Nancy Abramson. Cherished grandather of Chloe Spear. Dear brother of Harold Kase. Loving uncle of John Kase, Jay and Richard Goldberger. Services on Thursday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Greenspan Hints Era of Very Low Rates May Be Nearing End
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6  Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, offered a first hint today that the era of rock-bottom interest rates may be drawing to a close.

title: Dr. Dean and the Pickup Truck
description: A year out from the presidential election, former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont has advanced from the political backwoods to the front of the Democratic pack. Dr. Dean's unequivocal opposition to the Iraq war and masterly use of the Internet for grass-roots fund-raising have made him the early, and unexpected, leader in the run for the nomination. Over the next few months, Democratic voters will be watching to see whether he has the political skills and staying power to win a presidential election.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 27 last year about telephone callers who offered tips in the Washington-area sniper case misstated the occupation of a man who spotted the suspects' car at a rest stop near Myersville, Md. The man, Whitney Donahue, is a supermarket refrigerator repairman, not a rest stop attendant. (The article figured last May in corrections of erroneous reporting by Jayson Blair, but this error did not come to light until Mr. Donahue testified on Monday.)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Expected To Gain In 2004
description: After a two-year-long slump that has left many chip companies struggling, total sales of semiconductors are expected to increase nearly 20 percent next year, according to a report released yesterday by the Semiconductor Industry Association. Computer and electronic manufacturers said they were relieved at the optimistic forecast, which they consider an important measure of anticipated customer demand. The trade association said chip sales would grow by 19.4 percent in 2004, for total sales next year of $194.6 billion. But according to the association, growth in the semiconductor market is expected to slow in 2005 because of the cycles in which corporations upgrade their personal computers. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Retail Resurrection, Of a Shoe Legend
description: Roger Vivier, a pacesetting French shoe designer of the 1950's, 60's and 70's, died in 1998. But Diego Della Valle, the owner of J. P. Tod's, is resurrecting the Vivier brand with a luxury shoe collection designed by Bruno Frisoni, right. (Prices range from $400 to $15,000.)

title: Bush Outlines Vision for Expanding Democracy in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — President Bush described today a vision of how democracy could unfold in the Middle East and beyond once Iraq is stabilized, challenging Iran, Syria and one crucial American ally in the region — Egypt — to end traditions of authoritarianism.

title: Roche Is Told To Curb Sales Of Novel Test
description: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered Roche to stop selling a novel diagnostic test until it obtains regulatory approval. In a letter to the company posted on the F.D.A. Web site on Tuesday, the agency said Roche had improperly classified the test in a way that allowed it to skirt regulatory review.

title: Speaker Agrees To Back Bill On Removing Lead Paint
description: Under pressure from children's advocates and his fellow City Council members, Speaker Gifford Miller has agreed to support a bill that would govern how lead-paint hazards are removed from city apartments, officials close to the talks said yesterday.

title: 'The Reagans,' No Longer on CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHSTEIN, MURRAY
description: ROTHSTEIN--Murray, age 91, on November 4, 2003, in Encinitas, California. Beloved husband of Martha (nee Miller). Loving father of Donna and Charles Sher, and Wendy Rothstein. Adoring grandfather of Hayley and Mia Sher. Mr. Rothstein was a veteran of Omaha Beach, WWII. A decorated member of the Jewish War Veterans Post #

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: With Vick Still Out, Falcons Go South
description: Three days after quarterback Michael Vick broke his leg in a preseason game on Aug. 16, the Atlanta Falcons scoffed at any suggestion that their playoff aspirations were in jeopardy without him. In the middle of a still-buoyant locker room, the veteran cornerback Ray Buchanan said he and his teammates were insulted at the suggestion that they were going to be a losing team without Vick's sensational playmaking.

title: Death Penalty Trial Begins In an Alleged Gang Murder
description: ''Informers must die'' was the motto of a Flatbush drug gang that prospered by killing and intimidating witnesses against it, a prosecutor said yesterday at the opening of a federal death penalty trial of a Brooklyn man accused of being a feared member of the gang.

title: Cisco Earnings and Growth Beat Predictions
description: Cisco Systems, the large Internet equipment maker, reported quarterly earnings and revenue growth Wednesday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations. That result, company executives said, offered further evidence of economic recovery.

title: As Houston Cools Off, Bucks Ease Past Knicks
description: For 20 intoxicating minutes of the first half, Allan Houston was as artful as he was automatic, putting Milwaukee into a helpless trance by making 12 of 14 shots from everywhere on the floor and pouring in 27 points.

title: In Amazon's Text Search, a Field Day for Book Browsers
description: DAVID SMITH, a product manager in Seattle, knows of the hubbub surrounding Amazon.com's new feature, Search Inside the Book. The service, introduced two weeks ago, allows people to do keyword searches within the text of books before buying them. Predictions about the future of books have been swirling in the air ever since.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: 'The Reagans,' No Longer on CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Team Effort In Kick Fiasco
description: Jets place-kicker Doug Brien, who was blamed by coaches for the field-goal fiasco in the overtime loss to the Giants on Sunday, admitted Wednesday that he took too long to get ready for the attempt but said that he was not the only one at fault.

title: Can't Get No Satisfaction? Change the Camera Angle
description: The Rolling Stones' ''Four Flicks'' DVD set, set for release next week, includes a feature that lets viewers create an impromptu director's cut. Three songs on the four-disk set have an option called Select-a-Stone that lets the viewer choose any of five camera angles without interrupting the performance.

title: LAWYERS AT E.P.A. SAY IT WILL DROP POLLUTION CASES
description: A change in enforcement policy will lead the Environmental Protection Agency to drop investigations into 50 power plants for past violations of the Clean Air Act, lawyers at the agency who were briefed on the decision this week said.

title: ELECTRONICS COMPANY TO TAKE $287 MILLION CHARGE
description: Royal Philips Electronics said yesterday that it would take a 250 million euro ($287 million) charge by the end of 2005 as part of an effort to revamp its consumer electronics division. The company, which expects to save $400 million a year, said it was fighting strong competition from abroad. Philips said its domestic consumer electronics division had been hit especially hard by price wars. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: In Japan, Rethinking the Shoe Box
description: A SMALL house need not be claustrophobic, even here, where the average apartment is just 774 square feet.

title: Carlisle Was Able To Land On His Feet
description: Byron Scott has been around the N.B.A. too long to be surprised by sudden shifts. But one day last spring, even he had to regain his balance.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Novell's agreement to buy SuSE Linux of Germany misstated the given name of SuSE's chief executive. He is Richard Seibt, not Robert.

title: Troops Say Farewell to Comrades Who Died in Copter Attack
description: AL ASAD, Iraq, Nov. 6 — Several hundred American soldiers gathered this evening at a former Iraqi air base here to say farewell to 15 comrades who died Sunday after their Chinook helicopter was struck by a missile.

title: British Police Brace For Bush Protesters
description: President Bush, who has been shielded from protests in recent travels, arrives in Britain on a state visit in two weeks, and the police are weighing how to deal with demonstrations against his Iraq policy.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: First Female Governor
description: Olene S. Walker, a Republican, was sworn in as the state's first female governor, replacing Michael O. Leavitt, who resigned to lead the Environmental Protection Agency. Ms. Walker, 72, who was lieutenant governor, will serve out Mr. Leavitt's term, which ends in January 2005. Gayle McKeachnie, a lawyer, was sworn in as the new lieutenant governor. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Unsure of Role, Levens Is Glad to Be Playing
description: For the past three games, Dorsey Levens has been a part of the Giants' running back rotation. But ask him if he knows his role with the Giants now, and Levens laughs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENZER, MICHAEL M.
description: ENZER--Michael M. Died suddenly at home November 5. Husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Roberta (Leonard) Kahn and Sharon. Adoring grandfather of Scott and Audra. Member of NYS Society of CPAs. Services today 12 noon Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: The Neediest Cases; Offstage, Her Life's Script Takes a Devastating Twist
description: For Quintell Williams, the year leading up to the summer of 2002 was a good one, maybe even great.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Tariff Plan Advances
description: The European Commission has agreed to a plan that would place sanctions on a wide range of American imports in March unless the United States repeals a law that grants tax breaks for exporters. A commission spokeswoman, Arancha Gonzalez, said that the plan was still subject to the approval of countries in the European Union. The total cost of the plan to American exporters would reach 319 million euros ($366 million) in 2004 and rise to 600 million euros in 2005, Ms. Gonzalez said. The House and Senate are considering proposals to repeal or alter the tax breaks. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: SHARES OF ESPERION UP 35% AFTER NEWS ON DRUG
description: Shares of Esperion Therapeutics rose 35 percent yesterday after the company said that its experimental drug had melted fatty deposits from arteries in a five-week study, a first in heart-disease treatment. The medicine, called ETC-216, reduced the layer of plaque lining patients' arteries about 4.2 percent, according to research published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Esperion announced the findings late Tuesday. The medicine's success is crucial for Esperion, which has no products on the market. ETC-216 would be used to prevent heart attacks and reverse heart disease. Shares of Esperion, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., rose $6.10, to $23.60 a share.

title: Sports Briefing
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASS, MARILYN R.
description: GLASS--Marilyn R. On November 5. Mother of David and Jean. Grandmother of Jeremy. Sister of Allan and Phyllis. Service Friday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rises in Services and Factory Orders
description: Service industries expanded at a faster rate last month and factory orders rose in September for a fourth time in five months, reports released yesterday show, amid signs that the economic expansion may be adding jobs in services at a faster pace.

title: U.N. Panel Puts Off Vote on Measures to Restrict Cloning
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 6 — The United Nations voted today to postpone for two years any further consideration of a ban on human cloning, an issue that has sharply divided member states.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 376 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRISTEL, BEVERLY
description: KRISTEL--Beverly. On November 4, 2003. Beloved wife to Ira for 53 years. Devoted mother to Alan, Steven and Mindy. Dear niece to Molly. Adored grandmother to Jackie, Elizabeth, Anna, Lara, Nicole, Jordana, Nathaniel, Julia, Anton and Matthew. Throughout her life, Beverly treasured her family above all. We will all miss her deeply. Service will be held today at 11:30am at BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Donations may be made in her name to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, 386 Park Ave South, 14 flr, NY, NY 10016

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about the results of the City Council election misidentified the borough in which Gifford Miller, the speaker, campaigned on behalf of Councilman Michael E. McMahon. It was Staten Island, not Queens.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about efforts by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, embattled founder of the Russian oil company Yukos, to gain access to influential Americans referred incompletely to his approach to the Brookings Institution, the Washington policy research organization. While Brookings said it had debated the possibility of accepting money from Mr. Khodorkovsky, he never formally offered any.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Accused Drug Kingpin Sentenced
description: The leader of what federal prosecutors describe as an extended family of violent drug dealers was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole. Judge Janet C. Hall sentenced the accused leader, Kelvin Burden, on charges including attempted murder. Prosecutors said that Mr. Burden ran his drug operation even while in state prison in 2000, and that the enterprise was responsible for many shootings in South Norwalk and Bridgeport. Mr. Burden was also convicted of conspiracy to kill members of a rival drug gang. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: 43,000 ALERTED FOR DUTY IN IRAQ
description: The Pentagon began alerting 43,000 Reserve and National Guard troops late Wednesday for the possibility of yearlong duty in Iraq or Kuwait as part of a force-rotation plan that would reduce the overall American military presence in Iraq by next spring, senior Pentagon officials said.

title: Let Them Eat Cupcakes
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including opinions about cupcakes and the musical "Wicked."

title: In Plea Deal That Spares His Life, Man Admits Killing 48 Women
description: Ending a terrifying murder mystery that confounded the police for two decades, Gary L. Ridgway pleaded guilty on Wednesday to strangling 48 young women in the Seattle area during the Green River killing spree in the 1980's, rendering him the deadliest convicted serial killer in the nation's history.

title: Witnesses on HealthSouth Disavow Any Sense of Fraud
description: A roomful of people who made a lot of money doing business with Richard M. Scrushy, the indicted former chief executive of HealthSouth, testified at a Congressional hearing on Wednesday that they had no inkling until March of suspected securities fraud at the company.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Rookies Meet but Don't Dominate
description: To some, it is 1979 all over again, and two rookies, LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony, are expected to energize the N.B.A. as Magic Johnson and Larry Bird did before them. Increased popularity, a defining rivalry and great basketball are supposed to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARRAS, DR. CARON
description: TARRAS--Dr. Caron. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Sidney Freedman, President

title: Phelps Signs Lucrative Endorsement Deal
description: Eighteen-year-old Michael Phelps, who broke seven world records in 41 days last summer, signed what is probably the most lucrative endorsement contract in the history of swimming yesterday. Speedo, his swimsuit manufacturer, gave him a contract through 2009 that supersedes the one that had two years left.

title: Tories Name New Leader, Michael Howard, to Take On Blair
description: LONDON, Nov. 6  Britain's quarrelsome opposition Conservatives united today to name a veteran lawmaker, Michael Howard, as their new leader in hopes of ending years of infighting and mounting a serious challenge to Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: Challenging a Mendacious Law
description: Less than an hour after President Bush lifted his pen yesterday to sign the stealthy attempt to roll back Roe v. Wade known as the Partial Birth Abortion Act of 2003, a federal trial judge in Nebraska issued a temporary restraining order blocking its enforcement against four physician plaintiffs and their associates. The judge's decision cited the absence in the new law of an exception to preserve the health of the pregnant woman.

title: A Movable Feast Of Lamps, Short and Tall
description: The French designer Adrien Gardre, 30, below, grew up in India, where his parents served as French diplomats. He combines classicism with innovation in his adjustable lamp, Melampo, available from Artemide, www.tizio.com. The table version is $350, and a floor version is $390. In an exhibition at Le Printemps in Paris, Mr. Gardre showed off his design skills by mixing haute couture pieces with up-to-the-minute contemporary and video art, creating an ethereal universe, he said, ''to show a department store public that fashion is not only what it wears but also a craft, an art, a know-how.''

title: Rewarding Apple Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: PILLSBURY OWNER CUTS PROFIT FORECAST FOR YEAR
description: The International Multifoods Corporation, the maker of Pillsbury baking mixes, reduced its forecast for this year's profit after losing market share. International Multifoods expects net income of $1 to $1.10 a share for the year ending Feb. 28, down from its previous estimate of $1.40 to $1.45. It reported a net loss of $2.37 a share in 2003. The chief executive, Gary E. Costley, said he had been caught off guard by increased competition from Aurora Foods and General Mills. He said the company, based in Minnetonka, Minn., would focus on generating cash flow instead of increasing profit.

title: 'The Reagans,' No Longer on CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony and Bertelsmann Announce Plans for Merging Music Units
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 6  Bertelsmann A.G. and the Sony Corporation said today that they had signed a preliminary agreement to combine their music divisions in a joint venture, becoming the latest dance partners in an industry roundelay that reflects the turbulent economics of recorded music.

title: Hollow But Full Of Character
description: The designer Laurence Brabant, below, began working with glass three years ago. Since then, her collections of glasses, carafes, pitchers, cups and saucers have kept her tiny Paris studio humming. ''I love glass because you can play with the invisible and visible,'' said Ms. Brabant, whose Verre Rouge, above, with its hollow stem, may pass unnoticed until filled, when it becomes a guaranteed dinner table conversation piece. The glasses are $63 each, plus shipping; through laurence.brabant@free.fr.

title: Ferry Captain Appears in Court but Remains Silent on Crash
description: The elusive captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed into a pier three weeks ago made his first public appearance yesterday, showing up for a hearing at which a federal judge ordered him to meet with federal accident investigators.

title: Case Dropped Against Mother In Fire Deaths
description: The Brooklyn district attorney's office has decided not to pursue charges against a woman whose two children died in a fire after she left them home alone to go to work.

title: The Future of Iraq, And Its Occupiers
description: To the Editor:

title: On a Treasure Hunt, Poetry as the Payoff
description: MY LIFE AS A FAKE

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Premier Rejects Deportation Inquiry
description: Prime Minister Jean Chrtien rejected calls for a public inquiry into the case of Maher Arar, the Canadian citizen who was deported to Syria by the United States last year on suspicion that he was a terrorist. Mr. Chrtien called the case ''deplorable'' and blamed the United States, saying that the Canadian government had nothing to do with it. Mr. Arar, of Ottawa, has called for an independent inquiry to clear his name and uncover what role Canada might have played in the decision to detain him at Kennedy Airport and deport him to his native Syria, where, he said, he was tortured. American officials have said they were acting on information from Canadian agencies. Mr. Chretien said a new inquiry was not necessary since the Royal Canadian Mounted Police is conducting one. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Drug Makers Settled 7 Suits by Whistle-Blowers, Group Says
description: Drug companies have paid a total of $1.6 billion since 2001 to settle seven suits brought by whistle-blowers that accused them of marketing fraud and overbilling Medicare and Medicaid, according to a report released yesterday by an advocacy group.

title: Grasso Motive For Payout Put in Doubt
description: Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, asked to receive the $139.5 million he was owed because he was fearful that a future board would prevent him from receiving such a large sum, according to directors who have been interviewed by stock exchange lawyers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MCNICOL, DORIS
description: McNICOL--Doris. A Memorial Service will be held Friday, November 7, 10:30 A.M. at United Methodist Church, 1515 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, New York, phone 516-883-1430.

title: The Next Best Thing To Getting Inside His Head
description: When you are sitting next to a friend playing a video game, sometimes the only way to win is to give your opponent a shove that will knock the game controller to the floor. It is a strategy that evens up the odds but invites retaliation. Now Gamester offers an alternative to a fistfight on the couch: Clash Pads, a pair of game controllers for PlayStation 2 that allow players to interfere with each other's controllers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Financial Merger Considered
description: Thailand's largest financing company, National Finance, said it was considering merging with an affiliate, Thanachart Bank. National owns 99 percent of Thanachart. Thailand's central bank said it planned to issue a master plan early next year that would encourage finance companies like National Finance to either merge with banks or become full-service banks. National Finance and Thanachart have at least 150 billion baht ($3.8 billion) in combined assets. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Ex-Tyco Executive Testifies About Loans
description: A lawyer for Tyco International advised the company that it did not have to disclose $95.9 million in mortgage loans it forgave for 50 executives, including L. Dennis Kozlowski, a former Tyco executive testified yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Editorial Observer; The Moral Dimension of Weather in an Age of Forecasts From Everywhere
description: For the past few months I've been thinking about getting a wireless weather station, a little desktop unit that displays the temperature, humidity, barometric pressure and atomic time from a transmitter mounted somewhere outside the house. It appeals to me, the thought of knowing that at a certain exact instant -- as measured by one of the nation's official time labs -- the temperature is just so and the humidity is just such and the barometric pressure is just that and rising. Most days, though, it seems to me that buying such an instrument is only a way of adding to the forlorn data of one's life, when I could instead take a walk up the road and observe for myself that it's a pretty nice day. And so I hold off.

title: Readers Share Customer Service Stories
description: You cant imagine the outpouring of anger, passion and inspiration that resulted from last weeks column about what I call passive-aggressive robbery. Thats when phone companies and others make nickel-and-dime errors on our bills, on the premise that a certain percentage of customers wont notice or wont bother spending the time to get them corrected.

title: Suburban Democrats Undercut Myth of Republican Stronghold
