description: The landscape has been shifting for years, but the political mythology of the New York City region has endured -- an overwhelmingly Democratic city ringed by staunchly Republican suburbs.

title: Heavy Reading
description: Last week Dr. Howard J. Bennett of the George Washington University Medical Center diagnosed one of those half-serious maladies of modern living, like Frisbee finger or Nintendinitis. In a whimsical letter to The New England Journal of Medicine, he gave it a name: the Hogwarts headache.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tellabs Co-Founder To Step Down
description: Tellabs, the maker of fiber optic network equipment, said yesterday that the company's co-founder, Michael J. Birck, will step down as chief executive by April after 26 years in the job. Mr. Birck, 65, will remain chairman, the company, based in Naperville, Ill., said. Tellabs will consider internal and external candidates to succeed Mr. Birck, who helped start the company in 1975. In the last two years, he has cut 61 percent of jobs and outsourced North American manufacturing to cope with losses and falling sales amid lower spending by phone carriers. Losses narrowed in the last two quarters. Analysts say Edward H. Kennedy, head of North American operations, and Anders Gustafsson, president of the international unit, might be candidates to succeed Mr. Birck. Mr. Birck said he had navigated Tellabs through a difficult time. He has cut the work force to 3,455, from 7,300, since April 2001. Shares of Tellabs fell 13 cents, to $7.54.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ESTE LAUDER COS., New York, increased its annual dividend to 30 cents a share from 20 cents, payable on Jan. 6.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new material that Intel says will help it continue to reduce the size of computer chips misspelled the name of a city in Oregon where the company has research laboratories. It is Hillsboro, not Hillsborough.

title: 'The Reagans,' No Longer on CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: With Silicon's Help, a Change in Status for the Lowly Battery
description: THEY used to be known simply as D cells, C cells, double A's and the like. But these days very little is simple about batteries, particularly the rechargeable kinds found in laptops, cellphones and other electronic gadgets, which are more likely to be called energy storage elements or power management systems.

title: DNA on Rifle Is Very Likely From Suspect, Analyst Says
description: Genetic material found on the Bushmaster rifle the police say was used in the Washington-area sniper shootings last fall almost certainly came from John A. Muhammad, an analyst with the F.B.I. testified in Mr. Muhammad's trial on Wednesday.

title: European Union Grades Members-Elect, Cautioning Poland
description: The European Commission issued a generally encouraging report on Wednesday detailing the progress of the 10 countries joining the Union next May, two others -- Romania and Bulgaria -- hoping to join in 2007, and Turkey, which has yet to be given a date.

title: It's Got a Good Beat, But Where's the Cover?
description: RYAN MILLER, singer and guitarist for the band Guster, has mixed feelings about his iPod digital music player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STIEGLITZ, TARRAS, CARON
description: STIEGLITZ - TARRAS -- Caron, passed away on November 4th surrounded by her loving family. Adored by her husband, Marc. Beloved mother of Elizabeth, Alexander, Melissa and Danielle. Treasured sister of Evan and cherished daughter of George and Arlene. Funeral Thursday, 11AM, at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center with special gratitude to Dr. Nancy Kemeny and Dr. Diane Stover.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Sweet Olive Goes Sour

title: Earnings Rise at Ralph Lauren
description: By Bloomberg News)

title: G.M. Puts Off Its Hybrids, Letting Ford Go First
description: General Motors has delayed plans to sell a hybrid vehicle similar to the Toyota Prius by two years, until 2007, according to people close to the company's product development strategy.

title: Sharon Seeks Support for Prisoner Swap Involving 400 Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 6  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon lobbied today to build support for a potential prisoner swap that would see Israel free about 400 Arabs in exchange for a kidnapped Israeli businessman and the remains of three soldiers, all of them held by the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah.

title: Soldier Accused as Coward Says He Is Guilty Only of Panic Attack
description: Not since the Vietnam War has the Army punished a soldier for being too scared to do his duty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRICKLER, MAYA
description: STRICKLER--Maya, on November 4, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Isaak. Loving mother of Miriam and mother-in-law of Martin. Devoted grandmother of Brandt, Mathew and Katie. Services Friday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Senate Panel Narrowly Backs Bush Nominee for U.S. Court
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee endorsed one of President Bush's federal appeals court nominees today in a narrow vote that reflected the deep partisan differences over judicial confirmations.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mayor Defies Order To Pay Claim
description: A land dispute has put Mexico City's popular mayor in a legal bind. The mayor, Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, is widely seen as a strong candidate for president in 2006. He is refusing to pay a $164 million judgment against the city, imposed for expropriating 750 acres and evicting thousands of squatters in 1989. A citizen claimed title to the land and won the judgment after years of court battles. The mayor says the claim is based on fraudulent documentation, and the nation's Supreme Court has declined to hear the city's appeal. Now, the mayor must either pay the judgment or stand in contempt of court. Legal scholars say a contempt citation could conceivably force him from office. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: 'Omnium Gatherum' to Close Nov. 30
description: ''Omnium Gatherum,'' the politically charged satire that received high praise at last spring's Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., but did not find an audience in New York, is to close on Nov. 30. It will have had 77 regular performances and 17 previews at the Variety Arts Theater in the East Village.

title: Have a Seat. Well, Maybe Not That One.
description: THERE is never a good reason to buy a new sofa.

title: Paris Journal; To Sell Lingerie, Inhibitions, and Much More, Are Falling
description: Underwear seduction courses in a department store?

title: Caution: Will Melt if Left in Water Too Long
description: Cralin, an environmentally friendly material made from wheat husks, was created in French laboratories two years ago. B.S.M. Dveloppement has commissioned the French designers Savinel & Roz to make a line of Cralin serving ware, left. A large bowl is $42, a small one is $24, and a tray (19 by 16 inches) is $80; at the MoMA Design Store; (800) 793-3167. Cralin disintegrates if left in water more than four hours but otherwise can last a lifetime. B.S.M. is researching its use as a building material.

title: Hearing on Starved Children Draws Advocates' Concern
description: New Jersey's embattled child welfare agency will face a new level of scrutiny on Thursday as federal lawmakers hold a Congressional hearing on the case of four boys who the authorities said were starved by their adoptive parents.

title: Going With the Flow, Tech Nouveau Arrives
description: REAL estate in the Notting Hill section of London has become a lot more valuable since the designer Ross Lovegrove bought a building there nine years ago and established his home and studio. So when he needed more room this year, instead of building outward, he expanded downward -- with a remarkable staircase.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: HIGH-RISE FIRE SAFETY Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, responding to a downtown fire that killed six people last month, told the City Council he wanted sprinklers in nearly all high-rise buildings by 2016. Residential buildings and landmarks would be exempt, though they would have to improve fire safety in other ways. The mayor has proposed tax incentives to help offset the cost, which would be in the millions. New commercial and residential buildings higher than 35 feet would be required to install sprinklers under the proposal, which the City Council will vote on within weeks. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Welch Foods to Begin Account Review
description: Welch Foods in Concord, Mass., has begun a review for its account, which has been handled for more than 20 years by the New York office of Arnold Worldwide and predecessor agencies. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Perfect Choice After Torre: Randolph
description: TUCKED into a file folder of mine that contains an assortment of clippings is a column written for another newspaper. It is now more than 15 years old and begins with a pair of italicized quotes:

title: 'The Reagans,' No Longer on CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Use of Private Militias in Iraq Is Not Likely Soon, U.S. Says
description: Occupying forces here have no immediate plans to use private Iraqi militias to augment the Iraqi Army and police force, senior American and Iraqi officials said Wednesday.

title: Leave Some Pork on the Table
description: The Republican Congressional majority is working its will in the fine print of the huge appropriations bills that will detail the spending next year by a government already hobbled by a record deficit. From an incumbent's point of view, the print gets no finer than the $1 billion in ''earmarks'' -- custom-tailored pork-barrel spending -- tucked into the enormous $470 billion budget for the labor, education and health agencies. Fans of Congressional budget politicking are familiar with the way lawmakers compete for projects that benefit their districts alone. But earmarks take it one step further, granting to specially favored lawmakers the ability to bypass formulas for allocating federal funds and pluck money from the budget. Sugarplums is a better term.

title: A Signal From the Sky Lets You Stay Tuned
description: Q. What makes satellite radio different from standard radio stations, aside from my having to pay for it?

title: National Briefing: South
description: VIRGINIA: HELP IN CRIME FIGHT The state police will join forces with Richmond officers within the next two weeks to help combat a soaring homicide rate in the state capital. Richmond has had 83 homicides this year, compared with 59 at this time last year. Last weekend alone, 12 shootings resulted in two deaths. The state police counterterrorism and criminal interdiction unit is being sent in to focus on neighborhoods where violence has been especially prevalent. (AP)

title: Credit Agencies Worry About Health of China's Banks
description: Responding to hints in recent weeks from senior Chinese financial regulators that another bailout of the country's biggest banks might be needed, two credit rating agencies issued separate reports on Wednesday suggesting that China's previous efforts had not solved the banking system's troubles.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: InterActiveCorp Posts $18.7 Million Profit
description: InterActiveCorp, the Internet commerce company controlled by Barry Diller, yesterday posted a third-quarter profit of $18.7 million. InterActiveCorp, whose shares fell as much as 14 percent yesterday, spent more to market its travel Web sites against competitors like Travelocity and Orbitz. The net income of 2 cents a share was in contrast to a year-earlier loss of $36.6 million, or 8 cents, the company said. Revenue rose 36 percent, to $1.61 billion from $1.19 billion. The company's travel Web sites, which include Expedia and Hotels.com, are spending more to attract customers as competitors advertise and cut prices, and as hotel chains sell more of their own rooms online, Mr. Diller said. He has been expanding in online travel, and completed the purchase of the discount travel site Hotwire.com yesterday. InterActiveCorp shares fell $2.81, or about 7.6 percent, to $34.19. Excluding noncash expenses to pay employees in stock, costs to write down the value of assets and some other items, InterActiveCorp said it would have earned 17 cents a share. That was less than the estimate of 18 cents from analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Revenue exceeded the average forecast of $1.55 billion.

title: Putin Links Arrest of Oil Tycoon to Law-and-Order Push
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6  President Vladimir Putin today cast the arrest of the country's richest man last month as part of a law-and-order campaign aimed at redressing large-scale economic crimes.

title: An External DVD Drive Flaunts Its Fluency
description: So many DVD formats, so little time. If owning a DVD recorder seems appealing but remembering which blank DVD format it accepts does not, Iomega's new Super DVD Writer All-Format U.S.B. 2.0 external drive may be ideal. It records and reads discs in all current DVD and CD formats.

title: Big Appetites for Small Spaces
description: NOT every home has a dining room. But not every home needs one to entertain a hungry crowd. A living room can do double duty, and a studio apartment can have its own eating area with coffee tables that rise up and extend out, and dining tables positioned in front of sofas or corner banquettes.

title: Sri Lankan President Declares a State of Emergency
description: Sri Lanka's president declared a state of emergency Wednesday, deepening a political crisis in the country and giving herself sweeping powers to ban assemblies, detain people without cause and censor news reports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PION, HOWARD
description: PION--Howard. We mourn the loss of our dear cousin. Our hearts are with the entire family. Michael Tenzer Family Circle

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about efforts by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, embattled founder of the Russian oil company Yukos, to gain access to influential Americans referred incompletely to his approach to the Brookings Institution, the Washington policy research organization. While Brookings said it had debated the possibility of accepting money from Mr. Khodorkovsky, he never formally offered any.

title: Zimbabwe Court Hears Arguments in Presidential Loser's Case
description: Zimbabwe's High Court completed a brief hearing Tuesday into charges that President Robert Mugabe's supporters rigged his 2002 re-election victory, but there was no indication when, or which way, the court might rule.

title: Price for a Klimt Soars to $29 Million
description: In the auction world, all it takes is three determined people with big egos and bank accounts to match. That's why a 1917 Klimt landscape sold for $29.1 million last night at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art. The price surprised even the auction house experts.

title: Mexico's Top Court Opens the Way to 'Dirty War' Prosecutions
description: Mexico's highest court ruled on Wednesday that former senior government officials could be prosecuted for kidnapping suspected leftists decades ago.

title: Center to Speed U.S. Translations
description: Counterterrorism officials said on Wednesday that they planned to open a clearinghouse for government and private linguists by January to allow faster translation of possible terrorist communications.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: U.S. CITES FRAUD IN VOTE The United States ambassador, Richard Miles, told President Eduard A. Shevardnadze that the central election commission must quickly release a vote count for last Sunday's parliamentary elections, and an embassy statement alleged for the first time that there was fraud in the voting. "The mismanagement and fraud" of the election "denied many Georgian citizens their constitutional right to vote," the statement said. A demonstration by opposition supporters in the capital, Tbilisi, on Tuesday attracted thousands of protesters. The Russian news agency Interfax quoted the election commission as saying that with 65 percent of ballots counted, Mr. Shevardnadze's party, known as For New Georgia, was leading by a narrow margin.    (Reuters)

title: The Smart Money Beats Bloomberg's Money
description: Ever since his come-from-way-behind election victory in 2001, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken a special delight in proving what he calls ''the smart money'' wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBB, WILLIAM JAY GAYNOR
description: WEBB--William Jay Gaynor. 73, of Vero Beach, FL died November 4th, 2003 at Indian River Memorial Hospital, Vero Beach, FL after a brief illness. Surviving are his wife of 47 years, Carol Webb of Vero Beach, FL, daughters, Eliza Webb Eppli, Electra Tortorella and Angela Kensinger and five grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, RICHARD B.
description: SMITH--Richard B., on November 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Patricia H. Smith. Loving father of Landis, Leslie, Tom, Eliza and step-father of Elizabeth. Devoted grandfather of Elliot, Isabel, Colin, Graham and stepgrandfather of Victoria. Family will receive friends Thursday 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Funeral services Friday, 4 PM at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave at 91 St. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan with special gratitude to Dr. David Kelsen.

title: McGreevey Savors Party's Gains as G.O.P. Reviews Losses
description: A day after the resounding Democratic victory in Tuesday's elections, Gov. James E. McGreevey was savoring a rare day of good news and Republicans were left dispirited by the Democrats' new grip on both houses of the State Legislature.

title: New Slogan for Pepsi About More Than Joy
description: The Pepsi-Cola Company division of PepsiCo said yesterday that it would replace ''The joy of Pepsi,'' its advertising theme since 2000, with ''Pepsi. It's the cola,'' beginning with commercials set to appear around Thanksgiving.

title: A Higher Profile, and a Smaller Car
description: YOU won't often find Christopher O. Ward, commissioner of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection, traveling around town in the back of a shiny, black car.

title: Quixotic Inventions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANTERMAN, PHYLLIS COGIN
description: KANTERMAN--Phyllis Cogin. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Edgar A. Kanterman. Devoted sister, aunt and great-aunt.

title: Under an audacious campaign, the chatter before the movie starts might just be about a Nissan.
description: After walking through the fourth wall, the advertiser can begin its pitch. NISSAN MOTOR is planting actors in movie theaters to perform live commercials before the start of showings of ''The Matrix Revolutions'' in an effort to expose jaded, skeptical consumers to advertising by masking it as something else.

title: $1.8 Million Check for a Job Not Done Jolts Boston University
description: It could have paid the salaries of additional professors in the understaffed mathematics department, or for more space in the overcrowded science and engineering library, with its unwieldy movable stacks. Or it could have paid for bonuses of $1,000 each for the 1,800 faculty members, almost none of whom have received raises for two years.

title: Heart Laser Treatment Used Mostly on Patients Who Don't Meet the Federal Criteria
description: About three-quarters of the patients who receive an expensive, invasive and risky laser treatment for the chest pains of heart disease do not meet the medical criteria for which it was approved, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Samples From the Cameras
description: STILLS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAR, ILLAN, DAVID
description: BAR-ILLAN--David. It is with the most profound sadness that we mourn the loss of our dear friend. David Bar-Illan. He gave tirelessly to his friends and countrymen as an eloquent spokesman for Israel and the Jewish people. His artistic and intellectual talents improved the quality of life for us all. We will miss him deeply. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife Beverly and his children Daniella, Jeremy and Kim. The Zises Family

title: 2 American Teams Play a Slam, Each Making It, in Monaco
description: Play in the world championships began here Monday, with 22 teams competing in the Bermuda Bowl for Open Teams and 18 teams in the Venice Cup for women's teams.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: The Stars Align in Venice
description: In Venice, there's a whiff of madness in the air.

title: Mitch Epstein's Photos
description: "Family Business," a book of photographs by Mitch Epstein, chronicles the demise of a particular version of the American dream.

title: Bang for Your Buck
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Theater:  Recent Openings
description: Ashley Judd, John Stamos, Kristen Chenoweth and John Lithgow are a few of the actors appearing in shows which recently opened on Broadway.

title: Gender-Benders
description: A rich tapestry of a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art seeks to redefine the skirt and promote its place in the wardrobe of everyday.

title: The Synagogues of the South Bronx
description: Scores of South Bronx synagogues are now being used as churches, day care centers, clinics, video stores and jails.

title: In Court, It's O'Donnell on Rosie
description: When it came time yesterday for defense lawyers to present their case in the civil lawsuit between Rosie O'Donnell and her erstwhile publishing partner, Gruner & Jahr USA, they did not mess around.

title: Nets' Rally Is Spoiled By Former Teammate
description: Anthony Johnson ducked into the Nets' locker room minutes before the game. His former teammates greeted him with handshakes and hugs, smiles and cheers.

title: GLAXO IS SETTING UP BIOTECHNOLOGY RESEARCH DIVISION
description: The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline said yesterday that it planned to establish a research division that would concentrate on developing biotechnology medicines. The new unit will add to the half-dozen research divisions the company established two years ago as part of a strategy to speed the development of drugs. Glaxo's newest unit will specialize in developing therapeutic vaccines, antibodies and other protein-based medicines for diseases like cancer. It will begin operations by the end of the year at facilities outside Philadelphia and in Britain and will employ about 350 people, Glaxo said.

title: Sheila Smythe, 71, Health Care Advocate
description: Sheila Smythe, a former head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and dean of the school of public health at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y., died on Tuesday at New York Weill Cornell Center. She was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 28 about scholars' views of the medical contributions of a pioneer gynecologist, Dr. J. Marion Sims, misstated the affiliation of one historian and the dates of his writings on the subject. It was in his 1968 dissertation, when he was at the University of California at Los Angeles, not in 1974 and not while he was at Trinity College, that the historian, Dr. Graham J. Barker-Benfield, first wrote that Sims had used slaves as guinea pigs.

title: Senators and Attorneys General Seek Investigation Into E.P.A. Rules Change
description: Democratic senators and attorneys general from the Northeast called on Thursday for an investigation into a policy change by the Environmental Protection Agency that lawyers at the agency say will lead it to drop investigations of 50 power plants for Clean Air Act violations.

title: CALIFORNIA SEEKS WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS' RECORDS
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals, a maker of generic drugs, said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from California's attorney general seeking records on its pricing for medicines. The company has not yet responded to the subpoena, which was delivered in August, Watson said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Watson is among 26 drug makers that received requests for information from a Congressional committee looking into prices and billing of Medicaid. It is also one of 13 generic drug makers being sued by the Massachusetts attorney general, who contends that they inflated drug prices for the state's Medicaid program.

title: With Medicare Bill Stalled, House Speaker Prods Panel
description: The Speaker of the House tried on Thursday to revive negotiations on a Medicare drug bill, stalled by deep ideological disagreements over the future of the health insurance program for the elderly.

title: Gabriel Orozco
description: Marian Goodman Gallery

title: Jazz Generation Sees The Future: It's Not Cool
description: The gods who govern the fortunes of playwrights are an arbitrary lot, stroking with one hand, smiting with the other. In the last year, they have mostly been stroking Richard Greenberg, the lyrical, thoughtful dramatist whose wonderful new work, ''The Violet Hour,'' opened last night in a less than wonderful production at the Biltmore Theater. It is, not incidentally, a play about the waywardness of destiny and how it tarnishes the golden and the gifted.

title: F.B.I. Said to Query Celebrity Lawyers About Wiretaps
description: Several prominent Hollywood lawyers have been questioned in recent months by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with a grand jury investigation into suspected illegal wiretapping by the private investigator Anthony Pellicano, according to two people involved in the investigation.

title: Trying to Fill Jordan's Shoes
description: The Air Zoom Generation sneakers on LeBron James's size 13 feet have run up and down courts in Sacramento, Phoenix, Portland and Cleveland, carrying him to two great games and two mediocre ones.

title: From Choral to Klezmer
description: The ''Only in America'' conference runs through Tuesday at the Jewish Theological Seminary, 3080 Broadway, at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 866-7418. Included are lectures, panel discussions and workshops on a broad variety of musical topics. On Sunday morning at 10, for example, one can choose between a session on art-music composers who addressed Jewish texts, and one on synagogue music from the American South. The Sunday schedule also includes Jonathan Sarna's keynote lecture, ''The Question of Music in American Judaism: Reflections at 350 Years'' and sessions on klezmer, choral music and the Hasidic tradition. Also offered as part of the conference is a series of public concerts, as well as complete Friday evening and Saturday morning Sabbath services with interesting musical twists, as well as more conventional concerts. Admission is free to all events, except concerts, for faculty members and students at the Jewish Theological Seminary. General registration for the full conference is $320; $215 for the sessions only, without the concerts;($125 for non-Seminary students.) Registration for Sunday events is $160 for all events or $110 for the conference only (student tickets are $85 for the conference only). Conference registration for Monday and Tuesday is $130 for both days; student tickets are $85. Tickets for all the concerts tomorrow, Sunday and Monday evenings are $85. Individual ticket prices are listed below.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTPORT RESOURCES, Denver, a producer of oil and natural gas, said it would buy gas reserves in southern Texas from the closely held United Resources for $350 million.

title: Tiong Ang -- 'Prisoners'
description: Florence Lynch Gallery

title: Panthers Finally Find Their Running Back
description: Stephen Davis had a national audience and an open opportunity to bash his former coach with the Washington Redskins, Steve Spurrier, along with all of the National Football League teams that overlooked him as a free agent this past off-season.

title: Soros Raided in Moscow in Property Dispute
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6  Commandos in masks and camouflage broke into offices of the Soros Foundation in Moscow late Thursday in what a foundation official said was part of a legal dispute over the building.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Technology Acquisition
description: The Hon Hai Precision Industry Company, the electronics maker, has agreed to buy the Ambit Microsystems Corporation for 36.7 billion Taiwan dollars ($1.08 billion) in stock to expand its communications and notebook-computer businesses. Hon Hai will exchange 0.672 of a share for one Ambit share. The offer values Ambit shares at 103.49 Taiwan dollars, a 12 percent premium over yesterday's closing price. Hon Hai, based in Taipei, makes PC's for Hewlett-Packard and PlayStation 2 game consoles for Sony. Ambit makes communications equipment like routers and notebook PC parts.

title: Dean's Gaffe: What Did We Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Spacecraft That Could
description: Voyager 1, a spacecraft launched by NASA more than a quarter-century ago, has reached or at least approached the very edge of our solar system, a violent frontier where high-speed solar winds propelled by the Sun slow to a celestial crawl as they collide with the thin gases of interstellar space. It is another important milestone for an amazingly durable spacecraft, which has already explored Jupiter and Saturn and may well keep returning data until its power runs out in about 2020.

title: Challenge to Civil Liberties Union Dropped
description: The Temporary State Commission on Lobbying has dropped its challenge to the New York Civil Liberties Union over a billboard outside an upstate mall, saying the group no longer has to list the cost of the billboard as a lobbying expense.

title: Injured Officer Kills S.I. Man After Attack In Apartment
description: For the police, there is no such thing as a routine domestic disturbance call. Emotions run high and common sense and reason usually do not. Yesterday, an officer on Staten Island stopped to take a report for a trespassing complaint, and ended up stabbed and thrown through a glass table before shooting his attacker to death, the police said.

title: Mammograms Done at Clinic May Be Flawed, State Says
description: Thousands of women who had their most recent breast X-rays at a Manhattan mammography clinic have been urged by state health officials to immediately have new mammograms after a review of some of the clinic's work found what the officials called a high risk that signs of cancer might have been missed.

title: Waltzing Walls and Nature Denatured
description: The tradition of the empty art gallery as artwork, initiated by Yves Klein in Paris in 1958, approaches its half-century mark along a path that is by turns innovative and tepidly academic. By this measure you could say that Pierre Huyghe's ''Streamside Day Follies'' at Dia:Chelsea has wheels in both lanes. The latest effort by this hot French artist -- who was born in 1962, the year Klein died -- is alternately seductive and didactic, and irksomely lightweight either way. Yet for a host of reasons, it is a thought-provoking symptom of the art of the moment.

title: School Violence Data Under a Cloud in Houston
description: It was one of the most unforgettable of schoolhouse crimes: a disabled 17-year-old student was shoved into a boys' bathroom in her wheelchair by a classmate at Yates High School here, dragged to the floor and raped. Her attacker was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: INSIDE
description: An Optimistic Fed Chief

title: Sending the Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The United States Army's Old Guard is best known for its ceremonial duties. Its soldiers stand vigil at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldiers at Arlington National Cemetery and serve in color guards for visiting dignitaries.

title: Union Backs Dean; Clark Discusses Iraq
description: One day after Howard Dean apologized for remarks about the Confederate flag, he was endorsed by the nation's most diverse labor organization, the 1.6-million-member Service Employees International Union.

title: Yankees Coaches Are Practiced in Upheaval
description: Rick Down would not offer specifics, and he would not say how many phone calls he received. But at least a couple of times last season, Down, who was fired as the Yankees' hitting coach last week, said that George Steinbrenner called him, demanding answers about the performance of certain hitters.

title: Something There Is That Doesnt Love a . . . (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Slain Councilman's Brother Concedes and Looks Ahead
description: Two days after his loss to a third-party candidate for City Council, Geoffrey A. Davis appeared at City Hall yesterday to concede to his opponent, Letitia James, and to explain his candidacy as therapy in dealing with the murder of his brother, Councilman James E. Davis.

title: Diverse Union Decides Dean Is Its Candidate
description: One day after Howard Dean scrambled to stanch a controversy over his remarks about the Confederate flag, he secured a critical endorsement from the most diverse labor group in the country, the 1.6-million-member Service Employees International Union.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Guilty Plea In Stowaway Case
description: A man who embarrassed transportation security personnel in September by shipping himself undetected in a crate from New York City to his parents' home in suburban Dallas, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to stowaway charges. The man, Charles D. McKinley of New York, faces up to a year in prison. Mr. McKinley has said his 15-hour journey was cheaper than a ticket. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SUIT ON GLOBAL WARMING REPORT IS DISMISSED A lawsuit seeking to stop the Bush administration from disseminating an assessment of the impacts of global warming has been dismissed for technical reasons. The suit had been filed by the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a group with industry backing, contending that the analysis, which was done in the Clinton administration and projects many harmful repercussions if temperatures rise, did not meet federal standards for the quality of data.

title: Tradition, Tradition, Tradition? Not in American Jewish Music
description: During his two decades on the faculty at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Neil W. Levin has been studying the evolution of Jewish music in America, and he has come to a pair of conclusions that, on the surface, seem contradictory. The first is that the earliest Jewish communities, in colonial times, considered it so crucial that the music of the Sabbath and holidays be preserved in all its traditional details that they imported cantors to sing the services decades before they brought over the rabbis.

title: Catholics in Survey Seek Accountability by Church
description: Three of every four Roman Catholics who regularly attend Mass say they want their church to be more financially accountable in the wake of its sexual-abuse crisis, according to a new Gallup survey, and one in four say they did not respond this year to financial appeals from the national church.

title: NFL Network Is New But Can Be Improved
description: Now that the NFL Network is entering its fourth day of operations, it's time to think of ways to improve it. It is dicey, and maybe unfair, to lobby for changes to a network that only satellite-dish-enabled viewers can see and that is trying to persuade cable operators to carry it.

title: Putin Says Oilman's Arrest Is No Threat to Private Enterprise
description: President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday cast the arrest of the country's richest man almost two weeks ago as part of a law and order campaign aimed at Russia's hugely wealthy oligarchs.

title: For One Lad, Pointy Shoes Turn Out to Be Hard to Fill
description: In ''Elf,'' New York City -- and the rest of the world as well -- is suffering from a dearth of Christmas cheer. In the real world this seems to be a recurrent affliction, and every November movies like this one, which opens nationwide today, are shipped to theaters as part of a nationwide, studio-sponsored vaccination program. Some of them, like ''Santa Clause 2'' and ''How the Grinch Stole Christmas,'' spread the very disease they are meant to cure, clogging vulnerable immune systems with virulent sentimentality and turning perfectly decent, mild-tempered folk (movie critics, for instance) into Scrooges and Grinches.

title: Bayer to Spin Off Most of Its Chemical Businesses
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 7  The German drug and chemical giant Bayer, after more than a year of casting about for ways to revitalize itself, said today that it would spin off most of its chemical businesses.

title: Roy Lucas, 61, Legal Theorist Who Helped Shape Roe Suit
description: Roy Lucas, a lawyer who helped fashion the ''right to privacy'' legal argument used in Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion in the United States, died on Monday in Prague. He was 61 and lived in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday showing how a proposal for nonpartisan elections in New York City would have worked included an erroneous example of a third-party primary. The only third parties qualified to hold primaries in New York State are the Independent, Conservative and Working Families parties; the Libertarians failed to collect the 50,000 votes required for automatic placement on the ballot.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suit On Global Warming Report Is Dismissed
description: A lawsuit seeking to stop the Bush administration from disseminating an assessment of the impacts of global warming has been dismissed for technical reasons. The suit had been filed by the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a group with industry backing, contending that the analysis, which was done in the Clinton administration and projects many harmful repercussions if temperatures rise, did not meet federal standards for the quality of data. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Prosecutors Lay Out Case Against Scientist in Plague Case
description: In the first four days of the trial of a Texas Tech professor accused of lying to federal agents when he reported that cultures of plague bacteria were missing from his laboratory in January, federal prosecutors have argued that the professor deliberately contrived the story to distract university investigators closing in on ethical and financial improprieties in his research.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Wednesday about efforts by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, founder of the Russian oil company Yukos, to gain access to influential Americans misstated the relationship between former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and the Open Russia Foundation, a Russian philanthropy based in Britain and financed by Mr. Khodorkovsky. Although Mr. Khodorkovsky asked Mr. Bradley to serve on the foundation's board, Mr. Bradley says he declined and is not advising the foundation.

title: Anwar Ibrahim's lawyers press his case : With Mahathir retired, ex-deputy may go free
description: SINGAPORE:  Though his political nemesis has stepped aside to await history's judgment, Malaysia's former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, remains in a tiny prison cell, awaiting his own shot at vindication.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 21-Year Hunt for Killer Shapes Man and Family
description: A young detective in 1986, Dave Reichert had been working the case of the Green River killer night and day for years, and with at least 40 women dead and no promising leads, he decided to take Ted Bundy up on his offer of help.

title: Outspoken Minister Resigns in Clash With Colombia's President
description: Fernando Londoo, the outspoken and contentious interior and justice minister who has frequently clashed with Congress, resigned Thursday after making remarks disavowed by President lvaro Uribe.

title: Something There Is That Doesn't Love a  . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Dean's Gaffe: What Did We Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: All Things Automotive Under the Desert Sun
description: MORE than 100,000 people descended upon the Las Vegas Convention Center this week in search of the coolest steering wheels, tires, rims, dashboards and suspension systems in the universe. At the annual gathering of the Specialty Equipment Market Association, they prowled the aisles, looking for the Next Big Thing. Page 8.

title: U.S. SEEKS INFORMATION ABOUT CLEAR CHANNEL ADS
description: Clear Channel Communications said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the Justice Department seeking information about gambling advertisements that ran on its stations. The subpoena was issued Sept. 9 by the assistant United States attorney in St. Louis, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, said it was asked to provide information about ads run on behalf of ''offshore and/or online gambling businesses.'' The businesses included sports bookmaking and ''casino-style'' gambling, the filing said. Clear Channel said it was cooperating with the Justice Department.

title: Sports of The Times; Final Round for an Everlast Plant
description: FROM the outside, it's a gloomy gray building in a gloomy gray industrial section of the Bronx, not far from the Triborough Bridge, about as far away as you can get from the casino glitz of a big fight these days. But inside, the Everlast plant is where most of the boxing gloves in a big fight have been made for decades -- Muhammad Ali's gloves, Joe Frazier's gloves, George Foreman's gloves, Larry Holmes's gloves, Mike Tyson's gloves, Lennox Lewis's gloves.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sixty years of Western nations excusing and accommodating the lack of freedom in the Middle East did nothing to make us safe, because in the long run, stability cannot be purchased at the expense of liberty.''

title: In Mideast, Reaction to Bush Speech Is Dismissive
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7 — Commentators across the Middle East today largely dismissed President Bush's speech calling for wider democracy in the region, labeling it something for domestic consumption to justify the war in Iraq rather than signaling a real change in United States policy.

title: Phelps Signs Lucrative Endorsement Deal
description: Eighteen-year-old Michael Phelps, who broke seven world records in 41 days last summer, signed what is probably the most lucrative endorsement contract in the history of swimming yesterday. Speedo, his swimsuit manufacturer, gave him a contract through 2009 that supersedes the one that had two years left.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Earnings At BMW
description: The carmaker BMW improved its performance in the third quarter, helped by its Mini brand and the release of the 5 Series sedan in Europe. Net profit rose to 445 million euros ($509 million) for the quarter, which ended Sept. 30, up 2.8 percent from a year ago. It was the first quarterly increase this year. Despite lower demand in the first six months, BMW said it expected results for the year to match those of 2002.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cisco's Strong Profit Propels Nasdaq to 22-Month High
description: Stocks rose yesterday, led by technology companies, as Cisco Systems reported a record quarterly profit and the most sales in almost three years. The Nasdaq composite index closed at its highest in 22 months.

title: For the G.O.P., a Mixed Day on Nominees
description: The battle over judicial confirmations was waged on two fronts on Thursday as the Senate Judiciary Committee voted along party lines to approve President Bush's nomination of Janice Rogers Brown to a seat on the federal appeals court based in Washington and send it to the full Senate.

title: Joe Fig
description: Plus Ultra Gallery

title: Few Voted in New York, and the Vote Wasn't Close
description: To the Editor:

title: Schinveld Journal; Deafening Din of the Awacs Rouses the Folk Next Door
description: Along a little country road, right on the Dutch-German border, a showdown is in the making, one in which normally peace-loving citizens are determined to take on the world's most powerful military alliance.

title: Islanders Show More Weapons
description: For all the talk about the Islanders' promising start, a flicker of doubt has hung over the team regarding its ability to generate goals outside of its top line. Mariusz Czerkawski, Aleksei Yashin and Oleg Kvasha had accounted for 18 of the Islanders' 37 goals before their game against Dallas on Thursday night.

title: A Western woman's journey inside the Bin Laden 'village'
description: GENEVA  In the late 1970's, Osama bin Laden went to visit his brother Yeslam, who lived in the sprawling family settlement near Jidda. Answering the doorbell, Carmen Binladin, Yeslam's Swiss-born wife, stood face to face with her brother-in-law and invited him in.

title: After Deadly Crash, Many Tears in Queens
description: Friends and relatives of a girl who was run down by a car on Wednesday night remembered her yesterday as a bright, energetic student at St. Francis Prep in Queens, where she was a sophomore.

title: Nelson and Garcia Won't Attend
description: Jeff Nelson and Karim Garcia of the Yankees will not attend a hearing in Boston today to determine if either will face a misdemeanor charge of assault and battery for his role in a fight with a member of the grounds crew at Fenway Park.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the appointment of Robert S. Smith to fill a vacancy on the New York State Court of Appeals misstated the affiliation of Vincent M. Bonventre, who commented on the appointment. He is a professor at Albany Law School of Union University, not at the University of Albany. A biographical chart misstated a development in Mr. Smith's career as a lawyer. He started his own legal practice last year and also joined Kornstein, Veisz, Wexler & Pollard; he did not start that firm.

title: For Sterilization, Target Is Women
description: When Kumari Pidse, a mite of a government health worker in Mangata, in Chattisgarh State, approaches a man about a vasectomy, the answer is always the same: ''Take my wife.''

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: RAHWAY: AMTRAK REPORTS ON DERAILMENT The derailment of a New Jersey Transit train last week that disrupted travel for thousands of passengers on the line was caused by a defect in track-switching equipment, Amtrak announced yesterday. A 10-car commuter train tried to transfer from one track to another near the Rahway station on Friday and passed over a track switch, which moved. An Amtrak spokesman, Dan Stessel, said that investigators had ruled out vandalism and were trying to determine why the switch moved. The device, now out of service, was installed in April 2001 and passed a monthly test two days before the mishap, he said. No injuries were reported among the 700 passengers.   Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Teenagers Accused Of Posing as Police In a Robbery Spree
description: The police arrested five teenage boys yesterday and charged them with robbery and criminal impersonation of a police officer, after a monthlong spree involving at least five attacks in the West Village, Chelsea and downtown.

title: 2 Networks Try to Mend Schedules
description: Both NBC and CBS made changes to their prime-time schedules yesterday, as they scrambled to address some unexpected -- and heavily publicized -- problems.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: XM Satellite Posts Wider Loss
description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings, the biggest satellite-radio service, had a wider third-quarter loss as interest payments increased. The company said yesterday that it had more than one million subscribers, helped by sales of radios through General Motors and Honda cars. The net loss expanded to $133.4 million from $109.6 million a year earlier, Washington-based XM said in a statement. Sales jumped almost fivefold to $26.9 million from $5.6 million. XM used automotive and retail partners to add about 237,000 subscribers in the recent quarter, and passed one million late last month. The company will have more than 2.5 million subscribers by the end of 2004, the chief executive, Hugh Panero said. Subscriber-acquisition costs -- the cost of getting a new subscriber -- fell to $76 from $80 in the previous quarter. XM has said it will have 1.2 million customers by the end of the year and be ''cash-flow break-even'' by the end of 2004. On a per-share basis, XM's net loss shrank to $1.12 a share from $1.26. The company had an average of 129.7 million shares in the quarter, compared with 91.2 million shares a year earlier. XM was expected to report a loss of $1.17 a share, based on the average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call.

title: Seneca Indians Start Ad Campaign Against State's Tax Plan for Reservations
description: Leaders of the Seneca Nation have begun an aggressive advertising campaign against a New York State plan to begin collecting taxes from non-Indian customers on reservations.

title: Unjustified, Even in War
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Alone, Britain Lifts Its Key Rate To 3.75%
description: Breaking ranks with other leading central banks, the Bank of England raised its benchmark interest rate by one quarter of a percentage point Thursday, bucking a global three-year trend toward lower borrowing costs.

title: Corrections
description: The Living Here column last Friday about houses with turrets misspelled the name of a lake near Sandpoint, Idaho. It is Lake Pend Oreille, not Ponderay (which is the name of a community on the lake).

title: 9/11 Panel May Reject Offer Of Limited Access to Briefings
description: The White House has offered to provide a federal commission with limited access to Oval Office intelligence reports regarding the Sept. 11 terror attacks, but some members of the panel have described the offer as inadequate and are renewing the threat of a subpoena, commission officials said on Thursday.

title: 'Gloomy Sunday'
description: Directed by Rolf Schbel

title: Withdrawals From Putnam Set Heavy Pace
description: Investors withdrew $3.9 billion from stock funds managed by Putnam Investments in the week ended Wednesday, according to AMG Data Services, indicating that regulators' accusations of improper trading by Putnam fund managers continue to rattle its shareholders.

title: Flags Versus Dollars
description: Howard Dean's remarks about the need to appeal to white Southerners could certainly have been better phrased. But his rivals for the Democratic nomination should be ashamed of their reaction. They know what he was trying to say -- and it wasn't that his party should go soft on racism. By playing gotcha, by seizing on the chance to take the front-runner down a peg, they damaged the cause they claim to serve -- and missed a chance to confront the real issue he raised.

title: With U.S. Tax Checks Spent, Retailers Report Slower Gains
description: Wal-Mart Stores and the Target Corporation reported slower sales gains for October yesterday after a boost from federal tax-credit checks wore off and warmer weather limited the demand for autumn clothing.

title: Agency Leader Going to Thompson
description: Agency Leader

title: Penn State Will Pay To Allow Students To Download Music
description: Pennsylvania State University has agreed to cover the cost of providing its students with a legal method to download music from a catalog of half a million songs, in a departure from punitive efforts to curtail music swapping on college campuses.

title: Sharon Urges Trade of 400 Arabs for an Israeli and Remains of 3
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon lobbied Thursday for a potential prisoner trade in which Israel would free about 400 Arabs in exchange for a kidnapped Israeli businessman and the remains of three soldiers, all held by the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah.

title: In the Land Of the Free, Who Wears The Skirts?
description: ANDREW BOLTON knows how to put across the fluctuating relationship between difference and similarity, and what more can you ask for? The young British curator has woven a rich tapestry of a show from a theme that promises little more than wan provocation. Entitled ''Bravehearts: Men in Skirts,'' the exhibition is this season's offering at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute, where Mr. Bolton is associate curator. You may go for the legs. You'll stay for the plaids.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Wednesday about the results of legislative races in New Jersey misstated the total spent on legislative campaigns in 2001, a record that was likely to be exceeded this year. It was $41.7 million, not billion.

title: An Earful for Bloomberg
description: Tip O'Neill liked to tell the story about Solomon, who, already blessed with great power and intelligence, wisely asked the Lord to give him ''a heart that hears.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about efforts by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, founder of the Russian oil company Yukos, to gain access to influential Americans misstated the relationship between former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and the Open Russia Foundation, a Russian philanthropy based in Britain and financed by Mr. Khodorkovsky. Although Mr. Khodorkovsky asked Mr. Bradley to serve on the foundation's board, Mr. Bradley says he declined and is not advising the foundation.

title: Bush Aides Play Down Effort To Avert War at Last Minute
description: Bush administration officials on Thursday played down the significance of an Iraqi effort to avert war by holding last-ditch negotiations with Washington through a back channel in the weeks before the war began in March.

title: 36 Hours | Berkeley, Calif.
description: ALTHOUGH often only an afterthought for visitors to its fancier cousin across the bay, for those with a hankering for fabulous food, a passion for politics, or an independent bookstore addiction, Berkeley should be a target destination. Plus, in Berkeley, fog is simply a three-letter Scrabble word, and temperatures in the East Bay usually run a good 10 degrees warmer than those by the Golden Gate. Autumn in Northern California is usually lovely; the afternoon sun casts a tawny glow on the eastern hills, and there's the real possibility of a psychedelic sunset or a Maxfield Parrish moonscape. Sensible shoes are de rigeur, not a Manolo in sight. But true to the hippie stereotype, you'll see scads of Birkenstocks. People here take liberation seriously. Fashion tip: Don't wear fur. LOUISE RAFKIN

title: Mobs! Murder! Mayhem! (And a Few Good Deals)
description: LAST June, Baltimore police officers Karen Brzowsky and Timothy Beall were patrolling their beat in the city's Northern District when something caught their attention -- a middle-aged man walking along the street pushing a lawn mower to which he had strapped two bicycles and a handful of tools.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pentagon Approves Pact On Planes for Refueling

title: Desperately Trying to Relate To Her Body by Cutting It
description: From nail biting and nose picking to bulimia and drug taking, the list of potentially self-destructive compulsions to which we are susceptible is virtually endless. Marina de Van's ''In My Skin,'' a harrowing portrait of a 30-something woman who succumbs to an obsession with cutting her own flesh, suggests that such extreme behavior is often a desperate attempt to re-establish a connection with the body that has been lost.

title: Unions Call Mayor's Plan Unfair to Workers
description: A coalition of labor unions sharply criticized Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's $13.1 billion school construction proposal yesterday, saying it included $1.5 billion for projects that the group said would skirt wage laws and violate other workers' rights.

title: Julian Pozzi
description: Jeff Bailey Gallery

title: 'Billabong Odyssey'
description: Directed by Philip Boston

title: Prosecutor Says Medical Data Point to 4 Boys' Starvation
description: A New Jersey prosecutor said at a Congressional hearing on Thursday that four boys who were found severely malnourished in October had rapidly gained several pounds after their discovery. He said this development bolstered his charge that they had been intentionally malnourished.

title: Big Windows On the Sky
description: It turns out the sky's not the limit -- at least when it comes to moonroofs and sunroofs these days. A handful of carmakers are offering tops on their 2004 models that are almost all window, from the Skyview roof, a rectangular window running almost the length of the car, on the $27,000 Nissan Maxima sedan and the $24,000 Quest minivan (which has two), to the panorama sunroof on Mercedes's $25,000 C230 coupe, which promises ''an almost uninterrupted view of the sky.''

title: Few Voted in New York, and the Vote Wasn't Close
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Blocks New Statute That Limits Abortions
description: A federal judge in Manhattan blocked the government's new ban on a type of abortion yesterday, granting a temporary restraining order to a network of abortion providers that challenged the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act as unconstitutional just moments after President Bush signed it into law on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMYTHE, SHEILA MARY
description: SMYTHE--Sheila Mary. Mutual of America, its Board of Directors together with all of its officers and employees mourn the passing of Sheila M. Smythe, an esteemed member of our Board of Directors. Sheila Smythe served on Mutual of America's Board since April 1991, participating on the Audit, Investment, Long-Range Planning and Nominating Committees. During her tenure as a director, she contributed to the decisions that led to the Company's growth and current position of financial strength. She always remained focused on the importance of Mutual of America's mission to serve the retirement needs of small employers in both the not-forprofit and for-profit worlds. Ms. Smythe's work as an educator and a public health administrator, including as president and CEO of Empire BlueCross BlueShield and as the chief health policy advisor to the U.S. General Accounting Office, significantly improved the quality and delivery of health care in this country. Her successful establishment of the Graduate School of Health Sciences of New York Medical College is further testament to Ms. Smythe's accomplishments. Her service on the boards of numerous charitable and educational organizations further exemplifies her dedication to public service, which was appropriately recognized by Manhattanville College when they established the Sheila Mary Smythe Award in 1997. Her sudden death leaves a void in our hearts. We will miss Ms. Smythe's professional insights as well as her warmth and friendship. Our sincere condolences to her niece, Sheila P. Gonley, and to her many friends and loved ones. William J. Flynn Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Moran President & CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

description: And Coming Up, A Rare Bierstadt

title: Chowing Down on Raw Fish Along the Path to Manhood
description: Brother Bear

title: National Briefing | Washington: Coming Soon, A New Nickel
description: The United States Mint introduced two new designs for the nickel, which are to begin circulating next spring and fall. President Bush signed legislation in April authorizing a temporary three-year commemorative redesign of the nickel, left, to celebrate the bicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase and the Lewis and Clark expedition. Thomas Jefferson's face will remain on the coin's front; his home, Monticello, will return to the back in 2006. The Jefferson nickel has been around since 1938. John Files (NYT)

title: Jessica Lynch Criticizes U.S. Accounts Of Her Ordeal
description: In her first public statements since her rescue in Iraq, Jessica Lynch criticized the military for exaggerating accounts of her rescue and re-casting her ordeal as a patriotic fable.

title: Questioning Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: Rush to War, Revisited
description: To appreciate the significance of James Risen's article in yesterday's Times about an 11th-hour Iraqi peace offer last March, it helps to think back to that period. For months the Bush administration had been arguing that the only hope of disarming Baghdad was to steadily ratchet up the threat of an imminent American invasion. Only at that point, Washington asserted, might Saddam Hussein yield to the demands of repeated United Nations Security Council disarmament resolutions.

title: A Reverence For Wood And Nature
description: If you had to name one artist collected by Steven Spielberg, Brad Pitt, Steve Jobs, Julianne Moore and Narcisco Rodriguez, you probably would not guess George Nakashima (1905-1990), the Japanese-American master woodworker and furniture designer.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pub Group Acquired
description: Punch Taverns, Britain's second-largest pub chain, said it would buy the Pubmaster Group for 168 million ($280 million). As part of the deal, which nearly doubles the number of Punch's pubs to 7,400, the company will take on 1.03 billion of debt. Pubmaster became a takeover target when it lost a bidding war for Scottish and Newcastle's pub business earlier this year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: BUSH ASKS LANDS IN MIDEAST TO TRY DEMOCRATIC WAYS
description: President Bush on Thursday challenged Iran, Syria and two crucial Middle East allies of the United States -- Egypt and Saudi Arabia -- to begin embracing democratic traditions, and to view the fall of Saddam Hussein as ''a watershed event in the global democratic revolution.''

title: The President And the Mourning
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekender | Coventry, Conn.
description: ''THIS is the whole reason we're here,'' said Patricia Hackett, gesturing toward the expansive view of the water a few steps from the back door of her small lakeside house. To see the breadth of Wangumbaug Lake, which locals call simply Coventry Lake, is to understand why the neighborhoods around the water are so crowded and how easily the view makes one forget the proximity of neighbors.

title: Turkey Wont Send Troops to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The government of Turkey, reversing a recent decision that had sparked anger at home and alarm in Iraq, said today that it would not send troops across the border in support of the American campaign in Iraq.

title: Isaac Julien -- 'Baltimore'
description: Metro Pictures

title: Intense Bidding for a Klimt Ends in a $29 Million Price
description: In the auction world all it takes is three determined people with big egos and bank accounts to match. That's why a 1917 Klimt landscape sold for $29.1 million on Wednesday at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art. The price surprised even the auction house experts.

title: Lowe President Is Planning to Resign
description: Tim Lindsay, president at Lowe & Partners Worldwide since 2001, will resign, effective in January, the agency said.

title: Jim Nutt
description: Nolan/Eckman

title: Italian, With a Messiaen Accent
description: The influence of Messiaen's "Quartet for the End of Time" on contemporary chamber music has been such that even when it isn't played, one can often see its shadow. The young musicians in Antares play the instruments that the Messiaen requires: violin, clarinet, piano and cello. By deploying themselves in different combinations, they are able to play a fairly broad repertory, and they proved as much on Wednesday evening in an installment of the Contemporary Classic Italian series at the Italian Academy for Advanced Studies in America, at Columbia University.

title: Two Parties Interpret Nassau Vote Differently
description: It was the election night victory party that almost wasn't.

title: McDyess Closer to Returning
description: A day after being booed off the court for a dispirited 106-90 loss to the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, the Knicks had reason to hope.

title: Pew Charitable Trusts Will Become Public Charity
description: The Pew Charitable Trusts, one of the nation's 10 largest private foundations, will become a public charity next year in a move almost unheard of in the lofty realms of multibillion-dollar philanthropy.

title: Big Pension Fund Objects To Proposal for Big Board
description: The nation's largest pension fund urged federal regulators yesterday to reject the two-board structure for the New York Stock Exchange proposed by its interim chairman, John S. Reed, saying the main board would not be independent enough and would not be representative of investors' interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCKER, WALLIS G.
description: HOCKER--Wallis G., 88, of Windham, NH, on Sunday, November 2, 2003. Formerly of Raleigh, NC, and Summit, NJ area. Employed as Vice President and General Credit Manager for JC Penney Co., retiring in 1975. Husband of the late Marie (Bauer) Hocker (1998) and Ruth (Popkins) Hocker (1965). Father of Nancy Michels and her husband, John, Londonderry, NH, Jeanne Michels and her husband, Ed, Raleigh, NC, grandfather of five, great-grandfather of one, brother of Nancy Ward, Owensboro, KY. Graveside services Saturday, November 15th at 11:00AM in St. Teresa's Cemetery, Summit, NJ. For more information, visit www.peabody funeralhome.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABINOR, RUTH GLEEN
description: RABINOR--Ruth Gleen. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ruth Rabinor, beloved mother of Arnold Rabinor, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest sympathies to Arnold, and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

description: if (document.layers) { document.write(" "); } else { document.write(" "); } British News Media Dance Around a Royal Rumor var google_hints = "Royal+Family,Great+Britain";

title: Japan Farms: An Old Man's Game
description: When the motorcade of earnest agricultural promotion agents rolled up the other morning to his father's rice paddy, Shunseki Ouchi sensed a lecture on the virtues of farming. Without even a bow, Mr. Ouchi, a 22-year-old college student, ran away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIGENBAUM, DAVID HOWARD
description: FEIGENBAUM--David Howard. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of David Howard Feigenbaum, beloved brother of Marilyn Feigenbaum Salenger. We extend our deepest condolences to Marilyn and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Nature With Golden Haze Or Ominous Thunderheads
description: The Luminist painter Sanford R. Gifford (1823-80) knew how to entice the viewer into a landscape. Under his controlling brush, his subjects appeared at their most sublime: vast, timeless and suffused with glorious atmospheric effects.

title: Agency Leader Going to Thompson
description: Rosemarie Ryan will step down in January after eight years as president at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, to fill the long-vacant post of president at the flagship New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group.

title: Player-of-Year Contenders Will Have to Play Catch-Up
description: The contenders for the PGA Tour's Player of the Year award were hoping for a better start in the Tour Championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, HAROLD L., JR.
description: SCHWARTZ--Harold L., Jr., on November 5, 2003. Beloved husband for 53 years to Betty. Loving father of Ellen (Ron), Robin & Scott (Wendy). Devoted grandfather of Jamie (Dave), Tracy, Samantha, Kevin and Kyle. Dear brother of Jules (Emily) and Bernard (Irene). You are forever in our hearts and will be missed. Service private.

title: After the Fires, Back in Business
description: JUST a week ago, it looked as though Mountain High ski resort might not open at all this year. The ski area, 220 acres in the San Bernardino Mountains east of Los Angeles, is less than 10 miles from the reach of the Old Fire, one of the worst of the blazes that tore through almost 750,000 acres here in late October. Then the temperature dropped 40 degrees, snow started falling and, Monday morning at 8:30 a.m., the first skier of the season headed up on the chairlift.

title: Finding the Beast Within, And Portraying It Without
description: The image of a creature that is part human and part something else has been around for a long time. It's still with us, though the something else now tends to be mechanical rather than living. In premodern times, the other part was usually animal: horse, bull, bird, goat, lion, fish; the list goes on.

title: Sports Briefing
description: BASEBALL

title: U.K. first in G-7 to tighten borrowing costs : British interest rates rise
description: LONDON:  The Bank of England raised its base interest rate by a quarter percentage point on Thursday, to 3.75 percent, becoming the first central bank among the Group of 7 leading industrialized countries to tighten borrowing costs as the global economic recovery picks up speed.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Some Repayment In Stock Fraud
description: Millions of dollars recovered among the assets of Robert E. Brennan, left, the bankrupt penny-stock tycoon, are one step closer to being paid to thousands of defrauded investors. Donald F. Conway, the court-appointed bankruptcy trustee, announced yesterday that he had mailed $39 million to major creditors among the many owed about $130 million by Mr. Brennan, the former head of First Jersey Securities, who is now in prison. After a six-year global search and long court proceedings, Mr. Conway said, he had recovered the money from trusts and securities and Mr. Brennan's interests in real estate, a casino boat in Florida, and a golf course in Colts Neck, N.J. He said that the money was sent yesterday, including $17.5 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission and $16.7 million to an investor fund. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: It's Time to Hear What Bill Donaldson Wants the Big Board to Do
description: WHERE'S Bill?

title: 'Martin and Orloff'
description: Directed by Lawrence Blume

title: Moss Shines in the Jets' Dim Season
description: The question clouded the Jets' future even before Chad Pennington was hurt: how was a journeyman like Curtis Conway going to replace a young star like Laveranues Coles? But in the Jets' locker room, Curtis Martin knew who would take over. And so, during the preseason, he approached Santana Moss, the third-year receiver who was not then in the starting lineup.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Houses Are Planned On 7.2-Acre Site in Queens
description: The first six of what will be 68 semiattached two-family houses are under construction on a 7.2-acre site in Woodhaven, Queens, that because of its history has provided a rare opportunity for large-scale development in a central location.

title: Tories Choose Longtime Lawmaker as New Leader
description: Britain's quarrelsome opposition Conservatives united on Thursday to name a longtime lawmaker, Michael Howard, as their new leader in hopes of ending years of infighting and of mounting a serious challenge to Labor Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: ROBERT GUCCIONE STEPS DOWN AS CHIEF OF PENTHOUSE
description: Robert Guccione, the chairman and chief executive of Penthouse International Inc., resigned yesterday from the magazine publishing company he founded almost 40 years ago. Charles Samel, an executive vice president at company, who also stepped down, said the departures were ''absolutely not'' related to an investigation into the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission. He declined to comment further. The company's General Media publishing unit filed for bankruptcy protection in August after competition from the Internet, retail video outlets and cable television left it unable to pay its creditors. Penthouse disclosed the same month that the S.E.C. had opened a formal investigation into its accounting.

title: Billions and Billions Served, Hundreds of Millions Donated
description: National Public Radio announced yesterday that it had received a bequest worth at least $200 million from the widow of the longtime chairman of the McDonald's restaurant chain.

title: Steinbrenner Is Said to Want Schilling
description: Two years ago, Curt Schilling dismissed the Yankees' postseason magic by saying Mystique and Aura were nothing more than names of nightclub dancers. He backed that up with a sterling performance in the World Series, helping the Diamondbacks beat the Yankees.

title: Ferry Captain Remains Silent In Questioning
description: Appearing before investigators for the first time, the captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed into a pier three weeks ago refused yesterday to answer any questions about the accident, in which 10 people died and dozens were injured, the authorities said.

title: Rifle Is Being Used as Linchpin in Sniper Case
description: It is known as Commonwealth's exhibit No. 1: the .223-caliber Bushmaster semi-automatic rifle that investigators found in John A. Muhammad's car when he was arrested in the Washington-area sniper attacks last October.

title: Powell Praises Informal Peace Negotiators in Mideast
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 7  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has praised the Israelis and Palestinians who negotiated an informal peace accord, they declared today. But the endorsement was seen as a jab at the Israeli government, which has sharply denounced the unofficial diplomatic initiative.

title: Reduced Charges for Soldier Accused of Cowardice in Iraq
description: Army officials dropped cowardice charges on Thursday in the case of a sergeant who said he had suffered from a panic attack in Iraq but charged him with the lesser offense of dereliction of duty.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NORWICK, DOUGLAS J.
description: NORWICK--Douglas J. Your star shines brightly and your spirit dances on. Always love. Herbert J. Baker

title: 'The Matrix': Global Opening
description: It would be an overstatement to call ''The Matrix'' -- the original film released four and a half years ago -- a small movie that went big. But its revenues, domestic and global, certainly far exceeded expectations. When the final installment of the series opened on Wednesday, Warner Brothers and its distributors left nothing to chance. ''The Matrix Revolutions'' opened simultaneously worldwide in 43 languages and on more than 10,000 screens, including IMAX. This is the largest single release of any film ever. The strategy is partly to impede piracy by ''globalizing'' the film immediately. But it is also meant to turn the film's release into a big moment -- to ''event-ize'' the movie, as one executive put it in the tone-deaf jargon of Hollywood.

title: Anthrax Scare Leads to Closing of Mail Centers in Washington
description: Eleven Washington-area post offices were closed today after a routine air sample taken at a Navy mail facility in the region tested "positive for anthrax," a Postal Service spokesman said.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: SEEKING BETTER ORTHODOX-VATICAN TIES A spokesman for the Russian Orthodox Church voiced hope for better relations with the Vatican after President Vladimir V. Putin's meeting with Pope John Paul II, but he said nothing about the prospect of a papal visit. The spokesman, the Rev. Vsevolod Chaplin, also repeated the Orthodox position that ties frayed "when Catholic missionaries decided they could cultivate Russia as a spiritual desert." The Catholic Church has attracted new followers in Russia since the collapse of Communism 1991; the Orthodox Church has accused Catholics of poaching converts.   (AP)

title: Brooklynese Spoken
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARFIELD, RUTH
description: GARFIELD--Ruth. On November 6, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Sid Garfield. Cherished mother of Judy Farinet (Gene) and Janet Jamieson (Bob). Adored grandmother of Andrew Jamieson and Jennifer Farinet. Throughout her life, Ruth treasured her family above all else and we will miss her love, wisdom and devotion with all our hearts. Visitation on Saturday 6:30-9 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Service private.

title: American Not Ruling Out A Discount-Fare Airline
description: American Airlines is closely watching the attempts by its two largest rivals to start low-cost carriers and might eventually decide to start one of its own, its chief executive said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Chief Rebukes Wall St. for Mutual Fund Scandals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in response to the growing scandals in the mutual fund industry, said today that the agency intends to overhaul the regulation of the industry soon by adopting measures restraining abusive trading, clarifying conflicts of interests rules and compelling better disclosure on fees.

description: Amarillo, Tex.
