description: By Bloomberg News

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Vote On Cloning Ban Delayed For 2 Years
description: The General Assembly voted to postpone for two years consideration of a ban on human cloning. The General Assembly's legal committee, which comprises all the members, voted 80 to 79 in favor of a deferral motion introduced by Iran on behalf of Islamic countries. Fifteen members abstained. The vote suspended a contentious debate over two resolutions. One, backed by the United States, called for a ban on all forms of human cloning. The other, supported by a smaller group led by Belgium, called for a more limited ban that would prohibit the development of cloned embryos to produce a human being but would permit the use of such embryos for medical experiments. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: 'Hidden in Plain Sight'
description: Directed by John H. Smihula

title: U.S. Teams Do Well in Bridge
description: All the North American teams are doing well in the World Championships here and are likely to qualify for playoffs beginning Sunday.

title: In Spain, Basque Parliament Agrees to Debate Independence Plan
description: A Basque independence plan, considered a far-fetched dream even by some supporters, took a small step toward becoming a reality when the divided Basque parliament voted this week to grant it an official hearing and to open debate.

title: Battle of the Network Docudramas
description: ONE is an unworldly blond teenager whose capture and miraculous rescue entranced the nation. The other is an unworldly blond teenager whose capture and miraculous rescue entranced the nation.

title: Eugene Speicher -- 'An Artist Reconsidered'
description: American Academy of Arts and Letters

title: Indian Pt. Foes Challenge U.S. On Safety Plan
description: Opponents of the Indian Point nuclear power plant filed an administrative appeal on Thursday seeking to overturn federal approval of plans to protect residents near the plant's two reactors in case of an emergency.

title: New Jersey Driver Survey Cites Agony but No Ecstasy
description: Ah, the life of the New Jersey motorist. The police are mean, everyone else on the road is an idiot, the tollbooths are in the wrong place, and who is the genius who thought of reducing Route 1 to two lanes between Woodbridge and the Menlo Park Mall?

title: Carolina's Power Play Is Lifted by the Rangers
description: By reverting to form, the Rangers received just what they deserved in their 6-3 loss to the Carolina Hurricanes on Thursday night.

title: A Keen Eye and Oh, Such Compelling Friends
description: IN deference to the nervous Nellies who insure the extroverted contents of Jeff Soref's art-centric apartment on Gramercy Park, a scholarly itemization of his collection of African and Eastern sculpture, most of it carved in timeworn wood, is forbidden. But gawking is permitted. He is constantly asked which pieces he'd rescue in a fire: fortunately he has no spouse, kids or pets to further complicate things. He's inordinately fond of an ancestor figure, presumably a king, from Congo; it seems a good king is hard to find. Then there's the 11th century hermaphrodite from Mali. Decisions, decisions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Reports Profit
description: The French bank Socit Gnrale said it earned 670 million euros ($766 million) in its third quarter, helped by the strong stock market and gains in investment banking. Profit was up from 146 million euros a year earlier. Socit Gnrale's results come one day after a rival, BNP Paribas, reported a 69 percent increase in profits, also helped by the stock market recovery. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRISTEL, BEVERLY
description: KRISTEL--Beverly. On November 4, 2003. Beloved wife to Ira for 53 years. Devoted mother to Alan, Steven and Mindy. Dear niece to Molly. Adored grandmother to Jackie, Elizabeth, Anna, Lara, Nicole, Jordana, Nathaniel, Julia, Anton and Matthew. Throughout her life, Beverly treasured her family above all. We will all miss her deeply. Donations may be made in her name to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, 386 Park Ave South, 14 flr, New York, NY 10016

title: U.S. Prosecutors Ask Judge to Keep Stewart Charges Intact
description: The United States attorney's office in Manhattan has asked a federal judge to deny Martha Stewart's request to dismiss two of the five criminal charges against her, according to court papers filed late Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FREED, MILDRED
description: FREED--Mildred, 11/6/01. We miss you every day. We will never forget you. Ruth and Harry

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: COUNCIL DELAYS LANDLORD TAX The City Council passed a bill yesterday to delay collecting a 25 percent property tax surcharge on absentee landlords that estimates say would raise $44 million for the city. Council Speaker Gifford Miller proposed the delay, until March 1, after the Department of Finance found it difficult to identify absentee landlords. The department had planned to send higher bills to owners who had not sent in papers stating that they lived in their homes.   Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Travel Expenses Criticized
description: Defense Department employees spend millions of dollars a year on first- and business-class airline tickets that they are not authorized to buy, Congressional investigators said. The investigators, from the General Accounting Office, a nonpartisan research arm of Congress, said the Pentagon spent almost $124 million in 2001 and 2002 on 68,000 tickets that were above coach class. More than 70 percent of the purchases were improper, costing the department an extra $20 to $60 million, they said. Renwick McClean (NYT)

title: Bush Sees Signs That Tax Cuts Are Working
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  Buoyed by good news about the economy, President Bush campaigned today in North Carolina, where he promised that his administration would not rest "until everybody who wants to work can find a job."

title: The Neediest Cases; A Family's Good Life Takes a Horrible Turn So Suddenly
description: Amber leaped into her mother's blue Ford Tempo. Another day of second grade was over and she was eager to tell her mother, Wendy Colletti, what she had learned.

title: Mets Hire 2 Special Assistants
description: The Mets said yesterday that they had hired two superscouts to help them get a better handle on evaluating talent inside and outside the organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about efforts on television and the Internet to defend Raymond and Vanessa Jackson of Camden, N.J., who are accused of having starved four adopted sons, misidentified the CBS program that has exclusive rights to an interview with the family. It is ''60 Minutes II,'' not ''60 Minutes.'' In some copies the article also misstated the date of the Jacksons' arrest. It was Oct. 24, not. Oct. 21.

title: Greenspan Hints at End To Low Rates
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered a first hint on Thursday that the era of rock-bottom interest rates may be slowly drawing to a close.

title: Tales of Love, the True and the Not-So-True
description: ''Love Actually,'' which opens today nationwide, is an indigestible Christmas pudding from the British whimsy factory responsible for such reasonably palatable confections as ''Four Weddings and a Funeral,'' ''Notting Hill'' and ''Bridget Jones's Diary.'' A romantic comedy swollen to the length of an Oscar-trawling epic -- nearly two and a quarter hours of cheekiness, diffidence and high-tone smirking -- it is more like a record label's greatest-hits compilation or a ''very special'' sitcom clip-reel show than an actual movie.

title: Employment Climbed in October as Jobless Rate Fell
description: The longest hiring slump in more than 60 years finally appears to be ending.

title: Prime Minister Returns to Calmer Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka's prime minister returned to the country today amid reports that the president would lift the state of emergency she declared Thursday. The president had also suspended the country's Parliament for two weeks.

title: The Great Job Machine
description: Apparently unconvinced by last week's eye-popping growth figures, economic pessimists remain fixated on the labor market. Today's release of the Labor Department's latest employment figures, we are told, will give a true picture of the pace of economic recovery.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Commission Names Debate Sites
description: The Commission on Presidential Debates said college campuses in Florida, Missouri and Arizona would play host to presidential debates for the 2004 general election. The debates will be held on Sept. 30 at the University of Miami in Coral Gables; Oct. 8 at Washington University in St. Louis and Oct. 13 at Arizona State University in Tempe. A debate by vice-presidential candidates is scheduled for Oct. 5 at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. John Files (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Delays Landlord Tax
description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday to delay collecting a 25 percent property tax surcharge on absentee landlords that estimates say would raise $44 million for the city. Council Speaker Gifford Miller proposed the delay, until March 1, after the Department of Finance found it difficult to identify absentee landlords. The department had planned to send higher bills to owners who had not sent in papers stating that they lived in their homes. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: At a Base in Iraq, American Troops Honor Victims of Copter Attack
description: Several hundred American soldiers gathered Thursday evening at a former Iraqi air base here to say farewell to 15 comrades who died Sunday after their Chinook helicopter was struck by a missile. [Late Thursday in Washington, the Pentagon announced that a 16th soldier died in a hospital in Hamburg, Germany.]

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about car customizing misidentified a car-tuning club in Detroit. It is Redline Motorsport, not Motorsports.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Personnel Costs Rise
description: New York City's municipal work force shed 10,000 full-time jobs, 4 percent of the work force, over the last three fiscal years. But personnel costs, like pensions and overtime, rose 20 percent during the same period, according to a study released yesterday. The number of city workers, now about 240,000, dropped in almost all departments except education, according to the report by the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan watchdog agency. The number of police officers, firefighters, correction officers and sanitation workers declined, but wages, overtime pay, health insurance premiums and pension contributions rose. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Story of League's Top Teams Unfolds in the Fourth Quarter
description: Seventeen N.F.L. teams own records of .500 or better. For the others, making the playoffs remains possible; 26 teams in the past 10 years have reached the postseason after starting with records of 4-4 or worse.

title: Defector Ties Iran to 1994 Bombing of Argentine Jewish Center
description: Testifying in a public setting for the first time, a defector from Iran's intelligence agency has accused a group of senior government officials in Tehran of having ''led, orchestrated and executed'' a bomb attack on a Jewish community center in Argentina that killed 85 people and wounded 200 almost a decade ago.

title: Brazil Eases Its Dependence on I.M.F.
description: Confident it has stabilized Brazil's economy, the country's left-leaning government said this week that its 12-month extension of a standby agreement with the International Monetary Fund signals an end to years of dependence on I.M.F. bailouts.

description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark said Thursday that military operations in Iraq should be turned over to a North Atlantic Treaty Organization force under United States command and that he would replace the civilian administration there with an international effort not under American leadership.

title: Britain raises rates; Greenspan is upbeat on U.S. outlook : More signs of worldwide rebound
description: LONDON:  In the clearest sign yet that the global recovery is picking up speed, the Bank of England raised interest rates Thursday, the first of the world's major central banks to tighten credit after a stifling three-year economic slump pushed borrowing costs to historic lows.

title: At Ground Zero Oasis, a Path Is Restored
description: For the first time in memory, you can get to the chapel by way of Church.

title: National Briefing | Religion: Churches Join Boycott
description: The National Council of Churches voted at its general assembly meeting to join a boycott against Taco Bell and Mount Olive Pickle to protest conditions for farmworkers who pick tomatoes and pickles. The council represents 36 Orthodox, Anglican and Protestant denominations. It last endorsed a boycott 15 years ago. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTLIEB, DR. PAUL
description: GOTTLIEB--Dr. Paul, Director of the School of Biological Sciences died November 1, 2003, in Austin, Texas, of liver cancer at the age of 59. He was both a creative scientist and an empathetic administrator. He became Director of the School in the College of Natural Sciences in September 2001 after serving several years as chairman of Molecular Genetics and Microbiology. During his tenure as the School's Director, he worked unceasingly to increase the interactions between two seemingly disparate groups of biological scientists, those who study whole organisms and those like Dr. Gottlieb who study specific molecular processes. His achievements have left an enduring legacy at the University. Dr. Gottlieb expanded programs and helped increase funding for biological research and for both graduate and undergraduate education. Gottlieb received a BA from Princeton University in 1965. He then earned a doctoral degree from The Rockefeller University, working with Nobel Laureate Gerald Edelman. After a post-doctoral fellowship at Stanford Gottlieb took a faculty appointment at MIT. He came to the University of Texas as Professor in 1980. His research focused on the cells that constitute the body's immune system. In his early career, he made seminal contributions to deciphering the structure and function of antibodies, laying the groundwork for understanding how each immune cell produces only a single antibody. Later, he worked to understand the function of a major class of immune cells, called killer T cells. Gottlieb also discovered a new gene important for T cell function and for cardiovascular system development. Mice lacking this protein have an embryonic heart defect that has important implications for cardiac disease in children. A co-author of more than 70 scientific articles, Gottlieb also served as an editor of various immunology journals and as a member of national research immune cell produces only a single antibody. Later, he worked to understand the function of a major class of immune cells, called killer T cells. Gottlieb also discovered a new gene important for T cell function and for cardiovascular system development. Mice lacking this protein have an embryonic heart defect that has important implications for cardiac disease in children. A co-author of more than 70 scientific articles, Gottlieb also served as an editor of various immunology journals and as a member of national research committees. He was a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Gottlieb was a native of New Brunswick, N.J. He is survived in Austin by his wife, Nell Gottlieb; his daughter, Erin A. Gottlieb, and sonin-law, Eric A. Bedell from Galveston; his brother, Michael Gottlieb from Pasadena, Calif.; and his mother, Beatrice Gottlieb from Highland Park, N.J. The College of Biological Sciences of the University of Texas at Austin deeply mourns his passing. Donations may be made to The Paul Gottlieb Memorial Fund at the School of Biological Sciences, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Friday about charges of cowardly conduct filed against Sgt. Georg Andreas Pogany, an American interrogator in Iraq, misstated his connection to the Army's Special Forces. Although assigned to a team of Green Berets from the 10th Special Forces Group, the sergeant is not himself a Green Beret.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: At Sono, his last restaurant, Tadashi Ono explored his ambitious style of French-Japanese fusion in a contemplative atmosphere. Too much tranquillity might have got on his nerves. At Matsuri, the beast is loose. The restaurant, in the Maritime Hotel, has the dimensions of an airplane hangar and the propulsive vibe of an after-hours club. A 100-sake wine list may account for the upbeat mood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEE, ALEXANDER (LEX)
description: SCHNEE--Alexander (Lex). Passed away on July 4, 2003. A graduate of Dartmouth College, he also attended the London School of Economics and the National War College, Washington DC. Schnee spent 40 years with the Department of State, including 25 years in the Foreign Service and 15 years in Congressional Relations. During WWII he was a First Lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corps. He is predeceased by his wife, Helen Louise (Lala) and his sister, Amy Goldberg. He is survived by his sister, Hedwig Goldstein and his daughters, Susan Carol Holt and Alix Sandra Schnee (Giordano) and families. Interment services for Lex and Lala will be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY on November 9, 2003.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Posts Income
description: The insurance company Aegon reported an 8.2 percent increase in third-quarter income. Aegon earned 464 million euros ($531 million) compared with 429 million euros in the third quarter a year earlier. The results surpassed analysts' expectations. Third-quarter revenue fell 6.1 percent, to 6.75 billion euros, from 7.19 billion euros. Aegon attributed part of its profit increase to lower provisions for potential bond defaults and a rise in capital gains. Earlier this year, Aegon agreed to sell most of its Transamerica Finance commercial lending business to General Electric for $1 billion. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Small Screen, Big Ideas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTLIEB, JEROME
description: GOTTLIEB--Jerome. 61. Suddenly, at home in Hollywood, CA, much too soon. Mourned by his cherished wife Janice Gottlieb, beloved sons Benjamin and Jonathan, loving siblings Roberta and Melvyn Klein, Susan and Mark Beckerman, Jerry Gemeinhardt, treasured nieces and nephews, David and Stephanie, Bill and Deborah, Ruth, dear mother-in-law Janette Gemeinhardt countless other family members and friends. Services November 7 in California. For information contact 212-724-4126 ext 200.

title: Pentagon Says A Covert Force Hunts Hussein
description: The top American military commander for the Middle East has created a covert commando force to hunt Saddam Hussein, Osama bin Laden and key terrorists throughout the region, according to Pentagon and military officials.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Beautiful, Baby

title: Creditors Seek Judge's Removal In Asbestos Case
description: In move that could prolong and complicate an already contentious bankruptcy case, creditors of Owens Corning, which was driven into Chapter 11 proceedings by asbestos lawsuits, are pressing for the removal of the presiding judge. Legal experts say the challenge by the creditors could be used to undermine the legitimacy of the judge's previous rulings in its case.

title: A Suicidal Man and a World, in a State of Suspension
description: Artists of all stripes give a lot of thought to the methods and purposes of creativity: how and why do they do what they do? And much work, both beautiful and pretentious, has derived from self-examination. Such is ''The Hanging Man,'' a wry rumination on death and the purpose of art by the British troupe Improbable Theater.

title: SPIEGEL SEEKS COURT PERMISSION TO OPEN NEW STORES
description: Spiegel, the troubled retailer, asked a federal judge yesterday for permission to open 7 new Eddie Bauer stores in six states and Canada and as many as 10 additional stores. Spiegel, in a court filing, asked Judge Cornelius Blackshear of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to allow the store openings, in Calgary; Colorado Springs; South Windsor, Conn.; Troutdale, Ore.; Lee, Mass.; Short Pump, Va.; and Alderwood, Wash. The move is a reversal for Spiegel, which since filing for bankruptcy protection in March, has closed more than 60 stores along with distribution and customer service centers. A hearing on the request is scheduled for Nov. 18.

title: 9 Immigrants Arrested In Raid File Lawsuit Against Wal-Mart
description: Nine Mexican immigrants who worked as janitors at Wal-Marts in New Jersey sued the company on Wednesday, accusing Wal-Mart and its cleaning contractors of failing to pay overtime, withhold taxes and make required workers' compensation contributions.

title: COMPANY NEWS BEAR STEARNS IS BUYING CAMELBAK PRODUCTS
description: Bear Stearns has agreed to buy a privately held recreational equipment maker, CamelBak Products, for $210 million from the Bowes family, which bought it for $4 million in 1995, CamelBak said yesterday. John G. Bowes, CamelBak's chairman, owns the company with his daughters and said he would leave when Bear Stearns completed the purchase. CamelBak, based in Petaluma, Calif., was established in 1989 by a former paramedic, Michael Edison, and makes backpacks that allow hikers, runners and other athletes to drink hands-free during physical activity. It also makes those products for hunters, the government and the military. CamelBak's chief executive, Glenn Gross, 59, said he would remain after the purchase.

title: States in India Take New Steps To Limit Births
description: A new reckoning is under way in India over how best to stabilize a population that is set to surpass China's as the world's biggest by midcentury.

title: Dean's Gaffe: What Did We Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Asian-American Health Study
description: New York University's medical school received a $5 million federal grant to study diseases and other health problems that occur more frequently among people of Asian heritage. The National Institutes of Health and N.Y.U. said on Wednesday that the medical school would use the money to establish the Center for the Study of Asian-American Health. There is more incidence of liver and stomach cancer among Asian-Americans than in any other ethnic group, researchers say. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

description: Speedy Changes At O'Neill Center

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Oct. 31 about Thierry Desmarest, the chairman of Total, misstated the location of the Kashagan oil fields, in which the company has a 20 percent stake. They are in Kazakhstan, not Russia.

title: Forecasts of an ad blitz by wireless services providers ahead of a key rule change may prove wrong.
description: CONSUMERS being barraged by a relentless flood of pitches from the giant wireless service providers are bracing for an additional onslaught, to be unleashed as a result of rules taking effect Nov. 24 that allow consumers to keep their cellphone numbers when they change carriers within the same calling area.

title: Bertelsmann and Sony to Join Music Units
description: Bertelsmann and Sony have agreed to combine their music divisions, becoming the latest partners in an industry roundelay that reflects the turbulent economics of recorded music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWINNELLS, DANA WILSON
description: DWINNELLS--Dana Wilson. Our best friend can never be described in words. All we can ever hope to do is to continue to live out the dreams he began with us. The love he brought to our lives can never be forgotten because every memory is over-flowing with his genuine smile, his laugh, and his real character. He will be a part of our lives forever. Services on Sunday, November 9, 11:00 AM at The Lillis Funeral Home, New Milford, CT, 860-354-4655. Laura, Ed, Daniel and Melody Merker

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALISH, AIDA DR.
description: KALISH--Aida Dr. Loving aunt of Miriam Kaplan, William Gerber, Deborah Stabarra and Barbara Bergmann. Services were held at the ''Riverside'' Chapel, 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Love in a Cold Climate
description: Hugh Grant and Martine McCutcheon (right) star in Richard Curtis's new holiday offering, ''Love Actually.'' The ensemble cast includes Bill Nighy, Alan Rickman, Colin Firth, Liam Neeson and Emma Thompson. The film, writes A. O. Scott, ''is more like a record label's greatest-hits compilation'' than ''an actual movie.''

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MICHIGAN: EX-CHIEF PLEADS NO CONTEST TO GUN CHARGE Detroit's former police chief, Jerry Oliver, pleaded no contest to possession of an unlicensed handgun in an incident that led to his resignation. Under an agreement with prosecutors, the charge could be dismissed in 90 days if Mr. Oliver stays out of trouble. Mr. Oliver, 56, failed to tell airport officials he had a .25-caliber pistol in his checked luggage before flying from Detroit to Philadelphia on Oct. 18. He resigned on Oct. 31. (AP)

title: One-of-a-Kind Real Estate Deal For Eternal Rest in Manhattan
description: It is barely a studio, really -- just 8 by 10 feet, with a low ceiling and a terrible view. But as they say, in Manhattan it's all about location, location, location.

title: Few Voted in New York, and the Vote Wasn't Close
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: France/Spain: Unproductive Summit Talks
description: President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar met in Carcassonne, France, for their annual summit meeting, but had little to show for it. The countries, eager to show that a bitter rift over Iraq is behind them, remain at odds over the draft of the European Union constitution, which deletes earlier accords that give Spain near equal voting rights with France and Germany in the European Council. Mr. Aznar lobbied for Mr. Chirac's support in making the constitution adhere to the existing rules, but Mr. Chirac replied coolly that he wanted union members to stick ''as closely as possible'' to the draft. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: An Evolving South Bronx, Seen in Synagogues; As Jews Left, the Buildings Became Home to Churches, Clinics, and Even Jails
description: ''Synagogues are only buildings made of bricks and mortar,'' Dr. Seymour J. Perlin once wrote. ''The people of a congregation make a synagogue come to life.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tobacco Unit Sold
description: British American Tobacco, the world's second-largest tobacco company, sold its operations in Myanmar, giving in to pressure from the British government to leave the country, which is run by the military. Myanmar, formerly Burma, has been criticized for its human rights record. Distinction Investment Holdings of Singapore will buy British Tobacco's 60 percent stake in Rothmans of Pall Mall Myanmar, for an undisclosed sum. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: An Electronic Exchange
description: To the Editor:

title: On Visit, Congo President Faults U.S. Farm Subsidies
description: Though seeking further support from the Bush administration to help bolster his fragile government, Joseph Kabila, the president of Congo, criticized the United States this week for maintaining agricultural subsidies that harm farmers in his country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Poughkeepsie: Vassar Fined For Waste
description: Vassar College has been fined nearly $100,000 for the improper disposal of what federal inspectors called hazardous wastes, as well as the poor training of campus personnel in labeling, keeping track of and handling such wastes. Vassar has 30 days to respond. Vassar officials said they would challenge some of the findings and hoped to negotiate a reduction in the $97,581 penalty from the Environmental Protection Agency, which announced the fine on Wednesday. The violations, found during a March 2002 inspection, included improper disposal of laboratory chemicals, the agency said. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Wednesday about the recent decline of Penn State's football program under Coach Joe Paterno misspelled the surname of a Paterno defender, the chairman of the university's trustees. He is Edward Hintz, not Himtz.

title: Las Vegas Auto Couture: A Fashion Show for Cars
description: KAI T. WEISSKOPF, the president of the American arm of Recaro, the German racing-seat maker, is showing off one of his company's newest entries at the Specialty Equipment Market Association's annual convention here. The seat includes tiny speakers in the headrest for surround sound and a suspension system that mellows out the bumps in the road. It is covered with a velvety soft fabric on top of a breathable mesh fiber that wicks away sweat.

title: Step Back By Defense Has Giants Stymied
description: The passes came like body blows in the fourth quarter, the Jets slicing off chunks of yardage against the Giants' secondary. Parts of Sunday's game -- particularly two big fourth-quarter drives -- were a miserable flashback to weeks past for the Giants, weeks that once dropped them to last in the N.F.L. in defense, weeks they thought were long forgotten.

title: Manslaughter Charge in Newark Neglect Case
description: A 17-year-old cousin of Faheem Williams, the Newark boy whose body was found in a plastic bin in the locked basement of an aunt's house, was indicted Thursday on manslaughter charges in the case, which put a national spotlight on the state's troubled child welfare system.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Brewer Increases Profit
description: Lion Nathan, which makes beer in Australia, China and New Zealand, reported that net profit rose 11 percent, to 180 million Australian dollars ($127.6 million) on sales of 1.7 billion Australian dollars in the year through September. Sales rose 6 percent. The brewer's main brand is Tooheys. It also owns Petaluma, an Australian maker of premium wines. The chief executive, Gordon Cairns, said that beer sales in China had increased 30 percent and that operations there, started three years ago, were approaching break-even levels. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Shrinking From Campaign Reform
description: It is historic, not just regrettable, that former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont thinks that he had best drop out of the publicly subsidized campaign financing system and reach for bigger money through private donations. That would be a grave blow by a Democratic front-runner to a system that has served well since the Watergate days, when political corruption by special-interest money scandalized the nation into reform.

title: Opera Festival of New Jersey Shuts Down
description: Citing financial difficulties, the Opera Festival of New Jersey, a well-regarded regional summer festival, announced yesterday that it would close permanently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, BELLE W.
description: FEINBERG--Belle W. Age 94, of Lauderhill, Florida. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Passed away November 5, 2003. Cherished wife of the late Irving H. Beloved mother of Hon. Michael and Frank, mother-in-law of Marlene and Anita, grandmother of Roberta, Felicia, Andrew, Adam and Sharon. Greatgrandmother of Austin and Travis. A teacher for the NYC Board of Education for 33 years and a graduate of NYU. She will be missed by all. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Avenue L) today at 10:00 am.

title: Compromise Plane Deal Wins Pentagon Approval
description: The Pentagon approved a compromise plan yesterday that paves the way for the Air Force to acquire 100 Boeing 767's for use as aerial refueling tankers, ending months of controversy over a program that became a test case for the Pentagon's ability to lease major military equipment.

title: ICAD WINS APPROVAL FOR NEW BREAST CANCER SCREENING
description: Icad, a maker of computer-assisted medical tests, said yesterday that it had won Food and Drug Administration approval to sell a product that might offer a cheaper way to screen for breast cancer. The product is intended for health centers and clinics that perform fewer than 20 mammography screenings a day, the chief executive, W. Scott Parr, said. Shipments will probably start in the fourth quarter, Mr. Parr said. Shares of Icad rose 65 cents, or 13 percent, to $5.60.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOW, ANNE R.
description: DOW--Anne R. 65, of Cambridge, MA, on October 31. For 20 years, directed English as a Second Language programs at Harvard. Developed multi-media English language learning materials. Memorial service at Harvard's Memorial Church, December 5 at 11:30. Donations may be sent in her memory to Cambridge Community Chorus, PO Box 390278, Cambridge, MA 02139.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Minority Leader For Governor?
description: The Assembly minority leader, Paul DiGaetano, said yesterday that he would explore a campaign for governor in 2005. The decision, he said, meant that he would not seek to renew his position as head of the Republican caucus. With six Assembly terms behind him, Mr. DiGaetano said he was ready ''to take the Republican message statewide.'' He also announced that he had hired Kieran Mahoney, an adviser and campaign aide to Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, as the general consultant for a committee to explore his prospects in the governor's race. After the announcement, the Republican caucus selected Assemblyman Alex DeCroce, the Republican conference leader, to replace Mr. DiGaetano and fill the party's top post in the Legislature. Assemblyman Guy Gregg was chosen for the position of Assembly Republican conference leader.

title: Hearing for Two Yankees Postponed
description: Ahearing to determine whether two Yankees  outfielder Karim Garcia and reliever Jeff Nelson  will be charged with assault and battery in connection with a bullpen brawl during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series at Fenway Park has been postponed until Dec. 12.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Down With Communism!
description: The remains of the former Palace of the Republic in Schlossplatz, in what was East Berlin, will be torn down next year, a parliamentary committee said. The 1970's glass and steel construction, which once housed East Germany's Parliament, a concert hall, several restaurants and leisure facilities, was closed because of asbestos contamination shortly after the Communist government collapsed in 1989. Since then the building has been stripped to its framework and glass facade. Once funds have been raised, Germany wants to rebuild the Hohenzollern Royal Palace on the site. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Protecting Children As Vehicles Back Up
description: WHEN Kathy Rubenstein bought her 2003 Acura MDX last spring, she was focused on getting the navigation package. But she considered the rearview camera that came as part of it as little more than a novelty.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Schwarzenegger to Name Private Investigator in Sexual Misconduct Accusation
description: Gov.-elect Arnold Schwarzenegger will name a private investigator to look into accusations of sexual misconduct made against him in the final days of the California recall campaign, an aide said on Thursday.

title: Thumbs Down, Thumbs Up: Prizing a Personal Voice Even if It Hurts
description: Last week, defying the consensus of the connoisseurs, I went to a concert in the New York Philharmonic's series of all the Beethoven symphonies and concertos. Critics may complain about such supposedly unimaginative programming, but Avery Fisher Hall was fuller than I've seen at a Philharmonic concert in a long while.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data Systems Names Sales Head
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the world's second-largest seller of computer services, yesterday named Michael Boustridge to head its biggest sales efforts as the company tries to revive growth. Mr. Boustridge, 41, succeeds Steve Smith, who left to join Lucent Technologies Inc.

title: Peter Serkin Explores the Radical Bach Who Sought Out Adverture
description: The pianist Peter Serkin has long been known for his impassioned advocacy of contemporary music. But Mr. Serkin has had many musical passions, high among them the music of Bach. His debut solo recording, released in 1965 when he was 18, was an incisive and sensitive account of Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations.

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: GAY PANEL MEMBERS QUIT All seven members of the New Orleans mayor's gay advisory panel resigned after the mayor, Ray Nagin, endorsed a conservative Republican, Bobby Jindal, for governor. "Mr. Jindal has ignored numerous requests over the last three months to meet with representatives of our community to discuss issues, including economic development and civil rights," the panel's chairman, Randal M. Beach, said in a letter. Mr. Jindal, who faces a Nov. 15 runoff against Kathleen Blanco, a Democrat, said he had not had time to meet with the Louisiana League for Equality, a statewide gay rights group. (AP)

title: Witness Has a Change of Heart
description: Testifying for the third straight day, Rod Hamson, former finance director for the Salt Lake Olympic Bid Committee, said yesterday that the indicted bid leaders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson had authorized numerous payments to International Olympic Committee voting members and concealed their intentions from their bid committee overseers.

title: Jim Nutt; Eugene Speicher; Isaac Julien
description: Jim Nutt

title: Corrections
description: The Living Here column last Friday about houses with turrets misspelled the name of a lake near Sandpoint, Idaho. It is Lake Pend Oreille, not Ponderay (which is the name of a community on the lake).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAPOSSNEK, HOWARD S.
description: SAPOSSNEK--Howard S. (71), of Boynton Beach, FL. Former Junior high school principal, musician and computer expert known for establishing computer use in NYC schools. Survived by his wife, Gert; children Robin, Mark and Jill, six grandchildren. Services Sunday, 11:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: 'Just an American Boy'
description: Directed by Amos Poe

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Investigators in 2 Other Cases Await Verdict in Durst Trial
description: Thousands of miles from the courthouse where a jury is deliberating the fate of Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate heir charged with murder, there are small armies of people intensely focused on the outcome of the trial. They range from Mr. Durst's wife to detectives in two states and friends and relatives of the scion's first wife, who disappeared mysteriously 21 years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Rahway: Amtrak Reports On Derailment
description: The derailment of a New Jersey Transit train last week that disrupted travel for thousands of passengers on the line was caused by a defect in track-switching equipment, Amtrak announced yesterday. A 10-car commuter train tried to transfer from one track to another near the Rahway station on Friday and passed over a track switch, which moved. An Amtrak spokesman, Dan Stessel, said that investigators had ruled out vandalism and were trying to determine why the switch moved. The device, now out of service, was installed in April 2001 and passed a monthly test two days before the mishap, he said. No injuries were reported among the 700 passengers. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Finding Surprises as They Are Turned Up by the Karma Wheel
description: ''Everyone Gets Lighter'' is the good-news message on a billboard across the street from the Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art at Snug Harbor on Staten Island. The words, by the New York poet John Giorno, introduce a show titled ''The Invisible Thread: Buddhist Spirit in Contemporary Art.'' And after a visit, you may indeed feel a little more buoyant than usual.

title: That Old-Timers' Rock 'n' Roll
description: SOME rock singers warm up with vocal exercises and humidifiers; others prefer bourbon and cigarettes. Don Tuohey, the leader of a Long Island bar band called Galloway's Truck, prepares by racing home from work and feeding his two children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRODIN, SYLVANA
description: GRODIN--Sylvana. On November 5, 2003. Devoted mother of Daniel and William Schneider and Elizabeth Schneider Gross, loving sister of Leonard and Martin Grodin, cherished grandmother of Taryn, Dean, Cole and Maxwell Schneider and Tyler and Preston Gross, daughter of Esther and Sam Grodin. Beloved Aunt, cousin, niece and friend. Funeral services Friday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam. 212-362-6600

title: Six Killed in U.S. Helicopter Crash in Iraq
description: TIKRIT, Iraq, Nov. 7 — Six American soldiers died here on Friday when their Black Hawk helicopter crashed and burned in the reeds and mire along the Tigris River after exploding in the air, according to Iraqi witnesses.

title: A Visionary With Modernist Nightmares
description: GOYA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETERS, SANDRA DAPHNE
description: PETERS--Sandra Daphne, on November 6, 2003, born in London, England. Loving mother of Jonathan, devoted daughter of the late Rose and Maurice Cassell. Dear cousin of Daphne, Brian and Sheila, Roger and Sue Cookson. Loving friend to all animals. Donations may be given to the American Cancer Society, the ASPCA or the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Manhattan.

title: Strong Sales in Europe and Japan Give Mazda a Lift
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation said on Thursday that its profits doubled in the first six months of the year, in part because of strong sales in Europe and Japan.

title: Stars Were Aligned for Mergers, Then Investors Spoke
description: The latest merger boom may turn out to be just a boomlet.

title: Minority Leader Considers Entering Race for Governor
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6  The Assembly minority leader, Paul DiGaetano, said Thursday that he would explore running for governor in 2005. The decision, he added, meant that he would not seek to renew his position as head of the Republican caucus.

title: The President And the Mourning
description: To the Editor:

title: Houses Under $100,000: Sometimes Money Is the Object
description: WHO -- Rex Heer, 52, multimedia designer at Iowa State University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOEY, ROSAMOND
description: LOEY--Rosamond. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the death of our beloved member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her brother Ben, niece Jane, and nephew James, and their loved ones. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Rabbi Scott M. Corngold Cantor Bruce L. Ruben Michael H. Laufer, President

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Unlocking High-Rise Doors
description: Chicago high-rise owners have one week to unlock their doors under a measure passed unanimously by the City Council on Wednesday. Building owners may install an automatic unlocking system or simply leave doors unlocked at all times, council members said. Six people died last month in a fire after they were trapped in a locked stairwell that quickly filled with smoke. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Shopping List| Longboarding
description: IF bikes or inline skates aren't your preferred mode of transportation, maybe you're better suited to carve the streets on a longboard. Longboarding's surfing roots are more obvious than in traditional trick-focused skateboarding: a longboard's elongated deck and larger wheels make for a floating, smoother ride. Suit up with some protective (and stylish) gear and you'll be ready to cruise the town.

title: Bobby Hatfield Dies at 63; Righteous Brothers Tenor
description: Bobby Hatfield, whose wholesomely passionate tenor carried the upper harmonies of the pop-soul duo the Righteous Brothers, died on Wednesday in a hotel room in Kalamazoo, Mich. He was 63 and lived in Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Almost Famous
description: The new Hollywood luminaries take their style as seriously as their Method. What's their motivation? To be ready for their close-up. Always.

title: American Girl, Too
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: College Costs
description: The flight paths of college costs and state budgets.

title: Photos Only
description: In Venice, there's a whiff of madness in the air.

title: Longboarding
description:
By BONNIE TSUI
If bikes or inline skates aren't your preferred mode of transportation, maybe you're better suited to carve the streets on a longboard.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the closing of Harry's at Hanover Square, a restaurant in Manhattan's financial district, referred imprecisely to the India House Club, which housed the restaurant in a basement. (The Wine Talk column in the Dining section on Wednesday, about the extensive cellar at Harry's, repeated the error.) The club is open during the day to members; it is not closed. Bayard's, another restaurant, operates there in the evening.

title: Our Man In Havana
description: It would take some chutzpah for me to accuse President Bush, Congressional Democrats and a courageous Nobel Peace Prize-winning dissident of bolstering some of the world's most odious dictators.

title: Devils Can't Hold Lead Against Leafs
description: Martin Brodeur found a seat at the far end of the Devils' bench Friday night, popped a stick of chewing gum in his mouth, and was a spectator at a Devils game for the first time this season. Corey Schwab, the usual seat-warmer, took Brodeur's place against the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Once Again: Was War Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: First Sniper Trial Heartens Defense for the Second
description: Lawyers for Lee Malvo, the younger suspect in the wave of sniper shootings that terrorized the Washington area last fall, have watched the first weeks of the trial of the other defendant, John Muhammad, with mounting delight.

title: Design Guidelines for Ground Zero Point More to Space City U.S.A.
description: How did we end up in Houston? That is the burning question raised by a new set of design guidelines for the office towers at ground zero. True, we've got a hole the size of Texas sitting down there in Lower Manhattan. But how did ground zero come to inherit a vision of glitzy, structurally inept towers that would look more at home in an office park for energy companies in Space City U.S.A.?

title: Barnes & Noble Makes Bid For Shares of Online Unit
description: Barnes & Noble made an offer yesterday to buy back the publicly traded shares of its Barnesandnoble.com subsidiary for $2.50 each, reversing an initial public offering made at $18 a share during the Internet boom four years ago.

title: Small Isn't Always Better
description: There has been understandable excitement about Bill Gates's gift of $51 million to create 67 small public high schools in New York City. Who could be against closing giant and dangerous factory-style high schools and replacing them with small, safe programs in which every teacher knows every student?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, CATHERINE F., 97, (NEE MCPARTLAND)
description: DIAMOND--Catherine F., 97, (nee McPartland) Hobe Sound, FL. on November 4, 2003, born July 12, 1906 New York City, Preceded by husband James W. Diamond in 1985. Survived by three children Robert Diamond, Mary V. Kaufman, Suzanne Martin, eight grandchildren, ten great grandchildren. Funeral Saturday, St. Christopher Catholic Church, Hobe Sound, FL.

title: The Tragic Life of the Father Next Door
description: Those who knew him best wonder if it wasn't all a mistake, some kind of misguided Robin Hood complex, that led Ronald P. McKeown Jr. to give away money that prosecutors say he embezzled from a Red Cross fund for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 31 about Steven M. Theede, the American who became chief executive of the Russian oil company Yukos after the arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky on Oct. 25, misspelled the name of Mr. Theede's birthplace. It is Hutchinson, Kan., not Hutchison.

title: Bloom Is on the Economy
description: One flower may not prove the winter is over, but yesterday's employment report provided a strong indication that the economy is in an accelerating recovery.

title: TIAA-CREF Estimates Chief's 2003 Compensation at $9 Million
description: TIAA-CREF, the pension fund giant, said yesterday that its chief executive, Herbert M. Allison Jr., would earn at least $9 million this year.

title: Power Line Kills Man
description: One construction worker was killed and two were injured yesterday after a crane cable they were moving struck a power line in Queens, the police said. The accident occurred at 3 p.m. yesterday in Edgemere on the Rockaway peninsula.

title: Mideast View: Bush Spoke More to U.S. Than to Us
description: Commentators across the Middle East on Friday largely dismissed the speech by President Bush calling for wider democracy in the region, labeling it something for domestic consumption to justify the war in Iraq rather than signaling a real change in policy.

title: Richard Wollheim, Philosopher, Dies at 80
description: Richard Wollheim, a philosopher who synthesized analytic philosophy, psychoanalysis and the study of painting to develop aesthetic insights that are considered among the most profound of the postwar era, died on Tuesday at his home in London. He was 80.

title: INSIDE
description: Panel Subpoenas Pentagon

title: 6 AMERICANS DIE IN COPTER CRASH IN HUSSEIN'S CITY
description: Six American soldiers died here on Friday when their Black Hawk helicopter crashed and burned in the reeds and mire along the Tigris River after exploding in the air, according to Iraqi witnesses.

title: Parents Are Uneasy After Man Tries to Lure Girl Into S.U.V.
description: When a 9-year-old girl left her apartment at 1 West 64th Street about 7:45 on Thursday morning, she went downstairs to wait outside the building for a ride to school from a car service.

title: Paroled Killer Of 2 Officers Is Arrested
description: Thomas Trantino, a paroled killer of two New Jersey police officers in 1963 and one of the state's most notorious convicts during his 38 years in state prison, was arrested in Camden, N.J., on Thursday on charges of beating his companion on five occasions since late October, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Scheme Fools Job Seekers And State, Officials Say
description: They were hungry for work, so more than a hundred people came to the state job recruitment center in Jersey City last month for a job fair. They thought nothing of paying a $42 ''application fee'' to recruiters from a private company who interviewed them and had them fill out pages and pages of forms asking for sensitive personal information.

title: Once Again: Was War Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer To Issue Stock
description: The scandal-scarred Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold said it planned to issue at least 2.5 billion euros ($2.85 billion) worth of new stock as part of an effort to pay down about 12 billion euros in debt and recover from $1.1 billion worth of accounting irregularities discovered earlier this year. The company also intends to sell at least 2.5 billion euros worth of its assets, including its Spanish operations. Ahold made its fund-raising plans public in conjunction with its second-quarter results. The company earned 42 million euros ($47.9 million) in contrast to a loss of 270 million euros in the period a year ago. Net sales fell 12.4 percent, to 13 billion euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: At High School, 2 Fires in a Day
description: Two fires broke out yesterday at Brooklyn Technical High School. At least two others have occurred at the same building since the school year began.

title: With a U.S. Nod, Turkey Says It Won't Send Force to Iraq
description: With the quiet blessings of the White House, Turkey said Friday that it was withdrawing its offer to deploy troops to help stabilize Iraq. The decision ended a lengthy and almost entirely futile effort by the Bush administration to solicit large numbers of foreign troops to bolster the American presence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, JANE TRAFFORD LUKE
description: MURPHY -- Jane Trafford Luke. Died on Wednesday, November 5, 2003, from complications from Lupus. She is lovingly remembered by her friends and family for her courageous battle with the disease, and for her generous spirit. Born October 17, 1953 in Charleston, S.C., Jane earned a B.S. from Briarcliff College and her R.N. from Pace University. A devoted mother to her two sons, Jane was an active volunteer at Greens Farms Academy, and she was a member of the Women's Fellowship at Trinity Church. Jane is survived by her husband, Jonathan J. Murphy, two sons, J. Luke Murphy and Gordon T. Murphy, all of Fairfield, CT.; her parents, Joy and John A. Luke, Sr., a brother John A. Luke, Jr., and a sister, Hope L. Hetherington, all of New Canaan, CT.; a brother William H. Luke of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Southport, CT on Tuesday, November 11th, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Jane's memory to the Lupus Research Institute, 149 Madison Ave, Suite 205, N.Y., N.Y. 10016

title: S.E.C. Chief Vows to Act on Mutual Funds
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday that the agency intended to overhaul the regulation of the mutual fund industry soon by adopting measures to curtail abusive trading, clarify rules on conflicts of interests and compel better disclosure of fees.

title: Hearing for Two Yankees Postponed
description: A hearing to determine whether two Yankees -- outfielder Karim Garcia and reliever Jeff Nelson -- will be charged with assault and battery in connection with a bullpen brawl during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series at Fenway Park has been postponed until Dec. 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, MARILYN E.
description: SLOAN--Marilyn E., of Teaneck, NJ and Amagansett, NY. Dear sister of Geraldine Sloan and Jeffrey Sloan. Loving aunt of David Kopelman and Heather Kopelman. Services Sunday, 3PM, ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions to the Association for Retarded Children, Nassau County Chapter, 100 Wheatley Rd., Brookville, NY.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO REPUBLIC: EBOLA OUTBREAK SUSPECTED Nine people have died from what is feared to be the Ebola virus in a remote forest region where 120 people died of the disease earlier this year, said the health minister, Alain Moka. The area lies near Mbomo, 440 miles north of the capital, Brazzaville. There is no known cure for Ebola, which is passed on by infected body fluids and kills 50 to 90 percent of victims.    (Reuters)

title: Witness Fails to Back Police In Account of '99 Shooting
description: The day after Gidone Busch was shot to death by police officers on a Borough Park sidewalk in 1999, the police commissioner, Howard Safir, told reporters that ''seven independent witnesses'' backed the police account of a justified shooting because Mr. Busch was attacking officers with a ''claw hammer.''

title: The Neediest Cases; A Father Emerges From Grief to Fight Cancer
description: Ten years. To Jose Lopez, 58, it has all been a blur.

title: European Regulators Prepare to Grapple With 2 Possible Music Industry Mergers
description: For a record company, the worsening state of the industry is hardly a reason for cheer, unless you are planning a merger with a big rival.

title: If Gladiators Wore Togas, We Can Wear Skirts
description: To the Editor:

title: Mauritania's Election Pits Staunch U.S. Ally Against 5 Opponents
description: At a polling station in the working-class suburb of Quartier Arafat, a heated Election Day argument erupted at high noon on Friday.

title: Selling of Tax-Credit Forms Is Investigated
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday that it had opened an investigation into a Brooklyn woman who has been selling state tax forms for a credit for homeowners and renters with annual household incomes of less than $18,000.

title: Trying to Reduce Fatal Mix of Deer and Drivers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  To reverse the rising toll of death from highway collisions with deer, either the deer or the drivers will have to change behavior, according to a new report. It will probably have to be the deer, the researchers found.

title: Johnson & Johnson Is Sued By Rival Over Sales Methods
description: A New York medical device company has accused Johnson & Johnson of antitrust violations in the selling of its surgical devices to hospitals, joining other businesses and government officials that have already been questioning its marketing practices.

title: Understanding Indonesia, by Its Leaders and Its Gossip
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 7  Midway through Theodore Friend's compelling "Indonesian Destinies," the reader comes across the essential kernel needed by any outsider to understand the complexities of the history and society that underlie Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim country. Mr. Friend wisely chooses to devote a fat paragraph to the words of a retired Roman Catholic priest, architectural planner, writer and social activist, Romo Mangun.

title: Prince Charles Denies a Rumor, but Won't Say What It's About
description: No one would say what the rumor was. Not the British newspapers, which were writing long, innuendo-laced articles about it. Not the television commentators, who were discussing it with acrobatic opacity. Especially not Prince Charles, who seemed to be hoping it would just go away.

title: PIPELINE COMPANY DETAILS EXPENSE FROM BUYING BACK DEBT
description: The Williams Companies, a pipeline owner that is selling assets to remain solvent, said it expected a pretax expense of $56 million in the fourth quarter because of the repurchase of $951 million of debt. Williams received tenders for more than half of the $1.64 billion in debt securities it sought to repurchase by a Thursday deadline, the company said. Stock in Williams, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., fell 64 cents, or 6.5 percent, to $9.21 a share. The stock fell 3.6 percent on Thursday after Williams issued its earnings statement for the third quarter and said profit fell short of Wall Street's expectations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schrder's Stimulus Package Delayed
description: The opposition-controlled upper house, the Bundesrat, temporarily blocked Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's package of labor reforms and tax cuts aimed at reviving the economy. The bills, which have passed the lower house, were to take effect Jan. 1. They included $17.85 billion in income-tax cuts, reductions in welfare and unemployment benefits, and cuts in subsidies and tax breaks for home buyers and commuters. The Christian Union alliance, which holds the majority in the Bundesrat, called the plans to finance tax cuts mainly through higher borrowing ''immoral,'' given the country's record deficit. The bills now go to a mediating committee to work out compromises. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: BERKSHIRE THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT JUMPS 58%
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company run by Warren E. Buffett, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit increased 58 percent, led by gains in its insurance units. Net income rose to $1.8 billion, or $1,176 per Class A share, up from $1.14 billion, or $744 a share, a year earlier. Profit excluding investment gains climbed 38 percent, to $1.35 billion, or $881 a share. Mr. Buffett has raised prices and bolstered reserves at the General Re Corporation, the reinsurer that had $7.5 billion in underwriting losses in the four years after he bought it in 1998. General Re had a $32 million underwriting profit in the quarter, in contrast to a $434 million loss last year. The shares were unchanged yesterday at $80,000. Berkshire announced its earnings after the close of trading.

title: Hugh H. Bownes, 83, Judge Who Ruled for Civil Liberties
description: Hugh H. Bownes, a former federal appeals court judge whose rulings in defense of civil liberties often put him at odds with conservative New Englanders, died at Yale New Haven Hospital on Wednesday. He was 83 and lived in Branford, Conn.

title: Master Plan for New Trade Center Gets Down to the Finest Detail
description: After months of dealing in broad concepts, the planners of the new World Trade Center are devising guidelines that will prescribe the actual forms of the buildings -- in inches and feet, metal and stone.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: CHICAGO PROPOSES DESEGREGATION PLAN Chicago school officials have submitted a plan to federal court that seeks to end the government's 23-year-old desegregation case against the city. A key element of the plan, submitted on Thursday, is a promise that the school district will spend as much on neighborhood schools as it does on elite magnet schools, which attract more white students. A lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union criticized the plan as too general, saying it promised studies instead of solutions. (AP)

title: Yanks and Red Sox to Compete For Free-Agent Second Basemen
description: The Yankees and the Red Sox cannot stay out of each other's way. After pursuing some of the same players last winter and playing 26 fierce games against each other through October, both teams want to sign a premier second baseman.

title: The Orioles Turn to Mazzilli To Help Turn Things Around
description: The call came to Lee Mazzilli at midnight Thursday, and he broke down in tears. A half-hour later, Mazzilli, by then a former Yankees coach, called Joe Torre. Mazzilli had played for Torre with the Mets in the late 1970's. After accepting the Baltimore Orioles' manager's job, Mazzilli was suddenly Torre's peer.

title: After a Scare Over Anthrax, Postal Offices Are to Reopen
description: Federal authorities will begin reopening 12 closed postal offices in the capital on Saturday after testing of 20 air samples taken from a naval mail sorting center and other offices failed to detect the presence of anthrax, federal officials said on Friday.

title: About New York; Grief Forms a Family, Then Drives a Wedge Into It
description: THE last remains of 2001's other disaster sit in a refrigerated trailer on the East Side of Manhattan. They have been there for nearly two years, beside the medical examiner's office, in frigid limbo.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Maker Cuts Outlook
description: Kawasaki Heavy Industries, Japan's second-largest maker of heavy machinery, cut its annual profit forecast by half as the stronger yen cut the value of its overseas sales. Net income for the year ending March 31, 2004, will probably total 4 billion yen ($36.3 million), half the company's 8 billion yen forecast in May, and less than a third of the previous year's 13 billion yen profit, the company said. The company, based in Kobe, Japan, said its first-half net loss narrowed 2.6 percent, helped by more profit from its aerospace and shipbuilding units.

title: Once Again: Was War Necessary? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Oil Company's Profit Rises
description: The French oil company Total said its third-quarter profit rose 6.9 percent despite the negative impact of the fall of the dollar against the euro. The company, which is based in Paris, said it earned 1.71 billion euros ($1.97 billion), up from 1.6 billion euros in the third quarter of 2002. Despite higher oil prices, sales fell 4 percent because of the strong euro. Per-share earnings rose 13 percent, helped by the company's program to buy back shares. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Tougher Role On Transport Is Ordered By Pataki
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has ordered the state transportation commissioner to take a more aggressive role in overseeing and coordinating the patchwork of authorities that operate the state's sprawling transportation system.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm John Kerry, and I approve this message!''

title: New Bids for the Nets Are Due on Monday
description: The three bidders seeking to buy the Nets must submit a new round of offers to YankeeNets by midnight Monday, and the sale could be completed by mid-December, people involved in the process said yesterday.

title: Where the Streets Have Too Many Names
description: It's the year 2103 and Brooklyn remains a vibrant, bustling borough thanks in no small part to the fortitude and creativity of a century's worth of immigrants. Some things, however, have changed. For several generations now, Bedford-Stuyvesant has been predominantly Latino, while East New York and Brownsville residents come mostly from India. These New Yorkers want their cultures honored, so they start lobbying to rename the Jackie Robinson Parkway for Roberto Clemente or Gandhi.

title: Jones the Favorite, but Not to Tarver
description: Almost a decade ago, when he was a junior welterweight and welterweight champion at the end of his career, Buddy McGirt wanted to fight Roy Jones Jr.

title: Bill Includes Funds to Study Indian Point
description: Congress is expected to pass a measure next week to provide $1 million to research ways to make up for energy that would be lost if the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County were closed.

title: At Sniper Trial, Theme of Molding a Killer
description: Throughout the four-week-old trial of John A. Muhammad, the man accused of masterminding the Washington-area sniper attacks, prosecutors have had to work around what seemed a significant shortcoming in their case: most of the evidence linked only Lee Malvo, who is accused of being Mr. Muhammad's accomplice, to the killings.

title: 3 Months of Job Growth Best in 3 Years
description: The longest hiring slump in more than 60 years appears to be finally ending.

title: A Japanese Witness to History Adroitly Survived It
description: SEEN through the prism of old photographs that sit atop the piano in the family living room, Toshikazu Kase is the Zelig of Japanese diplomatic history.

title: Sports of The Times; Even on a Missed Kick, It's Not Always Fair to Kick the Kicker
description: IN the grim world of professional football, it is common to blame the wretched place-kicker or punter when a game gets away. At the very least, this ploy catches the attention of expendable linemen and backs, which is always useful.

title: A Book Is a Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston School Official Defends Action
description: Houston's school superintendent, Kaye Stripling, defended crime reporting in the schools yesterday, saying the district had adhered to state laws that require the reporting of disciplinary actions against students.

title: Gephardt and Gays
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Again: Was War Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Again: Was War Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROCKWELL AUTOMATION, Milwaukee, the world's largest maker of factory controls, said it had hired James Gelly, treasurer of Honeywell, to succeed Michael Bless as chief financial officer on Jan. 5.

title: Uncovering the Humor in Pinter's Pawn-and-Catalyst Caretaker
description: The question was obvious. Was ''Star Trek'' preparation for acting Pinter?

title: In Court, O'Donnell Says a 'Coup' Led to Collapse of Her Magazine
description: During the week of the civil trial between Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing and Rosie O'Donnell over who deserves the blame for the demise of their magazine co-venture, the news media horde amused themselves with a single question: How would Ms. O'Donnell, who had been depicted in testimony as vindictive and mercurial, perform as a witness?

title: If Gladiators Wore Togas, We Can Wear Skirts (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 25 about the shooting death of Kamal Singh, a Bronx teenager who was an advocate of improving safety at the Knox-Gates Playground in his neighborhood, Norwood, misstated the site of the crime. It was across the street from the playground, not inside it.

title: A Libyan Brings a High Profile But Low Skills to Italian Soccer
description: All that Al Saadi Qaddafi wanted was a fair chance, a clean shot, or so he told reporters after he signed to play with the professional soccer team in Perugia and arrived there last summer, bodyguards in tow.

title: Mentally Ill, in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Mining Again in a Montana Town That's Fallen on Hard Times
description: Burned by the promises of a New West an economy based on the Internet and telecommunications -- this city high in the Rockies is celebrating a return to the Old West, as hundreds of copper miners return to work.

title: Love, Internet Style
description: The Internet slows things down.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Housing Lender's Profit Rises
description: St. George Bank, a regional financial services group with 70 percent of its loans in housing, said its profit last year rose 64 percent, to 6 million Australian dollars ($4.3 million). The bank's per-share earnings climbed 14 percent. The chief executive, Gail Kelly, an American appointed three years ago, estimated per-share growth next year would decline to about 10 percent as a result of a slowdown in lending for homes. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: SCHRÖDER'S STIMULUS PACKAGE DELAYED The opposition-controlled upper house, the Bundesrat, temporarily blocked Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's package of labor reforms and tax cuts aimed at reviving the economy. The bills, which have passed the lower house, were to take effect Jan. 1. They included $17.85 billion in income-tax cuts, reductions in welfare and unemployment benefits, and cuts in subsidies and tax breaks for home buyers and commuters. The Christian Union alliance, which holds the majority in the Bundesrat, called the plans to finance tax cuts mainly through higher borrowing "immoral," given the country's record deficit. The bills now go to a mediating committee to work out compromises.    Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Mentally Ill, in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DESLAURIERS, RUDOLPH
description: DESLAURIERS -- Rudolph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Rudolph Deslauriers, associated with The Times from May 1949 until retiring in January 1972.

title: Treating Osteoporosis
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fruits of Secrecy
description: One of President Bush's first acts was to convene a task force to produce a national energy strategy. Led by Vice President Dick Cheney, the group met secretly with hundreds of witnesses. It heard from few environmentalists, but many lobbyists and executives from industries whose fortunes would be affected by any new policies. Despite lawsuits, the White House has refused to divulge the names of those privileged to get Mr. Cheney's ear. The results, however, have been plain as day: policies that broadly favor industry -- including big campaign contributors -- at the expense of the environment and public health.

title: A Professor Who Refuses To Pull His Punches
description: In the ring his nickname was Busy Louie. In the classroom, where he spends much more of his time these days, it is easy to see why. Confined by street clothes, his feints and jabs accompanied not by leather gloves but merely by a dwindling piece of chalk and a blackboard eraser, Loc Wacquant, a professor of sociology at the University of California campus here, all but dances his way through a seminar on the criminal justice system.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Setback For Jeb Bush Over Feeding Tube
description: A judge has denied Gov. Jeb Bush's motion to dismiss a suit seeking to stop his intervention in the case of a brain-damaged woman whose husband wants her feeding tube removed. The suit contends that a new state law letting Mr. Bush order the feeding tube reinserted in the woman, Terri Schiavo, is unconstitutional. Mr. Bush had argued that lawyers for Mrs. Schiavo's husband, Michael, did not file the suit properly. But Judge Douglas Baird, of the state's Sixth Circuit Court, disagreed and ordered Mr. Bush's lawyers to file a brief by Monday. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Retribution and Lust Collide in the Ghetto
description: The tenor Neil Shicoff was the driving force behind the Metropolitan Opera's decision to present ''La Juive'' by Fromental Halvy for the first time since 1936. Once a staple of the repertory (and Enrico Caruso's final new role at the Met), this French grand opera has all but disappeared from the canon. Mr. Shicoff, the son of a Brooklyn cantor, has said that he was deeply touched by the opera's exploration of anti-Semitism and that he found the role of Elazar, a Jewish goldsmith in 15th-century Switzerland embittered by the brutal persecution of his people, ideally suited to his nervously intense artistry.

title: Howell Keeps Contenders At Bay
description: Charles Howell III will not win the PGA Tour Player of the Year award, but he may win the Tour Championship.

title: Groups Sue to Prevent Sale Of Columbus Circle Building
description: Three preservation groups filed suit yesterday to stop the city from selling the vacant city-owned building at 2 Columbus Circle to a museum that wants to strip off the building's modernist facade.

title: Judges Strike Down Law on Religion in Prison
description: A federal law meant to protect prisoners' religious rights is unconstitutional, a three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Cincinnati ruled yesterday. The judges ruled that the law amounted to an endorsement of religion by the government, violating the establishment clause of the First Amendment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, ELLA CLYDE MYERS
description: STEVENS--Ella Clyde Myers, age 95, died on Monday, November 3, 2003 after a long and productive life. Born in Columbia, South Carolina, to the late Isaiah and Ola Myers. The widow of the late New York Supreme Court Justice Harold A. Stevens. A graduate of Benedict College and graduate studies in New York and Chicago, she retired as a teacher in the NYC Public School system. She is survived by a cousin, Doris Toppin, a nephew, James Q. Stevens II, two grand nephews, James III and Jeffrey, and a grand niece, Gabrielle. In addition, there is a host of friends and associates from her many years of service in her religious, charitable and social activities. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 a.m., Monday, November 10th, at St. Mark's Evangelist R.C. Church, West 138th Street between 5th Ave and Lenox. Entombment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorials may be donated in memory of Ella to Inner City Scholarship Fund or Catholic Charities. Visiting hours are from 1:00 to 3:00 pm on Sunday November 9th at the Elizabeth Smith Funeral Service, 2284 Adam Clayton Powell Blvd., at 134th St.

title: Staff Saw Warnings of Danger At South Jersey Adoption Unit
description: On Sept. 14, 2000, nine New Jersey child welfare workers based in offices in the southern part of the state met to discuss adoption and foster care. The resulting critique, meant to be confidential, painted a disturbing picture of a staff that did not have enough homes in which to place foster children awaiting adoption. Nor did that staff have the tools to meaningfully evaluate the homes that were available.

title: If Gladiators Wore Togas, We Can Wear Skirts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man Who Would Save Reagan From a TV History
description: Growing up in a conservative family outside Philadelphia, he came of age politically when Ronald Reagan was president and never lost his reverence for him.

title: Mentally Ill, in Prison (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about the closing of Harry's at Hanover Square, a restaurant in Manhattan's financial district, referred imprecisely to the India House Club, which housed the restaurant in a basement. (The Wine Talk column in the Dining section on Wednesday, about the extensive cellar at Harry's, repeated the error.) The club is open during the day to members; it is not closed. Bayard's, another restaurant, operates there in the evening.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: SETBACK FOR JEB BUSH OVER FEEDING TUBE A judge has denied Gov. Jeb Bush's motion to dismiss a suit seeking to stop his intervention in the case of a brain-damaged woman whose husband wants her feeding tube removed. The suit contends that a new state law letting Mr. Bush order the feeding tube reinserted in the woman, Terri Schiavo, is unconstitutional. Mr. Bush had argued that lawyers for Mrs. Schiavo's husband, Michael, did not file the suit properly. But Judge Douglas Baird, of the state's Sixth Circuit Court, disagreed and ordered Mr. Bush's lawyers to file a brief by Monday.

title: Celtics Make the Nets Feel at Home, Again
description: For the Nets, the road out of every rough spot is paved with parquet.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the movie ''The Human Stain'' misstated the nationality of a cast member, Wentworth Miller. Although born in England, he is American.

title: Court Reinstates Perjury Charges in a Case Linked to 9/11
description: In a coup for the Bush administration, a federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the detention of a grand jury witness was constitutional, and it reinstated perjury charges against a Jordanian student accused of lying about his association with one of the Sept. 11 hijackers.

title: Surviving Auschwitz, Surrendering To Despair
