description: PRIMO LEVI

title: JetBlue Backs Off on Move to Jamaica From Forest Hills
description: Attempts to lure JetBlue Airways into moving its headquarters to a planned $200 million office tower in Jamaica, Queens, appear all but dead for now, with the company saying the move would be too costly and would take longer than expected to complete.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 30 about the sale of a family tomb at Mountain View Cemetery in Oakland, Calif., misstated the name of an opera in which one family member heard her husband singing when they met. It is ''Die Walkre''; it includes the scene known as the ''Ride of the Valkyries.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Puffing To Continue, For A While
description: Health Minister Micheal Martin eased his plan to ban smoking in all workplaces next year after the attorney general said the measure could not be enforced in ''temporary dwellings'' like prisons, nursing homes, hospitals and hotel rooms. Bar owners opposed to the ban said the exemptions would permit them to challenge its legality. European Union rules require him to wait three months before the revised ban, originally scheduled to begin Jan. 1, can take effect. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: China Begins Giving Free H.I.V./AIDS Drugs to the Poor
description: The Chinese government has started providing free treatment for poor people with H.I.V. and AIDS and plans to expand the program next year until every poor person who has tested positive is receiving medical help, a top Health Ministry official said in a speech this week.

title: Guard at Boys and Girls Club Is Accused of Strip Searches
description: A security guard at a Boys and Girls Club in Newark was fired after reports that he strip-searched several boys on Thursday, officials at the club said yesterday.

title: A Frequent Playoff Journey Has Become a Road to Nowhere for the Jets
description: On Sunday, for the fifth time in less than two calendar years, the Jets will walk into the boiling caldron that is Network Associates Coliseum in Oakland to play the Raiders.

title: Facing Protests, New York Delays Sales Taxes on Indian Reservations
description: The Pataki administration has postponed a plan to begin collecting taxes from non-Indian customers on reservations in New York, a proposal that had drawn fierce opposition from the Seneca Indian Nation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 31 about Steven M. Theede, the American who became chief executive of the Russian oil company Yukos after the arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky on Oct. 25, misspelled the name of Mr. Theede's birthplace. It is Hutchinson, Kan., not Hutchison.

title: With a Fortune Riding on Gucci, A French Scion Steps Forward
description: Like many French adolescents, Franois-Henri Pinault had a passion for soccer. But rather than just buying him a soccer ball, his father, Franois Pinault, one of France's wealthiest men and the owner of Pinault Printemps-Redoute, bought a whole team: Stade Rennais, a professional team in their native Normandy.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: AdSlogans Unlimited, London, was renamed AdSlogans.com to draw attention to its redesigned Web site, which provides information and analysis on marketing slogans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the election of Daniel M. Donovan Jr. as Staten Island district attorney misstated the last time a Republican was elected to the post. (The error also appeared in a front-page article that summarized election results and in an article on Oct. 31 about the race.) The last time was in 1951, when Sidney O. Simonson was elected to a single term -- not more than a century ago.

title: Senate Postpones Vote on Internet Tax Ban
description: The Senate postponed a vote on banning Internet access taxes yesterday after sponsors agreed to extend the prohibition without making it permanent.

title: Witness Has a Change of Heart
description: Testifying for the third straight day, Rod Hamson, former finance director for the Salt Lake Olympic Bid Committee, said yesterday that the indicted bid leaders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson had authorized numerous payments to International Olympic Committee voting members and concealed their intentions from their bid committee overseers.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: 'Choose Life' Plates Opposed
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and Planned Parenthood filed a federal suit in Nashville to keep the state from issuing ''Choose Life'' license plates. They say the plates are unconstitutional because the state does not offer plates for opposing viewpoints. Similar license-plate laws have been passed in Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma and South Carolina. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Tips Problem Is Resolved, Ending Strike At Restaurant
description: La Caravelle, one of the city's top French restaurants, announced yesterday that it had settled a three-day strike. The last issue to be resolved was the amount of the sommelier's tips.

title: Fine Print Is Given Full Voice in Campaign Ads
description: In one of his television commercials, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts announces his candidacy for president before a throng of adoring, placard-waving supporters.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rights Criticism From U.N.
description: In a new report, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights criticizes Russia for abuses in its war in Chechnya and for limits imposed on the media. In Chechnya, the report found torture, summary executions, disappearances and rape. Regarding the media, it described closings and government takeovers of newspapers and television stations, and the arrests of journalists. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANVY, LESLIE P.
description: LANVY--Leslie P., beloved wife, devoted mother, cherished sister and daughter, and dearest friend, passed away on November 6, 2003. Leslie was a bright light who touched many lives in so many ways. She will be missed and remembered by all. Services in her honor will be held on Sunday, November 9th at 2:00 PM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583 to be followed by a gathering of friends. For directions call 914-723-7727. All donations may be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, NY NY 10087. Donations by phone 646 - 227 - 3546 or www.mskcc.org/giving/giftin tro.html. Please mention the gift is in memory of Leslie Lanvy.

title: Job Figures Buoy Bush, but Democratic Hopefuls See Room to Attack
description: The Democratic presidential candidates persisted in pounding President Bush about the economy on Friday, even in the face of new data showing strong growth in jobs last month that the president said was a vindication of his policies.

title: Ivy League's Prospects Have Been Improved
description: On a sunny November day in 1996, Ron Wolf took a seat in the stands at Columbia's Wien Stadium.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Evolution Prevails In Textbook Debate
description: The State Board of Education approved spending $193 million for new high school biology textbooks, ending months of debate in which religious conservatives protested that the texts did not present alternatives to evolution or adequately discuss what they described as flaws in Darwinian theory. The books' advocates, including scientists and members of the clergy, defended the texts as consistent with accepted science and argued that requesting changes would weaken the course material. Four Republican board members failed to persuade their 11 colleagues to consider the 14 books individually rather than as a group. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: One U.S. Team Is in Trouble With the Playoffs Approaching
description: Five of the six North American teams at the World Championships here seem likely to qualify for playoffs starting here on Sunday, but one is in serious jeopardy.

title: A Global Democracy Policy
description: Addressing the National Endowment for Democracy on Thursday, President Bush sought to look beyond the current bloody chaos in Iraq. Successfully implanting a democratic government in Iraq, he predicted, would energize a democratic revolution that would sweep away tyrannies from Cuba to North Korea. Specifically, Mr. Bush proclaimed a new ''forward strategy'' for advancing freedom in the Middle East, rightly declaring that 60 years of excusing and accommodating dictatorships there ''did nothing to make us safe'' because stability cannot be purchased at liberty's expense.

title: Powell Praises Informal Plan For Accord In Middle East
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has praised Israelis and Palestinians who negotiated a symbolic peace deal. His endorsement is seen as a jab at Israel's government, which has been a sharp critic of the unofficial diplomatic initiative.

title: Japan's Voters Have Actual Choice Tomorrow at the Polls
description: When Japanese voters go to the polls on Sunday to choose their next government, they will be able to choose between the governing Liberal Democratic Party and, for the first time, an almost full-fledged opposition, the Democratic Party of Japan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the election of Daniel M. Donovan Jr. as Staten Island district attorney misstated the last time a Republican was elected to the post. (The error also appeared in a front-page article that summarized election results and in an article on Oct. 31 about the race.) The last time was in 1951, when Sidney O. Simonson was elected to a single term -- not more than a century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEMB, MILDRED
description: DEMB--Mildred, on November 5, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother to Doris and Sheila. Caring mother-in-law to Jay and grandmother-in-law to Nancy. Adored grandmother to Rhonda, Lloyd, Hayes, and Tracey. And loving greatgrandmother to Daniel, Michael, and Zachary. She will be missed by all of us and always remembered for her love and devotion to our family. Services were private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, MILTON S.
description: SHAPIRO--Milton S., 81, on November 7, 2003 at his home. Devoted husband of Beatrice, loving father of Susan and Steven Levkoff and Janet and Philip Shapiro, adoring grandfather of Cameron, Josh, Brooke, Logan and Lou. Loyal brother of Dorothy Rothschild, Muriel Firestone and the late Anna Mark. Prominent attorney and distinguished philanthropic leader. Funeral service November 9th at 11:30AM at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York, NY. Contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund.

title: Talk of Labor Party rift flares again in Britain
description: LONDON:  With the battle over the leadership of Britain's Conservative Party resolved, parlor talk here has shifted back to a perennial favorite, the apparent rift between Prime Minister Tony Blair and his main rival in the Labor Party, Gordon Brown.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Antiterror Forces Reduced
description: The cabinet decided to reduce the number of antiterrorism troops to 3,100, from 3,900. The reduction reflects the withdrawal of 800 specialists in nuclear, chemical and biological warfare from Kuwait after the end of combat operations in Iraq. Parliament is expected to approve the move next week. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARLMAN, JEAN
description: PEARLMAN--Jean on November 5, 2003. Devoted wife of 47 years of the late Harold Pearlman. Beloved mother of Bernard Pearlman and Eugene (Ann) Pearlman. Adored grandmother of Rachel. Born Briansk, Russia in 1913, she and her family survived war and revolution before immigrating to America in 1922. She lived to see her children and grandchild achieve a life of security and fulfillment. Services Monday November 10, 12noon at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNAN, BEATRICE O'SHEA
description: BRENNAN--Beatrice O'Shea. Of Eastchester. Died on November 2, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Mother of Bonnie, Suzanne, Jeanne and Mary Claire. Grandmother of six. Visitation Sunday November 9 from 2-4 and 7-9 at Westchester Funeral Home, Eastchester. A Mass of Christian burial Monday, November 10 at 10:45AM at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale. Private interment is at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: John Gleason, 62, Whose Lights Colored the Stage in New Ways
description: John Gleason, a lighting designer and teacher who developed new ways to use color in theatrical productions, died on Oct. 28. He was 62 and lived in Watsontown, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOEPPEL, DR. JEROME
description: KOEPPEL--Dr. Jerome, of Lutherville, MD, and South Palm Beach, FL, on November 7, 2003. Mark Lacher deeply mourns the loss of the brother of his business partner of over 20 years, Howard Koeppel. Jerome was also a dear friend to Mark and his wife Susan for many years. The Lachers send condolences to Jerome's wife Marlene and their entire family. For funeral information, contact Sol Levinson & Brothers Funeral Home, 410-653-8900. Donations in memory of Dr. Koeppel may be sent to the Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins University, 401 N. Broadway, Suite 1100, Bethesda, MD 21231.

title: Bayer, Seeking Revitalization, Will Spin Off Chemical Units
description: The German drug and chemical giant Bayer, after more than a year of casting about for ways to revitalize itself, said on Friday that it would spin off most of its chemical business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, WILLIAM P
description: KATZ--William P, 77, Artist. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of William P. Katz, Jr, Eric Katz, Jason Katz and Barbara Jo Metcalfe. Dear brother of Arthur Katz and Phyllis Greenberg. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Sunday November 9, 2003 at 2pm at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Williams Looking to Defeat Amherst, Then Take a Walk
description: Inside St. Pierre's Barber Shop on Spring Street in Williamstown, Mass., they are preparing for one of the most unusual traditions in college sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLOGHER, JOSEPHINE O. (ST. PETER)
description: CLOGHER--Josephine O. (St. Peter). Of Levittown, N.Y., on November 4, 2003 at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late William J., loving mother of Joanne Bryan, William J., Jr. and Richard P; grandmother of Sean and Timothy Bryan and Jay Bryon. Mr. and Mrs. Clogher were long time residents of Levittown and active in local affairs. Visitation Vernon C. Wagner, 125 Old Country Road, Hicksville, NY, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass St. Bernards RC Church, Monday 11am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, N.Y. In lieu of flowers donations to ''Yom'' Community Center, 152 Center Lane, Levittown, N.Y. Attention Adult Day Care.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Blackout Aid of $5 Million Is U.S. Limit for State
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  New York State can collect only $5 million in emergency federal aid for the blackout in August, not the more than $58 million it had requested, the government told the state on Friday.

title: From Savior to Target in a Year
description: At college football's holiest cathedral home of Rockne and the Gipper -- the pressure to win is perhaps greater than it is anywhere else in the land. Tyrone Willingham knew this when he left Stanford to become the coach at Notre Dame. But only now, one and a half seasons into the job, is he truly feeling the magnitude of the expectations.

title: No Olympics For the U.S. Baseball Team
description: The most American of sports will not have United States representation in the most global of athletic competitions. The United States baseball team was knocked out of the Olympic qualifying tournament in the quarterfinals by Mexico yesterday in Panama and will not be able to defend its gold medal next summer at the Athens Games.

title: City Officials Suspend Pilot In the Crash Of S.I. Ferry
description: The city's Department of Transportation has suspended the assistant captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed into a pier last month, killing 10 people and injuring dozens.

title: The Catchall of Country: Many Roads to Heartfelt
description: When Lyle Lovett performed at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, fans heard blues, western swing, ballads, rhythm and blues, jazz and gospel. At Joe's Pub the same night, Shelby Lynne sang torch songs, soul, chugging rockers and Chicago-style blues. Yet fans who wanted to buy their albums would find them in the country section of a store.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 382 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Raiders' Fall Is Filled With Discontent
description: It was decided, late last month, that players for the Oakland Raiders needed a sit-down. So a players-only meeting was scheduled after a loss to Kansas City on Oct. 20, the team's fifth defeat in seven games. The ground rules were simple: Those who wanted to could vent about Coach Bill Callahan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the rhythm-and-blues singer R. Kelly misstated the year his album with Jay-Z, ''The Best of Both Worlds,'' was released. It was 2002, not 2000.

title: Dean's Flag Remarks Thrill and Repel in South
description: Tywon McLamore is 21 and black and has been thinking about putting a Confederate flag sticker on his bumper, to make a statement.

title: Virgin Group Seeks Base For U.S. Unit
description: The Virgin Group is in talks with several United States cities to find a base for a low-cost carrier that the company intends to start by summer or fall next year, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: 'Town' Cancels Performances
description: Producers of the Broadway revival of the musical ''Wonderful Town'' have canceled performances through the weekend because the star, Donna Murphy, has the flu.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOEPPEL, JERRY
description: KOEPPEL -- Jerry, dear brother of my partner, Howard Koeppel, you will always have a place in my heart. We shared many great times together and I will never forget your warmth, generosity, spirit and wonderful sense of humor. Mark Hsiao

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: 14 Michigan State (7-2) at 7 Ohio State (8-1)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hiring Surged Last Month; Jobless Rate Falls to 6%

title: Back Where She Belongs: Carol Channing Reminisces
description: One singular sensation

title: The Price of Forgiveness
description: When it comes to the Holocaust, the Germans just can't catch a break. With the 65th anniversary of Kristallnacht tomorrow and a memorial to the victims of Nazi genocide under construction in Berlin, the discussion in Germany has suddenly shifted from broken glass to purified gas.

title: Disability Requests Reflect Changes in SAT Procedure
description: Last year, when the College Board announced that as of this fall it would no longer flag the SAT scores of students with disabilities who took the test with extended time, educators expected a flood of requests from savvy parents eager to secure every advantage for their children.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Currency Protection
description: Foreign reserves in Singapore and Thailand are both on the rise, a development that economists say suggests that authorities in the two countries are buying United States dollars to prevent rising export revenues from pushing their own currencies higher. Singapore's foreign reserves rose to $92.46 billion in October, compared with $81.31 billion a year earlier. Thailand said its foreign reserves stood at $40.3 billion, compared with $37 billion a year ago. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Once Again: Was War Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Suzuki's Profit Doubles
description: The Suzuki Motor Corporation said its profit more than doubled in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, helped by strong sales overseas and cost-cutting measures. Suzuki earned 25 billion yen ($227 million), 19 percent above the company's forecast. Sales grew 5.2 percent. Suzuki, which is based in Shizuoka, Japan, is a leading maker of minicars, which have small engines and are popular in crowded urban areas in Asia. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A credit line in the National Briefing column yesterday for a report about unauthorized travel spending by the Defense Department misspelled the surname of the writer. He is Renwick McLean, not McClean.

title: The Greater Threat To Russia's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Copter Crashes Reflect a Growing Threat
description: The crash of an Army helicopter in Iraq on Friday, coupled with two others that were struck by ground fire in the last two weeks, reflects a growing threat by insurgents taking aim at American aircraft, military officials said. Twenty-two Americans died in the three incidents.

title: Lindros Expected to Play
description: Rangers center Eric Lindros, who has missed the last seven games with a left chest sprain, is expected to play against his former team, the Philadelphia Flyers, at Madison Square Garden this afternoon, Coach Glen Sather said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RYMER, HARRY
description: RYMER--Harry. 11/08/02. We miss your caring and compassion. In our hearts forever. Jane Martin & Susan Fleisher And familie

title: Brokers Say Prudential Approved Trading
description: Before he resigned last month, Martin J. Druffner was considered a star stockbroker at the Boston office of what had once been called Prudential Securities.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Falls
description: The unemployment rate in Canada declined to 7.6 percent in October from 8 percent in September, Statistics Canada reported, confirming recent signs of economic recovery. A total of 65,000 jobs, mostly in the service sector, were created in October, the strongest gain in 19 months and well above most analysts' forecasts. The report helped push the Canadian dollar higher as prospects of further interest rate cuts by the Bank of Canada receded Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Quietly, Barber's Receptions Add Up
description: From a defensive standpoint, Giants running back Tiki Barber probably looks like the best player to allow to catch a pass. Receiver Amani Toomer averages 20 yards a reception. Receiver Ike Hilliard can split a defense with a shifty move. Tight end Jeremy Shockey can turn a secondary into bowling pins.

title: BLACK & DECKER SAYS IT MAY OWE I.R.S. $140 MILLION
description: The Black & Decker Corporation, the power tool maker, may have to pay $140 million after the Internal Revenue Service disallowed some deductions the company had taken. The I.R.S. notified the company of its ruling last week after an audit of its tax returns from 1998 through 2000, Black & Decker said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Black & Decker, which is based in Towson, Md., and makes Dustbuster vacuum cleaners and SnakeLight flashlights, said it would dispute the ruling. There are adequate reserves to pay the additional taxes and related interest if the I.R.S. decision stands, the company said, adding that any payment probably would not occur until at least 2005.

title: Cosmetics Retailer Is Accused of Discrimination
description: Even on their breaks and during lunch, the women say, they were told not to speak Spanish, their first language. Their supervisors mimicked their accents and derided their culture, they say, and if they complained about it, they suffered even more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACHRACH, BARBARA R.
description: BACHRACH--Barbara R. Beloved wife of Donald. Dear sister of Tomas Weber. Services Sunday, 10am, ''Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschenbaum Chapel'', 1153 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn.

title: Congressional Memo; As the Session Winds Down, Sniping Rises on Capitol Hill
description: Congress is winding down, which is causing the partisanship to be ratcheted up.

title: 9/11 Panel Issues Subpoena to Pentagon
description: The federal commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks stepped up pressure on the Bush administration to cooperate by issuing a subpoena on Friday to the Pentagon.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Expects Loss
description: McDonald's Holdings Japan said it would lose money this year instead of turning a small profit as sales deteriorate and workers voluntarily retire. The company, Japan's largest fast-food chain, expects to lose 3.7 billion yen ($34 million) in the year ending Dec. 31, the second consecutive loss. The company previously expected a 2 billion yen profit. Same-store sales fell 7.2 percent in the July-September quarter, leading McDonald's to trim its full-year sales forecast 1.7 percent. The company expects to have 118 fewer stores in Japan by the end of the year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Warming Emotional Winter With Passion and Yearning
description: The casts were mostly new, but the dances fine and familiar at American Ballet Theater's performance on Wednesday night at City Center.

title: The City Life; Can You Walk and Chew Pizza?
description: New Yorkers can find multitasking potential in any activity. I catch up with my grandmother on my cellphone while picking up my dry cleaning, write a check to the gas company while standing in line at the grocery store. And I often inhale my meals while sprinting from errand to errand.

title: Dean and the Rebel Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lottery Numbers
Night of Desperation and Elation for Knicks
description: Allan Houston felt the desperation tingling all the way to his fingertips, almost as if it were a playoff game and not the fifth game of a confounding Knicks season.

title: 'A Floating Metaphor'
description: Landon Nordeman developed an intense feeling for the Staten Island ferry and its people when he photographed it last year.

title: A Funny Thing . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACKBOARD: Noticed; What's Not In This Picture?
description: Not long ago, college students absolutely had to have five things to brighten dorm life: a telephone, television, mini-fridge, computer and really cool stereo or boom box. No more. Oh, music is as important as ever, but thanks to digital music and file sharing, most students are leaving their stereos at home, if they even own one. ''I listen to all my music on my desktop,'' says Teresa Veramendi, a freshman at New York University who has 1,100 MP3 files on her computer. ''The convenience of my music taking up no space in my tiny dorm room is priceless. I don't need a CD tower, and I have all the music I want.''

title: A Composer Gives Video Games a Musical Life
description: ANDY BRICK is used to the double-take, the incredulous look, the questions. Symphonic video game music? That's an oxymoron, right? No one seriously composes music for video games, do they? In fact, some people do, and Mr. Brick, an award-winning composer with impeccable musical credentials, is on the cusp of a surprising trend.

title: North Korea's Bomb: Untested but Ready, C.I.A. Concludes
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has told Congress that it now believes that North Korea has mastered the technology of turning its nuclear fuel into functioning weapons, without having to prove their effectiveness through nuclear tests.

title: Brodeur and Devils Keep Senators Silent
description: Displaying the patience that seems to come naturally to hockey's most gifted players, Marian Hossa, the Ottawa Senators' All-Star forward, kept the puck on his stick as he glided across the front of the crease minutes into Saturday's game against the Devils.

title: Starting Early Toward Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: The New New Historians
description: RIGHT TO EXIST

title: BLACKBOARD: Anniversaries; Past Times At Hollywood High
description: One began as a school for California farm children, turned into a launching pad for stars like Lana Turner and Mickey Rooney and now operates year-round to accommodate 2,700 students representing 20 languages. The other, created for stage children in New York, counts Milton Berle and Elliott Gould among its early graduates and still considers an audition a legitimate excuse to cut class.

title: A Fashion Genie Finds Her Lamp
description: IF the stork is the obstetrician of legend for run-of-the-mill babies, what on earth delivers fashionistas?

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: I recently read Betty Friedan's ''Feminine Mystique,'' and I found her description of the symptoms of hopelessness and depression suffered by desperate housewives strikingly familiar. I myself had felt all of those things, but as an associate in a law firm, where every day I sat at my desk and billed my time on tasks to enrich the partners while someone else cared for my new baby. The choice was clear: I left four years ago and have never looked back.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Which Is Proved
description: File this homework memory in the ages-and-ages-ago, and geeky-beyond-words categories.

title: Hunting and Exploring in the Snow in Maine
description: Three otters were cavorting out front of our camp on Salmon Stream Lake in Maine when we arrived by canoe for a week's stay in mid-October. One climbed up on a boulder to dine on a big pickerel it had just caught, and in less than a minute the others followed suit, one with a smaller pickerel, the other with what appeared to be a smallmouth bass.

title: She's Taken to Her Bed, But No One's Sure Why
description: FRAN'S bed was once a source of comfort to her, or maybe an escape, given her perpetual melancholia. But Fran's family knew nothing of her gnawing depression. Hank, her husband of 35 years, was oblivious to her frustrations about their stultified existence in a stultifying Michigan suburb. The last place on earth where Fran would want to move is a condo in Florida. So Hank buys a condo in Florida.

title: The World; In Russia, Apathy Dims Democracy...
description: NOT long before masked agents arrested him on a cold Siberian runway, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky sat glumly at a conference table in his gleaming corporate headquarters in Moscow and said Russia stood at a crossroads.

title: London Food Critics Have Knives Out for the Chefs
description: FOR one of the most feared men in London these days, the writer A. A. Gill looks incongruously relaxed. Perched at the dining table of his Fulham apartment -- easily found thanks to a Mountain Dew-colored Bentley parked out front -- Mr. Gill, who looks a decade younger than his 50 years, is answering the charge that he is, hands down, London's most vicious restaurant critic.

title: Ephs Win One for Their Coach
description: WILLIAMS 14, AMHERST 10

title: What the Camera Sees in Her
description: Cate Blanchett is not, at first glance, conventionally beautiful; indeed, her strong face can, from certain angles, seem almost plain. Her cheekbones look less enviably sculptured than they do on-screen, and her gorgeously ripe mouth shows up less than it does when it is slashed with crimson, as it is in ''The Talented Mr. Ripley'' and ''Charlotte Gray.'' Her ears (as she points out, lest I fail to notice) are big, and she wears her hair scraped back in a non-do. She is not, in fact, immediately recognizable until you get up close and see those extraordinary wraparound eyes, long, narrow and a searching pale blue. Show-stopping eyes that register emotions with a clarity that conveys some Platonic essence of whatever the emotion in question is. So, I think, this is what it means to be photogenic -- to have the kind of face that veils its magic until it meets up with the camera.

title: Human-Rights Complaint Filed Against Hirsch Corp.
description: A state human-rights complaint has been filed against the Hirsch International Corporation of Hauppauge on behalf of 32 women, current and former Hirsch employees who say that a former manager hid a video camera in a restroom ceiling.

title: In the Clubs, Choreography's First Steps
description: NELL'S, the nightclub on West 14th Street in Manhattan, was hopping one recent evening. Los Soneros de Oriente, an 11-piece New York-based Cuban band, was playing salsa from the 30's and 40's. Dressed in a bright blue shirt and dark pants, Alexandre Magno stood watching the dance floor, swaying to the music. He was there both to enjoy himself and to pick up ideas for his day job: choreographer.

title: BUZZWORDS
description: Have you achieved ''masstige''? You have if you buy prestige brands priced for mass appeal. The term appears to be reaching linguistic critical mass (if not masstige).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SIMMONS, HELEN E.
description: SIMMONS--Helen E. Loved and remembered always. Deirdre, Maud and Charles

title: 'Rain': Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker's Liquid Dance
description: IN Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker's ''Rain,'' 10 dancers walk, run and tumble for 70 minutes with hardly a break. Moments after they converge in a cluster -- looking a bit like a school of fish dressed in billowing haute couture -- they part like a ripple in a lake. In this mercurial 2001 dance, which will be presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday through Saturday, Ms. De Keersmaeker, whose company, Rosas, is based in Brussels, takes inspiration from Kirsty Gunn's haunting novel (also called ''Rain''). In the book, a young child drowns. But it would be out of character for Ms. De Keersmaeker, a revered experimenter, to retell that tale.

title: Streetscapes/83rd Street and West End Avenue; For McKim, Mead & White, Even Minor Was Major
description: THE firm established by Charles McKim, William Mead and Stanford White in 1879 has an enduring reputation for majestic buildings. But it also designed much more modest works, whether to render services to friends or clients or just to pay the rent.

title: Dysfunctional? Yes. But Helpless? Yes
description: LIZA MINNELLI is sweating, and it has nothing to do with lawsuits or divorce. She's rehearsing on the set of Fox's ''Arrested Development.'' She fans herself with a script. When the actors break, she smokes a Marlboro Light 100 down to its filter.

title: INSIDE
description: SPECIAL TODAY

title: Peering Beyond the Gridlock
description: WHEN the owners of the sprawling Garden State Plaza describe their plans for a 16-screen movie theater complex and new restaurants there, they visualize in their best public relations jargon -- a ''lifestyle entertainment precinct.''

title: 'Family Business': A Town, a Father and a Fire
description: WHEN the photographer Mitch Epstein returned to his hometown, Holyoke, Mass., a few years ago, he intended to make an extended portrait of his 82-year-old father, a businessman who ran the family furniture store and rental real estate enterprise. What he ended up documenting in his new book, ''Family Business'' (Steidl), was the demise of a particular version of the American dream.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last week with the continuation of an article about the opera ''La Juive'' misidentified the actor shown in it at the Vienna State Opera. It was Neil Shicoff as lazar, not Alastair Miles as Cardinal Brogni.

title: Becoming a Thoughtful Woman's Idea of a Leading Man Part 2
description: Jude Law is in his pajama bottoms, or rather, Alfie's pajama bottoms. They're striped blue and white, and riding low on his hips. Law is at Pinewood Studios, an hour from his North London home, filming Paramount's as-yet-untitled remake of ''Alfie,'' the classic 1966 Michael Caine movie about a ladies' man who gets his comeuppance. He's working on a scene in which Alfie stands shaving at his bathroom mirror. Shirtless, Law looks directly into the camera and says, ''Go on -- turn around!'' The camera does not oblige (who would, really?). Law drops his chin slightly to give the camera an I-dare-you stare, then with a defiant twist of his head he turns his back, sheds the pajama bottoms and steps into the shower.

title: Al Qaeda Blamed in Deadly Attack on Saudi Homes
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 9 - The attack against a residential compound that killed 17 people and wounded 122 others started with two to three gunmen standing high atop the khaki desert cliffs facing the gated complex and raining gunfire on the guards, Saudi officials and western diplomats said on Sunday.

title: Warning on Charity Fraud
description: As state and federal officials survey the damage from the wildfires in California, the Federal Trade Commission is warning consumers to be wary of potential charity fraud. ''Scam artists may take advantage of this situation by creating bogus fund-raising operations,'' the commission said in a recent consumer alert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EAGLE, GOLDA
description: EAGLE--Golda. Beloved wife of the late Maurice, devoted mother of Harriette and Robert, adored grandmother of Abby and Alan and greatgrandmother of Megan, Nicole, and Noah. Services Monday, 11/10, 12pm, Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

title: A Ball Like Grandmother's, With Skimpier Clothes
description: AS guests arrived for a Halloween party at Bacchus House, the Greenwich Village mansion of Enrico Marone Cinzano, they were greeted by young women clad in wisps of lingerie, who led them up a spiral staircase to the drawing room.

title: Time Out
description: IT'S an early, overcast weekend morning. The house is quiet. Our block is quiet. It's still dark outside, and perhaps there are hours of sleep left before anyone gets up. As I'm about to shut my eyes again, I try to guess what the weather is like behind the blinds. But the silence -- no patter of rain, no splash of car tires along the streets -- already tells me what I don't want to know. It's not raining outside. At best, just drizzling.

title: The Best and Worst DVD's of Classic Films
description: There are many great films that have been made into great-looking DVD's. Here (in alphabetical order) are 10 of the worthiest:

title: Yankee Stadium's Best Seats Are Also the Hottest Ones
description: The most attractive seats at Yankee Stadium are the two spots on the blue dugout bench beside Manager Joe Torre. Those premium seats have been occupied by Don Zimmer, the bench coach, and Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach, for the last eight seasons. Torre relied on Zimmer and Stottlemyre more than anyone else on the staff.

title: Power to the Principals
description: Making Schools Work:

title: One Hundred Years Of Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Release of Berkeley Professor Is Delayed by Irans Judiciary
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 9  Iran has been holding an Iranian-American political science professor from the University of California at Berkeley for four months on espionage charges, and the hard-line judiciary has refused to release him even though the Foreign Ministry said a week ago that he was about to be freed.

title: Commercial Property; Owners and Brokers Seek Brand-Name Recognition
description: LANDLORDS and brokerage companies are increasingly using tools that range from advertising and graphics to staff uniforms to establish themselves as brands. This effort, they hope, would distinguish their offerings in the large crowd of property owners and brokers competing for clients and tenants.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Sleep on It
description: The best homework assignment that I can recollect came from one teacher that I had during junior year. He said ''Go home and sleep.'' While I can't specifically recall which teacher ''assigned'' this, it was definitely a well deserved break from the workload that he had placed on us in recent days in class.

title: Women in Politics: An All-Points Bulletin
description: To the Editor:

title: C. Z. Guest, Society Royalty, Dies at 83
description: C. Z. Guest, one of the monarchs of New York society who was a perennial selection on the best-dressed list, a noted horsewoman and an authority on gardening, died yesterday at home in Old Westbury, N.Y. She was 83.

title: A Third Party Makes Its First Mark
description: Until last year, the Working Families Party seemed invisible in New York City politics -- so much so that its own members carried around a giant cardboard cutout of an H to call attention to the party's line on the ballot, the very last column.

title: Sport Fishermen Are Not Destroying Stocks
description: In ''Fishing and Bickering Over Striped Bass'' [Nov. 2], Arnold Leo, a spokesman for the commercial fishing industry, creates the illusion that sport fisherman are contributing to the destruction of the striped bass fishery. Mr. Leo has been espousing similar positions for years and, to those unaware of the facts, his musings may sound plausible. Unfortunately, the facts don't square with Mr. Leo's propaganda. It is undisputable that the commercial fishing industry, which ''takes'' but seldom if ever ''puts back,'' is directly responsible for:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIEDE, BROTHER RANDAL
description: RIEDE -- Brother Randal, C.F.X. On November 7, 2003. Dear brother of Sr. Marita and the late Fr. Clifford and Keller. Fond brother-in-law of Jean Riede and several nieces and nephews. Visiting Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Andrews Church.

title: Paperback Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: New York City Has Ally In Latest Tourism Push
description: THIS fall, New York City tourism officials inaugurated their newest goodwill ambassador: a cartoon bunny named Miffy who stars in a series of children's books, including the latest, ''Miffy Loves New York City!'' in which she extols the wonders of the five boroughs (pretzels, the Plaza, Ellis Island and the Empire State Building, to name a few).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about the writer and critic Dale Peck referred imprecisely to his new book, ''What We Lost.'' It is a memoir with some fictional accounts, not a novel. The article also misstates the setting of part of the book. The main character grows up in New York State, not Kansas.

title: Girl, 14, Raped in Harlem
description: A 14-year-old girl was raped in a West Harlem apartment lobby on Friday evening by a man who grabbed her three blocks away and walked her to the building, the police said.

title: The Bridge-and-Tunnel Crowd Finds a Home in New York
description: IT is somewhat unusual these days for a serious play to move from a non-commercial regional theater to Broadway, where most producers are unwilling to take a risk on productions other than splashy musicals or shows that originated in London.

title: Synergy Is a Gym Next Door To a Bake Shop
description: The chalkboard in front of the Sugar and Spice Bake Shop on City Island beckons, polite but persistent. ''Homemade Soup,'' it read the other day. ''Mmm mmm mmm.''

title: A Former Rulers Candidacy Revives Fears in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 8 — Sunday is Election Day, and a once reviled and now revived old dictator stands a chance of regaining power.

title: Lucky Break for Soldiers Heading Home From Iraq Turns to Heartbreak for Families
description: For the six months that Specialist Brian H. Penisten of the Army was gone, he tried to convince his fiance that he was relatively protected, repairing military vehicles on a tightly secured air base in Iraq, far enough away from the bullets and bombs.

title: Music Man
description: Michael Eidman might be Englewood's musical Clark Kent -- he segues from a personal injury lawyer by day to music promoter by night. A resident of the city for 10 years, he has been booking music there since 1996. His business venture, Pipe Dream Productions, tries to hire nationally known performers for small local sites while spending almost no money on promotion. His secret? E-mail.

title: A New Credit for 'Just Shoot Me' Star
description: Laura SAN GIACOMO wasn't acting when she swelled with pride the day her 7-year-old son got in trouble for talking in class. Her son, Mason, who has cerebral palsy and communicates through a computer, earned a public reprimand from his teacher for speaking out of turn.

title: Stowe
description: Stowe, Vt., is a resort town with a soul. Nearly every business is locally owned; there is not a chain-affiliated store, restaurant or motel to be found. For the visitor, this tends to lead to frequent encounters with informed, earnest townspeople who have a stake in their community. And the hospitality feels genuine.

title: Ideas & Trends: Atomic Scales; Striking Notes of Progress on the World's Tiniest Guitar
description: IT was weird enough when NASA's Chandra X-Ray Observatory recently came across a black hole, 250 million light years away, humming a bass note 57 octaves below middle C. Now scientists have found an accompanist to hold up the treble end.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Sunday rendered a quotation from President Bush incorrectly. As the article reported, the president said, ''I'll say that the world is more peaceful and more free under my leadership, and America is more secure'' (not ''more free and more peaceful'').

title: Virginia Tech Falls Prey to Top-10 Mayhem
description: Pittsburgh wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald had been quiet Saturday night, at least by his standards. He had five catches before the Panthers' final drive, and he spent more of his time as a decoy than as a weapon.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11.9.03: On Language; Slog
description: 'It is pretty clear that the coalition can win in Afghanistan and Iraq in one way or another,'' wrote Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld toward the end of a memo to a quartet of his top aides, ''but it will be a long, hard slog.''

title: Page Two: Nov. 2-8; IN BRIEF
description: * Gary L. Ridgway pleaded guilty to strangling 48 women in the Seattle area during the 1980's Green River killing spree. The deadliest convicted serial killer in the nation's history, Mr. Ridgway, a 54-year-old truck painter from a Seattle suburb, confessed to killing the women in a plea agreement that spared him the death penalty.

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; A Rap for Drums
description: I got this homework from my music teacher for hand drums. She told us to make up a rap about ourselves and this was mine:

title: New Direction for an Italian Job
description: At a time when luxury brands are leveraging their reputations to ever higher price levels -- as evidence, look no further than Mercedes-Benz adding the Maybach line of ultraluxury sedans starting at more than $300,000 -- the arrival of the new Gallardo from Lamborghini might be seen as a contrarian move by this small-scale but legendary maker of exotic sports cars.

title: Cemetery of the Front Page
description: THE writer Nicholson Baker was so shocked when he first saw the Historic Newspaper Archives here in 1999 that he came away calling it a ''ghastly anti-library.'' What he saw was a jumbled and tattered repository filled with thousands of complete runs of newspapers that were being methodically dismembered and their individual copies sold off as birthday and wedding gifts.

title: Nancy Yaffa, Pieter le Roux
description: Nancy E. Yaffa and Dr. Pieter Johannes le Roux were married on Friday by Heide Evans, a superintendent registrar, at Fulham Town Hall in London. Yesterday, Rabbi Douglas Krantz conducted a religious ceremony at Claridge's in London.

title: Boots, Poles And Cellphone
description: WHEN I was learning how to ski, the primary force propelling me down the slopes was the fear of being separated from my older brother.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An article on Oct. 12 about the Breeders' Cup, a steeplechase race held annually at Moorland Farms in Far Hills, described the social scene at the event.

title: Quiz Answers
description: Questions are on Page 41.

title: For Many College Students, a Job (or Two) to Pay Tuition
description: BRANDON COX, a senior at the University of Kansas, has struggled to make ends meet throughout his college years. In particularly hard times, he has considered selling his blood to earn extra cash.

title: FEATURED MATCHUP
description: TIKI BARBER -- Giants running back vs. KEITH BROOKING -- Falcons linebacker

title: H. L. Woodring Dies at 77; Was Driver in Patton Crash
description: Horace L. Woodring, an Army private who was chauffeuring the Cadillac limousine of Gen. George S. Patton through the German countryside when it crashed and caused the injuries that resulted in Patton's death, died last Sunday at a Detroit hospital. He was 77 and lived in White Lake, Mich.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Katrina Roche, 40

title: Where Does It Go?
description: THE flight paths of college costs and state budgets are diverging to the point that C. D. Mote Jr., president of the University of Maryland at College Park, says he doesn't know how much longer the ship can hold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, KATHLEEN O'NEIL
description: BAKER -- Kathleen O'Neil. Passed away peacefully November 7, in Halifax, Nova Scotia. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Sylvester S. Baker. She is grieved by her daughter Nancy Baker Weeren, son-in-law Donald, and family. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Smith College, she had a distinguished career in the New York City public school system as an inspiring teacher and later administrator at Julia Richman High School. She will be deeply missed by all who were touched by her caring, courage and joie de vivre.

title: These Bowery Boys Are Taking On Mayor Bloomberg and City Hall
description: As political statements go, the sign posted on the door of Paragon Restaurant World, a restaurant supply store on the Bowery, near Prince Street, isn't subtle. Written on sturdy paper, in scribbled ink, it declares: ''Impeach Mayor Bloomberg.''

title: BLACKBOARD: Oral History; Stories of the Things That Mattered, to You
description: Three white-haired ladies squinted at a wall of old school photos in an exhibition called ''Telling Lives'' at the New-York Historical Society. They watched a video of just-folks recounting school memories. Their faces lighted up as their own recollections were sparked, and they decided to enter the exhibition's inner sanctum, to sit before a camera, follow computer prompts and tell their own 10-minute stories.

title: Giants Are Seeing Quick Results From Some Lower-Round Draft Picks
description: When Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora sprinted out of a crowd and ran down Jets running back LaMont Jordan from behind in overtime Sunday, he did more than stop a play for no gain and show the burst of speed that once persuaded the Giants to draft him out of Troy State.

title: Barriers Built For Protection Have Become A Top Target
description: For the 77 Construction Company here, the guerrilla war against allied forces occupying Iraq has provided an unexpected business bonanza worth several hundred thousand dollars.

title: U.S. Troops Raid Tikrit in Hunt for Guerrillas
description: American forces used tanks, howitzers and fighter planes in an overnight raid on a volatile area around Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein, the Fourth Infantry Division said Saturday.

title: States Planning Own Lawsuits Over Pollution
description: The attorneys general of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say they are ready to open a new round of litigation to force power plants to make billions of dollars of pollution-control improvements after a decision by the Bush administration to abandon more than 50 investigations into possible violations of the Clean Air Act.

title: Beethoven Hall As a Wedding Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Meet Madeleine Albright

title: Intimate Escapes
description: THOSE of us who are romantic types cling to the fantasy that there are still lovely spots, as yet undiscovered and not too far from home, where we can escape for a quiet weekend in the country. Like M.F.K. Fisher, we'll eat simple but delicious food in sweet local restaurants within walking distance of our charming, inexpensive hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTH, ROBERT
description: ROTH--Robert. On November 7, after a courageous battle with cancer. Died with his beloved wife Jane of 46 years by his side. Loving father of Jaye and Andrew Roth and Jonathan Roth. Loving brother-in-law of Marion Somerstein and Marika and Stuart Somerstein. Devoted nephew of Harriet Wolf of Los Angeles, CA. Adored uncle of Ivy Somerstein, Barbara and Bill Fine, Joel Somerstein, Lisa Friedman and Steven Friedman. Bobby, we will miss you more than can be imagined and we will always have a great dinner, a glass of Super Tuscan, and a Cuban waiting for you. We will love you forever. Funeral services will be private.

title: VIRGIN MARY IN A TREE STUMP
description: For several weeks, thousands of people have been making pilgrimages to a tree stump in a vacant lot in Passaic that they believe has taken the form of the Virgin Mary. Some attribute supernatural powers to the stump, including healing chest pain and stopping arguments between couples. The image on the three-foot-high stump was apparently created accidentally in August when teenage workers were clearing trees near Route 21. A spokeswoman for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson said that the church would investigate the matter to determine whether the hand of God had a role in creating the stump. ''I thought it looked like a parrot, myself,'' said the spokeswoman, Marianna Thompson. Nonetheless, she said the diocese would not discourage people from visiting the stump. ''There's no harm worshipping the mother of God,'' she said. Jonathan Miller

title: BOOX
Meredith Love, Joel Kent
description: Meredith Stacy Love, the daughter of Carol and Michael Love of Grand Rapids, Mich., was married last evening to Joel Stephen Kent, a son of Ellen Kent and Dr. Donald Kent of Tarpon Springs, Fla. Rabbi Steven M. Graber performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, N.Y.

title: Impressive Homestand Is Suddenly Less So
description: Sure, it was an impressive homestand. But the Islanders could only dwell on the one that got away Saturday night -- and how quickly it did.

title: A Tower Returns, to the Neighbors' Dismay
description: Besides keeping strange hours, meatpackers and nightclub impresarios had little in common until a 32-story tower was proposed for 848 Washington Street, in the heart of the meatpacking district. The apartment tower and its well-heeled tenants, they argued, would ruin the neighborhood's witching hours.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: YOUTH, by J. M. Coetzee. (Penguin, $14.) This follow-up to the Nobel Prize-winning author's first memoir, ''Boyhood,'' picks up at the age of 19 and tells of Coetzee's desperate desire to become a writer. Early on, he leaves South Africa for London, where he displays the psychic wounds of a young colonial while writing poetry, punishing himself for his failures and stumbling about in search of his true love. '' 'Youth' covers that period of a man's life when he's most repulsive both to himself and others,'' William Deresiewicz wrote here in 2002. ''The story is not new, but Coetzee tells it with brutal honesty.''

title: The Ungroomed Vail
description: THE backcountry gate at Vail's westernmost boundary is a bit like the entrance to Alice's rabbit hole. Passing through it on a blustery January afternoon, I was suddenly transported from the Colorado ber-resort's manicured ski boulevards into a topsy-turvy wonderland: a backwoods bowl filled with snow so deep that the surrounding stands of aspen and lodgepole pine trees seemed dwarfed -- their trunks buried six feet under thick white curds. Piled high with powder, rocks and tree stumps morphed into puffy white mushrooms. Tangles of spiky underbrush lurked like serpents beneath the surface, nipping at skis and sending unsuspecting revelers flying into what amounts to frozen quicksand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORREST, RICHARD E.
description: FORREST--Richard E. October 25. Devoted husband of Judy. Father of Kathleen Forrest Shun and husband Adam, and Susan Forrest-Reynolds. Beloved grandfather of Nicholas and Lucia. Citizen of New York City. At his request a remembrance of Richard will be held at his home on December 7, from 4 to 7 PM. Donations in Richard's name may be made to the Hudson River Foundation or Scenic Hudson. ''Phlebas the Phoenician, a fortnight dead...''

title: The Humiliation Factor
description: If President Bush wants to get a better handle on the problems he's facing in Iraq and the West Bank, I suggest he study the speech made Oct. 16 by Malaysia's departing prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, to a conclave of Muslim leaders. Most of that speech was a brutally frank look into the causes of the Muslim world's decline. Though it was also laced with shameful anti-Jewish slurs, it was still revealing. Five times he referred to Muslims as humiliated. If I've learned one thing covering world affairs, it's this: The single most underappreciated force in international relations is humiliation.

title: Solar Energy's Relative Cost
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
