description: My Precious

title: Living in Translation
description: COMMUNICATING has always been really important to me. I first realized this when I was growing up next to a French family and found it frustrating not to be able to really talk to them. I learned French, and then Russian, in high school, then Italian and Chinese in college. I learned German later.

title: Quandary for U.S. in the Olympics
description: Does the United States need major league stars to reclaim the Olympic gold medal in baseball?

title: Nine Immigrants Arrested in Raid File Lawsuit Against Wal-Mart
description: Nine Mexican immigrants who worked as janitors at Wal-Marts in New Jersey sued the company on Wednesday, accusing Wal-Mart and its cleaning contractors of failing to pay overtime, withhold taxes and make required workers' compensation contributions.

title: The Week Ahead; IN COURT
description: Lee B. Malvo, the 18-year-old accused of participating in the sniper shootings that terrorized the Washington area last fall, will go on trial in Chesapeake, Va. Like John A. Muhammad, the 42-year-old accused of masterminding the shootings, Mr. Malvo has been charged with two counts of capital murder. Mr. Malvo's lawyers say he will argue he is not guilty by reason of insanity. The prosecution is expected to build its case on statements Mr. Malvo made to officials in which he allegedly took responsibility for several of the 10 killings. James Dao

title: Digital Art's Year-Round Summer Camp
description: WALK into the Eyebeam gallery any given day and you might think nothing much is going on. The raw brick space, a former parking garage on West 21st Street, is cavernous without the Chelsea chic, more workplace than showplace. The folding table by the door is manned by a few well-dressed graduate students with laptops and cellphones. The atmosphere is low-key almost to the vanishing point.

title: Chicks and the City
description: BITTER WITH BAGGAGE SEEKS SAME

title: Letters
description: You Can't Always Get What You Want

title: Pennington Finds a Lesson in Adversity
description: Amid all the confusion and chaos, Chad Pennington failed to realize that it was 10-10 at halftime. In the Jets' 30-10 playoff loss to the Raiders last January, Pennington was pulled under by relentless Raiders pressure and soaring emotions, a lethal combination that had shaken the preternaturally poised quarterback for the first time in his career.

title: A New Pear Tree Will Pay Homage to Old New York
description: A famous pear tree planted in the mid-1600's by Peter Stuyvesant, the Dutch governor of New Amsterdam, at what is now the northeast corner of Third Avenue and 13th Street, died a very New York death.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: I read Belkin's article with great interest, as I am a working physician with children. My sense is that she is writing about a very narrow group of women who have pursued law or business careers. In my experience, most women who have entered other fields, like medicine, education, academia, the arts, science, etc., have not given up working. They seem to have more genuine passion for what they do and have found ways to combine raising a family with continuing to work.

title: Technology; It's a Multi-Multimedia World
description: Students enrolled in Near Eastern and Mediterranean archaeology at the University of Southern California get the kind of assignment that resonates with collegians throughout the land -- turn in a well-argued report based on semester-long research on a subject of their choosing. But here's the rub: no neat, single-spaced pages, painstakingly typed and annotated. These students must present their results in an entirely different way, one that has more in common with video games, films and Web sites.

title: On Automatic
description: W. B. YEATS

title: F.Y.I.
description: Plaque for a Lost Giant

title: Blaming the Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Playlist column last Sunday misstated the name of the new album by Clay Aiken. It is ''Measure of a Man,'' not ''Made to Measure.''

title: Feeble Jones Regains Light-Heavyweight Title
description: The smaller they are, the more trouble they have winning, according to the ordeals of Roy Jones Jr.

title: Pictures on the Wall, Imprinted on the Heart
description: THIS weekend, a special exhibition, ''Heart Gallery,'' opens at Real Art Ways in Hartford. The show consists of portraits of 40 children in state care, taken by three dozen Connecticut photographers. The project captures the playful spirits of the children and is designed to help them find permanent, loving families. It is the kind of show that will break your heart.

title: Four American Teams Advance In World Bridge Championships
description: All four American teams survived at the World Bridge Championships here on Saturday, but one of them needed a remarkable stretch drive. Going into the final qualifying match, with eight teams due to advance in the Bermuda Bowl, the United States No. 2 team, led by the veteran star Bobby Wolff, was in ninth position. Canada was in eighth, 13 victory points clear. But the Americans scored steadily against New Zealand and snatched the eighth position when the Canadians lost to Poland.

title: Running on Trips; Disabled on Planes
description: Running on Trips

title: Maggie Haberman, Dareh Gregorian
description: Maggie Lindsy Haberman, the daughter of Nancy Haberman and Clyde Haberman, both of Manhattan, is to be married today to Dareh Ardashes Gregorian, a son of Clare and Vartan Gregorian, also of Manhattan. Judge Edward R. Korman, the chief judge of the United States District Court in Brooklyn, is to officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan.

title: Business; Finally, a Few Buyers Are Returning to Antiques
description: WHEN Frank Partridge packed up his fine 18th-century Georgian chests, Regency tables and Adam mirrors from a fair a few weeks ago at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, he was happier than he had been in a long time.

title: Page Two: Nov. 2-8; The Return Of Greenspan's Prophetic Touch
description: HAS Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, reacquired the oracle's touch?

title: Our Dog
description: AROUND the corner, Chelsea barks all day long. Her owners don't hear her because they work late; then they come home and walk her briskly before bed. Down the block, Leslie's children pine for a puppy to play with, but she hesitates. ''Who would walk the dog at night, when the kids are in bed?'' she asks.

title: FEDERAL HEARING HELD
description: In Washington, New Jersey's embattled child welfare agency faced new scrutiny last week as the Human Resources Subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee held hearings on the case of four Collingswood boys who the authorities said were starved by their adoptive parents. Some child welfare advocacy groups questioned whether lawmakers might consider ending programs like adoption subsidies. The parents in the Collingswood case, Raymond and Vanessa Jackson, were released last weekend on $100,000 bail each. And a protest rally was held in Trenton by members of a union representing nine child welfare workers who were fired after the case came to light.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Ahead of the Pack

title: Q and A
description: Finding London Apartments

title: Reelin' and Rockin'
description: NEVER MIND THE POLLACKS

title: Nonstop Flights to Link U.S. and Singapore
description: Singapore Airlines plans to begin nonstop service between New York and Singapore, roughly 18 hours and 10,000 miles apart, by next August. The flights will be made possible by new long-range Airbus A340-500's, which Singapore Airlines will outfit in a less-crowded fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GESUALDI, MARY
description: GESUALDI--Mary, in her 102nd year, of Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, on November 5th, 2003. A scholarship recipient, Mary graduated from New Rochelle College as an accomplished French teacher in the NYC Board of Education. She was fondly admired by colleagues and students at New Utrecht H.S., 1923-1964. An honorary member of Arista, Mary was a language tutor and patron of the arts.

title: Jennifer Raynovich, Mark Patricio
description: Jennifer Leigh Raynovich, the daughter of Lynda and Rod Raynovich of Weston, Mass., was married last evening to Patrick Mark Patricio, a son of Barbara Patricio and Dr. Gracito Patricio of Lutherville, Md. The Rev. David Van Dusen, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Runners' World
description: The camaraderie of more than 12,000 international runners was on display as they sang national songs during a run from the United Nations through Midtown into Central Park, to an annual breakfast near the Tavern on the Green. Many wore costumes or carried their country's flag. The run, on Saturday, was part of the festivities that culminated in Sunday's marathon, where some of the same runners wore their costumes for the 26.2-mile race.

title: Patron Saint of Inconsistency
description: INSIDE GEORGE ORWELL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERSTEIN, MARGARET ''PEG'' KIRRANE
description: SILBERSTEIN -- Margaret ''Peg'' Kirrane. Died Thursday, November 6, 2003 following a courageous battle with leukemia. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she had been a resident of East Haddam since 1961 and was married for 48 years to the late David Silberstein. She is survived by her brother the Reverend James A. Kirrane of New York; son David Silberstein and daughterin-law Mollye MacLeod and grandchildren David, Marget, and William of Marlborough, MA; daughter Deirdre E. Silberstein of Stamford; and son Donald J. Silberstein and daughter-in-law Mary-Margaret Silberstein and grandchildren James and Alana of Farmington. Peg retired in 1950 from Prentice-Hall, Inc. and began her over 50-year dedication to volunteer service with the Teaneck, NJ school system. After moving to Connecticut, she was instrumental in developing the East Haddam school library system and also served for many years with the PTA and Board of Education. She worked closely on a volunteer basis with the Goodspeed Opera House by providing transportation, costume sewing, and as Treasurer of the Goodspeed Opera Guild. She served St. Bridget of Kildare Church as the first female lector in the state of Connecticut and continued that service for over three decades. As Minister of the Eucharist, she often brought Communion to those unable to attend church services. Visiting hours will be Monday November 10, 2003 at St. Bridget of Kildare Church, 75 Moodus Leesville Road in Moodus from 8:30-10:30a.m. followed by a funeral liturgy at 11 AM at St. Bridget of Kildare Church. Memorial contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society or to the Goodspeed Opera House Foundation.

title: The Best Novelists, The Worst Movie Adaptations
description: ''THE Human Stain,'' Robert Benton's new film based on the novel of the same name, starts with three male academics walking across a sunlit campus and absorbed in elaborate banter about Monica Lewinsky. Two things jump out at the viewer: that we are, as Gary Sinise's voiceover solemnly confirms, in the sanctimonious summer of 1998; and that we are in the world of Philip Roth, in which anguished and libidinous men of a certain age articulate, with exaggerated fluency, the moral and metaphysical concerns of the times. It's a world that countless American readers are familiar with and, over the last five decades, have come to associate with similarly perplexed, male and yearning viewpoints presented by Saul Bellow and John Updike -- the writers widely regarded as occupying the two other spots on the medal podium of living American novelists. (Morrison, Pynchon, DeLillo? Newcomers by comparison.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIMMELFARB, MARTIN R.
description: HIMMELFARB--Martin R., of Delray Beach, FL and Bergenfield, NJ. Beloved husband of Bella (nee Grossberg). Devoted father of Arthur L. and Stuart V. Cherished father-in-law of Deborah and Robin. Dear brother of Herbert S. Himmelfarb. Loving grandfather of Katie, Eric, Ben and Becky. Services Monday, 11:30AM, ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions to the Jewish Home at Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, NJ 07647

title: No Letup in the Abortion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Aclassical music listing on Page 45 of Arts & Leisure today for a recital tomorrow by the soprano Christiane Oelze at the Walter Reade Theater has become outdated. After the section had gone to press, the concert was canceled because of Ms. Oelze's illness.

title: Turning Menus' Pages To Travel the World
description: READ between the lines of menu offerings from restaurants throughout Westchester and you're bound to find sagas of journeys from far-off lands, memories of grandmothers' kitchens and youthful dreams fulfilled. Following are five options for dining that serve up ethnic dishes as well as tales from across the globe.

title: Take a Loss Sitting Down? Nah, the G.O.P. Leans Right
description: In some ways, losing an election can be a good thing. A party relieved of responsibility for making anything work can float interesting ideas. It can speak honestly -- although that is never conducive to fund-raising -- and generally act high-minded.

title: Becoming a Thoughtful Woman's Idea of A Leading Man Part 1
description: On a cloudless day between the rains this summer, Mark Ruffalo, the 35-year-old actor, took his John Deere tractor out of the barn and began to clear brush on his 50 acres in Sullivan County, not far from where the Delaware River runs between New York and Pennsylvania. He had on jeans and a faded blue shirt that flapped around his thin torso, and his hair was still damp from a swim in the pond that lies at the foot of a grassy hill and a short walk from his two-story Swiss chalet-style house. A patio umbrella and several weathered lawn chairs were set up along the edge, and there was a dock with a wooden diving board that Ruffalo and his younger brother, Scott, a hairdresser in Beverly Hills, built last summer. When the brothers were growing up in Kenosha, Wis., they built many tree houses in the woods near their family's house -- Scott guesses they built one every 10 feet -- and they called themselves the Foresters. Two years ago, when Mark was recovering from surgery to remove a benign tumor in his brain, and thinking that his film career had ended just as it was taking off with his widely praised performance in ''You Can Count on Me,'' he designed the large sleeping porch at the back of the house. Constructed from hemlock, with open beams, it has double-high screened windows, many comfortable old chairs and beds and a closeness with the outdoors.

title: Women in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; A Bill Signed, but It's Not Picture Perfect
description: THE ink from President Bush's signature was barely dry when the photograph of him signing the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act began circulating on the Internet. There he was, surrounded by the bill's Congressional sponsors: a bevy of white men wearing dark suits and smiles.

title: The Imperfect Science of Release Dates
description: On Dec. 25, which this year happens to be a Thursday, five new movies will be released in theaters -- six, if you count a new Disney IMAX film called ''Young Black Stallion.'' As with the Fourth of July and Thanksgiving, there is a special cachet to opening a film on Christmas Day. It announces to the audience that this is not just any movie but a cinematic event. It infuses a studio's marketing campaign with the warm, ''It's a Wonderful Life'' feelings most people have at that time of year. And, as Robert Harper, vice chairman of 20th Century Fox, points out, ''Everyone knows when Christmas is.''

title: When Bad DVD's Happen to Great Films
description: IF you paid $40 for the DVD of ''Lawrence of Arabia'' when Columbia released it with great fanfare in April 2001, you probably felt hoodwinked when, this autumn, the studio brought out a new, improved version for two-thirds the price and (sorry) no factory trade-in for your not-so-old but flawed copy.

title: Brittany Podell, Brandon Levin
description: Brittany C. Podell, the daughter of Monica Podell and Jon Podell, both of New York, was married last evening to Brandon Keith Levin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Barry Levin of Potomac, Md. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the Plaza.

title: MetroStars Face Crucial Playoff Game
description: The MetroStars have been ineffective at the most important time of the season. After losing by 2-0 to the New England Revolution in the opener of the two-game Major League Soccer playoff series, the MetroStars need a victory by three goals this afternoon at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Mass., to advance to the Eastern Conference finals.

title: 26.2 Miles of Food
description: EVERY year I am offered a seat in a pace car of the New York City Marathon. To paraphrase Mel Brooks, it's good to be the sports columnist.

title: Introduction
description: Lisa Belkin's cover article about women who have opted out of the workplace drew record-breaking mail. Here, many readers tell their own stories of similar disenchantment with corporate life, while others ask, Is this a new trend in feminism -- or a backlash?

title: More Memories Of Grandma's Recipes
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspective/Inside the C.I.A.; Iraqi Insurgents Take a Page From the Afghan 'Freedom Fighters'
description: AS the daily attacks against American forces in Iraq increase in number and sophistication, the Bush administration continues to portray its adversaries as an assortment of die-hard Baathists, criminals, thugs and foreign terrorists, all acting out of desperation.

title: The Nation; Explaining Why They Didn't Inhale
description: THE question during the debate, held in front of an audience of twenty-somethings in Boston, was inevitable. The answers showed how much the times have changed.

title: Single and Looking for Love? So Are the Cats
description: DAWSON, Simone, Belle and Tanya had been at the singles event just briefly when the management asked that they leave.

title: Inside George Orwell
description: As a young man Eric Blair was fascinated by ghost stories and intrigued by black magic. Once, seemingly to deadly effect, he laid a curse on a schoolboy who had offended him. On another occasion he reported seeing a ghost. Later, he told a friend that he used a pseudonym so that no enemy could take his name and work magic against him. In dreams he looked for symbols and interpretations, and more than once had highly prophetic visions. None of this quite fits with the widely held image of a man who transformed himself into the writer of clear-headed, rational and lucid prose, George Orwell. But behind every bearer of a pseudonym there stands an individual life, an individual who can appear in various guises and a life which can come to us in different versions. That is because personalities and lives are kaleidoscopic - records, images glimpsed behind words or lodged in reminiscence, fragments viewed and re-viewed through the mirrors of memory and conscious reflection, all projected in turn in new configurations through the eyes of biographers.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing on Page 45 of Arts & Leisure today for a recital tomorrow by the soprano Christiane Oelze at the Walter Reade Theater has become outdated. After the section had gone to press, the concert was canceled because of Ms. Oelze's illness.

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; From a Pest to a Person
description: I remember an assignment that started with choosing a picture. I wasn't exactly sure of what our class was getting assigned but it seemed like fun if we had to choose a picture.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11.9.03: The Ethicist; Purse Grab
description: Driving home through a state park, I stopped to use the restroom and accidentally left my purse behind. I drove back an hour later and found it on the floor of a parked car. I called Emergency Roadside Assistance. When they arrived, I told the driver it wasn't my car, but it was my purse. He opened the car and retrieved it. I put an explanatory note on the seat, relocked the car and drove off -- outlawish but efficient. Ethical? Nicole Young, Bolinas, Calif.

title: Hoping to See, on the L.I.E., A Rest Area-Visitor Center
description: Re ''A Plan to Build the Best-Protected Bathroom Ever'' [Nov. 2]:

title: Student Notebook; Disconnections
description: I've learned a lot in adult-ed courses -- tips on buying a condo, basics of sign language and beginning bridge (which I never quite mastered). Since I caught the writing bug, I've taken all sorts of classes. I've written to music, used props to inspire ideas and read countless timed pieces out loud.

title: Saving Oscar (R)
description: After the Oscars last year, the ABC television network did some research that it later shared with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The network, which has broadcast the Academy Awards since 1976, gathered viewers in groups of 20 to ask them a few questions. For starters: how many members of the focus group had seen all five films nominated for best picture? No hands went up. O.K., how about four out of the five? Again, nobody. This continued, Bruce Davis, the academy's executive director, told me recently, until the researchers discovered that most of them hadn't seen any of the nominated films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MONTGOMERY, WILLIAM W.
description: MONTGOMERY--William W. M.D. Of Chestnut Hill, originally from West Rutland, VT. November 7, 2003. Beloved father of Lynn of Placitas, NM, Scott of Addison, NY, Stuart and his wife Diane of Hopkinton, MA, Leslie of Brattleboro, VT, and Robert of Fairlee, VT. William is also survived by his seven loving grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held in the Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Harvard University, on Saturday, November 22, 2003, at 12:00 PM. Relatives and friends are kindly invited. Late Surgeon and Professor, Harvard University Medical School. Decorated Veteran of WWII and Korea, United States Army and Navy. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be made to the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary, 243 Charles St, Boston, MA 02114, Attn: Dr. William Montgomery Fellowship Fund. Bell-O'Dea Funeral Home, 617-277-7652.

title: Bishops' Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: In Many Recruitment Efforts, Health Benefits Act as Lure
description: When Maggie Mateer was offered a job last July as an accountant for the Xerox Corporation, she hesitated. It wasn't that she did not want the job, or that the salary was too low. Ms. Mateer, who had five years of experience as a certified public accountant, wanted to pore over the details of the company's health plan before she signed on.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: From the perspective of this early feminist, the point of the movement was never ''standing at the helm in the macho realms of business and government and law.'' It was, among other things, about transforming those realms. Yet today, although women have far greater opportunity in the job market, they still do most of the work at home, while jobs require longer and longer hours, making them more hostile, not less, to anyone trying to run a household. It's hardly surprising when women who have a choice reject this regimen. But their choice says less about women's desires than about our still-unequal situation -- not to mention the oppressiveness of 12-hour workdays for women and men alike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANYI, MARTON
description: LANYI--Marton, of Fenton, MI. formerly of NYC, died Wednesday, November 5, at his home. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10AM Monday, November 10 at St. Matthew Catholic Church, 706 Beach St in Flint, MI. Marton Lanyi is survived by his wife, Spencer Kelly Lanyi of Fenton; mother, Nadya Lanyi of NYC; brother Dr. Ronald L. Lanyi and niece, Claire Lanyi of Altadena, CA; sister-in-law, Anne Lanyi and niece, Alexandra Lanyi of NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WISE, EUGENIE M.
description: WISE--Eugenie M. (Pisani). Former Manhattan resident. On November 7, 2003 at Southampton Hospital, L.I. Predeceased by her parents, Eugene and Helen Wise and brother Thomas. Beloved widow of the late Dr. Anthony J. Pisani. Survived by nieces Wendy Wise Routh and Jennifer M. Wise. Invaluable administrator of Remsen Millham & Curran for many years. Mass of Christian Burial 10AM Monday at Sacred Heart Church, Southampton, L.I. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to the JC for JD Foundation, (Juvenile Diabetes), POB 865, Water Mill, NY 11976.

title: In the Region/Long Island; New Law School Helping to Fulfill Islip Master Plan
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun here on a law school that represents an important piece of a comprehensive plan created 20 years ago for the 788-acre former Central Islip Psychiatric Center, which once housed more than 10,000 patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOEPPEL, JEROME
description: KOEPPEL -- Jerome, M.D. Passed away peacefully in Baltimore, MD. on Friday, November 7, 2003. Born November 26, 1927, he lived a rich, full life and was loved by everyone who knew him. He left behind his loving wife Marlene, his children John, Claudia, Lisa and Gabrielle and many grandchildren. He was the best big brother you could ever have and I will miss him forever. Howard Koeppel

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   THOMAS, DYLAN MARLAIS
description: THOMAS--Dylan Marlais, Poet, 1914--1953 Cry forever Meridian through the courters' lanes. Buffalo

title: Skiing the Web, no mittens required
description: Skiing Web sites have progressed in the past few years, as mountain operators and ski publishers have realized that there is perhaps no better way to satiate the skier's need for up-to-date and comprehensive snow information than by presenting it online. Skiers who engage in even a little surfing before they choose a resort, book a flight or drive to the mountain can save money and avoid the frustration that poor ski conditions can bring.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212)556-7219; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Splitting Hairs Over Iraq's Reconstruction
description: CONGRESS approved the $87 billion supplemental aid package for Iraq last week, but tinkered a bit with the portion set aside for reconstruction. Of the $20.3 billion requested by President Bush, Congress nipped and tucked about a dozen projects to bring the total down to $18.4 billion. Some of those cuts are detailed below.

title: Women in Politics: An All-Points Bulletin
description: To the Editor:

title: Disabled on Planes
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''U.S. Moves to Aid Disabled Who Fly'' (Oct. 26), by Matthew L. Wald: The stories of lazy and cruel treatment of wheelchair-bound travelers and airline carelessness with critical and expensive passenger wheelchairs are appalling. However, there are many other kinds and degrees of disability that make travel difficult and are likewise indifferently addressed by the airlines and the travel industry.

title: No Letup in the Abortion Debate (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Joseph V. Doria, the mayor of Bayonne, and his loss of the speakership of the State Assembly misstated the given name and home county of his successor. He is Albio Sires, not Alberto; he is from Hudson County, not Union County.

title: BENEFITS
description: Aiding the Urban League

title: Israel Approves Prisoner Swap; Palestinian Announces Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 9  After an emotionally charged debate, Israel's Cabinet narrowly approved a planned prisoner swap with Lebanon's Hezbollah guerrillas that would free more than 400 imprisoned Arabs in return for a kidnapped Israeli businessman and the remains of three soldiers.

title: Auditioning the Next James Bond
description: AS 2003 rolls to an end, the phrase ''Academy Award winner'' will appear more frequently in movie ads, Tom Cruise will gaze winsomely from the cover of every magazine except Cook's Illustrated and Black Enterprise, and the annual, unofficial ''Who will be the next James Bond?'' sweepstakes will commence.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We don't have flak jackets. We don't have good cars. And we are face to face with death, because everybody thinks we are supporting the Americans.''

title: Mitsuko Uchida Flies Round-Trip To Beethoven
description: Mitsuko Uchida's perspectives, as shown in her Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall over the next few weeks, are clear. The lines lead forward and backward to Beethoven, scarcely leave the city of Vienna and touch only on masterpieces. Given that Ms. Uchida is at the height of her pianistic powers -- able to draw out the delicacy and expressive fragility in the most solid music as well as the poignancy in a throwaway gesture -- these concerts should be a revelation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about the Peruvian Amazon misstated the name and location of a lodge in which the author stayed. It is the Heath River Wildlife Center, not the Heath Wildlife Center; Ese Eja Lodge is its former name. It is in the Tambopata-Madidi Wilderness, not the Manu Wilderness.

title: INVESTING WITH/Peter D. Luke; Smith Barney Convertible Fund
description: THE $163 million Smith Barney Convertible fund has benefited from the stock market rally this year, even though the fund doesn't focus on common stocks, says Peter D. Luke, the fund's manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DICK, REUBEN
description: DICK--Reuben. On November 6, 2003. Age 95. Beloved husband of the late Pauline and the late Egidia. Adored father of Marcella Rappoport andher husband Stanley and Renee Snyder. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Susan, Bonnie and Jennifer. Loving great - grandfather. Service private.

title: The World: Tunnel Vision; Watching Iraq, Seeing Vietnam
description: ''QUAGMIRE,'' ''attrition,'' ''credibility gap,'' ''Iraqification'' -- a listener to the debate over the situation in Iraq might think that it truly is Vietnam all over again.

title: Business People; Eat as I Eat, Not as I Ate
description: Gary Hirshberg, chief executive of Stonyfield Farm, is betting that he can persuade school-age children to trade their Snickers bars and Doritos for dried fruit and soy chips.

title: Going Beyond Black and White, Hispanics in Census Pick 'Other'
description: Patria Rodriguez, an advertising sales director for a women's magazine in New York, takes after her father. With light brown skin and thick, curly hair, she says she resembles the actress Rosie Perez, but some people have asked her if she is Italian, and others have told her she looks like the singer Sade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOGAN, SHERIDAN ASHTON
description: LOGAN -- Sheridan Ashton. 102, died at the family home in Saint Joseph, Missouri, on November 5, 2003. Harvard College 1923; First National Bank, New York; Executive Secretary, George F. Baker Trust; Treasurer, Harvard Club of New York City; Treasurer, Cooper Union. Wrote two books, ''George F. Baker and His Bank, 1840-1855, A Double Biography,'' ''Old Saint Jo, Gateway to the West, 1799-1932.'' Survived by his niece, Lisa Logan Armbruster. Services 1:30 PM, Sunday, November 16, 2003, First Presbyterian Church, St. Joseph, Missouri. For information contact Meierhoffer Family Funeral Service, 816232-3366.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: THE X PRESIDENT, by Philip Baruth (Bantam, paper, $11.95), begins with a five-page infodump -- a little lecture on background events that an author feels the reader must know in order to understand a particular story set in the future. These canned bits of ''future history'' are usually a sign of authorial laziness; it is more difficult but far more effective to embed the necessary information in the fabric of the story, so that readers experience everything from the point of view of the major characters.

title: DEAN'S NEW STEPS RESHAPE CONTEST
description: After months of being viewed by Democrats as an improbable if persistent candidate, Howard Dean has erased questions about his staying power and forced his rivals to upend their strategies to counter his increasing influence on the race, party leaders, strategists and even rival campaigns say.

title: Winners' Tales: New York's New Classics
description: EVERYONE knows the traditional New York classics, like E. B. White's ''Here Is New York,'' from 1949, and Joseph Mitchell's ''Bottom of the Harbor'' (1959). But what books published in the past quarter century might join their ranks?

title: Jennifer Lander, Michael Steinfink
description: Dr. Jennifer Lander and Michael Steinfink were married yesterday by Rabbi Michael Ehrlich at the Metropolitan Hotel in New York.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SELECTED STORIES

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER--Richard. 38 years ago you went away. Forever in my heart, my precious Richie. Mom

title: Ethnic With a Small 'e'
description: ON THE EDGE of this trip-back-in-time, red-brick-and-sandstone Colonial hamlet on the Bergen County border is a road sign reading ''Restaurant Row.'' This is something of a misnomer: though five fairly ambitious restaurants are scattered about town, the only row is a pair of adjoining storefronts in a new strip mall. The older one is Barcelona, a sophisticated Spanish-Cuban place reviewed in this space in January 2002. Its neighbor, the trim, Mediterranean-accented Village Grille, celebrated its first birthday last August.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Hercules Under Scrutiny
description: Probably some of the best homework assignments I've had were in an English class when we studied Greek mythology. We were given a book of mythology stories and the teacher would ask us to read one of them every couple of days. I read through the entire book in about a week. I really liked the stories about the Greek gods. I'm not sure why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALKER, DANIEL
description: WALKER--Daniel. February 1, 1909--October 8, 2003, born in DeWitt, VA, parents Albert and Rosa Walker. Survivors, Audrey, Cooper, Felton, Albertine, Vicie, and Carla Walker, Edward Earl and Charles Earl Harris. He lived on Lenox Avenue for over 50 years. He attended the A. Phillips Randolph Senior Center for many years. He was buried in Dallas, TX, on October 14, 2003.

title: Lauren Strapp, Garrick Stannard
description: Lauren Frances Strapp, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Strapp of Roseland, N.J., was married yesterday to Garrick Paul Stannard, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Stannard of Ramsey, Minn. Frank R. Camera, a Rhode Island justice of the peace, officiated at Kay Chapel in Newport, R.I.

title: Finding Travel's Glamour (by Solving Its Glitches)
description: IT was almost 20 years ago, but Pamela Fiori remembers it well. As a Christmas treat, she took her parents, Italian-Americans, on their first trip to Italy. After they arrived at the Hotel Cipriani in Venice and unpacked, panic ensued: her father had left some vital medicine behind.

title: Food; Cowboy Cuisine
description: As I was driving south a few months ago from Jackson toward Cora beneath the Wind River Range in western Wyoming, I noticed a herd of antelope grazing in a pasture, separated by a barbed-wire fence from the blacktop that stretched in a diminishing V toward the distant mountains like an image on an eye chart. Since I had never been to Wyoming before and had no idea how untamed it still was, I assumed I had come upon a zoo or the private herd of an eccentric rancher. It didn't occur to me that in Wyoming the buffalo still roam, the deer and the antelope play and the skies are not cloudy all day.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about a golf course under construction in Bayonne misstated the headquarters location of the developer, Cherokee Investment Partners, and referred incompletely to the scope of its business. The company is in Raleigh, N.C., not in London. In addition to creating golf courses, it cleans up manufacturing and industrial sites.

title: Fresh Pricing Is a Draw for Exchange-Traded Funds
description: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds can be traded throughout the day at constantly updated prices, a feature that may have particular appeal to investors who are troubled by the trading practices at many mutual funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MITCHELL, VALERIE (NIELD)
description: MITCHELL--Valerie (Nield). 67, died at home in Yarmouth Port, MA, Thursday, October 30, after a three year battle with cancer. Born in New York City, she attended Nightingale-Bamford School, was presented at the Tuxedo Autum Ball and graduated from Bennett Junior College. She worked for the Shubert Theatre Organization, Playwright Howard Teichman and the late David Suskind. She is survived by her husband Garry, her daughter Heather Mitchell of Los Angeles and her brother Ogden Nield of Fort Lauderdale. Memorial donations may be made to the Chatham Drama Guild, P.O. Box 92, 134 Krowell Road, Chatham, MA 02633.

title: Happily Above The Fireworks
description: I NEVER wanted to be an airline pilot; it seemed boring. I thought it was too much ''flying by numbers,'' or rather, the computer flying by numbers and you just watching it. A glorified bus driver, really. I wanted to do something more exciting, that had more variety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELIK, SOSS E.
description: MELIK--Soss E., on October 11, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Lois May Radley Melik. Graveside services were held at the Miami Cemetery, Waynesville, OH on Friday, October 24, 2003. Mr. Melik was born on August 2, 1914 in Kislovodsk, Russia, of Armenian parents. He was predeceased by his father, the late Efrem Melik Shah-Nazaroff, his mother Maria Avanesov, and his brother Zaven. He was a world-renowned artist whose many portraits are exhibited at the National Portrait Gallery at the Smithsonian Institute in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Armenian National Science and Educational Fund, FAR, 630 2nd Ave., NY, NY 10016.

title: Oh, the Places You'll See! Right Here
description: YOU know how it is. When you lived in New York City, you never visited the Statue of Liberty or the Empire State Building, unless you had out-of-town visitors. And so it is in Westchester, a county rich in attractions, which few of us who live here actually take the time to visit.

title: Tasmin Little, the Violin Star Next Door
description: SOME star musicians take their stardom seriously. You don't just meet them; you're invited to approach and kiss the ring. But there are others, the more human kind, who simply laugh. And I can hear the laughter halfway down the street -- an otherwise sedate Edwardian boulevard in a West London suburb -- as I make my way to Tasmin Little's end-of-summer garden party.

title: The Web Isnt Always Up-to-the-Minute
description: The Internet provides loads of information for consumers and businesses, quickly and often, but it is also littered with Web sites that are woefully out of date.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; High-End Housing Boom in Downtown Morristown
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON and his Continental Army troops called downtown Morristown home during the severe winter of 1779-80, when they hunkered down in wood and clay huts on a hill east of the Morristown Green. For the next 200-plus years, however, living downtown has not been much of an option, except for residents of the Victorian manses on the fringes that are passed from generation to generation and rarely seem to come on the market.

title: Spammers Can Run but They Can't Hide
description: AS Steve Linford walks his German shepherd, Zen, across the gangway from his houseboat into his prim little garden on this small island in the Thames, he hardly looks like a man in a battle over the future of cyberspace. He has a salt-and-pepper beard and a twinkle in his blue eyes, but the effect is more former hippie than Sean Connery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FROME, LEO
description: FROME--Leo, 82, died November 5, in New York City, after a long illness. Trained at Goodman Theater in Chicago. Director of Development at Institute of International Education in New York. Devoted husband of 56 years of Joan (Hansi). Loving father of Kathy & Alex, and grandfather of Nicholas. A gentle, peace-loving human being, he will be sorely missed by his family and friends. Memorial at a later date.

title: Running on Trips
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''His Best Trips Are Never No Sweat''(Oct. 26), by Samuel G. Freedman: I worked as a guitar technician (roadie) for several rock and pop musicians, and had the opportunity to tour the United States, Canada and Europe extensively. On my infrequent days off, I would wake up and plan my running route.

title: Never Mind the Pollacks
description: What a wonderful morning. I'd just finished reviewing the galleys of my book The Threepenny Hip-Hopera , which compares the sociopolitical roots of Chuck D's work with those of Kurt Weill's. It serves as an excellent companion piece to my oft-studied book From Bauhaus to Compton: Sixty Years of Revolution in Western Popular Music .

title: Mauritania Vote Disputed
description: With preliminary results of Mauritania's presidential elections on Friday showing the American-allied incumbent leader ahead by a wide margin, the principal opposition party rejected the results on Saturday and called for a new election.

title: OSHA Reinstates Plum Island Employee
description: An employee fired in June by a contractor at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center after expressing safety concerns was protected by federal whistleblower laws and must be reinstated, the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has ruled.

title: Governor Reagan
description: The most systematic record of Reagan's apprenticeship as governor of California is contained in the minutes of his meetings with his staff and executive directors during the first two years of the governorship. This record, known as "cabinet minutes," was the work of Austrian-born Helene von Damm, secretary to William P. Clark, Reagan's first cabinet secretary. Clark instructed the meticulous von Damm to "write it all down," and she produced minutes that show Reagan and his inner cabinet without promotional gloss.

title: Trends Bode Well For Online Shopping
description: IT'S too soon to call it mature, but online retailing, including online travel, is a $100 billion business. That is 2.3 percent of all retail sales.

title: Trying to Keep The New Jersey Afloat
description: The battleship New Jersey served valiantly in three major wars, but in recent months it has been limping through a peaceful dotage on the Camden waterfront, where it has been a tourist attraction since 2001. It lost an expected $7.2 million state grant because of New Jersey's budget difficulties, and the number of visitors was down because of a rainy summer, officials say.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ZELDIN, BENJAMIN
description: ZELDIN -- Benjamin. Four years of sorrow. The pain remains...but thank you for a lifetime of love. Beverly and Childre

title: See Me, Shoot Me, Ask Me, Love Me
description: In Venice, there's a whiff of madness in the air. Or perhaps it's just the deep silliness of a major international film festival, where luminaries of the movie world congregate, as sweaty with hope as sales reps at a trade show.

title: Will Investors Stampede Out of Mutual Funds?
description: THE investigations into anti-investor practices at mutual funds are starting to register with fund shareholders. In the week that ended Nov. 5, investors in Putnam funds pulled roughly $5.4 billion from the company, according to AMG Data Services. Guess these folks don't like the idea that Putnam fund managers might have put their personal profits ahead of their shareholders, as regulators contend.

title: The Littlest Test Takers
description: In this era of testing and accountability, preschool is the last frontier. Most preschool educators are coming to accept that with more states getting into the business of educating 3- and 4-year-olds, the political demands for accountability -- for showing that preschools and kindergartens work -- are inevitable. This means that children as young as 3 have to be observed, evaluated and in some way tested.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11.9.03; Lost Weekends
description: I try to go out to the movies -- popcorn, previews, a Manhattan crowd -- at least once a week. Usually I fail. I pick up the movie listings with the vague feeling that there's something I thought I wanted to see -- something that opened over the weekend -- and it turns out to be ''Old School'' or ''Tears of the Sun.'' So I catch an early train home to the country instead, where I can have supper with my wife and the dogs and listen to crickets singing in the moonlight.

title: BLAST SHATTERS HOUSING ENCLAVE IN SAUDI CAPITAL
description: Saudi Arabia's capital, Riyadh, was rocked by a huge explosion just before midnight Saturday in what the country's Interior Ministry described as a terrorist attack against a residential compound.

title: Tara Tessaro, Arthur Mueller III
description: Tara Leigh Tessaro, a daughter of June G. Tessaro and Robert T. Tessaro of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Lt. Arthur August Mueller III, a son of Mr. Mueller Jr. and a stepson of Christie Mueller of St. Charles, Mo. The Rev. Miles Barrett, a Roman Catholic priest and a chaplain at the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., performed the ceremony in the academy's chapel.

title: All That R.E.M. Can't Leave Behind
description: THE wildfires were closing in on the city of Los Angeles, but within the leafy, walled compound of the Chateau Marmont, just above Sunset Boulevard, the only heat you could feel was the warm glow of celebrity. One of the young stars of ''Y Tu Mam Tambin'' idled in and about the lobby. Spike Jonze sat at a table, facing a team of serious-looking, well-dressed foreign journalists. And the three members of R.E.M. monopolized a comfortable set of upholstery in the corner, considering the lunch options.

title: The Painter And the President
description: WHEN Robert A. Anderson and George W. Bush were in Spanish class together at Yale, it was at least as far-fetched that one would become a painter as it was that the other would end up as president. Yet 35 years later, that is exactly where the two members of the class of 1968 find themselves, one posing for an official portrait and one behind the easel.

title: First, There's One. Then Another, and Another...
description: IT starts innocently, as so many things do. Just this once, you say. Well, maybe once more. Or twice. Then one day, at the coaxing of a loved one (or the face in the mirror), you come to grips with reality and admit the truth: you are a collector. And there's rarely any turning back.

title: Serving Up Washington
description: THE GEORGETOWN LADIES' SOCIAL CLUB

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: As an old-fashioned feminist, I found the article depressing. I don't think it's all about work versus ''life.'' Work is life, just as much as children are. So I am not sure that it is the pull of motherhood that's at issue, so much as the dissatisfaction with what a career entails. Perhaps these golden girls thought it would all fall in their laps, and they wouldn't have to compete with equally ambitious colleagues, network, butter up the bosses, mentor novices to be able to have dependable assistants. Perhaps they weren't taught the old feminist lessons of how to fight informal discrimination against women. Perhaps they got stymied by the stigma of anything smacking of a ''mommy track.'' Perhaps they got tired of trying to enlist their spouses in a genuine shared parenting arrangement. How much of these well-educated women's lives is devoted to parenting? How many are organizing something, doing voluntary charity work or consulting for pay?

title: When the Ultimate Monument Isn't a Building
description: LOUIS KAHN, the subject of a brilliant film portrait by his son, Nathaniel Kahn, is the ghost at the banquet that architecture has become since his death in 1974. As the movie makes clear, Louis would have made a bad banquet master. He was too dedicated to mastering architecture. That left little room for the aesthetic jollies in which today's designers take such splashy delight.

title: Trying to Get Even, Knicks Are Pushed Back Down
description: The nearly two-year scramble to reach the plateau of mediocrity -- not a winning record but at least not a losing one -- eluded the Knicks' outstretched arms once again, going the way of loose balls and rebounds in the fourth quarter.

title: 3 Autoimmune Diseases Are Found to Have Genetic Link
description: To their surprise, scientists have found a genetic link between three common autoimmune diseases: psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: Brittany Podell, Brandon Levin
description: Brittany C. Podell, the daughter of Monica Podell and Jon Podell, both of New York, was married last evening to Brandon Keith Levin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Barry Levin of Potomac, Md. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the Plaza.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic View column last Sunday, about the struggle of the formerly unemployed to make up for lost income, misstated the average time that an unemployed worker spends looking for another job. It is 19.7 weeks, not 19.7 months.

title: Mercer Reeves, Matthew Procino
description: Katherine Mercer Reeves, the daughter of Kay Van Allen of Lynchburg, Va., and Ed Reeves Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married last evening to Matthew Charles Procino, a son of Susan B. Campbell of Hong Kong and the late Mark C. Procino. The Rev. Martha Forrest, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Callaway Gardens, a hotel in Pine Mountain, Ga.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Sailing the Wine-Dark Sea
description: Zeus, who controlled rain and clouds and held in his hand the awful thunderbolt, was Lord of the Sky and greatest of the gods, but not the oldest. He and the eleven other Olympians-the gods and goddesses who dwelt in the heaven at the top of Mount Olympus, Greece's highest mountain-had been preceded in their reign by the elder gods, the Titans, whom they had overthrown. The Titans had been formed by Father Heaven and Mother Earth, which had existed before any of the gods, having emerged from the primordial Chaos, whose children, Darkness and Death, had given birth to Light and Love (for Night is the mother of Day), which made possible the appearance of Heaven and Earth.

title: Dean Rejects Public Financing in Primaries
description: Howard Dean on Saturday became the first Democrat to opt out of the presidential public financing system in 30 years, striking a severe blow to the Watergate-era program.

title: Mine Safety Official Critical of Policies Faces Firing
description: The Bush administration has notified a mine safety official who has sharply criticized federal mining policies that it intends to fire him, according to documents and the official's lawyers.

title: Pfc. Jessica Lynch Isn't Rambo Anymore
description: AH, the dazzling pyrotechnics of ''shock and awe.'' The finality of the toppling of Saddam Hussein's statue. The thrill of that re-enactment of ''Top Gun.'' The sense of closure provided by the banner reading ''Mission Accomplished.'' Like all wars of the TV age, the war in Iraq is not just a clash of armies, but a succession of iconic images. Those who control the images, and the narratives they encapsulate, control history. At least until a new reality crashes in.

title: Fear of Plane Crashes Near Hackensack Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: The Knottiest Cases Of Landlord v. Tenant
description: PINK boxes on enlarged monthly calendars perched on easels beside the witness box in housing court in downtown Manhattan indicated days when the tenant facing eviction, Carole Langer, a documentary filmmaker, was in New York City.

title: Kathryn Kimble, Christopher Arner
description: Kathryn Eugenie Kimble, a daughter of Barbara Johnson and Dr. John Kimble, both of New Orleans, was married there on Friday to Christopher Weldon Arner, the son of Emilia Ley Arner and Gregory R. Arner of New Providence, N.J. The Rev. Neale L. Miller, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Charles Presbyterian Avenue Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, MARIELLA
description: WOLF--Mariella. The K.S. Giniger Company mourns the loss of its longtime London representative and dear friend. Our sincere condolences to her many friends and loved ones.

title: One Classroom, Many Minds; A Paddle for the Mainstream
description: SOME fourth graders at the Rand School read at second-grade level; some have already finished ''Lord of the Rings.'' So Cheryl Caggiano organizes her class into clusters based on proficiency, each with a different book and assignment. At any given time, four things are going on at once in Ms. Caggiano's classroom.

title: Editors' Note

title: Inside Autumn, Art and History
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: November 16, 2003, Sunday A picture caption in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a preview of the exhibition "Glass and Glamour: Steuben's Modern Moment, 1930-1960" at the Museum of the City of New York on Nov. 5 misstated the middle name of a former design director at Steuben Glass. He was John Monteith Gates, not Meredith.

title: PRIVATE JOKES, PUBLIC PLACES
description: BLAME Bilbao. Frank Gehry's extravagant design for the Spanish outpost of the Guggenheim Museum was an impressive architectural achievement, but it also started an insidious trend, argues Oren Safdie, author of ''Private Jokes, Public Places,'' a Shavian satire of contemporary architecture that opened last Wednesday at the Theater at the Center for Architecture in Greenwich Village.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Dot, Dash, Dot
description: My most memorable homework assignment was in 1972. I was a junior at Mount Holyoke College, on exchange from Bowdoin College, and I was taking a course from Mount Holyoke at Hampshire College.

title: Assisted Living to Viagra: A Dictionary Nod to Aging
description: THERE have been many warnings to advertisers that their fascination with youthful consumers runs against the grain of demographics: America is graying and older people have much more money to spend than the young.

title: Right to Exist
description: The war against the Jews goes on. Jewish children are shot in their beds, and the shooters are celebrated as heroes. Jewish teenagers are blown up, and the mothers of their murderers exult. Elderly Jews are burned to death, and the killers gloat on their Web sites. And across the Arab world from Pakistan to Morocco, hundreds of millions have nothing better to do than to chant for the death of the Jews. If there was one thing to be learned from the twentieth century, it is that when people consistently say that they want the Jews dead, they may actually mean it. And when the rest of the world looks away or pretends not to hear, the killers take silence for acquiescence, acquiescence for concurrence, and concurrence for support.

title: Payrolls Up. Layoffs Up. What's Up?
description: Pick your statistic. Or, as a wise soul often put it, ''Yes, but.''

title: Pistons, Brown's Latest Project, Pose Threat to the Nets
description: In a conference in which the slightest change can make all the difference, the East could be decided by a 63-year-old coach who makes more stops than the People Mover, Detroit's elevated train.

title: Running on Trips
description: To the Editor: Samuel Freedman's essay brought back wonderful memories of jogging while on vacation -- among the hedgerows and beautiful countryside of Normandy with my son, along purple fields of grapes in Burgundy, and along deserted beaches in the early morning on the California coast.

title: Paying for the Pipers

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; Remembering That Number
description: I'll never forget when I was in second grade at Daniel Webster Elementary School in New Rochelle in the late 1960's. I was new to the school and so was my teacher -- the very glamorous and beautiful Miss Sidleman, who remains that way to this very day. I wanted desperately to be like Miss Sidleman, but due to perennial bad hair days and being 7, I thought I'd wow her with my homework instead.

title: Sharing a Life, a Family and a Workweek
description: TOMORROW morning, Dr. Michele Chai will go to work at the neonatal intensive care unit of the Hamot Medical Center in Erie, Pa., where she is a neonatologist. The next three days she will be on call 24 hours a day. While she is working, her husband, Jonathan, will be home, caring for their three children, ages 6, 4 and 2.

title: An Appeal to Himself
description: Tony Hoagland's disarming poetry collection WHAT NARCISSISM MEANS TO ME (Graywolf, paper, $14) has the appeal of a mean-but-funny friend, a smart aleck you can't dismiss, he's so entertaining and (most of the time) so spot on in his insights. Hoagland's central subject is the self, specifically, a prickly, grandiose American masculine poetic self, or to be more specific still, what the author ruefully labels in one poem ''a government called Tony Hoagland.'' In a recent essay, Hoagland made the case for meanness in poetry as ''metaphysical straight-talk,'' and there is something refreshing about his willingness to expose his crummier impulses: rooting for a white tennis player, hating his detractors ''from the core of my donkey soul.'' But some of Hoagland's sharpest offerings are insightful portraits of others, like the woman who despised her husband ''as a way of pushing off, / like you would push off from the wall of a swimming pool'' or a newly minted wine expert who ''squints as if recalling his childhood in France.'' A chorus of friends chimes in in several poems, dishing up aphorisms like ''That woman has a Ph.D. in Face.'' Hoagland's wisecrack lyricism doesn't always jell, and a few jokes fall flat. But a prickly force carries the day, building a portrait of emotional longing that is ''like a heavy piece of furniture inside you; / you carry it, it burdens you, it drags you down -- / then you stop, and rest on top of it.'' Emily Nussbaum

title: Home Sweet Home To Chocolate Makers
description: CHOCOLATE is usually not a hard sell, no matter how and where it is made. Beyond the guilty pleasures imported from Belgium, Switzerland, France and some corners of the United States, a lot of scrumptious chocolates are made in Connecticut, often on a cottage-industry scale by people who are eager to convert you to their special premium handmade chocolates.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about cable channels created by the National Basketball Association and the National Football League misstated the name of another professional sports organization, the PGA Tour; misstated the annual television revenue for Major League Baseball and Nascar; misidentified two of the networks that broadcast Major League Baseball games; and omitted one that broadcasts Nascar races. The chart also referred incompletely to the expiration of Major League Baseball's and Nascar's current TV deals. A corrected version of the affected part of the chart appears today, on Page 10.

Gifted high school students now spend far more time studying a work's purpose and social context, like how patronage and power shaped its creation, as well as art beyond the European tradition. Below are examples of the new focus.

For a father of young children, the prospect stretched beyond titillating to the realm of the glorious, but I thought the chances of actually successfully passing off raw debauchery as good works stood at somewhere between zero and nil.

title: Power to the Principals
description: The Oxford Dictionary of Islam. John L. Esposito, editor. Oxford University Press.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Use Complete Sentences
description: For eighth-grade social studies my teacher made us write all of our homework assignments in complete sentences, even if they were questions that only needed a one-word answer. She told us that if we didn't turn the question around and make it a full sentence that we would not make it in high school.

title: Funk Is Doing His Best to Be the Tour Spoiler
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 8  Fred Funk did not make the PGA Tour until he was 32 years old. Before that, he was the golf coach at the University of Maryland. Before that, he was a circulation supervisor for a newspaper.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Origin of a Word Lover
description: What I remember best about homework is not one particular assignment, but three years' worth of homework, assigned to me and all her other pupils, by Miss Livingston, my English teacher from when I entered Aberdeen Academy in Aberdeen, Scotland, at age 11 until I moved into the senior school there at age 14. Miss Livingston was of the ''old school'' even then -- a teacher who brooked no idle chatter, one who could control a class of 38 girls with a single look, and one whose homework assignments opened up the world of words to me.

title: Lives; Sex and the Single Older Woman
description: This is the first time I've written an original screenplay by myself. If I'm not ready at 53, I'll never be. I used to work in collaboration with my now ex-husband, Charles Shyer. We would talk for months, and when we hit on something, we'd write it down. ''Private Benjamin'' came out in 1980. I wrote that with Charles and Harvey Miller. After that, I wrote ''Irreconcilable Differences'' with Charles, and then we wrote the ''Father of the Bride'' movies and ''The Parent Trap.'' Collaboration is great for screenwriting. It's not as simple as two heads are better than one, but if you find the right person, you can feed off each other. But I don't think I could have collaborated on my latest film, ''Something's Gotta Give.'' I had an idea about a man who chronically dates younger women, who meets the mother of a girl he's dating. This was more personal than other films I've written. I don't think I would have been that open.

title: At United Way, a Change in Direction
description: LAST year, United Way of Long Island ran a fund-raising campaign called ''Give a Little'' with a goal of $13 million. The campaign finished nearly $2 million short, pushing the organization into the red by $340,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALEXANDER, ALEX T.
description: ALEXANDER--Alex T. 51, died on October 19, after a short battle with cancer. An expert on foreign exchange related issues, his banking career spanned 26 years, with Lloyds of London, Barclays, Credit Lyonnaise, Deutschebank, and with Wachovia Bank in North Carolina helping develop their international division. Born March 5, 1952, in Asheville, NC, the son of the late Thomas and Virginia Chakales Alexander, Alex was a graduate of Asheville Country Day School, Yale University and Boston Law School; served on the boards of Music-Theatre Group and Asheville Lyric Opera; was a member of the Yale Alumni Club. A NYC memorial will be held March 5, 2004. Donations in Alex's name may be made to the Music-Theatre Group, 30 W. 26th Street, Suite 1001, NYC 10010. Alex was a beacon for truth and beauty and lived a life of great passion. We are deeply saddened by his passing. Hooper Brooks, Jack Curry, Diane Wondisford and The Board of Music-Theatre Group

title: When Campus Violence Flares
description: THESE days, on college campuses across New Jersey, the familiar and once-reassuring progress of freshman orientation, homecoming, mid-term exams and winter break has seemingly been shattered by a new rite of passage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLLYDAY, RICHARD C., JR.
description: HOLLYDAY--Richard C., Jr. Died on November 5 after a brief illness. Surviving are his wife of 49 years Jane P. Hollyday of Wilton, CT and his three children Richard C. Hollyday, III, Anne B. Hollyday and Thomas P. Hollyday. Also surviving are his two sisters Edith Hollyday and Blair Gray and his brother James Hollyday. Hollyday graduated with the class of 1945 from St. Paul's School, Concord, NH. After serving in the US Army for two years, he graduated from Princeton University, class of 1950 and from Columbia Law School class of 1953. Following law school and a brief stint at a law firm, Hollyday worked at IBM for 30 years as a lead counsel for the real estate and construction division. A memorial service will be 2PM Wednesday, November 12 at St. Matthews Church, Bedford, NY. Donations may be made to the ALS Association, 818-880-9007.

title: RUTGERS PRESIDENT ADMITS AFFAIR
description: After months of denials, the president of Rutgers University acknowledged last Sunday that he had had an affair with a subordinate during his seven years as president of the University of Washington, and that it had been a factor in his decision to leave Seattle for New Jersey's state university a year ago. Confirming a report on the liaison in The Seattle Times, Richard L. McCormick, 55, called the romance inappropriate, humiliating and a serious lapse in judgment. But he said he was not considering resigning his $525,000-a-year post, and he was promptly supported by the Rutgers board of governors.

description: RAFTERY--Patrick J. Formerly of Floral Park, on November 7, 2003. Devoted husband of the late Kathryn. Loving brother of John, Helen Hayes and the late Mary Henley. Friends may call Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave, Floral Park, NY (at RR Plaza). Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.
