Schiff of New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest and a former president of Georgetown University, took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIRNS, EDWIN M.
description: BIRNS--Edwin M., 66, of Woodbury, NY, on November 6, 2003. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Tokar). Devoted father of Stuart and Jodi, Richard and Bonnie, David and Ronit. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Evan, Mitchell, Jessica and Jason. Loving brother of Patricia Malamutt and adored son-in-law of Rose Tokar. Hall-of-Fame insurance agent of Equitable Life for 48 years. Funeral services on Sunday, 12 PM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury.

title: For Author of 'Prozac Nation,' Delayed Film Is a Downer
description: IN 1994, the writer Elizabeth Wurtzel, then 27, published ''Prozac Nation,'' a memoir of clinical depression. While some reviewers praised the searingly candid portrait of an unhappy young life, others savaged it as narcissistic, overwrought and exasperating.

title: BLACKBOARD: Good News Dept.; They Did Not Tell a Lie
description: Internet plagiarism and illegal file-sharing may be on the rise on campus, but there is evidence that students are at least entering college with their integrity intact. Concerned that competition for admission may encourage high school seniors to exaggerate their accomplishments, the University of California decided to conduct a random check of applications for this fall's freshman class. About 10 percent of the 77,000 applicants were asked to provide documentation backing up claims about extracurricular activities, awards and personal statements. The result? There wasn't a liar in the bunch. ''There was no evidence to suggest falsification,'' says Susan Wilbur, director of undergraduate admissions. While other universities might investigate obviously suspicious claims, California is said to be the first to use a formal verification process. Encouraged by positive reactions from parents and high-school counselors, officials plan to spot-check future freshmen classes. Applicants beware: embellishment equals rejection. LAURA RANDALL

title: Elise Martin, Gregory Bates
description: Elise Campbell Martin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Martin of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Stephen Bates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Bates of Sudbury, Mass. The Rev. Christopher Brdlik, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, NAOMI
description: GREENE--Naomi. November 8, 2003, at peace. Loving and devoted wife of Franklin, mother to Beverly and Jeffrey, proud grandmother of Ariel and Emily, mother-inlaw to Miriam and Martin. She dedicated her life with passion to early childhood education. Services to be held on Monday, November 10, 12 noon, Schwartz Bros Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Donations may be sent to NYU Medical Center, Stanley and Rita Kaplan Cancer Fund.

title: Holiday on Tuesday -- Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Mezzo in Too Much of a Hurry
description: MAGDALENA KOZENA, a rising Czech mezzo-soprano, is trying hard to burst boundaries. She already appears in the soprano role of Cleopatra in a new recording of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare,'' conducted by Marc Minkowski on Deutsche Grammophon. Now, again with Mr. Minkowski on Deutsche Grammophon, she adds an album of French opera arias: new terrain for a singer who has so far made her name in Bach, Handel and Czech song. And the recording is jampacked, ranging from Adrien Boieldieu's ''Dame Blanche,'' written in 1825, to Ravel's ''Heure Espagnole,'' first performed in 1911.

title: No Business Like Snow Business
description: SKI resort operators have their fingers crossed for another winter like the 2002-3 season, when a series of huge snowstorms, surging interest among young skiers and snowboarders and enticing lift ticket and lodging discounts helped them post their third consecutive record year. Industry analysts say last year's strong showing -- measured in ''skier visits'' -- demonstrates the remarkable resilience of mountain resorts.

title: Columbia Strikes Late To Knock Off Harvard
description: Columbia's football team had lost four straight games. It was on the verge of losing again yesterday, against Harvard. Then, in an instant, it all turned around. Columbia intercepted a pass with 1 minute 55 seconds left, and three plays later the Lions scored on a 10-yard touchdown pass for a 16-13 victory.

title: Women in Politics: An All-Points Bulletin
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERND, WALTER E., JR.
description: BERND--Walter E., Jr. Age 89. Of Long Island City and Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Jessica, of Long Island City. Loving father of Jessica and Walter. Adored grandfather to Sean, David and Chris. All around hot-shot to those lives he touched. He worked hard at being a curmudgeon, and was usually successful in his efforts. Yet, underneath an outwardly gruff (and challenging) exterior lay a heart of gold, willing hand and a proud father. He loved philosophical and political discussions, and contributed generously to people's lives and worthy causes. He is sorely missed. Contributions please to: Dawn Farm, 502 W. Huron St., Ann Arbor, MI. 48104, Center for Drug and Alcohol Rehabilitation.

title: What a Deal!
description: When economists describe the way colleges charge tuition, the analogy they most like to use is an airplane with each passenger in a row paying a different price. Only the differences are not always as easily explained as one person buying a ticket 21 days in advance -- or even as one student coming from a poorer family.

title: The Week Ahead
description: JAPAN VOTES Japanese will choose their next government in an election on Sunday. The Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is expected to retain power; a big victory would give him a mandate to push through economic and political reforms that some members of his own party have resisted.

title: Like Fingernails on a Chalkboard
description: SWEAT pours down the sides of your face leaving two small puddles of perspiration on each side of your overcramped desk. The school air conditioner is under repair on the hottest day of the school year, and you are wearing jeans and a long sleeve shirt, because your unreliable meteorologist predicted that temperatures were going to be in the mid-50's.

title: Page Two: Nov. 2-8; A FASHIONABLE SPLIT AT GUCCI
description: It is hard to imagine what could have qualified as bigger news in the fashion world than Tom Ford's departure from Gucci, announced last week. Only if Prada had de cided to shut its doors would the high heels of the world's shopping capitals have teetered more perilously.

title: Arafat and His Premier Seem Poised to Form a Government
description: After weeks of deadlock, the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei appeared Saturday to be on the verge of forming a new government, with Mr. Arafat retaining ultimate control of the Palestinian security forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIDDLE, CHARLES
description: BIDDLE--Charles. Of Princeton, NJ on November 1, 2003 at the age 78. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, Phoebe Emlen Taylor, their children Charles J. Biddle III of North Salem, NY, Willing L. Biddle of South Salem, NY and four grandchildren: Charles, Katharine, Elinor and Dana. Born in Philadelphia and raised as a river rat at Andalusia on the banks of the Delaware River, Mr. Biddle attended St. Paul's School and Princeton University, class of 1947 prior to serving in the U.S. Army Air Force as a pilot and navigator. Returning from the service he completed Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School, attended Harvard Law School and graduated from Harvard Business School in 1951. After working at Atlantic Refining Company and Union Carbide he joined International Flavors and Fragrances as a management trainee in 1961. He held many executive positions at IFF including area president of North America, Europe, Africa and Asia. He retired in 1985 as a Corporate Vice President to travel, enjoy his beloved St. Barths and his interests in archaeology, Caribbean horticulture and animal husbandry. In lieu of flowers please send donations to: The Andalusia Foundation, Box 158, Andalusia, PA. 19020 or the Small Animal Veterinary Endowment, 900 Herrontown Rd., Princeton, New Jersey 08540. Interment, private. A celebration of his life will be held at the Princeton University Chapel at 3:00 P.M., Friday, November 14, 2003.

title: Beyond the Fringe: The Fuzz That Was
description: ON a mid-September day in Brooklyn, I had a tonsorial epiphany.

title: This Time, Turnovers Doom Scarlet Knights
description: Most of Rutgers's many losses over the last several seasons have been the result of being overmatched. That was not the case Saturday. Sometimes a team just throws one away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, MILTON S.
description: SHAPIRO--Milton S., 81, on November 7, 2003 at his home. Devoted husband of Beatrice, loving father of Susan and Steven Levkoff and Janet and Philip Shapiro, adoring grandfather of Cameron, Josh, Brooke, Logan and Lou. Loyal brother of Dorothy Rothschild, Muriel Firestone and the late Anna Mark. Prominent attorney and distinguished philanthropic leader. Funeral service November 9th at 11:30AM at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, New York, NY. Contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund.

title: When Time Is Running Short, Elegant Traps Come in Handy
description: The First Samba Cup, in Skanderborg, Denmark, from Oct. 10 to 19, intended to be the initiation of a new tournament series, saw four grandmasters tie for first place -- Peter Heine Nielsen and Curt Hansen of Denmark, Darmen Sadvakasov of Kazakhstan and Nigel Short of England. Each tallied 5 1/2-3 1/2 in the 10-player invitational event.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: The personal is political. Remember that? Feminism was never just about reaching parity in the workplace; it was also about remaking love and marriage so that we could reach parity at home. If there is, as Belkin says, something revolutionary in the decision by privileged women to opt out of paid work, it looks anything but revolutionary from the perspective of the family. With moms at home and dads at work as the sole support of the household, it looks pretty traditional to me. Combining professional work and motherhood over the long haul -- now that's something new. We never thought we could remake work without remaking the family. Those of us who still choose work remain committed to that project.

title: Secrets and Surprises
description: INTELLIGENCE IN WAR

title: POSTINGS: Annual Co-op and Condo Conference; Aiming to Build Better Boards
description: Have birds roosted on your co-op or condominium building? Have oil, gas or electricity bills hit the roof? Has a resident's noisy renovation been getting on everyone's nerves?

title: Toasty Coats to Melt the Ice
description: After the bitter cold of last winter, shoppers are choosing coats that offer plenty of warmth along with style. Whether made from shearling, down or old-fashioned boiled wool, the most popular models keep in the heat without compromising fit or fashion. Below, in a meat locker dry run, are some of this season's coziest.

title: No Letup in the Abortion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Island Stands Tall in Guide
description: When Hugh Johnson, the British wine critic, publishes a book, it sells. He may be the most widely read wine expert in the English-speaking world. Almost certainly when Long Island wineries are cited, wine purchases follow, perhaps from enthusiasts carrying the indispensable 2004 edition of ''Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine Book,'' now in bookstores.

title: Controlling The Board Of a Co-op
description: ONE of the most vexing aspects of co-op living involves the issue of who controls the running of the building. And while choosing directors who can effectively manage a co-op without alienating at least some shareholders is difficult, dealing with a sponsor who continues to exert control over a building years after the conversion can be downright infuriating.

title: Business; Russia's Oil Industry, Caught in a Tug of War
description: THE battle between President Vladimir V. Putin and a Russian oil tycoon has spread fears that Western companies will shy away from investing in the country's vast energy industry.

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; Speech Proudly Memorized
description: My best homework assignment was when I had to write a speech about Emmitt Smith. This was my best homework assignment because I like football and I was able to accomplish something I didn't think I could. I was in the fourth grade when I did my speech about Emmitt Smith.

title: A New Way to Unclog the Arteries
description: Last week's report of an experimental treatment that seems to remove plaque from clogged arteries is potentially good news for legions of people threatened with cardiovascular disease. If the findings can be verified in larger and longer studies, the medical profession may have entered a new era in treatments to ward off heart attacks and strokes. Yet this therapy might never have been pursued were it not for a fluke discovery that made patenting possible. Otherwise there would have been little financial incentive for any company to develop the treatment for clinical use.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Point Pleasant, N.J.; A Borough With a Variety of Boating
description: THE police chief of Point Pleasant Borough, N.J., Robert A. Cooper, is relieved that the hundreds of boats in this Ocean County community are finally being hauled out of the water or encased in shrink-wrap for the winter. During the summer, the two lift bridges over the Point Pleasant Canal crank up and down more than 300 times daily -- even during rush hours -- to allow pleasure boats to pass underneath. In the process they sever Route 88 and Bridge Avenue, the two east-west arteries through the 3.5-square-mile borough, a condition that has forced the municipality to build firehouses and to station police cars and ambulances on both sides of the canal.

title: Never Mess With a Poet
description: MY LIFE AS A FAKE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOENBURG, PETER
description: SCHOENBURG -- Peter. Of Claryville, NY, and Manhattan, died on November 7, 2003, at age 88. Beloved husband of Lee, father of Alexandra, Peter and Victoria, grandfather of Mandolina, John Taki, Johannes, Benjamin, Will and Liza, and brother of Sophie. A man of noble birth, exquisite curiosity and an inspiring life. Much loved by all around him.

title: Habitats/Soundview, the Bronx; A Former Addict Finds A Home for Her Family
description: LAST Sunday was a family day for Vernell Shaw and her four children, Shirlina, 14, Jesse, 11, Deja, 6, and Vanessa, 5. Ms. Shaw made oxtail stew and rice, baked a cake and tussled with Shirlina, who was less than thrilled to be spending the day away from friends.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IN 1964, Robert Crane was a clean-cut, churchgoing, fruit-juice-drinking Los Angeles disc jockey and family man. Paul Schrader's AUTO FOCUS (2002) is the sordid but engrossing story of how he changed. When Crane (Greg Kinnear) gets his own television series, ''Hogan's Heroes,'' he begins making money, and women begin coming on to him. John Carpenter (Willem Dafoe), whom Crane calls ''the James Bond of video nuts,'' is a bad influence. Carpenter sells the earliest VTR's (videotape recorders, pre-cassette) and is soon taping orgies starring him, Crane and whatever women they pick up that night. Crane leaves his wife (Rita Wilson), who was already worried when she found ''shady magazines'' in the garage, and marries his blond co-star. Then the series ends -- Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:15 a.m. on Cinemax.

title: Revolutionary Road
description: BRAVE ENEMIES

title: Rich Colleges Receiving Richest Share of U.S. Aid
description: If there is any grand, elegant logic behind the federal government's dispersal of more than a billion dollars in college aid, then Maria Hernandez is humble enough to confess that it has escaped her.

title: Diplomatic Memo; A Loud Silence From U.S. on Russian's Arrest
description: In the two weeks since Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky was arrested and his oil company's assets were impounded in Russia, President Bush and other top American officials have offered little public criticism of what many in the administration acknowledge has been an extremely worrisome development.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: CANADIAN RAIL DISCOUNT -- VIA Rail Canada has off-season price reductions during the colder months. For example, the Canadian, which takes three days to go between Toronto and Vancouver, crossing the prairies and Canadian Rockies, has Silver and Blue Class service with domed observation cars and private sleeping compartments. Through May 31, a one-way ticket with a sleeping compartment for three nights and all meals is $794, a person, double occupancy, at $1.34 Canadian to the United States dollar; this is a savings of about 37 percent. Tickets must be purchased at least seven days in advance; one stopover anywhere along the route is allowed at no extra cost. Fares on other routes are also being discounted. And through Feb. 28, passengers 60 or older get a 75 percent discount for their companions (of any age) and a 10 percent trim for themselves. Book at least 10 days ahead, asking for the Senior's Companion Fare. This deal is not available Dec. 15 to Jan. 5. For more information, call (888) 842-7245 or go to www.viarail.ca.

title: On the Market
description: 3-bedroom, 1-bath ranch with great room addition at 3105 Mattapan Avenue, $234,900.

title: Power to the Principals
description: Shakespeare, Einstein and the Bottom Line: The Marketing

title: Hoping to Scare Grownups Too
description: R.L. STINE, famous for his ''Goosebumps'' and ''Fear Street'' horror series, may have given more chills to more children than any author in history. But his audience has grown up, and Mr. Stine says he is ready to move on too, with his new novel, ''The Sitter,'' a horror story for adults.

title: Very Tired, Very Merry
description: WHEN a Staten Island ferryboat crashed into a pier and killed 10 passengers on Oct. 15, shock and sadness struck Landon Nordeman in an unusual way. Mr. Nordeman, a 29-year-old photographer whose work has appeared in National Geographic, developed an intense feeling for the ferry and its people as he captured it in a photo essay last year.

title: The World; Money, if Not Power
description: THE drama in Russia over the arrest of the billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky turns a spotlight on the small group of relatively young menthe so-called oligarchswho were allowed to grab enormous fortunes when Russia sold off Soviet state assets in the mid-1990s under President Boris Yeltsin. What they have not been allowed to do is use that wealth to mount any challenge to Mr. Putin, and their attempts to do so has sent some of them to prison, and others into exile. The rest mostly keep quiet. Here is a look at several oligarchs, and where they are now:

title: War, an Equal Opportunity Employer
description: FROM CHIVALRY

title: No-Tears Makeover: Ask First, Paint Second, Party Third
description: WHAT does a girl really want? If she's anything like Lynese Browder, an exuberant 17-year-old with a passion for creative dance and Lil' Kim, she wants the freedom to express herself -- in a room that reflects her personality.

title: Battling to Be Lord of the Dance
description: EVERY Wednesday and Saturday night, 27-year-old Claudia Spagnolo of Franklin Square went to Blu, the high-dollar, high-octane nightclub at the Garden City Hotel, to drink, dance, hang out with friends and meet people. But last year, a cavernous Egyptian-themed club called Mirage opened in Westbury and the see-and-be-seen crowd at Blu started to wither.

title: Private Sector; Picking Up the Marbles at Cinar
description: ARTHUR has become the world's most famous aardvark by encouraging children to solve life's problems by tolerating one another's differences. Michael Hirsh has applied the aardvark principle over the past three months to the bickering grown-ups at Cinar, the Canadian company that brings Arthur and his cuddly friends to life on television.

title: Ilana Tolins, Mitchell Frankel
description: Ilana Esther Tolins, a daughter of Edith and Paul Tolins of Port Washington, N.Y., was married last evening to Mitchell Darin Frankel, the son of Freda and Arthur Frankel of Plainview, N.Y. Rabbi Robert D. Block performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Shhh
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Leaders Party Holds On to Power in Vote
description: TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 10  Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's governing coalition held on to power in parliamentary elections on Sunday, even as voters handed big gains to the main opposition party in a ballot that could help lead Japan toward a two-party system.

title: Terrorism's Cost in a Global Economy
description: SINCE Sept. 11, 2001, the war on terrorism has been broadly portrayed as a phenomenon whose battlefronts range from Bali to Baghdad and whose successes and failures are measured in the bloodshed of suicide bombings or airplane attacks.

title: Reverse Mainstreaming; Very Special Ed
description: Far beyond the boundaries of this scrubby, sandy shore town, word is out about the public preschool here, and about how good it is supposed to be. Donna Grygiel, a former kindergarten teacher, moved her family out of their North Brunswick home and into her mother-in-law's house in Brick Township so her daughters could attend the school -- or at least have a shot at attending. Svetlana and Dmitri Mushkarova, a graphic designer and carpenter who moved from Brooklyn to Brick for a greener life and better schools, inspected 20 private preschools. But they pinned their hopes on their 3-year-old, Katya, coming out a winner in the annual lottery for spots in the public preschool.

title: U.S. Detains 18 for Attack That Came Close to Wolfowitz
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 9 — American forces have detained 18 people in connection with a rocket attack last month on the hotel where Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz stayed when he visited the country, a military spokesman said today.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 9, 2003
description: Weeks

title: The Web Isn't Always Up to the Minute
description: The Internet provides loads of information for consumers and businesses, quickly and often, but it is also littered with Web sites that are woefully out of date.

title: The Organizer
description: LOST PROPHET

title: The Week Ahead; JAPAN VOTES
description: Japanese will choose their next government in an election on Sunday. The Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is expected to retain power; a big victory would give him a mandate to push through economic and political reforms that some members of his own party have resisted.

title: You Can't Always Get What You Want
description: To the Editor:

title: Word of Mouth
description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Almost Famous
description: Like Elizabeth Bathory, the 16th-century Hungarian countess who bathed in the blood of virgins to maintain her dewy beauty, Hollywood thrives on young blood -- a regular transfusion that drives old-school cineastes to distraction and shopworn celebrities to the gym. Each year brings talk of the latest young masters of the Hollywood universe. Is Ashton the neo Leo? Are the Olsen Twins the new Pickford Sisters? The new luminaries photographed on these pages take their style as seriously as their Method. What's their motivation? To be ready for their close-up. Always.

title: Court Treatment System Is Found to Help Drug Offenders Stay Clean
description: Nonviolent drug offenders who complete judge-supervised treatment programs are significantly less likely to commit crimes again than those who serve prison time, according to a new study by an independent research arm of the New York State court system.

title: To Dote on Old Fans or Court New Ones?
description: TEN years ago it seemed as if professional basketball was poised to become a national sport. With pro football suffering from declining ratings and attendance, and Major League Baseball on the verge of a strike that would kill the 1994 World Series, the N.B.A., with Michael Jordan at the peak of his popularity, was ready to rule.

title: New C.I.A. Concerns On Korean Weapons
description: The C.I.A. has told Congress it now believes that North Korea has mastered the technology of turning its nuclear fuel into functioning weapons, without having to prove their effectiveness through nuclear tests.

title: Tuning In for a Morning Jolt
description: THEY are not like the rest of us.

title: Correction: Rights Fees for Sports
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about cable channels created by the National Basketball Association and the National Football League misstated the name of another professional sports organization, the PGA Tour; misstated the annual television revenue for Major League Baseball and Nascar; misidentified two of the networks that broadcast Major League Baseball games; and omitted one that broadcasts Nascar races. The chart also referred incompletely to the expiration of Major League Baseball's and Nascar's current TV deals. A corrected version of the affected part of the chart appears below.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 9, 2003
description: Weeks

title: Maggie Haberman, Dareh Gregorian
description: Maggie Lindsy Haberman, the daughter of Nancy Haberman and Clyde Haberman, both of Manhattan, is to be married today to Dareh Ardashes Gregorian, a son of Clare and Vartan Gregorian, also of Manhattan. Judge Edward R. Korman, the chief judge of the United States District Court in Brooklyn, is to officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Ex-Power Broker Says Downfall Saved Him

title: Galya Shalit, Mark Lodish
description: Dr. Galya Shalit, a daughter of Mary L. Shalit and Dr. Maish N. Shalit of Houston, was married last evening to Mark David Lodish, the son of Carolyn W. Lodish and Dr. Jules R. Lodish of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Joseph R. Radinsky officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Michelle Gerstle, Matthew Dresser
description: Michelle Janeen Gerstle, the daughter of Donna and Michael Gerstle of Randall Manor, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Matthew Sheldon Dresser, the son of Sandra and Donald Dresser of Panama City, Fla. The Rev. John DeLora, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Worst Roads in the State? That's an Essay Question
description: Hold an election for state Senate and you can't drag people to the polls. But ask people to vote on their most hated highways and the votes pour in like speeders on the Turnpike.

title: I'm NOT Going To Pay a Lot For This Education
description: Parents no longer need to hear how expensive college is. They get it. What they may not get is what they can do about it. Many parents, probably resigned to their fate, don't even fill out the financial aid application. They won't qualify anyway -- why bother?

title: Of Tooth And Claw: A Kitten Gets Mugged
description: GRISA was born like a crack baby under the stoop of a Harlem brownstone, progeny of a stray feline who got around, as the neighbors liked to say. Who knew what neurological or psychological problems might lurk under that filthy, matted, flea-infested fur? But after a baby-shampoo bath in the kitchen sink, she came out looking kind of cute, with milk-blue eyes and gray-and-black tiger stripes.

title: The Chicago Way
description: In the movie ''The Untouchables,'' Sean Connery, a cop named Malone, instructs a nave Eliot Ness on going up against gangsters.

title: Article 2003110993637173229 -- No Title
description: DRILLING DOWN/CELLPHONES

title: Jennifer Lobo, George Plamondon III
description: Jennifer Jean Lobo and George Lawrence Plamondon III were married by the Rev. Anthony Ottey, an Anglican priest, yesterday at the Round Hill Hotel and Villas in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: Diantha Wilson, Dorn Redd Jr.
description: Diantha Curtis Wilson, a daughter of Eve-Ann and James Reid Wilson Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Dorn Lee Redd Jr., a son of Marylew Redd of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Redd. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Islanders Impressed With Their Fast Start
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 7  How good are these guys? The Islanders' start has been fast enough to raise the question.

title: A Bull's-Eye Of a Book
description: For holiday wine buying, ''Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine Book'' (Mitchell Beazley, 2004) is vital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, HASKELL M.
description: BLOCK--Haskell M. 80, of New York City, died November 7, 2003, after a long illness. A graduate of the University of Chicago, Harvard University and the University of Paris, he was the author of many books and articles on comparative literature and a veteran of WWII. He gave a lifetime of service to New York City and State. He was retired from SUNY - Binghampton and previously taught at Brooklyn College, The University of Wisconsin, Queens College and established the Graduate Program in Comparative Literature at the CUNY Graduate Center. He received Fulbright Fellowships to teach at the University of Cologne and the University of Dusseldorf. He was a past President of the American Comparative Literature Association and served on the Board of the Modern Language Association and the International Comparative Literature Association. He is remembered fondly by many students and colleagues. Beloved son of the late Abraham Block, the late Edith Hymen and brother of the late Marilyn Margules of Chicago. He is survived by his sister Helene Lome of Chicago, his daughter Laurie and son-inlaw Jerry Spigel of Riverdale, his daughter Linda of Brooklyn, and his son Randall, daughter-in-law Karen Davis of Newton, MA, and his grandchildren Kalman, Solomon, Jeffrey, Peter and Kaley. Services will be held on Monday, November 10. Please call 212-362-6600 for time and location of service.

title: The Mysterious World of Mutual Fund Costs
description: THE mutual fund scandals provide a reminder that shareholders are routinely charged for costs that they know little or nothing about.

title: Alexandra Crain, James Armstrong
description: Alexandra Terry Crain, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Keith E. Crain of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married yesterday at the Windsor Club, a resort in Vero Beach, Fla., to James Robert Armstrong, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Graham C. Armstrong of Mooi River, South Africa. The Rev. Charles W. Bowman, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated with Simon Barnes, a friend of the bride's family, who is the executive director of the Fellowship of Christians in Universities and Schools of Charlottesville, Va.

title: Endpaper; The Age of Reasons
description: Shortly after entering his sophomore year in high school, my 16-year-old son began talking about attending college in Philadelphia. This warmed the cockles of my heart, as I am a native of the City of Brotherly Love and a graduate of St. Joseph's, a venerable Jesuit university. Moreover, because Philadelphia is only 130 miles from my home in Tarrytown, N.Y., Gordon's enrollment would allow me to keep my eye on him. Frankly, I never trusted the kid.

title: Stephanie Vautravers and Conon Green
description: ON the Monday night of Presidents' Day weekend this year, when a snowstorm piled huge drifts along the streets of Manhattan, people passing the subway station at Canal and Varick Streets might have noticed an odd sight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about the current film ''The Singing Detective'' misidentified the theme song of the British mini-series on which it is based. It was ''Peg o' My Heart,'' not ''After You've Gone.''

title: Dewey Defeats Truman. Madden Defeats Geist.
description: While the vote totals were coming in Tuesday night at Fred Madden's campaign headquarters in Gloucester County, the Democratic Senate candidate was out of the gate fast. What he said was not surprising: ''You believed in me, and I'm going to take that belief to Trenton.'' But his timing startled even some campaign advisers.

title: Editorial Observer; What World War I's Greatest Poet Would Say About Hiding Our War Dead
description: When World War I broke out, the English saw going off to battle as a fine thing to do. They embraced the Latin poet Horace's dictum, ''Dulce et decorum est, pro patria mori'' -- It is sweet and proper to die for one's country. But four years later, that romantic notion had been shattered by the grim reality of the mustard-gas-laced killing fields, and by the bitter words of Wilfred Owen, a British officer now recognized as the greatest poet of the Great War. Owen reported from the battlefields of France that, contrary to the prettified accounts being served up, the war he witnessed was full of blood ''gargling'' up from ''froth-corrupted lungs'' and ''vile, incurable sores on innocent tongues.''

title: McNair's Air Game Is Solidly Grounded
description: A recent bye week for the Tennessee Titans offered one player an escape to Los Angeles, two players festive spins through New York City's dance clubs and several others entertaining visits to cities in between.

title: Kill Bills: The Cost of Living
description: Timothy DALY wants to be president. Seriously. As a 22-year-old senior majoring in economics at the University of Maryland at College Park, he admits he has a long way to go. But he has already built a reputation as student body president, beating the drum for what he calls the injustice of tuition increases. ''The governor was in the Bahamas when his staff announced that an additional $60 million in cuts would be made to the university,'' he says, ''so we created a character named Bahama Bobby Ehrlich.'' Mr. Daly (above, driving) dressed as a Secret Service agent, a friend donned a wig and they toured the campus in a golf cart shouting, 'I'm Bahama Bob, I'm going to raise your tuition.'''

title: Immigrant Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankrupt. Who Pays?
description: IN the final days at Workbench on Route 17 here, the store was as spare as the sleek, modern furniture it sold.

title: A Move Toward The Middle
description: DEMOCRATS in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were jubilant over their victories at the polls on Tuesday and boldly declared that Long Island's days as a staunch Republican stronghold are over. But the voters also gave Republicans some things to crow about, suggesting that rather than replacing one party's domination for another's, the trend is toward a vigorous, competitive two-party system.

title: Drawn to Narrative
description: Nearly everywhere he goes, Tim Burton carries a pocket-size sketchbook and a small watercolor kit. Even when he's directing movies like ''Beetlejuice,'' ''Batman'' and ''Big Fish,'' his latest film, which opens in New York on Dec. 10, he is always drawing. He'll walk to a pub in Camden Town, near his home in London, and sit at the bar and sketch a woman as she flirts or conjure a tiny child. His artwork, like his movies, is a combination of the beautiful and the strange. In Burton's rendering, the flirting woman will end up looking rather like an alien and the tiny child will have long needles in his eyes. And yet there is a pervasive sweetness in Burton's work that tempers the ghoulishness. He favors his misfits, especially if, as he has imagined, they have clamshells for heads or their bodies resemble pincushions.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 10
description: Tampa Bay Buccaneers (4-4) at Carolina Panthers (6-2)

title: Living Large, and Never Thirsty
description: A RECENT study links higher levels of obesity to sprawling suburbs. Acid-tongued commentators who are always eager to poke fun at us suburbanites have seized on the notion that the extra pounds we tote around here where the grass is greener are due to our more sedentary lifestyle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BYRNE, SANDRA M.
description: BYRNE--Sandra M. 9/26/68-10/26/03. Beloved mother of Ryan W. Byrne, age 31/2, and Jack E. Byrne, age 11/2. Devoted wife to Terence F. Byrne. Survived by mother Fong Yuk Eng and father Hon Yue Eng, and sister Cindy Eng, brothers Norman and Gary Eng. Sandy was born in Hong Kong and moved to Chinatown, NYC, as a baby. The family moved to Vernon, CT when she was 7 years old. She attended middle school there and graduated from Rockville HS in 1986. She received a BA in Economics at Rutgers College and graduated in 1990; there she met her husband. They lived in NYC for 13 years. Sandy enjoyed a successful career in banking and foreign exchange. Most recently she was VP for Standard Chartered. She breathed life and joy into everyone she met. She truly was a special person. She will be deeply missed but her spirit will live on. God bless.

title: Police Find Abducted Queens Boy on L.I.
description: The police on Long Island found a 2-year-old boy early this morning after he had been abducted hours earlier on a busy Queens street by a thief who took the mother's car, the authorities said.

title: Senators on Intelligence Panel Clash on Talk Show
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9  The Republican chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee and a senior Democratic member of the panel clashed in unusually sharp and public ways today in a dispute that has interrupted the committee's review of prewar intelligence on Iraq.

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; From One Book Report
description: My most memorable piece of homework was my first fifth-grade book report. I thought it was crazy to give a fifth-grader a book report in September! I had a partner to do it with, though. And we made a list of the things we could do along with a written or typed report. We chose to type up an essay and make a puppet show on our book.

title: The Nation: Who Knew?; It's Not Just the Media. These Days, Everybody's Biased.
description: PRESIDENT BUSH asserts that a media ''filter'' is keeping out the good news from Iraq; conservatives denounce the liberal bias of the CBS mini-series on Ronald Reagan; a Columbus, Ohio, sportswriter blames ''East Coast media bias'' for an Associated Press college football poll that ranked the Hokies of Virginia Tech over the Ohio State Buckeyes. Today people pronounce ''media bias'' as if it were a single word.

title: Lawmakers Push Costs Of Tax Cuts Out of Sight
description: PERHAPS it is time for Congress to pass a Truth-in-Advertising Act for tax cuts.

title: College Prep
description: Ephraim PI, a junior at Rye High School, was sniffling and coughing so much that his mother let him skip school. He was not, however, allowed to miss his SAT prep class that evening. It was the final review for the verbal section. But in the haze of his illness, 16-year-old Ephraim brought his math review book by mistake.

title: The Nation: Food Fight; Is Obesity the Responsibility of the Body Politic?
description: IN what is shaping up to be the great American food fight, there are two increasingly discordant sides.

title: POSTINGS: Summit, N.J., Mill Envisioned as Offices; Putting a New Spin On 1906 Silk Factory
description: A dozen bidders competed last summer to to buy an old silk mill in Summit, N.J. Some wanted to demolish the building and build anew on its site. A few companies wanted to transform it into modern offices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYO, YETTA
description: MAYO--Yetta. It is with profound sorrow that the BMP mourns the loss of our longtime member, Yetta Mayo. Heartfelt coldolences to Jeffrey and his family. Andrew Friedman, President

description: VERNON GOD LITTLE

title: The Week Ahead; TRAPPED IN D.C.
description: Members of Congress are hoping to begin their vacation by Thanksgiving, but bitter partisan disputes are putting that deadline in doubt. On Wednesday, Republican senators plan to lead 30 hours of debate to protest Democratic filibusters against four of President Bush's judicial nominees. Appropriations bills are moving so slowly that Republican leaders may roll the remaining measures into a catchall bill. David Firestone

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; It's More Than a Smile
description: The best homework I ever had came to me about two weeks ago. At the end of my dance class in school my teacher gave us some homework. We had to do something nice and generous for someone with or without them knowing.

title: Enlightened Occupiers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Is Always Believing
description: If CBS News were to come on the air tonight and announce that former Presidents Bill Clinton and George H. W. Bush had said things they never said -- expressing contempt, say, for their wives or proposing war against Iran -- it would take only minutes before everyone involved with the fiction was thrown out the door.

description: To the Editor:

title: Thanks, Harry Potter. Were Readers Now. (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lindros's Return Can't Revive Rangers
description: Even with Eric Lindros back in the lineup at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the Rangers' power play was nonexistent again.

title: The Alien Archipelago in Gehry's Hall

title: Many Story Lines, but Campbell's 61 Is the Story

title: Bridge-and-Tunnel Crowd Moves In
description: IT is somewhat unusual these days for a serious play to move from a noncommercial regional theater to Broadway, where most producers are unwilling to take a risk on productions other than splashy musicals or shows that originated in London. But that is exactly where ''Anna in the Tropics,'' an old-fashioned love story set in a Cuban-American cigar factory in Florida, was headed after it closed its six-week run at Princeton's McCarter Theater Center last month. Winner of this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama, the play, by Nilo Cruz, began previews last week at the Royale Theater on West 45th Street in New York City; it opens next Sunday.

title: The Fed's Election Year Problem
description: Alan Greenspan may be in for a rough election. Indeed, if you ran the Federal Reserve, you'd probably just want to take off every fourth year. A presidential campaign can be an awkward time for the nation's independent central banker, who has more power to influence the economy quickly than any single branch of government, even though it is the president who gets the lion's share of credit or blame for how things are going.

title: Have You Heard the New Neil Young Novel?
description: REAL Neil Young loyalists will buy a new record just because they feel like they owe him the money. But until now, his forays into extended narrative (the films ''Journey Through the Past'' and ''Human Highway'') made most of his audience temporarily jump ship. With ''Greendale,'' loyalty pays off: what comes out of the jewel-box is a completely viable artifact, on the basis of the audio disc and accompanying booklet alone. The bonus DVD, featuring a solo live performance of the same basic material that's presented on the audio disc and in print, is nice but redundant. Better to consume this product by treating it as a hybrid between a printed work and a book-on-tape -- to read it as one reads a novel, because in fact that's what it is. Mr. Young has always been remarkable for his creative resilience, and this time he really has done something new, rendering into this combination of print and audio a novel that is surprisingly sophisticated and satisfyingly complete.

title: Face-Off

title: Lottery Numbers
Elliot Smith's Legacy and Pink's Big Idea
description: DOLOREAN -- This is the legacy of the late Elliott Smith: a generation of indie-rock songwriters, not much younger than he was, using their own ramshackle voices to sing their own stories of creeping sadness and fleeting joy. Alex James leads Dolorean, a band based in Portland, Ore., that began recording its beautiful debut album, ''Not Exotic,'' almost two years ago. (At first, the band distributed the disc on its own; last Tuesday, the independent label Yep Roc released the album nationwide.) The songs gesture at folk and country, but they do it quietly and slowly, as if hesitant to disturb Mr. James's delicate parables. And yet, despite the stillness, this is a wild, passionate album -- loves and lovers die, not always by accident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARNES, DR. JAMES H., JR.
description: STARNES--Dr. James H., Jr. Age 64 of Yorktown, VA died October 27, 2003. He is survived by wife, Sue Starnes; daughter, Susan Katherine Starnes; son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Starnes, III; sister, Ruth Ann Rodgers Lumpkin; brother, Dr. Joseph W. Starnes. He served in the U.S. Navy, received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Engineering Mechanics from Georgia Tech and his PhD in Aeronautics from the California Institute of Technology. Dr. Starnes was the Chief Engineer for Structures & Materials at NASA Langley Research Center, where his career spanned 33 years. He was internationally recognized as an expert in the field of aerospace structures. His contributions can be seen on every aircraft that flies today. Many regarded him as the preeminent composite structures technology expert in the Nation and a national resource. He contributed directly to NASA investigations for the Space Shuttles Challenger and Columbia accidents and the International Space Station. He was also a technical advisor for other government agencies, industry and universities and represented NASA in the NATO Research and Technology Organization. He lead NASA's efforts on the National Transportation Safety Board's Failure Investigation of American Airlines Flight 587. He was awarded NASA's Exceptional Engineering Achievement Medal. He was a Fellow in the American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics, the American Society for Composites, and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and a member of the Georgia Tech Academy of Distinguished Engineering Alumni. Dr. Starnes' legacy to aerospace technology is monumental. His colleagues expressed: ''Dr. Starnes is greatly remembered at NASA for his dedication to the agency, exemplary service, and positive attitude. He was recognized by his employees as an exceptional supervisor, mentor, and technical leader. He routinely demonstrated great technical breadth and depth, enthusiasm, and a willingness to listen. In addition, Dr. Starnes was masterful at motivating his employees to make contributions that far exceeded their own expectations. He gained the respect of everyone whose life he touched and profoundly influenced the careers and lives of many.'' Tom M. Wages Funeral Service, Inc., Snellville, GA 770/979-3200.

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Dreading 'Essay E'
description: When I was in ninth grade at Great Neck South Junior High School in 1976, I had the good fortune of having an amazing English Honors teacher, Isabelle Jacques. We had no idea how old she was, but we were all sure she was really really old. In addition to wonderfully useful vocabulary words (myriad, esoteric, redundant -- why do I remember these?) and tireless efforts to teach us the proper use of pronouns (''give the book to Valerie and me''), she assigned us a Herculean packet on Greek mythology. We spend a lot of time on Edith Hamilton's ''Greek Mythology'' and had to work through the booklet, which contained various assignments until we got to the dreaded ''Essay E.''

title: Intelligence in War
description: o war can be conducted successfully without early and good intelligence," wrote the great Duke of Marlborough. George Washington agreed: "The necessity of procuring good intelligence is apparent and need not be further argued." No sensible soldier or sailor or airman does argue. From the earliest times, military leaders have always sought information of the enemy, his strengths, his weaknesses, his intentions, his dispositions. Alexander the Great, presiding at the Macedonian court as a boy while his father, Philip, was absent on campaign, was remembered by visitors from thelands he would later conquer for his persistence in questioning them about the size of the population of their territory, the productiveness of the soil, the course of the routes and rivers that crossed it, the location of its towns, harbours and strong places, the identity of the important men. The young Alexander was assembling what today would be called economic, regional or strategic intelligence, and the knowledge he accumulated served him well when he began his invasion of the Persian empire, enormous in extent and widely diverse in composition. Alexander triumphed because he brought to his battlefields a ferocious fighting force of tribal warriors personally devoted to the Macedonian monarchy; but he also picked the Persian empire to pieces, attacking at its weak points and exploiting its internal divisions.

description: ROSENBERG--Michael L., 56. October 11, 2003. The Board of Directors of the Sunny and Abe Rosenberg Foundation mourn the passing of Michael L. Goldstein and fellow Director, Robert Gassman. The Foundation has created the Michael L. Rosenberg Memorial Fund to honor his passion for the Arts. The funeral was held in Dallas, Texas on Wednesday, October 15, 2003. A private memorial service was held on Sunday, November 2, 2003 for family and friends in New York City. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETITT, DONALD
description: PETITT--Donald. Industrial designer, died in NY after a long illness. He is survived by his wife Sara and daughter Victoria. Petitt served in WWII. After attending the Institute of Design in Chicago, he worked with designers Harry Bertoia, Eero Saarinen and George Nelson. He then went on to design his own line of furniture for Knoll including the Petitt Chair, as well as major furniture collections for SunarHauserman, Thonet and Cadsana. His furniture has been in exhibitions at the Louvre, the Bauhaus archive in Berlin, and the Philadelphia Art Institute.
