description: FOR some, wigs represent a commitment to a religious tradition, or an ethnic heritage. For many others, stricken by illness, hairpieces are a lifeline to a normal life. And, less seriously, they can be a fun fashion accessory or a nifty addition to a masquerade costume.

title: A Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Back Into the Cold: The Return of the Spy
description: IN ''Intelligence in War'' (Knopf, 2003), the military historian John Keegan says terrorist groups like Al Qaeda are part of the long struggle between ''western Christendom and the Islamic world,'' and he describes the spies needed to fight the enemy. ''In the last resort,'' he writes, ''attacks on Al Qaeda and other fundamentalist networks will be made successful only by recourse to the oldest of all intelligence methods, direct and personal counterespionage.''

title: Crib Notes From the Underground
description: EVEN after waiting outside in an insistent wind for more than two hours, Jeffrey Babbitt was eager to talk to strangers about the first time he drove a New York City subway train. It was in the early 50's, on one of the old low-voltage IRT expresses, and the motorman let him work the controls from Franklin Avenue to Borough Hall in Brooklyn, or maybe even all the way up Lexington Avenue and into the Bronx. He couldn't remember exactly; he was only 3 at the time.

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; Now That's Unusual
description: My quirky eighth-grade English teacher (somewhere in the 1960's) assigned the class to try and find examples of people who had unusual jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODIE, SHELDON J.
description: BRODIE--Sheldon J., M.D. The faculty and staff of the NYU Medical Center Skin & Cancer Unit and the Ronald O. Perelman Department of Dermatology sadly mourn the loss of Sheldon Brodie on October 29, 2003. A wonderfully member of our faculty for over 40 years, Dr. Brodie served as Chief of the Tuesday Service for decades. Our condolences to his wife Charlotte, his children, and his grandchildren. Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D. MacKee Professor & Chair

title: The Ivy League Degree
description: To the Editor:

title: Philanthropy; Picture This: Your Name on a . . . Flowerpot
description: Campus immortality is not just for millionaire benefactors. Faced with budget cuts and only so many plaque-ready benches, development offices are giving donors of all levels the chance to leave a legacy on campus. Donor names can now be found on everything from flowerpots and library books to elevators and lab equipment. Some colleges that have embraced the trend:

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Tribes Now Ready to Deal With Their New Governor
description: The Viejas Band of Kumeyaay Indians, which operates a lucrative casino on its reservation here east of San Diego, spent $2 million of its gambling earnings trying to keep Arnold Schwarzenegger out of the governor's office.

title: Corrections
description: A 1910 photograph with the Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the construction of a mansion at 84th Street and Fifth Avenue, carried an incorrect credit. It was from the New-York Historical Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, JANE TRAFFORD LUKE
description: MURPHY -- Jane Trafford Luke. Died on Wednesday, November 5, 2003, from complications from Lupus. She is lovingly remembered by her friends and family for her courageous battle with the disease, and for her generous spirit. Born October 17, 1953 in Charleston, S.C., Jane earned a B.S. from Briarcliff College and her R.N. from Pace University. A devoted mother to her two sons, Jane was an active volunteer at Greens Farms Academy, and she was a member of the Women's Fellowship at Trinity Church. Jane is survived by her husband, Jonathan J. Murphy, two sons, J. Luke Murphy and Gordon T. Murphy, all of Fairfield, CT.; her parents, Joy and John A. Luke, Sr., a brother John A. Luke, Jr., and a sister, Hope L. Hetherington, all of New Canaan, CT.; a brother William H. Luke of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Southport, CT on Tuesday, November 11th, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Jane's memory to the Lupus Research Institute, 149 Madison Ave, Suite 205, N.Y., N.Y. 10016

title: Life for Aerial White Elephant
description: AN airplane meriting chapters in two books entitled ''The World's Worst Planes'' would seem unworthy of all the fuss. But such is the determination of a group of volunteers at the Cradle of Aviation Museum to preserve Long Island's aviation history that building the plane from scratch seems not only reasonable but imperative.

title: Big, Loud Clubs Seek New Glitter
description: ''I DIDN'T invite her,'' said Eve Salvail, a model with a dragon tattoo on the side of her head, who gets $500 to linger a few hours and look cool at Avalon, the latest incarnation of the Episcopal church in Chelsea once known as Limelight.

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; Location Is Everything
description: Islets of Langerhans: the irregular microscopic masses of cells that constitute the endocrine pancreas. Little did I think the term s would remain such a vivid memory 34 years after Mrs. William's homework assignment in the fourth grade.

title: Too Many Times Square Tourists? Can I Get Back to You on That?
description: Every day, throngs of people traverse oceans and cross mountains just to stand in Times Square and bask in its neon glow. Sabine Rothman, an editor at House and Garden magazine, is not among them.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE HIDDEN MODEL

title: Jillian Berman, Daniel Tvenge
description: Jillian Adele Berman and Daniel Richard Tvenge were married last evening by the Rev. Nancy Weber, an interfaith minister, at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: The Dueling Prosecutors: Dillon Criticizes Spota
description: Denis Dillon, Nassau County's district attorney, has taken Thomas J. Spota to task for releasing a grand jury report a year ago detailing cases of sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests in the Diocese of Rockville Centre.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SPECIAL

title: The Studio-Indie, Pop-Prestige, Art-Commerce King
description: In the second half of Jean-Luc Godard's ''In Praise of Love,'' a very tall African-American woman in a red sports car arrives at the home of an elderly French couple, veterans of the anti-Nazi resistance who need an infusion of cash to keep their small seaside hotel in business. The visitor and her colleagues are interested in purchasing the rights to the couple's life story on behalf of an outfit called ''Steven Spielberg Associates and Incorporated.'' This curiously named company's motives are summed up in a classic Old European canard: since Americans have no history of their own, someone observes, they are compelled to go around buying that of other people. At the news conference following the film's screening at the 2001 Cannes Film Festival, a journalist asked Godard what he had against Steven Spielberg. Of course it was nothing personal, Godard replied, and in any case a proper answer would require a detailed, shot-by-shot analysis of Spielberg's movies, for which there was, alas, insufficient time.

title: At 5-5, Boykins Has Overcome Big Obstacles
description: It had been a rough night for the young Earl Boykins. A few of his ill-timed errors in a recreation-league basketball game had cost his and his father's team a victory. Never mind that at 12, he was the only preteen in the mostly adult league, or that he was well below 5 feet tall. None of that mattered to Willie Williams, who scolded his son harshly.

title: Duck Hunters Face New Menace: People
description: JANUARY'S meager sun had yet to cast its light on Mount Sinai Harbor, but Ed Hessler was ready. Dressed in camouflage and with a shotgun perched on his shoulder, he crouched 100 feet from shore on a floating blind festooned with grass and waited for the mallards and black ducks that are the Long Island duck hunter's principal quarry. By day's end he had one of each.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Drug Industry's Holy Grail
description: IF the drug industry has a commercial Holy Grail, it might be an anti-aging pill, one that would let you live longer and prolong your youthful vigor. The market would be huge, of course. The problem is that to get it approved by the Food and Drug Administration, researchers would have to find a way to demonstrate that it works.

title: Too Big a Man for the Small Screen
description: The sweetness, silvery voice and deceptively gentle manner of Ronald Reagan used to remind me of the soft fur that enwraps stored phosphorus. He seemed so easy to bruise that your instinct was to protect him from anything sharp, in way of questions, criticisms, legal process or just plain discourtesy. But beneath the softness was solid metal: a moral and political philosophy of considerable mass, formed over half a century, and (like phosphorus) capable of bursting into sudden flame.

title: Stronger Canadian Dollar Weakens Tourism
description: With the Canadian dollar at its strongest in nearly a decade, visiting Canada has become less of a bargain for travelers from the United States. Until recently, Americans could count on highly favorable exchange rates; in 2002, for example, one United States dollar bought an average of $1.57 Canadian. At the start of November, the typical credit card rate was about $1.34. (Put the other way, the Canadian dollar was worth 64 U.S. cents in 2002 but is worth about 77 cents now.)

title: Four Legs and Flies
description: HORSE PEOPLE

title: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall
description: IF ever there has been someone who knows how to recreate her image through the decades, it is Madonna.

title: Amtrak Publishes Nationwide Schedule
description: For the first time since 1992, Amtrak has published a schedule for the entire railroad, from the Downeaster, which runs between Boston and Portland, Me., to the Pacific Surfliner, linking Paso Robles, Calif., and San Diego.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Father's Dream: Seeing His Son Walk
description: August Marziliano is clear about his hopes for his 7-year-old son Antonio, who was born with cerebral palsy and now relies on a wheelchair. ''I would like to see him walk,'' he said. ''That's the biggest thing, if I ever saw him walk ----''

title: 4 Starved Boys Growing, But Harm May Be Lasting
description: Weeks after Bruce Jackson was found rummaging for food in a neighbor's garbage in Collingswood, N.J., the facts about his health and medical history remain elusive.

title: Almost Heaven
description: The soldiers protecting Eileen Collins and her crew in July 1999 are a reminder that, though civilian since its birth in 1958, NASA is a Cold War legacy. Created by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in direct response to the launch of the Soviet satellite Sputnik , NASA has always projected a military aura. This was probably inevitable, for though deliberately civilian and dedicated to peaceful exploration, many of its early leaders were military men. Their culture, not surprisingly, shaped much of the agency's attitude toward women, especially in the early years.

title: Encounter With Prehistory
description: WHAT slender thread of hope we had last year for being granted permission to visit the Altamira caves, the stunning 15,000-year-old painted document to human creativity in northern Spain near Bilbao, snapped 10 days before we arrived. At the beginning of September the Spanish government suddenly announced that it was closing the caves for at least two years.

title: Playoff Plan Needs Thought
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: After School, Lessons Learned; Radio Daze
description: I was a media studies major in the 1970's at Sacred Heart University. The assignment was a radio play for my Introduction to Radio class. The good ones would be broadcast on student-run station.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11.9.03; What They Were Thinking
description: Dean Tavoularis on the set of the film 'One From the Heart,' Hollywood, Calif., 1982

title: S.U.V.'s and Their Parking Lead to Loss of a Life
description: I had been reading with some amusement the article [''In Great Neck, New Front in S.U.V. War,'' Oct. 12] and ensuing letters regarding S.U.V.'s and parking in Great Neck Plaza. Last Saturday night that all changed.

title: Vibrant Flavors at New Italian
description: MIO is a riot of sunflowers. The new Roslyn Italian is aglow with them: a sturdy one on every table, others suspended in hanging vases, and in bouquets found on the bar and in front of the open kitchen. There are also framed paintings of sunflowers and a metal wall sculpture of a radiant sun. The rest of the dcor is a backdrop: carpeting, beige walls, whirling fans near the deep blue ceiling and a room-spanning banquette in a dark, muted print.

title: Mary Patten, Paul Rice
description: Mary Catherine Patten, a pediatric nurse practitioner, and Paul Gregory Rice, a police officer, were married yesterday. Msgr. Kenneth Lasch performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Mendham, N.J.

title: Amy Novesky, ND Koster
description: Amy Novesky and ND Koster were married yesterday by Ema Drouillard, a minister of the Universal Life Church, at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, Calif.

title: Workers Sensed Danger Before Collapse of Parking Garage
description: They are construction workers, not engineers or safety experts. But George Tolson, Norman Williams and John Pietrosante Jr. found themselves focusing on a common thought: something unsafe or at least unsettling was going on as they rushed to complete a $245 million expansion of the Tropicana Casino and Resort.

title: Article 2003110990539396316 -- No Title
description: if (document.layers) { document.write(" "); } else { document.write(" "); } Journal: var google_hints = "";

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; Project Panda, Actually Fun
description: I would much rather say ''I hate all of my assignments'' and leave it at that. But since this is supposed to be about our best or worst assignment, I may as well be positive and tell you about my best one.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: As a stay-at-home mom with a Ph.D. in economics from Yale, I suppose I should relate to the women depicted in Belkin's article. But rather than rationalize my choice to opt out by patting myself on the back and saying I am smarter for doing so, I am filled with many worries. What kind of role model am I being for my children, especially my daughter? What happens in a few years when I wish to re-enter the work force? Is it really a ''choice'' to stay at home or rather a lack of options from which to choose?

title: The Week Ahead; IN GUATEMALA, A RETURN?
description: Guatemala, still wounded from three decades of civil war, holds presidential elections on Sunday. By Monday, it should be clear whether Efran Ros Montt can return to power. Mr. Ros Montt is a former general and evangelical minister, and 22 years ago he seized power in a coup. His brief rule was vicious; tens of thousands of peasants were killed and hundreds of villages razed as the army carried out a scorched-earth war against a small band of leftist guerrillas. Guatemala today is riven by criminal gangs -- many of them former soldiers -- and Mr. Ros Montt promises an iron hand against them. Tim Weiner

title: The Nation; What You Say Can't Hurt You Until It Can
description: FOR all the hoopla last week over Howard Dean's musings about the Confederate flag, they should not have come as a surprise. He made similar comments as far back as February, at a national meeting of the Democratic Party. That was not even the first time. At event after event, countless reporters, party stalwarts and even Dr. Dean's rivals in the presidential campaign had heard him say he hoped to draw support from Southerners who display that flag.

title: Executive Life; Was He Disloyal? Millions at Stake
description: EXECUTIVES assigned to serve on the boards of outside companies often receive options or other compensation for their work. It is a tidy arrangement that usually receives little scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLEMENT, CONSTANCE
description: CLEMENT -- Constance Chambers of New Haven, CT. on November 4, 2003. Widow of David Hale Clement and mother of Constance (Cecie). Services and interment private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Whitney Center Health Center, 200 Leeder Hill Drive, Hamden, CT. 06517, or to a charity of ones choice.

title: No One's Humming
description: To the Editor:

title: Homework Defined: Best and Worst; If You Take a Long View
description: I spent one eternal hellish year -- ninth grade -- in private high school. A straight-A student, I was always plagued by science. It didn't come naturally to me and I would stare for hours at the periodic table or at chemistry formulas as if they were written in Urdu. After a torturous two hours of plowing through a particularly difficult homework assignment, I came downstairs in total panic, sobbing hysterically.

title: Toasty Coats to Melt the Ice
description: After the bitter cold of last winter, shoppers are choosing coats that offer plenty of warmth along with style.

title: Betting on a Chancy Thing, An Adult's Music Magazine
description: Creating an independently financed magazine is always a perilous activity, but the endeavor takes on more foolhardy dimensions when the publication is aimed at music fans.

title: 4 Highest-Paid University Presidents Top $800,000 a Year
description: Four presidents of private universities were paid more than $800,000 last year, and the era of the million-dollar college president is fast approaching, according to an annual survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: U.S. Moves to Block Money For Troops Held in '91 War
description: The Bush administration is seeking to block a group of American troops who were tortured in Iraqi prisons during the Persian Gulf war in 1991 from collecting any of the hundreds of millions of dollars in frozen Iraqi assets they won last summer in a federal court ruling against the government of Saddam Hussein.

title: The Experts Respond
description: Following are e-mail excerpts from experts in the field across the country, who responded on how the brain works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAFTALI, RAYMOND
description: NAFTALI -- Raymond. No vember 7, 2003. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Nicole. Cherished grandfather of Anthony. He was a deeply respected and admired man who enjoyed life with his family and friends to the fullest. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Monday, 7-9 PM, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with a service at Frank E. Campbell Wednesday, November 12, 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, HELEN REISER
description: MILLER--Helen Reiser, 94, wife of the late Dr. Theodore R. Miller, died Sunday, November 2, at home. Longtime residents of NYC, the Millers retired to NJ in 1975. Mrs. Miller was a volunteer Braille transcriber for the Lighthouse, a patron member of Mu Phi Epsilon, a member of the P.E.O. Sisterhood, served on the Board of the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women in NY, and a Board Secretary of Vellore Christian Medical College in India. An accomplished pianist, she studied at Juilliard School of Music. Surviving are Iona Pickering and Ludvig zur Neiden, cousins, and Dr. William H. Miller, brother-in-law. Memorial service 1:30 pm, Saturday, November 15, at the auditorium at Monroe Village, Half Acre Rd., Monroe Twp., NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Presbyterian Homes of NJ Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAUBES, FRANK
description: TAUBES--Frank. Of Greenwich, CT, and Longboat Key, FL, died on November 7, 2003. Beloved husband of Laura, loving father of Leslie Martin, Lisa Turzilli, Timothy Taubes, Christopher Taubes. Also survived by eight grandchildren. He will be missed and remembered for his brilliant mind, his zest for life, his enduring and indomitable spirit and his keen sense of humor. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, November 12, 2003, at 10 AM, in the Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home, 267 Greenwich Ave., Greenwich, CT. Contributions may be made to Muscular Dystrophy Association, 7 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, NY 10532.

title: E-Commerce Report; Sports teams have discovered that they can put more spectators in the seats through online ticket sales.
description: AS last week's earnings report from InterActiveCorp indicated, the growth of online ticket sales continues unabated. More than half of the $1.1 billion worth of tickets sold by the company's Ticketmaster division in the third quarter were bought online, reducing Ticketmaster's reliance on more capital-intensive sales channels like ticket outlets and telephone banks.

title: Wireless and Restless
description: Which cellular phone companies will best survive P-day?

title: New Deal for CBS and U.S. Open
description: CBS Sports yesterday extended its contract to carry the United States Open through 2008 and agreed to carry at least four summer events leading into the tournament. Although the agreement runs through 2008, the U.S.T.A. can opt out of it after 2006.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINSIER, JOAN TUBY
description: WEINSIER--Joan Tuby. It's so hard without your wondrous presence! Four years seems like forever, yet our love will never die. Evelyn, Phil, Michael, Wend

title: After Retirement, Clark Has Forged a Lucrative Career
description: When Wesley K. Clark retired from the military three years ago and was building a new career, one of the first people he called was Richard C. Holbrooke, the former United Nations envoy.

title: Construction Delays and Vandalism Mar a New College Dorm
description: The inside of the Lazarus I. Levine Residence Hall at Sullivan County Community College resembles many dormitories: cinder blocks, fluorescent lighting and the thump of hip-hop music.

title: It's All Going Wrong For Raiders and Rice
description: Raiders wide receiver Jerry Rice did not wait for the first question. He knew exactly what was coming.

title: Cozy Arrangements to Fit A Girlish, Not Nave, Voice
description: New instruments kept appearing when Rickie Lee Jones led her band at Town Hall on Friday night. Dobro, violin, trumpet, harmonica, bass clarinet, accordion, mandolin, alto horn and vibraphone all turned up in the course of her set. They were there to lend precise daubs of color and connotation to songs that dreamed their way across a panorama of American music.

title: Poppies, Rocks, Shards of Trouble
description: For the past two weeks German soldiers have been securing northeastern Afghanistan, one of the biggest opium-growing areas in the world. But there they are safe only so long as they don't get in the way of the local chieftains and their booming drug trade. Orders to the troops are: Look the other way.

title: Fresh Blood in the Theocracy
description: In the nuclear poker game with the West, a third faction is exerting its influence in the power struggle between the right and the reformers: the pragmatic conservatives. In advance of the parliamentary elections, there is growing disappointment in the reformers surrounding President Mohammed Khatami.

title: Kidnapped Child Found Safe, but Mother May Face Inquiry
description: It was after midnight yesterday on the night of the fall's first freeze when Officer James Phillips found his quarry: Deniro Rhumble, 2 years old, asleep in a parking lot behind the Park Lake Housing Development in Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Predict the Future of Technology and Win a Plasma TV
description: Online markets that trade predictions about the future are popping up everywhere these days, including a new one sponsored by M.I.T.'s Technology Review magazine that lets players bet on the outcome of technology-related events.

title: Two Men Charged With Arson in Orthodox Community of Brooklyn
description: Two men have been charged with arson in a fire that tore through four buildings in Williamsburg on the eve of Yom Kippur, displacing 20 Orthodox Jewish families and burning a small synagogue, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: MAN IS HIT BY PATROL CAR AND DIES LATER A 76-year-old Brooklyn man died yesterday after he was struck by police patrol car that had hit another vehicle, the authorities said. Yuekar Yuen, of 2322 East 21st Street, was struck at 10:45 a.m. as he walked on the sidewalk near Ocean Avenue and Avenue U north of Sheepshead Bay. He was treated for a hip injury at Lutheran Medical Center, but died later from a heart attack, according to his son, Paul Yuen. The police said the the patrol car was responding to a reported assault with its siren sounding when it struck the rear of a Mercedes-Benz. The two officers in the patrol car were in stable condition at Coney Island Hospital yesterday, and the occupants of the Mercedes-Benz were not hurt, the police said.   Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERGENSON, A. LEON
description: FERGENSON--A. Leon. Died October 28, 2003, in Mamaroneck, NY. Beloved husband of Constance Friend. Father of Anne Teall and Arthur, grandfather of Leah, Nina Festa, Micah, and Emily Teall, son of Harry and Lena, brother of Moses, Flora, Dorothy Rubinstein, and Rita Bergman. Born in Fitchberg, MA, in 1912, he graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Law School. After engaging in the practice of law for ten years, he became General Counsel and Vice President of General Cable Corporation in 1946. In 1966, he was appointed President and CEO of General Cable, later GK Technologies. He also served as director of more than a dozen companies including Penn Central Corporation and Sun Chemical Corporation, now Sequa Corporation. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions be made to the Whitby School, Greenwich, CT, or Gilman School, Baltimore, MD.

title: Children at the Borders: Why Are They Endangered? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Forces in Airborne Assault on Rebels in 2 Afghan Areas
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 10  American forces opened a large-scale airborne assault against suspected Taliban and other antigovernment forces in two mountainous northeastern provinces over the weekend, a United States military spokesman said today.

title: Out of Reinforcements, Nets Run Out of Gas Against the Pistons
description: Jason Kidd wore so much ice around his right shoulder that he looked the part of a starting pitcher who had just finished a complete game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEATH, FLORENCE HART
description: HEATH--Florence Hart. In loving memory of Florence Hart Heath (died October 30, 2003) from her children Linda Miller Bain, Byron S. Miller Ph.D. & Gail Hart Miller and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, MILTON
description: SHAPIRO--Milton. The commitment, vitality and passion with which Milton lived his life has been an inspiration to all of us. Our thoughts and love are extended to the entire Shapiro and Levkoff families. Gerry, Hank, David and Brooke

title: The Age of Liberty
description: With a strong sense of history, George W. Bush last week made the case for ''a forward strategy'' of idealism in American foreign policy. He dared to place his Big Idea -- what has become the central theme and purpose of his presidency -- in the direct line of aspirations expressed by three of the past century's most far-seeing and controversial U.S. presidents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERSTEIN, CHARLES K.
description: SILBERSTEIN--Charles K. On November 8, 2003. Beloved father of Michael, Jeffrey, Alexander and Clarence. Devoted grandfather of Yisrael, Binyomin, Sara Esther, Masha, Yitzhok, Cecilia and Leila.

title: Mantle's Family Decides to Sell Some Treasures
description: Since Mickey Mantle's death in 1995, his family resisted selling its trove of his artifacts and memorabilia. When Arlan Ettinger of Guernsey's auction house in Manhattan spoke over the past few years to Danny Mantle, one of Mickey's two surviving sons, the answer was always no.

title: U.S. Aides Acknowledge String of Missteps With Turkey
description: Even inside the Bush administration, few foreign policy aides say relations with Turkey, one of the United States' most important allies in Europe and the Muslim world, have been a great success. Some say dealings with Turkey have been clumsily handled for nearly a year.

title: WITH CASH TIGHT, STATES REASSESS LONG JAIL TERMS
description: After two decades of passing ever tougher sentencing laws and prompting a prison building boom, state legislatures facing budget crises are beginning to rethink their costly approaches to crime.

title: Paul Stuart Account Goes to AgencySacks
description: Paul Stuart in New York, the apparel retailer, has named AgencySacks in New York as agency of record to handle its account, which had most recently been handled internally. Billings were estimated at $4 million. The decision was made after a review in which the other participants were not disclosed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Disabled Woman Kills Son, Police Say
description: A 55-year-old woman who uses a wheelchair fatally stabbed her 35-year-old son with a kitchen knife Saturday night after a fight over money in the apartment they shared in a housing project, law enforcement officials said. The police arrested the woman, Mary McCray, but no charges were filed and she was released after the police conferred with the Bronx district attorney's office, the police said. Michelle Medley, a spokeswoman for the district attorney, said the case was under investigation and would not say whether charges would be filed. The police said they went to 750 East 163rd Street in the Morrisania section about 9:15 Saturday night and found blood in the hallway leading to Ms. McCray's 15th-floor apartment. DeWayne McCray was later pronounced dead at Lincoln Hospital, the police said. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Generals Seen Behind Resignation of Colombia Defense Chief
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 10  Marta Lucia Ramirez, the tough, blunt defense minister who had close ties with Bush administration officials, resigned on Sunday amid mounting pressure from high-ranking generals who bristled at her management style and efforts to root out corruption, government officials and political analysts said today.

title: WeatherBug to Offer Option of Fewer Ads
description: WeatherBug in Gaithersburg, Md., today will begin offering a way to view its Web site with limited advertising. Each month WeatherBug, part of AWS Convergence Technologies, will ask computer users to choose one marketer from a roster of site advertisers. The site will show the selected marketer's ads for three days, then show no ads for the rest of the month. Those users who do not select a marketer will see banner and pop-ups ads from various marketers throughout the month.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. vs. P.O.W.'s

title: Berlin Journal; Germany's Grief and Glory, Wrapped Up in a Soccer Ball
description: The tears have been flowing in Germany lately, including the tears of the chancellor himself, Gerhard Schrder, who not only announced that he cried but also urged his fellow German males to loosen their macho inhibitions and join him.

title: Tennessee And McNair Show Miami No Mercy
description: TITANS 31, DOLPHINS 7

title: Alliance Forces Out 2 Top Executives
description: Two more senior executives were forced out in the widening mutual fund scandal today, as Alliance Capital Management Holding L.P., the nation's largest publicly traded money management firm, said it had replaced its president and chief operating officer and and the chairman of the firm's mutual fund distribution unit.

title: In $87.5 Billion Bill, $2 Million Bounty For Exiled Liberian
description: The United States is offering a $2 million reward for the capture of the former Liberian president, Charles G. Taylor, a Congressional aide said on Sunday.

title: Miami's Winslow 'Immediately Regretted' Outburst
description: University of Miami tight end Kellen Winslow II apologized yesterday for a postgame tirade on Saturday in which he lashed out at a Southeastern Conference officiating crew and invoked the metaphor of war.

title: Russian Tycoon Moves Into Politics and Then Jail
description: In the new Russia, cozy ties to power have been the quickest way to riches. This was a maxim well understood by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the oil and banking tycoon -- until he landed in jail.

title: Jones's Reputation Takes Hit In Lackluster Victory for Title
description: Maybe it was too few carbohydrates or too much grapefruit, but whatever diet Roy Jones Jr. was on took off more than weight. Maybe he will go back to eating fast food to regain strength for the fight against Mike Tyson that he hopes is his farewell.

title: NASD Investigating Fund Sales by Some J.P. Morgan Brokers
description: Securities regulators are investigating more than two dozen brokers at a unit of J.P. Morgan Chase to determine if they improperly sold mutual fund shares to generate increased commissions, according to a regulatory official briefed on the matter. Roughly a dozen of the brokers' supervisors are also under scrutiny, the official said.

title: Issue of Competition Causes Widest Split Over Medicare
description: In the current debate over Medicare, no issue excites more passion than a proposal for it to compete directly with private health plans.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor To Visit Israel and Kosovo
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to travel to Israel and Kosovo this month, his aides said last night. First Mr. Bloomberg plans to fly to Israel, where his mother, Charlotte, 94, is being honored on Nov. 24 at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. Later that day, the mayor plans to fly to Kosovo, where he is to participate in an Albanian Flag Day celebration, lay a wreath at a monument for Mother Teresa and dine with American troops at Camp Bondsteel. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: U.S. Arrests Suspects in Rashid Hotel Attack
description: American forces have detained 18 people in connection with a rocket attack two weeks ago on the hotel where Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz was staying, a military spokesman said on Sunday.

title: U.S. and Brazil Meet in Effort To Ease Coming Trade Talks
description: Hoping to head off another breakdown in trade talks, the United States and Brazil came to an understanding over the weekend that top officials said could increase the prospects for some success at hemisphere-wide trade talks next week in Miami.

title: Deal to Buy Stake In Canadian Airline
description: Victor Li, son of Asia's richest businessman, agreed to buy a 31 percent stake in Air Canada for 650 million Canadian dollars ($486 million), an investment that will help the carrier emerge from bankruptcy protection, the company said yesterday.

title: Democracy? Lets Lead by Example (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: C. Z. Guest, Beauty Who Rose to Top of New York Society, Dies at 83
description: C. Z. Guest, one of the monarchs of New York society who was a perennial selection on the best-dressed list, a noted horsewoman and an authority on gardening, died on Saturday at home in Old Westbury, N.Y. She was 83.

title: Newspaper War, Waged a Character at a Time; Chinese-Language Dailies Battle Fiercely in New York
description: During the blackout in August, reporters for the city's four Chinese dailies did not have electric generators to see them through the night. But that did not stop one of them, Ming Pao Daily News, from trying to best its rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANSON, DR. ROY A.
description: MANSON--Dr. Roy A. Of New York City. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Linda and Steven. Dearest brother of Audrey Singer. He will missed by all. Services will be private.

title: A Whale Stops By, But Doesn't Stay Long
description: It was around noon yesterday when the whale first appeared, about 300 yards off the Rockaways, according to those who got a glimpse: a 25-foot sea creature that sent up periodic jets of spray from its blowhole.

title: Loosened Rules At the E.P.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton, in Beijing, Puts Focus on AIDS Issue
description: BEIJING, Nov. 10  Former President Bill Clinton, speaking at an international conference on AIDS here, today called the price of AIDS drugs in the developing world "an international scandal" and warned that AIDS could threaten China's economic boom and claim millions of lives unless government leaders moved quickly to stem its spread.

title: Unhappy in Class, More Are Learning at Home
description: In Penny Kjellberg's modest living room in Stuyvesant Town, one of her 11-year-old twins conjugates French verbs while cuddling a kitten. The book shelves sag with The Encyclopedia of the Ancient World, ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to Understanding Einstein'' and Ken Burns's videos about the Civil War. Ms. Kjellberg's other daughter devours a book about Ulysses with periodic romps outdoors when she grows antsy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Girl Admits Rape Claim Was False
description: A 14-year-old girl who told the police she was raped on Friday in a West Harlem apartment lobby has admitted she made the story up, investigators said yesterday. The girl's identity and motives were not disclosed. After recanting her story, the police said, she was charged as a juvenile with filing a false police report. She had said she was approached by a man about 5 p.m. on Friday at 135th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and was raped in the rear lobby of her building at 523 West 138th Street. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Guatemalan Voters Reject a Former Dictator
description: Guatemalans hungry for change voted for president in huge numbers on Sunday, and early returns on Monday showed the people repudiating a former dictator backed by the ruling party.

title: AL QAEDA BLAMED IN DEADLY ATTACK ON SAUDI HOMES
description: The casualty toll leaped to 17 dead and 122 wounded on Sunday in a bombing that officials attributed to Al Qaeda. The attack against a residential compound started with two to three gunmen standing high atop the khaki desert cliffs facing the gated complex and raining bullets on the guards, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOOM, SALLY
description: BLOOM--Sally. Died November 8, 2003, in Pompano Beach, FL. Dear wife of the late Dr. William Bloom. Loving mother of Steven (Sharon), and the late Robin Bloom. Devoted grandmother to Dara. We remember our aunt, who faced life's many vicissitudes with courage and love. Raphael Bloom and Susan Bloom

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Collecting; Back in 1964, First Pony Out of the Gate
description: THE frenzy among car buyers set off by the April 1964 introduction of the Ford Mustang nearly equaled the reaction of music fans to the Beatles' first appearance on television's ''Ed Sullivan Show,'' just two months earlier.

title: The Neediest Cases; An Artisan With a Disability Sees a Dream Coming True
description: In a small store in Port Chester, N.Y., in a space four feet long and two feet deep, Manuel Pilco bends over an old wooden desk, using pliers to twist gold filigree into delicate spirals. He warms the gold with a soldering iron, pressing gently to join the network of wires. The web forms the wings of golden mosquito earrings.

title: 'Italiese' joins other European hybrids : Italy struggles to keep the mother tongue pure
description: MILAN:  It is no surprise that English is the most-studied foreign language. And most people could probably guess that French, Spanish and German are second, third and fourth.

title: For Colombia's Ascetic Leader, Signs That Violence Is Easing
description: For years, Colombia's drug-fueled conflict raged, with Marxist rebels and right-wing paramilitaries gaining ground and growing ever more violent as the United States spent billions trying to control the mayhem.

title: Spain Says Yes As Its Prince Picks a Bride
description: Spain's future queen wore an anchor's microphone instead of a glass slipper. Her Prince Charming, heir to the Spanish throne, crossed paths with her at news events.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Lovers Rent Asunder, Sentimental or Cruel
description: Two very different kinds of goodbyes fill the new albums by Sarah McLachlan and Pink. Ms. McLachlan's songs revolve around the private partings of lovers who can't let go, while Pink revels in one loud, decisive heave-ho after another.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOREAU, PIERRE
description: MOREAU -- Pierre. Passed away in Limoges, France, on Monday, November 4, 2003, at the age of 75. He lived a rich, full life, and was respected and loved by everyone who knew him. He left behind his loving wife Janine and his son Jean-Paul. He was the most courageous and selfless man we ever knew, and we will miss him forever. Janine and Jean-Paul

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Is Hit By Patrol Car and Dies Later
description: A 76-year-old Brooklyn man died yesterday after he was struck by police patrol car that had hit another vehicle, the authorities said. Yuekar Yuen, of 2322 East 21st Street, was struck at 10:45 a.m. as he walked on the sidewalk near Ocean Avenue and Avenue U north of Sheepshead Bay. He was treated for a hip injury at Lutheran Medical Center, but died later from a heart attack, according to his son, Paul Yuen. The police said the the patrol car was responding to a reported assault with its siren sounding when it struck the rear of a Mercedes-Benz. The two officers in the patrol car were in stable condition at Coney Island Hospital yesterday, and the occupants of the Mercedes-Benz were not hurt, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: A Gossip Yes, But Accurate Nonetheless
description: It does not sound like a hard job to fill: writing colorful and witty dispatches about some of the most public people in America.

title: Forces Cruel, Kindly and Shifty in Pinterland
description: A promising stretch of silence begins the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of Harold Pinter's ''Caretaker,'' which stars Patrick Stewart and Kyle MacLachlan. Of course, there would be silence, wouldn't there, this being a Pinter play.

title: New Yorkers Pay Highest Local Taxes by Far, Study Shows
description: ALBANY, Nov. 10  New Yorkers pay more in local taxes than residents of any other state in the nation, according to a study by a budget watchdog group.

title: Stability Itself Is the Enemy
description: For years, Osama bin Laden called for the violent overthrow of the Saudi royal family for allowing American bases in the holiest land of Islam.

title: New Duties Announced At Kirshenbaum Bond
description: The Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York named senior managers after the resignation of Rosemarie Ryan, president, who left to become president at the flagship New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group.

title: U.S. Had Warning of Attack, But No Details on Time or Site
description: Only days before the bombing in Saudi Arabia on Saturday that killed at least 17 people, American intelligence agencies had been warned that such an attack by Al Qaeda was imminent but the warnings lacked sufficient detail to disrupt the plot, officials said Sunday.

title: Living on Borrowed Money
description: It's interesting that so much attention is being paid to the modest job creation numbers for October, and so little is being given to a much more significant issue that Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards is homing in on.

title: Democracy? Let's Lead by Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Welfare Reform for Farmers
description: A great rift is opening in America's once-impregnable farm lobby. It is a gap between those forms of agriculture that can prosper on their own and the ones that must be perpetually propped up by huge subsidies. This is a critical development if this country is ever going to control the costs of its farm programs and deal fairly with poor countries that want their chance to prosper from global trade. The United States has to acknowledge that it can no longer continue to support hopelessly unprofitable agricultural enterprises, even if they are in states represented by powerful members of Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALLACH, JEROME J.
description: WALLACH--Jerome J. Devoted husband, loving father and grandfather.

title: Democracy? Let's Lead by Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy? Let's Lead by Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Offerings for Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

title: Heart Drug Duo Doesn't Cut Complications
description: Two heart drugs from Johnson & Johnson, Retavase and ReoPro, together did not cut complications in heart attack patients any better than ReoPro alone, a study released yesterday showed.

title: Ossining Journal; Restaurant's Owner Alleges Bias in Complaints on Music
description: The trouble began after Sept. 11, 2001, said Dr. Syed A. Nayeem, the owner of Maison Lafitte, a restaurant in a Georgian-style mansion here with sweeping views of the Hudson River.

title: Champions Among the Mustang Herd
description: THE most desirable Mustangs are the high-performance editions built by Carroll Shelby, the legendary race-car driver. The rarest of the Shelby Mustangs command six-figure prices, but the standard production Mustangs are easier to drive and easier on the wallet.

title: One Title Is Campbell's, Another Is Unsettled
description: Chad Campbell turned the Tour Championship into a runaway. The voting for PGA Tour player of the year, however, will be closer than it has been in years.

title: At Milwaukee Newspaper, the Old-Timers Are Cashing In
description: Shortly after John E. Mollwitz joined The Milwaukee Journal in 1969, he attended a going-away party for a lifelong company bookkeeper. She had just learned that her shares in the employee-owned newspaper were worth $1 million. ''She looked at me with very sad eyes and said 'Where could we have ever done this at any other company?''' recalled Mr. Mollwitz, noting her bewilderment over her good fortune.

title: Embracing Life Outside the B.C.S. Box
description: There were sweet moments -- Minnesota place-kicker Rhys Lloyd bolting toward the Wisconsin sideline to retrieve Paul Bunyan's Axe as soon as his 35-yard game-winning field goal went between the posts. There were bittersweet ones -- the 40-yard game-ending field goal by D. J. Fitzpatrick that gave Notre Dame a much-needed victory and made Fitzpatrick, a walk-on kicker, an unlikely star at the expense of tearful Navy players who had played well enough to snap their 39-game losing streak to the Irish.

title: Wal-Mart Plan Could Cost Suppliers Millions
description: Some consumer products companies will have to invest millions of dollars to comply with Wal-Mart's drive to have every carton and palette it receives carry a radio identification tag, according to a report to be released today by A.T. Kearney, a consulting firm.

title: Editorial Observer; Viewing California Politics Through the Lens of a Science Fiction Movie
description: The pop-culture pastime of predicting the future through science fiction goes back at least as far as Jules Verne, the 19th-century novelist who foresaw space travel and cities beneath the sea. His view of the future is a picnic compared with the apocalyptic scenarios that dominate science fiction today. Civilization lies in ruins and what remains of the human race is enslaved by the murderous computer from the ''Matrix'' series or stalked by bone-crushing cyborgs like the one made famous by Arnold Schwarzenegger, the next California governor, in the first ''Terminator'' film.

title: Pataki Pledges to Build Memorial to Victims of 2001 Plane Crash in Queens
description: Almost two years after American Airlines Flight 587 crashed into Belle Harbor, Queens, Gov. George E. Pataki promised yesterday that ''a suitable and fitting memorial will be built'' to commemorate the crash, in which 265 people were killed.

title: 3 Autoimmune Diseases Share A Genetic Defect, Scientists Find
description: Scientists have found an unexpected genetic link among three common autoimmune diseases: psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: W.T.O. Rules U.S. Tariffs on Steel Are Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  The World Trade Organization upheld today its ruling against the steel tariffs imposed by President Bush last year, giving the green light to Europe to impose more than $2 billion of sanctions against the United States.

title: Kaiser Permanente Has Big Assignment
description: Kaiser Permanente, the health maintenance organization that operates in nine states and Washington, has begun a review for a large new assignment, national brand agency for advertising. In the coming year, the company is looking to double its budget of about $20 million, said Christine Paige, senior vice president for marketing at the company, which is based in Oakland, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Sports Briefing column on Friday about the death of Dernell Stenson, a Cincinnati Reds outfielder, referred incorrectly to an arrest in the case, near Phoenix. The authorities said Reginald Riddle was arrested on Thursday for investigation of homicide, robbery and kidnapping but was not formally charged. The report also misstated an action taken against Reginald Riddle's half-brother Kevin. He was booked for investigation of possession of stolen property but was not formally charged.

title: An Elf and a Bear Trip Up the Final 'Matrix'
description: In the weekend battle at the box office, the real antagonists for the hero of ''The Matrix: Revolutions,'' turned out not to be a renegade computer program bent on the destruction of the human race, but instead an oversized elf and an animated bear.

title: Offered Freedom, Burmese Dissenter Refuses
description: Myanmar's military junta has said that the pro-democracy activist Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is no longer under house arrest, but she is declining to take her freedom until about 30 other political prisons are released, a United Nations human rights envoy, Paulo Sergio Pinheiro, said in Yangon, the capital, on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BONHAM, WILLIAM R.
description: BONHAM -- William R. 1921-1987. True love never dies. You are still my true love. Mo

title: Oldest Living Start-Up Tells All
description: RFco Inc. is a paradox: a hot new Silicon Valley start-up, with plenty of history. The nugget of innovation that RFco, a semiconductor company, is trying to commercialize has its roots in the mid-1990's. The search for venture financing took more than two years. And the company's top five executives are all about 60 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Russian Network in Talks To Sell Satellite Business

title: Holiday Tomorrow: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, MICHAEL L.
description: ROSENBERG--Michael L., 56. October 11, 2003. The Board of Directors of the Sunny and Abe Rosenberg Foundation mourn the passing of Michael L. Rosenberg, beloved son of President Emeritus, Sonia Rosenberg and the late Abraham Rosenberg; sister of President, Susan R. Goldstein; brother-in-law, Vice President/Treasurer, Stuart D. Goldstein and fellow Director, Robert Gassman. The Foundation has created the Michael L. Rosenberg Memorial Fund to honor his passion for the Arts. Donations can be made to the Sunny and Abe Rosenberg Foundation and mailed to 888 Seventh Avenue, 24th Floor, New York, New York 10019. The funeral was held in Dallas, Texas on Wednesday, October 15, 2003. A private memorial service was held on Sunday, November 2, 2003 for family and friends in New York City. We will miss Michael dearly and his passion for the Arts and Education.

title: Loosened Rules at the E.P.A. (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIEN, DONNA JOY
description: LEVIEN--Donna Joy. Of Kings Point, NY, died on November 8, 2003, of metastatic breast cancer. Dedicated and forever supportive wife to Phil, loving and caring mother to sons Jeff and Mark, and her daughters-in-law Ivy and Joanne. Proud Nanny of grandson Gray. Protective sister and friend to brother Ron Kisner and his wife Ellen. Also survived by mother-inlaw Jane, brothers-in-law Barry and George, and their respective wives, Jane and Margon, and nieces and nephews David, Melissa, Michael, Jamie, David, Tracy, Ashley, Danielle and Alec. She guided her family with love and devotion, and was a loyal and engaging friend to many. She will be missed immensely for her leadership, and will be revered for her courage in her struggle against breast cancer. She was an avid reader, card player, movie goer and traveler. Interment private. Memorial service to be held Monday, November 10, at 2 PM, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers the family asks for donations to be made to your favorite charity in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SERENA, DR. JOHN M.
description: SERENA--Dr. John M. 90, November 8, Norwalk, CT. Husband of late Rita Miner Serena. Born Yonkers, NY. Son of late Alexander and Mildred DeLucy Serena. Graduate Syracuse University, 1936, medical degree Hanaman Medical School, 1940. Major, United States Army Medical Crops, anesthesiologist-surgeon in Europe with the 3rd Auxiliary Field Hospital, 1st Army, and the British 8th Army. Dr. Serena practiced anesthesiology at Norwalk Hospital for forty-five years. Survived by son John Miner Serena, daughter-in-law Linda Serena, brother Dr. Frank Serena, companion Allison Bailey, granddaughter Nicole. Mass Wednesday, 10 am, St. Thomas the Apostle, Norwalk, CT. St. John Cemetery, Norwalk. Wake Wednesday, 8:30 to 9:30 am, Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave., Norwalk, CT 203-866-0747.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, ARNOLD J.
description: BERNSTEIN--Arnold J. 93, of Sarasota, FL, and Scarsdale, NY, died November 9, at home. He was the husband of Jeanne Postley for 63 years; father of Janael McQueen of Santa Cruz, CA, Linda B. Miller of Washington, DC, and Carol B. Clark of London; grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of three. A graduate of Harvard College, Class of 1932, and Columbia Law School, he was a longtime Trustee of Blythedale Children's Hospital and the Hospital for Joint Diseases. Contributions to Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, NY.

title: Democracy? Let's Lead by Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokerage Campaign Is Set to Name Names
description: A campaign for TD Waterhouse U.S.A. scheduled to begin today with a budget estimated at $40 million to $50 million, brings to the brokerage category a tactic borrowed from the cola wars: naming competitors' names.

title: Children at the Borders: Why Are They Endangered?
description: To the Editor:

title: Solving the Brain
description: Zach Mainen, Assistant Professor, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory

title: Clinton to Join Economic Unit Aiding Upstate
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is teaming up with one of the leading members of her husband's White House economic staff to try to address upstate New York's economic problems.

title: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 0.95 percent and the rate on the six-month issue at 1.07 percent. The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

title: U.S. Soldier Dies in Iraq; Bremer Warns of Worse to Come
description: An American military policeman was killed in a rocket-propelled grenade attack, the military said, and the coalition's chief administrator in Iraq warned that stepped-up attacks by insurgents could be expected in the coming months.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday on the threat facing American aircraft in Iraq, in light of the downing of a Chinook helicopter that killed 16 American soldiers, misstated the number of Iraqi Army and security service members who could possibly have been trained to use surface-to-air missiles. Of the more than 500,000 members of those forces, only a fraction would have received such training.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINGOLD, J. PAUL
description: FINGOLD--J. Paul. To our close friend Paul, for many years your friendship, great golf games at the Palm Beach Country Club and wonderful trips and dinners together. You will be greatly missed. To Malka and the rest of the family, our deepest sympathy and love. Carol and Mark Lederman

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel, Beware: A Chant Begins
description: LIKE smoke rising from a small brush fire, the chant began in the southeast corner of the lower stands at Giants Stadium late in the third quarter yesterday with the Atlanta Falcons leading, 20-7.

title: Islanders Are Trying to Trade Wiemer
description: The Islanders are trying to trade Jason Wiemer or will place him on waivers, the team confirmed yesterday, while denying that the move was the start of a larger-scale salary dump. Wiemer, a 27-year-old forward who has a goal and three assists this season, did not make the trip for the Islanders' game at Philadelphia tonight.

title: Spurrier Gets Some Shelter From Storm
description: REDSKINS 27, SEAHAWKS 20

title: Europe Exceeds U.S. in Refining Grid Computing
description: When the Swiss-based pharmaceutical giant Novartis needed a new supercomputer for designing drugs, the company found it already had one. It was hidden in the unused computing power the company had available in the thousands of PC's that were already being used in its offices.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction, the weather report was omitted from an early edition yesterday. Copies from a later edition may be requested from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Police Say Disabled Woman in Bronx Fatally Stabbed Her Son, 35
description: A55-year-old woman who uses a wheelchair fatally stabbed her 35-year-old son with a kitchen knife Saturday night after a fight over money in the apartment they shared in a Bronx housing project, law enforcement officials said.

title: Pointing the Car Toward Mecca
description: THE Koran requires Muslims to pray five times a day while facing Mecca, the birthplace of the prophet Muhammad. Traditionally muezzins climb the minarets of mosques to call out prayer time, but in the modern world the devout are not always within earshot.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: The Dolls That Even a Feminist Could Love
description: To the Editor:

title: SEMA Is Now a Must-Do for the Automakers
description: LAS VEGAS -- There are a few things you need to know about the SEMA show.

title: White House Letter; Black and White and Read by Precious Few
description: People call it a lot of things: the world's most exclusive newspaper, a supersecret product of the Central Intelligence Agency and a document so sensitive that widespread dissemination would endanger lives.

title: Superfund Job, Not Quite Finished, Frustrates a Town
description: The worst has been removed from this industrial city's largest hazardous waste site. Barrels of chemicals have been carted away. Contaminated front yards have been stripped and covered with fresh sod. The rusty buildings where rats and homeless men took shelter have been demolished and removed.

title: The Dolls That Even a Feminist Could Love (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Printers To Merge, A $2.8 Billion Stock Deal
description: R.R. Donnelley & Sons agreed yesterday to acquire Moore Wallace for $2.8 billion in stock, creating a printing giant that manufactures everything from magazines like Sports Illustrated and TV Guide to billing and shipping labels for companies like United Parcel Service and J.C. Penney.

title: The Dolls That Even a Feminist Could Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Criticizes Expanded Terrorism Law
description: Former Vice President Al Gore called on Sunday for a repeal of the law expanding counterterrorism powers, calling it a ''terrible mistake'' for its effect on civil liberties.

title: A Manufactured Crisis on Judges
description: Conservative activists have been demanding that Senate Republicans do more to push through the Bush administration's most extreme judicial nominees. So the Republican leadership is planning a 30-hour talk marathon later this week to protest the Democrats' blocking of a handful of candidates. To up the public-relations quotient, there may be calls for votes on three controversial female nominees. Lost amid the grandstanding about a ''crisis'' in judicial nominations are the facts: 168 Bush nominees have been confirmed and only four rejected, a far better percentage than for President Bill Clinton.

title: Children at the Borders: Why Are They Endangered?
description: To the Editor:

title: States Pay for Jobs, but It Doesn't Always Pay Off
description: A huge, light-gray building, trimmed jauntily in blue, rises from the rolling, grassy fields on the far side of the runways at Indianapolis International Airport. From the approach road, the building seems active. But the parking lots are empty and, inside, the 12 elaborately equipped hangar bays are silent and dark. It is as if the owner of a lavishly furnished mansion had suddenly walked away, leaving everything in place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHOEN, MICHAEL
description: SCHOEN--Michael. Dear Michael, these ten years have not diminished our love and yearning for you to be with us. We miss you so. Mom, Lisa and Jerry

title: 7 Straight Losses Later, Reeves Wins His 200th
description: Week after week, Dan Reeves suffered.

title: In the Fate Of Pompeii, Allegories For Today
description: The Mickey Mouse ears, hers in white, his in black, were the clincher, the end of the dream.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.B.A.

title: Political Memo; He's Spoiling For a Chance To Take On Schumer
description: In New York Republican circles, Michael Benjamin has become a bit like the kid on the basketball court begging the other players to pass him the ball.

title: M. S. Shapiro, Zionist Leader And Lawyer, 81
description: Milton S. Shapiro, a lawyer who was active in many organizations in support of Israel, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday on the threat facing American aircraft in Iraq, in light of the downing of a Chinook helicopter that killed 16 American soldiers, misstated the number of Iraqi Army and security service members who could possibly have been trained to use surface-to-air missiles. Of the more than 500,000 members of those forces, only a fraction would have received such training.

title: The Market Opens Today For Baseball's Free Agents
description: The 30 general managers in Major League Baseball have had today's date imprinted on their schedules for weeks. The general managers' meetings begin today in Phoenix, and open bidding on a deep free-agent market was allowed starting at 12:01 this morning.

title: 2 Sides Seem Entrenched In Supermarket Dispute
description: As 80 picketing workers bellowed chants outside the supermarket Thursday evening, Rosalyn Colvard, a grocery stocker, said she would need help from welfare to make ends meet if Southern California's three largest grocery chains won their four-week-old battle with 70,000 workers.

title: People
description: Val DiFebo, director for client services at Deutsch, New York, was named to the vacant position of New York general manager, while continuing as a managing partner. Deutsch is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KISSEL, ROBERT
description: KISSEL--Robert. November 8. It is with deep sorrow that we announce the untimely passing of Robert P. Kissel. Adored father of Elaine, June and Rees. Beloved son of William and the late Elaine. Cherished brother of Andrew and Jane. Special uncle to Anna, Audrey, Dara and Ruth and brother-in-law to Hayley and Richard. Rob was a caring father, a son to be proud of, a dedicated brother and always a loyal friend. He was loved and respected by all who had the privilege of knowing him. He will remain in our hearts forever and his soul will have an eternal presence in this world. Funeral services to be arranged.

title: RealNetworks In a Venture With Comcast
description: The relationship between online music and high-speed Internet access just got a little closer. Comcast Cable, the biggest provider of broadband Internet services, is set to announce today that it will offer the Rhapsody online music service from RealNetworks to its nearly 5 million subscribers.

title: Kenseth Says Points Title Is a Relief
description: There is one race left in the Nascar Winston Cup series this season, the Ford 400 at Homestead-Miami Speedway.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think they are after the royal family. There is a determined fight to rattle the government if not bring it down.''

title: Trial of Second Sniper Suspect Gets Under Way in Virginia
description: The trial of Lee B. Malvo, the younger suspect in the sniper killings that terrorized the Washington area last year, started today in Virginia with his arraignment and jury selection, overlapping with the trial of John A. Muhammad, who prosecutors say was the mastermind of the shootings.

title: Domingo and 'Walkre' Put Adversity to Surprising Use
description: Simply looking at Plcido Domingo gives the opera lover jet lag. There he was little more than a month ago running the Los Angeles Opera and singing Rasputin in Deborah Drattell's ''Nicholas and Alexandra.'' Here he was on Saturday running the Washington Opera and singing Siegmund in Wagner's ''Die Walkre.'' Only his manager knows how many stops have come between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, JANE TRAFFORD LUKE
description: MURPHY -- Jane Trafford Luke. Died on Wednesday, November 5, 2003, from complications from Lupus. She is lovingly remembered by her friends and family for her courageous battle with the disease, and for her generous spirit. Born October 17, 1953 in Charleston, S.C., Jane earned a B.S. from Briarcliff College and her R.N. from Pace University. A devoted mother to her two sons, Jane was an active volunteer at Greens Farms Academy, and she was a member of the Women's Fellowship at Trinity Church. Jane is survived by her husband, Jonathan J. Murphy, two sons, J. Luke Murphy and Gordon T. Murphy, all of Fairfield, CT.; her parents, Joy and John A. Luke, Sr., a brother John A. Luke, Jr., and a sister, Hope L. Hetherington, all of New Canaan, CT.; a brother William H. Luke of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Southport, CT on Tuesday, November 11th, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Jane's memory to the Lupus Research Institute, 149 Madison Ave, Suite 205, N.Y., N.Y. 10016

description: The Department of Defense has identified 388 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: With a Second Chance, Brien Atones and Jets Win
description: The officials made sure Jets kicker Doug Brien had plenty of time to stretch his hamstrings and pull up his socks. A review of the spot of the ball meant there would be no rush, none of the excruciating ticking of the clock to interrupt Brien's preparation for another overtime field-goal attempt, another chance to save what remains of the Jets' season.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, FRIEDA V.
description: WILLIAMS--Frieda V. Of Harlem. Died on November 7, 2003, at home with her beloved family: her husband of 29 years, Ronald H. Williams, and her two sons, Todd Williams and Matthew Williams. She passed away in peace after her long, brave struggle with cancer. Visitation is on Tuesday, November 11, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. The visiting hours are from 4 o'clock p.m. to 8 o'clock p.m. The phone number is (212) 288-3500. The funeral service will be on Wednesday, November 12, at Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place (formerly West 138th St.), in New York City. Service will begin at 10 o'clock a.m. The church phone number is (212) 862-7474. After the service the burial will take place at Pinelawn Memorial Cemetery in Farmingdale, Long Island, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGELMAYER, LIBA (LILY)
description: ENGELMAYER--Liba (Lily). 90, on November 8, in Teaneck, NJ. The widow of Abraham Engelmayer, she is survived by her son, Rabbi Shammai Engelmayer, and daughter-in-law Marilyn Henry of Teaneck; her grandchildren Malki Cohen and her husband Danny, Juda Engelmayer and his wife Debra, and Jay Engelmayer, and his wife Annie, all of Manhattan; ten great-grandchildren; her sister Esther Saltzman, of Brookline, MA; her brother, Rabbi Samuel Klein and his wife Sydelle, of Chicago; and ten nieces and nephews. The family suggests donations to The Center for Older Adults, Jewish Center of Teaneck, 70 Sterling Place, Teaneck, NJ 07666. Burial was in Jerusalem.

title: Japan's Governing Party Keeps Power, but Loses Strength
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's governing coalition held on to power in parliamentary elections on Sunday, even as voters handed big gains to the main opposition party in a ballot that could help lead Japan toward a two-party system.

title: MetroStars' Season Put on Ice
description: With a new coach and several new players, the MetroStars went further than they did last year, making the playoffs in Major League Soccer, but their season ended Sunday when they were eliminated in the first round after losing a two-game total-goals series to the New England Revolution, 3-1.

title: Melancholy Songs, But Life Seems Swell; Sarah McLachlan Is Back in the Limelight After a Pause for Marriage and Motherhood
description: Reveling in a peaceful state of utter anonymity, the singer Sarah McLachlan strolled about Central Park one recent afternoon, unencumbered by fans begging for autographs or pesky paparazzi snapping photos.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOROWITZ, MAX
description: HOROWITZ--Max. November 10, 1972. Miss You, Daddy

description: Today

title: Giants Receive Chill on Day That Was to Be a Breeze
description: By the time Sunday's game ground to its merciful end, a few thousand fans littered Giants Stadium, seemingly frozen in their seats for the final quarter in the grim chill of the day. They mustered one last wave of boos as the Giants trudged toward their locker room, a place that would provide no safe harbor.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK: KIDNAPPING SUSPECTS FACE STATE CHARGES Two men accused of kidnapping a United States senator's wife now face criminal charges in New Jersey, where they were arrested last month. A Middlesex County grand jury on Friday filed charges against the two men, Christopher Forbes, 32, of Falls Church, Va., and Michael Pierre, 26, of Upper Marlboro, Md. The indictment alleges that the pair received stolen property, contending that they took a car in Alexandria, Va., and used it during the Oct. 7 robbery and abduction of Kathleen Gregg, above, the wife of Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire.   (AP)

title: In the last year, 17 restaurant chains have fired their agencies. A sign of the times.
description: LIKE the owner of a baseball team conducting a grim review of underperforming assets, restaurant companies are taking a long, hard look at their advertising agencies. And more of them want a new pitching coach.

title: Merger of Rivals Throws Up New Hurdle for EMI Chief
description: Has EMI's chairman, Eric Nicoli, missed his chance for a merger -- again?

title: Kerry Fires His Campaign Manager
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts has fired his campaign manager as he struggles to deal with continuing turmoil in his campaign and the perception among many Democrats that he had fallen from a once-dominant position in the Democratic presidential contest.

title: The Perils of Improvising a Racial Self
description: Early in the new movie ''The Human Stain,'' the protagonist, Coleman Silk, hears a recording of ''Cheek to Cheek'' and breaks into spontaneous dance. Silk, played by Anthony Hopkins, is a light-skinned African-American college dean, who passes himself as white and Jewish.

title: Russia and Iran Appear Closer to Accord on Nuclear Plant
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 10  Russia and Iran appeared to draw closer today to an agreement that would clear the way for the completion of a nuclear power plant that the Russians are building in Iran.

title: 18 Held in Iraq Attack
description: American forces have detained 18 people in connection with a rocket attack on Oct. 26 on the hotel where Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz was staying. Page A6.

title: In Close Vote, Israeli Cabinet Backs Trade Of Prisoners
description: The Israeli cabinet on Sunday narrowly approved a planned prisoner exchange with Lebanon's Hezbollah guerrillas that would free more than 400 Arabs in return for a kidnapped Israeli businessman and the remains of three soldiers.

title: U.S. Teams Gain in World Play
description: United States teams continue to do well in the World Championships here. In the Bermuda Bowl, for open teams, the United States No. 1 team, led by Nick Nickell, is overwhelming the Taiwan team, leading by 101 imps with 48 of 96 deals completed. The No. 2 team, captained by Bobby Wolff, leads Poland by 49 at the same point. If both leads hold up, the American teams will face each other in the semifinal starting Tuesday.

title: Predictions Don't Work Vs. Carolina
description: PANTHERS 27, BUCCANEERS 24

title: U.S. to Seek Support for Ozone Exemptions at Meetings
description: The two-decade effort to eliminate chemicals that harm the ozone layer faces its most serious test in recent years this week as the Bush administration seeks international support for broad exemptions to a 2005 ban on a popular pesticide.

title: Study Raises Doubt About Allergy to Genetic Corn
description: Remember StarLink corn? Three years ago this genetically engineered corn was found in taco shells and other foods, even though it had not been approved for human consumption.

title: Market Timing: A Longtime Practice Comes Under New Scrutiny
description: In the early 1990's, mutual fund companies occasionally allowed select institutional clients to trade fund shares rapidly, a practice known as market timing. But such trades were relatively small and usually limited to funds that held corporate bonds or mortgage-backed securities, hedge fund executives and others said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIGHTMAN, BERNARD
description: BRIGHTMAN--Bernard. Beloved husband of Natasha. Devoted father of Ezra, Fred and Adam; Lynn, Jodi and Liza. Doting grandfather of Anna, Sarah, Jonathan and Isabel. Services on Tuesday, November 11, at Riverside Memorial Chapel; 212-362-6600. We love you and will miss you forever.

description: GUEST--C. Z. In honor of the passing of our dear friend, C. Z., whose humor, warmth, kindness and hospitality will forever be with us. We will miss this courageous champion. Love, Bunny and Charles Koppelman

title: American Artists in Interwar Paris, Seeking Novelty
description: From the 1870's to World War I, American painters trekked to France to study. And their belief that France was the world capital of art was reinforced when American collectors began snapping up Impressionist and post-Impressionist works. But after 1918 the relationship began to change. While Paris was now the cradle of Modern art, resistance to copying Europe was growing among American artists.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: CHARGES IN YALE STRIKE DISMISSED A judge dismissed disorderly conduct charges on Friday against 65 people who demonstrated during the labor strike at Yale. Five other cases are pending. Laura Smith, president of Local 34, and Bob Proto, president of Local 35, are among those who will return to court on Saturday because they face more than one charge, said Hugh F. Keefe, their lawyer. The three-week strike by 2,000 workers ended Sept. 19. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, YETTA (NEE HERZLICH)
description: KATZ--Yetta (nee Herzlich). At 92, peacefully on November 8, 2003, at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Jonas for 57 years; both born in Dynow, Poland. Cherished mother of Sandy, Helen and Stanley, Nancy and Harold. Adored grandmother of Howard, Lori, Andrea, Lois, David, Mary, Adam, Dana, Robert, Lily, Eliza and Michelle. Great-grandmother of Anna-Lise, Casey, Ariel, Eli, Zachery and Eden. She was a gracious lady whose legacy of kindness, wisdom, strength and optimism is an inspiration to us all. Those who knew and loved her will hold her always in their hearts and thoughts. Private family service.

title: A Showman Revs Up the Classical Genre
description: There was quite a scene at Carnegie Hall on Friday night for the sold-out recital of the superstar Chinese pianist Lang Lang. A video crew from German television captured images of the expectant crowds entering the hall, and a battery of cameras in the auditorium recorded the event for later broadcast.

title: Dark Days in Shangri-La
description: In the 60's Nepal was a hashish-filled Shangri-La for hippies. In the 80's its hills swarmed with trekkers catching the evening sun as it hit Annapurna. Now a more sinister show is playing in the villages and in the capital, Katmandu -- and it should make Americans worry.

description: Novell was left for dead years ago, another casualty of Microsoft's hegemony over computer operating systems.

description: GIBBY--Anne Willard. Of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ, and Pocono Lake Preserve, PA, died November 7. She is survived by her husband, Robert, and children, Robert Jr., Susan Gillim, Alan, and James, and sister, Mary Atwater Keer, plus eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Services will be private.
