title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Inquiry Into Baby Formula Deaths
description: Three Israeli babies have died and at least 17 more have suffered serious illnesses in recent months after receiving a nondairy baby formula that lacked vitamin B1, despite the ingredient being listed on the label, Israeli officials said. The Remedia baby formula, a kosher, soya-based product made by the German firm Humana, has been pulled from store shelves, and the police have opened a criminal investigation. The Israeli Health Ministry said the absence of the B1 vitamin is believed to have caused the babies to suffer from beriberi, a disease that leads to serious neurological and heart problems. But Humana's chief, Rolf Janshen, said in Germany that independent laboratories had checked the formula and that ''contrary to the Israeli findings, vitamin B1 has been found,'' Reuters reported. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Hand-Held Computer Shipments Drop
description: Third-quarter shipments of hand-held computers fell for an eighth consecutive period as people instead bought cellphones featuring calendars and address books, the market researcher Gartner Inc. said yesterday. Worldwide shipments dropped 0.2 percent to 2.52 million, Gartner, based in Stamford, Conn., said in a statement. The industrywide result would have tumbled 13 percent if Hewlett- Packard had not almost doubled its shipments, Gartner said. Cellphone makers are cramming features like Internet access and digital cameras into their devices to attract buyers. A Gartner analyst, Todd Kort, said this trend is affecting companies that rely on consumers, like PalmOne and Sony, more than Hewlett-Packard, which aims for corporate customers.

title: Kerry Invokes Bush's Carrier Landing to Emphasize Points
description: With this 30-second advertisement, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts becomes the first major Democratic hopeful to use President Bush's well-known visit to the carrier Abraham Lincoln on a combat refueling plane, an S-3B Viking, on May 1, when he declared the end of major combat operations in Iraq. The spot, called ''Carrier,'' is to be broadcast on television stations throughout Iowa and New Hampshire starting today. Campaign officials would not say how long it would run or how much they paid to place it

title: For Bush, a Light Moment on a Painful Topic
description: President Bush rarely refers to one of the unhappier chapters in his life, the compulsive drinking that led him to give up alcohol altogether 17 years ago.

title: The Long Shadow of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article in Business Day on Friday about recent acquisitions referred incorrectly to a banking analyst at Smith Barney, who commented on Bank of America's agreement to buy FleetBoston Financial. The analyst, Ruchi Madan, is a woman.

title: Is War Our Biological Destiny?
description: In these days of hidebound militarism and round-robin carnage, when even that beloved ambassador of peace, the Dalai Lama, says it may be necessary to counter terrorism with violence, it's fair to ask: Is humanity doomed? Are we born for the battlefield -- congenitally, hormonally incapable of putting war behind us? Is there no alternative to the bullet-riddled trapdoor, short of mass sedation or a Marshall Plan for our DNA?

title: Irv Kupcinet, 91, Dies; Chronicled Chicago for 60 Years
description: Irv Kupcinet, the celebrity-adoring gossip columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times whose daily jottings amounted to a love letter to the city where he himself became a celebrity, died there on Monday. He was 91, and his last column ran on Thursday.

title: Spellbound by the Eternal Riddle, Scientists Revel in Their Captivity
description: From an early age, I loved to solve puzzles. When my math teachers assigned homework, most students groaned, but I relished the job. I would save my math problems for last, right before bedtime, like bites of chocolate cake awaiting me after a long and dutiful meal of history and Latin. Then, I would devour my cake.

title: What Should We Eat?
description: In a word -- less.

description: Science Times celebrates its 25th anniversary by asking 25 of the most compelling questions facing science today, including:

Service today, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: N.C.A.A. to Start Testing for New Steroid
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association president, Myles Brand, said yesterday that member colleges and universities are going to start testing, possibly this fall, for tetrahydrogestrinone, a previously undetectable "designer" steroid, linked to prominent professional athletes.

description: BLOOM--Sally. Dear Friend, whose humor and warmth and kindness will forever be with me. I will miss you. Love, Barbara Blitz

description: SCHLOSSMAN--Barbara. Of West Orange, N.J. Wife of Mitchell, mother of Edye and David Schlossman and Julie Levy. Dear grandmother. Services at Bernheim-ApterKreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, New Jersey, Wednesday at noon.

title: Rangers' Loss Has Fans Chanting for Change
description: No one can accuse fans at Madison Square Garden of not keeping up with current events. As soon as the Edmonton Oilers scored their fourth straight goal last night, on the way to a 5-4 victory over the Rangers, the chants of ''We Want Keenan!'' could be heard from a significant portion of the crowd on the 33rd Street end of the building.

title: Two Classics, and a Young Bodybuilder With Politics in His Future
description: ''Best ever'' movies resurface rarely, but this week we have two. Arnold Schwarzenegger campaigns, and David Cronenberg types.

title: Corrections
description: A profile of the college football coach John Gagliardi on Thursday misstated the name of his university. It is St. John's University in Collegeville, Minn., not St. John's College. The article also referred incompletely to his education. While he originally attended Trinidad Junior College, he earned a bachelor's degree in education, in 1949 from Colorado College in Colorado Springs.

title: Will Humans Ever Visit Mars?
description: People have been walking on the surface of Mars for more than a century, in tales of science fiction and fantasy. Now, however, the possibility is real enough that many people think the question is not whether humans will go to Mars, but when they will go, how they will get there and who will go first.

title: Front Row; Creative Energy That Soared Too High
description: The mad mood swing might seem as indispensable a part of fashion's tool chest as a sewing machine. But even diva acts have their limits. And so, one sunny day in 1951, the photographer Francesco Scavullo found himself being taken from a Glamour magazine shoot in Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Gracie Square Hospital, a Manhattan psychiatric facility, where he was put under observation. Doctors said he had manic depression.

title: Bush Links Efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan to U.S. Security
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 — President Bush said today that the grand experiment of democracy must succeed in Iraq and Afghanistan, not just for the sake of the people in those countries but to protect the national security of the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAIN, EDWARD A., JR., DDS
description: CAIN--Edward A., Jr., DDS. JW Benfield Professor Emeritus, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Died at home on November 8, 2003 at age 83. Beloved husband of 55 years of Jeanne W. Cain. Devoted father of Edward A., III (Kathryn), Barbara Rucci (Jerry), William, Susan Webster (Robert), Jeanne Dingle. Cherished grandfather of Meighan, Courtney, Thomas, Matthew, Catherine, Sam and Sally. Dear brother of Harriet F. Cain. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday 7-9PM and Thursday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Mother Cabrini Chapel, 701 Ft Washington Ave at W 192nd St, Friday 10AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Barrier Route Would Give Israel 15% of West Bank, U.N. Says
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11  Israel's projected route for a controversial barrier would put nearly 15 percent of West Bank land on the Israeli side and disrupt the lives of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians, according to a United Nations report released today.

title: AIRLINE REPORTS AGREEMENT WITH PILOTS' UNION
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines said yesterday that its pilots' union, the Air Line Pilots Association, had agreed to a new contract with wages and work rules that would go into effect if the company created a low-cost airline. Atlantic Coast is a regional carrier for United Airlines and operates for United under the name of United Express, but it has been saying it wants to end that relationship and start a low-cost airline. Investors and analysts have been skeptical, and the share value of Atlantic Coast dropped after it first announced its intentions in July. Getting the pilots to ratify the contract was a critical step toward creating that new airline, as some experts predicted that the pilots' union would balk. Atlantic Coast said that the new contract, which goes into effect only if the low-cost airline goes into operation, creates a new pay scale for pilots flying Boeing 737's or Airbus A320's. The Mesa Air Group, another regional airline, is trying to buy out Atlantic Coast to create the country's largest regional carrier. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: A Manufacturer Returns, And Gets Dessert
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg welcomed a company back from New Jersey to its old home in College Point, Queens, yesterday with $1.3 million in tax breaks and two cheesecakes from a local bakery. The company, Gelmart Industries, a manufacturer of lingerie, plans to spend around $1 million renovating its old plant and to return its operations, and 140 jobs, there in the spring. It was formerly situated in Lyndhurst, N.J. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Jury Gets Conspiracy Case Of Former City Councilman
description: Did Sheldon S. Leffler, the former councilman who represented Queens for 24 years, conspire to steal matching funds for campaign contributions from the government during his ill-fated run for borough president two years ago, or was he simply the victim of overzealous supporters?

title: EchoStar Posts a Profit
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation, the satellite television service, earned a third-quarter profit of $35.1 million after taking subscribers from cable TV services.

title: The Long Shadow of the Holocaust (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

description: KOEPPEL--Jerome, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved brother of our good friend, Howard Koeppel, a respected member of our Society of Founders and our Men's Division, and a Guardian of the University, who established a laboratory for multiple sclerosis research at our medical school. To Howard and the entire family, we offer our sincere condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Neil A. Clark, Chairman Men's Division

title: Giants' Mara Not Among Fassel's Many Detractors
description: In the cold, drafty tunnel of Giants Stadium on Monday afternoon, Wellington Mara walked into the latest tempest over his team's season. Wearing his usual Giants parka, hat and good-humor-despite-everything expression, Mara said he heard everything swirling around the Giants since Sunday's crushing loss to Atlanta.

title: Accountant At Tyco Tells Of Payments To Executives
description: An accountant for Tyco International told jurors yesterday how she and other company employees recorded bonus payments and loans made to the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, and the former chief financial officer, Mark H. Swartz.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Best Buy Offers Musicnow's Download Service
description: The Best Buy Company, the nation's largest electronics chain, will make MusicNow's download service available on the company's Web site to let shoppers purchase music from the Internet. More than 400,000 songs can be bought for 99 cents each from the site, Best Buy, which is based in Richfield, Minn., said in a statement. A monthly $9.95 subscription will also be available. A MusicNow spokesman, Greg Rudin, declined to comment on details of the revenue-sharing agreement. Web music sales are forecast to rise to about $700 million in 2008, from $35 million this year, as more people buy downloaded songs, according to Jupiter Research, a technology research firm. Best Buy, which sells music CD's, already offers a download service from RealNetworks' Rhapsody service. Best Buy also will feature the music service of closely held MusicNow on kiosks in its stores. The digital downloads from MusicNow, based in Chicago, can be transferred to more than 40 portable listening devices, Best Buy said. The subscription service is also available at other retailers. Shares of Best Buy rose 64 cents, to $58.78.

title: Russia Ready to Aid Iran With A-Plant
description: Russia and Iran appeared to draw closer on Monday to an agreement that would clear the way for the completion of a nuclear power plant that Russians are building in Iran.

title: Alliance Ousts 2 Executives, Seeing a Failure To Police Trades
description: Alliance Capital Management said yesterday that it had requested the resignations of two senior executives because they failed to prevent improper trading in its mutual funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNE, ELIOT ''BUDDY''
description: BERNE--Eliot ''Buddy'', veteran of WWII, peacefully on November 10, at 79. Survived by Ruth, his extraordinary wife of 57 years. Loving father of Bob & Shelley Berne, Cathy & Peter DeMartis, Allison & Bruce Nadler, Bill & Lori Berne. Devoted grandfather of Rebecca, Jessie, Michael, Alyssa, Carly, Craig, Jessica and Gaby. Devoted brother of Junerose & Bernard Dolgin and David & Joan Blum. His love for life continues to inspire his family and friends.

title: Euro RSCG Agency Focuses on Latinos
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas, is forming an agency, Euro RSCG Latino, to specialize in marketing to Spanish-speaking consumers in the United States and offer creative advice on campaigns for Latin America. Initial clients include MCI and Polaroid.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Auto Stake For Sale
description: Creditors of the auto maker Ssangyong Motors said that they would put their stake up for sale. The creditors, including Chohung Bank and 27 others, plan to offer their 54 percent stake in December, according to a regulatory filing by Ssangyong. The company has been run by its creditors since 1999 when the Daewoo Group, its parent at the time, filed for bankruptcy. Ssangyong sells most of its vehicles domestically and has been profitable the last few years after carving out a niche for sport utility vehicles. Sam Len (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Warning On Israeli Baby Formula
description: City health officials warned New Yorkers yesterday that an Israeli baby formula called Remedia could harm infants because it lacked a crucial vitamin. They said that Americans might have bought it on trips to Israel, or had it shipped to them by relatives there. They also cited unconfirmed reports that one or two stores in Brooklyn might have stocked Remedia. Israeli officials have said that since last spring, vitamin B1 has been left out of the kosher version of Remedia, causing the deaths of three children and brain damage in others. The Israeli government has also begun a criminal investigation into the possibility that the formula was sabotaged. The formula is made by a German company, Humana Milchunion, and marketed by Heinz Remedia, an Israeli company mostly owned by the American conglomerate H. J. Heinz. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Iraqi Security Forces Outnumber American Troops, U.S. Says
description: International Herald Tribune

title: A Sly Arrangement of Chamber Music
description: The influence of Messiaen's "Quartet for the End of Time" on contemporary chamber music has been such that even when it isn't played, one can often see its shadow. The young musicians in Antares play the instruments that the Messiaen requires: violin, clarinet, piano and cello. By deploying themselves in different combinations, they are able to play a fairly broad repertory, and they proved as much on Nov. 5 in an installment of the Contemporary Classic Italian series at the Italian Academy for Advanced Studies in America, at Columbia University.

title: Memo at Rosie Trial Reveals Plan to 'Manage Financials'
description: For more than a week, the court case between Rosie O'Donnell and Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing has provided drama, tears and a criss-cross of accusations over which side was to blame for the demise of Rosie magazine. But yesterday, those who were enticed to attend by the legal hi-jinks of the past week were treated to a very deliberate tutorial on business accounting.

title: Rudolph E. Tanzi
description: Neurobiologist and director, Genetics and Aging Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: Is Evolution Truly Random?
description: In nearly every life, there is a moment when a person realizes, with a shudder, how easily she might never have come to be: how her parents nearly missed meeting, or how some other critical genealogical event almost didn't happen.

title: Reopening Planned for RCA Building Deck
description: Seventeen years after Rockefeller Center closed the historic observation decks atop 30 Rockefeller Plaza, developers plan to renovate the space and reopen it to the public, pending city approval.

title: Sir Paul M. Nurse
description: President, Rockefeller University, 2001 Nobel Prize winner for medicine.

title: After the Crossing, Danger to Migrants Isn't Over
description: A new Spanish word has entered the American lexicon: bajadero.

title: Songs of a Modern Allegiance and Reverence
description: Many countries with small military budgets arm themselves with culture. Art tells outsiders what a people think and feel; it also provides a rallying ground and common cause for those within a nation's borders. Never underestimate its power.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Carrier Posts Profit
description: Reflecting the recovery in global shipping, Neptune Orient Lines said that it earned $205.8 million in the third quarter, reversing a $28.5 million loss a year earlier. Neptune Orient, which owns American President Lines, also said it would offer stockholders about $300 million in new shares to pay off debts. Recovering export demand from the United States has spurred a boom in shipping in Asia, sending rates higher and shipbuilders into high gear filling orders for new vessels. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: CONVENTION CENTER LAW REVERSAL A year-old law that gave Republicans control of the Pennsylvania Convention Center in Philadelphia has been ruled unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court, which said it addressed too wide a range of subjects. The court delayed imposition of its decision, issued on Friday, for three months to give the General Assembly time "to consider appropriate remedial measures." The law, which among other things expanded the Pennsylvania Convention Authority with appointees chosen by legislative leaders and from Republican-leaning suburban counties, was passed in response to labor troubles at the center.    (AP)

title: Jack C. Grigg, 83, a Shaper Of Nuclear Navy's Systems
description: Jack Clifton Grigg, an electrical engineer who helped guide the Navy into the age of nuclear propulsion and the country into the realm of commercial nuclear power, died on Nov. 1 at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ELLMAN, SIDNEY
description: ELLMAN--Sidney. Born ninety years ago, missed all the years to come. Joyce

title: Baiting North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.C.'s Graduation Rate to Rise, Study Says
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference not only bolstered its power on the football field by adding Miami, Virginia Tech and Boston College, it is also on the way to raising its graduation rate, according to a study released yesterday by the Institute for Diversity and Ethics in Sport at the University of Central Florida.

title: Fund Is Started to Defend Paroled Killer in Beating Case
description: A Quaker official who helped set up a counseling job for Thomas Trantino, the paroled killer of two police officers, said on Monday that she had started a defense fund in his behalf.

title: Tehran Journal; Marriages Made Not in Heaven but in a Cleric's Office
description: Jaffar Savalanpour Ardabili, 38, a midranking Shiite cleric, sits at his desk, sifting through reams of applications filled with yearning.

title: The Presidents Veterans Day Speech
description: WASHINGTON  Following is the text of President Bush's address to the Heritage Foundation, as recorded by e-Media:

title: Meeting Online: But Will You Really Click?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTNETT, TIMOTHY V.
description: HARTNETT--Timothy V. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Timothy V. Hartnett, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, Pres. Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: New York Cabdrivers Deserve Better
description: In a city not known for bargains, there are thousands available every day on the streets of New York, in the confines of a yellow cab. At $2 plus 30 cents for every fifth of a mile, and no extra charge for additional passengers, riders enjoy one of the least expensive taxi fare rates among the nation's largest cities. And while that may seem a good deal for residents and visitors, those who feel the pinch -- cabdrivers and garage operators -- want a fare increase. And they should get it.

title: The Long Shadow of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUEST, LUCY C. (C.Z.)
description: GUEST--Lucy C. (C.Z.) of Old Westbury, L.I., on November 8th, 2003. Loving wife to the late Winston. Adored mother of Cornelia and Alexander. ''Ganny'' to her grandchildren who she called her ''3 Hercules'', Gregory, Winston and Ivor. Memorial service is on Saturday, November 15, 2003 at 11:00AM, Church of the Advent, located at 555 Advent St, Westbury, NY 11590. In lieu of flowers, a donation can be made to the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, Suite 351, 450 Shrewsbury Plaza, Shrewsbury, NJ 07702.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day yesterday reported on discussions between Rupert Murdoch's company, the News Corporation, and a Russian media company, Gazprom. Citing people close to the negotiations, the article said the News Corporation was in talks on a potential acquisition of the satellite business of NTV, the television network owned by Gazprom. The Times should have obtained comment from the two companies.

title: Meeting Online: But Will You Really Click?
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Leaders Say Officers Shouldn't Moonlight at Bars
description: New York City police officials came out strongly yesterday against a proposal that would allow off-duty officers to work extra jobs providing security outside bars and nightclubs.

title: Support The Troops
description: Yesterday's absurd conspiracy theory about the Bush administration has a way of turning into today's conventional wisdom. Remember when people were ridiculed for claiming that Dick Cheney and Paul Wolfowitz, eager to fight a war, were hyping the threat from Iraq?

title: West Farms Journal; Does a Burger Slay Hunger Or Reflect a Violent Past?
description: The Murder Burger -- half a pound of ground beef mixed with bread crumbs, Worcestershire sauce, adobo spice mix, milk, eggs and a dash of Accent seasoning cooked to succulence atop the skillet and served on a kaiser roll with onions, relish and secret sauce -- has not changed much since the First-Way Deli in the Bronx first put it on the menu nearly 20 years ago.

title: MetroStars Face Changes for '04
description: Tim Howard made a seamless transition to starting goalkeeper with Manchester United, but his departure from Major League Soccer left a hole in the heart of his former team, the MetroStars.

title: Mother of Boy Who Was Abducted, Then Found, Will Not Be Charged
description: A mother whose toddler was abducted by a car thief when she left him unattended in the back seat on Saturday will not face charges, District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said yesterday. He characterized the case as a cautionary tale rather than a criminal one.

title: He Really Wants To Direct
description: Last week when Tom Ford announced that he would be leaving as creative director of Gucci next year, the world -- or that sector of it concerned with the professional trajectories of fashion designers -- began to play the parlor game of guessing what he might do next. Take over Versace? (It's not for sale.) Start his own line? (Too small a challenge at this point.) Fortunately, Mr. Ford has made things relatively simple for the contestants: Over the years, like so many models, actors, cinematographers, best boys, gaffers and grips before him, he has said that what he really wants to do is to try his hand at the movie business.

title: In Year of Outsider, an Insider Holds His Own
description: If this is going to be the year of the outsider, Representative Richard A. Gephardt is talking up what might seem to be an unlikely asset: his 27 years in Congress.

title: Most Extreme Sport Catches On, Again
description: Those who know the Banzai Pipeline don't call it so. Man-eater is more common. Meat grinder. Cement mixer. Or just Pipe.

title: Work Out, See a Rembrandt or Play the Slots, All Between Flights
description: Most business travelers loathe airline delays. Not Peter Shankman, if the airport is McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAJID, DR. AHMED ABDUL
description: MAJID--Dr. Ahmed Abdul. Beloved husband of the late Ekbal Basith and loving father of daughters, Aliza and Nerissa. He will be dearly missed by family and friends whose lives he touched with love, intellect and humor. Dr. Majid was a professor at the New York Institute of Technology for over 30 years. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 10AM-12 noon, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment Wednesday, 11:30AM, Rosehill Cemetery, Linden, NJ.

title: A. Michael DeSisto, 64, Who Founded School for Troubled Youth, Dies
description: A. Michael DeSisto, founder and headmaster of the innovative DeSisto School in Stockbridge, Mass., which specializes in helping troubled adolescents through unusual programs in fields like the culinary and performing arts, died on Nov. 1 in Boston. He was 64 and lived on the school's campus.

title: Japan and E.U. Threaten U.S. on Import Sanctions
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 11  A day after the World Trade Organization ruled that American steel tariffs are illegal, Japan and the European Union threatened the United States today with billions of dollars' worth of sanctions. China and South Korea threatened similar action if Washington retained the tariffs on imported steel.

title: Rule of Gun Said to Imperil Afghan Democracy Efforts
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 11 — Terrorism, drug-related crime and factional fighting in Afghanistan threaten to reverse advances in the rebuilding of the country and jeopardize efforts to establish a democratically elected government, the German ambassador to the United Nations told the Security Council today.

title: F.C.C. Backs Phone Number Portability
description: Starting Nov. 24, consumers will be able to switch their home telephone numbers to their mobile phones, the Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday. The order sets the stage for a scramble by traditional phone companies seeking to keep their customers as they face fierce competition from cellular providers and a growing threat from Internet-based phone services.

title: Here Come the Last-Minute Riders
description: End-of-session spending bills provide fertile ground for mischievous last-minute amendments, often at the expense of the environment. Bill Clinton vetoed many dubious legislative riders. The Bush administration, however, seems largely indifferent to the practice, especially when the legislators involved are Republicans of some standing. There are two particularly egregious riders now before the Senate. Both should be voted down, not only because they would benefit a narrow constituency (most riders do) but also because they would undermine basic environmental protections.

title: Suit by Wal-Mart Cleaners Asserts Rackets Violation
description: Lawyers filed a class-action suit against Wal-Mart yesterday in New Jersey, saying it violated federal racketeering laws by conspiring with cleaning contractors to cheat immigrant janitors out of wages.

title: Clones, Quarks and a Cosmos or Two
description: Correction: November 18, 2003, Tuesday A picture in Science Times last Tuesday with a chart showing scientific milestones of the last 25 years was published in error. It showed a laboratory rat, not a "knockout" mouse with a suppressed gene.

title: Rousing Science Out of the Lab and Into the Limelight
description: Last summer, the pollster Daniel Yankelovich reported what might seem a strange finding: scientists are distressed by the media's insistence on presenting ''both sides.''

title: Appliance Store Owner Jailed in Fraud Case
description: It isn't easy to win superlatives running a small appliance-repair shop, but the authorities say that after more than 15 years in business, Doug and Lori Cass have earned one: operators of the worst business in Suffolk County.

title: Brian Williams to Leave His CNBC Program
description: As he prepares to succeed Tom Brokaw as the anchor of the ''NBC Nightly News'' after the 2004 presidential election, Brian Williams is shedding a high-profile assignment on one of the network's cable channels.

title: Art Carney, Played Ed Norton on The Honeymooners, Dies at 85
description: Art Carney, the Academy Award-winning comic actor who first gained fame as the guffawing, slightly off-center sewer worker Ed Norton in the early 1950's television series "The Honeymooners," died on Sunday at a convalescent home in Chester, Conn. He was 85.

title: Spare Revival of 'Town' Could Be a Long Shot
description: On the face of it, the new staging of ''Wonderful Town'' that is about to open on Broadway does not look like much of a risk.

title: German Company Says Baby Formula Lacked Vital Ingredient
description: BERLIN, Nov. 11  Following the deaths of two children in Israel because of a severe vitamin deficiency, the German manufacturer of an infant formula admitted today that a kosher, soy-based product it sells in Israel was missing an ingredient necessary to sustain infant life.

title: Can Robots Become Conscious?
description: It's a three-part question. What is consciousness? Can you put it in a machine? And if you did, how could you ever know for sure?

title: Final Defeat for Tiger Lady Means End of Preserve
description: The tigers are finally leaving New Jersey.

title: The Things They Wrote
description: Veterans Day honors all who have served in the military -- in peace and in war, at home and abroad, living and dead. Today is the 50th anniversary of the holiday renamed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 to ''solemnly remember the sacrifices of all those who fought so valiantly, on the seas, in the air, and on foreign shores, to preserve our heritage of freedom.'' Before 1954 the holiday was called Armistice Day.

title: For Disco's First Diva, It's Still Not Last Dance
description: Disco music has faded, but Donna Summer hasn't. The uncontested Queen of Disco, a sultry singer whose music defined an era, Ms. Summer says she is no longer a diva, no longer a sex goddess, no longer locked into the music of the 1970's. After several years without making a record, she has released one album, is starting another and plans a concert tour in the new year.

title: Younger Suspect Pleads Not Guilty in Killing
description: He speaks softly, in a breathy, high-pitched voice that has not yet fully hardened into adulthood, and his jaunty, even cocky, attitude does not always fit the gravity of his circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVENE, JULIET KALIKOW
description: LEVENE--Juliet Kalikow. I well remember this day three years ago, when you finally gained relief from all suffering, and found the peace you so needed. I also remember the many wonderful years we shared. Sleep well in peace. Stephen

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Camera Maker's Profit Rises
description: The Olympus Corporation said profit rose 16 percent in the six months that ended Sept. 30, helped by sales of digital cameras. Olympus earned 15.5 billion yen ($141 million) as sales grew 15 percent, to 300 billion yen ($2.7 billion). The company still expects to earn 37 billion yen ($336 million) for the year, but raised its sales goal 1.5 percent, to 660 billion yen ($6 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARCOVE, RALPH, M.D.
description: MARCOVE--Ralph, M.D. Happy Birthday. Loved and remembered today and each day. Christina and Laura

title: Corrections
description: A credit note was omitted yesterday from the front-page article about Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest man, now under arrest on fraud charges. Sabrina Tavernise reported from Moscow and Timothy L. O'Brien from New York.

title: The White House Steel Trap
description: To no one's surprise, the World Trade Organization issued a final ruling yesterday that the Bush administration violated trade laws when it slapped onerous tariffs on an array of steel imports last year. The tariffs, as harmful to the American economy as they were to foreign exporters, were a political gambit, aimed at scoring points in such key electoral battlegrounds as Pennsylvania.

title: Scientists Look Ahead
description: Sir Paul M. Nurse

title: Cronkite Responds To Video Lawsuit
description: In a legal filing, Walter Cronkite, the former CBS news anchor, said a Florida television production company misled him and tarnished his reputation when it persuaded him to appear in videos that promoted prescription drugs and other products.

title: A Window Washer Falls to His Death
description: A window washer fell to his death yesterday from the 12th floor of an apartment building at 38 West 26th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Ex-Guatemalan Dictator's Political Career Screeches to a Halt
description: The people of Guatemala, long plagued by war, corruption and poverty, have sent their former dictator into political retirement, and perhaps to a war crimes court, with a resounding vote against him, election returns showed Monday.

title: FRIEND OF THE COURT: One Lawyer's Inside Track; Cozying Up to Judges, and Reaping Opportunity
description: Ravi Batra practices the kind of law that does not come with steno pools or 40th-floor conference rooms with views of Central Park. His office is in a brick building in a section of Manhattan known as Little India. His legal pedigree is respectable but unremarkable. His clients tend to be small companies or people who have been hurt in accidents.

title: What Is the Next Plague?
description: No one knows when or where the next plague will occur, or whether it will be from a natural or bioterrorist attack.

title: Deadline in Ferry Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Berroa Edges Matsui for Rookie of the Year Award
description: A first-place vote in the rookie of the year balloting is worth 5 points. Hideki Matsui missed winning the award yesterday by a smaller margin than that.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMATO, MARIA ADELAIDE
description: AMATO--Maria Adelaide. On November 10, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Frank Amato. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, November 11th, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Wednesday, 10:30AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Saint Jude's Shrine, Pallotine Fathers, 309 North Paca Street, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

title: Accounts
description: Buffets Inc., Eagan, Minn., which operates 400 restaurants in 36 states, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by the Minneapolis office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Star Names Executive
description: The Star Group, an Asian satellite television provider owned by the News Corporation, said that Michelle Guthrie, left, its executive vice president for business development, would become its chief executive. She succeeds James Murdoch, who has been nominated to become chief of BSkyB, a pay TV company in Europe; News Corporation owns 35.4 percent of BSkyB. Mr. Murdoch is a son of Rupert Murdoch, who controls the News Corporation. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Modernista Is Chosen By TIAA-CREF
description: TIAA-CREF in New York, the financial services company, is changing agencies on its account after a closely watched review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAFTALI, RAYMOND
description: NAFTALI -- Raymond. No vember 7, 2003. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Nicole. Cherished grandfather of Anthony. He was a deeply respected and admired man who enjoyed life with his family and friends to the fullest. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Monday, 7-9 PM, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with a service at Frank E. Campbell Wednesday, November 12, 11:30 AM.

title: Unexpected Selections In a Sacred Program
description: For his program of sacred works at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, George Steel avoided the usual sources, including Renaissance and Baroque settings that he has conducted to great effect in the past and even conventional religious settings by modern composers. Instead he turned on Saturday night to the works of musical iconoclasts who either treated conventional religious ideas in peculiar ways or used their music to imagine religious notions that are beyond the Western canon, and, in one case, entirely fanciful.

title: Corrections
description: Acredit note was omitted yesterday from the front-page article about Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest man, now under arrest on fraud charges. Sabrina Tavernise reported from Moscow and Timothy L. O'Brien from New York.

title: BIG COPPER AND GOLD MINER REVISES PROFIT DOWNWARD
description: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold Inc., owner of the world's largest gold mine, said third-quarter profit was 14 percent lower than reported last month, as some copper sales were incorrectly recorded. Net income was $53.5 million, or 29 cents a share, excluding $8.5 million, or 4 cents, of profit from copper sales that will be recorded during the current quarter, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The per-share earnings reflect payment of dividends on preferred stock. The company lowered third-quarter revenue to $632 million from the previously reported $668.8 million. Net income after payment of dividends was $47.4 million. The company had net income of $71 million, or 39 cents a share, in the third quarter of 2002.

title: Finding Common Ground In Asking the Court to Act
description: While the Supreme Court often receives unsolicited advice in the form of briefs from ''friends of the court,'' the briefs filed on behalf of the Guantnamo Bay detainees reflected an unusual range of backgrounds and vantage points, all with the single focus of persuading the justices to hear the cases.

title: Cheney Theme of Qaeda Ties to Bombings in Iraq Is Questioned by Some in Administration
description: Vice President Dick Cheney has in recent speeches mentioned the major bombings in Iraq this past summer in the same breath as the deadly strikes in Bali, Casablanca and Riyadh, which authorities say were carried out by Al Qaeda or groups affiliated with it.

title: Senator Urges Action on Tax Shelters
description: Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, called yesterday for increased penalties against accounting firms that design and sell abusive tax shelters and announced Congressional hearings next week to spotlight the firms, their executives and their sales practices.

title: The Secret Life of a Retirement Account
description: In 1997, Congress gave retirement savers an attractive deal: put after-tax dollars into a Roth I.R.A. and withdraw all future investment gains and contributions without ever paying another penny of tax.

title: KERRY DISMISSES CAMPAIGN CHIEF
description: Senator John Kerry announced on Monday that he had fired his campaign manager as he struggled to revive a candidacy that has tumbled from a dominant position in the Democratic presidential contest.

title: National Briefing | Washington: 26 Democrats To Demand Rumsfeld's Ouster
description: Twenty-six House Democrats have agreed to support a resolution calling for the resignation of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, said Representative Charles B. Rangel, the senior Democrat from New York who sponsored the measure. The resolution accuses Mr. Rumsfeld of ''gross mismanagement'' in planning and conducting the war in Iraq and of misleading the public on progress since Baghdad fell. Two other senior House Democrats had already called for a shake-up of the Pentagon's management. David Firestone (NYT)

title: NBC Faults Nielsen for Reduction in Viewers
description: After some dogged investigating, NBC yesterday offered up its answer to television's big mystery of the fall, the case of the disappearing young, male viewer. And in this television version of Clue, the solution by NBC was a young Hispanic man, in the living room, with the remote. Or perhaps more accurately, without the remote.

title: Sports of The Times; It Is Not Time for Flutie To Ride Off Into Sunset
description: IT has come to this: Age, as Shakespeare might have put it, cannot wither Doug Flutie.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No Spitting Or Smooching
description: Moscow authorities are considering a ban on kissing in the subway and in other public places. The rule could go into effect early next year as part of a draft resolution aimed at ''improving morals'' in the city, according to the newspaper Stolichnaya Vechernyaya Gazeta, which first reported the proposal. Also to be banned under the plan are public drinking, spitting, loud cursing and drunkenness, the newspaper said. The kissing ban would apply to all couples, including spouses. Fines would range from 300 to 500 rubles ($10 to $17). If a kissing couple did not have the money for the fine, the police could hold them until someone paid it. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: New York Pays Highest Taxes, Study Finds
description: New Yorkers pay more of their income in local taxes than residents of any other state, according to a study by a budget watchdog group.

title: The Things They Wrote
description: Veterans Day honors all who have served in the military -- in peace and in war, at home and abroad, living and dead. Today is the 50th anniversary of the holiday renamed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 to ''solemnly remember the sacrifices of all those who fought so valiantly, on the seas, in the air, and on foreign shores, to preserve our heritage of freedom.'' Before 1954 the holiday was called Armistice Day.

title: Aircraft Security
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. APPROVES GENERIC VERSION OF BACTROBAN
description: Agis Industries, an Israeli generic drug maker, received Food and Drug Administration approval to sell a version of GlaxoSmithKline's Bactroban. Agis got approval yesterday to market the ointment for the children's skin disease impetigo, it said in a statement to the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. Teva Pharmaceutical Industries also said it won the F.D.A.'s approval to sell its Bactroban-like product. Bactroban had United States sales of $97 million in the last 12 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINGOLD, J. PAUL
description: FINGOLD--J. Paul. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, J. Paul Fingold, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife Malka and other members of her family. Michael Stein, President Stephen Fiverson, Secretary

title: C. Z. Guest, American Classic
description: Pity the poor socialite today. She will never know what it's like to be painted in the nude by Diego Rivera or photographed in couture by Cecil Beaton, Horst and Louise Dahl-Wolfe, though she can claim one or two paparazzi snaps. Her company will never be sought by Ernest Hemingway, Truman Capote or the Maharaja of Jaipur. And she most definitely can't say she has been hunting with Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

title: Farrah Fawcett Play Closes in Previews
description: In a sudden and unusual move, the producer of ''Bobbi Boland,'' a comedy starring Farrah Fawcett in her Broadway debut as a former beauty queen, decided yesterday to close the show after only a week of previews.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Guilty Plea In Insurance Fraud
description: An insurance adjuster pleaded guilty yesterday to operating an ''arson-for-profit'' scheme. Prosecutors said the adjuster, Marc Rossi, 39, a former investigator with the Mercer County prosecutor's office, was responsible for six fires that eventually netted him more than $500,000. No one was reported hurt in the fires. Mr. Rossi admitted to conspiring with others to set fire to the conspirators' homes and businesses and share in the insurance proceeds. They were also accused of setting fires at other buildings without the owners' knowledge, said John Haggerty, a spokesman for the New Jersey attorney general's office. Mr. Rossi faces 10 years in state prison and more than $500,000 in restitution to various insurance companies. His sentencing is scheduled for Jan. 9.

title: South Africa's Ruling Party Struggles Within
description: Less than six months before South Africa's third presidential election, the ruling African National Congress is embroiled in an internal bloodletting that it seems powerless to stop.

title: Looking for Truth In TV Biopics
description: To the Editor:

title: School Unions Want to Cancel Labor Hearings, Official Says
description: Labor unions and elected officials are pressuring the City Council's Education Committee to cancel four days of hearings on union work rules governing teachers, principals and custodians, the committee chairwoman said yesterday.

title: Are Men Necessary?
description: Well, are they?

title: The Long Shadow of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Injured Shockey May Miss The Rest of the Season
description: Of all the blows the Giants have absorbed this season, losing tight end Jeremy Shockey to a knee injury may be the most painful.

title: How Much Of the Body Is Replaceable?
description: Legend has it that in the fifth century A.D., a beautiful woman kissed the hand of Pope Leo I during Mass. The pope, mortified at feeling desire for the woman, ordered a servant to cut off the offending hand. The Virgin Mary later restored the limb by performing the Miracle of the Severed Hand, an act immortalized in stained glass at the Church of Orsanmichele in Florence.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Are Animals Smarter Than We Think?
description: Debating the intelligence of animals can be as unsatisfying as arguing over free will. Which animals? What do you mean by intelligence?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, JANE TRAFFORD LUKE
description: MURPHY -- Jane Trafford Luke. Died on Wednesday, November 5, 2003, from complications from Lupus. She is lovingly remembered by her friends and family for her courageous battle with the disease, and for her generous spirit. Born October 17, 1953 in Charleston, S.C., Jane earned a B.S. from Briarcliff College and her R.N. from Pace University. A devoted mother to her two sons, Jane was an active volunteer at Greens Farms Academy, and she was a member of the Women's Fellowship at Trinity Church. Jane is survived by her husband, Jonathan J. Murphy, two sons, J. Luke Murphy and Gordon T. Murphy, all of Fairfield, CT.; her parents, Joy and John A. Luke, Sr., a brother John A. Luke, Jr., and a sister, Hope L. Hetherington, all of New Canaan, CT.; a brother William H. Luke of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Southport, CT on Tuesday, November 11th, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Jane's memory to the Lupus Research Institute, 149 Madison Ave, Suite 205, N.Y., N.Y. 10016

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brewer's Profit Slips
description: Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, the world's fifth-biggest brewer, reported a third-quarter profit of 340 million reais ($118 million) nearly a third weaker than in the period a year earlier, when the company benefited from a tax break. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, another indicator of the company's health, grew to 777.8 million reais ($270 million), compared with 644.4 million reais a year earlier. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Wounded G.I.'s in the Care Of Wounded Veteran of '91
description: When a squad of dark gray buses pulled up at the Army hospital here this week, bearing 21 soldiers wounded in an attack on their Chinook helicopter, none of the waiting doctors could identify with the victims quite the way the hospital's commander, Col. Rhonda L. Cornum, did.

title: Should We Improve Our Genome?
description: Now that we have decoded the human genome, why don't we improve it?

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: PROTESTERS INCREASE PRESSURE Opposition activists threatened a hunger strike and reportedly blocked trainloads of government troops headed for the capital, Tbilisi, as thousands of protesters gathered outside Parliament for a third straight day, calling for the resignation of President Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Parliament. More than a week after parliamentary elections last Sunday, the vote count has still not been completed. The latest figures showed Mr. Shevardnadze's bloc with a slight lead. Opposition leaders want the election declared invalid. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: How Much Nature Is Enough?
description: Even some ardent conservationists acknowledge that the diversity of life on Earth cannot be fully sustained as human populations expand, use more resources, nudge the climate and move weedlike pests and predators from place to place.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: INSIDE
description: Sniper Prosecution Rests

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 1 about James O'Gara, a retired editor of Commonweal magazine, misspelled the surname of one of its former publishers. He was Edward S. Skillin, not Sklin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, MILTON S.
description: SHAPIRO--Milton S. Milton's wisdom and insight overflowed into the lives of all those with whom he came into contact. We were privileged to be among those who knew him. The many facets of his character, his humor and his wit are now ingrained in all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his cherished wife Bea, his beloved daughter Susan and son Philip and to all his family and friends who will miss him deeply. The employees of Liberty Maritime Corporation

title: SUPERIOR TELECOM REPORTS IT IS OUT OF BANKRUPTCY
description: Superior TeleCom Inc., North America's largest maker of copper-wire and cable products before it sought bankruptcy in March, said it exited court protection as Superior Essex Inc. and appointed Stephen M. Carter as chief executive. Last month, Superior won court approval of a bankruptcy recovery plan to eliminate $1.1 billion in debt. The company is based in Atlanta.

title: Virginia Prosecutors Close Their Case at One Sniper Trial
description: The prosecution rested its case against John A. Muhammad on Monday, asserting that he had devised and directed a scheme of serial killings intended to terrorize the Washington area and extort $10 million from local governments.

title: The Birth of Science Times: A Surprise, but No Accident
description: Twenty-five years ago, editors of The New York Times had a big problem: what to do about Tuesdays?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, ARNOLD J.
description: BERNSTEIN--Arnold J. The entire Board of Trustees and the Blythedale Children's Hospital community mourn the loss of our dear friend and long-standing Board Member, Arnold J. Bernstein. Arnold was a devoted supporter of the work of the Hospital since 1953 when he became a member of the Board. In 1964, he became Vice President, a position he held until 1972 when he was elected to a five-year term as President of the Board. In 1990, Arnold stepped down as a member of our ''active'' Board and became an Honorary Trustee. He cared deeply about our children and their care. We send deep and sincere condolences to his wife Jeanne, his daughters Linda Miller, Carol Clark and Janael McQueen, as well as the entire Bernstein family. Laurence W. Cohen, Chair of the Board of Trustees Larry Levine, President and CEO Joelle Mast, PhD, M.D., VP and Chief Medical Officer

title: British Air Reports 36% Drop In Profits
description: British Airways, the largest airline in Europe, said Monday that profit declined 36 percent in its second quarter, a result of slimmed-down corporate travel budgets and a wildcat strike.

title: Bicycle Repairmen and Their Flying Machines
description: For gentle boys who shun ''Punk'd,'' porn and PlayStation -- those enchanting third-graders who even now sort coin collections atop bedspreads spangled with Saturns -- television has always been easy. Send in the usual wonderment programming: race cars, rockets, engineering, science.

title: Iraqi Tribes, Asked to Help G.I.'s, Say They Can't
description: As a tribal chieftain in Iraq's most rebellious city, Sheik Khamis el-Essawi has met more American commanders in the last seven months than he can remember.

title: Can Science Prove the Existence of God?
description: ''I have no need for that hypothesis,'' Pierre-Simon Laplace famously responded when asked where God fit into his new astronomical theory. Using calculus and Newton's laws of gravity, he explained the forces that kept the planets from gradually drifting out of orbit, imparting some stability to the solar system. Newton had thought the Great Engineer must step in now and then to readjust the machine.

title: Revenge of the One-Hit Wonders, Hip-Hop Division
description: Whenever I see talented performers crammed into a play that isn't good enough for them, I rue the day musical theater decided that shows with plots were more sophisticated than revues, vaudeville and variety. I want to shout, ''Don't let a little thing like a script get between you and your audience.''

title: The Long Shadow of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIEN, DONNA JOY
description: LEVIEN--Donna Joy. Love changes everything, how we live and how we die. You lived to the fullest. You battled courageously. Your love, smile and warmth will be missed by so many. Our hearts are with Phil, Jeffrey, Ivy, Grayson, Mark, Joanne, Ron and Ellen. Love, Roni, Greg, Kate, Auden, Sandy and Jarret

title: The Things They Wrote
description: Veterans Day honors all who have served in the military -- in peace and in war, at home and abroad, living and dead. Today is the 50th anniversary of the holiday renamed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 to ''solemnly remember the sacrifices of all those who fought so valiantly, on the seas, in the air, and on foreign shores, to preserve our heritage of freedom.'' Before 1954 the holiday was called Armistice Day.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CARSON, BROOKE J.
description: CARSON--Brooke J. First you called it your bird-day, then when you were older you were so proud that your birthday was on the same day on which our Veterans were honored. Brooke, we miss you. Best love, Mother, Ian and Devereaux

title: What Happened Before the Big Bang?
description: Like baseball, in which three strikes make an out, three outs on a side make an inning, nine innings make a regular game, the universe makes its own time. There is no outside timekeeper. Space and time are part of the universe, not the other way around, thinkers since Augustine have said, and that is one of the central and haunting lessons of Einstein's general theory of relativity.

title: What Did We Learn From AIDS?
description: If AIDS is any indication, the plagues that await us in the future are certain to leave scientists far wiser than they are today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTJET, Calgary, Alberta, said it would exercise options to buy seven 737-700 aircraft from Boeing, Chicago, for about $329 million, based on the low end of Boeing's 737-700 catalog price.

title: Martha McClintock
description: Director, In stitute for Mind and Biology, University of Chicago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Administrative Judge Promoted
description: The chief administrative judge for the State Supreme Courts in Brooklyn and Staten Island was named yesterday to become New York State's first deputy chief administrative judge, effective Jan. 1. The judge, Ann T. Pfau, was brought in to oversee Brooklyn's courts early last year after a Brooklyn judge was charged with bribery. Inquiries were begun into the activities of several other judges as well. During her tenure, Justice Pfau, 55, oversaw investigators' placement of a hidden camera in the robing room of a second judge charged with taking bribes. Justice Pfau will be succeeded by a Brooklyn Supreme Court justice, Neil Jon Firetog. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Russian Court Refuses to Release Jailed Billionaire on Bail
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11 - A court here refused today to free Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest businessman, upholding an earlier decision to hold him in prison at least until the end of the year as prosecutors complete an investigation into charges of fraud, tax evasion and other crimes.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Ex-Commissioner Pleads Guilty
description: A week and a half after her conviction on state perjury and obstruction of justice charges, the former state agriculture commissioner, Meg Scott Phipps, pleaded guilty to related federal extortion charges. Ms. Phipps accepted illegal campaign donations, sometimes personally, in exchange for state fair contracts, said Frank D. Whitney, a United States attorney. In the state case, Ms. Phipps's lawyers had argued that her staff took the payments without her knowledge. Ms. Phipps, the daughter and granddaughter of governors, faces up to 55 years in prison on the federal charges but will probably be sentenced to about 5 years, Mr. Whitney said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Does Science Matter?
description: Through its rituals of discovery, science has extended life, conquered disease and offered new sexual and commercial freedoms. It has pushed aside demigods and demons and revealed a cosmos more intricate and awesome than anything produced by pure imagination.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These alien smugglers are the lowest form of life. They are rapists and glue sniffers and they have no regard for human life. They sell someone a dream and quite often they steal it.''

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 393 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: SOUTH DAKOTA: SPLIT RULING FOR CONGRESSMAN A judge ruled that jurors in Representative Bill Janklow's coming trial in the death of a motorcyclist can hear testimony about a close call he had at the same intersection, but not about 3 accidents and 12 speeding tickets. Mr. Janklow, a former governor elected to Congress last year, is charged with manslaughter in the accident near Trent on Aug. 16. His trial is to start on Dec. 1. Judge Rodney Steele said the law did not allow testimony about Mr. Janklow's driving record, but did allow testimony by Jennifer Walters of Trent, who has said that in December 2002, Mr. Janklow nearly hit her family's pickup truck.    (AP)

title: Cynics Without A Cause
description: Over the past few months, the Democratic presidential candidates have been peddling a story. The story is that the Bush administration is circumventing the competitive bidding process to funnel sweetheart Iraq reconstruction contracts to major campaign contributors, especially Dick Cheney's old firm, Halliburton.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel and Son Are Well Aware of How the Story Ends
description: JOHN FASSEL watched his father's New York Giants get smacked around by the lowly Atlanta Falcons from his office at New Mexico Highlands University in Las Vegas, N.M.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC GROUP TO ACQUIRE CHEMICALS MAKER
description: The Texas Pacific Group, a buyout firm run by David Bonderman, will acquire a chemicals maker, the Kraton Polymers Group, from another private equity group, Ripplewood Holdings, for $770 million. Ripplewood bought Kraton Polymers for $520 million in February 2001 from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Ripplewood's managing director, Ian Snow, said. Texas Pacific, which was founded in 1993, is acquiring companies as it raises more than $4 billion for a new buyout fund. Kraton Polymers, which is based in Houston, makes products that enhance adhesives, asphalt and footwear. It has 1,000 employees, annual revenue of more than $600 million and factories in Europe, Brazil, Japan and the United States.

title: What Is the Most Important Problem in Math Today?
description: Many mathematicians would say it's the problem they're working on, but of all the famous unsolved problems, one stands out -- the Riemann hypothesis. Posed in 1859 by the German mathematician Georg Friedrich Bernhard Riemann, it has tantalized mathematicians ever since. Recently, efforts to prove it have taken on a new intensity, with mathematicians turning to physics for insight.

title: The Things They Wrote
description: Veterans Day honors all who have served in the military -- in peace and in war, at home and abroad, living and dead. Today is the 50th anniversary of the holiday renamed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 to ''solemnly remember the sacrifices of all those who fought so valiantly, on the seas, in the air, and on foreign shores, to preserve our heritage of freedom.'' Before 1954 the holiday was called Armistice Day.

title: Modernista Chosen as TIAA-CREFs Agency
description: Modernista Is Chosen

title: Jordan Is Big In Short Yardage
description: For the Jets this season, only one running back has scored a touchdown and only one has a run longer than 21 yards.

title: Where Are Those Aliens?
description: It was at lunch in Los Alamos, N.M., in 1950 that Enrico Fermi, best known for building the first atomic reactor, asked the question that has haunted those who like to wonder about other life in the universe ever since.

title: Blair, Defending Bush, Urges War Protesters to Listen to Him
description: LONDON, Nov. 11  Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he fully supported American actions in Iraq and the wider world, and he urged demonstrators preparing street protests to President Bush's visit here next week to look beyond their objections to the war and focus on the future.

title: Panama Challenges Miami As Free Trade Headquarters
description: In a region that relishes a good beauty contest, the competition is heating up between Miami and this Central American nation to be chosen as the headquarters for a future Free Trade Area of the Americas.

title: U.S. Tariffs on Steel Are Illegal, World Trade Organization Says
description: The World Trade Organization ruled on Monday that steel tariffs imposed by President Bush last year were illegal, clearing the way for the European Union to impose more than $2 billion of sanctions on imports from the United States unless Washington quickly drops the duties.

title: Could We Live Forever?
description: ''There is no fixed life span,'' says Dr. James Vaupel, no wall of death dictated by basic biology that we are edging toward. People are living longer and longer, he said, and he sees no reason to think the trend will slow or stop in the foreseeable future.

title: Looking for Truth In TV Biopics
description: To the Editor:

title: Delay on Energy Bill Vote Threatens Adjournment Plan
description: The push by Congress to finish its work before Thanksgiving encountered new turbulence on Monday when House leaders canceled business for this week because a wide-ranging energy measure was not ready.

title: Among the Saudis, Attack Has Soured Qaeda Supporters
description: The bombing of a housing compound whose residents were almost entirely Arab and Muslim late on Saturday has appalled Saudis far more than other terrorist attacks, evaporating expressions of support for Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network that were vaguely whispered or occasionally even shouted over the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOCH, CYNTHIA RICE
description: MOCH--Cynthia Rice. Beloved wife of Irving, mother of Dr. Anne (David) Steinberg, grandmother of Evan and William, niece of Evelyn Frank, sister-in-law of Gerald (Joan) Moch, and the late Royce (Dr. Frank) Roth, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Funeral private. Contributions to a favorite charity or Temple Beth Emeth, Wilmington, DE. Shiva will be observed at the home of Anne and David Steinberg from Thursday evening through Friday until the beginning of Shabbat.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A lawsuit on public offerings shines a spotlight on a dispute between the S.E.C. and the Justice Dept.
description: A CLASS-ACTION lawsuit about initial public offerings that produced a ruling favorable to Wall Street bankers last week also aired an unusual public dispute between the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Radio Ad Revenue Rose in September
description: Advertising revenue for radio networks and stations resumed growth in September, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported.

title: Creative Energy That Soared Too High
description: The mad mood swing might seem as indispensable a part of fashion's tool chest as a sewing machine. But even diva acts have their limits. And so, one sunny day in 1951, the photographer Francesco Scavullo found himself being taken from a Glamour magazine shoot in Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Gracie Square Hospital, a Manhattan psychiatric facility, where he was put under observation. Doctors said he had manic depression.

title: ASSISTED-LIVING COMPANY TO BUY 25 COMPLEXES
description: CNL Retirement Properties Inc., a closely held owner of assisted-living centers, agreed to buy 25 senior-housing complexes for about $198 million to add homes in Florida, Texas, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, North Carolina and South Carolina. CNL, which is based in Orlando, Fla., will buy the homes from the closely held EdenCare Senior Living Services, CNL said. Sunrise Senior Living Inc. will manage 22 of the properties. The acquisitions will include 1,913 living units, including 1,095 assisted-living units. After the purchase, CNL will have 117 properties with more than 12,000 living units in 27 states. The company is an affiliate of the CNL Financial Group.

title: Pressure Cited As Colombian Resigns Post
description: The resignation on Sunday of Marta Luca Ramrez, the tough, blunt Colombian defense minister, came as pressure for her removal mounted from high-ranking generals who bristled at her management style and her efforts to root out corruption, government officials and political analysts said Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWELL, CRAIG D.
description: POWELL--Craig D. On November 8, 2003 at age 35. Investment banker with the Blackstone Group. Beloved husband of Christine M. Hery. Loving father of Christian and Chloe. Devoted son of J.R. and Anita Powell. Dear brother of J. Robert and Jess A. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Tuesday, November 11th, 7-9PM with service at 7:30PM. Interment Charlottesville, VA. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, NYC Chapter, 475 Park Ave So., 8th Flr, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: Meeting Online: But Will You Really Click?
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Paranormal Phenomena Exist?
description: Mention mind reading, ghosts, premonitions, the bending of spoons through thought or other supposed mysteries of the paranormal, and most scientists will say there are no such things.

title: The Long Shadow of the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: In Baby Teeth, a Test of Fallout; A Long-Shot Search for Nuclear Peril in Molars and Cuspids
description: Joseph J. Mangano does not even notice the smell anymore. It hits you the moment you walk into his tiny, tidy apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, something musty and a little acrid, though not entirely unpleasant.

title: What Is Gravity, Really?
description: ''Gravity . . . it's not just a good idea. It's the Law,'' reads a popular bumper sticker.

title: Bon Jovi in Alliance With Samsung
description: The rock band Bon Jovi, seeking to promote a new album in nontraditional ways, has formed a marketing alliance with Samsung Electronics America in Ridgefield Park, N.J. Terms were not disclosed.

title: I.B.M. and Partners Promoting Linux Against Windows
description: Linux is a rising star in the geeky back office of computing. Its gains have come as an operating system for the data-serving computers that run corporate networks and serve up Web pages. On the desktop, Microsoft's Windows still reigns supreme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, PETER B.
description: COOPER--Peter B., on November 9, 2003 in Upper Montclair, NJ. He served the community as a Judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey, practicing lawyer, Councilman and Mayor of the Township of Livingston, NJ. Memorial Service Tuesday, November 11, 2003 at Temple Emanuel, Livingston, NJ at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations will be accepted by the Essex County Bar Association, in order to establish a fund in Judge Cooper's name to promote compassion and equity in probate practice. Please make donations to the ''Peter Cooper Trust Account''. Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, Livingston, NJ.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Governor To Appeal Right-To-Die Ruling
description: Gov. Jeb Bush will appeal a judge's denial of his request to dismiss a lawsuit challenging his intervention in the case of a brain-damaged woman, a spokesman said. The husband of the woman, Terri Schiavo, filed the suit in hopes of overturning a law that empowered Mr. Bush to order Mrs. Schiavo's feeding tube reinserted. The husband, Michael Schiavo, contends his wife is in a permanent vegetative state and he wants to remove the tube, paving the way for her death. But Mrs. Schiavo's parents want her to live, and Mr. Bush has joined their fight. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Terrorism in Saudi Arabia
description: Saudi Arabia has a growing terrorism problem. The latest example is Saturday's terrorist bombing in Riyadh, which tragically killed 17 people, among them 5 children, and wounded 122 others, laying waste to a neighborhood of modest homes. Saudi and American authorities now attribute the slaughter to Al Qaeda. Washington should not hesitate to offer its cooperation in helping to hunt down and prosecute a common terrorist foe.

title: Queens Woman, 71, Found Shot in Home; Police Talking to Her Son-in-Law
description: A 71-year-old woman from Hollis, Queens, was found slain in her home yesterday afternoon on a quiet block of two-story houses.

title: Eva Harris
description: Assistant professor of infectious diseases, School of Public Health at University of California at Berkeley.

title: Why Do We Sleep?
description: Any second grader knows why humans need food and water. The logic behind sex becomes obvious with a quick lesson on birds and bees.

title: Secret Service Hides Cheney As Plane Enters Restricted Area
description: The Secret Service hustled Vice President Dick Cheney into a secure site on Monday morning after a small plane flew into restricted airspace around Washington, government officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Volkswagen Strike Ends
description: About 10,000 striking workers at Volkswagen's plants in the So Paulo region voted to return to work, after a court awarded them an 18 percent raise. The ABC Metalworkers' Union, once led by President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, said the strike, which began industrywide on Oct. 28, was declared over after Volkswagen workers welcomed the ruling of a regional labor court, which effectively obliged Volkswagen to match offers made by other automakers and accepted by their employees last week. The strikers had wanted 20 percent, while Volkswagen had stuck to its initial offer of 16 percent. Volkswagen, which is planning to cut 4,000 jobs in Brazil, could appeal the ruling. Initially, the strike involved Ford, Mercedes-Benz, Scania Trucks and Toyota, but strikers at those plants negotiated compromises and most returned to work a week after the strike began. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Battling the Darkness, With the Law as His Lamp
description: THE world, as viewed by the newly appointed dean of Yale Law School, Harold Hongju Koh, is divided between darkness and light.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: They Dissed Us Actually

title: Can Drugs Make Us Happier? Smarter?
description: It depends on what is meant by ''happy'' and ''smart.''

title: When Will the Next Ice Age Begin?
description: The maxim ''what goes around comes around'' applies to few things more aptly than ice ages. In a rhythm attuned to regular wiggles in Earth's orbit and spin, 10 eras of spreading ice sheets and falling seas have come and gone over the last million years.

title: Drama's Lines Evoke Yesterday's Headlines
description: Cherylene Lee's ambitious drama ''The Legacy Codes'' was inspired by the case of Dr. Wen Ho Lee, the physicist who was accused of passing American nuclear secrets to China.

title: How Did Life Begin?
description: The origin of life is biology's most daunting problem. Scientists are good at understanding processes that they can study. But the emergence of life was a single event that occurred 3.5 billion to 4 billion years ago. Even the rocks of that era have mostly vanished.

title: (7) How Much of the Body is Replaceable?
description: The seventh question of the anniversary package is presented online as an interactive feature.

title: Trans Fats to Safe Sex: How Health Advice Has Changed
description: The times (and The Times) sure have changed. On April 18, 1966, Dr. William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson released the findings of an 11-year study of the physiology of sex in their groundbreaking book, ''Human Sexual Response.''

title: 4 Bids Entered to Buy Nets From YankeeNets
description: Four bids to buy the Nets from YankeeNets were submitted yesterday, including one that was unexpected, according to three people involved in the process.

title: Oracle Says PeopleSoft Plan For Rebates May Imperil Bid
description: In its hostile takeover bid for PeopleSoft, Oracle asked a Delaware court yesterday to expedite its request for an injunction against a PeopleSoft rebate program that takes effect upon an acquisition. Oracle said the rebate program could force it to withdraw its offer.

title: U.S. Wins a World Bridge Title
description: The United States won one world title here on Monday, and has a good chance of winning two more later in the week. The Senior Bowl, for players 55 and over, was won by Grant Baze, Gaylor Kasle, Steve Robinson, Kit Woolsey, Roger Bates and Garey Hayden. They held on to their overall lead despite losing narrowly to France in the last round. The French were second, and another American team, led by John Mohan, was third.

title: A Family Haunted By Ghosts Of History
description: LIVING TO TELL THE TALE

title: People
description: Jon Tracosas was named to the vacant post of president at the Irvine, Calif., office of Foote Cone & Belding, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He had been executive vice president and general manager at the New York office of Arnold Worldwide, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas.

title: 6 Afghans Die In U.S. Raid, Reports Say
description: American forces began a large-scale airborne assault against suspected Taliban and other antigovernment forces in two mountainous northeastern provinces over the weekend, a United States military spokesman said Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMALIAN, LEO
description: HAMALIAN--Leo. Died November 8, 2003 at 83. For more than 40 years beloved CCNY English professor; dean of guidance at CCNY and dean of academic affairs at California Institute of the Arts; distinguished author or editor of more than 25 books and well over 150 articles; Fulbright or exchange scholar at Universities of Damascus, Tehran, Hamburg and Paris; for 31 years editor of the literary quarterly Ararat. He is mourned by his wife, Linda, of Manhattan, as well as by sons Derek of Hilliard, OH, and Jeffrey of Ridgefield Park, NJ; daughter Leslie H. Kaiser of Temple, ME, and six grandchildren. Private services. Donations may be made to Amnesty International.

title: Dreaming Beyond Traditional Forms From North India
description: The venerable North Indian dance form called Kathak was used as a starting point for fresh departures at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center on Friday night.

title: Talk of Wiretaps Rattles Hollywood
description: The case began with a dead fish and a rose in an aluminum pan, left on the hood of a car parked on a Los Angeles street. Taped to the windshield of the car, which belonged to a reporter for The Los Angeles Times, was a piece of cardboard with a single word: ''Stop.''

title: Looking for Truth In TV Biopics
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing in Business Day yesterday about an offer to computer users to reduce the advertising they see on WeatherBug, a service that provides continually updated weather information, referred incorrectly to the technology. It delivers information to a desktop application, not through a Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHENBERG, AMY
