description: ROTHENBERG -- Amy. On November 10, 2003. Born in 1914 in Brooklyn to Nicholas and Elsie (Morris) Bernstein. Loving mother of Terry Monness Cohen. Caring stepmother of James Rothenberg. Devoted sister of Shirley Siegel. She adored her grandchildren Allison, Joanna and Nicholas Cohen, and stepgrandchildren Lauren and Carla Rothenberg. She was predeceased by her husband Albert Rothenberg. Her first husband, Abbot Monness and her daughter Ellen Monness, also predeceased her. She was always a lady. Memorial service at the Osborn Chapel, 101 Theodore Fremd Rd., Rye, N.Y. Wednesday, 2PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to a hospice of your choice. Inquiries Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Business Briefing column on Saturday about annual results for the St. George Bank of Australia misstated its profit. It was 606 million Australian dollars (about $430 million), not 6 million Australian dollars.

title: Iran Has Made Plutonium, U.N. Reports
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency said on Monday that it found no evidence that Iran was producing nuclear weapons, but that inspections and documents turned over by the country found a clear pattern of years of experimentation in producing small amounts of materials that could be fabricated into weapons, including plutonium.

title: Front Row; A Resale Shop for Hip Teenagers
description: Devlin Hennessy hung back as his girlfriend, Kate Hug, pawed through the racks at Plato's Closet, a clothing store in Paramus, N.J. ''Half of her income she spends on clothes,'' he said with resignation. Ms. Hug, 16, a student at Ramapo High School in Franklin Lakes, N.J., had ventured into the store because she was impressed by its youth-minded labels, a selection that included Banana Republic, Steve Madden and Polo. ''But what I really love are the prices,'' she said.

title: Dolphins Hope to Revive Sinking Season
description: With his team fading and one radio caller after another urging his firing, Miami Dolphins Coach Dave Wannstedt put a must-win label on Sunday's game against Baltimore.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would test one-class service on Boeing 737-800 aircraft on selected flights between Atlanta and Houston and Atlanta and Kansas City, Mo., starting today and running through Jan. 31. Aircraft cabins for those flights have been altered to remove first-class seats and provide all coach seats with 36 inches of legroom, in a bid to attract more business travelers, who tend to pay higher fares.

title: Are Women Necessary?
description: Abundant evidence suggests that females are the first sex, the ancestral sex, the sex from which males are derived.

title: Issue 1: Tricky Bacteria, Body Scans and Doomsday
description: Introduced on Nov. 14, 1978, with a ''skyline'' at the top of that day's Page A1, Science Times at first was relatively modest, taking up parts of four or five pages (in black and white, as the rest of the daily paper was until 1997). As the first issue shows, part of the cover and a good deal of the inside was devoted to education news; the back of the section contained arts and fashion coverage. But if it lacked something in size, Science Times made up for it in scope, addressing serious subjects from the start. Here's a look at that first issue, with the hindsight offered by 25 years of scientific advancement.

title: JUSTICES TO HEAR CASE OF DETAINEES AT GUANTNAMO
description: Setting the stage for a historic clash between presidential and judicial authority in a time of military conflict, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether prisoners at the United States naval base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, are entitled to access to civilian courts to challenge their open-ended detention.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bat Names Executive
description: British American Tobacco named its managing director, Paul Adams, as chief executive to succeed Martin Broughton who is to become the chairman of British Airways. Mr. Adams, 50, whose appointment is effective on Jan. 1, joined the company in 1991 from PepsiCo. BAT also said that Jan du Plessis, 49, a nonexecutive director and chief financial officer of the luxury goods maker Richemont, would become the nonexecutive chairman on July 1, 2004. Mr. Broughton has been serving as chairman and chief executive of BAT. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Kabul; In Afghanistan's Capital, Hospitality and New Hope
description: Kabul was one of the world's great business destinations in the Middle Ages, an important link between East and West. During its glory days as a Silk Route city, its most famous business traveler was Marco Polo, who passed through on his way to China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPATZ, EUGENE
description: SPATZ--Eugene. Photographer, died at home in NYC. Loving son of Paula and the late Jack. Brother of Amy Lowen and Cathy Spatz Widom; uncle of Rebecca Widom, Jessica and Hannah Lowen. Contributions to your favorite charity.

title: 'NFL Today,' Tomorrow A Coach
description: Deion Sanders's desire to become the coach of the Atlanta Falcons -- which became known 10 days ago -- has become a most amusing aspect of CBS's show ''The NFL Today.'' Sanders isn't wishy-washy. He believes that despite his lack of coaching experience, he can do a better job than Dan Reeves.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Protesters Increase Pressure
description: Opposition activists threatened a hunger strike and reportedly blocked trainloads of government troops headed for the capital, Tbilisi, as thousands of protesters gathered outside Parliament for a third straight day, calling for the resignation of President Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Parliament. More than a week after parliamentary elections last Sunday, the vote count has still not been completed. The latest figures showed Mr. Shevardnadze's bloc with a slight lead. Opposition leaders want the election declared invalid. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Clinton Urges China to Act Fast on AIDS
description: Former President Bill Clinton, speaking here on Monday at an international conference on AIDS, called the price of AIDS drugs in the developing world ''an international scandal'' and warned that AIDS could threaten China's economic boom and claim millions of lives unless leaders move quickly to stem its spread.

title: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS CHIEF TO STEP DOWN
description: Quest Diagnostics Inc., an operator of medical testing labs, said its chief executive, Kenneth Freeman, would step down by May after leading the company since it was spun off from Corning Inc. in 1996. Mr. Freeman, 53, will stay on as chairman after a shareholders' meeting in May, Quest said. The president and chief operating officer, Surya Mohapatra, 54, will replace him as chief executive, the company said.

title: John Maeda
description: Muriel Cooper professor of media arts and sciences at the Media Laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Charles Bars TV Appearance
description: Prince Charles announced that he would not go on television to discuss the rumor about his sex life that has been swirling through Britain in the past week. Last week, a spokesman for the prince strenuously denied that he had taken part in an ''incident,'' without saying what the incident was. Although Britain's tough libel laws have prevented the newspapers here from providing more than the barest hint of the rumored incident, said to involve a person belonging to the royal family and a former royal servant, details of the report -- made by another former royal servant -- are beginning to seep out. ''Is Charles bisexual?'' The News of the World asked on its front page on Sunday. Later, it answered its own question: ''Emphatically not.'' Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Despite Glints of Hope, California G.O.P. Faces Obstacles to Ousting Senator Boxer
description: Within days of Arnold Schwarzenegger's triumph in last month's election to recall Gov. Gray Davis, many jubilant Republicans began talking about taking on another prominent Democrat, Barbara Boxer, in next year's Senate race.

title: Drug-Coated Stent Is Found Safe and Effective for Arteries
description: A study of heart patients a year after they received a drug-coated stent to keep cleared arteries open shows that the device is safe and effective, scientists reported on Monday at a meeting of the American Heart Association here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: W.T.O. Rules U.S. Tariffs On Steel Are Illegal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRISON, EARL G., JR.
description: HARRISON--Earl G., Jr., 71, Headmaster and Educator, of Washington, DC, died Monday, November 10. Beloved husband of Jean Young Harrison, wife of 46 years. Loving father of Dana Harrison and his wife, Stephanie, and of Colin Harrison and his wife, Kathryn. Proud and adored grandfather of Sarah, Walker, Nikolas, Abigail and Julia Harrison. Also survived by his brother Barton Harrison and his wife Renata and their children, and by his brother Paul Harrison and his wife Diana and by their children. Born in Philadelphia, PA and raised in Rose Valley, PA, Earl Harrison attended The School in Rose Valley, Westtown School, Haverford College, Yale University, and Columbia University Teachers College. He served as the Headmaster of Westtown School, in Westtown, PA, from 1968-78, and as Head of the Sidwell Friends School, in Washington, DC, from 197898. His professional life was devoted to the caring guidance of the schools and to the larger mission of Quaker education. For more than four decades, he lent his wisdom to local and national educational organizations. A man of spiritual strength and genuine humility, Earl Harrison touched thousands of lives. He retreated to his garden for renewal, to the tennis court for exercise and to Quaker Meeting for contemplation. His was a life well lived, and he will be missed by all those who knew and loved him. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to the Sidwell Friends School, Westtown School, or the American Cancer Society. A memorial service will be held at the Friends Meeting of Washington, at 2111 Florida Ave, NW, Washington, DC on Saturday December 6 at 1:30 PM.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KPN Profit
description: The telecommunications company Royal KPN said it had earned 139 million euros ($160 million) in the third quarter, up from 68 million euros a year ago, allowing it to pay a dividend for the first time in three years. KPN, which has reduced its debt to 9.4 billion euros from 23 billion euros, attributed the improvement in part to higher demand for cellphone and broadband services. The result included a one-time charge of 33 million euros for restructuring while the period a year ago included a gain of 30 million euros from the sale of assets. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; A Little Help in Taking On the Time, Cost and Energy of a 2-Year-Old
description: When Paula Austin fell and sprained her knee in September, she knew her injury was going to be more than a small inconvenience. Getting around on crutches for a few weeks was one thing, but chasing after her 2-year-old grandson, Shamir? She could barely do that on two good legs.

title: Witness Backs Police Account Of '99 Shooting In Borough Park
description: The first civilian witness to back the police account of the 1999 shooting of Gidone Busch testified yesterday that officers were pushed up against a wall and had ''nowhere to go'' as Mr. Busch repeatedly lunged at them, swinging a hammer the instant before the officers shot him to death.

title: Martin Could Return for Spurs
description: The Nets are hopeful that Kenyon Martin will be back for their N.B.A. finals rematch with the San Antonio Spurs tomorrow at Continental Arena.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Softbank Reports Loss
description: The Softbank Corporation, an Internet access provider, lost 77 billion yen ($704 million) in the six-month period that ended on Sept. 30, 38 percent more than its loss in the same period last year. Softbank, which sells high-speed broadband connections, said sales rose 18 percent in the first six months of the fiscal year. But with growth in the market slowing, Softbank had to spend more to attract new customers, leaving it with an operating loss of 39.4 billion yen ($358 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHARDS, IRVING S.
description: RICHARDS--Irving S., 96, of New York, NY. Died November 10 at home. Husband of the late Rosalind Richards. Father of Lois Broido and Eric. Grandfather of Belinda Broido, Amy Rabenhorst and the late Lisa Kenoe. Greatgrandfather of Alana, Jack and Anika. Loving longtime companion of Marjorie Davis. Mr. Richards was one of the pioneers of modern design, beginning with the ''Salon d'Automne'' in 1927. In the 1930s he partnered with designer Russel Wright to create home furnishing products including the legendary American Modern dinnerware. This led to the formation of Raymor/RichardsMorgenthau, working with interior designers including George Nelson, Ben Siebel, Eva Zeisel and Hans Wegner. He sought designers whose work ended up having a major impact on the shape and direction of mid-20th century product design. With a discerning eye, he not only built a contemporary art collection, but was able to express his creativity through his own unique painting and sculpture. Service to held Thursday, 11 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Friday showing volume for trading in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange misstated the number of shares traded on the Archipelago stock exchange, the electronic trading network known as ArcaEx. It was 15,591,800, not 29,089,500.

title: New York Real Estate Heir Acquitted of Murder in Texas
description: Robert A. Durst, the millionaire real estate heir from New York who was living like a drifter in Texas, was acquitted today of charges that he murdered a 71-year-old neighbor in Galveston two years ago.

title: Arlie O. Petters
description: Cosmologist, professor of mathematics and physics, Duke University.

title: Curtailing Medicines From Canada
description: Brand-name drug makers have stepped up their drive to curtail exports of cheap medicines from Canada to the United States, raising prices in Canada for the first time in several years and imposing new restrictions on sales to Canadian pharmacies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOF, IRVING
description: SOLOF--Irving. Close to our hearts. Mentor to our nieces and nephews. Our family will never be the same. The Winikoff Family

title: Meeting Online: But Will You Really Click?
description: To the Editor:

title: As James Steals Show, the Knicks Pan Themselves
description: No one ever told LeBron James there would be nights like this. He might have petitioned to come to the N.B.A. sooner.

title: Will We Ever Find Atlantis?
description: Somewhere in the imagination, at an intersection of the idealized Golden Age and mankind's descent into manifest imperfection, existed the island civilization of Atlantis. This realm of divine origin was ruled from a splendid metropolis in the distant ocean. Its empire, described by a philosopher as ''larger than Libya and Asia combined,'' enjoyed prosperity and great power.

title: China's Bounding Economy Fuels Both Hope and Concern
description: China reported on Monday that industrial production surged in October, highlighting again its torrid economic growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKINNEY, ELIZABETH MCLANE
description: McKINNEY--Elizabeth McLane. Died after a short illness in Cincinnati, Ohio November 7, age 73. Survived by her husband Richardson McKinney and children Cricket Brien, Rick, Christopher, Jono and twelve grandchildren, brothers Thomas L. and James W. McLane, sister Greer Hopkins. Contributions in her memory to Cincinnati Opera Association, 1241 Elm Street, 45210, or Impact-Overthe-Rhine, P.O. Box 10003, 45202, appreciated.

title: The Things They Wrote
description: Veterans Day honors all who have served in the military -- in peace and in war, at home and abroad, living and dead. Today is the 50th anniversary of the holiday renamed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 to ''solemnly remember the sacrifices of all those who fought so valiantly, on the seas, in the air, and on foreign shores, to preserve our heritage of freedom.'' Before 1954 the holiday was called Armistice Day.

title: How Does the Brain Work?
description: In the continuing effort to understand the human brain, the mysteries keep piling up. Consider what scientists are up against. Stretched flat, the human neocortex -- the center of our higher mental functions -- is about the size and thickness of a formal dinner napkin.

title: The Things They Wrote
description: Veterans Day honors all who have served in the military -- in peace and in war, at home and abroad, living and dead. Today is the 50th anniversary of the holiday renamed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1954 to ''solemnly remember the sacrifices of all those who fought so valiantly, on the seas, in the air, and on foreign shores, to preserve our heritage of freedom.'' Before 1954 the holiday was called Armistice Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICH, LEAH
description: RICH--Leah. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Loving mother of Rosalie and Barry Kurtz and Jerome and Sandra Rich. Cherished grandmother of Wendy and Cory, Matthew, Jennifer and Cengiz, Andrew, Daniel, and Randy and great-grandmother of Maxx. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10AM Tuesday.

title: A Baggage Lock for You And the Federal Screeners
description: AIRLINE passengers will be able to lock checked bags confidently again starting tomorrow, thanks to a new customer-service initiative between private enterprise and the Transportation Security Administration.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Thursday about the defeat of a ballot proposal to eliminate party primaries referred imprecisely to testimony in July by Nicole A. Gordon, executive director of the city's Campaign Finance Board. While she raised concerns about the proposal, saying it could increase the influence of spending by political parties, she did not take a position on the vote.

title: Defense Minister From Vietnam Meets Rumsfeld
description: In a visit heavy with symbolism, the defense minister of a Vietnam united under Communism came to the Pentagon and State Department on Monday for the first time.

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: EX-COMMISSIONER PLEADS GUILTY A week and a half after her conviction on state perjury and obstruction of justice charges, the former state agriculture commissioner, Meg Scott Phipps, pleaded guilty to related federal extortion charges. Ms. Phipps accepted illegal campaign donations, sometimes personally, in exchange for state fair contracts, said Frank D. Whitney, a United States attorney. In the state case, Ms. Phipps's lawyers had argued that her staff took the payments without her knowledge. Ms. Phipps, the daughter and granddaughter of governors, faces up to 55 years in prison on the federal charges but will probably be sentenced to about 5 years, Mr. Whitney said.

title: The Case of the Operatic Moon; In Rio, a Drawer-Dropping Director Is Due in Court
description: Those in the opening-night audience at the Teatro Municipal here hated the director Gerald Thomas's radical reworking of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' and they were eager to let him know it.

title: Drug Testing at the Top Of Selig's List for Now
description: On a day Commissioner Bud Selig spoke about being saddened by the United States baseball team losing an opportunity to qualify for the Olympics, the need for a World Cup in baseball, the future of the Montreal Expos, the future of Pete Rose and the potential sale of the Los Angeles Dodgers, drug testing was the topic that received intense attention at the general managers' meetings.

title: Grudge Match: Italy vs. the Bean Counters
description: There is a sick giant in Italian industry that is staggering under excessive debt, stagnating sales, surging costs, limited growth prospects and accusations of sketchy accounting practices. That same industry, though, has captured the hearts and minds of most Italians, and their efforts to save it have created a controversy that goes to the very top of Italy's government -- and puts them on a collision course with European Union officials.

title: U.S. Commander in Iraq Outlines Tougher Strategy
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 11  Stung by the deaths of nearly 40 American soldiers over the past 10 days, the top American military commander in Iraq spoke of a "turning point" in the conflict on Tuesday and outlined a new get-tough approach to combat operations in areas north and west of Baghdad, strongholds for loyalists of Saddam Hussein.

title: Photos From 'Open Wound'
description: Stanley Greene used his photographs to draw attention to the latest surge in Chechnya's century-long struggle for independence from Russia.

title: Scientific Scenes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Battling Over Travel Teams
description: Increasingly, coaches and parents are organizing against ultracompetitive travel sports teams for children.

title: Ex-Economist at Goldman Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: John M. Youngdahl, a former senior economist at Goldman Sachs , pleaded guilty today to criminal charges in connection with the purchase of about $318 million of 30-year bonds and bond futures minutes ahead of the Treasury's announcement in 2001 that it was ending the sale of the 30-year bonds.

title: Islanders Unable to Play Follow the Leader
description: For all the hubbub surrounding the Islanders' attempt to ditch Jason Wiemer, a midlevel forward, the team had far more pressing matters to confront Tuesday night after a 2-1 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Talk of Closing Manhattan V.A. Hospital Prompts Campaign to Save It
description: For the past 28 years, Julius E. Dixson, a songwriter who fought in Europe during World War II, has been taking taxis from his Midtown apartment to the V.A. Medical Center New York, the only Veterans Affairs hospital in Manhattan.

title: Spanning the Globe, With Fire and Spice
description: THE Biltmore Room may be the best restaurant ever to come out of far left field. It crept into town unheralded, installed a chef as elusive as the Scarlet Pimpernel and set up shop in a neighborhood that has no known name. Chelsea Heights, perhaps? The nearby culinary competition pretty much boils down to the Krispy Kreme doughnut shop and the F&B hot-dog shop on 23rd Street.

title: Survivors of Riyadh Bombing Pick Up Pieces of Their Lives
description: They were neighbors and newlyweds, and late on Saturday night they bumped into each other by chance outside the obstetrician's office.

title: When Bush Talks of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: And You Thought a 3-Hour Recipe Was Long
description: Often, a history of cooking in America will begin with the first Thanksgiving. But in ''A Thousand Years Over a Hot Stove'' (W. W. Norton, $35), a history of women and their cooking in America, Laura Schenone starts with the Stone Age in America and asks why women do the cooking. She then looks at how cooking has evolved as a way to make raw ingredients palatable and as a socializing force. She examines American Indian traditions; Christian influences from New England; settlers in the South, men arriving without women who relied on slaves; the tension between pioneers and Indians; the effects of industrialization, the influx of immigrants; and the bland ''Americanization through cooking'' promoted by home economists.

title: Durst Verdict Tied to Local Mores and a Shrewd Defense
description: Even in Texas, with its history of legal lenience when it comes to self-defense, they are wondering how Robert A. Durst was found not guilty of murder yesterday in the killing of Morris Black, an elderly neighbor in a Galveston apartment house.

title: Where Diners Are in the Dark, but Waiters Can See
description: Given the interest in culinary experimentation at restaurants, being in the dark about what you are eating is hardly unusual. Being in the dark while you are eating, however, is. That's the premise of the Dinner in the Dark series at Suba. The meals (which benefit City Harvest) are prepared by chefs including Chris Santos from Mojo, Zak Pelaccio from 5 Ninth and Anita Lo from Annisa, and they are served in utter darkness by waiters wearing night vision goggles.

title: When Bush Talks of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Is Nearing Approval Of Record Pentagon Spending
description: After agreeing to drop a provision requiring many military contracts to go to American companies, Congress is on the verge of passing a record authorization bill to let the Pentagon spend more than $400 billion for the next year.

title: Report on Blackout Is Said To Describe Failure to React
description: A report on the Aug. 14 blackout identifies specific lapses by various parties, including FirstEnergy's failure to react properly to the loss of a transmission line, people who have seen drafts of it say.

title: For College Chiefs, How Much Pay Is Too Much?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nashville Tribute to Johnny Cash
description: Johnny Cash was remembered as a musician and a songwriter, a maverick and a believer, a hell-raiser and a mentor, an icon and a family man in a concert on Monday night at the Ryman Auditorium here, where he made his Grand Ole Opry debut in 1956.

title: A Cow for the Lunchbox
description: The major organic milk companies have introduced convenient single-serve milks designed for lunchboxes and sold in supermarkets. Organic Valley sells two-percent milk in plain or chocolate. It comes in 11-ounce plastic bottles with handy screw-on caps for about $1.50. Though Horizon Organic's eight-ounce reduced-fat milks (about $1) do not have plastic screw caps, they are shelf-stable until opened. And in addition to plain and chocolate, they also come in orange and caramel flavors.

title: Performers From Down Under, Along With Composers
description: New Zealand String Quartet

title: New College Programs Reflect a Renewed Interest in Africa
description: After decades of looking the other way, colleges and universities are beginning to show interest in Africa.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 3 about smuggling of children across the border from Mexico misspelled the surname of the United States Attorney for the District of Arizona, who spoke about the problem. He is Paul K. Charlton, not Charleton.

title: Korean for Extra Credit, in the East Village
description: A LOT of people open restaurants, but not too many of them are students. That did not discourage Joohee Maeng, the owner of Temple, a slender, inviting Korean restaurant that opened in March in the East Village.

title: MURPHY OIL REDUCES 3RD-QUARTER PROFIT REPORT
description: The Murphy Oil Corporation said third-quarter profit was $4.4 million lower than it reported last month because of costs for an unsuccessful natural-gas well in Alberta. The costs related to the well, known as the Stolberg gas prospect, reduced net income by 5 cents a share to about $68.7 million, or 74 cents a share, a Murphy spokeswoman, Mindy West, said. Last month, the company reported third-quarter profit of $73.1 million, or 79 cents a share. Accounting rules require that costs incurred in the third quarter be included in results for that period if a company has not yet filed its quarterly statement with regulators. Additional costs of about $1 million will be recorded in the current quarter, Ms. West said. Murphy has a 30 percent stake in the Stolberg prospect. Royal Dutch/Shell Group is the operator.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Soldiers' Stories, And Our Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: BERLIN: PERGAMON PLANS
description: Breaking years of deadlock, the German culture minister, Christina Weiss, and the federal department of finance have agreed on the restoration of the Pergamon Museum, on the Museum Island, a Unesco World Heritage site in Berlin. The architect Oswald Mathias Ungers now has permission to begin the project, including construction of an extension of the museum, which houses the renowned second-century Pergamon Altar, depicting the battle between the Greek gods and giants. Reconstruction and modernization of the entire museum complex is to cost more than $1.1 billion and be completed in 2013. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Market Rise Helps UBS To Best Profit In 3 Years
description: UBS, Europe's largest bank by assets, reported its highest quarterly profit in three years Tuesday as stock market gains enhanced earnings from wealth management.

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops Move to Reinforce Ban on Birth Control
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, acknowledging that American Catholics pay little heed to their teaching on contraception, launched an effort today to reinforce the ban on birth control and linked it to the anti-abortion campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a federal investigation into suspected illegal wiretapping by a private investigator in Hollywood referred incorrectly to a comment by the comedian Garry Shandling. Mr. Shandling, who has been approached by the F.B.I. in connection with the inquiry, said in a telephone interview that an agent had asked him ''questions about wiretapping.'' He did not say the agent had informed him that he had been wiretapped.

title: Sponsor Spurns Ballet Theater
description: The Movado Watch Company has withdrawn its considerable financial support from American Ballet Theater and given it instead to the New York City Ballet, saying it was forced to do so because of financial mismanagement at Ballet Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONG, TERRY
description: LEONG--Terry. Died August 16, 2003 just before his 65th birthday, September 17. He was a scenic and costume designer for many years in New York. He is survived by his companion, Adam Pollack, and many friends and family. A memorial service will be held November 15, 2003 from 12-3 PM at the American Globe Theatre, 145 West 46th Street, NY, NY.

title: Republicans Begin Marathon Senate Session in Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 — The Senate began an extraordinary 30-hour through-the-night session this evening initiated by Republicans who are trying to dramatize what they say is the unfairness of the Democrats in blocking several of President Bush's judicial nominees.

title: A Nouveau That Might Not Need Hype
description: REMEMBER Beaujolais nouveau? Sure you do. It's the French wine, the first of the harvest, that used to arrive in New York every November with all the subtlety and stealth of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey.

title: New York City Real Estate Heir Is Acquitted of Murder in Texas
description: Robert A. Durst, the New York multimillionaire who admitted that he had butchered his 71-year-old neighbor's body with a bow saw and dumped the parts into Galveston Bay, was acquitted of the man's murder on Tuesday. Mr. Durst told the jury that despite what happened afterward, the killing itself had been accidental and an act of self-defense.

title: Afghans' Political Prognosis Is Still Hazy, U.N. Panel Says
description: Terrorism, drug-related crime and factional fighting threaten to reverse advances in the rebuilding of Afghanistan and jeopardize efforts to form a democratic government, the German ambassador here told the Security Council on Tuesday.

title: Feared Symbol of Nazi Era Seeks Bankruptcy
description: At its zenith during World War II, I.G. Farben was the world's largest chemical company and a sinister symbol of Nazi industrial might. On Monday, the company, notorious for producing poison gas and using slave labor during the war, announced that it would file for bankruptcy.

title: Wine Enough To Please Them All
description: THESE next five or six preholiday weeks are the times that try wine lovers' souls.

title: Shares Fall, Led by Selling Of Some Technology Issues
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by Scientific-Atlanta and EchoStar Communications, as investors shifted cash out of the technology shares that have led the market's surge this year.

title: Sather Seems Set to Shuffle the Rangers' Lines
description: Rangers Coach Glen Sather cautioned reporters not to read anything into his line combinations and defensive pairings at practice Tuesday. But it looks as though Eric Lindros will move back to being the center on a line with the promising wings Dominic Moore and Jamie Lundmark. For the past two games, Lindros has played as Bobby Holik's right wing.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: G.M. Opens A Lab
description: General Motors said that it had set up a $21 million auto research laboratory in Bangalore, India's technology capital. The laboratory, G.M.'s first outside the United States, will focus on vehicle design, manufacturing technology and electronic integration. The laboratory employs 17 scientists and the number will increase to 100 soon. ''The lab provides an increased diversity of talent and resources to our global research and development network,'' said Alan Taub, executive director of the science laboratories for G.M. research and development. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about the cultivation of pepper in southern India misstated the type of ship commanded by Jonathan Carnes, a sea captain who took the United States into the pepper trade with a voyage in the 1790's. While his vessel, the Rajah, was a schooner, it was not a clipper; that type of schooner did not exist until the 1830's.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Nov. 3 about smuggling of children across the border from Mexico misspelled the surname of the United States Attorney for the District of Arizona, who spoke about the problem. He is Paul K. Charlton, not Charleton.

title: When Bush Talks of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manorville: Corpse Found In Woods Near Highway
description: Further tests will be carried out on a profoundly decomposed body found near the Long Island Expressway, since an autopsy failed to disclose even the sex of the corpse, the authorities said yesterday. The body, degraded by insects, may be examined by a forensic anthropologist or other experts trained to examine partial remains, said Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick of the Suffolk County police. Passers-by looking for wild mushrooms discovered the corpse on Monday between Exits 70 and 71, in woods several hundred yards from the highway. Three other bodies have been discovered near the same stretch of highway in the last three years; none have been identified. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Commander of Colombias Armed Forces Steps Down
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 12  The commander of Colombia's armed forces said today that he was resigning, joining three cabinet ministers who have stepped down in a shake-up marring President Alvaro Uribe's administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRUMKES, CONSTANCE
description: FRUMKES -- Constance, of Kansas City (formerly Harrison, NY). Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Ronald, the late Cathy Sloan and Steven Frumkes. Mother - in - law of Lisa Frumkes, Tom and Krista Sloan. Sister of Marilyn Oppenheim. Loving grandmother of Justin, Susan Ritzer, Andrew and Steven Sloan, aunt of Cathy Groves. Info: ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Senate Follows House and Votes to Impose Sanctions Against Syria
description: The Senate joined the House in endorsing diplomatic and economic sanctions against Syria on Tuesday, to go into effect unless that nation meets a series of conditions, including halting movement across its border of people and equipment destined for attacks on Americans in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GARSON, EUGENE
description: GARSON--Eugene. November 12, 1998. An everlasting bond of love and devotion can never be broken. Gloria

title: The Road to Preserving History
description: Tucked inside federal transportation law is a small phrase that has done a fairly heroic job of protecting some of the nation's most important historic areas for almost 40 years. These few words in the 1966 Department of Transportation Act say that a federal highway project cannot destroy any historic area if there is a ''prudent and feasible alternative.'' These words have blocked, for example, highways from paving parts of the French Quarter in New Orleans and Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco.

title: Cablevision Reports Wider Loss And Will Restate Some Earnings
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation posted a wider third-quarter loss yesterday and told investors that it would have to restate its quarterly earnings statements for 2003 to reflect $15 million of expenses that were improperly recorded in 2002 and earlier.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro increased after a German industry report showed that investor confidence climbed to the highest in 16 months. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1509, up from $1.1496 on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the growing number of shops selling cupcakes in New York City misstated the recent history of a space that houses one, the Magnolia Bakery, at 401 Bleecker Street. When Magnolia opened in 1996, it occupied part of what had been a bird shop. Later, a florist took over the rest of the space. Magnolia did not open next to the bird shop.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Guns For Pilots Of Cargo Planes
description: The Senate approved a measure allowing pilots of cargo planes to carry guns in the cockpit, just days after the Homeland Security Department warned that Al Qaeda might be plotting to fly such planes into sites like nuclear plants, bridges and dams. The bill amends a law permitting airline pilots to carry guns. John Files (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Mau Mau Group Recognized
description: The Kenyan government formally recognized the Mau Mau movement, overturning colonial-era legislation that branded members of the group as terrorists for their uprising against British colonialists in the 1950's. Vice President Moody Awori praised the group for being ''not afraid of death in order to earn freedom for its countrymen.'' The government's move is expected to aid a lawsuit by surviving Mau Mau fighters seeking compensation from the British for brutal treatment under colonial rule. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: A Suggestion for the M.T.A.: Training in Communication
description: As part of their training, prospective Metro-North Railroad conductors practice saying ''Ticket, please,'' to each other in happy, sad and angry voices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, GERALDINE M.
description: ALTMAN--Geraldine M. November 10, 2003, beloved wife of the late Sidney, devoted mother of Roger C. Altman, and Richard M. Altman, cherished grandmother of Alexandra, Nicholas, and Kristina. Loving sister of Mimsi, and the late Pauline, Doris, Dolly, Millie, and Marjorie. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1075 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, November 13th at 6-8 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, November 14th at 10 A.M. at St. Ignatia Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: Malnutrition Long Noticed In Youth, 19
description: The 19-year-old who was found severely malnourished last month at a home where he was raised by adoptive parents had been hospitalized at age 7, before he was placed in foster care, for signs of malnutrition and for consuming large amounts of alcohol and prescription medication, according to his state child-welfare case file.

title: Recipe: Mellow Lamb Steaks
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: It's a Question Of Federal Turf
description: In its decision to accept the Guantnamo Bay prisoners' appeals despite the Bush administration's objections, the Supreme Court brushed past the ''judges keep out'' fence the administration had tried to erect around its open-ended detention policy.

title: Defense Rests in Trial of Older Sniper Suspect
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Nov. 12  Lawyers for John Allen Muhammad, the older suspect in the sniper attacks that terrorized the Washington area last fall, wrapped up their defense this afternoon, about three hours after they had begun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'SHAUGHNESSY, LUCY ELEANOR
description: O'SHAUGHNESSY -- Lucy Eleanor. On Monday, November 10, 2003 at the age of 79 years, she died peacefully in her home surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of the late Denis (December 1977). Loving mother of Denis, Maureen (Shawn) Kennedy, John, Jean O'Brien, Patrice Fay, Mark and Eleanor Baker. Proud grandmother of 17. Born in Forge, MA, she came to New York and lived here for over 60 years, sharing her small town warmth with all who knew her. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 E. Tremont Ave, Bronx, NY until Friday 9:30am. Mass of Christian burial at St. Frances de Chantal Church, Bronx, NY 10am. Interment at St. Raymond Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2:00 to 5:00 and 7:00 to 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations to Visiting Nurse Service of NY 1250 Broadway, NY, NY 10001. James E. McQuade, Dir.

title: Off the Menu
description: ASIATE in the Mandarin Oriental New York hotel is the first restaurant to open in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle. The chef, NORI SUGIE , left, is from Japan but has worked in France and Australia and with Charlie Trotter in Chicago. He uses local and Japanese ingredients in dishes like lobster in a casserole with a vegetable and shellfish broth, and a green apple and lime parfait with apple soup. The restaurant has 90 seats and is on the 35th floor, the lobby level of the hotel, which occupies 20 floors in the north building of the complex. Glass curtain walls on two sides open the subdued, elegant room, which was designed by Tony Chi, to sweeping views of Central Park and the Upper East and West Sides.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Escapes From Police
description: A man arrested on a narcotics charge on Sunday slipped out of his handcuffs and escaped last night while being transferred to a van that was to take him to Central Booking in Lower Manhattan, the police said. The man, Gerald Blunt, 39, was seen running from the van at 119th Street and Third Avenue about 7 p.m. The police said the escape was the 24th in 2003, eight fewer than last year at this time. The police said that 294,360 arrests have been made so far this year. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: U.S. Awaits South Korea Plan On Troop Numbers in Seoul
description: American and South Korean negotiators are close to agreement on a plan to relocate thousands of United States troops from Seoul. But as Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld prepares to visit the region, the deal is being held up while South Korea decides how many American forces, if any, it wants to remain in the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SANDERS, REGINALD BYRON
description: SANDERS--Reginald Byron. 9/25/25-11/12/01 Biron: As we once were, that we still are. Elv

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Murder
description: Police arrested a man last night and charged him with second-degree murder in the shooting death of his mother-in-law in her Queens home on Monday afternoon. Olga Prince, 71, died from a single gunshot wound to the head. The police discovered the body at the entrance to her kitchen with a handgun lying beside her, and charged Sydney Sampson, 54. Officers had previously responded to complaints of loud arguments in the house eight times in the last year, most recently on Friday, the police said. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas Agree To Reunion Center
description: Raising hopes of increased reunions between millions of family members separated since the Korean War half a century ago, North and South Korea agreed to build a permanent meeting center at an isolated resort on the eastern coast of the North, the Red Cross in Seoul said. Eight reunions, each lasting just a few days, have been held since a summit meeting in 2000 between the countries. To date, about 8,000 separated family members have had such reunions. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ACCUSATIONS OF CENSORSHIP A rumored incident said to involve a person belonging to the royal family and a former royal servant provoked accusations of censorship after European newspapers reporting the incident were prevented from delivering to newsstands across Britain. "European Press Censored in England," Le Monde said in a headline on its Web site, after its British distributor, fearful of Britain's tough libel laws, refused to deliver the newspaper. That move followed 15 other European newspapers that carried similar reports, including Le Figaro in France, La Stampa in Italy and El Pais in Spain, being taken off British stands on Saturday, Le Monde noted. Last week, a spokesman for Prince Charles strenuously denied that the prince had taken part in an "incident," without saying what the incident was. (Agence France-Presse)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER CLIMBS. Copper rose on speculation that Indonesia's government might restrict output at Grasberg, a large mine, after a landslide. In New York, copper for December delivery rose 1.65 cents, to 94.45 cents a pound.

title: For Bush, A Janus-Like View of Trade
description: In the next few weeks, President Bush will decide what kind of a trade president he wants to be.

title: Dioceses Lag on Responses to Abuse Survey
description: Nearly one-fifth of Roman Catholic dioceses in the United States have failed to respond to a survey on the extent of the sexual molestation of minors by priests, a church-appointed monitor said Tuesday, but she added that she was confident all would respond in time for sweeping reports on the abuse crisis to be released on Feb. 27.

title: Small Champagnes, Proudly Quirky
description: IT may seem surprising, but wine tastings can sometimes be excruciating. Even though we spit out almost every drop, a few hours spent with 30 tannic, acidic red wines leave the tongue swollen, the brain pickled and the spirit crying out for a beer. But this particular tasting, of 25 Champagnes produced by small houses from their own grapes, was not one of those difficult jobs. In fact, the Dining section's wine panel judged it to be extraordinarily enjoyable.

title: Sports of The Times; It's a Victory for Regular Guys
description: THE two unlikely cobblers of N.B.A. history paced on opposite ends of the sideline last night, displaying distinctive DNA markers of the Van Gundy basketball dynasty:

title: Bush Looking to Transfer Power to Iraqis, U.S. Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, asserted today that the pacification of Iraq was going well despite inevitable problems. But Secretary of State Colin L. Powell later acknowledged that there had been discussions at the White House about the state of security in Iraq.

title: G.O.P. Convention Has Police Alert and Protesters Planning
description: Police in New York City have been at work since June preparing for the Republican National Convention next summer, an event that could draw hundreds of thousands of protesters to the congested streets of Midtown while President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney are in town.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: No Charges In Dog Owner's Death
description: A man who was accused of shooting a dog and then killing its owner will not be charged in the death because of the state's ''make my day'' law. After his dog was wounded, the slain man, Richard Hammock, went to the home of a neighbor, Eric Griffin, with a piece of lumber. The two argued, and Mr. Griffin shot Mr. Hammock. The law protects people from charges or lawsuits if they use force against an intruder who they believe has criminal intent. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Systems: Computer Sciences Posts 16% Profit Rise
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, which manages computers for clients like General Dynamics and the National Security Agency, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 16 percent as government sales increased. Net income rose to $108.1 million, or 57 cents a share, from $92.9 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Computer Sciences purchased DynCorp in March for $950 million to spur government sales. Shares of Computer Sciences rose to $41.75 in extended trading after the report. They fell 16 cents, to $40.79, in regular trading.

title: In Small Houses, Champagne Finds Its Soul
description: LIKE any bottle of Champagne, Larmandier-Bernier's Terre de Vertus, with its tapered, graceful curves, can ignite the imagination. Simply glancing at it transports you to a world of tuxedos and gowns, where the music is soft, the dancing close, and elegance as near as a pop and a pour and a sigh. A more careful examination of the bottle, though, reveals a label completely at odds with the bubbly, urbane notion of Champagne. Its central image?

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bristol: Fugitive Son Arrested In Mother's Death
description: A fugitive accused of killing his mother in 1998 by setting fire to her house has been arrested in Florida, the Bristol police said yesterday. A warrant was issued in April for the fugitive, Buddy Beavers Jr., 43, of Bristol, accusing him of murder and arson in the death of his mother, Wilma, 68. Mr. Beavers became a fugitive when he failed to appear in New Britain Superior Court on robbery charges unrelated to his mother's death. Mr. Beavers is a former West Virginia police officer and volunteer firefighter. He was arrested in Miami on Monday after details of his mother's death were broadcast on the television program ''America's Most Wanted.'' Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: General Vows to Intensify U.S. Response to Attackers
description: Stung by the deaths of nearly 40 American soldiers over the past 10 days, the top American military commander in Iraq spoke of a ''turning point'' in the conflict on Tuesday and outlined a new get-tough approach to combat operations in areas north and west of Baghdad, strongholds for loyalists of Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAWSON, BRIGID RUTH
description: DAWSON--Brigid Ruth. Age 73, on November 7, 2003. Daughter of the late Cyril and Marjorie, of Yorkshire, England. Sister of Michael and Valarie and family, Judy and Ken and family, and Chris and Christine and family. An English teacher of many years. A celebration of her life will be held at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday 3:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory will be announced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Bowl Parade Will Likely Pass UConn By
description: There are certainly more preferable places to be than Detroit in late December, but the University of Connecticut football players would like nothing better than to spend the holidays there, away from their families, freezing in the Michigan winter. Let it snow. They wouldn't care. Of course, Boise, Idaho, would be fine, too. Any place playing host to a bowl game would do.

title: Cider With the Soul of Wine
description: THE second-floor chapel of the old Brick Meetinghouse in this Berkshire mountain town was standing room only. Simple white pews spilled over with hard cider enthusiasts, amateur fermenters and fall-color weekenders who found their way here earlier this month for Cider Day, the largest -- and possibly only -- national celebration of artisanal ciders, heirloom apples and every doughnut, juice and jelly in between. On the first weekend of November, Colrain and other towns across Franklin County held apple festivals and grafting workshops, cooking demonstrations and cider making clinics.

title: Water Main Break Under River Disrupts Service in Jersey City
description: A water main break here Tuesday morning sent residents scurrying to boil tap water, purchase bottled water and retrieve children from schools that closed early. The police went through neighborhoods notifying those unaware of the emergency.

title: Strong Quarter at 2 Retailers; Penney Is Off
description: May Department Stores, owner of the Lord & Taylor chain, and TJX Companies, operator of T.J. Maxx stores, said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose. Earnings declined at J.C. Penney, the department store company, because of sluggish drugstore sales.

title: Spurs' Visit Recalls One Made by Kidd
description: Rod Thorn dreaded the thought of this game. Jason Kidd pondered whether he would be booed during the introductions. The Nets must have wondered whether they would be blown out or merely beaten.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Warning On Mesh For Hernias
description: The Food and Drug Administration is warning doctors to watch for counterfeit versions of a synthetic mesh that is widely used to repair hernias. The mesh, Prolene, is made by Ethicon. Details are online at www.fda.gov/medwatch/SAFETY/2003/prolene.htm. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: Finding His Calling in Chechnya's Images of War; A Photojournalist's New Book Portrays the Devastation Of a Bitter Conflict
description: Stanley Greene traveled a long road to become a photojournalist, one that passed through personal crises and professional digressions, and eventually led to a search for a good reason to be a photographer. Early in 1995, as the Russian military bombarded the Chechen capital, Grozny, he found that reason.

title: Study Finds Differences in 2 Cholesterol-Lowering Drugs
description: The first study to compare two powerful cholesterol-lowering drugs head-to-head in coronary artery disease finds one clearly superior. Patients taking the highest available dose of pravastatin, or Pravachol, made by Bristol-Myers Squibb, had slowly progressing atherosclerosis over an 18-month period. But the disease was halted in those who took the highest dose of atorvastatin, or Lipitor, the drug made by Pfizer.

title: Teenagers Onstage, Ambition in the Wings
description: Beware of the theatrical enterprise that refers to itself as ''the global phenomenon,'' which means little more than that it has a recognizable brand name, like Coke or McDonald's.

title: High School Admission Rules Change Sense of 'Not in My Backyard'
description: The law and math institutes at Cardozo High School are two of the most popular public high school programs in the city. More than 5,000 students applied last year for just over 150 seats. But both programs are open only to students from Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UCHIN, JEROME F., D.D.S.
description: UCHIN--Jerome F., D.D.S. on November 11, 2003. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of Highland Park and Princeton, N.J. A graduate of the NYU School of Dentistry (1942) and practiced in the New Brunswick area. Loving husband of Dorothy to whom he was married 58 years. Adored father of Larry Uchin and Meryl Schultz. Cherished grandfather, beloved brother.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Drug Companies Underpin the Office Market
description: When the telecommunications industry suddenly shrank and left New Jersey's office real estate market reeling several years ago, the expanding pharmaceutical industry, brokers fondly recall, stepped in and played hero.

title: When Bush Talks of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Jays' Halladay Wins The A.L. Cy Young Award
description: John Gibbons could have seen this coming. When the Toronto Blue Jays hired Gibbons as their bullpen catcher before the 2002 season, Roy Halladay made an immediate impression. Gibbons could feel it in his glove hand.

title: Market Place; Tied to Milken, The Ride Still Can Be Bumpy
description: Investing in the second act of Michael Milken, the onetime king of junk bonds, has not been a rewarding experience for everyone. Just ask the shareholders of Nextera Enterprises, a company controlled by Mr. Milken and his brother, Lowell, and Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman of the Oracle Corporation.

title: Art Carney, 85, Lauded 'Honeymooners' Actor, Dies
description: Art Carney, the Academy Award-winning comic actor who first gained fame as the guffawing, slightly off-center sewer worker Ed Norton in the early 1950's television series ''The Honeymooners,'' died on Sunday at a convalescent home in Chester, Conn. He was 85.

title: Cyla Wiesenthal, 95, Survivor Of Holocaust With Nazi Nemesis
description: Cyla Mueller Wiesenthal, the wife of the Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal, died Monday in Vienna, where the couple lived after surviving concentration camps and separation in World War II. She was 95.

title: Editorial Observer; Trying to Measure the Amount of Information That Humans Create
description: Do you know what an exabyte is? I didn't until I started reading a new report, called ''How Much Information? 2003,'' from the University of California at Berkeley's School of Information Management and Systems. An exabyte turns out to be a billion gigabytes. Most new computers, by comparison, come with hard drives around 40 to 100 gigabytes in size.

title: 2 Children Die in Upstate Fire And a Third Is Presumed Dead
description: Two children were killed and another was missing and presumed dead in an early-morning fire yesterday that destroyed a home outside Rome, N.Y., the authorities said. Six other people were injured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEGOUVEIA, HILARIA S.
description: DeGOUVEIA--Hilaria S. on November 10, 2003. Beloved mother of Keith, Lauren, Gerald, Colin, Wayne and Bevan. Loving grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of two. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 2-4 and 79PM at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial St. Thomas More Church, Thursday, 11AM. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ.

title: Fire Destroys Supermarket And a Church In Harlem
description: An early morning fire yesterday in Harlem destroyed a supermarket and a popular church that drew its congregation from across the city.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Automaker Expects Loss
description: Mitsubishi Motors lost money in the first half of the fiscal year and now expects a loss in the full year because of sliding sales in North America. Mitsubishi, Japan's fourth-largest carmaker, lost 80 billion yen ($737 million) in the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, partly driven by high default rates on auto loans in the United States. Sales in North America declined 15 percent in the half year. Mitsubishi, which is 37 percent owned by DaimlerChrysler, forecasts a full-year net loss of 11 billion yen instead of the 10 billion yen profit it previously anticipated. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAFTALI, RAYMOND
description: NAFTALI -- Raymond. The MacDougal-Sullivan Garden Association mourns the death of our longtime friend & neighbor Raymond Naftali. Raymond was an esteemed member of our community and we will miss him. We extend our love and deep sympathy to his family.

title: Even as Inflation Fears Rise, Rates Remain Oddly Stable
description: Afunny thing has happened on the way to stronger economic growth. While expectations of future inflation have moved higher, interest rates have managed to remain below their highs for the year.

title: N.Y.S.E. Chief Suggests Fund To Cover Losses
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, proposed yesterday that the exchange set up a fund to compensate investors for any losses they may have suffered because of trading violations by the exchange's specialist traders, a senior executive at a specialist firm said.

title: ITT INDUSTRIES TO BUY GERMAN COMPANY FOR $229 MILLION
description: ITT Industries Inc., the world's largest maker of pumps, agreed to buy Wedeco AG Water Technology of Germany for 198.8 million euros ($228.9 million) to increase sales of water treatment systems in Europe. Wedeco shareholders will get 18 euros a share, a 30 percent premium over Monday's closing price. ITT, based in White Plains, will also assume 34.3 million euros in debt, said Ralf Koenig, a Wedeco spokesman in Dsseldorf, Germany. This will be ITT's third purchase this year as the company makes acquisitions to expand its product line. Wedeco's systems use ultraviolet light to treat water.

title: Never Love A Stranger
description: Both power centers of the Democratic establishment the Kennedy left and the Clinton middle -- are frantic at the prospect of losing control of their party to Howard Dean. They fear a McGovernesque debacle that would hand the G.O.P. a super-majority in the Senate.

title: Miami Coach Tells Winslow He Will Not Start
description: Kellen Winslow II, the University of Miami's leading receiver, will not start Saturday against Syracuse because of ''extracurricular'' penalties, Coach Larry Coker said Tuesday.

title: Term Waning, Gov. Davis Reflects on the Battle Lost
description: The bookshelves in Gov. Gray Davis's Los Angeles office are bare, stripped of his books, photographs, mementos. The traces of his three decades in public life are boxed up and headed for storage.

title: Recipe: Caramelized Onion and Quark Dip
description: Time: 1 hour plus 20 minutes' cooling

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Costume May Bring Complaint
description: Black leaders in Houma said they would meet with a white Terrebonne Parish judge who on Halloween dressed in blackface to decide whether to file a judicial complaint, said Jerome Boykin, the local N.A.A.C.P. president. The judge, Timothy C. Ellender, has expressed contrition. The state code of judicial conduct requires judges to act ''at all times'' in a way that promotes public confidence in the judiciary's integrity and impartiality. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALY, DANIEL R.
description: DALY--Daniel R., 78, former resident of Baldwin, NY, died Sunday, November 9 in Gardner, MA following a long illness. He was the oldest son of Daniel E. and Mary (Murphy) Daly's seven children. A lifelong educator, Mr. Daly taught hundreds of students during his 36-year career as a teacher. He taught English at Lawrence High School, Cedarhurst, NY on Long Island from 1951-68. Mr. Daly received his Bachelor's degree in English and History in 1950 from the University of Massachusetts-Amherst. He received his Master's degree in Education from Harvard University's School of Education, Cambridge, MA in 1951. Mr. Daly, affectionately known as ''Digger,'' saw active duty in the Pacific Theater of World War II as a United States Marine. He leaves his wife of 52 years, Ellen E. (Crahan) Daly of Gardner, three sons, Brian, Daniel, and Christopher, one daughter, Ellen Bell, and five grandchildren. The Funeral Mass will be held Thursday, November 13 at 10:00 A.M. at Holy Spirit Church, 50 Lovewell Street, Gardner.

title: The Neediest Cases; Big Sister Decides to Step Up, Putting Her Dreams on Hold
description: Mary Fulford, 23, leaned forward on a black love seat in her apartment in East New York, Brooklyn, stretching and clenching her fingers.

title: U.N. Estimates Israeli Barrier Will Disrupt Lives of 600,000
description: The route for Israel's planned boundary barrier would put nearly 15 percent of West Bank land on the Israeli side and disrupt the lives of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians, according to a United Nations report released Tuesday.

title: As Team Sports Conflict, Some Parents Rebel
description: More than 40 million children participate in organized sports in the United States, a cultural phenomenon known as much for its excesses as its successes.

title: Old Loyalist and New Face Divide Backing of Unions
description: Gerald W. McEntee, the president of the nation's largest public-sector union, has long been looking for a Democratic presidential contender who can be a winner, and two months ago he was leaning toward the candidacy of Gen. Wesley K. Clark.

title: Cashman, Yankees Pursuing Schilling
description: Brian Cashman was the last general manager to arrive at the Arizona Biltmore Resort and Spa for the general managers' meetings on Tuesday, but he quickly swooped into action to begin revamping the Yankees. Cashman's early moves suggest he is interested in a superb pitcher like Curt Schilling.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Digital Rogue To Reigning Elf

title: Clark Tells Veterans He Backs Amendment on Flag Desecration
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark said on Tuesday that he supported a proposed constitutional amendment that would make it illegal to desecrate the American flag by burning or other means, a position that puts him at odds with many constituencies in the Democratic Party and several other candidates for the Democratic nomination for president.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: End the Debates Before They Start
description: Last week the Commission on Presidential Debates announced its schedule for next year. Debates among the presidential candidates are the most important events of the campaign, and they should be the most effective forum possible for the education of American voters. But they won't be, as long as the commission continues to organize them.

title: Will Hydrogen Clear the Air? Maybe Not, Say Some
description: Widespread hydrogen use has been enthusiastically embraced by major corporations and environmentalists alike as a panacea for global warming and the depletion of fossil fuels, and is a particular favorite of the Bush administration. But skeptics, and even some hydrogen advocates, say that use of hydrogen could instead make the air dirtier and the globe warmer.

title: F.B.I.'s Reach Into Records Is Set to Grow
description: A little-noticed measure approved by both the House and Senate would significantly expand the F.B.I.'s power to demand financial records, without a judge's approval, from car dealers, travel agents, pawnbrokers and many other businesses, officials said on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Nov. 8 mischaracterized the innovation for which Robert Fulton is known. It is steam navigation for ships, not the creation of the steam engine.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I walk into the compound now, they think I am a ghost.''

title: The Big Apple Circus
description: This is the story of two apples that live just across the street from each other.

title: Audition for Mark Jackson
description: The former Knicks guard Mark Jackson will audition for ABC Sports tonight to be its lead N.B.A. analyst. Jackson and Al Michaels, who recently signed to be ABC's lead N.B.A. announcer, will simulcast the Raptors-Lakers game at Staples Center, a network spokesman said.

title: A Different Sears Looks a Lot Like Some of Its Rivals
description: Sears, Roebuck is a 117-year-old retailer wandering in search of its future. And the trail has led here, to this prosperous Salt Lake City suburb, and a month-old store called Sears Grand.

title: Alabama Justice on Trial Over Ten Commandments
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 12  Alabama's chief justice, Roy S. Moore, appeared in front of a special judicial court today to face charges that could lead to his ouster from the bench for refusing to remove a monument of the Ten Commandments that he had installed in the rotunda of the State Supreme Court.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Wednesday about John Gordon, a dealer in American folk art, misstated the given name of the founder of the Barnes Foundation, in Merion, Pa., where Mr. Gordon studied Pennsylvania folk art. The founder was Dr. Albert C. Barnes, not Alfred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, MILTON S.
description: SHAPIRO--Milton S. Milton's wisdom and insight overflowed into the lives of all those with whom he came into contact. We were privileged to be among those who knew him. The many facets of his character, his humor and his wit are now ingrained in all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his cherished wife Bea, his beloved daughter Susan and son Philip and to all his family and friends who will miss him deeply. The employees of Liberty Maritime Corporation

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Fugitive Lottery Winner's Number Is Up
description: A winning lottery ticket worth $7 million cannot be cashed in by a man who broke a verbal contract with 19 fellow workers to share the prize and disappeared with the ticket, a judge ruled. The unidentified man and his colleagues in the Catalonian town of Ripollet had formed a syndicate in which they played the national lottery every Friday and said they would share any payout. The judge upheld the verbal agreement and blocked payment of the $7 million prize. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Beets and Peppers For the Candy Dish
description: Eating your vegetables has never been sweeter, at least since Fauchon introduced pte de lgumes, a new line of vegetable-based confections. Like their cousins, pte de fruits (fruit jellies), these jewel-toned, sugary squares have intense flavors, but with beet, red pepper, fennel and carrot replacing the usual passion fruit and black currant. Imported from France, they are made using the same technique as Fauchon's pte de fruits, substituting vegetables that are naturally high in sugar. While beet, with its magenta hue, is the most striking, the red pepper is the eye-opener. Tangy, ripe and spicy, with a dried-apricotlike vibrancy, it makes you wonder why red peppers are not used more often in desserts. Pte de lgumes are $40 a pound at Fauchon, 442 Park Avenue (56th Street), (212) 308-5919; 1000 Madison Avenue (77th Street), (212) 570-2211; and 1383 Third Avenue (78th Street), (212) 517-9600. MELISSA CLARK

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Testifies In Rape Case
description: A man accused of luring two teenage girls from Mexico to Brooklyn, where the police say he raped them and held them as sex slaves, faced one of them in court. The man, David Perez, 22, was arrested in May 2002, and is charged with rape, unlawful imprisonment and other crimes. The young woman testifying, now 20, said on Monday that the sexual abuse began not long after she met Mr. Perez, a Mexican citizen, in Puebla, her hometown. Mr. Perez promised her and a 17-year-old girl jobs in the United States as nannies or maids, prosecutors said. But the police say Mr. Perez raped the young women in his Brooklyn apartment for two weeks, from May 12 until May 27 of last year. The two told the police that they escaped after Mr. Perez put them to work at a Manhattan brothel. Mr. Perez's lawyer, Barry Krinsky, said there was ''absolutely no evidence'' that the girls were held against their will. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: 'Now Batting, but Trying to Stop the Hitting . . .'
description: JOE TORRE has polished off his plate of striped bass, autographed a few menus and complimented Il Vagabondo on its vittles and indoor boccie court. Gripping an iced tea in the hand weighted down by a diamond-studded bauble, his 1999 World Series championship ring, he amiably pronounces himself ready, set and eager to be seen out of context. Way out of context.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: AFRICAN LEADERS URGE U.N. ROLE West African heads of state urged the United Nations to consider deploying peacekeepers in war-divided Ivory Coast to reinforce and eventually replace a stretched regional force. The leaders' appeal was issued after a one-day summit meeting in Ghana meant to ease regional tensions aggravated by the civil war that exploded in Ivory Coast after a failed rebel uprising last year. The leaders of Burkina Faso, Togo and Ivory Coast took part in the meeting, along with the presidents of Nigeria, Benin, Niger and Ghana. (Reuters)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Immunomedics Shares Plummet
description: Shares of Immunomedics lost more than half their value after Amgen, the world's largest biotechnology company, said yesterday that it would not proceed with new tests of an experimental cancer medicine the companies were developing. Amgen will either return the drug to Immunomedics or try to sell its rights to another party, an Amgen spokeswoman, Trish Hawkins, said. Amgen, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., licensed the drug from Immunomedics, which develops products for cancer and infectious diseases, in 2000. The companies stopped a test of the drug earlier this year. New medicines approved after that trial began also are designed to treat patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma who no longer respond to older treatments, the companies said at the time. In a statement, Immunomedics said the partners were unable to settle terms of an expanded agreement that would have allowed Amgen to sell the drug worldwide. Ms. Hawkins said Amgen's decision not to proceed with the drug was based on more than a disagreement over marketing. She declined to elaborate. Calls to executives with Immunomedics, based in Morris Plains, N.J., were not returned. Immunomedics stock dropped $3.87, or 53 percent, to $3.38, a seven-month low and the biggest percentage drop in one day in at least 16 years. Amgen slipped 16 cents, to $58.98.

title: Guns, Pain and Horror: Congress Should Act
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: MISSISSIPPI: JUDGE REJECTS SUIT ON LAWYERS A state judge ruled that poor criminal defendants in a northwestern county received adequate legal representation, rejecting a lawsuit brought by the county against the state. Quitman County said it could not afford the quality of representation required in the state's Constitution. Judge Ann H. Lamar of Circuit Court noted in her ruling that "this lawsuit has raised issues of statewide concern which give rise to serious constitutional dilemmas."

title: Embracing Southern Art: Old Times There Are Not Forgotten
description: The opening of the Ogden Museum of Southern Art here was much celebrated, but when the speeches and Champagne toasts were over, the awkward question remained: What exactly is Southern art?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Monday with an article about connections between Irving Berlin and the protagonist in the movie ''The Human Stain'' referred incorrectly to the film ''The Jazz Singer.'' It incorporated one Berlin song, ''Blue Skies,'' not one of the minstrel and ragtime works that he wrote for white performers.

title: Failed Pensions: A Painful Lesson in Assumptions
description: Robert M. Bowden retired from his job as accounts manager for a large trucking company with a plan to travel for himself.

title: More Big 3 Cars to China
description: General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler said yesterday that they had reached agreements with China to import more cars and trucks built in the United States.

title: Guns, Pain and Horror: Congress Should Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TABACHNIKOFF, RABBI BARRY
description: TABACHNIKOFF -- Rabbi Barry. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with great sorrow the untimely passing of a devoted champion of Israel who served from 1995 to 1997 as chairman of its National Rabbinic Cabinet. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joshua Matza, President & CEO Burton P. Resnick, Chairman of the Board Bobbie Goldstein, Nat'l Campaign Chairman Rabbi Gary A. Glickstein, Chairman, National Rabbinic Cabinet Rabbi Yaacov Rone, National Director, Synagogue & Rabbinic Activities

title: A Former Navy Base Takes On a New Life
description: In 1993, this North Shore suburb of Chicago got the news that the naval air base occupying 1.5 square miles in the middle of its village -- 15 percent of its area -- would be closing. At the time, the base had 110 buildings and 300 acres of runways and aprons, and residents had to drive around it to get from one part of town to another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THURLOW, HERBERT WIL LIAMS
description: THURLOW -- Herbert Wil liams. Died on Sunday November 9, 2003, formerly of Aiken, SC, and Babylon, NY. Survived by his wife, Merritt Walbridge McCully, four children, nine grandchildren, and two great grandchildren.

title: $62 Million in a 'Fast and Furious' Sale
description: The hungry horde of art dealers and collectors who overflowed Christie's salesroom last night couldn't stop shopping. They fought and fought over works from the 1940's right through to the 90's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLATT, JANE (NEE GOLDBERG)
description: BLATT--Jane (nee Goldberg). Formerly of Chicago, Il; beloved wife of late Edward Blatt and Leonard Rubin. Dear sister of Robert. Funeral Friday 10AM, November 14, 2003 at Woodlawn Cemetery Chapel, Bronx.

title: Nippon Telephone Profit Rises Sharply
description: Profit at Nippon Telegraph and Telephone increased more than tenfold to a record in the first half of the company's fiscal year as its cellphone provider, NTT DoCoMo, posted strong growth in subscriptions for its third-generation phone service.

title: Rosie ODonnell Case Ends Without a Winner
description: AManhattan judge decided today to award no damages to either side in the lawsuit between Rosie O'Donnell and her former publishing partner over who was to blame for the demise of the magazine named after the former talk show host.

title: Fall's Not Just in the Air, But on the Palate
description: THIS seems to have been the longest summer. At this time of year, people should, by rights, be growing bored with fall, and yet it seems just to be starting. And anyone would think that I, as one who has written about extending summer, should be pleased, yet I find myself hankering after traditional autumnal evenings, with food that is warm, cozy, homemaking and welcoming.

title: Queens Windows Shatter as Manhole Covers Explode
description: Three manhole covers exploded into the air yesterday morning on a residential block in central Queens, injuring no one but shattering glass in apartment buildings as high as the 19th floor and jolting residents who feared a terrorist attack.

title: Sports Briefing
description: HOCKEY

title: Rivals Move to Exploit A Network TV Problem
description: Competitors of broadcast network television are moving to capitalize on its problems with data from Nielsen Media Research that show a decline in viewership among men ages 18 to 34. Trade publications this week are filled with advertisements from media companies boasting how they are able to help advertisers reach that demographic group.

title: Rodriguez Is Available For a Price, Rangers Say
description: The Texas Rangers insist they are not actively trying to trade Alex Rodriguez.
