Scott Boras, Rodriguez's agent, says club officials have not asked his client about waiving his no-trade clause to facilitate a deal. So why do so many baseball officials at the general managers' meetings here think that Rodriguez will soon be traded?

title: Marvin Smith, 93, Whose Photographs Defined Harlem Life
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Surprise Word on Nuclear Gains by North Korea and Iran
description: Two intelligence reports issued in recent days find that North Korea and Iran have made advances on a variety of technologies necessary to build nuclear weapons that surprised many nuclear experts and Western intelligence officials.

title: Big Three Reach Deal to Export 15,000 Vehicles to China
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12  In a move to quell criticism of its huge trade surplus with the United States, Beijing has agreed to allow the Big Three automakers to export about 15,000 cars and trucks to China, as well as more than $1 billion in parts from General Motors , over the next couple years.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the New DVD's column yesterday about the film ''Tokyo Story'' misspelled the surname of the scholar who provides the commentary on the DVD. He is David Desser, not Dresser.

title: Uncovering The Inner Pie
description: I KNOW it's un-American to say so, but I'm not a big fan of apple pie. I especially dislike the two-crust variety, in which the apples steam in their own juices, becoming apple chunks in their juice at best -- and hard, undercooked chunks at worst -- sitting between two crusts. An applesauce sandwich.

title: A Stained-Glass Window, Once Lost, Now Found
description: The thieves never even bothered to change the license plates on the van they stole, but they sure seemed to have used it for all it was worth. The treads were worn down on the tires, bought new just two days before the van disappeared, and a bag of Jack-in-the-Box fast food sat in the front seat.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Troubled Pension Plans Are Lesson in Assumptions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLEIER, SHIRLEY BAND
description: BLEIER--Shirley Band. Mother, grandmother, great grandmother died November 2, 2003 at age 89. She will be forever loved, missed and never forgotten.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RUBY TUESDAY, Maryville, Tenn., an operator of casual dining restaurants, said it would change its cooking oil and introduce a low-carbohydrate menu to meet customer demand for healthier food.

title: General Vows to Intensify U.S. Response to Attackers
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 11  Stung by the deaths of nearly 40 American soldiers over the past 10 days, the top American military commander in Iraq spoke of a "turning point" in the conflict on Tuesday and outlined a new get-tough approach to combat operations in areas north and west of Baghdad, strongholds for loyalists of Saddam Hussein.

title: Strong Flavors to Tickle the Palate, Not Overwhelm It
description: THE small-producer Champagnes are much as they should be. Small but determined. Charming though evanescent. They are fun treats and ought not to be washed out by intrusive foods.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Official May Resign
description: John T. Odermatt, left, the commissioner of the city's Office of Emergency Management, is expected to announce his resignation today to take a private-sector job, several city officials said yesterday. He will leave at the end of the year to take a job with Citigroup as the director of business continuity, a post in which he will manage the financial-service company's efforts to prepare for and recover from disasters, one official said. Mr. Odermatt has headed the emergency agency since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed him in April 2002. The agency is responsible for coordinating the response of city agencies to emergencies ranging from floods and hurricanes to blackouts and terrorist attacks. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: At Least 26 Killed in a Bombing of an Italian Compound in Iraq
description: NASIRIYA, Iraq, Nov. 12  A car or truck bomb exploded in the courtyard of an Italian paramilitary police headquarters in this southern Iraqi city on Wednesday, killing 17 Italians and at least 9 Iraqis and wounding more than 105 others. It was the most lethal single attack on forces of the American-led occupation since Saddam Hussein was swept from power in April.

title: In Middle of the Kerry Storm, A Man Known to Whirlwinds
description: As Democratic strategists go, Bob Shrum has long been considered one of the heavyweights: a talented speechwriter, an expert at debate preparations, an ideologically committed liberal who has a knack for distilling the essence of a candidate's message into a slogan, sound bite or 30-second commercial.

title: Two Voters for A.L. Rookie of the Year Anger Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner has taken on managers and coaches, superstars and scrubs, league officials and fellow owners. Now he is angry at the two sportswriters who left Hideki Matsui off their ballots for American League rookie of the year.

title: Guns, Pain and Horror: Congress Should Act (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about Pippa Calland, a chef, misstated part of the name of the TriBeCa restaurant where she will work when it opens on New Year's Eve. It is Della Rovere, not Bella.

title: Republican Evolution, From Lincoln to Reagan
description: GRAND OLD PARTY

title: Educating Hunter, A Child of Autism
description: WHAT can Hunter become? It would be so much easier for Hunter's parents, Cynde Greene and Peter Fellman, if the answer were a little clearer. Hunter's older brother, Nigel, a junior at Medfield High, has become a member of the honor society and plays three sports, but Hunter, their 13-year-old eighth grader, has autism, which is a wild card.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about differing interpretations of the election results in Nassau County on Long Island misstated the share of elected countywide offices now held by Democrats. It is three out of five, not three out of four.

title: Chatter in the Cave of the Winds
description: Senate majority Republicans might take a moment -- or even a vote -- to extend reassurance to the nation's millions of unemployed tonight during the 30-hour ersatz ''filibuster'' they plan to protest the Democrats' blocking of President Bush's more extremist judicial appointees. The filibusterers will talk through the night, performing from a political script in a time-wasting tableau designed to produce campaign fodder for next year. But out there in real life, federal emergency unemployment benefits are scheduled to expire on Dec. 31 with no sign of notice from the Republicans in Congress. A year ago, they blithely quit the Capitol and let the unemployed stew through the holidays before retroactively approving a benefit extension that was far too modest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARR, MAX
description: TARR--Max. Violinist and teacher, passed away on November 7, 2003 in Miami, FL at the age of 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINCIELI, MILLIE
description: MINCIELI--Millie. On November 11, 2003. Beautiful wife of Michael Mincieli, loving mother of Michael and Dennis, adoring great-grandmother ''GG'' of Jack and Will Allee. She was one of the lucky ones--a lively, beautiful woman blessed with an extraordinarily loving and gentle husband, devoted family, good health and a long life--one week short of 90 years. We will love you always Millie. Mike, Michael, Dennis and Debra Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell on Thursday, November 13, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral on Friday, November 14 at St. Ignatius of Loyola Church. Contributions to St. Aloysius Gonzaga Boys Program, 223 W. 132 St.

title: Europeans Warn U.S. on Wider Effects From Steel Tariffs
description: European nations including Britain warned on Tuesday that a trade war could erupt if the United States ignored a ruling by the World Trade Organization that American tariffs on imported steel are illegal.

title: Italian Forces Will Stay in Iraq, Berlusconi Says
description: ROME, Nov. 12  Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, said today that his mind was unchanged and his determination unshaken: Italian forces belonged and would stay in Iraq, despite the deaths of 18 Italians in a suicide bombing there.

title: Our Towns; Please Forgive Gnarled Limbs. Its Age Is 600.
description: IN cities across the region, there are those who would stop at almost nothing to preserve old buildings, weathered monuments and other manufactured landmarks that evoke history and craftsmanship. For them, virtually every facade, every bracket, every column stands as an almost sacred relic worthy of preservation.

title: Blair Expresses Support for Bush And Cautions Demonstrators
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair said Tuesday that he fully supported American actions in Iraq and throughout the world, and he urged demonstrators mounting street protests against President Bush's visit here next week to look beyond their objections to the war and focus on the future.

title: N.C.A.A. to Start Testing for New Steroid
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association president, Myles Brand, said yesterday that member colleges and universities are going to start testing, possibly this fall, for tetrahydrogestrinone, a previously undetectable ''designer'' steroid linked to prominent professional athletes.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the growing number of shops selling cupcakes in New York City misstated the recent history of a space that houses one, the Magnolia Bakery, at 401 Bleecker Street. When Magnolia opened in 1996, it occupied part of what had been a bird shop. Later, a florist took over the rest of the space. Magnolia did not open next to the bird shop.

title: Cheese for Rocket Scientists, and Others
description: IT'S hard to take a cheese seriously when it shares its name with both a subatomic particle and a computer application. Or, perhaps, it's hard to take the subatomic particle or the application seriously since they share their name with a cheese. However you look at it, quark, the cheese, has always deserved both its own identity and more respect.

title: Recipe: Quark Mousse With Mixed Berries
description: Adapted from Gotham Bar and Grill

title: A Storm-Tossed Hero, Now Dry; New Roof Repays Family's Debt to Savior of 170 in 1945 Fire
description: With aid of neither cane nor helping hand, Clarence Moore, who is in his 90's, hobbles about the last house left standing on old Wallace Road. On the wall, he has placed three decorations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANNING, EILEEN G.
description: MANNING--Eileen G. We remember your beautiful countenance, and matching inner spirit. Your indomitable courage is an inspiration to us all. Jack and Rita Lichtenstein and Family

title: House G.O.P. Offers Compromise in Hope of Ending Stalemate on Medicare Bill
description: House Republicans floated a compromise on Tuesday that they said could delay direct competition between private health plans and traditional Medicare, the most contentious issue in a bill to help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs.

title: Budget, Too, Helps Unsettle Colombia
description: This strategically situated Andean country, with Latin America's fifth-largest economy, had for years posted solid economic growth while controlling its foreign debt. No matter its grinding civil conflict, Colombia boasted sound fiscal management that stood in contrast to its reputation as chaotic and violent.

title: 2 Sides at First Sniper Trial Vie to Put On a Human Face
description: They died in the middle of the everyday acts of ordinary lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANN, LESTER
description: MANN--Lester. Age 79 on November 7, 2003 of Horsham, PA. Accomplished child psychologist, former professor of special education at Hunter College and current Director of Special Education and President of Delta Schools. Dr. Mann was devoted to children with learning disabilities, and was the author of numerous books and professional articles on special education, learning disabilities, behavioral management. Survived by his wife Constance C. (Cooper) Mann, one son Douglas L. Mann, M.D., and three grandchildren. He was predeceased by a son Dr. David C. Mann, a sister Shirley Anderman. A memorial service will be held Saturday November 15, 2003 at 2PM for relatives and friends at the Emil J. Ciavarelli Family Funeral Homes, 951 East Butler Pike, Ambler, PA. Interment private at convenience of the family. Visitation from 1-2PM before service at funeral home.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: If You Don't Buy Her Book, The Terrorists Win

title: Court Hearing On Adult Trial For Athletes In Abuse Case
description: Three high school freshmen who said they were sexually abused at a summer training camp in Pennsylvania are expected to testify on Wednesday at a court hearing that represents a crucial juncture in the saga of the Mepham High School football team.

title: Still mired in problems, the Interpublic Group posts a larger third-quarter loss than last year.
description: THE daunting challenges that still confront the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York as it struggles to effect a turnaround were underlined yesterday in red ink -- pots of red ink.

title: ALLIANCE GAMING AGREES TO BUY SIERRA DESIGN
description: The Alliance Gaming Corporation, the second-largest maker of slot machines in North America, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy closely held Sierra Design Group, another maker of gambling devices, for as much as $140 million. Alliance said it would acquire all Sierra shares for about $45 million in cash and stock. Alliance, based in Las Vegas, may also pay $95 million in cash and stock over the next three years if Sierra meets financial goals. The purchase adds Sierra's Raining Diamonds, a slot machine that pays out diamond jewelry as a jackpot award, to Alliance's Bally Gaming and Systems unit. Sierra Designs is based in Reno, Nev.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, ARNOLD J.
description: BERNSTEIN--Arnold J. The entire Board of Trustees and the Blythedale Children's Hospital community mourn the loss of our dear friend and long-standing Board Member, Arnold J. Bernstein. Arnold was a devoted supporter of the work of the Hospital since 1953 when he became a member of the Board. In 1964, he became Vice President, a position he held until 1972 when he was elected to a five-year term as President of the Board. In 1990, Arnold stepped down as a member of our ''active'' Board and became an Honorary Trustee. He cared deeply about our children and their care. We send deep and sincere condolences to his wife Jeanne, his daughters Linda Miller, Carol Clark and Janael McQueen, as well as the entire Bernstein family. Laurence W. Cohen, Chair of the Board of Trustees Larry Levine, President and CEO Joelle Mast, PhD, M.D., VP and Chief Medical Officer

title: Meet the Spirits That Lift The Spirit High
description: EATING lots of rich food, as people tend to do at this time of year, is fine as long as it ends well. And although this may come as a surprise, lying on the sofa in a food coma really isn't the goal.

title: FOOTSTAR REVIEWS FIRING OF ITS FORMER CHIEF
description: Footstar Inc., which operates more than 530 athletic-shoe stores, said yesterday that its board had decided that its former chief executive, J.M. Robinson, had been ''terminated for cause.'' Mr. Robinson left the company in September amid an investigation into accounting discrepancies. The decision resulted from a review of Mr. Robinson's activities, the company, in West Nyack, N.Y., said. The company, which runs Footaction and Just for Feet stores, said on Sept. 15 that Robinson had resigned and that it would restate results.

title: INSIDE
description: Surprising Nuclear Gains

title: Corrections
description: A program listing, highlight entry and picture caption in the Wednesday pages of the Television section on Sunday for the new Court TV series ''House of Clues'' has become outdated. The series will have its premiere on Saturday at 11 p.m.; an episode of the crime-solving series ''I, Detective'' will be shown tonight at 8:30.

title: Moscow Court Turns Down Oil Tycoon's Bid for Release on Bail
description: A court here refused on Tuesday to free Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest businessman, upholding an earlier decision to hold him in prison at least until the end of the year as prosecutors complete an investigation of fraud, tax evasion and other crimes.

title: When Bush Talks of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Soldiers' Stories, And Our Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Oct. 13 about the fate of a building designed by Edward Durell Stone at Columbus Circle incorrectly described the circumstances under which the Museum of Arts and Design changed its name and hired a former landmarks commissioner. The museum changed its name from the American Craft Museum after it was awarded the 2 Columbus Circle site in June 2002, not before. It also put the former commissioner, Laurie Beckelman, on its payroll after winning the site, not before. The article incorrectly described the status of Donald J. Trump's bid to develop the site. Mr. Trump never removed himself from consideration.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machine Orders Decline
description: Defying expectations for an increase, orders in Japan for new machinery slid for a third straight month, a sign that an upturn in capital spending may be losing steam. Orders, which anticipate capital spending by about a half year, fell 1.6 percent in September compared with those in August. Corporate investment has been one driver of the economy and the slowdown in the third quarter suggests that the recovery is slowing. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hold The Vitriol
description: Considering the savagery with which the Snarling Right excoriated President Clinton as a ''sociopath,'' blocked judicial appointments, undermined U.S. military operations from Kosovo to Iraq, hounded Vincent Foster and then accused the Clintons of murdering him, it is utterly hypocritical for conservatives to complain about liberal incivility.

title: S.&P. Cuts Fords Debt Rating to Lowest Investment Grade
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its credit ratings today on $180 billion worth of debt issued by the Ford Motor Company , a move that could conceivably drive the auto giant's borrowing costs higher in the future.

title: Panel Urges Small Clinical Trials for Testosterone Therapy
description: The United States government should sponsor small, targeted clinical trials asking whether testosterone therapy can improve conditions like frailty, weakness, failing memories, and loss of sexual function in aging men with low levels of the hormone, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: Homelessness-Prevention Methods Urged
description: New York City must make greater efforts at preventing low-income families from losing their housing if it is ever going to curb the growing shelter population, a court-approved panel on homeless policy has found.

title: German Company Admits Defect in Infant Food
description: After the deaths of two Israeli children because of a severe vitamin deficiency, the German manufacturer of infant formula admitted Tuesday that a kosher, soy-based product it sells in Israel was missing an ingredient necessary to sustain infant life.

title: U.S. Aide in Iraq in Urgent Talks at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, made a hurried return to Washington on Tuesday as Bush administration officials held an urgent round of meetings to discuss ways of speeding up the transfer of power to Iraqis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABINOR, RUTH GLEEN
description: RABINOR--Ruth Gleen. The Anti - Defamation League mourns the passing of Ruth Gleen Rabinor, beloved mother of Arnold Rabinor, an ADL National Commissioner. We extend our sincere condolences to Arnold and the entire family. Barbara B. Balser, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: UNITED TO GIVE GATES IN DENVER TO FRONTIER
description: Frontier Airlines said yesterday that it planned to be operating a total of 16 to 20 gates for large jets at Denver International Airport when its current expansion plan is completed. Frontier, which is based in Denver, had been ironing out that plan since an announcement by the airport on Sunday that United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation and Frontier's biggest rival, would stay at the airport. United and the airport were involved in a dispute over United's contract. As part of a new agreement, United will give one gate on Concourse A to Frontier for permanent use, the airport said. United will also give Frontier two gates temporarily. United has said it plans to compete with Frontier in Denver by starting a low-cost airline aimed at leisure travelers. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: 2 Crucial Questions Before Sniper Jury Pool
description: ''This defendant was four months from his 18th birthday at the time these crimes were committed,'' said Robert F. Horan Jr., a prosecutor. He faced the jury box, where three potential jurors sat, and he gestured across the courtroom toward Lee Malvo, who is accused of participating in last fall's wave of sniper attacks in the Washington area.

title: About New York; Mustering A Parade And Rousing Old Memories
description: THE Veterans Day speeches had ended, taps had sounded, and the sun had given way to clouds the color of battleships. It was time to give a dollar to that old man on the corner for a red paper poppy that shows you care about veterans. Time to think about places called Bataan and Inchon, Khe Sanh and Baghdad. Time to watch a parade.

title: U.S. Teams Head for World Finals in Bridge
description: Two American teams are sure to be in the finals of the two main events at the World Bridge Championships here, but which teams those will be is in considerable doubt at the midpoint of semifinal play.

title: Sports of The Times; A City Always Needing A Title
description: IN New York, the long, dreadful nightmare continues. The demand for coaches' heads grows by the hour.

title: Picturing Good and Evil in Dorian
description: Afresh cast took over three leading roles in ``Dorian'' at American Ballet Theater's performance on Nov. 6 night at City Center. But the dancers only intermittently breathed fresh life into Robert Hill's adaptation of Oscar Wilde's ``Picture of Dorian Gray.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Reports A Loss
description: The German drug and chemicals maker Bayer reported a third-quarter loss because of poor results at its chemicals and polymers units and high revamping costs. Bayer reported a net loss of 123 million euros ($141 million), in contrast to a profit of 656 million euros a year ago. The loss was in line with market expectations. Excluding one-time charges for revamping, Bayer had an operating profit of 21 million euros. Sales were hurt by currency effects and fell 8 percent, to 6.8 billion euros. The company, which is based in Leverkusen, said on Friday that it planned to spin off the chemicals and polymers businesses to focus on pharmaceuticals and crop protection businesses. Those divisions improved their performance compared with 2002's third quarter. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Continent Wrings Its Hands Over Proclaiming Its Faith
description: Unlike the United States, with its ''In God We Trust'' engravings on coins and in courtrooms, its Washington prayer breakfasts and various other religious ceremonies in public life, most countries of Europe pretty much keep religious rituals outside the rituals of government.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A Son's Documentary
description: ''My Architect,'' a film about the architect Louis I. Kahn by his son, Nathaniel, opens today at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village. The movie was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films Series, and a review by Stephen Holden appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The review is available online at nytimes.com/movies.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Judge Rejects Suit On Lawyers
description: A state judge ruled that poor criminal defendants in a northwestern county received adequate legal representation, rejecting a lawsuit brought by the county against the state. Quitman County said it could not afford the quality of representation required in the state's Constitution. Judge Ann H. Lamar of Circuit Court noted in her ruling that ''this lawsuit has raised issues of statewide concern which give rise to serious constitutional dilemmas.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERFARB, DANIEL H.
description: LIEBERFARB -- Daniel H. Died November 11. Beloved husband, revered father, cherished grandfather. WWII veteran, entrepreneur. We love you always. Your wisdom, humor and charm will be missed. You raised the bar for us all. We will keep you alive in our hearts forever. William, Monica, Ellen, Ronnie, Marisa, Amanda, Lauryn, Melanie

title: Knicks Eager For McDyess
description: As the season quickly slides away from the Knicks after two straight losses, they grow increasingly eager for Antonio McDyess to return.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 2 about a petition by scholars and others criticizing the Smithsonian Institution's exhibition of the bomber Enola Gay misstated the issue and the timing of the display. The exhibition does in fact note that the Enola Gay dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima. The petition criticizes the absence of any mention of casualties and what it says is a lack of historical context. While the Enola Gay and other planes have been installed at the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center near Dulles International Airport, the exhibition does not open to the public until Dec. 15.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a report from a consulting firm, A. T. Kearney, saying that suppliers would have to invest millions to comply with Wal-Mart's policy on electronic tagging of merchandise, misstated the name of the firm's parent. It is Electronic Data Systems, not Services.

title: In Search of Nuclear Control
description: After years of claiming to seek only peaceful nuclear reactors, Iran now acknowledges having tested uranium enrichment and plutonium reprocessing, both of which can be used to make weapons material. Fortunately, to make a bomb, the uranium needed further enrichment and the amount of plutonium was insufficient. In other words, Iran seems to have been caught at an early stage of a secret program. But nobody can be sure whether this is the whole truth or whether Iran simply admitted what it thinks international inspectors already know. It is especially troubling that the inspectors -- who revealed Iran's admission in a new report from the International Atomic Energy Agency -- found traces of highly enriched uranium that have yet to be satisfactorily explained.

title: Recipe: Autumnal Spiced Plums
description: Time: 1 hour 10 minutes

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Bank's Profit Rises
description: Australia's largest bank, National Australia Bank, said its income rose 17 percent in its most recent year, to 3.95 billion Australian dollars ($2.83 billion), helped by a 20 percent increase in home loans and a 9 percent increase in business loans. The chief executive, Frank Cicutto, left, said a 20 percent increase this year in the value of the Australian dollar, which reached a four-year high against the United States dollar, reduced the bank's profit by 65 million Australian dollars. The bank said that profit expansion could slow this year because of an expected decline in the national growth of home lending, now at record levels. The company's last fiscal year ended on Sept. 30. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Barber Letting Season Slip Through His Fingers
description: This walk off the field has become too familiar for Giants running back Tiki Barber, a lost fumble behind him, a coach ahead of him on the sideline greeting him with the same words.

title: U.S. AIDE IN IRAQ IN URGENT TALKS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, made a hurried return to Washington on Tuesday as Bush administration officials held an urgent round of meetings to discuss ways of speeding up the transfer of power to Iraqis.

title: A Showdown in Hockey East
description: Merely your average week early in the season in Hockey East: two national championship contenders deliver a one-two punch to send the undefeated, top-ranked team in the country reeling.

title: Smithsonian Rejects Pleas On Labeling Of Enola Gay
description: The National Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian Institution has rejected a petition seeking revision of the labeling of its exhibition of the B-29 Superfortress Enola Gay, which dropped the first atomic bomb on Japan, in 1945.

title: Soldiers' Stories, And Our Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat Urges an End to Violence as He Swears In New Government
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Nov. 12  The Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and his prime minister called for reconciliation with Israel and delivered strong pleas to restart the troubled Middle East peace plan in speeches today to the Palestinian Parliament, which approved a new government.

title: Music in Review
description: ROCK

title: When Bush Talks of Freedom (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HAAS, RHODA WILLNER
description: HAAS--Rhoda Willner. We miss you. Jane, Jay, Stella, Abbie Willner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DICKMAN, PAULA
description: DICKMAN--Paula. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Paula Dickman, beloved mother of Susan Dickman, Executive Vice President of the Jewish Communal Fund and a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: OFFICIAL MAY RESIGN John T. Odermatt, left, the commissioner of the city's Office of Emergency Management, is expected to announce his resignation today to take a private-sector job, several city officials said yesterday. He will leave at the end of the year to take a job with Citigroup as the director of business continuity, a post in which he will manage the financial-service company's efforts to prepare for and recover from disasters, one official said. Mr. Odermatt has headed the emergency agency since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed him in April 2002. The agency is responsible for coordinating the response of city agencies to emergencies ranging from floods and hurricanes to blackouts and terrorist attacks.    William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: A Truck Convoy to Texas With Fuel in the Tank, and Tigers in the Back
description: The 24 tigers confiscated here after a long legal battle began their trip to a new home in Texas on Tuesday evening, nearly five years after the authorities became alarmed at the animals' treatment by their owner.

title: From Punkers, Anguish And Slap-Happy Love Songs
description: Blink-182

title: Defibrillators For the Public Aid Survival, Study Says
description: Cardiac arrest patients are twice as likely to survive in places where defibrillators are publicly available and volunteers have been trained to use them, according to a study reported Tuesday at a meeting of the American Heart Association here.

title: Colombian Police Chief Resigns
description: The general who commands the Colombian National Police, the 110,000-member force that works closely with American officials to combat drug trafficking here, resigned Tuesday in the wake of corruption scandals that had embarrassed President lvaro Uribe's government.

title: To Opt In or Opt Out
description: In one of the most critical decisions of his campaign thus far, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts says he will announce in coming days whether he will follow his rival Howard Dean and decline public financing in the Democratic presidential primaries.

title: Japan and EU issue threats of billions of dollars in tariffs: U.S. faces sanctions on steel
description: HONG KONG:  One day after the World Trade Organization issued a final ruling that said U.S. steel tariffs were illegal, Japan and the European Union on Tuesday threatened the United States with billions of dollars' worth of sanctions. China and South Korea threatened similar action if Washington retained the tariffs on imported steel.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Accounting Question
description: Shares and bonds of Parmalat Finanziaria S.p.A., which owns Europe's biggest dairy, fell after its auditor, Deloitte & Touche S.p.A., questioned the company's accounts. Deloitte is ''unable to confirm'' that a $135 million gain from a currency derivative contract was treated correctly in Parmalat's first-half results, the auditor said. Parmalat, which had a pretax profit of 120 million euros ($140 million) for the six months ended June 30, said its financial results are ''true and complete.'' Parmalat, which is based in Milan, sells milk and yogurt, Santal juice, ice cream, canned vegetables and baked goods in 30 countries. Its stock fell 8 percent.

title: An Immigrant's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Improving Run Defense A Challenge for Cottrell
description: Ted Cottrell, the Jets' defensive coordinator, stood on the sideline last Sunday, watching the Oakland Raiders grind out a 19-run touchdown drive in the first quarter. As his assistants in the press box desperately tried to decipher the Raiders' last-second substitutions, Cottrell was thinking the same thing as everyone else.

title: Recent Openings
description: A musical based on the movie "Fame" and a revival of a classic Harold Pinter play are among the new shows in New York.

title: Gifts and Beyond
description: Whether you are shopping for gifts or sprucing up your home for guests, five new stores in New York can help with the holidays.

title: Best at Home, Not Over the Shoulder
description: Kate Spade, the handbag designer,  has extended her reach into  tableware, bedding and fabrics.

title: At the Houses
description: Some of the items recently at auction at the major houses.

title: The Trade in Children in Albania
description: A substantial trade in children has established itself in Albania, Europe's most impoverished and isolated country.

title: United We Stand
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Monitoring Broadcast News From Your Desk or Laptop
description: Television recording devices like TiVo free viewers from rigid network schedules by letting them decide when to watch their favorite programs. But such devices are still subject to at least one limitation: they must be plugged into a television set.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: S.E.C. Bars Questioning Of Lawyers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has told lawyers for Martha Stewart that they cannot question two of its lawyers who interviewed an important witness in her criminal case.

title: The Questions About Halliburton
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Rating Of Ford Motor Is Downgraded By Agency
description: Standard & Poor's lowered the Ford Motor Company's debt to its lowest investment grade rating on Wednesday, reflecting skepticism about the company's turnaround plan and a gloomy view of the domestic auto industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINCIELI, MILLIE
description: MINCIELI--Millie. On November 11, 2003. Beautiful wife of Michael Mincieli, loving mother of Michael and Dennis, adoring great-grandmother ''GG'' of Jack and Will Allee. She was one of the lucky ones--a lively, beautiful woman blessed with an extraordinarily loving and gentle husband, devoted family, good health and a long life--one week short of 90 years. We will love you always Millie. Mike, Michael, Dennis and Debra Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell on Thursday, November 13, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral on Friday, November 14 at St. Ignatius of Loyola Church. Contributions to St. Aloysius Gonzaga Boys Program, 223 W. 132 St.

title: Economic Scene; Rapid productivity growth probably did not cause slow post-recession job growth.
description: THE latest reports from the Labor Department suggest that what might be called the Energizer Bunny recession in the job market -- it just keeps going and going -- might finally have come to an end.

title: A Widening Tussle Over a London Office Complex
description: The real estate developer Paul Reichmann, whose Olympia & York group made its mark on the landscape of Manhattan, is now grappling to save the London property that helped push Olympia & York into bankruptcy a decade ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, DR. LLOYD N.
description: GOLDMAN--Dr. Lloyd N., poet. Retired Professor of English Literature at Jersey City State College. Husband of Sande Grant Goldman. Father of Rabbi Yehonoson (Chava) Goldman. Loving grandfather. Services today, Thursday, 10am at ''Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschenbaum Chapels'', 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers please donate to a charity of your choice.

title: Iraqi Leaders Seek Power Before Drafting a Charter
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 12  Iraqi political leaders have decided to reject a plan to write a new constitution in the coming months, saying they will propose instead that they immediately assume the powers of a provisional government.

title: RELIANT RESOURCES QUESTIONED ON ENERGY PRICE REPORTS
description: Reliant Resources, a power producer, said the United States attorney in the Southern District of Texas had requested information as part of an investigation of energy price manipulation. The request, made last month, was for information ''regarding certain price reporting matters,'' Reliant said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Reliant has admitted engaging in ''round trip'' trades, in which the same amount of electricity was bought and sold at an identical price. Federal prosecutors and regulators have been investigating Reliant and other traders for false reporting to publications that compile energy price indexes used to set contract prices.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Fell in October
description: Magazine advertising pages fell in October for a fifth consecutive month, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York said yesterday. Ad pages last month declined 3.2 percent compared with a year earlier, bureau data showed. For the first 10 months of 2003, ad pages have fallen 0.2 percent compared with the period in 2002; through the first nine months, ad pages had been ahead of last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPERLING, DAVID E.
description: SPERLING--David E. Age 75. Died at home November 9, 2003. Survived by loving wife Mary; his children James and Gabrielle; grandchildren Bryan, Lauren, Maxwell and his sisters Gloria Zeisel and Renee Ginsberg. We shared many great times together and we will never forget his warmth, spirit and wonderful sense of humor.

title: CANCELLATION
description: ''A Weekend With Mary Cleere Haran,'' a three-day series that was to begin tonight as part of Lincoln Center's American Songbook season, has been canceled as a result of a fall in which Ms. Haran, left, fractured several ribs, a spokesman for her said yesterday. The series at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse, in the Rose Building at 165 West 65th Street, was to include a master class tonight, a discussion and partial screening of the 1953 film ''The Band Wagon'' tomorrow night, and two sets of performances by Ms. Haran on Saturday. Refunds for tickets are available through Lincoln Center, at (212) 875-5456. BEN SISARIO

title: The Questions About Halliburton
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Democracy, Enshrined in Faith
description: In his admirable if overdue speech last week, President Bush acknowledged 60 years of American error and announced a new policy of encouraging democracy rather than dictatorship in the Muslim world. What Mr. Bush neglected to mention was that many Muslims, if freed to make their own democratic choices, will choose Islam over secularism. A case in point is the newly released draft of the Afghan constitution, which enshrines Islamic values even as it guarantees basic liberties.

title: Sheldon Leffler, Former Councilman, Is Convicted in Campaign Fraud Scheme
description: Sheldon S. Leffler, the former city councilman who represented Queens for nearly a quarter-century, was found guilty yesterday of scheming to defraud the government in his unsuccessful run for borough president two years ago.

title: At 41, Flutie Is Giving a Stiff-Arm to Age
description: Every so often, Doug Flutie does something so memorable on the football field that it evokes new interest in this undersize quarterback whom the aging process seems to be passing by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, AARON
description: ROSENTHAL -- Aaron, 89, born on July 12, 1914 in NYC, died on November 11, 2003 at his home in Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Edna Rosenthal, father of Stephen Rosenthal (Marjorie) and Marjorie Bloom (Paul), grandfather of Adam, Eric, Ester, Daniel, Jeffrey, and Judah, brother of Estelle Walnick. Resident of Washington, DC and Manchester, VT. Graduate of Stuyvesant HS and CCNY (BA, MS). Served in the US Army, 1943-1945. Had an outstanding 33 year career in the US Government as Comptroller of the Veterans Administration, Budget Director of NASA, and Comptroller of the National Science Foundation. Subsequently was Comptroller of the National Academy of Sciences. Served as US Representative Supervisor of the Radiation Effects Research Foundation in Hiroshima, Japan. Recipient, Exceptional Service Award, VA, 1960, and Distinguished Service Award, NSF, 1969. Prize winning amateur photographer. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 3 about Abu Abbas, the Palestine Liberation Front leader who is in American custody after being captured in April in Iraq, referred incompletely to his current status. While lawyers for the Justice Department are not sure that Mr. Abbas can be convicted in the United States for his role in the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985, the Defense Department says American officials indeed remain interested in questioning him.

title: Angered by Filibusters on Nominees, Republicans Stage Their Own Protest
description: The Senate on Wednesday began an extraordinary 30-hour through-the-night session initiated by Republicans to dramatize what they say is the unfairness of the Democrats in blocking four of President Bush's judicial nominees.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD CLIMBS. Gold futures increased on signs that Europe's economy was rebounding. In New York, gold for December delivery rose $6.80, or 1.8 percent, to $395 an ounce.

title: A Glimpse Behind One Man's Makeup; 'Taboo' Is Act II For Boy George
description: Anyone wondering whether Boy George has been battered by the turbulence surrounding his new musical, ''Taboo,'' would have banished such thoughts after hearing him the other evening: The rumors that he and the producer, Rosie O'Donnell, have squabbled. The distraction of her high-profile legal brawl with the publishers of her defunct magazine. His tiffs with a New York theater critic who pronounced ''Taboo'' a ''turkey'' in need of fixing.

title: Brightening Thrillers With a Gloomy Swedish Detective
description: Beneath its apparently ordered surface, Henning Mankell's Sweden is a place of dark crimes and vicious psychopaths, of fractured families and a fraying society. It is the sort of place where a government official could plausibly be assassinated in broad daylight, as happened in September, when Anna Lindh, Sweden's ebullient foreign minister, was stabbed as she shopped in downtown Stockholm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAWSON, BRIGID RUTH
description: DAWSON--Brigid Ruth. Age 73, on November 7, 2003. Daughter of the late Cyril and Marjorie, of Yorkshire, England. Sister of Michael and Valarie and family, Judy and Ken and family, and Chris and Christine and family. An English teacher of many years. A celebration of her life will be held at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Friday 3:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory will be announced.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE AGREES TO BUY MEN'S CLOTHING COMPANY
description: Liz Claiborne, the maker of Elisabeth and Liz Claiborne clothing, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Enyce Holdings, a clothing designer, for $114 million to expand its brands of young men's clothing. The price includes debt, and the deal will increase 2004 earnings by 5 cents a share, Liz Claiborne said. Enyce, which gets 84 percent of its sales from men's clothing, is expected to have sales of $95 million this year. Both companies are based in New York. Profit this year will be unaffected by the purchase.

title: U.S. Moves to Speed Up Iraqi Vote and Shift of Power
description: The Bush administration, moving up its timetable for self-government in Iraq and yielding to its own handpicked leadership there, has decided to try to hold elections in the first half of next year and turn civilian authority over to a temporary government before a new constitution is written, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEAD, STEPHEN II.
description: MEAD--Stephen II. Of Hamilton, MA and Beaufort, SC, died November 8th. His wife, Betty Ann, predeceased him. He is survived by his sister, Barbara Hodges; children, S. Mead Jr., S. Dorsey and D.L. Mead; his stepchildren, S. Doyle, E. Dick, S. Boulet-Gercourt and W. Doyle; eight grandchildren; six step grandchildren; and his former wife, Virginia Lapham Pescosolido. A memorial service at the Middlesex School Chapel, Concord, MA, December 14th at 2:30 PM.

title: Lawyers' Fees To Defend Poor Will Increase
description: New York City settled a lawsuit yesterday over the fees paid to private lawyers assigned to represent the poor in criminal cases, agreeing to nearly double in some cases the rate that has been in place for nearly two decades.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Current Account Grows
description: Japan's current account surplus grew 38 percent in September from a year earlier, helped by strong exports. It was the third straight expansion. The surplus hit 1.6 trillion yen as the trade surplus increased 8.7 percent and the deficit in the service account shrank 30 percent. Three-quarters of the current account, the broadest measure of goods and services going in and out of Japan, is trade in merchandise; the rest is services and financial investments. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Top Executives Named At Three Agencies
description: Three agencies named senior executives to new posts yesterday.

title: A Tropical City as Fruit, Rotten at the Center
description: Late in ''Mango Yellow,'' a teeming mosaic set in the Brazilian coastal city Recife, one character reels off a list of personal associations with the color yellow, and they have nothing to do with sunshine and flowers. Hepatitis and rotten teeth are among the ills metaphorically invoked to suggest the malaise that engulfs the noisily desperate characters in this raw slice of downscale urban life.

title: Iraqi Leaders Seek Power Before Drafting a Charter
description: Iraqi political leaders have decided to reject a plan to write a new constitution in the coming months, saying they will propose instead that they immediately assume the powers of a provisional government.

title: Out of Touch? Check the TV In Your Pocket
description: Beginning today, millions of Sprint PCS Vision subscribers will have access to a new multimedia service: television.

title: Panel Reaches Deal on Access To 9/11 Papers
description: The commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks said on Wednesday that it had reached agreement with the White House to give the panel access to copies of the daily intelligence briefings sent to President Bush's desk shortly before the attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PACE, GENOVEFFA
description: PACE--Genoveffa, suddenly on November 11, 2003. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Theresa DeMarco, Frank, Diana Simulcik and Lydia Antonetz. Survived by nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Services will be held at Santa Maria Church, Bronx, NY, Friday, 9:30AM. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers or gift baskets, please make donations to Elmsford Animal Shelter: 914-592-7326. For further information call Castle Hill Funeral Home, Bronx, NY: 718-828-9222.

title: Try It, Buy It, Store It or Display It
description: WHETHER you are shopping for gifts or sprucing up your home for guests, five new stores in New York can help with the holidays. Among their wares are Chinese antiques and first-apartment furniture, as well as 25,000 square feet of storage solutions, some previously available only through Web sites, catalogs or in suburban malls. This season, they are right around the corner, or just a subway ride away.

title: Branch's Second Effort Rewards 10-0 Colgate
description: Colgate running back Jamaal Branch, the leading rusher in Division I-AA, spent last season chopping wood to stay in shape and breaking up fights so that he could have some spending money.

title: So a Guy Walks Into a School in a Skirt . . .
description: Even now, no one is entirely sure why Kevin Dougherty, 15, showed up for school one day last month wearing a floral skirt and matching scarf tied jauntily around his neck. Pantyhose, eye shadow and lipstick completed the look.

title: Sabres Visit Rochester and Give Fans a Tie
description: A National Hockey League game was a novelty here, and the Buffalo Sabres are determined to belong to all of western New York now. A capacity crowd packed a 50-year-old minor league arena and stuck around until the end.

title: Beats Walking? At 3.4 M.P.H., Not This Bus
description: If you ride the M23 bus, chances are you are not in a hurry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIESENTHAL, CYLA
description: WIESENTHAL--Cyla. Vienna, Austria. Beloved wife of famous Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal. She was a grand lady who stood steadfast at her husband's side as he undertook his lifetime work of the pursuit of justice for the six million who perished in the Holocaust. Sincerest and loving condolences to Simon, Paulinka, Gerald and the grandchildren. Joan and Martin Rosen

title: Sentencings Seen Today In Fraud Case
description: A federal judge is expected to impose sentences today on five former HealthSouth employees who have admitted that they helped manipulate the company's books.

title: A High-Risk Film on the High Seas
description: Every once in a while a Hollywood studio throws out the hit-formula playbook and bets that smart moviegoers will go along for the ride. ''Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World,'' which opens Friday, is that rare case.

title: Rivers Replacing Shockey, For Now
description: Giants tight end Marcellus Rivers struck his usual low-key pose at practice Wednesday. He will take over as the starter for the injured Jeremy Shockey on Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles, but Rivers, calm and polite by nature, has not drawn as much attention in his career as Shockey can on one play. Rivers is 6 feet 4 inches and 250 pounds, and yet it is possible to watch the Giants and forget he is even there.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Business Day on Sept. 26 within a chart about the personal finances of Richard M. Scrushy, former chief executive of HealthSouth, was published in error. It showed a condominium on Ono Island in Orange Beach, Ala., that is owned by someone else, not one that the government hoped to seize from Mr. Scrushy. The error was brought to the attention of The Times on Oct. 29 by a Web site set up to defend Mr. Scrushy, who faces fraud charges, and was confirmed by the government this week.

title: Popular Science
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including opinions about the past 25 years in science.

title: Keeping the Public Colleges Afloat
description: The United States has moved entire generations into the middle class and beyond by subsidizing public colleges, putting higher education within the reach of many deserving low-income students. The public college system is in steep decline, however, because of decades of declining support from states that historically kept educational quality high and tuition low. The Times's Greg Winter reported recently that the federal government aggravated the problem by giving a disproportionately large share of federal aid to rich private colleges and tossing scraps to public colleges, which enroll about 80 percent of the nation's college students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMAN, MARION
description: NEWMAN--Marion. November 12, 2003 at age 92. The backbone and inspiration of this family. Came to U.S. in 1920 from Zyradow, Poland at age 9. Wife of the late Morris. Mother of Harriet N. Cohen (Arthur Feinberg), Alvin Newman (Ruby), Molli Mezrich (Reuben), Sandra Newman (Jack Kerry). Grandmother of Martha Stine (Carl), Amy Ziegelbaum (Michael), Susan Hirsch (Bruce), Patricia Epstein (Steven), Jonathan Mezrich, Benjamin Mezrich, Joshua Mezrich (Gretchen Schwarze), Michael Newman (Elena Levine), Kurt Newman, Amy Newman. Great grandmother. She will be sorely missed. Funeral Friday November 14, 10:30AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11234 (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: Seeking Clues in an Upstate Fire That Killed 3 Children
description: Fire investigators were still looking on Wednesday for the cause of a house fire that left three children dead on the southern outskirts of this upstate city. They have two places to search -- the ashes that remained from what, until Tuesday morning, had been an imposing colonial-style home, and the terrified memories of the six other family members who managed to escape before it was destroyed.

title: No Cover-Up in Bid, A Witness Concedes
description: A key government witness admitted Wednesday that federal agents could not have built their case against the indicted Olympic bidders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson without the detailed audit trail and ledger kept by the Salt Lake Bid Committee.

title: At Least 26 Killed in a Bombing Of an Italian Compound in Iraq
description: A car or truck bomb exploded in the courtyard of an Italian paramilitary police headquarters in this southern Iraqi city on Wednesday, killing 17 Italians and at least 9 Iraqis and wounding more than 105 others. It was the most lethal single attack on forces of the American-led occupation since Saddam Hussein was swept from power in April.

title: Clark Proposes Joint Venture With Saudis Against Al Qaeda
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark sharply criticized the Bush administration on Wednesday for failing in the hunt for Osama bin Laden and proposed deployment of a joint American-Saudi Arabian commando force to search the Afghanistan-Pakistan border region for the Qaeda terrorist organization.

title: After a Bombing, Saudis Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KINOY, ARTHUR
description: KINOY--Arthur. People's lawyer, teacher. Sunday, November 16, 2PM, Synod House, 110 St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: At Play in Chinatown's Backyard; Eastern Chess Meets Western Basketball Under the Mulberries
description: Blind Man Chin shuffles into Columbus Park in Chinatown, lifts his wooden chess set and shakes the pieces inside, sounding a crackle that scatters the pigeons. It is his invitation to play.

title: Iran's Leader Says U.N. Report Removes Suspicions of Weapons
description: President Mohammad Khatami said Wednesday that a recent report on Iran's nuclear programs by the International Atomic Energy Agency cleared Iran of suspicions that it is developing nuclear weapons. But he added that Tehran might end its voluntary cooperation if the agency's next report, due on Nov. 20, bends to political pressures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOMPKINS, JOHN
description: TOMPKINS--John, 79, died suddenly Saturday night, November 8th of a heart attack. John was a World War II veteran who enlisted at the age of 17. After the war, he graduated from the University of Michigan on the G.I. bill, and then moved to New York to work for Grace Line. The move to New York launched his distinguished career as a journalist working first for the Wall Street Journal. From there he moved to The New York Times, Business Week and finally Time Magazine which led to his appointment to the Price Commission in Washington, DC. He authored two non fiction books ''The Crime Confederation'' and ''The Weapons of World War III''. At the time of his death, John was writing a column for CoiningMoney.com an online investment newsletter. He loved to scrounge for obscure antiques and had an undending thirst and curiosity for information. He was a man of great faith and conviction. His passing is a loss for all who knew him. He is survived by his devoted wife Michele Stephenson and his daughters Claire Tompkins Timothy and Nancy Tompkins Heinemann. The memorial service will be at 5:30 PM Friday, November 14 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 81st Street and Madison Ave. Donations may be made to Hospice of New York, 45-18 Court Square, Long Island City, NY 11101.

title: Where Album Art Survives
description: To the Editor:

title: European Antitrust Office Sits Down With Microsoft
description: Microsoft stuck to the defense it has presented before to European antitrust regulators as it opened a three-day hearing on Wednesday into whether the company was illegally abusing its dominance in operating software.

title: Watching McDyess Gives Lift To Chaney
description: The drills had been run, a four-on-four halfcourt workout was over and Antonio McDyess was sweating. The Knicks were about to begin a full-court scrimmage when Coach Don Chaney and Greg Brittenham, the team's strength and conditioning coach, told McDyess he was done.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: NEW YORK

title: Do-It-Yourselfer's Fantasy: Modern Housing, in a Kit
description: Modern prefab houses are finally here. Leading the pack is Rocio Romero, whose LV home (prototype at top) opens for visits on Saturday in Perryville, Mo. Kits for the 1,152-square-foot LV are $29,195. With extras like delivery ($2,500), glass and interiors, the total cost is $75,000 and up; www.livemodern.com or (415) 722-7171. ''The majority of inquiries are coming from California,'' said Marshall Mayer, the sales manager. ''The photograph of the prototype looks like it's California, but it's in Chile.''

title: Magic Carpet Deals in New Jersey
description: Deals can be had at the new Tufenkian Carpets showroom near the Lincoln Tunnel in New Jersey. While expensive hand-woven rugs from Tibet and Armenia are displayed in the main area, discounts are in the closeout section, at up to 60 percent off. At left is a 6-by-9-foot rug called Stones Cocoa, now $1,815, down from $4,950. Other buys include rugs 3 by 5 feet that were $1,575, now $575. Tufenkian is at 450 Huyler Street, South Hackensack; (201) 994-1900. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: New Cabinet Approved, Arafat Seeks to Restart Mideast Talks
description: The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and his prime minister called Wednesday for reconciliation with Israel and delivered strong pleas to restart the troubled Middle East peace plan in speeches to the Palestinian parliament, which approved a new government.

title: GARDEN Q.&A.
description: To Deny a Deer, Spurge

title: WASHINGTON: ARTS HONORS
description: The director Ron Howard, the dancer and choreographer Suzanne Farrell, the dancer and choreographer Tommy Tune and the conductor Leonard Slatkin were among 10 recipients awarded the 2003 National Medal of Arts by President and Mrs. Bush in ceremonies yesterday in the Oval Office. The winners of the medals, the nation's highest honor for artistic excellence, are chosen by the National Endowment for the Arts. Others honorees were the children's book author Beverly Cleary, the blues musician Buddy Guy, the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, the country singer and songwriter George Strait, the arts educator Rafe Esquith and the PBS television show ''Austin City Limits.'' ELIZABETH OLSON

title: Smile, Gamers: You're in the Picture
description: RICHARD MARX, a 34-year-old astronautical and aeronautical engineer, has been spending a lot of time lately pretending to be Harry Potter. His wand is made from parts of a hotel clothes hanger and has a brightly colored ball on one end. But when he waves it, Dr. Marx says, it begins to glow and emit a distinctive hum in a TV monitor across the room.

title: Charles Brown, 82, Former AT&T Chief, Dies
description: Charles L. Brown, the former chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, who agreed to the historic breakup of the Bell system, died yesterday in Richmond, Va. He was 82 and had lived in Princeton, N.J., since 1975.

title: State Proposal Would Reduce Fish Deaths At Indian Point
description: New York State told the company that owns the Indian Point nuclear plant yesterday to begin taking steps to install a new water cooling system that would prevent the deaths of large numbers of fish each year.

title: Helping Presidents and Others Look Their Best
description: WHAT do political bosses, athletes and high-ranking clergymen at the Vatican have in common?

title: Biogen-Idec Deal Backed
description: Shareholders of Biogen and Idec Pharmaceuticals approved their $5.8 billion merger, creating the third-biggest biotechnology company in the nation. The stock transaction was expected to be completed by Thursday, Biogen executives said. James C. Mullen, Biogen's chief executive, will be the combined company's chief executive.

title: Nasal Spray's Use to Curb Hunger Is Found Safe in Small Test
description: A hormone that suppresses appetite has been made into a nasal spray which, in a preliminary test in 15 people, safely entered the bloodstream and appeared to reduce hunger pangs.

title: L.I. Athletes Are Said to Face Juvenile Trial
description: Three varsity football players from Long Island accused of sexually abusing freshman teammates will not be prosecuted as adults, a Pennsylvania judge ruled Wednesday evening, according to relatives of the victims.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Headmaster Quits Amid Charges
description: The headmaster of a Manhattan preparatory school who is facing pornography charges has resigned, the school said yesterday. The announcement by The Trevor Day School that its headmaster, Dr. John H. Dexter, had resigned came on the same day that the authorities brought an additional charge against him, possession of child pornography. Dr. Dexter had been on a leave of absence from the school since Oct. 27, after the Westchester County district attorney's office charged him with two counts of sending indecent messages to underage girls over the Internet. The underage girls were, in fact, investigators posing as 14- and 15-year-old girls in an Internet sting ordered by the district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro. The child pornography was found on a computer that was seized as evidence at the time of the original charges, Ms. Pirro's office said. The Trevor Day School said in its statement yesterday that neither the new charges nor the old involved any students at the Trevor Day School. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Aiming to Be the Next Big Amenity
description: AS the horizon turned to a deep pink outside the floor-to-ceiling windows of their serene living room, the Cantone family looked out over the Hudson River and pondered the meaning of living ''green.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JONES APPAREL GROUP, Bristol, Pa., said it had increased its offer for the bankrupt Kasper A.S.L., Secaucus, N.J., owner of the Anne Klein brand, by $17 million, to $232.5 million.

title: Profit Falls at Federated Stores
description: Federated Department Stores, the owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 37 percent because of costs from closing and combining stores.

title: The Questions About Halliburton
description: To the Editor:

title: Rematch Is Not Nice Reminder For Nets
description: Kenyon Martin strutted across the court, skipped to the scorer's table and waved his arms wildly to the crowd at Continental Arena.

title: A Sofa Embraced in Its Native Habitat
description: A LOT has happened on the sofa front.

title: Freak Storm Leaves Los Angeles Under a Foot of Hail
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13  Some say the world will end in fire, some say in ice.

title: C.I.A. Report Suggests Iraqis Are Losing Faith in U.S. Efforts
description: A bleak top-secret report by the Central Intelligence Agency suggests that the situation in Iraq is approaching a crucial turning point, with ordinary Iraqis losing faith in American-led occupation forces and in the United States-appointed Iraqi Governing Council.

title: North Carolina Orders Review of Alliance Pension Contract
description: Alliance Capital Management Holding, a New York-based money manager being investigated for improper mutual fund trading, may lose a contract to oversee $7 billion for the State of North Carolina.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Protests For Spill Anniversary
description: Environmental and civic groups called for demonstrations in 22 Galician towns today, the first anniversary of the sinking of the oil tanker Prestige and the spill that sullied beaches on the northern coast. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: VHS Memories Parade Into Your DVD Vault
description: LIKE other families, we had a camcorder when I was growing up in the 1980's, but my father wasn't one of those video guys who would amass hours of soccer games and science fairs. No, my friends and I are largely responsible for the most memorable videos. Sadly, certain projects like our ''Star Trek'' sendup are believed lost for good, or taped over, but I still have one tape, dating from seventh-grade English class, labeled ''NBC Nightly News.''

title: Joe Kleinerman, 91, a Founder Of the New York Road Runners
description: Joe Kleinerman, a runner, track coach and Runyonesque character who was a key figure in developing the New York Road Runners Club, the New York City Marathon and women's distance running, died on Tuesday in Calvary Hospice in the Bronx. He was 91.

title: Justices Mull Twist in Law On Age Bias
description: When Congress made it illegal 36 years ago for employers to discriminate on the basis of age, it was clear that older workers were protected from discriminatory treatment that favored those who were younger. The question in a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday was whether the Age Discrimination in Employment Act also meant the reverse: if Congress in addition meant to prohibit policies that favor older workers over younger ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POVERENY, RACHEL
description: POVERENY--Rachel, 92. Beloved aunt, great-aunt, greatgreat-aunt, cousin and friend. Former teacher and guidance counselor at Bronx High School of Science. Profound influence on both children and adults, whom she nurtured intellectually and infused with a joy of life in all forms. Memorial Service November 16, 2003, Society for Advancement of Judaism, 15 West 86 St, NY, NY at 3:30pm.

title: Has Home Schooling Achieved Respect?
description: To the Editor:

title: There's Green Stuff in the Kitchen and Laundry
description: AS an architect, I have a weakness for high-performance anything, whether concrete blocks or dishwashers. My criteria are excellence in engineering, beauty and energy efficiency.

title: Sarah Lawrence College Drops SAT Requirement, Saying a New Writing Test Misses the Point
description: Sarah Lawrence College is joining a growing list of schools that no longer require standardized test scores for admission, citing concerns about a writing test that is being added to the SAT.

title: Woven With a Woman's Touch And a Moroccan Sensibility
description: Sheva Fruitman, above, a photographer, went to Marrakesh two years ago and learned to weave airy textiles. She bought a loom, hired a weaver, Hammoud el-Foukahi, and began producing woven cotton panels suspended between sheer layers of polyester. The open weave of the panels, made in Marrakesh, makes them seem fragile, but she said they are surprisingly strong. Most Moroccan weavers are men, and she said that except for Mr. Foukahi, ''men don't want to work for a woman.'' So she trained two women to help. A panel 10 by 4 1/2 feet is $1,200 in cream, pale gray and pale blue. Shevafruitman@hotmail.com or (212) 925-5618. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Torre Won't Seek to Extend Contract During the Season
description: Roger Clemens is comfortable with his plans for the future. Joe Torre is not so sure. Clemens considers himself retired and said last night that nothing could change his mind. Torre, the Yankees' manager, said he would not seek a contract extension until after the coming season, if at all.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: U.S. to Push for Iraqis to Take On Bigger Role, Bush Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The United States is developing a plan to "encourage more Iraqis to assume more responsibility" quickly in governing the country, President Bush said today as the top military commander in Iraq blamed most of the violence there on a band of no more than 5,000.

title: Tales of Love Gone Terribly Wrong
description: In emo songs boys are always beaten up by girls: eyes are blinded, backs are stabbed, hearts are broken. If the violence is metaphorical, this is the language of teenage love. But if the violence is literal, this is the language of horror movies.

title: Sting's Loyal Fans Line Up For a Singer-Turned-Author
description: Kim Herzig, one of several hundred fans who descended on the Barnes & Noble bookstore on 66th Street and Broadway yesterday, hugged Sting's new memoir, ''Sting: Broken Music,'' and did her best to catch her breath.

title: Even as They Win One, Rangers Lose Lindros
description: The Rangers finally won a game they were expected to win last night at Madison Square Garden, but they lost Eric Lindros to injury again.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Home Builder Study Attacked
description: A construction industry study critical of proposed ''antisprawl'' regulations was quickly denounced as flawed yesterday by state officials. The National Association of Home Builders said yesterday that its study had concluded that the Department of Environmental Protection's proposed regulations would cost New Jersey nearly 43,000 jobs, reduce state revenue and increase the average home price to $483,000. ''The D.E.P.'s regulatory strategy translates into families without homes and workers without jobs,'' said Patrick J. O'Keefe, head of the New Jersey Builders Association. Bradley M. Campbell, above, the environmental protection commissioner, said the study assumed wrongly that the administration's aim was to stop all growth. Mr. Campbell said growth should be directed first to areas already developed Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Their Master's Voice
description: It must be the voice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Not the Love Boat
description: The first of four aging former United States Navy vessels supposed to be scrapped in Britain after crossing the Atlantic docked in the northern port of Hartlepool. The four ships -- nicknamed ''ghost ships'' by British newspapers -- were among 13 initially set to be dismantled in the British yard. But protesters complained that the ships were laden with asbestos and other toxins, and British authorities suspended the plan to scrap them, leaving their fate uncertain. A separate court order in the United States prevented the other nine ships from leaving the James River in Virginia. As the 58-year-old tanker Caloosahatchee docked in Hartlepool, protesters held placards saying: ''Hartlepool is my home, not America's dustbin.'' Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the historian and presidential adviser Richard E. Neustadt on Nov. 3 and in some late copies on Nov. 2 misstated his birthplace and omitted his place of death. He was born in Philadelphia, not New York City, and he died at his English country home in the village of Furneux Pelham, in Hertfordshire. The article also misstated the name of the political party led by his wife in the House of Lords. It is the Liberal Democrats, not the Social Democratic Party.

title: Iraq Aside, French View the U.S. With a Mixture of Attraction and Repulsion
description: One way of understanding how the French really feel about the United States these days is to ask them not about Iraq but about Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: For Men's Shirts, It's Bright Colors And Bold Patterns
description: Once coveted only by British fops, the so-called dandy shirts -- in wild prints, paisleys and bold, colorful stripes -- have become the hottest sellers in the men's wear business heading into Christmas.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 3 about Abu Abbas, the Palestine Liberation Front leader who is in American custody after being captured in April in Iraq, referred incompletely to his current status. While lawyers for the Justice Department are not sure that Mr. Abbas can be convicted in the United States for his role in the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985, the Defense Department says American officials indeed remain interested in questioning him.

title: Study of Two Cholesterol Drugs Finds One Halts Heart Disease
description: The first study to compare two powerful cholesterol-lowering drugs head-to-head in coronary artery disease finds that one appears to be superior.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Report Urges U.S. To Upgrade Its Fleet Of Deep-Diving Craft
description: Alvin, the submersible that for decades led the American effort to probe the depths of the seas, illuminating such things as the rusting hulk of the Titanic and bizarre ecosystems lush with tube worms, should be upgraded, replaced or joined by a new vehicle that can take people even deeper, a report to the government said on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHIN, HSIU, LING KU
description: CHIN--Hsiu-Ling Ku. Loving wife of Dr. Henry Chin, M.D. for more than 62 years. Devoted mother of Justice Dorothy Ku Chin-Brandt and Frederic Ku Chin. Burial private.

title: Former Guantnamo Interpreter Indicted
description: A former civilian interpreter at the Guantnamo Bay Naval Base was indicted by a federal grand jury on Wednesday on charges of improperly gathering military information and lying to the F.B.I.

title: Peeking Behind the Curtain of Secrecy
description: IN George Orwell's ''1984,'' documents deemed embarrassing to the State were tossed down a memory hole, a disposal chute in the Ministry of Truth that led to enormous furnaces. Taking a cue from the novel, Russ Kick, a journalist and author, established www.thememoryhole.org, a Web site dedicated to saving official documents from oblivion and posting them online.

title: Metro Matters; High-Stepping On a Platform Of Lower Taxes
description: New York Pays Highest Taxes,

title: Ballet Theater Is Calm In Face of Loss of Funds
description: American Ballet Theater insisted yesterday that the Movado Watch Company's decision to switch its support to the New York City Ballet would not damage Ballet Theater's financial health. But others in the worlds of art and philanthropy said Movado, which withdrew its funds over accusations of mismanagement, had delivered a stinging blow at a time when corporate money for dance was limited and cultural backing in decline.

title: U.S. Mounts Fierce Air Battle Against Suspected Guerrilla Targets in Baghdad
description: American forces carried out two ferocious airstrikes Wednesday evening against suspected loyalists of Saddam Hussein's regime, signaling a new and more aggressive strategy to regain the initiative in the guerrilla war now raging across the country's Sunni Muslim heartland.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fired M.T.A. Official Sues Agency
description: One of two top officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority whose dismissal in May caused a furor has sued the agency for lost wages and his old job back. Nicholas B. Casale, the former deputy director of security, was dismissed along with Louis R. Anemone, the director of security, after the M.T.A.'s inspector general concluded the two officials' corruption investigation was based on a nonexistent informant. Mr. Casale and Mr. Anemone, formerly the highest ranking uniformed officer in the Police Department, denied the charge. The two men were also accused of obstructing the inspector general's inquiry. In his lawsuit, filed in September in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Casale said transportation officials wanted to thwart Mr. Anemone's and Mr. Casale's investigation. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Has Home Schooling Achieved Respect? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Regulators Meet With Microsoft on Software

title: Vending Machines Don't Fill McDonald's Plate
description: McDonald's said on Wednesday that it would close its four giant vending machines in the Washington metropolitan area after a yearlong experiment with ''automated convenience stores.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, IRVING
description: COHEN--Irving. Beloved husband of Ruth for 59 years. Devoted father of Judy and Stuart Brenner, Steven and Barbara Cohen. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather of David, Joanna, Michelle and Harold, Jeffrey, Andrew, Scott and Justin. Dear brother of Albert. Funeral services Thursday 10AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: A PATERNITY ROUNDUP The Mecklenburg County Child Support Enforcement Office has summoned men named in 1,000 child-support cases where paternity is disputed to take DNA tests, the office's director said. The 535 people who came in were charged $43 toward the test's cost. Those who do not respond will be summoned before a judge. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Board of Trade Rival Going Out of Business
description: The BrokerTec Futures Exchange, an electronic futures market owned by Wall Street banks, will stop doing business on Nov. 26 because of a slump in trading, according to its general counsel, Douglas E. Harris.

title: After Durst's Acquittal, Fears of Revenge
description: Robert A. Durst's legal problems did not end with his acquittal Tuesday in Galveston, Tex., on charges of killing a 71-year-old retired merchant seaman.
