But the verdict did seem to fuel the fears of people who know him, including his brothers and the woman he was dating in 1982 when his first wife mysteriously vanished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMINS, PHILLIP D., ESQ.
description: AMINS--Phillip D., Esq., of Fort Lee, NJ, on November 12, 2003. Devoted father of Boruch Amins. Dear brother of Merrel Farrington. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday 11:30AM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made in memory of Phillip D. Amins to the Segev Shalom Foundation, 7 Ryan Court, Nanuet, NY 10954.

title: After a Bombing, Saudis Reflect
description: To the Editor:

title: General Says Hussein Loyalists Pose Growing Threat in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The senior American commander in the Middle East said today that the American-led occupation in Iraq faced no more than 5,000 guerrilla fighters, but that they were increasingly well organized, well financed and gradually expanding their attacks to the country's relatively calm north and south.

title: U.S. Moves to Speed Up Iraqi Vote and Shift of Power
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The Bush administration, moving up its timetable for self-government in Iraq and yielding to its own handpicked leadership there, has decided to try to hold elections in the first half of next year and turn civilian authority over to a temporary government before a new constitution is written, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: The E.P.A.'s Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Reveling In the Plushiest Of Bacharach
description: Anyone who doubts that the romantic turbulence in the music of Burt Bacharach exceeds even the most passionate flights of Cole Porter should have been at the Supper Club on Tuesday evening where the singer Ronald Isley performed more than a dozen mostly familiar Bacharach standards.

title: Market Place; Janus Capital Meets the Enemy And It Is Janus
description: Janus Capital, which has lost hundreds of millions in assets and more than 20 percent of the market value of its shares in recent weeks, has not satisfied some shareholders with its effort to end regulatory scrutiny and to revive its investment performance.

title: Minimalism in Mexico: Expect Volcanic Stone
description: Fashionable globe-trotters have a new stamping ground: the W Mexico City, the first Latin American hotel in the W chain. A New York design firm, Studio Gaia, known for Bond Street and Jimmy's Uptown and Downtown, combined volcanic stone finishes and adobe in the spa with a minimalist setting. The lobby, called the Living Room, has a bar, below, and moody lighting, platforms over shallow ponds and box chairs from Studio Gaia called OO, above. On the second floor is a restaurant where diners can be seen from the sidewalk. ''We were playing with the idea of private dining in a public space,'' said Anurag Nema, a principal in Gaia with Ilan Waisbrod. Standard rooms are $179 to $269 a night. Information: www.whotels.com. ARIC CHEN

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: CLINTON URGES AIR PATROLS Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton urged the federal government yesterday to consider flying air patrols over New York State's nuclear power plants. In a letter to Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, Senator Clinton urged patrols over the Indian Point, Nine Mile and Gina nuclear power plants. The letter, also sent to the Department of Homeland Security, noted federal warnings this week that operatives of Al Qaeda might try to hijack cargo jets from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean and fly them into nuclear plants. The Sept. 11 hijackers, Senator Clinton wrote, "were believed to have flown over or nearby the Indian Point reactors on their way down the Hudson River."

title: In the Spirit of Gutenberg, Treasures for All
description: RARE books like the Gutenberg Bible are usually squirreled away in private libraries or locked in sealed cases in public institutions, where only a relative few people are able to peruse them.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the acquittal of Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate heir, in a Texas murder trial misstated the form in which the jury's verdict was delivered. A bailiff took it from the foreman and passed it to the judge, who read it aloud; the bailiff did not announce it.

title: Military Aide Quits, Joining 3 Others in Colombia's Shake-Up
description: The commander of Colombia's armed forces said Wednesday that he was resigning, joining three cabinet ministers who have stepped down in a shake-up marring President lvaro Uribe's administration.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KARBEL, RAE
description: KARBEL--Rae. My dearest, on this your first anniversary, you are missed by all. Not a day goes by that your loving memory fills our hearts with happiness for having had the joy and privilege of knowing and loving you. No more pain. Rest in peace, my darling. Manny, children and grandchildren

title: Salt Lake Bid Trial Delayed
description: The federal trial of the indicted Olympic bidders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson was unexpectedly recessed yesterday, a day after the prosecution's case may have been undermined by its key witness.

title: Breaking Into More Male Strongholds
description: After several requests from female friends looking for a woman to do contracting projects, Linda Simpson asked herself: Why not start a handywoman-referral service? From her work as an insurance adjuster, Ms. Simpson, 43, knew a handful of women in her hometown, Denver, who worked in home repair. And she knew there would be plenty of demand because many women live alone and feel uncomfortable about letting men enter their homes.

title: Set-Top Box Summons Video From the PC Upstairs
description: In just a few short years, the home computer has transformed itself from a humble word processor and solitaire machine into a full-fledged multimedia powerhouse capable of playing music and video and screening photo slide shows. But sitting in front of a computer screen to watch a home video is not everyone's ideal, so Pinnacle Systems has set out to close the distance between the PC and the entertainment center.

title: 2 Large Unions Plan a Big Push for Dean
description: Leaders of two of the nation's largest and most politically sophisticated unions vowed Wednesday to flood early primary states with volunteers and cash on behalf of Howard Dean, predicting that their endorsements could narrow the nine-person Democratic presidential contest.

title: Maybe Hanging Chads Werent So Bad After All
description: If there's one thing you learn as you grow older, it's that life is painted in shades of gray. I find it harder and harder to view any issue in black and white; if you really think about it, you can almost always see the other guy's point of view.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Englewood: Woman Found Dead After Fire
description: A 37-year-old Englewood woman was found dead in her basement last night after a fire was reported at her home, the police said. The woman's husband and a 4-month-old baby were also in the house, though they were apparently uninjured, the authorities said. The baby was taken to a hospital as a precaution. The names of the three were not released, and the authorities had not determined how the woman had died. ''As of right now, the husband came home and found his wife in the basement,'' said Lt. Steven Sabo of the Englewood Police Department. ''It appears there was some kind of fire in the basement.'' When the police arrived at the house, at 78 Durie Avenue, the fire was not active, the authorities said. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: The Sara Lee Corp., Chicago, began a review for an agency or agencies to handle creative duties on the accounts of two brands, Ball Park Franks and Jimmy Dean sausage, which had been handled by Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe. Billings are estimated at $25 million. Burnett and Sara Lee said they had agreed to part ways over creative differences. Sara Lee may reassign the accounts to other agencies on its creative roster.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Where Album Art Survives

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINERMAN, JOSEPH GEORGE
description: KLEINERMAN -- Joseph George. New York Road Runners founder, board member emeritus, coach, competitive runner, supporter of running, and beloved friend Joe Kleinerman died peacefully in his sleep on Tuesday, November 11, 2003 at age 91. He was the son of David and Rose Kleinerman and is survived by three nieces, Ruth, Martha, and Deena, and numerous grand-nieces and nephews. NYRR mourns Coach Joe's passing but celebrates his long, full life. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 A.M. on Friday, November 14, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Joe Kleinerman Scholarship Fund, C/O NYRR, 9 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rival Leaders Meet
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe met in an effort to resolve the political standoff that began last week when the president fired three ministers and suspended Parliament. They exchanged views ''on events leading to the present situation,'' according to a joint statement issued after the meeting, and agreed to meet again. The statement also said they would continue a dialogue with all ''parties concerned.'' Ms. Kumaratunga's actions put on hold efforts to restart stalled peace talks with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, who have been fighting for an ethnic Tamil homeland for two decades. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Shoe Stake Sold
description: The Italian company Prada Holding, the owner of fashion brands sold 10 percent of the British shoemaker Church & Company to the Equinox private equity fund. Prada did not disclose financial details. Prada of Milan bought Church for $172 million in 1999 and sold a 45 percent stake to Equinox, an Italian buyout fund, in April.

title: Lakers Bryant Makes No Plea During Court Hearing
description: Los Angeles Laker guard Kobe Bryant appeared in an Eagle, Colo., courtroom today for his first appearance before the judge who will preside over his sexual assault trial.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Job Market section on Sunday about companies' use of health benefit plans to attract workers misstated the headquarters location of the Xerox Corporation. It is Stamford, Conn., not Rochester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASON, EUGENE WATERMAN IV
description: MASON--Eugene Waterman IV, 53, of Jackson heights, NY, suddenly on November 10, 2003. Son of Mary Y. Mason of Peapack, NJ, and the late Eugene W. Mason III. Brother of Mary Mason Johnson, of NY. Companion of Eduardo Madrid. Also survived by his niece, Christina Johnson. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 15, 2003 at 11:00AM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Mountaintop Road, Bernardsville, NJ, 07924. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to St. John's Episcopal Church. For information, please contact Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack, NJ.

title: Rapid Changes Among Ministers Damage Uribes Credibility
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 13  When he took office 15 months ago, President Alvaro Uribe said his ministers would remain with him throughout his four-year term, a pledge aimed at casting an image of stability and purpose in a country where governments are usually scorned.

title: G.E. TO ACQUIRE BOSTON LENDER FOR $72.4 MILLION
description: General Electric said yesterday that it would buy HPSC, a lender based in Boston, for $72.4 million, adding $1 billion in assets as it expands into financing equipment for doctors and dentists. General Electric, which is based in Fairfield, Conn., will pay $14.50 a share in stock, a 60 percent premium to HPSC's closing share price yesterday, the companies said. The transaction is expected to close late this year or early next. GE Healthcare Financial Services, which is based in Chicago and has $10 billion in assets, will add 130 HPSC employees in 13 states to its 700 employees. The unit is part of GE Commercial Finance, which has $200 billion in assets, and is one of the areas that General Electric's chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, has said he will expand as he moves into faster-growing industries.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about a caricature of Jennifer Jason Leigh that was drawn by Al Hirschfeld on a restaurant tablecloth gave an incorrect name at one point for the restaurant. It was Chez Josephine, not Chez Louis.

title: Has Home Schooling Achieved Respect?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WINIKOFF, ELLEN
description: WINIKOFF--Ellen. It is 32 years since you have left us. We think of you daily and miss you terribly. Stanley, Marcia, Amy, Linda, Kenny, Sami and now El

title: New York Skylines, Fading Into Night at a Mouse Click
description: Instant cinematic dusk and winter descend on Manhattan through a new Web site, www.celluloidskyline.com. The images are from an archive of Hollywood photographs from 1930 to 1975, commissioned by art directors to ensure accuracy and continuity in making backdrops. James Sanders, author of ''Celluloid Skyline: New York and the Movies'' (Knopf, $29.95), developed the site with Mateo Zlatar, a digital artist. Pop-up windows describe the architects, the history of the prominent buildings and the best-known films set there. A click of the mouse can cause skies to fade and leaves to vanish, while windows begin to glow in patchy checkerboards and laundry is even yanked from clotheslines. EVE M. KAHN

title: Japanese Prospect Called a Stronger Suzuki
description: Kazuo Matsui is the latest front-runner in what has turned into the annual installment of the Japan sweepstakes.

title: Lottery Numbers
So Green, It's Platinum
description: TODAY, when Robert Redford opens the Southern California office of the Natural Resources Defense Council here, a building that bears his name, he is likely to stop short of declaring it the greenest commercial design in America. Experts in sustainable architecture say that trying to assess the energy efficiency of a new building is usually folly, since what is important is performance over time.

title: Push to Sell a Romanian S.U.V. in U.S.
description: Communist soldiers once drove them on maneuvers in the Transylvanian Alps. The Romanian dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, owned one outfitted with Persian carpet on the floorboards and trapdoors on the roof. Now, if a Miami entrepreneur gets his way, it could be your turn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOTLER, MARTIN
description: KOTLER--Martin, 78, who oversaw ground - breaking public service programs in New York City and was the Chairman of the Board of Macro International died of complications from nonHodgkins lymphoma on November 6 in Maryland. Under Mayor Wagner, he was Director of Job Development for JOIN and was Deputy Director of the Anti-Poverty Program. Under Mayor Lindsay, he was Deputy Commissioner of the Addiction Services Agency, a seminal force in creating therapeutic communities and group therapy. As Chairman of the Board at Macro, he worked closely with Federal Agencies, such as NIDA, CDC, HHS, NIH, and the White House Special Action Office for Drug Abuse. Survived by his wife Ruth, a daughter Laura Kotler Klein and son-in-law Robert Klein. He was a great guy!

title: Panel Recommends Studies On Testosterone Therapy
description: The government should sponsor small clinical trials on whether testosterone therapy can improve conditions like frailty, weakness, failing memories and loss of sexual function in aging men with low levels of the hormone, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences said yesterday.

title: The Testosterone Gamble
description: Can American men be rushing into the same reckless use of hormones that brought grief and anxiety to so many unsuspecting women? That disquieting possibility is raised by a new report that laments a huge upsurge in testosterone replacement therapy for men despite a paucity of evidence that it is safe or beneficial. One wonders whether another medical debacle is in the making.

title: Contemporary Art Stays Strong for a Second Night
description: A 40ish crowd with new money made in the world financial markets and a compulsion to spend it fueled the market for contemporary art at Sotheby's last night.

title: High Winds Roughing Up Northeast and Central U.S.
description: Air traffic was delayed, trees were toppled and some power transmission was disrupted today when high winds whipped parts of the Northeast and Central United States, and the National Weather Service warned that there could be widespread power failures as gusts developed almost to the strength of a hurricane.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Tuesday showing the daily performance of the stocks held by the largest number of accounts at Merrill Lynch carried outdated figures. It showed the results of trading from Friday, not Monday.

title: Tip Leads Police to Boy, Lost for Week, In Hospital
description: Last Friday, a New York City police officer called Metropolitan Hospital Center in Manhattan to ask if anyone there knew about Francisco Gonzalez Barreto, a 16-year-old Mexican boy who had been missing for more than a week. ''I told them that his parents were worried sick,'' the officer said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Marriage Scheme Guilty Plea
description: A woman who the authorities said married more than two dozen illegal immigrants for a fee so that they could obtain green cards and other benefits pleaded guilty yesterday and is to be sentenced to six months in jail. The woman, Dezerrie Cortes, 40, of the Bronx, had applied for 27 marriage licenses, officials in the Manhattan district attorney's office said. But Ms. Cortes never bothered to divorce any of her husbands, who came from Pakistan, India, Peru, Ecuador and other countries. Ms. Cortes pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to offering a false instrument for filing, among other things. Justice Micki A. Scherer is expected to sentence Ms. Cortes to five months of probation in addition to jail time when she is sentenced on Jan. 7. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Couple Charged In Girl's Death
description: Manslaughter charges were pressed in state court against the parents of Molly Holt, 10, who the police say died while chained to her bed when fire destroyed her family's home on Sunday night. The parents, Lloyd Holt, 32, and Teresa Dick, 31, and two other children were not injured in the fire, which the authorities said was apparently accidental. The prosecutor in rural Johnson County, about 100 miles west of Little Rock, would not say whether the defendants had offered an explanation for the chaining. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Kidnapped Tourists In Videotape
description: Seven foreign backpackers held by leftist rebels on a remote mountain complained of being hungry and cold and called on Colombia's government to meet their kidnappers' demands in a videotape released by the guerrillas. In the videotape handed over to Reuters, the British, Spanish and German captives said they had been treated well since their Sept. 12 abduction but that the experience had been tough. Four Israeli captives, all young men, were seen playing cards. ''I've got thinner, started smoking again, but desperate times, desperate measures,'' Mark Henderson, from Britain, said on the tape, which was broadcast on local stations. The rebels want the government to send a commission to investigate what they call the oppression of native people by right-wing militiamen. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Walter Duranty's Pulitzer
description: To the Editor:

title: Prince Charles Rumors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KURTZ, ELAINE
description: KURTZ--Elaine. Suddenly, on Tuesday, November 11, 2003. Loved wife for 47 years of Jerome Kurtz, and mother of Madeleine Kurtz and Nettie Greenstein. Devoted grandmother of Noah and Eliza Miedel, and Emma & Nathan Greenstein. She was a productive and widely respected painter of abstract and atmospheric work. Her untimely death is a shock to all who knew her. She is deeply missed. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Center for Arts Education, Attn: The Elaine Kurtz Fund for Art Education for Children, 225 West 34 Street, Suite 1112, NY, NY 10122.

title: A 16-Acre Memorial That'll Never Be
description: TAKE a deep breath.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLENN, BARBARA
description: GLENN--Barbara. Fondly remembered and sadly missed by the undersigned and her other American-standard colleagues at 40 W 40. Charles Carroll & Charles Gordon

title: Is That You, Son? Voice Authentication Trips Up the Experts
description: IT'S not easy to recognize speakers solely by their voices. A voice on an audiotape might be that of Osama bin Laden, but it might also be that of a skilled imposter.

title: Derk Bodde, 94, a Longtime Scholar on China
description: Derk Bodde, who began his academic career as the first Fulbright scholar and over more than 50 years wrote influential books on China that included an eyewitness account of Mao's revolution, died on Nov. 3 at a retirement home in Philadelphia. He was 94.

title: Empowering Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Arafat Calls for Peace Talks

title: The Questions About Halliburton
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHENBERG, AMY
description: ROTHENBERG--Amy. The Board of Governors and Members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Amy Rothenberg and extend to the members of her family our sincere condolences. Bruce D. Frank, President Roger Eichel, Secretary

title: Italy Outmaneuvers Norway at World Tournament
description: There were three lopsided matches at the world championships here Wednesday but one thriller. In the semifinal of the Bermuda Bowl, for open teams, the Italians, who own two other world titles, built up a big lead against Norway, 66.3 imps at the midpoint of the match. But the Vikings roared back, cutting the lead to 13.3 with 16 deals remaining. In the final session, however, the Italians surged to victory, as they have done many times before, and won by 35.3. The Italian players are Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Lorenzo Lauria, Alfredo Versace, Fulvio Fantoni and Claudio Nunes.

title: China Lowers the Wall for U.S. Cars and Parts
description: In a move to quell criticism of its huge trade surplus with the United States, China agreed to let the Big Three automakers send it about 15,000 cars and trucks over the next couple of years as well as more than $1 billion in parts from General Motors, the companies said Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about work on laser-powered planes misstated the surname of one researcher, a NASA scientist, at one point. He is David Bushman, not Bowman.

title: Ryanair Chief Makes Pitch For Allowing Airport Deal
description: The European Commission will probably rule against an agreement that provided discounted landing fees for Ryanair at Charleroi Airport south of Brussels when its investigation concludes in a few weeks, Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said on Wednesday.

title: Light Up the Grocery List, or Nag a Child Fluorescently
description: The Lumi Pad, a sort of backlighted whiteboard, could turn out to be the amusing, harmless holiday-season gadget that unexpectedly actually proves useful. The tablet, which runs on four AAA batteries, uses dry erase markers and fluorescent ink to create an illuminated writing surface.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETRUCCI, NEAL J.
description: PETRUCCI--Neal J. of Yonkers, beloved husband of Olga, cherished father of Deborah Petrucci and Lynn P. Tishman, loving father-in-law of Peter V. Tishman, dear brother of Celia Neto, died November 11, 2003 at 87. He will be deeply missed by family and friends whose lives he touched. Visiting at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY today, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Service Friday 10:00 am at funeral home. Interment Rose Hills Memorial Park. Putnam Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Neal J. Petrucci Memorial Fund, East Yonkers Kiwanis Club, c/o Volino, 385 Kimball Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10704.

title: For Albanians, It's Come to This: A Son for a TV
description: Fatmira Bonjaku's husband is in jail, accused by the police of selling their 3-year-old son to an Italian man in return for the television set that six other children watch in the family's dimly lighted room. The police also say her husband had plans to sell their newest born, whom she is breast feeding.

title: Economist Pleads Guilty in 30-Year Bond Trades
description: John M. Youngdahl, a former senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges in connection with the purchase of millions of dollars of 30-year bonds and bond futures minutes ahead of the Treasury Department's announcement in 2001 that it was ending the sale of such bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMOLEN, CECILIE F.
description: SMOLEN--Cecilie F. Of New York, NY. Died May 2, 2003. Assistant Vice President with Chase Bank until she retired. Survived by a brother and three nephews.

title: Mario Merz, 78, an Italian Installation Artist
description: Mario Merz, an Italian artist whose installations exemplified the Arte Povera movement and its use of humble, often organic materials, died on Sunday at his home in Milan. He was 78.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: KIDNAPPED TOURISTS IN VIDEOTAPE Seven foreign backpackers held by leftist rebels on a remote mountain complained of being hungry and cold and called on Colombia's government to meet their kidnappers' demands in a videotape released by the guerrillas. In the videotape handed over to Reuters, the British, Spanish and German captives said they had been treated well since their Sept. 12 abduction but that the experience had been tough. Four Israeli captives, all young men, were seen playing cards. "I've got thinner, started smoking again, but desperate times, desperate measures," Mark Henderson, from Britain, said on the tape, which was broadcast on local stations. The rebels want the government to send a commission to investigate what they call the oppression of native people by right-wing militiamen. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: City Officers Are Arrested In Bogus Claims Of Accidents
description: Several current and former New York City police officers and nearly a dozen other people have been arrested in a scheme to file fake accident reports and collect insurance money, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Bush's Allies Plan to Block Effort to Ease Ban on Cuban Travel
description: President Bush's allies in Congress quietly eliminated a widely supported provision easing restrictions on American travel to Cuba from a major appropriations bill to save him from embarrassment over his political designs in Florida, officials from both parties said Wednesday evening.

title: Memory Jolt on a Chip Restores a PC's Vigor
description: Q. My three-year-old PC with Windows XP Professional and 128 megabytes of memory runs very slowly. Do I need to add more RAM to make it work better?

title: People
description: Alda Abbracciamento was named managing partner at Soho Square, New York, an agency recently formed by the WPP Group to handle the account of Yahoo. She succeeds Elizabeth Talerman, who resigned after three months to open her own agency. Ms. Abbracciamento previously held posts that included executive vice president and global business director for the Merrill Lynch account at another WPP agency in New York, J. Walter Thompson.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Convicted
description: Sheldon S. Leffler, a former city councilman from Queens, was convicted of scheming to defraud the government. Page B4.

title: A YankeeNets Split Is Not a Simple, Straightforward Transaction
description: Some teams are put up for sale and are sold.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: A Paternity Roundup
description: The Mecklenburg County Child Support Enforcement Office has summoned men named in 1,000 child-support cases where paternity is disputed to take DNA tests, the office's director said. The 535 people who came in were charged $43 toward the test's cost. Those who do not respond will be summoned before a judge. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Keeping That Whippersnapper In Touch With Grandpa DOS
description: For years, users of Macintosh and Linux computers have been able to play games or run software written for Microsoft's DOS operating system by using DOS emulation software. So when Microsoft released Windows XP, which removed the underlying DOS code from the Windows operating system, it suddenly became easier to run DOS software on a Mac than on a Windows PC. While XP does include a way to run some DOS programs, in many cases it will crash or the sound will not work.

title: A Shrewd Eye for the Wash Cycle
description: CARROLL LANCASTER, a 74-year-old Texan with the drawl to prove it, is all for saving Mother Earth. So when he and his wife, Catherine, built their retirement home a few years ago near Zephyr, Tex., they bought a front-loading washing machine, which uses less water and energy than a regular model; installed compact fluorescent lighting, which consumes less electricity than incandescent lamps; designed a two-foot roof overhang, which provides shade in the sizzling summers; and paid for a heating and air-conditioning unit so energy efficient that their utility company gave them a rebate.

title: Nets Try to Find Backup for Kidd
description: In their third year looking for a backup point guard, the Nets auditioned a new candidate to spell Jason Kidd on Wednesday.

title: A Hero's Surfeit of Fertility And the Poetic Use Thereof
description: GENESIS

title: Tentative Medicare Pact Offers Drug Benefits to Elderly
description: House and Senate leaders said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly, but many Democrats spurned it, saying parts of the deal would weaken the traditional government-run Medicare program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: No Suspects In Girl's Disappearance
description: The police confirmed that they still have no suspects in the case of a 9-year-old girl who disappeared three weeks ago from her home in a middle-class Toronto neighborhood. The parents of the girl, Cecilia Zhang, say they awoke on Oct. 20 to find their daughter's bed empty and a window in their house forced open. Early in the investigation, the police suggested it was not a random attack by a predator, and said they were focusing on a possible kidnapping for money but have not discussed any evidence. The girl's parents, immigrants from China, as well as college students who rent rooms in their house, have been ruled out as suspects, the police said. They are still searching for dozens of former tenants who have lived in the family's home. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Gearing Up for the Big Switch
description: GUY RADER lives in Queens, but when it comes to cellphone service, he feels as if he has been ''in pre-glasnost Russia.''

title: Warnaco Cuts Losses, but Shares Plunge
description: The Warnaco Group, the maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Olga bras, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss narrowed by more than half to $6.66 million as it cut costs.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Fell in October
description: Magazine advertising pages fell in October for a fifth consecutive month, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York said yesterday. Ad pages last month declined 3.2 percent compared with a year earlier, bureau data showed. For the first 10 months of 2003, ad pages have fallen 0.2 percent compared with the period in 2002; through the first nine months, ad pages had been ahead of last year.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Harrah's To Start Gambling Site In Britain
description: Harrah's Entertainment Inc., the casino operator, said yesterday that it was developing a subscription-based Internet gambling site that would be introduced in Britain. Gamblers in the United States, where Internet bets are prohibited, will be unable to play, but the site's design is aimed at winning eventual approval for its use in this country. Subscribers will pay from $17 to $84 a month to play games including bingo and win cash prizes of as much as $1.7 million at the site, to be called Lucky Me, the company said in a statement. Harrah's, which is based in Las Vegas, has received British regulatory approval to start the site in the first quarter of 2004. The site will not include traditional casino games like roulette, blackjack and slots that do not translate well to the Internet, and the subscription requirement may ease American concerns about online gambling, the company said. Harrah's already has an agreement with Gala Group Ltd. to develop casinos in Britain, where gambling is a multibillion-dollar industry. Shares of Harrah's rose $1.69, to $47.49.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar on continued signs of strength in Europe's economy. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1633, up from $1.1509 on Tuesday.

title: Iraq Policy in Crisis
description: The abrupt recall of America's top administrator in Iraq, Paul Bremer III, for two days of urgent White House consultations signals a new level of alarm among American policy makers. Anxieties in Washington surely deepened yesterday after the bombing of an Italian military police compound killed at least 17 Italians and 9 Iraqis.

title: Japan Delays Deployment to Iraq After Attack on Italians
description: TOKYO, Nov. 13  The Japanese government suggested today that it would delay sending ground troops to Iraq a day after 18 Italian troops and 9 Iraqis were killed in the single deadliest attack against coalition forces there since Saddam Hussein was toppled.

title: Has Home Schooling Achieved Respect?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit by Computer Workers
description: A class-action lawsuit, filed yesterday on behalf of thousands of employees of the Computer Services Corporation, accuses the company of refusing to pay overtime to computer service workers in violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

title: With His Policies Facing a Major Test, Berlusconi Insists the Troops Will Stay in Iraq
description: Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, said Wednesday that his mind was unchanged and his determination unshaken: Italian forces belonged and would stay in Iraq, despite the deaths of 17 Italians in a suicide bombing.

title: Swiss Army Recorder: TiVo/DVD
description: SOONER or later, the technologies of the various areas of our lives merge, resulting in a savings of cost, cables and clutter. For the nightstand, you can buy a clock-radio-telephone. In the car, you've got one radio-CD-player-heating-control unit. In your pocket, a Swiss Army knife.

title: The Questions About Halliburton
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Says It Benefits 2 Ways From On-Demand Computing
description: I.B.M.'s chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, said Wednesday that his company had generated $7 billion in orders in the last year for its the ''on demand'' computing services.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: State To Sell Oil Stakes
description: The Indian government, which has missed its target for sales of state assets for the last four years, said it planned to sell $3 billion of shares in the Indian Oil Corporation and the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation to investors by March. The government will sell a fifth of Indian Oil, the nation's biggest refiner, valued at 94 billion rupees ($2 billion), B.K. Chaturvedi, secretary in the Petroleum Ministry, said. India plans to sell 5 percent of Oil and Natural Gas, valued at 47.3 billion rupees, he said.

title: The Neediest Cases; For a Man in Pain, Progress Is a Wearable Pair of Shoes
description: All his life, Frederick Hart, 46, has been trying to stand on his own two feet. The problem is his feet won't cooperate.

title: More Questions Raised on School Security in Mount Vernon
description: School officials in Mount Vernon, N.Y., are reviewing their security procedures after the police arrested an 18-year-old man last Friday who they say signed a 14-year-old girl out of school under false pretenses and took her to his home, where he had sex with her.

title: Paris Journal; For the Tobacconists of France, Life's a Pack of Trouble
description: Not just anyone can sell cigarettes in France.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Study On Housing Costs
description: Government regulations are largely responsible for the high cost of housing construction in Manhattan, according to a study released yesterday. The study -- ''Why Is Manhattan So Expensive?'' -- was published by the Manhattan Institute, a policy research group that favors less government regulation. It focused on why so few new apartments have been built in Manhattan since 1980, despite a solid economy and escalating real estate prices. The study's authors -- Edward L. Glaeser of Harvard and Joseph Gyourko of the University of Pennsylvania -- concluded, by a mathematical analysis of costs, that government regulations were a form of tax. It can amount to as much as 50 percent of the total price of the median condominium, for example, the authors said. The study did not cite specific regulations. Some housing experts said the study neglected difficult-to-measure factors, like demographics. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Ex-Boxer Sues Stallone Over 'Rocky' and Sequels
description: Chuck Wepner, the former heavyweight who rose from boxing obscurity to a 1975 title match against Muhammad Ali and inspired the movie ''Rocky,'' filed suit on Wednesday against the film's star and creator, Sylvester Stallone, over the actor's continuing use of his name in promoting the film and related enterprises.

title: Delta Air Increases Its Estimate of Loss
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that its net loss this quarter would be as much as $415 million, wider than an earlier forecast, as costs rose from pilots' retirement. Delta increased its financing of pilots' pensions by $140 million this quarter.

title: A Saudi-Israeli Deal
description: Reading the latest poll from the European Union, which indicates that 59 percent of E.U. citizens now consider Israel the greatest ''threat to world peace,'' reading reports that Mikis Theodorakis, the composer of ''Zorba the Greek,'' has opined that Jews are ''the root of evil,'' and observing the latest bombing in Saudi Arabia by Islamist fanatics, the following heretical thought comes to mind: The keepers of the Muslim holy places and the keepers of the Jewish holy places really need each other today.

title: Council Panel Holds Inquiry On Custodians In the Schools
description: Custodians in the New York City public schools can paint walls up to 10 feet high, but painting even an inch higher requires a member of the painters' union. Custodians can replace fluorescent light bulbs but not the current-regulating ballasts required to turn them on. And in small schools, only 75 loose or missing floor tiles can be replaced per month; in the biggest schools, 200.

title: Warfare, Bird's-Eye And Trench
description: SAVAGE: THE BATTLE FOR NEWERTH

title: Dr. Paul Janssen, 77, Dies; Founder of a Drug Company
description: Dr. Paul Janssen, a Belgian doctor whose research led to the start of the international pharmaceutical company Janssen Pharmaceutica, now part of Johnson & Johnson, died on Tuesday at a hotel in Rome, where he was attending a conference.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Reports Loss
description: Germany's third-largest bank, Commerzbank, reported a net loss of 2.3 billion euros ($2.64 billion) in the third quarter after writing down the value of several holdings, including the German truck manufacturer MAN. It also eliminated its dividend. Commerzbank said it would sell off other assets to focus on its core banking franchise. Analysts viewed the move, which was unexpected, as a way to clean up the bank's balance sheet to make it more attractive to a potential buyer. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Bishops Open A New Drive Opposing Contraception
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, acknowledging that American Catholics pay little heed to their church's ban on contraception, undertook an effort Wednesday to reinforce it, and linked it to the anti-abortion campaign.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the Broadway lighting designer John Gleason on Saturday included a garbled passage. The second sentence of the last paragraph should have read: ''In a 1970 review of Sam Shepard's production of 'Operation Sidewinder,' Walter Kerr wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Gleason's work had lighted the stage 'so cunningly and so persuasively that the remarks of the young couple who first come across it seem vapid echoes from some other and some less colorful planet.' ''

title: The Questions About Haliburton (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: French Court Convicts and Jails Ex-Leaders of Oil Company
description: After a riveting eight-month trial that gave the French a replay of a decade of corporate malfeasance, a French court on Wednesday convicted several senior executives of the former French oil company Elf Aquitaine of corruption and sentenced them to jail terms and fines for their role in bilking Elf of hundreds of millions of dollars while it was still a state-owned company.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: 'Match Me, Sidney'

title: AT HOME WITH: James Zemaitis; Blue-Chip Modern. It's So Fly.
description: DRESSED in a track-suit jacket, a skateboarding T-shirt and blue jeans, James Zemaitis, 35, looks like a fairly average young professional living on the Upper West Side. This, despite the fact that Mr. Zemaitis is the new director of 20th-century design for Sotheby's in New York, where even the publicists live in suits.

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, Nov. 12, 2003. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

title: A. Michael DeSisto, 64, Head Of School for Troubled Students
description: A. Michael DeSisto, founder and headmaster of the innovative DeSisto School in Stockbridge, Mass., which specializes in helping troubled adolescents through unusual programs that include the culinary and performing arts, died on Nov. 1 in Boston. He was 64 and lived on the school's campus.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Game Maker Posts Profit
description: The game maker Sega said profit in the first six months of the fiscal year grew nearly sixfold on strong demand for video game software and arcade games. Sega, based in Tokyo, said it earned 5.9 billion yen ($54 million) in the six months that ended Sept. 30, up from 1 billion yen in the period last year. Sales fell 1.7 percent. Sega left its full-year profit and sales targets unchanged. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: FRIEDMAN'S SHARES DOWN AS S.E.C. WIDENS INQUIRY
description: Friedman's, a jewelry retailer, said federal investigations of its financial reporting practices had expanded, setting off a 39 percent decline in its share price yesterday. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department are reviewing Friedman's estimate of credit losses and whether it issued false or misleading financial statements, the company said late on Tuesday. The S.E.C. is also examining possible violations of internal controls at the company, which said the chief financial officer, Victor M. Suglia, had been placed on leave. Friedman's said in September that the S.E.C. was conducting an informal inquiry into whether the company and 13 others aided a former supplier in an accounting fraud. Stock in the company, which is based in Savannah, Ga., fell $4.68, to $7.31 a share.

title: Concussion and Its Aftereffects End Season for Jets' Chrebet
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet, who sustained a concussion Nov. 2 against the Giants and is still experiencing headaches and malaise, was placed on injured reserve on Wednesday with a mild case of postconcussion syndrome, ending his season.

title: South Africa AIDS Budget
description: The government plans to spend more than $1.73 billion over the next three years to battle AIDS, more than tripling the amount it spent during the preceding three years, a top official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRESCO, JEANNE
description: FRESCO--Jeanne, suddenly on November 12, 2003. Beloved sister, niece, cousin and friend. Services Sunday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: COMPANY DREDGING IN IRAQ IS BOUGHT FOR $340 MILLION
description: Madison Dearborn Partners will acquire the Great Lakes Dredge and Dock Corporation, a company that has a contract to dredge the war-damaged Iraqi port of Umm Qasr, for $340 million from a firm owned by Citigroup Venture Capital. Citigroup bought Great Lakes in July 1998, according to Great Lakes, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill. Great Lakes says it is the biggest provider of dredging services in the United States. Madison Dearborn is a Chicago buyout firm with more than $7.5 billion under management.

title: Change on Early Admission Produces Application Shifts
description: Changes in the early admissions rules at Harvard, Yale and Stanford have produced sharp shifts in where students applied early this year.

title: He'd Do It Again, Says the 'Ten Commandments Judge'
description: Alabama's chief justice, Roy S. Moore, was called in front of a special court Wednesday to face ethics charges, but even with his job on the line he was defiant as ever.

title: Old and New Managers Win Leagues' Awards
description: Jack McKeon was managing Missoula of the Pioneer League in 1957, the year Tony Pea was born. Forty-six years later, McKeon is still managing, and Pea has begun an impressive managerial career.

title: Toward a Universal Charger
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, LINDA
description: QUINN--Linda. The partners, associates and staff of Shearman & Sterling LLP mourn the death at the height of her career of Linda Quinn. She was an eminent colleague, partner and friend. As an expert on securities law, she was a trusted and respected advisor to major corporations in the U.S., Europe and Asia, notably on issues of disclosure and corporate governance. Earlier, as the Director of the Division of Corporation Finance of the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1986 to 1996, her vision and leadership were key to achieving the historic reforms that opened broad participation in U.S. capital markets by foreign corporations. She has left an enduring mark not only on the law but also on all of us who had the great privilege of working with her. Her memory will be cherished for her dedication to the highest principles of the profession and her personal qualities of integrity, enthusiasm and warmth.

title: Has Home Schooling Achieved Respect?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'SHAUGHNESSY, LUCY ELEANOR
description: O'SHAUGHNESSY -- Lucy Eleanor. On Monday, November 10, 2003 at the age of 79 years, she died peacefully in her home surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of the late Denis (December 1977). Loving mother of Denis, Maureen (Shawn) Kennedy, John, Jean O'Brien, Patrice Fay, Mark and Eleanor Baker. Proud grandmother of 17. Born in Forge, MA, she came to New York and lived here for over 60 years, sharing her small town warmth with all who knew her. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 E. Tremont Ave, Bronx, NY until Friday 9:30am. Mass of Christian burial at St. Frances de Chantal Church, Bronx, NY 10am. Interment at St. Raymond Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2:00 to 5:00 and 7:00 to 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations to Visiting Nurse Service of NY 1250 Broadway, NY, NY 10001. James E. McQuade, Dir.

title: Eagles Ready for Giants After Poor Start
description: The Philadelphia Eagles had a dreadful start this season, losing their first two games at home while being outscored, 48-10. Some Broadway flops don't begin that badly. Their offense looked inept. Their defense looked porous. Outsiders looked for reasons, heaping tons of criticism on the coach, Andy Reid, and the quarterback, Donovan McNabb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANNING, EILEEN G.
description: MANNING--Eileen G. The Board of Directors of the Catholic Big Sisters notes with sorrow the death of our friend, board member and generous supporter, Eileen Manning. Our thoughts and prayers are with her family.

title: Defense Rests in Sniper Case After Less Than 3 Hours
description: Lawyers for John A. Muhammad, who is charged with plotting the Washington-area sniper attacks, rested their case on Wednesday after taking just under three hours to present a defense.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The judge seemed to say, 'OK, you guys are both responsible. You got married. You got divorced. It is up to you to fix the problem.' We see it differently, but he is the judge.''

title: Agency Won't Compete For Nokia Account
description: The Richards Group in Dallas is resigning the strategic and creative duties on the North American account of Nokia by declining to take part in a review. The assignment, which Richards had handled since 1997, has billings estimated at $35 million.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the historian and presidential adviser Richard E. Neustadt on Nov. 3 and in some late copies on Nov. 2 misstated his birthplace and omitted his place of death. He was born in Philadelphia, not New York City, and he died at his English country home in the village of Furneux Pelham, in Hertfordshire. The article also misstated the name of the political party led by his wife in the House of Lords. It is the Liberal Democrats, not the Social Democratic Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELSOHN, JULE MICHAEL, DR.
description: ELSOHN--Jule Michael, Dr. On November 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Margit Subak Elsohn, married for 57 years. Loving uncle of Nina Elsohn of San Francisco, Linda Indek of Bloomfield, NJ, Neal Elsohn of Cape May, NJ and cherished great-uncle. Dr. Elsohn was a Captain in the United States Airforce during WW II. He was a dentist in Manhattan for 50 years and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from MIT and New York University Dental School. Services Friday November 14th, 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. New York City.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Clinton Urges Air Patrols
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton urged the federal government yesterday to consider flying air patrols over New York State's nuclear power plants. In a letter to Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, Senator Clinton urged patrols over the Indian Point, Nine Mile and Gina nuclear power plants. The letter, also sent to the Department of Homeland Security, noted federal warnings this week that operatives of Al Qaeda might try to hijack cargo jets from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean and fly them into nuclear plants. The Sept. 11 hijackers, Senator Clinton wrote, ''were believed to have flown over or nearby the Indian Point reactors on their way down the Hudson River.'' Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Demand Spurs Quick Sales Of Philippine Cellphone Stock
description: Taking advantage of surging demand for Asian assets among international investors, the two largest shareholders of the Philippine cellular operator Globe Telecom sold roughly $100 million of their stock on Wednesday for 12.5 percent more than they paid Deutsche Telekom for it less than two weeks ago.

title: Bush, in Florida, Urges Passage of Prescription Drug Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 — As he campaigned in Florida today, President Bush urged Senate and House negotiators to reach agreement soon on changes in the Medicare program.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: ENGLEWOOD: WOMAN FOUND DEAD AFTER FIRE A 37-year-old Englewood woman was found dead in her basement last night after a fire was reported at her home, the police said. The woman's husband and a 4-month-old baby were also in the house, though they were apparently uninjured, the authorities said. The baby was taken to a hospital as a precaution. The names of the three were not released, and the authorities had not determined how the woman had died. "As of right now, the husband came home and found his wife in the basement," said Lt. Steven Sabo of the Englewood Police Department. "It appears there was some kind of fire in the basement." When the police arrived at the house, at 78 Durie Avenue, the fire was not active, the authorities said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Posts A Loss
description: The Elan Corporation, the Irish drug maker that has been selling assets to raise cash and pay off debt, said it lost $91 million in the third quarter, an improvement on the $996 million it lost a year earlier. The company also said that sales from divisions that the company has retained rose 31 percent. Total revenue in the period, which ended Sept. 30, fell 47 percent, to $175 million. Elan has sold assets worth $1.8 billion to pay down debt and focus on fewer products. Elan is continuing research into treatments for autoimmune and neurological disorders with Biogen, and Alzheimer's disease, with Wyeth. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Living in a Concerto for Memorabilia and Strings
description: JOSHUA BELL, the boyish 35-year-old star of classical violin, often greets fans after a performance, giving them a chance to get a close look at the prominent red mark on his neck where he cradles his 290-year-old Stradivarius.

title: Botswana's Brain Drain Cripples War on AIDS
description: As the Bush administration shapes its plan to combat AIDS in Africa, Botswana's president, Festus G. Mogae, said Wednesday that one of the biggest obstacles to a rapid expansion of treatment for people with AIDS in his country is not so much a lack of money or drugs as a dearth of doctors, nurses, pharmacists and other health workers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Gen. Wesley K. Clark's support for a constitutional amendment to ban desecration of the flag referred incorrectly to the process for adopting one. In the process that begins with passage by Congress, a proposed amendment is normally sent to state legislatures or state conventions for approval, not directly to voters.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco To Buy Latitude For $80 Million
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of equipment to link computers, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $80 million for Latitude Communications Inc., a seller of gear for audio and Web conferencing. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., said in a statement that it had agreed to pay $3.95 in cash for each share of Latitude, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif. That was about 30 percent higher than the closing price on Tuesday. Shares of Cisco rose 62 cents, to $22.97. Latitude shares rose 84 cents, or 27.5 percent, to $3.89.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Death Penalty Abolished
description: Turkey formally abolished the death penalty, an important step toward European Union membership. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Driver Sought In Fatal Crash
description: The police were looking for a young man who was involved in a car accident that killed a 73-year-old man and injured a 72-year-old woman last night in the Arrochar section. Two cars collided at the intersection of Columbia Avenue and Fingerboard Road just before 8 p.m. The driver of one of the cars, a silver BMW, ran from the scene, according to the police. He was described as a man in his 20's. The two occupants of the other car, a red Honda, were taken to Staten Island University Hospital. The man, Dominic DiMarinis, of Fairbanks Avenue, was dead on arrival and the woman was in critical condition early today. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Companies to Pay New Jersey $17 Million for Toxic Cleanup
description: Three industrial companies have agreed to give the state $17 million to pay for environmental damage at hundreds of sites in northern New Jersey that were contaminated with the deadly chemical chromium, Gov. James E. McGreevey announced on Wednesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At Porsche
description: The carmaker Porsche posted a 24 percent increase in second-half profit, helped by demand for its new Cayenne sport utility vehicle. Net income in the six months ended July 31 rose to 463 million euros ($538 million) from 372.6 million euros, said Porsche, which is based in Stuttgart. Pretax profit rose 11 percent, to 747 million euros.

title: Arizona Lets Yanks Know Schilling Has A High Price
description: The Yankees continued their methodical pursuit of pitcher Curt Schilling by having more discussions with the Arizona Diamondbacks on Wednesday, but the potential trade has encountered an obstacle because of a disagreement over the price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIERCE, WILLIAM CURTIS
description: PIERCE--William Curtis, 97, peacefully in the old family home in West Baldwin, ME, November 12. Predeceased by his sons William Jr. and Martin, survived by his wife of 74 years, Elizabeth Neall Gay, brother Benjamin, children Josiah, Elizabeth Fuchs and Mackin Pulsifer; seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He attended Groton, Boden and Harvard Law School. He retired as a partner of Sullivan & Cromwell. From 1942 to 1945 he saw active duty as a Lieutenant Commander in the US Navy. He was President of the Maine Historical Society, Vice President of the Board of Trustees of Boden College and Treasurer of the Brown Memorial Library. Service at home November 15, 2PM. Gifts may be sent to the Brown Memorial Library, POB 24, E. Baldwin, ME 04024.

title: CHEVRONTEXACO EXPECTS CHARGE FROM DYNEGY ASSET SALE
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation said yesterday that it would record a charge in the fourth quarter to reflect its share of a loss from the sale of Dynegy's Illinois Power utility. ChevronTexaco owns a 26 percent stake in Dynegy, which said Nov. 3 that it expected a charge to reflect the write-down of the Illinois Power assets. Dynegy agreed to sell Illinois Power to the Exelon Corporation. ChevronTexaco announced its intentions in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The size of the loss was not disclosed, and ChevronTexaco will not know how large its expense will be until Dynegy discloses the loss on the sale of the utility, a ChevronTexaco spokeswoman, Bonnie Chaikind, said.

title: Death of a Sewer Worker
description: New York is a mythic place, and one of the most mythic parts of it is the part that nobody ever sees: the sewers. Alligators and giant rats barely begin to sum up the state of our fears about the sewers, when we acknowledge those fears at all. So it's worth remembering how great a joke it is that the New York city sewers should also contain Ed Norton, played on ''The Honeymooners'' by Art Carney, who died on Sunday at 85.

title: Sports of The Times; Gonzaga Should Resist Going Over to the Dark Side
description: BEFORE jetting east for a first appearance on the Broadway stage, Mark Few and Gonzaga University were dotting i's and crossing t's, preparing to announce the signing of three prize recruits. The most celebrated David of college basketball is apparently experimenting with growth hormones, with becoming a national Goliath.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Loss At Lufthansa
description: The airline Lufthansa posted a third-quarter loss and a decline in sales in the third quarter, not meeting the market's forecast for a return to profit. Lufthansa lost 17 million euros in the quarter, down from a profit of 371 million euros a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended Sept. 30, fell to 4.2 billion euros from 4.5 billion euros. The chief executive, Wolfgang Mayrhuber, reiterated the company's plans to cut costs by 20 percent over the next two years, including at least 2,000 more job cuts by 2005. The company said it now expected to break even on an operating basis. In August, it predicted that it would have an operating loss for the year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: For Gephardt, Congress Role Is Both Platform and Hurdle
description: His wife of 37 years, Jane Gephardt, did not really want him to make another race for the presidency, and much of the conventional wisdom argued against it.

title: Kate Spades That Are Best Left at Home, Not Slung Over the Shoulder
description: There is something literary about Kate Spade, the handbag designer who is on the brink of empire-building. She designs products with graphic clarity, luscious tones and a witty story to tell. If Dorothy Parker were a product, she would be a Kate Spade clutch.

title: No Damages In Rosie Case, Judge Hints
description: After each side in the battle of blame over the demise of Rosie magazine finished presenting its legal arguments, it took all of one minute for the judge to suggest yesterday that the contract dispute was little more than a schoolyard spat writ large.

title: RALCORP IS BUYING BAKERY CHEF FOR $287.5 MILLION
description: Ralcorp Holdings, which makes RyKrisp crackers and store-brand cereals for supermarkets, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Bakery Chef for $287.5 million to add frozen foods. The purchase will increase yearly earnings at Ralcorp by 25 cents to 35 cents a share. Bakery Chef, with sales in 2002 of $165 million, produces products like frozen waffles and breads, mainly for the food-service industry, Ralcorp said. Bakery Chef, based in Westmont, Ill., is owned by Wind Point Partners of Chicago. Ralcorp, based in St. Louis, said the purchase would close within 30 days.

title: With Goggles and a Joystick, Kasparov Takes On 'Fritz'
description: ARE fancy 3-D goggles enough to make chess appealing to the PlayStation generation?

title: Best Illustrated Children's Books
description: These illustrations have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 2003.

title: Thanksgiving Table
description:
By SUZANNE HAMLIN
Give early thanks now for the merchants who are standing by, willing and eager to help set the Thanksgiving table.

title: New Jobs and New Strife
description: A U.S. trade law has given Africa hope and hard jobs.

title: Extreme Close-Ups
description: Lucas Samaras makes magic with his androgynous form and extraordinary sense of craft in his myriad of self-portraits as seen at the Whitney Museum of Art.

title: Photos From 'The Devil's Playground'
description: In her sprawling new book, "The Devil's Playground," the photographer Nan Goldin's world has broadened, but the view is still intimate.

title: Attacks in Iraq
description: A look at some of the recent bombings and violence in Iraq.

title: Saving Private Pensions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: A House on a Hill'
description: Directed by Chuck Workman

title: Flagrantly Stylish, Outrageously Sexy
description: Aw, look at those frisky, frolicsome creatures up there, in their bright tufted costumes and motley makeup. They sure still are a peppy bunch -- leaping, pirouetting, shaking their furry selves to a bouncy Broadway beat. Who would ever have thought that the popular cats of ''Cats'' would be restored to us so soon after the end of that musical's long, long run?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOMBROFF, RITA
description: DOMBROFF--Rita. Wife of the late Joseph Dombroff. After 104 wonderful years passed from a short illness November 11. She was much loved. A vibrant woman, a student and teacher seeking truth. An inspiration to all who knew her. She is survived by great-nieces Deanna Morton, Wendy Sternberg and a host of young family members and dedicated friends. A memorial service will be held on Friday, November 14 at 4PM at The Atria, 333 W. 86 St, NYC. Donation in Rita's memory may be made to Ananda Ashram, Monroe, N.Y. or a charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about a Sony engineer who developed a camera-and-sensor technology for the PlayStation 2 video console misspelled his surname. He is Richard Marks, not Marx.

title: 2nd Sniper Trial Opens, Its Focus On Audiotapes
description: Two hours of chilling audiotaped confessions are the heart of the case against Lee Malvo, the younger defendant in last fall's sniper shootings, a prosecutor told jurors here Thursday morning.

title: Master Of the Sea (And the French)
description: ''DO you want to see a guillotine in Piccadilly? Do you want your children to grow up singing the 'Marseillaise'?'' This is Jack Aubrey, commander of H.M.S. Surprise, rousing the patriotism of his men as they prepare to engage a faster, larger French vessel somewhere off the coast of South America. This ship is England, he proclaims, and ''Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World,'' which opens nationwide today, makes his point with magnificent vigor and precision.

title: Sports Briefing
description: N.B.A.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: FIRST HUMAN DEATH FROM RACCOON RABIES The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported the first human death from raccoon rabies ever documented in the United States. A 25-year-old from Virginia died of the disease in March. It was diagnosed after he died, and investigators could not determine how he was exposed. The man visited his doctor, was admitted to a hospital six days later and died two weeks after that. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Webs Connecting the Power Brokers, the Money and, Ultimately, the World
description: Mark Lombardi was onto something before he committed suicide in 2000. His drawings -- you could call them maps or charts, and they also have some connection with 19th-century panoramas -- track global financial fiascos and related political shenanigans, mostly of the 1980's and 90's. Some drawings are as much as 10 feet wide, rather lightly marked in pencil with arrows and names: delicate spider webs of scandal.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Trojan Horse
description: What are we going to do about Medicare? That should be the subject of an open national debate. But right now Congressional leaders are trying to settle the question by stealth, with legislation that purports to be doing something else.

title: Accounts
description: Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority renewed its contact with R&R Partners, Las Vegas, for an additional five years. Total billings over the term of the contract were estimated at $320 million. R&R, which was awarded the renewal without a review, has handled the account since 1980.

title: 'Memory and Disappearance' -- 'Recent Thai Art'
description: Momenta Art

title: AMERCO PROPOSES CASH PAYMENTS TO CREDITORS
description: Amerco Inc., owner of the U-Haul truck-rental business, agreed to use cash and notes to pay bondholders and other creditors the $714.6 million they are owed. The recovery proposal would not cut the value of the company's shares by using stock to pay debts, the company, based in Reno, Nev., said. Court approval of the proposal would let Amerco complete its reorganization and exit bankruptcy in less than seven months. Amerco's unsecured creditors committee agreed to support the plan, but the company still needs the support of secured lenders and a panel of shareholders to avoid a court fight. Judge Gregg Zive in Reno will consider at a Nov. 18 hearing whether the plan can be sent to creditors for a vote.

title: Charges Dismissed In Kidnapping Case
description: Manhattan prosecutors dismissed charges yesterday against a TriBeCa lawyer who was accused last spring of locking his business partner in an apartment crawl space.

title: For Simon Rattle and the Berlin, a New Century
description: Few orchestras have a more storied heritage than the Berlin Philharmonic. Yet when the announcement came in 1999 that the British conductor Simon Rattle, then in his early 40's, would succeed Claudio Abbado as music director, the entire Berlin Philharmonic organization, from board members to bass players, showed the courage to change.

title: The Sabotage of Democracy
description: The hastily called conference at the White House involving America's top man in Baghdad, L. Paul Bremer, clearly revealed that the Bush administration knows its program in Iraq is failing. The ''Iraqification'' of the security forces has not dimmed the rate or deadliness of attacks against coalition troops; the Iraqi Governing Council has willfully stalled the process of drafting a new constitution; a new American intelligence report leaked to the press indicates that Iraqis are increasingly angry with the American presence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, ALVIN H., M.D.
description: WEINER--Alvin H., M.D. Beloved husband of Norma. Cherished father of Dr. Alison Weiner and Robert Solomon, Dr. Kevin and Lauren Weiner. Loving grandfather of Sara Solomon and Ryan Weiner. Reposing at Midwood Chapels, Coney Island Avenue and Avenue M, Brooklyn, NY. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM. Funeral services Sunday 10:30 AM. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Americans in the Age of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Bugs Bunny and Friends Dash Through Movie Lore
description: ''Looney Tunes: Back in Action,'' a frantically paced, densely populated farce in which beloved cartoon characters interact with Hollywood stars, cheerfully describes itself as a smackdown between those long-running rivals Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. But the real smackdown pits Warner Brothers' stable of animated characters, some of which date back more than 70 years, against mild-mannered actors like Brendan Fraser and Jenna Elfman.

title: Canadian Line Shows How to Run a Railroad
description: Whether seeing it as a war chest, insurance for a rainy day or keeping your powder dry, few in the railroad industry have failed to notice that the Canadian National Railway is pumping up its financial muscles.

title: Earnings Are Up 21% at Dell
description: Dell Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 21 percent as sales exceeded $10 billion for the first time. Looking ahead, the company said revenue this quarter would beat analysts' forecasts.

title: Americans in the Age of Anger (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Practical Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Singing Forest'
description: Directed by Jorge Ameer

title: Finally, a Big Game in Cincinnati
description: For more than a decade, the Cincinnati Bengals played football to a laugh track. Plaudits and adulation belonged to others. The Bengals went season to season making opponents feel good about themselves.

title: TWO TOP EDITORS AT TIME INC. SIGN CONTRACTS
description: Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief of Time Inc., and John Huey, its editorial director, both signed multiyear contracts this week, according to a senior company executive. Mr. Pearlstine became editor in chief in 1995. Before joining Time Inc., Mr. Pearlstine was executive editor of The Wall Street Journal from 1991 to 1992 and then served as a partner in a media investment firm. Mr. Huey, who had been managing editor of Fortune Magazine, succeeded Walter Isaacson as editorial director in July of 2001. A company spokesman declined to comment. David Carr (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZENKER, PAULINE
description: ZENKER--Pauline. On November 12, 2003 of Roslyn Heights, L.I. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Steven (Denise), Barbara Zenker and Suzanne Gilbride (Thomas). Dear sister of Milton Lukaczer and the late Rose Nichols. Adored grandmother of Jody and Deven. Cherished great grandmother of Benjamin. Services today 11:30AM at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: I.B.M. Says Supercomputer To Be Suitable for Businesses
description: I.B.M. plans to introduce a dishwasher-size prototype supercomputer on Friday that the company says will also have broad uses in high-capacity corporate data centers in the future.

title: That Refined British Touch
description: It isn't just their cultivated accents and custom of speaking in full, grammatically correct sentences; when British pop, jazz and even rock performers embrace American musical idioms, they tend to invest them with a highbrow gloss. Pop songs are presented as art songs, and the raucous edges of jazz are tempered with a classical sense of decorum.

title: 4 Israeli Intelligence Experts Call for Political Solution
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 14  Four former heads of the Israeli security service Shin Bet have delivered a blunt collective criticism of their nation's tough military policies toward the Palestinians, saying Israel urgently needs a political solution to the Mideast conflict.

title: The Artists Who Helped Take Dance Off the Wall
description: The choreographer Trisha Brown has been wonderfully persuasive at tempting contemporary artists into the field of dance. Her 40-odd years of innovative creation and performance have brought about some memorable collaborations, most frequently with Robert Rauschenberg but also with Robert Whitman, Donald Judd, Nancy Graves, Terry Winters and Fujiko Nakaya.

title: INSIDE
description: Medicare Bill Bogs Down

title: After Facing a Judge, Rosie O'Donnell Faces the Critics
description: Rosie O'Donnell's contract dispute with her former publisher, Gruner & Jahr, may have ended on Wednesday with the judicial equivalent of a draw, but last night on Broadway, it would have been hard to argue with her standing in the court of public opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TINTLE, WILLIAM F., JR.
description: TINTLE--William F., Jr., 60, of East Hampton, NY, formerly of Bethpage, NY on November 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Carrie. Loving father of Mary E. Grieco of Muttontown, Ann, John B., Jessica L. Perry of East Hampton and the late William III. Devoted son of Margaret and the late William. Dear brother of Patricia A. Flemming of Hendersonville, TN and Colleen A. Volmut of Wading River. Also survived by three grandchildren, Hannah, Isabella, and Nicholas. Reposing Yardley & Pino, 94 Pantigo Rd., East Hampton, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, November 17, 9:30 AM, Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton. Interment Most Holy Trinity Cemetery. Memorial donations to East End Hospice or the East Hampton Volunteer Ambulance Corps would be appreciated.

title: Donald R. Griffin, 88, Dies; Argued Animals Can Think
description: Dr. Donald R. Griffin, who was considered the founder of the modern field involving the study of animal thinking and consciousness, and who early in his career helped unravel the secret of bats' navigation system, died last Friday in Lexington, Mass. He was 88.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Buffett Company Cuts Level 3 Stake
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the company run by Warren E. Buffett, has sold most of its shares of Level 3 Communications, a fiber network operator, after doubling its money in 16 months. Berkshire cut its stake in Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., to 1.6 million shares at the end of the third quarter, from 19.9 million in the second quarter, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday. Mr. Buffett acquired the shares in June by converting Level 3 bonds into stock. Mr. Buffett has said he is not comfortable owning shares of telecommunications companies because he does not know how to value them. The $500 million bond investment that he and partners made in July 2002 earned 9 percent interest and gave them an equity stake worth about $1 billion at the time of conversion. Berkshire raised about $93 million in the sale of the shares, based on Level 3's average share price of $5.09 in the third quarter. Berkshire's partners in the convertible bond investment were Longleaf Partners Funds and Legg Mason. Longleaf owned 127 million Level 3 shares in the third quarter, Southeastern Asset Management, which owns Longleaf, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELSOHN, JULE MICHAEL
description: ELSOHN--Jule Michael, Dr. On November 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Margit Subak Elsohn, married for 57 years. Loving uncle of Nina Elsohn of San Francisco, Linda Indek of Bloomfield, NJ, Neal Elsohn of Cape May, NJ and cherished great-uncle. Dr. Elsohn was a Captain in the United States Airforce during WW II. He was a dentist in Manhattan for 50 years and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from MIT and New York University Dental School. Services Friday November 14th, 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. New York City.

title: Study Calls California Parole System a $1 Billion Failure
description: At a time when California faces a record budget deficit, the state is wasting $1 billion a year on a failed system of sending large numbers of recently released inmates back to prison for minor parole violations, according to a study released Thursday by a state watchdog agency.

title: In U.S., Fears Are Voiced Of a Too-Rapid Iraq Exit
description: The Bush administration's decision to speed the transfer of sovereignty to Iraq and replace American troops with Iraqis is bringing fresh warnings from Congress and policy experts against pulling out of Iraq too early and letting election-year considerations dictate Iraq policy.

title: Judicial Courage in Alabama
description: The Court of the Judiciary in Alabama acted courageously yesterday when it removed Roy Moore, widely known as the Ten Commandments judge, as chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court. Given Mr. Moore's knack for demagoguery, and the large following he has attracted, it would have been far easier to dodge the issue. But the court rightly found that Mr. Moore lacked the most basic requirement for judicial office: respect for the rule of law.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Jackie Kennedy And Suicide
description: In the months after her husband was assassinated, Jacqueline Kennedy fell into despair, asking her Jesuit spiritual adviser at one point, ''Do you think that God would separate me from my husband if I killed myself?''
