That plea, and other exchanges with her adviser, the late Rev. Richard T. McSorley, were included in his diary and letters between him and Mrs. Kennedy that were made available on Wednesday by Georgetown University, where he was a theology professor. The recollections of Father McSorley, who died in 2002, were in a new book ''The Kennedys: America's Emerald Kings'' by Thomas Maier. John Files (NYT)

title: Americans in the Age of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Dodgers' Gagne Wins the N.L. Cy Young Award
description: When the Los Angeles Dodgers reported for spring training in 2002, they had a $110 million roster and no closer. They explored trades for the Florida Marlins' Antonio Alfonseca, the Boston Red Sox' Ugueth Urbina and the Chicago White Sox' Bob Howry. Eric Gagne, then a developing pitcher pushed out of the Dodgers' swollen starting rotation, had no career saves and a closer's rsum of 11 games with the Canadian national team in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHAEFFER, LILLIAN
description: SCHAEFFER -- Lillian (nee Kessler), November 12, 2003. Wife of late Jack of Cherry Hill. Mother of Temma (Alfred) Kingsley and Illene (Warren) Rubin. Sister of Ruth Schimmel. Grandmother of Mark (Bonni) Kingsley, Audrey Kingsley, Paul Rubin and Julie Rubin. Great-grandmother of Jack Spencer Kingsley and Noah Kingsley. Services Friday, 10:30AM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., Cherry Hill, NJ.

title: Steve Mumford
description: Postmasters Gallery

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: A United Way And Boy Scouts Part Company
description: The United Way of Austin will end financial support for the local Boy Scouts organization after 2005, citing the Scouts' refusal to accept gay youths. Contributions from the United Way's central fund total about $157,000 annually, or about 5 percent of the Austin Scouts' $2.9 million budget. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: QAEDA SUSPECT MAY BE HANDED OVER TO U.S. Germany's highest court, the Constitutional Court, paved the way for the extradition of a Yemeni cleric to the United States on charges of financing terrorism after the United States agreed not to try him in a military tribunal, where he could receive the death penalty. American prosecutors have charged that the cleric, Sheik Muhammad Ali Hassan al-Mouyad, used a Brooklyn mosque to raise millions of dollars for Osama bin Laden. Sheik Mouyad, who was arrested in Germany in January, told an F.B.I. informant that he was Mr. bin Laden's spiritual adviser, according to a United States affidavit. A spokesman for the Justice Ministry said it would soon make a final decision on the extradition in consultation with the Foreign Ministry.    (Reuters)

title: Ford to Invest in Belgian Plant
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 13 (AP) - The Ford Motor Company said Thursday that it planned to invest $550 million to $600 million to produce two new models at its plant in Genk, Belgium, but that it would still layoff a third of the work force.

title: 'Ad Reinhardt and Contemporaries: 1940-50'
description: Barbara Mathes Gallery

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 395 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: TV Producer Starts Campaign To Register Young Voters for '04
description: Norman Lear, the 81-year-old television producer, said Thursday that he was beginning a $9 million campaign to register one million to two million new young voters for the 2004 election.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: 'Castle' May Be Saved
description: A once-grand 1930's manor that a local preservationist wanted to save and that real estate developers wanted to demolish may be left largely intact, thanks to a recently reached compromise. Rene Kahn, the preservationist, had urged the city's zoning board to stop a condominium development that would have leveled the French Normandy castle on the 30-acre estate. Under the compromise, developers, who once called the building ''not historically significant,'' have agreed to convert much of it into two condominium units that would be offered for sale along with 57 newer units. In exchange, Ms. Kahn plans to tell the board that she no longer objects to the project. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: A Mystery in Navajoland, Coded With Bright Color
description: Television has a hard time conveying heat and cold. Forget what Marshall McLuhan discursively considered cool or hot; scenes on television always look room temperature to me. Perhaps the medium is still too closely identified with climate-controlled soundstages in seasonless Los Angeles. Maybe pixels are intrinsically tepid.

title: Clean-Air Rules for Parks
description: The Environmental Protection Agency must propose a clean-air rule for national parks and wildernesses by Sept. 30 as part of a settlement announced on Thursday by the agency and environmental groups. The rule, to go into effect in September 2005, would address nitrogen oxide levels at parks like Acadia, Grand Canyon, Great Smoky Mountains, Rocky Mountain and Shenandoah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FILIPPELLI, NICHOLAS
description: FILIPPELLI--Nicholas. The League Treatment Center family, Board of Directors, Staff and Clients extend our deepest sympathy to Stella Filippelli, President of our PTA. We all deeply mourn the tragic loss of Nicholas Filippelli, a kind man of strength and compassion who was deeply devoted to his wife, Stella and son, Jimmy. The entire League Treatment Center family grieves the loss of Nicholas. He will be sorely missed. With deepest sympathy, Dr. Steven Katz, President Board of Trustees Hannah Achtenberg, Executive Director League Treatment Center

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about people over 40 who balance family responsibilities while continuing to perform part time as rock musicians misidentified the group with which John Sullivan plays. It is Ginger Moon, not Ginger Root.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Legal Services For Detainees
description: Starting this week, prisoners in the Passaic County Jail who have been accused of immigration violations will be able to dial a toll-free number, (877) 818-4845, to get help obtaining a lawyer. Since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, thousands of people have been questioned about their immigration status and hundreds have been detained, sometimes for long periods. But advocacy groups for the immigrants say that low-income detainees have difficulty getting lawyers because phone calls from jail are costly and toll-free numbers are generally unavailable. The New Jersey Civil Rights Defense Committee and the state chapter of the Council on American Islamic Relations helped start the toll-free service in Passaic and hope to get Hudson, Bergen and Middlesex County jails to allow it. Along with helping callers to obtain a lawyer, volunteers for the service will also relay direct information from the detainees to family members. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Fitzgerald May Contest N.F.L. Eligibility Rule
description: The father of Pittsburgh receiver Larry Fitzgerald, one of the top college football players in the country, is exploring the possibility of his son's early entry into the National Football League draft in April and says he believes his son is physically ready to play at the professional level.

title: Air Raid Sends Iraqis Message, But What Is It?
description: After the start of a well-publicized offensive against Iraqi insurgents, American commanders said Thursday that they were intent on sending the rebels ''a message.''

title: John Chamberlain; Etchings in Light; Ad Reinhardt and Contemporaries: 1940-50
description: John Chamberlain

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: We Await the Musical

title: Howard Hodgkin
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: Fraud Didn't Enrich Officers, Authorities Say
description: It all started in a barbershop in the Bronx. Between the bustle of four chairs, a Ms. Pac-Man machine and the Spanish soap operas on the little television, prosecutors said, two owners of the barbershop, one of them a former police officer, came up with a way to be paid for automobile accidents that had never happened.

title: Afghanistan's Constitutional Effort
description: Almost two years after the war, Afghans face growing insecurity, rising troubles with the Taliban and diminishing help from the West. A draft of a new constitution released at the end of October offers a first step toward real elections and a more humane society. This draft includes some promising aspirations, with a preamble that calls for observation of the United Nations Charter and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and for a civil society with a ''deserving place in the international community.'' But there are also troubling aspects of this crucial document, which will go before a constitutional convention next month for ratification.

title: Editorial Observer; Accounting for the Invisible Casualties of War Shouldn't Be a Matter of Politics
description: One of the most enduring memories from the funeral of my friend Michael Kelly, who was killed covering the war in Iraq for Atlantic Monthly, was standing by his open grave in a cemetery in Cambridge, Mass., watching an Army officer in dress uniform make his way through the cold, persistent drizzle and up the small hill to Michael's wife and boys. He spoke to the family quietly and then got down on one knee on the wet artificial turf that had been placed there in a vain attempt to shield the mourners from the earth. He gave the boys a flag and a medal.

title: Results of Steroid Testing Spur Baseball to Set Tougher Rules
description: Major League Baseball, which has labored for several seasons under suspicion that some of its star players were using steroids, said Thursday that in the first year of testing for steroids more than 5 percent of players' tests were positive. As a result, stricter testing standards will go into effect next year.

title: On Film, at Least, a Rap Star Defies Death
description: ''Tupac: Resurrection,'' which opens nationwide today, is a documentary with a curious, uncanny twist: it seems to be narrated, from beyond the grave, by its subject, the actor and rap star Tupac Shakur, who was shot to death at a Las Vegas intersection in 1996. ''I got shot,'' Shakur's voice-over says as clouds roll across the screen. ''I'm surprised but I'm happy.''

title: Libeskind Isn't Finished
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Real Estate; Less Space but More Rent? Court Says No
description: After one wall was shifted -- making the apartment next door larger -- a vacated rent-stabilized apartment at 302 East Third Street in Manhattan was rendered 86 square feet smaller. Yet the landlord charged the tenants who moved into the downsized unit a monthly rent of $1,950, nearly triple what the former tenant had paid.

title: Yankees Shift Focus To Vazquez And Coln
description: The Yankees have switched their focus away from trying to acquire Curt Schilling from the Arizona Diamondbacks and are in discussions with the Montreal Expos about trying to obtain Javier Vazquez. They are also talking about pursuing the free agent Bartolo Coln.

title: Report Finds F.B.I. Bosses Engaged in Lewd Conduct
description: A number of F.B.I. supervisors recently engaged in lewd conduct and improper sexual activity, and a senior official resigned after he was found to have had affairs with two subordinates, according to a Justice Department report released on Thursday.

title: Tardy Pay Called G.I.'s Fate
description: Members of the Army National Guard who have been called up for active duty since the Sept. 11 attacks have often been paid late or improperly, according to a congressional report released on Thursday.

title: Jury Wants All 5,201 Plans For 9/11 Memorial Shown
description: While only one design will win, all 5,201 submissions to the memorial competition for the World Trade Center site will go on public display, at the request of the 13-member jury, though it is not yet clear where they can fit.

title: A Father's Lessons, Taught in Firewood
description: ''WHEN you split a piece of wood,'' my father instructed me when I was about 6 years old, standing in the backwoods with a splitting maul in his hands, ''you look for the natural cracks. If you can hit it on the crack it will split a lot easier.''

title: South African Mines in a 3-Way Deal
description: In a complex deal aimed at meeting new South African regulations requiring increased black equity in the mining industry, three mining companies announced on Thursday that they would create the country's largest black-owned diversified mining company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABEND, ESTELLE L.
description: ABEND--Estelle L. (Hiller). Formerly of NY, on Wednesday, November 12, 2003. Wife of the late Phillip. Mother of Anne Brophy of Los Angeles and Paula Abend of Boston. Sister of Ruth Ames of CA and the late Arthur Hiller. Services at Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Sunday, November 16. Remembrances may be made to the Hebrew Rehabilitation Center for Aged, 1200 Centre Street, Boston, MA 02131.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ULLMAN, SUSAN BETH
description: ULLMAN--Susan Beth. 11/14/56 - 12/21/62 Our precious little gem. We miss you today on your birthday and all the days without you. You are forever loved. Your Family

title: Regulators Sue Former Officers Of Gateway
description: Federal regulators yesterday sued former top executives of Gateway Inc., accusing them of inflating earnings three years ago to meet analysts' expectations.

title: Skien Journal; Where East Meets West Warily, She Makes Them Laugh
description: A hush falls over the audience at the Ibsen House theater here when Shabana Rehman takes the stage to stand motionless in a black burka that conceals everything but her dark eyes. Then, as loud Norwegian folk music breaks the silence, she breaks into a frantic jig. The effect is hilarious but, the stand-up comedian hopes, instructive, too.

title: Back-Road Haunts, Along Georgia's Coast
description: SPEEDING down Interstate 95, you can easily drive from Savannah, Ga., to Kingsland and the Florida state line in a couple of hours. But those blessed with time can take the back roads from Tybee Island, the northernmost in a chain of barrier islands along Georgia's Atlantic Coast, and move a lot slower.

title: Loss of Chrebet Throws Jets' Offense Out of Comfort Zone and Into the Unknown
description: Only two days ago, the Jets mused with obvious excitement about how their offense was finally clicking. Now they are wondering how the offense will work with one of its key parts removed.

title: G.O.P. Leader Solicits Money For Charity Tied to Convention
description: It is an unusual charity brochure: a 13-page document, complete with pictures of fireworks and a golf course, that invites potential donors to give as much as $500,000 to spend time with Tom DeLay during the Republican convention in New York City next summer -- and to have part of the money go to help abused and neglected children.

title: Dean Proposes $7.1 Billion To Help Cover College Costs
description: Taking a page from philanthropists who adopt elementary school classes and promise to pay tuition for those who make it to college, Howard Dean proposed a $7.1 billion program on Thursday to guarantee eighth graders who commit to higher education $10,000 a year in grants and loans.

title: Realigned N.B.A. Keeps West Superior to East
description: On Wednesday night, the Detroit Pistons and the Golden State Warriors appeared to be evenly matched, battling through four quarters into overtime. In the end, Golden State, despite playing without its leading scorer, Jason Richardson, was better, winning by 87-85.

title: Raising Lichtenstein in Manhattan
description: This weekend a team of five riggers will begin assembling a 50-foot-tall fiberglass sculpture of four colorful brushstrokes in the octagonal rotunda of the former Tweed Courthouse, renamed City Hall Academy as the New York City Education Department's new headquarters.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a report from a consulting firm, A. T. Kearney, saying that suppliers would have to invest millions to comply with Wal-Mart's policy on electronic tagging of merchandise misstated the surname of a Kearney consultant. He is David Donnan, not Dannon.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Tobacco Companies Agree to Drop Ads
description: Four tobacco companies have agreed to not place ads in weekly newsmagazines that are distributed in middle schools and high schools as part of classroom programs.

title: Charity Debut at Convention
description: Celebrations for Children Inc., a new charity with close ties to Representative Tom DeLay, the majority leader, is raising money at the Republican National Convention by holding events and providing donors access to elected officials.

title: Americans in the Age of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Anything but Love'
description: Directed by Robert Cary

title: Chrtien Leaves at Ease, Even if Bush Is Displeased
description: The departing prime minister, Jean Chrtien, defended keeping Canadian troops out of Iraq, pushing for gay marriage and liberalizing drug laws in an interview this week that made clear his lasting differences with the Bush administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a downgrade in the debt rating of the Ford Motor Company by Standard & Poor's referred incorrectly to the ratings of General Motors and DaimlerChrysler. While S.& P. has a negative outlook on the companies, it does not have them on a more serious credit watch. The article also referred incorrectly to the profit margins achieved by the top Japanese automakers. The 8 percent figure was for operating margins, not net ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORAK, MAE
description: BORAK--Mae. On November 13, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Pat Hirsch, Marc and Phylis Borak. Loving sister of Thelma Chabot. Adoring Nana of David and Debbie Hirsch, Hillary and Todd Emmerman, Howard and Pam Hirsch, Jennifer and Amy Borak. Precious great-grandmother MAMIE to Alexandra and Jonathan, Matthew and Emily, Miranda and Caroline. Special aunt of Jeffrey and Renee Citron. She gave us her wisdom, humor and passion for life. We will keep you forever in our hearts. Services Friday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Adrift in Postwar Italy, Perilously Close to 30
description: Ernest Hemingway once remarked that all of American literature came out of ''Huckleberry Finn.'' With only slightly greater exaggeration, it could be said that much of American cinema, at least in the last 30 years or so, comes out of ''I Vitelloni,'' Federico Fellini's second movie as sole director, first released in 1953 and on view for a week, in a restored print, at Film Forum starting today. Without Fellini's sweet, lyrical story of a group of young men drifting aimlessly toward 30, we would probably not have ''American Graffiti'' or ''Mean Streets'' or ''Diner.'' Nor would we have the countless mid-90's comedies of male friendship and 20-something commitment-phobia that followed.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 3 Big Issues Stump Negotiators In a Bill to Revamp Medicare
description: After months of grueling work, House and Senate negotiators said on Thursday that they had been unable to agree on three big issues in a bill to revamp Medicare and provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Satellite Provider To Leave Bankruptcy
description: StarBand Communications, a provider of high-speed satellite Internet service to American homes and small businesses, has won a judge's approval of its plan to leave bankruptcy protection. StarBand, which is closely held, will convert $113 million in bank debt into 51 percent of the company's equity and plans to leave court protection by the end of the month. Gilat Satellite Networks of Israel, the company's hardware supplier, received 49 percent of StarBand and a $14 million note in exchange for $90 million in debt. StarBand, which is based in McLean, Va., filed for bankruptcy protection in May 2002 in Wilmington, Del. StarBand listed about $58 million in assets and $229 million in debts in its Chapter 11 petition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWEET, ROBERT H.
description: SWEET--Robert H. On November 10, 2003. Beloved father of Robin Sweet, Margery (Boo) Grace, Christopher and Jonathan Sweet. Loving grandfather of six grandchildren. Chairman Emeritus of the Robbins Company. Cremation was private. Inquiries Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel. Memorial service November 17, 4PM at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 50 St at Park Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Humane Society of N.Y., Bryant College, Saint MarySacred Heart School, North Attleboro, MA. or Telluride Educational Foundation, CO.

title: City to Get $64 Million To Counter Terrorism
description: The Bush administration announced on Thursday that it would provide the New York City region about $64 million for antiterrorism programs, an amount that several New York lawmakers called inadequate.

title: 2 Men Charged In Brief Theft Of a Painting At Kennedy
description: Lucian Freud, the London-based artist known for the stark realism of his paintings, got a dose of New York City reality this week when one of his recently completed works -- appraised at $1.5 million -- was stolen at Kennedy International Airport, the authorities said.

title: A Rapper Whose Targets Include Himself, Shooting From the Hip
description: Near the beginning of his performance on Tuesday at S.O.B.'s, the Minneapolis-based rapper Slug told the audience, ''Put your gun up!,'' and all you could see were thumbs and index fingers. ''Aim that gun at me,'' he added. Then, staring down a few hundred imaginary barrels, he turned an ordinary hip-hop chant into a suicidal fantasy: ''Boom, boom, boom-boom.''

title: Americans in the Age of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal S.I. Ferry Crash Case To Shift to U.S. Prosecutors
description: Federal prosecutors will take over the criminal investigation into the Staten Island ferry crash that killed 10 people and injured dozens last month, several law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Tokyo Switch on Iraq Troops Not an Issue in Rumsfeld Talks
description: TOKYO, Nov. 14  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld held talks here tonight with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, and in the 45-minute session neither side brought up Tokyo's announcement that it had deferred its decision on whether to volunteer troops for Iraq, American officials said.

title: Dashing Through a Storm of Color, With a Preference for Pink
description: ''Rain'' is refreshing.

title: Marathon in the Senate: The Talk Is Long, but Temper Short
description: It may come as no surprise that people who can hardly stand each other during regular business hours would treat each other all the more harshly in an all-night working session. But tempers were especially raw during the Senate's debate on judicial nominations, which ran wearily on into a third day Friday morning toward an end scheduled for 39 hours after it began.

title: NBC Moves To Break Up Relationship With Paxson
description: NBC moved yesterday to break up its increasingly troubled relationship with Paxson Communications, exercising a right to demand a full redemption of its investment in the company, a decision that could cost Paxson as much as $600 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, GERTRUDE
description: FISHER--Gertrude. On November 13, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Alexander. Devoted mother of William and Lisa and mother-in-law of Holly Fisher and Jay Sugarman. Cherished grandmother of Alex, Daniel, Joseph, Joshua and Sarah. Services Friday 1PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to a charity of choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: A Step Forward On Patents
description: India's patent authority gave Novartis exclusive marketing rights for its cancer drug Glivec for five years, in what was seen as the Indian government's willingness to accept global patent standards. India has followed its own patent regime for two decades, but, in a deal with the World Trade Organization, has agreed to accept global customs by 2005. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Defiant Chief Justice Ousted in Alabama
description: A special ethics panel ousted Alabama's chief justice, Roy S. Moore, for defying a federal court order to remove a giant monument of the Ten Commandments that he placed in the lobby of the State Supreme Court.

title: FIRSTENERGY WILL GET $198 MILLION IN DISPUTE WITH NRG
description: Xcel Energy's bankrupt NRG Energy unit will pay the FirstEnergy Corporation $198 million to settle a dispute over a power plant deal, FirstEnergy said yesterday. FirstEnergy agreed to sell four Ohio plants to NRG in November 2001 for about $1.5 billion but canceled the deal in August last year after NRG's financial troubles became clear. In December, FirstEnergy, which is based in Akron, Ohio, decided to keep the plants after failing to find another buyer, and said at the time that it reserved the right to seek damages. NRG agreed to settle for $396 million, subject to bankruptcy court approval. Under NRG's proposed reorganization plan, unsecured creditors will receive 50 cents on the dollar. NRG's parent, Xcel, is based in Minneapolis.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: PanAmSat Buys Sonic Telecom
description: The PanAmSat Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the bankrupt Sonic Telecom for $6 million to give it an additional way of transmitting video. PanAmSat, based in Wilton, Conn., owns satellites that broadcasters use to send video. PanAmSat would have had to spend three or four times what it paid for Sonic Telecom to build a fiber network like that run by Sonic Telecom, a PanAmSat spokeswoman, Kathryn Lancioni, said. Sonic is based in Chantilly, Va.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANIS, EFFIE
description: TANIS--Effie. On Wednesday, November 12, 2003 of Wayne, NJ. Formerly of Paterson, NJ. Wife of the late Philip Tanis. Mother of Debra Tanis and her husband Mark White, Edie Tanis Brenna and her husband Chuck Brenna of Philadelphia, PA, Joni Tanis and her husband Alan O'Neill of Oakland, CA, and Marc Tanis of Wayne, NJ. Grandmother of Simon, Eli, Sasha, Ariel and Harry. Services 1pm Sunday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Rte 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: PBHG Funds Oust Leaders; Putnam Settles Fraud Case

title: Microsoft Seems Ready to Settle Europe Suit
description: Microsoft has given its strongest signal yet that it hopes to reach a settlement of the European Union's long-running antitrust case.

title: Council Majority Leader Is Sued Over Campaign Funds
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board has filed a lawsuit against Joel Rivera, the majority leader of the City Council, seeking the return of $36,245 in public funds it says his campaign received but did not account for.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by American Catholic bishops to reinforce church teaching on contraception misstated the current assignment of a bishop who said widespread acceptance of contraception was a cultural problem, and in some copies misstated his initial. The bishop is Joseph F. Martino, not E. He now heads the Diocese of Scranton, Pa.; he is no longer the auxiliary bishop of Philadelphia.

title: Manager Prospered as Investors Suffered
description: WHO would have thought that Gary L. Pilgrim would seek to profit at the expense of the mutual fund shareholders whose trust had made him wealthy?

title: Lunchbox for Art: A New Museum
description: The New Museum of Contemporary Art wants to build a seven-story bento box for art on the Bowery. Plans and models for this deftly composed lunch break of a building are now on view in the museum's mezzanine gallery, at 583 Broadway, between Houston and Prince Streets in SoHo. Produced by Saana, a Tokyo firm, the design should please those who believe that art museums should be neutral containers. If executed with proper attention to detail, the building will also delight the Victorians among us who incline toward tender passion.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sometimes, crime does not make a whole lot of sense.''

title: An Intelligent Thing to Do
description: The White House has finally agreed to allow the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks to read parts of the same intelligence reports the president read every morning in the months leading up to the attacks. As commission members begin to review these briefings, they may be forgiven for asking: what was all the fuss about?

title: Beholding Windmills and Wisdom From a New Vantage
description: DON QUIXOTE

title: With a Few Zings, Taking Comedy Across Borders
description: DRESSED in gym sweats, Omid Djalili ushers a visitor into his single-guy-like cluttered suite in an East Side Manhattan hotel, where he's been staying for months while shooting episodes for NBC's new hit sitcom, ''Whoopi.'' Mr. Djalili plays Nasim, an Iranian hotel handyman who is both the target and the trigger of zinging one-liners about Middle Easterners. But Mr. Djalili's wife and three children are back home in London, so he fills his lonely hours with a project: losing weight.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Americans in the Age of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Twilight Zone For ZIP Code At Ground Zero
description: FROM the beginning, the collapse of the World Trade Center has been a tale told in numbers as well as words.

title: Fans Gone With Wind, but Devils Still Win
description: There were plenty of tickets available, good and bad, for the Devils' game Thursday night against Florida. Apparently, many of the people who did have tickets decided that the game was not worth a trip into the harsh wind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, COWAN, DAISY BELL
description: MOORE-COWAN--Daisy Bell. 101, died Tuesday in her home in Greenville, SC. She is survived by her grandson, John Lee (Mattye) CowanJones and great grandson, Orlando Jones. Funeral November 17 in Prichard, AL.

title: The Neediest Cases; Once Lost in Pain of Father's Death, Family Finds Hope
description: Tayshah Armstrong met Bernard Vickers when she was barely 20 years old. Her first impression: they were an unlikely match. He was older, 29, shorter and bigger than the guys she usually went out with, said Ms. Armstrong, now 28.

title: Eye Injury Keeps Lindros Out
description: Eric Lindros's injured left eye was re-examined yesterday by the Rangers' ophthalmologist, Mark Fromer, and the team said Lindros's status was day to day.

title: Geoffrey Hendricks
description: Emily Harvey Gallery

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Army Diet Found Lacking
description: Russian Army conscripts suffer malnutrition and poor health care, the rights group Human Rights Watch said in a report. The official military diet promises meat, fish, fruits, vegetables and butter, said Anna Neistat, director of the Moscow office of Human Rights Watch, ''but we haven't come across a single case when this diet was in fact available.'' In one case, the report said, a conscript serving in Siberia died after less than four months of service, with emaciation listed as a cause of death. His mother said he had complained in letters of constant hunger. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Do I Hear $2 Million?
description: GARY GORDON wanted to sell his Naples, Fla., house -- fast. So last week, Dr. Gordon, a dentist turned real estate investor, did what would once have been unthinkable. He put his sprawling, newly completed Mediterranean-style home on the auction block. ''I love the idea of selling it in one day,'' he said.

title: Woman Dies And Thousands Lose Power In High Winds
description: Fierce winds lashed the New York region yesterday, delaying flights, knocking out power for thousands of businesses and residents and bringing scaffolding and trees crashing down in New York City. At least one person was killed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Profit At Telefnica
description: The Spanish telecommunications giant Telefnica reported a net profit of 2.01 billion euros ($2.34 billion) for the first nine months of the year, reversing a loss of 5.03 billion euros for the period a year earlier. The company said the turnaround resulted from a strong performance by its cellular divisions, which grew 7 percent compared with a year ago, and it noted the high cost of last year's restructuring of cellphone operations in Austria, Germany, Italy and Switzerland. About half of Telefnica's 94 million clients are now cellphone users. The company reported a recovery in Latin American operations for the first time since 2001. Sales, however, slipped 3 percent, to 20.8 billion euros, for the nine-month period as a result of currency fluctuations. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Reparations Proposed in Mexican Killings
description: A federal investigator appointed by President Vicente Fox to look into the unsolved killings of several hundred women said Thursday that Mexico should consider paying ''a symbolic reparation for damages, for negligence, to the victims' families.''

title: Students' Scores Rise in Math, Not in Reading
description: Elementary and middle school children have continued a decade of progress on a nationally administered math test, with all groups showing gains in every state. But reading scores remained essentially flat in most of the country, according to test results released here on Thursday.

title: Shocking! Offensive! But Being Pleasant Is Beside the Point
description: Although the phrase ''shock and awe'' has become as clichd as the suffix -gate, it has dutifully been evoked in the British press to describe this year's Turner Prize entries. Actually, it is really only the entry by the brothers Jake and Dinos Chapman -- some think it's the favorite -- that has evoked, or provoked, that phrase. And awe has a lot less to do with it than shock.

title: Violence in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Martin Reidy was named president of Digitas West, San Francisco, part of Digitas. He had been president and chief executive at R/GA, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. At R/GA, Robert Greenberg, chairman and chief creative officer, will add the post of chief executive.

title: House and Senate Reach Deal on Broad Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 — Senate and House Republicans reached agreement today on energy legislation intended to increase domestic production and make transmission networks more reliable.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: OpenTV-DirecTV Deal To End
description: The OpenTV Corporation said yesterday that it had lost a contract to provide its interactive-television software to DirecTV, the largest satellite TV provider in the United States, after the companies were unable to agree to new terms. The existing agreement will expire on Dec. 22, OpenTV said. OpenTV, based in Mountain View, Calif., will deactivate 10.4 million set-top boxes now in use on the DirecTV network. The contract with DirecTV generated sales of about $1 million, or 2 percent of OpenTV's revenue, for the first nine months of the year, OpenTV said.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary yesterday referring to an article about New York legislators' efforts to reduce a budget deficit of at least $6 billion was published in error. The article was not published; it appears today on Page B1.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Sacramento

title: Op-Chart
description: How are things really going in Iraq? That's a tricky question. First, it is inherently difficult to measure progress in counterinsurgency warfare and nation-building efforts. Second, reports of the latest violence -- including the deaths of more than 50 American and other coalition troops in the first two weeks of November -- and the highly partisan debate in Washington dominate the news coverage, overshadowing more in-depth analysis.

title: From Wrestling Buddy to Official Portraitist
description: Moments before the official portrait of former Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota was unveiled yesterday morning in the State Capitol Rotunda in St. Paul, the subject had a word with the artist.

title: MCDONALD'S TO START LICENSED PRODUCTS FOR CHILDREN
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it would introduce McKids, a multicategory licensing plan aimed at children. The product line is the company's latest effort to attract younger customers and to revive the McDonald's brand. McKids products, which will appear in stores in the spring, will feature the Golden Arches on children's toys, clothing and interactive videos and books. The product line will also include several items, like Spin Master Toys' McFlurry Maker, that already have licensing agreements with McDonald's and are sold in Wal-Mart, Target and Toys R Us. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: First Human Death From Raccoon Rabies
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported the first human death from raccoon rabies ever documented in the United States. A 25-year-old from Virginia died of the disease in March. It was diagnosed after he died, and investigators could not determine how he was exposed. The man visited his doctor, was admitted to a hospital six days later and died two weeks after that. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Sterilization in India
description: To the Editor:

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: No Place to Go For Sondheim?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, LINDA
description: QUINN--Linda. The partners, associates and staff of Shearman & Sterling LLP mourn the death at the height of her career of Linda Quinn. She was an eminent colleague, partner and friend. As an expert on securities law, she was a trusted and respected advisor to major corporations in the U.S., Europe and Asia, notably on issues of disclosure and corporate governance. Earlier, as the Director of the Division of Corporation Finance of the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1986 to 1996, her vision and leadership were key to achieving the historic reforms that opened broad participation in U.S. capital markets by foreign corporations. She has left an enduring mark not only on the law but also on all of us who had the great privilege of working with her. Her memory will be cherished for her dedication to the highest principles of the profession and her personal qualities of integrity, enthusiasm and warmth.

title: Nets' Martin Passes M.R.I. Test
description: Kenyon Martin underwent a magnetic resonance imaging exam Thursday on his strained right knee, an injury sustained Wednesday in his first game back since his left ankle was sprained. The M.R.I. was negative, but Martin missed practice, and the Nets did not know whether he would be available when they play host to the Knicks on Friday night.

title: Teachers May Give Ground On Grievances
description: Randi Weingarten, the president of the teachers' union, yesterday proposed changing the teachers' contract to speed up grievance procedures and disciplinary proceedings, areas that city officials have long said pose an obstacle to firing bad teachers.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Unionization Push
description: Two of the labor movement's main allies in Congress, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representative George Miller of California, both Democrats, introduced a bill that would allow unions to organize a workplace without an election and by simply getting 50.1 percent of the workers to sign cards saying they want a union. It would also require employers to pay triple back pay when they illegally fired workers for supporting a union. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: ANTIQUES
description: Time to Write Finis For a Book Trove

title: Trouble in Iraq: A Shift in Perception
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NITZBERG, JEROME
description: NITZBERG -- Jerome. Be loved husband and devoted father, grandfather and brother. Jerome devoted his work life to creating a center in which people with developmental disabilities could work and grow in a setting where they were truly encouraged to realize themselves. Farewell service at Hatton/Harden Funeral Home, 208-17 Northern Blvd, Bayside, Saturday, November 15th, 29pm. 718-229-0744.

title: John Chamberlain -- 'Early Works'
description: Allan Stone Gallery

title: Russia Offers Reassurances About Rights To Property
description: The Russian government went on a charm offensive Thursday, with liberal Kremlin aides and international financial aid officials saying the country was not headed toward a reversal on privatized property after the arrest of the country's wealthiest businessman.

title: U.S. Trade Law Gives Africa Hope and Hard Jobs
description: Uganda is banking its future on 1,400 girls young women, really -- plucked from their villages around the country and plopped down in front of row upon row of sewing machines at a vast factory here outside the capital.

title: A Playful Narcissist's Song of Himself
description: ARE you ready for Lucas Samaras's close-up? He is, as always, so brace yourself when the elevator doors open onto the fourth floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art. Front and center is a towering image of Mr. Samaras's impish 67-year-old face, a black-and-white photograph silhouetted on a black wall. With its taut skin, terse smile, soft beard and imperious gaze, it is part Pan, part Merlin, part Rasputin.

title: Following Dean, Kerry Opts Out of Public Financing for 2004
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  Senator John Kerry followed both President Bush and his rival Democratic candidate, Howard Dean, in declining public financing for his presidential campaign today, a move that will allow him to inject more of his personal money into the race.

title: Linda C. Quinn, 55, a Lawyer Who Oversaw S.E.C. Regulation
description: Linda C. Quinn, a specialist in securities law and an influential force at the Securities and Exchange Commission in the 1980's and 1990's, died on Tuesday in Dalton, Mass.

title: Cuba: You Can't Get There From Here . . .
description: FOR a 52-year-old Manhattan lawyer, there is a lot about Cuba that is alluring, from the beaches to the architecture to the music straight out of ''Buena Vista Social Club.'' But the real draw of traveling to Cuba: it is illegal. ''There's certainly an excitement to going somewhere that's off limits,'' the man said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said he had been to Cuba three times, most recently for a weekend trip in late 2001.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fraud Conviction Upheld
description: A federal appeals panel yesterday upheld the conviction of a Manhattan obstetrician for defrauding insurance companies. The doctor, Niels H. Lauersen, based his appeal primarily on objections that the trial judge owned stock in one of the insurance companies, court papers said. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found that the trial judge followed proper procedure and that his disqualification was not required. Dr. Lauersen had billed companies for gynecological procedures that were covered by his patients' policies to hide the uncovered fertility procedures he was performing. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Industry Fights Back on Product Placement
description: Industry Fights Back

title: Strawberry Back, as Is Stottlemyre
description: Two Yankees returned to the organization yesterday, and one of the moves was a major surprise.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: CAMPAIGN VIOLATIONS CHARGED An ambulance company executive was accused yesterday of violating campaign-contribution laws. Federal charges of making $32,500 in illegal campaign contributions were filed against Steven Zakheim, an official of MetroCare Ambulance, Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn, announced. In 2000, MetroCare became the first for-profit company to get a city contract to have its ambulances answer 911 calls. Prosecutors said that Mr. Zakheim reimbursed employees for "straw donations," intended to circumvent limits of federal campaign law, given to, among others, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Charles E. Schumer. The prosecutors did not allege wrongdoing by the candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASS, ESTHER RAFFEL
description: GLASS--Esther Raffel. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted mother of Richard H. and Howard L. Glass, loving grandmother of four. Service 11:00 AM today at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer'' Queens Blvd and 76th Road Forest Hills, NY.

title: Wal-Mart Profit Falls a Bit Short
description: In a performance that many on Wall Street took as a disappointment, Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter fell a penny short of analysts' estimates.

title: The Collectibles Many Grew Up With in an Age of Optimism
description: Modernism used to be the future. Now it's the past, a period style. And what followed Modernism -- postmodernism -- has become history, too. What we have now, no one knows what to call: post-something or neo-something, probably, but what?

title: Industry Fights Back On Product Placement
description: A coalition of advertising organizations is lashing back at Commercial Alert, an advocacy group that last month called the practice of product placement ''an affront to basic honesty'' and demanded new government regulations like advisories superimposed on screen during television programs that display products in exchange for payments.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Art Arising From Ashes

title: Berlin Holocaust Shrine Stays With Company Tied to Nazi Gas
description: The trustees of the huge Holocaust memorial planned for the very center of Berlin decided Thursday to continue with construction even though a subcontractor in the project was once involved in making the poison gas used in the Nazi death camps.

title: Partison Feud on Iraq Review Leaves Senate Panel in Gridlock
description: A bitter partisan dispute on the Senate Intelligence Committee over the handling of a review on Iraq intensified on Thursday, with Republicans and Democrats accusing one another of putting politics ahead of national security.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday reported on a federal inquiry into suspected illegal wiretapping by a private investigator in Hollywood, Anthony Pellicano. The article incorporated a paragraph about an incident in which Mr. Pellicano recovered the body of Elizabeth Taylor's third husband, Mike Todd, which had been removed from its grave at a Chicago cemetery. That paragraph was reproduced nearly verbatim from a Weblog compiled by a Los Angeles journalist, Luke Ford, who adapted it from a passage in the 2000 book ''Dish,'' by Jeannette Walls. In February 1994, a similar account appeared in Los Angeles magazine. The Times should have credited the Weblog for its version.

title: P.&G. Campaign Uses Text Messaging
description: Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati is beginning its first United States campaign that uses text messaging on many cellphones as a medium. The television, radio and online elements of the campaign, created by Arc Marketing in Greenwich, Conn., part of the Publicis Groupe, will encourage consumers to take part in a sweepstakes for Clairol Herbal Essences hair products by sending text messages and receiving clues.

title: 36 Hours | Charlotte, N.C.
description: OVER the last 20 years, Charlotte, North Carolina's biggest city, has remade itself from a textiles town into an investment and banking center, the nation's second-largest financial-services hub after New York City (and about to become bigger if the proposed merger of Bank of America and Fleet goes through). The moderate Carolina weather makes the city a pleasant place to stroll in winter, while museums and hip shops are also a draw. And though the city has a thriving historic-preservation movement, you get the unmistakable feeling that Charlotte sees itself as a city of the future -- and it has the new skyscrapers to prove it. LOUIS JACOBSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTINO, SAMUEL E.
description: MARTINO--Samuel E. of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, a decorated veteran of World War II, died November 13 at his home. Survived by his wife Angelina (nee Scudieri) Martino; a daughter Donna Martino of Englewood, NJ; two sons Edward A. (Peggy) Martino of Greenwich, CT and the Hon. Michael J. (Antoinette) Martino of Tuckahoe, NY and six grandchildren; Michael C, Stephanie, Mark, Michael K, Maggie and Annie and his sister Mary Pecoraro of Richmond, CA. Reposing Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Challenging Detroit's Redoubt, Nissan Starts Up the Titan Pickup Truck
description: Nissan's new pickup truck, the Titan, has been debated and dissected all year long. Now it is priced and ready to go out the showroom door.

title: Growth Is Back for French, Germans and Dutch
description: Three major European countries returned to economic growth in the summer, underscoring the momentum of the global recovery and Europe's lagging role in it.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the New DVD's column on Tuesday about the film ''Ashes and Diamonds'' misstated the date of V-E Day, the last day of World War II in Europe, on which the film takes place. It was May 8, 1945, not July 8.

title: L.I. Athletes Said to Admit Responsibility In Abuse Case
description: The three Mepham High School varsity football players accused of sexually abusing three freshman teammates at a Pennsylvania training camp have all admitted responsibility for the attacks, people close to the case said.

title: For Knicks and Nets, A Rivalry of Uncertainty
description: This year, the banner ceremony to celebrate the Nets' second straight Eastern Conference championship was deliberately understated. Lou Lamoriello, the Nets' chief executive, did not want to overplay the team's achievement, because they had again lost in the N.B.A. finals.

title: Sports of The Times; No. 1 Is a Role Roddick Is Playing for Keeps
description: ANDY RODDICK was locked in a stick-'em-up pose arms in the air, feet apart, with ''don't move'' on his mind -- while the wardrobe folks at ''Saturday Night Live'' put their guest host through a caffeinated version of Mr. Potato Head between every sketch last week.

title: Stephen A. Benton, 61, an Expert Researcher in Holography
description: Stephen A. Benton, a pioneer in medical-imaging and fine-arts holography who invented the ''rainbow'' holograms now found on credit cards, died on Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 61 and lived in nearby Lincoln, Mass.

title: A Play on Words; Brooklyn Accents and Trends Are Central to One-Woman Show
description: With his beefy arms, booming voice and bristly crew cut, Joseph Attianese doesn't immediately remind people of a petite 25-year-old woman from the Midwest. In his 38 years, he has always lived in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. And he is certainly not feminine.

title: Italian Team Leads in the Finals Of World Bridge Championship
description: Italy took the lead in the finals of the world bridge team championship here on Thursday, playing against an American team headed by Nick Nickell. In the Bermuda Bowl for open teams, Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Lorenzo Lauria, Alfredo Versace, Fulvio Fantoni and Claudio Nunes led by 30 imps with 48 deals of 128 completed. The match will end on Saturday. The Nickell team includes Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell. All 12 players are world champions, past or present.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about agreements by the Big Three automakers to export cars and parts to China reversed the identities of two General Motors executives. The company's chairman, Rick Wagoner, was at the right; Gary Cowger, a vice president, was at the left.

title: Parrish Helps the Islanders Perk Up
description: In a game that hinged on the Islanders' ability to overcome their mistakes, Michael Peca shoveled a backhand pass to Mark Parrish late in the second period against the Montreal Canadiens on Thursday night. Parrish pivoted and tapped the puck past Montreal goaltender Jos Thodore to put the Islanders a goal ahead.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by McDonald's to close four giant vending machines in the Washington metropolitan area after a yearlong experiment with what it called ''automated convenience stores'' omitted credit for the publication that first reported it. It was The Washington Post.

title: JETBLUE GIVES MOST PASSENGERS 2 INCHES MORE LEGROOM
description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it had removed a row of seats from each of its planes, increasing legroom for most passengers by two inches. Sixty-five percent of the 156 seats on each of JetBlue's Airbus A320 planes now have a seat pitch, or distance between seats, of 34 inches, in contrast to the old pitch of 32 inches. Nine rows in each aircraft near the front of the cabin will still have 32 inches. JetBlue's move mirrors the ''More Room in Coach'' campaign in which American Airlines increased its seat pitches to 33 to 35 inches. American recently said it was adding seats back to nearly a third of its planes. Analysts concluded that the retreat signaled that the extra legroom had failed to generate additional revenue. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Houses With Window Walls: Making the Most of a View
description: WHO -- Katherine Slingluff, 29, professional photographer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, JEAN LARKIN
description: FRIEDLAND--Jean Larkin. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Cherished mother of Edward, Hope, Mary and Nancy. Proud grandmother of eight and great grand mother of four. Pioneer in the personnel industry. A woman of great strength & courage. Shiva will be held at 360 East 72 Street. Contributions in her name can be made to Rockland ARC, Congers, NY 10920.

title: Lands Worth Leaving Alone
description: Last April, Interior Secretary Gale Norton and Gov. Michael Leavitt of Utah struck a deal that removed federal protection from about 2.6 million acres of land in Utah that her predecessor, Bruce Babbitt, had designated as potential wilderness. The consequences of that deal are now becoming clear. The Bureau of Land Management, part of Interior, recently announced plans to sell oil and gas leases on 16,000 acres in and near Desolation Canyon, a fragile landscape that would almost certainly have remained off limits under the Babbitt policy. Environmental groups have filed protests aimed not only at protecting Desolation Canyon but also at sending a larger message: that the fate of these and other lands of national significance should ultimately be decided by Congress, not the oil and gas industry.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City College Given $3.7 Million
description: The City College of New York has received $3.7 million from the Carroll and Milton Petrie Foundation, which the college described as the largest foundation grant in its 156-year history. The money will be used to train some assistant principals in New York City public high schools, so that they can provide instructional support to teachers. The training program will be administered by City College's School of Education. The college recently received $2 million from Stanley H. Kaplan for a similar program for assistant principals in middle schools. Kimetris N. Baltrip (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Humanities Medals To Be Given
description: The novelist John Updike, the actor Hal Holbrook and eight others are to be presented with the National Humanities Medal this morning by President Bush in a White House ceremony, the National Endowment for the Humanities announced. The other recipients this year are Robert Ballard, the deep-sea explorer who found the remains of the Titanic; Joan Ganz Cooney, co-founder of the Children's Television Workshop and ''Sesame Street''; Joseph Epstein, essayist and literary critic; Midge Decter, author and former editor of the magazine Commentary; Jean Fritz, author of children's books; Elizabeth Fox-Genovese, author and Emory University professor of humanities and history; Edith Kurzweil, author and former editor of The Partisan Review; and Frank M. Snowden, a professor of black history at Howard University. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Iran's reaction to an International Atomic Energy Agency report on its nuclear programs misstated the title of John R. Bolton, who commented on the report. He is under secretary of state for arms control, not deputy under secretary.

title: Cabinet Shake-Up Spoils Colombia's Effort to Cast Stable Image
description: After taking office 15 months ago, President lvaro Uribe said his ministers would remain with him throughout his four-year term, a pledge aimed at casting an image of stability and purpose in a nation where governments are usually scorned.

title: White House Memo; President Raises Cash And Question
description: First, it was cinnamon buns and Mickey Mouse-shaped cereal treats on Thursday morning with for donors in a hotel ballroom at Walt Disney World near Orlando.

title: Eclecticism and Humor in Works by Lewis Spratlan
description: Lewis Spratlan, a composer who lives in Amherst, Mass., won the Pulitzer Prize in 2000 for his opera, "Life Is a Dream" - actually, for a concert version of its second act. At the time his music was barely known in New York, and to this day there has not been a full staging of the opera. Still, if the Pulitzer has done Mr. Spratlan any good, it has been in creating a curiosity about his work. On Nov. 6 the new-music ensemble Sequitur played four of his pieces in a Composer Portrait concert at the Miller Theater.

title: Americans in the Age of Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Perelman to Aid Revlon With Loan of $125 Million
description: Ronald O. Perelman plans to advance money to Revlon to keep the company from running out of cash while it negotiates with lenders, the company said yesterday.

title: New Indian Pt. Cooling System: Years in the Making, and More to Come
description: A day after New York State laid out rigorous requirements for the Indian Point nuclear plant that were intended to reduce fish kills, environmentalists and other critics disputed the plant owner's claims that a new cooling system would cost more than $1 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BETZIG, WILLIAM B.
description: BETZIG -- William B. Of Larchmont, N.Y. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 914834-0144. Mass Monday 11AM at Sts. John & Paul Church, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Iran's reaction to an International Atomic Energy Agency report on its nuclear programs misstated the title of John R. Bolton, who commented on the report. He is under secretary of state for arms control, not deputy under secretary.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Profit
description: Britain's biggest phone com-pany, BT Group, raised its dividend 42 percent after fiscal second-quarter profit increased by a fifth as the company cut costs and won more broadband Internet customers. The shares fell as much as 7 percent after the company said revenue declined. BT raised its interim dividend to 3.2 pence a share and said it would also start buying back shares. Net income rose to 377 million ($632 million) for the three months ended Sept. 30. Sales were 4.57 billion, down 2 percent.

title: Fassel Relying on Veterans To Help the Giants Regroup
description: With speculation about his future swirling almost as intensely as the 50-mile-an-hour gusts outside Giants Stadium on Thursday, Coach Jim Fassel has turned to his veterans for leadership support this week as the Giants (4-5) prepare for Sunday's game in Philadelphia against the Eagles (6-3).

title: Holocaust Survivors in U.S. Say Settlement Slights Them
description: In the five years since a landmark $1.25 billion settlement of a class-action suit against Swiss banks over their role during the Nazi era, American court officials have distributed nearly $500 million to Holocaust survivors around the world.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Englewood: Man Questioned In Wife's Death
description: The death of a woman found in her home on Wednesday with multiple stab wounds has been ruled a homicide by the Bergen County prosecutor's office. The woman, Marcia Melo, 37, was found dead in the basement of her three-story home by her husband, Renato M. Melo, the police said Mr. Melo told them. Mr. Melo was questioned on Wednesday night and again yesterday, said John L. Molinelli, the county prosecutor. He added that many people were being interviewed and that no arrests had been made. Jason George (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Campaign Violations Charged
description: An ambulance company executive was accused yesterday of violating campaign-contribution laws. Federal charges of making $32,500 in illegal campaign contributions were filed against Steven Zakheim, an official of MetroCare Ambulance, Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn, announced. In 2000, MetroCare became the first for-profit company to get a city contract to have its ambulances answer 911 calls. Prosecutors said that Mr. Zakheim reimbursed employees for ''straw donations,'' intended to circumvent limits of federal campaign law, given to, among others, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Charles E. Schumer. The prosecutors did not allege wrongdoing by the candidates. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Chowing Down on Raw Fish Along the Path to Manhood
description: Brother Bear

title: Bush Is Said to Weigh Changes to the Tax Code
description: Senior Bush administration officials said Thursday that they were considering plans to simplify the tax code and to revive earlier ideas for savings plans that would allow people to exclude almost all their investment income from taxes.

title: Guerrillas Posing More Danger, Says U.S. Commander for Iraq
description: The senior American commander in the Middle East said Thursday that the Unites States-led occupation in Iraq faces no more than 5,000 guerrilla fighters, but that they are increasingly well organized and well financed, and are gradually expanding their attacks to the previously calm north and south.

title: Budget Gap In Westchester To Force 236 Layoffs
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, will announce a budget today that calls for laying off 236 employees in an effort to close an estimated shortfall of more than $100 million in the county's $1.4 billion budget. The layoffs, most of which will come in the Social Services and Health Departments, were the only way the county could avoid a tax increase of nearly 30 percent, Mr. Spano said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: I.B.M. CORPORATION, Armonk, N.Y., said it bought closely held Productivity Solutions Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., to add self-service checkout registers for stores. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Deal on 9/11 Briefings Lets White House Edit Papers
description: The commission investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks said on Thursday that its deal with the White House for access to highly classified Oval Office intelligence reports would let the White House edit the documents before they were released to the commission's representatives.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: On the Road To Bandera, Lyle Lovett Rides Again
description: LYLE LOVETT was nervous. The two of us were about to go on a ride through his beloved Texas Hill Country on two of his Ducati motorcycles -- a 916 for me and a 998R for him, arrow-fast bikes that could easily hit 150 miles an hour if you were willing to take the risk.

title: Alabama Panel Ousts Judge Over Ten Commandments
description: A special ethics panel on Thursday ousted Alabama's chief justice, Roy S. Moore, who was lionized by the religious right for his refusal to remove a titanic monument of the Ten Commandments he had put in the lobby of the state judicial building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOMPKINS, JOHN
description: TOMPKINS--John, 79, died suddenly Saturday night, November 8th of a heart attack. John was a World War II veteran who enlisted at the age of 17. After the war, he graduated from the University of Michigan on the G.I. bill, and then moved to New York to work for Grace Line. The move to New York launched his distinguished career as a journalist working first for the Wall Street Journal. From there he moved to The New York Times, Business Week and finally Time Magazine which led to his appointment to the Price Commission in Washington, DC. He authored two non fiction books ''The Crime Confederation'' and ''The Weapons of World War III''. At the time of his death, John was writing a column for CoiningMoney.com an online investment newsletter. He loved to scrounge for obscure antiques and had an undending thirst and curiosity for information. He was a man of great faith and conviction. His passing is a loss for all who knew him. He is survived by his devoted wife Michele Stephenson and his daughters Claire Tompkins Timothy and Nancy Tompkins Heinemann. The memorial service will be at 5:30 PM Friday, November 14 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 81st Street and Madison Ave. Donations may be made to Hospice of New York, 45-18 Court Square, Long Island City, NY 11101.

title: Salt Lake Bid Trial Delayed
description: The federal trial of the indicted Olympic bidders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson was unexpectedly recessed yesterday, a day after the prosecution's case may have been undermined by its key witness.

title: Ex-Secretary Testifies on Tyco Loans
description: The former secretary of L. Dennis Kozlowski at Tyco International told a New York jury yesterday that she had had an affair with her boss and that he had asked her to apply for company loans to cover his personal expenses.

title: Watch Out or You Might Get Rhymed in the Nose
description: The distracted camera in ''Interscope Presents: The Next Episode'' notices a dark, dangling air freshener and slants of light on heavy bags in a basement gym.

title: Ann Cornelisen, 77, Writer on Impoverished Southern Italy
description: Ann Cornelisen, an American expatriate writer who brought spry and steely language to her evocative books about the poverty-stricken South of Italy, died on Wednesday at her home in Rome, Ga. She was 77.

title: 'Etchings in Light' -- 'Talbot and Photogravure'
description: Hans P. Kraus Jr. Inc.

title: Japan's Economic Growth Tops Forecast for Quarter
description: Japan's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the third quarter, better than expected, as exports and capital spending continued to buoy the nearly two-year-long recovery.

title: New Threat to State Budget: Mandated Education Costs
description: For all the bitterness and discord of this year's legislative session in New York, next year's threatens to be worse as lawmakers struggle with a budget deficit of up to $6 billion while trying to comply with a court order to pump perhaps billions of new dollars into education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMAN, MARION
description: NEWMAN--Marion. November 12, 2003 at age 92. The backbone and inspiration of this family. Came to U.S. in 1920 from Zyradow, Poland at age 9. Wife of the late Morris. Mother of Harriet N. Cohen (Arthur Feinberg), Alvin Newman (Ruby), Molli Mezrich (Reuben), Sandra Newman (Jack Kerry). Grandmother of Martha Stine (Carl), Amy Ziegelbaum (Michael), Susan Hirsch (Bruce), Patricia Epstein (Steven), Jonathan Mezrich, Benjamin Mezrich, Joshua Mezrich (Gretchen Schwarze), Michael Newman (Elena Levine), Kurt Newman, Amy Newman. Great grandmother. She will be sorely missed. Funeral Friday November 14, 10:30AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11234 (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TITNER, HYMAN
description: TITNER -- Hyman. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Devoted father of Roberta Meyers and Lois Laskowitz. Loving grandfather of Shari, Amy, Warren and Mindi. Services Friday, 12 PM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapels, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers.

title: Rumsfeld, on Asia Tour, Hints Of Shifts in U.S. Forces There
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld opened a six-day tour of Asia and the Pacific on Thursday, hinting at substantial changes in how American forces are deployed in the region.

title: Russia Loses Fight Over Chechen's Extradition
description: A British judge on Thursday rejected a Russian request to extradite Akhmed Zakayev, a senior Chechen official, saying that he faced ''substantial risk'' of being tortured if he was returned to Moscow to stand trial on murder and kidnapping charges.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Youth Reigns in $11.4 Million Contemporary-Art Sale
description: A glass cabinet filled with animal skeletons, a pair of floor polishers encased in Plexiglas and a photograph of a cowboy were among the top five sellers at Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg's auction of contemporary art last night.

title: VIRBAC DELAYS RESULTS TO REVIEW ITS ACCOUNTING
description: The Virbac Corporation, a provider of health care products for pets, said it would delay reporting third-quarter results after its auditor questioned some accounting practices. Virbac fell $1.85, or 22 percent, to $6.50 a share. PricewaterhouseCoopers raised questions about some revenue recognition and inventory accounting practices. Virbac, which is based in Fort Worth, said in its 2002 financial regulatory filing that it recognizes revenue when ownership transfers at the time of shipment. It estimates sales reductions for returns in each period. In 2002, returns were $1.8 million on $63.8 million in net revenue. Virbac said it had retained outside counsel to conduct a review.

title: In Early Start to Season, Sloppy Play Abounds
description: The college basketball season started earlier than ever last night at Madison Square Garden and it showed.

title: Rain and Hail Deluge a Slice of the Los Angeles Basin
description: Some say the world will end in fire, some say in ice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, SEYMOUR
description: COHN--Seymour. With deep sorrow, the family announces the passing of Seymour Cohn. A friend to so many and looked up to by all those whose lives were touched by his boldness and imagination. Services will be held Sunday, November 16, 2003, 9AM, at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. 718-263-7600

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Held In Robbery Spree
description: Two men went on an hourlong crime spree in Brooklyn yesterday morning, robbing 12 people at 12 different locations before they were arrested, the police said. They said that the men, Carmine Carini, 22, and Joseph Opperisano, 23, began robbing victims on Pearson Street in Flatlands. An hour later, investigators said, they concluded with a final robbery at Avenue U and East 63rd Street, just seven blocks from where the holdups began. The police said the robbers stole more than $500 by driving up to victims, showing a machete and taking wallets and money. Mr. Carini and Mr. Opperisano, who both live in Brooklyn, were charged with robbery. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: 2 MUTUAL FUNDS MOVE TO ASSURE WARY INVESTORS
description: Trying to contain deepening investor mistrust, one large mutual fund company ousted its founders yesterday and another settled a securities fraud case brought against it only two weeks ago.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Grotta Azzurra got its name because it once had a blue grotto. Actually it was more of a basement, with blue stucco walls, that a 1948 dining guide called ''a cave of Isle-of-Capri classicism.'' Well, after nearly a century, the grotto is gone. The owners have decided to make the restaurant something more than a quaint artifact, and to signal their intentions, they have turned the grotto into a wine cellar and private dining room.

title: Reports Say AOL Sought Europe Deal
description: Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of Time Warner, has held preliminary discussions with executives of the T-Online division of Deutsche Telekom about a possible merger or joint venture involving Time Warner's America Online division, two company executives said yesterday.

title: 2 G.I.s Killed by Bomb; Drive Against Insurgents Goes On
description: Two American soldiers were killed and three were wounded when their convoy struck an improvised explosive device about 45 miles north of Baghdad, the United States military said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Tries to Defend Steroid Percentage
description: IF beauty is in the eye of the beholder, apparently steroid use is, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINERMAN, JOSEPH GEORGE
description: KLEINERMAN -- Joseph George. New York Road Runners founder, board member emeritus, coach, competitive runner, supporter of running, and beloved friend Joe Kleinerman died peacefully in his sleep on Tuesday, November 11, 2003 at age 91. He was the son of David and Rose Kleinerman and is survived by three nieces, Ruth, Martha, and Deena, and numerous grand-nieces and nephews. NYRR mourns Coach Joe's passing but celebrates his long, full life. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 A.M. on Friday, November 14, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Joe Kleinerman Scholarship Fund, C/O NYRR, 9 East 89th Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: TEARY BUT UNBOWED A tearful Imelda Marcos said that she loved her country and would never run away, as government lawyers tried to have the former first lady arrested for returning late from a foreign trip. Mrs. Marcos flew back to the Philippines from London on Wednesday, missing by 10 days a deadline set by a court that is trying her on corruption charges related to the two-decade rule of her husband, Ferdinand. The court had granted her a 30-day travel permit to visit the United States and Europe on medical and religious grounds, but some newspapers reported she had been spotted in Italy sipping wine in restaurants and shopping for luxury goods. "This has been the most harassed and stressful trip of my life," she told reporters after the 50-minute hearing. "I won't flee. I love my country." She is to return to court today.    (Reuters)

title: Seemingly Unrelated Movements, Joined in Kinetic Collage
description: Kindred artistic spirits were united on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater when Garth Fagan Dance presented the world premiere of Mr. Fagan's ''DancecollageforRomie.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Scores Left Homeless By Fire
description: More than 80 people were left homeless when a three-alarm fire, whipped by 50-mile-an-hour winds, destroyed an apartment house yesterday morning. Two firefighters suffered minor injuries. The fire started on an upper floor of the five-story building at 105 North Fifth Street and raced to the roof, said Thaddeus Kennedy, a Fire Department spokesman. The fire left the building uninhabitable, he said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sales Fall At Havas
description: The advertising company Havas said third-quarter sales fell 16 percent as clients cut spending and the dollar weakened against the euro. Sales fell to 373 million euros ($435 million) from 443 million euros in the period a year earlier. The company offered 50 million euros in cash to bondholders to waive an option for early repayment on 450 million euros of debt maturing in 2009. Alain de Pouzilhac, the chief executive, said the company expected higher sales, excluding the effect of currency factors, next year.

title: Saturdays Top Matchups
description: Texas Tech (7-3)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHRAGER, THERESA
description: SCHRAGER--Theresa (Babe) On November 13, 2003. Beloved mother of Hope and Martin. Loving ''Mommon'' of Gwen, Larry, Samantha, Rebecca, Gabrielle, Stephanie, and great-grandmother of Jessica, Michelle and Juliet. Services Friday 3PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Amsterdam Nursing Home, NYC.

title: Woman, 18, Is Found Strangled In a Bronx Apartment Building
description: An 18-year-old woman from upstate New York was found strangled yesterday morning in the stairwell of the Bronx apartment building where her sister lives, the police said.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: New On The DNA Front
description: Dr. J. Craig Venter, the scientist whose company decoded the human genome sequence, said he had developed a new technique for synthesizing DNA and used it to reconstitute the DNA of a virus that attacks bacteria. The new technique was better than existing methods, Dr. Venter said. A colleague, Dr. Hamilton Smith, said the new technique could probably be used, in combination with another method, to regenerate viable smallpox from the virus's published DNA sequence. They spoke at a news conference held by Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham, who speculated that someday synthesized microbes might generate hydrogen and remove carbon dioxide from the air. Nicholas Wade (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, ARNOLD
description: BERNSTEIN -- Arnold.
