The Board of Directors and Members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Arnold Bernstein, whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Steven M. Slaven, President Thomas W. Brock, Secretary

title: Woman Who Accused Paroled Killer of Beating Her Does Not Show Up at Hearing
description: The woman who accused Thomas Trantino, the paroled killer of two policemen, of beating her and then recanted failed to appear at a court hearing here Thursday on her domestic violence complaint against him.

title: Tricking an Elderly Bachelor Blinded by Youth and Beauty
description: With a dizzying 63 operas already under his belt, Donizetti knew what he was doing when he made it to ''Don Pasquale.'' Packed with memorable tunes, vividly drawn characters and the droll tribulations of its aging bachelor, the opera is the comic masterpiece among Donizetti's output, which was nearing its close when the work had its premiere in 1843.

title: Shopping List | Thanksgiving Table
description: PEOPLE with second homes can be forgiven their seasonal smugness. What better place than a rural setting to celebrate the nation's first native feast? Added inducements are expandable space, crisp air and, possibly, farm stands just down the road. As for nonedible supplies, give early thanks now for the merchants who are standing by, willing and eager to help set the table. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Manilow's Musical Shuts Down Production
description: ''Harmony,'' a Broadway-bound musical written by Barry Manilow and Bruce Sussman, unexpectedly shut down production yesterday morning after it became apparent that its producers were millions of dollars short of capitalizing the show.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Right-Wing Gunmen To Disarm
description: Hundreds of fighters from a right-wing paramilitary faction based in Medelln will begin disarming on Nov. 25, the first phase of what President lvaro Uribe's government hopes will be the complete demobilization of a paramilitary army responsible for thousands of deaths. Mr. Uribe's peace commissioner, Luis Carlos Restrepo, announced that fighters from the so-called Cacique Nutibara Bloc, one of several factions that make up the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, would be reincorporated into Colombian society with help from the government. The deal will be sure to set off criticism from rights groups and members of Congress who believe Mr. Uribe's government is overlooking vast rights abuses and offering sweetheart deals to entice the paramilitaries to disband. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Private Schools Gain in India
description: From slums to villages, the march to private education, once reserved for the elite, is on.

title: The N.H.L.'s First Inuit
description: Jordin Tootoo of the Nashville Predators hails from the recently formed Canadian territory of Nunavut.

title: Sold!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: ALLIANT ENERGY IS TOLD TO PAY $18.5 MILLION IN TAXES
description: Alliant Energy, a Wisconsin electric utility, must pay $18.5 million in federal taxes on the $90 million profit it made from a tax shelter, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in Chicago ruled yesterday. Alliant will get a refund of $12 million plus interest, not the more than $30 million it had sought. Alliant argued that the Internal Revenue Service had ''ambushed'' it by demanding taxes on $90 million of gross profits from the tax shelter, but the appeals court said the company's own statements showed that it knew it owed the tax. A trial court had thrown out the tax shelter, sold by the Twenty-First Securities Corporation, a New York firm that specializes in tax shelters, but the appeals court reinstated it.

title: Small Returns For Close Ties?
description: On the day last week when Gov. George E. Pataki stood in Iowa to defend President Bush's handling of Iraq, news came from Washington that the governor's full request for federal aid for the recent blackout would not be forthcoming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'TOOLE, THOMAS
description: O'TOOLE--Thomas. On Wednesday, November 12, 2003, at home in Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Mary Kate Cranston; loving father of Ryan O'Toole and Tom O'Toole, Owen O'Toole, Ellen Hubbard and Peter O'Toole; grandfather of Emily and Annie Hubbard. Also survived by his former wife, Vitaline O'Connell O'Toole. Friends may call at DeVol Funeral Home, 2222 Wisconsin Ave., NW, on Sunday from 2 to 5 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament, Western Avenue at Quesada Street on Monday, November 17, at 9:30 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: To Spot Today's Bidders Look for Prada and Fendi
description: Perhaps the biggest surprise of the two-week round of auctions that ended Thursday night was the emergence of a new breed of buyer: people in their 40's with new money made in world financial markets who have decided to put their extra cash into postwar and contemporary art.

title: Same Tactics, New Target
description: With the terrorist attack on Riyadh last week, which killed at least 17 people, the Saudis are finally experiencing the nightmare many other Arab and Muslim regimes have already lived through: the Islamist monster they created has turned against them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NITZBERG, JERRY
description: NITZBERG--Jerry. The Board of Directors, staff, and participants of AHRC NYC mourn the passing of Jerry Nitzberg. For many years, a mainstay of AHRC's vocational services, Jerry's commitment to the lives of the developmentally disabled was deep and will be missed. Farewell, Old Friend. Genevieve O'Neil, President Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director

title: It's a Long Way Down to Nashville
description: On a recent trip for the Nashville Predators, Jordin Tootoo, a rookie, spoke by telephone with his family. Their home is 200 miles south of the Arctic Circle. The veteran Jim McKenzie, his roommate and mentor, recalled Tootoo's report.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit At Insurer
description: The Dutch insurance and banking concern ING reported a 3.8 percent increase in its third-quarter profit, to 977 million euros ($1.15 billion) from the year-earlier period. ING earned 941 million in the third quarter of 2002, but that included 200 million euros in capital gains from the sale of investments. Excluding those gains, ING's third-quarter profit this year was up 32 percent. Income at the banking division, which includes its Internet bank ING Direct, more than doubled to 399 million euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's current visit to Asia misstated his recent travel history. He had previously visited several parts of Asia since joining the present Bush administration. This is not his first trip there.

title: Skirts, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WEIRTON STEEL CORP., Wheeling, W. Va., a bankrupt steel maker, may proceed with its reorganization plan, a bankruptcy judge ruled. The ruling was a step toward the company's planned emergence from bankruptcy protection.

title: Second Day of Potent Winds Brings More Power Problems
description: A second day of high winds across the New York region continued to bedevil utility companies, as work crews hustled to repair downed power lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADEL, CHARLOTTE F.
description: NADEL--Charlotte F. Died peacefully on November 13 in her 100th year. She was the wife of the late Benjamin Nadel and is survived by her sons, Lawrence, Norman and Joshua, by six grandchildren, Charles, Brian, Melissa, Victoria, Dan and Etyan, and seven great-grandchildren, Emily, Graham, Nicole, Peter, Jamie, Brendan and Lauren. She brought brightness to all she encountered and her gentle dignity will be missed. Services 10AM Sunday, at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: A political brawl rages at Acadmie Franaise
description: PARIS:  A bitter political fight has broken out at the pinnacle of the French literary world over whether Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former French president, is an acceptable choice for the Academie Francaise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, RUTH F.
description: MILLER--Ruth F. Of Tucson, AZ. Beloved wife of Earl Darwin passed away on Sunday, November 9, 2003 at home surrounded by her children, David Miller, Andrew Miller, Phillip Miller and Emily Keeler. She also leaves four grandchildren. A memorial service planned for Sunday, November 23, 2003, 2 P.M. at Congregation Anshei Israel, Epstein Chapel, 5550 E. 5th Street, Tucson, AZ.

title: About New York; To Buy or Pry, A Chance to See Lives in Storage
description: A LOT of stuff in here!'' the auctioneer calls out, trying his singsong best to conjure up luster for the contents of self-storage compartment No. 0104. But the words do not exist that could gild these ordinary remnants of someone else's life: the car battery, the damaged headboard, the bag of clothing.

title: Lottery Numbers
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fidel's Triumph on Capitol Hill
description: In the debate over how to export American values to Cuba, Congressional leaders have managed to import some of Fidel Castro's values. That old tyrant in Havana is the prime beneficiary of the decision this week to drop a measure that would have effectively lifted the ban on travel to Cuba. He can now go on railing against Yankee imperialism, trying to pin the blame for all of his regime's shortcomings and brutality on American sanctions.

title: Clark's First Televised Ad To Highlight War Record
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark's campaign is set to broadcast the first of its television advertisements on Tuesday with a minute-long spot that highlights his combat record and his term as the NATO supreme allied commander.

title: The Neediest Cases; Bringing Nature's Bounty Closer to Tables in the City
description: Lucille Abrego likes to eat the old-fashioned way: by preparing meals in her own kitchen, new or trusted recipes at hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAGLIANO, ALEXANDER MARINO
description: VAGLIANO--Alexander Marino died at home in Norfolk, CT on Thursday, November 13, 2003 of complications of diabetes. In a varied and distinguished career, Mr. Vagliano was Executive Vice-President of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co., a director in the Agency for International Development and a gentleman sheep farmer. He is survived by his wife, Sara Ector Vagliano, children Barbara, Andre and Justin Vagliano, step-son Dan Via, sister Lally Segard and 5 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Norfolk Library on the Village Green in Norfolk, CT at 3PM on Saturday, December 6. Memorial gifts may be made to the Norfolk Library, Norfolk, CT 06058 or to Foothills Visiting Nurse & Home Care, 32 Union Street, Winsted, CT 06098. The family will also receive friends in New York at a later date.

title: Retail Sales Decline 0.3%; Industrial Output Rises 0.2%
description: Total sales at retailers fell 0.3 percent in October, and industrial production increased 0.2 percent. Also, October's Producer Price Index rose 0.8 percent, more than forecast, and consumer confidence jumped this month -- all according to reports issued yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about ''Grand Old Party'' by Lewis L. Gould, misstated a word in the title of a work by Thomas Wolfe about the forgettable qualities of 19th-century Republican presidents, with the exception of Lincoln. It is ''From Death to Morning,'' not ''Mourning.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Schools Chief Decides To Retire
description: The schools superintendent of the District of Columbia, Paul L. Vance, 73, announced that he would retire at the end of the year. He said he had not been asked to step down, but cited no reason for his departure. Washington schools have faced budget problems during his tenure, and city officials, residents and Congress have engaged in a sharp debate over a voucher plan this year. John Files (NYT)

title: Mets Surprised by Piazza's Reported Request
description: The Mets were taken aback yesterday by published reports that Mike Piazza, unhappy over the team's direction and his own impending move to first base, was willing to be traded to an American League team, where he could continue as a catcher and serve as a designated hitter.

title: Canadian Pharmacy Regulators Seek to Stop Exports
description: Canadian pharmacy regulators have asked the government in Ottawa to ban exports of prescription drugs to the United States, joining a widening drive by drug manufacturers and their supporters to curtail Americans' access to cheaper foreign medications.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the leeway that companies have in financing their pension funds referred incompletely to the response by CNF Inc., a freight and logistics company, to a lawsuit filed by a group of retirees who had worked for the company and for Consolidated Freightways, a division that was spun off. While CNF declined to discuss the suit for the article, it did file a motion to dismiss the case on Sept. 22. The motion said that CNF had no fiduciary duty to the retirees or their pension fund after the spinoff.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Expects Loss
description: The Japan Airlines System Corporation lost 58 billion yen ($524 million) in the first half of the fiscal year, twice as much as expected, because of higher fuel costs and reduced travel as a result of the war in Iraq and the spread of the SARS virus. The airline said that it expected to lose 65 billion yen in the full year, which ends in March.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Expects Loss
description: The bank Resona Holdings Inc., which was effectively nationalized by the Japanese government, expects to lose 1.71 trillion yen ($15.6 billion) in the year to next March as it writes off the bulk of its nonperforming loans. The company also said it planned to cut 4,000 more jobs. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hollinger Says Filings Had Inaccuracies
description: Hollinger International, publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, disclosed Friday that a committee of independent directors looking into its corporate governance practices had found inaccuracies in some regulatory filings. It said the filings were related to payments made to Conrad Black, the controlling shareholder, and his partners.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Insurer Names Executive
description: The Nordic insurer, Skandia, named Hans-Erik Andersson as chief executive to lead efforts to revive earnings and restore investor confidence after some of the company's business practices were criticized. Mr. Andersson, 53, is the chairman of the Nordic business of the Marsh & McLennan Companies and will take the helm at Skandia on Jan. 1. He will replace Leif Victorin, who was named interim chief executive after Lars-Eric Petersson was fired in April, Skandia said.

title: A Houston On the Hudson?
description: Houston is the only large American city with no zoning, and no ground rules to guide development. Because architects there have complete freedom, the view of the skyline is a tour of architectural egos. As a result, they have assembled half an ark: one building of every kind. At the street level, the iconic towers sit in empty plazas, silent about their neighbors and the city around them.

title: Bitter Senators Divided Anew On Judgeships
description: Senate Democrats used filibusters on Friday to block three of President Bush's judicial nominees, two of them for the first time, immediately after nearly 40 hours of debate in which Republicans complained about how the Democrats had been rejecting Mr. Bush's candidates for the bench.

title: Swords Into Plowshares
description: I've been waiting for one of the trailing Democratic presidential candidates to give the following speech. Since none have, I'm offering it to them, free of charge:

title: Israel, Saudi Arabia And Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Reassert Control Over Their Neighbor
description: In a rivalry game usually dominated by one team or the other, nine miles has seldom seemed so short a distance and the Hudson River has seldom appeared so narrow a border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIDOFF, GERALD
description: WIDOFF--Gerald. Maverick Concerts mourns the loss of Board Member and former Chairman, Gerald Widoff. His participation in the evolution of Maverick Concerts was invaluable. He was a brilliant human being and artist, an inspiration to his family and loved ones. The classical music realm is diminished immeasurably.

title: Modest Goals For Meeting On Free Trade
description: After the collapse of global trade talks in Cancn, Mexico, trade ministers gathering in Miami on Sunday to discuss creating a free trade area for the Americas have scaled back their ambitions, hoping to avoid another debacle.

title: Our Ancestors' Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors Seek Unusual Appeal
description: Federal prosecutors will seek to reinstate the insider-trading conviction of John Cassese, co-founder of the Computer Horizons Corporation, a Mountain Lakes, N.J., seller of computer staffing and services.

title: Corrections
description: The Floyd Norris column in Business Day yesterday, about Gary L. Pilgrim, who was ousted from the company he helped found, PBHG Funds, misstated the given name of the other founder in some copies. He is Harold J. Baxter, not Frank.

title: Newark Sets Out Plan for 'Urban Village'
description: City officials on Friday presented a $550 million redevelopment plan to include an ''urban village'' in a sagging section of the city's downtown, although the proposed arena for the Nets and the Devils that would be its northern anchor and premier attraction remains in limbo.

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review in Weekend yesterday about the design for the new building of the New Museum of Contemporary Art on the Bowery in Manhattan misspelled the name of the Tokyo firm that designed it. It is Sanaa, not Saana.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Posts Profit
description: The insurance company Allianz reported a profit of 372 million euros ($438 million) for the third quarter, despite a loss at Dresdner, its banking unit. The Allianz results were helped by a 2.2 percent increase in premium income to 13.9 billion euros. A year earlier, Allianz posted a loss of 2.5 billion euros.

title: Freddie Mac Narrows List For New Chief
description: The field is beginning to narrow in Freddie Mac's search for a chief executive.

title: Miller Denies Aide's Claim Of a Bid For City Hall
description: As e-mail messages go, it sounded innocent enough: Council Speaker Gifford Miller was looking to hire a communications director, and possibly a press secretary, as he prepared to make a run for mayor in 2005.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, HOWARD A.
description: BERNSTEIN--Howard A. Lovingly remembering you on your birthday. In our hearts forever. Our Family

title: Officials Say Saks Has Picked Its Next Chief
description: Fred Wilson, the chief executive at Donna Karan International, will take over as the new head of the Saks Fifth Avenue chain, according to executives involved in the move.

title: Ex-Warnaco Chief Settles Fraud Suit
description: Linda Wachner, the former chief executive of the Warnaco Group, and two other officials have agreed to pay $12.85 million to settle a lawsuit accusing them of defrauding investors, lawyers said yesterday.

title: President of Georgia Pleads For Calm as Protests Grow
description: A postelection standoff erupted into turmoil in Georgia on Friday as thousands of antigovernment protesters filled the streets, surrounding the presidential compound as truckloads of soldiers stood by.

title: Westchester Budget Seeks Layoffs and Property Tax Rise
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, unveiled his proposed 2004 budget today, in which he calls for laying off 236 employees while raising the county property tax by only 2 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about former City Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler's conviction on fraud charges misstated a related charge of which he was acquitted. It was possession of a forged instrument, not offering false documents for filing. The article also misstated the number of years in prison he faces at sentencing. It is up to four, not up to seven. A prosecutor's given name was also misstated. He is Daniel Cort, not David.

title: TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: Texas Tech (7-3) at 6 Texas (8-2)

title: Grace Creditors Ask Judge To Step Aside Over Advisers
description: Bankruptcy proceedings for companies struggling under a wave of asbestos claims grew even more convoluted yesterday when a group of creditors in one case asked the presiding judge to step down because of potential conflicts of interest involving his advisers.

title: The President and Our War Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Briefing: OLYMPICS; Salt Lake Witness Granted Immunity
description: Rod Hamson, a key government witness in the Olympic bribery trial in Salt Lake City, was granted immunity from federal prosecution yesterday, two days after he suggested during cross-examination that he had sought reimbursement from the Salt Lake Bid Committee for expenses he apparently did not incur.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: First Nuclear Plant Shut
description: In a first step to phase out atomic power in Germany, a 32-year-old nuclear plant in the northern city of Stade was disconnected from the grid, the Environment Ministry said. The plant will be dismantled starting in 2005, after spent nuclear fuel rods are removed and sent to France for reprocessing. Demolition work is expected to last up to 12 years. The country's 18 remaining nuclear plants are to be closed over the next two decades under an accord between power utilities and the government. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Joy, and Jeers, As New Police Patrol Baghdad
description: Tires squealing, sirens wailing and adrenaline pumping madly, dozens of Iraqi police officers charged through central Baghdad to take back their city from bandits.

title: General Managers Meet, But Do Little Dealing
description: Several of baseball's 30 general managers scurried out of the Arizona Biltmore Resort and Spa on Friday as if they had an airplane to catch. Many of them did. Virtually all of them were hustling to the airport after five days of meetings, which included plenty of discussions but flimsy results.

title: A 'New' Palestinian Authority
description: A year and a half after President Bush demanded that the Palestinians remove Yasir Arafat from power, a new Palestinian government has now been installed and its unchallenged leader is . . . Yasir Arafat. Despite weeks of trying, the new prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, was unable to wrest control of the key security services from Mr. Arafat. This is a tragic failure. As long as Mr. Arafat remains at the top of the Palestinian Authority, it will view violence as a legitimate political tool.

title: 15-Year-Old Gets a Jail Term In an Unsuccessful Carjacking
description: The youngest of three heavily armed teenagers who the police say were arrested before they could go on a suburban shooting rampage in July was sentenced on Friday to four years in prison.

title: India's Poor Bet Precious Sums on Private Schools
description: In this democracy of more than one billion people, an educational revolution is under way, its telltale signs the small children everywhere in uniforms and ties. From slums to villages, the march to private education, once reserved for the elite, is on.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm not going to fight with one hand tied behind my back. I don't believe in unilateral disarmament.''

title: Exxon Is Ordered to Pay $11.9 Billion to Alabama
description: A jury in Alabama ordered the Exxon Mobil Corporation yesterday to pay the state $11.9 billion for depriving it of proper royalties on the natural gas the company gathers there.

title: 4 Israeli Ex-Security Chiefs Denounce Sharon's Hard Line
description: In a joint interview published Friday, four former heads of the Shin Bet security service delivered a blistering collective criticism of Israel's tough military policies toward the Palestinians, saying Israel urgently needed a political solution to the Middle East conflict.

title: ALLIED WASTE TO SELL BUSINESSES FOR $120 MILLION
description: Allied Waste Industries, the trash hauler, agreed to sell businesses in northern and central Florida to Capital Environmental Resource Inc. for $120 million to trim debt. The businesses are in Tampa, Sarasota and Jacksonville and had 2002 net income of $11.1 million from 233,000 residential customers and 14,500 business customers, Capital Environmental said. Allied, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., previously shed or agreed to sell at least $113 million in assets this year as part of a plan to raise $300 million to improve its balance sheet. Capital Environmental is based in Burlington, Ontario.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Family Reunion
description: Prince Edward, his wife, Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, and their newly born but not-yet-named daughter were reunited for the first time after the child was born prematurely on Nov. 8 and taken to an intensive care unit 35 miles away. Edward, 39, the third son and youngest child of Queen Elizabeth II, said it was a ''day of great relief and joy.'' Sophie, 38, is recovering from an emergency Caesarean section. The prince did not say when she and their daughter would leave the hospital. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: 9/11 Suspect Loses Ruling

title: Kerry, Following Dean, Rejects Public Financing for Primaries
description: Senator John Kerry on Friday became the second Democratic candidate to reject public financing for the presidential primaries, a move that will free him from spending limits and allow him to inject more of his personal money into the race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINUS, BRUCE C.
description: MINUS--Bruce C. Of The Bronx, N.Y., on November 9, 2003. Beloved father of Clifton C. Wynter, Sr. of New York City, Shonie Minus Crighead of Wilmington, DE., Maria Minus of West Palm Beach, FL., Stephanie Minus Taylor of Nassau, Bahamas & Donnamae Minus also of the Bahamas. Also survived by seven stepchildren, 33 grandchildren, 41 great grandchildren and cherished nieces and nephews. Treasured friend to many. Wake Monday, November 17th, 4-8PM at John H. Joyce Funeral Home, 2332 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvd. at 137 St. Service Tuesday, November 18th, 10AM, Trinity Methodist Church, corner 166 St and Washington Ave, Bronx. Interment Rose Hill Mausoleums, Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Make Home Schooling Safe for Children
description: When the authorities in a small New Jersey town discovered four starved boys, so frail that they resembled concentration camp victims from World War II, Americans everywhere wondered how their condition had gone unnoticed by people outside their family for so long. Part of the answer was that they had been home-schooled, and New Jersey is one of a number of states that provide no supervision over parents who decide to keep their offspring out of the public and private school systems.

title: Washington Journal; His Conservative Connections Help to Put Novelist on Best-Seller List
description: This is a Washington success story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASANOVA, LORENZO
description: CASANOVA--Lorenzo, Attorney at Law on November 13, 2003 at age 70. He was engaged in practice of law in Jackson Heights until his death. Survived by his wife Ana, his daughter Dianna (Dr. Nazar) Sayegh, his son Marc and two grandchildren, three brothers Luis, Miguel, and Rafael, two sisters Sara and Hilda. Memorial services on Sunday, November 23 from 14 PM at the Polish Community Center, 92 Waverly St, Yonkers (Yonkers and Nepperhan Ave). Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: With Colts Up Next, Jets Strive to Stay Focused
description: A 3-6 team has virtually no margin for error, especially when it plays on Sunday against the 7-2 Colts in the claustrophobic RCA Dome.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STEINKOLER, ALEX
description: STEINKOLER--Alex. 11/15/02 Always loved, Always cherished. Your family

title: 3 Brokers Face Sanctions on Fund Discounts
description: The American Express Company, the Wachovia Corporation and Legg Mason Inc. said yesterday that they faced federal sanctions for not passing volume discounts to some large mutual fund clients.

title: Going at the Changes In, Ya Know, English
description: On Dec. 8, 1941, the day after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Representative Charles A. Eaton, Republican of New Jersey, made his case in the House for why the nation should enter the Second World War.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's current visit to Asia misstated his recent travel history. He had previously visited several parts of Asia since joining the present Bush administration. This is not his first trip there.

title: Overhaul Has Led to Chaos, Principals' Union Charges
description: The president of the school principals' union charged yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's efforts to overhaul the schools had caused chaos, with special education students particularly endangered by poor record keeping and communication.

title: A.I.G. SAYS RULE CHANGE WILL COST $200 MILLION
description: The American International Group said yesterday that a new accounting rule dealing with life insurance benefits would reduce its first-quarter profit by about $200 million. The new standard adopted by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants requires life insurers to establish reserves to pay death benefits and other guarantees on variable annuities and variable life insurance, where clients' premiums are invested in mutual funds. The rule, effective Jan. 1, will ''require A.I.G. to recognize a liability for guaranteed minimum death benefits and other living benefits related to its variable annuity and variable life contracts,'' according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The charge is ''not material to A.I.G.'s financial condition or liquidity,'' the filing said.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Spare Times column in some copies of Weekend yesterday about a walking tour of Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, leaving from the main gate at Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, misstated the date. It is tomorrow at 1 p.m., not today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDINER, KATHARINE HONE EMMET BRAMWELL
description: GARDINER--Katharine Hone Emmet Bramwell, died peacefully August 18, 2003 in Princeton, NJ, aged 88. Daughter of Helen (Auerbach) and Herman LeRoy Emmet, and a descendant of both New York's Mayor Philip Hone and NY State's Attorney General Thomas Addis Emmet, Kate leaves her wonderful husband, Henry Gardiner of Quogue, NY, daughter Heidi Bramwell Humes, granddaughters Julia Emmet Bramwell Frick, Heidi Hamilton Kerko and Helena Humes Martin, and one greatgrandson, Henry Wilder Martin. Kate was the sister of Lydia Emmet Williams of Cleveland, and the late Anne Emmet Aaron, Helena Emmet Tredway and Herman LeRoy Emmet Jr. Kate's first husband of almost 50 years, Gerald Ames Bramwell, and two of their children, Katharine Bramwell Hamilton and Gerald Ames Bramwell Jr. predeceased her. Known by her family and many friends for her enthusiasm, intelligence, range of interests and generosity, Kate graduated from St. Timothy's as a proud member of the Spider team, and attended Smith College before marrying in 1934. An early advocate of natural products and organic farming, Kate was also a devoted bird watcher who created a bird sanctuary behind her Princeton, NJ house (which she later donated to the YWCA). An adventurous traveler and opera lover, she was a Board member and supporter of many organizations, including the North Country School in Lake Placid, NY. A proud and involved member of the Emmet family, Kate was our historian, collector of artifacts and raconteur. Her warm and vital presence will be deeply missed by those lucky enough to have known and loved her. Contributions in Kate's honor may be made to the North Country School, PO Box 187, Lake Placid, NY 12946. A memorial service will be held on Memorial Day weekend 2004 in Keene Valley, New York.

title: The President and Our War Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Twas the Month Before Christmas
description: Christmas, it seems, has come earlier than ever to New York. It is 12 days before Thanksgiving, and Macy's windows glitter with gift boxes, Starbucks employees are donning tinsel halos and the tree at Rockefeller Center is already standing.

title: The Wal-Martization of America
description: The 70,000 grocery workers on strike in Southern California are the front line in a battle to prevent middle-class service jobs from turning into poverty-level ones. The supermarkets say they are forced to lower their labor costs to compete with Wal-Mart, a nonunion, low-wage employer aggressively moving into the grocery business. Everyone should be concerned about this fight. It is, at bottom, about the ability of retail workers to earn wages that keep their families out of poverty.

title: The President and Our War Dead (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: EUROPEAN WARNING The European Union will withhold $469 million in aid promised for Ivory Coast's rebuilding until combatants in the civil war comply with a stalled peace accord, the European Commission president, Romano Prodi, said. He insisted that the accord signed in January had to be fully implemented before the money would be distributed. "The money is on the table," Mr. Prodi said. "We're waiting for the country to make progress. We have no sticks, only carrots." (AP)

title: Berlioz's Maverick Music, Extremes and All
description: Berlioz sounds more accessible than he is. The man -- whose 200th birthday this year is being celebrated with much fanfare and many concerts -- wrote strange music. Lovely? Yes. Richly melodic in places, it pours forth torrents of feeling. But somehow you don't often leave the hall humming his tunes. It is music that resists easy apprehension. And it sounds like nobody else's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINHAUS, ESTHER
description: KLEINHAUS -- Esther. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our dear, longtime member. Funeral Sunday, November 16th at noon, Gutterman's, Rockville Centre. May the bereaved family find solace and consolation amongst all mourners in Israel. Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi Joel M. Greenberg, Pres.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Xerox Settles Dispute Over Pension Benefits

title: Report Finds No Violations At Pentagon By Adviser
description: The Pentagon's inspector general concluded this week that Richard N. Perle violated no ethics laws or rules when he was leading an influential Pentagon advisory board while at the same timerepresenting two companies in their dealings with the government.

title: Problems Disclosed In Funds at Schwab
description: Charles Schwab said that it had uncovered evidence of improper mutual fund trading in both its supermarket of funds and a fund family of a subsidiary, U.S. Trust.

title: A Heavily Mortgaged Montage by Handel
description: Such a premium is put on originality these days that copying is stigmatized as plagiarism, and the idea that Handel borrowed music liberally, both from himself and from other composers, is viewed as a denigration. But in his day, borrowing was perfectly legitimate -- even to the extent of stitching together an entire opera out of music that had already been written.

title: An Old Band, by No Means Faded Away
description: Bands popular in America grow slack when they lose their primary function and begin touring the secondary circuits: nostalgia shows, theme parks, tourist events. You just don't expect a spinoff of a famous old band to be much more than an aide-memoire for aging fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONARD, EASON H.
description: LEONARD--Eason H. The partners of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners mourn the passing of Eason H. Leonard, founding partner of I.M. Pei & Partners and friend and colleague of 50 years, on November 13th, 2003. A Memorial Service will be held on December 6th, 2003 in Carmel, CA.

title: Face of Mideast Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; No Hope for the Knicks Is Understandable; Little Interest in the Nets Is Not
description: I'M amazed at how many fans in New York City and throughout the state still hold out hope for the Knicks. They'll walk up to me and ask one of two questions: ''What's up with the Knicks?'' or ''Any hope for the Knicks?''

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about preliminary talks on a merger or joint venture between the America Online division of Time Warner and the T-Online unit of Deutsche Telekom referred incorrectly to the disussions. While the parent companies held talks, according to executives briefed on the matter, Time Warner did not seek a deal.

title: 2 Microsoft Competitors Address Antitrust Hearing in Europe
description: Sun Microsystems and Real Networks, two companies that have the most to gain if European Union regulators force Microsoft to change the way that it operates, presented their arguments on the third and final day of a closed hearing in the antitrust proceedings Friday.

title: Qaeda Pawn, U.S. Calls Him. Victim, He Calls Himself.
description: MAHER ARAR has been back from Syria for five weeks now, with his wife and two children in their simple apartment, earnestly pleading to all who will listen that he is an innocent casualty of the Bush administration's war on terror.

title: West Virginia Bracing For the Backyard Brawl
description: The last time West Virginia won a big football game at home, David Hardesty, the university president, waited for a recording of John Denver's ''Take Me Home, Country Roads'' to be played.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen Cuts Spending Plan
description: Volkswagen said that it had reduced its capital spending plans for the next five years by 11 percent. The company, based in Wolfsburg, said that the reduction, to 41.6 billion euros ($49 billion), was a result of weak global demand but would not affect the introduction of new models.

title: Understanding Indonesia, By Its Leaders and Its Gossip
description: INDONESIAN DESTINIES

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At Broadcaster
description: British Sky Broadcasting said it earned 90 million ($152 million) in the three months that ended Sept. 30, versus break-even a year ago. The company's revenues rose 17 percent. In its annual shareholder meeting, the company chairman, Rupert Murdoch, said a committee would review BSkyB's corporate governance as a result of criticism of the appointment of his son James to be chief executive. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Automaker Upgrade Possible
description: Moody's Investors Service is considering upgrading the credit ratings of Nissan Motor. Moody's, which now rates Nissan's credit at Baa3, cited improved cash flow and more efficient operations.

title: Irving Richards, 96, Distributor of Modern Design
description: Irving Richards, an entrepreneur who helped take modern design to the dinner table, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

title: A Fuji a Day Keeps Granny Smith Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Stories of Love and Loss, to a Latin Beat
description: The time: the 1920's. The place: Buenos Aires. Late at night in the smoky light swirling through the dance hall of a brothel, hardened women strike angular poses on the wooden chairs, their dresses sometimes rising or falling away to reveal the bare flesh of the gartered thighs above their hose. Beneath black fedoras, men in tight dark suits and open-collared white shirts, occasional flashes of blood-red scarves at their throats, slouch in. The unmistakable sound of the accordionlike bandoneon propels the music of Astor Piazzolla.

title: Time Limits for Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, ALVIN H., M.D.
description: WEINER--Alvin H., M.D. Beloved husband of Norma. Cherished father of Dr. Alison Weiner and Robert Solomon, Dr. Kevin and Lauren Weiner. Loving grandfather of Sara Solomon and Ryan Weiner. Reposing at Midwood Chapels, Coney Island Avenue and Avenue M, Brooklyn, NY. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM. Funeral services Sunday 10:30 AM. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Stewart Lawyers Attack Basis of U.S. Case
description: Martha Stewart should not be charged with securities fraud, her lawyers argued in a brief filed in United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday, because the statements she is accused of making that are the basis for the charge ''were immaterial as a matter of law.''

title: St. Joseph's and Gonzaga Have a Grand Finale
description: Jameer Nelson struggled with the decision for months, hearing the enticing call of the N.B.A. last summer. But in his head he heard a deafening roar that drowned out the whispers of cash and fame. Nelson returned to St. Joseph's for his senior season, and last night, he heard all the reasons explaining his return.

title: Two Sides in B.C.S. Dispute Set to Meet
description: University presidents will meet in New Orleans tomorrow to discuss whether they can agree on a framework to give teams from less prominent conferences more access to the college football Bowl Championship Series.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Profit For Finance Group
description: The financial services group Macquarie Bank reported that profit rose 32 percent, to 242 million Australian dollars ($174 million) in the six-month period through September. Assets under management rose 21 percent, to 56.7 billion Australian dollars, mainly because of growth in funds that invest in international utilities like airports and rail and water service. The managing director, Allan Moss, said that profit in the second half of the fiscal year, which ends in March, could decline.

title: A Scary Afghan Road
description: Here's a foreign affairs quiz:

title: AT&T WIRELESS INCREASES PLANNED JOB CUTS TO 1,900
description: AT&T Wireless Services Inc., the cellphone carrier, increased its planned job cuts to 1,900 from 1,500 as it seeks to reduce costs and increase profit. The cuts, about 6.1 percent of the work force, will come mainly through layoffs, AT&T Wireless said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. About 800 workers had left as of Sept. 30. The rest will depart by the end of next year, the company said in the filing. AT&T Wireless, which is based in Redmond, Wash., is relying on cost cuts to increase earnings as sales and subscriber growth slow.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Convicted Spy Loses Bid To Appeal Sentence
description: A federal judge has rejected requests by Jonathan J. Pollard, an American convicted of spying for Israel, to appeal his life sentence and allow his lawyers to review classified government documents related to his effort for clemency. The judge, Thomas F. Hogan of Federal District Court in Washington, ruled that Mr. Pollard's lawyers had provided no compelling reason for access to sealed intelligence documents. Lawyers for Mr. Pollard argued that he had received ineffective counsel and that the government had broken an agreement to seek a more lenient sentence. Mr. Pollard pleaded guilty in 1987 and was sentenced to life in prison. John Files (NYT)

title: A Sketch of Arab-Americans; Survey Touches Off Disputes Over Who Should Study Whom
description: When researchers decided to survey attitudes, values and the impact of Sept. 11 among 1,000 Arab-Americans in the Detroit area, they saw their study as a groundbreaking attempt to accurately portray a community that felt stereotyped and under siege.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILMARTIN, MARY D.
description: GILMARTIN--Mary D. Mary Doris Gilmartin, 83, of Vero Beach, died unexpectedly November 12, 2003. Loving wife of Roger T. Gilmartin (deceased) for 56 years. Surviving are her sons Thomas D. Gilmartin and Roger A. Gilmartin; daughter, Molly Gilmartin, Christin Gilmartin and Carol Gilmartin; and six grandchildren. Contributions can be to St. Joseph's College, Office of Institutional Advancement, 245 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11205 in her memory.

title: Lawyers Paint Two Pictures Of a '99 Killing in Brooklyn
description: The police officers who shot Gidone Busch to death on a Borough Park sidewalk four years ago were protecting themselves from a man lunging at them with a hammer, a lawyer for the city told jurors yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, SEYMOUR
description: COHN--Seymour. With deep sorrow, the family announces the passing of Seymour Cohn. A friend to so many and looked up to by all those whose lives were touched by his boldness and imagination. Services will be held Sunday, November 16, 2003, 9AM, at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. 718-263-7600

description: To the Editor:

title: For an Ancient Afghan Town, No End to War, With Rival Generals Now Clashing
description: For the people of this ancient, sleepy town, more than 20 years of war and insecurity have still not ended.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with a Sports of The Times column yesterday about the drug testing policies of major professional leagues misstated the policy of the National Basketball Association. The N.B.A. does indeed ban the use of androstenedione and conduct regular tests and random tests for it.

title: Giants Exploring Ways To Add Third Tight End
description: The Giants, who lost Jeremy Shockey to a knee injury, have not relished the idea of playing the Eagles in Philadelphia tomorrow with only two tight ends on their roster. So they will take until the 4 p.m. deadline today to figure out how to avoid it.

title: Soliloquies In Sound Bites From 44 B.C.
description: We live in a media maelstrom, and the Moonwork theater company's ''Julius Caesar'' comes hurtling toward us right from its center. This production, at the Connelly Theater in the East Village through Nov. 23, is set in the here and now. Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar'' is about politics, rhetoric and power; about manipulation of a nation's image and its people; about conspiracy, murder and the war that leads to a new regime. What play is better suited for our times?

title: U.S. Mideast Chief Summons Generals to Strategy Meeting
description: The head of American forces in the Middle East has summoned his senior commanders to a meeting in Tampa, Fla., next week to discuss strategy for combating the guerrilla fighters in Iraq and terrorists from Al Qaeda in Afghanistan.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 397 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Texas Christian Could Bowl Over B.C.S. Barrier
description: Not everything is big in Texas. Texas Christian University has an enrollment of 8,200 students, plays in a small-time football conference (Conference USA) and is named for a tiny amphibian called a horned frog that is all of three to five inches. The only thing big about T.C.U. is its aspirations.

title: Sports Briefing
description: HOCKEY

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Linda C. Quinn, a former official at the Securities and Exchange Commission, omitted a survivor. In addition to her brother, Michael, Ms. Quinn is survived by her father, E. John Quinn, of Amenia, N.Y.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Peas Plot
description: Until they were captured in Ireland in 1940, three Nazi saboteurs planned to attack Buckingham Palace with homemade explosives packed in cans of processed peas from France, according to newly declassified files from MI5, Britain's domestic intelligence agency. The plan by the men, two Germans and an Indian, failed as soon as their boat landed on the southwestern Irish coast and they asked a resident to take them to the Irish Republican Army. They were taken to the police instead. The MI5 documents say the plot seemed ''rather fantastic'' since their explosives were ''of the most primitive kind.'' Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: No Wiggle Room in a Window War; State's New Building Code Collides With Amish Tradition
description: In the unyielding world of the Old Order Amish, very little changes, not the horse and buggy they ride in, not the capes and bonnets they wear.

title: Emerging technology portends using fixed lines, worldwide : Cheaper cellphone calls on horizon
description: PARIS:  New technology being evaluated by phone operators in Europe, Asia and the United States promises to achieve what regulators and competition have so far failed to do: drastically reduce mobile phone bills.

title: A Fuji a Day Keeps Granny Smith Away (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Magic of an Era Is Going, Going, Gone
description: NEAR the end of Billy Crystal's HBO film, ''61*,'' the actress who plays Pat Maris watches on television as Mark McGwire breaks her husband's 37-year-old home run record and makes a dash across the decades, to the box seats behind first base, to the waiting arms of Roger Maris's sons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIDWELL, KATHARINE TUDOR O'NEIL
description: BIDWELL--Katharine Tudor O'Neil, of New York, NY and Fishers Island, NY on November 13, 2003, an amazing mother, wife and grandmother. She devoted her life to her family and to education and music. Her memory will be a beacon for her family and friends. Funeral Services Thursday, November 20th, 1 P.M., at St. Thomas Church, One West 53rd St., Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Katharine Bidwell Foundation for Young Singers C/O Rosemary McGunnigle, Thelen Reid & Priest LLP, 875 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022 would be appreciated.

title: Israel, Saudi Arabia and Anti-Semitism (4 Letters)

title: 'Wonderful Town' Star to Miss Two Evenings
description: Donna Murphy, the star of the first Broadway revival of ''Wonderful Town,'' the 1953 classic musical with a score by Leonard Bernstein and lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, will sit out two preview performances this weekend while she recovers from the flu.

title: Israel, Saudi Arabia And Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Bars 9/11 Suspect From Being Own Lawyer
description: A judge on Friday barred the terrorism suspect Zacarias Moussaoui from continuing to represent himself in court, saying he had repeatedly violated her orders by filing court papers that were ''frivolous, scandalous, disrespectful or repetitive.''

title: A Merchant Marine Cadet Is Killed While Subway Surfing
description: In the second subway-surfing death in a month, a merchant marine cadet riding on top of a train in the Bronx was killed early yesterday morning when a steel girder fractured his skull in the darkness. A second cadet was critically injured.

title: For Iowa Party Boss, a Time of Little Rest and Much to Do
description: Gordon R. Fischer, the Iowa Democratic Party chairman, hunched into the wind as he weaved through traffic on Fourth Street in early November, late for the first of two meetings he had scheduled at Java Joe's, a funky downtown coffeehouse that has become one of his offices-on-the-run.

title: Troop Issue Is Ignored As Rumsfeld Visits Tokyo
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld held talks with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi here on Friday night, a 45-minute session that was noteworthy primarily for what was not mentioned: Tokyo's announcement this week that it had deferred its decision on whether to volunteer troops for Iraq.

title: Israel, Saudi Arabia And Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: The Smoke and Mirrors Of Food Labeling
description: Food companies -- including some that have pledged to act in the face of rising obesity rates -- routinely exploit labeling laws that allow them to make their products seem less fattening than they really are, according to nutritionists and consumer groups.

title: Settlement for Coral Power
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group's Coral Power unit agreed yesterday to pay $7.79 million to settle federal allegations of electricity-market manipulation in California in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAZEN, IRENE A.
description: HAZEN--Irene A. (nee Blitstein). At 74, peacefully, on November 13, 2003 at her home. Beloved wife of Joseph for 55 years. Cherished mother of Stephanie and Andrew. Adored grandmother of Shane and loving sister of Gladys. She was a wonderful woman whose kindness and wisdom is an inspiration to us all. Those who knew her loved her, and will hold her always in their hearts and thoughts. Services on Sunday, November 16th, at 2:00pm at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester, 229 Bedford Road, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to: James F. Holland Research Fund, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Box 1129, 1 Gustave Levy Place, NY, NY 10029 or to a favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WAGNER, ROBERT F., JR.
description: WAGNER--Robert F., Jr. January 6, 1944-November 15, 1993. The finest public servant of his generation. Connorton, Crotty, Edelstein, Koch, Lewis, Stern and Duncan Wagne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORDY, LEON, M.D.
description: PORDY -- Leon, M.D., F.A.C.C., 84, died Friday, November 14th, 2003 at his home in Manhattan after a valiant battle with a long illness. His accomplishments were bountiful. Graduating Phi Beta Kappa from NYU in 1938, he went on to receive a Master's in Biochemistry prior to attending Louisiana State University Medical School where he graduated first in his Class of 1943. He was an incredibly remarkable person and received humanitarian awards as well as alumni recognition awards from Mt. Sinai, authored a world famous computer electrocardiography textbook, penned countless articles published in prestigious medical journals and served as Captain and Head of the hospital in Udine, Italy during WWII. Even more so, he had two completely diverse careers as he was Chairman and CEO of Chock Full O'Nuts for 10+ years along with his medical career at Mt. Sinai and was brilliantly successful at both. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, three children, Dr. William, Dr. Robert, and Melissa Pordy, daughter-in-law, Dr. Cathryn Devons, and three grandchildren, Rachel, Jessica and Matthew Pordy. Services will be held on Sunday, November 16th, 2003, 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NYC, 212-288-3500. Donations may be made to either Kidney and Urology Foundation of America, 1250 Broadway, NY NY 10001, 212-629-9770 or Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, Box 1216, Mt. Sinai Hospital, 1 Gustave Levy Pl., NY NY 10029, 212-241-4141.

title: As Counties Face Fiscal Squeeze, Taxes Soar and Spending Shrinks
description: A study released this week found that New York State residents pay the highest local taxes in the nation by far. A look at county budgets introduced across the state this fall indicates that New York will keep that distinction -- with a vengeance.

title: Plan for Guerrilla Action May Have Predated War
description: American intelligence agencies have found increasing evidence that the broad outlines of the guerrilla campaign being waged against American forces in Iraq were laid down before the war by the Iraqi Intelligence Service, government officials said Friday.

title: The President and Our War Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwab Discloses Suspect Fund Trades
description: Charles Schwab, the discount broker that revolutionized the mutual fund industry, said yesterday that it had uncovered evidence of improper mutual fund trading in both its supermarket of funds and a fund family of a subsidiary, U.S. Trust.

title: Richard Squires, 72, Racket Sports Expert
description: Richard C. Squires, who built a career on racket sports, including serving as publisher of tennis magazines, died Wednesday at his home in Rowayton, Conn. He was 72.

title: Woman, 83, Is Struck by Bus in Brooklyn
description: An 83-year-old Brooklyn woman was struck by a city bus yesterday at a busy intersection in Coney Island.

title: William W. Montgomery, 80, Harvard Surgeon and Innovator
description: Dr. William W. Montgomery, a Harvard surgeon who originated many techniques that are now widely used in operations on the throat and the vocal cords, died on Nov. 7, at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKOWITZ, MARTIN, M.D.
description: MARKOWITZ--Martin, M.D. 93, of Blooming Grove, NY died November 14, 2003. Born in Brooklyn to Max and Rose Markowitz. Retired from his practice in Brooklyn, former President of Kings County Medical Society and NYS Family Practice Association. Husband of the late Mildred Malkin Markowitz. Survived by son, Dr. Robert J. Markowitz and wife Hope, Blooming Grove, NY and Sandra Markowitz, wife of the late Roy Markowitz, Punta Gorda, FL. Five grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Funeral service Sunday November 16th, 10:30AM at Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Inc., 117 Maple Ave, Monroe, NY. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Donations to Mental Health Association of Orange County, 20 Walker St, Goshen, NY 10924

title: Ferry Captain's Lawyers Offer Hint of Defense
description: Lawyers for the captain of the ferry that crashed last month gave the first hint yesterday of their defense against possible criminal charges, arguing that New York City has little formal policy on where the captain should have been in the moments before the crash.

title: Indians Now Disdain a Farm Once Hailed for Giving Tribe Jobs
description: Seven miles west of the tiny town of White River, on a snow-covered rise surrounded by bluffs and valleys, 24 metal-roofed barns create an isolated barracks for tens of thousands of fattening hogs.

title: Cardinal Health to Cut 850
description: Cardinal Health Inc., a drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it would cut 850 jobs over the next two years at its medical products and services business.

title: Seymour Cohn, 92, a Founder Of a New York Realty Giant
description: Seymour Cohn, co-founder and chairman of the Sylvan Lawrence Company, long a major commercial real estate power in New York City, died on Thursday. He was 92.

title: In Test, New NASA Safety Group Studies 4 Potential Problems
description: NASA's new engineering and safety group, formed in response to the loss of the shuttle Columbia, is cautiously beginning its operations by looking at four potential problems in programs throughout the agency, officials said on Friday.

title: The President and Our War Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: A Manhattan Cemetery
description: To the Editor:

title: Test Results Demand Time for Introspection
description: After years of facing mounting criticism, Major League Baseball has acknowledged a problem with steroid use and will now try to catch those who are essentially corking their bodies the way some hitters cork their bats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHRER, LARRY
description: LEHRER -- Larry. You touched our lives in countless ways. We miss you already. Ben, Billy, David, Gary and Michael

title: Man Charged in Wife's Suicide By His Gun Pleads Not Guilty
description: The Norwalk man who is being prosecuted because his wife killed herself using a handgun that he left in a dresser drawer pleaded not guilty on Friday in State Superior Court in Stamford.

title: Billionaires Aren't Targets, Putin Tells Russian Group
description: President Vladimir V. Putin, in his first comments to Russia's business elite on the arrest of the country's richest man, reiterated Friday that he had no intention of revisiting the controversial privatizations of the 1990's.

title: Raise Persuades Stottlemyre to Return
description: Mel Stottlemyre knew better than to decide his future immediately after the season, when resentment over his treatment by the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, caused him to say he felt ''personally abused.'' Instead, Stottlemyre waited to see if he was wanted, and the Yankees dispelled his doubts by giving him a raise.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Bates Midwest, Indianapolis, part of Bates Worldwide, was renamed the Roman Brandgroup by the WPP Group, London, as part of a reorganization that began after WPP acquired the Bates parent, the Cordiant Communications Group. Roman will operate as a division of the J. Walter Thompson unit of WPP; many accounts and employees of Bates USA, New York, have been absorbed by Thompson. Dan Roman continues as chairman at the renamed agency.

title: ACCORD REACHED BY REPUBLICANS FOR ENERGY BILL
description: Congressional Republicans announced Friday that they had agreed on wide-ranging national energy legislation that would provide billions of dollars in tax breaks for power producers and impose new standards intended to reduce the chances of blackouts like the one that hit the Northeast and Midwest last summer.

title: Robbery Suspect Is Shot to Death By Police Officer
description: A police officer fatally shot a man last night during a robbery in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Xerox Reaches Settlement With Retirees on Pension Suit
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to settle a lawsuit over the way it calculated pension benefits by paying an additional $239 million to thousands of employees who retired from 1990 to 1999.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Wins Venice Cup And Leads Bermuda Bowl
description: The United States secured one major title on Friday afternoon at the World Championships and was on track to capture another. In the Venice Cup for women's teams, the Americans led China by 23 imps at the start of the day. A sensational slam deal in the closing stages permitted China to close the gap to 8 imps, but the tide turned again and the Americans won by 19.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERELMAN, VICTOR B.
description: PERELMAN--Victor B. Famous journalist and editor-inchief of Russian magazine ''Time and We''. Of Cliffside Park, NJ, on November 13, 2003. Husband of Alla (nee Dubrovina). Father of Irina Perelman - Grabois. Grand father of Mark and Lara. Services Sunday 12:30 PM, ''Wien & Wien'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: German Legislator Is Ousted for Slur on Jews
description: Germany's largest opposition party voted Friday to expel a member two weeks after it became known that he had made comments widely viewed here as anti-Semitic.

title: Religion Journal; One Man's Goal: For a Tribe to Pray in Its Own Language
description: The automated voice is flat and monotonous, but Allen Sockabasin says he hears the words and prayers of his ancestors through the speakers of the Macintosh computer on his desk.

title: U.S. IS TO RETURN POWER TO IRAQIS AS EARLY AS JUNE
description: The Bush administration has agreed to restore independence to Iraq as early as next June, apparently hoping the move will change the perception of the United States as an occupying power and curb the mounting attacks on American forces in the country, Iraqi and American officials said Friday.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Sniper Defendant Working On His Boyish Appearance
description: Lee Malvo's wardrobe, mostly a series of boyish, slightly baggy sweaters, has been a subject of discussion at the brief news conferences his lawyers hold after court here each day. Mr. Malvo, 18, is accused of participating in the sniper attacks last fall in the Washington region. The sweaters make him look like a high school student.

title: Van Horn Not Much Help As Houston Goes It Alone
description: Allan Houston has a bad back and is not getting any younger at 32.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Grand Jury Urges County Clerk's Ouster
description: A special grand jury has recommended that the Pulaski County clerk, Carolyn Staley, resign or be removed from office because it said she had failed to correct problems with a voter registration database. In recent years, chaotic elections have been the rule in Pulaski County, which includes Little Rock and is the state's most populous. Thousands of voters have been sent to the wrong polling places and candidates have been omitted from ballots. Six months ago, the grand jury found that half the 250,000 entries in the voter database had inaccurate information, and ordered Ms. Staley to make improvements. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Repairing Limbs and Lives
description: At the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, soldiers who have lost limbs in Iraq begin to piece their lives back together.

title: You've Got Mail ... From the Microwave
description: A coffeepot that starts when your alarm clock goes off (after warning you the night before if you forget to fill it). A security camera that e-mails you at work if it detects motion and then lets you see through it and pan around a room remotely. A refrigerator that will scan its own contents to keep a running inventory. A combination oven/refrigerator that can be instructed from a cellphone to start dinner and have it ready when you get home. A microwave that scans the bar codes on frozen pizzas and programs itself with the manufacturer's suggested cooking time. A home theater that plays music and movies off the Net. Remote controls for lights, locks and the thermostat. Add to that your pick of remote-control consoles: laptop, cellphone, TV screen, the bedside clock, even the refrigerator door (too many options, if anything, rather than not enough).

title: Business People; The Punchy Writer And His Punchy Prose
description: Where does Marc Kirschner, 29, the owner and publisher of the Short List, a series of guidebooks to businesses in New York, get the inspiration for his pithy prose?

title: Blueprint for A Mess
description: Will David Rieff, in the interest of balance, report back a year from now? Let's see if his gloomy portrayal and prognosis plays out; it's still very early in the game.

title: Millie Umschweis and Arnold Spitz
description: IN poetry and music, love and youth may be inextricably linked. But Millie Umschweis and Arnold Spitz know better. Young love was theirs for the taking. But that was 56 years ago, when friends fixed up Ms. Umschweis, then just 17, and Mr. Spitz, 33, on a blind date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PARADNY, ROBERT, MD.
description: PARADNY--Robert, MD. Dear Bob/Dad/Doc, You live deep in our hearts and you are with us forever. Not a day goes by when we don't remember your greatness and how lucky we are to have you as ours. Your loving family.

title: California In Motion
description: There seemed to be some vague symmetry in the air when I asked the gas station attendant in Paso Robles how best to get across to Parkfield, a tiny village buried in a valley near the Cholame Hills in central California. ''Head east on 46,'' he said. ''Then watch out for the James Dean Memorial, and turn left again just after it. Then 10 miles up the road. Can't miss it.''

title: The Egg and Him
description: ERAGON

title: Kisses, $10 Apiece
description: To the Editor:

title: If Youre Looking for an Easier Job, This Isnt It
description: Attention, top executives: If you're thinking about going into academia to achieve a better work-life balance, don't. At least that's the advice from Bruce Willison, who recently announced that in June he would be leaving his spot as dean of the Anderson business school at the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Page Two: Nov. 9-15; George Soros Gives, And Republicans React With Fury
description: SENATOR GEORGE ALLEN, who chairs the committee charged with electing Senate Republicans, was outraged. ''Our enemies have stooped to a new low,'' he wrote in an e-mail message to Republican supporters last week.

title: Forget Dean, Gephardt and the Rest. For a Night, the Focus Is on Hillary Clinton.
description: The Iowa campaign teams of the Democratic presidential candidates spent most of this week getting ready for the big dinner that took place here on Saturday night.

title: Ahead of the Curve
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Slagle, Corey Todaro
description: Pamela Elizabeth Slagle and Corey Benjamin Todaro were married yesterday at Rosy's Jazz Hall in New Orleans. Brent E. Rolen, a friend of the couple's and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Missing Link
description: It looks like a device you might see a crew member working on the Starship Enterprise. And it should: the iPronto, from Philips Electronics, is a significant upgrade to the old-fashioned universal remote. Instead of a wand to be waved at nearby appliances, it's a Net-linked command console that lets you run the entire house from the couch.

title: Maryellen Reilly, William Lamb III
description: Maryellen Reilly, was married yesterday in Philadelphia to William Adamson Lamb III. The Rev. Stephen J. Connor, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Our Mother of Consolation Church.

title: Even the Heavy Bottle Is Extraordinary
description: THE updraft in prices of Long Island wines reached the stratosphere when Wlffer Estate announced last month that its 2001 superpremium merlot would cost $125.

title: Skirts All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for Her Close-Up
description: Alice's Adventures

title: Feelings Are Not Mutual In 401(k)'s
description: EMPLOYEES saving for retirement can't seem to catch a break. After nearly three years of painful bear-market losses, 2003 was shaping up as the year of the rebound, as a stock rally finally lifted portfolio values.

title: A Cheat Sheet for Dancehall Beats
description: IGGY POP -- Who needs maturity? All it took for Iggy Pop, 56, to make his best album in two decades was to regroup the surviving Stooges, his original late-1960's band, and reclaim his old reckless bluntness. ''My life is dirty, my mind is loaded,'' he proclaims in the title song of ''Skull Ring'' (Virgin), and the music lives up to his raunch, spite and hard-headed punch lines. He leers, sneers and offers some self-analysis: ''Supermarket'' and ''Til Wrong Feels Right'' sum up his complicity and disgust with pop as product. ''Skull Ring'' is part reunion, part tribute; the pop-punk whippersnappers Green Day and Sum 41 also back him up, and Peaches raps some deadpan smut alongside him. The generational split is clear: the youngsters like clean-cut songs and the geezers prefer molten psychedelic mayhem.

title: Fast and Furious: The Race to Wire America
description: JAYDENE WASHBURN'S rambler-style home here, 20 minutes south of Salt Lake City, seems the epitome of suburban tranquillity. The neatly cropped lawn is free of weeds. The skis and bicycles are hung tidily in the garage. In the house, the walls are adorned with family photographs and religious images.

title: A Lyrical Gift
description: I hate the idea of parting with things. My house and office are cluttered with stuff I can't bear to give up: Trigger, my rocking horse from when I was 5; my Halloween flapper costume from when I was 8; the ''Flashdance'' LP I played to psych myself up before my job interview with Abe Rosenthal at The Times and every embarrassing Joan Collins power suit I wore in the 80's.

title: A New Chapter of Nan Goldin's Diary
description: NAN GOLDIN is a photographer whose work is a record of her life. If this were the 19th century, she might be called a diarist. Her formal compositions have depicted her friends in candid moments -- in bars and clubs, funky bedrooms and bathrooms, hanging out, having sex, doing drugs, looking warily at each other, themselves or the camera. Often these characters were estranged from society, but not necessarily from each other, and especially not from the photographer. Anything and anyone Ms. Goldin shot were intimate to her. In exhibitions and in books, she has included some self-portraits, a few of which presented devastating views of her own self-destructiveness. But, she suggests, no portrait of her could be complete without the people she loves and what's around her. ''The Ballad of Sexual Dependency,'' the work in which she first documented her friends and herself, her scene, forged a genre, with photography as influential as any in the last 20 years.

title: What if Jackson Pollock Were a PC?
description: CREATING a computer program that mimics Jackson Pollock's painting technique may sound like a daunting task, but it is just the kind of challenge that Daniel Shiffman enjoys. Mr. Shiffman, 30, a media artist with a background in math and theater, wanted to develop a program that would ''paint'' an abstracted screen portrait of whoever was in front of the display, slowly repainting and revising the picture as the viewer moved.

title: Screen Memory
description: GARBO LAUGHS

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When we get injured, all it says is 'one soldier wounded.' Not that a soldier has lost an arm or a leg, or how hard that is.''

title: The Home of American Golf
description: SAY ''home of golf,'' and people will think of St. Andrews in Scotland. Say ''home of golf in the United States,'' and Pebble Beach, Calif., Augusta, Ga., or Pinehurst, N.C., may come to mind.

title: Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended; Assignment Violin
description: Remembering the Best and Worst Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended Illustrations by Tom Bloom

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Museum for Contemporary Art in a Historic District
description: AMID the spacious antique homes of Main Street, where many of Ridgefield's wealthier residents live, sits a modest 6,000-square-foot former general store, built in 1783 and occupying a street-side corner of a three-acre property, known as the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. It might be called ''the little museum that could.''

title: Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended; It Led to a Career
description: Remembering the Best and Worst Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended Illustrations by Tom Bloom

title: Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended; A Too-Perfect Paper
description: Remembering the Best and Worst Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended Illustrations by Tom Bloom

title: German City Tries to Persuade Pentagon to Keep Bases Open
description: The birthplace of Johann Gutenberg and the center of the German wine-growing industry, this is a gracious city, proud of its Roman roots and splendid medieval cathedral.

description: THE DUCHESS
