title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE ALAN
description: TISCH--Laurence Alan. 80. Saturday, November 15. Dearly beloved husband of Billie for 55 years. Adored and adoring father of Andrew & Ann, Daniel & Bonnie, James & Merryl, Thomas & Alice. Proud and loving grandfather of Alexander & Bara, Lacey, Sarah, Charlotte, David, Michael, Alan, Jessica, Benjamin, Samuel, Maude, Joseph, Abigail, and Louise. Dear and devoted brother of Preston Robert (Bob) & Joan. Cherished uncle, relative and friend. Services Monday, November 17, at 11 AM at Central Synagogue. Interment private.

title: Far From Fifth Avenue, a Homegrown Museum Mile
description: It won't exactly be Museum Mile. But if an event planned for next Sunday is successful, a 60-block stretch of upper Broadway will be lined with ad hoc exhibition spaces showing the work of local artists, and visitors from inside and outside the neighborhood will be poking their heads in to take a look.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review of ''Living to Tell the Tale,'' a memoir by Gabriel Garca Mrquez, on Page 8 of the Book Review today misstates the year of the author's birth in some copies. It was 1927, as he has recently acknowledged, not 1928, as it appears in many reference works and on Web sites.

title: For Middle Class, Health Insurance Becomes a Luxury
description: The last time Kevin Thornton had health insurance was three years ago, which was not much of a problem until he began having trouble swallowing.

title: Business; Newman's Own: Two Friends and a Canoe Paddle
description: DRIVING along the back roads of Westport, Conn., in his 1961 red Corvette, slowly enough to reminisce, A.E. Hotchner would like to make it clear that it has not been easy putting up with Paul Newman since they both bought houses here in the 1950's. To hear it from Mr. Hotchner -- or Hotch, as everyone calls him -- he has at times been pushed to the cusp of despair by Mr. Newman's whims and high jinks, though the men are friends as well as business partners.

title: Voters' Choice: The Third Party
description: IN the municipal elections in two rural eastern Connecticut towns, third-party candidates proved attractive to voters.

title: Trade Throw-In Is Sonics' Surprise
description: Wally Walker and Rick Sund had just traded Gary Payton, perhaps the greatest player in Seattle SuperSonics history, and they were under siege. With fans in near-revolt, Sund, the club's general manager, was reluctant to answer his cellphone, even as Seattle was demolishing its trade partner, Milwaukee, in a game the day after the deal. But when a Milwaukee area code flashed on the caller ID, Sund, figuring he was safe, answered. This is what he heard: ''Rick, it's Flip. We're kicking their tails.''

title: Woman Warrior
description: Trickster's Choice

title: Tropical Hues and Food Via Guatemala
description: ON Main Street here, a bright neon sign announces the presence of the Mango Caf. The neat white oval features two stylish mangos, playful curlicue lettering, and a trademark symbol. With its paper placemats, modest prices and potted plastic palms, the Mango Caf has the look and feel of a template for a franchise.

title: Repairing Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man in the Mask
description: NIXON'S SHADOW

title: Politicians Join Criticism Of Finances In New York
description: At conferences like the one that ended here on Friday titled ''Fixing New York State's Fiscal Practices,'' it is not uncommon to hear gloom-and-doom assessments from those seeking change in government. Elected officials, if they show up at all, can be counted on to defend the status quo.

title: Dance Listings
description: BALLET HISPANICO  Premiere of the evening-length "Nightclub." Jack H. Skirball Center for Performing Arts, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square S. (212) 992-8484. Today, 3.

title: Squaring Off
description: Andy Camann, a tall, gangly 14-year-old, wears a serene expression on his face as he stares down at the colorful blur of a Rubik's Cube spinning in his hands. In public -- on the street, at his school -- he is usually alone doing this, and the object of puzzled stares. Today, though, he is sitting amid a crowd of like-minded souls, also spinning cubes, in a 500-seat auditorium at the Ontario Science Center in Toronto, the site of the 2003 World Rubik's Game Championships. It is Day 2 of an event that has attracted nearly a hundred competitors from 20 countries.

title: Tour Takes Visitors Inside Windsor Castle
description: A new tour at Windsor Castle takes groups of visitors behind the scenes to rooms that are not usually open to the public. The tour, From Great Kitchen to State Apartments, starts with tea or coffee and biscuits in the Winchester Tower and a talk by a senior warden that includes tales of Henry VIII's enormous appetite and Queen Victoria's speedy eating, which often left her guests feeling hungry as protocol dictated that the plates for each course be cleared as soon as she had finished.

title: Feeling Romantic? Feeling Rich, Too?
description: FOR $10,000, you can come home to a real castle -- if only for one night.

title: At Home Among the Bluenosers
description: ''Nova Scotia -- conjunction of improbabilities,'' I say. ''What do you think?''

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 2, about a trip to Greenland, misstated the governmental status of Nunavut, in Canada. It is a territory, not a province.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 26 about the artist Mark Lombardi, who died in March 2000, referred incompletely to his gallery representation. While the Pierogi Gallery now represents his work, Deven Golden Fine Art did so until it closed in 2000.

title: Are Team Sports Hurting Kids?
description: To the Editor:

title: To Seville With Love
description: Since the conquest, Mexico has had a crush on Spain. That's why I never believed my Mexican family's boasts about our Spanish patriarch, a composer of waltzes who supposedly once performed for the Mexican president. I assumed it was puro cuento, just another story. Until Uncle Enrique stepped forward with Great-grandfather's baptism certificate from San Esteban, a church in the old part of Seville.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: The War Within
description: EARLY one morning last July, my rifle company boarded a convoy of trucks leaving Nasiriyah, an Iraqi city 180 miles south of Baghdad, bound for Kuwait. After tossing my pack onto a truck, I looked back at members of the Carabinieri, Italy's military police force, who were staying. They were made groggy and disgruntled by the early hour, and about to assume watch over the building we had shared for the past month.

title: Autumn Accents
description: Songwriters long ago expressed the exuberance of autumn in New York. The magic continues, with Indian summer days and nights so frosty there were icicles a week ago on a Conservatory Garden fountain. Dogs snuggled in sweaters and coats (and hats!), and women wore maple-leaf colors and fox stoles. A cyclist, right, had an embroidered cloak with matching hat and shoes.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption in this section on Nov. 2 with a picture grouping about travel on a budget in three American cities misstated the name of a neighborhood in Atlanta noted for shopping and restaurants. It is Virginia Highland, not Highlands.

title: Wanna, Gonna
description: Atop a column of mine about ethical concerns churned up by scientific advances in longevity, an International Herald Tribune editor ran this provocative headline: ''Do You Wanna Live Forever?''

title: Lingering Echoes Of an Old Beer Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERKUS, DAVID T., M.D.
description: HERKUS--David T., M.D. Born Brooklyn, NY, February 19, 1908, died November 14, 2003. Graduate of Boys High School, City College of New York, and Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons in Edinburgh. Beloved husband of the late Lillian Herkus (Wolberg) and the late Marie Herkus (Heghmann). Father of Joanne Rogovin and Andrew Herkus (Carmella); grandfather of Elissa Rogovin and Gabriel Herkus. Brother of Pearl Horowitz and the late Milton Herkus, brother-in-law of Shirley Hoffman and Larry Hoffman, uncle of Jeffrey Hoffman, Randy Hoffman, Jeffrey Horowitz, Arlene and Jill Herkus. General practitioner in Astoria, NY, for over 60 years. Member of Queens County Medical Society. Lover of music, theatre, travel, art and life. Services will be private. Donations in David's memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Alyssa Weiskopf, Jeremy Zeff
description: Alyssa Jill Weiskopf, a daughter of Leslie and Alan Weiskopf of White Plains and Wilmington, N.C., was married last evening to Jeremy Michael Zeff, the son of Marion and Steven Zeff of Harrington Park, N.J. Cantor Kerry Ben-David officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINHAUS, ESTHER
description: KLEINHAUS--Esther, on November 14th, 2003 at 95 years. Beloved wife of Jack for 72 years. Devoted mother of Sari (Raymond) and Betty. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Carolyn Dlugatz, Steven Wortman
description: Carolyn Joy Dlugatz, a daughter of Linda and Martin Dlugatz of Middletown, N.Y., was married last evening in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., to Steven Hadley Wortman, a son of Shelly Schack of Hollywood, Fla., and Dr. Kenneth Wortman of Coral Springs, Fla. Rabbi Steven Lindemann, a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Woodcliff Lake Hilton.

title: Laurence A. Tisch, Investor Known for Saving CBS Inc. From Takeover, Dies at 80
description: Laurence A. Tisch, the self-made New York billionaire who was hailed as a white knight for saving CBS Inc. from a hostile takeover and then reviled for diminishing what was once the nation's premier broadcasting network, died early yesterday at Tisch Hospital of the New York University Medical Center. He was 80. The cause was complications from gastric cancer, said his wife, Wilma, who is known as Billie.

title: Penn Holds Off Harvard To Secure League Title
description: Pennsylvania's unbeaten football team figured to beat Harvard on Saturday, and both offenses figured to score often. Penn did win, 32-24, and the offenses were spectacular, Penn at the start and Harvard in a frenetic finish.

title: A Star-Spangled Reason for a Party
description: EVERY party has one: the guest who blurts out uncomfortable truths, insists on singing or seems far too eager to fit in. Last week, Bob MacLeod and Steve Byckiewicz gave a party at their penthouse on the Upper West Side to celebrate Mr. MacLeod's new United States citizenship. (He was born in Canada.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALY, CECILE T.
description: DALY--Cecile T. On November 14, 2003. Longtime resident of Jackson Heights. Loving sister of Anne, Rita O'Brien and Thomas. Visiting at the Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Heights, Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, Monday, 10:15 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NITZBERG, JERRY
description: NITZBERG--Jerry. A brilliant, compassionate, fiercely dedicated man and a loyal friend. We loved and admired you more than you knew. Alan and Sue Dubrow

title: PAGE TWO: BUZZWORDS
description: The Senate's debate on judicial nominations ran on for 39 stupefying hours, before Democrats succeeded in blocking three of President Bush's nominees to the federal appeals courts.

title: Homework: Liked or Loathed but Still Remembered
description: Done but not forgotten. That's the verdict from readers who wrote about their most memorable homework assignments, the very best and the very worst. Here is a sampling of projects that stood the test of time:

title: Ashley Edens, Robert Reid IV
description: Ashley Elizabeth Edens and Robert Dennis Reid IV were married yesterday in Phoenix. The Rev. Robert A. Stanley, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Phoenix Country Club.

title: Bondi, Beyond The Beach
description: ONE could certainly spend a perfect day in Bondi without ever venturing off the beach. The fat half-mile crescent of soft yellow sand frames a frothy blue-white ocean stretching out to forever. Dozens of surfers in black neoprene bob patiently on the water waiting for the perfect wave, and sunbathers scatter themselves across the sand in various states of undress depending on the weather. Less than four miles from Sydney's city center, Bondi offers a classic seaside experience.

title: 'Master and Commander': On the Far Side of Credibility
description: ADMIRERS of Patrick O'Brian's splendid story of a Royal Navy frigate pursuing an American warship around the tip of South America and into the Pacific during the War of 1812 may be disappointed as I was by Peter Weir's new film. They would be churlish however not to acknowledge the craftsmanship that lends the film, if not the feeling of truth -- that this is how it must have been for these people on that ship in those waters -- at least the feeling of truth's earnest, impoverished second cousin, verisimilitude: that this is how it may have looked.

title: Who Wants the Wishbone?
description: Boy, do I have a bone to pick!

title: Georgi Vladimov, 72, Dies; Russian Author of Dark Allegories
description: Georgi Vladimov, a dissident Russian writer whose dark, allegorical novels of life under the Soviet regime forced him into exile, died on Oct. 19 in Germany, Agence France-Presse reported. He was 72.

title: California Attractions Spared by the Fires
description: After last month's devastating wildfires burned more than 140,000 acres near Lake Arrowhead, Calif., anyone driving up the Rim of the World Highway from San Bernardino might expect the worst.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Diebold Inc., which supplies touch-screen voting machines through a subsidiary, referred imprecisely to the way Walden W. O'Dell, Diebold's president and chief executive, joined the company in 1999. He was hired with those titles at Diebold Inc., not the subsidiary, Diebold Election Systems; the subsidiary was created after Diebold Inc. acquired Global Election Systems in 2002.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Playlist column last Sunday misspelled the given name of a musician who was cited for his influence on a younger generation of songwriters. He was Elliott Smith, not Elliot.

title: Jeri Johnson, Iain Wooster
description: Jeri Lynne Johnson, a daughter of Raye and Jerry Johnson of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married in Philadelphia last evening to Iain Martin Wooster, a son of Linda and Robert Wooster of High Wycombe, England. Bishop Charles E. Bennison Jr. of the Episcopal diocese of Pennsylvania performed the ceremony at the Philadelphia Episcopal Cathedral.

title: Photographs That Reveal Taste for Mystery and Drama
description: The Earth and Other Sacred Places

title: A Better Army for Iraq
description: As President Bush and his aides met frantically this week to discuss speeding up Iraq's transition to democracy, a paradox in the administration's foreign policy became evident. It is the conflict between the occupation's overarching goal -- to build a stable, democratic Iraq -- and the desire to get American troops out of harm's way well before the presidential election next November.

title: Starlight That Sheds No Shadows
description: Lovers of rich desserts or long books might find that Richard Strauss's opera ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten'' (''The Woman Without a Shadow'') sets something resonating within them. And the Metropolitan Opera's 2001 staging of the work -- the first and last American production of the German director Herbert Wernicke, who died just months after its debut -- will offer a fine means of access on its return tomorrow.

title: Ohio State Stays in Title Hunt, Barely
description: Ohio State won without its offense scoring a touchdown. It won even when its game-winning field goal was tipped. It won because Purdue's usually reliable field-goal kicker missed not one but two field-goal attempts that he normally drills through the uprights.

title: One-Track Minds
description: PRAIRIE TRAIN

title: A New Moral Majority?
description: Q: As president of the Christian Coalition of America, you must have been delighted to see President Bush sign the legislation outlawing so-called partial-birth abortion early this month.

title: A Muslim Scholar Raises Hackles in France
description: Of all the Muslim leaders in Europe, perhaps none has more visibility -- and more faces -- than Tariq Ramadan.

title: BENEFITS
description: Lost Musical Scores

title: Executive Life; Learning Teamwork By Making Music
description: HANS LIE was attending a rehearsal of the Park Avenue Chamber Symphony last fall when fate presented him with a career move.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SORREL, WILLIAM E.
description: SORREL--William E. One long sad year has passed. You will always be in our hearts. We love you. We miss you. ..Your family

description: A is For Abigail

title: Chair Umpires Making the Calls for the Love of the Game
description: The woman who was watching the teenagers play tennis is a biomechanical engineer with a master's degree in biomechanics and a doctorate in engineering, both earned at Northeastern University in Boston, where students and other faculty members call her professor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINUS, BRUCE C.
description: MINUS--Bruce C. Of The Bronx, N.Y., on November 9, 2003. Beloved father of Clifton C. Wynter, Sr. of New York City, Shonie Minus Crighead of Wilmington, DE., Maria Minus of West Palm Beach, FL., Stephanie Minus Taylor of Nassau, Bahamas & Donnamae Minus also of the Bahamas. Also survived by seven stepchildren, 33 grandchildren, 41 great grandchildren and cherished nieces and nephews. Treasured friend to many. Wake Monday, November 17th, 4-8PM at John H. Joyce Funeral Home, 2332 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvd. at 137 St. Service Tuesday, November 18th, 10AM, Trinity Methodist Church, corner 166 St and Washington Ave, Bronx. Interment Rose Hill Mausoleums, Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Sandra Sobieraj, Franklin Westfall Jr.
description: Sandra Jean Sobieraj, a journalist, and Franklin Edward Westfall Jr., a security specialist for the Secret Service, were married yesterday. Msgr. Salvatore Criscuolo performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Deal 'in Principle' For Medicare Plan To Cover Drug Costs
description: The top Republicans in Congress and two Democratic senators announced Saturday that they had reached an ''agreement in principle'' on a bill to help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs. It would be the biggest expansion of Medicare since the program was created in 1965.

title: Setback for Bronxville School Construction
description: THE never ending story of the Bronxville High School construction project got even longer this week.

title: Witness; The New Iraq Is Grim, Hopeful and Still Scary
description: TO return to Baghdad after six months is to encounter a country at once dispiriting and yet, in spite of all, still hopeful, if flaggingly so. The letdown begins at 19,500 feet over the southwestern limits of the city, in a twin-turboprop aircraft of Royal Jordanian Airlines that seeks safety from ground-to-air missiles by flying a downward spiral over what was Saddam International Airport -- the first foothold seized by American troops when they reached the city on April 3, and now a principal stronghold of the American occupation.

title: What We Lost
description: The old man has an odor like a force field. He wakes the boy before dawn. Quiet, he says, and underneath his black coat his kitchen whites reek of cabbage, stewed meat, spoiled milk. We don't want to get your mother up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCMAHON, WILLIAM
description: McMAHON--William. 68, died 9/21/03, in Cooper, ME. Survived by wife, Joanne. Wellknown sculptor, graduate of SVA. He will be missed.

title: For Released Inmates, Someone to Talk To
description: ONE might think that being released from prison is a joyous experience and that an inmate would be giddy with the anticipated freedom that lays ahead. But the reality is often more complicated than that.

title: Two Cops Who'll Never Be On the Back of a Nickel
description: WHAT kind of ''Mystery!'' presentation is this, anyway? No teacups, no exotic poisons, no plummy British accents -- and the familiar black-and-white figures by Edward Gorey are waving red-white-and-blue American flags.

title: The Fine Points of Teasing A Suspect Into Confessing
description: Each television genre has its primal scene. On teen shows, it's the crush revelation; on medical series, the surgical screw-up; on reality television, the broken alliance. For cop shows, that plum scene is the interrogation, a duet of psychological bullying. ''It's the classic kind of drama,'' says Tom Fontana, the executive producer of the late, lamented ''Homicide: Life on the Street,'' which ran from 1993 to 1999 on NBC. ''The protagonist and the antagonist down to their barest essentials.''

title: The Beauty Makers
description: As teenage fashion models, Annie Walker, left, and Renay Arbour met in Tokyo, where they discovered a shared penchant for beauty products. Fifteen years later, the friendship and the penchant are stronger than ever as evidenced by Deep Steep, a line of all-natural bath and body products that they created (sold at Fred Segal in Los Angeles and Harvey Nichols in London).

title: Photo Elves Prep the Kids
description: Although most mothers would be thrilled to receive portraits of their children as a holiday gift, few fathers dare to brave the tasks that such a project requires, like styling hair and coordinating clothing.

title: A P.R. Challenge: Marketing Croquet to the Malletless Masses in America
description: Robert Fulford, the reigning world champion of croquet, settled into a cushioned wicker chair and surveyed a corner of his realm -- an emerald lawn dotted with wire wickets, a shady veranda set up for luncheon, white-shorted spectators murmuring and nibbling, waiters gliding about bearing jars of Grey Poupon.

title: Playing Cowboy, Aussie Style
description: ''THE first thing to understand,'' said Jillian Sullivan, glancing back at Jessy, her salt-and-pepper quarter horse, ''is that the horse is a prey animal, and we are predators. So it's a 'big ask' to have a predator riding on a prey animal's back.''

title: Page Two: Nov. 9-15; IN BRIEF
description: * The Senate and House Republicans said they reached an agreement on energy legislation intended to increase domestic production and make transmission networks more reliable. The bill includes construction of a pipeline to bring natural gas from Alaska's North Slope to the Chicago area; what its sponsors call a ''total reform'' in electricity laws, and higher efficiency standards for many new products. One thing the bill does not do: call for drilling in parts of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Dear Santa, Could You Please Bring Me a Life Like Eloise's?
description: ANYONE who knows Eloise, that terribly cosmopolitan 6-year-old resident of the Plaza Hotel, knows there is nothing she would ''rawther'' do than cause trouble. Nothing at all.

title: Who's Reading Your X-Ray?
description: SANJAY SAINI was not prepared for the hate mail. A radiologist at Massachusetts General Hospital, Dr. Saini thought he had found a clever way to relieve an acute shortage of specialists who could read X-rays and M.R.I. scans. The hospital would beam images electronically from some scans to India, to be worked on by radiologists there.

title: Far Out East in Australia
description: AT first glance Byron Bay seems to be in a 60's time warp. Heading into town, you are likely to see a few dreadlocked hippies of indeterminate age and psychedelic vans painted with slogans like ''The Only Permanence Is Impermanence.''

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: INVESTING WITH: S. Basu Mullick; Neuberger Berman Partners Fund
description: INDUSTRY slowdowns, a weak economy or even bad weather can easily push down the share prices of solid companies, said S. Basu Mullick, manager of the $1.6 billion Neuberger Berman Partners fund. The important question for an investor, he said, is whether those price declines are likely to last long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINMAN, BELLA PAULINE (NEE FINGER)
description: KLEINMAN -- Bella Pauline (nee Finger). Died on November 8th of complications following a heart attack. Beloved sister-in-law of Ida and Sidney Kleinman and Robert Haines, aunt of Ruth Kleinman, Daniel Haines, Matthew Haines and Francine Kane, her niece by marriage, greataunt of Philip and David, she was preceded in death by Isadore, her dear husband, by their beloved son Michael, and by her loving sister, Mildred Finger Haines. A graduate of Hunter College, Class of 1941 and a recognized expert and collector of 18th century English porcelain, her family and friends will miss her intelligence, her wit, her passion, her dignity and her will to overcome the difficulties of life. Donations may be made to the Michael Kleinman Memorial Fund of the Columbia University School of Law, and would be greatly appreciated.

title: Ronda Wist, Frank Chaney
description: Ronda Faith Wist, the executive director of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, and Frank Edward Chaney, a zoning and real estate consultant, are to be married today at the National Arts Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Mark Lipson will officiate.

title: The Schwarzenegger Era Is Poised to Begin in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16  Arnold Schwarzenegger will be sworn in as California's governor on Monday after a whirlwind campaign followed by a six-week transition period during which he was largely invisible.

title: The Gloved Ones
description: With more women including strength training in their workout routines, Nike's lightweight training gloves have become a must-have accessory. The gray mesh gloves, out for the first time this season ($10, at select Niketown stores, 800-806-6453), are trimmed in pale blue and offer what may be the only chic alternative to traditional black weight-lifting gloves. They are in high demand -- sold out in Los Angeles and in scant supply in New York.

title: Telling Their Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Yesteryear Is Today's Special
description: IT was 1905, Russian workers were marching on the Czar's Winter Palace, the Trans-Siberian Railroad made its first 21-hour trip from Vladivostok to Paris and Louie's Oyster Bar and Grill opened in Port Washington on a barge in Manhasset Bay. Twenty-two years later, in 1927, Al Jolson was starring in ''The Jazz Singer,'' the first talking picture, the New York Yankees' ''Murderer's Row'' was being called the greatest baseball team ever and Hildebrandt's opened for business in Williston Park. Around that same time, Gurney's started up in Montauk. Seven years later Dick and Dora came to Massapequa.

title: Homework: Liked or Loathed but Still Remembered
description: Done but not forgotten. That's the verdict from readers who wrote about their most memorable homework assignments, the very best and the very worst. Here is a sampling of projects that stood the test of time:

title: Men Are the Real Dolls in This House of Ibsen
description: HENRIK IBSEN'S 1879 play ''A Doll's House'' concludes with one of the most famous exits in modern drama. When Nora Helmer walked out of her husband Torvald's house to begin a life of independence, her slamming of the door could be seen as the opening salvo in a battle over women's rights that continues today.

title: A Retiring Hall of Famer Is Secure With or Without a Record
description: Jerry Yeagley, the Indiana men's soccer coach for 31 years, made it clear before this season that it would be his last. Already a member of the Hall of Fame, he began the season with 527 victories, needing just 17 to tie Stephen Negoesco of the University of San Francisco for most in a college career.

title: Living to Tell the Tale
description: My mother asked me to go with her to sell the house. She had come that morning from the distant town where the family lived, and she had no idea how to find me. She asked around among acquaintances and was told to look for me at the Libreria Mundo, or in the nearby cafes, where I went twice a day to talk with my writer friends. The one who told her this warned her: "Be careful, because they're all out of their minds." She arrived at twelve sharp. With her light step she made her way among the tables of books on display, stopped in front of me, looking into my eyes with the mischievous smile of her better days, and before I could react she said:

title: 'Knife in the Water': Trapped on a Boat With Polanski
description: ON the Criterion Collection's new ''Knife in the Water'' DVD, you'll find the sort of worthwhile features aficionados have come to expect -- an extensive collection of stills, an informative interview, a flawless digital transfer. But sooner or later you'll discover a slightly perverse anti-feature. By special request of the director, Roman Polanski, it's impossible to fast-forward through the film. You can skip to any one of the 14 chapters, but once you're there you're stuck.

title: The Nation: Prescriptions Filled; If Americans Want to Pay Less for Drugs, They Will
description: AMERICANS, who pay the highest drug prices in the world, are clamoring for access to cheap imports of prescription drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACKERMAN, GWENDOLYN J. (NEE HILL)
description: ACKERMAN--Gwendolyn J. (nee Hill). Age 89, died November 7th. Mrs. Ackerman, widow of Dr. Nathan W. Ackerman, founder of the Ackerman Institute for the Family, is survived by her daughters Deborah Carol Ackerman of NYC and Jeannie Ackerman Curhan (Mrs. Joseph Williams) of Boston, MA; her grandsons Jon David Curhan of Newton Centre, MA and Jeffrey Ackerman Curhan of Sarasota, FL; and four great grandchildren. Gwen, a Board Member Emeritus of the Ackerman Institute, also served for several years as its Executive Secretary. A memorial service is planned for December 9th at 6 PM at the Ackerman Institute, 149 East 78th Street in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Ackerman Institute.

title: Nicole Hyatt, Douglas Steinberg
description: Nicole Hyatt and Douglas Steinberg were married yesterday in the Virgin Islands. Anne Marie Porter, a civil wedding officiant, performed the ceremony at the Caneel Bay Resort, on St. John.

title: Rumbera Heaven
description: IN a Miami version of the Cinderella story, the candlelit restaurant 190 undergoes a magic transformation every Saturday night at 11. At the first tuck-tuck-tuck of the drum, that hollow but warm sound of human palm against taut mule hide, plates are pushed back, tables are removed and the restaurant becomes a patio of a Cuban solar -- a common space where Havana dwellers with a weakness for rumba gather to dance to the drums.

title: Rumsfeld Presses Japan on U.S. Suspects' Rights
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told the Japanese government on Saturday that it was urgent to resolve the festering issue of defining legal rights for American military personnel in Japan suspected of violent crimes, in particular rape and murder, senior Pentagon officials said.

title: The World: Bush's Royal Visit; Viewing U.S., British See Good, Bad, Ugly
description: TUCKED inside ''Love Actually,'' the new cinematic ode to happy endings from the British director Richard Curtis, lies a pointed moment of wishful political thinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, ALVIN, M.D.
description: WEINER--Alvin, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Alvin Weiner. Dr. Weiner was an obstetrician and gynecologist for over 40 years. He was an exemplary role model for the physicians who learned from him. He treated his patients with much kindness and dignity. He always had a smile for everyone. He will be sorely missed by all of his colleagues, patients and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Herbert Lehman, M.D., Pres. Ira Mayer, M.D., Pres. Elect Warren Wexelman, M.D., Sercretary Steven Farber, M.D., Treas.

title: Predators Knock the Isles Off Their Feet
description: This rugged game ended with one Islander in the hospital for a brief visit and his team in a slump at the start of a four-game trip. The injured player was defenseman Radek Martinek, who sustained a concussion during the second period of the Islanders' 4-3 loss to the Nashville Predators.

title: N.Y.U. Runners to Compete in Nationals
description: The New York University men's cross-country team finished third in the N.C.A.A. Atlantic regional meet yesterday and qualified for the national championships Saturday in Hanover, Ind., for the first time since it entered Division III competition, in 1982.

title: Reasons To Love A City
description: I HAVE to admit that spending six months in chemotherapy and radiation wasn't on the top of my ''to do'' list for my family's long-awaited and much dreamed of year abroad, courtesy of my husband, an academic taking his sabbatical year. We were off to Scotland -- magical land of lochs, jagged bald peaks, and distant wild islands shrouded in mist -- and I wanted to see it all.

title: 'Doris From Rego Park' Mourned On Late-Night Sports Talk Radio
description: Listeners of the late-night sports talk show on WFAN-AM (660) knew something was wrong last week when Short Al from Brooklyn called in and did not talk baseball. Instead, he called to say that Doris from Rego Park was in the hospital.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: If women are going to talk about motherhood as a movement, then it should involve ways to be a mother without losing the career you worked so hard for. What about more leave time, husbands' taking on equal responsibility for child rearing or federal funding for child care?

description: Opera

title: The Takedown Artist
description: You have to give Dale Peck credit for never picking on anyone smaller than himself (James Atlas, Oct. 26). His targets are always prominent and sometimes overpraised writers, and in the end he probably helps the sales of their books. As my grandmother used to say, ''Every knock is a boost.'' Indeed, many of us unknown writers can only dream of having the good fortune to be savaged in print by one of Peck's bad-boy reviews.

description: It took a freshman to halt Miami's uncharacteristic free fall, and the Hurricanes may have unveiled a star in the process.

title: As Rents Rise, So Does Deregulation
description: AS the New York City housing market flourished in much of the period between 1999 and 2002, the pace of apartment deregulation quickened in the most desirable neighborhoods of Manhattan and market rents rose sharply in much of the city, especially in Brooklyn and Queens, where median rents exceed $1,000 for the first time in some neighborhoods.

title: Hope for the Upstate Economy in the Next Wave of Computer Chips
description: Workers are still putting the finishing touches on NanoFab 300 South, a futuristic building of blue glass and white steel just erected here.

It showed Park Place between Underhill and Washington Avenues; the block described is between Underhill and Vanderbilt.

title: The World; It's the Heyday Of Arabic But It May Not Be Enough
description: FOR Americans, Arabic is a difficult language. It has some unfamiliar throaty sounds, a vast and ancient vocabulary, script that reads from right to left and dialects so distinct that native speakers from Morocco, Yemen and Iraq often cannot understand one another.

title: Buzzzz, Murmurs Follow Novel
description: IT'S the buzz of Bronxville: who are the real-life inspirations for the characters in a newly available self-published book titled ''The Bronxville Book Club''?

title: Good Hands At Work
description: TURN a key in a lock. Snap a photograph. Signal a simple ''thumbs up.'' There's magic in the human hand, even in these most basic of motions. It's found in the 27 bones that give the hand structure and the 35 muscles that power it, 15 from the forearm that give strength and 20 within the hand itself that allow precise movements.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; CALIFORNIA'S NEW GOVERNOR
description: The Arnold Schwarzenegger Era in California politics officially begins shortly after 11 a.m. on Monday, when the movie actor and former champion bodybuilder is sworn in as the state's 38th governor on the lawn of the Capitol in Sacramento.

title: Argentine Moves Against Police Corruption
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16  When President Nestor Kirchner moved to purge the armed forces and Supreme Court immediately after taking office in May, both institutions rapidly bowed to his will. But now that he is taking on a corrupt police force that he says is responsible for a recent epidemic of kidnappings, he seems to be meeting stiff resistance.

title: Good. Better. Best.
description: SALES pitches spare no superlatives in the signs that line New Jersey streets and highways.

title: Bridgeport Mayor Knows He's the Focus
description: JOHN M. FABRIZI had less than 20 hours to celebrate his victory in the Bridgeport mayoral race on Nov. 4 before critics started biting. Ken (Citizen) Smith, the afternoon talk-radio host on WICC, had called Mr. Fabrizi's press office and asked for an interview, but had been denied. So, as radio talk-show hosts often do, he went on an indignant rant.

title: Iraq Goes Sour
description: The American involvement with Iraq appears to have turned a corner. The Bush administration's old game plan -- drafting a constitution, followed by elections, followed by American withdrawal -- has been replaced by a new timetable. It's a bit cynical to say that the plan is to toss the whole hot potato to whatever Iraqis are willing to grab it. But the White House thinking is veering close.

title: Democrat Wins Runoff Election In Louisiana
description: Lt. Gov. Kathleen B. Blanco, a Democrat, defeated Piyush Jindal, the Republican whiz kid, to become the first woman elected governor of Louisiana in a runoff on Saturday.

description: AT least no one has pulled a knife.

title: Dog Bed to Custom Cage: Tailoring the House to Fit the Pet
description: SATURDAY sounds in suburban neighborhoods tend toward a generic mix of leaf blowers, car engines, children and babies. Maybe an occasional seagull or sparrow in the background. But in Wantagh, the familiar soundtrack is frequently overpowered by an unlikely sound: the high-pitched screams of a hyacinth macaw named Bentley.

title: Gathering Forces in the Battle on Hunger
description: SYD MANDELBAUM's home office isn't even the size of can of sardines, so he is at the kitchen table, which is set with all the fixings for Sunday brunch: bagels, cream cheese, lox, tuna fish, lettuce, tomatoes and slices of American cheese. He puts together a Dagwood sandwich and digs in.

title: Shaking the Last Cards Out of Their Sleeves
description: IT is 3 p.m. in the former magic capital of the world, and the basement of Maui Tacos, on Fifth Avenue at 33rd Street, is mostly quiet. The slapping of cards against baize is the only sound in the room as Doug Edwards, a thrusting, beak-faced man perpetually in sunglasses, a baseball cap and knee-length shorts, finishes his trick. There is a general murmur of approval.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Oct. 26, about the 125th Street subway viaduct, misstated the relationship of Perry Belmont, who made an inspection trip of the line in 1904, and August Belmont, its principal promoter. Perry Belmont was August's brother, not his son.

title: Children's Books in Brief; A Walker Over the City
description: In 1974, the aerialist Philippe Petit performed a breathtaking feat: he walked a tightrope between the towers of the World Trade Center. Mordicai Gerstein's book about this event, THE MAN WHO WALKED BETWEEN THE TOWERS (Roaring Brook, $17.95; ages 5 and up), reaches its climax with two dramatic foldout spreads. When I opened the first for a kindergarten class, the 5-year-olds gasped with amazement. In imitation of the feat itself, the stunning image took their breath away.

title: Nicolle Golchin, Nicholas Cannone
description: Nicolle Golchin, a daughter of Lucia Nieto of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Jahanbakhsh Golchin, was married on Friday to Nicholas Cannone, a son of Joanne and Thomas Cannone of Poughquag, N.Y. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

description: THE apartment is filled with ''big house furniture,'' as the Rev. David DeGarmo described it: a massive pine armoire, a rolled-arm sofa large enough to cradle a grown man in full sprawl without having his legs dangle over the arms, a farm table that seats 12, a king size bed.

title: The Substance of Style
description: People don't generally go to Selkirk, New York, to look for the future. Manhattan, yes. L.A., San Francisco, even Seattle. But not Selkirk.

In the ''Swann's Way'' volume of ''In Search of Lost Time,'' it is Marcel, not Charles Swann, who bites into a madeleine.

description: It is the perception in many parts of the world that the Bush administration was redefined on Sept. 11, 2001, by its response to global terrorism, even as a wave of global sympathy engulfed the United States after the attacks.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT all starts at the Cannes Film Festival during a screening of ''Est-Ouest.'' In Brian De Palma's lively FEMME FATALE (2002), Laure Ash (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos), an almost overpoweringly beautiful blonde, sets in motion a diamond heist, which takes place during a torrid lesbian love scene in an otherwise empty ladies' room. Afterward Laure has a chance to start a new life (thanks to a look-alike who commits suicide and to Laure's being upgraded to first class on her flight to the United States) and she does. But eventually she returns to France (with her ambassador husband, played by Peter Coyote), and one annoying paparazzo (Antonio Banderas) is still around, sure to get her into trouble -- Saturday at 10 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4 a.m. on Cinemax.

title: Who's Smoking Now?
description: WHEN Forbes magazine splashed a marijuana leaf on its cover last month, John Buffalo Mailer weighed the propriety of flaunting such images in public. Mr. Mailer, who is just starting out in journalism, said he hoped never to run such a cover. ''It's a personal thing, but I don't believe we should be throwing that in people's faces,'' he said. ''I don't think that's our role.''

title: Francine Alfandary, Laurent Nahon
description: Francine Louise Alfandary and Laurent Edouard Nahon were married last evening at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi Miriam Ancis performed the ceremony.

title: Too Good to Be True or Too Good to Pass Up?
description: TO have a crime, you must have victims. A Ponzi scheme usually has a lot. But in an odd twist, the supposed victims of what the F.B.I. and S.E.C. said was an elaborate Ponzi scheme run by a Gales Ferry company are saying they were never harmed and never lost a nickel until federal authorities raided the place and shut it down in September.

title: Garbo Laughs
description: Kenny lay awake in the smallest room in the house. It had a narrow bed, a narrow desk, and a cupboard-closet that started partway up the wall. In the dark he could make out his desk covered in books - including his bible, the movie guide of 1996 - and his clothes hanging from a hook on the open cupboard door. With his dad he had gone to a used-clothing store and bought the oversized brown-and-white checked-tweed sports jacket and the red-and-pink tie and the long-sleeved blue shirt, his gangster outfit, and his dad had let him borrow, indefinitely, his black fedora. From Bolivia. His dad was a traveller.

description: BACK in 1960, when it seemed that the cute Irish guy might actually make it to the White House, my Irish immigrant parents were almost too superstitious to talk about the idea. Never big on assimilation, they still referred to Ireland as home, even though they had lived in New York for more than 30 years.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Food Inspections Online

title: The Last Word; You Could Already Be a Winner
description: Every year, around the middle of October, the finalists for the National Book Awards are announced to general bafflement. Specifically, it's the fiction shortlist that provokes head-scratching. The fiction prize is the N.B.A.'s flagship honor; its presentation is the high point of the evening in November (this Wednesday, in fact) when the winners are announced. Picking the year's best work of fiction by an American citizen is where the National Book Foundation can claim special expertise over the Pulitzer board, whose prizes get more publicity. The Pulitzer Prizes are awarded by journalists (using suggestions from a jury of authors, critics and academics), but the winner of the National Book Award for fiction is chosen by fellow authors of novels and short stories. Theoretically, they ought to know best, but we're all familiar with that inconvenient gap between theory and practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIE, E.T. BEDFORD ''BUDDY,''
description: DAVIE--E.T. Bedford ''Buddy,'' of Palm Beach, Florida, died at his home in Palm Beach, on Tuesday, November 11, 2003. He had recently celebrated his 90th birthday. His grandfather, Edward T. Bedford, was a Director and a member of the Executive Committee of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey. Mr. Davie was born in Greens Farms, CT on September 19, 1913. He attended Aiken Prep, the Brooks School and was a member of the Class of 1936 at Yale University. ''Buddy'' was a veteran and an accomplished sportsman extraordinaire, excelling in a variety of sports. He was a world class golfer, a black belt in karate and an excellent tennis and squash racquets player. He held many world records in power boats including the current World Outboard Speed Record. Mr. Davie was a member of the Seminole Golf Club in North Palm Beach, the Bath and Tennis Club, the Everglades Club and the Sailfish Club in Palm Beach. ''Buddy'' will be wellremembered for his engaging sense of humor. He is survived by his wife, Dysie, of 44 years, his son, E.T. Bedford Davie, Jr. and his daughter, Deirdre Davie Quonbeck. Mr. Davie will be interred in the Bedford Plot in Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

title: Surprise Delivery

There are little girls all over the world who need a loving home like Silverman's and who would be no less suited than a biological child to enjoy hopscotch, shopping trips and long conversations.

title: Streetscapes/Fifth Avenue Between 125th and 124th Streets; Patient Restoration on a Harlem Brownstone Block
description: DRIVERS caught in southbound traffic on Fifth Avenue as it reaches Mount Morris Park in Harlem are usually so eager to proceed that they rarely glance at the row of 19th-century brownstones that line the block from 125th to 124th Street. But over the last two decades, as prices have risen, some owners have remade at least part of that stretch of what had become shabby rooming houses. Now, two decades after it began on a small scale, the total renovation of one house is almost complete.

title: A Quick Swing Through Little Costa Rica
description: The tourists appear to be blocking one lane of the coastal road outside Trcoles, a busy thoroughfare that sees a lot of serious 18-wheelers coming and going from the Pacific port of Caldera. When the first burly local driver arrives with his rig and brakes, he appears a bit distressed. He looks thoughtfully at the bus and at the foreigners lined up along the highway. None of them, however, look at him. Their binoculars and cameras are fixed on the astonishing sight of six scarlet macaws in a nearby ceiba tree. Scarlet macaws in the wild are mind-bending, the total technicolor parrots, flaunting every color in the rainbow. To realize that we still share the ordinary world with the scarlet macaw, that it's not some kind of copyrighted entertainment phenomenon in Orlando, Fla., is to hope good things for the future.

The musical genius born in a two-room house in Tupelo, Miss., died in a kind of squalor not far along the road here, amid the wreckage of his own global fame. The public man has been well delineated. The private one remains somehow fugitive, and yet his presence can be powerfully felt here at a storage place near his homestead shrine where the air smells of must and where the documents of a singular life are stored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELDEN, KEVIN M.
description: BELDEN--Kevin M. Age 40, of New York City passed away unexpectedly of a cardiac arrest on Tuesday, November 4, 2003. Kevin graduated from Catholic University in 1986, and received his MBA from University of Notre Dame in 1989. At the time of his death, he was Executive Director of Integrated Marketing at Conde Nast. Kevin's career was marked by the top names in the publishing industry, having worked for Details, In Style, Entertainment Weekly, Talk Magazine and Disney Publications in various positions of creative marketing. While at Gentleman's Quarterly he initiated the ''GQ Man of the Year Award'' which continues today. Throughout his career, he raised millions of dollars for a multitude of charitable causes; most recently being the 2003 Ford Breast Cancer Awareness Scarf. A memorial service will be held Monday, November 17, at 6:15 PM at Church of St. Francis Xavier, 46 West 16th St, between 5th and 6th Avenues. Memorial contributions can be made to the Physicians' Research Network, 20 West 22 St, 11th flr, NY, NY 10010. Surviving are his parents, Paul III and Shirley Belden and his brothers, Paul IV and Todd Belden.

title: The Rabbit Factory
description: The kitten was wild and skinny, and its tail looked almost broken, kind of hung down crooked. It had been around the neighborhood for several days, darting here and there, dodging traffic sometimes, and Arthur had been trying to catch it, setting the Havahart cage in the yard and baiting it with anchovies, but even though the kitten seemed desperately hungry, it would not enter the trap. It only sat and looked at the bait, and at them. But there was no big rush. Arthur had plenty of money and plenty of time to mess with stuff like that whenever he wasn't sitting in front of the big-screen TV watching westerns. Sometimes he dozed off.

title: Decades Later, a Cast of Players Faces the Biggest Chill
description: IN Denys Arcand's ''Barbarian Invasions,'' a middle-aged history professor named Rmy is diagnosed with inoperable cancer and must use his remaining weeks to cope with the terror of dying and confront the sins of his past. Terminal illness tends to bring out the worst in filmmakers -- lugubrious sentimentality in the hacks and high-minded poeticizing in the artistes. But at 62, Mr. Arcand, a French-Canadian director known for his lively intellect and historical perspective, has what it takes to look death in the face and take its measure. There are devastating moments in ''The Barbarian Invasions'' (which opens Friday), but the movie feels vigorous and elemental. It's also entertaining. As Mr. Arcand's longtime fans know, Rmy (played by the popular French-Canadian actor Rmy Girard) has a lot of sins to confront.

The goal is to look comfortable in the halls of American power and ambition. But this presents a conundrum for the German chancellor.

title: Superstardom Is Boring: Jay-Z Quits (Again)
description: JAY-Z is bored with hip-hop. It was around 1 a.m. on a Thursday in late June, and he was in the V.I.P. room at the 40/40 Club, the sports bar he owns on West 25th Street in Manhattan. The professional basketball stars Antoine Walker and Tracy McGrady sat on one side of the room playing cards while Jay-Z was in a corner holding court with the producer Timbaland and the 18-year-old basketball phenom LeBron James, who seemed more interested in playing a video game on his cellphone. There was a neo-Rat Pack vibe to the scene: lounging millionaires, tall models playing pool, and a sexy waitress in a short skirt offering cognac and cigars. Jay-Z seemed to be on top of the world. But then he let slip that he would soon retire from hip-hop. His next album, ''The Black Album,'' would be his last. ''It's not like it was with Big and Pac,'' he said, referring to the rappers Notorious B.I.G. and Tupac Shakur, whose deaths in the late 90's ushered in a new era in hip-hop. ''Hip-hop's corny now.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Outside the Brochures
description: Draped in beaded jewelry and bright cloth, the Masai people of East Africa are familiar images in travel brochures and on posters taped to the walls of tour agencies in places like Nairobi and Dar es Salaam. But to the photojournalist Elizabeth L. Gilbert, the Masai are a culture existing in ''a fragile moment of transition,'' their traditional ways profoundly threatened by modernity. In BROKEN SPEARS: A Maasai Journey (Atlantic Monthly, $50), Gilbert displays, in dramatic black-and-white photographs and in an accompanying text that is nearly as beguiling as her pictures, the results of the four-year mission she assigned herself in 1998: to document, before it is too late, the rituals that shape the lives of the Masai. She traveled deep into the 5,000-square-mile tract of wilderness that begins south of Nairobi and stretches far into Tanzania -- Masailand -- where most of the approximately 400,000 Masai make their homes; many of them raising cattle near their thatched houses mortared with sun-hardened cow dung, and marking the stages of their lives with elaborate, intensely emotional rites. Through often delicate negotiations, Gilbert gained access to circumcision rituals for both sexes, an arranged marriage involving a 14-year-old girl and rites marking the induction and retirement of Masai warriors, those ''tall, flirtatious and confident'' young men who spend the seven most fulfilling years of their lives in the bush, hunting, defending their camps and raiding the camps of others. Gilbert's remarkable photographs of a traditional lion hunt -- the ultimate event in a warrior's life but now illegal in much of Masailand -- are but a few of the vivid illustrations of her journey into ''history suspended in time.'' Suzanne MacNeille

title: Small Store Stands Tall In the World of Buttons

That's all it says, and that's all it needs to say because buttons are virtually all that is sold at the shoebox-size shop in Rockville Centre. Buttons as big as demitasse saucers. Buttons as bitty as ladybugs. Round rhinestone buttons sparkling in a rainbow of hues. Buttons made of buffalo horn, shiny brass, leather, fabric and carved wood; funky, fluffy real-mink buttons and sleekly chic leopard-skin buttons. Up-to-the-minute buttons made of transparent plastic; iridescent mother-of-pearl buttons, some almost a century old. Smiley face buttons, saxophone buttons, flower-power buttons, alligator buttons, star buttons, cowboy boot buttons. Vintage buttons that sell for as much as $30 each; simple white shirt buttons that can be bought for as little as 5 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HESS, ILSE JOHANNA
description: HESS--Ilse Johanna. On November 12, 2003, age 89, at home in Chevy Chase, MD. Cherished wife of Charles Hess, of blessed memory. Adored mother of twins, Marion Ein Lewin (Larry) of Chevy Chase and Steven Hess (Sarah Atkinson) of Rochester, NY. Treasured grandmother of Mark and Jon Ein, Michael (Jennifer), Daniel, David (Diane) and Suzanne Hess. Great-grandmother of Eli, Jacob and Alexandra. Beloved by Daniel, Linn and Meyer Lewin and countless others. Born in Recklinghausen, Germany, Ilse fled with her husband to Amsterdam in 1936, where their children were later born. The heroic efforts of the couple saved the lives of their children and many others during the occupation of Amsterdam, five months in the Westerbork concentration camp and two years in the Bergen Belsen concentration camp. The family emigrated to New York in 1947, and Ilse moved to Friendship Heights in 1990. A private burial will be held at Cedar Park cemetery in New Jersey; a memorial service in Chevy Chase will be held at the Village Center of Friendship Heights on Sunday, November 23, 2003, at 4 p.m. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Village Center of Friendship Heights, 4433 South Park Avenue, Chevy Chase, MD 20815, attention: The Ilse Hess Memorial Fund.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: As a Harvard Law graduate who withdrew from partnership in corporate-law practice to stay home with my three sons, I thank Lisa Belkin for her careful and nuanced treatment of the issue of professional women opting out of the work force (Oct. 26). I was particularly interested by her discussion of whether, and on what terms, the professional world will take us back after a hiatus to raise children. In my experience in the legal world, there is a vested interest in perpetuating the notion that the only path to success is through unremitting sacrifice. ''The law is a jealous mistress,'' we were told. As long as time at home to raise children is regarded as a potentially ruinous blemish on a rsum, we're not there yet.

title: A Musical Theater Gem Is Reborn at Goodspeed
description: A delectable and important nugget of musical theater history is yours for the taking at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, where a musical version of ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,'' is playing.

title: Militants Are Holding Back Recovery in Central Iraq
description: As another relief agency closed its doors in the capital this week, a group of Iraqis and Americans in this city 100 miles southeast of Baghdad poured concrete for the foundation of another elementary school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BADER, BEATRICE
description: BADER--Beatrice. November 13, 2003, after a long illness. Beloved mother, adored grandmother and great grandmother. From your loving family, we will always miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIDOFF, GERALD J.
description: WIDOFF--Gerald J. 11/4/22 11/13/03. A native New Yorker, he attended Townsend Harris High School and City College, where he won many international fencing competitions and is listed in the City College Athletic Hall of Fame. Gerald served in the U.S. Army Intelligence in WWII as a Japanese interpreter with Merrill's Marauders in the Burma theater of operations. In civilian life, he was a professional violinist and Concert Master with major symphony orchestras. He was a co-founder of Discount Records, a nationwide chain of retail record stores. In recent years, he was on the board of the Maverick Concert series in Woodstock, NY. Gerald was extraordinarily well-read and witty, with a great depth of knowledge of music, literature, politics and culture. He is survived by his three children, musicians Antony and Adam and Dr. Juliet Widoff, Juliet's partner Jacqueline Woodson, his granddaughter Toshi, two sisters, Dr. Judith Greenberg and Libby Saines, and his longtime and devoted companion Adrienne Owen. An informal celebration of his life will be held Saturday, November 22, at 2 PM at 228 Meads Mountain Rd., Woodstock, NY. For directions, call Adam at 917602-4397. Donations in Gerald Widoff's name can be made to Maverick Concerts, P.O. Box 9, Woodstock, NY 12498.

With skin that cracked like old parchment, Wepner, now 64, was known as the Bayonne Bleeder because he cut so easily, mostly around the eyes. He claims to have been sewn up with 326 stitches, including 23 when he was stopped by Muhammad Ali in 1975 at the Coliseum outside Cleveland.

Bragg had reportedly been reinforced at nearby Shelbyville, "with 40,000 [new men], we are receiving reinforcements & there may be a battle. If we don't go to the rebs they will come to us." Either way, he didn't mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRUSSLIN, HERBERT
description: PRUSSLIN--Herbert. 81, on November 14, 2003. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn. Beloved husband of the late Hilda Prusslin. Loving father of Norman, Marc and Gail Prusslin, and father-in-law of Susan Risoli and Michael Yellin. Proud grandfather of Alexandra, Allison, Amanda, Hannah and Rebecca. Adoring brother of Leonore Siegel and the late Helen Lewis. Loving son of the late Tennie and Joseph Prusslin. He will be remembered for his love of family, strength and gentle spirit.

title: The Difference Between 'and' and 'or'
description: Q. I am the owner of a co-op apartment. My brother, his wife and their three children have been living in my apartment for 15 years. Recently, the board authorized the co-op's lawyer to file an eviction action for violation of the proprietary lease. The lease prohibits subletting of an apartment without board consent. However, the lease also provides that the shareholder and members of the shareholder's family may use the apartment as a private dwelling without the co-op's consent. Family members include a spouse, parents, children, parents-in-law, brothers, sisters and grandchildren. The co-op's lawyer argues that my brother and his family are considered sublessees since I do not live with them and that I must submit a sublet application and pay a sublet fee in accordance with the co-op's policy. Is my brother considered a sublessee? . . . Zeke Gropper, Manhattan.

title: Sugar And Spice, And Sour Dads
description: CHILD rearing, divorce and sexism are each, on their own, topics that can fill a long day's worth of conversation. Throw them together, and you have fodder for weeks of debate.

description: BORAK--Mae. On November 13, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Pat Hirsch, Marc and Phylis Borak. Loving sister of Thelma Chabot. Adoring Nana of David and Debbie Hirsch, Hillary and Todd Emmerman, Howard and Pam Hirsch, Jennifer and Amy Borak. Precious great-grandmother Mamie to Alexandra and Jonathan, Matthew and Emily, Miranda and Caroline. Special aunt of Jeffrey and Renee Citron. She gave us her wisdom, humor and passion for life. We will keep you forever in our hearts. Services Friday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Mr. Kerry fired his campaign manager, Jim Jordan, and two other campaign officials quickly followed, protesting what many of Mr. Kerry's aides told him was a bit of scapegoating by a candidate who seems on the rocks.

title: Hello Pully, Ciao Hoodie
description: Just as the sheepskin Ugg boot reaches the grimy, matted peak of its popularity, another wardrobe essential is trickling up from surf culture. The oversize pullover hooded sweatshirt -- the ''pully'' -- is popping up in high-end stores, slowly elbowing out shrunken cashmere hoodies, which have virtually become the symbol for Fashion Victim. A heavyweight cotton pully by Rogan (right; $195 at www.rogannyc.com) is cut high in the back so it doesn't droop sloppily over the hips, and the neckline is dropped so the hood doesn't clutch at the throat. At Satine, a West Hollywood boutique, a pully by Shopaholic is embroidered with birds and flowers ($105, 323-655-2142). Charlotte Ronson adds athletic-inspired detailing ($65 at Henri Bendel), while Lucien Pellat-Finet pays homage to the pully's laid-back roots by silk-screening an image of a marijuana leaf on the back of its $790 version (at Barneys New York). CHRISTINE SHEA

Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPTON, SOLOMON
description: LIPTON -- Solomon. Passed away November 15, at 89, as a result of complications from open-heart surgery. The devoted father of Roger, David and Marilyn. The beloved grandfather of Leslie, Hannah, and Benjamin. The loving brother of Marty and the late Ruth Weisman. He lived a full life, a dedicated family man, a consummate professional (C.P.A.) to the end, skied into his late seventies, played singles tennis into his late eighties, self sufficient and competent until he entered the hospital three weeks before his passing. Didn't want to be inactive or dependent in his last years, which his failing heart would have undoubtedly created. Philanthropic and generous in spirit to all he came in contact with. He was a mensch in every sense of the word, and his memory will inspire all who knew him. He showed us how to live, and he showed us how to leave. Services will be conducted at the Menorah Chapel on Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Monday, November 17, at 11:30 AM.

description: THE 25 or so cars in the overflowing parking lot on a recent night at Wellman's Pub here had license plates representing a dozen states and bumper stickers from three current presidential campaigns, not to mention decals from six colleges and universities.

title: Deep Skin Diving
description: Kiehl's first foray into anti-aging products, Abyssine cream ($38), was created to defend skin from environmental stress. Made of ''Abyssine 657'' -- described as a protective molecule harvested from deep-sea micro-organisms -- the cream also has soy and wheat proteins, purported to minimize the appearance of fine lines. The first shipment sold out in New York within a week; the second arrived Friday to a 500-customer waiting list.

title: The Takedown Artist

title: Remote Possibilities
description: When cat lovers go on vacation and leave their animals behind, they usually worry neurotically: did they leave enough food in the bowl for Fluffy? But there isn't much they can do about it. That is, unless they've got what Karen Lurker's got -- a pet feeder you can control from anywhere in the world using your mobile phone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, SEYMOUR
description: COHN -- Seymour. Beloved son of the late Charles Cohn and Bella Cohen Cohn, adored brother of the late Mildred Cohn, Maurice Cohn, Irene Colvin, Pearl C. Miller and Sylvan Lawrence, devoted husband of the late Estelle G. Cohn, cherished father of Paula Hallman and Marc Cohn, revered brother-in-law of Leon and Joan Grossman and Alice Lawrence, beloved grandfather of Bridget Hallman, Samantha Hallman, Ellen and Corey Menscher and Daniel Cohn, respected father-in-law of Eric Hallman and Melanie Cohn and uncle or great-uncle to each and every member of the family. Even in a large family noted for its accomplishments, Seymour was an over-achiever. He was an outstanding athlete throughout high school and college; his favorite sports being football and basketball. In what would become the hallmark of his life, Seymour met every challenge he faced head-on, with his eyes open regardless of any pitfalls or consequences. Seymour began his long career in the real estate business at any early age, working for his late uncle Elias A. Cohen, one of the great real estate men of his generation. After World War II ended, Seymour, newly married, decided to open his own firm. Soon after, he decided to team up with his younger brother Sylvan, beginning a uniquely close working relationship which lasted until Sylvan's passing in 1981. It was said the two lived and breathed real estate. In the 1950's, at the end of each long day, they would continue to talk real estate during the long drive home. In what will surely be remembered as one of the great New York success stories of the last hundred years, the two brothers, who started with nothing and labored tirelessly for almost 30 years, had amassed a real estate portfolio of over 100 properties, located mainly in downtown and midtown Manhattan and in Brooklyn. Over the course of sixty-odd years, the great names in real estate, people who will be remembered for years to come, made deals with, knew and respected Seymour Cohn. Many will remember Seymour for his tenacity and determination. His great intelligence, imagination and ingenuity were always balanced by a keen sense of the practical. Always thinking about the future, Seymour maintained an ever-watchful eye on the present. For over 40 years, Seymour devoted himself to a sport he so enjoyed. Like a real estate deal done right, nothing pleased him as much as watching a win by one of his homebred Thoroughbreds. As he did in the real estate business, Seymour's tireless and unflagging effort made over the years, earned him the respect of everyone with a true understanding of New York horse racing. Despite his success, Seymour particularly enjoyed life's simple joys, especially his family, with whom he kept in constant touch. Seymour relished his summers spent at Tranquillity Camp, started by his late uncle Elias A. Cohen in 1919 as a summer haven in the country for deserving children with outstanding academic records. Carrying on the family's long-held belief in helping others in the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige,'' Seymour devoted an enormous amount of time and energy to his beloved Tranquillity. As the special man he was, Seymour's philanthropies, both great and small, were as varied as the people whose lives he touched. Seymour was one of the original founders of the North Shore Synagogue in Syosset, NY. In later years he was devoted to the restoration of the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. These were only a few of his most enduring qualities. Seymour will forever be remembered in our hearts for his ever-ready smile and that twinkle in his eye, maybe even a wink. The passing of his larger-than-life presence has left a void which can never be filled. Services will be held on Sunday, November 16, 2003, 9 AM, at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY, (718) 263-7600. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Tranquillity Camp Inc. or the Charles Cohn Foundation Inc. would be appreciated.

title: Too Much
description: Parents who object to the amount of homework their children are given often are frustrated by the uselessness of the assigned work. It is painful to watch an 8-year-old child spend an hour, for example, on a ''science'' project that involves cutting out pictures of sea creatures from magazines. In fact, many parents I know agree that the most dreaded word in elementary school education is ''project.'' It is even more painful to watch a child labor over a math worksheet full of badly worded questions and inane instructions. (''Use estimation to decide if $35.09 plus $35.21 is more or less than $70. Explain.'' I'm not making this up.) To save our children from wasting their time or tearing their hair out, we sometimes just do the homework for them. It's no wonder that when the kids bring their graded work back home, we ask them, ''What did I get?''

title: On Guard With a Stiff-Cardboard Upper Lip
description: A clean-cut soldier with a row of decorations over his heart stands watch night and day from behind a wall of sandbags at a New York State armory on Manor Road. As he looks out the window of his guard booth, he never gets tired and he never blinks. That is because he is a life-size poster.

description: THE link between steel and orange juice may not seem apparent at first blush, but it will soon become so.

title: The Week Ahead
description: DITTOHEADS, TURN THOSE RADIOS UP Rush Limbaugh will be back on the air tomorrow. Mr. Limbaugh, the nation's highest-rated and highest-paid radio talk show host, was last heard on Oct. 10, when he announced that he was addicted to prescription painkillers and was checking into a rehabilitation center. His return was announced by his brother, David, on  where else?  his show, which continued with guest hosts, including Matt Drudge, the Web gossip. "Rush has successfully completed the first phase of his treatment," David Limbaugh said. "He's very realistic about the long road ahead of him, and he's committed to staying the course."

title: United Nations Role in Iraq Waits for New Timetables
description: When United Nations officials speak of Iraq these days, any impulse to gloat is quickly supplanted by frustration over the harsh realities of the situation in Iraq and sadness over the loss of 22 colleagues and visitors who died in a bombing of their Baghdad headquarters in August.

His golden 2001 Sydre ''Argelette,'' a biodynamic dry sparkling cider, can accompany Thanksgiving dinner from aperitif to dessert. Richly tangy and supple, with low alcohol (4 percent), it's like a brilliant blend of wine, lager beer, honey and apple pie. Nancy's, 313 Columbus Avenue (75th Street), asks $16. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Head-to-Head Drug Combat
description: A clinical trial that pitted two cholesterol-lowering drugs against each other provided strong evidence last week that one worked much better than the other in curbing the volume of artery-clogging plaque. Whether that matters much in helping patients prevent heart attacks and strokes remains to be demonstrated. Even so, the test is a welcome sign that drug companies may be increasingly willing to compare their own products with competitive drugs head-to-head. Assuming such studies are objective and thorough, they can provide patients and doctors with information that has long been unavailable.

title: Letters
description: Our article on the aftermath in Iraq drew mail calling for patience. Other readers called the ''cruelest'' cure for phobias plain common sense. An essay on homework prompted grumblings about more work for mom and dad. And many women continued to support or to challenge the decision to opt out of the office.

title: Portugal Would Stage Americas Cup
description: CASCAIS, Portugal, Nov. 12  It is easy to imagine the next America's Cup here in 2007. It is easy to picture high-tech yachts gliding offshore instead of the cargo ships that were plodding by in the sunshine earlier this week. Or to imagine Russell Coutts and his formidable band of Alinghi mercenaries driving their luxury cars or taking their training runs along the pretty coastal road with its ocean views and seafood shacks. Or to imagine Patrick Monteiro de Barros, commodore of the Clube Naval de Cascais, greeting the sailing world in any one of the six languages he speaks.

title: An Online Boost For the AAA
description: The AAA, is revamping its Web sites to compete with online travel agencies like Expedia, Travelocity and Orbitz.

title: City in the Sky
description: The phone rang at 7 A.M.. in the four-story, red-brick town house on East Sixty-fifth Street where David Rockefeller was just finishing up his breakfast before his commute to work. Rockefeller, the youngest grandson of America's first billionaire, liked to ride the Lexington Avenue subway downtown to his office at Chase National Bank, one hand clutching the dangling strap, the other a newspaper folded lengthwise so that he could read it in the morning crush. As he swayed with the unsteady rhythms of the city's populist heart, he could have been any other executive on his way to work in Lower Manhattan. But the unexpected phone call on this day in February 1955 meant that Rockefeller would make his commute in the back of a gray Cadillac limousine that carried two telephones, enough room for seven passengers, and license plates that read, very simply, WZ. Those were the initials of William Zeckendorf, the unpredictable, inventive, and stupendously energetic real estate promoter-and an old Rockefeller family friend-who had called to say he had an idea that couldn't wait.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 2 by Francisco Goldman about meeting Gabriel Garcia Marquez and other Latin American fiction writers misidentified a Marcel Proust character discussed by the Mexican novelist Carlos Fuentes in a lecture Goldman attended. In the ''Swann's Way'' volume of ''In Search of Lost Time,'' it is Marcel, not Charles Swann, who bites into a madeleine.

title: Jennifer Hodges, John Edwards

The Rev. Christopher Martin performed the ceremony at the Episcopal church of All Saints' Parish in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Farrah Fawcett's Early Exit
description: IF the classic actor's nightmare is being caught without lines, this might run a close second: having one's Broadway play close after only a week of previews. That's exactly what happened to Farrah Fawcett, who was starring in ''Bobbi Boland,'' the tragicomic tale of a former Miss Florida. The play, by Nancy Hasty, was produced by Joyce Johnson -- a neophyte producer and one of the heirs, by marriage, to the Johnson pharmaceutical fortune -- after she saw a production of it Off Broadway in 2001 and envisioned it as a perfect showcase for Ms. Fawcett. At the time, Bruce Weber, writing in The New York Times, found the play's first act promising but called its second act a ''plot-driven melodrama,'' adding: ''It's a disappointingly uncomplicated conclusion, and unfair to the interesting woman we've grown to like and even admire.''

title: Hit Replay
description: Anthony Wood had two goals in the summer of 2002: get in shape and figure out what to do with the rest of his life. The year before, the 36-year-old Silicon Valley entrepreneur had sold ReplayTV, the digital video recorder company that he founded, for $125 million plus the assumption of debt. Now recruiters were calling him about C.E.O. posts at technology companies, and he had to make a decision -- take a job or start all over. He packed up his Palo Alto household for the season and with his wife, Susan, and two toddlers, headed for Sunriver, Ore., a resort area in Deschutes National Forest. ''It's not like Aspen,'' Wood says. ''It's a regular place, and it's beautiful.'' It was there, biking on a trail surrounded by ponderosa and lodgepole pines, sandwiched between the river and snowcapped mountains, that he resolved his fate: ''I settled on the idea of starting a company in the digital-media-player space,'' he says, ''since it was going like gangbusters.'' He couldn't get excited about being a ''hired gun.''

title: Martin Luther King of Manhattan Wins Title

title: The Cruelest Cure
description: Of course David H. Barlow's ''cure'' works (Lauren Slater, Nov. 2). People have forever been proving that it works! Those who fall off bicycles are urged to ride again. Those who survive automobile accidents are urged to drive again, lest they become paralyzed by their fear. Overcoming irrational fear is part of growing up. Some call it ''biting the bullet.''
