title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEUTSCH, SHARRY
description: DEUTSCH--Sharry. Of West Orange, NJ. Suddenly on November 7, at age 55. Beloved wife of Howard. Mother of Michael and his spouse Meira, Daniel and Adam. Daughter of Florence and Abraham Cohn, sister of Adrienne. A respected and admired teaching assistant at the Solomon Schechter Day School in Cranford, NJ, and life member of Hadassah. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Young Judaea, care of Hadassah House, 50 W. 58 St., 8th Floor, NYC 10019.

title: Ambra Kervellec, Sean Teague
description: Ambra Selene Kervellec, the daughter of Mary Mancuso Klindt and the stepdaughter of Steven Klindt of Tampa, Fla., was married yesterday to Sean Martin Teague, a son of Brigid and James Teague of Blauvelt, N.Y. The Rev. J. Colm Campbell performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Beaten Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Workers Are Shifting From Private to State Jobs
description: A federal order requiring the state to hire more social workers to improve oversight of abuse cases is having an unintended consequence: the workers, lured by bigger state paychecks, are leaving private social service agencies in droves.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic View column last Sunday, about a move in Congress to overhaul corporate tax laws, misstated the cost of a provision in a House bill that would reduce taxes on foreign royalties for American movies. It would be $535 million over 10 years, not $597 billion.

title: The Poet and the War Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiking in Tuscany; New Years in Paris; Acapulco Family Trip
description: Hiking in Tuscany

title: For a Taste of Sauerkraut or Strudel
description: WHEN autumn comes and cold winds blow, thoughts turn to kassler rippchen, bratwurst, potato pancakes and red cabbage. That piece of grilled fish and a sprightly salad, which were so appealing just a few weeks ago, taste like a penance when there's a nip in the air.

title: Behind Durst Acquittal, a Defense Team That Almost Wasn't
description: The lawyers who successfully defended Robert A. Durst against murder charges in Galveston, Tex., are the toast of talk radio on Houston and national television programs. But the $2 million legal dream team -- Dick DeGuerin, Mike Ramsey and Chip Lewis -- almost disintegrated before filing its first motion, because of a war waged by Mr. Durst's wife, Debrah Lee Charatan, against the Durst family, according to interviews and transcripts of jailhouse conversations.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Assisted Living, With Assist to Nature Preserve
description: A BLIGHTED area in this Nassau County village is being revitalized through collaborative projects involving the county, an education center and Sterling Glen Communities, a New York City-based company with more than 250 assisted living residences in the state.

title: Israelis Raid Palestinian Camp, Killing 1
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 16  Israeli forces raided a Palestinian refugee camp in the southern Gaza Strip early today, killing one Palestinian and arresting a man the army held responsible for digging smuggling tunnels under the Egyptian border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'NEIL BIDWELL, KATHAR INE
description: O'NEIL BIDWELL -- Kathar ine. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 455 East 57th Street note with great sadness the death of Katharine O'Neil Bidwell, a member of the board and much admired resident. We extend our condolences to her husband, Truman, and to her family.

title: AT LEAST 17 DEAD AS 2 U.S. COPTERS COLLIDE OVER IRAQ
description: Two American Black Hawk helicopters collided in midair and crashed Saturday evening in the northern city of Mosul, killing at least 17 of the American soldiers aboard and injuring 5 others, officials said. One other soldier was reported missing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, DONALD
description: KLEIN--Donald. Of Armonk, NY. Died peacefully on November 15, 2003. Respected lawyer and loyal friend. He is survived by his wife Barbara, son Jason, daughter Zoe and other beloved family members. His family would like to express gratitude to all of those who showed their love and care. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. Donations in his honor can be made to: The Musella Foundation, 1100 Peninsula Blvd, Hewlett, NY 11557. All donations will go towards brain tumor research.

title: Success Stories In New Jersey Rock: The Un-Springsteen
description: THIRTY years on, it's still mostly impossible to write about New Jersey rock acts that made good without paying tribute to Bruce Springsteen. His glory days refuse to pass him by, but that says more about his rarefied perch in the rock world than it does about the state's record of turning out stars.

title: PAGE TWO: THE READING FILE
description: Taking the Dj Vu View Of the Occupation in Iraq

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BAKER, JACK
description: BAKER--Jack, Nov 17, 1994 Loving thoughts of you are always in our hearts & minds. Paula, Beau and Bobby

title: Homework: Liked or Loathed but Still Remembered
description: Done but not forgotten. That's the verdict from readers who wrote about their most memorable homework assignments, the very best and the very worst. Here is a sampling of projects that stood the test of time:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLAUM, HERBERT L.
description: FLAUM--Herbert L. Father of Lloyd and Stuart, brother of Hortense Laub, passed away November 15, 2003. Respectfully, a private funeral will ensue. Should friends desire, contributions can be made in memory of Herbert Flaum to the Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Mt. Sinai Hospital, 1255 5th Ave, NYC 10029; or your favorite charity

title: Rutgers Puts Up a Fight, But B.C. Goes the Distance
description: The field-goal attempt by Ryan Sands, from 43 yards with 1 minute 32 seconds remaining, seemed to flutter forever in the chilly fall air before it landed, a tad wide to the right. Had it been a few feet longer and a few feet straighter, Rutgers could have taken the game to overtime, and anything could have happened. Rutgers came that close to beating an opponent with more tradition, a better record and more talent.

title: Oodles From Doodles
description: LANDING with a thud in the why-didn't-I-think-of-that category is Kids Art Inc., a company that raises funds for schools while turning children's doodles into works of art.

title: The Takedown Artist
description: In a couple of years no one will remember Dale Peck or his mean-spirited rantings. He's got about 4 of his proverbial 15 minutes left. On the other hand, 100 years from now, readers will continue to marvel at the literary magnificence of Dickens, Roth, Faulkner and others who have met Peck's wrath.

title: In Longstanding Plan for Met Expansion, Battle Line Is Fifth Avenue
description: A dispute that has been brewing on the Upper East Side for more than two years has the elements of a typical neighborhood fight: an organization with plans to expand; residents with worries about extra traffic and noise; and, as of last week, a lawsuit.

title: Should John Hinckley Go Free?
description: On March 30, 1981 -- after a half-dozen years of aimless wandering between Texas, Colorado, Connecticut and California; after a stint living in Hollywood, where he hoped to become famous as a songwriter; after stalking President Jimmy Carter at campaign stops in Ohio and stalking the young actress Jodie Foster at Yale -- John W. Hinckley Jr. finally settled on a course of action. He awakened at the Park Central Hotel in Washington. He got breakfast from McDonald's. He left behind a note in his hotel room, addressed to Foster. ''Jodie,'' he pleaded, ''I'm asking you to please look into your heart and at least give me the chance, with this historical deed, to gain your respect and love.'' At 2:25 p.m., as President Ronald Reagan walked to his limousine after delivering a speech at the Washington Hilton, Hinckley fired six shots with a .22-caliber pistol that wounded four people and cast him, forever, as an American pariah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, BILLIE ANN LEVINE
description: KELLY--Billie Ann Levine. On November 14, 2003. Beloved wife of Brian, loving mother of Daniel and James, and step-daughter Elizabeth. Devoted daughter of Lenore and Irvin Levine. Cherished sister of Margaret, Connie, Cathy and Milon. She is, and will always be, the light of our lives.

title: Nets Finally Break Free And Reach 100 Points
description: The Nets needed 10 games to find their backdoor passes and halfcourt lobs, but in one night with the Atlanta Hawks they rediscovered their old fast-breaking selves.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Pam Newell Bradley, Tony Goetz Elementary, Muskogee, Okla., Oct. 27, 2003

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISCHER, LAURENZ SVANTE
description: FISCHER--Laurenz Svante. In deep sorrow and with great appreciation for his many intellectual and personal gifts we have to take leave of Laurenz Svante Fischer, 1925-2003. There will be a memorial service on December 6, 3:30PM at the Church of St. Paul & St. Andrew, 263 West 86th St. Please no flowers. The Fischer/Peterson Family The Justice Family

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 2 about a weekend in Chicago on a $1,500 budget referred incorrectly to ''Secret in the Wings,'' a play at the Lookingglass Theater. It is a remounting of the production originally staged by the theater in 1991; it is not new. The article also misstated the title of Mary Zimmerman; she is the director of the play, not artistic director of the company.

title: Page Two: Nov. 9-15; ROSIE'S NUMBERS, REVEALED
description: The judge suggested that there will be little in the way of monetary damages in the trial over who is to blame for the demise of Rosie magazine, but there is plenty of collateral damage to the publishing industry.

title: New Tape, Said to Be by Hussein, Assails U.S. and Iraqi Allies
description: MOSUL, Iraq, Nov. 16  An Arab television station broadcast a new audiotape today that it said had been recorded by the deposed Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein in which he mixed invective against Israel, calls for holy war and curses on American and other foreign occupation troops in Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page caption in this section on Nov. 2 with a picture grouping about travel on a budget in three American cities misstated the name of a neighborhood in Atlanta noted for shopping and restaurants. It is Virginia Highland, not Highlands.

title: Private Sector; A Bet on Beef (and Sizzle) Pays Off
description: WHEN Jair Coser arrived in Texas six years ago from So Paulo with a plan to open a chain of high-end Brazilian steakhouses in the United States, restaurateurs told him that he was crazy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIDWELL, KATHARINE TUDOR O'NEIL
description: BIDWELL--Katharine Tudor O'Neil, of New York, NY and Fishers Island, NY on November 13, 2003, an amazing mother, wife and grandmother. She devoted her life to her family and to education and music. Her memory will be a beacon for her family and friends. Funeral Services Thursday, November 20th, 1 P.M., at St. Thomas Church, One West 53rd St., Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Katharine Bidwell Foundation for Young Singers C/O Rosemary McGunnigle, Thelen Reid & Priest LLP, 875 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022 would be appreciated.

title: Academy Needs State Certification
description: To the Editor:

title: Even in Fund Families, Parents Can Play Favorites
description: A NEW study has concluded that mutual fund families often play favorites with their funds. They do this, it says, by giving certain funds extra shares of the most-sought-after initial public offerings and by arranging for funds in a family to take the opposite sides of certain trades, to the advantage of a chosen few of those funds.

title: A Spot of Kitsch Keeps High Art Honest
description: IT'S very easy to feel envious of Paola Antonelli. One fancies her life as curator of design at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan to be an endless series of charming intellectual and aesthetic enigmas, mused over for hours with a large box of chocolates close at hand. Is this chair really a whole new paradigm? This coffeepot is genius, but how genius? Was this the typewriter that truly exemplified the Bauhaus?

title: Energy Bill Could Upend Lawsuits Over Gasoline Additive
description: The Authors of sweeping energy legislation made public on Saturday said they believed they had assembled a balanced measure that would win Congressional approval, even as the proposal faced new criticism over its benefits to oil companies.

title: Beguiled by Botswana
description: What strikes you first is the sky and its emptiness. There is nothing there, just air of a blue that is so attenuated that it is almost white. You stand there, on the tarmac of Seretse Khama Airport, you breathe in the dry air, feel the sun upon your neck and you know that now you have reached the edge. Just a few miles away, over the scrub plain, is the Kalahari and its singing emptiness. You are in Botswana, a country that relatively few people visit but that is in many respects one of the most remarkable countries of Africa.

title: Iraqis Agree To Move Fast To Establish A Government
description: Buoyed by an American promise of independence by June, Iraqi political leaders on Saturday pledged to quickly organize elections and build a democratic government on the ruins of Saddam Hussein's dictatorship.

title: Subway-Surfing Cadet in Critical Condition
description: A merchant marine cadet from an academy in the Bronx remained in critical condition yesterday, a day after he and a fellow cadet were struck by an overhead beam while riding atop a subway car.

title: Taking a Child Abroad, Alone
description: IT was supposed to be an idyllic week of father-daughter togetherness in Mexico.

title: Manning Remains Sturdy Beneath a Heavy Burden
description: In the springtime before football season, a limousine pulled onto the Indiana state fairgrounds carrying a hidden figure to a receiving line of officials and celebrities, among them Peyton Manning, the quarterback of the Indianapolis Colts.

title: St. Petersburg
description: St. Petersburg's skyline is newly muscular, with high-rise luxury condos, the $40 million BayWalk shopping and entertainment complex and a growing assortment of gleaming hotels and offices.

title: The Housing Project
description: Mrs. D. Lee, a South Korean homemaker, moved into her dream apartment one year ago -- a million-dollar-plus dwelling that also happens to be networked, so she can switch off her washer with her cellphone, surf the Net on her plasma TV or turn up the air-conditioner from her touch-screen computer. There's only one glitch: she has no idea how any of it works.

title: Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended; Thanks to Rod Serling
description: Remembering the Best and Worst Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended Illustrations by Tom Bloom

title: POSTINGS: Coalition for the Homeless; Agency Gets New Building
description: The Coalition for the Homeless, which has been providing services to New York's homeless for 22 years, is settling into a new home at 129 Fulton Street in downtown Manhattan after outgrowing two floors of leased space at 89 Chambers Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADEL, CHARLOTTE F.
description: NADEL--Charlotte F. Died peacefully on November 13 in her 100th year. She was the wife of the late Benjamin Nadel and is survived by her sons, Lawrence, Norman and Joshua, by six grandchildren, Charles, Brian, Melissa, Victoria, Dan and Etyan, and seven great-grandchildren, Emily, Graham, Nicole, Peter, Jamie, Brendan and Lauren. She brought brightness to all she encountered and her gentle dignity will be missed. Services 10AM Sunday, at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: These Are Your Movies On Piracy
description: IF you have been to the movies lately -- and, given that the box office seems headed for another record year, it's likely that you have -- chances are you have seen David Goldstein or Manny Perry. They pop up more frequently on the multiplex screens these days than Neo or Nemo or Nicole Kidman, but Mr. Goldstein and Mr. Perry are not actors. A set painter and a stuntman, respectively, they star in the first two in a series of public service announcements that seem to answer the question, ''Who makes movies?''

title: Angels, Reagan And AIDS In America
description: TONIGHT is the night when Americans might have tuned into Part 1 of ''The Reagans'' on CBS. But the joke is on the whiners who forced the mini-series off the air. Just three weeks from tonight, HBO will present the first three-hour installment of Mike Nichols's film version of Tony Kushner's ''Angels in America,'' starring Al Pacino and Meryl Streep. (Part 2 is a week later.) This epic is, among other things, a searing indictment of how the Reagan administration's long silence stoked the plague of AIDS in the 1980's. If ''Angels'' reaches an audience typical for HBO hits, it could detonate a debate bloody enough to make the fight over ''The Reagans'' look like an exhibition bout.

title: Sports Briefing
description: TENNIS

title: Gers and Perhaps Golf On a Mongolian Vacation
description: LAST summer, Andre Tolme, a hardy Californian, whacked golf balls halfway across Mongolia, treating this vast grassland of rolling hills and occasional sand traps as a par-11,880 course.

title: Kara Kenney, Peter McConville
description: Kara Brigid Kenney, a daughter of Brigid and Edward J. T. Kenney of Ossining, N.Y., was married on Friday to Peter Liam McConville, a son of Barbara and Jack McConville of Jersey City. The Rev. Joseph R. Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Church of St. Joseph, in New York. The Rev. Francis P. Gorman, a cousin of the bride and a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: What Ever Happened to the Great Auk?
description: DANGEROUS PLANET

title: Group Tied to Al Qaeda Says It Bombed Turkish Synagogues
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 16  An obscure terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda claimed responsibility today for the twin truck-bombings at two synagogues here that killed 23 people and wounded more than 300 on Saturday, and Turkish officials said they had evidence that suicide drivers had carried out the blasts.

title: A Museum Increases Its Wingspan
description: THE Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum is generally considered to be the most visited museum in the world, with over nine million visitors a year. But even the most dedicated of those see just a few highlights of the Smithsonian's collection, because the building on the National Mall has had space to display only about 10 percent of the museum's holdings.

title: In a Homeland Far From Home
description: One witless day forever changed the life of Loeun Lun, a Cambodian-American who fled the killing fields as a baby and grew up in a crime-ridden housing project in Tacoma, Wash. It was not even a whole day, really, but an afternoon, a costly afternoon at the mall.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: Bright Lights, Big City: The Journey of a Tree
description: Andy Katkauskas, a Northeast Utilities employee who has lived in Manchester all of his life, usually cuts down his own Christmas tree or buys one from the local fire department.

title: The Real Story
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C.'S OVERSIGHT OF MUTUAL FUNDS IS SAID TO BE LAX
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission failed for years to police the mutual fund industry effectively because it was captive to the industry when writing new regulations, was preoccupied by other problems on Wall Street and was severely short of staff and money, current and former officials say.

title: Kandahar's New Governor Seeks Help to Fight Taliban and Chaos
description: Nearly three months after President Hamid Karzai replaced one of the more powerful and colorful warlords in this important southern province, local and foreign officials are warning that the new governor will fail unless he receives more resources and support from the central government and international donors.

title: The Wrong Side of the Tracks: Seeking a Transfer Where Lines Converge
description: If Shalinqua Fuller can avoid switching from the No. 3 train to the L train in East New York, Brooklyn, she does. But as a design student, she sometimes takes night classes, and one of them required her to switch. ''I had to get off at the Junius stop, and walk through the darkness to the L train side,'' she said. She didn't feel safe, and she didn't like the cost. ''It's not fair for us to pay two times to go from one side to the other,'' she said.

title: The Lessons of a Quagmire
description: This month's setbacks in Iraq -- the downing of American helicopters, the suicide bombing of an Italian headquarters -- have made President Bush's mantra of ''progress'' ring increasingly hollow. It's true that 80 percent of Iraq remains peaceful and stable, but we seem to be losing in the other 20 percent, mostly among Sunni Muslims who benefited from Saddam Hussein's rule. The escalating violence lends credence to critics who see parallels with Vietnam.

title: Letters
description: Skirts All Around

title: Vote for Sewage Study Breaks Logjam
description: AFTER years of wrangling, county legislators last week broke through the logjam that had blocked efforts to keep untreated human waste out of reservoirs supplying drinking water to nearly one million New York City and Westchester residents.

title: On the Ninth Avenue Barricades, Les Misrables
description: Late last month, the city erected a pedestrian wall at Ninth Avenue and 36th Street to increase public safety. So why, residents are asking, have several pedestrians been struck by cars since then?

title: An Especially Taxing Burden
description: IT is a matter of near-universal agreement in Westchester that property taxes are too high. But what is not obvious is whether the burden is being shared equally.

title: On the Waterfront Becomes on the Beach
description: With Gravesend Bay as his backyard, Michael Breslof built a pier from his property jutting out 100 feet into the water.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: Belkin's article evokes a subtle nod to ''Lysistrata'': women withdrawing their talents until the workplace becomes a more humane environment. By seeking more balance in their lives, their impact on society may well prove women to be the ultimate change agents.

title: Adventures and Epics
description: March 16, 1986

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Education Life section last Sunday about saving money on college tuition misstated a policy of DePaul University in Chicago. It does not offer a tuition discount if a sibling enrolls. The article also misstated a basis for qualifying as a dependent for financial aid. A student need not be listed as an exemption on parents' income tax returns.

title: Kimberly Wegbreit, Joshua Koran
description: Kimberly Anne Wegbreit and Joshua Ethan Miller Koran were married last evening by Rabbi Yitzak Miller at the Kohl Mansion in Burlingame, Calif.

title: Opposite Approaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 33 of Arts & Leisure today about James Brown's performances at the Apollo Theater misstates the date of a show that was unfavorably reviewed in The New York Times. It was May 1973, not 1972.

title: The Poet and the War Dead (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Deafening, That Silence
description: WHAT'S that sound of relative silence floating about the county ever since the federal government approved Indian Point's evacuation plan in the summer?

title: Live From Pea Ridge
description: TESTAMENT

title: POSTINGS: A 50-Foot-High Glass Cone; New Entrance To Gardens In Brooklyn
description: From the tip of its 50-foot-high green-tinted cast glass cone down to the embracing arms of its stainless steel-sheathed walls, the new entrance being built at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on Eastern Parkway seeks to link, like the 12,000 varieties of plants harbored inside, sky, light and earth -- at least symbolically, said its creator, James Polshek of Polshek Partnership Architects.

title: Blueprint for A Mess
description: It was striking how infrequently President Bush was mentioned in Rieff's article. This is a mess that must be laid at his feet. Preventing a rivalry like the one between Defense and State called for a leader who thinks for himself and steps in to end it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILMARTIN, MARY D.
description: GILMARTIN--Mary D. Mary Doris Gilmartin, 83, of Vero Beach, died unexpectedly November 12, 2003. Loving wife of Roger T. Gilmartin (deceased) for 56 years. Surviving are her sons Thomas D. Gilmartin and Roger A. Gilmartin; daughter, Molly Gilmartin, Christin Gilmartin and Carol Gilmartin; and six grandchildren. Contributions can be to St. Joseph's College, Office of Institutional Advancement, 245 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11205 in her memory.

title: Like Old Times, Miller Burns The Knicks
description: Reggie Miller stepped into Madison Square Garden, his personal Hall of Fame, and spun back time on his fingertips. He walked out victorious, the villain again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORDY, LEON, M.D., F.A.C.C.
description: PORDY--Leon, M.D., F.A.C.C. 84, died Friday, November 14th, 2003 at his home in Manhattan after a valiant battle with a long illness. His accomplishments were bountiful. Graduating Phi Beta Kappa from NYU in 1938, he went on to receive a Master's in Biochemistry prior to attending Louisiana State University Medical School where he graduated first in his Class of 1943. He was an incredibly remarkable person and received humanitarian awards as well as alumni recognition awards from Mt. Sinai, authored a world famous computer electrocardiography textbook, penned countless articles published in prestigious medical journals and served as Captain and Head of the hospital in Udine, Italy during WWII. Even more so, he had two completely diverse careers as he was Chairman and CEO of Chock Full O'Nuts for 10+ years along with his medical career at Mt. Sinai and was brilliantly successful at both. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, three children, Dr. William, Dr. Robert, and Melissa Pordy, daughter-in-law, Dr. Cathryn Devons, and three grandchildren, Rachel, Jessica and Matthew Pordy. Services will be held on Sunday, November 16th, 2003, 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NYC, 212288-3500. Donations may be made to either Kidney and Urology Foundation of America, 1250 Broadway, NY NY 10001, 212-629-9770 or Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, Box 1216, Mt. Sinai Hospital, 1 Gustave Levy Pl., NY NY 10029, 212-241-4141.

title: Best Illustrated Books
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 2003. Every year since 1952, the Book Review has asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published that year. The judges this year were Kate McClelland, a librarian at the Perrot Memorial Library in Old Greenwich, Conn.; Sam Swope, a critic and author of children's books, including ''The Araboolies of Liberty Street'' and ''Gotta Go! Gotta Go!''; and Peter McCarty, an artist whose most recent book is ''Hondo & Fabian.'' As a matter of note, Maurice Sendak has been a winner 20 times before, Peter Ss five times, William Steig four times and Mordicai Gerstein twice.

title: Bremer Reaffirms U.S. Commitment to Iraqs Security
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 — The United States administrator for Iraq reaffirmed today that Washington was committed to providing that country with long-term security, saying American-led troops would stay in Iraq after power was handed to the Iraqis next year even though the American-led civilian authority would cease to exist.

title: Sex-Ed Night School
description: Sex education was an awkward business once. In my school they called the subject ''Health.'' The teacher diagrammed the reproductive organs on a blackboard that still showed the ghosts of algebra problems, then cleared his throat and asked for ''any questions.'' We had plenty, but none we wished to ask him. Too shy. Too polite. And too fearful that our teacher, who we found it hard to believe had had sex recently (we didn't want to picture it if he had), would suffer some sort of fundamental breakdown if our inquiries grew too vivid. Instead, we silently studied our illustrated textbooks while our teacher huddled behind his desk nervously sorting and sharpening colored pencils. While I was reading, I thought I heard one snap.

title: America's Gamble: Faster Power Shift in Iraq
description: The announcement of a firm date to create an interim Iraqi government and end the formal American occupation -- though not the American military presence -- promises the Iraqis the sovereignty they have clamored for, and offers President Bush the political symbol he needed: the beginnings of an exit strategy that he can explain to American voters.

title: The 32 Steps
description: SEVEN years ago, Ernie Fellenbaum noticed a town house for sale on West 103rd Street, down the street from the apartment where he lived with his wife and stepdaughter. The building was dilapidated and selling for the princely sum of $565,000. ''It seemed like an awful lot of money,'' Mr. Fellenbaum recalled the other day, and he and his wife decided to pass.

title: An All-American Bouquet
description: Teresa Fasolino's engaging depiction of the official flowers of the 50 states (if you count mistletoe, sagebrush and a pine cone as flowers) first appeared on March 3, 1991, and immediately became the most popular art feature we've ever published. Here it is again, for your renewed enjoyment.

title: Jean Bliss, Peter Olson
description: Jean Hutchinson Bliss, a daughter of Margo Gillespie Elliott of San Carlos, Calif., and John S. Bliss of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Hull Olson, a son of Phylis and Wayne Olson of Janesville, Wis. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in New York.

title: An Empty Armory Bursts With Possibilities
description: When completed around 1914, the massive brick castle in Kingsbridge Heights, the Bronx, was said to have the world's biggest drill hall. Over the years, the Kingsbridge Armory has had other moments of glory, including a Beach Boys concert in 1971. But as military use dwindled in the 90's, squabbles arose over what to do with the deteriorating building. The structure has sat unused since 2000.

title: DataBank; Drug Shares Rise, but the Market Falls
description: Shares of technology and financial companies led the major stock market indexes down last week, but drug makers rose on hopes that Congress would expand Medicare benefits for the elderly.

title: Her Brilliant Career
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's Co-Designing What for Co-Whom?
description: THOUGH the ground zero matchup between David M. Childs and Daniel Libeskind is the highest-profile example, more than a few major collaborative architectural efforts are now under way in Manhattan. On West 53rd Street, Yoshio Taniguchi, the exacting Japanese modernist, is paired with the corporate workhorse firm Kohn Pedersen Fox on the expansion of the Museum of Modern Art. Nearing completion at Columbus Circle, the Time Warner Center by Mr. Childs contains Rafael Violy's performance spaces for Jazz at Lincoln Center, nestled inside like a marshmallow chick embedded within a chocolate egg. More recently, in a current competition for a new building at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Art and Science, Zaha Hadid, the London architect known for explosively fragmented forms, has matched up with Beyer Blinder Belle, a firm whose name has become synonymous with underachieving since its plans for ground zero were rejected by the public.

title: Learning to Love To Hate
description: James Traub gets only half the story on the rise of liberal vitriol (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 26). It is not just a reaction to being slapped around by right-wing toughs. It is also a reaction against a Democratic Party leadership that is perceived by the grass roots as being cowardly and incompetent. Remember that Goldwater in 1964 was not just rebelling against liberalism. He was also rebelling against a G.O.P. establishment that had gone soft. We are witnessing a very similar situation today among Democrats.

title: You'll Never Be Paged in This Town Again
description: STILL HOLDING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARFSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: SHARFSTEIN--Samuel, 95, of Manalapan, NJ formerly of NYC and W. Palm Beach, FL, November 12, 2003. Former Attorney and NYS Insurance Examiner, beloved father of Anita Greenberg and Adele Burstein; father-in-law of Norman and Allan; grandfather of Lisa, Steven, Mimi, Mark and David; great-grandfather of Jack. We will all miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEINZEN, CLARE WILLIAMS
description: HEINZEN--Clare Williams. Of Plandome, N.Y. Wife of Dr. Bruce Heinzen, mother of Jerome, Barbara, Thomas and Nancy, died November 7, 2003. President of the Manhasset School Board and accomplished quilt maker. Clare was a lovely person, loved by many. Memorial service Congregational Church of Manhasset, 1845 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, N.Y. 12PM on Sunday, November 23, 2003. Memorial Gifts to Adventures in Learning, High Street, Manhasset, N.Y. 11030, 516-365-7131.

title: Irene Herman, Joshua Goldstein
description: Dr. Irene Michele Herman, a vascular surgeon, and Dr. Joshua Lewis Goldstein, an assistant professor of pediatric neurology, were married in New York last evening. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers.

title: Final Restoration Phase Set for Philipsburg Manor
description: Philipsburg Manor, a national historic landmark in Sleepy Hollow, has weathered three centuries of Westchester history, but three years ago, Tropical Storm Floyd delivered a blow that caused $4.1 million worth of damage to the property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPITZER, LOUISE F.
description: SPITZER--Louise F. Died peacefully at home November 5, 2003. Predeceased by her husband Sidney Spitzer and survived by Karen Marshall, grandchildren, and extended family. Born in 1908, she lived a full life with a passion for the arts, a philanthropic heart and a strong love and dedication to her family and friends. Contributions in her memory can be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUHBY, A. LEONARD
description: LUHBY--A. Leonard. Retired professor of hematology and Director of the Pediatric Hematology and Oncology Unit at New York Medical College. Pioneered research in folic acid and pediatric leukemia. Loving husband of Sara, devoted father of Tami and father-in-law of Ed Purce. Services will be held Sunday at noon, at Plaza Funeral Home, at 630 Amsterdam Ave, with burial to follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, LI.

title: The Nation; They Support Free Trade, Except in the Case of . . .
description: POLITICAL candidates who stand on the ideological scale between Ralph Nader on the left and Patrick J. Buchanan on the right tend to accept, in the abstract, the conventional view of economists: International trade helps many more people than it hurts.

title: Still Bill: Patriots' Belichick Adapts and Thrives
description: He explained his team's startling turnabout and his willingness in some instances to ''change his colors.'' He was excited when discussing how defensive scheming can bring a coach the type of creative satisfaction most often associated with offensive scheming. Then Bill Belichick was peppered with questions about Bill Parcells, and the conversation went this way:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROEMER, MALCOLM WILLIAM
description: ROEMER--Malcolm William. October 23, 1927 to November 12, 2003. May his soul rest in peace.

title: Manufactured Here
description: LEA & PERRINS' Worcestershire Sauce is made in Worchester, England, and just one other place: New Jersey.

title: Foul by the Writer; Soccer Dad Should Stop Whining
description: To the Editor:

title: Low-Cost Path to Low Emissions
description: THERE is no magic under the hood of a partial zero-emission vehicle, or PZEV. It is powered by a gasoline engine, and that is indeed a tailpipe coming out the back end. But by some measures the emissions from that tailpipe may be cleaner than the ambient air. And unlike most cars, the PZEV does not pollute when it is shut off and parked.

title: Madison Ave. Finds Itself in Elegance Deficit As the Bentleys Purr Smoothly Away
description: Luis Cepeda, a clerk at Dino Baldini at 49th Street and Madison Avenue, sells $3,000 sport jackets and $850 shoes. So when the Bentley dealership across the street moved out, it didn't exactly put a dent in his business. Still, Mr. Cepeda feels that something has been missing lately, if only a touch of spectacle.

title: Kate Whitman, Craig Annis
description: Kate Russell Whitman, the daughter of former Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and John Russell Whitman of Oldwick, N.J., was married yesterday to Craig Annis, a son of Marguerite C. Annis of Manchester, N.H., and the late Clayton R. Annis. The Rev. Dr. Carol A. Miles performed the ceremony at the Lamington Presbyterian Church in Bedminister, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 33 of Arts & Leisure today about James Brown's performances at the Apollo Theater misstates the date of a show that was unfavorably reviewed in The New York Times . It was May 1973, not 1972.

title: Coming to a Location Very Near You
description: The world has become increasingly networked in recent years, ever more affordably so, and PC's have long been able to double as televisions and radios, but before screens could start showing up in various sizes in all manner of places, a few things had to happen. The storage capacity of digital data had to be both big and cheap enough to make large media files, like movies, portable. Screens also needed to be thin enough to fit anywhere. Those criteria are now being met. The appearance, over the last few years, of MP3 players and iPods, which combine screens and vast storage capability, offer a preview of what's coming, video-wise. In this new screen world, viewers take their own content with them wherever they go -- whether it's on a DVD, CD, MP3 player, portable hard drive, camera, camcorder or other device -- and then plug it into whatever screen is at hand. It might be a giant one at home, a smaller one in the car, a tiny one on a P.D.A. or a cellphone.

title: For Job Seekers, More Hoops and Hurdles
description: Rob McIntosh feels like he's been jilted -- 10 times in a row. Over the past year, Mr. McIntosh, a graphic designer and creative director, has come close to snagging a job that many times, only to be told ''no thanks'' in the 11th hour. One company promised him a job that later vanished. Another asked him to complete hundreds of dollars of freelance work as a ''tryout,'' then balked at payment. Still another invited him to interviews on four occasions for a position that he is now convinced never existed.

title: India Grapples With Changes in the Kashmir Insurgency
description: More young Kashmiri men appear to be joining a guerrilla campaign for independence in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir, according to Kashmiri political leaders and human rights groups.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; Transit Center Is Planned as a Catalyst for a Revival
description: RONALD D. ALIANO likes to cite the time during the Civil War when this city was known for its numerous millionaires. Norwich's deep-water port and the rail lines that ran along the Thames River provided transportation links that fed its commerce, mainly mills and merchant shipping, and generated great wealth.

title: BASEBALL: Inside Baseball; General Managers Planning to Study Players' Bulk More Closely
description: When General Manager Allard Baird is scouting players whom he may want to sign or acquire for the Kansas City Royals, he analyzes videotapes from two, three and four years ago. He is interested in assessing how a player swings, throws and runs, but those tapes occasionally give him other fuzzier information he is forced to ponder.

title: A Looming City Tax Surcharge
description: EARLIER this month, the New York City Council voted to postpone implementation of a new law that would add a 25 percent surcharge to the property tax bills of owners who rent homes for income and do not live in them. The ''absentee-landlord surcharge'' -- originally adopted by the City Council and signed into law by Mayor Michael Bloomberg last summer -- generated such controversy that the mayor recently asked the Council to repeal the tax.

title: Bruce Alexander Cook, 71, Crime Writer
description: Bruce Alexander Cook, a writer of crime fiction and nonfiction, died on Nov. 9 in Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: Belkin quotes the 2003 Catalyst study of Women in Corporate Leadership and concludes that women don't want to run Fortune 1,000 companies because 26 percent of the women already within three levels of the top aren't clamoring to be C.E.O.'s What is truly interesting about our data is that 55 percent of the women want to be C.E.O.'s, and another 19 percent are as yet undecided but remain in the running. Fifty-one percent of these women have children under the age of 18 living at home.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Corwin, Stephen Kitzinger
description: Beth Alisa Corwin, the daughter of Louise J. Corwin and Barnet C. Corwin of Clarksville, Md., was married last evening to Stephen Edward Kitzinger, a son of Cynthia Z. Kitzinger of Englewood, N.J., and the late Richard J. Kitzinger. Rabbi Stanley M. Urbas performed the ceremony at Beth Am Synagogue in Baltimore.

title: Them Against the World, Part 2
description: On a rain-soaked October night in Miami, the police have commandeered downtown. It is midnight, and patrol cars cordon off the streets of run-down delis and dollar stores. Dozens of black-clad officers maneuver and bullhorn in the distance, practicing their tactics. ''We're expecting about 70,000 to 100,000 protesters to come down here in November,'' says a beat cop, guarding a corner from his squad car. ''Our guys are doing exercises all around.''

title: Old Faces Inaugurate a Renovated Gallery for Wesleyan
description: THE Center for the Arts at Wesleyan University in Middletown is 30 years old, and has just renovated its Ezra and Cecile Zilkha Gallery. In celebration of both events, the center is putting on ''The Alumni Show,'' an exhibition of work by 26 contemporary artists who claim Wesleyan as their alma mater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOPKINS, JANET P.
description: HOPKINS--Janet P. On November 12, 2003 of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Colleen (Hopkins) and Christopher Grazioso, Lauren Elizabeth and Blythe Anne Hopkins. Cherished grandmother of Molly Grazioso. Loving daughter of Mary C. Perry and daughter-in-law of John and Mary Hopkins. Fond sister of Anne Yamatsui and Curt Perry. Religious service Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, 1PM Monday, November 17. Private interment in Roxbury, CT.

title: Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended; Lombardi's Assignment
description: Remembering the Best and Worst Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended Illustrations by Tom Bloom

title: Lightning Man
description: On April 30, 1789, Jedediah Morse was installed as pastor of the First Congregational Church of Charlestown, Massachusetts. The occasion was triply significant to him. Twenty-seven years old, he had come to his vocation by study at Yale and graduate work in theology. He felt eager to promote the interests of religion but awed to contemplate the degenerate state of his fellow mortals, who every day crucified their Redeemer anew. The labor now to be undertaken by him was worthy but daunting, "a good work," he said, "but alas who is sufficient for these things."

title: Katherine O'Hanlan, Lonie Walker
description: Dr. Katherine Anne O'Hanlan and Lonie Adele Walker are to be married today in Tofino, British Columbia. Sherin Jensen, a marriage commissioner for the townships of Tofino and Ucluelet, British Columbia, will perform the ceremony at the Wickaninnish Inn.

title: Soup Season Superstars
description: AS the seasons change, it's out with flip-flops and in with sturdy oxfords. Out with tick checks; in with scarves. Out with strawberries, cherries and sunflowers; in with apples, pears and parsnips. And, finally, out with frozen lemonade on the boardwalk, and in with soups. Not just any soups -- but fragrant, simmered-all-day soups, with rich stocks that start with a triumvirate of bones, aromatics and thyme, the soups with aromas and flavors that can turn a house into a home, or a restaurant into a destination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARSHOFSKY, ISAAC
description: WARSHOFSKY--Isaac. The entire Continuum Health Partners family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Isaac Warshofsky, beloved father of our dear friend and longtime colleague, Renee Warshofsky-Altholz, Corporate Director of Patient Care Services for Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) and St. Luke's-Roosevelt (SLR) Hospital Center. To Renee, her mother Suzanne, her brother Stephen and sister Barbara, the entire Warshofsky family and all of her mother's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Stanley Brezenoff, President and CEO Continuum Richard F. Daines, M.D., President and CEO, SLR Thomas Killip, M.D., Interim President and CEO BIMC Frank J. Cracolici, Sr. VP, Pt. Care Services BIMC and SLR

title: Too Much
description: Margaret Talbot (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 2) suggests that children who go ''to elite private schools or to demanding public ones'' are experiencing a time crunch because they (or their parents) are so anxious that homework be done well.

title: When the House Starts Talking to Itself
description: The ''smart helpmeets'' are on their way: our homes, our offices, our cars and our clothes. They are meant to be aware, not dumb; proactive, not inert. They are meant to be understanding. If that sounds Frankensteinian -- well, get over it.

title: Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended; Observing a Sister
description: Remembering the Best and Worst Homework's Lessons Are Often Unintended Illustrations by Tom Bloom

title: It Was a Dull Month, But a Great View
description: YOU could think of them as vacation photographs -- taken on an idyllic vacation after which you did not come home with a sunburn and a suitcase full of sand. Or you could think of them as glimpses of a vacation to come -- complete with a day-by-day countdown to the day you get away.

title: Investing; It's Bad. But It Isn't Market Timing.
description: DESPITE some suggestions to the contrary, market timing is not really to blame for the mutual fund scandal.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; A YEAR'S WORK IN ONE WEEK
description: It is crunch time in Congress. If lawmakers want to adjourn by Friday as planned, they will have to adopt practically a year's worth of legislation in one week -- including major energy and Medicare bills and the majority of the 13 spending measures for federal agencies. The wide-ranging energy deal unveiled at the end of the week came under quick fire and the plan to add drug coverage to Medicare was teetering as well. The days ahead, particularly in the Senate, promise to be an interesting test of exactly how poisoned relations have become in the wake of a nearly 40-hour debate over stalled judicial nominations. Carl Hulse

title: Pinchas Zukerman Conducts a Revival
description: YOU wouldn't call him modest, exactly. Few star performers are, let alone conductors. A healthy ego is virtually part of the job description.

title: Letters Entertain You
description: M IS FOR MUSIC

title: Kimberly Brown, David Halbfinger
description: Kimberly Beth Brown and David M. Halbfinger, both journalists, are to be married today in Miami Beach. Rabbi Hillel Norry is to officiate at the Eden Roc.

title: The Buzz of Princeton Is From a Computer
description: WHEN 60,000 Italian honeybees moved into the heart of this college town's shopping district, some eyebrows were raised. The idea was to bring the sounds of the country into the village, but it wasn't long before the drone of the live insects was replaced with a computer-aided recorded version.

title: Con Ed Project Attracts Criminal Energy, Too
description: When a Con Edison project began over the summer on 11th Street near Avenue C, local residents girded themselves for rumbling noise, Sahara-like dust and bottled traffic. They all came as surely as the sun rises. But, residents say, something else has risen, too: criminal activity.

description: Museums/Institutions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZACHARIA, CLARA
description: ZACHARIA--Clara. Age 91. Loving wife of the late Morris. Beloved mother of Joy Appelbaum and the late Irwin Zacharia. Dear mother-in-law of Sara Zacharia. Adored sister of Ethel Wasserman. Cherished grandmother of four and great grandmother of five. Services were held.

title: Joyce Robbins, Alan Glickman
description: Joyce Trina Robbins and Alan Richard Glickman were married last evening by Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Egyptian Like Me
description: Last fall, with the war in Iraq looming, I traveled to Egypt. Ever since I converted to Islam nearly a decade ago, when I was 21, I have wanted to study in Cairo. One day in March, I went out to the dusty balcony of my downtown apartment to find, beneath the cinnamon-colored smog, thousands of Egyptian men in buttoned shirts and village robes, marching with fists raised and chanting anti-American slogans. Veiled mothers on the balconies opposite mine watched, clutching their veiled daughters.

title: Street of Dreams
description: Wait a minute, where am I? Just a moment ago, I was walking south on Hudson Street from Christopher, past the John Melser Charrette School (a k a P. S. 3), took a left on Grove -- or was it Marloes Road in London (the sudden Englishness of the hidden mews at Grove Court has regyroscoped my geographical inner ear) -- and I've run smack into a Federal wood house from early 19th-century America on the corner, No. 100 Bedford Street. Beside it, at 102, is a stucco Tudor worthy of note, at least for its eccentricity, and now I'm turning around to see the back of the school on whose pediment has been carved ''Childhood Shows the Man.'' Must be America. But when I turn right and cross the street, it seems I've wound up in . . . the Ninth Arrondissement? Can't be. The street signs all along the boulevard say Bedford, but on this side of Seventh and that side of Carmine, I could almost swear I was in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CREHORE, WILLIAM W. III.
description: CREHORE--William W. III. 76, of Lynchburg, VA, died Wednesday, November 12, 2003, at Virginia Baptist Hospital. He was married to Shirley Kraft Crehore for 54 years. Mr. Crehore was born in New York, NY, the son of the late William W. Crehore, Jr., and Edna Forde Mellor. He proudly served our country in the US Navy during World War II, and was retired from Mobil Oil Corporation where he worked as an engineering manager. The graduate of Lehigh University is survived by his wife, two sons, four daughters, and nine grandchildren. Memorial services to be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lynchburg VA.

title: Page Two; Yes, He Dismembered Him. So What?
description: THE 12 jurors who acquitted Robert A. Durst of murder in Galveston, Tex., last week have taken a pounding in the news media for ignoring his admission that he sliced up his 71-year-old neighbor's body and dumped the parts in Galveston Bay.

title: Why Celebrate Cheats At the Marathon?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Phone Call
description: FERNANDO RAMIREZ felt surrounded by people who loved him, the people he worked with and sold coffee to at the Fairway supermarket near 125th Street in Harlem. Like a lot of solitary New Yorkers, cut off for one reason or another from their real families, he had found another kind of family in one of those peculiar improvised communities that spring up so randomly in the city.

title: Pushkin
description: Aleksandr Pushkin was born in Moscow on Thursday 26 May 1799, in a "half-brick and half-wooden house" on a plot of land situated on the corner of Malaya Pochtovaya Street and Gospitalny Lane. This was in the eastern suburb known as the German Settlement, to which foreigners had been banished in 1652. Though distant from the centre, it was, up to the fire of 1812, a fashionable area, "the faubourg Saint-Germain of Moscow." On 8 June he was baptized in the parish church, the Church of the Epiphany on Elokhovskaya Square. And that autumn his parents, Sergey and Nadezhda, took him and his sister Olga-born in December 1797-to visit their grandfather Osip Gannibal, Nadezhda's father, on his estate at Mikhailovskoe, in the Pskov region. Most of the next year was spent in St. Petersburg. The Emperor Paul, coming across Pushkin and his nurse, reprimanded the latter for not removing the baby's cap in the presence of royalty, and proceeded to do so himself. In the autumn they moved back to Moscow, where they were to remain for the duration of Pushkin's childhood.

title: Paperback Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Greenburgh Moves Closer To Acquiring Green Space
description: The town of Greenburgh moved a step closer to securing nearly 200 acres of green space this week with the dismissal of a lawsuit trying to stop the acquisition. Justice Richard A. Molea of State Supreme Court dismissed the second of two lawsuits filed by Robert Bernstein against the project. The lawsuit had contended that the town was improperly financing the acquisition of the land, which borders Route 9 in Tarrytown and a portion of the New York State Thruway. In September, Justice Molea dismissed the other Bernstein suit, which claimed the town had improperly denied him access to records. The town board was scheduled to vote Wednesday on the appropriation of $3.7 million to acquire the property, but the vote was held over to the Nov. 24 meeting. The state and county are to pick up two-thirds of the cost of acquiring the property. Barbara Whitaker

title: It's All Groovy: London Was Calling
description: WEARING his trademark thick black spectacles and a boldly striped charcoal-and-white shirt as he sat at the head of the table at a dinner party held in his honor last month, Peter Schlesinger looked distinctly uncomfortable.

title: N.Y.U. Women Gain Round of 8
description: The New York University women won the N.C.A.A. Division III New York regional and advanced to the Round of 8 with a 30-15, 32-30, 30-25 victory over Cortland State (44-3) yesterday at the Coles Sports Center in Manhattan. The Violets (38-4) were led by Jennifer Gardikas with 17 kills and will face top-ranked Juniata College (38-0), the Mid-Atlantic champion, next Saturday at a site to be determined. Jeffrey Bernstein

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Playlist column last Sunday misspelled the given name of a musician who was cited for his influence on a younger generation of songwriters. He was Elliott Smith, not Elliot.

title: Nip in the Air, Time to Party
The Neediest Cases; A Mother Battles to Break a Vicious Cycle of Addiction
description: Zoraida Rodriguez has vivid memories of her childhood. But in the poverty of the Lower East Side, they were far from days of innocence.

title: Drug Shows Promise Against Vision Loss
description: An experimental drug can slow the loss of vision caused by a maddening eye disease that is the leading cause of blindness among the elderly, doctors reported on Saturday.

title: Unsolved, and Unsettling; Murders Are Down, but Open Cases Nag at the Public and the Police
description: One night last January, a young man about to start his first job in New York City was shot dead on the Lower East Side as he returned home after a night out with friends. On Sept. 9, a young woman and three elderly relatives were found dead in bloody tableaux throughout their two-story house in Jamaica, Queens. On two consecutive days later in September, a Hunter College student was fatally shot on a Harlem corner, and a Mexican immigrant was stabbed to death as his subway car neared Times Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWYER, CHRISTINE M.
description: DWYER--Christine M. 57. Died November 8, of cancer. Beloved wife of Marc Fasteau, loving step-mother of Alexis and all-star aunt to Lindsay, Alexandra, Christopher, Meghan, Brad and Zack. Survived also by her parents, Arthur J. and Martha Dwyer, and brothers Arthur and Paul. A George Washington University graduate, she first worked in the fashion industry as Valentino's representative to US department stores. Switching to banking, she was a lending officer at Banker's Trust, Chase and Manufacturers Hanover. In 1989, she founded a financial services executive search firm, which she ran until falling ill in 2000. Christine's energy and spirit touched everyone she knew. A beautiful woman with a big heart, she will be sorely missed. Memorial service: 4 PM, December 1, Harvard Club, 27 West 44 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contribute to Institute for Computational Biomedicine, Box 75, Weill Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: A Smasher of Trash or a Trojan Horse?
description: What Pratt Industries is proposing sounds like an environmentalist's dream. The company says it wants to build an $80 million facility next to its paper recycling plant in Travis that would take the 370 tons of household trash Staten Island produces each year and turn it into recycled materials and steam power.

title: Ellen Gold, Adam Lechner
description: Ellen Jean Gold, a daughter of Mari S. Gold of Manhattan and John A. Gold of Aspen, Colo., is to be married this evening to Adam Seth Lechner, the son of Mildred and Herbert Lechner of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa J. Grushcow will officiate at Raphael Vineyards in Peconic, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDINER, KATHARINE HONE EMMET BRAMWELL
description: GARDINER--Katharine Hone Emmet Bramwell, died peacefully August 18, 2003 in Princeton, NJ, aged 88. Daughter of Helen (Auerbach) and Herman LeRoy Emmet, and a descendant of both New York's Mayor Philip Hone and NY State's Attorney General Thomas Addis Emmet, Kate leaves her wonderful husband, Henry Gardiner of Quogue, NY, daughter Heidi Bramwell Humes, granddaughters Julia Emmet Bramwell Frick, Heidi Hamilton Kerko and Helena Humes Martin, and one greatgrandson, Henry Wilder Martin. Kate was the sister of Lydia Emmet Williams of Cleveland, and the late Anne Emmet Aaron, Helena Emmet Tredway and Herman LeRoy Emmet Jr. Kate's first husband of almost 50 years, Gerald Ames Bramwell, and two of their children, Katharine Bramwell Hamilton and Gerald Ames Bramwell Jr. predeceased her. Known by her family and many friends for her enthusiasm, intelligence, range of interests and generosity, Kate graduated from St. Timothy's as a proud member of the Spider team, and attended Smith College before marrying in 1934. An early advocate of natural products and organic farming, Kate was also a devoted bird watcher who created a bird sanctuary behind her Princeton, NJ house (which she later donated to the YWCA). An adventurous traveler and opera lover, she was a Board member and supporter of many organizations, including the North Country School in Lake Placid, NY. A proud and involved member of the Emmet family, Kate was our historian, collector of artifacts and raconteur. Her warm and vital presence will be deeply missed by those lucky enough to have known and loved her. Contributions in Kate's honor may be made to the North Country School, PO Box 187, Lake Placid, NY 12946. A memorial service will be held on Memorial Day weekend 2004 in Keene Valley, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, WADE
description: MILLER--Wade, 79, of Millburn, NJ, died on Sunday, November 9, 2003. He was an actor/dancer in theatre, film, and TV in Hollywood and New York City. He was Stage Manager and then General Manager of Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, NJ. Services held at The Chapels at Short Hills, Millburn, NJ, Monday, November 17, 2 PM.

title: Edwards the Campaigner Backs Edwards the Lawyer
description: Let others deride lawyers as soulless predators. Senator John Edwards, a former trial lawyer, is not only an unabashed defender of his profession, he is also portraying himself in his Democratic presidential run as a defender of the weak and the powerless and points to his years in the courtroom to prove it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGAN, MONTY
description: MORGAN--Monty. TV producer, died at 86. Producer extraordinaire of ''Girl Talk,'' ''Dr. Joyce Brothers,'' ''Celebrity Chefs,'' and the Amazing Kreskin. Memorial to be held Sunday, November 16 at the Devonshire, 28 East 10th Street, NYC, 2PM-6PM.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: The Ghosts of Childhood
description: LIVING TO TELL THE TALE

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Focus PZEV; A Stealthy Operative In the War on Pollution
description: AT first glance, the Ford Focus PZEV, which combines gasoline-engine practicality with ultraclean tailpipe emissions, seems to be the gift that no one asked for. Car owners who care about their vehicles' evaporative emissions performance, or the rate at which catalytic converters heat up, seem few and far between.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture in the special Education Life section last Sunday, in a quiz on art history, was reproduced in mirror image. In the photograph, of Masaccio's painting ''Tribute Money,'' the figures of St. Peter and the tax collector should have appeared at the right.

title: Business People; If You're Looking For An Easier Job, This Isn't It
description: Attention, top executives: If you're thinking about going into academia to achieve a better work-life balance, don't. At least that's the advice from Bruce Willison, who recently announced that in June he would be leaving his spot as dean of the Anderson business school at the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Australia Advances To World Cup Final
description: Once again when the pressure was on in the late stages of a Rugby World Cup, Australia rose to the occasion while New Zealand could not. Australia beat New Zealand, 22-10, Saturday before 82,444 at the Telstra Stadium, the former Olympic Stadium.

title: Cinderella, Ready for the Ball (If It's at a Disco)
description: PERHAPS it's her kittenish, Audrey Hepburn looks and her playful sense of style, or the way she lovingly fingers a dress by Galliano or a Pucci scarf. But watching Anna Netrebko navigate the aisles of Bergdorf Goodman and Henri Bendel, it's hard not to be reminded of the free-spirited Holly Golightly in ''Breakfast at Tiffany's.''

title: Beijing; The Walls Come Tumbling Down
description: 'You have to understand. Beijing was wonderful during SARS,'' said Jeremy Wingfield, the manager of the CourtYard Gallery. ''Romantic, beautiful. The sky was clear, for once. Everything shut down. There was no smog or dust or traffic jams. No tourists. No cars.'' He looked at me closely, to make sure I was the sort of American who understood that, of course, he also knew that SARS was a terrible plague that killed people. But it was important nonetheless to acknowledge the marvel of the moment when Beijing stopped. ''One day they announced SARS was over,'' he said, almost wistfully. ''And it was as if nothing had ever happened.''

title: Deals and Discounts
description: Ski season is here, along with early-season offers.

title: Speak Out, Doc
description: I am a physician. A school-bus driver admitted to the E.R. was agitated, paranoid and threatening, and his urine was positive for recent cocaine use. Over the next six months, he was admitted twice more in a similar condition. I told him that his cocaine use could endanger his passengers; he shrugged it off, saying that he uses only during his off hours. I refused to sign a form giving him medical clearance to return to driving and still consider him a threat to the kids. The hospital lawyer said I could not report him to his employer, citing patient confidentiality. What do you think? Anonymous, Connecticut

title: Business People; Visions of Sarah Jessica Danced in His Head
description: Richard D. Parsons may be chief executive of Time Warner, and he may have been honored as the keynote speaker at the annual Knight-Bagehot Fellowship dinner last week, but, alas, good fortune doesn't come without a price. To be at the Knight-Bagehot dinner, he had to turn down a competing dinner where Sarah Jessica Parker, the ''Sex and the City'' star, was the M.C. He also turned down an event where Cher was to appear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRANOW, SARINDA C.
description: DRANOW--Sarinda C. Died peacefully on November 13, 2003. She is survived by daughters Patricia Beard and Elizabeth Krysztofiak; grandchildren Alex and Hillary Beard; brother David Cowin; and son-in-law Samuel Beard. Predeceased by husband Harry Dranow, brother Daniel Cowin and son-in-law Samuel Gutner. Gifts may be made to Dranow Memorial Tree Fund C/O Central Park Conservancy.

title: Who Wants the Wishbone?
description: In my most interesting homework assignment, in 1970, students were assigned to go to a live poultry shop, rarely seen in the Great Neck area anymore, and have a chicken slaughtered and defeathered. The whole chicken was to be taken home, boiled, disassembled, and each bone was to be individually cleaned and reassembled into a skeleton. This was a fabulous hands-on way to learn about skeletal structures, and the results were very impressive. When my dog ate the head of my chicken and I replaced it with a doll's head, the teacher gave me credit for originality.

title: Catalonian Political Rivals Agree on Seeking Autonomy
description: Madrid, Spain's official capital, has government ministries and the headquarters of multinational corporations. Fashion-conscious Barcelona, a short train ride from the French border, calls itself the country's most ''European'' city and cultural heart. It is a longstanding rivalry.

title: Meals From Cabbies, Firemen and Everyone Else
description: THE NEW YORK CABBIE COOKBOOK:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAGLIANO, ALEXANDER MARINO
description: VAGLIANO--Alexander Marino died at home in Norfolk, CT on Thursday, November 13, 2003 of complications of diabetes. In a varied and distinguished career, Mr. Vagliano was Executive Vice-President of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co., a director in the Agency for International Development and a gentleman sheep farmer. He is survived by his wife, Sara Ector Vagliano, children Barbara, Andre and Justin Vagliano, step-son Dan Via, sister Lally Segard and 5 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Norfolk Library on the Village Green in Norfolk, CT at 3PM on Saturday, December 6. Memorial gifts may be made to the Norfolk Library, Norfolk, CT 06058 or to Foothills Visiting Nurse & Home Care, 32 Union Street, Winsted, CT 06098. The family will also receive friends in New York at a later date.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Great Dream of Heaven: Stories, by Sam Shepard. (Vintage, $12.) Though better known as a playwright, Shepard is also an accomplished narrative writer, as these brief and intensely focused tales attest. Rendering small events with poetic compression, the author typically zeroes in on lonely souls whose thoughts reveal how everyday life intersects with truths as large as the Western landscape. ''Half a dozen stories among the 18 . . . are extraordinary by any measure,'' Caryn James wrote here in 2002. ''With this collection he becomes a storyteller in the purest sense.''

title: Homework: Liked or Loathed but Still Remembered
description: Done but not forgotten. That's the verdict from readers who wrote about their most memorable homework assignments, the very best and the very worst. Here is a sampling of projects that stood the test of time:

title: Big Ben
description: Ben Franklin's ALMANAC

title: Nothing but Clear Skies
description: IF you're a regular runner or walker on the forgiving dirt track around the reservoir in Central Park, you've probably seen the city in a startlingly beautiful new way in recent weeks. As part of the park's 150th anniversary, the forbidding-looking seven-foot-high chain link fence that separates the track from the water is coming down; a graceful Victorian model of shiny black steel and cast iron, patterned on the fence that surrounded the reservoir from 1864 to 1926, is taking its place.

title: Who's Deserving?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Correspondence / Cultural Revolution; In China, It's Easier to Get Lost in the Crowd
description: THERE I was, blending in beautifully, having a long conversation with a young woman on the street, when I blew my cover.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Connecticut and Westchester copies on Nov. 2 about the master plan for Stamford, Conn., misstated the history of two of the city's neighborhoods. Before being incorporated into Stamford in 1949, Glenbrook and Springdale were part of the Town of Stamford, which was then separate from the city; the two areas were not separate.

title: Wanted: Men in Skirts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Disconnections
description: TRUE CROSS

title: Learning to Love To Hate
description: Is there some rule that every writer must force the phrase ''conservative'' or ''right wing'' or, in Traub's case, ''Fox's liberal-hater in chief'' next to Bill O'Reilly's name?

title: At Dinosaur State Park, Unrest Over New Director
description: Margaret A. Enkler thought that when she became the new director of Dinosaur State Park in Rocky Hill last month, it would be ''fun and exciting working at one of the most unique places in the world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONARD, EASON H.
description: LEONARD--Eason H. The partners of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners mourn the passing of Eason H. Leonard, founding partner of I.M. Pei & Partners and friend and colleague of 50 years, on November 13th, 2003. A Memorial Service will be held on December 6th, 2003 in Carmel, CA.

title: Domesticating The (Electronic) Help
description: Home robots were the jet-pack future's sweetest lie: personal assistants working tirelessly and without complaint -- companions, servants and pets. They would be nimble and able, and computers would be blinking omniscient behemoths.

title: Higher and Higher
description: CITY IN THE SKY

title: 20 Years of Photography
description: A sampling of the vibrant imagery that filled the pages of The Sophisticated Traveler over the past two decades.

title: Clothes Hound
description: That Elvis Presley was a clothes hound is not lost on anyone remotely familiar with the late legend.

title: Grief in Istanbul
description: Twin truck bombings at two synagogues on Saturday killed 23 people and wounded more than 300.

title: Turkish Police Expect to Identify 2 Suicide Bombers
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 17  Turkish officials said today that they were close to identifying two suicide bombers who attacked two synagogues here on Saturday, while one more body was pulled from the rubble left by the blasts, raising the death toll to 24 people.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about the history of foreign investment in Bolivia's natural resources misspelled the name of a mineral-rich area that was designated for development in 1992 as part of a project, now abandoned, to export lithium. It is Salar de Uyuni, not Salar de Uyumi.

title: A real innocent
description: During the Iraq war, Jessica Lynch became a symbol of a glorious military campaign. In her recently published book, she is portrayed as a country girl who naively stumbled into a foreign war. Now, once again, she is a symbol for America's state of mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CIARDIELLO, JEAN, ED.D.
description: CIARDIELLO -- Jean, Ed.D. Loving mother of Amy. Beloved sister of Albert. Daughter of the late Albert S. and Jennie. Reposing at Martin Hughes Funeral Home, 530 Narrows Rd South, SI, NY. Visiting Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services Tuesday, 8 PM. Committal Moravian Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Institute of Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy of New Jersey (IPPNJ), 19B Prospect St., South Orange, NJ 07079.

title: Vision of Personal Computers As Heart of Home Entertainment
description: If Intel and Microsoft have their way, the personal computer will soon be moving out of the office and den into the living room, kitchen and bedroom.

title: Families, Already Rattled, Kept on Edge by News of Crash
description: On days like Sunday, and there have been a blur of them here lately, everything seems to freeze. Wives, parents, ministers all wait for the day to run itself out, hoping to hear nothing from the bosses at the military base.

title: Together They Stand
description: Hand-wringing diplomats on both sides of the Atlantic are saying that ''it seemed like such a good idea at the time.'' They are having second thoughts about this week's full-fledged state visit of a U.S. president to the United Kingdom.

title: Coats, Cans, Books, Toys, Quilts and More
description: HOLIDAY charitable drives often call to mind drop boxes for canned goods or Santa-clad volunteers ringing bells for spare change on city streets. A little imagination, though, can go a long way to create a local tradition and raise donations for a variety of causes. Here is a roundup of some innovative drives:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KISSEL, ROBERT P.
description: KISSEL--Robert P. Services will be held Tuesday, November 18th, at 11 AM, at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. Interment will be at Riverside Cemetery in Saddle Brook, NJ. May Robert's memory eternally be for blessing, and may comfort, strength and consolation be granted to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBY, RUTH
description: JACOBY--Ruth. 89, died November 14, in Vermont. She enjoyed being a ''retired skibum'' in Vermont and summering on Fire Island. Beloved wife of Henry, and mother of Joan and Susan, and beloved sister of Gisella. Burial will take place Novemeber 17, at the Park Lawn Cemetery in Bennington, VT.

title: Equity Offerings for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the search for a new chief executive at Freddie Mac, the home mortgage buyer, misstated comments made by Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, regarding speculation that he was being considered for the job. Mr. Zoellick said that it was not unusual for people with his background to be approached about such positions. He did not say he had been approached by the board of Freddie Mac.

title: Fitting Gifts to the Business: Restaurant, Meet Food Bank
description: THE Mandarin Oriental, Manhattan's newest hotel, does not have much in common with a soup kitchen. It boasts views of Central Park, a spa with what it calls Asian-based rituals and a butler on every floor. Rooms start at $600 a night, and its restaurant serves trendy Japanese-French cuisine. But the Mandarin Oriental has a close tie, in fact, with the soup kitchen business because it gives both leftover food from its catering events and nearly all of its cash donations to City Harvest.

title: The Judge and the Commandments (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: This Mayor's a Workhorse, and She Does It for Nothing
description: AT 60, Janet Taylor was contemplating retirement. But there was the nagging question of what she could do for Salem, the city she describes as her ''salvation.''

title: Catalan Voters Lean Left
description: Elections on Sunday in Catalonia left a minor nationalist party, the Republican Left, holding the key to control of the regional parliament.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 25 and in some late editions on Oct. 24 referred imprecisely to her attempt to influence political control in Taiwan in 1988, after the death of her stepson, Chiang Ching-kuo, who had been president as well as chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party. Mme. Chiang tried unsuccessfully to block his successor as president, Lee Teng-hui, from succeeding him as chairman; she did not seek office for herself, nor was she eligible to do so.

title: 30 Narcotics Officers Are Shifted In Shake-Up Linked to Overtime
description: Twenty-four detectives and six sergeants suspected of swindling the Police Department out of a total of $45,000 to $50,000 in overtime were transferred to patrol duty over the weekend, Deputy Commissioner Michael P. O'Looney, a department spokesman, said yesterday.

title: White House Letter; Of Battle Stories and Fraternity Brothers
description: Peter Markle is the director of ''Saving Jessica Lynch,'' the NBC movie broadcast last week about the injured Army supply clerk rescued by American forces from her hospital bed in Iraq. Mr. Markle is also, as it happens, a Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity brother of President Bush's who spent lots of Saturday nights with him enjoying parties at what Mr. Markle happily calls ''kind of the Animal House.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Monday about a Silicon Valley start-up company that is developing a radiofrequency semiconductor misidentified the first 19th-century experimenter in radio transmission. He was Nikola Tesla, not Guglielmo Marconi.

title: Hollywood's Investigator To the Stars Heads to Jail
description: Anthony Pellicano, the celebrated private investigator who has worked for celebrities like Michael Jackson, Kevin Costner and Tom Cruise, is expected to surrender to the authorities on Monday to begin a jail term for possessing illegal weapons. But Mr. Pellicano will hardly disappear from public view.

title: Limbaugh Is Back on the Air, With Fans and Foes All Ears
description: More than five weeks after he entered a residential treatment center for what he described as an addiction to prescription pain medication, Rush Limbaugh is to return to the airwaves today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRENADIER, NEIL
description: GRENADIER -- Neil. My brother passed after a long and heroic battle with chronic pulmonary disease. His memory will be cherished in my heart. My husband, Kenneth Richman, and my son, Skyler Richman, remember the kind and intuitive qualities that define Neil. God bless the attending physicians and staff at St. Luke's Hospital for insuring peaceful and painless journey into heaven. Services will be held Monday, November 17, at 9:45 AM, at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76 St, where you can join the family in prayer. Dr. Gayle Grenadier Richman Kenneth & Skyler

title: Speaking Up for Fishermen As Rules Cloud Their Future
description: NAME: Shore Support, New Bedford, Mass.

title: Palestinian Sides Agree to Cease-Fire Talks
