description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 17  A senior Egyptian mediator reached agreement with Palestinian leaders today to start cease-fire talks among militant groups within two days, Palestinian officials said. And during a visit to Rome, the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said today that he might meet the Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, "in the next few days."

title: 2 Yemenis Tied to Al Qaeda Extradited by Germany to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Two Yemenis accused of funneling money to Al Qaeda from Muslim supporters in Brooklyn and elsewhere have been extradited to the United States from Germany to face criminal charges, officials said today.

title: Berlin Philharmonic Returns, Energized by a New Leader
description: The esteemed Berlin Philharmonic has become a revitalized and adventurous ensemble under its dynamic new conductor, Simon Rattle. That strong impression, left by the orchestra's Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday night, was confirmed and then some on Thursday and Friday nights as the Berlin Philharmonic finished its series at Carnegie Hall, its first New York appearances since Sir Simon took over last season. And he proved an inspired programmer. When repertory staples are played in the context of daring new works as well as works from the earlier decades of the 20th century, the staples are revealed as the audacious scores they were when new.

title: More Consumers Reach Out to Touch the Screen
description: Striding into the airport here one recent afternoon, Kimberly Ward did not so much as glance at the two ticket agents waiting at the counter. Like most of her fellow travelers, she instead claimed an automated check-in terminal, touched its screen a few times, and took the proferred boarding pass with a quick smile of thanks.

title: The Judge and the Commandments
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Books, Add Food, Watch the World Change
description: MOHAMMED ADOW, a 28-year-old Somali journalist with the BBC World Service in London, attended primary school in Garissa, a dry, dusty region in Kenya. The school was poor, but students received meals through an international school feeding program.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: HEALTH OVERSIGHT OF PRISONS URGED Democratic state legislators and advocates for prisoners urged the passage of legislation to give the State Health Department oversight over some aspects of the health care system for the 65,800 inmates in New York state prisons. The measure would mandate that the Health Department assess the treatment of inmates with AIDS, the H.I.V. virus and hepatitis C in the 70 state prison facilities. About 9,250 inmates have hepatitis C, 5,500 are H.I.V.-positive and just over 1,000 have AIDS, according to the corrections commissioner, Glenn Goord. (AP)

title: Petah Tikva Journal; With a Common Thread, Israelis Unravel Infants' Illness
description: The ailing infants, some near death, began arriving daily at Israeli hospitals in early November with almost identical symptoms: persistent vomiting, spasms, eyes that could not focus, listlessness.

title: A Pop Art Jigsaw Puzzle Is Assembled Deftly
description: Cramming a 55-foot-tall sculpture into the Tweed Courthouse rotunda is not an easy job. In terms of sheer difficulty, the task probably lies somewhere between building a ship in a bottle and stuffing a Steinway up a stovepipe.

title: Tougher Seat Belt Laws Save Lives, Study Finds
description: The failure by most states to allow police officers to pull over drivers who are not wearing seat belts has cost about 12,000 lives since the National Transportation Safety Board first recommended the passage of such laws in 1995, according to a study to be released Monday.

title: New Taser Finds Unexpected Home In Hands of Police
description: In 1995, Rick Smith, then a 25-year-old entrepreneur with a newly minted master's in business administration, got a telephone call from an official with the Czech National Police Academy. Could Mr. Smith come to Prague to demonstrate his new nonlethal gun?

title: Three Colleagues Help One Doctor on a Mission
description: SEATED amid the wealth of technology in the intensive care unit of the Children's Hospital and Research Center at Oakland, Dr. Olajire Idowu twisted and folded his slender fingers and silenced a shrieking pager while trying to find the precise words in English to describe his overseas humanitarian work.

title: Keeping Youngsters Running on the Road To Higher Education
description: NAME: The Dominican Track and Field Association of New York.

title: Clarifying What Y.M.C.A. Stands For
description: MENTION the Y.M.C.A. and everyone has a different notion of what it is all about.

title: Regulation Begins at Home
description: With two decisions in the last two weeks, the Bush administration has sent its clearest message yet that it values corporate interests over the interests of average Americans. In the Securities and Exchange Commission's settlement with Putnam Investments, the public comes away short-changed. In the Environmental Protection Agency's decision to forgo enforcement of the Clean Air Act, the public comes away completely empty-handed.

title: In Haven for Art, Brewery Puts Focus Back on Craft
description: The warehouse is nearly empty now. Funk music from a portable stereo echoes off the walls, a bottle of hot sauce sits unused and a sickly sweet smell rises off the remaining cases of beer as a worker in a paper face mask cleans up.

title: E-Commerce Report; Nervous about bidding on eBay? Hartford Insurance and a start-up are offering a policy to allay buyers' fears.
description: IN every fear lurks an insurance opportunity, even online. A small start-up company and the giant Hartford Financial Services Group plan to roll out a buyer protection plan today that is meant to instill confidence in shoppers on eBay -- the Web auction site that does a booming business but engenders such a fear of fraud that an estimated 8 of every 10 online shoppers steer clear of it.

title: The Gray Area For Nonprofits, Where Legal Is Questionable
description: IT goes by many names: the Help for Education Program, the Four Corners Indian Organization and the Arizona Indian Heritage Association, among them.

title: Sports of The Times; A Monotone Response To a Deflating Defeat
description: JIM FASSEL's tone of voice was different. After the Giants' five other defeats this season, he sounded angry or annoyed or sometimes confident of a turnaround. But in his autopsy of yesterday's 28-10 loss to the Eagles, dropping the Giants to 4-6, he spoke in a monotone.

title: Sports of The Times; The Ignorance Defense Won't Work This Time
description: THE four Oakland Raiders with the murky urine possess the power of heavy machinery and wear the jersey size of a Winnebago, and yet a skinny health geek may be at the root of their might.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Crisp, Cool and Clear: Autumn in Montauk
description: I saw the fish only moments after we arrived at the Star Island Yacht Club. They were all tuna, an assortment of longfin, albacore and yellowtail, each of them weighing about 30 pounds -- heavy enough for the men handling them to grunt as they tossed the stiff, gunmetal-blue carcasses into the bed of a black pick-up.

title: Turning Art Inside Out to Give Youth Power
description: NAME: Inside Out Community Arts.

title: Bringing Celebrities, Fish And Checkbooks Together
description: JOHN HAVLICEK, the Hall of Fame guard for the Boston Celtics, did not wear black tie to the party. He wore foul-weather gear, and it was a good thing he did. As the celebrity guest of the Mercury Redbone Celebrity Tournament Series, a fishing event to raise money for cystic fibrosis, Mr. Havlicek was in for a cold, wet, miserable morning, facing high winds and pouring rain in a small boat with no cabin.

title: Over Baghdad: Wary Targets, Yet Confident
description: As the rooftops of the Iraqi capital passed beneath him, the crewman of a Black Hawk helicopter looked down, shook his head and stated what had once again, only the night before, become so tragically clear.

title: Alexander Vagliano, 76; Aided Iran Talks
description: Alexander M. Vagliano, who was involved in the negotiations for the return of American hostages from Iran, died on Thursday at his home in Norfolk, Conn. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, ALVIN H., M.D.
description: WEINER--Alvin H., M.D. Loyal son, dedicated and loving husband, father and grandfather, superb and memorable friend, accomplished and respected physician beloved by all patients, Napoleonic scholar and collector, epicurean and generous mensch. We thank you for all you have contributed to all of our lives. With the love, spirit and lessons of 1810.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday answering the question ''What Is Gravity, Really?'' misstated part of Newton's law of universal gravitation. The force attracting two masses is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them, not simply to the distance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIGNAN, AIMEE T.
description: DIGNAN--Aimee T. On November 15, 2003. Beloved sister of Malle Andrade. Loving aunt of Jose and Eduardo N. T. Andrade. Interment private.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 25 and in some late editions on Oct. 24 referred imprecisely to her attempt to influence political control in Taiwan in 1988, after the death of her stepson, Chiang Ching-kuo, who had been president as well as chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party. Mme. Chiang tried unsuccessfully to block his successor as president, Lee Teng-hui, from succeeding him as chairman; she did not seek office for herself, nor was she eligible to do so.

title: RealNetworks Says Windows Works Without Media Player
description: RealNetworks Inc., one of the participants in an antitrust hearing last week concerning the Microsoft Corporation, disproved claims by Microsoft that its Windows operating system depended on the inclusion of its Media Player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOONEY, ELIZABETH COLE MAN
description: MOONEY -- Elizabeth Cole man. Of New York City, caring and courageous wife, mother and grandmother, died November 15, 2003, after a brief illness. With an MA in Education from the College of New Rochelle, she taught reading to the learning disabled for more than 25 years. Westover School, where she prepared for college, honored her for unique use of the telephone for one-on-one instruction. Passion for music led her to establish a classical music series at her alma mater, Bryn Mawr College. Betty was a great athlete and a good sport, too. A native of Baltimore, she moved to Washington, DC, after college, and later to Paris, Pelham, NY, and Hartford. She is survived by her husband Richard E. Mooney, three sons, James C. of Saxtons River, VT, Stephen E. of Roslindale, MA, and John B. of Montclair, NJ, their wives and seven grandchildren, and her sister Susan N. Coleman of Sedona, AZ. Gifts may be made to Star Learning Center, 26 West 84th St., NY, NY 10024, or the Learning to Listen Music Fund, Bryn Mawr College, 101 North Merion Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA 19010. Funeral service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. at 90th St., on Thursday, November 20, at 11 AM.

title: Putting Her Hopes Where Her Heart Lies
description: BILL AND MELINDA GATES, through their foundation, have given away almost $6.25 billion, which includes more than $60 million to microbicide development, $5.8 million to 10 Alaska school districts and $2.5 million to a cancer research center in King County in Washington State.

title: What Voters Want: Two Good Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: In Connecticut, Two Versions of a Police Dog's Attack on a Woman
description: The police say that when they tried to arrest Jean Church for welfare fraud last January at her apartment in a public housing complex here, she refused to cooperate, flailing her arms and shouting obscenities. So the police dog accompanying the arresting officers was ordered to attack her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOTCHER, NORTON J.
description: KOTCHER--Norton J. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Irwin and Merri and Daniel and Sharon. Cherished grandfather of Brett, Jeffrey, E. J. and Rebecca. Devoted brother of Roberta Kohn. Caring uncle. Owner of Ferndale Farms. Services Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Chirac Assails Anti-Semitism After Attack on Jewish School
description: PARIS, Nov. 17  Forty-eight hours after the latest serious attack on a Jewish institution in France, President Jacques Chirac condemned today all acts of anti-Semitism, "solemnly, in the name of the nation," and pledged to reinforce measures against any spread of anti-Jewish feeling.

title: Charity That Begins at the Cash Register
description: BLOOMINGDALE'S has dropped black-tie charity events altogether, opting instead for individual, local charity contributions and services suggested by employees and customers. Among them are a New York Fire Department Shop in the store, with all proceeds going to the city's firefighters, and the volunteering efforts of 64 employees to mentor first, second and third graders at a local public school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSSMAN, MORTON
description: GROSSMAN--Morton. Of Los Angeles, CA, died on Friday, November 14, 2003. Dear father of Benjamin and Andrea; beloved brother of Edythe Gottlieb and Florence Bauman; loving uncle of Fern, Steven, Madeline, Carole and Patricia; devoted friend to so many. As beautiful inside as he was outside. His kindness, sense of humor and zest for life will be sorely missed. To know him was to love him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, DONALD
description: KLEIN--Donald. Of Armonk, NY. Died peacefully on November 15, 2003. Respected lawyer and loyal friend. He is survived by his wife Barbara, son Jason, daughter Zoe and other beloved family members. His family would like to express gratitude to all of those who showed their love and care. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date. Donations in his honor can be made to: The Musella Foundation, 1100 Peninsula Blvd, Hewlett, NY 11557. All donations will go towards brain tumor research.

title: A Big Gift Changes Life at a Little Magazine
description: SINCE 1912, poets and editors have produced the monthly magazine Poetry on a budget sometimes stretched perilously thin. Recently, its home has been a cramped, borrowed office beside the stacks in a Chicago library.

title: Metro Matters; An Evolution In Leadership, And in Fashion
description: EVER notice how politics, like everything else, has its fashion trends?

title: HUSSEIN, ON TAPE SENT TO ARAB TV, SAID TO URGE WAR
description: An Arab television station broadcast a new audiotape on Sunday that it said had been made by Saddam Hussein in which the speaker mixed invective against Israel, calls for holy war and curses on American and other foreign occupation troops in Iraq.

title: Clergy Group to Counter Conservatives
description: In an effort to counter the influence of conservative Christian organizations, a coalition of moderate and liberal religious leaders is starting a political advocacy organization to mobilize voters in opposition to Bush administration policies.

title: Baugur to Buy Oasis Chain
description: By Bloomberg News

title: England Boots France To Advance to Cup Final
description: There were still 13 minutes to play in the rugby World Cup semifinal match on Sunday when the massed ranks of white-shirted English fans launched into a rousing chorus of ''God Save the Queen.'' They could have sung the praises of the weather, too.

title: Senior Executives Leave BBDO And Euro RSCG
description: Two prominent senior executives are changing agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBSON, DR. MURRAY B.
description: JACOBSON--Dr. Murray B. Of Perth Amboy, NJ, on November 15, 2003. Surviving son Joel Jacobson, daughter Norma Messing, sister Rae Rosengarten, four grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Funeral Monday, 11 AM, at the Flynn and Son Funeral Home, 424 East Ave, Perth Amboy, NJ.

title: Sprint Is to Join the Competition In 'Push to Talk' Mobile Phones
description: Sprint plans to announce today that it will become the third wireless provider to offer ''push to talk,'' a walkie-talkie feature that lets users communicate with one another without dialing phone numbers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 8 about the effect of the reopening of a copper mine in Butte, Mont., misstated the year in which Montana Power, an economic mainstay of the city, sold off its electrical business and became an Internet service provider, Touch America. It was 2000, not 1997. (Touch America went out of business this year.)

title: Editorial Observer; The Doctor and the Net: His Bloggers and Donors Pursue Victory via the Mouse
description: Every modern office has its Internet munchkins deliriously ingrown at their computer screens, puzzling the rest of us over what they're up to. Here at the small, unremarkable headquarters of Howard Dean, the prodigy front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination, the laid-back workers on the Web team are making lucrative campaign history as they tap away.

title: The Case for 2 Approaches
description: It has long been a truism in philanthropy that service programs are financed more readily than so-called advocacy programs.

title: Media Talk; Collaborative Book Idea Gets a Nasty Review
description: Evisceration is not pretty, especially on the Internet, where the verbal slicing and dicing can be done before a potential audience of millions. Which is pretty much what happened to Tony Perkins, the founder of the defunct Red Herring magazine and currently the head of a Web venture, the AlwaysOn Network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIDOFF, GERALD
description: WIDOFF--Gerald. Maverick Concerts mourns the loss of Board Member and former Chairman, Gerald Widoff. His participation in the evolution of Maverick Concerts was invaluable. He was a brilliant human being and artist, an inspiration to his family and loved ones. The classical music realm is diminished immeasurably

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOUDON, DOROTHY
description: LOUDON -- Dorothy. On November 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Norman Paris. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Wednesday, November 19th, 6-8 PM, with services, Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Actor's Fund of America or Broadway Cares Equity Fights AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE ALAN
description: TISCH--Laurence Alan. 80. Saturday, November 15. Dearly beloved husband of Billie for 55 years. Adored and adoring father of Andrew & Ann, Daniel & Bonnie, James & Merryl, Thomas & Alice. Proud and loving grandfather of Alexander & Bara, Lacey, Sarah, Charlotte, David, Michael, Alan, Jessica, Benjamin, Samuel, Maude, Joseph, Abigail, and Louise. Dear and devoted brother of Preston Robert (Bob) & Joan. Cherished uncle, relative and friend. Services Monday, November 17, at 11 AM at Central Synagogue. Interment private.

title: Imminent Bush Visit Fueling Debate in Britian Over Iraq War
description: LONDON, Nov. 17  Prime Minister Tony Blair today dismissed antiwar protesters' criticism of this week's state visit by President Bush to Britain as peace demonstrations got under way and police tightened security around London.

title: G.O.P. Begins Push for Medicare Bill
description: Republican leaders began an intensive campaign on Sunday to sell their new agreement on Medicare drug benefits, racing to push the legislation through Congress over the objections of leading Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARLIN, LEONARD
description: KARLIN--Leonard. On November 14, at age 81, following a brief illness. Editor, wordsmith, writer of elegance and wit. He had a lifelong association with Long Island University, where he taught journalism, directed public relations, and served on the Polk Awards Committee from its inception. His wife, Lee Karlin, died before him, as did his sisters, Ethel and Gertrude, and his brothers-in-law, Isidore Cytron and Meyer Isenman. He is survived by his daughters: Elisabeth, of Manhattan; Katherine, of Pittsburgh; Susannah, of Long Beach, LI; by his sons-in-law, Joshua Zaret and Christopher Remple; and by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews of the Cytron, Isenman and Schor families. We loved him. A service will be held on Sunday, November 23, at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, at 1 PM; 516487-9600. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Len Karlin Scholarship at Long Island University.

title: Economy's Advances in Atlanta Don't Lead to Popping of Corks
description: This city, which boomed even more than the rest of the country in the 1990's and busted even harder when the century turned, may well be the epicenter of the economy's emerging recovery.

title: Pantry U. Gives Facts To Those Who Give Food
description: MARCIA HUFF scribbled notes as fast as she could as Nancy Lee described the soup kitchen she worked at, called Inspiration Cafe.

title: Bush Says U.S. Is Not Seeking a Quick Way Out of Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  President Bush emphasized today that the United States was not seeking a quick way out of Iraq, despite plans for an interim government there by mid-2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELLER, ANNETTE
description: GELLER--Annette. Beloved wife of the late Fred Geller. Devoted mother of Randi and Evan Mondshine, Linda and Bob Bloch, Michele and Richard Kutnick. Adored grandmother of Ross, Justin and Taylor Mondshine, Russell and Amanda Block and Jonathan and Freddi Kutnick. Dear sister of Eva Saperstein. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Plattsburg's Favorite Phrases? 'Stop By' and 'Pitch In'
description: AT 11:30 a.m., Helen Russell, a petite 78-year-old, left the genealogy library office at the Courtyard Community Center, where she volunteers every Monday. As she walked briskly down Main Street toward the Plattsburg Senior Center for lunch, she pointed at one of the many flowerpots on the sidewalk.

title: The Court and Guantnamo
description: The Supreme Court took a welcome step when it agreed last week to decide whether the Guantnamo detainees could challenge their status in civilian courts. Over the objections of the Bush administration, the justices will review a lower court's refusal to hear their claims. The Supreme Court should hold that the detainees have a right to a legal proceeding to challenge their confinement.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Every night, I see the tracer rounds go up, and I know that one of them one day might hit me.'

title: Hollingers Chief Is Stepping Down; Company Is for Sale
description: Conrad M. Black said today that he would step down as chief executive of Hollinger International , a multinational newspaper publisher, and put the company up for sale after an internal investigation found that he and other executives of the company had received $15.6 million in unauthorized payments.

title: Community Is Reeling From Hepatitis Outbreak
description: It was her friend Eve's idea: a bunch of high school girls and a bunch of Mexican food to celebrate her 15th birthday. Jennifer Seevers, 14, said Mexican food was not her favorite, but it was Eve's birthday and in Beaver County there are only so many places for Mexican food. Therefore, Chi-Chi's it was.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 4 about federal subsidies for United States companies that buy subsidized American cotton referred incompletely to a United States proposal for addressing a West African request for relief from American and European cotton subsidies. In addition to proposing a simple study of the cotton issue, the United States offered to consider reducing government subsidies and removing nontariff and other barriers on cotton, synthetic fibers, textiles and clothing.

title: Albert's a Prince. Just Ask Cinderella.
description: IT might be hard to find two television shows that differ more than ''SpongeBob SquarePants,'' the Nickelodeon cartoon, and ''Six Feet Under,'' HBO's mordant comedy. But they do have a link: His Serene Highness, Prince Albert of Monaco.

title: AARP Backs Republican Plan for Medicare Drug Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  AARP, the largest and most influential organization of older Americans, said today that it would strongly support a Republican plan to provide prescription drug benefits under Medicare.

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Design; Grilles Are Asking to Be Taken at Face Value
description: LEWIS CLAYTON, a partner in the New York law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, knows firsthand how important automobile grilles are. As an intellectual property lawyer, he polices an area of law that includes logos and trademarks, the rights to song lyrics and even the design of toys like the Barbie doll.

title: No-Show Defense Means No Hope for Jets
description: When the two old friends, defensive buffs their entire careers, met at midfield Sunday, they could manage some ruefulness.

title: Bloody Ramadan
description: Another change of course in Baghdad: Under the pressure of new attacks, America wants to transfer responsibility to an interim government as quickly as possible. But the Iraqis are squabbling over who should assume this responsibility.

title: Time Warner And Madonna Are at Odds On Her Label
description: After 20 years and billions of dollars in music sales, Madonna's relationship with Time Warner is showing signs of strain over the future of her label, Maverick Records, with other negotiations just ahead on the value of Time Warner stock options she has received.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Oops! It's Album Time Again, Britney
description: Is it possible to take dance-pop seriously? Three singers find three different ways to say no.

title: Media Talk; Pearl Jam, on Its Own, Seizes the Moment And Sells CD on the Web
description: When Pearl Jam's contract with Sony Music Entertainment's Epic Records expired earlier this year, how the iconoclastic band would exploit its new freedom quickly became a topic of great interest to music industry executives.

title: Italian Mistake Puts U.S. Team Over the Top
description: MONACO, Nov. 16  The Bermuda Bowl championship reached an extraordinary conclusion here on Saturday that is still echoing around the world of bridge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLAUM, HERBERT L.
description: FLAUM--Herbert L. Father of Lloyd and Stuart, brother of Hortense Laub, passed away November 15, 2003. Respectfully, a private funeral will ensue. Should friends desire, contributions can be made in memory of Herbert Flaum to the Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Mt. Sinai Hospital, 1255 5th Ave, NYC 10029; or your favorite charity

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRONFELD, BERTA
description: KRONFELD--Berta. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of John Kronfeld and Lynn Koondel and mother-in-law of Ira. Cherished grandmother of Alison and Joanna. Loving sister of Frances Wanderman.

title: High Risks in Afghanistan
description: While the failure of American policy in Iraq in recent months has been painfully visible and at the forefront of public debate, the Bush administration's failures in Afghanistan have been as serious, and the risks are also great. It was Afghanistan, not Iraq, that was the spawning ground for the Sept. 11 attacks. And now, less than two years after President Bush celebrated his first military victory, Afghanistan is in danger of reverting to a deadly combination of rule by warlords and the Taliban, the allies and protectors of Osama bin Laden.

title: What Voters Want: Two Good Choices (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 7 about a written survey of synagogues in the Bronx misidentified the person who used it in research for a possible exhibition at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Battery Park. He was Yitzchak Mais, a former acting director of the museum; Dr. Seymour J. Perlin was the author of the survey.

title: The Tarps of Kilimanjaro
description: The green-gold expanse of savanna; above it, the purple horizon-hiding haze; and above that, like a pyramid improbably suspended in the sky, the snows of Kilimanjaro.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: A Much-Loved Concept Gets a Few New Twists
description: IT started out as a simple concept: employees would contribute to a charity of their choice, and companies would match their gift.

title: 125th Street Journal; Mr. Clinton, Your Harlem Neighbors Need to See You More Often
description: Consider this an open letter from the citizens of 125th Street to former President Bill Clinton. Its message is simple: Mr. Clinton, please come home.

title: Uninsured, in Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: Rat Poison: Murder Weapon of Choice in Rural China
description: The red-and-white banners with the latest government propaganda fluttered above the grimy main street, warning farmers at an outdoor market about a substance that might not spring to mind as a dire menace: rat poison.

title: Selling to Nonprofits Proves Not That Easy
description: IN terms of numbers, the nonprofit sector of the economy might look like a golden sales opportunity for almost any business. Nonprofit groups had revenues of $665 billion in 1997 and employed 9.3 percent of all paid workers in the United States in 1998, the last years in which such statistics were gathered by Independent Sector, a Washington clearinghouse for management and policy discussion in the nonprofit world.

title: Dorothy Loudon, Tony Winner, Is Dead at 70
description: Dorothy Loudon, the actress and comedian who won a Tony Award in 1977 for her portrayal of Miss Hannigan, the mean-spirited orphanage headmistress in the hit musical ''Annie,'' died on Saturday. She was 70.

title: The Judge and the Commandments
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Schools' Parent Coordinators Are Not Easily Reached, Study Says
description: When the Bloomberg administration took over the city's school system this year, it tried to improve communication between parents and school administrators by hiring parent coordinators in all 1,200 public schools and arming each one with a cellphone.

title: Patents; From off-the-shelf materials comes a cycle made for a low-impact upper body workout.
description: IN every industry, considerable amounts of research and development go into the hunt for new products. That includes the fitness industry. Each week the Patent and Trademark Office issues a dozen or more patents for exercise machines and methods of physical workouts or playing sports.

title: Sometimes Purebred Dogs Need to Be Rescued, Too
description: THE call came in late September from a veterinarian's office in Northern California to the South Bay Purebred Rescue in San Jose, Calif. A chocolate-brown Labrador retriever, Cocoa, had been brought in to be euthanized. She was days from giving birth. The owners were moving and did not want the dog or the puppies.

title: Slow Traffic? Buses Should Be Above It All
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAZEN, IRENE
description: HAZEN--Irene. ''So we'll go no more a-roving/by day or when it's night,/though the heart be still as loving,/the sun and moon still bright./For the sword wears out its sheath/and the soul wears out the breast/and the heart must pause to breathe/and love itself have rest.'' Irene, our brave, beautiful and beloved cousin, you will live in our hearts forever. Ellie Hershaft and Alan Hoffman

title: B.C.S. to Explore a More Inclusive System
description: The Bowl Championship Series, which encompasses four lucrative bowl games and determines college football's national championship, will not exist in its current form when its contract expires after the 2005 season, according to university presidents who met yesterday in New Orleans to discuss how to make the system more inclusive.

title: Lotte Berk, 90, German Dancer Who Slimmed London's Stylish
description: Lotte Berk, the dancer who gave her name to a no-nonsense system for achieving slim waists, trim thighs and taut bottoms that became a must for glamorous women in the 1960's, died on Nov. 4 in England. She was 90 and had lived there in Hungerford, Berkshire, since retiring about 20 years ago.

title: Morgan Stanley Is Said to Be Ready to Settle With S.E.C.
description: Morgan Stanley is expected to settle a complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission as early as today, according to people who have been briefed on the investigation.

title: Miami Looks to Trade Group to Revive Bank Industry
description: Glancing at the skyline along Brickell Avenue in Miami's financial district, this city's international banking industry seems anything but sickly. Developers even recently completed a 70-story skyscraper, the nation's tallest building south of Atlanta, with a 2,000-pound nude by the Colombian sculptor Fernando Botero in its lobby.

title: The Band That Can't Stop Recording; Guided by Voices May Not Have Megahits, but the Albums Just Keep Coming
description: Avid record collectors might understand someone acquiring eight copies of the same album. Truly devoted fans might even fathom paying $950 for a copy of that album. But certainly only a fanatic for the indie-rock group Guided by Voices could sympathize with Breck Rowell, who paid up to $950 each for eight copies of one of the group's vinyl records, and Mr. Rowell doesn't even own a turntable to play them on.

title: A Tokyo Novelist Mixes Felonies With Feminism
description: As a former jazz club waitress, ceramics shop owner and homemaker, Natsuo Kirino began her life as a writer more than two decades ago, tossing off entertaining but forgettable bodice-rippers in the velvety-red tradition of the Harlequin novel. From the beginning, though, she knew that she had more to say, so in the late 1990's she switched genres, churning out hard-boiled crime stories that have won her prizes for mystery writing and have perennially been high on best-seller lists in Japan.

title: From Delta, 48 Channels At Your Seat
description: Delta Air Lines plans to announce today an in-flight entertainment system that will be installed at every seat on its new low-fare carrier, Song.

title: Slow Traffic? Buses Should Be Above It All (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Offers South Korea Assurances on Deterrence
description: SEOUL, Nov. 17  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld spent today translating the Pentagon's new language of transformation into terms of reassurance for a key Asian ally, saying that efforts to reorganize American forces in South Korea would not diminish America's commitment or capability to deter aggression by the North.

title: They're Mad as Hell, and They're Not Making Donations Anymore
description: ROBERT FORD and Ihor Belinsky believe they do their social good on their jobs -- investigating inequities and complaints for the federal Department of Education's Philadelphia office. They used to give outside the office, too, by donating to charities.

title: Okinawans Ask Rumsfeld to Thin Out Troops
description: The governor of Okinawa petitioned Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld on Sunday to reduce or relocate American military bases on this strategic Japanese island, and urged removing large numbers of American marines to reduce crime here.

title: Health Care for Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Politics Hold Sway in Choice of Judges Upstate, Too
description: In most ways, this small upstate city seems a world away from Brooklyn. But walk into the Oneida County Courthouse, and things appear awfully familiar.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 5 about the history of foreign investment in Bolivia's natural resources misspelled the name of a mineral-rich area that was designated for development in 1992 as part of a project, now abandoned, to export lithium. It is Salar de Uyuni, not Salar de Uyumi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGLADE, PATRICIA MARY MCNULTY
description: LANGLADE--Patricia Mary McNulty. On November 14, 2003. Beloved wife of Gerald, loving mother of Laura and Tracey. Cherished sister of Kevin, Diane and Maureen. Treasured sister-in-law of Mary, James and Frank. Loved aunt of Jennifer, Charlie, Tommy, Emma, Tommy Finn and Juliette. We will always miss you, but you will be in our lives forever. Monday services at Andrett Funeral Home, 20 St & 2nd Ave. Funeral Mass, Tuesday 10 AM, at Epiphany Church, 22 St and 2nd Ave.

title: Error by Italy Helps U.S. Win Bermuda Bowl
description: In a come-from-behind finish that bridge aficionados will debate for generations, the United States capitalized on brilliant play and an opponent's blunder to defeat archrival Italy on Saturday in the biennial world contract bridge championships known as the Bermuda Bowl.

title: With Ward Cleaver Gone, Institutions Are Reaching Out to June
description: WHEN Mary Ellen Shepherd's husband died three years ago, after a quick and unexpected illness, she felt lost and overwhelmed.

title: UNFINISHED SENTENCES: Keeping Prisoners as Patients; Questions Rise Over Imprisoning Sex Offenders Past Their Terms
description: Robert Deavers, guilty of two rapes, has done his 20 years in prison. He still has not been freed. Instead, for five years, he has been locked up by state officials who are worried about what he might do.

title: Two Years After the Attacks, the Response Shifts Gears
description: IN the late summer of 2001, Robert Twomey drove his two sons south. His older, Emeric, was starting college at Clemson. The younger son, Robert, still in high school, went along, and they drove on to the University of Georgia, which the elder Robert had attended 25 years earlier.

title: In This Reunion, Belichick Defense No Joy to Parcells
description: Bill Parcells had seen this before.

title: Sharing a Love Affair With Each Other and Artists
description: WHENEVER Pat Steir thinks of art collectors who double as philanthropists, she remembers a telephone call she received at her studio two years ago. Ms. Steir is a painter known for her Zen-inducing landscapes. But that day, even she had no calming influence over the caller, a Chelsea art dealer who was giddily describing his good fortune. Two of the art world's most celebrated collectors, Raymond Learsy and Melva Bucksbaum, had just wandered in. Soon after, they bought a piece by the gallery's newest artist.

title: For 'The Producers,' Another Box Office Bonanza
description: Who says theater is dead?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEN, AMI, EVE
description: BEN-AMI--Eve. Beloved wife of the late Yitshaq. Loving mother of Deborah BenamiRahm, and Jeremy Daniel Ben-Ami. Dear grandmother of Joshua and Shira. Funeral services Monday, November 17, 12:45 PM, at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, New York.

title: Turkey Says Foreign Terrorists May Be Behind Suicide Blasts
description: An obscure terrorist group linked to Al Qaeda took responsibility on Sunday for the twin truck bombings at two synagogues that killed 23 people and wounded more than 300 here on Saturday. Turkish officials said they had evidence that suicide drivers had carried out the blasts.

title: Business of Governing Starts Today for Schwarzenegger
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger will be sworn in as California's governor on Monday after a whirlwind campaign followed by a six-week transition period in which he was largely invisible.

title: 5 Bands, 2 Languages, A Multitude Of Sounds
description: The melting pot boiled over in the quintuple bill of Latin rock at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Saturday night. Maldita Vecindad, Molotov and El Gran Silencio came from Mexico, Los Rabanes from Panama and Yerba Buena from New York City. Stylistic distinctions that might make sense north of the border were demolished; rapping, power chords and funk fused with rhythms from the English- and Spanish-speaking Caribbean, all in the service of a cheerfully rebellious good time. Fans shouted along and hurled themselves into mosh pits that sometimes covered the whole dance floor.

title: Information Pack Rats
description: To get an idea of how much information is in some of the world's largest databases, imagine a bookshelf 150 miles long: the content of the books on that shelf would be roughly one terabyte of data.

title: Serbians Fail, Again, to Elect A President
description: Serbia was left in institutional limbo on Sunday night after it failed for a third successive time in just over a year to elect a president.

title: INSIDE
description: More Hepatitis Cases Seen

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Nov. 6, about Christopher O. Ward, commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection, referred imprecisely to a 1976 film's use of the Central Park reservoir pump house, where he was interviewed. Although the climactic scene of ''Marathon Man'' was set there, it was filmed in a reproduction at Paramount Studios in Hollywood.

title: 4 Players in N.F.L. Said to Have Failed Test for New Steroid
description: Four members of the National Football League's Oakland Raiders have tested positive for tetrahydrogestrinone, or THG, a newly detectable banned steroid, according to an online report yesterday that was confirmed by four people briefed on the test results. They became the first professional athletes from a North American sports league to be identified as having used THG.

title: Eagles Make A Stand And Giants Take a Fall
description: As Giants running back Tiki Barber caught the pitch from his quarterback and raced toward the corner, all he could see was a wall of Eagles. The end zone might as well have been 100 yards away instead of 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, RAYMOND D. JR.
description: STEVENS--Raymond D. Jr. November 15, 2003, of Buffalo, NY. Husband of the late Aline Larkin Stevens, father of Raymond D. Stevens III, Larkin E. Stevens, Courtney C. Stevens, Hunter H. Stevens. Survived by four grandchildren. Brother of George E. Stevens and Annette S. Wilton. Son of the late Raymond D. and Annette Stevens. Memorial service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Tuesday, at 4:30 PM, November 18, 2003. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 404 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Guatemala Turns a Page
description: Guatemalans who voted in presidential elections last week should be congratulated for thwarting the comeback bid of one of the country's most brutal former military dictators, Gen. Efran Ros Montt. During his 18 months in power in the early 1980's, thousands of Mayan Indian peasants were slaughtered by soldiers moving against left-wing guerrillas. His crushing electoral defeat is a welcome sign of health for a fragile democracy.

title: Israelis Raid Gaza Camp
description: Israeli forces raided a Palestinian refugee camp in the southern Gaza Strip early on Sunday, killing one Palestinian and arresting a man the army held responsible for digging smuggling tunnels under the Egyptian border.

title: High-Strung on the Far Side of the World
description: SEA OF GLORY

title: Packers Gain Measure Of Revenge Against Bucs
description: The Green Bay Packers never planned any reprisals against Tampa Bay defensive tackle Warren Sapp Sunday for his blindside hit on Packers offensive tackle Chad Clifton last season during an interception return. The block, which took place far from the action, caused a career-threatening injury.

title: The Eagles Break Out, Especially Westbrook
description: Jon Runyan, the Eagles' Pro Bowl tackle, had no doubt.

title: In Louisiana Election, a First and a Near First
description: In the end, the whiz kid fizzled.

title: School's New Iroquois Flag Stirs Protest
description: For more than 30 years, young members of the five tribes who live on the Onondaga reservation some 10 miles south of Syracuse have felt that the schools they attend, which are run by non-Indians, were not treating them as equals.

title: In One Oregon City, Jobless Residents Ask, 'What Recovery?'
description: Gloria Hunt has heard the news, all about the nation's apparent economic recovery, about the thousands of new jobs, the upturn, the rosier outlook. Those upbeat bulletins, though, sound to Ms. Hunt like the good fortune of a distant cousin who struck it rich while the rest of the family was still dirt poor.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Woman's Need to Help; a Boy's Need for Special Care
description: Sometimes Marion Britt speaks as if she has had two lives. There was the one before Cameron, in which she battled breast cancer. And there's the one she has now, with the cancer behind her and a son to raise.

title: Meeting the Grille of Your Dreams
description: MOST buyers are satisfied with the look of the vehicles they have chosen. Others scour accessory catalogs in search of personalization, the touch that says ''me!'' with resounding clarity. Among the growing offerings from these specialty businesses: the spider-web grille from Putco Inc. of Story City, Iowa, shown here for a GMC truck.

title: They Bring Them Back Alive, Quite Often, From Niagara
description: A Michigan man's feat of surviving a plunge over Niagara Falls wearing little more than the parka on his back made headlines around the world last month. Unlikely as Kirk Jones's Oct. 20 ride into history was, it did not surprise one man who knows the world-famous cataract and the river that feeds it as well as anyone.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the popularity of shirts with wild prints and bold stripes misspelled the name of the traditional center of custom tailoring in London. It is Savile Row, not Saville.

title: Argentine Moves Against Police Corruption
description: When President Nstor Kirchner moved to purge the armed forces and Supreme Court immediately after taking office in May, both institutions rapidly bowed to his will. But now that he is taking on a corrupt police force that he says is responsible for a recent epidemic of kidnappings, he seems to be meeting stiff resistance.

title: 2 Ousted Fund Managers Are Due Payout
description: The founders of Pilgrim Baxter & Associates, Gary L. Pilgrim and Harold J. Baxter, will receive about $69.3 million from Old Mutual P.L.C., the London-based insurer that bought their firm three years ago. Mr. Pilgrim and Mr. Baxter lost their jobs last week in the industrywide investigation of improper mutual fund trading

title: Muhammad Is Found Guilty in Sniper Case
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Nov. 17  A state jury in Virginia Beach found John A. Muhammad guilty of capital murder, conspiracy and firearms charges today in connection with a string of sniper shootings in which 10 people were killed in the Washington area last year. Jurors immediately began hearing evidence on whether Mr. Muhammad should be sentenced to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIDWELL, KATHARINE TUDOR O'NEIL
description: BIDWELL--Katharine Tudor O'Neil, of New York, NY and Fishers Island, NY on November 13, 2003, an amazing mother, wife and grandmother. She devoted her life to her family and to education and music. Her memory will be a beacon for her family and friends. Funeral Services Thursday, November 20th, 1 P.M., at St. Thomas Church, One West 53rd St., Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Katharine Bidwell Foundation for Young Singers C/O Rosemary McGunnigle, Thelen Reid & Priest LLP, 875 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022 would be appreciated.

title: The Poetry of Yearning, The Artistry of Seduction
description: That slowly rotating ceiling fan isn't the only thing stirring the air in Nilo Cruz's ''Anna in the Tropics,'' the earnestly poetic play that won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama and is only now making its New York debut.

title: A Jet Makes Up for Lost Time Really Fast
description: After careful consideration, Jonathan Carter decided that it was cooler to have scored a 62-yard touchdown on the very first catch of his professional career than it was to have scored on a 90-yard kickoff return.

title: Virginia Jury to Decide Whether to Impose Death Sentence
description: Astate jury in Virginia Beach found John A. Muhammad guilty of capital murder, conspiracy and firearms charges today in connection with a string of sniper shootings in which 10 people were killed in the Washington area last year. Jurors next have to decide whether Mr. Muhammad should be sentenced to death.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Today

title: Hemisphere Trade Talks in Miami Are Reported to Hit a Bump
description: Talks here intended to produce a tariff-reducing agreement for 34 countries in the Western Hemisphere may have already hit a bump: officials from Canada, Chile and several other nations disapprove of an agreement reached between the United States and Brazil to limit the scope of any deal, negotiators said Sunday.

title: Sports of The Times; Have-Nots And Haves Call Truce
description: SCOTT COWEN, the president of Tulane University, has emerged as the hero of a movement of college football's have-nots. A few months ago, Cowen wondered why 54 of the lower-end colleges that play Division I-A football begin their N.C.A.A. season with no chance of playing for the national championship because they are not part of the Bowl Championship Series. The B.C.S. is made up of six high-powered conferences and Notre Dame, which have an agreement with ABC that the national champion will come from its membership.

title: The Judge and the Commandments
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonprofits Chase Dean's Example
description: DEAN WILKERSON, the executive director of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, has a lot of hope when it comes to raising money online. While he concedes that the organization's total of $66,900 through October is unlikely to turn heads, it is twice what the group raised in the same period last year. And MADD is still learning how to challenge donors in ways that keep them active and giving money.

title: Exploring New Ideas for Making Finances Clearer and Scandals Rarer
description: EVERYWHERE you turn in the world of philanthropy and nonprofits these days, people are talking about accountability. And it's no wonder.

title: At Broadway Pres, It's a Lively Scramble To Make Ends Meet
description: AT the Starbucks on Broadway and 114th Street in Manhattan, pierced Columbia University students and neighborhood loafers are lining up for late-morning coffee. Next door, at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, the homeless will soon be lining up for lunch.

title: The Judge and the Commandments
description: To the Editor:

title: On Rare Diseases, Parents Take Hope Into Their Own Hands
description: WHEN Leslie Gordon and Scott Berns learned in 1998 that their toddler, Sam, suffered from an obscure genetic disorder called progeria, they scoured the known universe for answers -- and found almost nothing.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Horned Frogs B.C.S. Dreams

title: Gains Seen in Short Study-Abroad Trips
description: The number of American students weaving study-abroad sojourns into their college curriculums is continuing to grow, but the concept of what it means to study abroad is changing.

title: Slow Traffic? Buses Should Be Above It All
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 2 about Dorothy Farnan, a New York City teacher who wrote ''Auden in Love,'' a book about W. H. Auden and his companion, Chester Kallman, misstated the year in which she became chairman of the English department at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn. It was 1966, not 1986.

title: Spend It Now! Why Some Foundations Plan Their Demise
description: PRIVATE foundations come and go. But mostly they go -- on and on. They can become entrenched institutions, with buildings, internal bureaucracies and executives pulling down six-figure compensation packages.

title: Recurring Errors Are Burying Knicks
description: The Knicks were riding an offensive avalanche by scoring a dizzying 24 straight points -- a franchise record -- and still lost to Indiana on Saturday night because they failed to grab two rebounds in the final 25 seconds.

title: The Months of Work Behind Eileen's Lunch With Melissa
description: ANYONE who has planned a charity auction knows that it requires a head-spinning amount of organization. So when staff members for Communities in Schools, a national nonprofit group based in Alexandria, Va., gathered a few months ago to prepare for their second auction, the focus was on the pesky details of generating publicity and rallying for last-minute donations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEITELMAN, MAX
description: SEITELMAN--Max. Beloved husband of Miriam and the late Margot (nee Bravman). Devoted father of Jeffrey (Judy), Paul (Ruth), and David (Lori); loving grandfather of Robert and Lily; Staci (Troy Marshall), Cori and Ari; Sara, Benjamin and Jessica. Brother of Leo and the late Albert. Uncle to Edward, Mark, Joan and Gail. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: In Utah, Public Works Project in Digital
description: When it comes to the Internet, residents of Utah are taking matters into their own hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIALEK, ROSE
description: BIALEK--Rose. Died peacefully at home in her 94th year on November 14, 2003. She is survived by her son Ardie, her daughter-in-law Ann, her grandchildren Howard and Carol Epstein, Lynn and Gary Laurino, Michele and Todd Neufeld, David and Amy Bialek, her sister Shirley Brass and nine great-grandchildren.

title: Debate Without a Script
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, HORTENSE CINER
description: KLEIN--Hortense Ciner. On November 15, 2003, at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Daniel J. Klein. Loving mother of Carolyne and Edward Levy and Robert and Susan Klein. Adoring grandmother of Jim and Sigal Levy, Matthew and Sharon Levy, Andrew and Alyssa Klein and Jeffrey Klein. Cherished great-grandmother of Danny and Lauren Levy and Olivia and Ellie Klein. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday, November 17th, 11:30 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: What Voters Want: Two Good Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sleeping Beauty With an Attack of Insomnia
description: Just as ancient Greek myths have inspired countless generations of playwrights to interpret them anew, so the scenarios and musical scores of the classic ballets can also prompt choreographers to take fresh looks at familiar source material.

title: 2 Insurance Giants to Merge in $16 Billion Deal
description: The Travelers Property Casualty Corporation and the St. Paul Companies announced today that they intended to merge in a stock deal valued at about $16 billion that would create the second largest commercial insurance company in the United States.

title: The Judge and the Commandments
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Walking in Circles Gets Charities Going
description: ONE of the first times it held a walkathon, which was more than 30 years ago, the March of Dimes learned an important lesson: November is not the best time to conduct an outdoor activity in Ohio.

title: New Equation For Charities: More Money, Less Oversight
description: AMERICA has the world's biggest collection of charities, but oversight of the nonprofit sector is parochial, piecemeal, political and, at times, accidental.

title: 14 States File Suit in Attempt to Block New E.P.A. Rules
description: Acoalition of 14 states plus the District of Columbia filed papers in federal court today in an effort to stop the Environmental Protection Agency from introducing a new rule that the states say will seriously weaken the provisions of the Clean Air Act and send more pollution into the atmosphere.

title: Schwarzenegger Is Sworn In as Governor of California
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 17  Arnold Schwarzenegger completed an unlikely odyssey today, taking the oath of office as California's 38th governor after a historic recall election.

title: Gap and Este Lauder Plan Novel Campaigns
description: Two big advertisers are entering the important holiday shopping season with initiatives.

title: Senior Executives Leave BBDO and Euro RSCG
description: Two prominent senior executives are changing agencies.

title: Bond Offerings For the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill on Tuesday.

title: Internal Combustion Cleans Up Its Act
description: The road to clean air is sometimes paved with confusion. Cars that depend on petroleum fuels are using a nasty technology that pollutes unnecessarily, wastes scarce resources, and after a century of refinements, cannot hope to get better, or so the thinking goes. Fuel cells, a technology developed for the Apollo moon-landing program, are a cleaner way to power cars, say proponents. Fuel cells convert fuel to electricity chemically, and in theory, they make no byproducts except for a dribble of water that is purer than Perrier. If it comes from NASA, it must be better, right?

title: Cellists Offer North and South American Works in Translation
description: The cello section of the Berlin Philharmonic has been moonlighting as a chamber group for 30 years, and it separated itself from its colleagues long enough to play at Zankel Hall on Tuesday night. Same-instrument combinations -- whistles, pianos, trumpets, trombones, tubas -- range from novelties to stunts, but the cello mix is a reasonable one. The instrument can momentarily imitate higher or lower cousins of the string family and, when of a collective mind, produce a pleasing sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, BILLIE ANN LEVINE
description: KELLY--Billie Ann Levine. On November 14, 2003. Beloved wife of Brian, loving mother of Daniel and James, and step-daughter Elizabeth. Devoted daughter of Lenore and Irvin Levine. Cherished sister of Margaret, Connie, Cathy and Milon. She is, and will always be, the light of our lives.

title: Democrats In Florida Drop Poll Plan
description: The Florida Democratic Party rejected a plan on Sunday to insert Florida into the early presidential nominating process by conducting an informal poll of delegates at a party convention next month, well ahead of the official primary in March.

title: EBay's Founder Meets an Idea That Reminds Him of His Own
description: Pierre M. Omidyar, the founder of eBay, has not felt much need to stay involved in business. He remains chairman of eBay, but last year he resigned from other company boards to devote more time to building his foundation.

title: Rising Demand Squeezes Food Banks
description: EVERY day, tractor-trailer rigs pull up to the loading dock of an old paper warehouse on the bank of the Genesee River here and unload donated food. The sturdy concrete warehouse was a donation itself, to Foodlink, a nonprofit wholesaler that distributes about six million pounds of food each year to soup kitchens, food pantries and meals-on-wheels programs in the Finger Lakes region of western New York.

title: Big Tobacco Pays This Foundation To Bash Tobacco
description: ''WELCOME to Crazyworld,'' the madcap carnival barkers yelp in a new series of antitobacco advertisements that went on the air during this year's broadcast of the MTV Music Video Awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPTON, SOLOMON
description: LIPTON -- Solomon. Passed away November 15, at 89, as a result of complications from open-heart surgery. The devoted father of Roger, David and Marilyn. The beloved grandfather of Leslie, Hannah, and Benjamin. The loving brother of Marty and the late Ruth Weisman. He lived a full life, a dedicated family man, a consummate professional (C.P.A.) to the end, skied into his late seventies, played singles tennis into his late eighties, self sufficient and competent until he entered the hospital three weeks before his passing. Didn't want to be inactive or dependent in his last years, which his failing heart would have undoubtedly created. Philanthropic and generous in spirit to all he came in contact with. He was a mensch in every sense of the word, and his memory will inspire all who knew him. He showed us how to live, and he showed us how to leave. Services will be conducted at the Menorah Chapel on Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Monday, November 17, at 11:30 AM.

title: Love in the Time of Benzene
description: In the power corridors of Silicon Valley, Amanda Hawes and Ted Smith could be called the antipower couple. Theirs is a marriage of common crusades against some of the region's biggest companies.

title: For Boston's Archdiocese, An Appeal Is Rebranded
description: FOR nearly two decades, Cardinal Bernard F. Law was the face of the annual Cardinal's Appeal, the primary fund-raising drive for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston. A letter from the popular archbishop, featuring his photograph, was enough to attract significant donations.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Publicis Groupe's leader proves that a French agency can compete worldwide.
description: FOIE gras and fashion? Yes, the French can handle that. But advertising? Leave that to the British and Americans, masters of understatement and the brash riposte, with their ad powerhouses, like the Omnicom Group and the Interpublic Group of Companies in the United States and the WPP Group in Britain.

title: Building a Web Media Empire On a Daily Dose of Fresh Links
description: ''Thank you, Paris Hilton,'' exclaimed Nick Denton last week as traffic flowed in to his new Web venture, a pornography Web log called Fleshbot.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Morgan Stanley Expected To Settle S.E.C. Complaint

title: Scandal for School (Don't Try This at Home)
description: The targets of the satire in ''Bright Ideas,'' Eric Coble's overzealous black comedy now at the East 13th Street Theater, are yuppie parents, the striving and competitive couples who will stop at nothing to give their children an advantage.

title: Worried Sick
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Landing on the East River
description: To a small and select breed of aviators, the East River and its slapping waves have a special draw.

title: National Briefing | Washington: States Protest E.P.A. Rules
description: Fourteen states asked a federal appeals court in Washington to block rules by the Environmental Protection Agency that the states say will allow power plants to undertake large construction projects without adding pollution-control devices, even if the projects create more air pollution. Richard A. Oppel Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE A.
description: TISCH--Laurence A. Bob, Joan, Steve, Jamie, Laurie and Jonathan and their children feel blessed to have spent so many wonderful years with Bob's brother and our dear ''Uncle Larry.'' We learned wisdom, passion, integrity, and ''tikkun olam'' by following his example. His remarkable legacy will remain with us forever. The Preston Robert Tisch Family

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about efforts by Senate Democrats to block three of President Bush's judicial nominees reversed two of their identities. Justice Priscilla R. Owen of Texas was at the left and Judge Carolyn B. Kuhl of California at the right.

title: ArvinMeritor Raises Offer for Dana
description: The auto supplier ArvinMeritor made what it indicated would be its final offer for the Dana Corporation on Monday, raising its hostile bid by 20 percent, to $18 a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Tire Venture
description: The French tire maker Michelin will buy a 14.9 percent stake in Apollo Tires. Apollo said that its board approved the equity sale for about $28 million. The companies will also set up a venture in India, Michelin Apollo Tire, with Michelin owning 51 percent. Michelin Apollo, with an investment of $70 million, will make and sell radial tires for buses and trucks. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: 5 Principles, and Many Voices, Go Into Trade Center Memorial Design
description: The designs for a World Trade Center memorial cannot satisfy everyone. They will almost surely not satisfy anyone who believes in the inviolability of the twin towers' structural outlines. But the eight proposals to be unveiled tomorrow must satisfy a carefully worded mission and five key principles.

title: Bush Insists That U.S. Troops Will Stay in Iraq
description: President Bush said emphatically on Monday that the United States would not leave Iraq even though the White House had decided to speed the transfer of American civilian authority to a new government in Baghdad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSHENBAUM, MORRIS BEHR
description: KIRSHENBAUM -- Morris Behr. Died on November 17 in Pittsburgh at the age of 85. A funeral service will be held for him on Wednesday, November 19 at the Ralph Schugar Funeral Home, 5509 Centre Avenue, Pittsburgh at 11AM, followed by burial at Shaare Torah Cemetery. An artist and advertising executive, Mr. Kirshenbaum was the founder and President of the Ivy School of Professional Art in Pittsburgh. He is survived by Joy Fox Kirshenbaum, his wife of 54 years, his brother, Bernard Kirshenbaum, his children Adam, Lyn and Susan Kirshenbaum, Ava Kirshenbaum Doppelt and his sons-in law Jack Ostrofsky and Arthur Doppelt.

title: The List Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: North Carolina Pressing Funds For Changes
description: Hoping to use his power as a customer to impose better practices on investment managers, the state treasurer of North Carolina said yesterday he would insist that mutual funds and others handling the state's $58 billion in retirement money provide better disclosure of fees and place limits on trading by their employees.

title: Mexicos Envoy to U.N. Is Fired After Criticizing U.S. Policy
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18  Mexico's ambassador to the United Nations has been dismissed after saying the United States regards Mexico as a second-class country, government officials said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: W.R. GRACE & CO., Columbia, Md., which is in bankruptcy protection because of asbestos lawsuits, saw its case become more complicated when creditors asked a judge to step down because of potential conflicts of interest.

title: What Good Is a Miracle Without Savvy Publicity?
description: OUR LADY OF THE FOREST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUSCHEL, ANNE ORZEL
description: MUSCHEL--Anne Orzel. On November 16, 2003. Loving mother of Ruth. Beloved wife of Louis. Funeral service Tuesday 11AM, Campbell Funeral Home, 81st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: We Welcome You To Lush Zimbabwe! Your Wallet, Please!
description: Underscoring the rising desperation in Zimbabwe's economy, the police and paramilitary squads have begun seizing foreign money from tourists and moneychangers in an effort to allay an acute shortage of hard currency, Zimbabwe citizens familiar with the situation there said Monday.

title: He Gave of Himself, So That I Could Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Glances Into the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: $16 Billion Deal Joins St. Paul and Travelers
description: Taking a page out of the playbook of Sanford I. Weill, one of the great corporate empire builders, Jay S. Fishman said yesterday that his midsize Midwestern insurance company, the St. Paul Companies, was taking control of one of the largest American insurers, the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation, in a $16 billion stock swap.

title: Struggling Buccaneers Frustrate Gruden
description: Coach Jon Gruden is not sure what more he can do to inspire the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to play up to last season's Super Bowl-winning form. Gruden has used virtually all of his offensive players in an effort to spark the Buccaneers' anemic attack, and he went for a motivational home run the week before Sunday's 20-13 loss to the Green Bay Packers, which dropped Tampa Bay to 4-6 with six games left.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sun Microsystems Signs Licensing Pact With Chinese Concern
description: Sun Microsystems said yesterday that it had struck a desktop computing software licensing agreement with the China Standard Software Company, a consortium created by two government ministries in China. The agreement, which Sun executives said could lead to Sun's Linux desktop operating system and StarOffice productivity application being made the standard personal computer software in the world's most populous country, is the first major win for the computer maker. Sun, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., is a rival of Microsoft. It has been trying to develop a strategy to compete against Microsoft based on open-source software, creating price competition for Microsoft, the Redmond, Wash.-based software publisher. Sun did not disclose any dollar amounts for the contract, which involves both the Chinese Ministry of Information Industry and the Ministry of Science and Technology, but Jonathan I. Schwartz, Sun's executive vice president for software, said that beginning early next year, volumes would reach into the millions of copies in the next 12 to 18 months. Sun also said yesterday it planned to make servers with a new semiconductor from Advanced Micro Devices. Sun will introduce a line of servers using Advanced Micro Opteron chips in the first half of 2004, a Sun spokeswoman, Sabrina Guttman, said. Solaris and Java software from Sun will run on Opteron systems, she said. Shares of Sun fell 2 cents, to $4.08. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Muhammad Is Guilty of Slaying In Sniper Spree in Capital Area
description: After a monthlong trial that re-created 16 shootings in gripping detail, a jury on Monday convicted John A. Muhammad of murdering a man at a Virginia gas station last fall as part of a plot to terrorize Washington, D.C., and its suburbs.

title: Eruption Science: Volcanoes as Labs
description: Tucked away in a four-foot-high, blue steel box in the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, a few steps from the tourists milling among the hot dog stands outside, is a 2,000-degree speck of magma -- molten rock, held under terrific pressure -- from the catastrophic eruption of Mount Vesuvius in Roman times.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Expansion
description: Singapore's economy expanded 1.7 percent in the third quarter in contrast to the period a year earlier, the government reported. Brisk trade in securities and manufactured goods helped the city bounce back from a second-quarter contraction. Exports, excluding oil, rose 20.6 percent in October, to 10.7 billion Singapore dollars ($6.2 billion), led by sales of chips to South Korea and drugs to Australia. Retail sales climbed 13.6 percent, in part because of car sales. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: All the Views Unfit to Print On a Billboard
description: THE REV. KRISTOPHER OKWEDY and the New York Civil Liberties Union have so little in common that they would probably have a hard time agreeing on a lunch order.

title: Record Grain Crop Causes Railcar Shortage
description: By Bloomberg News

title: Hotel Rooms and High-Technology Befuddlement
description: THERE'S a television commercial that happens to dramatize the subject of this column, which is that some terrific hotels, in their zeal to be hip, have designed elements of almost comic incomprehensibility into their guest rooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIDWELL, KATHARINE O'NEIL
description: BIDWELL--Katharine O'Neil. The Board of Directors, artists and staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center are deeply saddened by the loss of Katharine O'Neil Bidwell, member of the Board since 1996, founder of our Patrons Program and the moving force behind a commissioning fund for new chamber music. Katharine was a charismatic and tireless champion of the arts. For her, nothing was impossible, and she inspired all of us who worked with her to greater efforts and acommplishments. All of her endeavors were marked by her personal elegance, grace and good humor. We will cherish her memory for her indomitable spirit and passionate commitment to chamber music. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, J. Truman Bidwell, and her family. Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Chairman Peter Frelinghuysen, President David Shifrin, Artistic Director Norma Hurlburt, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, BILLIE ANN LEVINE
description: KELLY--Billie Ann Levine. On November 14, 2003. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP are deeply saddened by the sudden and tragic loss of our beloved friend and colleague, Billie Ann Levine Kelly. Billie's career at our firm began on July 9, 1979. As Director of Legal Personnel and Recruiting, her remarkable commitment, passion, dedication and spirit during the past 25 years touched countless people throughout their careers at our firm, and she has been a true and valued mentor, friend and member of the Willkie family. Our deepest sympathies are sent to her beloved husband and our friend, Brian Kelly, to her two sons, Daniel and James, her step-daughter Elizabeth, and to the entire Kelly and Levine families. Billie will be remembered with love and deep respect. She will always remain in our hearts and thoughts. On behalf of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Your Doctor's Drug Problem
description: The rising costs of prescription drugs are driving the current debate about Medicare reform. Yet Republicans and Democrats alike may be unaware of a primary reason for this inflation: doctors are taught about drugs by agents of the pharmaceutical industry, which works hard to persuade them to select the newest and most expensive medications -- even in the absence of scientific evidence that they are any better than older, less costly ones.

title: Hewlett Now Wants to Be Your Copier Company, Too
description: Hewlett-Packard is king in the land of computer printers, but for years it has eyed the nearby office copier as an enticing market to conquer. Today the company is introducing a line of powerful printers that double as copiers, hoping to capture a sizable slice of the $24-billion-a-year copier market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COVELLO, JAMES L.
description: COVELLO--James L. 48 years, of Pound Ridge, NY, died on November 16, 2003. Beloved husband of Mariann. Devoted father of Jamie and Caitlin. Jim was a self-employed lighting director and an Emmy award winning cameraman in broadcast and corporate television worldwide. Jim was a devoted father, a loving husband, and a friend to all he met. He was an avid guitarist, an accomplished cook and a fabulous gardener. Jim was able to incorporate his love for music and comedy into his television career. Jim was known and will be remembered for his sense of humor and love of life. Loving son of Terry and the late James Covello, Sr. Nephew of Clara. Brother of Nancy, Marcy and Bob. Memorial visiting hours will be at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. The memorial service will be held at the Croton Falls Community Church, Croton Falls, NY Thursday at 10 am. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory may be made to The Educational Trust for James and Caitlin Covello, 1 Lafayette Place, 2nd floor, U.B.S., Greenwich, CT 06830 or the Hiram Halle Memorial Library, Pound Ridge, NY.

title: Grades for Arthritis Remedies Rise
description: People who buy dietary supplements to ease the pain and stiffness of arthritis are generally getting what they pay for, an independent testing company has found. But some people -- especially those who buy the supplements for their pets -- may not be getting what they think they are, the company says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANLY, PATRICK
description: HANLY--Patrick. On November 8, 2003, after a long illness. Dearest friend and husband of Wende. Loving father of Katherine and Caroline. Devoted grandfather of Emma, Freya and Nilas. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 22nd, 11AM at Sacred Heart and Saint Stephen Church, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Church Renovation and Restoration Fund, 108 Carroll St., Bklyn, N.Y. 11231 or The American Diabetes Association, POB 2787, North Canton, OH. 44720.

title: Hot Sounds From a Cold Trumpet? Cryogenic Theory Falls Flat
description: Without, er, fanfare, two Tufts University engineering researchers announced results of a study last week rebutting a popular myth among some trumpet players that deep-freezing the instruments will change the sound for the better.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Ex-Official Sentenced In Art Theft
description: A judge sentenced a former senior warden at Rikers Island to one to three years in prison yesterday for his role in the theft of a drawing by Salvador Dal. The warden, Mitchell Hochhauser, 40, of Queens, pleaded guilty in September and implicated three other Rikers employees -- another assistant deputy warden and two correction officers, who were all charged and are still awaiting trial. In March, the $250,000 drawing, displayed near the entrance of a jail complex, disappeared, and it has not been recovered. In court testimony, Mr. Hochhauser said another assistant deputy warden, Benny Nuzzo, masterminded the theft and arranged to replace the Dal drawing -- a depiction of Christ's crucifixion -- during a fire drill. Mr. Nuzzo has denied any role in the theft. The fake Dal was discovered within hours, when a Rikers employee stopped to pray before the drawing, as he always did, and noticed the fake in its place.

title: Diversity at the table / A fight against blandness: The Brillat-Savarins of slow food: They're eating well and doing right
description: NAPLES  Slow Food, one of the world's largest and most avant-garde alliances of food lovers, gathered more than 600 protesters of fast food from 36 countries on a recent weekend in Naples to assail blandness and to extol "eco-gastronomy," authentic food traditions and third world peasants.

title: High Court in Massachusetts Rules Gays Have Right to Marry
description: The highest court in Massachusetts ruled today that gay and lesbian couples have the right to marry under the state constitution, emphatically stating that the Commonwealth had failed to identify any constitutional reasons why they could not wed.
