title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MMO2 Posts First Profit Since Spinoff
description: Britain's fourth-biggest mobile-phone company, MMO2, posted its first profit yesterday since it was spun off from BT Group two years ago. The stock fell 3.7 percent because MMO2 did not raise forecasts, analysts said. Net income was 23 million ($39 million), or 0.3 penny a share, for the six months that ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of 277 million, or 3.2 pence a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed 21 percent to 2.68 billion, the company, based in Slough, England, said. ''We don't anticipate growing at the same rate in the second half, but we're confident of delivering good year-end results,'' the chief executive, Peter Erskine, left, told reporters on a conference call. Intense competition and price cuts imposed by the British regulator will hurt growth, he said. Shares of MMO2 dropped 2.5 pence, to 66 pence ($1.12).

title: Turkey Links Synagogue Bombers to Al Qaeda
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 18 — Turkey said today that the suicide bombers who killed at least 25 people at two synagogues here on Saturday were Turkish citizens with links to Al Qaeda.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Concern's Profit Grows
description: Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru cars, said profit in the first six months increased 16 percent because of cost-cutting. The company, which is 21 percent owned by General Motors, earned 19.4 billion yen ($176 million) in the six months to Sept. 30. Sales were 665 billion yen ($6.1 billion), up 2.6 percent from a year earlier. Fuji makes a variety of industrial products. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRACHMAN, STANLEY, M.D.
description: DRACHMAN--Stanley, M.D. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted, long-time member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Amy Lemle, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Fires and Warming
description: Q. How much do fireplaces and wood stoves contribute to global warming? What about the burning of garden waste?

title: Palestinian Kills Two Soldiers; Israel Raids Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 18  A Palestinian gunman pulled an automatic rifle from a rolled-up prayer rug as he approached an Israeli military checkpoint just south of Jerusalem and shot two soldiers to death at dawn today. One soldier was speaking to his mother on a mobile phone at the time of the shooting, a family member said.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Diane Meier; Providing Care, When the Cure Is Out of Reach
description: The day of reckoning for Dr. Diane E. Meier, a geriatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, came a decade ago when she encountered a 73-year-old man with terminal lung cancer. His hands and feet were tied to the bed because he repeatedly pulled out the feeding tube inserted through his nose, despite his explicit wish that he receive no treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORDY, LEON, M.D.
description: PORDY--Leon, M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague. Devoted to his patients whom he cared for with expertise and compassion and a conscientious mentor who touch the lives of countless students and residents, he was respected by his peers and loved by his patients. In 2000, The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its coveted Special Recognition Award to Dr. Pordy acknowledging over 50 years of dedication to Mount Sinai, his significant contributions in the field of cardiology, and his role in the establishment of the Page & William Black Postgraduate School of Medicine. A compassionate human being and a gentle man, he leaves a legacy of devotion to the art and science of medicine and an example of scholarship for generations to come. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. William G. Stein, M.D.--Pres. Barry D. Stimmel, M.D.--V.P. Elliot Rayfield, M.D.--Sec'y Betty Mintz, M.D.--Treas.

title: Easing the Pain of Tiniest Babies
description: Despite clear evidence that newborns feel pain, most premature infants are given no analgesics in hospitals, even though they are regularly subjected to painful procedures, a new study reports.

title: More Action Over Fund Practices
description: The oldest mutual fund company in the nation, and one of the largest, has suspended its longtime practice of directing brokerage commissions to securities firms that sell its funds or bring it new clients, according to a brokerage firm executive apprised of the change last week.

title: Among the Recent Deaths, Two Freshly Minted Pilots
description: Many of the 17 soldiers who died when two Black Hawks helicopters collided on Saturday had worked in Iraq for nearly nine months, but two men had just arrived there, fresh from flight training school together.

title: Glances Into the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Pesky Pigeons
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Upgradings Possible
description: Moody's Investors Service, the ratings agency, said it was considering an upgrading to the credit ratings of Resona Bank and Saitama Resona Bank because of increased confidence in the regulatory support mechanism. The banks received almost two trillion yen ($18.2 billion) from the government in June when audits showed them short of capital. The bailout ignited a rally in bank shares because investors perceived the government as unwilling to allow a major bank to fail. Resona Bank and Saitama Resona Bank have long-term deposit ratings of Baa3. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEGRANDPRE, JEANNE
description: deGRANDPRE--Jeanne. Baroness von Griescheim. Born June 25, 1903, in Linz, Austria. Died November 13, 2003, in New York City. She was married to Baron von Griescheim, a German diplomat who was part of the conspiracy to assassinate Hitler. Educated in Paris, France, by the Madams of the Sacred Heart, she was a linguist, speaking several languages fluently. In her youth, she was an avid equestrian, a fabulous dancer and singer. She loved the opera and classical music. An active member of the Manhattan East Chapter of the Visiting Nurse Services. Gigi also participated as a member of several clubs including but not limited to, the Circumnavigators Club, Metropolitan Club, Doubles, Dinner Dances, English Speaking Union, US Navy League and the National Women's Republican Club. Gigi loved life and people of all generations. She was a frequent world traveler and lived in Vienna, Berlin, Lima and Santiago, Chile. A love of New York made this city her home. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Wednesday, 3-5 and 6-8 PM. Funeral service Friday, 4 PM, at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Services, 107 East 70 St., New York, NY 10021.

title: Letters and Reader Responses
description: Debating Darwin, and Divinity

title: Chrysler Introduces 8 Vehicles Due in 2004
description: The Chrysler Group introduced on Monday eight of its nine new or redesigned vehicles due next year, a product wave executives say will revive the company's fortunes.

title: Path to War: Retracing Our Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: Stroke Risk: The Rise and Fall
description: Women who smoke are at much higher risk for bleeding strokes, but those who have quit can bring their risk back to normal, researchers have found.

title: Miami Girds For Protests At Trade Talks
description: This city's downtown was nearly deserted on Monday as police and government officials prepared for an international trade meeting that is likely to draw thousands of protesters, some threatening the same violent tactics that crippled a World Trade Association meeting in Seattle in 1999.

title: Despite Lacking Latest Virus, Flu Vaccine Is Thought to Work
description: The influenza vaccine now being given was not developed to protect against a strain of the virus that has surfaced in this country this fall, but the government is optimistic that this year's vaccine will stave off outbreaks, a top federal health official said yesterday.

title: Unlikely Star Helps Knicks End a Skid
description: Paul Pierce's 3-pointer bounced off the rim with seven seconds remaining as a Knicks victory -- if not their season so far -- hung perilously in the air. Michael Doleac, the dutiful Knicks reserve, bulldozed Tony Battie out of the way, stretched out his arms and snared the rebound. He protected it like hidden treasure, drawing the foul.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: West Nile Cases Total 31
description: State officials yesterday reported the 30th and 31st cases of West Nile virus, the mosquito-borne illness, this year. A 34-year-old woman from Wildwood and a 31-year-old man from Cranford are recovering. As with previous cases, the patients were not identified. The woman, who first showed symptoms on Sept. 25, was never hospitalized. The man, whose symptoms first appeared on Oct. 15, was hospitalized for 10 days, then released. Last year, in New Jersey, the illnesses of 25 people were diagnosed as West Nile, but no deaths were reported. The state health department said test results in several other possible cases were pending. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: He Gave of Himself, So That I Could Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARANTZ, IRMA
description: MARANTZ -- Irma. Beloved wife of the late Morris, died peacefully November 16. Her son Howard, granddaughter Gayle Nobel, sisters Madeleine Kesselman, Rose Schindelheim, Hermine Gewirtz, Janice Feinson mourn her passing. She gave much and grew old with dignity. Services Tuesday at 11:30 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Hemisphere Trade Talks Move Slowly
description: Negotiators gained little ground in surmounting differences over a measure intended to scale back a trade agreement for 34 countries in the Americas on Monday, but they were able to agree on selecting a headquarters city for the trade pact by next summer.

title: DUPONT TO SELL INVISTA UNIT FOR $4.4 BILLION
description: DuPont, which invented nylon almost 70 years ago, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Invista synthetic fibers business to Koch Industries for $4.4 billion to concentrate on faster-growing businesses. Invista had $6.3 billion in sales, 25 percent of DuPont's revenue, last year. Invista has the Stainmaster carpet and Lycra brands and is the biggest maker of nylon. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., is selling some of its most famous products to focus on more profitable lines, like flat-screen computer technology and Corian countertops. The company said the sale would cut its energy costs in half. A DuPont spokesman, G. Irvin Lipp, said the company had not decided what to do with the income from the sale.

title: Anthony Ripley; Journalist, 75
description: Anthony Ripley, a former national correspondent for The New York Times and a founding editor of the quarterly Discovery YMCA, died on Friday in Boulder, Colo. He was 75 and lived in nearby Lyons. The cause was a stroke, his family said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Civilians Killed
description: American and Afghan forces killed six Afghan men in eastern Afghanistan on Saturday, Afghan officials reported. Accounts varied. The governor of Paktika Province, Muhammad Ali Jalali, said American and Afghan forces fired on the men when they refused to stop their vehicle in the Barmal district, near the border with Pakistan. He called the incident a misunderstanding and said the men were armed local tribesman who fired back before being killed and were not Taliban fighters. Dawlat Khan, the provincial police chief, said the men were unarmed and died when their truck was bombed by an American aircraft. He said Taliban forces were active in the area. American military officials said the men were terrorists. David Rohde (NYT)

title: NEW DVD's; The 'Alien' Series, Stretched to the Nines
description: Erupting with content -- commentary, interviews, behind-the-scenes documentaries, trailers, not to mention the movies themselves -- DVD is always setting size records. Now there is one you can measure with a yardstick.

title: Front Row; Citizen Von Furstenberg
description: On Thursday, the Diane Von Furstenberg Studio in the West Village will welcome a guest not typically in attendance at the fashion shows, readings and dance performances held there. That guest is Gen. Wesley K. Clark, and Ms. Von Furstenberg is holding a fund-raiser for him.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rape Suspect Flees
description: The authorities asked yesterday for the public's help in finding a livery cab driver who jumped bail before his trial on charges that he raped and kidnapped women passengers. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, released a photograph of the driver, Jaime Oliveira, 22, of 40-19 99th Street in Elmhurst. Mr. Brown called him ''a sexual predator'' and said his work as a driver ''gave him the opportunity and the means to come in contact with young female victims.'' Mr. Oliveira, above, was described as 5-foot-9, 200 pounds, with black wavy hair and brown eyes. He faces up to 50 years in prison if convicted of all the charges against him. Anyone with information about Mr. Oliveira was urged to call the district attorney's office at (718) 286-6505.

title: CBS Picks Producer For '60 Minutes II'
description: Josh Howard, who has worked at ''60 Minutes'' for 14 years, has been named the executive producer of its sister broadcast, ''60 Minutes II,'' the president of CBS News, Andrew Heyward, announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about Albanian families who sell their children to international traffickers misstated the timing of one possible case. Kimete Sinani, a woman in Pogradec, is accused of having sold a 6-year-old grandson to a man who took the boy to Greece six years ago, not nine.

title: Path to War: Retracing Our Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Thousands of Italians in Tribute to the 19 Lost
description: The sight was extraordinary, but less so than the sound, or rather the lack of it. Although thousands upon thousands of people filled one of this city's most chaotic squares during the evening rush hour on Monday, the decibel level seldom rose above a whisper's.

title: I Came, I Bought And I Helped
description: No one blinks anymore when the fashion world tantalizes the public with its design flirtation du jour. People are so inured to 15-second novelties that, by the time one registers broadly, it has typically become a remote blip on the cognoscenti's radar screens. Velour hoodies? Yawn. Ugg boots? Weren't those the weird things Kate Hudson wore with her bikini when she went arugula shopping in Malibu?

title: Two Squatters Killed in Fire In Deserted Bed-Stuy Building
description: A homeless couple died in an electrical fire early yesterday in the city-owned building in Bedford-Stuyvesant where they squatted, the authorities said.

title: A Parody of Plumed Horses, And Dromedary Camels as Well
description: Big Apple Circus

title: Still Spry and Vigorous at 70, With New Touches on Tradition
description: Christmas Spectacular

title: Best Overall Player in Japan Says He Plans to Play in U.S.
description: Shortstop Kazuo Matsui, regarded as Japan's best all-around player, announced yesterday in Tokyo that he intended to play in the United States, opening the way for him to sign with a major league team as a free agent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLISKIN, SYLVIA
description: PLISKIN--Sylvia. Wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Kurt and Louise Pliskin and Muriel Deutsch; dear grandmother of Jeffrey and Jodi Pliskin, David Pliskin, Richard and Lisa Pliskin, and Bruce Deutsch; great-grandmother of Adam, Stuart, Julie, Emma and Lily.

title: LVMH Battles Against Morgan Stanley in Court
description: Echoes of a four-year battle for the Gucci Group resounded here on Monday as a commercial court heard opening arguments in a lawsuit that pits LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods group that lost the struggle for control of Gucci, against Morgan Stanley, Gucci's investment banker.

title: East Foes Are Trying To Imitate Nets' Style
description: The first time Jason Kidd saw the New Orleans Hornets this season, he might as well have been watching his own team in a different uniform. It was as if he had left his playbook on Bourbon Street and Baron Davis had picked it up for safekeeping.

title: Front Row; New Name Under the Tents
description: Just as members of the fashion corps were growing accustomed to referring to the seasonal collections in New York by their official name, Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, the official name changed. Yesterday, Seventh on Sixth, the producers of the shows, announced that Olympus would replace the automotive company as the title sponsor. Thus the fall 2004 collections scheduled for February will become the first Olympus Fashion Week. Mercedes-Benz, having concluded its three-year contract with Seventh on Sixth, opted out of another, though it will remain the chief sponsor of the twice-a-year shows in Los Angeles.

title: Turkey Expects to Identify Synagogue Bombers Soon
description: Turkish officials said Monday that they were close to identifying the suicide bombers who attacked two synagogues here on Saturday, killing 24 people and wounding more than 300 others.

title: Ex-Governor Of Hawaii Questions Use Of Law Firm
description: A former governor of Hawaii who ordered an investigation into accusations of tax fraud by ChevronTexaco says he was unaware that the law firm hired to investigate had worked for the predecessors of the company, which the firm eventually cleared of wrongdoing.

title: Tone It Down? Democrats Say No (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A U.S. General Speeds the Shift In an Iraqi City
description: An American commander is preparing to pull troops back from Ramadi, a city at the center of guerrilla activity, and turn it over to Iraqi officers, an experiment that could change the course of the occupation of Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GINSBURG, FREDA GORDON
description: GINSBURG--Freda Gordon. Born 1903, lived in the Bronx and Brooklyn, NY. Mother of the late Helene Ellinger, grandmother of Diane Rosmarin, and Mark Ellinger, great-grandmother of Adam, Seth, and Jodi, and great great-grandmother of Alexis. Worked as a bookkeeper in the floral industry in Manhattan for many years. A thoughtful and gracious woman interested throughout her entire life in world affairs, and NYC. Voracious reader and avid NYC sports fan. Loved NYC and all the cultural opportunities it offered including the theatre and symphony. Graveside services Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ, today at 2 P.M.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Rape Suspect Arrested
description: A suspect in the rape of a 17-year-old girl and the attempted rape of a 25-year-old woman was arrested on Sunday after the girl spotted him on the street, the police said yesterday. The man, Juan Vasquez, 23, is accused of following the girl into the stairwell of her building in the South Bronx last Tuesday and raping her at knifepoint. Last Friday, the police said, he followed the woman into her home and threatened her with a knife, but fled after she tried to fight him off, the police said. Both women had walked home from a subway station. After Mr. Vasquez was arrested at 149 Brook Avenue, a third woman, who saw the arrest, said that he had groped her. Mr. Vasquez, who is on parole for selling drugs, was charged with first degree rape, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: DYCOM TO BUY FINDER OF UNDERGROUND UTILITY LINES
description: Dycom Industries, which provides engineering and construction services to the telecommunications industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the UtiliQuest Holdings Corporation for $120 million, expanding its underground-utility locating services. UtiliQuest, based in Atlanta, identifies and marks cable television, telephone, gas and power lines before excavations. UtiliQuest is controlled by the closely held investment firms Oaktree Capital Management and GFI Energy Ventures. Dycom, which is based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., already offers utility-locating services.

title: INSIDE
description: Insurers to Merge

title: Chirac to Tackle Anti-Semitism and Muslim Slums of Bitterness
description: Reflecting concern that disaffected Muslim youths are behind anti-Semitic acts in France, President Jacques Chirac on Monday called an emergency high-level meeting to approve measures to stop attacks on Jewish sites.

title: Cigna Sells Its Retirement Business
description: Prudential Financial, one of the biggest life insurers, said last night that it had agreed to buy the retirement investment business of Cigna, a leader in health insurance, for $2.1 billion.

title: Press Baron Will Quit His Post; Received Unauthorized Payments
description: Conrad M. Black, the Canadian press baron who sought to build a global collection of newspapers with a conservative bent, is quitting as chief executive and putting the company up for sale after an internal investigation disclosed yesterday that he and his partners had received $15.6 million in unauthorized payments.

title: Reading Minds and Bending Spoons
description: To the Editor:

title: No UN appearance necessary, he says : A top EU aide backs Iran in feud over arms
description: BRUSSELS:  Reiterating a policy of engagement with Iran, the European Union's foreign policy chief said Monday that the Iranian government had been honest about its nuclear program and should not be made to appear before the United Nations Security Council.

title: Gala Goes On Despite Problems, Problems, Problems
description: Drama was certainly in evidence at the annual Richard Tucker Music Foundation gala at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night. So much was going on, in fact, that the actual music part was almost superfluous -- which was just as well, since it was a little disappointing.

title: Pageantry and Protests Planned as Bush Arrives in Britain
description: LONDON, Nov. 18  President Bush arrived in Britain tonight at the beginning of a four-day state visit that will pit the pageantry of royal ceremony and vows of Anglo-American solidarity against attention-getting protest marches and demonstrations by tens of thousands of war objectors.

title: Editorial Observer; The Black Seminole Indians Keep Fighting for Equality in the American West
description: The picture of Brent Staples posted on The Times's Web site shows a bearded man who is black to the naked eye. But what seems clear to the naked eye is rarely the full story when it comes to race. My great-great-grandfathers on both sides were white. The one on my paternal side was a Virginia slave owner who fathered children with a woman he owned. The white progenitor on my mother's side was a post-Civil War Virginian who scandalized his white family by taking a mistress who was part black and part Cherokee. This relationship produced my great-grandmother, a tall, striking woman with dark hair so long she had to move it aside to sit down.

title: Limbaugh Signs On Again, Sharing Life's Tough Lessons
description: Emerging from a self-imposed exile in which he was treated for an addiction to painkillers, Rush Limbaugh returned to the air yesterday. And listeners who tuned in during the first few minutes of his radio show would have been forgiven if they thought they were hearing an Oprah-style self-help session.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas on Nov. 8 with a profile of Loc Wacquant, a sociology professor who took up boxing, misidentified a painting by George Bellows shown in a print that hangs at his home in Berkeley, Calif. It is ''Dempsey and Firpo'' (1922), not ''Boxing'' (1901).

title: Debating Darwin, and Divinity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUSHING, JUSTINE BAYARD (NEE CUTTING)
description: CUSHING -- Justine Bayard (nee Cutting) on Saturday, November 15, 2003. Loving mother to three daughters, witty Granny to six grandchildren & three great-grandchildren. Memorial service Wednesday, November 26, 11 am, the Chapel of St George's Church, 209 East 16th St, NYC.

title: Path to War: Retracing Our Steps (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHWALT, FATHER RICHARD A., M.M.
description: HOCHWALT--Father Richard A., M.M., 79, of Dayton, Ohio, a Maryknoll missioner to Africa, died November 16 at St. Teresa's Residence, Ossining, NY. A priest for 52 years, he is survived by a brother, Carroll Hochwalt, Jr., of Upper Montclair, N.J., and nieces and nephews. Wake services: Tuesday, November 18, 7:30 p.m, funeral Mass: Wed, November 19, 11 a.m., at Maryknoll Society Center, Ossining. Memorial donations may be made in his name to Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers. P.O. Box 302, Maryknoll, N.Y. 10545

title: Congress Puts Authorization Of L. I. Cable In Energy Bill
description: The battle between Connecticut and New York over the 24-mile electric cable crossing under Long Island Sound is escalating to Congress, which is set to vote this week on a broad national energy bill with one sentence granting permanent approval for the cable's operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEITEL, SARALEE. (NEE FINGER)
description: TEITEL--Saralee. (nee Finger). On November 16, 2003. Mother of Ilana (Carlos) and Tanya, (Mark) grandmother of Emily, Rebecca, Justin, and Lauren.

title: Europe Will Examine Bid By Oracle to Buy PeopleSoft
description: The European Commission opened an investigation on Monday into whether the Oracle Corporation's hostile $7.3 billion bid to take over a rival software maker, PeopleSoft Inc., would create a company that would dominate markets in Europe, the commission said in a statement.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: CHURCH FREEZES TIES WITH EPISCOPALIANS The Russian Orthodox Church announced that it was suspending relations with the Episcopal Church U.S.A. because of the consecration as bishop this month of V. Gene Robinson of New Hampshire, who is openly gay. In a statement by its Department for External Church Relations, the church said: "We see a great danger to modern man in the processes which are going on in the Episcopal Church in the U.S.A. and in some other Christian communities of the Western world. The consequences are terrible, as even people with normal sexual orientation are joining in homosexualism." The statement noted nearly 200 years of good relations with the Episcopal Church, maintained even in the cold war, but said the Russian church now felt forced to freeze all contacts and suspend the work of a joint committee on theological and humanitarian issues. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, DONALD S.
description: KLEIN--Donald S. The Officers and Directors of the Westchester Women's Bar Association Foundation are profoundly saddened by the untimely passing of our treasured friend & former Board member, Donald S. Klein. Donald was a wonderful mentor to our fledgling organization. We will sorely miss his unfailing encouragement, guidance and generous spirit. Carla D. Glassman, President

title: Police Justified In '99 Killing, A Jury Decides
description: After less than a day of deliberation, a federal jury in Brooklyn found yesterday that the city and five police officers were not liable for the shooting death four years ago of an emotionally disturbed man, Gidone Busch, who was clutching a hammer on the sidewalk outside his Borough Park apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, MAURICE
description: SILVER--Maurice. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Maurice Silver, beloved father of L. David Silver. We extend our deepest condolences to David and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: A 'brand experience' on the monorail as adsinfiltrate new arenas.
description: THE trend to advertise in places that had until recently been advertising-free is accelerating, with two major marketers clambering aboard the booming brand wagon.

title: The Meaning of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICARE PLAN COVERING DRUGS BACKED BY AARP
description: AARP, the largest and most influential organization of older Americans, threw its weight behind a bill on Monday that offers drug benefits to the elderly as part of the biggest transformation of Medicare in its 38-year history.

title: Defense Fails Jets Again, And Cottrell Takes Heat
description: For 10 weeks, the explanations for the Jets' defensive collapses have been strikingly similar, replete with references to missed tackles and improperly played calls. There has been plenty of blame to go around, from the players, to the coaches, to the scheme.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Dry Run on the Moon

title: Clear to Land, but Dodging East River Flotsam
description: Of all the airplane runways in New York City, the longest and most treacherous is the murky vein of the East River. It does all a river can do to distinguish itself from the asphalt lanes at Newark and La Guardia and Kennedy.

title: Leon Pordy, 84, Coffee Chief
description: Dr. Leon Pordy, a Manhattan cardiologist who unexpectedly moved into the corporate world, becoming chairman of the Chock full o'Nuts coffee company, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Mayor's Office Objects to Bill on Lead Abatement
description: The Bloomberg administration yesterday picked apart a lead-paint abatement law proposed by the City Council, saying it would give landlords too little time to eliminate hazards and might increase health risks to young children.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Two Portraits of a Beating Emerge in Court in a Brutality Suit Against Nassau Officers
description: In his nearly two decades as a police officer for New York City and then Nassau County, Anthony Raymond has earned more than 50 commendations and racked up almost 40 civilian complaints. He has been arrested once, and was found liable by a civil jury for shooting a man to death.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a fatal fire in Rome, N.Y., missstated the name of the Syracuse hospital where some victims were treated. It is University Hospital, not University Medical Center.

title: He Gave of Himself, So That I Could Live (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: When Mothers Change Fathers
description: Women whose second child had a father different from the first child's were at higher risk for birth complications, a new study has found.

title: Tone It Down? Democrats Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions Fit for Soap Opera On Russian Immigrants in 1916
description: 'The Lady Next Door'

title: Path to War: Retracing Our Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Agency to Pull 30 Foreign Staff From Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 18  The United Nations refugee agency announced today that it was temporarily pulling 30 foreign staff members out of large areas of southern and eastern Afghanistan and closing refugee reception centers in four provinces, officials said.

title: Drugs in Sports Creating Games of Illusion
description: No result in any elite sport can be trusted with reasonable certainty to have been achieved without performance-enhancing drugs, a number of American scientists say. The continuing revelations of drug use have undermined, and perhaps even destroyed, the reliability of sport as fair play, they say.

title: Tone It Down? Democrats Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Rare Infection Threatens To Spread in Blood Supply
description: A parasitic infection common in Latin America is threatening the United States blood supply, public health experts say. They are especially concerned because there will be no test for it in donated blood until next year at the earliest.

title: Spreading Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Already a Loner, Bonds Will Go It Alone in Marketing of His Image
description: Barry Bonds, considered an island unto himself with the San Francisco Giants, elected last week to isolate himself from all other major league ballplayers by pulling out of the group licensing program run by the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: For a Day, at Least, Stars Shine on Sacramento
description: This sleepy capital town became the center of the televised world on Monday morning as Hollywood middleweights, political and financial power brokers, and more than 700 reporters from 14 countries converged on the Statehouse lawn to see Arnold Schwarzenegger sworn in as the 38th governor of California.

title: Rodriguez Wins M.V.P. As Trade Talks Swirl
description: Alex Rodriguez won his first American League Most Valuable Player award yesterday, but his triumph quickly became an afterthought when he revealed he had told the Texas Rangers he would be willing to consider a trade.

title: Doctors Look for Source of Stent Complications
description: When a new therapy performs extraordinarily well in clinical tests and is widely publicized and licensed, excitement mounts. But after hundreds of thousands of patients receive the new treatment, unexpected problems can turn up to temper the enthusiasm.

title: Hamburg Journal; Girls From Ghana Are Mired in a German City's Conflict
description: You wouldn't think of Gifty and Sylvia Oppong, 12 and 13 years old respectively, as much of a danger to Germany. They are, after all, only sisters going to school to learn German, and living with a mother whose proudest boast is that she's never taken a penny of public money.

title: A Maverick Starts a Museum Chain; A Parisian Curator Intends to Make Art Popular (and Make Money)
description: Marc Restellini, a French art curator with the soul of an entrepreneur, likes crowds. A Modigliani exhibition that he organized last year at the Muse du Luxembourg had 587,000 visitors, more than any other Paris show in 2002. Now he has come up with another likely crowd-pleaser: ''Intimate Picasso: The Collection of Jacqueline,'' the first public display of works inherited by Jacqueline Roque, Picasso's second wife.

title: White House Moves to Impose Quotas on Chinese Textiles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  The Bush Administration moved today to block large volumes of Chinese textile exports to the United States, provoking fears of protectionism in international markets but cheers from American producers in the southern United States.

title: How Banks Do Well While Doing Good
description: Mining and energy projects in poor countries often disrupt communities, pollute the environment and generate corruption. Residents of areas rich with natural resources often end up wanting to stuff the oil, gas or gold back into the ground.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Police Cleared Of Misconduct
description: A five-month county, state and federal investigation found no evidence of criminal misconduct by the Tacoma Police Department in an April murder-suicide involving the police chief but abundant evidence of management troubles, Attorney General Christine Gregoire said. The inquiry was begun after the chief, David Brame, shot his wife, Crystal Brame, then killed himself. Ms. Brame died a week later. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: CHINA SET TO ACT ON FUEL ECONOMY
description: The Chinese government is preparing to impose minimum fuel economy standards on new cars for the first time, and the rules will be significantly more stringent than those in the United States, according to Chinese experts involved in drafting them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLSTEIN, ETHEL
description: MILLSTEIN--Ethel. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member Ethel Millstein. We extend heartfelt sympathy. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred Youngwood, President

title: Glances Into the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Leaders Indicted
description: Prosecutors have brought the first criminal charges directly related to suspected corruption in the selection of Brooklyn judges: an indictment of the borough's top two Democratic officials on charges that they tried to strong-arm judicial candidates into hiring consultants favored by the party, officials said.

title: Writer's Block at a Hotel, With Many a Cure at Hand
description: 'Like I Say'

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 412 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, CYNTHIA
description: SCHWARTZ -- Cynthia. Age 80, passed away on November 16, 2003. Loving wife of the late Jack Schwartz, cherished mother of Martha Mason and Albert Simon, Lise, Eric Schwartz and Catherine Graham, Karl Schwartz and Helen Marino. Survived by five grandchildren and her brother Alvin Schechter and half-sister Zena Chudnoff. Services will be held at Temple Israel of New Rochelle on Tuesday at 12 P.M. Interment to follow at Beth Israel Memorial Park. For information please call George T. Davis Funeral Home, at 914-632-0324.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, ELIEZER
description: SCHWARTZ--Eliezer. Adored son of Rabbi Gershon and Dr. Shuly Rubin Schwartz, cherished brother of Moshe, Tali, and Hadar, devoted grandson of Shirley Schwartz. We mourn the tragic death of our beloved nephew, Elie. Elie's wit, charisma and goodness were a blessing to us all. Funeral today at 10:30, Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th St, New York. Neil and Alisa Rubin Kurshan Jack and Leslie Rubin

title: Path to War: Retracing Our Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WITTY, JEANNE
description: WITTY--Jeanne. On November 17, 2003. Jeanne Witty (nee Cohen Cole). Loving wife of the late Irwin D. Witty. Beloved mother of Joanne, Jonathan L. and Alan R. Witty. Devoted mother-in-law of Eugene J. Keilin and Merrill Witty. Daughter of the late Albert and Minnie Cohen. Loving grandmother of Gregory, Charles and Rachael Keilin, and Claire, Reid Cherlin. Loving great-grandmother of Ariel Hekier. Services and interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, NY, on Tuesday, November 18, at 2:30 PM. Please omit flowers. Contributions in her memory may be directed to the American Diabetes Association of Maryland, 3120 Timanus Lane #

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: N.Y.U. Professor Is Tribunal President
description: Theodor Meron, a longtime professor at New York University Law School and an authority on international human rights and humanitarian law, was elected to a full two-year term as president of the United Nations war crimes tribunal that deals with the worst excesses of the 1990's wars that broke up Yugoslavia. Judge Meron, 73, a Polish-born American, succeeds a Frenchman, Claude Jorda, who moved to the new International Criminal Court, also in The Hague.

title: That Spunky Old Belle Isn't Just Whistlin' 'Dixie'
description: Lucy Marsden, the narrator of Allan Gurganus's popular 1989 novel, ''Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All,'' is 99 years old. The date is 1985, and Lucy is in the Lane's End rest home, spilling out her life story, mostly about her marriage to the final Confederate survivor of the Civil War, whom she married when he was 51 and she 15. With her husband's memories seemingly absorbed as her own, her life seems to span well over a century in rural North Carolina, from the days of slaves and slaveholders to the days of T-shirts that read, ''Disco Ain't Dead Yet.''

title: Well-Observed Waiting, And a Fruitful First Play
description: Tristine Skyler is intrigued by waiting rooms. Her first film, ''Getting to Know You,'' was set in a bus station waiting room. Her first play, ''The Moonlight Room,'' which opened earlier this month at the TriBeCa Playhouse, takes place in a hospital waiting room.

title: Broadway Triumphs, Revisited
description: The Encores! series of musicals in concert, a popular feature at City Center over the last decade, generally focuses on works grown dusty in storage. But at three omnibus performances on Sunday and Monday some of the American musical's best-known songs were featured in a very happy celebration of City Center itself.

title: Giants and Fassel Are Caught In a Whirlpool of Confusion
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel has started to feel like the middle of a pinwheel. No matter how many dizzying rotations his team goes through this season, everything circles back to him.

title: Yankees Might Open in Japan
description: Major League Baseball has asked the Yankees and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays to move their season-opening series next spring to Japan, a person involved in the negotiations said last night. If approved, the move would send the former Japanese star and current Yankee Hideki Matsui back to his old home at the Tokyo Dome.

title: Still Carrying a Torch for AIDS Prevention
description: FIVE years after the ultimate coronation, the crystal trophies this offbeat beauty queen received for her AIDS activism before, during and after her 1998 reign as Miss America occupy an entire wall of curio cabinetry in her one-room apartment. The statuary doesn't exactly outshine her, but it's close, especially after she drapes that androgynous blue hoodie over the sexy black camisole that left her feeling ''underdressed for the occasion'' but worked fine earlier at an acting audition.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK: OFF-DUTY OFFICER SHOOTS MAN An off-duty New York City police officer who said she happened on masked men fleeing from the house where she lives shot and critically injured one suspect and scuffled with another before she was beaten and her gun wrested away, the Nassau County police said yesterday. They said the men, along with a third suspect, fled, but were arrested in their vehicle minutes later. The wounded suspect, shot in the stomach, was taken to Nassau University Medical Center, where he was listed in serious condition. The officer, 29, was treated for cuts and abrasions. Her name was not immediately released. Early yesterday morning, she arrived at the two-family house where she lives. Two men fleeing from the second-floor apartment in an apparent burglary attempted to push past her, but she drew her gun and fired, the police said. The officer's weapon was recovered when the suspects were arrested, the police said.

title: Front Row; Best-Dressed List Lives On
description: In the last decade, nobody could really claim that the International Best-Dressed List had much meaning to anyone beyond the group of editors and socialites who served on the selection committee or the finalists themselves. The list was the crusty enterprise of the press agent Eleanor Lambert, who ran it for 63 years until her death in October.

title: S.E.C. Chief Assures Congress of Greater Funds Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission told lawmakers today that he was committed to rooting out abuses in the mutual fund industry, abuses that he said represented a fundamental betrayal of American investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTABROOK, KENNETH
description: ESTABROOK -- Kenneth. Weill Cornell Medical College is saddened by the passing of Mr. Kenneth Estabrook, the beloved husband of our esteemed Overseer Anne Estabrook. A graduate of Cornell University and Cornell Law School, Mr. Estabrook was a generous volunteer and benefactor, dedicated to promoting excellence in higher education. Our deepest condolences are extended to Anne and the entire Estabrook family. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman of the Board of Overseers Dean Antonio M. Gotto, M.D. Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University

title: In Rejecting Affirmative Action Case, Supreme Court Also Exposes Conflict Among Justices
description: A dispute within the Supreme Court over what, if anything, to do next about affirmative action broke into the open on Monday when two justices dissented from the court's refusal to take up a white-owned construction company's challenge to an affirmative action program for public contracting in Denver.

title: Unraveling The Secret Of the Spells
description: Ten years ago I was on vacation, sitting at a harborside restaurant in Baltimore sipping a daiquiri. We had planned to leave the next morning on a daylong Chesapeake Bay cruise. With that drink my whole world, and my perception of myself in it, changed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about four former chiefs of Israel's General Security Service who criticized the country's tough military policy toward Palestinians referred incorrectly to the display of their interview in the newspaper Yediot Ahronot. As the article noted, their photograph was on the front page with a headline that read "Four Directors of G.S.S. Warn: Israel in Grave Danger." But the interview itself was on Page 4, with their photograph and a headline  reproduced with the Times article  that read "We Are on the Way to a Catastrophe."

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: An Influx Of In-Laws
description: The number of extended families living in single-family homes has reached record levels in the state, a result of rapidly increasing home prices, according to the University of Massachusetts. The number of ''subfamilies,'' or parents who move in with relatives because they cannot afford housing, nearly doubled in the past two decades to 52,008 in 2000. The median home price in the state is $287,000, the third highest in the country behind Hawaii and California. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: What Those Letters Mean
description: The clean-car categories set by California (and adopted by four other states) can be confusing. Here is a rundown of the terms, in ascending order of cleanliness:

title: Market Place; Loews Executives Facing Some Difficult Choices
description: The legacy of Laurence A. Tisch, the co-founder of the Loews Corporation who died on Saturday, is an $8 billion diversified conglomerate -- the kind of company that generally fell out of favor a decade ago.

title: Rumsfeld Reassures Seoul on Regrouping G.I.'s
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld reassured South Korea on Monday that efforts to reorganize American forces in South Korea would not diminish either the capacity or commitment to deter aggression by the North.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAIOLA, HEDWIG BIRKENFELD
description: CAIOLA--Hedwig Birkenfeld, born February 21, 1925 in New York. A resident of New York, Geneva and Rome, she died peacefully on November 13th in Rome. A loving wife and mother, she is survived by husband Dr. Nicola Caiola; children Amelia, Sara and Francesco; granddaughter Chiara; and sons-in law Laurence Ross and Chandran Madhu. Memorial gifts may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of New York, 360 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017. The family will also receive friends in New York at a later date.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: China to Impose Standards For Fuel Economy on Cars

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOUDON, DOROTHY
description: LOUDON -- Dorothy. On November 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Norman Paris. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Wednesday, November 19th, 6-8 PM, with services, Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Actor's Fund of America or Broadway Cares Equity Fights AIDS.

title: TIME APPOINTS NEW PUBLISHERS AT MAGAZINES
description: Time Inc. announced several changes yesterday on the publishing side of its magazines. Dave Morris, who was the publisher of Entertainment Weekly, will become publisher of Sports Illustrated, succeeding Fabio Freyre, who was named group vice president for corporate sales and marketing. Mr. Morris will be succeeded at Entertainment Weekly by Paul Caine, who previously worked as publisher of Teen People. And Cathy O'Brien, most recently vice president and general manager at Entertainment Weekly, will become group publisher of Time Inc.'s child-oriented and ethnic titles. The changes were announced by Ann Moore, chairwoman and chief executive of Time Inc., a division of Time Warner. David Carr (NYT)

title: Schwarzenegger Takes Oath And Vows End to Divisions
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger completed an unlikely odyssey on Monday, taking the oath of office as California's 38th governor after the state's historic recall election.

title: Ferry's Assistant Captain Testifies on Crash
description: The assistant captain who was piloting the Staten Island ferry when it slammed into a maintenance pier, killing 10 people, met with federal prosecutors and the city police yesterday for the first time since the Oct. 15 incident, law enforcement officials said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Will this further damage the integrity or stature or nobility of sport? A reasonable argument can be made that there's nothing left to chip away at, that much of sport at the elite level is purely entertainment.''

title: Bonds Wins Record Sixth M.V.P. Award
description: Barry Bonds and his father, Bobby, had it down to routine. Bonds, the Giants' slugging left fielder, would get tickets for his wife and family in a designated section of the stands and establish eye contact early in the game. Bobby Bonds would serve as an at-home hitting coach, relaying tips to Bonds's wife, who signaled her husband on the field.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bigger Loss For Eurodisney
description: The amusement park operator Eurodisney said its net loss increased sharply for the fiscal year ended in September because of lower sales and higher investment in a new theme park. The company posted a 56 million euro ($66 million) loss for the fiscal year after a 33.1 million euro loss in fiscal 2002. Sales fell 2.1 percent, to 1.05 billion euros ($1.24 billion). Eurodisney said the results were affected by a drop in tourism and a series of strikes. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: CORNING MAY RECORD AN EXPENSE FOR REVAMPING
description: Corning, the world's largest maker of fiber optic cable for telecommunications networks, said yesterday that it might record a one-time restructuring expense from its semiconductor business in the fourth quarter. The company said it might also reduce the value of its Samsung Corning Corporation venture. The company, which is based in Corning, N.Y., said it still expected to have earnings of 3 cents to 4 cents a share before any one-time items. Sales will be $740 million to $765 million.

title: Blair Says Bush's State Visit Comes at 'the Right Time'
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair on Monday dismissed antiwar protesters' criticism of the state visit this week by President Bush as peace demonstrations got under way and the police tightened security around London.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Massapequa Park: Off-Duty Officer Shoots Man
description: An off-duty New York City police officer who said she happened on masked men fleeing from the house where she lives shot and critically injured one suspect and scuffled with another before she was beaten and her gun wrested away, the Nassau County police said yesterday. They said the men, along with a third suspect, fled, but were arrested in their vehicle minutes later. The wounded suspect, shot in the stomach, was taken to Nassau University Medical Center, where he was listed in serious condition. The officer, 29, was treated for cuts and abrasions. Her name was not immediately released. Early yesterday morning, she arrived at the two-family house where she lives. Two men fleeing from the second-floor apartment in an apparent burglary attempted to push past her, but she drew her gun and fired, the police said. The officer's weapon was recovered when the suspects were arrested, the police said.

title: No Longer Joined, Boys Face Tough Journey
description: For the 2-year-old twins Ahmed and Mohamed Ibrahim, it has been a month of firsts: the first time they have ever slept in separate beds, sat upright or seen each other face to face.

title: Dual Roles for Big Board Chief Could Be Retained
description: John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, is leaning toward keeping the roles of chairman and chief executive combined in his effort to find a strong successor, according to directors involved in the search process.

title: 2 Top Brooklyn Democrats Charged in Judicial Corruption
description: Prosecutors have obtained the first criminal charges directly related to suspected corruption in the selection of Brooklyn judges: an indictment of the borough's top two Democratic officials on charges that they tried to strong-arm judicial candidates into hiring consultants favored by the party, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Is Cut From Tylenol Review
description: The Johnson & Johnson division that sells the Tylenol line of pain relievers has dismissed the brand's United States creative agency of 28 years, Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, by eliminating the agency from a review for the assignment. Billings were estimated at $115 million.

title: Michael Jacksons Ranch Is Raided
description: LOS OLIVOS, Calif., Nov. 18 — The authorities were searching Michael Jackson's secluded Neverland Ranch near here today, but they would not say why.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And Yet, It's Never Worked for Us

title: Negotiators Make Deal on $30 Billion Energy Bill
description: Congressional negotiators sped major energy legislation to the House and Senate floors on Monday after brushing aside Democratic attempts to eliminate provisions that have stirred opposition by conservation groups.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Honolulu; The Line To Paradise Begins Here
description: More than two-thirds of Hawaii's jobs are clustered around Honolulu. Tourism dominates the economy, but the state is trying to diversify into trade and banking -- promoting its location between the West Coast and Asia -- and also into technology, though that effort is hampered by a lack of venture capital.

title: Stuff and Nonsense
description: As you know, there are two kinds of women's magazines in the world, nonsmiling and smiling. In the nonsmiling magazines, which tend to be upscale, the models in the photo spreads wear these blank or haughty expressions because, you know, happiness is so middle class.

title: Hedging Against a Failure
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said he had no intention of turning yesterday's public hearing into a collective bargaining session but then attacked contract rules that prevent teachers from patrolling hallways and bar custodians from painting walls above 10 feet.

title: The Hammer Eyes Manhattan
description: The House Republican leader, Tom DeLay -- Congress's undisputed master of the fund-raising universe -- has begun mapping New York for the Republican National Convention next August. Mr. DeLay, dubbed The Hammer, thinks he has found a way around the new law banning soft-money contributions from influence-hungry corporate donors, who have long financed galas, dinners and yacht cruises for conventioneers of both parties.

title: A Crowd-Pleasing Concoction That Blends Sounds and Styles
description: Pat Metheny, the guitarist, recently commented that he conceives of jazz as a kind of highly complex folk music, which says something about how easily he manages to combine popular and esoteric ideas.

title: The Neediest Cases; Known for Helping Others, Woman Gets Help Herself
description: It was Labor Day 2001, and Doris Ware planned on taking her grandson, Steven, to the West Indian Day Parade in Brooklyn, as she did every year. On their way to the parade, the two stopped at a neighborhood get-together, where Ms. Ware had a couple of drinks with friends.

title: The Universal Cure
description: The public has good reason to be worried about health coverage. After five years of relative stability, insurance premiums, prescription-drug prices and other costs have soared. This year, premiums went up nearly 14 percent, with those paid by employees increasing nearly 50 percent since 2000. The number of Americans without health insurance increased more than 5 percent just in the last year. And strikes by workers in Los Angeles and elsewhere show that health coverage is the flashpoint of labor discord.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: U.N. AGENCY GROUNDS STAFF The United Nations suspended its operations in the southern half of Afghanistan after the killing of a Frenchwoman working for the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and two other attacks, a spokeswoman said. United Nations officials also withdrew four expatriate workers from the eastern town of Ghazni, where the 29-year-old woman was shot Sunday. The four international workers were relocated to Kabul, said the spokeswoman, Marie Okabe. In another incident over the weekend, she said, a vehicle carrying three Afghan workers for the United Nations in Paktia Province came under attack, though there were no casualties. The incidents came less than a week after a car bomb was detonated outside the organization's offices in Kandahar. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, TOBA
description: ADLER--Toba. Died unexpectedly on November 13. Loving mother of Andrew and Suzy, grandmother of Jack, Lily and Naomi and a great friend to many. Private gathering at her home. Donations may be made to Gay Men's Health Crisis or The Central Park Conservancy. New York will not be the same without her.

title: Glances Into the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: No Threat From Hinckley, Lawyer Says
description: John Hinckley Jr., who shot President Ronald Reagan in 1981, is not a danger to himself or to others, his lawyer said. Mr. Hinckley, left, appeared in federal court for a hearing to determine if his mental condition has improved enough for him to be permitted unsupervised visits with his parents. The government and Mr. Reagan's family have opposed Mr. Hinckley's request. Mr. Hinckley, 48, has remained at a hospital in Washington since his acquittal, by reason of insanity, for the shooting of the president and three others. John Files (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Suit Over Police Vests
description: Attorney General Thomas F. Reilly has sued companies over a bulletproof vest worn by more than 5,000 officers in the state, saying the vests are defective. Mr. Reilly filed the suit against Second Chance, a Michigan company that makes the vests, and a Japanese company that manufactures the material the vests are made from. Second Chance disclosed problems with the vest in September, after officers wearing the vests in California and Pennsylvania were killed. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Court Questions Eliminating Trade Center Memorial Entry
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation was ordered yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice to explain why it eliminated an entry titled ''Twin Piers'' from the World Trade Center memorial competition. The entry was apparently under serious consideration until early last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, DORIS (SILK)
description: SIMON--Doris (Silk) on November 16, 2003. Wife of Kenneth, mother of Ira Simon, Emily Simon and Ann Simon. Service today 10 A.M. at the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck. Zion Memorial 914-381-1809 for more info.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Sprint's plan to introduce a walkie-talkie feature to its cellular network misidentified the employer of Roger Entner, an analyst who commented. It is the Yankee Group, not Forrester Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLENNON, HARRISON R., JR.
description: GLENNON--Harrison R., Jr., died on November 15, 2003 in Greenwich, CT, at the age of 89. Devoted husband of Dickie Bailey Glennon. Cherished father of Harrison Randolph Glennon III and Blair Glennon Kernochan. Funeral and reception Wednesday, November 19, at 1:00 pm, St Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Ave, Riverside, CT.

title: Hepatitis Inquiry Moves Deliberately From Farm to Plate
description: At first, it just seemed like a nasty case of the flu. Jeff Cook, a 38-year-old unemployed auto mechanic, felt achy and nauseated, so he took some over-the-counter pain medicine and got some rest.

title: Name a Proxy Early to Prepare for the Unexpected
description: Two years ago, before entering the hospital for elective surgery, I appointed my husband as my health care proxy in case something happened to impair my ability to make decisions about further treatment.

title: A Moth, a Butterfly, an Elegant Merger of Science and Art
description: It is widely known in biology that moths and butterflies, the lepidopterans, are covered with scales. But the purpose of those scales has remained a mystery to many.

title: 911 Tape, Heard in One Sniper Trial, Is Barred From the Other
description: Panting, hysterical, in a voice shot through with primal pain, William Franklin knelt over his wife in a Home Depot parking lot and called 911.

title: Funds and Games
description: You're selling your house, and your real estate agent claims that he's representing your interests. But he sells the property at less than fair value to a friend, who resells it at a substantial profit, on which the agent receives a kickback. You complain to the county attorney. But he gets big campaign contributions from the agent, so he pays no attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGLADE, PATRICIA
description: LANGLADE -- Patricia. On November 14, 2003. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP are deeply saddened by the sudden and tragic loss of our beloved friend and colleague Patricia Langlade. Trish's career at our firm began on July 7, 1978, and more recently she was Director of Legal Recruiting. Her infectious laughter, good humor and spirit touched us all. Trish, who was recently honored for her 25 years of outstanding service with the firm, was much beloved by her many colleagues. She was a great friend who made us better people for having known her. We will remember her always. Our deepest sympathies are sent to her beloved husband, Gerald Langlade, to her two daughters, Tracey and Laura, and to the entire Langlade and McNulty families. On behalf of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP

title: Two Yemenis Held Abroad Are to Face Trial in a U.S. Court on Conspiracy Charges
description: A well-known Yemeni cleric and his assistant, accused of funneling money to Al Qaeda from Muslim supporters in Brooklyn and elsewhere, will face conspiracy charges in the United States, officials said Monday.

title: Glances Into the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Church Freezes Ties With Episcopalians
description: The Russian Orthodox Church announced that it was suspending relations with the Episcopal Church U.S.A. because of the consecration as bishop this month of V. Gene Robinson of New Hampshire, who is openly gay. In a statement by its Department for External Church Relations, the church said: ''We see a great danger to modern man in the processes which are going on in the Episcopal Church in the U.S.A. and in some other Christian communities of the Western world. The consequences are terrible, as even people with normal sexual orientation are joining in homosexualism.'' The statement noted nearly 200 years of good relations with the Episcopal Church, maintained even in the cold war, but said the Russian church now felt forced to freeze all contacts and suspend the work of a joint committee on theological and humanitarian issues.

title: Boy, 8, Caught in Crossfire, Dies on a Street in Brooklyn
description: An 8-year-old boy walking home with his father and two siblings was killed yesterday when he was caught in a barrage of gunfire on a gritty block of East New York, Brooklyn, the police said. A 23-year-old man who may have been the target of the shooting was also killed.

title: Testimony: I.O.C. Member's Son Hired to Help Bid
description: A Salt Lake City businessman testified yesterday that he hired the son of an International Olympic Committee member at the behest of the finance director of the city's Olympic bid committee to help it become the host of the 2002 Winter Games.

title: SHARES RISE AFTER GOOD NEWS ABOUT CANCER DRUG
description: American Pharmaceutical Partners stock rose 10 percent yesterday as new details about the company's breast-cancer drug, Abraxane, prompted Wall Street to compare it favorably to the Bristol-Myers Squibb drug Taxol. The talk stemmed from abstracts posted late Friday on the Web site of the San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium. The documents gave, for the first time, specifics from Abraxane's Phase III study. The full study is to be presented on Dec. 5. ''Abraxane appears to double the efficacy of Taxol with a better or similar safety profile,'' a CIBC analyst, Elliot Wilbur, wrote in a research note. Shares of American Pharmaceutical Partners, based in Los Angeles, rose $3.25, to $35.54.

title: Political Will Can Stop the Plant
description: More than a year ago, this page urged Gov. George Pataki and his environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, to put an end to plans to build an enormous new cement plant on the east bank of the Hudson River just south of Hudson, N.Y. Since then, the mills of bureaucratic procedure have continued to grind exceedingly fine, as they have since the construction of this plant was first proposed. It has been some two and a half years since St. Lawrence Cement completed its application to the Department of Environmental Conservation. Nearly every significant aspect of the plant's impact must be adjudicated before a final decision can be reached. The bureaucratic landscape changes slowly, but it does change.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Science Times last Tuesday with a chart showing scientific milestones of the last 25 years was published in error. It showed a laboratory rat, not a ''knockout'' mouse with a suppressed gene.

title: Investor Seeks a HealthSouth Meeting
description: A pension plan that is a shareholder in the HealthSouth Corporation asked a Delaware judge Monday to force the company to hold an annual meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARLIN, LEONARD
description: KARLIN--Leonard. On November 14, at age 81, following a brief illness. Editor, wordsmith, writer of elegance and wit. He had a lifelong association with Long Island University, where he taught journalism, directed public relations, and served on the Polk Awards Committee from its inception. His wife, Lee Karlin, died before him, as did his sisters, Ethel and Gertrude, and his brothers-in-law, Isidore Cytron and Meyer Isenman. He is survived by his daughters: Elisabeth, of Manhattan; Katherine, of Pittsburgh; Susannah, of Long Beach, LI; by his sons-in-law, Joshua Zaret and Christopher Remple; and by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews of the Cytron, Isenman and Schor families. We loved him. A service will be held on Sunday, November 23, at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, at 1 PM; 516487-9600. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Len Karlin Scholarship at Long Island University.

title: A Shortage of Energy
description: President Bush seems to have been the recipient of poor intelligence again. Last weekend, he claimed that the energy bill approved by Republican leaders would make the country ''more secure.'' Senator John McCain's description of the bill as a ''leave no lobbyist behind'' barrel of pork for selected industries and campaign contributors was closer to the truth. So was Senator Robert Byrd's unsparing judgment that the bill would ''do about as much to improve the nation's energy security as the administration's invasion of Iraq has done to stem the tide of global terrorism.''

title: If Claude Bbar Speaks, French Companies Listen
description: When outraged shareholders ousted the chairman of the big French chemical company Rhodia last month, accusing him of gross mismanagement, the spotlight focused on a man seen as being behind the shake-up, a man with no official role at the company but with a great deal of influence in French business.

title: Palestinians Said to Near Talks on Cease-Fire
description: A senior Egyptian mediator reached agreement with Palestinian leaders on Monday to start cease-fire talks among militants within two days, Palestinian officials said.

title: Hard-Wired for War
description: To the Editor:

title: Messier Likely to Play in Old-Timers' Game
description: Though Mark Messier, the Rangers' 42-year-old captain, said he would not announce his official decision until today, he left little doubt after practice in San Jose yesterday that he intended to play for a team of former Edmonton Oilers stars against a team of former Montreal Canadiens in an outdoor game at Edmonton's Commonwealth Stadium on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOHL, DAVID
description: WOHL--David. 1955-1994. You were an angel before the fates took you and my darling child forever. Love, Momm

title: Produce Items Are Vulnerable To Biological Contamination
description: The possibility that the large outbreak of hepatitis A in Pennsylvania was caused by contaminated scallions is a reminder that supposedly healthful foods -- fruits, raw vegetables and salads -- can be contaminated with dangerous microbes and make people sick.

title: Sharons Trip to Italy Reflects a Growing Alliance
description: ROME, Nov. 18  When Israel's prime minister decided to travel here this week, it was no surprise. Italy holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, and Israeli officials are as concerned as ever about currents of anti-Semitism among some Europeans and opposition to Israeli policies among a great many.

title: Judges Question Detention of American
description: Two federal appeals court judges were hostile to the Bush administration's position yesterday as the government argued that the requirements of the antiterror effort meant that the president could indefinitely detain an American who was arrested in this country as an ''enemy combatant'' and deny him contact with his lawyer.

title: Mets Say Piazza Isn't Asking For a Trade
description: The Mets were told by Mike Piazza last weekend that he was not seeking a trade and that he was willing to play first base next season, according to a person involved in their decision-making.

title: Plea Deals Being Used to Clear Balkan War Tribunal's Docket
description: The United Nations tribunal for the war crimes in the Balkans in the 1990's is suddenly rushing through its backlog of cases, adopting a disputed strategy to promote plea bargains with much reduced sentences in exchange for cooperation and guilty pleas.

title: Tone It Down? Democrats Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOGT, REV. ROBERT HENRY
description: VOGT--Rev. Robert Henry, S.J. Fond nephew of Anita Ruesing. Dear uncle of Laraine Cubeta and Mary O'Connell. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Road. Visitation Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Wednesday, 11:30 AM. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Serial-Killing Suspects Held
description: Two serial-killing suspects have been arrested in two provinces with the police accusing them of a staggering total of 90 murders, the local media reported. A former convict, Yang Zhiya, was arrested on Nov. 3 in Hebei Province and charged with stabbing 65 people to death and raping 23 women, newspapers reported. Then on Nov. 13, the police in Henan Province arrested an ex-soldier, Huang Yong. Mr. Huang reportedly confessed to strangling 25 teenage boys he had lured to his apartment by promising them jobs, The Beijing Evening News reported. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Politics: Ex-Chief Of Now Joins Braun
description: Patricia Ireland, the former president of the National Organization for Women, has become the campaign manager for Carol Moseley Braun's presidential campaign. Ms. Ireland, who was ousted last month as chief executive of the Y.W.C.A., will try to turn Ms. Braun's endorsements from women's groups into donations. As of Sept. 30, Ms. Braun had raised only $342,519. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Tone It Down? Democrats Say No
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Talking Baseball, Where Frolics Are Always in Season
description: ALL right, kids, gather round the camp fire, and if you're really good, I promise I won't scare you with any horror stories about the Jets or the Giants or those four Oakland Raiders who tested positive for steroids.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ad Agency's Profit Falls
description: Japan's biggest ad agency, Dentsu, said that profit fell 77 percent in the first six months as companies spent less on advertising. Dentsu, which went public two years ago, earned 6.8 billion yen ($62 million) in the period, which ended Sept. 30. Sales fell 2.3 percent. The company cited the war in Iraq and the SARS virus for declines in corporate marketing budgets, and it cut its profit forecast for the year by 15 percent, to 18.7 billion yen ($170 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about four former chiefs of Israel's General Security Service who criticized the country's tough military policy toward Palestinians referred incorrectly to the display of their interview in the newspaper Yediot Ahronot. As the article noted, their photograph was on the front page with a headline that read ''Four Directors of G.S.S. Warn: Israel in Grave Danger.'' But the interview itself was on Page 4, with their photograph and a headline -- reproduced with the Times article -- that read ''We Are on the Way to a Catastrophe.''

title: Theater in Review
description: Questions Fit for Soap Opera on Russian Immigrants in 1916

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIDMAN, RICHARD
description: MAIDMAN--Richard. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dr. Richard Maidman, beloved brother of Sandra Cahn, a dedicated supporter of the Jewish community. A longtime leader at UJA-Federation and its beneficiary agencies, Sandy serves on our Board of Directors and chairs Women's Philanthropy of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest sympathies to Sandy, Stewart, and to the entire Maidman family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REYES, AMELIA, M.D.
description: REYES--Amelia, M.D. On November 15, 2003 in Port Washington, NY. Beloved pediatrician for more than 20 years, who loved to garden. She leaves behind her mother Adelaida, three sisters, four children, 15 nieces and nephews and many dear friends including the Rev. Diana Austin. Religious services will be held at the Lutheran Church, 12 Franklin Avenue, Port Washington on Wednesday, November 19 at 4:00 PM.

title: In Turkey, a History Lesson in Peace
description: In Istanbul this past summer, an Israeli friend and I visited a synagogue in Ortakoy, a neighborhood on the shores of the Bosporus. Ortakoy is home to a mosque, a synagogue and a Greek Orthodox church, which huddle together between the sea and gently sloping hills. It is a place where the frescoes of Byzantium meet the architecture of Islam, and where the white-washed summer residencies of the Ottoman aristocracy, with their latticed woodwork, coexist with the Bauhaus buildings of the newer middle class.

title: Medicare Compromise Plan Won't Cut Costs, Critics Say
description: Critics of the Medicare plan devised by Congressional leaders said yesterday that it contained little in the way of mechanisms to slow the runaway costs of drugs and medical services even as it provided tens of billions of dollars for hospitals, health plans, employers, doctors and the drug industry.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At Power Company
description: The power company, E.On, said its earnings rose in the first nine months, helped by the strong performance of its core energy businesses. Consolidated net profit was 3.4 billion euros ($4 billion) in the period from January to September, an increase of 16 percent from a year earlier. Sales rose 33 percent, to 33.3 billion euros, and operating profit increased 11 percent, to 3.4 billion euros. But one-time charges related to unexpected shutdowns kept profit from reaching forecasts. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Hard-Wired for War
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a proposal to display all 5,201 submissions to the World Trade Center memorial competition misstated the number of works in ''Matisse Picasso'' at the Museum of Modern of Art, an exhibition that this one would greatly exceed in size. It was 137, not 200.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Oct. 3 about a mining boom in Mongolia misstated the terms of a legal settlement reached in Colorado in 2000 by Robert M. Friedland, the chairman of a company that is developing a copper and gold deposit in the Gobi Desert. He agreed to a one-time payment of $20.7 million, not $27.7 million over a decade, to settle state and federal accusations that the Summitville gold mine, run by a company in which he was a large shareholder, contributed to pollution of a nearby river. (The government paid Mr. Friedland $1.25 million for costs in related litigation, and he has recovered about $17 million from others involved in the Summitville mine.)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Art Carney on Wednesday listed three television credits erroneously. He did not make guest appearances on ''Star Trek,'' ''The Defenders'' or ''All in the Family.''

title: Catholic Center of N.Y.U. May Move to Nearby Parish
description: The Catholic Center at New York University may soon move off campus and merge with the nearby parish of St. Joseph-Greenwich Village. The center's director made the announcement during Masses this weekend.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Baby Food Maker Dismisses 4
description: Humana Milchunion, the German manufacturer of infant formula linked to the deaths of two Israeli children, dismissed four senior executives in its development, chemical laboratory and quality control departments. The company has acknowledged that too little vitamin B1 had been added to the kosher, soy-based formula it made for the Israeli market, citing human error. The company said it had put additional safety measures in place.

title: U.S. Intelligence Review Is Softening Some Judgments About Illicit Arms Abroad
description: A broad United States government reappraisal of intelligence about illicit weapons programs around the world is prompting a softening of some earlier judgments about foreign arsenals, according to several American officials.

title: Trial for Wife of Enron Executive
