description: HOUSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) - The wife of the Enron Corporation's former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow, will go to trial in Houston, a judge ruled.

title: Explorers Reveal Riches of Machu Picchu's Neglected Neighbor
description: Some forgotten cities in the mountains of Peru, abandoned to overgrown ruin, remained ''lost'' only because their possible significance was not fully appreciated by earlier explorers. That happened to a place known as Llactapata.

title: Debating Darwin, and Divinity
description: To the Editor:

title: Aliens Among Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADEL, CHARLOTTE F.
description: NADEL--Charlotte F. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Charlotte Nadel, beloved mother of Lawrence, both cherished friends and generous supporters of UJAFederation. We extend our deepest sympathies to Lawrence and to the entire Nadel family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.N. Agency Grounds Staff
description: The United Nations suspended its operations in the southern half of Afghanistan after the killing of a Frenchwoman working for the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and two other attacks, a spokeswoman said. United Nations officials also withdrew four expatriate workers from the eastern town of Ghazni, where the 29-year-old woman was shot Sunday. The four international workers were relocated to Kabul, said the spokeswoman, Marie Okabe. In another incident over the weekend, she said, a vehicle carrying three Afghan workers for the United Nations in Paktia Province came under attack, though there were no casualties. The incidents came less than a week after a car bomb was detonated outside the organization's offices in Kandahar. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: FREDDIE MAC TO ANNOUNCE NOTE SALES EACH QUARTER
description: Freddie Mac will announce its two- and three-year note sales quarterly instead of once a year to give itself more flexibility in selling debt, the company said yesterday. The company, which is chartered by the government, also made its two- and three-year Reference Note sales optional, a Freddie Mac spokeswoman, Heather Sieber, said. The company, based in McLean, Va., will publish its intentions for debt sales in a new quarterly funding announcement and summary, she said. Sales of 5- and 10-year Reference Notes will continue to be held once a quarter, Louise Herrle, Freddie Mac's treasurer, said. The minimum size for each Reference Note sale will stay at $3 billion, she said.

title: Glances Into the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Path to War: Retracing Our Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: Showtime To Present 'Reagans' This Month
description: Looking to take full advantage of the publicity the television film ''The Reagans'' has stirred, the Showtime pay-cable channel has decided to show it on Nov. 30, just two weeks after it would have been broadcast on CBS.

title: He Gave of Himself, So That I Could Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about the singer Donna Summer misstated the precedent for attaining three consecutive No. 1 platinum albums -- that is, each with sales of at least a million copies. Ms. Summer is not the only one; others include Madonna and Janet Jackson. The article also referred incorrectly to Ms. Summer's reunion with the producer Giorgio Moroder for her new album. They recorded a song in 1992 in addition to working together earlier. The separation was not 22 years.

title: New View of Data Supports Human Link to Global Warming
description: One of the last gaps in the evidence pointing to a human cause for global warming appears to be closing.

title: Dean Takes On Rival Gephardt One on One
description: Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, started a tough advertising campaign against Representative Richard A. Gephardt in Iowa on Monday that highlights Mr. Gephardt's role in drafting a resolution on a war in Iraq.

title: 14-Year-Old Signs Contract With Major League Soccer
description: Major League Soccer, competing against some of the top clubs in the world, has signed the teenage soccer star Freddy Adu to a six-year contract. Adu, 14, will play next season for D.C. United, becoming the youngest player in league history. He plans to live at home with his family in Potomac, Md.

title: MEMO PAD
description: The Boeing Company yesterday announced interior design features for its proposed new 7E7 aircraft that underscore the importance many airlines say they are assigning to making improvements in passenger comfort in all cabins.

title: Times on the Web Is Winner of Award
description: The New York Times on the Web has won an award from the Online News Association for coverage of the war in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAUSS, MICHAEL L.
description: MAUSS--Michael L. Beloved and devoted husband of Ellen. Loving father of Barry and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Alex, Marc, Brandon and Carly. Brother of Eileen Trattner and son of Renee Mauss. We will miss you dearly and you will be in our hearts forever. Services Wednesday, 2PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: The Fire's Armas Bounces Back
description: Chris Armas's anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee crumbled in Washington on May 12, 2002. After playing as the hub in Coach Bruce Arena's midfield, Armas would not join his United States teammates at the World Cup in South Korea.

title: F.C.C. Considering DirecTV Transaction
description: The Federal Communications Commission restarted its informal clock on Monday, counting down time on the agency's review of the News Corporation's DirecTV deal, with completion now set for mid-December.

title: Minnesota Seeks Glaxo Drug Documents
description: Minnesota's attorney general, Mike Hatch, asked a federal court yesterday to compel the drug maker GlaxoSmithKline to produce documents related to the company's clampdown on supplies to online drugstores in Canada.

title: Fewer Airline Passengers, But More-Crowded Planes
description: Randy Kabrich, a broadcasting consultant from Tampa who flies more than 250,000 miles a year, has been pulled off a plane twice in the last six months because there were too many passengers and not enough seats.

title: Ohio State Passes Southern California in B.C.S.
description: The Ohio State Buckeyes have been nicknamed the ''Luckeyes'' this season because they have won 10 of their 11 games with little production from their offense in some of them and by close scores in many of them.

title: Religious Leaders Attack Rules On Housing for New Jersey Poor
description: A group of religious leaders said Monday that New Jersey's proposed new rules for providing more low- and moderate-income housing would further concentrate poverty in the cities, and they called for a show of opposition at public hearings next week.

title: Debating Darwin, and Divinity
description: To the Editor:

title: Wider Split Between U.S. and Europe Over Iran
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 17  The split between Europe and the United States over Iran's nuclear program widened on Monday with the foreign policy chief of the European Union saying that the Iranian government had been honest about its nuclear work and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell saying that such a conclusion went too far.

title: Net Group Tries to Click Democrats to Power
description: When Wes Boyd walked into the New York offices of George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist, in September he was not sure why he had been invited.

title: No. 1 UConn Pushed by Gritty Yale
description: For Connecticut's men's basketball team, a season of boundless promise opened with a pinch of uncertainty Monday night.

title: Day of Mourning
description: Italians observed a national day of mourning for the victims of the attack in Nasiriyah, Iraq, last week.

title: Whole Lotta Lava
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: She May Be His Lucky Star
description: What is it like to trail Madonna professionally? A day in the life of a paparazzo provides a glimpse.

title: Revisiting That Historic Day in Dallas, in Many Specials
description: All the 40th-anniversary specials on John F. Kennedy's assassination include gripping images, some iconically familiar, others, like scenes of a surly Lee Harvey Oswald proclaiming his innocence to reporters after his arrest, more rare. Here are some of the more interesting specials.

title: CALENDAR
description: Cooking for a Cause

title: Adu, 14, Signs An M.L.S. Deal For Six Years
description: Freddy Adu, a 14-year-old soccer phenomenon, was signed to a six-year contract yesterday by Major League Soccer and is set to join the league next spring, when he will begin competing against men who in some cases will be more than twice his age.

title: Wells Is Welcome To Return
description: David Wells wants to pitch one more season in the major leagues, and the Yankees want him to do it with them. Despite Wells's chronic back problems, the team has told his agent that they want him back.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Breakaway Church In Talks
description: The Russian Orthodox Church Outside of Russia, the pro-monarchist migr church based in New York, is holding talks in Russia for the first time on reuniting that faction with the Moscow Patriarchate. The faction was formed after the Russian Revolution and declared that it would have nothing to do with the dominant Russian Orthodox Church until the fall of Communism. The talks were set in motion during President Vladimir V. Putin's visit to New York in September. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Go-Ahead For Kurdish Broadcasts
description: Officials set out guidelines for Kurdish-language radio and television broadcasts, part of Parliament's package of expanded rights for the country's more than 12 million Kurds. Under the rules, all national television channels and radio stations will be able to broadcast in Kurdish for five hours a week. The European Union has pressured Turkey on Kurdish reforms as a requirement for joining the bloc. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: L.S.U. Ignoring Anxiety and Hype
description: The scenarios for the national championship game chase Louisiana State players across the campus, across the sports pages and across the airwaves: a loss by Ohio State, a lackluster victory by Southern California, impressive victories by L.S.U., and it could be L.S.U. vs. Oklahoma.

title: The Life of the Party: Two Centuries of Democrats
description: PARTY OF THE PEOPLE

title: Daniel Boulud Does Pots and Pans
description: The heavy-duty enamel cast-iron pieces from Daniel Boulud Kitchen, a new line of cookware, are perfect for vegetable casseroles or for turkey dressing at Thanksgiving. And in colors like rich burgundy or sleek gray, black or white, they can go from oven to table.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 8 about Franois-Henri Pinault, the head of the retailing empire that includes Gucci, misidentified his family's native region in France, where it owns the soccer team Stade Rennais. It is Brittany, not Normandy.

title: After the Tumult, Boston U. Wonders Where It Goes From Here
description: Nearly three weeks after Boston University's board astonished all of academia by paying Daniel S. Goldin $1.8 million to walk away from the presidency, many questions about the university's future remain unanswered.

title: MCDONALD'S REDUCES FAT IN CHICKEN MCNUGGETS
description: The McDonald's Corporation, which made its popular Chicken McNuggets with a blend of dark and white chicken for 20 years, said yesterday that it was switching to lower-fat white meat. A four-piece serving of the white-meat McNugget contains 170 calories -- 40 fewer than the previous version -- and 10 grams of fat, down from 13, McDonalds said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Doctor Ousted In Dispute
description: The president of the medical staff at Christ Hospital, Dr. George Ciechanowski, has been removed from the prestigious elective position by colleagues who oppose a government plan for malpractice insurance reform, which he favors. Dr. Ciechanowski confirmed yesterday that at a Monday night meeting, colleagues voted to remove him. In June, thousands of doctors staged a demonstration protesting what they regard as ruinously high premiums for needed malpractice insurance. Dr. Ciechanowski, who remains the hospital's chief of pulmonary and critical care, publicly supported the state's plan to subsidize malpractice insurance to reduce premiums. Other doctors favor limiting jury awards in malpractice cases. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Investigation Pins Origin of Blackout on Ohio Utility
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 — While the vast power blackout of Aug. 14 had many causes, it was born in Northern Ohio on an otherwise ordinary afternoon, according to a government investigation made public today.

title: Giants' Rookie Receiver Brightened Dreary Day
description: As a sixth-round pick, it was an accomplishment simply to survive training camp as a member of the Giants this year. David Tyree did that and more, emerging as a valuable contributor to the special teams as the regular season progressed. And then on Sunday, Tyree got the chance he was waiting for.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Way It Was

title: 'I Really Appreciate Your Business,' It Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, SEYMOUR
description: COHN -- Seymour. North Shore Synagogue, Syossetmourns the loss of devoted founding member and lifelong benefactor Seymour Cohn. A man of strength, determination, and vision whose commitment to Judaism prompted his more than half century of loving support to this congregation. We honor him for a life of integrity, charity, and kindness. To Marc and Melanie and Penny and Eric we extend our condolences. May the memory of the rightous always be for a blessing. Dr. Jeffrey Tulman, President Rabbi David Whiman Rabbi Eric Eisenkramer Cantor Renee Coleson Cantor Kathy Barr

title: Scratch an American, Find an Immigrant
description: THANKSGIVING is the quintessential American holiday and deserves to be celebrated, at least occasionally, with the bounty of our fields, our farms, our seas and rivers and, by all means, our vineyards. Hardly anyone is going to argue with that premise. It's when you get down to particulars, especially where the vineyards are concerned, that the trouble starts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EASLEY, HOLMES
description: EASLEY--Holmes. Was born on September 24, 1934 in San Saba, TX. A resident of NYC since 1970 he died October 11, 2003, while visiting in Carmel, CA, following two years of treatment for colon cancer. He obtained his Master of Fine Arts degree in stage, scenic and costume design at the Yale School of Drama. Following six years of teaching stage design at Stanford University and Colgate University, he spent three years with the Asolo Theatre in Sarasota, FL as resident scenic and costume designer. He also designed for the Sacramento Summer Theatre and the Alley Theatre. Returning to the northeast, Easley began a 25 year association with CBS Television Network. He served as set director for Guiding Light and As the World Turns for which he won an Emmy Award in 1991. He designed productions for the Roundabout Theatre in NY, for which he received two Obie Awards for best set design, in 1974 and 1976. He retired from CBS in 1996. Following his retirement from CBS he segued into a second career in interior design and architecture, designing major residential projects in NYC, Summit, NJ and St. Louis, MO. Through his life Easley was interested in education, the theatre arts, and the mentoring of young people. There will be a memorial service for Easley at St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53 St. at Fifth Ave. at 3PM Thursday, November 20. The family asks that any contributions in his memory be made to your local hospice.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Annan Plea For Africa
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, began the organization's yearly fund-raising drive, seeking $3 billion in 2004 to help address 21 of the world's most serious aid crises. Seventeen of the crises are in Africa. The 2003 appeal has received just 66 percent of the needed amount, with several of the African cases disproportionately underfinanced, Mr. Annan said. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Superior School Fails A Crucial Federal Test
description: IN 1998, when Virginia introduced its new education testing and accountability system, the first year was a disaster. Only 2 percent of Virginia schools scored well enough on state tests to get a ''fully accredited'' rating.

title: The Mediterranean Sun Warms Rainy London
description: THE underground kitchen at Passione Restaurant felt like a safe haven from the damp and groggy city above. The kitchen has low ceilings and was dry and warm from the ovens. Gennaro Contaldo, the owner and an old friend of Jamie Oliver, was shuffling around, organizing his work space, occasionally pushing a fig and rosemary focaccia onto guests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIDMAN, RICHARD. F.E.G.S.
description: MAIDMAN--Richard. F.E.G.S. Health and Human Services System mourns the passing of Dr. Richard Maidman, beloved brother of Sandra Cahn, esteemed Member of the F.E.G.S. Board of Directors and a leader of UJA-Federation of New York. Sandra's commitment, compassion, creativity and leadership have been a source of strength for our community. We offer Sandra and her family our heartfelt condolences. Joseph Stein Jr., Pres. & Chair Alfred P. Miller, CEO

title: The Neediest Cases; Friendship Spans Generations For Nursing Home Volunteers
description: At the Schervier Nursing Care Center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, Elizabeth Foster is a volunteer manager of the coffee shop.

title: Keeping Mom's Suitors at Bay With Attitude and Deceit
description: Survival of the fittest begins at home. That is where children fight for their right to love and attention. And when they are competing for just one parent -- a pretty, 36-year-old mother in Joyce Carol Oates's play ''Bad Girls'' -- the struggle gets lethal. The children become a tribe and the mother becomes their territory. All suitors are invaders.

title: 'Mistakes Were Made'
description: What if, by some miracle, everyone 'fessed up to mistakes made about the surprisingly easy overthrow of Saddam and its unexpectedly bloody aftermath, and mistakes now being made in building democracy?

title: INSIDE
description: Few Signs of Iraq Infiltration

title: Confirmed: No 'Bounce' To Broadway This Season
description: The producers of ''Bounce,'' Stephen Sondheim's first new musical in nine years, confirmed yesterday what many Sondheim fans had already suspected: the show, which received lukewarm reviews in two tryout runs, is not coming to Broadway anytime soon.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Shifts In King Family
description: The sons of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said they would leave their leadership posts at two civil rights institutions founded by their parents, and one will replace the other. Martin Luther King III, 46, will step down in January as head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. He will take the place of his brother, Dexter Scott King, 42, as president of the King Center, which their mother, Coretta Scott King, established in 1968 to preserve Dr. King's legacy. Dexter Scott King will pursue film and television opportunities to advance his father's legacy, said Robert Vickers, a spokesman for the center. The leadership conference has not yet selected a new chief, a spokeswoman said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Quietly, North Korea Opens Markets
description: North Korea's tentative turn at opening markets is best captured in snapshots of happy South Koreans touring Pyongyang, a long forbidden city lampooned as ''a Stalinist theme park.''

title: CENDANT EXPECTS INCREASE IN PROFIT FOR 2004
description: The Cendant Corporation, the real estate and travel-services company, says that its net income will rise to as much as $1.62 a share next year on sales growth of at least 5 percent. Profit will range from $1.55 to $1.62 a share in 2004, the company said. Cendant was expected to earn $1.41 a share this year and $1.60 in 2004, according to estimates of Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Cendant's profit has been helped by its real estate business, which franchises brokerage operations including Century 21 and ERA, and provides mortgages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIDWELL, KATHARINE O'NEIL
description: BIDWELL--Katharine O'Neil. The Board of Directors, artists and staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center are deeply saddened by the loss of Katharine O'Neil Bidwell, member of the Board since 1996, founder of our Patrons Program and the moving force behind a commissioning fund for new chamber music. Katharine was a charismatic and tireless champion of the arts. For her, nothing was impossible, and she inspired all of us who worked with her to greater efforts and acommplishments. All of her endeavors were marked by her personal elegance, grace and good humor. We will cherish her memory for her indomitable spirit and passionate commitment to chamber music. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, J. Truman Bidwell, and her family. Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Chairman Peter Frelinghuysen, President David Shifrin, Artistic Director Norma Hurlburt, Executive Director

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SURGES. Crude oil climbed on signs that inventory gains will be limited, which touched off buying by speculators. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose $1.55, or 4.9 percent, to $33.28 a barrel

title: Pilots Blamed for Wellstone Crash
description: A plane carrying Senator Paul Wellstone and seven others crashed last year in Minnesota, killing everyone aboard, because the pilots let the aircraft slow to the point that it could no longer fly, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bush in Britain: Views of the Hosts
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Executive Leaves Goodby, Silverstein
description: A top creative executive is leaving Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco to join a smaller, independent agency as part of a reorganization.

title: Spotlight Is Refocused On Malone and Payton
description: The arguments have always been about whom the team belongs to, the immovable force in the middle or the majestic glider on the wing. A few weeks ago, the debate grew more public and more volatile, threatening to ruin the season.

title: Mixed Outlook as Losses Persist for Phone Giants
description: The Vodafone Group, the world's largest wireless operator, reported a narrowed loss for the first half of its fiscal year and an increase in its dividend on Tuesday, and said that it would repurchase 2.5 billion ($4.2 billion) of its stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEMESHNIK, WILLIAM
description: LEMESHNIK--William. Patriarch, husband, father, grandfather, great - grand father, brother, uncle, friend. Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY 11:30AM, November 20.

title: A Thorny Issue For 2004 Race
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision on gay marriage Tuesday forced President Bush and his Democratic opponents onto difficult political ground, as they struggled to deal with a polarizing issue that is critical to their most fervent supporters but that has confused and divided much of the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLISKIN, SYLVIA
description: PLISKIN--Sylvia. Wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Kurt and Louise Pliskin and Muriel Deutsch; dear grandmother of Jeffrey and Jodi Pliskin, David Pliskin, Richard and Lisa Pliskin, and Bruce Deutsch; great-grandmother of Adam, Stuart, Julie, Emma and Lily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERSOHN, RICHARD
description: BERSOHN--Richard. Died on November 18, 2003. He is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Nehama, his children Malcolm Mark, David, Rina and Leora, his grandchildren Daniel and Rebecca, his daughter-in-law Shelley Shapiro and son-in-law Adam Spiewak, his twin brother Malcolm and his sister Barbara Elkin, his sisters-in-law JoAnn Bersohn, Miriam Rezler and Sara Rezler. Richard was the Higgins Professor of Natural Science at Columbia University. He will be sadly missed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Brooklyn Brewery's sale of its distribution rights to two companies reversed the references to the purchases. Phoenix Beverage bought the rights to the brewery's Brooklyn brands, and Union Beer the rights to its other specialty beers.

title: Unclaimed Holocaust Reparations To Endow Yeshiva U. Study Center
description: The law school at Yeshiva University will use $2.25 million in assets unclaimed by Holocaust victims or their descendants to establish an endowment fund for a center for Holocaust studies and human rights.

title: With Testimony Looming, Bonds Wins Sixth M.V.P.
description: San Francisco's Barry Bonds was named the National League's most valuable player for the third straight time yesterday, making baseball history just two weeks before he will testify before a federal grand jury looking into a company linked to the current furor over steroids.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZURROW, TOBY NATALIE
description: ZURROW--Toby Natalie. Beloved wife of Doctor Milton, devoted mother of Stephen and Robert, dear sister of Dan Wohl, loving grandmother of Gabriella. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEN AMI, EVE
description: BEN AMI--Eve. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our beloved longtime member, Eve Ben Ami, wife of the late Yitzhak Ben Ami. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her son Jeremy, her daughter Deborah, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

title: Case Turns On Whether Usual Politics Is a Felony
description: There is surprisingly little dispute between the prosecution and the defense about most of the facts behind the recent grand larceny charges against the two top Democratic officials in Brooklyn.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: Mine Expansion Delayed
description: De Beers, the diamond mining company, said it had postponed a decision on a 7 billion rand ($1 billion) mine project because of the appreciation of South Africa's currency, the rand, against the dollar. The effort to extend the life of the 100-year-old Cullinan mine is the largest project to be delayed by the rand's 78 percent gain since 2001. De Beers has delayed a decision on whether to deepen the mine until the second half of 2004, rather than this year, a spokesman for the company, Brian Roodt, said.

title: Off Union Square, the Sausage Takes Center Stage
description: I WILL say it straight out: fast food is good. Why should being in a hurry stop anybody from eating well?

title: Spare a Dollar?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BANGS, JEAN GRIDLEY
description: BANGS--Jean Gridley, died on November 18, 2003, eight days before her 77th birthday; on Kiawah Island, SC; after brief illness. Beloved wife for 54 years of Nathaniel Swift Bangs; loving mother of Cally and Betsy Bangs; grandmother of Cally's son Peter; sister of Bill and Harry Gridley. Memorial service next summer on Madeline Island. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Madeline Island Library or the Madeline Island Historical Society, LaPointe, WI 54850

description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Democratic Candidates Attack Medicare Measure
description: Six of the Democratic presidential candidates mounted a heated attack on the new Medicare bill on Tuesday at a forum sponsored by AARP. The contenders denounced the plan to provide drug benefits to the elderly as a Republican-led effort to privatize and undermine the federal insurance program.

title: Palestinian Premier Starts Cease-Fire Bid
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 19  The Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, began his first major initiative since his swearing-in last week, traveling to the Gaza Strip today in a bid to persuade Palestinian factions to halt attacks against Israel.

title: Fritz Kraemer, 95, Tutor to U.S. Generals and Kissinger, Dies
description: Fritz Kraemer, a refugee from Nazi Germany who tutored generations of America's leading generals in historical and geopolitical thinking, died in Washington on Sept. 8. He was 95.

title: Adu Added to U.S. Youth Team Roster
description: Freddy Adu, the 14-year-old striker who signed a six-year contract yesterday with Major League Soccer, was added to the United States' roster for the world youth championships by Coach Thomas Rongen because of an injury to Arturo Alvarez.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: MARRIAGE BY GAYS GAINS BIG VICTORY IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Massachusetts' highest court ruled on Tuesday that gay couples have the right to marry under the state's Constitution, and it gave the state legislature 180 days to make same-sex marriages possible.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the French government's effort to stop anti-Semitic violence referred incorrectly to results of a recent opinion survey sponsored by the European Commission. (The error also appeared on Sunday in an article about European attitudes toward President Bush.) Respondents were asked to identify the countries -- not the leaders -- they perceived as the greatest threats to world peace. A majority perceived Israel (not Prime Minister Ariel Sharon) as the greatest threat; the United States and North Korea (not Mr. Bush and the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il) were ranked No. 2.

title: THEATER: NEW HEAD FOR THE WING
description: Howard Sherman, a veteran of the nonprofit theater world, has been named the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which owns the Tony Awards and produces the Tony Awards show with the League of American Theaters and Producers. Mr. Sherman, who had been interim director for four months, replaces Roy A. Somlyo, who resigned on May 2. In the last decade, Mr. Sherman has been the executive director of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.; the general manager of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn.; the managing director of the Geva Theater Center in Rochester; and the publicity director of the Hartford Stage Company. Mr. Sherman said his background in nonprofit theater would influence his leadership: ''In the past the focus of the wing has been largely tied to Broadway, and now we have an opportunity to reach beyond that.'' He added that he hoped to use television and the Internet to promote theater. One thing that many board members credit Mr. Sherman with already accomplishing is easing the long-held tension between the American Theater Wing and the League of American Theaters and Producers over the direction of the Tony Awards. ''The league's mission has been to sell Broadway as a brand,'' Mr. Sherman said in describing the friction between the organizations. ''Our interest is in celebrating excellence. That is not identical.'' JASON ZINOMAN

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday about lessons from Vietnam for Iraq misspelled the name of the British aristocrat who gave his name to a code of conduct for boxing. He was the marquess of Queensberry, not Queensbury.

title: Our Towns; The Arts, Lost In Yonkers
description: THIS week's award for worst timing has to go to Rita Sabini. She made a three-hour trip by bus and subway from her home in Astoria, Queens, to the headquarters of the Yonkers Public Schools system here, where -- lacking a scheduled appointment but full of vigor -- she had hoped to embark upon a new career as a substitute teacher.

title: A Violinist's Pocketful Of Molto Agitato
description: The stern warning has become standard in almost every performance hall in the city: ''Please turn off all pagers and cellphones before the performance begins.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Friday about the winners of National Humanities Medals omitted part of one winner's name and, because of an editing error, misstated his position. He is Frank M. Snowden Jr., not Frank M. Snowden; he is an emeritus professor of classics at Howard University, not a professor of black history. The report also referred imprecisely to another winner, Midge Decter. She is a former managing editor of Commentary magazine, not former editor.

title: Resurgent Taliban Threatens Afghan Stability, U.S. Says
description: Nearly two years after the Taliban's ouster from Kabul, a resurgence in its activities and cross-border operations have posed a new threat to eastern and southern Afghanistan and a new diplomatic challenge in American dealings with Pakistan, Bush administration officials said this week.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: HOLOCAUST MUSEUM FIRE A fire destroyed a Terre Haute museum dedicated to the Holocaust, and arson is suspected, a museum official said. "Remember Timmy McVeigh" was scrawled on a wall of the Candles museum, which houses artifacts from Auschwitz and documents relating to Dr. Josef Mengele. Mr. McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, was executed at a federal prison outside Terre Haute in 2001.   (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OLNICK, HARVEY
description: OLNICK--Harvey. The Musicians, Trustees, and Staff of The Marlboro Music School and Festival, note with sadness the passing of Harvey Olnick, Administrative Director in 1956 and 1957, and Trustee and Emeritus Trustee for over forty years. His passion for Marlboro and his organizational strengths had enormous impact on the Music School and Festival in its early years, and created an invaluable structure for the Organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KASHDAN, BERNARD
description: KASHDAN--Bernard of Ft. Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Harriet, devoted father of Bennett, and daughter-in-law Susan. Dear brother of Lawrence and George. Loving grandfather of Jason and Rachel. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533

title: The Medicare Choice
description: Despite its shortcomings, the Medicare prescription drug bill heading for a vote in Congress is worthy of passage. Fears that the legislation contains seeds that will ultimately destroy the traditional Medicare program strike us as overblown. Our own chief qualm is that the country, with deficits looming as far as prognosticators can see, cannot afford a program that will cost, at a minimum, $400 billion over 10 years.

title: Gunman Kills Israeli Soldiers At Checkpoint In West Bank
description: A Palestinian gunman pulled an automatic rifle from inside a rolled-up prayer rug as he approached an Israeli military checkpoint just south of Jerusalem and killed two soldiers at dawn on Tuesday. He then escaped.

title: Janus Tightens Trading Policies; Calpers Pulls Out of Putnam
description: Janus Capital, under pressure from regulators and shareholders to account for rapid trading in and out of its funds, said yesterday that it was tightening its policies to limit frequent trading.

title: About New York; The Bull's-Eye Versus The Pork Barrel
description: LIFE in New York has its own math: a series of formulas to help inhabitants make sense of an urban environment that might lead to madness if dwelt upon too long.

title: Messier Hoping He Can Play Outdoors
description: Mark Messier, the Rangers' captain, said Tuesday that he had still not been given permission by Coach Glen Sather to play for a team of former Oilers stars against a team of former Montreal Canadiens in an outdoor game on Saturday at Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton.

title: Test of an Experimental Ebola Vaccine Begins
description: The first test in humans of an experimental vaccine against the deadly Ebola virus began yesterday, government scientists said.

title: 14th-Century Jewish Text Stolen by Nazis Is Returned to Vienna
description: The auction catalog listed an intriguing item for sale, an extremely rare 14th-century manuscript of a central work of Jewish mysticism called the ''Sepher Yetzirah,'' or Book of Formation. And, oh, the catalog noted, it was looted by the Nazis from Vienna's Jewish library.

title: Wal-Mart and Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: PUTIN GAINS President Vladimir V. Putin's popularity rose to 82 percent, from 73 percent just three weeks ago, according to the independent polling organization Vtsiom, indicating approval of the government's arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest tycoon, and the impounding of the assets of his company, Yukos Oil. The poll of 1,600 Russians was carried out Nov. 13 to 16. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Police Face Lawsuits Over Tactics at Big Protests
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union plans to sue the Police Department today in an effort to bar officers from using certain tactics to control large protests.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEDO, NICKOLAS
description: NEDO--Nickolas, 48, Tarrytown, NY, died November 17 after a lengthy illness. He is survived by his parents, Otto and Karin V. Nedo of Douglaston, NY; his wife, Roula Theofanis Nedo and his son Alexander. Visitation Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY Thursday 2-4 & 6-8 P.M. Funeral Service Friday 1:00 P.M., St. Vladimir Seminary, 575 Scarsdale Rd., Crestwood, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Russian Gift of Life, PO Box 403, Seacliff, NY 11579

title: How the Death Of a President Led to the Birth Of a Medium
description: The swirl of interviews, documentaries and specials building up to Nov. 22 are not really about the 40th anniversary of the Kennedy assassination. They commemorate the 40th anniversary of television: the day a young, vigorous medium was swept into power and forever changed American culture and politics.

title: Van Horn Hobbling; McDyess Practicing
description: As Antonio McDyess made a rusty return to the court for his first full scrimmage in more than a year, Keith Van Horn hopped off on a sprained right ankle. Allan Houston sat out because his back is sore from carrying the team.

title: Bush in Britain: Views of the Hosts
description: To the Editor:

title: Friendliness With a Splash of Seawater
description: THERE are two reasons Italian restaurants will always be popular. First, the cuisine. Italian cooking is simple, satisfying and not terribly expensive. But the real secret behind the staying power of Italian restaurants is that Italians run them. As long ago as 1879, a guidebook to New York noted the prevalence of Italians in the restaurant trade, ''a business for which their natural politeness renders them peculiarly fit.''

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Departing College President
description: John M. McCardell Jr., the president of Middlebury College for 12 years, said he would step down in June. ''He feels it's time to move on and do something else,'' said Phil Benoit, the college's director of public affairs. Dr. McCardell joined the faculty at Middlebury in 1976 and plans to return to the college as a history professor in July 2005 after a year's leave of absence. Kimetris N. Baltrip (NYT)

title: Get a Grip on Your Turkey
description: Orka's sturdy silicone oven mitts may not be the prettiest new item in your kitchen, but they could be the best tools for lifting an 18-pound turkey out of its roasting pan without damaging its skin or piercing the flesh. Sure they're bulky, but the palms have nonskid treads, the mitts are highly heat resistant and can go into the dishwasher. The mitts are $21 each at the Art of Cooking in Greenwich Village and $16.95 at Broadway Panhandler in SoHo, and $20 at Viking Culinary Arts Center in Garden City, N.Y., and elsewhere.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Prime Minister Clears Way For Successor
description: Prime Minister Jean Chrtien announced that he would retire on Dec. 12 after a decade in the post, transferring power to Paul Martin, left, his longtime rival and the new leader of the governing Liberal Party. Mr. Chrtien, 69, had said he would leave office by February but had been reluctant to set a date. Mr. Martin, 65, won the leadership of the party last week. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Friday incorrectly stated that 88 percent of the public lands in the Rocky Mountains are open for oil and gas drilling. The figure, 88 percent, refers only to natural gas reserves open for drilling.

title: Judge Declines to Dismiss 2 Charges in Stewart Case
description: In a setback for Martha Stewart, a federal judge yesterday denied her lawyers' efforts to have two of the five criminal charges against her dismissed.

title: G.E., Seeking to Spur Growth, Will Sell Many Insurance Assets
description: General Electric, struggling to climb back to double-digit earnings growth, announced a plan yesterday to spin off most of its life insurance and mortgage insurance business next year.

title: Thanksgiving Dinner, With 12 Chefs On the Side
description: ALMOST everybody has a story about the year the family rebel tried to overthrow the tradition of turkey on Thanksgiving. The story never ends well for the transgressor. His revolt is crushed, he is mocked and now he spends most of the holiday muttering to himself.

title: HOME DEPOT SHOWS GAIN IN QUARTERLY EARNINGS
description: Home Depot Inc., the home-improvement chain, said third-quarter earnings climbed 22 percent as demand for John Deere lawn tractors, Behr paint and lumber helped sales at older stores increase at the fastest pace in four years. Net income rose to $1.15 billion, or 50 cents a share, as sales in the quarter ended Nov. 2 rose 15 percent, to $16.6 billion, the company said. Profit was 4 cents more than analysts expected. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 7.8 percent, a second straight gain. The average sales ticket rose to a record $52.10 as income tax rebates and a rebounding economy prompted customers to spend more to fix up their homes. Net income a year earlier was $940 million, or 40 cents a share.

title: Step No. 1: Don't Drop The Baster
description: This new flat-top bulb baster designed by Lucas Bignon does a headstand so that it will not drip on the counter or roll off onto the floor.

title: For Baking, For Mashing, Forever
description: WISCONSIN means cheese, Florida means oranges, Texas means beef, Maine means lobsters -- and Idaho means potatoes.

title: European Commission Presses Germany to Curb Deficit
description: The European Commission on Tuesday urged Germany to make deeper budget cuts next year to curb its deficit, stoking a dispute between Brussels and Berlin over Germany's red-ink-stained finances.

title: George Plimpton Recalled as Writer, Editor and Man of Charm
description: The fraternity of writers in which George Plimpton held a lifelong membership remembered him yesterday at a gathering in Manhattan not as just as the writer, editor and skilled raconteur that he was but also as the life of the party.

title: Shares Fall as Dollar Weakens; Foreign Investment Is Off
description: Stocks fell for a fourth trading day yesterday as the dollar sank to a record low against the euro, raising concern that foreign investors will shun United States assets. Concerns about a surge in oil prices also weighed on shares.

title: 'Widow' Closes After One Night
description: ''Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All,'' which opened to a barrage of mostly bad reviews on Monday, closed yesterday after just one regular performance, one of the shortest Broadway runs in recent history.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prison Guard Accused
description: A city correction officer was charged yesterday with plotting to steal $25,000 offered by an inmate at Rikers Island in exchange for helping the inmate escape, city officials said. The officer, Heriberto Vasquez, 35, of Brooklyn, told investigators that he considered the $25,000 a loan he did not plan to repay. He was charged with attempted grand larceny, a felony, and faces up to four years in prison if convicted, said Rose Gill Hearn, commissioner of the city Department of Investigation, the agency that uncovered the scheme. Officer Vasquez said he had never intended to help the inmate escape, and Commissioner Hearn noted that no escape plan was discovered. Officer Vasquez, who joined the Department of Correction in 1996, has been suspended without pay. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: To Many Britons, Cost of U.S. Ties Have Become Too High
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  When President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill forged their strong alliance during World War II, the phrase "special relationship" was coined to describe the ties between Britain and the United States.

title: The Desire to Change
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Pro-President Rally
description: Supporters of President Eduard A. Shevardnadze, bused in by a regional chief who backs him, staged a tit-for-tat mass rally in the capital, Tbilisi, after a huge demonstration on Friday demanding the president's resignation. The opposition has called for a nationwide strike to protest the results of a parliamentary election on Nov. 2 that international observers said was manipulated to produce a victory for the president's supporters. Mr. Shevardnadze, above, has said he will call on the new Parliament to convene immediately after the completed vote count is officially announced Friday. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Study Pinpoints Campaign Fund Sources
description: An independent study of state campaign contributions has found that nearly half of the money came from a small group of ZIP codes and a quarter of it from only 10 ZIP codes in Manhattan and Albany. The New York Public Interest Research Group, which led the study, said that over a recent 18-month period, nearly 46 percent of the $55.3 million in campaign contributions to statewide legislative races in New York came from within 50 of the state's 1,599 ZIP codes. The study also found that between Jan. 15, 2002, and July 15 of this year, more than $15 million was sent from 10 ZIP codes, in Manhattan and Albany, where political action committees, the wealthy and corporate headquarters are concentrated. Put another way, Manhattan alone contributed a quarter of all money in the study. Blair Horner, of the research group, said that ''a tiny elite'' gives most of the campaign money and has ''a disproportionate impact on state policy making.'' Al Baker (NYT)

title: China Regrets Decision by U.S. to Limit Imports
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 19  The Chinese government gave a temperate response today to the Bush administration's decision to limit the growth of imports of certain Chinese fabrics and garments, contending that the move violated free trade principles.

title: Executive-Elect Vows to Cut Suffolk's Expenses
description: Suffolk County faces a potential $200 million deficit in 2005, the incoming county executive warned on Tuesday, adding that he will ''hit the ground running'' to prevent a shortfall.

title: Devil Goes a Long Way With a Longer Name
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 18  Replicas of Jamie Langenbrunner's Devils sweater, his 13-letter surname sweeping from left shoulder to right, have become more commonplace among fans in the corridors of Continental Arena.

title: Canada Rebuffs U.S. on Prescription Drugs
description: Spurning a request by the Food and Drug Administration to clamp down on exports of cheap drugs to the United States, the Canadian government said Tuesday that there was no evidence that these exports had violated Canadian laws or jeopardized the health of Americans.

title: Medicare Bill Supporters Confident of Passage
description: With senators and representatives back in the Capitol for the first time since negotiators agreed on legislation to overhaul Medicare last weekend, supporters of the measure expressed confidence on Tuesday that it would be passed within a week. At the same time, some opponents raised doubts about whether they had enough votes to block the bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BYRNE, CHARLES E.
description: BYRNE--Charles E. Of Milford, Pa. Died November 15. Founder of Logos Corporation and pioneer in the field of machine translation, Charles was a decorated veteran of World War II. He and his wife, Patricia, were parents of eleven children and grandparents of 21. Burial at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: S.E.C. Outlines Plan for Tighter Control of Mutual Funds
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress on Tuesday that he supported a plan for an overhaul of the way mutual funds govern themselves, forcing their chairmen and three-quarters of their directors to be independent.

title: Excerpts From the Massachusetts Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from the majority opinion by Chief Justice Margaret H. Marshall yesterday in the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruling that the prohibition against civil marriages for same-sex couples violates the Massachusetts Constitution. The text of the decision in the case, Goodridge & Others v. Department of Public Health and Another, is online through www.nytimes.com/national.

title: Bush in London With a Message for Critics
description: Starting a trip that will combine high ceremony at Buckingham Palace with the likelihood of raucous antiwar demonstrations in the streets, President Bush arrived here on Tuesday night for a state visit to Britain, a nation deeply split by its decision to stand by the United States in confronting Iraq.

title: At a Harvard Cafe, Health for Lunch
description: IF you make healthful food look good and taste good, can you get people to eat more of it? At Sebastian's Cafe at the Harvard School of Public Health in Boston, the answer is a resounding yes.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Chinadotcom Offers To Buy Pivotal
description: The Chinadotcom Corporation, a Hong Kong-based software vendor, offered yesterday to buy the Pivotal Corporation for as much as $56.2 million in stock and cash, the third bid for the company in six weeks, to expand its line of customer-service software. Chinadotcom's offer allows Pivotal shareholders to choose a payment of $2 cash, or $2.14 in cash and Chinadotcom shares, for each Pivotal share, it said in a statement. Pivotal has not said whether it would accept the offer, which is at least 8.1 percent higher than Monday's closing share price of $1.85. The bid follows the Pivotal board's rejection last week of an offer by the Onyx Software Corporation, valued at about $2 a share in Onyx stock. Pivotal, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, agreed last month to be acquired by the closely held Oak Investment Partners for $1.78 a share. Acquiring Pivotal would increase Chinadotcom's 2004 revenue about 30 percent to $240 million, the company said. Chinadotcom also offered Pivotal $20 million in financing to ensure that the company, which has not reported a quarterly profit in more than three years, can continue to operate. It would become part of Chinadotcom's CDC Software unit. A Pivotal spokeswoman, Leslie Castellani, declined to comment on the offer. The board will meet on Friday to discuss the acquisition proposals, she said. Shares of Chinadotcom rose 4 cents, to $8.40. Pivotal shares rose 21 cents, to $2.06.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOVE, GRANT ALONZA
description: DOVE--Grant Alonza. Born May 30, 1928 in Sycamore, VA, passed away November 17, 2003 in Dallas, TX at the age of 75. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather, a true Southern gentleman. From very humble beginnings, he became a leader in computer technology and research and was a respected business leader and board member for more than 20 companies. He grew up on a small tobacco farm in Gretna, VA, where he graduated from high school. With the small amount of money he saved from his own crops, he entered Virginia Polytechnical Institute, where he studied for one year before joining the U.S. Navy, where he served on a submarine rescue ship. He returned to Virginia Tech and graduated in 1951 with a degree in electrical engineering. After graduation, he took a job as a design engineer with Sperry Gyroscope Co. After about two years there, he discovered his preference for the customer and marketing side of the business and moved to a new position at W.L. Maxson Corp., a NY defense electronics contractor, in field engineering and equipment testing. He was sent to Texas by Maxson to work with Texas Instruments (TI) on a major missile program contract. Subsequently, in 1959, he began what would be a long and fruitful career at TI, culminating in his retirement 28 years later as an Executive Vice President. During his tenure at TI, his duties included overseeing several divisions, including the company's hi-tech research development department. He played a key role in landing TI's first anti-radar contracts for the Shrike missile and directed the development of its successor, the HARM missile, and its tactical radar systems. These anti-radar missile systems continued to play an important role in the Persian Gulf war and the Iraqi conflict. He subsequently held various positions running TI's radar unit and research labs, vice president of corporate and long range planning, overseeing various functions such as Corporate Development, the Defense Systems and Electronics Groups, the Materials and Controls Groups, the Latin American Division, Marketing and Consumer Products and TI's geophysical services unit, GSI. After retiring from TI in 1987, he became chairman and chief executive officer of Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corp., or MCC, an Austin-based private research cooperative launched in 1983 to help the U.S. regain its high-tech competitiveness against other international countries. In 1992, he joined Technology Strategies and Alliances, a venture capital company focused on investments in high-tech start-up companies, as a Managing Partner. In that capacity, he was active in assisting both large and small companies in growth and diversification strategies, through alliances as well as merger and acquisition activity. He was involved as a founder, investor and served as a director on many boards in the technology sector during this period. He was a director of several companies that were sold or acquired including Western Company of North America, Control Data Corporation, Net Worth, Net Speed, and Forefront Group. After serving on the U.S. West board of directors for 10 years, he joined the board of Media One Group, a spinout. He was the chairman and lead director for Optek Technology. He also served on the boards of InterVoice-Brite Inc., Cooper Cameron, Vocal Data, Object Space, Inet Technologies Inc., Intrusion Inc. and Control Systems International. He was also the former Chairman of the National Security Industrial Association. He received the Distinguished Alumnus Award for 1995 from the Virginia Tech College of Engineering, where he also served on the Committee of 100, as a member of the College's Advisory Board and Bradley Department of Electrical Engineering Advisory Board. He was an avid sportsman and an excellent athlete. He enjoyed golf, having been a member at Preston Trail Golf Club in Dallas for over thirty years, fishing, especially flyfishing for Atlantic Salmon in Labrador, skiing, especially in Taos, NM, flying his own aircraft, and boating, especially the ''September Song'' and ''Liberty'' in Maine. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Peg Brady Dove, sons and daughters-in-law Gene and Carmen Dove of Daly City, CA, Tim and Jenny Dove of Frisco, TX, Brian and Cindy Dove of Missouri City, TX and Terry Dove of New York, NY, and six grandchildren, Brendan, Brittany, Lindsay and Lana Dove of Frisco, Texas and Jessica and Brady Dove of Missouri City, TX, all of whom knew him as ''Poppy''; he was preceded in death by his daughter, Maura Dove. He is also survived by his sisters, Ajean McKinsey of Rockville, MD and Ann Marie Shelton of Gretna, VA. A funeral mass will be held at 10:30 a.m. on Thursday November 20 at All Saints Catholic Church, 5231 Meadowcreek Drive, Richardson, TX 75248. In lieu of flowers please make donations to UT Southwestern/Bone Marrow Transplant Unit for the continuing research of Drs. Robert Collins and Robert Ilaria, P.O. Box 910888, Dallas, TX 75391-0888. For further information, contact Restland: 972 - 238 - 7111, www.restland funeralhome.com.

title: 'Ticket to Jerusalem'
description: ''Ticket to Jerusalem,'' a film by Rashid Masharawi about a Palestinian man who makes a living by showing movies to children in the West Bank, opens today at the MoMA Gramercy Theater, 127 East 23rd Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues. The movie (in Arabic, with English subtitles) was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films Series, and a review by A. O. Scott appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The review is available online at nytimes.com/movies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARBINE, RAYMOND E.
description: CARBINE--Raymond E. Of Charlottesville, Va. Died on November 17. Beloved husband of Adele. Cherished father of Joyce and Mark. Devoted brother of Dennis. Extraordinary artist. His talent will truly be missed.

title: 4 Bids for Nets to Be Reviewed
description: The YankeeNets board is expected to meet this afternoon in Manhattan to begin considering the four bids to acquire the Nets.

title: Bit by Bit, Government Eases Its Grip on Rents in New York
description: In New York City, where for generations government has played a uniquely ambitious role in helping people pay their rents, a fundamental shift is taking hold -- apartment by apartment, building by building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HURST, RUTH GRUBER
description: HURST--Ruth Gruber. Died peacefully November 16, 2003. Born in Queens April 15, 1923 to Max Mechel Gruber & Molly Masha Lustig Gruber. Beloved wife of the late Milton, cherished sister of the late Leo, Sam & Marty Gruber. Survived by her devoted son, Marc & daughter-in-law Molly Karp, her loving grandsons, Adam & Jonah, and her devoted son, Mitchell. Her children, grandchildren, nieces and nephews will miss her indomitable spirit and unique character as the family matriarch. Her firm guidance in the ways of the world is a joyful memory to those who knew and loved her; it will be missed. Donations may be made to the AHRC, 189 Wheatley Rd, Brookville, N.Y. 11545-2699 & Magen David Adom USA, 8930 Gross Point Rd, Suite 800, Skokie, Il. 60077-1864. Shiva until Friday at the Karp-Hurst home. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Veil Lifts on Finalists for 9/11 Memorial Design
description: It would be a luminous place, a verdant place.

title: Bushs Speech in London on Iraq and Mideast
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference in London on Wednesday, as recorded by e-Media.

title: JAZZ MASTERS NAMED
description: The guitarist Jim Hall, the drummer Chico Hamilton, the pianist Herbie Hancock, the vocalist Nancy Wilson and the writer Nat Hentoff are to receive the National Endowment for the Arts' annual Jazz Masters awards for life achievement in ceremonies today at the La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts in Manhattan. The late arranger and composer Luther Henderson is also being honored with the award. In conjunction with this year's awards, the endowment is expanding this program of $25,000 fellowships, established in 1982, to six from three. In addition, it will begin to finance nonprofit concert presenters who will set up 50-state tours for some of the past and present winners, beginning next spring; Verve records will release their best music on CD's; and the endowment will produce public radio segments on the winners' careers. In announcing the awards, Dana Gioia, chairman of the endowment, said: ''I'm concerned, as a lover of jazz, that there's a whole generation of Americans who know nothing about jazz. And I'm especially concerned that there's a young generation of African-Americans who have lost touch with one of the greatest contributions of black culture. So we intend to support this expanded Jazz Masters program every year from here on, and to make it one of the fixtures of American cultural life.'' BEN RATLIFF

title: Shootings Stir Fears of a Backslide in East New York
description: The balloons were an unusual touch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, TOBA
description: ADLER--Toba. Died unexpectedly on November 13. Loving mother of Andrew and Suzy, grandmother of Jack, Lily and Naomi and a great friend to many. Private gathering at her home. Donations may be made to Gay Men's Health Crisis or The Central Park Conservancy. New York will not be the same without her.

title: Islanders Recall Timander
description: The Islanders recalled defenseman Mattias Timander from their Bridgeport, Conn., affiliate yesterday while Radek Martinek recovers from a concussion he sustained when hit by the Nashville Predators' Jordin Tootoo in a game on Saturday. Timander, who played in 80 games for the Islanders last season but just one in the playoffs, will be in uniform for the Islanders' road game against the Florida Panthers tonight. Ron Dicker

title: WINE CALENDAR
description: Unveiling the New Beaujolais

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Jail Possible For Chatty Drivers
description: The transportation minister proposed that talking on cellphones while driving be banned, with penalties for repeat violators rising to $500 fines, permanent loss of driving licenses and three-month jail sentences. The proposal is expected to pass through Parliament without objections. It would replace an earlier plan that was abandoned because it did not sufficiently distinguish between cellphones and the two-way radios used by emergency services. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Size of Proposed Tax Breaks in Energy Bill Startles Experts
description: Policy analysts across the political spectrum yesterday denounced the energy bill that Republicans in Congress hope to push to approval this week, saying it represented micromanagement of the economy and would open vast new opportunities for tax cheating.

title: Big Board Members Approve New Structure
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its members voted to approve John S. Reed's plan to hand management of the exchange to an eight-member board, in the biggest policy shift in three decades.

title: Capping the Cost of Atrocity; Survivor of Nazi Experiments Says $8,000 Isn't Enough
description: The medical experiments that Simon Rozenkier says he saw and experienced in Nazi concentration camps strain the imagination.

title: Mexico Dismisses Its U.N. Envoy For Critical Remark About U.S.
description: Mexico's ambassador to the United Nations has been dismissed after saying the United States regards Mexico as a second-class country, government officials said Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Concerns Over Combat Readiness
description: The Russian armed forces are so poorly equipped that they could not wage an offensive war, Defense Minister Sergei Ivanov said, according to the Interfax news agency. ''Conditions are on an acceptable level only for the fulfillment of nuclear deterrent, counterterrorist and peacekeeping activities,'' the minister said. ''As a whole, the armed forces are only 75 to 80 percent equipped with fully functioning ammunition and technology, and of this, modern weapons make up less than 20 percent.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REARDON, ELEANOR D. (NEE DOLAN)
description: REARDON--Eleanor D. (nee Dolan). At age 99, on November 17, 2003. Beloved mother of Joan Dillon and loving grandmother of Lori Dillon Sedia and Paul. Funeral Friday, 9AM at the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Bklyn where visiting will be held Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10AM at Saint Edmunds R.C. Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, ELLIOT H.
description: GREENE--Elliot H. of West Orange, N.J. on November 17, 2003. Born in Manhattan on March 17, 1909, son of Max and Lyn Greene, he was a 46 year resident of South Orange. He was a source of wisdom, strength; and deep pride to his family, who lovingly called him Popu. An engineering graduate of Rutgers and Harvard, he was president of R and A Co. in Bloomfield for many years. He is survived by Jean L. Greene, his beloved wife of 66 years, son Andrew, daughter Ellen, son-in-law Philip Drill, brother Leonard, grandchildren Douglas and Lori, Kenneth, Kristina and Markus, and William, great-granddaughter Jessica. Services will be private. Should friends wish, contributions may be made to Saint Barnabas Hospice and Palliative Care Center, 187 Millburn Avenue, Millburn, N.J. 07041

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, ALLEN
description: WEISS--Allen. Beloved brother and son. Loving husband and devoted father, died on Monday, November 17, 2003. His award-winning photography and artistic accomplishments will be remembered and cherished by all who knew him. Marsha and Neil Remland

title: A Solo for Drumsticks
description: THOSE who believe the best part of the Thanksgiving turkey is the day-after sandwiches with leftover cranberry sauce will welcome this recipe. It teams the relatively unappreciated drumsticks with the rarely used fresh cranberries to produce a dish of uncommon complexity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE A.
description: TISCH--Laurence A. Bob, Joan, Steve, Jamie, Laurie and Jonathan and their children feel blessed to have spent so many wonderful years with Bob's brother and our dear ''Uncle Larry.'' We learned wisdom, passion, integrity, and ''tikkun olam'' by following his example. His remarkable legacy will remain with us forever. The Preston Robert Tisch Family

title: Chef Arrested On Drug Charges
description: Alex Garcia, a chef who helped popularize Nuevo Latino food at several New York City restaurants and on television, has been charged with conspiracy and money laundering in connection with a drug ring that is said to have imported thousands of pounds of cocaine.

title: California Lottery Drops Indemnity Clause
description: The California Lottery Commission has eliminated indemnification language that concerned some agencies from materials for the most recent review for its account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILLMAN, WILLIAM G.
description: GILLMAN--William G., 88 of Eastchester, died November 18, 2003. Survived by his wife Marcelle; two daughters Alecia Gillman and Eileen Choron; son-in-law Greg Choron; grandchildren Rachel, Deborah and Rebecca Choron. Retired executive of Faber, Coe & Gregg, and AnCorp National Services. Graduate of Fordham University and Xavier High School, he proudly served in WWII as Lt. Colonel. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, November 20 at 10:30AM, Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALMONOWITZ, IDA
description: SALMONOWITZ--Ida. Age 96. Passed away peacefully at her home in Florida, November 14, 2003. Mother of Irwin and Barry. Margulis. Motherin-law to Sharon and Sheila. Grandmother of five. Great grandmother of eleven. Loved by all. Rest in peace.

title: Europe to Oppose U.S. Effort To Air Iran Arms Issue in U.N.
description: Europe will resist an American effort to bring the suspected Iranian development of nuclear weapons before the United Nations Security Council, hoping to lure Iran into compliance with negotiations and incentives, European officials said Tuesday.

title: Editors' Note
description: An obituary last Wednesday about Marvin Smith, a leading photographer of Harlem who worked with his identical twin, Morgan, described the closeness of the two men -- it was said that they never used the pronoun ''I'' -- and recounted an anecdote about Marvin Smith's response to the illness that caused his brother's death, in 1993.

title: 'Enemy Combatant' Sham
description: The Bush administration insists that it can hold American citizens in secret as long as it wants, without access to lawyers, simply by calling them ''enemy combatants.'' A New York federal appeals court heard a challenge to that policy this week by the so-called dirty bomber, Jose Padilla. The administration's position makes a mockery of the Constitution and puts every American's liberty at risk. It is important that the court strike it down, and give Mr. Padilla the rights he has been denied.

title: 3 Held in Slayings at New Jersey Mall
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 18  A 26-year-old truck driver and two Newark residents were arrested Tuesday on charges of murdering two employees of a video game store in a mall near here on Dec. 1 and stealing about $10,000 worth of merchandise, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'HARA, VINCENT F.
description: O'HARA--Vincent F. on November 15, 2003, in Wilton, CT. He was a highly respected colleague from 1957 to his retirement in 1983 and then as a consultant to our company. Vincent specialized in the development and operation of employee benefit plans. He served as an officer of the firm, retiring as our Vice Chair and general counsel. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Martin E. Segal, Founder and Chairman Emeritus Robert D. Krinsky, Chairman Howard Fluhr, President & CEO The Segal Company

title: Another Ranger Reminder That No Lead Is Safe
description: If the Rangers proved anything Tuesday night, it is that they can be equally inept on the road when leading after two periods as they are at home.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Egi Maccioni; Behind The Family, Molto Mama
description: IT may look like an apartment in a Midtown high-rise, but in the kitchen, where Egi Maccioni cuts butter by the slab and measures salt in the palm of her hand, it feels like a Tuscan farmhouse. It sounds like one, too, as Mrs. Maccioni, married almost 40 years, beats her steady path from sink to stove to table, all the while telling the stories her family knows by heart. The fact that the daddy in this household is Sirio Maccioni, the debonair owner of Le Cirque 2000, just makes them more fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOUDON, DOROTHY
description: LOUDON -- Dorothy. On November 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Norman Paris. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Wednesday, November 19th, 6-8 PM, with services, Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Actor's Fund of America or Broadway Cares Equity Fights AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSHENBAUM, MORRIS BEHR
description: KIRSHENBAUM -- Morris Behr. Died on November 17 in Pittsburgh at the age of 85. A funeral service will be held for him on Wednesday, November 19 at the Ralph Schugar Funeral Home, 5509 Centre Avenue, Pittsburgh at 11AM, followed by burial at Shaare Torah Cemetery. An artist and advertising executive, Mr. Kirshenbaum was the founder and President of the Ivy School of Professional Art in Pittsburgh. He is survived by Joy Fox Kirshenbaum, his wife of 54 years, his brother, Bernard Kirshenbaum, his children Adam, Lyn and Susan Kirshenbaum, Ava Kirshenbaum Doppelt and his sons-in law Jack Ostrofsky and Arthur Doppelt.

title: Supreme Court Paved Way for Marriage Ruling With Sodomy Law Decision
description: In its gay rights decision five months ago striking down a Texas criminal sodomy law, the Supreme Court said gay people were entitled to freedom, dignity and ''respect for their private lives.'' It pointedly did not say they were entitled to marry.

title: Katharine Bidwell, 66; Led the Met Opera Guild
description: Katharine Thomas O'Neil Bidwell, a patron of music and education who headed the Metropolitan Opera Guild in the 1980's, died last Thursday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 66 and also had a home on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY: DOCTOR OUSTED IN DISPUTE The president of the medical staff at Christ Hospital, Dr. George Ciechanowski, has been removed from the prestigious elective position by colleagues who oppose a government plan for malpractice insurance reform, which he favors. Dr. Ciechanowski confirmed yesterday that at a Monday night meeting, colleagues voted to remove him. In June, thousands of doctors staged a demonstration protesting what they regard as ruinously high premiums for needed malpractice insurance. Dr. Ciechanowski, who remains the hospital's chief of pulmonary and critical care, publicly supported the state's plan to subsidize malpractice insurance to reduce premiums. Other doctors favor limiting jury awards in malpractice cases.

title: MBNA Claims Pieces of Wilmington's Elegant Past
description: Not since the 1980's, when Hercules Inc., a specialty chemical company, built an architectural showpiece to bring itself out of the shadow of DuPont, has a real estate project carried so much symbolic freight here.

title: Such Good Friends! (However Unlikely)
description: When Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, decided to travel here this week, it was no surprise. Italy holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, and Israeli officials are as concerned as ever about currents of anti-Semitism among some Europeans and opposition to Israeli policies among a great many.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Police Ruse Is Upheld
description: Judge Sharon Armstrong of King County Superior Court ruled that a police ruse used to trick a murder suspect into mailing a sample of his DNA did not violate the state's Constitution. Last year, the Seattle police posing as a law firm sent a letter to John N. Athan of Palisades Park, N.J., a suspect in a 1982 murder of a 13-year-old Seattle girl, asking him to join in a nonexistent class-action suit. The police used saliva from the reply envelope to link Mr. Athan to the killing. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Astros Making A Big Pitch For Pettitte
description: George Steinbrenner has essentially vowed to spend whatever he can to rebuild the Yankees into a championship team. But if the Yankees' most reliable starting pitcher wants to work in his hometown next season, there is nothing Steinbrenner can do to stop him.

title: Letter From Asia; Japan Heads to Iraq, Haunted By Taboo Bred in Another War
description: Not one Japanese soldier has been killed, or has killed, in combat since the end of World War II.

title: Frustrated, U.S. Will Seek Bilateral Trade Pacts
description: United States officials, frustrated with the prospect of a watered-down hemispheric trade agreement, said Tuesday they would focus on bilateral agreements with several compliant nations in the Andes, Central America and the Caribbean as a way to get past differences with South America's largest economy, Brazil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINSON, HELEN NEE GEHER
description: ROBINSON--Helen nee Geher. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Loving mother of Marilyn and Mike Oshinsky. Cherished grandmother of Jim Oshinsky and Wendy Coren and great grandmother of Joshua, Dustin, Casey, Breanna, and Kira. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI 9:30am Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, WILLIAM T.
description: SMITH--William T. Of Albany, New York, a Yonkers native and former director of the state's Division of Probation, of an apparent heart attack November 13 at his vacation home in Southbury, CT. Predeceased by his wife Lucille (Walsh) Smith, of Albany, and his sister Helen Sheehan of the Bronx. Survived by his nephews the Rev. James C. Sheehan of New York and Thomas Sheehan of Boston. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM, November 21, at Tebbutt & Frederick Memorial Home, Albany; a memorial Mass 11 AM, November 22 at Our Lady of Angels Church, Albany. Interment 2 PM, November 24 at St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx. For information call 518-489-4454.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 416 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry's Profit Rises
description: The Burberry Group, the 150-year-old British fashion house, said that first-half profit rose 162 percent, to 41.9 million ($70.9 million). Last year's results include fees the company incurred to go public. Total sales increased 17 percent, to 321 million, and the company opened three new stores. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Laurence A. Tisch, the self-made New York billionaire who helped run the Loews conglomerate, misstated the name of a company controlled by Loews. It is CNA Financial, not CAN Financial.

title: Making Gap Between Jazz And Classical Disappear
description: The music notation probably looks similar for compositions by the pianists Sylvie Courvoisier, a classical composer who also improvises, and Matthew Shipp, whose background is in modern jazz. Both are fond of dissonant chords and clusters that make way for skittering commotion; both use terse melodic motifs, often exploring a single interval, and both come up with complex ostinatos.

title: Remains Thought to Be Dean's Missing Brother
description: Every day on the campaign trail, Howard Dean wears an unfashionable black belt that belonged to his younger brother Charlie, a silent memorial to the man who vanished while traveling the Mekong River 29 years ago.

title: 47 Currency Traders Are Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: Forty-seven currency traders were indicted today on charges of conspiracy, wire fraud, money laundering and securities fraud for what prosecutors said were wide-ranging crimes involving nearly every level of foreign-exchange trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUSNER, STANLEY
description: HAUSNER--Stanley. Service Guild of Long Island Jewish Medical Center mourns the passing of our invaluable Life Member and husband of past Guild President, Florence Hausner. We extend our deepest condolences to Florance and her family. Isabel R. Albom, President

title: Only the Party Is Minor, Not Its Councilwoman
description: LETITIA JAMES, who captured a New York City Council seat on the Working Families Party line, is recalling a political opponent's remark just two weeks ago. ''He said, 'Why don't you start a family? Why don't you find a man?'' says Ms. James, a lawyer who is 44, single and not the sort to be baited.

title: Skeptical Hearing for Audit Firm
description: Senior partners of the KPMG accounting firm told a Senate panel on Tuesday that the firm no longer sells aggressive tax shelters, but their answers to questions failed to persuade Senator Carl Levin, who during three hours of questioning wondered aloud whether he would ''ever get an honest answer'' from the firm.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Who Needs 12th Grade?
