description: Some lawmakers have asked State Department of Education officials to study the possibility of eliminating the 12th grade in favor of a year of preschool. The idea arose at a joint budget committee meeting, although it is not clear how much such a change would save. State Senator Ronald J. Teck, a Republican, said the concept might generate ''more bang for the buck'' and help seniors who do not seem ''engaged'' after their educational requirements are fulfilled before graduation. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: 'I Really Appreciate Your Business,' It Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Earl Battey, 68, Four-Time All-Star Catcher for Minnesota Twins
description: Earl Battey, a four-time All-Star catcher for the Minnesota Twins in the 1960's, died last Saturday at a hospital in Gainesville, Fla. Battey, who lived in Ocala, Fla., was 68.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, HORTENSE
description: KLEIN--Hortense. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Hortense Klein, beloved mother of Robert Klein, a dear friend and dedicated supporter of UJA-Federation. We extend our sincerest sympathies to Robert and to the entire Klein family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: In Recount, Madden Defeats Geist in Senate Race
description: The State Senate race that shattered spending records in New Jersey was resolved on Tuesday night when a recount gave Fred Madden, a political newcomer, a 63-vote victory over the Republican incumbent, George F. Geist.

title: Safety First
description: It's easy to criticize the Bush administration for its foolishness in invading Iraq, at a cost so far of 400 American lives and (one study suggests) at least 11,000 Iraqi lives. But it's much harder to figure out what to do next.

title: Gene Anthony Ray, 41, a Dancer in 'Fame'
description: Gene Anthony Ray, who starred as Leroy, a street-smart urban teenager, in the 1980 movie ''Fame'' and the later television series, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 41.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, EDYTHE
description: ROSS--Edythe. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jerome H. Ross. Cherished mother of Lorraine Ross Goldman. Dear and adored friend of so many. A woman of elegance, indomitable strength and courage who loved life and was an inspiration to all, especially the physically disabled. A beautiful woman, an outstanding mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, whose intelligence and strength of mind fought the ravages of physical hardship always with a smile and a desire to forever love her family. Her vital presence will be deeply missed. Services, Friday, November 21, 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: Mayor Sees More Budget Cuts With Nearly $2 Billion Deficit
description: New York's budget problems have eased slightly because of higher taxes and an improving Wall Street economy, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned yesterday that the city still faces a deficit of nearly $2 billion for the fiscal year that starts next July.

title: Designs Leave Many Unhappy, Some Inspired
description: Victims' families yearned to touch the bedrock where the World Trade Center stood. Firefighters had to see their buddies' names listed together. Artists dreamed of a revelation. The fiercely protective hoped for an expression of the essential horror of the tragedy, and the spirit of the city that endured.

title: JOHNSON DRUG CLOSER TO APPROVAL FOR MIGRAINE USE
description: Johnson & Johnson moved closer to selling the seizure medicine Topamax to treat migraines after regulators said they were prepared to clear the new use. The Food and Drug Administration sent a letter to the company, proposing labeling for the drug and requesting analyses of safety results before granting approval, Johnson & Johnson said. Topamax had $687 million in worldwide sales last year, a spokeswoman, Lesley Fishman, said. Topamax is cleared in the United States to treat seizures in combination with another drug. It is used in adults and children ages 2 to 16.

title: Japan Telecom Expects Red Ink
description: Japan Telecom Holdings, which operates Japan's third-largest mobile phone company, expects to lose money in its current fiscal year as it pays for the sale of its fixed-line division and spends more to attract customers.

title: Brown's Goalie Leads Way
description: If recent goaltending trends in the National Hockey League are any indication, Brown University has the French-Canadian connection that may be its key to success this season.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Three Held In Mall Slayings
description: A truck driver and two other people were arrested yesterday on charges of killing two employees of a video game store, FuncoLand, at the Roxbury Mall near here on Dec. 1 and stealing about $10,000 worth of merchandise, the authorities said. The Morris County prosecutor, Michael M. Rubbinaccio, said a surveillance photo taken in a fast-food restaurant nearby before the slayings led detectives to the driver, Omar S. Thomas, 26, of Irvington. He and the two other suspects, Rahman A. Vaughn, 24, and a 15-year-old youth who was not identified, both of Newark, were charged with fatally shooting the store manager, Erik Rewoldt, 26, and the assistant manager, Jeff Eresman, 22. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRITTENHAM, RAYMOND L.
description: BRITTENHAM--Raymond L. The Officers, Directors and Staff of The Tinker Foundation Inc., express their deep sorrow at the death of Mr. Raymond L. Brittenham. Mr. Brittenham was a steady rock in the early years of the Foundation's development. He continued his stewardship for thirty-six years as its Secretary, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1999. He will be sorely missed and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his widow, Mrs. Brittenham, and their children.

title: Johnson And Bucs On the Way To a Divorce
description: Tampa Bay deactivated wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson for the season yesterday, a stunning development in a dismal season for the Buccaneers, the defending Super Bowl champions, who are in jeopardy of missing the N.F.L. playoffs.

title: Banking for the World's Poor
description: Microcredit -- tiny business loans extended to poor people in developing countries -- is a proven development strategy, expected to benefit 100 million of the world's poorest families by 2005. But the world's poor desperately need access to a broader range of financial services -- microfinance is the more apt term -- to improve their living standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, JULIUS, M.D.
description: ROSENBERG--Julius, M.D. Age 88. Died peacefully at home in Palm Beach on November 17, 2003. His loving wife, Cathy, was at his side as always during these last difficult weeks and through the many years of joy they shared. Born in NYC, July 13, 1915, he graduated from New York University in 1936. He received his medical degree from New York University School of Medicine in 1940. He entered the US Navy in 1942 and was most proud of the year spent as a Medical Officer on Guadalcanal receiving two Battle Stars. He remained on Active Duty upon returning from the Pacific being promoted to Lt. Commander. He practiced medicine in Brooklyn, NY and was on the teaching faculty at Downstate Medical Center. He received Board Certification in Internal Medicine and Gastroenterology and was proud to be a Fellow of the American College of Physicians as well as a Fellow of the American College of Gastroenterology. In 1971, he moved to Florida, practicing medicine in West Palm Beach until his retirement in 1988. Dr. Rosenberg was predeceased by his first wife and the mother of his sons, Natalie. He is survived by his loving wife, Cathy, sons, Dr. Robert Rosenberg, and Dr. Mark Rosenberg, his wife Susan, and grandchildren, Stacey, Jed, Josh, Courtney and close friend, Bob Spray. Family, friends, patients and colleagues will remember him for his compassion, intellect, humor and love of sports. His family has requested in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Friends will be received at 9:30 A.M. on Thursday, November 20, 2003 at Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 1201 S. Olive Ave., West Palm Beach, FL 33401, with services beginning at 10:00 A.M. Interment will follow at Lake Worth Memory Gardens Cemetery.

title: F.B.I. Agents Raid Currency Offices
description: F.B.I. agents arrested dozens of people and seized boxes of records last night in an investigation that a law enforcement official said involved small currency firms and employees of large Wall Street firms.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Flimsy Bulletproof Vests
description: Justice Department officials will investigate the safety of the bulletproof vests used by police officers around the country because of concerns about the reliability of the material used in many of them, Attorney General John Ashcroft announced. Law enforcement groups say they have found that Zylon, the fiber used in some vests, has deteriorated more quickly than expected. The State of Massachusetts filed a lawsuit this week against Second Chance Body Armor Inc., a Michigan manufacturer that uses the material. Toyobo, a Japanese company that manufactures Zylon, has sent the department its test data on the product and said that it welcomed the investigation. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, SAM
description: KLEINER -- Sam. Fisher Brothers mourns the passing of our dear counsel, Sam Kleiner. For over two decades, he was our invaluable partner, confidant and most importantly, great friend. Beside being a skilled and knowledgeable attorney, Sam was an astute, fair-minded businessman, profoundly respected by all. Our hearts go out to his wife, Darlene, his five sons, Jeremy, Benjamin, Kenneth, David and Christopher, his two granddaughters, Karson and Devon, as well as his mother, Betty Kleiner, and his sister, Hannah Weise. Sam was taken from us all too soon. His warmth, gentleness, wisdom and pure sweetness will never be forgotten. Fisher Brothers Arnold Fisher Richard L. Fisher Ken Fisher Steven Fisher Winston C. Fisher

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Oversight Urged For Cell Towers
description: City and state officials called yesterday for more government oversight of cellphone transmission towers. They cited concerns that the proliferation of such antennas on residential buildings might lead to harmful electromagnetic fields. Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. has called for a public hearing and has proposed legislation requiring better tracking of such equipment, as well as a health study. In addition, Assemblyman Michael Gianaris said he was planning legislation that would, among other things, establish a board to regulate the placement of future cell towers and a four-month moratorium on new construction. ''The placement of cellphone towers has become like the Wild West,'' said Mr. Gianaris. ''Residents have almost nothing to say about these towers being placed over their homes.'' Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: U.S. Officers in Iraq Find Few Signs of Infiltration by Foreign Fighters
description: The commanding general of the United States Army division that patrols much of Iraq's western borders with Syria, Jordan and Saudi Arabia said Tuesday that his men had encountered only a handful of foreign fighters trying to sneak into the country to attack American and allied forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, MARTIN
description: JOSEPH--Martin, 64, musician, teacher, and bandleader, died on November 16, 2003, due to complications from surgery. Born May 29, 1939 in the Bronx, NY, he was known as Marty Stevens, President of Marty Stevens Music. Receiving an MA in history from New York University, Marty taught history and eventually music in the New York City public school system for 25 years while continuing to perform as a musician. In 1984 he founded Marty Stevens Music, a successful orchestra specializing in private parties, weddings, benefits and corporate events. Highly respected for his integrity, musicianship, charisma and wit, Marty provided music and joy at over 4000 events in 40 years. He is survived by his wife Carol, sons Dennis and Greg, daughter-in-law Yana, and grandson Gabriel. Services were held.

title: Leonard Karlin, 81, Dies; Polk Award Co-Founder
description: Leonard Karlin, who helped conceive, develop and run the George Polk Awards, one of journalism's highest honors, died on Friday at a hospice in the Bronx. He was 81 and lived in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, IRVING A.
description: RUBIN--Irving A. The National Board of Trustees, Founders, and staff of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America mourn the loss of our dedicated Chairperson Emeritus and dear friend, Irving A. Rubin. As our second National President, Irving played a crucial role in the development and success of the Foundation. He was an inspiring leader, highly respected among physician and lay leadership. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Irwin and Suzanne Rosenthal William and Shelby Modell Henry D. Janowitz, M.D. National Co-Founders Eugene A. Kestenbaum Chair, Board of Trustees Rodger L. DeRose President & CEO

title: U.S. Offers $10 Million Reward in Hunt for Top Hussein Aide
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 19  American officials offered a $10 million reward today for information leading to the capture or death of a senior member of Saddam Hussein's government who is believed to be directing attacks against American troops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOK, G. WHITFIELD, III
description: COOK--G. Whitfield, III, 94 years, of Lyme, CT died on November 12, 2003 at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London, CT of cardiac complications. Graduate of Yale Drama School. Broadway writer, director, and stage manager. Screenwriter for MGM-Alfred Hitchcock Productions, and television. Novelist, short story writer, and composer, his successful career spanned over 70 years in the literary and entertainment field. Predeceased by his wife Elizabeth Heiskell Cook. Survived by his son George W. Cook IV, daughterin-law Ann Mariah Cook, and granddaughter Kathleen-Elizabeth Fitzgerald Cook, all of New Hampshire. Graveside services private. A memorial service in New York City is planned for April 10, 2004. Memorial gifts may be made to: The Whitfield Cook Prize, New Dramatists, 424 West 44th St, New York NY 10036.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of the comedy ''Martin and Orloff'' in Weekend on Nov. 7 reversed the names of the actors in the title roles. Ian Roberts portrays Martin Flam, and Matt Walsh plays Dr. Orloff. The review also misidentified two characters. Orloff's girlfriend is Kashia (Kim Raver), not Donna (Katie Roberts). And Patty's ex-boyfriend is Jimbo (Sal Valente), not Ron (Matt Besser).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEAHY, JOAN E. (NEE GOMEZ, FRANCO)
description: LEAHY--Joan E. (nee Gomez-Franco), on September 28, 2003 in Henderson, NV from lung cancer. Born 1934 in New York City to Harry and Ada Allen Gomez-Franco, Joan moved with her family to Mexico City in 1938 where she spent much of her young life. She returned to the US to finish high school and attend Fordham University earning a BA in 1956. In 1957 Joan began a long career in advertising sales with A.C. Nielsen Co., and later BBDO and SSC&B. She began a nearly 25 year career with the NBC television network in the early 1970s. For most of her career with NBC, Joan was a prime-time network sales account executive and, for a time, Vice President, Marketing and VP of daytime and late-night network sales. Although too humble to acknowledge the fact, Joan was a trailblazer in the then male-dominated field of Advertising and helped break the ''glass ceiling'' for many of the women who followed. According to family lore, which may in fact be true, Joan was the first woman to be served a drink at the bar of ''21 Club'' in NYC where she often met with clients. Joan was a long time resident of Manhattan, and concurrently Sag Harbor, NY. After she retired from NBC in 1996, she moved to Santa Fe, NM and later the Las Vegas area. Joan is survived by three sisters, Linda Royer of Malverne, NY, Suzanne Mantone of Oyster Bay Cove, NY, and Barbara White of Arroyo Grande, CA. She was preceded in death by her sister, Eleanor Rofheart in 2002. Joan is also survived by several nieces and nephews, and many friends throughout the Country. Aunt Joan, as she was known to many in the family, will be greatly missed for her sharp intellect, good humor and straight forward, no-nonsense way. At Joan's request, no memorial services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRANOW, SARINDA
description: DRANOW -- Sarinda. The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board mourns the passing of Sarinda Dranow, our member since 1983. Mrs. Dranow cochaired our gift shop where she worked for many years with the gracious consistance and a high standard of service. All of us extend our condolences to her family. Sue K. Feld, President The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RICH, GORDON A.
description: RICH--Gordon A. 11/8/57--11/19/00. Death be not proud. He lives within our hearts. Loving you, missing you...now and forever. Mom and Da

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the French government's effort to stop anti-Semitic violence referred incorrectly to results of a recent opinion survey sponsored by the European Commission. (The error also appeared on Sunday in an article about European attitudes toward President Bush.) Respondents were asked to identify the countries -- not the leaders -- they perceived as the greatest threats to world peace. A majority perceived Israel (not Prime Minister Ariel Sharon) as the greatest threat; the United States and North Korea (not Mr. Bush and the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il) were ranked No. 2.

title: 2 Networks Eye Rivers
description: If he wants to return to his former role as a TV analyst, Doc Rivers, who was fired Monday as head coach of the Orlando Magic, has two suitors: ABC Sports and TNT, which contacted his agent early yesterday.

title: Cutting Shakespeare Down to Size at His Own Game
description: ''The Beard of Avon,'' Amy Freed's jocular take on the who-wrote-Shakespeare's-plays debate, has been a busy traveler in regional theater since its premiere in 2001 at the South Coast Repertory in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Apple Picking

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REA, ELIZABETH MEEKS
description: REA -- Elizabeth Meeks. Passed today at her home in Menands, NY. She was 83. The cause of death was complications due to Parkinson disease. Elizabeth is survived by her children, Jane Crotty, C.W. ''Woody'' Rea, and Steven C. Rea and five grandchildren, John, Elizabeth and David Crotty and C.W. ''Tripp'' Rea III and Brooke Rea, as well as two greatgrandchildren. There will be calling hours on Thursday, November 20th at Morris Stebbins Funeral Home on Hoosick Street in Troy, from 4:00-8:00 P.M. The funeral will be on Friday, November 21st at 10:30 A.M. at Hope Memorial Methodist Church in Center Brunswick, and a burial will take place at Memory's Garden Cemetery in Colonie. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made to the Parkinson Foundation, Cerebral Palsy Association or Hope Memorial Methodist.

title: World Trade Center Site Memorial Competition Jury Statement
description: The following is the complete text of the jury statement provided by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation .

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Utility's Stock Surges
description: The China Yangtze Power Company, which raised 10 billion yuan ($1.2 billion) in the country's largest initial offering this year, rose 44 percent on its first day of trading. Yangtze Power, operator of the Three Gorges dam, closed at 6.18 yuan (75 cents) in Shanghai, up from the offer price of 4.30 yuan. China may raise electricity rates to encourage companies to build more power plants in the nation, where generation capacity is forecast to fall short of demand for at least two years. That would increase earnings at Yangtze Power, owner of the world's biggest hydropower project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KISNER, JACOB
description: KISNER--Jacob. On November 17, 2003. Beloved husband of Gladys Feinstein Kisner. Dear father of Lesley (Nicholas) Cafarelli. Cherished grandfather of Micol and Ariel. Services today November 19th, 4 P.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Gains
description: President Vladimir V. Putin's popularity rose to 82 percent, from 73 percent just three weeks ago, according to the independent polling organization Vtsiom, indicating approval of the government's arrest of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest tycoon, and the impounding of the assets of his company, Yukos Oil. The poll of 1,600 Russians was carried out Nov. 13 to 16. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Cranberries for Thursday (and Friday, Too)
description: Clarisse Persanyi, a former international banker on Wall Street, has a mission: to put cranberries on the table year-round. So six weeks ago she opened a shop, All Things Cranberry, in Monmouth Beach, N.J. ''We're only about 25 miles from New Jersey's cranberry farms,'' she said. And the timing is excellent.

title: Ethereal Queen Redeemed By Her Human Heart
description: Two years ago, the Metropolitan Opera lifted the spirits of music-lovers in New York with a humane, visually ravishing and musically distinguished new production of one of opera's most problematic works, Richard Strauss's ''Frau Ohne Schatten.'' Every element of that production by Herbert Wernicke in his Met debut was enchanting. Add to that the winning cast, headed by the soprano Deborah Voigt in a milestone performance as the Empress, and the incandescent conducting of Christian Thielemann, and this ''Die Frau'' was the finest work the Met had done in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDERMAN, EVAN
description: RUDERMAN--Evan, 44, was a lifelong activist who fought injustice in many forms from organizing women factory workers to becoming one of the first female union electricians in NYC and building the Women's Construction Brigade that went to Nicaragua in 1987. A founding member of Women in the Trades, she consulted for NEW throughout her life. A longtime survivor of AIDS, Evan helped to found Health GAP, working tirelessly for treatment access for HIV patients around the world. A delegate to the World AIDS Conferences in Durban and Barcelona, she organized the Women's Conference in Barcelona in 2002. Evan was active in AIDS prevention and education, publishing articles on surviving with AIDS and speaking to young people and other populations at risk. Her mother, father and step-mother, sister, brothers, nieces and nephews, and many many friends are proud to have known her and shared her life. Services 2PM Thursday, Park Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: SCO Plans To Sue Linux User
description: The SCO Group plans to file suit against a major corporate user of the Linux operating system within 90 days, the company's lawyer said yesterday. The planned move is part of a stepped-up effort by SCO to get payments from distributors and corporate users of Linux. SCO owns the license rights to the Unix operating system, and the company contends that Linux, a variant of Unix, violates SCO's license and copyright. To pursue its campaign, SCO said yesterday that it was tightening its relationship with its outside law firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner, which will receive a payment of $1 million in cash and 400,000 shares of SCO. The company, based in Lindon, Utah, said it would take a charge of $8.9 million against its earnings for the payment. Earlier this year, SCO sued I.B.M., a leading corporate supporter of Linux, claiming that it violated SCO's license rights to Unix. SCO also sent out warning letters to 1,500 large companies, saying their use of Linux without payment of license fees to SCO was illegal. Within three months, ''we will identify a defendant that we believe will illustrate the nature of the problem,'' said David Boies, managing partner of Boies Schiller & Flexner. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Consumer Prices Steady After Four-Month Climb
description: The Consumer Price Index held steady in October after rising for four months, as Americans paid less for gasoline and new cars, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: BIAS AGAINST INDIANS Nearly one in three American Indians faces discrimination when trying to rent a home, a rate higher than any other minority, a government-sponsored study found. The study, conducted for the Department of Housing and Urban Development by the Urban Institute, a private Washington research organization, found that Indian renters were discriminated against more than 29 percent of the time. Findings were based on testing done off tribal lands in Minnesota, Montana and New Mexico. Data previously released by the department found that Hispanic renters faced discrimination 26 percent of the time, blacks 22 percent of the time and Asian-Americans 21 percent.   (AP)

title: Sports of The Times; Hill's Ankle Proved to Be Rivers's Achilles' Heel
description: WITH the party balloons still falling in the months after the Orlando Magic signed Tracy McGrady and Grant Hill, a twin-engine airplane plunged into the grasslands of Mississippi.

title: Report Finds Few Benefits for Mexico in Nafta
description: As the North American Free Trade Agreement nears its 10th anniversary, a study from the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace concludes that the pact failed to generate substantial job growth in Mexico, hurt hundreds of thousands of subsistence farmers there and had ''minuscule'' net effects on jobs in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about digestifs, many of them distilled from grapes, included an incorrect example of a grape variety used to make Italian grappa. Valpolicella is a wine-producing region, not a type of grape.

title: Three Soldiers Are Charged With Assault On Prisoners
description: The Army has charged three Reserve soldiers with assaulting Iraqi prisoners in southern Iraq six months ago.

title: National Briefing | Washington: General's Delayed Promotion
description: After more than a year's delay, the Senate approved the promotion of a general who commanded a base where a gay soldier was beaten to death in 1999. The officer, Maj. Gen. Robert T. Clark, commanded the base, Fort Campbell, Ky., when the soldier, Pfc. Barry Winchell, 21, was bludgeoned to death by a fellow soldier after an evening of drinking beer. President Bush nominated General Clark in August 2002 as a lieutenant general and commander of the Fifth Army, but the Senate Armed Services Committee delayed voting two times, allowing more time to investigate his handling of the case. John Files (NYT)

title: Government Mapping Out A Strategy to Fight Autism
description: Propelled by the skyrocketing number of diagnoses of the perplexing brain disorder autism in children, federal officials have for the first time mapped out a long-term, interagency plan to deal with the problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, DONALD S.
description: KLEIN--Donald S. The Westchester Trusts and Estates Round Table Study Group is deeply saddened by the loss of our esteemed member. He was our founder, our mentor and, above all, our friend.

title: Off the Menu
description: MARCO CANORA, left, who worked with Tom Colicchio at Craft and Craftbar, and PAUL GRIECO, who was the wine director at Craft, now have their own place, HEARTH, which is opening tomorrow at 403 East 12th Street. Mr. Colicchio is a backer of this restaurant, which seats 85, including some at the bar facing the open kitchen. Hearth is done in brick, copper, stone and warm woods. The menu is American as seen through an Italian prism.

title: Jets Need a Big Receiver, But Which One Is a Fit?
description: When Jets Coach Herman Edwards was an assistant with Tampa Bay in 2000, Keyshawn Johnson, then newly acquired from the Jets in a trade, used to attend Edwards's son's high school football games. After watching a few plays during the first game he attended, Johnson began yelling for the coach to throw Marcus Edwards the ball.

description: UNGEMACH--Winifred (nee Farrell). A bright light with a spiritual sense of the positive and of self - expression. www.ungemach.com/ win.htm

title: Marc Jacobs Executive Is Shifted to Donna Karan
description: Assured that Donna Karan International was not going to be sold out from under him -- at least not anytime soon -- Jeffry M. Aronsson was named chief executive yesterday, leaving his job as head of Marc Jacobs International. Both companies are owned by LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's largest conglomerate of luxury goods.

description: Since winning the California recall election, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has been vague about how he would deal with the state's mammoth budget problems, the driving force behind the ouster of Gov. Gray Davis.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Small Shops Lead the Demand in Retailing
description: Average asking rents have risen for retail space in Manhattan in the last year, most sharply in prime shopping corridors like Fifth Avenue, Madison Avenue and 57th Street.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Party Rejects Food And Drug Tax
description: The largest party in Congress, the opposition Institutional Revolutionary Party, withdrew its support for President Vicente Fox's unpopular plan to apply a 10 percent tax on food and medicine, sinking yet another of the government's proposed economic reforms. John Moody (NYT)

title: The Grim Lessons Of Terror in Istanbul
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning In America
description: In the middle of the night on Oct. 23, 1983, the White House learned that suicide bombers had struck in Lebanon. At the Beirut airport, 241 marines were killed in their barracks. Ten minutes later a second suicide bomber killed 58 French soldiers two miles away. The next morning I was asked if I could get away from my job in the White House policy planning office for a few days to handle the press advance if President Ronald Reagan decided to attend a memorial service for the slain marines.

title: U.S. Moves to Limit Textile Imports From China
description: The Bush administration moved on Tuesday to severely restrict the growth of a half-billion dollars' worth of Chinese textile imports and immediately found itself caught between battle cries from the industry for more protectionism and anxiety among global investors who fear it.

title: Echoes of a June Ruling
description: A Supreme Court ruling on sodomy paved the way for yesterday's decision, experts said. Page A24.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS PLANT CLOSING TO TRIM 300 JOBS
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., the bankrupt maker of Ralph Lauren Home, Martha Stewart and Joe Boxer bedding and bath products, plans to close an Alabama sheet factory and cut 300 jobs because the plant made outdated styles. Some employees of the plant, which is in Valley, Ala., will be offered jobs at other factories, a spokeswoman for WestPoint, Toni Cauble, said. The plant will close in early 2004. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in June after losing more than $103 million since 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRACHMAN, STANLEY ROBERT, M.D.
description: DRACHMAN -- Stanley Robert, M.D., on November 16, 2003, at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Sally Ann. Devoted father of Virginia, Susan, Josh and Dori. Cherished brother of Harvey and Diane. Doting grandfather of Wendy, Abigail, Eliza, and Andrew. A graduate of Columbia University and the College of Physicians and Surgeons, he was a specialist in internal medicine and a Fellow of the American College of Physicians. A generous man, his curiosity was unbounded. He loved life in every possible way. Funeral services Thursday, November 20, 12:30pm, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY.

title: U.S. Investigates Moscow Theater Siege, Seeking Qaeda Link
description: American law enforcement officials are investigating the deadly takeover of a Moscow theater last year by Chechen rebels to determine whether Al Qaeda was involved and whether criminal charges should be brought in the United States, officials have said.

title: Big Shift on Housing
description: In New York City, where for generations government has played an ambitious role in helping people pay their rents, a fundamental shift is taking hold. Three major programs, originally intended as temporary relief measures, are winding down.

title: Yonkers Awaits Deep Education Cutbacks
description: The school system here has a history of announcing budget shortfalls and proposing layoffs, followed by 11th-hour rescues, but this year the white knight might not come in time to save jobs or sports programs and clubs.

title: Anatomy of a failed product introduction: How a nasal spray flu vaccine flopped in the marketplace.
description: IT sounds like a marketer's dream -- a flu vaccine that is given through a spray in the nose rather than an often painful shot in the arm. But attempts to sell such a vaccine this flu season have turned into a nightmare.

title: Consensus on Energy Bill Arose One Project at a Time
description: Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, has raised pointed and repeated objections to the way Republicans met behind closed doors to assemble the wide-ranging energy measure that was easily approved by the House on Tuesday.

title: Online Dating
description: To the Editor:

title: House Votes to Tighten Regulation of Mutual Fund Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly this afternoon to tighten up regulation of the mutual fund industry, which has been tainted by a series of scandals.

title: At Sniper Trial, A Chilling Tape Is Heard by Jury
description: Last November, during questioning, a homicide detective gave Lee Malvo a chance to show that his heart was not entirely cold.

title: Bloomberg Smells Rat in Message About Speaker
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took a shot yesterday at a potential political rival, Speaker Gifford Miller of the City Council, saying an e-mail message sent out by Mr. Miller's aide last week indicated that the speaker may be inappropriately using Council resources to begin a campaign for mayor.

title: A Death May Be Related to Vaccines
description: A 22-year-old Army reservist who died in April may have succumbed to a combination of vaccinations, including those for smallpox and anthrax, the Pentagon said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Is the Mutual Fund Issue Abuses, or Is It Fees?
description: The coming battle over mutual fund regulation may well end up focusing not on trading abuses, which are now the subject of regulatory action, but on the fees and costs that funds charge investors.

title: Singer Is Fired by Mets For Insensitive Remarks
description: Bill Singer's brief tenure as a special assistant to the Mets came to an end yesterday when he was fired for insensitive remarks to a Los Angeles Dodgers executive during the general managers' meetings in Arizona last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAJOR, LASZLO
description: BAJOR--Laszlo. On November 8, 2003. A memorial service will be held at Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, (between 9th & 10th Sts), Thursday November 20, 11AM.

title: Rivals Call Eminem Racist Over Lyrics From the Past
description: Over the years the rap star Eminem has been called a homophobe and a misogynist, not to mention a foul-mouthed menace to society. Now he is being branded a racist over lyrics that he acknowledges he wrote and recorded at least a decade ago.

title: Bush, in London, Tries to Shore Up Support for War Effort
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  President Bush exhorted Britain today to stand with the United States in rallying European governments and the United Nations behind a long-term campaign to defeat terrorism and bring democracy to the Islamic nations of the Middle East.

title: Getting a Job in the Valley Is Easy, if You're Perfect
description: As the economy bounces back, even Silicon Valley's job market is showing signs of revival. But it has a long way to go. Employers are being extremely picky, the few jobs being offered pay less than they once did, and they do not come with the bountiful benefits and sterling opportunities of the 1990's boom, job seekers say.

title: Bush in Britain: Views of the Hosts
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Raiders And Upshaw Will Meet
description: The four Oakland Raiders identified as having tested positive for the newly detectable banned steroid THG will meet today with Gene Upshaw, executive director of the National Football League players' union, a person with detailed knowledge of the meeting plans said.

title: Deal by Wisconsin Oneidas May Clear Way for Casino
description: The Oneida Indians of Wisconsin plan to announce today that they have acquired two large tracts in New York to set in motion a bid for a casino as part of a settlement of the tribe's longstanding land claims.

title: U.S. Plans to Toughen Rules For Cargo Shipping Industry
description: The Bush administration will try to force the nation's largest shipping companies to install electronic tamper sensors and use reinforced metal seals on millions of steel-box cargo containers in an effort to keep terrorists from trying to ship nuclear or other catastrophic weapons into the United States, senior officials said Tuesday.

title: China's Message on Energy
description: Pete Domenici, an architect of one of the most depressing legislative initiatives in recent Congressional history -- the energy bill approved by the House yesterday and headed for a Senate vote -- acknowledged recently that it could not withstand close inspection. ''We know that as soon as you start reading the language, we're duck soup,'' he said, referring to the bill's embarrassingly long list of special favors for legislators and their contributors.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Qantas Director Resigns
description: Trevor J. Kennedy, a director of Qantas, Australia's national airline, resigned after accusations that he and two partners concealed shareholdings by handling them through a Swiss bank. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission, the federal watchdog on stock market issues, said it was investigating share trading by Mr. Kennedy. Mr. Kennedy, who said he was resigning all seven of his company directorships, said, ''I do not believe I have broken any law.'' He was a founder of Ozemail, an Internet company, and has interests in media, technology and oil operations. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report by Reuters in the World Briefing column yesterday about James C. Oberwetter, a Texas oil lobbyist who is President Bush's choice as ambassador to Saudi Arabia, misstated his connection to the American Petroleum Institute. He is former chairman of its general committee on communications, not of the institute over all.

title: Senators and Filibusters
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're planning a spring wedding.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Banking Rule Relaxed
description: In a trial program, Beijing will allow Hong Kong banks to conduct limited banking in the Chinese currency, the yuan, for retail customers but not for corporate clients. Hong Kong banks will be allowed to take deposits, convert up to $2,300 in currency a day per person, handle remittances and help holders of mainland credit cards use them in Hong Kong. The transactions will be cleared on the mainland in the adjacent city of Shenzhen, under the supervision of the People's Bank of China. China has been gradually loosening currency controls. There have been complaints from abroad that China's currency is artificially weak in foreign exchange markets, making its exports more competitive. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: REVIEW RESUMES ON GENERAL ELECTRIC BID FOR AGFA UNIT
description: European antitrust regulators restarted their review of the 400 million euro ($471 million) bid by General Electric for the ultrasonic testing unit of Agfa-Gevaert, after the company supplied missing information, the European Commission said. The commission, which will rule on the takeover by Dec. 4, suspended the review on July 9 to take account of the unusual circumstances brought on by the decision of seven European countries to hand the case to the Brussels regulators. The commission could clear the deal or open a four-month inquiry. The deal involves businesses that are too small to warrant an automatic review by the commission, which took the case in May at the request of Germany, Austria, Greece, Ireland, Spain, Portugal and Italy. General Electric agreed in January to buy the Agfa unit, which had sales of 220 million euros last year.

title: Michael Jackson's Ranch Is Raided in Criminal Inquiry
description: Equipped with a search warrant, more than 60 law enforcement officers raided the ranch of the singer Michael Jackson here on Tuesday, looking for evidence in what the authorities described as a criminal investigation.

title: Murder-Case Witness Backs Prosecutors and Aids Defense
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn called a witness yesterday who said he saw a murder at the center of a death penalty case that has drawn national attention. He said what the prosecutors hoped he would say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAVALRY INVESTMENT, Hawthorne, N.Y., a consumer debt-collection firm, said that the investment arm of Bear Stearns & Co., New York, the investment banker, had bought a minority stake in it. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Biggest Accounting Firm? Best Consult the Fine Print
description: It is difficult to account for accountants' differences.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the surgical separation of Ahmed and Mohamed Ibrahim, the Egyptian twins joined at the head, misstated the name of the hospital where the operation took place. It is Children's Medical Center Dallas, not Children's Hospital.

title: Hornets Beat Nets At Their Own Game
description: Byron Scott did not say the Nets were scared, and he did not say they played like women. He resisted any urge to resurrect those sound bites, but his displeasure still rang true Tuesday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the French government's effort to stop anti-Semitic violence referred incorrectly to results of a recent opinion survey sponsored by the European Commission. (The error also appeared on Sunday in an article about European attitudes toward President Bush.) Respondents were asked to identify the countries  not the leaders  they perceived as the greatest threats to world peace. A majority perceived Israel (not Prime Minister Ariel Sharon) as the greatest threat; the United States and North Korea (not Mr. Bush and the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il) were ranked No. 2.

title: U.N. Agency Cuts Back in Afghanistan
description: The United Nations refugee agency announced Tuesday that it was temporarily pulling 30 foreign staff members out of large areas of southern and eastern Afghanistan and closing refugee reception centers in four provinces, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAUSS, MICHAEL L.
description: MAUSS--Michael L. Dearest brother-gone to soon. We will remember you always. Our hearts go out to the family. Sister Eileen and Richard

title: An Adventure for Concertgoers When Video Embellishes Sound
description: The next big thing in classical music concerts -- adorning performances with video -- has been around for a while, as so many next big things have. In the 1960's, Virgil Fox proselytized among young listeners by playing ''Heavy Organ'' concerts, offering Bach with the support of psychedelic light shows. During the last two decades, Philip Glass and his ensemble have toured widely, performing his scores for ''Koyaanisqatsi'' and other films, with the films projected above the band.

title: 2 Tyco Witnesses Disagree
description: A lawyer who advised Tyco International Ltd. on what it should tell investors about company loan programs said she was not informed of plans to forgive mortgage loans for top executives, including the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski.

title: Intrigued by Characters With Dark Mysteries
description: When the director David Jones was trying to cast the New York revival of Harold Pinter's play ''The Caretaker'' early this year he called Mr. Pinter to ask about a slightly risky proposition: using a young Irish actor with no Broadway experience named Aidan Gillen.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Increases Pension Fund
description: British Airways said its pension contributions would double to 251 million ($427 million), after falling markets quadrupled the shortfall in its employee pension plan. Last week, British Airways reported a 36 percent drop in earnings because of falling business travel and competition from discount airlines. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Practically a Pilgrim, Celebrating the Old Way
description: MARJORIE CRONIN has been hooked on Thanksgiving since she was a little girl growing up in Plymouth, Mass. One year she and her relatives were chosen to be the pilgrim family for the town's celebration, perhaps because her clan was large enough to stage a pageant on its own.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SRI LANKA: PANEL FOR THE POLITICAL DIVIDE The country's squabbling president and prime minister appointed a panel of officials to work out differences between the rival leaders and to try to end their power struggle. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Two Brothers, One Mystery, And a Life Transformed
description: When those closest to Howard Dean try to explain what transformed the somewhat directionless young man into a driven family man, they frequently light upon the unexplained disappearance of his beloved brother Charlie in violence-ravaged Laos in 1974 at the height of the Vietnam War.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day yesterday with an article about the merger of the St. Paul Companies and the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation, showing states where the new company would rank first or second in premiums written, carried an erroneous label in some copies for the state directly south of Minnesota. It is Iowa, not New Mexico.

description: Linda Fargo has a new book "Dreams Through the Glass: Windows From Bergdorf Goodman''  and she is also unveiling  this year's holiday windows.
