title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EASLEY, HOLMES
description: EASLEY--Holmes. Was born on September 24, 1934 in San Saba, TX. A resident of NYC since 1970 he died October 11, 2003, while visiting in Carmel, CA, following two years of treatment for colon cancer. He obtained his Master of Fine Arts degree in stage, scenic and costume design at the Yale School of Drama. Following six years of teaching stage design at Stanford University and Colgate University, he spent three years with the Asolo Theatre in Sarasota, FL as resident scenic and costume designer. He also designed for the Sacramento Summer Theatre and the Alley Theatre. Returning to the northeast, Easley began a 25 year association with CBS Television Network. He served as set director for Guiding Light and As the World Turns for which he won an Emmy Award in 1991. He designed productions for the Roundabout Theatre in NY, for which he received two Obie Awards for best set design, in 1974 and 1976. He retired from CBS in 1996. Following his retirement from CBS he segued into a second career in interior design and architecture, designing major residential projects in NYC, Summit, NJ and St. Louis, MO. Through his life Easley was interested in education, the theatre arts, and the mentoring of young people. There will be a memorial service for Easley at St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53 St. at Fifth Ave. at 3PM Thursday, November 20. The family asks that any contributions in his memory be made to your local hospice.

title: S.E.C. Issues Subpoenas to Hollinger Officials
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued subpoenas to officials of Hollinger International, the publishing company controlled by Conrad Black, the embattled press baron, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Mideast Moderates
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHWAB TO BUY SOUNDVIEW FOR $321 MILLION
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation agreed to buy the SoundView Technology Group for $321.3 million to expand its research coverage of technology and telecommunications companies. Schwab, which began offering stock ratings to individuals in May 2002, is adding research for professional investors, like hedge funds and mutual funds, after a two-year decline in online trading. Schwab will pay $15.50 for each SoundView share, a 17 percent premium over the closing price on Tuesday. Schwab wants to compete with companies that offer trading and research to professional investors, the chief executive, David Pottruck, said in a conference call with investors. SoundView, which is based in Old Greenwich, Conn., covers about 210 companies in aerospace, technology, media and health care.

title: A Flying Saucer For Your Floor
description: I DISLIKE housecleaning, so a robotic vacuum cleaner appeals to me -- at least in theory. I would much prefer to relax while a robot inhales dust bunnies. After seeing advertisements for a real-life model called the Roomba, I wondered if I would finally be able to buy something as cute as Rosie, the Jetsons' robot, who cleaned house as well as any human.

title: Yanks Plan To Pursue Vazquez And Coln
description: The Yankees went into spring training last season with seven starting pitchers, and that appears to be their plan again. If the Yankees accomplish their off-season goals, the clubhouse at Legends Field in Tampa will be stuffed with starters.

title: Canada Resists U.S. Pressure On Drug Sales
description: A day after signing an agreement to improve cross-border collaboration on prescription drugs, American and Canadian officials were at odds again on Wednesday over Canada's policy of permitting exports of cheap prescription medicines to the United States.

title: The Memorial Finalists
description: When coming generations try to make sense of what we felt on Sept. 11, 2001, they will turn to the documentary records: the newspapers, the videotapes, the interviews. But when they try to understand how we wanted that tragedy to be remembered -- something very different -- they will turn to the art that arose from it and to the memorial that will be created at ground zero. The memory of that morning is something we all keep within us. The memorial is a public expression of that private memory, a way of arranging space and light and imagination so something more than the past is evoked. The most powerful memorials we know do not merely consecrate an event. They dignify our presence, too.

title: European Union Expansion Has Drug Makers Worried
description: As the European Union prepares for its biggest expansion, the Continent's leading pharmaceutical companies are lobbying intensively to ensure that the 10 relatively poor new member states -- from Malta to Lithuania -- do not become conduits for cheap prescription drugs to flood wealthier markets like France and Germany, industry officials said.

title: Married or Not, It's a Full House
description: WHEN Steven Lofton, Roger Croteau and Mr. Lofton's five foster children -- who were born to H.I.V.-positive mothers -- prepare Thanksgiving dinner, it will be in a kitchen in Portland, Ore., with cobalt blue walls and fire-engine-red Formica cabinets. Then they will join more than 20 guests in a dining room with an orange tabletop, yellow carpeting and a silver ceiling.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer Selects Executive
description: The British grocery chain J Sainsbury has named Justin King, director of food at the Marks & Spencer Group, as its new chief executive. Mr. King, 42, will join Sainsbury on March 29, the current chief executive, Sir Peter Davis, said. Sir Peter will become chairman at that time. Sainsbury, based in London, also reported results and said its income was 206 million ($351 million), or 10.8 pence a share, in the 28 weeks ended Oct. 11. Sales rose 0.1 percent at British stores open at least a year, below the growth rate of 2.5 percent a year earlier.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Teachers' Contract Avoids Strike
description: Members of the Chicago Teachers Union approved a four-year contract by a slim majority, avoiding what could have been the first strike in 16 years. The contract calls for an annual raise of 4 percent and improved health care benefits. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Adu Added to U.S. Youth Team Roster
description: Freddy Adu, the 14-year-old striker who signed a six-year contract yesterday with Major League Soccer, was added to the United States roster for the world youth championships by Coach Thomas Rongen because of an injury to Arturo Alvarez. The team is scheduled to leave for the United Arab Emirates on Saturday. The tournament begins for the Americans against Paraguay on Nov. 29. Adu's addition to the roster must be approved by FIFA, the sport's world governing body. Jack Bell

title: Of Blair and Bush, and the Ties That Bind
description: When President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill forged their strong alliance during World War II, the phrase ''special relationship'' was coined to describe the ties between Britain and the United States.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Man Chokes On Bag Of Marijuana
description: A suburban Fort Worth man, Nickolas Sandoval, choked to death on a small bag of marijuana that the police said he apparently tried to hide from officers who had stopped to help him while he was changing a tire. The two patrolmen tried to clear his airway when they noticed him choking. Mr. Sandoval, 24, was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital of ''asphyxiation due to aspiration of plastic bag.'' The police said he had been arrested several times for drug possession. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the memorial service for the author George Plimpton misidentified a speaker. She was his sister, Sarah G. Plimpton, not his wife, Sarah Dudley Plimpton.

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Design Meets The Quality Of Life, Relationships And Society
description: Life Symphony Part 1, an exhibition at Felissimo Design House, is partly an eco-design show and partly a forum on the quality of daily life, relationships and society. Pretty heady stuff, but it is kept down to earth by solid design. More than 40 well-known (and less-known) designers were invited to create or exhibit pieces. Myda Chambers (right) and her husband, Eddie, constructed the Odeon cork chair from castoffs from the Odeon restaurant in TriBeCa, where Ms. Chambers once worked. (The corks are held together with fishing line and a steel frame.) The Emergency Tea Set (above), by Benjamin Bearsch, is a take on the St. Bernard brandy flask. It transforms into a table, chairs and burner for making and sharing tea. Felissimo is at 10 West 56th Street; (212) 247-5656. The exhibition runs through January.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Oct. 29 with an article about automakers' sales incentives misstated the average size of those for the Volvo S80 as calculated by Edmunds.com. It is $7,684, not $9,619.

title: Mr. Phoenix Turns Tumbledown Into Taj
description: THE three-story house here owned by Christopher Ohrstrom appears pretty much as it might have in the 1830's, all pearl-white clapboard and window glass so wavy it always looks as if it's raining outside. Nearby stands a barn that dates from before the Civil War. And clustered around the two buildings are several modest white structures, including a privy where one of Robert E. Lee's sons is said to have hidden from Union soldiers.

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about calls from the European Commission for Germany to curb its budget deficit misstated the surname of Ireland's finance minister, who expressed sympathy for the Germans' struggle. He is Charlie McCreevy, not McGreevy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 26 Accused Of Drug Trafficking
description: In a sweeping move against the drug trade in upper Manhattan, the police arrested 26 people yesterday on charges of possessing or selling narcotics, said Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner. What the police described as a network of sellers worked in an area from West 139th Street to West 143rd Street, long infamous as a drug wholesale market, the police said. It was popular with out-of-town dealers, the police said, because it was close to major thoroughfares and bridges. The police also closed 10 businesses where the sellers had operated, and arrested 22 more people on narcotics-related crimes, Mr. Kelly said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: From Around the World, Artists and Architects Who Rose to a Challenge
description: Votives in Suspension

title: Barrier to Stay, Israel Declares
description: Israel rejected Wednesday President Bush's criticism of the barrier it is building in the West Bank, saying construction would proceed as planned.

title: Afghan Women
description: To the Editor:

title: From Around the World, Artists and Architects Who Rose to a Challenge
description: Suspending Memory

title: Knicks Keep Pace With Lakers for 24 Minutes
description: There were 2.4 seconds left in the first half last night when the Frank Williams-led Knicks, against all Hall of Fame odds, were locked in a tie with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: In Breakup Of Hollinger, Telegraph Is the Plum
description: Conrad M. Black's decision to put Hollinger International up for sale is focusing attention on its most valuable assets, the British publications that make up the Telegraph Group.

title: Curl Up by the Fire, No Fireplace Needed
description: When it's too cold to bring in a log (or if you have no fireplace), add a little atmosphere and warmth with log-inspired oil lamps, above, from the German company Carl Mertens. The unit consists of two seven-and-a-half-inch stainless steel tubes, held in place with pegs. It uses regular lamp oil and Fiberglas wicks. Available from Ameico for $275, with the 10-by-14-inch slate base included; (888) 350-8765.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Cyclist Is Hit-Run Victim
description: The police are searching for a hit-and-run driver in a white Cadillac Escalade sport utility vehicle who fatally struck a cyclist early yesterday morning in Sunnyside. The cyclist, Jaime Gonzalez, 21, was struck at the intersection of 43rd Street and Northern Boulevard about 1:40 a.m., as he rode home from work. The driver, who was heading west on Northern Boulevard, fled the scene. Mr. Gonzalez was taken to Elmhurst General Hospital, where he died. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Bush administration's move to restrict the growth of China's textile exports to the United States referred imprecisely to the trade deficit with China this year. It is on track to exceed last year's level of $103 billion, not to match it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Convicted Murderer Sleeps At Sentencing Hearing
description: A burglar who was found guilty last month of a triple murder on the Lower East Side was sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole in each of the deaths. The burglar, Steven Santos, left, slept in State Supreme Court in Manhattan as family and friends of the victims gave statements expressing their grief. When asked if he had anything to say, Mr. Santos, 21, said no. At trial, prosecutors said Mr. Santos had climbed through the bathroom windows of his victims -- Larry Sprung, 86, and his wife, Sara, 88, and their neighbor, Raymond Damelio, 49 -- then shot them in the head, stole money, drank liquor and watched videos. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Reyes Might Have to Move If Mets Sign Kazuo Matsui
description: Mets General Manager Jim Duquette gave Jos Reyes the same assurances in a conversation this off-season that he has maintained publicly: that Reyes is his shortstop and that it will take a monumental occurrence to move him to second base.

title: A Nuclear Mixed Message
description: When the Board of Governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency meets in Vienna today, there will probably be a fight over Iran's suspected nuclear weapons program. The United States wants Iran hauled before the United Nations Security Council for violating the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The European members, however, want to negotiate with Iran.

title: Finding the Inner Bar In Your Home
description: Turn your home into a trendy bar, without having to get past the rope at Bungalow 8. The Hotel Collection from Charter Club offers direct competition to Target and Kmart with luxurious goods at reasonable prices (and without any celebrity endorsements). The line includes bedding, bath and tabletop products: 100 percent cotton sheets, in 460- or 600-thread counts, are $80 to $135 for a queen flat sheet; a goose down comforter is $500. The ribbed, stainless cocktail shaker, above, is $29.99; an ice bucket-tong set is $49.99; a martini glass is $7.99. Available at participating Macy's stores nationwide. For information, www.macys.com.

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMS, MELVIN
description: ABRAMS--Melvin. On November 19, 2003. Beloved husband of Catherine, loving father of Jonathan, Larry and Gail. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St., and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For Bushes, French Wine And U.S. Tunes
description: Guests at Queen Elizabeth's state banquet were seated at an immense U-shaped table brimming with floral arrangements, candelabra, fresh fruit and a dizzying array of gold-plated tableware and wine glasses.

title: Hundreds of Knives Are Seized in Raids on Two Stores
description: Lucky, a variety store and longtime fixture on the Lower East Side, stocks shelf after shelf of dolls that crawl, fire engines with sirens and Pokmon toys. But yesterday, the police said, a raid turned up dozens of illegal weapons, including ''gravity knives'' that release hidden blades from a handle with a flick of the wrist, and brass-knuckle knives that cut with every punch.

title: Economic Scene; Which party in the White House means good times for stock investors?
description: DOES the stock market do better when a Republican is president or when a Democrat is?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Outlooks Raised
description: Standard & Poor's raised the outlook for some large banks to stable from negative, a sign that credit ratings of the lenders would not be lowered soon. S.&P. said Mizuho Corporate Bank, Mizuho Bank, the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, UFJ Bank and UFJ Trust Bank were reducing their risky assets and were benefiting from an improving economy and potential support from government regulators. S.&P. said, however, that the banks remained weak by international standards. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday about presidential attendance at military funerals incorrectly described the 241 victims of the truck bombing at a Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983. Eighteen sailors and three soldiers were among the dead; they were not all marines.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EASTMAN KODAK CO., Rochester, the world's largest photography company, said it would sell more than 200 digital preshow marketing systems to closely held Cinema Screen Media, a supplier of advertisements to movie theaters. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Leo Burnett Worldwide To Reorganize Unit
description: Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, said yesterday that it would fold LB Works, which specializes in technology and business-to-business clients, into Leo Burnett USA, effective immediately.

title: Textile Towns Appeal for Help, But Quotas May Not Suffice
description: Even as he worries about losing his job to competitors in China, Jay Crumpton cannot really avoid doing business with China.

title: AMERCO REQUESTS MORE TIME FOR BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: Amerco Inc., owner of the U-Haul truck-rental business, asked a federal judge to extend a deadline for advancing its bankruptcy recovery plan. Amerco will amend its recovery plan by Nov. 27 to reflect an accord reached last week that would fully repay bondholders $714.6 million. A hearing to review the plan, scheduled for Tuesday, was pushed back to Dec. 12. The company asked Judge Greg Zive of United States Bankruptcy Court in Reno, Nev., to block stakeholders from proposing competing plans through Feb. 28. A hearing on final approval of the plan has been moved back to Jan. 26 from Jan. 12, said Jennifer Flachman, a spokeswoman for Amerco, which is based in Reno. U-Haul was not included in the bankruptcy filing.

title: A Hard Road for Democrats In a Day of No 'Soft Money'
description: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic National Committee chairman, found himself under the disco lights at a dance-club fund-raiser one recent evening. The total raised from 4,400 donors was about $250,000.

title: The Buck House Stops Here
description: President Bush thought he had at last found someplace even more sequestered from the real world than the Republican fund-raisers and conservative think tanks where he makes his carefully controlled ''public'' appearances.

title: Basic Failures by Ohio Utility Set Off Blackout, Report Finds
description: The largest blackout in North American history was set off by a series of human and computer failures at an Ohio power company, where workers could not act to halt an escalating crisis because they did not even know it existed, a panel of government and industry officials reported on Wednesday.

title: Chirac's anti-Semitism fight
description: PARIS:  With his condemnation of the rise of a new anti-Semitism in France, and his promises to combat it, President Jacques Chirac has conceded that his country has a troubled place among the European nations where anti-Jewish outbursts and attacks have become an undeniable and embarrassing pattern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, EDYTHE
description: ROSS--Edythe. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jerome H. Ross. Cherished mother of Lorraine Ross Goldman. Dear and adored friend of so many. A woman of elegance, indomitable strength and courage who loved life and was an inspiration to all, especially the physically disabled. A beautiful woman, an outstanding mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, whose intelligence and strength of mind fought the ravages of physical hardship always with a smile and a desire to forever love her family. Her vital presence will be deeply missed. Services, Friday, November 21, 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: House Backs Bill to Overhaul Mutual Funds
description: Responding to the spate of mutual fund scandals, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation on Wednesday aimed at deterring trading abuses and fund mismanagement, improving the disclosure of fee information and increasing the independence of fund boards.

title: Coaching in Schembechler's Shadow
description: After Chris Perry of Michigan carried the football a team-record 51 times for 219 yards in a recent victory over Michigan State, Coach Lloyd Carr was asked whether this conservative approach would please the former coach Bo Schembechler, who favored a ground-based attack.

title: Currency Fraud Ran Deep, Officials Say
description: What began with an undercover F.B.I. agent's ''posing as a bad guy with money'' led to the discovery of rigged currency trading by traders at some of Wall Street's biggest banks, federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Reports Wider 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: Qwest Communications International, the nation's No.4 local-telephone company, said yesterday that its third-quarter loss from continuing operations widened as it wrote down the value of wireless assets and terminated some contracts. The company offered to buy back $2.25 billion of debt. The loss from continuing operations widened to $686 million, or 39 cents a share, from $238 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. After a gain from the sale of its yellow pages unit, Qwest, which is based in Denver, reported net income of $1.83 billion, or $1.05 a share. Sales dropped 5.4 percent. The bond buyback would allow Qwest to cut debt to about $19 billion, from a peak last year of more than $26 billion, and save $100 million a year in interest. The company, close to filing for bankruptcy protection last year before raising $7 billion by selling the yellow pages unit, may see an increase in sales next year, the chief financial officer, Oren G. Shaffer, said on a conference call. Shares of Qwest rose 30 cents, or 8.8 percent, to $3.70 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Which Camera Is Right for You?
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Comparing the Cameras Chart: The Cameras in Focus

title: A Bigger Showroom Means More to Show Off
description: Jonathan Adler (right) introduced his now iconic striped vases nine years ago, and they have become so ubiquitous that one showed up in a car insurance commercial. (The owner successfully caught a falling Adler vase.) With the opening of Mr. Adler's new 2,000-square-foot store this week in SoHo (around the corner from his original, 350-square-foot starter shop), he gets to show a broader range. The Butterfield couch on which he sits ($2,950) is 72 inches wide, covered in super-wide-wale corduroy. (Other sizes and fabrics are available.) ''It's couture techniques at prt--porter prices,'' Mr. Adler said. His Quadra vases (in the niches) are $95 to $135. Jonathan Adler, 47 Greene Street (Broome), New York; (877) 287-1910.

title: Star's Costs Mount as Album Sales Slump
description: The charges of child molesting against Michael Jackson come at a time when the pop star who ruled the Billboard charts in the 1980's was making another effort to resurrect a career that in recent years has been battered by sharply declining album sales and costly legal judgments against him.

title: Stardom Plus Scandal In a Shame-Free Age
description: One of the oddest things about Michael Jackson is that this 45-year-old former Motown child prodigy has remained a superstar despite all the Peter Pan fantasies, Potemkin marriages, cosmetic surgery, spending sprees and now criminal charges of child molestation. He is both a popular entertainer and a tabloid freak show. In that sense he is the perfect icon for the shame-free age: a television twofer.

title: More Proof of Iraq-Qaeda Link, or Not?
description: Late last month, a top Pentagon official fired off the latest salvo in the politically charged debate about whether there were links between Saddam Hussein's government and the Qaeda terrorist network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'HARA, VINCENT FRANCIS
description: O'HARA -- Vincent Francis. Died on November 15, 2003 in Wilton, CT. as a result of metastatic cancer. At the time of his death, Vincent O'Hara was 85 years old. Vincent Francis O'Hara was born on September 26, 1918 in Goshen, NY as the third of five children born to Richard Luke O'Hara and Mary Ann Conroy O'Hara. On March 6, 1943, Vincent O'Hara married Madeline Mary Sheridan, his wife of 52 years, before her death in 1995. Vincent Francis O'Hara graduated from Fordham University in 1939 and received his LL.B. from Fordham Law School in 1946. Vincent's time in law school was interrupted by his service as Captain of a minesweeper in the U.S. Navy, Pacific Theater. After World War II, Vincent was discharged from the U.S. Navy with the rank of Lieutenant Commander and resumed his legal career. Vincent subsequently received an LL.M from Brooklyn Law School and did further work at NYU Law School. He began his legal career in the field of labor law and pension law and subsequently worked with The Martin E. Segal Co. until his retirement as President and Vice Chairman of the Board. He then worked as a consultant until 1991. In the course of his career, Vincent represented Labor Unions and worked with many of the largest Taft-Hartley Funds in the U.S. throughout his life, Vincent was known for his integrity, intelligence, generosity, humor, and devotion to his family. Throughout their lives, Vincent and Madeline stressed the importance of family by word or example, which included strong support for education and advancement of all their children. Even as his illness advanced, Vincent's concern and interests centered on his family. Until recently, Vincent enjoyed golf and tennis with his friends in Connecticut and Florida. Vincent was a lifelong member of the Catholic Church, attending Holy Spirit Parish in Stamford and St. Aloysius in New Canaan since 1966. Vincent was preceded in death by his wife Madeline Sheridan O'Hara, by his parents, his sisters Helen O'Hara and Irene O'Hara McCaffrey, and his brother James. Vincent is survived by his brother Richard L. O'Hara, his first cousin, who was like a brother, Norman Leonard, and other cousins. Vincent's family who survive him and who miss him greatly includes his six children, their spouses, and his eleven grandchildren: Patricia O'Hara Capaccio, her husband Peter Capaccio, and their children Jennifer Mennella and Peter Jr.; Gregory Francis O'Hara, his wife Beth, and their children Madeline, Logan, and Gavin; Mary Ann O'Hara de Moll, her husband Richard de Moll, and their children Ellen and Elizabeth; Vincent F. O'Hara, Jr., his wife Rosemary and their children Jesse McTiernan, Vincent, and Brendan; Jane O'Hara, her husband Robert Thompson, and their daughter Kathleen Caggiano; and Sister Ellen O'Hara, CSJ. All of Vincent's family wishes to acknowledge their love and gratitude to Mary Ann and Vincent for their extensive personal commitment to the care of our father. The family also wishes to acknowledge and thank the staff of The Green Retirement Center and the caring and professional nurses of Geron Nursing Registry for their many kindnesses and concern for Vincent in his last illness. Vincent's wake will be held at Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, CT from 6:00 P.M. to 8:00 P.M. on November 19th and 20th, 2003 and a Roman Catholic Mass Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11:00 A.M. on November 21, 2003 at St. Aloysius Church, 21 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT, followed by burial in Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan, CT.

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sniper's Ex-Wife Testifies That He Threatened Her
description: There was a time, Mildred Muhammad recalled on Wednesday, when life with her former husband, John, seemed normal, even happy. They had three young children, a thriving auto repair business in Tacoma, Wash., and a reputation for caring for children from broken homes.

title: Market Place; Lower Bid For Music Unit Could Tempt Time Warner
description: For Time Warner, the lower bid may be the better deal.

title: The Neediest Cases; Duty Calls After Sept. 11, Straining Family Finances
description: A kidney on the verge of shutting down. A home on the verge of being lost. For Kenneth and Angelean Thomas, the last few years have been one ordeal after another.

title: Reeling Giants Lose Two Starters on Defense
description: As if the task of reviving the Giants' season were not big enough for Coach Jim Fassel, he will have to do it with two fewer defensive starters after the team placed safety Shaun Williams and end Kenny Holmes on season-ending injured reserve Wednesday.

title: For Harlem Homebuyers, Prices Head North
description: TALK about having their work cut out for them. Richard Parnell Habersham II, a real estate agent with the Corcoran Group, and his colleague, Nancy Love, are charged with selling a town house in Harlem for $2.2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COURLAND, NECHAMA
description: COURLAND--Nechama. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its distinguished member, Ms. Nechama Courland, beloved sister of Raphael Courland. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Sports of The Times; Teenager Handles Adult World With Poise
description: FREDDY ADU is mature far beyond his 14 years.

title: More Megapixels For the Money
description: A LOAF of bread, a jug of wine and thousands of other consumer items: sooner or later, inflation will hit all of them. In one funny little corner of the economic universe, however, that law doesn't apply. It's consumer technology, where prices head ever downward even as power and features improve.

title: Cotton Association Selects New Agency
description: Cotton Inc., the trade association for American cotton growers and importers, said yesterday that it had dismissed its creative agency of 31 years, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, and had named DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the account. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Johnson Is Gone, So Bucs Move On
description: Near the end of Tampa Bay's loss to the Green Bay Packers on Sunday, Buccaneers wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson could be seen with his back to the field, smiling to fans at Raymond James Stadium. Several minutes after the game, Johnson was on the field posing for a photograph with two Packers.

title: Who's That Man At the Keyboard?
description: MILLIONS of children must imagine that Santa's workshop is wired to the Web.

title: Amid Embellishment and Message, a Voice of Simplicity Cries to Be Heard
description: Keep it simple. Eliminate inessentials. Cut the rhetoric. These are the principles that should be adhered to when considering ground zero. But for better or worse, we are living in baroque if not byzantine times. Some of our most impressive contemporary architecture reflects this. All eight designs chosen as finalists for a memorial of the World Trade Center disaster bear strong traces of it, to a greater or lesser degree. Each of them suffers as a result.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   METSCH, MARTIN
description: METSCH--Martin. On November 18, 2003. Civil engineer and past President of Temple Beth Abraham. Husband of Joan. Father of Richard, Cynthia, Laura Knapp and Susan. Father-in-law of Christine, and Michael Knapp. Grandfather of David, Geoffrey, Jacob and Benjamin. Services Thursday 9:30 am at Temple Beth Abraham of Tarrytown, 25 Leroy Avenue Tarrytown, NY.

title: Retailers Rise in Google Rankings as Rivals Cry Foul
description: FOR many people, ordering a gift online goes something like this: type a few words into a search engine, click on a few of the top results and place an order.

title: Bertelsmann Chairman Resigns After a Dispute
description: A rancorous dispute in the boardroom of the German media giant Bertelsmann prompted the resignation on Wednesday of its chairman, Gerd Schulte-Hillen.

title: Competing Designs Are Shimmering Elegies in Light, Water and Glass
description: SUSPENDING MEMORY

title: Praying Hands, Wringing Hands; Deaf Congregation on East Side Fears for Its Future
description: The hands are flying above the pews, middle fingers rapidly touching palms to signify the wounds, and the name, of Jesus. Fingers interlace to say ''pray.'' Palms finally close together: Amen.

title: Shirley Hazzard a Winner At National Book Awards
description: Shirley Hazzard, who twice before was a finalist for the National Book Award for fiction, won the award last night for ''The Great Fire'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), a love story set in devastated post-World War II Japan and her first novel in 23 years.

title: Edwards Admonishes Jets on Johnson
description: The Jets cannot talk to Keyshawn Johnson yet, but he was a topic of conversation during a team meeting Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: Credits in Weekend on Friday for illustrations of the new building for the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan were reversed. The site photography was by Christopher Dawson, and the digital rendering of the proposed building inserted into a photograph of the site was by Sanaa, the building's designer.

title: Plane Scare Prompts Partial White House Evacuation
description: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

title: Cabaret Law, Decades Old, Faces Repeal
description: The age-old battle between the New York of nightclubbing revelers and the New York of sleep-deprived neighbors entered a new phase yesterday when the Bloomberg administration said it would move to repeal a Jazz Age law that prohibits dancing in bars and nightclubs that do not hold special licenses.

title: A Dozen Women With Plenty to Say, and Only One to Portray Them
description: Several mothers and daughters turn up in ''Women on Fire,'' Judith Ivey's new, bewitching one-woman show, which opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater.

title: Powerful Truck Bomb Kills 5 People in Northern Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 20  A powerful truck bomb killed five people near the offices of a pro-American Kurdish group in the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk today, while the commander of American forces in Baghdad reported that a 12-day bombing campaign against suspected guerrilla bases had significantly reduced attacks on occupation troops.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Dr. Leon Pordy, a cardiologist, who became chairman of the Chock full o'Nuts coffee company, omitted the name of a survivor. She is his daughter, Melissa Pordy of Manhattan.

title: Panel Says Inspections Don't Protect Home Buyers
description: New Jersey's building inspection system is so rife with incompetence and corruption that it offers home buyers little protection from costly and dangerous construction errors, state officials said on Wednesday.

title: All Work and No Play? Not in This Home Office
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } From Web Cameras to Lilliputian Hard Disks, Desktop Staples Blur Fun and Function

title: Wish Lists Remain Just That Online
description: AT last count, Chris-Rachael Oseland, a writer in Louisville, Ky., had almost 200 books, CD's, DVD's and gadgets on her wish list at Amazon.com. Ms. Oseland uses the list, which she updates about every other week, to keep track of items she might like to buy for herself someday.

title: Senate Starts Energy Debate Under Threat Of Filibuster
description: New energy legislation encountered significant opposition on Wednesday as the Senate began debate, with Republican and Democratic critics threatening a filibuster that could prevent a chief priority of President Bush from becoming law this year.

title: Bush Hints That U.S. Might Not Reduce Troops in Iraq
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  President Bush said today that he was open to rethinking the Pentagon's plan to reduce the size of the United States military force in Iraq next year.

title: INSIDE
description: Opposing Gay Marriage

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Man Who Was Forced To Give DNA Sues
description: A Baton Rouge man who was forced to surrender a DNA sample during the hunt for a serial killer has sued in Federal District Court for damages and the return of his DNA. The man, Shannon Kohler, said the police warned him that refusing the sample could put his name in the newspapers. Mr. Kohler's suit argues that in obtaining the court order for his DNA, the police ignored information they knew could eliminate him as a suspect, like his shoe size. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: 3 Men Die After Power Line Falls on Parked Car
description: Two brothers and a cousin were electrocuted yesterday morning in West Orange, N.J., after a power line fell across a parked car outside their home, the authorities said. One victim was killed as he tried to get into the car, and the others died trying to help him, officials said.

title: Tis the Season of the DVD
description: Man, if I were a VCR, Id be nervous right about now. If the Pioneer DVD-burning TiVo that I reviewed last week is any indication, the videotape era is almost over.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: DETERMINING WHY FISH DIED The federal government said several factors, including low water levels, were to blame for the death of 34,000 fish in the Klamath River in 2002. A report from the Fish and Wildlife Service said unusually large numbers of fish crowded warm stretches of the lower Klamath, allowing deadly pathogens to spread. Environmentalists and others blamed the government's decision to divert water to farmers in the Klamath Basin, which encompasses part of Oregon and California, instead of raising river levels for fish. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: CHERRY HILL: FATHER IN STARVATION CASE GETS NEW LAWYER A man accused with his wife of starving their four adopted sons has a new lawyer. The man, Raymond Jackson, 50, will be represented by Richard Josselson, who has handled many high-profile cases in South Jersey. It was not immediately clear who would represent Mr. Jackson's wife, Vanessa, 48. Both are charged with aggravated assault and child endangerment. The announcement, by Mr. Josselson, came just days after the law firm of Liebling& Malamut said it would withdraw from the case, citing a conflict of interest that the firm would not discuss in detail. (AP)

title: Our War Dead Deserve Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, WILLIAM T.
description: SMITH--William T. Of Albany, New York, a Yonkers native and former director of the state's Division of Probation, of an apparent heart attack November 13 at his vacation home in Southbury, CT. Predeceased by his wife Lucille (Walsh) Smith, of Albany, and his sister Helen Sheehan of the Bronx. Survived by his nephews the Rev. James C. Sheehan of New York and Thomas Sheehan of Boston. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM, November 21, at Tebbutt & Frederick Memorial Home, Albany; a memorial Mass 11 AM, November 22 at Our Lady of Angels Church, Albany. Interment 2 PM, November 24 at St. Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx. For information call 518-489-4454.

title: AT WARNACO, PRESIDENT OF SPORTSWEAR GROUP RESIGNS
description: The Warnaco Group, maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Olga bras, said John Kourakos had resigned as president of its sportswear group after less than two years. Mr. Kourakos, 54, will continue to advise Warnaco as a consultant, the company said. Warnaco, which is based in New York, said last week that profit this year might lag its forecast, partly because of sluggish sportswear sales, which fell 19 percent in the third quarter. Mr. Kourakos, a former Tommy Hilfiger Corporation executive, was named president of sportswear in January 2002.

title: 'Minor' Health Problems Briefly Fell Mubarak
description: President Hosni Mubarak interrupted a nationally televised speech for some 45 minutes on Wednesday because of what were described as minor health problems, the unusual pause underscoring the fact that he has never designated a successor.

title: Conservatives Mobilize Against Ruling on Gay Marriage
description: Galvanized by a Massachusetts ruling on Tuesday allowing gay marriage in that state, representatives from half a dozen conservative groups met here on Wednesday to plan a national strategy to counter it, focusing their initial efforts on a federal constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage.

title: Tapping the Inner Cool Of a 20's Teardown
description: AT first glance, the tall red house looks brand new. On a hillside covered with stands of eucalyptus and homes from the 1920's, it has square corners, a flat roof and an angular aluminum staircase jutting from the front facade.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: PROTESTING FARMERS GIVE AWAY TOMATOES Thousands of farmers from around the country marched through Madrid to protest a European Union agreement to import cheaper produce from Morocco. They handed out crates of tomatoes and eggplants along the way and maintained that they were not to blamed for the high price of produce in stores. One Madrid resident, Julia Moreno, 68, who fought through a crowd to scoop up the free tomatoes, sold in stores for more than $3.50 a pound, said, "I've never seen such high prices in all my life." Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Embracing a Father's Creation, if Not His Tastes
description: JULIET HARTFORD has become accustomed to talking about her father.

title: Lovely Branches, Delivered Right to Your Doorstep
description: THERE is nothing quite like going to a Christmas tree farm and chopping down your own tree. (Experience allows me to tell you that you will be sore for several days, however.) Or you can visit a farm and buy a tree already cut.

title: Testimony About Bid Funds
description: A former United States Olympic Committee official testified Wednesday that he secretly contracted with Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson to assist them in Salt Lake City's campaign to win the rights to be host of the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: VIETNAM: U.S. WARSHIP ARRIVES The American missile frigate Vandegrift docked at Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, the first Navy ship to visit since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975. Watched by curious onlookers, the frigate arrived flying the flags of both countries. "We are showing the world that former foes can be friends," said Raymond Burghardt, the United States ambassador. The ship, with a crew of 215, will spend four days in port. Groups of sailors in uniform began filtering onto the streets by late afternoon, drawing stares and some friendly greetings. "Welcome to Ho Chi Minh City!" one man shouted. (Reuters)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Legal Action Over Dioxin
description: A coalition of environmental groups said yesterday that they planned to sue four chemical companies over the dumping of cancer-causing dioxins into the Passaic River for more than 20 years. The groups charged that the chemicals find their way into Newark Bay, into which the river empties, where fishermen and crabbers, either unknowingly or defiantly, harvest seafood contaminated with the chemicals and then eat it. In letters to the four companies, the groups said they would file their suit in 90 days. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Approve Expansion Of F.B.I.'s Antiterrorism Powers
description: Congressional negotiators approved a measure on Wednesday to expand the F.B.I.'s counterterrorism powers, despite concerns from some lawmakers who said that the measure gave the government too much authority and that the public had been shut out of the debate.

title: Reserve and Guard Ordered To Alert More Troops for Iraq
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld ordered an additional 15,000 Reserve and National Guard troops on Wednesday to prepare for the possibility of yearlong duty in Iraq or Kuwait, rounding out a plan to rotate American forces in the region by next spring.

title: Counting Votes and Attacks In Final Push for Medicare Bill
description: In a final blur of vote counting and deal making, Congressional negotiators raced on Wednesday to finish sweeping Medicare legislation, hoping to send it to the full House and Senate by week's end. But Democratic leaders mounted a furious new attack on the measure, assailing the endorsement by AARP on Monday as a betrayal of the organization's members and as a capitulation to the Republicans.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose a day after it fell to a record low against the euro. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1885, down from $1.1945 on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 109.30 yen, up from 108.04 yen.

title: Toward More Perfect Unions
description: On Tuesday, the highest court in Massachusetts issued a path-breaking decision, making the state the first to extend to gay couples not just many of the rights and benefits of marriage but the right to marry itself. In another sense, however, the decision is simply one more in a series of steps that have already provided legal rights to tens of thousands of same-sex couples throughout America.

title: Capture an Image. Now, Run With It.
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } With the Latest Storage Tools and Widgets, Shutterbugs Aim for Posterity

title: This Crop of Broadway Shows Is Finding Dog Days in the Fall
description: When ''Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All'' opened at the Longacre Theater on Monday night, it did so with all the pomp one expects from a big Broadway opening: the red carpet, the shouting paparazzi and, of course, a standing ovation for its star, Ellen Burstyn.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Some Tax Relief For Homeowners
description: The City Council yesterday authorized some tax relief to owners of one-, two- and three-family homes. The new rate will be $14.550 per $100 of assessed value, down from the $14.979 rate adopted in June. City officials said the change would mean a savings of about $72 a year for a $340,000 home. By contrast, the tax rate for utilities will rise slightly to $12.418 from $12.343, and for commercial properties to $11.431 from $11.333. David I. Weprin, chairman of the Finance Committee, said that the Council made adjustments every year to help single-family homeowners cope with the rapidly rising value of their homes. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Aiming at Chinese Imports, Again
description: The Victoria's Secret prime-time fashion show was broadcast last night. Neither Heidi Klum nor Tyra Banks unfurled banners protesting Washington's plans to restrict the importation of made-in-China lingerie. And that's too bad. It might have lent the vapid hour a worthier air.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Inside and Out, It's Shades of Gray
description: Catherine Memmi, who is based in Paris, has initiated the Greys, a limited-edition collection of furniture. The indoor-outdoor Lodge lounge chair ($3,004) and matching ottoman ($1,842), below, with or without casters, are of African hardwood, painted anthracite gray and sealed with varnish. There are also a low coffee table, a canopy bed and an outsized wardrobe cabinet. Catherine Memmi, 45 Greene Street (Broome Street) in New York; (212) 226-8200.

title: ATLANTIC COAST TO FLY IN 2004 AS INDEPENDENCE AIR
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines said yesterday that it was calling its new low-cost airline venture Independence Air, and that it had entered into an agreement with Airbus to buy 15 A320-family aircraft and lease 10 others to form the ''backbone'' of that operation. Last July, Atlantic Coast, which operates as a regional carrier for United Airlines, said that it planned to transform itself into a low-cost airline based at Dulles International Airport, near Washington. Atlantic Coast said late Tuesday night that its first Airbus plane would arrive in September 2004 and be ready for service by November 2004. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the expectation of protests at an international trade meeting in Miami misstated the name of the group that faced violent protests in Seattle in 1999. It is the World Trade Organization, not Association.

title: Retired Teachers Have Florida, Not the Schools, on Their Minds
description: It is hard to imagine New York City public school teachers happier than the 2,000 gathered at a luncheon yesterday who had recently retired. It was even harder to find anyone at the union-sponsored event who had anything positive to say about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, and their efforts to fix the schools.

title: Some Senators Skeptical on N.Y.S.E. Reform Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 — Senators expressed doubt today that proposed changes in the operation of the New York Stock Exchange would go far enough to end abuses and win back the faith of investors.

title: Study Warns of Lack of Scientists as Visa Applications Drop
description: The dependence on foreign-born scientists and engineers in the United States soared in the 1990's, raising questions about how the nation will sustain its technology-driven economy as competition for brainpower increases worldwide, the National Science Board said on Wednesday.

title: AT HOME WITH: Slim Aarons; Teaching the Rich To Say Cheese
description: ''THIS fireplace heats the whole house,'' Slim Aarons said, pointing to the ravenous fire warming his book-lined living room on a frigid afternoon earlier this month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Five Hurt In Fight On Train
description: Five youths were injured during a fight yesterday afternoon on a northbound No. 9 train at West 125th Street and Broadway, the police said. Two were stabbed in the torso and another was slashed in the face. The two others suffered less serious injuries. All were taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition last night. The cause of the fight remained unclear last night, but all five were charged with assault, the police said. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Thursday about a study comparing two of the cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins referred incompletely to the manufacturer of a third drug, Zetia, which helps prevent the body from absorbing cholesterol. It is made by Merck & Company not alone but in a joint venture with the Schering-Plough Corporation.

title: Explosions in Istanbul DestroyBritish Consulate and Bank;At Least 27 Killed, 400 Injured
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 20 - Two huge truck-bomb explosions wrecked the British Consulate and a British bank here on Thursday, killing at least 27 people and wounding 450 in an assault that coincided with President Bush's state visit to London.

title: 8 Designs Confront Many Agendas at Ground Zero
description: Victims' families yearned to touch the bedrock where the World Trade Center stood. Firefighters had to see their buddies' names listed together. Artists dreamed of a revelation. The fiercely protective hoped for an expression of the essential horror of the tragedy, and the spirit of the city that endured.

title: CBS Drops Jackson Show From Its Schedule
description: Reacting quickly to news of the arrest warrant issued for Michael Jackson, CBS said yesterday that it was dropping a one-hour special with the singer that had been scheduled for next Wednesday. The special was to include a rare performance by Mr. Jackson, who released a greatest-hits compilation this week, and tributes from music industry celebrities.

description: United Airlines Seeks Delay In Pension Contributions

description: Following is a transcript of the speech yesterday by President Bush at Whitehall Palace in London, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: Presenting Several Versions of the Shape of Grief and Recollection
description: Eight possible memorials at the World Trade Center site, each deferring in some way to the ghosts of the twin towers, were shown to the nation yesterday.

title: Intel Forcefully Rebuffs Skeptics of Its Advanced Itanium Chip
description: Intel delivered a forceful defense of its advanced Itanium microprocessor today, declaring the chip well on its way to success despite considerable skepticism in the computer industry.

description: Garden of Lights

title: Medicaid and Overtime Eat City's Tax Gains
description: Unexpected surges in Wall Street profits and real estate taxes have been pouring into the city's coffers, but the revenue gains have been eaten away by ballooning costs for Medicaid and increased overtime pay for municipal workers, according to figures released yesterday by the mayor's office.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: NEW MOTHER GOES HOME Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, wife of Prince Edward, left the hospital, 12 days after the premature birth of their daughter in an emergency Caesarean section. The still-unnamed baby will remain at the hospital for now, a Buckingham Palace spokeswoman said. (Reuters)

title: As Bush and Blair Speak, They Find Many Ways to Say, We Must Fight Terror
description: Following is a transcript of a news conference on Thursday by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair in London, as recorded by e-Media.

title: From Acorns (and Sticks) A Tiny Gotham Grows
description: ''SO where's City Hall?'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asked last year at the opening of the Holiday Train Show in the Victorian greenhouse at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The miniature New York City had nearly 100 landmarks -- the Apollo Theater, the Brooklyn Bridge, Edgar Allan Poe's house -- but no City Hall.

title: Carter's Style on the Ice Leaves Sather Unhappy
description: Anson Carter is perhaps the most stylish member of the Rangers, from his immaculate tailor-made suits to the dreadlocks that pile out of his helmet to the Louis Vuitton upholstery he recently had put in his car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, MARTIN
description: JOSEPH--Martin, 64, musician, teacher, and bandleader, died on November 16, 2003, due to complications from surgery. Born May 29, 1939 in the Bronx, NY, he was known as Marty Stevens, President of Marty Stevens Music. Receiving an MA in history from New York University, Marty taught history and eventually music in the New York City public school system for 25 years while continuing to perform as a musician. In 1984 he founded Marty Stevens Music, a successful orchestra specializing in private parties, weddings, benefits and corporate events. Highly respected for his integrity, musicianship, charisma and wit, Marty provided music and joy at over 4000 events in 40 years. He is survived by his wife Carol, sons Dennis and Greg, daughter-in-law Yana, and grandson Gabriel. Services were held.

title: Present Mayor And Contender Break Bread
description: It is hardly the standard procedure for potential political rivals, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Fernando Ferrer shared a dinner Tuesday night.

title: U.S. Offers $10 Million To Stop or Kill Hussein Aide
description: American officials offered a $10 million reward on Wednesday for information leading to the death or capture of a senior member of Saddam Hussein's government believed to be directing attacks against American troops.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: World Bank Increases Lending
description: The World Bank is sharply increasing lending for antipoverty programs in Nepal, where 4 out of 10 people live below the poverty line. The bank's board approved a $70 million no-interest loan, part of an estimated $190 million package for each of the next four years. The bank had been lending Nepal less than $25 million a year. It is investing more because of steps the country has taken to combat corruption, professionalize state-owned banks and give villages more control over schools and health clinics. ''In our judgment, the reforms they've implemented are remarkable,'' said Deborah Bateman, the bank's program coordinator for Nepal. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Tyco Accountant Testifies About Expenses
description: An accountant for Tyco International told jurors yesterday that she questioned expenses charged to Tyco by its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, including large tips and flowers for a Christmas party that cost $50,000.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: It's the Only One In the Married-Folks Section

title: A House on the Lake With an Unparalleled View
description: It's from the 2003 Neiman Marcus holiday catalog, but the luxury ice-fishing house, below, is reasonably priced. Custom built by Dave Anderson, a Minnesota cabinetmaker, the house is 10 feet by 24 feet, fully heated and insulated. Amenities include a 30-inch propane cook stove, a bathroom ready for plumbing, built-in queen and full beds and 120-volt wiring (meant for a generator). The interiors are knotty pine; kitchen cabinets are cedar. For those who want to haul it onto a lake, it is mounted on steel runners, and it has six fishing holes. (Sealed covers are included.) There is even an underwater camera. The base price is $27,000, not including delivery. And this being Neiman Marcus, it can be customized with as much as you can afford. (877) 966-4438.

title: Boredom Busters for the Youngest Travelers
description: WHEN the plane tickets for a cross-country trip arrived, my stomach swirled with a mixture of hope and dread. I love to travel and have no fear of flying, but I got a little queasy imagining the havoc my two young sons could wreak on a six-hour flight.

title: Nuclear Board Said to Rebuff Bush Over Iran
description: The board of the International Atomic Energy Agency appears prepared to approve a resolution on Iran's 18 years of secret work on a nuclear program that will stop short of recommending United Nations Security Council action, a setback to President Bush, senior officials from several countries said here Wednesday.

title: BUSH, IN BRITAIN, URGES EUROPEANS TO FIGHT TERROR
description: President Bush encouraged Britain on Wednesday to stand with the United States in rallying European governments and the United Nations behind a long-term campaign to defeat terrorism and bring democracy to the Islamic nations of the Middle East.

title: Top Mafia suspect / Four decades at large: Bernardo Provenzano, fugitive of '100,000 stratagems'
description: ROME  He is the invisible man of the Mafia, the alleged boss of all bosses of the Sicilian Cosa Nostra, who for the past four decades has outwitted legions of police officers and top investigators, always a step behind their prey.

title: Eason H. Leonard, 83, Architect And Managing Partner With Pei
description: Eason Harris Leonard, a founding partner and longtime reigning impresario of the Manhattan architectural firm I. M. Pei & Partners, now Pei Cobb Freed & Partners, died last Thursday in Carmel, Calif., where he had retired in 1990. He was 83 and formerly lived in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: All Sides in Liberian Conflict Make Women Spoils of War
description: On that burning hot morning, peace had already been declared in this war-beaten country, West African peacekeepers were on the ground and President Charles G. Taylor had already left the country, ushering in what was widely seen as an end to strife.

title: Turks Identify Synagogue Bombers and Look for Qaeda Link
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 19 — The authorities named two Turkish citizens on Wednesday as the suicide bombers who carried out twin attacks on synagogues here five days ago, suggesting that the country's radical Islamic movement may be reconstituting itself with inspiration, if not material help, from abroad.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Anti-Dowry Woman Weds
description: Nisha Sharma, the woman who became the talk of India when she sent her groom to prison last May for demanding a huge dowry, tied the knot in a simple ceremony that went off without a hitch. Ms. Sharma, 22, captivated Indians when she called the police on her cellphone when she heard that her groom and his family were trying to extort a $25,000 cash dowry moments before their wedding ceremony. Last week, Munish Dalal, her imprisoned suitor, filed a suit trying to block the wedding, stating that she was lawfully wedded to him. Ms. Sharma ignored the suit and went ahead with a simple wedding for 75 people. Over the past six months, she had become a celebrity, inspiring other women to resist the dowry demands of their suitors. James Brooke (NYT)

description: Lower Waters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VASILE, JOSEPH
description: VASILE--Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Vasile, associated with The Times from March 1998 until October 2003

title: Huskies Haven't Lived Up To Billing
description: With less than 12 minutes remaining in the first half of a second-round Preseason N.I.T. game Wednesday night, Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun's eyes sank toward the floor as he called a timeout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENROTH, STEVEN
description: MORGENROTH -- Steven. Born December 2, 1944, passed away November 18th in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Steve was the adored and adoring husband of Margaret (nee O'Shaughnessy) and the loving and proud father of Martin. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Carolyn and Julius, and his brother Marty. Steve's kindness, sense of humor and love of the NY Yankees will be forever part of the wife and son he cherished, his cousins Lynn, Mike, Teddy and Jon Friedman, and the many friends he has made over the years. We were lucky to have known you. The funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 23rd at 3 P.M. at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapels, 5411 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, FL. In New York, the family will receive visitors on Tuesday, November 25th from 2:30-9:00 P.M. at the Friedman residence, 50 East 89 Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: Housing Starts In October Near 18-Year High
description: Starts of new housing unexpectedly rose in October to the highest level in almost 18 years, led by record single-family home building, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Thar She Blows! Researchers Say A New Species of Whale Is Found
description: There is a new whale in the ocean, Japanese scientists reported today in the journal Nature.

title: Technology Briefing | Nanotechnology: Bill To Create Office Of Nanotechnology
description: Congress is about to send President Bush a bill creating the National Nanotechnology Coordination Office and authorizing the appropriation of $3.7 billion over the four years starting next October for nanotechnology research and development. The legislation, which Mr. Bush is expected to sign, converts an investment initiative originally established by President Bill Clinton into a continuing arm of the government. It requires the office to undergo triennial performance reviews by the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences. The first such review would also include a study of whether it is feasible to create nanoscale devices that can assemble themselves or copies of themselves molecule by molecule -- a subject of fierce debate among nanotechnology experts. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)
