description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan Warns Against Creeping Protectionism in Trade
description: In an apparent criticism of the Bush administration, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today that it was "imperative" that the "creeping protectionism" in the nation's trade policy be reversed.

title: China Threatens Retaliation in Trade Dispute With U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 20  China's vice minister of commerce threatened today to raise tariffs on imports from the United States in a steel dispute, and summoned the American ambassador to protest the Bush administration's announcement this week of plans to impose quotas on Chinese sleepwear, bras and certain fabrics.

title: Vick Has a Setback in Recovery
description: Quarterback Michael Vick had a setback in his recovery from a broken leg on Wednesday when a teammate stepped on his right foot during a morning walk-through session at the Atlanta Falcons' practice facility.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Dismissal Of Campaign Finance Complaint
description: The Federal Election Commission dismissed a campaign finance complaint against Denise Rich, the former wife of Marc Rich, a fugitive commodities trader who was pardoned by President Bill Clinton hours before he left office in 2001. The complaint, filed by Judicial Watch, a conservative watchdog group, contended that Ms. Rich donated money and furniture to the Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York in an effort to gain her husband a pardon. The commission decided last month that Ms. Rich's contributions were legal but released its ruling on Wednesday. John Files (NYT)

title: Before Gift-Giving, Gift-Thinking
description: I WAS in denial for years about my holiday shopping problem. I even convinced myself that from time to time all gift buyers ran out of ideas and became desperate enough to give a brother a sweater de-piller. Or two.

title: The Contributors
description: Product descriptions for the Holiday Buying Guide were compiled from these contributors:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEMAN, JOHN R. (JULES)
description: FREEMAN--John R. (Jules) on November 19, 2003. Beloved husband of Rita. Dear father of Helene, Sandi and Sherry. Cherished grandfather of Gracie and Elena. Services Friday, November 21, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 417 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Greenpoint Fire Guts Half-Block And Displaces 29 Families
description: A half-block of a quiet tree-lined neighborhood of immigrant families was gutted by flames yesterday morning, leaving dozens of people in Brooklyn homeless.

title: Allan J. Erslev, a Trailblazer In Anemia Research, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Allan J. Erslev, who identified a hormone that is now widely used in its synthetic form to treat anemic disorders, and abused to enhance athletic performance, died on Nov. 12 at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 84.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sirius Plans To Raise $154 Million In Stock Sale
description: Sirius Satellite Radio, the nation's second-biggest satellite radio broadcaster, plans to raise about $154 million in a stock sale as part of a plan to increase capital and have its receivers distributed in more cars. The sale, to be underwritten by UBS Securities, is expected to close next Monday, Sirius said yesterday in a statement. It priced the 73.2 million common shares at $2.10 each and said it expected proceeds of about $150 million after paying investment banking fees. In August, Sirius said it would raise as much as $500 million for debt reduction and capital spending. Sirius reimburses automakers like Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler for engineering and hardware costs to install radios. Shares of Sirius fell 12 cents, or 5.5 percent, to $2.10.

title: From Around the World, Artists and Architects Who Rose to a Challenge
description: Dual Memory

title: Devils' Unbeaten Streak Reaches 10
description: Buffalo goaltender Martin Biron lifted his stick the way a butcher hoists a meat cleaver and swiftly slammed it on top of the net. He then flipped the broken stick toward the middle of the ice, as if nothing could help him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGEMACH, WINIFRED (NEE FARRELL)
description: UNGEMACH--Winifred (nee Farrell). A bright light with a spiritual sense of the positive and of self - expression. www.ungemach.com/ win.htm

title: For a Construction Project Underneath West Street, the Long Line of Opposition Forms Here
description: Grass-roots campaigns are usually won when people speak loudly and often -- emphasis on often -- and that is what opponents to the West Street tunnel did yesterday.

title: From Around the World, Artists and Architects Who Rose to a Challenge
description: Inversion of Light

title: The Syncretism of Tai Chi and Bach
description: With its silvery mirrored surfaces and trickle of water across the stage, there is no doubt about the stunning theatricality of ''Moon Water,'' the New York premiere that the choreographer Lin Hwai-min is presenting with his Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Saturday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Gas Contract Awarded
description: Petrleos Mexicanos, Mexico's government-owned oil monopoly, awarded a $265 million contract to a consortium led by Petrleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, of Brazil to dig for gas in a field close to the Texas border, a Pemex spokesman said. The Teikoku Oil Company of Japan and D&S Petroleum of Mexico are the other two members of the consortium, which won when Pemex disqualified a competing group that included the China National Petroleum Corporation. This is the fourth such contract Pemex has awarded. Two of them were won by the Petrobras consortium and two others were declared void when the bidders pulled out. A final contract will be settled in January.

title: South Africa Approves Plan to Offer Free AIDS Medication
description: The South African government approved on Wednesday a long-awaited plan to distribute free antiretroviral medication to millions of citizens infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUSHING, JUSTINE BAYARD (NEE CUTTING)
description: CUSHING -- Justine Bayard (nee Cutting) on Saturday, November 15, 2003. Loving mother to three daughters, witty Granny to six grandchildren & three great-grandchildren. Memorial service Wednesday, November 26, 11 am, the Chapel of St George's Church, 209 East 16th St, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 23 about plans for a Marriott Courtyard Hotel near the 125th Street Metro-North station in Harlem misspelled the surname of the architect. He is Enrique Norten, not Norton.

title: Michael Jackson Faces Arrest On Charges of Child Molesting
description: Law enforcement officials announced here on Wednesday that they had issued an arrest warrant for Michael Jackson, the pop singer, on multiple counts of child molesting, opening a perilous new chapter in a life of global fame, untold riches and increasingly bizarre behavior.

title: Sorenstam Hopes to End Memorable Year in Style
description: Excuse Annika Sorenstam if a part of her is sorry to see 2003 end.

title: Massachusetts Ruling on Gay Marriage Bolsters Hopes in New Jersey
description: Gay and lesbian couples who want to marry lost a round in New Jersey two weeks ago, but the Massachusetts Supreme Court's ruling that same-sex couples have the right to marry is expected to bolster the New Jersey case as it goes to a higher court.

title: Satoru Masamune, 75, Creator Of Ways to Synthesize Molecules
description: Satoru Masamune, who developed a wide array of techniques for synthesizing organic molecules, including antibiotics, died on Nov. 9 in Newton, Mass. He was 75.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Protesting Farmers Give Away Tomatoes
description: Thousands of farmers from around the country marched through Madrid to protest a European Union agreement to import cheaper produce from Morocco. They handed out crates of tomatoes and eggplants along the way and maintained that they were not to blamed for the high price of produce in stores. One Madrid resident, Julia Moreno, 68, who fought through a crowd to scoop up the free tomatoes, sold in stores for more than $3.50 a pound, said, ''I've never seen such high prices in all my life.'' Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: China Protests U.S. Limit on Textiles
description: The Chinese government gave a temperate response on Wednesday to the Bush administration's decision to limit the growth of imports of certain Chinese fabrics and garments, with the Chinese contending that the move violated free trade principles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAJOR, LASZLO
description: BAJOR--Laszlo. On November 8, 2003. A memorial service will be held at Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, (between 9th & 10th Sts), Thursday November 20, 11AM.

title: Information's Pleasures
description: To the Editor:

title: 9/11 Commission Orders New York to Hand Over Documents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  The federal commission investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks announced today that it had subpoenaed New York City for a variety of police tapes and other material about the attacks. It said that the city's refusal to hand over the material had "significantly impeded the commission's investigation."

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sensing Shiites Will Rule Iraq, U.S. Starts to See Friends, Not Foes
description: The Bush administration, which was wary earlier this year of installing a government dominated by Shiites in Iraq, has concluded that such a development is virtually inevitable and not necessarily harmful to American interests, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, ESTHER K.
description: DAVIS--Esther K., formerly of Savannah, Georgia and Brooklyn, New York. Died peacefully on November 17, 2003 in her 101st year. She is survived by Harold and Isabelle, Barry, Georgie and Lowell, Jill and Lenny, Lewis, Ben, Eric, Jonathan, Steven, Brian, L. Grant and Jack. The services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINS, ALLAN
description: LEVINS--Allan. Suddenly on November 15. Son of Rose and Benjamin Levins. Donations may be made to the Sierra Club, 116 John St., NYC.

title: A PC Salesman Who Pushes The Right Buttons
description: HARALD LEVENTHAL has little patience with the sales clerks at computer stores, who often seem to know less about the products they sell than he does.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by the producers of the musical ''Bounce'' against bringing it to Broadway this season misspelled the surname of a star. He is Howard McGillin, not McGillan.

title: Rule to Protect Traders Disrupts Thailand
description: The efforts by Thailand's prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, to prevent the country's boom from turning into a bubble have put him and Thailand's brokerage firms at odds with the country's securities regulator.

title: Groups Demand Dioxin Study in Bay, Too
description: NEWARK, Nov. 19  A coalition of environmental groups said on Wednesday that they planned to sue four chemical companies for dumping cancer-causing dioxins into the Passaic River for more than 20 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Posts Profit
description: Zurich Financial Services, the insurance company, posted its third consecutive quarterly profit after selling businesses, cutting costs and raising premiums. Net income was $701 million in the third quarter after a loss of $763 million a year earlier. The company also added $354 million to reserves at its Centre unit. Asset sales added $311 million before tax to earnings in the first nine months and added about $1 billion to shareholder equity, meeting a goal. The Centre unit, which sells reinsurance and asset management products, lost $488 million in the quarter.

title: Delay in YankeeNets Breakup Makes Bidders for Nets Wait
description: A meeting of the YankeeNets board, at which four bids to acquire the Nets were to be presented, was postponed yesterday because a long-awaited agreement to split up the YankeeNets was not completed in time, two officials involved in the transactions said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the aftermath of an investigation into ChevronTexaco in Hawaii referred incorrectly to Ben Cayetano, the former governor, who raised objections about the state's choice of a law firm. He was prohibited from running again in 2002 because of term limits; he did not lose an election.

title: From Around the World, Artists and Architects Who Rose to a Challenge
description: Reflecting Absence

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: MAN WHO WAS FORCED TO GIVE DNA SUES A Baton Rouge man who was forced to surrender a DNA sample during the hunt for a serial killer has sued in Federal District Court for damages and the return of his DNA. The man, Shannon Kohler, said the police warned him that refusing the sample could put his name in the newspapers. Mr. Kohler's suit argues that in obtaining the court order for his DNA, the police ignored information they knew could eliminate him as a suspect, like his shoe size. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Lakers Bring Their Circus To Midtown
description: WEIGHTED by the turmoil of criminal allegation and internal disputation, the Lakers hit Madison Square Garden last night feeling the burden of expectation. Losers of their previous three road games, burned in the fourth quarter Tuesday night in Detroit, the Lakers were presented with the wobbled and hobbled Knicks and a Broadway opportunity to reinflate their sense of super self-worth.

title: Chemistry, Alchemy: Lakers Still Get It Done
description: They will not be hanging out together on the Lakers' day off, but from their chemistry in Los Angeles's shellacking of the Knicks last night it seemed that Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant have moved beyond their past problems.

title: Keeping the Power Humming When the Lights Go Out
description: I WAS just outside the blackout area in August, but I may have been a victim nonetheless. My clue that something had gone wrong came when I found that my computer was acting strange, a TV had died and my digital clocks needed to be reset.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police To Have Access To Interpol Files
description: The city's Police Department will soon have access to a new computer database on terrorists and criminals as part of a pilot program with Interpol, the two agencies announced yesterday. The New York police will be the first municipal police force in the United States to have direct access to Interpol's new encrypted communications network, known as I-24/7, which includes information on suspected terrorists, international fugitives and stolen travel documents.

title: Critic's Notebook; Unguarded Lyrics Embarrass Eminem
description: Hip-hop listening sessions are usually pretty dull affairs. It's hard to enjoy any hip-hop album when you're trapped in a conference room with a bunch of media professionals. But when executives from The Source, a hip-hop magazine, asked reporters to attend a listening session on Tuesday night, they weren't expecting people to have a good time. ''This is a very important evening,'' said David Mays, the magazine's co-founder and chief executive. And then, through some rather feeble speakers, he played a profoundly poor hip-hop track from about a decade ago, maybe longer.

title: A Plan to Postpone Pension Financing At United Airlines
description: United Airlines is devising a plan to postpone about $2 billion of required pension contributions over the next three years, having concluded that doing so is the only way to bring the airline out of bankruptcy.

title: A Victory for Gay Marriage
description: ''Without a doubt, this is the happiest day of our lives,'' declared Gloria Bailey, a 62-year-old Cape Cod resident. Ms. Bailey and her partner were two of the plaintiffs in this week's landmark Massachusetts ruling that says gay people have the right to marry. When the rights of disadvantaged groups are newly recognized, there is often opposition, some of it fierce, and the road ahead may be rough. But like the early court rulings striking down segregation, this has the feel of a legal revolution beginning.

title: Hey, That Big Computer Is Really a Great Actor
description: In hindsight, Richard Dresser says, the commission was a painful test for a playwright, and he took it only because he thought nothing would ever come of it. But then the project landed a grant, and he was faced with what he had promised to do: write a seven-minute play about the interplay between man and technology, without live actors, to be told through machines to one person at a time.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Overture Stops Selling Ads To Unlicensed Pharmacies
description: Overture Services has stopped selling search-related advertising to unlicensed online pharmacies, in response to concern about illegal drug sales over the Internet. Overture, the commercial search subsidiary of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that it had filtered the last of its advertisements related to online pharmacies or pharmaceutical drug sales on Monday, and it notified advertisers over the weekend that it would cease selling the ads.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Increased Patrols In High-Crime Areas
description: In a new initiative meant to curb violent crime, 1,000 police officers assigned to desk jobs will move out of the office and into the field in December. The officers will be required to patrol high-crime areas for one week out of every five to help reduce the number of killings related to the drug trade. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: China Warns
description: China has bluntly warned Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, that ''the use of force may become unavoidable'' if Taiwanese leaders pursue efforts toward formal independence. The threat seemed to reflect a growing concern among Chinese leaders over recent moves by Mr. Chen and came from Wang Zaixi, vice minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office. Mr. Wang, whose comments were reported in the state-run news media, added that separatists ''are set to pay a high cost if they think we will not use force against their conspiracy to promote formal independence.'' Mr. Chen, who is running for re-election in March, has advocated a redrafting of the Constitution and called for legislation that would allow national referendums. China believes his real agenda is to push for eventual independence. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Debate Over Brain-Damaged Woman
description: Defending his order to reinsert a brain-damaged woman's feeding tube against her husband's wishes, Gov. Jeb Bush said in court papers that he had not violated the privacy of the woman, Terri Schiavo, because she had left no written directive regarding her wishes. Lawyers for the husband, Michael Schiavo, said that argument flouted the state's right-to-die law. Mr. Bush also requested a jury trial in which he could present evidence on whether Mrs. Schiavo, 39, would want to be kept alive artificially, and on whether his order protected or violated her rights. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article last Thursday about a study comparing two of the cholesterol-lowering drugs known as statins referred incompletely to the manufacturer of a third drug, Zetia, which helps prevent the body from absorbing cholesterol. It is made by Merck & Company not alone but in a joint venture with the Schering-Plough Corporation.

title: The Medicare Bill: A Good Thing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Turks Identify Synagogue Bombers and Look for Qaeda Link
description: The authorities named two Turkish citizens on Wednesday as the suicide bombers who carried out twin attacks on synagogues here five days ago, suggesting that the country's radical Islamic movement may be reconstituting itself with inspiration, if not material help, from abroad.

title: The Old College Try
description: Highlights from this week's forums, including opinions about N.F.L. draft rules and the Massachusetts decision on gay marriage.

title: Iran Balks at Nuclear Accord in Effort to Blunt Criticism
description: VIENNA, Nov. 20  The International Atomic Energy Agency's debate about how to deal with Iran's 18-year-long effort to conceal its nuclear programs got off to a sputtering start here today.

title: Irving Berlin, American
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Catholic Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODERICK, PATRICIA (NEE BIOW)
description: BRODERICK--Patricia (nee Biow). Cherished partner of Jack Wesley. Beloved wife of the late James. Devoted mother of Martha, Janet Kraft and Matthew. Dear sister of Richard Biow. Loving grandmother of James, Alexis, Zachary, Hannah, and James Wilkie. Memorial service to be announced. For further information please call the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 212-674-8055.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Names Executive
description: The bank and insurer ING Group said that it had appointed Michel Tilmant as its chairman and the successor to Ewald Kist. Mr. Tilmant has been serving as vice chairman of the executive board. In June, he will succeed Mr. Kist, who has been chairman since 2000 and will soon reach the standard retirement age of 60. Mr. Tilmant, 51, is also chairman of the executive committee of ING Europe and chairman of ING Bank.

title: U.S. Suit Accuses Credit Counselor of Deception
description: The Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint yesterday accusing AmeriDebt, a large service operating as a nonprofit credit counselor, of deceptive practices that masked high fees and connections to for-profit enterprises.

title: Dallas Comes to Terms With the Day That Defined It
description: Days after President John F. Kennedy and Lee Harvey Oswald were gunned down in this city in November 1963, Brig. Gen. Herbert A. Hall, retired in Tucson, folded a large, beribboned certificate into an envelope and mailed it to the mayor of Dallas, Earle Cabell.

title: The Most Sensational Deal In the Bermuda Bowl Finals
description: The World Championships, which ended on Saturday in Monaco, were a triumph for the United States, winning three major titles: the Bermuda Bowl, with Nick Nickell, Richard Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, with Sidney Lazard as nonplaying captain; the Venice Cup, with Kathie Wei-Sender, Betty Ann Kennedy, Sue Picus, Jill Levin, Janice Seamon-Molson and Tobi Sokolow; and the Senior Bowl, with Gaylor Kasle, Roger Bates, Steve Robinson, Kit Woolsey, Garey Hayden and Grant Baze. The Americans also won two sets of bronze medals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No Toast For The Winner
description: He was just one of 40,000 Russians who die each year from alcohol poisoning, but he won a prize for it. In an all-you-can-drink contest, a food store in the southwestern city of Volgadonsk handed out half-liter mugs and invited contestants to fill them from a barrel of vodka, according to the newspaper Sobesednik. A man named Aleksandr Nakonechny drank the most -- three mugs -- but then dropped dead. Four other contestants were hospitalized. It was not clear who claimed Mr. Nakonechny's prize of 10 bottles of vodka. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: National Briefing | West: California: Determining Why Fish Died
description: The federal government said several factors, including low water levels, were to blame for the death of 34,000 fish in the Klamath River in 2002. A report from the Fish and Wildlife Service said unusually large numbers of fish crowded warm stretches of the lower Klamath, allowing deadly pathogens to spread. Environmentalists and others blamed the government's decision to divert water to farmers in the Klamath Basin, which encompasses part of Oregon and California, instead of raising river levels for fish. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: A Family of Entrepreneurs
description: If you belong to a certain extended family in Seattle, you're probably an entrepreneur. It seems to be about the only career many of the members ever considered.

title: The Answer, My Friend, Could Be Remastered Dylan
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } From Satellite Radio to Phones to Online Stores, Music Is Everywhere, and Endlessly Repackaged

title: PBHG Founders Could Face Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York attorney general could take action against the founders of PBHG Funds, as well as the firm itself, as early as today, according to people briefed on the investigations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Rush Limbaugh's return to his radio program after treatment for addiction to painkillers referred incorrectly to his analysis of political opponents. He said he had learned in treatment that he tried too hard ''to be liked,'' and later said one problem with liberals was that ''they don't like themselves.'' But he did not say he had tried to incorporate what he had learned about himself and use it to psychoanalyze opponents.

title: Why Blair Took the Risk Of Making War on Iraq
description: HUG THEM CLOSE

title: You Gotta Have Friends
description: So I step off the plane in London and the British customs guy sees on my form that I'm a journalist and asks, ''Is it true there are more police to protect your president in London than there are in Baghdad?'' Then I pick up The Independent to read in the taxi and I see that London's left-wing mayor, Ken Livingstone, has denounced President Bush as ''the greatest threat to life on this planet that we've most probably ever seen.'' Then I check out The Guardian, which carried open letters to the president, one of which is from the famous playwright Harold Pinter, who says: ''Dear President Bush, I'm sure you'll be having a nice little tea party with your fellow war criminal, Tony Blair. Please wash the cucumber sandwiches down with a glass of blood.''

title: Gays' Victory Leaves Massachusetts Lawmakers Hesitant
description: The Massachusetts legislature was awash in turmoil and indecision on Wednesday as lawmakers struggled to come to terms with the meaning of the court ruling that legalized gay marriage in the state.

title: Origins of a Blackout
description: The technical and managerial ineptitude of one Ohio power company, FirstEnergy, appears to have been the primary cause of last August's vast power failure, which cut off electricity to tens of millions of people in eight states and parts of Canada. There is consolation in knowing that we can attribute the blackout to sloppiness rather than, say, sabotage. Nevertheless, yesterday's report from a joint U.S.-Canadian task force raises broader questions about the management of power nationwide. Some of the questions are addressed in legislation before Congress. Others need further attention.

title: St. Nick Has Spoken: You Can Take It With You
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Wireless Technology and the Shrink Factor Stretch the Limits of Portability

title: A Season of Magic at Boise State
description: Until now, Boise State has been known more for the color of its artificial turf than the caliber of its program. The Broncos' recent success, however, has people looking beyond the blue Smurf Turf to a team that is inching closer to the upper echelon of college football.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Professor Suspended From Research
description: A professor at the University of Washington has been suspended from research on laboratory animals after an internal committee found many violations of animal protection guidelines. The professor, Chen Dong, published an article in the Journal of Clinical Investigation without university approval for his research and subjected laboratory rats to undue suffering by clipping their tails without anesthesia, said Susanna Cunningham, chairwoman of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. The current issue of the journal includes a retraction by Dr. Dong, whose field is immunology. He said he did not understand the complexities of the animal welfare rules. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Recycling Endangered Species of Jokes
description: Ruth Gottschall, Cheryl Stern, Darrin Baker, Robert Creighton and Barry Finkel are the five performers in ''Laughing Room Only'' who put in an honest day's work. They're the singers and dancers who are charged with surrounding the star, keeping his ego inflated and occasionally, when he needs a break from repeating his old routines, putting on the musical vaudeville numbers that make up most of the show's original material. It isn't their fault that this is some of the trashiest musical comedy material ever written for the Broadway stage. They deserve credit -- and their paychecks -- for their professional pluck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, SAM
description: KLEINER -- Sam. Fisher Brothers mourns the passing of our dear counsel, Sam Kleiner. For over two decades, he was our invaluable partner, confidant and most importantly, great friend. Beside being a skilled and knowledgeable attorney, Sam was an astute, fair-minded businessman, profoundly respected by all. Our hearts go out to his wife, Darlene, his five sons, Jeremy, Benjamin, Kenneth, David and Christopher, his two granddaughters, Karson and Devon, as well as his mother, Betty Kleiner, and his sister, Hannah Weise. Sam was taken from us all too soon. His warmth, gentleness, wisdom and pure sweetness will never be forgotten. Fisher Brothers Arnold Fisher Richard L. Fisher Ken Fisher Steven Fisher Winston C. Fisher

title: Caruso's Tenor, a Century Later; Memorabilia Shown at the Metropolitan Honors a Legend
description: He was, they say, the greatest tenor who ever lived. He was the first blockbuster recording artist, at a time when relatively few people even owned record players and a record cost more than a ticket to the opera. He was the subject of scandal: in 1906, an ambiguous encounter with a woman in the monkey house of the Central Park Zoo -- he said a look, she said a pinch -- landed him in court and in international headlines. He sang at the Metropolitan Opera more than any other artist of his day: more than 800 times in 18 seasons, in a range of roles nearly unthinkable today. His name is still invoked as a synonym for greatness, long after many people have forgotten what he actually sounded like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTER, SAMUEL PORTER WILLIAMS
description: CARTER--Samuel Porter Williams, 76, died November 16. He is survived by his son, daughter-in-law, two grandsons, two brothers, sisters-inlaw and seven nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife Margaret on July 1, 2003. Funeral service at 1 PM, November 23 at Irvington Presbyterian Church, 21 N. Broadway, Irvington NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE A.
description: TISCH--Laurence A. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Faculty at Suffield Academy are deeply saddened by the death of Laurence Tisch. Laurence brought vision, leadership and a kind heart to the world. We are proud that his four sons and one of his grandsons are Suffield Academy alumni: Andrew 1967, Daniel 1969 (a member of Suffield's Board of Trustees), James 1971, Thomas 1972 and Michael 2002. Suffield is forever grateful for Laurence's friendship and generosity. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Billie and the entire Tisch family. The Suffield Academy Community

title: Glamour in the Windows and on the Ceilings at Bergdorf
description: The holiday season is getting the full glamour treatment at Bergdorf Goodman. Linda Fargo (above left), the store's vice president for visual presentation and imaging, has been in charge of its windows for seven years. Her book ''Dreams Through the Glass'' ($50, Assouline) is out today, and so are this year's holiday windows. Ms. Fargo is known for the extravagant, dreamlike quality of her displays, like the 1998 window for clothes by Chlo and Jean Paul Gaultier (above, right). ''I try to invoke that feeling of enchantment that's difficult to capture for an adult,'' Ms. Fargo said. The windows will include the Crystal Palace chandeliers from Swarovski, shown as a group for the first time in this country. New models from Diane Von Furstenberg and Ted Muehling will be in the store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRITTENHAM, RAYMOND L.
description: BRITTENHAM--Raymond L. The Officers, Directors and Staff of The Tinker Foundation Inc., express their deep sorrow at the death of Mr. Raymond L. Brittenham. Mr. Brittenham was a steady rock in the early years of the Foundation's development. He continued his stewardship for thirty-six years as its Secretary, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1999. He will be sorely missed and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his widow, Mrs. Brittenham, and their children.

title: Protestors Rally Against Bushs Visit to London
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  Tens of thousands of demonstrators in Trafalgar Square cheered and whistled today as a papier-mache effigy of President Bush, painted gold to resemble the toppled statue of Saddam Hussein, was yanked to the ground at a peaceful rally.

title: After Bombings in Turkey, Bush and Blair Remain Steadfast
description: LONDON, Nov. 20  President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair today defiantly pledged no retreat from combating terror or stabilizing Iraq after bombers struck British targets in Turkey in the middle of Mr. Bush's state visit to Britain.

title: Metro Matters; School Contract? One of the 3 R's Has to Be Regret
description: WELL, it was a good try. But it was impossible to listen to days of recent testimony on school union contracts before the City Council's Education Committee without thinking that the most potentially revealing witnesses were missing: the mayors, chancellors and city and school negotiators of times past.

title: Getting Into College
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEMESHNIK, WILLIAM
description: LEMESHNIK--William. Patriarch, husband, father, grandfather, great - grand father, brother, uncle, friend. Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY 11:30AM, November 20.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The people have given us the duty to defend them, and that duty sometimes requires the violent restraint of violent men. In some cases, the measured use of force is all that protects us from a chaotic world ruled by force.''

title: Iraq and the Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: POLICE TO HAVE ACCESS TO INTERPOL FILES The city's Police Department will soon have access to a new computer database on terrorists and criminals as part of a pilot program with Interpol, the two agencies announced yesterday. The New York police will be the first municipal police force in the United States to have direct access to Interpol's new encrypted communications network, known as I-24/7, which includes information on suspected terrorists, international fugitives and stolen travel documents.

A Little Digital Something for Everyone

title: Metro Briefing | New York: North Amityville: Girl, 13, Is Shot Accidentally
description: A 13-year-old girl was in critical condition last night after her cousin accidentally shot her in the face, the Suffolk County police said. The cousin, who was not identified because of his age, found a semi-automatic pistol in a locked box in his father's bedroom, pried the box open and was showing off the gun when it went off, the police said. The bullet struck the girl, Malika Holland, in the left side of her face. She was taken to Stony Brook University Hospital. The boy's father, Frederick Miley, 39, of North Amityville was charged with illegal possession of a weapon and endangering the welfare of a child. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Novartis to Give Consumer Ads a Big Role in Selling Drugs
description: Novartis, the Swiss drug giant, said at an investor conference yesterday that it intends to rely increasingly on advertising to consumers to wring more sales out of its current crop of big sellers.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Root Knowledge

title: In Pepsi's new campaign, the drink goes with everything except celebrities and lifestyle issues.
description: THE cola wars are taking an unusual twist as the Pepsi-Cola Company division of PepsiCo introduces its first campaign in years meant to offer rational reasons to drink its flagship beverage rather than intangible emotional ones.

title: IONICS WILL BUY ECOLOCHEM FOR $338 MILLION
description: Ionics Inc., a water-purification and treatment company, has agreed to buy closely held Ecolochem Inc. for $338 million to gain customers in the power and petrochemical industries. The offer includes $200 million in cash and $138 million in stock, Ionics said. The company, which is based in Watertown, Mass., expects the purchase to close early next year and to add about 14 cents a share to 2004 profit before some costs. Ecolochem is based in Norfolk, Va.

title: Hewlett-Packard Rebounds To Beat Forecasts in Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company supplied reassuring evidence yesterday that its business was back on track when it reported quarterly sales and profits that modestly surpassed Wall Street's expectations.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged in Gunfight That Killed 8-Year-Old Boy
description: A 19-year-old man from East New York, Brooklyn, has been charged with felony murder in connection with a gun battle on Monday that resulted in the death of an 8-year-old boy.

title: Chandigarh Journal; Sleepy City Has High Hopes, Dreaming of High Tech
description: Thirty years after a ''green revolution'' turned the plains around this small city into India's breadbasket, a cadre of ambitious government officials, pricey consultants and local high technology entrepreneurs is trying to accomplish something almost as ambitious -- transforming this sleepy farm state capital into the ''technology hub of northern India.''

title: First Group Of Refugees Has Returned Home to Iraq
description: A first, small convoy of 69 Iraqi refugees returned home on Wednesday, after months of negotiations with allied forces in Iraq, the office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees said.

title: On Eve of Trip to U.S., Schrder Gets Mandate From Party
description: Two numbers seem to define the political fortunes of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder as he heads to New York on Thursday for meetings intended to convince American businessmen that Germany is back, at least economically.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Qurei Trying to Halt Attacks Against Israel
description: The Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, opened his first major initiative on Wednesday since his swearing in last week, traveling to the Gaza Strip in an effort to persuade Palestinian factions to halt attacks against Israel.

title: Gold Prices Decline as the Dollar Rebounds
description: Gold futures fell in New York yesterday, retreating after rising beyond $400 an ounce, as the dollar rebounded from a record low against the euro, making gold more costly for European buyers.

title: Lawyer Faces New Charges Of Giving Support to Terrorist
description: Federal prosecutors filed new charges yesterday against the defense lawyer Lynne F. Stewart, who had succeeded in getting a federal judge to dismiss earlier charges that she had helped one of her clients, a convicted terrorist, pass messages from prison.

title: At Least 25 Killed, 320 Hurt in Attacks on Bank and Consulate
description: Explosions blasted the British consulate and the international bank HSBC in Istanbul today, and a television station reported that more than two dozen people were killed in the blasts, which were so powerful that they sheared the face off the buildings and rocked nearby houses.

title: Cable Network Buys College Sports Web Site
description: The fledgling cable network College Sports Television has agreed to buy the Official College Sports Network, a Web site, for $7.1 million. The Web site, the largest focused on college sports, had 7.5 million different visitors last month.

title: Castles in the Sky
description: How the other 0.1 percent flies.

title: Explosions in Turkey
description: At least 27 people were killed when two blasts rocked Istanbul on Thursday.

title: Bombings in Turkey
description: Two explosions rocked Istanbul on Thursday, one at the British consulate and the other at the British international bank HSBC.

title: Legally Wed
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Perspectives
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Two Teenage Girls and a Swimmer, Staking Out Territory in a Triangle
description: The shy Taiwanese teenagers caught in a romantic triangle in Chih-Yen Yee's tender wisp of a film ''Blue Gate Crossing'' may be nave and virginal, but their innocence doesn't prevent them from succumbing to acute romantic anguish. The movie inevitably reminds you of the life-and-death gravity of your own crushes at an age when the world seemed to depend on the bestowal or withholding of a chaste peck on the lips.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC To Sell Internet Calling Service To Businesses
description: SBC Communications Inc., the second-largest local-telephone company, is selling Internet-based calling and data services to businesses nationwide in an effort to stem declines in revenue. The service, which uses voice-over-Internet-protocol technology to let users make calls from personal computers, is available in 18 cities, SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said in a statement. Such calling is unregulated and can be less expensive for carriers and customers. SBC said its new service included local and long distance and would extend to the markets of other regional-phone companies by year's end.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Wednesday about the closing of ''Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All'' after a single performance on Broadway misspelled the surname of the author of the novel on which the play is based. He is Allan Gurganus, not Gurganis.

title: INSIDE
description: Founders of Fund Company Are Accused of Fraud

title: Theodore Roszak
description: Zabriskie Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLAK, HELEN FIELD
description: POLLAK--Helen Field. Postgraduate Center for Mental Health notes with profound sorrow the loss of Helen Field Pollak, wife of our esteemed Trustee, Alan H. Pollak. Helen, who passed away on November 12, was a great friend of the agency who donated much time and energy to help us. We will miss her advice and support. We express our heartfelt sympathy to her husband and children. Aniello A. Bianco, Chairman Dr. Jacob Barak, President and CEO

title: Gays and Marriage in America (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Queer Brain Behind 'Queer Eye'
description: FIRST he slaps a racy black beret over his fashionably bald pate, which boasts just the faintest horseshoe of hair around the perimeter, all of it well tended. Then he switches to a striped yarn skullcap that riffs off the color scheme of his multistriped socks and Tsubo techno-sneakers: David Collins, 36, compact, gay and comically extroverted, puts on his best leer and flashes an over-the-top thumbs-up for the camera. Does he look like a big-shot television producer, or what? Click, click, click. He's a natural ham. A hot one. Hatless again, he rubs his bare head with his palms as if consulting a crystal ball, which is precisely what, in regards to the public's appetite for new television shows, it has functioned as.

title: Saturdays Top Matchups
description: All Times Eastern

title: Writer Run: Early Years Of the Updike Marathon
description: THE EARLY STORIES -- 1953-1975

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about a $2 million reward offered by the United States for the capture of Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, misspelled the name of the Nigerian city where he moved after resigning on Aug. 11. (The error also appeared in an article on Sept. 18 about the way Mr. Taylor enriched himself.) The city is Calabar, not Calaba.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Fraud Charges For Lawmaker
description: State Senator Gary R. George has been indicted on two counts of conspiracy, one accusing him of defrauding the state and the other of accepting more than $400,000 in kickbacks. Mr. George, who is a Democrat, and his personal lawyer, Mark E. Sostarich, are charged with bilking social welfare agencies out of hundreds of thousands of dollars, including $50,000 from the Police Athletic League for youths. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: International Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Second Arrest In Boy's Murder
description: A law enforcement offical confirmed the arrest last night of a second suspect in the East New York murders of 8-year-old Daesean Hill and Michael Walker, 23. The official said that detectives believe that the suspect, Rasheem Malik, 16, of Barbey Street, Brooklyn, had been firing a .22 caliber pistol in a shootout that led to the killings on Monday evening. Daesean was struck with a larger caliber bullet. On Wednesday, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced the arrest of Jarrell Perry, also of Barbey Street, who he described as a marijuana dealer. He said that that Mr. Perry and two other marijuana dealers had opened fire on a rival group of dealers in front of the Hill residence. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: City To Promote Bank Services
description: The city is dangling the prospect of up to $10 million in city bank deposits for banks and other financial institutions to encourage them to open branches in neighborhoods with few or no branches. Under the program, which was announced yesterday, banks that accept the municipal deposits will pay the city a reduced interest rate, but will offer discounted loans and other services to local communities. The city has set aside $100 million for the program. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the offer in Red Hook, one of six areas selected for the program. The others are the South Bronx, Sunset Park in Brooklyn, South Central Harlem, Roosevelt Island and St. George on Staten Island. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FOOT LOCKER REPORTS HIGHER PROFIT AND DEAL WITH NIKE
description: Shares of Foot Locker rose 13 percent yesterday after third-quarter profit topped analysts' forecasts and Nike agreed to restart shipments of some of its most popular sneakers, ending a dispute that has hurt both companies' sales. Foot Locker shares climbed $2.46, to $20.76. Nike rose $1.41, to $62.60. Nike said that by late next year it would again begin supplying Foot Locker with some of its so-called launch products, popular shoes that are introduced with advertising campaigns.

title: Parties Square Off Over Hearing on Donations
description: The Committee on House Administration voted today to give its chairman, Bob Ney, subpoena authority after six Democratic witnesses declined to appear at a hearing to examine the impact of last year's campaign finance law.

title: Warning Issued on Grasshopper Treats
description: The salty fried grasshoppers known as chapulines generally disappear quickly from the shelves of bodegas across the region. But New Jersey health officials issued an advisory this week saying that the grasshopper treats, from Mexico, might have dangerously high levels of lead.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section on Monday about corporate programs that match employee donations referred incorrectly to a figure for such donations cited by John Taylor, vice president for research and data services of the Council for Advancement and Support of Education. The figure, $164 million, was the amount of corporate matching funds given to 789 insitutions of higher education surveyed by the Council for Aid to Education, a separate group. It did not represent the amount given in matching funds to all colleges and universities.

title: Seeking a Reconciliation While Racing the Alzheimer's Clock
description: Here is a tear-jerker that earns its tears.

title: Demonstration Turns Violent at Trade Talks in Miami
description: Several dozen violent protesters clashed with the police just 200 yards from a trade ministers' meeting on Thursday as more than 10,000 demonstrators held a peaceful march to protest President Bush's push to create a free trade zone throughout the Americas.

title: Houses With Wood-Burning Stoves: The Warmth of Tradition
description: WHO -- William Corcoran, 74, lawyer

title: Turkey Arrests Suspects in 2 Bomb Attacks in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 21  Turkish authorities said today that they had arrested several people in connection with two huge truck-bomb explosions that killed 30 people in Istanbul, while foreign governments warned of more attacks. Three separate groups apparently linked to Al Qaeda have claimed responsibility for the bombings on Thursday.

title: Meteor Seen As Causing Extinctions On Earth
description: About three dozen minuscule shards of rock unearthed in Antarctica may be the fragments of a meteor that killed most life on Earth 250 million years ago, scientists are reporting today.

title: An African Diaspora Show Asks: What Is Africanness? What Is Diaspora?
description: Diaspora -- the exile or emigration of a group of people from their homeland -- is an idea that probably has little immediate resonance in the New York art world. Why should it? The city may be multiethnic, but its main gallery neighborhoods remain tight enclaves of mostly British-American art.

title: TAX REFUNDS WILL PUSH UP EXXON MOBIL PROFIT
description: Exxon Mobil said yesterday that its profit this quarter would increase by $2.2 billion as a result of refunds from a settlement of a dispute over tax deductions for natural gas sales. The settlement, reached with the Internal Revenue Service, followed three trials on the issue in which Exxon Mobil prevailed, the company said. The refunds will be for tax payments from 1976 through 1990 and were related to sales made mostly in Texas.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Acquiring Art Inventively

title: U.S. Considers Food Labels With Whole-Package Data
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it was considering whether to require food companies to list nutrition information in its entirety, rather than by serving size, on packaged-food labels.

title: Big Board Overhaul Plan Faulted
description: Republican and Democratic senators pressed the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday to consider significantly revising the New York Stock Exchange's recent overhaul proposal by either making the exchange's regulatory apparatus more independent or taking it over entirely.

title: J.P. Williams, 88, Bank Card Creator, Dies
description: Joseph P. Williams, who as a Bank of America executive in the 1950's came up with a revolutionary forerunner of all national bank credit cards, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Atlantis, Fla. He was 88.

title: FORD PLANS TO INVEST IN PLANTS IN MICHIGAN AND OHIO
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would invest as much as $325 million at plants in Michigan and Ohio to produce a new, more fuel-efficient transmission. The spending includes $170 million for a factory in Livonia, Mich., and $155 million for a plant in Sharonville, Ohio. The transmission, a rear-wheel-drive, six-speed automatic version, increases efficiency as much as 8 percent compared with a four-speed model, Ford said. Most of the new transmissions will be used in trucks and S.U.V.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, SAM
description: KLEINER -- Sam. Fisher Brothers mourns the passing of our dear counsel, Sam Kleiner. For over two decades, he was our invaluable partner, confidant and most importantly, great friend. Beside being a skilled and knowledgeable attorney, Sam was an astute, fair-minded businessman, profoundly respected by all. Our hearts go out to his wife, Darlene, his five sons, Jeremy, Benjamin, Kenneth, David and Christopher, his two granddaughters, Karson and Devon, as well as his mother, Betty Kleiner, and his sister, Hannah Weise. Sam was taken from us all too soon. His warmth, gentleness, wisdom and pure sweetness will never be forgotten. Fisher Brothers Arnold Fisher Richard L. Fisher Ken Fisher Steven Fisher Winston C. Fisher

title: How Long a Drive? 'Finding Nemo' or 'Harry Potter'?
description: EARLY this month, my family set off for a six-hour drive to a hockey tournament in Lake Placid, N.Y. As I loaded snacks, CD's and coloring books into our S.U.V., my children -- ages 11, 9 and 6 -- looked on woefully.

title: Avidly Dissected, the Eight Design Finalists Provide a Blueprint for Compromise
description: At some point, there will be a winner.

title: Mexicos Ambassador to the U.N. Resigns
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 21  Mexico's ambassador to the United Nations, who was due to be relieved of his post on Jan. 1 for criticizing the United States, resigned abruptly on Thursday. He accused the administration of President Vicente Fox of caving into pressure from the Bush administration, which he said had lobbied for his ouster.

title: Network Offers Spot in Studio
description: Keyshawn Johnson, Tampa Bay's unhappy and deactivated wide receiver, will appear on Fox's National Football League studio program on Sunday, and could be a contributor through the rest of the season.

title: An Alternate History
description: Nigel Hamilton, author of ``J.F.K.:Reckless Youth'' and ``Bill Clinton: An American Journey,'' is a visiting fellow in the McCormack Graduate School of Policy Studies, University of Massachusetts, Boston.

title: Residential Real Estate; Cold Call Leads to Philip Johnson Project on East Side
description: It is safe to assume that few designs for luxury high rises start with a cold call, but that is how Roy Stillman and Martin Levine, developers of a new 32-story condominium at East 90th Street and Third Avenue, first reached Philip Johnson and his partner, Alan Ritchie.

title: G.O.P. to Run An Ad for Bush On Terror Issue
description: After months of sustained attacks against President Bush in Democratic primary debates and commercials, the Republican Party is responding this week with its first advertisement of the presidential race, portraying Mr. Bush as fighting terrorism while his potential challengers try to undermine him with their sniping.

title: Freed From Conspiracy
description: In considering John F. Kennedy at this 40-year remove, the ultimate ''what if'' may involve what America might be like had the country been denied the president's violent death, with its long psychic burden, instead of the rest of his life.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: WEST ORANGE: LAB TO STUDY FATAL POWER LINE The high-voltage power line that led to the electrocution deaths of three members of one family was sent to a laboratory yesterday for study, according to Public Service Electric and Gas, the operator of the transmission line. "We just don't know at this point what happened," said Karen Johnson, a company spokeswoman. She said the utility had found no recent reports of trouble with the 7,600-volt line. At 4:15 a.m. on Wednesday, the line snapped and fell onto a parked car, setting it on fire and touching off its alarm. It is believed that Jose A. Pena-Rivera, 25, was electrocuted as he opened the car door; that his brother, Elmer, 28, died when he touched Jose; and that their cousin, Saul Lardaverde, 21, died when he touched Elmer. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Officials in Georgia Declare Shevardnadze Ballot Winner
description: The Central Election Commission of Georgia announced Thursday that supporters of President Eduard A. Shevardnadze had won a disputed parliamentary election held on Nov. 2, heightening tensions in the capital, Tbilisi.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Seeks To Terminate Ferry Captain
description: New York City has begun the formal process to fire Michael J. Gansas, the captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed Oct. 15, killing 10 people. A spokesman for the Transportation Department, Tom Cocola, said last night that taking Captain Gansas off the payroll was the first step in a multi-tiered grievance procedure than began last week when a department hearing officer recommended that he be terminated for failing to cooperate with the inquiry. Officials at the time said that Captain Gansas had invoked his Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination. Captain Gansas had been suspended without pay since Oct. 22 for failing to speak to investigators. The 30-day suspension would have ended today. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, ALAN
description: ROSENBERG -- Alan. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Helene, Stacy, Andrew and family. Alan was a great leader and admired by all in our industry. He was a prince and will be missed. Larry, Andrew and the entire Gans Family

title: My, a Cat Can Be Mean On a Very Big Screen
description: In 1957 Dr. Seuss published ''The Cat in the Hat,'' a whimsical story of feline misrule written in infectious four-beat anapestic lines, that forever changed the way American children learn to read. The book's rambunctious main character and its giddy, slightly disconcerting treatment of mischief in the absence of maternal supervision have proven remarkably durable as generations of children have grown to adulthood with its antic rhymes firmly lodged in their heads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMEN, MICHAEL
description: KAMEN--Michael. A loving friend and extremely talented composer, whose scores enriched motion pictures, and who brought the joy of music to children everywhere through the Mr. Holland's Opus Foundation, which he founded with his brother John. We will miss his humor, his generosity and his kindness. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Saundra and their children, and to his father and brother. Martin Richards and The Producer Circle Co.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Wednesday, about Letitia James, who won a City Council seat on the Working Families Party line, misstated the name of a Hasidic-based political group that supported her. It is the Crown Heights Political Action Committee -- not Jewish Political Action Committee.

title: Gays and Marriage in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: DoubleClick Plans $100 Million Stock Buyback
description: DoubleClick Inc., the biggest Internet-advertising services company, said yesterday that it might buy back as much as $100 million of its stock after the shares dropped by almost a third since mid-October. That represents as many as 11.8 million shares, or about 8.5 percent of the common stock outstanding, based on DoubleClick's closing price yesterday. The repurchases will be made with cash and marketable securities, which totaled $662 million as of September, DoubleClick said in a statement. Shares of DoubleClick climbed 46 cents, or 5.4 percent, to $8.97.

title: Classical Music and Dance Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about a $2 million reward offered by the United States for the capture of Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, misspelled the name of the Nigerian city where he moved after resigning on Aug. 11. (The error also appeared in an article on Sept. 18 about the way Mr. Taylor enriched himself.) The city is Calabar, not Calaba.

title: Viewer Interest Slipping for Notre Dame Games
description: NBC's six telecasts of Notre Dame's home football games this season tied for the worst ratings in the 13 years it has been showing the games.

title: Opponents of Medicare Bill Say AARP Has Conflicts
description: Seeking to discredit the AARP's endorsement of the Medicare bill now before Congress, opponents of the bill are pointing to what they say are the group's financial stakes in the legislation.

title: Courbet's Vivid Sense of Natural Truth
description: ''The past is useful only as education,'' the painter Gustave Courbet (1819-1877) wrote to his friend the social theorist Pierre-Joseph Proudhon in 1863. ''One must use only the present in one's works. Banish the mysterious, the miraculous, don't believe in the incomprehensible.''

title: Lee Mingwei -- 'Project 80'
description: Museum of Modern Art, Queens

title: Hearing Splits on Public Help For a Proposed Office Tower
description: The prospect of another skyscraper sets off a hue and cry in many Manhattan neighborhoods, but rarely in the glass-and-steel canyons along the Avenue of the Americas or 42nd Street.

title: Confession From the Other Side of the Wall
description: There was a voice through the vent between their cells. The man was saying they shared something: problems with informants.

title: Colleges Rarely Delve Into Spiritual Issues, Students Say in Poll
description: Most college students searching for the meaning of life are not getting direction from many of their professors, according to a survey of students at 46 colleges and universities released yesterday.

title: An Alternate History
description: When John F. Kennedy became the 35th president of the United States, on Jan. 20, 1961, a singular moment was felt to have arrived in postwar history: the first president to have been born in the 20th century, and the youngest ever elected to the Oval Office.

title: Trade Talks In Miami End Early
description: The United States and Brazil abruptly called an early end on Thursday to talks aimed at creating a 34-nation trade agreement in the Western Hemisphere after concluding there was little left to discuss here aside from a vague framework that allows officials to continue negotiating.

title: Quarterback Surprises And Lifts Southern Cal
description: Matt Leinart looks back on his most painful moment this season as the time he began to realize that he had won the job as Southern California's starting quarterback for good.

title: Worst Show On the Air? It Could Be The Knicks
description: Watching the Knicks on the MSG Network is like an elective course in torture. The Knicks used to be a must-see. Now they're a stay-away, except for those riveting news conferences when Don Chaney inexplicably receives another extension to his coaching contract.

title: Latest Merger Makes It Clearer Than Ever: Hartford Is No Longer the Insurance Capital
description: Tucked into this week's announcement of a merger between two insurance companies, the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation and the St. Paul Companies, was the news that the consolidated company will move its headquarters to Minnesota, removing another chess piece from Hartford's already diminished board. Within two years, the city once known as the insurance capital of the world will be the home office of just two major insurance corporations.

title: McGreevey Tells Local Officials There Are Too Many of Them
description: Warning that escalating property taxes threaten to strangle New Jersey's economy and undermine its quality of life, Gov. James E. McGreevey challenged the state's municipal leaders on Thursday to reduce the size of local government by consolidating services and merging some small school districts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Those who bloodied this holy day and massacred innocent people will account for it in both worlds. They will be damned until eternity.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, ALICE JUNE (NEE BARASCH)
description: HARRIS--Alice June (nee Barasch). On November 20, 2003. Beloved wife of Robert, devoted mother of Claudia and Debra, cherished grandmother of Bret, (and Jennifer), April and Benjamin and revered by her sons-in-law Stephen and Mark. Our love of this wonderful woman will always live on in our hearts. Donations may be made to Hospice of Naples, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL.

title: A Realist Who Morphed Into an Unrealist
description: Starting with a modest camera received as a wedding present, Aaron Siskind (1903-1991) became one of the greats of American photography, noted for the abstract imagery that linked him with painters of the New York School. His gestural compositions, made from markings, shredded posters, sign and graffiti fragments on flat walls, crossed the line between photography and painting. They influenced today's recognition of photography as an art equal to that made with brush and canvas.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about a $2 million reward offered by the United States for the capture of Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, misspelled the name of the Nigerian city where he moved after resigning on Aug. 11. (The error also appeared in an article on Sept. 18 about the way Mr. Taylor enriched himself.) The city is Calabar, not Calaba.

title: Slain Frenchwoman Buried in Afghanistan
description: A 29-year-old French refugee worker, killed on Sunday by a suspected Taliban gunman, was buried Thursday in the British Cemetery in Kabul in accordance with her wishes to be buried in Afghanistan.

title: Dr. Arthur L. Colwin, 92; Studied Fertilization Process
description: Dr. Arthur L. Colwin, part of a husband-and-wife team of biologists who helped uncover the complex process that takes place when a sperm cell and an egg cell merge to form a fertilized egg, died on Nov. 1 at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Kurilovo Journal; From Village Boy to Soldier, Martyr and, Many Say, Saint
description: Shoulders back, chest out, the young soldier stands as if on parade in his camouflage fatigues -- his boots polished, his rifle at his shoulder, a halo around his head.

title: Back-Seat Battle Cry: We Want Our Car TV!
description: ONCE, road bingo, reading and rummy were about all that parents had to keep children occupied on long car trips. Now, the back seat is becoming a rolling multiplex with the help of video gear from VCR's to satellite TV systems. Page 8.

title: A Band-Aid for the Fund Industry's Broken Leg?
description: What is the best way to fix what is wrong with mutual funds? The House of Representatives has offered a grab bag of options in a bill approved on Wednesday. But the bill may not sufficiently address the short-term trading abuse at the heart of the scandals that have come to light since September.

title: Despite All, British Bank Plans to Stay in Istanbul
description: LONDON, Nov. 20 — HSBC, the British bank, said Thursday that several of its employees may have been killed in attacks on two of its buildings in Istanbul, but that it would not pull out of the country. The bank said it had no details on its casualties, but some reports put the number of dead at 3, with 30 wounded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACOMBER, WILLIAM B., JR.
description: MACOMBER--William B., Jr. 82, died peacefully on November 19th in Nantucket of complications from Parkinsons. Loving husband, brother and uncle. Survived by his wife Phyllis and brother John. He served in WWII as a Marine officer in the OSS. Parachuted into France on two occasions to work with the French underground and later in Burma. He was a firm believer in public service, working in various congressional, AID and state department posts including Ambassador to Jordan, Turkey and as Under Secretary of State for Management. Upon leaving the State Department in 1977, he became President of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He retired to Nantucket and taught social studies at the high school and helped coach their football team, the latter being one of his great joys. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Macomber Family Scholarship at Phillips Academy, Andover, MA or the Nantucket Atheneum, PO Box 808, Nantucket, MA 02554

title: Gajin Fujita
description: Kravets Wehby

title: Rock With Dazzling Light Designs: Shades of the 60's
description: Bulletin from the front: the 60's never died! But to judge from SonicVision, the 38-minute sound-and-light extravaganza on view every Friday and Saturday night in the planetarium (excuse me: the Rose Center for Earth and Space) at the American Museum of Natural History, it may have faded away just a bit.

title: Marchers In London Denounce Bush Visit
description: Tens of thousands of demonstrators in Trafalgar Square cheered and whistled Thursday as a papier-mch effigy of President Bush, painted gold to resemble the toppled statue of Saddam Hussein, was yanked to the ground at a peaceful rally.

title: Brazil's Environmentalists Crying Foul
description: The environmental movement celebrated when Luiz Incio Lula da Silva was elected Brazil's president in October last year. More than a year later, though, that relationship is in danger of falling apart, with environmentalists talking of betrayal.

title: Disney Earnings Rise Sharply, Driven by Film and Cable TV
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, reflecting a surge in profit from its film and cable television businesses that far outweighed lackluster results from its theme parks and the ABC television network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPP, DAVID
description: RAPP--David. The Board of Directors, faculty and students of Yeshiva and Mesivta Toras Emes mourn the loss of the late David Rapp. A''H, son-in-law of our beloved president Mr. Lester and his wife Esther Klaus. Our sincere and heartfelt condolences to his wife Fraidy and children Menachem, Shimshon, Zvi Yehuda, Raizy and Bashie. May they be consoled amongst all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alan Zelinger, Baruch Singer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALCHIK, MEL
description: PALCHIK--Mel, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Lawrence, New York passed away November 19th surrounded by his loved ones at the age of 78. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend Toby. He will remain forever in the hearts of his children and cherished by his grandchildren. Donations in his honor should be made to cancer care.

title: Freddie Mac Restates Its 3-Year Profits Higher by $5 Billion
description: In a long-awaited announcement, Freddie Mac , the nation's second-biggest source of mortgage financing, restated its profits today for the last three years, raising them by $5 billion.

title: Chaney Looks for Williams To Show More Consistency
description: After Frank Williams's breakout game Wednesday night, Knicks Coach Don Chaney wanted to see him excel Thursday in a near-empty gym with no one keeping score. Williams, a reserve point guard who had a career-high 14 points in the Knicks' loss to the Los Angeles Lakers, satisfied his coach during a low-intensity scrimmage at the team's training facility.

title: Roy Lichtenstein
description: City Hall Park, City Hall and the Tweed Courthouse

title: Following an Addict on Her Uphill Road to Redemption
description: One of the saddest moments in ''Acts of Worship,'' a mercilessly gritty portrait of a drug addict scrounging for herself on the streets of the Lower East Side, is the moment when Alix (Ana Reeder), as she is called, badgers her boyfriend, Mark (Christopher Kadish), into scalping their tickets for a basketball game at Madison Square Garden to pay for drugs. The decision immediately sours a rare moment of tenderness between them.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: More Inmates Than Beds
description: Crowding in state prisons is at its worst in 40 years, leading officials to begin double-bunking inmates in cells. If the prison population continues to increase, the state says it will house inmates in prison classrooms and recreation areas. The system, meant to house 16,000 prisoners, is holding 22,000 inmates. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: For an Optimist in Romance, A Salute From His Opposite
description: In the middle of her splendid new cabaret tribute to Frank Loesser, Andrea Marcovicci quotes a character from Neil Simon's ''California Suite'' as complaining, ''You're worse than a hopeless romantic; you're a hopeful one.''

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: MORE INMATES THAN BEDS Crowding in state prisons is at its worst in 40 years, leading officials to begin double-bunking inmates in cells. If the prison population continues to increase, the state says it will house inmates in prison classrooms and recreation areas. The system, meant to house 16,000 prisoners, is holding 22,000 inmates. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Thomas Suozzi's Excellent Idea
description: A recent report that New Yorkers pay the highest local taxes in the country sent a lot of local politicians into the stratosphere. The Nassau County executive, Thomas Suozzi, was one of them. Like most people, Mr. Suozzi blamed the state government, which passes politically popular legislation and then sends the unpaid bill down the feeding chain to the cities and counties. He said at a conference last week that Albany had become such a ''horrible, rotten, terrible broken system'' that he now believes in term limits for state legislators.

title: E Pluribus Unum: Independence but No Great Diversity
description: The paradox of American opera houses is the independence of the institutions, one from another, and yet the almost identical cultures that each seems to produce. I like the independence: communities producing art for themselves are the beginning of wisdom for the classical music business. Even if I don't like the sameness, there isn't much to do about it.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Chicago gossip columnist Irv Kupcinet on Nov. 11 referred incompletely to his weekly television show. It began on CBS as ''At Random'' but later moved to ABC as ''Kup's Show.''

title: Penalty Phase of Sniper Trial Nears End
description: Prosecutors urged a jury here on Thursday to sentence John A. Muhammad to death for the sniper attacks in the Washington area, arguing that the crimes were not only depraved and wantonly vicious, but also an inspiration to terrorists worldwide.

title: Friendly Jabs Between Sapp And Strahan
description: Warren Sapp had been waiting on the set in Tampa Bay, shifting in his chair, not smiling once as his time ticked away. Finally, Michael Strahan strode into the lunchroom at Giants Stadium, carrying all the frustrations of the day and the week with him. He sat down, grabbed the N.F.L. Network microphone while an earpiece was stuck into his ear and exchanged a few seconds of small talk with Sapp.

title: Florida Governor Suspends Supervisor of Troubled Broward Elections
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida on Thursday suspended Broward County's embattled supervisor of elections, in a highly unusual move that the governor called necessary to protect the voting rights of county residents.

title: A Sportsman Who Hunted Fine Design
description: Anyone who visits Newport, R.I., looks through the imposing iron gates of the private mansions called ''summer cottages,'' longing to know what's inside. In some ways such houses have more cachet than the Newport Preservation Society properties because they are still occupied. Starting today, those of us with our noses against the gates can finally view the contents of one of these great homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENROTH, STEVEN
description: MORGENROTH -- Steven. Born December 2, 1944, passed away November 18th in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Steve was the adored and adoring husband of Margaret (nee O'Shaughnessy) and the loving and proud father of Martin. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Carolyn and Julius, and his brother Marty. Steve's kindness, sense of humor and love of the NY Yankees will be forever part of the wife and son he cherished, his cousins Lynn, Mike, Teddy and Jon Friedman, and the many friends he has made over the years. We were lucky to have known you. The funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 23rd at 3 P.M. at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapels, 5411 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, FL. In New York, the family will receive visitors on Tuesday, November 25th from 2:30-9:00 P.M. at the Friedman residence, 50 East 89 Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: Michael Jackson Is Booked on Molesting Charges That He Calls Lies
description: Michael Jackson, with his hands cuffed behind his back, was led into the county jail here on Thursday afternoon and booked on charges of child molesting, beginning what promises to be one of the biggest legal spectacles in years.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review in Weekend on Friday about a new translation of ''Don Quixote'' misstated Samuel Johnson's opinion of Milton's ''Paradise Lost.'' Johnson said that ''no man ever wished it longer,'' not shorter.

title: In Shylock vs. Antonio, a Ray of Hope for a Pitiable Soul
description: In the Pearl Theater Company's ''Merchant of Venice,'' Shylock certainly makes the most of his day in court, and all the days before, and that makes this production a sometimes troubling experience. Shepard Sobel, the company's founder and the director here, accomplishes this transformation by focusing our attention more intently than usual on the confrontations between Shylock and Antonio, the merchant of the title.

title: Sports Briefing
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Congress Appears Set to Reverse F.C.C.
description: Advocates of strict limits on ownership of television stations expressed confidence on Thursday that Congressional negotiators would resist White House pressure to allow broadcast networks to buy more local stations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Inquiries Into Journalists' Deaths
description: The police are investigating 18 cases of killings of journalists, according to the deputy interior minister, Aleksandr Chekalin. The press watchdog group Reporters Without Borders has called Russia the most dangerous country in Europe for working journalists. Last month the editor of The Togliatti Review was murdered, just 18 months after the killing of his predecessor. In the southern city of Togliatti alone, six journalists have been killed since 1995. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Boston
description: HISTORICALLY, Boston looms large, but geographically it's just a bean of a town: 51 square miles, with more than 20 distinct neighborhoods crammed cheek by jowl, with pricey Beacon Hill and gritty Chinatown facing off across Boston Common, high-brow art museums just a stroll from Fenway Park.
