That rich density makes even a short walk rewarding, and the beginning of the end of the Central Artery-Tunnel Project (a k a the Big Dig) scheduled for completion in 2005, has created the possibility of quick entries and exits. POOJA BHATIA

title: Now, The Fusionistas
description: IN a spotless Manhattan exercise studio, 30 people are drenched in sweat, limbs shaking from a workout that mixes yoga, weight lifting, Pilates and a little ballet. Cut to a skier in the middle of a backcountry run, sailing off a cliff and then throwing his skis over his head in a 360 revolution, landing a trick usually confined to the terrain park. Or switch the channel to Fox Sports Net, where the latest Gen Y action show serves up a mix of sports, music from bands like Audioslave and travelogues on things like kiteboarding in Austria.

title: 9/11 Memorial's Multiple Goals Leave New Yorkers Divided
description: It is not a war memorial, exactly. Or maybe it is. It is a grave site, but it should not feel like a graveyard. It must honor the dead, but it should be for the living. It will list the names. But it must express far more.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Hospital Suspends Gastric Surgery
description: The Roger Williams Medical Center in Providence has indefinitely suspended all gastric bypass operations after a man died in surgery on Tuesday. The hospital performs 200 bypasses a year. The operation promotes weight loss in severely obese people by rerouting the small intestine and reducing the size of the stomach. A 38-year-old woman died last month at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston when a staple gun misfired in surgery. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Committee Details F.B.I.'s Reliance on Killers
description: A report issued yesterday by the House Committee on Government Reform gave the fullest accounting to date of the F.B.I.'s use of murderers as informants in Boston for three decades and its protection of them even to the point of allowing innocent men to be sentenced to death.

title: So We're Admitting Our Mistakes . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Founders of Fund Group Accused of Fraud
description: Regulators filed accusations of fraud yesterday against Gary L. Pilgrim and Harold J. Baxter, the founders of PBHG Funds, saying the men allowed two investors to trade billions of dollars in and out of their mutual funds even as they discouraged others from such trading and acknowledged that it caused harm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELULA, JEROME D.
description: GELULA--Jerome D. On November 20, 2003, after a long illness. Devoted husband of Maryann. Memorial service for the immediate family will be held at a later date. The family will sit Shiva at the Gelula home on Saturday, 7pm9pm, and Sunday, 2pm-5pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Nantucket Cottage Hospital, 57 Prospect St, Nantucket, MA 02554.

title: Noche Flamenca
description: Lucille Lortel Theater

title: Record Producer Phil Spector Is Charged in Death of Actress
description: Phil Spector, the record producer whose lush orchestration helped create some of the biggest pop music hits of the 1960's, was charged on Thursday with murder in the shooting death of an actress at his hilltop home last February.

title: Rivers Hired as Lead Analyst by ABC
description: Doc Rivers was hired yesterday by ABC Sports as the lead analyst for its National Basketball Association broadcasts. Rivers, who was fired Monday as the coach of the Orlando Magic after a 1-10 start, will work with Al Michaels on select regular-season games and the playoffs, and with Brad Nessler on other games.

title: Dull Finishes That Are Slick
description: How do you stand out in a sea of high-gloss hot rods? Go dull.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHINDLER, JOE P.
description: SCHINDLER--Joe P. On November 20, 2003 at the age of 76. Beloved father, grandfather, son and friend passed away after a long and valiant fight with multiple myeloma. Born 1927 in Berlin into a prosperous merchant family. In the mid 1930s the decision to escape the Nazi government, the family started on an odyssey that would take them from Antwerp, Belgium to Nice, France trying to stay a step ahead of the pursuing German forces. This flight, which would last several years, was punctuated with local schooling that allowed the young Schindler to become fluent in French as well as German. After Nice became untenable the family was able to enter the safety of America. Mr. Schindler finished high school in the U.S. and entered Brooklyn Polytech in 1945. Shortly after starting his freshman year he was drafted into the U.S. Army where he served with distinction in Korea. After his release from the service, Joe Schindler returned to Brooklyn Polytech and received his BEE degree with honors in 1950. He then entered the electronics industry, earned his Masters degree in electronics engineering at night, and over the years became a world renowned expert in the field of microwave components and test equipment. As one of the few trilingual experts in the field of this new technology his advice was sought by companies all over the U.S., Western Europe and Japan. Along the way he was a top executive for NARDA Microwave and General Microwave in New York, as well as President of Polarad Electronics also of New York. In later years he founded Schindler Communications in Great Neck, NY that supplied esoteric microwave components to European electronic companies charged with maintaining military microwave systems. 43 resident of Great Neck. Survived by his children, Deborah, Rachel and Aaron, son-in-law Todd Thaler and granddaughter Emma Thaler. We will deeply miss his guidance, leadership, strength, wisdom and love. Funeral service Sunday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Joseph Michaeli Multiple Myeloma Research Fund at the New York Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Medical Center, attention Ruben Niesvizky, M.D. or American Jewish Committee.

title: So We're Admitting Our Mistakes . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush and Blair Say Bombings Fortify Resolve
description: A grim President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged defiantly Thursday to continue the fight to combat terror and stabilize Iraq, only hours after two coordinated truck-bomb attacks on British targets in Istanbul.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: SECOND ARREST IN BOY'S KILLING A law enforcement offical confirmed the arrest of a second suspect last night in the fatal shootings of Daesean Hill, 8, and Michael Walker, 23, in East New York on Monday. The official said that the suspect, Lawrence R. Malik, 16, of Barbey Street, was with Jarrell Perry on Monday evening and fired shots in a confrontation with rival drug dealers. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced Mr. Perry's arrest on Wednesday, saying that Mr. Perry and two other marijuana dealers had opened fire on a rival group of dealers in front of the Hill residence. The police said Mr. Walker had a gun in his hand when he died. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Move to Halt Cuts in Aid For College
description: A change in the government's financial aid formula that would force millions of students to pay more for their college educations will probably be suspended while lawmakers look for other options, Congressional leaders said yesterday.

title: 'El Leyton'
description: Directed by Gonzalo Justiniano

title: Catholic Center at N.Y.U. Won't Be Moved
description: The Catholic Center at New York University has won a reprieve.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Pipeline Investment
description: Europe's largest natural gas supplier, Gazprom, will spend 232 billion rubles ($7.9 billion) next year to increase exports by upgrading pipelines. The government approved the investment program yesterday, a Gazprom spokesman, Sergei Kupriyanov, said. Gazprom plans to increase gas exports to Europe 4.5 percent to 140 billion cubic meters next year, enough to supply France, Germany and Spain.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: West Orange: Lab To Study Fatal Power Line
description: The high-voltage power line that led to the electrocution deaths of three members of one family was sent to a laboratory yesterday for study, according to Public Service Electric and Gas, the operator of the transmission line. ''We just don't know at this point what happened,'' said Karen Johnson, a company spokeswoman. She said the utility had found no recent reports of trouble with the 7,600-volt line. At 4:15 a.m. on Wednesday, the line snapped and fell onto a parked car, setting it on fire and touching off its alarm. It is believed that Jose A. Pena-Rivera, 25, was electrocuted as he opened the car door; that his brother, Elmer, 28, died when he touched Jose; and that their cousin, Saul Lardaverde, 21, died when he touched Elmer. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: MetroCards For New PATH Stop
description: PATH passengers heading to New Jersey from the newly reopened World Trade Center station will be able for the first time to use MetroCards to pay for the ride. But only cards carrying a fixed value -- as opposed to those that allow unlimited passage for a certain amount of time -- will work in the PATH turnstiles, which will deduct $1.50. There will be no charge to passengers boarding at the World Trade Center station from 2 p.m. to midnight this Sunday, when the Lower Manhattan station opens for the first time since Sept. 11, 2001. All of the 12 other PATH stations will be equipped with MetroCard-friendly turnstiles beginning next year, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When the pinot noir hails from Tasmania and the falafel comes with kangaroo meat, you know you're being taken to the far end of the known culinary universe. Public, the latest addition to the crowded and quirky assemblage of restaurants and boutiques in NoLIta, is an extreme example of Antipodean fusion cuisine, and it comes courtesy of two New Zealand chefs, Peter Gordon and Anna Hansen, who own the Providores in London. They've brought over Brad Farmerie, their head chef at the Providores, to form a triple team in the kitchen.

title: Weekender | Dorset, Vt.
description: WITH its uniformly white clapboard houses trimmed in forest green or black, superbly situated on expansive lawns and with the occasional stallion cantering in the meadow, Dorset exudes an understated elegance. ''It has a sophisticated edge to it,'' said Andy Serafen, director of investments at Oppenheimer & Company in Atlanta, who with his wife, Jan, bought a four-bedroom house on 35 acres for $950,000 last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEAVY, EDWARD T.
description: LEAVY--Edward T. November 21, 1979. In loving memory, Your Children and Grandchildren

title: In the Balance: Attacks on Turkey Aim to Sever a Bridge Between Islam and the West
description: Turkey's worst fears were realized Thursday when the second major bomb attack in a week confirmed that this land has become a new battleground in the struggle over terror.

title: Nation-Building in Iraq: Lessons From the Past
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  James Dobbins has long been one of those troubleshooters who never seem to miss a crisis.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cotton Yarn Futures Trading To End
description: The Osaka Mercantile Exchange will close Japan's last cotton yarn futures market because of waning interest. Trading in cotton yarn futures will be suspended on Dec. 1 and will formally end in April 2004. Cotton yarn futures trading started in Osaka 110 years ago, hit its peak after World War II and declined steadily though the 1990s as textile production moved offshore. Trading in other commodities will continue. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: In A Different Sort Of Hot Water
description: Some criminals with substance abuse problems may do time in a sauna if the Corrections Department can finance a pilot program, Second Chance. It originated in Mexico, where drug problems are rampant in prisons, Charles King of the addiction services division of the department said. Officials plan to seek an $800,000 federal grant to pay for group and family therapy, educational workshops, vitamin supplements and detoxifying time in saunas. The theory behind the sauna is that some drugs, including cocaine and heroin, stay in fatty tissues and have to be cleansed out. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Richard Perle's Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Professors' Group Chooses Ex-SUNY Official
description: Roger W. Bowen, who resigned under pressure as president of the New Paltz campus of the State University of New York, has been named general secretary of the American Association of University Professors in Washington, succeeding Mary Burgan. He will take over in July, the association said on Wednesday. Dr. Bowen left New Paltz in 2001 after defending the university's right to hold a conference that included sexually frank theater and discussions of sadomasochism. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Banks Deny Making Improper Tax Loans
description: Two German banks told a Senate panel on Thursday that they had worked closely with the accounting firm KPMG to bankroll aggressive tax shelters, but the banks denied knowing at the time that they were participating in anything questionable.

title: Longtime Homeowners a Relative Rarity in U.S., Census Shows
description: In 42 years, Joseph and Joan Bieda have renovated their kitchen three times. They have redone the basement, and stripped out sinks, baths, showers and wallpaper in their two bathrooms three times. But even though their three-bedroom brick ranch house, which they bought in Warren, Mich., for just under $17,000 in 1961, is now worth about 10 times that amount, they are not anywhere near selling.

title: Kerry, Knocked Off Balance, Takes Steps to Right Himself
description: In a drive to regain his footing before the first Democratic presidential contests, Senator John Kerry is packing his schedule with events, has once again retooled his campaign theme and is trying to raise enough money to avoid spending huge sums of his own now that he has opted out of public financing for the primaries.

title: The Russian Triumvirate, Via an Italian Conductor
description: Igor Stravinsky was a Russian migr. Dmitri Shostakovich was a Soviet. Sergei Prokofiev was, at different times, both. To posterity, however, they will remain the Big Three of 20th-century Russian composers, and on Wednesday night they were united in a New York Philharmonic concert that showed each of them exploring musical form, specifically vocal music as translated into orchestral writing.

title: South Africa Gears Up for AIDS Fight
description: The South African generic drug maker Aspen Pharmacare made the country's first small batch of generic antiretroviral drugs in July to more publicity than demand.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Criticism For Berlusconi's Stand On Russia
description: The European Parliament passed a resolution that expressed profound distaste and emphatic disagreement with recent statements about Russian policies in Chechnya by Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister. Italy (and consequently Mr. Berlusconi) holds the rotating presidency of the European Union. He infuriated many European politicians by voluntarily defending the Russian government's forceful actions in the breakaway region of Chechnya at a news conference in Italy with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, two weeks ago. Mr. Berlusconi has steadfastly courted -- and, by all appearances has won -- Mr. Putin's friendship. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: School Janitors Sue Over Hiring of Outsiders
description: The school custodians' union has sued the city's Department of Education over the hiring of private contractors to clean public schools, arguing that the department violated competitive bidding requirements in awarding $60 million in work to two companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Statistics Overhaul
description: Li Deshui, the director of the National Bureau of Statistics, said that China would update its methods of reporting annual and quarterly economic growth to match international standards and would stop releasing monthly statistics except in special circumstances, the official New China News Agency said. Mr. Deshui denied an assessment by independent economists that in reporting economic growth of 8.5 percent from January through September, China had understated its recent economic growth to avoid the appearance of a speculative bubble. The current statistics are reliable, he said, and actual economic growth has been held down because an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome last spring affected the economy "very severely." Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: National Arts Center Orchestra
description: Avery Fisher Hall

title: Mexicos Ambassador to the United Nations Resigns
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 20 - Mexico's ambassador to the United Nations, who was due to be relieved of his post on Jan. 1 for criticizing the United States, resigned abruptly on Thursday. He accused the administration of President Vicente Fox of caving in to pressure from the Bush administration, which he said had lobbied for his ouster.

title: 'Mail Order Bride'
description: Directed by Robert Capelli Jr. and Jeffrey Wolf

title: Lottery Numbers
Kotaro Fukuma
description: Alice Tully Hall

title: Little-Known Suitor Pursues Nets
description: If Stuart D. Feldman succeeds in his bid to buy the Nets, it will be the most public thing he has ever done. His company, Chelsey Capital, has made few deals that have been in the news, let alone made headlines, and his offer of $257.5 million for the Nets indicates he has amassed his wealth without making the cover of Forbes.

title: In a Vermont Town, Calm and Clapboards
description: ''CAN you hear me now?'' Well, no, not if you're in Dorset. The town, in a narrow valley in southern Vermont, has no cellphone reception. But that hasn't stopped scores of people from buying second homes there -- lured by its laid-back atmosphere and and a robust arts scene. Page 7.

title: Elementary, Watson: Scan a Palm, Find a Clue
description: For more than a century, the fingerprint has been the quintessential piece of crime scene evidence. But fingerprints are only a tiny part of the story. All of a person's ''friction ridged skin'' is distinctively patterned: soles, palms and even the writer's palm, as the outer side of the hand is called.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Market column last Friday, about houses with window walls, mispelled the name of a mountain visible from one in Portland, Ore. It is Mount Rainier, not Ranier.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Another Death In Subway Surfing
description: A second merchant marine cadet who was struck by a beam while riding on top of a subway train last week has died. Brian Hochstetter, 21, of Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, died yesterday afternoon at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, said Nancy McPartlin-Gardella, a hospital spokeswoman. Mr. Hochstetter and Christopher Loughrey, 22, of Montague, N.J., both juniors at the State University of New York Maritime College in Throgs Neck were on a northbound No. 6 subway car in the Bronx early last Friday when the accident occurred. Mr. Loughrey suffered a skull fracture and died at the scene. The young men had been in Greenwich Village and had taken the train from Bleecker Street. Jed Stevenson (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Chief Is Asked To Revise N.Y.S.E. Plan

title: Greenspan Voices Concerns on U.S. Efforts to Limit Imports
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has implicitly criticized the Bush administration's increasingly combative stance against foreign imports.

title: WET SEAL SAYS PRICE CUTS WILL WIDEN QUARTERLY LOSS
description: Wet Seal, a teenage clothing chain, said yesterday that it would report a loss of as much as 21 cents a share in the fourth quarter because of price cuts and that its chief financial officer, William Langsdorf, had resigned for personal reasons. Joseph Deckop, executive vice president for central planning and allocation, will serve as interim chief financial officer. The company which operates Wet Seal, Arden B. and Zutopia stores, said it planned to close 16 stores and open one in the current quarter.

title: The New X-treme
description: FUSION is the new buzzword in sports, and its experimenters are pairing terrain park moves with backcountry ski jumping and weight lifting with Pilates. Page 2.

title: Senate in Nip-and-Tuck Struggle on Energy
description: An intense behind-the-scenes struggle erupted on Thursday in the Senate as authors of the energy bill, a chief domestic initiative of the Republican leadership, said they had not lined up the votes to overcome a filibuster in a showdown scheduled for Friday.

title: United Airlines unveils Ted, its low-fare airline and hope for the future.
description: UNITED AIRLINES once talked about a low-fare airline as the only strategy that would lift it out of bankruptcy protection. But it unveiled a decidedly less extensive solution this week in an airline that it plans to call Ted.

title: Iran Seeks U.N. Assurance on Nuclear Arms Issue
description: An International Atomic Energy Agency debate about how to deal with the 18-year-long effort by Iran to conceal its nuclear programs got off to a sputtering start on Thursday, when the Iranian delegation said it would not commit itself to an accord that would open the nation to more intrusive inspections until an agreement is reached on how strongly the agency will condemn Iran for its past actions.

title: Archdiocese of Cincinnati Fined in Sex Abuse Scandal
description: An Ohio state judge found the Archdiocese of Cincinnati guilty yesterday of failing to report sexually abusive priests in the 1970's and 80's and imposed the maximum penalty possible, a fine of $10,000.

title: Fighting for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Leone Classic, Liberated at Last From Television
description: The rapturous and more than slightly insane 1972 Sergio Leone western ''Duck, You Sucker,'' which opens today at Film Forum, is one of the rare movies that demand a theatrical run for an unusual reason. The picture is almost impossible to concentrate on when it turns up on television, possibly because, with the exception of the laser-disc version, the movie is always crammed into the small frame, rather than being unleashed in the director's own luxuriant brand of wide screen.

title: Gays and Marriage in America
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Picasso: The Classical Period; Roy Lichtenstein; Gajin Fujita
description: Picasso: The Classical Period'

title: Unequal Tax Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Parts Purchase
description: The world's biggest home appliances maker, Electrolux of Sweden, said that it planned to buy auto parts worth 10 billion rupees ($219 million) from Indian companies over the next three years in an effort to save money. The parts will be used by the Electrolux outdoor division, which makes garden equipment like chain saws, lawn mowers and tractors.

title: A Bad Day in Europe
description: Two devastating terror bombings against British targets in Turkey yesterday compounded the sense of siege already surrounding President Bush's cocooned state visit to Britain. Hours after the Istanbul explosions, which killed at least 27 people and injured 450, one of the largest weekday demonstrations in modern British history wound its way through Trafalgar Square in London to protest Mr. Bush's policies in Iraq and Prime Minister Tony Blair's down-the-line support for Washington.

title: Sentiment That's Laced With a Dose Of Menace
description: On Monday night at the Roseland Ballroom, Claudio Sanchez cried out, ''For you, I'd do anything just to make you happy/ Hear you tell me that you're proud of me,'' and the kids in the mosh pit pumped their fists, as if they knew exactly what he meant. But it seems safe to assume that they had no idea.

title: Sports of The Times; Regarding Johnson, Jets Should Just Say No
description: IF the Jets are really considering rehiring receiver Keyshawn Johnson next season, they should also consider that he left the Tampa Bay Buccaneers this week the same way he left the Jets before the 2000 season, acting the same way he acted with the Jets -- in a me-first manner that makes his presence more trouble than he's worth.

title: Truck Bomb Kills 5 in a Pro-U.S. Kurdish Stronghold in Northern Iraq
description: A powerful truck bomb killed five people on Thursday near the offices of a pro-American Kurdish group in Kirkuk, in the north, while the commander of American forces in Baghdad reported that a 12-day bombing campaign against suspected guerrilla bases had sharply reduced attacks on occupation troops.

title: The Memorial Designs: A Fitting Tribute? (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Care in Rural China Now Better Than Nothing
description: The free medicine arrived in July, and Lin Degui and Zhao Sanmin swallowed it down. In this village of 700, more than 100 people trudged the mud alleyways to the small clinic, each hoping for a reprieve from the scythe of AIDS. Forty, maybe 50, had already died.

title: Evans Returning to Jets With Sense of Gratitude
description: The ordeal of his drug suspension has lingered with Jets defensive tackle Josh Evans, shadowing him as he worked with such ferocity at practice the last three weeks that his teammates told him to calm down.

title: The Memorial Designs: A Fitting Tribute?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOOLEY, FRANCIS JOSEPH
description: DOOLEY--Francis Joseph. Died peacefully on November 20, 2003, after a valiant fight. Born in Everett, MA, March 12, 1916. Beloved husband of the late Eileen. Adored father of Margaret Ann, Paul, Mary, Francis, and Kathleen. Loving grandfather of Michael, Katie, Erin, Danny, Billy, Maureen and Joseph. Dear father-in-law of Peter, Nancy, Teresa and George. Services are at the McDonald Funeral Home, Marshfield, MA.

title: As Bush and Blair Speak, They Find Many Ways to Say, 'We Must Fight Terror'
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in London by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Bush, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/world.

title: Rangers' Fill-In At Goalie Loses His First Start
description: With his No. 1 goaltender, Mike Dunham, nursing a hip injury, Rangers Coach Glen Sather could have pressured the backup Jussi Markkanen to play Thursday night against Colorado.

title: Congress Poised for Vote on Anti-Spam Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a law to crack down on the floods of unsolicited e-mail messages that clog the nation's cybermail boxes.

title: Watching Over Freddie and Fannie
description: Our political system can be rather nimble at reacting to financial crises, but when it comes to preventing them, well, that's another matter. Issues that seem more urgent can get in the way of reforms that can stave off the next crisis, as can bureaucratic inertia and the fact that the status quo benefits powerful interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TONER, KATHLEEN
description: TONER--Kathleen, IHM, on November 19. Samaritan House mourns the passing of our founder, inspiration, and friend, Sister Kathleen Toner. In 1984 Kathy created in Brooklyn the model home for homeless women and children. She developed the home, ran it and--most vitally-lived in it. Her vision helped turn around a city that once warehoused thousands of homeless mothers and children in the worst of welfare hotels to a city that finances scores of residences with supportive services for women and children in need. We will always remember and be inspired by her brilliant mind, her sense of humor, her loving heart, and her fierce protection of those most in need. Calling hours Sunday, November 23, 2-8 PM. Mass Monday, November 24, at 10:30 AM, Marian Convent, Scranton, PA.

title: Blasts Hit 2 British Sites in Turkey as Bush Visits Blair
description: Two huge truck-bomb explosions wrecked the British Consulate and a British bank here on Thursday, killing at least 27 people and wounding 450 in an assault that coincided with President Bush's state visit to London.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: When Real Life Collides With Weekend Warriors
description: IT is Monday morning at the neighborhood bagel shop, and I catch someone's eye. Why does he look familiar? As our orders make their way through the assembly line, we finally figure it out: afternoon pick-up soccer the weekend before.

title: Free Bus Service Starts in Lower Manhattan
description: Free bus service began yesterday from the north end of Battery Park City to the western edge of the South Street Seaport, along a U-shaped route that also goes by Battery Park and ground zero.

title: White House Is Evacuated, But the Scene is Serene
description: Was it a bird, a plane, a computer glitch? No one connected to the nation's air defense system claimed to know, but whatever it was, it briefly turned the White House upside down on Thursday.

title: TERRORISM PANEL ISSUES SUBPOENA TO CITY FOR TAPES
description: The federal commission investigating the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks announced on Thursday that it had issued a subpoena to New York City for a variety of police tapes and other material related to the attacks. The panel said the city's refusal to hand over the material had ''significantly impeded the commission's investigation.''

title: Attack on Sheik Is Blow to City That Has Plan for Iraqi Police
description: When the American general in charge of this restive city announced earlier this week that he would hand over power to a group of cooperative Iraqi sheiks, he challenged them to rein in the guerrillas without American help.

title: Cellphone Users in Russia Reach a High in October
description: Russia is becoming a nation of cellphone users, with roughly one in five signed up for a mobile phone.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telecom Acquisition
description: China Unicom, a cellphone company, agreed to pay 3.2 billion yuan ($387 million) to buy eight provincial wireless networks from its state-owned parent to increase profit. Unicom will pay cash for the networks from its parent, the China United Telecommunications Corporation, and will assume 8.1 billion yuan in debt, Unicom said. Unicom, which is based in Hong Kong, will also sell its unprofitable paging business for 2.75 billion yuan to China United, which is based in Beijing.

title: A Laughingstock Is Now Having The Last Laugh
description: TO gauge just how far the Bengals have risen in reaching first place this late in a season for the first time since 1990, the Chad Johnson-Willie Anderson flap last week serves as a revealing backdrop.

title: Nancy Spero
description: Galerie Lelong

title: Pop and Jazz Listings
description: Aselective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: The Book Tide Is Running, For Readers And Browsers
description: Let's begin with the most challenging individual on your gift list: the aesthete-Armageddonist who has both a coffee table and sense of impending doom. Skip the visions of sugarplums when contemplating a picture book for this person. Ditto for pets, redecorating, travel or, frankly, anything else that requires time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOWALL, BONNIE CRENSHAW
description: KOWALL--Bonnie Crenshaw, 83, on November 8 in Kirkland, WA. Beloved wife of the late Konstant, devoted mother of Christina Edwards and grandmother of Jennifer Heiszler, and delighted greatgrandmother of Elke, all of Carnation, WA. She will be remembered by all her family and many friends in Washington DC, McLean And Great Falls, VA, and on Bainbridge and Shelter Islands. Rest in peace.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer's Profit Rises
description: The brewer SABMiller said net income for the first half of its fiscal year rose 93 percent from a year ago, to $309 million. Sales at the company, which is based in London and Johannesburg, increased 59 percent, to $6.33 billion. The company's results were helped by the acquisition of the Miller Brewing Company last year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Rockets Hit Two Hotels And Ministry
description: The Palestine and Sheraton hotels in central Baghdad were hit by a volley of rockets at about 7:15 on Friday morning. First indications were that there were no casualties among the large number of Americans and other Westerners who live in the Palestine Hotel, but a CNN report said at least two wounded people had been carried from the Sheraton Hotel after the attack.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Still in Search Of Diversity

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEMAN, JOHN R.
description: FREEMAN--John R. Sutton Place Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of our longtime member and Patron. Condolences to beloved wife Rita, daughters and grandchildren. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Mark Wiener, President

title: Falstaff and Hal, With War Afoot
description: CANDLES shine most brightly when it's dark outside. In Jack O'Brien's glorious staging of ''Henry IV'' for Lincoln Center Theater, a wall of endless night girds the uneasy kingdom of the greatest of Shakespeare's history plays, and the air is fogged with a constant awareness of death.

title: 51 Months For Key Figure In Corruption
description: Four years after Paul J. Silvester, the former state treasurer, first admitted accepting cash kickbacks in return for placing millions of dollars in state pension investments with certain equity funds, he was sentenced on Thursday to 51 months in prison.

title: Garth Fagan's Works of the Past Performed by Today's Troupe
description: Choreographers tend to be inspired by the individual gifts of their dancers. Garth Fagan's style was shaped in large part by the instinctual approach to dance of his first performers, many of whom were untrained. Three decades later, Mr. Fagan has become a master of the kind of choreographic non sequiturs that were of necessity his earliest material and were at the heart of the dances he presented on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Celebrities Have a Response To the Charges: No Comment
description: Many of Michael Jackson's close friends and acquaintances had little to say on Thursday when he surrendered to face charges of child molesting. In fact, the only people who seemed to have anything to utter were the army of celebrity publicists responding to calls from reporters with ''no comment.''

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Wella, the German hair care company now controlled by Procter & Gamble, said yesterday that it had shifted the creative assignment on its global account, with billings estimated at more than $100 million, to Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe .

title: Krasnoyarsk National Dance Company of Siberia
description: Lehman Concert Hall

title: Man Who Leads Prosecution Has Reputation for Tenacity
description: Early in his long career as a prosecutor, Thomas W. Sneddon Jr. was so driven that he was often called Mad Dog, a nickname that was apparently both complimentary and damning.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHAPIRO, ROSE
description: SHAPIRO--Rose. Eighteen years since you left us. Your love and devotion will never be forgotten. You live forever in our hearts. Your famil

title: Intel Rebuffs the Skeptics of Its Itanium Chip
description: Intel delivered a forceful defense yesterday of its advanced Itanium microprocessor, declaring the chip well on its way to success despite considerable skepticism in the computer industry.

title: Gays and Marriage in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Cuba
description: New Victory Theater

title: Home for the Holidays? Thanks but No Thanks
description: FOR the last 30 years, James and Luise Pace have cooked Thanksgiving dinner for their family of eight at their Somers, Conn., home. So what are they doing this year? Flying to Prague for four days to hear classical music. ''I get tired of having everyone over and then cleaning up afterward,'' said Mr. Pace, 57, who owns an auto-leasing company. ''The way it's going, I might just leave on Christmas.''

title: When Soldiers Go Without Paychecks
description: Members of the National Guard and the various military reserves joined up to be part-time civilian soldiers, called up during domestic emergencies and in time of war. This model was coming to an end even before the war in Iraq. Stretched thin by the peacekeeping missions of the 1990's, the Pentagon was already calling up more part-timers and stationing them abroad for longer. But the invasion and occupation of Iraq have magnified the problem.

title: Evan Ruderman, 44, Activist for Many Causes
description: Evan Ruderman, whose theatrical monologue about her own experience with AIDS was a major part of a documentary shown on public television in 1996, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. She was 44.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: China Threatens U.S. With Higher Import Tariffs
description: China's vice minister of commerce threatened on Thursday to raise tariffs on imports from the United States in a steel dispute, and summoned the American ambassador to protest the Bush administration's announcement this week of plans to impose quotas on Chinese sleepwear, bras and certain fabrics.

title: Will Barnet -- 'Figuration and Abstraction'
description: Alexandre Gallery

title: ENRON GETS PERMISSION TO SELL STAKE IN POWER PLANT
description: Enron won bankruptcy court permission yesterday to sell its 40 percent stake in a power plant in upstate New York for $225 million. Enron can also begin accepting bids to sell debt it holds in East Coast Power, which owns a power plant in Linden, N.J., Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan ruled. Enron will sell its stake in the New York plant, near Oswego, to RCMF Debt, RCP Debt and Sithe/Independence Equity. The auction for the debt in the New Jersey plant was scheduled for Dec. 16.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Readers Reflect on President John F. Kennedy
description: We asked readers to share their memories of the life and death of President John F. Kennedy, 40 years after his assassination.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Gays and Marriage in America
description: To the Editor:

title: The Incredible Bloated Money Bill
description: The Republican-led Congress is wallowing toward a garishly spectacular finale: a $284 billion omnibus spending bill, a haphazardly stitched hulk that gives a bad name to the usual legislative metaphors about sausage-making and bauble-laden Christmas trees. This bill, being rigged as a take-it-or-leave-it voting prod for lawmakers antsy to get home, begins by combining five expensive measures that deserve separate votes because they are vital for financing much of the government next year. But the real political goal is to festoon this appropriations wad with an incongruous mix of resurrected controversies, hometown pork and hot-button proposals.

title: Isles' Late Rally Can't Overtake The Lightning
description: If the Islanders used Thursday night's game against the Lightning to gauge how much they had improved from last season, they received a rather sobering assessment.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Baptists And The Judge
description: The Baptist State Convention, which represents more than one million Alabama Baptists, deleted former Chief Justice Roy Moore's name from a proposed resolution to support public displays of the Ten Commandments. Some delegates at the annual meeting in Mobile said that citing Mr. Moore as a leader in acknowledging God would seem to endorse his defiance of a federal court order to remove the Ten Commandments monument in the state court building. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRITTENHAM, RAYMOND L.
description: BRITTENHAM--Raymond L. The Officers, Directors and Staff of The Tinker Foundation Inc., express their deep sorrow at the death of Mr. Raymond L. Brittenham. Mr. Brittenham was a steady rock in the early years of the Foundation's development. He continued his stewardship for thirty-six years as its Secretary, retiring as Director Emeritus in 1999. He will be sorely missed and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his widow, Mrs. Brittenham, and their children.

title: Warner Pulls Away From EMI
description: Time Warner took a major step yesterday toward selling its Warner Music division for $2.5 billion to a consortium led by Edgar Bronfman Jr., as its board pulled away from a previously favored higher offer from the EMI Group, people involved in the board meeting said.

title: Japan's Recovering Economy Is Relying Heavily on China
description: Japan and the United States both complain that China's currency is undervalued, but while Americans watch their trade deficit with China balloon to record levels, Japan announced on Thursday a 27.8 percent increase in its exports to China.

title: 'Picasso: The Classical Period'
description: C & M Arts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE JONG, DOLA
description: de JONG--Dola, 92 years, died November 12, 2003. Born in Arnhem, Holland, Dola was a published author of 22 books in English and Dutch. Received City of Amsterdam Prize for Literature in 1947. Graduating from Empire State College at age 72, Dola then taught creative writing. Survived by son Ian Joseph, daughter - in - law Barbara, granddaughter Melissa, and niece Yael Ben Lev.

title: Gays and Marriage in America
description: To the Editor:

title: All Results Negative From N.F.L.'s Random Tests for THG
description: The National Football League announced yesterday that all of the more than 1,000 player urine samples tested for the banned steroid THG have come back negative since random testing for it began on Oct. 6.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: HUGE DIAMOND FINDS NO BUYER A 103-carat diamond said to be the largest ever put up for auction failed to sell because bids fell short of the $8.4 million asking price. Bidding stopped at $7.6 million for the stone, which had mesmerized jewelry dealers and collectors with its size and purity. It was discovered in the Premier Mine in South Africa. Designing and cutting the rough crystal took place in Johannesburg and New York and took 18 months to complete. Its sale by Sotheby's was meant to be the climax of a week of jewelry sales in Geneva. On Wednesday, a 478-carat sapphire larger than a hen's egg was sold by Christie's for $1.5 million. (AP)

title: AARP Gone Astray
description: ''This is a good bill that will help every Medicare beneficiary,'' wrote Tom Scully, the Medicare administrator, in a letter to The New York Times defending the prescription drug bill. That's flatly untrue. (Are you surprised?) As the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities points out, the bill will force millions of beneficiaries to pay more for drugs, thanks to a provision that cuts off supplemental aid from Medicaid. Poorer recipients may find previously affordable drugs moving out of reach.

title: Bush Says Pentagon's Plan to Reduce Forces in Iraq Next Year Could Be Reconsidered
description: President Bush said Thursday that he was open to rethinking the Pentagon's plan to reduce the size of the United States military force in Iraq next year.

title: Number of New Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
description: The number of Americans filing first-time unemployment claims fell last week, the Labor Department said yesterday, bringing the four-week average to the lowest since February 2001 as the economy strengthened. A measure of future economic activity rose for the fifth time in six months.

title: What if Kennedy Had Lived?
description: Some years after John F. Kennedy's assassination 40 years ago tomorrow -- a counter-Camelot myth took hold among historians and journalists. Supposedly, Kennedy was a reckless cold warrior, knee-deep in conspiracies against Fidel Castro. On domestic policy, he was timid and ineffective.

title: Music and Dance in Review
description: Dance Cuba

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HATCHER, BARBARA HOLDSWORTH
description: HATCHER--Barbara Holdsworth. Died November 18, 2003. She was predeceased by her husband Lloyd B. Hatcher. She is survived by her brother Frederick Holdsworth, Jr., a daughter Barbara H. van Marx of Darien, CT., a son L. Brower Hatcher of Block Island, RI, grandchildren Paul L.A. van Marx, deceased, Robert C.A. van Marx, Genevieve Gardner and Anabelle Jepsen, stepgranddaughters Jennifer Cunningham, Rachel Meyer and Claudia Meyer, greatgrandchildren Waylon and Ella Jepsen, step - great grandchildren Emma and Kate Cunningham. Donations may be made to St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, NY 11724.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Court Voids Judicial Sanction
description: The State Supreme Court struck down part of the judicial code as impermissibly vague and voided the sanction that a disciplinary board imposed on an African-American appellate judge who violated the rule. The judge, Wendell L. Griffen of the State Court of Appeals, was admonished by the Judicial Discipline Commission after urging the Black Caucus in the General Assembly to pressure the University of Arkansas to diversify its faculty and administration. The Supreme Court said the panel's action infringed on legitimate free speech. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Entries yesterday in a list of recent American military deaths identified the unit of Pfc. Richard W. Hafer and Pfc. Joey D. Whitener incompletely. They were with the First Battalion, 320th Field Artillery, 101st Airborne Division.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu Returns To profit
description: The truckmaker Isuzu Motors returned to profitability in the six months to Sept. 30, helped by cost-cutting and a rebound in truck sales in Japan. The company, which is 12 percent owned by General Motors, earned 25 billion yen ($227 million) in the first half of the fiscal year after losing 84 billion yen in the period last year. Sales jumped 14 percent, to 723 billion yen ($6.6 billion), ahead of the introduction of tighter emissions regulations for diesel trucks. Isuzu also raised its full-year profit target by 14 percent, to a record 40 billion yen ($363 million). The profit would be Isuzu's first in five years. To strengthen its balance sheet, Isuzu decided last year to stop making sports utility vehicles in the United States. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Dallas's commemoration of its place in history as the city where President John F. Kennedy was slain misstated a word from the inscription on a cenotaph erected there in 1970. The words, by the journalist Jim Lehrer, are, ''It is not a memorial to the pain and sorrow of death, but stands as a permanent tribute to the joy and excitement of one man's life, John F. Kennedy's life'' -- not ''pleasant tribute.''

title: Tom Burr
description: American Fine Arts

title: Eastern Germany Is Able to Prevent Industrial Flight To Third World
description: Hector Ruiz was not yet working for Advanced Micro Devices, the Silicon Valley chip maker, when it announced plans in the mid-1990's to build a factory in this slumbering eastern German city. But he remembers the catcalls aimed at Advanced Micro.

title: If You See a Roadside Ghost Afire, It's Best to Keep Right on Driving
description: In ''Gothika,'' a clammy new thriller that opens nationwide today, Halle Berry plays Miranda Grey, a psychiatrist at a Connecticut institution for the criminally insane. One of her patients is Chle (Penlope Cruz), a disheveled young woman who screeches and rants and claims that she is being sexually assaulted by the devil in her locked cell. One obvious symptom of Chle's illness, whatever it is, is a tendency to speak in lurid similes: ''He opened me up like a flower of pain,'' she says of her demonic attacker, and (about someone else), ''I sliced his adam's apple in half like a piece of fruit on a summer day.''

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about the European Commission's antitrust review of General Electric's proposed purchase of the ultrasonic testing unit of Agfa-Gevaert misstated the expected date of a ruling. It is Dec. 5, not Dec. 4.

title: Yankees Meet With Japanese Reliever
description: The Yankees were pleased with their foray into Japan last winter, when they signed outfielder Hideki Matsui, and they may be poised to recruit more talent from there.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: After Hours, An Odd Couple

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: L.P.G.A. Wants to Develop Its World View
description: Ty Votaw, commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, announced on Thursday that women's golf organizations from around the world would convene in New York in May for a World Congress of Women's Golf.

title: Grocery Workers' Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning and Martin Nearly Come to Blows at Practice
description: After a draining practice session, Alonzo Mourning and half of the Nets team, mostly second-unit players, were making their way through the final strides of a set of suicide drills, punishment for losing a contest to the rest of the team Thursday at the Champion Center, the team's practice facility. As Mourning trudged to the finish behind his teammates, already unhappy, he heard laughter from the players who were watching.

title: Molissa Fenley
description: Joyce SoHo

title: Fleeting Wisp Of Glory, And Eloquence
description: MAYBE his image was created in part with smoke and mirrors. Maybe a complaisant press corps overlooked his moral and physical frailties. Maybe his road to the White House went through cemetery gates in Chicago that Democratic bosses had opened to pump up the vote.

title: With Barbed Wit Aforethought
description: JOHN CURRIN, whose reputation, cooking in art circles for years, has lately boiled over into the larger public world, can put you off and turn you on at the same time. You see the arc of his progress in the much-anticipated mid-career survey now at the Whitney Museum, which has arrived by way of Chicago and London, where it caused a predictable fuss. Don't miss it, if possible. It's riveting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PASSANT, ROSE
description: PASSANT--Rose. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Rose Passant, associated with The Times from November 1946 until retiring in November 1977.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about efforts by some online retailers to improve their rankings in result displays on the Google search engine misspelled the given name of a Google founder, who said the company might adjust its ranking system. He is Sergey Brin, not Sergei.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LE CORBEILLER, CLARE EAMES
description: Le CORBEILLER -- Clare Eames. On November 19th, 2003, peacefully at her home in Manhattan. Survived by her husband, Jean, their daughter, Suzanne Le Corbeiller, and their daughter and son-in-law, Genevieve and Anthony White, and grandchildren, Jesse Stoler, Graham, Marion and Simon White. Burial private.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: BAPTISTS AND THE JUDGE The Baptist State Convention, which represents more than one million Alabama Baptists, deleted former Chief Justice Roy Moore's name from a proposed resolution to support public displays of the Ten Commandments. Some delegates at the annual meeting in Mobile said that citing Mr. Moore as a leader in acknowledging God would seem to endorse his defiance of a federal court order to remove the Ten Commandments monument in the state court building. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a New York City Council hearing on a proposed lead-abatement law gave an incorrect age range in some copies. The city would inspect apartments with children younger than 7 (not 7 and older).

title: Part Environmentalist, All Rabbi; Fighting to Educate Jewish Williamsburg About a Health Risk
description: In the Hasidic community of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, many people just call it ''moisture cure.''

title: Congress Completes Details of Medicare Bill
description: House and Senate negotiators finished work on a far-reaching overhaul of Medicare on Thursday, expanding benefits to build support for the legislation to the very end. Democrats shut out of the negotiations denounced the process as illegitimate and said the measure would leave millions of elderly people worse off.

title: Blair Gives Bush Support, But Receives Little Back
description: On the first two days of his three-day visit here, President Bush got fresh assurances of political, military and moral support from Prime Minister Tony Blair in his antiterrorism efforts. But he gave little back on several issues on which the United States and Britain are at odds, intensifying the domestic political pressure on Mr. Blair.

title: So We're Admitting Our Mistakes . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GST AUTOLEATHER, Hagerstown, Md., a leading supplier of seating leather to the automotive industry, plans to move its cutting operations to Mexico, eliminating as many as 315 jobs at plants in Williamsport, Md., and Reading, Pa., in early 2004.

title: Clark Offers Plan to Build New Alliance
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark accused the Bush administration yesterday of ''wrecking NATO'' with a unilateral policy on Iraq, and he angrily denounced as a smear a former colleague's statement that he was replaced as NATO commander early because of questions of character.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Grunge Musician Considers Campaign
description: The former bassist for the grunge group Nirvana, Krist Novoselic, is considering a campaign for lieutenant governor on the Democratic ticket next year. ''It's very serious,'' the state Democratic chairman, Paul Berendt, said. ''I think he stands a fabulous chance.'' If he decides to run, Mr. Novoselic, 38, would most likely face the two-term Democratic incumbent, Lt. Gov. Brad Owen. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: U.N. Envoy Resigns
description: Mexico's ambassador to the United Nations, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, who was due to be relieved of his post on Jan. 1 for criticizing the United States, resigned. He gave no public explanation but told reporters, ''It's clear I have to leave the U.N.'' Mexican officials said this week that Mr. Aguilar was being dismissed because he refused to retract comments he made in a speech last week in Mexico City in which he said that Washington wanted a ''relationship of convenience and subordination'' with Mexico and that the political and intellectual classes of the United States regarded their southern neighbor as ''a backyard.'' At Mr. Aguilar's final Security Council meeting, Secretary General Kofi Annan praised him for his ''independent spirit.'' Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROEDY, ALAN E.
description: BROEDY--Alan E. On November 19th in his 60th year. Beloved son of Esther. Brother of Sheila, and uncle of Scott. Having met him, you would not forget him.

title: Accused Nazi Guard Speaks Out, Denying He Had Role in Atrocities
description: For more than a half century, Jakiw Palij has lived a quiet life in New York City, working as a draftsman until he retired.

title: Chirac Has a Hearing Aid (At Least, That's the Whisper)
description: Is the president of France hard of hearing? And does he wear a hearing aid?

title: Stevens Nears Endurance Record, but Keeps Hits Coming
description: Devils defenseman Scott Stevens is closing in on a National Hockey League endurance record. He has not exactly paced himself along the way. He figures the best way to keep playing a rugged game is to hit someone before someone hits him.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Web Travel Executive Steps Down
description: Martha Lane Fox, the co-founder of lastminute.com, a discount-vacation Web site, said yesterday that she planned to leave the company, which reported its first profit. The company earned 200,000 ($340,000) in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, in contrast to a 16.2 million loss a year ago. The results were drastically below forecasts of about 7 million. Dow Jones reported that analysts did not expect such a sharp rise in depreciation, which was up more than 50 percent, to 14.8 million. Ms. Lane Fox will be replaced by the chief operating officer, Ian McCaig. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Bloom: Was That the Guy In 'The Producers'?

title: Sequined Sincerity in the Lyrics, Famous Friends in the Crowd
description: The 57-year-old lyricist, singer and show business socialite Carole Bayer Sager has one of those ageless Hollywood faces that belong to the Joan Collins school of cultivated perfection. That look, at once magnetic and a little scary, suits Ms. Sager's longtime image as an aggressively competitive alpha girl wielding the power of her connections to turn her every undertaking into a special event.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Scallion Blockade
description: Border inspectors are stopping scallion shipments from three companies in Mexico whose green onions are suspected of being involved in hepatitis A outbreaks in September in Georgia, North Carolina and Tennessee, the Food and Drug Administration said. The F.D.A. is also tracing scallion shipments for a Chi-Chi's restaurant in Monaca, Pa., 25 miles northwest of Pittsburgh. Officials suspect that scallions are involved with a hepatitis outbreak there in which more than 540 people have become ill and 3 have died since last month. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: QUICK ESCAPES
description: Calgary, Alberta

title: Bush Ends British Visit With Fish and Chips and Blair
description: LONDON, Nov. 21  President Bush ended his state visit to Britain today with renewed vows to get tough on terror, warm words of praise and friendship for Prime Minister Tony Blair and a hearty pub lunch in the northeast England town that Mr. Blair represents in Parliament.

title: Sorenstam Struggles As Diaz Takes Lead
description: Annika Sorenstam spent Thursday morning in an emergency room, being treated for pinkeye. Laura Diaz played Thursday's round on a tender left ankle that will require surgery next month.

title: The Memorial Designs: A Fitting Tribute?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; Family Attains a Milestone: First Member to Go to College
description: At 18, Tonya Walrond is the first in her family to go to college. ''College,'' she said, ''was a new start.''

title: Making a Mockery of Media Concentration Rules
description: IN Washington, they argue about whether more media concentration should be allowed. In places like Wichita Falls, Tex., they are living with concentration that already goes far beyond what the rules seem to allow.

title: Smaller Computer Chips Built Using DNA as Template
description: The recipe for a computer chip of the future may read something like this: Take some wires. Add DNA. Stir.

title: Shopping List | Car Babies
description: FINDING a sitter for a holiday getaway can be tough, but don't fret. Simply arm yourself with the right gear and you may find that back seat babbling can add a nice soundtrack to a long drive. Just be thankful that baby is still too young to demand a back-seat television. JESS WISLOSKI

title: 3 Directors' Videos That Transcend Music
description: Jim Carrey is sitting in bed wearing blue-and-yellow pj's and holding a steering wheel; this makes as much sense as anything, because the bed is mounted on the chassis of a car. While he does an Elvis impersonation, singing about pecan pie, he drives the bed-car into a gas station to fill it up. This surreally funny one-and-a-half minute film directed by Michel Gondry is a tempting prelude to the next, much bigger Gondry-Carrey collaboration, the movie ''Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind'' (scheduled to open in March). But ''Pecan Pie'' is available only on the DVD ''The Work of Director Michel Gondry,'' part of a series called The Directors Label that compiles short films and music videos.

title: The Memorial Designs: A Fitting Tribute?
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas Wish: A Room at the Inn
description: FEEL like going on a ski vacation to Aspen, Colo., this Christmas and want to stay at the Little Nell? Too bad: All of the hotel's 92 rooms were sold out 10 months ago -- as of Jan. 15, to be precise. Better luck in 2005. In December, the famed hotel begins taking reservations for guests who are willing to book two years in advance.

title: Does "Memorial" Serve Correctly?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On the Front Lines
description: In the wake of the national do-not-call registry, the telemarketers that Americans love to hate have their say.

title: This Old House
description: Once consigned to the dustbin of history -- the perfume counter -- antiquated French labels are getting a makeover.

title: Recent Openings
description: A new musical about 80's club culture, a revival of a Shakespeare classic and a Pulitzer Prize-winning play recently opened in New York.

title: Car Babies
description:
By JESS WISLOSKI
Arm yourself with the right gear and you may find that back seat babbling can add a nice soundtrack to a long drive.

title: What is Diaspora?
description: The panoramic group show at the Museum for African Art both stretches the map of contemporary art and confirms restrictive borders.

title: Gene-Altering Revolution Is About to Reach the Local Pet Store: Glow-in-the-Dark Fish
description: The genetically engineered pet appears to have arrived.

title: The Childhood of Michael Jackson
description: Unless he is proved guilty in a court of law, Michael Jackson is, of course, presumed to be innocent of the charges that led to his arrest on Thursday. But even before his trial begins -- a trial that threatens to suck all of civilization into its maw -- there is no doubt that Mr. Jackson is guilty of trying too hard to protect his innocence. Not the legal innocence that is vested in each of us, but the childlike innocence that we set aside sooner or later in order to get on with our lives. Most people have given up having slumber parties with prepubescent children by the time they cease being prepubescent themselves. Most people never need to be exiled from the Neverland of childhood. We leave it willingly on our own.

title: Camelot, Cut Short On Nov. 22, 1963
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LE CORBEILLER, CLARE EAMES
description: Le CORBEILLER -- Clare Eames. On November 19th, 2003, peacefully at her home in Manhattan. Survived by her husband, Jean, their daughter, Suzanne Le Corbeiller, and their daughter and son-in-law, Genevieve and Anthony White, and grandchildren, Jesse Stoler, Graham, Marion and Simon White. Burial private.

title: Stricter Security Measures Planned for Parade
description: In response to the recent terrorist bombings in Istanbul and other concerns, the Police Department is planning an extraordinary level of security for the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, including strict limitations on parking near the route and no backpacks for spectators, two officials said yesterday.

title: Homeless Man Is Crushed By Trash-Lifter
description: To the homeless men and women who live and sometimes work on the border of Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn, the long, elevated arc of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway near the Metropolitan Avenue exit is an inviting thing, beckoning with most of the few creature comforts the urban environment has to offer.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: NEW WRINKLES ON OLD ONES An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval two new antiwrinkle treatments, both of which are made from hyaluronic acid, a complex sugar found in all living organisms. The panel recommended approval of the Inamed Corporation's application to market an injectable gel called Hylaform made by the Genzyme Corporation to treat facial wrinkles, and earlier in the day had recommended a similar gel called Restylane marketed by the Medicis Pharmaceutical Corporation.

title: French Official Looks in His Mirror and Sees Future President
description: The not-so-secret secret is out: France's law-and-order interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, wants to run for president.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas on Nov. 8 with a profile of Loc Wacquant, a sociology professor who took up boxing, misidentified a painting by George Bellows shown in a print that hangs at his home in Berkeley, Calif., and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the date of the painting. It is ''Dempsey and Firpo'' (1924, not 1922) -- and not ''Boxing'' (1901).

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lawmakers Reach Pact On Bill to Slow Junk E-Mail

title: Insurgents Use Rockets on Donkey Carts to Hit Sites in Iraqi Capital
description: Faced with an American military crackdown using all the paraphernalia of high-technology warfare, Iraqi insurgents resorted today to the humblest of creatures and the simplest of transports to carry out what American officers called ''spectacular'' strikes against heavily fortified targets in Baghdad.

title: Shockey Practicing Earlier Than Expected
description: A day after Giants tight end Jeremy Shockey injured his knee against the Atlanta Falcons on Nov. 9, Coach Jim Fassel relayed the grim news that Shockey had a partial tear of the posterior cruciate ligament and that he would miss six to eight weeks, maybe the rest of the season. Two days later, Fassel revealed that further tests pushed the return date to as soon as three weeks.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Carolina Panthers (8-2)

title: What the President Saw in Britain (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Battle of Words Over War Intelligence
description: Intelligence -- or rather bad intelligence -- has become an obsession in Washington. Fueled by the growing casualties among American soldiers in Iraq and the administration's failure to find weapons of mass destruction there, the Central Intelligence Agency, Congress, an independent commission and scores of private experts and government analysts have been fiercely debating what went wrong in Iraq and, more broadly, the state of the government's intelligence capabilities.

title: 2 Sides of Clark on Stump: Passion and a Lack of It
description: It was near the end of a long day, more than 12 hours and counting of nonstop campaigning, when Gen. Wesley K. Clark started to cry.

title: Remembering John F. Kennedy
description: Forty years after his death, John F. Kennedy and his cruelly abbreviated presidency continue to resist generalization. It will probably always be thus. His tenure was too short to produce the coherent patterns favored by historians, too consumed by emergencies at home and abroad to leave much time for grand strategies.

title: Muslim SUNY Student's Expulsion Is Protested
description: Groups of legal advocates and students protested the arrest and expulsion of a State University of New York Maritime College student yesterday, claiming the college singled out the student, a Muslim from Nigeria, after he argued with a college official to lower his tuition. The Bronx-based college denied it had called the authorities, citing privacy laws that prohibit academic institutions from disclosing information about their students.

title: Expat adviser : Dual options for health insurance
National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: On And Over The Line
description: Two men were arrested on burglary charges after they inadvertently left on a stolen cellphone and discussed plans for crimes while the police listened. The police said the two taunted an officer investigating a burglary near Ringling, when he dialed the phone and identified himself, but they failed to deactivate it. As they entered Texas on Wednesday night, discussing plans for thefts and whether to kill a state trooper driving behind them, the eavesdropping deputy alerted officers near Amarillo, who arrested the pair, Scott L. Maddox, 19, and Chris Baker, 20. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASS, BEATRICE (NEE HAYNIG)
description: BASS--Beatrice (nee Haynig). Of Forest Hills. Retired New York City school teacher died November 20. Loving mother of Allen, Elizabeth and son-inlaw Joseph Masci, beloved grandmother of Jonathan Masci. Funeral services at 1:00 PM Sunday, Schwartz Bros., Forest Hills.

title: Death By Dividend
description: In this impoverished corner of southwestern Guatemala, lush with jungle and burbling brooks, you can just about see people dying as an indirect result of America's trade agenda.

title: A Healthy New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Generator Fumes Suspected in Deaths of 3 in the Bronx
description: Three people were found dead at a three-story house in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx last night, possibly from carbon monoxide poisoning, the fire department said. Another person was taken to a local hospital in serious condition, said Firefighter Sean Johnson.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Court Halts Riot Trial
description: The Supreme Court stayed the trial of 10 cases connected to the Hindu-Muslim riots in Gujarat State in 2002, giving the government there two weeks to explain why the cases should not be transferred outside the state. At least 1,000 Muslims were killed in the rioting, which state officials were accused of sanctioning. Trials of Hindus accused of participating have so far resulted in acquittals. The court expressed concern that most of the accused in the current cases had been released on bail. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Set for Whirlwind: Jerusalem and Kosovo in 36 Hours
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's travels to Jerusalem and Kosovo will last only 36 hours, but he will cover a lot of ground.

title: Seeking an Alternative To a Jewish State
description: When the distinguished historian Tony Judt declared in the pages of The New York Review of Books recently that ''the time has come to think the unthinkable,'' he must have expected a shocked reaction. The unthinkable was that Israel should be replaced by a binational country in which Jews and Palestinians would live together in democratic harmony. There is, Mr. Judt suggested, ''no place in the world today for a 'Jewish state.' ''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Spending Plan At Lukoil
description: Russia's second-largest oil producer, Lukoil Holdings, said it was planning an investment program of $25 billion over the next decade to increase its oil output to 2.8 million barrels a day by 2013. In 2004 alone, the company's capital spending is expected to total $2.5 billion. The investment is intended to increase oil production by 80 percent from current levels of about 1.64 million barrels a day. Next year's crude output is expected to be about 1.7 million barrels a day, the company said. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: GALEY & LORD SELLS UNIT TO PRIVATE INVESTORS
description: Galey & Lord, the textile maker that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February 2002, received court approval to sell its Klopman International Group to investors led by BS Private Equity. The sale of Klopman, which makes fabric and has sales headquarters in London, is valued at $47 million, including assumed obligations, Galey said. Galey, which makes textiles for sportswear, filed for bankruptcy after slowing sales and overseas competition left the company saddled with debt. The company, which is based in New York, listed $694.3 million in assets and $715 million in liabilities at the time of its filing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about evidence that a meteor killed most of life on Earth 250 million years ago misstated the place and time of the forum where some data will be presented. It is at a meeting of the American Geophysical Union (not Geological), and it is next month, not next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENROTH, STEVEN
description: MORGENROTH -- Steven. Born December 2, 1944, passed away November 18th in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Steve was the adored and adoring husband of Margaret (nee O'Shaughnessy) and the loving and proud father of Martin. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Carolyn and Julius, and his brother Marty. Steve's kindness, sense of humor and love of the NY Yankees will be forever part of the wife and son he cherished, his cousins Lynn, Mike, Teddy and Jon Friedman, and the many friends he has made over the years. We were lucky to have known you. The funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 23rd at 3 P.M. at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapels, 5411 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, FL. In New York, the family will receive visitors on Tuesday, November 25th from 2:30-9:00 P.M. at the Friedman residence, 50 East 89 Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: Officials Fear New Attacks by Militants in Southeast Asia
description: American officials in Southeast Asia are bracing for new terrorist attacks as they gather fresh information about Jemaah Islamiyah, the radical Islamic organization based in Indonesia.

title: What the President Saw in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: Divided House Approves Expansion of Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - A divided House on Saturday approved the biggest expansion of Medicare since its creation, narrowly passing legislation that would help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs while giving private health plans a huge new role in the program.

title: Are Memorial Designs Too Complex to Last?
description: Apart from Daniel Libeskind standing in a swarm of camera lights, there were relatively few architects present on Wednesday when the eight finalist designs in the World Trade Center Site Memorial Competition officially went on view downtown at the Winter Garden.

title: Customers Can Be So Rude
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HABER, MURRAY
description: HABER--Murray. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Husband of the late Tessie T. Haber. Father of Alfred Haber and the late Robert Haber. Father-in-law of Joy Haber. Brother-in-law of Joseph Turin and Gertrude Silver. Grandfather of Casey, Scott, David, Adam, Paul, Eric, Andrew, Michael and Peter Haber. Great grandfather of Matthew, Evan, Ellie, Ashley and Austin Haber. Service Sunday, 11AM at Congregation Sons of Israel, 150 Grand Ave, Leonia, N.J. Contributions to Congregation Sons of Israel in Murray's memory would be appreciated. For information, ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J.

title: Helping Soweto Youths Make the Music of Their Lives
description: ALTHOUGH the immediacy has dulled after 10 years of working in this South African township, there are little moments when Rosemary Nalden is reminded of the desperation around her.

title: Special Teams Are Hurting Jets
description: A lot usually goes wrong in a 3-7 season, but the Jets have a problem in an area that once seemed a strength: special teams.

title: Balancing Between Chaos And Control
description: Chino Moreno, the singer for the Deftones, kept leaping up onto the barricade separating the audience from the stage at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Thursday night. It was too narrow to balance on. To prop him up, a security guard grabbed his belt in the back, and some fans offered him their outstretched hands in the front.

title: Among G.O.P. Senators, A Favorite Democrat
description: Each Tuesday at 12:30 p.m., the Democrats of the Senate gather for a working lunch in an elegant chamber once occupied by the most powerful Senate Democrat of modern times, Lyndon B. Johnson. Every Democrat attends but one: Zell Miller of Georgia.

title: Officer Killed As Motorcycle Is Slammed By Minivan
description: A Clifton motorcycle police officer was killed Friday in a gruesome crash here when a minivan that he was trying to cut off slammed into him, officials here said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALCHIK, MEL
description: PALCHIK--Mel, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Lawrence, New York passed away November 19th surrounded by his loved ones at the age of 78. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend Toby. He will remain forever in the hearts of his children and cherished by his grandchildren. Donations in his honor should be made to cancer care.

title: Gold Prices Gain as Big Mine Abandons Hedging Strategy
description: Gold futures in New York rose for the first time in three days yesterday after Barrick Gold, the big producer, said that it was abandoning the practice of selling gold before it is mined.

title: Danone and Russian Company End Talks
description: Groupe Danone, the French food conglomerate, and Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods of Russia, a fast-growing juice and dairy company, have ended their merger talks, which have been the subject of market chatter here practically since the Russian company went public last year.

title: Kerry Outlines His First Steps as President
