description: Trying to stage a comeback in this all-important first-primary state, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts on Friday laid out his plan for the first 100 days of his presidency and promised ''to fight for every vote in New Hampshire.''

title: Body Is Found on Tracks
description: A woman's body was found yesterday on the subway tracks in the 18th Street station of the 1 and 9 trains, and the police were trying to determine how she died. Around 6 p.m., an operator of a northbound 3 train spotted the body, which the police said was that of an Asian woman in her 30's, and power was shut down between Times Square and Chambers Street. The woman's mangled body was found between the northbound and southbound express tracks next to the station, but within the station limits, said Marisa Baldel, a spokeswoman for New York City Transit.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Science Times on Tuesday about tests on dietary supplements for arthritis pain relief misstated a result. The testing company reported that two products for humans, not four, had significantly less of a major ingredient, chondroitin, than indicated on the label.

title: Putting down foreign roots: For expatriate writers, Hemingway's feast has long moved on
description: PARIS  The romantic archetype of the poor, isolated writer living abroad was perhaps best immortalized by Ernest Hemingway in "A Moveable Feast," his memoir of life in Paris as a young writer in the 1920s. Yet little remains of the kind of cafe life he described, while electronic communications, cheap travel and modern economics have virtually wiped out much of the expatriate writer ethos.

title: Father and Son Combine To Lift Don Bosco to Top
description: From the time he could walk, Brian Toal was in prep school locker rooms, observing two-a-day practices, attending football summer camps and cheering Greg Toal -- his father and favorite coach -- and his two older brothers to state football titles in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELULA, JEROME D.
description: GELULA--Jerome D. On November 20, 2003, after a long illness. Devoted husband of Maryann. Memorial service for the immediate family will be held at a later date. The family will sit Shiva at the Gelula home on Saturday, 7pm9pm, and Sunday, 2pm-5pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Nantucket Cottage Hospital, 57 Prospect St, Nantucket, MA 02554.

title: Wal-Mart Drops Two Putnam Funds
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has dropped two funds managed by Putnam Investments from its 401(k) plan offerings.

title: A Portrait Of the Artist's Troubled Daughter
description: She was the light giver, the ''wonder wild,'' James Joyce wrote of his daughter, Lucia. She was what Joyce scholars call the ''Rainbow girl'' in his masterpiece, ''Finnegans Wake,'' Issy the temptress, who magically breaks up into the colors of the rainbow. Lucia had a mind ''as clear and as unsparing as the lightning,'' Joyce once wrote in a letter. ''She is a fantastic being.''

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: DNA EVIDENCE FREES INMATE A man imprisoned for 16 years for the rape and murder of an elderly neighbor was released on bail after new DNA evidence showed that body fluids from the crime scene were not his. The inmate, Barry Laughman, above holding his niece, was serving a life sentence in the slaying of 85-year-old Edna Laughman, a distant relative. But last summer, The Patriot-News of Harrisburg said DNA samples from the case that it had tracked down and tested excluded Mr. Laughman as the source. He is seeking a new trial. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   UNGER, ROBERT
description: UNGER--Robert. Thinking of you and missing you each and every day. Your wisdom continues to inspire us. Anne and Toby Unge

title: Elias Has Final Say For Devils In Overtime
description: Despite the efforts of one very talented Penguins teenager, the Devils' unbeaten streak goes on.

title: For the Nets, No Apologies Or Fireworks
description: Twenty-four hours after their nasty near brawl, the Nets refused to acknowledge even a hairline fracture in their foundation.

title: INSIDE
description: Hepatitis Linked to Scallions

title: Special Registration for Arab Immigrants Will Reportedly Stop
description: The Homeland Security Department has decided to stop a program that required thousands of Arab and Muslim men to register with immigration authorities after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, officials said on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Cameras and Home Video section of the Holiday Buying Guide of Circuits on Thursday referred incorrectly at one point to the Epson Perfection 1670. It is a photo scanner; it is not a printer.

title: U.S. Survivors of Holocaust Lose Challenge on Fund for Victims
description: A federal judge this week rebuffed claims by American Holocaust survivors who said they were being treated unfairly in the distribution of part of a $1.25 billion fund created in 1998 when Swiss banks settled a class-action lawsuit over their role during the Nazi era.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Outlook For Office Equipment
description: Moody's Investors Service will consider upgrading the credit ratings of Japan's two largest office equipment makers, Canon and Ricoh, because of their profitability and strengthened finances. Moody's now rates Canon's long-term debt at A1 while Ricoh's is two notches lower at A3. In addition to producing office equipment like printers and copiers, Canon also makes top-selling analog and digital cameras. Moody's cited Ricoh's strong sales network. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: What the President Saw in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE
description: TISCH--Laurence. KiDS of NYU joins the New York community in expressing our heartfelt sympathies to the Tisch family.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Crackdown On Police
description: China has dismissed 259 police officers nationwide this year for offenses including drinking on duty, drunken driving and firearm violations, the state news media said. Central authorities have been pressing a campaign to clean up the nation's police force after domestic media reported in unusual detail on incidents involving beating deaths and gross negligence. The police have long been condemned for rights abuses by international rights groups. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAY, RONALD PATRICK
description: FAY--Ronald Patrick. Age 74 of Heathrow, Florida, died Tuesday, November 18, 2003. Ron is lovingly remembered for his warm smile, hearty chuckle, and sense of humor. A humble and modest man, he rarely mentioned his achievements. His integrity was without question and he was born a leader. Born in Milwaukee, WI. on May 25, 1929, Ron was the second of four sons born to Patrick Fay and Charlotte Welch. All have predeceased him, as well as Jean Reniewicki, his loving wife of 26 years. Formerly President of Wendy's International, the hamburger chain, Ron's character was formed during his 12 years of parochial school. He graduated from Saint John's Cathedral H.S. in Milwaukee, WI. in 1948. He was a member of Annunciation Catholic Church in Altamonte Springs, FL. and Saint Brigid of Kildare in Dublin, OH., where he maintained a second home. Ron was a veteran of the Korean Conflict and fought in the trenches at the battles of Hamburger Hill and Pork Chop Hill, where he was decorated for his service. Ron's impressive career began as a 14-year old busboy in a W.T. Grants department store in Milwaukee, WI. Ron quickly ascended the management ranks and was National Corporate Director of Marketing and Purchasing when the company filed bankruptcy in 1975. While at Grants, he pioneered a purchasing and delivery system that was adopted widely throughout the food service industry. He joined Wendy's in 1976 as a franchisee, but in 1981, he was named President of Wendy's International, overseeing one of the most intensely competitive periods in the industry's history. Under his leadership, Wendy's launched its widely successful ''Where's the Beef'' ad campaign. Ron retired in 1986. In 1990, he returned to the working world as the Operating Partner with Bob Stine, a Wendy's franchisee in Central Florida. The growing franchise was soon a regional leader in sales and operations. Motivating people by example, Ron visited at least one restaurant every day and was well known by managers and crew people alike. Just a few weeks before his death, the partnership was sold to Wendy's International and he retired. Ron was an avid golfer and former member at Tuckaway Country Club, Milwaukee, Indian Hills Country, Club, Long Island, Cavalier Golf Club, Virginia Beach, and Firestone Country Club, Akron. He was a current member of the county club in Heathrow, FL. and the country club at Muirfield Village, in Dublin, OH. While he had three holes in one, his proudest achievement was shooting a birdie on the 18th hole to help win the Pro-Am at the Memorial Tournament in 1985, teaming with John Bench and Tom Kite. Some of Ron's other distinguished golfing partners included the former Presidents, George Bush and Gerald Ford, and Neil Armstrong, along with a host of professional golfers whom he played with in a host of Pro-Am tournaments throughout the country. Ron was well-known for his homey aphorisms: do the ordinary things extraordinarily well; Keep on keepin' on, Kill'em with Kindness; I can only wear one pair of shoes at a time; you've got time to lean, you've got time to clean. Ron is survived by his devoted wife of 16 years, Ernesta Johnson Fay, Jean's children, Kallen Fay Brown (Rev. Larry), Lancaster, OH., Erin Marie Fay, Dublin, OH., Christopher Fay, Austin, TX., along with Ernie's children, Jennifer Nester (Steve), Lewis Center, OH., and Zachary Johnson (Shannon), Santa Barbara, CA., four grandchildren, Tarah, Derek and Kevin Brown of Lancaster, OH., and Luke Nester of Lewis Center, OH. Visitation will be held Saturday, November 22nd, 3-5PM at BaldwinFairchild Funeral Home, 994 E. Altamonte Dr., Altamonte Springs, FL. 32701 with a wake service 5PM at the funeral home. A family funeral will be conducted at Saint John's Cathedral, Milwaukee, and burial will be in Mount Oliviet Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Dave Thomas Foundation for Adoption, 1 Dave Thomas Blvd., Dublin, OH. 43017.

title: What the President Saw in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: William Macomber, Diplomat and Met Chief, Dies at 82
description: William Butts Macomber Jr., a former government official and diplomat who in 1978 became the first full-time president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Wednesday at his home in Nantucket, Mass. He was 82.

title: Germany, France and Russia Ask U.N. to Call International Meeting on Iraq's Future
description: Germany, France and Russia, three of the most vocal opponents of the war in Iraq, reunited in the Security Council on Friday to urge an international conference for the country, much like the conference for Afghanistan in 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Activity Rises
description: Industrial activity grew at a better-than-expected rate of 2.2 percent in September from August, a sign that Japan's recovery will pick up steam in the last quarter of the year. The growth reflected the recent recovery in production and an improvement in services, particularly finance and insurance. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNAMARA, JAMES J.
description: McNAMARA--James J., 81, on November 20, 2003. Beloved husband of 50 years of Rosemary. Loving father of John, Jeff, Elizabeth Melcher, Rosemary and James; dear brother of Eleanor and Muriel Daly; devoted grandfather of Christopher, Meaghan, Calla, William, Genevieve, Laura, Brendan and Bryan; also survived by many nieces, nephews and friends. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Heights, Saturday and Sunday 2-5, 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 11AM at the St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, Jackson Hts, N.Y. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, N.Y. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Sisters of St. Ursula, 50 Linwood Road, Rhinebeck, N.Y. 12572.

title: Save the Conservation Security Program
description: In the debacle of last year's farm bill, a few programs emerged that had both common sense and innovation behind them. One that actually made it into law was called the Conservation Security Program. It would pay farmers to keep up conservation practices they have already adopted and to add new ones as well. It was a way to support good farming practices in every region and on farms of every size. You didn't have to grow a commodity crop to qualify. It was, in short, a way for Americans to help farmers take good care of America's land. When President Bush signed the farm bill, he took the trouble to praise its conservation provisions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PRICE, BARRY
description: PRICE--Barry. Beautiful boy, away from us 28 years. You're always in our hearts. Love and kisses. Mommy, Daddy, Jodi, Blair and Mark

title: Knicks Offer No Relief To Ailing Houston
description: Allan Houston knew he desperately needed to take a game off to rest his ailing back. But Houston, the Knicks' captain, also knew how desperately his team needed him Friday night, especially with Keith Van Horn at home resting a sprained right ankle.

title: Free Trade,  la Carte
description: It was a good week for protectionists in Brazil and for subsidized American farmers. The outcome of this week's hemispheric trade gathering in Miami suggests that both will continue to be shielded from full competition in a global market. It also means the ambitious effort to create a mammoth free trade area throughout North and South America by 2005, begun with such fanfare nine years ago, runs the risk of being downsized to a point of near irrelevance.

title: Venezuelan Economy Declines Again
description: Venezuela's economy shrank 7.1 percent in the period from July to September, its seventh consecutive quarterly contraction, as its state-run oil company struggled to increase output after a nationwide strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, SHARON
description: SHAPIRO--Sharon. On November 20, 2003, at age 56. Beloved wife of Ahmed Halima. Loving mother of Shannon Shapiro. Dear sister of Michael Stark and the late identical twin sister, Wileen Meacham. Granddaughter of the late Abe Stark, Brooklyn Borough President. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Saturday, November 22nd, 11:30 AM. Interment New Paltz Rural Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to IAC, 39 West 14th Street, Room 206, New York, NY 10011.

title: College Football | Kickoff
description: TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS

title: Pushing Energy Conservation Into the Back Seat of the S.U.V.
description: Lynette Woide stayed home one recent afternoon so that someone from Progress Energy, the local utility, could check the house she has lived in for 20 years to make sure it was as energy efficient as possible.

title: Wal-Mart and Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Bill Would Welcome Back Diesels
description: Twenty-five years after diesel cars largely disappeared from American highways in a black cloud of tailpipe exhaust, the energy bill whose fate is hanging in the Senate invites a much cleaner incarnation back. These so-called advanced diesels would be eligible for tax credits equal to those in the bill for alternative-fuel vehicles and gas-electric hybrids.

title: Senate Blocks Energy Bill; Backers Vow to Try Again
description: Senate opponents of the energy bill blocked a final vote on the measure on Friday, at least temporarily derailing one of the primary policy initiatives of the Bush presidency.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: OKLAHOMA: MEXICAN MAN IS OFF DEATH ROW A Mexican citizen who came within days of being executed was sentenced to life in prison for a 1989 murder after Mexico protested that his rights had been violated, state officials said. On Thursday, a state court of appeals ordered the inmate, Gerardo Valdez, 43, resentenced in light of information that he had been denied a lawful consultation with the Mexican consulate. Mr. Valdez has admitted he shot and killed Juan Barron, cut up his body and hid it in a backyard barbecue pit in 1989 after Mr. Barron made unwanted homosexual advances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANASTASIO, ROSE
description: ANASTASIO--Rose. We will remember you & your sister, Mary, as two special people in the lives of the Mindel family.

title: Henry Phace Roberts, 92, Tap Dance Star
description: Henry Phace Roberts, a tap dancer who performed with the Copasetics and on television and in the movies, died on Nov. 8 in New York. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, SAMUEL
description: KLEINER--Samuel. Sam, you have been a great friend, advisor and mentor to all of us at Fisher Brothers. Your sense of humor, gentleness and kindness will be greatly missed. We send our most heartfelt condolences to Darlene, Ken, David, Christopher, Jeremy and Benjamin for your tremendous loss. You will greatly be missed but not forgotten. Staff of Fisher Brothers Management Company

title: ARMY IS PLANNING FOR 100,000 G.I.'S IN IRAQ TILL 2006
description: Army planning for Iraq currently assumes keeping about 100,000 United States troops there through early 2006, a senior Army officer said Friday. The plans reflect the concerns of some Army officials that stabilizing Iraq could be more difficult than originally planned.

title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Shopping (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Ethics Package Advances
description: In an effort to root out corruption in state government, legislators passed an ethics package that calls for the creation of inspectors general who could issue subpoenas to investigate improprieties. It would also prevent officials from taking jobs with companies they once regulated or granted state contracts of more than $25,000 for a year after they leave office. Registered lobbyists would be banned from serving on boards or commissions, and all state employees would be required to undergo ethics training. Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, a Democrat, has said he will sign the measure. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Insurer To List In New York
description: The largest insurer in China, the China Life Insurance Company, gained approval from regulators in the United States to list its shares in New York, paving the way for a $2.5 billion initial public offering, the largest in the world this year. China Life, the first mainland insurer to sell shares in the United States plans to sell 25 percent of its stock in Hong Kong and New York at 2.38 to 3.89 Hong Kong dollars (31 to 37 cents) a share, according to estimates by the sale's arrangers made in documents linked to the offer. The insurer, valued by its bankers at $7.9 billion to $12.9 billion, will start trading in the United States on Dec. 16 and in Hong Kong on Dec. 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, ALAN
description: ROSENBERG -- Alan. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to Helene, Stacy, Andrew and family. Alan was a great leader and admired by all in our industry. He was a prince and will be missed. Larry, Andrew and the entire Gans Family

title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mind That Grasped Both Heaven and Hell
description: Forty years ago today, as the world mourned the assassination of an American president, the passing of the 20th century's most influential Christian writer was hardly noticed: Clive Staples Lewis, professor of English literature at Oxford and Cambridge, died on Nov. 22, 1963. In his ability to nurture the faithful, as well as seduce the skeptic, C. S. Lewis had no peer.

title: About New York; Muted Finale To a Life Played Like a Sonata
description: ANOTHER New York nun passed away the other day. She got out of bed, sat down in a chair, said her last to a nurse, and died. She was 59, and will be buried on Monday near Scranton, alongside other Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary who went before her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURTON, MURRAY ELIAS
description: BURTON--Murray Elias, 78, M.D., F.A.C.S., Former Chief, Orthopedic Service at Hospital for Joint Diseases. Beloved husband of Anna, loving father of Deborah (Stan), Amy (John), and Andy (Sharyn), grandfather of Joshua, brother of Doris, loyal friend to many. Brilliant, witty, irreverent, loving, bigger than life. He will be missed. Services Sunday, November 23, 11:30AM, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue & 76 St.

title: Analysts See Terrorism Paradox: A Weaker Al Qaeda Despite Attacks
description: The recent surge in terrorist strikes on ''soft targets'' like consulates, banks and synagogues in places like Turkey and Saudi Arabia is worrying, but paradoxically reflects progress by the United States and Europe in disrupting Al Qaeda, especially its leadership structure, American and European intelligence officials said Friday.

title: Advantage Ladies? Advantage Fellas?
description: In its own oily way, an R&B concert is a remarkably even-handed event. The two halves of the audience are addressed separately, but more or less equally: if this one's for the ladies, then the next one will probably be for the fellas. And so when 112 and Kelis played Webster Hall on Tuesday night, the performers presided over yet another battle of the sexes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BURKS, ALVIN
description: BURKS--Alvin, on November 22, 2001. (Because you could not stop for Death-it kindly stopped for you...) Miss you. Harriette, Juanita, Ruth, Roslyn, Gyasi and Natasha

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, HAROLD, PH.D.
description: SCHWARTZ--Harold, Ph.D. On Thursday, November 20, 2003 of Short Hills. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Cohan) Schwartz for 52 years. Devoted father of I.B. Charneau, Liz Hinden and the late Jane Schwartz. Father-in-law of Bertrand Charneau & David Hinden. Loving brother of Irene Brustein. Adored grandfather of Keefer and Marlon Charneau, Jackson & Hunter Hinden. For information Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ on Sunday, November 23, 2003 at 1PM. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Jane Schwartz Foundation, 80 Kean Road, Short Hills, NJ.

title: Under the Musical Spell of the Sonidero; Mexican D.J.'s Relay Messages, on Dance Floor and to the Homeland
description: In droves, the young Mexican men crowded around Fausto Salazar at the nightclub, whispering softly in his ear or handing him poetic notes, as cumbia melodies whirled in the air around them.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the On the Ground column in the Business Travel pages on Tuesday, about Honolulu, misspelled the name of a hotel. As the column said it is the Ihilani Resort and Spa, not the Ilihani Resort and Spa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAWIL, IKE
description: TAWIL--Ike. We mourn the loss of a dear friend, most generous benefactor and valued member of the American Cancer Society family, Ike Tawil. To Joy Rosenthal and the Tawil family, we send our heartfelt condolences. Diana and Richard Feldman Luis Valero and Terrianne Zeifman Special Events Committee Don Distasio and Hector Batista of ACS Eastern Div.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHINDLER, JOE P.
description: SCHINDLER--Joe P., 76, November 20th, passed away after a long and valiant fight with Multiple Myeloma. Survived by children Deborah, Rachel and Aaron, son-in-law Todd Thaler and granddaughter Emma Thaler. We will deeply miss his guidance, leadership, strength, wisdom and love. Funeral service Sunday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Joseph Michaeli Multiple Myeloma Research Fund at the New York Presbyterian Hospital, Cornell, Att: Ruben Niesvizky, M.D. or A.J.C.

title: Pulitzer Board Won't Void '32 Award to Times Writer
description: The board that administers the Pulitzer Prizes said yesterday that it had decided not to revoke the prize awarded in 1932 to Walter Duranty of The New York Times for a series of articles about the Soviet Union that were later discredited as too credulous of Soviet propaganda.

title: Japan Offers Upbeat View of the Economy
description: Signaling renewed confidence in the economy, the Bank of Japan on Friday gave an upbeat assessment of the two-year-old recovery, thanks to a pickup in exports and manufacturing.

title: DaimlerChrysler Loses Bid to End Suit
description: DaimlerChrysler has lost a final bid to win dismissal of the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian's fraud lawsuit, which asserts he was deceived about the terms of the 1998 merger of Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corpopration.

title: Cialis, Lilly's Entry in Impotence Market, Is Approved
description: Cialis, a drug for impotence made by Eli Lilly & Company and the Icos Corporation, was approved yesterday, adding a new competitor in a $1.74 billion annual market.

title: Congress Set to Pass Bill That Restrains Unsolicited E-Mail
description: House and Senate leaders reached agreement on Friday on legislation intended to stanch the flood of junk messages filling e-mail in-boxes, making it likely that Congress will approve a final version of the bill by early next week.

title: Silverstein Will Get Most of His Cash Back In Trade Center Deal
description: The developer Larry A. Silverstein and his investors are getting back most of the cash they put up for their winning bid more than two years ago to take control of the World Trade Center in the largest real estate deal in New York history.

title: What the President Saw in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: Pension Funds Plan to Press Global Warming as an Issue
description: Officials controlling some of the nation's largest pension funds announced plans yesterday to press regulators, public companies and Wall Street to pay more heed to the potential financial upheaval from climate change. They said that their effort would be coordinated through a new group, the Investor Network on Climate Risk.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Extremists Banned:
description: The government banned three more Islamist groups, continuing a crackdown against extremist groups that was started last week. Some of the groups were outlawed last year but had re-emerged with changed names. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Mayor Seeks 10-Year Plan To Address Homelessness
description: The city is putting together a plan to end chronic homelessness in the next 10 years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Senate Blocks Energy Bill; Backers Vow to Try Again
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  Senate opponents of the energy bill blocked a final vote on the measure on Friday, at least temporarily derailing one of the primary policy initiatives of the Bush presidency.

title: Blame Home Schooling?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: UNIVERSITY STRIKE A student strike against government moves toward a Europewide system of degrees and higher tuition spread to 17 universities. The strikes started in Rennes in Brittany two weeks ago. Standard European diplomas have three levels, while in France there are five. Helene Fouquet (NYT)

title: Congressional Memo; 11th-Hour Bills Irk Lawmakers Left in the Dark
description: For weeks, hundreds of impatient Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill have steamed as Congressional leaders confined them to the anteroom while writing gigantic bills reshaping Medicare and energy policy.

title: Hippie Days Are Here Again (or Never Left)
description: Sometimes that old-fashioned holiday longing for a warm, loving extended family is better off unsatisfied. This is the first lesson that Dr. Mitch Snider, Southern California anesthesiologist to the stars, learns in ''National Lampoon's Thanksgiving Reunion,'' a silly, formulaic but well-acted television movie that will be shown tomorrow on TBS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, MARION
description: ALTMAN--Marion, of Edgewater, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Devoted mother of Howard and Karen Altman, Allan Altman, and Pavel Reyes and Kenneth Altman. Dear sister of Irwin Kirschenbaum. Loving grandmother of Seth Altman. Services were held Friday. For information ''Wien & Wien,'' Englewood.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: An Embarrassing Claim to Fame
description: North-South landed in a hopeless four-heart contract. South was facing a loser in each suit, with perhaps an additional trump loser. He knew from the bidding that most of the missing high-card strength was on his left.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: KASHMIR SEPARATIST GROUP AGREES TO TALKS Indian Kashmir's main separatist alliance accepted an Indian offer of talks. Umar Farooq, Kashmir's top cleric and a former head of the All Parties Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella organization of separatist groups, said the conference had a plan to end a 14-year Muslim revolt but gave no details. (Reuters)

title: Court Rejects Delay on Phone-Number Transfers
description: A federal court yesterday denied a request from a phone industry association to delay rules that allow customers to transfer numbers from traditional phones to cellphones.

title: POLYCOM TO EXPAND IN VIDEOCONFERENCING
description: Polycom Inc., the world's biggest maker of videoconferencing equipment, plans to buy Voyant Technologies, a closely held company, for $110.7 million to add conferencing services. Polycom may pay $35 million more in cash or stock to shareholders of Voyant over two years based on the sales of Voyant products, Polycom's chief financial officer, Michael Kourey, said. The purchase will add $10 million in sales each quarter and 1 cent to 2 cents a share to profit, starting in the second quarter, he said. The purchase gives Polycom the ReadiVoice videoconferencing service and call-routing technology products and about 100 customers, Mr. Kourey said. Polycom is based in Pleasanton, Calif., and Voyant is based in Westminster, Colo.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: University Strike
description: A student strike against government moves toward a Europewide system of degrees and higher tuition spread to 17 universities. The strikes started in Rennes in Brittany two weeks ago. Standard European diplomas have three levels, while in France there are five. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: The Power Of Marriage
description: Anybody who has several sexual partners in a year is committing spiritual suicide. He or she is ripping the veil from all that is private and delicate in oneself, and pulverizing it in an assembly line of selfish sensations.

title: That Superhero Guy? Try Apt. 3C
description: New York City is as important a part of the Marvel Universe as the Amazing Spider-Man. Here are a few crucial addresses in Marvel's version of New York. (Just don't tell Doctor Doom.)

title: No Charges For Jackson For a Week
description: The Santa Barbara County prosecutor's office said on Friday that it would not file formal charges against Michael Jackson until after Thanksgiving Day, leaving much of the case against the eccentric singer wrapped in mystery for at least another week.

title: Manning Rewrites The Family Legacy
description: David Cutcliffe has spent a lot of time in Archie Manning's living room. He first showed up there as the offensive coordinator of a Tennessee team that desperately wanted Peyton Manning, the middle son of one of the most famous sports sons of the South, to come to Knoxville. He got him. A few years later he was back as Mississippi's coach, hoping to talk Archie Manning's youngest, Eli, to throw the ball at Archie's alma mater. He got him, too.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MONAHAN, JAMES EDWARD
description: MONAHAN--James Edward. 1953--1998. It's lonely here without you. All that's left is the music. Sempre, Diane

title: 8 Are Arrested in a Medicaid Fraud That Used Agency Workers and Newspaper Ads
description: The advertisement in a Russian-language newspaper was straightforward: Medicaid benefits ''100 percent'' guaranteed to New York City residents who called a telephone number in the ad.

title: The President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Bush's Thanksgiving Day proclamation:

title: Merck Learns Anew the Risks of Focusing on Breakthrough Drugs
description: Several years ago, Merck researchers discovered a new cholesterol-lowering medicine. But the company decided not to develop it because it worked just like Zocor, its big-selling cholesterol pill.

title: Clothing Retailers Hope Shoppers Take Holiday Prices at Face Value
description: This holiday shopping season, America's clothing stores are offering their customers something they have not seen in years: full price.

title: Threat in Note Sends A Jet Back to J.F.K.
description: A passenger plane flying to London returned to Kennedy International Airport early yesterday after a flight attendant found a threatening note on a passenger seat in the plane, officials said. Airline officials later called the note a hoax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOUCHARD, EDWARD F.
description: BOUCHARD--Edward F., of Atlantic City, NJ (formerly of Northport, NY) on November 21, 2003, at 79 years of age. WWII veteran U.S. Navy, Lt. JG on USS Holt, retired Director of Safety and Regulatory Affairs with Pfizer Pharmaceuticals. Beloved husband of the late Virginia. Loving father of Richard, Donald, Barbara (the late Gerald) Sposato, Marie (Donald) DeFrees, and Joseph. Cherished grandfather of Gerald, Philip, Monica, Ricky, Valerie, Eugene, Elizabeth, Scott, Brian, Jacqueline, and Virginia. Great-grandfather of Alyssa. Devoted brother of Brother Joseph and Sister Alice. Reposing at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave., Northport, NY. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30 AM, at St. Philip Neri R.C. Church, Northport. Interment at parish cemetery. Donations to Birthright of Atlantic County, 3106 Atlantic Ave., Atlantic City, NJ 08401, in his memory appreciated. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUDSON, KAREN L.
description: HUDSON--Karen L., 55, died November 19 in Richmond, VA. Retired from NYNEX (AT&T). Visitation 4-6pm Sunday at Bliley Funeral Home, 8510 Staples Mill Rd, Richmond, VA. Graveside service Monday 11am, Forest Lawn Cemetery, Richmond VA. blileyfuneralhomes.com

title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Game Outdoors, National Hockey League Bundles Up
description: Like many who grew up playing hockey on frozen lakes, it didn't take long for Scott Ferguson to become familiar with the game's less celebrated elements: numb toes, a runny nose and mittens under his hockey gloves.

title: Macy's Band Playing It Safe, Skipping Jackson's 'Thriller'
description: This may not be the biggest bit of fallout from Michael Jackson's arrest on child molesting charges, but when one high school band struts in front of the cameras during Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade next week, the trombonists, sousaphonists and mellophonists will not play the piece they rehearsed for months.

title: N.Y.U. Has Nothing to Lose And Attempts to Win It All
description: Last month, with only one loss in an otherwise perfect season, the players on the New York University women's volleyball team had an epiphany. It occurred during the most unlikely of situations: back-to-back losses during a tournament in Huntington, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Jakiw Palij, a Queens resident who faces deportation over accusations that he was a guard at Nazi camps in Poland, included a location incorrectly among those at which he was accused of having been a guard at a Nazi training camp and a slave labor camp for Jews and, because of an editing error, misspelled the name of the correct location. Both camps were at Trawniki, not Trawinki. And the accusations did not involve the death camp at Treblinka. A quotation on this point from Eli M. Rosenbaum, a federal investigator, was rendered incorrectly. He gave the location as Trawniki, not Treblinka.

title: As House Debate Continues, Medicare Bill Nears Vote
description: A divided House debated legislation into the night on Friday that would make the biggest changes to Medicare since its creation in 1965.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TONER, KATHLEEN
description: TONER--Kathleen, IHM, on November 19. Samaritan House mourns the passing of our founder, inspiration, and friend, Sister Kathleen Toner. In 1984 Kathy created in Brooklyn the model home for homeless women and children. She developed the home, ran it and--most vitally-lived in it. Her vision helped turn around a city that once warehoused thousands of homeless mothers and children in the worst of welfare hotels to a city that finances scores of residences with supportive services for women and children in need. We will always remember and be inspired by her brilliant mind, her sense of humor, her loving heart, and her fierce protection of those most in need. Calling hours Sunday, November 23, 2-8 PM. Mass Monday, November 24, at 10:30 AM, Marian Convent, Scranton, PA.

title: UNITED'S FLIGHT ATTENDANTS' UNION OPPOSES MERGER
description: The United Airlines chapter of the Association of Flight Attendants said in a message to its members yesterday that they should vote against a proposed national merger with another union. The leaders of the chapter at United, a unit of UAL, said they opposed the merger with the Communications Workers of America because it would subordinate the flight attendants' union. The Association of Flight Attendants has 34,000 members while the C.W.A. has 700,000 members, the leaders at the United chapter said. In opposing the merger, those leaders are going against the recommendation of the national leadership of the flight attendants' union. Members have been voting this month, with the votes to be counted on Dec. 1. A spokesman for the national union said this month that a merger would give the Association of Flight Attendants more lobbying power in Washington. The leaders of the United chapter said yesterday that remaining an independent union would ''strengthen our profession and better support the people we have been entrusted to represent.'' Edward Wong (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; Mother Watches Proudly as Young Girl Surmounts Disability
description: Lyn Kest vividly remembers the best day of her life.

title: As Deadline for 9/11 Aid Nears, Many Relatives Haven't Filed
description: Members of New York's Congressional delegation say the federal government's ambitious effort to compensate the relatives of Sept. 11 victims will fall far short of its intent if Congress does not act soon to extend the Dec. 22 deadline for filing claims.

title: Leaders in New Jersey Legislature Push a New Set of Ethics Measures
description: After failing to pass major campaign reform bills during their last session, New Jersey legislative leaders are now pushing a series of new ethics provisions that would prohibit lawmakers from hiring their relatives or holding more than one public job.

title: Privacy Is Primary Issue, Mayor Says of 9/11 Tapes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vowed yesterday to challenge a federal subpoena requiring the city to turn over records of 911 calls from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He said that the request was ghoulish, and that complying would invade the privacy of the victims' families.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSS, HAROLD K.
description: ROSS--Harold K. One long sad year has passed. We continue to mourn your loss and love. We love and adore you. You are greatly missed. Love Sharon, Tiffany, Dean and Todd Ross

title: Freddie Mac Understated Its Earnings By $5 Billion
description: Freddie Mac said yesterday that it had understated its earnings by nearly $5 billion over more than three years, ending an 11-month review of the company's accounting that led to resignations by prominent executives and concerns by regulators and lawmakers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ARKIN, TESSIE
description: ARKIN--Tessie. April 10th, 1912 to November 22nd, 2000. Mom, you are always in my heart. Miss you more than you can know. Love, Joan

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Nov. 11 about Ravi Batra, a Manhattan lawyer who has been an influential figure within the Brooklyn courts, misstated the retirement status of a judge, Milton Mollen, at the time Mr. Batra organized a party for him, under circumstances that the two men dispute. The judge had retired several years earlier; he was no longer on the bench.

title: Mason's Broadway Revue Will End Run on Nov. 30
description: After receiving a round of negative reviews, ''Jackie Mason's Laughing Room Only,'' a new musical comedy revue at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, will close on Nov. 30, Mr. Mason's spokesman said yesterday. The show, which opened on Wednesday, will have played 31 previews and 14 performances.

title: As Filibuster Threat Fades, Medicare Bill Nears Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, said Friday that he would not support a filibuster against a bill offering prescription drug benefits to the elderly. His decision increases the chances for final action on the bill within days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINHARDT, JACK LEON
description: STEINHARDT--Jack Leon, on November 19, 2003. A man who knew an ecdysiast from an amanuensis. Decorated for his service in the ETO under General Patton in the 118 SRI Co. Whose love for broadcasting continued in radio stations in the South and Mid-Atlantic. Whose encyclopedic knowledge of movies and theater and passion for words never ceased to delight his wife of 53 years Anne, his daughter Thami, his son Avi and daughter-in-law Diane, or those who enjoyed the crossword puzzles he created for the New York Times. His grandchildren Miles, Shaylyn and Aaron will miss a kind, gentle, loving soul. As will all those who were part of his family, were his friends and who had the pleasure to work with or serve with him.

title: Patricia Broderick, 78, Writer and Painter
description: Patricia Broderick, a writer and painter who was the mother of the actor Matthew Broderick, died on Tuesday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 78.

title: Who Needs a Lecture? Coetzee Reads From a New Story
description: In a way it was no surprise. J. M. Coetzee, the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature, gave one of his first public appearances on Thursday evening since the prize's announcement last month by the Swedish Academy in Stockholm. But the extremely private, even mysterious Mr. Coetzee (pronounced kut-SEE-uh), though given a platform to express his thoughts on topics that preoccupy him, like literature, politics and animal rights, chose instead to embody his ideas more obliquely, in a work of fiction.

title: 2 Athletes In Abuse Case To Undergo Evaluation
description: Two Long Island teenagers accused of sexually abusing younger teammates at a summer football camp were taken away in handcuffs yesterday after a closed hearing in juvenile court in Wayne County, Pa.

title: Roars in Ann Arbor Likely to Reverberate
description: As a fifth-year senior, defensive tackle Grant Bowman of Michigan will take his last, long walk down the narrow, quiet tunnel of Michigan Stadium on Saturday when the Wolverines play host to Ohio State for the Big Ten championship and, for the Buckeyes, a chance at the national championship.

title: Generator Fumes Suspected In Deaths of 3 in the Bronx
description: Three members of a Bronx family, one of them a 2-month-old girl, were found dead in their home last night, a day after their electricity was cut off for lack of payment, the authorities said. The police are investigating the possibility that the cause was carbon monoxide poisoning from a generator in use at the house.

title: Messier and Sather Revisit Their Days in Edmonton
description: At age 42, Mark Messier could probably use a day off whenever he can get one. But instead of having a night off with the rest of the Rangers, he will be on the ice Saturday night when the N.H.L. stages an outdoor doubleheader before close to 57,000 fans at Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROEDY, ALAN E.
description: BROEDY--Alan E. On November 19th in his 60th year. Beloved son of Esther. Brother of Sheila, and uncle of Scott. Having met him, you would not forget him.

title: Government Makes It Official: Blame Scallions for Outbreak
description: Contaminated scallions, chopped up raw in salsa that was served free to every table at a Chi-Chi's restaurant in western Pennsylvania, almost certainly caused the large outbreak of hepatitis A in the region, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday.

title: Decline of the Language
description: To the Editor:

title: No Practice Is Perfect for Davies at Season-Ending Event
description: Laura Davies and Meg Mallon use different styles to produce winning results.

title: Uncertified Results Filed By Publisher
description: A day after Conrad M. Black abruptly resigned as its chief executive, Hollinger International filed a quarterly earnings report that it said would not satisfy the securities regulators who are investigating the company.

title: After 150 Years of Neglect, Berlioz Becomes a Fourth 'B'
description: The music of Berlioz -- odd in format, outsized in length and generally eccentric -- has skirted a central position in the standard repertory since his death in 1869. Celebrating his 200th birthday this year, on the other hand, has done wonders for his reputation. The Berlioz repertory issues from every opera house and concert hall. Perhaps audiences and performers, starved for innovation that has substance, don't mind going back 150 years to find it.

title: A Special Relationship, or an Abusive One?
description: Toward the end of the 19th century, Rudyard Kipling wrote two prescient poems that should be required reading for any student of the latter-day British-American ''special relationship,'' which has just been so effusively reaffirmed -- albeit amid protests -- by George W. Bush and Tony Blair across the Atlantic. The first poem, published to coincide with Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee of 1897, was titled ''Recessional.'' But instead of celebrating, as might have been expected, the greatness of the far-flung British Empire, Kipling drew attention to the transience of earthly power, and the ephemerality of global dominion: ''Lo, all our pomp of yesterday is one with Nineveh and Tyre.''

title: Estate Tax Lawyer Indicted by U.S.
description: One of the nation's most prominent estate tax lawyers, Owen Fiore of Gualala, Calif., has been indicted by a federal grand jury on charges he evaded $626,623 of taxes on more than $1.5 million of unreported income in 1996 through 1999.

title: Turkish Police Arrest Suspects in Attacks on British Sites
description: Turkish authorities said Friday that they had arrested several people in connection with two huge truck-bomb explosions that killed 30 people here on Thursday. Three groups claiming to have links with Al Qaeda have declared responsibility for the attacks.

title: Divided Over Iran's Nuclear Program, Agency Delays Action
description: The United States and Europe remain at such loggerheads over how harshly to rebuke Iran for its secret nuclear program that the board of the International Atomic Energy Agency on Friday delayed the passage of a resolution until at least the middle of next week.

title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: Baathists on Payrolls
description: Purging Iraq of the Baath Party has proved difficult, as some members have kept government jobs because local officials were afraid to make changes. In other cases, American commanders have intervened to keep Baathists on the payroll.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Airline Stake
description: Cerberus Capital Man-agement of New York has submitted a fresh bid for a stake in Air Canada, two weeks after the airline accepted a rival offer from a company controlled by Victor T.K. Li of Hong Kong. The airline, based in Montreal, accounts for about two-thirds of Canada's domestic air traffic. Cerberus and Mr. Li were the finalists in Air Canada's search for a new equity investor as part of a court-supervised restructuring. Mr. Li's company said that it viewed Cerberus's new offer as ''an improper interference.'' Mr. Li, who is a Canadian citizen and the eldest son of the Hong Kong magnate Li Ka-shing, has agreed to invest 650 million Canadian dollars ($500 million) for a 31 percent interest. Details of Cerberus's new offer were not disclosed. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas on Nov. 8 with a profile of Loc Wacquant, a sociology professor who took up boxing, misidentified a painting by George Bellows shown in a print that hangs at his home in Berkeley, Calif., and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the date of the painting. It is ''Dempsey and Firpo'' (1924, not 1922) -- and not ''Boxing'' (1901).

title: Yonkers Parents Growing Tired Of School-Financing Cliffhangers
description: For four years in a row, Yonkers officials have played chicken with school funding, and now -- for the fourth year in a row -- state officials seem to have blinked.

title: What the President Saw in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: Camelot, Cut Short On Nov. 22, 1963
description: To the Editor:

title: Camelot, Cut Short On Nov. 22, 1963
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Rubbery Ingredient Leads To Ice Cream Recall
description: A Massachusetts company said it was recalling more than 12,000 half-gallon containers of ice cream because they might contain a beige, rubberlike substance that poses a choking hazard. The company, the Friendly Ice Cream Corporation of Wilbraham, Mass., said the recall involved its ''apple pie  la mode'' flavor. The company said it had received three complaints, but no reports of injuries. The ice cream was sold in supermarkets, convenience stores and Friendly's Restaurants in the District of Columbia and 19 states, including Connecticut, New Jersey and New York. John Files (NYT)

title: At Sniper Trial, a Second Chilling Tape
description: On a second audiotaped confession, played for a jury here Friday, Lee Malvo revealed a chilling sense of humor, letting go with yips and giggles and prodigious belly laughs as he described the sniper attacks that left 10 people dead in the Washington area last fall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP., Bryn Mawr, Pa., an owner of water utilities, said it would buy Heater Utilities Inc., Cary, N.C., a water and wastewater business, from Allete Inc., Duluth, Minn., for $48 million in cash to add customers in North Carolina.

title: Baathists, Once Reviled, Prove Difficult to Remove
description: Purging Iraq of the Baath Party, the backbone of Saddam Hussein's dictatorship, has proved more difficult than many Iraqis had imagined.

title: Beliefs; The pigeonholing of religious combatants.
description: ''You can't analyze religion with categories like 'liberal' and 'conservative' that ultimately stem from politics.'' Everyone who regularly writes about religion has heard that complaint, and felt some sympathy with it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about relationships between American presidents and British prime ministers since World War II misstated the date of Bill Clinton's last visit to Britain as president. It was December 2000, not December 2001.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 424 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Bush Vows U.S. and Britain Will Work to Help Turks
description: President Bush said Friday that Turkey had become a new front in the campaign against terrorism and that Britain and the United States would work together to help the Turkish government head off further attacks.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Gene Anthony Ray, featured dancer in the movie ''Fame,'' misspelled part of the name of the Manhattan high school where he auditioned. It was Julia Richman High School, now part of the Julia Richman Educational Complex (not Richmond).

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about the Richard Tucker Music Foundation gala at Avery Fisher Hall, which included an aria from the opera ''Cecilia,'' misspelled the surname of the composer. He was Licinio Refice, not Recife.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I never believed that it was accidental that we didn't receive this bill until a very short time ago, 1,200 pages.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: NASA Official Hopeful on Shuttle Progress
description: NASA is making steady progress toward returning its shuttle fleet to flight so that construction of the International Space Station can resume, the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, said on Friday.

title: Whether Buying, Selling or Stalling, the Yankees Are Able Do It All
description: It has been a yellow-traffic-light kind of off-season for the Yankees, who are moving forward with caution. They are buyers, many other teams are sellers, and the free-agent market is loaded with talent. For now, the Yankees are waiting for the market to establish itself while they finish their plans.

title: Sports of The Times; Small Steps for Football, Giant Steps for Harlem
description: THE first play from scrimmage in the inaugural game was called 26 Power, the tailback running right, behind the tackle. ''It was a gain of about 2 yards,'' recalled the quarterback, Jachin Brown, acknowledging that it felt like two small steps for his football team, two giant steps to the future.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about relationships between American presidents and British prime ministers since World War II misstated the date of Bill Clinton's last visit to Britain as president. It was December 2000, not December 2001.

title: 33 Years Later, Draft Becomes Topic for Dean
description: In the winter of 1970, a 21-year-old student from Yale walked into his armed services physical in New York carrying X-rays and a letter from his orthopedist, eager to know whether a back condition might keep him out of the military draft.

title: World Business Briefing | Trade: Japan And Norway To Impose Tariffs
description: Japan and Norway said yesterday that they would impose duties on United States goods in retaliation for American steel tariffs. Japanese sanctions on imports worth $98 million add to a $2.2 billion retaliation list that Europe will impose on a range of products next month unless President Bush agrees to lift the tariffs. Norway is planning a 30 percent tariff on some products.

title: Hope and Anger in Kafil
description: Kifl, a small Iraqi village, is one measure of America's halting progress since Saddam Hussein's overthrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASS, BEATRICE (NEE HAYNIG)
description: BASS--Beatrice (nee Haynig). Of Forest Hills. Retired New York City school teacher died November 20. Loving mother of Allen, Elizabeth and son-inlaw Joseph Masci, beloved grandmother of Jonathan Masci. Funeral services at 1:00 PM Sunday, Schwartz Bros., Forest Hills.

title: Miss America Looks Beyond the Boardwalk
description: Looking to break out of stodginess and go a bit more national, the Miss America Organization last week appointed four new board members, including the man who wanted to rename the New Jersey Nets the Swamp Dragons and almost got away with it.

title: Corrections
description: A sports highlight entry and a picture caption in the Television section last Sunday for the Houston Masters Tennis Cup that day were outdated. Lleyton Hewitt, last year's winner, qualified for this year's event but decided against competing.

title: Elizabeth Clarkson, Brad Sutton
description: Elizabeth Alexandra Elliott Clarkson, a daughter of Eleanor M. Clarkson of Brookline, Mass., and Dr. Geoffrey P. E. Clarkson of Las Vegas, was married yesterday evening to Harold Bradley Sutton, a son of Michele and David M. Sutton of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Robert Kaiser officiated at the Mark Hopkins in San Francisco.

title: Ready for Revolution
description: My father's announcement took us children by surprise. My mother was part of the announcing, standing next to my father, her face a study in pride and determination. Any apprehension in her expression was held firmly in check beneath the weight of the first two.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Old Phones, New Uses

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARLMAN, ISABEL
description: PEARLMAN -- Isabel. For merly of New York City. Died November 7, 2003 in PA. at age 86. Survived by daughters Ruth and Jessica and granddaughter Jillian.

title: Scoring Against the Zone Plummets
description: Two years ago, in an effort to stop a considerable decline in scoring, the N.B.A. began allowing teams to play zone defense. The theory was that clubs would return to fast-break basketball to score before the defense could set up its zone.

title: In Praise of Nepotism
description: Most Americans have seen Francis Ford Coppola's Godfather trilogy, a Hollywood epic that celebrates three generations of an American mafia dynasty. Based on an equally popular novel by Mario Puzo, The Godfather's astonishing success fueled the rise of its director and his stars and spawned a host of imitations, establishing the gangster movie as the definitive American film genre of the late twentieth century. References to The Godfather permeate popular culture. Many people know the script almost by heart. Real gangsters are even said to have adopted the rituals and language of the Corleone family-a strange case of life imitating art.

title: Our Towns; Next Stop, the Trade Center, and Memories of the Last Ride Out
description: HE'S glad that they kept the name. World Trade Center. Others will no doubt disagree, but Richie Moran believes the greatest memorial at the PATH station opening today -- at the heart of ground zero and bearing a hauntingly familiar name -- will be the sight of trains rolling in and out again.

title: Business People; A Chance Meeting And a Mini-Makeover From the Expert
description: On her way to be honored by the Friars Club last week, and fresh from the salon, the investment diva Muriel Siebert ran into her friend Evelyn Lauder on the steps of the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Domestic Partner Registry Splits Great Neck
description: A proposal to create a domestic partner registry in the Village of Great Neck met with serious opposition last week from a divided board of trustees. Two of the five officials said they were worried that the law will be too far-reaching; one said it won't be effective enough.

title: Why They Take the A Train (and the 1/9)
description: DAVID Perez spends his workday on a padded stool in Elevator 108 in the 181st Street 1/9 subway stop in Washington Heights. He sits scootched back into his seat, so that his feet, in heavy black work shoes with blue gel insoles, don't quite touch the ground.

title: Closer Quarters
description: ALVA SCHULZ often gets angry when she looks out her window. Cars roar down her narrow street, and her wood-shingle cottage, where she has lived all her 76 years, is surrounded by large new houses packed tight where woods used to be.

title: Page Two: Nov. 16-22; THE BLACKOUT, EXPLAINED
description: In the early afternoon of Aug. 14, as power-line failures were building toward a historic blackout, a computer technician in Carmel, Ind., was trying to fix a program that prevents such events by developing an overall picture of the grid once every five minutes.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; TRAVEL
description: With gas prices falling, the roads will be packed with more Thanksgiving travelers than last year, said the AAA. Next Sunday is also the biggest air travel day of the year, according to the Air Transport Association, the airline industry's trade group. This year, the goal of the federal Transportation Security Administration is to screen each passenger in three minutes, not counting the time the traveler waits in line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, ALICE LEFTWICH
description: KING--Alice Leftwich. Of Bronxville, NY, died November 19, 2003. Widow of James H. Mother of Anne M. Regel, Patricia E. Kaufmann and Michael S. Sister of Edith Leftwich. Also survived by four grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, on Monday, 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Catharine Church, Spring Lake, NJ, on Tuesday at 11 AM. Interment St. Catharine Cemetery.

title: Spano Budget Bears Few Good Tidings
description: WHEN the Westchester County budget proposal for 2004 was made public not long ago, it bore few glad tidings. And one of the worst pieces of news for many people was that the budget plan relies on an increase in the sales tax in the county, where residents may already feel that they are being taxed within an inch of their lives.

title: Islanders Still Only Team Never to Beat Blue Jackets
description: It is one of those odd and embarrassing streaks the Islanders will have to wait until next season to address.

title: Iraq Picks American as Ambassador to U.S.
description: An Iraqi-American activist whose foundation has spent much of the last decade devising visions of democratic rule for Iraq and lobbying for a war crimes trial of Saddam Hussein, will become the country's diplomatic representative in Washington, Iraqi political leaders said Saturday.

title: It's Getting A Lot Harder To Cross Delancey
description: If New York can reduce the most seasoned drivers to a frazzled mess, a street like Delancey, which runs from the Williamsburg Bridge to the Bowery, is a good reason why.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Relationship Mended, a Reunited Family Must Establish a New Home
description: Like many couples, Dionne and Ryie Wells have a wish list for their apartment. They would like a freezer and new dressers. An entertainment center would be nice one day, too.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Before we talked only about girls and sex. Now we talk about Saddam -- and sex.''

title: The War Between The Street And Floor
description: IN early February, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, met with members of the New York Stock Exchange's compensation committee. The topic that day was Richard A. Grasso's pay.

title: 'Yellow Dog'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''The Serenity Prayer,'' by Elisabeth Sifton, on Nov. 2 misstated the date of a merger of two American churches -- the Congregational Church and the Evangelical and Reformed Synod (to which Sifton's father, the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr, belonged). They formed the United Church of Christ in 1957, not in the 1940's.

title: Dance Listings
description: MARIA BENITEZ TEATRO FLAMENCO  New work. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth AVe., at 19th St. (212) 242-0800. Tue., Wed., Fri., 8; Sat., 2 and 8; next Sun., 2 and 7:30.

title: Dear Mr. President: Are You Getting Out Enough?
description: BEFORE President Bush's visit to Britain last week, the liberal newspaper The Guardian asked 60 people to write him an open letter. Excerpts follow (the letters can be read in their entirety at www.guardian.co.uk/antiwar/story/0,12809,1087630,00.html).

title: The Excuse of Ignorance
description: To the Editor:

title: Founding Bubbas
description: THE HORNET'S NEST

title: Janine Gangi, Pradeep Jhanjee
description: Janine Theresa Gangi and Pradeep Robert Jhanjee were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the expansion of Arabic-language studies misstated the number of colleges and universities surveyed by the Modern Language Association last year about enrollment in language courses. It was 2,780, not 780.

title: Ideas & Trends; What Partisans Embrace, Politicians Fear
description: IN one corner are the social conservatives with their fists raised against gay marriage, girded for a new battle in the cultural wars. ''Politicians don't want to face it, but they're going to have to,'' warned Sandy Rios, the president of Concerned Women for America, a Christian group. ''It's going to be used by groups like ours as a litmus test.''

title: From Amityville, an Art Form Unto Himself
description: ON stage at the Westbury Music Fair, J.D. Lawrence flipped between characters. In one scene he was Mr. Clarence, a sassy grandfather checking for a baby bottle under the sofa cushion when he thought his daughter was coddling her son, a medical student. When the stage revolved moments later, Mr. Lawrence became Ms. Mary, a frumpy-looking, busybody church matriarch in a floral print dress with a falsetto voice, swinging her black pocketbook and passing judgment on makeup and drinking. In another scene, wearing a banana-colored wig and sequined sunglasses, Mr. Lawrence swished onstage as Sunshine, a brazen cafe manager, chiding her patrons and singing along softly as Edwin Hawkins, the four-time Grammy award-winning gospel singer, crooned a few lines of his hit ''Oh Happy Day.''

title: Sports of The Times; If Nets Keep This Up, Bidders Will Drive By
description: THUMBING through the weekend classifieds. . . .

title: What? No Presents?
description: WHEN Lily Hannigan of West Hartford turned 8, she played host to a birthday party. But instead of gifts, Lily asked her young guests to make donations to Foodshare, a nonprofit, anti-hunger organization in Windsor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LE CORBEILLER, CLARE
description: LE CORBEILLER -- Clare. Revered curator at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she served as curator in the Department of European Sculpture and Decorative Arts until her retirement in 2000. Widely respected, especially as a connoisseur and historian of French porcelains and silver, she also greatly furthered knowledge of German and Italian ceramics as well as of China Trade porcelain. She freely shared her erudition and boundless enthusiasm for her chosen subjects in many writings and in colloquy with other curators and students in the Parsons/Cooper-Hewitt Masters Program and the Bard Graduate Center. Her colleagues at the Metropolitan Museum mourn her loss while remembering her bravery and zest, and offer deepest condolences to her beloved husband, Jean, and their daughters, Suzanne and Genevieve. Philippe de Montebello, Director Ian Wardropper, Dept. of European Sculpture & Decorative Arts

title: Paycheck Goes, and the Dominoes Fall
description: OUR lives are held together by an unseen net, a complex weave of everything it takes to get us through each day. With only a small tear here, or a frayed spot there, the pieces of life begin to fall.

title: When Mini-Series Walked the Earth
description: Recently, CBS caved to political pressure and shunted its mini-series ''The Reagans'' off to the Showtime cable network. It was a depressing development for anyone concerned about de facto censorship, network cowardice or the career of James Brolin. But it was also another death rattle for that late, great TV genre: the blockbuster television mini-series.

title: Ideas & Trends: Environmental Calculus; Counting the Costs of Growth With a Forest of Formulas
description: IF the land-use planning process ever becomes a Saturday morning cartoon show (perhaps C-Span would be interested), the role of Suburban Sprawl would undoubtedly be played by somebody like the villainous Snidely Whiplash, facing off against the virtuous hero, Open Space, played by Dudley Do-Right.

title: Andrea Mirabito, Christopher Vecchiola
description: Andrea Lauren Mirabito, the daughter of Eliza P. Culverhouse of Coral Gables, Fla., and Andrew J. Mirabito of Miami, was married yesterday to Christopher Charles Vecchiola, a son of Gerre and Charles J. Vecchiola of Greensburg, Pa. Dr. David Perlmutter, who is an uncle of the bride and a justice of the peace in Naples, Fla., officiated at the Palms Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: Retirement in Mind, but Playing Well at 44
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 22  Rosie Jones, who turned 44 on Nov. 13, has insisted that 2004 will be her last full season on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

title: Democrats Fault Ad, but See It as Sign of Success
description: The Democratic candidates for president denounced the Republican Party on Friday for its new advertisement painting them as undermining the fight against terrorism -- saying it effectively questioned their patriotism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHINDLER, JOE P.
description: SCHINDLER--Joe P., 76, November 20th, passed away after a long and valiant fight with Multiple Myeloma. Survived by children Deborah, Rachel and Aaron, son-in-law Todd Thaler and granddaughter Emma Thaler. We will deeply miss his guidance, leadership, strength, wisdom and love. Funeral service Sunday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Joseph Michaeli Multiple Myeloma Research Fund at the New York Presbyterian Hospital, Cornell, Att: Ruben Niesvizky, M.D. or A.J.C.

title: In Teaching Civility, It's Everyday Stuff
description: IT was a sight to gladden the hearts of the standard-bearers of civilized behavior.

title: The Critic's Talk Back to Zagat; The Music Guide: 'Unreadable,' 'Average'
description: HERE'S a complicated question with a simple answer: What are the 10 best albums of all time?

title: Sorting Out Star Systems
description: IF you pick up a copy of Mobil's 2004 guide to the best hotels and restaurants in America, you'll find just three five-star hotels listed in New York City.

title: In Meriden, Parting of Ways As Scruggs Quits School Job
description: Judith Scruggs, the Meriden women who in October was convicted of putting a minor at risk after her son hanged himself nearly two years ago, has resigned from her position as a teacher's aide at the school her son had attended.

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: NONFICTION | FICTION

title: QUICK BITE/Teaneck; Turkey to Go or Stay
description: History links Thanksgiving to the Pilgrims and to the Mayflower. Noam Sokolow has a different ship in mind -- Noah's Ark. His deli/restaurant by that name in Teaneck offers a complete kosher Thanksgiving dinner for 12 for $149.95; it includes soup, 10 to 12 pounds of cooked turkey, gravy, stuffing, coleslaw, vegetables, rolls and a choice of three kinds of pie. Delivery is $20 more, or there are four seatings on Thanksgiving Day at Noah's Ark, which opened in 1988 and can hold 200. Mr. Sokolow, 36, has a Noah's Ark in Manhattan, too, and, across the street in Teaneck, Shelly's, a vegetarian restaurant.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; EUROPE
description: A battle of big versus small looms in Brussels, as finance ministers from the European Union meet to decide whether to discipline Germany and France for violating the union's limits on budget deficits. Small countries like Austria and the Netherlands are calling for Europe's giants to be given a strict deadline for cutting their deficits, with heavy fines if they fail. Germany and France insist they are already taking a scalpel to their finances. Few Europeans are betting on the little guys.

title: Iraqi Town Relishes Freedom, But Resentment Runs Beneath
description: The first bombs began falling unexpectedly on this village at 3:30 one morning in March. Ali Kazim Hamza was shepherding his family into what he hoped would be a safe room when one bomb landed outside his front door.

title: Bowing to Opposition, Leader of Georgia Steps Down
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 24  President Eduard A. Shevardnadze of Georgia, once acclaimed for his role in helping to end the cold war, resigned in disgrace today in the face of huge public protests over the corruption and economic collapse that have marked his 12-year rule.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Good to the Last Shop
description: SPREE: A CULTURAL HISTORY OF SHOPPING

title: Quiet Role of White Sox In Testing for Steroids
description: Kelly Wunsch said that the Chicago White Sox never planned to challenge Major League Baseball's steroid testing rules, but they did so last March. As players circulated a drug test acceptance form, Wunsch said, a few wondered what would happen if they refused to be tested. What would happen, the White Sox players learned, is that they could seriously influence the future of testing.

title: A Chance Meeting and a Mini-Makeover From the Expert
description: On her way to be honored by the Friars Club last week, and fresh from the salon, the investment diva Muriel Siebert ran into her friend Evelyn Lauder on the steps of the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Movies 2003
description: The academy blames the decline in Academy Awards TV viewership on ''awards overload.'' As a former, but not current, Oscar viewer, I can tell you that viewership started declining when the program started mixing the ''major'' awards throughout the evening, thus undercutting the suspense of the older format. Moving the current broadcast to February will do nothing to fix this.

title: The U.N. Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressman From Brooklyn Will Seek One Final Term
description: Representative Major R. Owens will run for re-election next year, but will retire from Congress after his next term, he said on Friday, previewing an announcement he plans to make on Sunday.

title: Credit Unions Go After a Larger Customer Base
description: MEMBERSHIP in a credit union has long been a perquisite for employees of some large companies, government agencies and the military, and for their families. A vestige of Depression-era America, credit unions were created to extend banking services to working-class people.

title: A Teacher Saw His Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Jodi Rubin, Michael Amaditz
description: Jodi Ellen Rubin, a daughter of Linda Rubin and Dr. Larry Rubin of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Michael Paul Amaditz, a son of Paula and Carl W. Amaditz of Forestburgh, N.Y. Justice Anthony T. Kane of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Albany, officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: McGreevey Pokes The Belly of the Beast
description: During many of the New Jersey League of Municipalities' annual conferences here, there are moments that feel like a collective exercise in averting one's eyes.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: 'A Feeling About People'

title: Wanted: More Campus Housing
description: LAST April, Montclair State University held a lottery for students interested in the Village at Little Falls -- a new 850-bed dormitory complex -- with four students to a unit sharing a living room, a kitchen, two bathrooms and three or four bedrooms. In a matter of hours, the complex was filled and a waiting list was started.

title: The Counterculture Had a Home, And Now It Could Become Official
description: Beatniks grooved in its coffeehouses. Earlier, freethinkers drank in its speakeasies. And even earlier, waves of Italian immigrants settled in the working-class neighborhood just south of Washington Square Park.

title: Just a Bunch of Big Babies
description: YOU can't stay young forever. But you can stay popular, as ''All Growed Up,'' the 10th-anniversary ''Rugrats'' special, proved on July 21, 2001. That evening, 70 percent of children in America between 2 and 11 tuned in to watch Angelica, Tommy, Chuckie and the rest of the Finster-Pickles clan morph from diaper- to designer-clad youngsters.

title: Business People; Pouring One for Ted
description: Sean Donohue is enjoying those long hours working to create United Airlines' new low-fare carrier, Ted, which begins flying next year.

title: Winning's Not No. 1 to This Team
description: MAX MAKSIMYADIS stands at the ice hockey net with the confident air of a 16-year-old who is cool and able on the rink.

title: A Tree Falls in a Co-op's Backyard
description: Q. I live in a co-op in Queens, and my apartment includes exclusive access to the backyard. During a recent storm a tree in the yard fell down and I had it removed. Is the co-op responsible for the removal of trees in the backyard since the trees have been there for many years, even before the conversion? Would the co-op's insurance policy cover a tree falling over in the yard or would the individual owner have to have that kind of coverage? . . . H. A. Jablonski, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, SAMUEL K.
description: KLEINER--Samuel K., 61 years old, died peacefully on November 18, 2003 after a valiant fight. Beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather, son, brother, uncle, brother-in-law and friend. He was a highly respected real estate attorney, serving as General Counsel to Fisher Brothers for the past 25 years. His zest for life was expressed by his devotion to his family, his passion for tennis and cinema and his commitment to his friends. He is survived by his adored and adoring wife, Darlene Diamond Kleiner, his beloved sons Kenneth (Farrah), David, Christopher (Mollie), Jeremy and Benjamin, his loved granddaughters Carson and Devin. Cherished son of Betty and the late Sidney Kleiner. He will be loved and missed by all that knew him. Service will be held at Central Synagogue (55th and Lexington Avenue), Thursday, November 20, 2003 at 10:30AM.

title: Wide Island
description: WHEN Robert Moses unveiled Long Island's parkways and Levittown advertised its reasonably priced cookie-cutter homes, New Yorkers couldn't uproot themselves from the city fast enough to claim their own patch of grass and breathe in all that fresh suburban air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACOMBER, WILLIAM B., JR.
description: MACOMBER--William B., Jr. 82, died peacefully on November 19th in Nantucket of complications from Parkinsons. Loving husband, brother and uncle. Survived by his wife Phyllis and brother John. He served in WWII as a Marine officer in the OSS. Parachuted into France on two occasions to work with the French underground and later in Burma. He was a firm believer in public service, working in various congressional, AID and state department posts including Ambassador to Jordan, Turkey and as Under Secretary of State for Management.
