Upon leaving the State Department in 1977, he became President of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He retired to Nantucket and taught social studies at the high school and helped coach their football team, the latter being one of his great joys. Contributions can be made in his memory to The Macomber Family Scholarship at Phillips Academy, Andover, MA or the Nantucket Atheneum, PO Box 808, Nantucket, MA 02554

title: Edward Schempp, 95, Dies; Fought School Bible Readings
description: Edward L. Schempp, a parent whose lawsuit against the required reading of Bible verses in school led to a landmark Supreme Court decision in 1963 restricting such practices, died on Nov. 8 at a nursing home in Hayward, Calif. He was 95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column on Nov. 9 about the fall dinner of the Dia Art Foundation on Nov. 6 at Dia: Chelsea misidentified the woman with La Monte Young and Jung Hee Choi. She was Marian Zazeela, not Amy Baker Sandback.

title: When New World Plants Were a Marvel
description: One of the delights for a gardener in winter is having the time to wander into a great public library and find some quirky exhibition. The one I stumbled on most recently, "America's Cornucopia: A Collector's View of American Botany and Horticulture," is at the LuEsther T. Mertz Library at the New York Botanical Garden, in the Bronx, through Feb. 16.

title: Movies 2003
description: I look forward to seeing Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson in Nancy Meyers's ''Something's Gotta Give'' about an older man (and a younger man) falling in love with an older woman (Lives, Nov. 9). However, while we older women are celebrating this movie plot, we should also note that Diane Keaton is about a decade younger than Jack Nicholson. Would it have been too radical to have an actress Jack's age playing his love interest? I was thinking of Maggie Smith or Vanessa Redgrave.

title: Bulgari Keeps Her Powder Dry
description: LIBERTY and makeup are not often held up as great companions, along the lines of, say, oil and vinegar or Laverne and Shirley. Indeed, if the early bra-burning women's movement can be said to have shared anything with corseted Victorian society, it was a sharp frown at the sexy smile that lipstick paints.

title: Debra Daumit, Jordan Klingsberg
description: Debra Michele Daumit, a daughter of Deedee Daumit and Dr. Gene P. Daumit of Charlotte, N.C., was married last evening to Jordan Lee Klingsberg, a son of Fran S. Klingsberg and David Klingsberg of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: New York Action Hero
description: ON a gargoyle gray afternoon, some 1,100 comic book fans shiver outside Midtown Comics, on 40th Street near Times Square, waiting to stump up the steep steps to get their copies of ''Amazing Spider-Man'' No.500 signed by three visiting dignitaries from Marvel Comics.

title: Stepping Between Bears and New Jersey Rifles
description: Encouraged by a recent court ruling that restricts hunting on federal land, advocates for animals have asked national park officials to curtail a bear hunt next month in New Jersey.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Demand Continues to Be Strong for Retail Properties
description: LAST year, as interest rates dropped toward record lows and the office market went limp, New Jersey real estate investors pursued retailing properties with intense interest. Now, with the end of 2003 near, that zeal has shown no sign of abating.

title: Goya
description: Ihad been thinking about Goya and looking at his works for a long time, off and on, before the triggering event that cleared me to write this book. I knew some of his etchings when I was a high-school student in Australia, and one of them became the first work of art I ever bought-in those far-off days before I realized that critics who collect art venture onto ethically dubious ground. My purchase was a poor second state of Capricho 43, El sueno de la razon produce monstruos ("The sleep of reason brings forth monsters"), that ineffably moving image of the intellectual beset with doubts and night terrors, slumped on his desk with owls gyring around his poor perplexed head like the flying foxes that I knew so well from my childhood. The dealer wanted ten pounds and I got it for eight, making up the last quid with coins, including four sixpenny bits. It was the first etching I had ever owned, but by no means the first I had seen. My family had a few etchings. They were kept in the pantry, face to the wall, icons of mild indecency-risque in their time-in exile. My grandfather, I suppose, had bought them, but they had offended my father's prudishness. They were the work of an artist vastly famous in Australia and wholly unknown outside it, a furiously energetic, charismatic, and mediocre old polymath called Norman Lindsay, who believed he was Picasso's main rival and whose bizarre mockoco nudes-somewhere between Aubrey Beardsley and Antoine Watteau, without the pictorial merits of either and swollen with cellulite transplanted from Rubens-were part of every Australian lawyer's or pubkeeper's private imaginative life.

title: Reproduction Values
description: GENESIS

title: THE LYRICS OF FRANK LOESSER
description: THE musicologist Robert Kimball has dedicated much of his career to the idea that great lyrics from musicals can be enjoyed on the page as well as in the theater. He has edited or co-edited a series of complete-lyrics volumes of the work of Ira Gershwin, Irving Berlin, Lorenz Hart and Cole Porter. His latest exhaustive anthology, edited with Steve Nelson, is ''The Complete Lyrics of Frank Loesser,'' published this month by Alfred A. Knopf. The book presents an impressive collection of witty, cunning favorites like ''Baby, It's Cold Outside.'' But the real pleasures are discovering the more obscure songs, like the comic duet in the following excerpt from Loesser's first musical, ''Where's Charley?,'' produced in 1948, two years before his smash ''Guys and Dolls.'' The song, ''Make a Miracle,'' has earned no less a distinction than an endorsement from Stephen Sondheim, who put it on a list of songs he wished he had written himself. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Bombers Kill 14 in Iraq; Missile Hits Civilian Plane
description: A missile hit a civilian airplane in Baghdad on Saturday, American military officials said, as suicide attackers exploded huge bombs at two police stations, one of them in this town north of Baghdad, killing at least 14 people, including two young girls, and wounding at least 50.

title: A Camel in the Sky?
description: OVER two years ago, the New York skyline lost some of its soul in the destruction of the World Trade Towers. To see the city without those towers is to see a stranger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHAETZEL, J. ROBERT
description: SCHAETZEL--J. Robert. On November 7, 2003, at home in Bethesda, MD. He is survived by his wife Imogen Spencer Schaetzel, two daughters and four grandchildren. There will not be a memorial service. Contributions in his name could be sent to America Coming Together (ACT), 1120 Connecticut Ave NW, Washington, DC 20036.

title: Revival Effort on the Half Shell
description: WHEN the Nature Conservancy on Long Island took title to 11,500 acres of submerged land in the Great South Bay last December, nobody in the group expected to find large numbers of clams. Neither did anyone expect to find so few.

title: The Island's Woods and Wetlands Are Her Inspiration
description: WHEN Barbara Roux grew up in Huntington Station in the 1950's and 1960's, her neighborhood included a farm, a section of woods and a vernal pond. As a child, she loved these places, which were untouched by suburban development. As an adult, she has devoted herself to protecting Long Island's shrinking natural environment while also capturing it in works of art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PASEKA, MARGARET CLARA (NEE MESZAROS)
description: PASEKA -- Margaret Clara (nee Meszaros). Born May 23, 1932, died November 13, 2003, in St. Thomas, U.S.V.I. Adventuress, world traveler, brilliant, independent, fearless, fun loving, caring and beautiful raconteur extraordinaire. Devoted school teacher at P.S. 221 in Douglaston. Loving mother of Kyle, Lawton, Kurt and Brett. Adoring grandmother of Katherine, Cody, Quin and Dylan. She will be missed by all. We love her so.

title: The Sari as a Sign of Progress
description: To anyone who has roamed the curry-scented neighborhoods of Edison around dinnertime or fought the urge to twirl to a Bollywood number ringing out of a double-parked Honda along Iselin's commercial strip, the jacket blurb on S. Mitra Kalita's new book, ''Suburban Sahibs'' (Rutgers University Press, $23.95), won't come as a surprise. ''Middlesex County, New Jersey,'' it says in part, ''is home to one of the largest Indian populations in the world outside India.''

description: Eric Lindros and Mike Dunham, the Rangers' No. 1 goaltender, practiced yesterday at the team's training facility in Greenburgh, N.Y.

title: Don Bosco Rolls Into State Final
description: Don Bosco Prep, ranked second in the country by USA Today, continued its march toward a second consecutive New Jersey football championship yesterday by routing St. Peter's Prep, 59-16, in a Parochial Group 4 semifinal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WONG, NANCY E. (LEO)
description: WONG--Nancy E. (Leo). In Monroe, CT, formerly of Rye, NY, and Houston, TX, loving wife of Kellogg, mom of Eric, Leta, and Trina, grandma to four grandchildren. Began her journey peacefully on November 8, 2003 after keeping lung cancer at bay for many months through the practice of Medical Qigong as taught by Master Benhui He. Her work as artist, designer, church worker and teacher in spiritual energy enriched our lives. Her exceptional quiet beauty, compassion and unconditional love, touched the hearts and souls of many throughout the U.S. and Asia. A Founding Member of The Houston Chinese Baptist Church, she was also Deaconess, Elder, and Clerk of Sessions of the Rye Presbyterian Church. Those who miss her, take solace in the belief that she will resume her good works at a new time and place. A celebration of her life will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church at 3 P.M. Saturday November 29, 2003. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the World Institute For Self Healing, 250 Lackland Drive, Suite 10, Middlesex, NJ 08846

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENROTH, STEVEN
description: MORGENROTH -- Steven. Born December 2, 1944, passed away November 18th in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Steve was the adored and adoring husband of Margaret (nee O'Shaughnessy) and the loving and proud father of Martin. He was pre-deceased by his parents, Carolyn and Julius, and his brother Marty. Steve's kindness, sense of humor and love of the NY Yankees will be forever part of the wife and son he cherished, his cousins Lynn, Mike, Teddy and Jon Friedman, and the many friends he has made over the years. We were lucky to have known you. The funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 23rd at 3 P.M. at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapels, 5411 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, FL. In New York, the family will receive visitors on Tuesday, November 25th from 2:30-9:00 P.M. at the Friedman residence, 50 East 89 Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

title: Page Two: Nov. 16-22; IN BRIEF
description: * Howard Dean, the Democratic presidential candidate, announced that a search team had found his younger brother's remains buried in a rice paddy in central Laos. The brother, Charles Dean, disappeared while traveling the Mekong River 29 years ago, when he was 23 years old. The Pentagon has not yet officially identified him, but personal items found with his body strongly suggest that the grave was his. Charles Dean is one of 1,875 Americans, including 35 civilians, still missing in connection with the Vietnam War.

description: STOCKING shelves and hauling boxes on the graveyard shift at Target was something Ed Marx never imagined he would be doing. After 27 years as a computer programmer, Mr. Marx said, he thought his technology skills ensured he would be employed in that field for many years.

title: Circus Minimus
description: MY daughter, Sonja, is behind the wheel of a lime green Fiat. She is 9 years old and about to hit the gas. Several young Italian men and women stand around her, instructing her in Italian and broken English, but mostly in vigorous body language. The expression on her face (anxious, perplexed) is what I imagine my own was while trying to find my way from the Forum to the Villa Borghese in a rental car with a questionable clutch.

description: FOR many parents, a third row of seats has become a must-have feature on vehicles ranging from S.U.V.'s like the Ford Explorer and Dodge Durango to sport wagons like the Chrysler Pacifica and Cadillac SRX.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRATZ, DONALD
description: GRATZ--Donald. On November 21, after along battle with cancer. Beloved husband and helpmate of Roberta. Doting father of Laura and Rebecca. Loving brother of Bill. Loving father-in-law of Jon and Joe. Adoring grandfather of Halina, Frank, Stella and Isaac. The owner and guiding force of Gratz Industries. Donald was the consummate craftsman and so much more. His wit was like a shaft of light. With him around, you never needed to dust off the encyclopedia. He could fix anything. He zipped through the Times crossword puzzle. He shot pool like a shark and he mastered the arts of friendship and love. Funeral arrangements to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you make a contribution to the Eldridge Street Project, 12 Eldridge St, NYC 10002, or cancer research.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution

I say go back to finding those intelligent, driven women without silver spoons in their mouths. We fought so hard in the early 70's to become recognized by top programs and change the admissions policies. If we're not careful, the subtle tide of hiring men over women for higher salaries will continue, and employers will be making the right decision.

But when most people in the audience applauded Dr. Dean, Ms. Liss did not. And when they leapt to their feet to cheer him on, Ms. Liss remained seated.

The Open Space Institute, a nonprofit land conservation organization, has bought the 9,646-acre Tahawus Tract from NL Industries, a Houston company that operated a titanium mine on a portion of the property between 1942 and 1984.

And as the official holiday shopping push begins, it is also a time to wander through stores and find a feast for the senses: gifts to see, touch, taste, smell and even hear. Below are some of this season's delicious temptations -- yet another reason to give thanks.

title: Cameras Love Neighborhoods. The Feeling's Rarely Mutual.
description: CHARLOTTE DEWALD had grown fond of the tree outside her Greenwich Village window, even though she didn't know what kind it was. Then one fall day, she looked out the window in silent greeting, only to discover that every leaf had been plucked off. A film crew, shooting ''The Out-of-Towners,'' with Goldie Hawn, had stripped the tree, apparently to simulate winter. When Ms. Dewald complained, she was told that the Parks Department had granted permission for the denuding.

title: 31 CASES OF WEST NILE VIRUS
description: The 30th and 31st cases this year of West Nile virus, the mosquito-borne illness, were reported by state officials last week. A 34-year-old woman from Wildwood and a 31-year-old man from Cranford are recovering. As with previous cases, the patients were not identified. The woman, who first showed symptoms on Sept. 25, was never hospitalized. The man, whose symptoms first appeared on Oct. 15, was hospitalized for 10 days. Last year, the illnesses of 25 people in New Jersey were diagnosed as West Nile. The state health department said test results in several other possible cases were pending.

When I was young if only I knew that I'd be spending so little time with you. I'm beginning to understand now that I'm sixty two, your old aches and pains that so bothered you. ...and Dad, I love you Larry

description: LITTELL--Gertrude (Gretchen) died at the age of 97 in Hendersonville, North Carolina on November 5, 2003. She was born in Keene, New Hampshire on December 27, 1905, to the late Rev. Dr. John Stockton Littell and Gertrude Wilson Littell. For more than thirty years, she worked as a proofreader for The New York Times. She was a poet and also active for many years as an actress in volunteer theater productions in the metropolitan area. She is survived by one daughter, Christine Adler, of Los Angeles, California, and a sister, Jean L. Winslow, of Wilmington, Delaware. Services and burial will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOUCHARD, EDWARD F.
description: BOUCHARD--Edward F., of Atlantic City, NJ (formerly of Northport, NY) on November 21, 2003, at 79 years of age. WWII veteran U.S. Navy, Lt. JG on USS Holt, retired Director of Safety and Regulatory Affairs with Pfizer Pharmaceuticals. Beloved husband of the late Virginia. Loving father of Richard, Donald, Barbara (the late Gerald) Sposato, Marie (Donald) DeFrees, and Joseph. Cherished grandfather of Gerald, Philip, Monica, Ricky, Valerie, Eugene, Elizabeth, Scott, Brian, Jacqueline, and Virginia. Great-grandfather of Alyssa. Devoted brother of Brother Joseph and Sister Alice. Reposing at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave., Northport, NY. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30 AM, at St. Philip Neri R.C. Church, Northport. Interment at parish cemetery. Donations to Birthright of Atlantic County, 3106 Atlantic Ave., Atlantic City, NJ 08401, in his memory appreciated. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: After a Bitter Debate, One School District Eliminates Tracking
description: NEXT fall, Abigail Taylor will enter Maplewood Middle School, following in the footsteps of two older sisters. But for the first time in years, sixth graders will not be separated into different classes for English, science and social studies based on grades and test scores.

title: Broadway's Too-Golden Golda Meir
description: GOLDA MEIR, whose life has inspired a current Broadway play, was something of a theater critic herself. In 1970, Israel's prime minister fired a broadside against ''The Queen of the Bathtub,'' a withering Tel Aviv play that mocked Meir and depicted an Israeli soldier returning from the dead to sarcastically thank his father for letting him die heroically on behalf of the Jewish people in the 1967 Six Day War. Meir was livid. Angry, divisive art undermined the patriotic, communal Zionist values that had built the Jewish state, she huffed. The play was eventually yanked.

title: POLITICS
description: The State Senate race that shattered spending records in New Jersey was resolved on Tuesday night when a recount of votes gave Fred Madden, a political newcomer, a 63-vote victory over the Republican incumbent, George F. Geist. Mr. Madden and his two Assembly running mates raised $4.2 million in the campaign, more than $200 for each vote they received. The previous spending record for a single legislative candidate was $1.8 million. The Fourth District seat was critical to the Democrats' fierce and well-financed campaign to take control of the evenly divided 40-member Senate. The Democrats won the 21st seat on election night, Nov. 4, so Mr. Madden's victory gives the party a 22-to-18 edge in the Senate. The Democrats also captured six seats in the Assembly, increasing their lead to 47 to 33. Laura Mansnerus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SISKIND, ROSELLA (NEE MASS)
description: SISKIND--Rosella (nee Mass). On November 12, age 81, resident of Great Neck. Brooklyn College Class of '42. Will be remembered as wife, mother, grandmother, sister, math teacher and dear friend.

title: In the Wild, Wild Backyard
description: A FLOCK of wild turkeys twittered nervously at some unseen danger one day not long ago, as Marlies and John Fry watched from their living room here overlooking the Cross River Reservoir. Then the Frys, spellbound, saw a lone coyote, slouched down low in the tall grass, stalking the birds like a cheetah.

title: Moriarty of Yale Wins IC4A Race
description: Biding his time behind the early pace-setters, Casey Moriarty of Yale surged from third to first after three and a half miles and raced on to victory in 24 minutes 58 seconds in the 95th annual IC4A five-mile cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Wealthy Schools Shun Fair-Aid Meet
description: AN education reform group made a stop on Long Island last weekend to rally support for a reapportionment of state aid to schools. But the meeting at Hofstra University, convened in an effort to reach a regional consensus about a court-mandated reslicing of the state education pie, wound up revealing more about the political fissures caused by decades of competition for state resources.

title: Page Two: Nov. 16-22; Bush in Britain; Terrorists In Istanbul
description: ON Tuesday night, President Bush arrived in Britain to present to the world a picture of an alliance resolute in its determination to defeat terrorism.

title: Is Order Chronological Or Emotional?
description: Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu doesn't shy from violence. Both his first movie, ''Amores Perros'' (2000), and his second, ''21 Grams,'' which opened Friday, tell multiple stories of people whose lives are forcibly entwined by a bloody car crash. But if Mr. Gonzlez Irritu is sometimes spoken of as Mexico's answer to Quentin Tarantino, the violence in his films is anything but playful. On the contrary, he uses it to underscore the pain and fragility of life. ''Amores Perros'' won more than two dozen awards worldwide, propelling Mr. Gonzlez Irritu, 40, into the front rank of directors who matter. Judging by its critical reception, ''21 Grams,'' shot in Memphis, Tenn., and starring Sean Penn, Naomi Watts and Benicio Del Toro, will only solidify that position. Last month, after ''21 Grams'' closed the New York Film Festival, Mr. Gonzlez Irritu spoke with Karen Durbin, the film critic for Elle magazine. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: Lisa Belkin's article (Oct. 26) and the letters in response (Nov. 9) made me queasy. What an agonizing quandary: whether to be a high-powered ladder climber or an at-home parent with a full complement of support and resources. This is a feminist dilemma? Just a reminder: most people can't opt out and later re-enter the work force when they've gotten that parenting thing out of their systems. Real life just doesn't allow for those kinds of luxurious choices. We live, we work, we raise our children -- and all at once, imagine that.

title: Ideas & Trends: Untying the Knot; For Better or Worse: Marriage's Stormy Future
description: TRADITIONALLY, the idea of being a little bit married made no more sense than being a little bit pregnant: you either were or you weren't.

title: Castles of Steel
description: On an afternoon in early July 1914, a middle-aged man with restless, bright blue eyes and curly, iron-gray hair boarded his yacht in the German Baltic harbor of Kiel, and the following morning departed on his annual summer cruise to the fjords of Norway. Two unusual and striking features marked the vacationing traveler: one of these he was eager to display; the other he was even more anxious to conceal. The first was his famous brushy mustache with its extended, upturned points, the creation of a skillful barber who worked on it every morning with a can of wax. The other, hidden from sight, but all the more noticeable for that, was his left arm, three inches shorter than the right. This misfortune was the result of an extraordinarily difficult breech delivery performed without anesthesia on his eighteen-year-old mother, Princess Victoria of England. He was unable to raise his left arm, and the fingers on his left hand were paralyzed. Every doctor had been consulted, every treatment attempted; nothing worked. Now, the useless hand was gloved and carried in his pocket, or placed at rest on the hilt of a sword or a dagger. At meals, a special one-piece knife-and-fork set was always placed next to his plate. To compensate for the helplessness of his left arm, he had developed the right to an unusual degree. He always wore large jeweled rings on his right hand; sometimes, grasping a welcoming hand so hard that the rings bit and the owner winced, the hand shaker said merrily, "Ha ha! The mailed fist! What!"

title: An Effort to Keep Warm May Have Killed 3 in Bronx
description: Early yesterday morning, a police officer could be seen removing a gas-powered generator from a Bronx house where three people died silently on Friday, their lives apparently claimed by fumes from the generator after they hastily set it up when their power was turned off on Thursday.

title: When You Need A Rental Car, Fast
description: ZIPCAR, the rental car club that provides funky cars like Volkswagen Golfs and Mini Coopers by the hour, has arrived in Westchester County.

title: Love in the Time of No Time
description: The city is full of people we can't reach. We pass them on sidewalks, sit across from them in the subway and in restaurants; we glimpse their lighted windows from our own lighted windows late at night. That's in New York. In most of America, people float alongside one another on freeways as they drive between the city and the places where they live. To lock eyes with a stranger is to feel the gulf between proximity and familiarity and to wish -- at least sometimes, briefly, most of us -- that we could jump the hedges of our own narrow lives and find those people again when they drift out of sight.

title: Victoria Gross, Daniel Coelho
description: Dr. Victoria Lynn Gross, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Gross of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., is to be married today to Dr. Daniel Henriques Coelho, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gary H. Coelho of New York. Rabbi Michael White is to perform the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: The People's Game
description: In Haikou, a city off the southern coast of China, a team of junior Olympic hopefuls drilled their way through another 40-hour workweek in the municipal arena. It was a warm day, like every day in Haikou. Outside the gym, walkers and cyclists in straw hats weaved sluggishly among the palm trees. Inside, the future of Chinese basketball couldn't stop himself from yawning.

title: A Day in the Life of Twyla Tharp
description: TWYLA THARP appeared at 6:03 a.m. on a recent Wednesday wrapped in a brown DKNY trench coat, her mop of silver-white hair bristling with energy in the predawn torpor of East 91st Street. At 6:04 a.m., she tripped over the prong of a forklift parked in front of Eli's Bread. Her newspaper lurched out of her hands. A fan of credit cards spilled from her wallet. She tumbled onto the street, hitting the ground hands first, executing a near-perfect forward roll and landing in a reasonable semblance of the splits.

description: AT about the age of 16, I decided I was not challenged in school. I asked my parents if they would support me in finishing high school early. They did, and I started at the local university.

description: As President Bush flew over the North Atlantic on Friday, heading home from three days as the houseguest of Queen Elizabeth, he switched his attention from the glamour of royal Britain to the grit of American politics.

title: When You Got It, Flaunt It
description: IF it's sex you're looking for, America's two most widely viewed porn videos of the year, starring Paris Hilton and L. Dennis Kozlowski, are nothing if not limp. Ms. Hilton's unimaginative exhibition, still playing on an Internet site near you, is as darkly lighted as a faded stag reel from the silent era. The hot parts of Mr. Kozlowski's $2 million toga party in Sardinia --so risible they were edited out of the version shown to jurors at his fraud trial -- include a guest ''mooning'' the camera, an ice sculpture of Michelangelo's ''David'' urinating Stoli, and a life-size woman-shaped cake with sparklers protruding from her breasts. Low camp hasn't had this high a budget since Bob Guccione made his movie of ''Caligula.''

title: The Democratic Way: Have Pencil, Will Prevail
description: By the time Maurice Y. Bisson had made up his mind to run for the Board of Selectmen in Hampton, the ballots had already been printed. But Mr. Bisson quickly proved that the democratic system was still viable in small-town Connecticut.

title: Alexandra Nelson, Scott Iwashyna
description: Alexandra Helen Nelson, a daughter of Doris M. Nelson and John R. Nelson of Richmond, Va., was married last evening to Scott James Iwashyna, a son of Eileen and Basil Iwashyna of Overland Park, Kan. The Rev. Dr. Nancy E. Meck performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: More on Glasgow
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently returned from a trip to Scotland, which included a stay the Kirklee Hotel, mentioned by Ms. Moses.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; POLITICS
description: Not even Thanksgiving can slow down the troupe of Democratic presidential candidates. On Monday, eight of them are assembling for another debate: the first officially sanctioned Democratic National Committee debate in Iowa, the first state to vote, in caucuses in January. So Democrats are looking to this one with a fair bit of interest.

title: A Battlefield In Belgium Lifts a Curtain On the Past
description: The muddy trenches of death of northern Europe have long been buried in pastures and farm fields, the memory of the slaughter of World War I kept alive only in black-and-white photographs and silent film.

title: In the Region/Westchester; For a Hospital Campus, New Research Buildings
description: ANTICIPATING continued growth of the biotechnology industry in Westchester, New York-Presbyterian Hospital is planning to begin construction next spring on a 384,000-square-foot treatment and research center on its 214-acre campus here. The $265 million Center of Excellence for Translational Medicine, as it is being called, will include a $100 million proton beam accelerator, designed to treat many different forms of cancer.

title: E.P.A. Extends Comment On Dredging Disposal
description: The Environmental Protection Agency agreed last week to extend until Dec. 15 a public comment period on plans for disposal over the next 20 years of up to 20 million cubic yards of dredged material from Connecticut rivers and harbors in two underwater disposal sites in western and central Long Island Sound.

title: Page Two; He Sure Acts a Lot Older Than 14
description: ''HE'S got to be older than 14.''

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: PURPLE HIBISCUS

title: The Bend in the River
description: WE would have had a blast in West Texas even if we had never gotten around to visiting Big Bend National Park. The park was the point of the trip, but my husband, Harvey, and I quickly realized that the region had a lot more going for it.

title: Drug Problems Driven by Money
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Another Holy Mystery
description: What would Jesus do, people sometimes ask themselves in these perplexing times. What would Jesus drive? What would Jesus read, I wonder. The Bible presumably. And if he wanted to be current, Dan Brown's thriller, ''The Da Vinci Code,'' which shot to the tops of the best-seller lists within weeks of publication last spring and has remained there ever since -- even though Brown's prose veers toward the clunky, Tom Clancy end of the thriller spectrum (as opposed to the more stylish end, represented by, say, Alan Furst). The book, while a gripping read, is not exactly an easy one: it's full of puzzles and anagrams to be solved, not to mention several minilectures on art history and iconography. Sales of ''The Da Vinci Code'' have been propelled, as is so often the case, by word of mouth. From the publicity and advertising and, indeed, from many of the reviews, you would never know what the book was about.

title: Brutality in Iraq: Don't Feed the Resentment
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Basil Academy Is Told To Apply for Change in Status
description: St. Basil Academy, a Greek Orthodox home for troubled children in Garrison, in Putnam County, has been told by state authorities that it must apply for a change in its status by Dec. 1 or face an order to close, school officials say.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Movies 2003
description: I'm curious to know why Robert Altman did not make the list of 70's iconic filmmakers in A. O. Scott's article, along with Scorsese, Coppola, Friedkin, Bogdanovich, Ashby and Rafelson. ''M*A*S*H,'' ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller'' and ''The Long Goodbye'' certainly rank among the best films of the era. (Not to mention that he gave us ''Gosford Park'' a couple of years ago.) Hell, let's throw in Woody Allen for that matter (''Annie Hall'' and ''Manhattan''). It was a great time to go to the movies!

title: Slim Pickings For Dessert
description: In the mid-1990's, it was not uncommon to encounter a block of underperforming Long Island wines. Today, the risk for consumers has declined significantly.

title: In Stonington, 'Wayne's World' It's Not
description: OVER the last few months, Marilyn Sheldon has become one of the most talked-about hosts that Comcast Cable of Groton has ever had for one of its public access programs.

title: Consumer, Beware
description: WHAT SHOULD I DO IF REVEREND BILLY IS IN MY STORE?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLA, FREDERICK
description: HALLA -- Frederick. We mourn the death of Fred Halla, patriot, friend & supporter. Battle of Brooklyn (1776) Committee

title: The Opposite of Fate
description: Soon after my first book was published, I found myself often confronted with the subject of my mortality. I remember being asked by a young woman what I did for a living. "I'm an author," I said with proud new authority.

title: Everyone's a Critic
description: NINA AND TIM ZAGAT, the people who elevated a pizzeria underneath the Brooklyn Bridge and a take-out soup shop to the heights of the New York culinary scene, are ready to bring democracy to the culture world.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Maloof Brothers; Boys and Their Toys
description: IF FHM or Maxim could invent their dream bachelor, he would no doubt be something like the Maloof brothers. Joe, 49, Gavin, 48, George, 39, and Phil, 35, run a billion-dollar family business that includes one of the top professional basketball teams in the country, the Sacramento Kings; the Palms Casino Hotel in Las Vegas; a record label, Maloof Music, with Interscope; and a racehorse named King Palm. They don't have weird hairpieces or paunches, they're friends with Tara Reid and they prefer grunge lite, like Puddle of Mudd and Nickleback.

title: Defense Portrays Different Sides of Sniper Suspect
description: Lee Malvo learned to shoot, his lawyers say, by playing ''very realistic and gory'' video games given him by John A. Muhammad.

title: Candice Koch, Geoffrey Postel
description: Candice Nicole Koch, the daughter of Paulette Koch and Dr. Ronald Koch of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there last evening to Geoffrey Ian Postel, a son of Bonnie and Ira Postel of New York. Rabbi Isaac Jeret officiated at the Breakers.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: I was troubled by the letter that suggests women who have chosen fields other than law or business ''seem to have more genuine passion for what they do.'' The issues raised by the article cannot be explained away by accusing the subjects of a lack of passion for what they do. The issues are also not limited to women or the fields of law and business. People should not blame themselves for lacking genuine passion for long, inflexible work hours and unsupportive work environments.

title: Home Alone: A Cautionary Tale
description: ''THIS is a big night for us,'' Penny Vane announced at a recent meeting of a community group. She explained that she and her husband had decided to allow their 10-year-old son to stay home alone for the first time. Both parents had meetings to attend that evening. They reasoned that they wouldn't be away from home long; they were close by, and Ms. Vane had her cellphone with her.

title: Playing (Silently): 'Bullitt'
description: LOS ANGELES might be a movie- obsessed town, but the inspiration for Jennifer McGarigle's dinner party came not from Hollywood but from a restaurant in San Francisco that shows silent movies on its outdoor patio.

title: Democrat Urges G.O.P. to Withdraw Bush Ad
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  With the television advertising wars gaining steam in the presidential campaign, the Senate Democratic leader angrily called today on Republicans to withdraw an advertisement that Democrats say depicts them unfairly as undercutting the fight against terrorism.

title: In Piermont, Detailed Elegance Awaits
description: PETER XAVIAR KELLY, chef and owner, is undaunted by scale; he seems to know exactly how to fit the gesture to the space. His other Rockland County place, Restaurant X, calling to the many, can accommodate a full-scale wedding. Xaviar's at Piermont, however, calling to the few, treats the discerning as honored guests in this lovely dining room, with only 11 tables.

title: A Longer List
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill to Curb Junk E-Mail Wins Easily
description: The House overwhelmingly passed legislation early on Saturday intended to reduce the glut of junk e-mail messages, and the Senate is expected to quickly follow suit this week.

title: INSIDE
description: Famed Client, Famed Lawyer

title: No Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Limits of a Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Meredith Fellows, Victor Cohen
description: Meredith Becky Fellows, a daughter of Marilyn Fellows of New City, N.Y., and Robert Fellows of Upper Nyack, N.Y., was married last evening to Victor Todd Cohen, a son of Judith and Raymond Cohen of Paramus, N.J. Rabbi Milton Kula, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Wartime Tales Of Sunken Ships And the Survival On Lifeboats
description: PHILIP J. WORSKI of Norwich was a Navy sailor who manned the guns on the merchant ship S.S. John Carter Rose during World War II, and vividly recalls the October day it was torpedoed and sunk in 1942, midway between South America and Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TONER, KATHLEEN, IHM
description: TONER--Kathleen, IHM, on November 19. Samaritan House mourns the passing of our founder, inspiration, and friend, Sister Kathleen Toner. In 1984 Kathy created in Brooklyn the model home for homeless women and children. She developed the home, ran it and--most vitally-lived in it. Her vision helped turn around a city that once warehoused thousands of homeless mothers and children in the worst of welfare hotels to a city that finances scores of residences with supportive services for women and children in need. We will always remember and be inspired by her brilliant mind, her sense of humor, her loving heart, and her fierce protection of those most in need. Calling hours Sunday, November 23, 2-8 PM. Mass Monday, November 24, at 10:30 AM, Marian Convent, Scranton, PA.

title: Oilers Old-Time Hockey: Gretzky and Messier Back
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 22  Moments after his Edmonton Oilers defeated the Boston Bruins in four games to win the Stanley Cup in 1988, Wayne Gretzky had reason to believe he would win a championship the next season, too.

title: Standard & Poor's Upgrades Nassau's Bond Rating
description: Nassau County's bond rating was increased by Standard & Poor's rating service last week, the second time this year the agency has upgraded the county's general obligation bonds.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery NumbersNov. 22, 2003

title: Alice Hughes, Christian Hull
description: Dr. Alice Teresa Dawson Hughes, a medical officer at the Food and Drug Administration, and Dr. Christian Manning Hull, an internist, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Claudia Gould Tielking performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.

title: Deborah Kirk, Peter Kahn
description: Deborah Heyman Kirk, a financial executive, and Peter Jonathan Kahn, a lawyer, were married on Friday by Judge Robert A. Katzmann of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in his chambers in New York. Yesterday, Cantor Joel L. Fleishman led a religious ceremony at the Peter White Studio in New York in which Judge Robert N. Chatigny of Federal District Court in Connecticut took part.

title: L.S.U. Stays in Title Contention After Countering the Magic of Manning
description: LOUISIANA STATE 17, MISSISSIPPI 14

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: LIVES OF THE ANIMALS

title: Destination Doll Palace
description: Little girls dressed for a Fifth Avenue holiday visit are a familiar sight. But last weekend, hundreds of them 4 to 9 were carrying dolls. Their destination was not Radio Center Music Hall, the tree in Rockefeller Center or the animated windows at Saks Fifth Avenue. These youngsters were 10 blocks south of their usual F. A. O. Schwarz destination. They were rushing to hair appointments for their dolls at American Girl Place, a three-floor entertainment and shopping complex for dolls and children, which had just opened at 49th Street. Some of the girls were dressed in matching outfits with their dolls.

title: The Slow Work of the Quick Change
description: HECTOR BERLIOZ'S comic opera ''Benvenuto Cellini'' is about the creation of an artwork, Cellini's sculpture ''Perseus Holding the Head of Medusa,'' which stands in the Loggia dei Lanzi in Florence, Italy. Cellini was a Renaissance man in every sense: a 16th-century goldsmith, sculptor, musician and memoirist, a swaggering, self-satisfied figure who saw himself as Michelangelo's artistic equal. Artists have taken up his cause ever since. Goethe translated Cellini's autobiography into German. Berlioz, also basing his work on the autobiography, created an idealized operatic portrait of Cellini as artist.

title: Health Insurance, But Provided by Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: After 200 Years of Growth, Level of Methane Stabilizes
description: After a 200-year rise driven mainly by human activities, atmospheric levels of methane, the second most important greenhouse gas, have stopped growing, scientists are reporting. Climate experts said the stabilization of methane, though probably temporary, is important evidence that steps to curb emissions could slow global warming even as disputes persist over what to do about carbon dioxide, the dominant greenhouse gas.

title: A Night of Balanchine, Pure and Simple
description: THE New York City Ballet will open ''Balanchine 100: The Centennial Celebration,'' its ambitious two-season tribute to George Balanchine, on a decidedly quiet note on Tuesday at the New York State Theater. The three ballets that will be performed -- ''Serenade,'' ''Bugaku'' and ''Symphony in C'' -- are pretty much standard repertory. Business as usual, but Balanchine's business was of a high order.

title: SHARPLY SPLIT, HOUSE PASSES BROAD MEDICARE OVERHAUL; FORCEFUL LOBBYING BY BUSH
description: A fiercely polarized House approved legislation on Saturday that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, after an all-night session and an extraordinary bout of Republican arm-twisting to muster a majority. The Senate opened its debate under threat of a filibuster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REID, WILLIAM J.
description: REID--William J. November 17, 2003, in Albany, NY. An internationally - recognized leader in advancing the scientific knowlege base of social work; author of over 20 books and 160 articles; the developer of the ''Task Centered Practice'' model now widely used in social services around the world; the founding editor of the journal Social Work Research; mentor to doctoral students and colleagues in many countries. Contributions in his memory may be made to the University at Albany Foundation, attn: The William J. Reid Endowment Fund, Albany, NY 12222.

title: Under Pressure to Change, Saudis Debate Their Future
description: The struggle over the future of Saudi Arabia is on.

title: My Dinner With Warren (Or Maybe With Bill)
description: Who is your fantasy dinner companion?

title: Health Insurance For All Americans?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Wheels, Four Churches
description: MY most common excuse for traveling these days is the need to accompany my teenage son Dan to tennis tournaments. The exercise I get during those trips consists of whipping my neck from side to side, watching the ball. So when Dan, our friend Dave, and I headed to San Antonio for the United States Tennis Association Junior Super National Hard Court Championships in August, I was determined to break a sweat myself.

title: A Wedding in Canada; Gay Couples Follow a Trail North Blazed by Slaves and War Resisters
description: ''HEAVEN was the word for Canada and the Negro sang of the hope that his escape on the Underground Railroad would carry him there,'' the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once noted in describing the codes American slaves used in their spirituals to fool their masters before taking flight.

title: Corrections
description: The Good Eating column last Sunday, about Thanksgiving dinners, misstated prices for Guastavino's. The restaurant's three-course dinner is $55, not $40. The price for children is $27, not $22.

title: Traditional Puerto Rican Music Finds a Home in New Jersey
description: ''GRACIAS, familia!''

title: Avis Offers Equipment For the Disabled
description: Avis is working to make driving easier for its disabled customers. The company has established a toll-free number for customers to request equipment for drivers and passengers with hearing and mobility handicaps.

title: Another Voice On Greenburgh
description: To the Editor:

title: Shevardnadze Faces Political Upheaval
description: Protesters in Georgia broke into Parliament, forcing President Eduard A. Shevardnadze to flee the hall, protected by bodyguards.

title: On Memorial, Criticism Outstrips Praise
description: It must be clear by now that New Yorkers do not lack for opinions. This was certainly the case yesterday at Pace University, where dozens of ordinary New Yorkers showed up to offer their views on the eight finalists for the World Trade Center memorial design competition.

title: From Grim to Gourmet
description: Just a few years ago, Clinton Street on the Lower East Side was grim and drug-infested. But in 1999 the restaurant 71 Clinton Fresh Food blazed a trail for fine dining, and the street is now a lively restaurant row.

title: Letters
description: High Times and Road to Ruin

title: A Harvest of Books by Notable Names
description: PUBLISHERS have produced a small boom this fall in the nonfiction category of ''barely known books by better-known people.'' At least four business books on that list deserve more attention than they may otherwise get.

title: Health Insurance, But Provided by Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; Oprah's Audience Wonders: Chair No. 1, No. 2 or No. 3?
description: If rebates and discounts become any bigger, Detroit will be giving away cars, or so goes the joke making the rounds in the auto industry. Last week, Ford did just that -- at least one car, anyway.

title: Sprawl and Aviation
description: WHERE planes once took off from an airport in Manahawkin, people now push shopping carts down the aisles of a giant Wal-Mart. Over in Marlboro, the airport closed last year and developers are seeking to build a housing complex there for the elderly.

title: DataBank; Indexes Dip, but Not Far From 2003 Highs
description: The three major stock indexes declined modestly last week on news of terrorism in Turkey and a further decline in the dollar. But the indexes remained close to their highs for the year.

title: Habitats/The Bowery; For an Art Dean, the Object Is the Objective
description: ROBERT RINDLER, dean of the School of Art at Cooper Union, has a saying: One thing is an object, two things are a pair. Three make a collection, and 100 things become art. How objects relate to one another, and the vibrancy and tenor of that conversation, is what fascinates Mr. Rindler, who uses these ideas to organize his own art -- photographic iterations of moments or objects -- as well as his one-room loft, a white painted rhomboid on the Bowery that he shares with James Connors, his partner of 25 years.

title: Hard to Find, but Worth Effort
description: THE Chachama Grill is a find in every sense of the word. After dark, it takes the tracking skills of Natty Bumppo to uncover this East Patchogue newcomer. There was no illuminated sign, and we circled the Waldbaum's shopping center a few times before spotting a leftover grand-opening banner with the restaurant's name.

title: Climate Lessons, Right From the Mountaintop
description: To the Editor:

title: No Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Capital? Just in Hartford
description: NO doubt, the shakeup of two of the largest insurance companies in the state is big news here. The companies, Travelers and CIGNA, employ thousands of people here and bring billions of dollars to the state's economy. When the industry makes a major move, people in the state hold their breath.

title: Corrections
description: The Habitats column on Nov. 9, about a onetime homeless person who is raising her family at Stratford House in the Bronx, included an erroneous figure from the president of Palladia, the agency operating the residence, about the price it paid the New York City Housing Authority for the buildings. It was $1, not $1 million.

title: Jannis Swerman, Don Rubinstein
description: Jannis Debra Swerman and Dr. Don Mathya Rubinstein are to be married today by Rabbi Mark Robbins at Congregation Ohev Shalom in Wallingford, Pa.

title: When New World Plants Were a Marvel
description: One of the delights for a gardener in winter is having the time to wander into a great public library and find some quirky exhibition. The one I stumbled on most recently, "America's Cornucopia: A Collector's View of American Botany and Horticulture," is at the LuEsther T. Mertz Library at the New York Botanical Garden, in the Bronx, through Feb. 16.

title: On the Front Lines
description: Telemarketers now know exactly how Americans really feel about them. The national do-not-call list started being enforced last month by the Federal Trade Commission, and 54 million phone numbers of testy customers are already on it. In order to comply, telemarketing companies must pay up to $7,375 every year to download the list and, in many cases, buy the software that automatically eliminates the registered numbers. We called five telemarketers at the Tele-Response Center in Weston, W.Va., and asked them how the new law affects their workdays.

title: Testing the Limits of Family: A Harrowing but Gleeful Journey
description: ON Halloween, when most kids only pretend to have hooks for arms or ghoulish features, the Tom family has a distinct advantage. Susan Tom, a sassy, no-nonsense single mother in Fairfield, Calif., has adopted 11 children with an array of infirmities and disabilities: buoyant, 13-year-old Xenia, for example, was born without legs; her sister Faith, 8, was severely disfigured by a fire in her crib.

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on Page 28 of The Times Magazine today, about fashion slang terms including "bling-bling," which can describe expensive jewelry, and its use in a Fox News headline about a theft from the rap artist Nelly, misspells his surname. He is Cornell Haynes Jr., not Hayes.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Business People; Ben Stein Is Worried About Your Money
description: As a television game-show host, Ben Stein regularly gave away his own money to winning contestants. But now he's worried about baby boomers' money.

title: Investing; Fund Scandal Puts College Saving Plans on Alert
description: OVER the last few years, investors' biggest complaint about state-sponsored college savings plans was that they often generated weak returns or actually lost money in the bear market.

title: Bling-Bling
description: When the rap artist Nelly, whose name is Cornell Hayes, claimed that more than a million dollars' worth of his jewelry had been stolen, the Fox News Online headline above the A.P. article read, ''Nelly's 'Bling-Bling' Stolen From Vegas Hotel Room.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Nov. 9 of a snowboarder at the Buttermilk ski area in Colorado, with an article about trends in the ski industry, carried an erroneous credit. It was from Jeffrey Aaronson/Network Aspen.

title: A 40-Story Pickle Commandeers London's Skyline
description: LONDON is about to be transformed. Work is nearing completion on 30 St. Mary Axe, also known as the Swiss Re tower, a 40-story skyscraper in the heart of the financial district. The architect is Norman Foster, a man famous for his audaciousness. He designed London's city hall, an eye-catching if utterly weird structure that looks like a bicycle helmet attacked by a madman wielding a large, dull ax. American tourists know Mr. Foster for his exuberant Great Court at the British Museum and for the delightful Millennium Bridge, linking the Tate Modern to St. Paul's Cathedral. But he has never been more audacious than now.

title: Sooners Leave No Doubt
description: OKLAHOMA 56 TEXAS TECH 25

title: Stonewalling the 9/11 Commission
description: The National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States has been working to determine what really happened on Sept. 11, and its accounting of that disastrous day must be as full and detailed as possible. After some reluctance, the White House is cooperating. The Pentagon has made tapes and transcripts available. Still, there is a key figure stubbornly refusing to hand over important data: Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

title: Queen Mary 2: Mourning, Then Back to Work
description: The gangway collapse in St.-Nazaire, France, that killed 15 people who were touring the Queen Mary 2 is not expected to delay the ship's inaugural voyage on Jan. 12 , a spokeswoman for the owner, the Cunard Line, said last week.

title: Tovah Reiss, Scott Kramer
description: Tovah Joy Reiss, a daughter of Phyllis and Alan Reiss of Suffern, N.Y., was married last evening in Lawrence, N.Y., to Scott Spencer Kramer, the son of Helen and Jeffrey Kramer of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Henry A. Sosland performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence.

title: This Old House
description: The redolence of old couture houses, of dowager labels more associated with fragrance than fashion, is wafting over the runways like so much floral perfume.

title: Safia Nurbhai, Kenneth Anand
description: Safia Anisa Nurbhai, a daughter of Scherie A. Nurbhai and Dr. Murtaza E. Nurbhai of Coudersport, Pa., was married last evening to Kenneth John Anand, a son of Dr. Bernadette T. Anand and Dr. Vivodh Z. J. Anand of Manhattan. The Rev. Laurie Sue Brockway, an interfaith minister, officiated at Grand Prospect Hall, a caterer in Brooklyn.

title: A Good Day for Mommy to Explain the Meaning of Life
description: IT felt like a day of playing hooky, cool enough for school to be in session, warm enough to spend the day outside. At 2 3/4, my daughter, Kate, is too young for school, so we headed uptown to the Cloisters, to take in the views, but save the museum for another day, or another decade, when Kate's fascination might turn from Disney princesses to those of the medieval variety.

title: Two Nations Fight AIDS
description: In the past few days, two nations with large numbers of AIDS-infected people have announced plans to distribute a triple cocktail of life-prolonging antiretroviral drugs free to all who need it. China has been treating 5,000 patients and plans to expand the program to cover everyone in the country. South Africa's cabinet approved a plan that includes drugs for all who need them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLOOM, BERNARD D., DDS.
description: BLOOM--Bernard D., DDS. April 11, 1922--Nov 23, 1992. 11 years ago today. Alive in our hearts forever. ..Jack

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Gordon Onslow Ford, 90, A Parisian Surrealist Painter
description: Gordon Onslow Ford, a painter who was one of the last Parisian Surrealists, died on Nov. 9 at his home in Inverness, Calif. He was 90.

title: They'd Ride the Subway, If They Could Only Get In
description: Aside from the occasional anxiety attack, subway riders tend to stay on a fairly even emotional keel, hovering between vague annoyance and muted resignation. Still, there are spots that can cause a commuter's blood to boil. The 34th Street/Herald Square station is one of them.

title: Grandma and Paul
description: THE WAY TO PARADISE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAWIL, IKE
description: TAWIL--Ike. We mourn the loss of a dear friend, most generous benefactor and valued member of the American Cancer Society family, Ike Tawil. To Joy Rosenthal and the Tawil family, we send our heartfelt condolences. Diana and Richard Feldman Luis Valero and Terrianne Zeifman Special Events Committee Don Distasio and Hector Batista of ACS Eastern Div.

title: The Reverend of Gospel Funk
description: JAMES CARTER -- This saxophonist is the ultimate peacock jazz musician, loudly showing off his gift and his seesawing traditional-progressive proclivities. On his new album, ''Gardenias for Lady Day'' (Columbia), he mixes a breathy-ballads temperament with anarchic squiggles when the mood becomes endangered by complacency. Though antique string-section grandeur suffuses the album, it's done with self-conscious gusto and intelligence, and here and there, with daring arrangements: a saxophone choir in ''Lowdown Groove,'' a brutal cacophony at the climax of ''Strange Fruit,'' sung by Miche Braden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WITKIN, ELAINE JUNE
description: WITKIN--Elaine June. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of Pamela and Patricia and mother-inlaw of Allen Dreyfss and Ira Rothstein. Adored grandmother of Michael, Jonathan, Brett and Jessica. Loving sister of Leona Post and the late Marion Godsick. Dear sisterin-law to Sophie, Ann, Diane and Fran. Her smile, her heart and her love will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Tax Cuts and New Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and picture caption in this section on Nov. 9 about warring high-end photo labs credited a large advertising sign erroneously to one lab, Coloredge. The sign, at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street for Louis Vuitton, was produced by a Manhattan company called Fuel Digital Inc.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Eternal Now of a Shakespeare Play
description: ''RIPPED from the headlines'' is not the tag line you would attach to Shakespeare, but the other way around works pretty often; headlines do seem to be ripped from Shakespeare. The latest reminder of this came last week at Lincoln Center Theater, where a glossy cast (Kevin Kline, Michael Hayden, Ethan Hawke, Audra McDonald, Richard Easton) opened in a production of ''Henry IV,'' which conflates Parts 1 and 2 of Shakespeare's history-inspired account of the jockeying for the English throne in the early 15th century.

title: Parkway Inspires A Career
description: AT age 15, Bryan Katz decided to take the road more traveled.

title: Page Two: Nov. 16-22; EIGHT DESIGNS, MANY OPINIONS
description: For the 13-member jury, the task was unenviable: choosing finalists for the World Trade Center memorial site.

title: Old School
description: Robert Frost made his visit in November of 1960, just a week after the general election. It tells you something about our school that the prospect of his arrival cooked up more interest than the contest between Nixon and Kennedy, which for most of us was no contest at all. Nixon was a straight arrow and a scold. If he'd been one of us we would have glued his shoes to the floor. Kennedy, though-here was a warrior, an ironist, terse and unhysterical. He had his clothes under control. His wife was a fox. And he read and wrote books, one of which, Why England Slept, was required reading in my honors history seminar. We recognized Kennedy; we could still see in him the boy who would have been a favorite here, roguish and literate, with that almost formal insouciance that both enacted and discounted the fact of his class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKST, SHARI
description: BAKST--Shari, of Boynton Beach, FL on November 20, 2003. Devoted wife of Bennett. Beloved mother of Lyle (Karen), Shauna Heeger (Peter), Kathy Miljanic (Mio) and Ronna. Loving sister of Andrea Goldberg (Martin) and cherished grandmother. Shari was devoted to many philanthropic and Jewish causes, and was past president of Women's American ORT, Five Towns Chapter. She will be remembered with love and admiration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, HORTENSE CINER
description: KLEIN--Hortense Ciner. On November 15, 2003, at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Daniel J. Klein. Loving mother of Carolyne and Edwin A. Levy and Robert and Susan Klein. Adoring grandmother of Jim and Sigal Levy, Matthew and Sharon Levy, Andrew and Alyssa Klein and Jeffrey Klein. Cherished great-grandmother of Danny and Lauren Levy and Olivia and Ellie Klein. Services were held at Frank E. Campbell. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALCHIK, MEL
description: PALCHIK--Mel, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Lawrence, New York passed away November 19th surrounded by his loved ones at the age of 78. He is survived by his beloved wife and best friend Toby. He will remain forever in the hearts of his children and cherished by his grandchildren. Donations in his honor should be made to cancer care.

title: The Takedown Artist
description: James Atlas (Oct. 26) quotes me as saying that reviewing is ''a fool's game.'' Since this would necessarily make me a considerable fool (I have been reviewing since I left university in 1988 and have followed no other profession), I am unlikely ever to have said it. In May, The New York Times interviewed me about my first novel, and mention was made of a negative review that had appeared in Britain, by Adam Mars-Jones. The interviewer wrote: ''Mr Wood, like Saul Bellow's Herzog, admits to fantasizing about writing letters to editors complaining about the bad reviews. 'I'd happily write to Adam Mars-Jones and tell him what I think of him,' Mr. Wood sighed. 'But it's a fool's game.' ''

When the actual beast shows up, he is nowhere near so formidable. And that, roughly, sums up the play itself. This is a pleasant enough show, with impeccable acting and some nice songs, but the gigantic payoffs you expect given the play's pedigree never arrive.

description: HAKIM--Touba. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the cherished matriarch of the Hakim family, beloved mother of Keyvan, a distinguished benefactor of our affiliate, The New York Synagogue. Our heartfelt sympathy to her nine children, 28 grandchildren, 41 great-grandchildren and two great - great - grandchildren. Her memory will always be a source of blessing and inspiration. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, Pres. Seymour G. Siegel, Treas.

title: For Anand, Fast Is Too Slow. But Twice as Fast? Just Fine.
description: The time limit in the Seventh Corsica Knockout Quickplay tournament was not quick enough for Viswanathan Anand, the 33-year-old Indian grandmaster. He did his dirty work in the tiebreaker games. After the first four games were drawn, at the rate of 10 minutes for all moves, plus a 10-second-a-move bonus, he had made no impression on his adversary, the Bulgarian grandmaster Veselin Topalov. Anand had to fight to get those draws. But once the time control was shortened to five minutes for all moves, plus a five-second bonus, Anand was in his element. He won the tiebreaker, two games to none.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORR, RHODA ELLIS
description: KORR--Rhoda Ellis. 88. Dr. Rhoda Ellis Korr, a former professor at Brooklyn College for 35 years, died November 14, in Sun City, AZ. Dr. Ellis earned her Ph.D. from NYU in 1944. She was active in the Beth Emeth Congregation, won awards for her work with the UJA-Federation of Greater Phoenix, and was a Charter Member of Sun City Hadassah and ORT. She is survived by daughter Joan Shrednick, sister Natalie Friedman and grandson Jason Shrednick (and wife Jacqueline). Rhoda was loved and respected by all who knew her and will be sorely missed.

Now Zurich, the financial capital of Switzerland, has a thriving night life and an excellent array of cultural events. Although the right-wing People's Party complains about foreigners invading the country, the influx has definitely spiced up restaurant choices.

But he simultaneously established a namesake organization devoted to housing for the poor and working class. Although his house is long gone, most of the projects of his creation, Phipps Houses, still survive, and now the organization is preparing a book on its work -- which is still going on.

When I read an article or a letter, I expect the name on it to be the author's. The P.R. rep argues that he is simply conveying my message more effectively than I could. But wouldn't I be lying to tack my name on his work? Tal Ziv, Honolulu

description: WHEN Betty Comden met Adolph Green, they were in their 20's, they were talented and they were struggling to make it as actors in the New York theater. Much like the Sherwood sisters in their musical ''Wonderful Town,'' which opens tonight at the Al Hirschfeld theater in its first Broadway revival since the original opening in 1953, Ms. Comden and Mr. Green spent their time knocking on doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, STANLEY
description: ROSS--Stanley. Died November 21, 2003. Born in Brooklyn, NY, January 20, 1924. Beloved husband of Bess for 55 years. Father of Alan, Michele and Caryn. Grandfather of Hanna, Haley, Jason and Jeremy. WWII veteran. Graduate of Brooklyn College, received J.D. and L.L.M. degrees from NYU and Brooklyn Law School. Founding member of the CPA-Attorney Society. In private practice for over 30 years and was an avid tennis player. ''You are our ever-lovin' Stan.'' For information, contact Munson Lovetere Funeral Home of Southbury.

title: Movies 2003
description: Much as I admire A. O. Scott, I think he stumbles when he calls ''A.I.,'' ''Minority Report'' and ''Catch Me if You Can'' ''as good as it is possible to imagine movies to be.'' No one doubts that Steven Spielberg is a wonderful filmmaker. But where others have gone to the brink and then stepped into the abyss -- I think of Godard's ''Weekend,'' Tykwer's ''Run Lola Run'' and Polanski's ''Pianist'' -- Spielberg seems always to take that little step back at the last minute. After establishing a bold and original concept in each of Scott's three examples, he settles for something well made but flat. None have resonance, either intellectually or viscerally; is there anyone who still debates them? They were delivered whole, complete, tied neatly in their packaging so that nothing was left for us.

title: The Way We Were
description: We've all had our ups and downs since 9/11, but last week's events in London tested even my congenital optimism. I was a participant in the 50th anniversary celebration of the Marshall scholarships. The Marshalls were created by the British government to honor Secretary of State George Marshall and to express Britain's gratitude for the Marshall Plan. Over the last 50 years, some 1,400 Americans have attended Oxford, Cambridge and other British universities on Marshall scholarships, paid for by British taxpayers. Twenty-eight years ago, I was one of those lucky Americans.

title: Sensory Stimuli
description: Thanksgiving is a time for glad gatherings and hearty indulgences. And as the official holiday shopping push begins, it is also a time to wander through stores and find a feast for the senses: gifts to see, touch, taste, smell and even hear. Below are some of this season's delicious temptations -- yet another reason to give thanks.

description: 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath split-level at 4 Cher-rywood Road, $645,000.

title: Disrepair and Crowding Plague British Trains

title: A Taste of France in a Corner of Stratford
description: PLOUF! is a casual French bistro imported into a waterfront neighborhood in Stratford. It is a real French bistro, not an American bistro. The food is French traditional, the chef is French and the experience of eating here feels remarkably French.

title: Finding the Intersection of Supply and Demand; Already Facing Demands for Higher Fares, City Considers Adding 900 Taxis
description: It is 5:22 p.m., and here at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street the rush hour dance is well under way: commuters are weaving toward the subway, lines have formed at the bus stops, hands are in the air for any available cab and a gridlock of cars and buses is on the streets, belching exhaust and raising tempers.

title: From Iceland to California
description: Olaf Olafsson's quietly moving new novel, WALKING INTO THE NIGHT (Pantheon, $23), is the story of Kristjan Benediktsson, a successful businessman in Iceland who, one night, packs his bag and deserts his wife and children for an actress in New York. The novel opens years later in San Simeon, William Randolph Hearst's fabulous estate on the California coast, where a guilt-ridden Kristjan -- now Christian -- is the butler to Hearst himself. Though it is unclear whether Kristjan renamed himself, his deep yearning to be unshackled from his past -- relatively poor parents, a lack of education, a sense of inferiority -- is palpable. Through letters he never sends to his abandoned wife, we learn that he first reinvented himself, earlier in life, in Copenhagen, where as a young man he waited on tables and cleaned classrooms. He meets his wife there and, from the start, Kristjan feels that in her presence he ''never knew which leg to stand on.'' He lies and tells her that he is working toward his business degree. They wed in Iceland, where Kristjan confronts who he truly is, and the pretenses on which he has built his life ultimately cause him to flee. He eventually lands in San Simeon, and even as he tries to ward off his memories by consuming himself in the details of caring for Hearst's castle, he is like one of the caged animals on the property: a sad and displaced prisoner. Olafsson, who writes in English -- he is the founder and former president and C.E.O. of Sony Interactive Entertainment -- based this novel on a true story. It is an evocative tale of grief and hope. Samina Ali

title: 'Oh, Garon!' May Echo On More City Sidewalks
description: PRAY for no rain. If the city gets its way, sidewalk cafes may soon spring up along Madison Avenue, in most of Midtown and in other areas of Manhattan where outdoor tables have long been barred.

The column also referred incorrectly to the Harlem Real Estate Board, which is headed by one of the home's owners, Michael T. Johnson. It is an association of brokers, not owners.

title: After 83 Years, Pitney Bowes Makes a Change
description: IT is hard to believe that downtown Stamford, which is dominated by Interstate 95 and a cluster of office towers, is home to a major factory. But Pitney Bowes, the $4.4 billion postage meter company, has been making meters in Stamford since 1920, when the device was invented by Arthur Pitney and Walter Bowes.

title: House Vote on Medicare Bill
description: Following is the 220-to-215 roll-call by which the House of Representatives on Saturday approved adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 195 Republicans and 16 Democrats. Voting ''no'' were 25 Republicans, 189 Democrats and one independent. Y is a ''yes'' vote. N is a ''no'' vote.

title: In Jets vs. Jaguars, It's Mentor vs. Student

description: To consumers who took nutritionists' advice seriously and began eating more fruits and vegetables, word that fresh green onions could carry the hepatitis virus came as a shock.

Long Islanders don't usually give much thought to recycling. And in the last few years, statistics show that many may be giving it even less thought, throwing out more trash while recycling less.

description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 23  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has hinted that he will consider unilaterally evacuating civilians from some isolated settlements in the Gaza Strip, as he prepares to renew negotiations with the Palestinian leadership.

title: Paintings Whose Figures Tell Tales
description: IN the 1960's when highly refined abstract painting was in vogue, Murray Zimiles began making narrative figurative paintings. Nowadays, since the art world has caught up with him, his kind of art is flourishing. Mr. Zimiles's inventive brand of realism is displayed in three distinct, yet related, series in ''Murray Zimiles: a Retrospective Exhibition'' here at the Neuberger Museum of Art .

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LICHTENSTEIN, HEDY HALPERT

title: Private Sector; Taking On the Tyco Challenge
description: LAURIE SIEGEL, the senior vice president for human resources at Tyco International, went to a management meeting last month. She and her fellow executives talked about international business, procurement, compensation programs, all sorts of nitty-gritty business subjects. Good ideas were floated, but what struck her was something else: ''It felt like such a wonderfully normal thing to do,'' she recalled, a smile spreading across her face.

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: You ran eight letters on Lisa Belkin's article. Not one addressed the issue of choice, or lack thereof. As a federal employee, I am entitled to unpaid maternity leave. It broke my heart to return to work when my son was 5 months old. My husband and I are scrambling to find a way for me to spend as much time as possible with the daughter we are expecting in a few months. I pray that we can, but it isn't looking good.

title: Congress Backs New Museum On Black History and Culture
description: Nearly 90 years after a similar idea was first advanced by a group of black Civil War veterans, Congress has passed legislation to build a national museum here dedicated to the history and culture of African-Americans.

title: How to Make The Deficit Look Smaller Than It Is
description: THE news on the federal budget deficit for fiscal 2003 was encouraging, wasn't it? In July 2003, the Office of Management and Budget projected a record deficit of $455 billion. But when the fiscal year ended in October, the shortfall was only $374 billion, equivalent to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product.

She's just standing at the ready, game to perform whatever silly song you might make up for her: a ballad about her love for you, a tribute to your best friend's golf game, a stirring rendition of the evening's dinner menu.

title: Guilty as Charged
description: I last saw my brother, Paul, in 1995 at a Dairy Queen in Tennessee. He was about to go to prison. He had been arrested for sexually assaulting boys who lived in his neighborhood. They were all under 12. We ate dinner and lingered over ice-cream sundaes. Mom couldn't look at him. Dad seemed old and defeated. I kissed Paul goodbye, figuring I would see him once more and we'd sort it all out. But he never explained himself; I still don't know his side of the story.

To celebrate that, the hotel will have $98 rooms Dec. 14 to 30, in single or double occupancy, plus tax. Availability is limited. Ask for the Fifth Year Anniversary Rate at (866) 610-0081. title: The Hornets Nest
description: Having experienced troubles with doubtful land titles in the Carolinas, Elijah Clarke and his neighboring families were careful to get the proper documents when they obtained rights to settle near the Savannah River along the northern border of the 1773 land grant. Elijah encouraged the other men to locate their homesteads so that the entire group could remain in close contact with one another. All of the cabins were soon connected with a spiderweb of trails. Elijah and Hannah decided to build a new cabin and barn that almost joined each other, and to accept the constant animal sounds and odors in lieu of risking another fire being set by undetected intruders. This proximate location made possible an additional safety precaution, as they spent weeks of hard work putting up a stockade of upright poles, just large enough to encompass the two buildings and a small yard. Except for slits left as rifle ports and the large swinging entrance gate, the barricade cut off their view of the surrounding woods, but they did not trust the Indians who lived only a few miles away, and felt that the increased safety was worth the trouble.
