title: Who's At The Door? A Doctor?
description: DR. JAMES FOLEY, 43, of Montclair, starts his day at 6:30 a.m. and often doesn't arrive home until 8:30 at night. But he doesn't work in an office, laboratory or hospital. He drives a Ford pickup truck equipped with portable EKG and X-ray machines in addition to a full array of medicines and medical instruments. Mounted to his dashboard is a laptop computer that contains patient records, the Physicians' Desk Reference and other texts. He also keeps three cellphones on hand, each a different color -- he rotates them to help minimize the cost of making 30 hours of calls each week, to patients, family members, pharmacies and others. And, oh, yes, his vehicle is equipped with a global positioning system.

title: Conserving Everyone's Energy but His Own
description: AN oval that appears to droop woozily to the south like a melting ice cream cone may not be the average person's idea of what a city hall should look like. But this is approximately the shape the architect Norman Foster gave the home of London's new local government, the Greater London Authority, completed in 2001.

title: Chicken Skeleton Project Gave Birth to a Doctor
description: Re the ''infamous chicken skeleton'' project, which has been offered by a veteran teacher in Great Neck for the past 30 or so years [''Homework: Liked or Loathed but Still Remembered,'' Nov. 16]: I am sure I am one of many former fifth- and sixth-graders who can safely say that this was one of the most challenging, creative and rewarding projects. Not only did we learn that a shin bone is actually a tibia and a knee bone is actually a patella, but we also had the opportunity to see, touch and construct these bones into a unified skeleton, and we saw for ourselves that they actually are connected to one another. While other students may have been traumatized, vegetarianized or disgusted by this project, I want to mention that it had other effects on some. I can still feel the satisfaction of those little foot bones (metatarsals) fitting so elegantly together.

title: Lynn Harris and David Adelson
description: FOR the better part of seven years, Breakup Girl, the blanket-caped cartoon superheroine created by Lynn Harris and Chris Kalb, has been dispensing advice online to the lovelorn and relationship-challenged. But when Ms. Harris was asked a week ago how she knew that the man in her own life was the one, her reply offered none of the wisecracking directness of her Breakup Girl alter ego.

title: Dreaming of a Drive-Through World
description: NOT far from Pittsburgh, men on the go can polish off a fast-food meal and then zip over to another sort of drive-through, this one just for dessert. The single item on the menu: fresh cheesecake. Yep, real girls taking their clothes off in something akin to a department store window. At 20 bucks for two minutes, not exactly a cheap thrill, but try to match that for convenience!

title: Dana Corp. Rejects $2.7 Billion Takeover Bid
description: DETROIT, Nov. 23  The Dana Corporation said today that it had rejected a $2.7 billion takeover bid, the latest offer from a rival maker of auto parts, ArvinMeritor .

title: The Unnamed Rsum
description: In the tight employment market, each online job posting can often elicit a flood of electronic rsums. Some come from people who are well qualified for the advertised position, but many rsums may be lacking one important detail: the name of the job seeker in the document file name.

title: Foes of Georgian Leader Storm Into Parliament Building
description: Protesters in Georgia broke into Parliament on Saturday, forcing President Eduard A. Shevardnadze to flee the hall surrounded by bodyguards, according to reports from the capital, Tbilisi.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Hailing the Chief

title: Gains for Pro-Democracy Party in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Nov. 24  Pro-democracy candidates mostly prevailed over pro-Beijing candidates on Sunday in the first elections here since three huge rallies last summer. Those rallies shook the political establishments here and in Beijing and forced the shelving of stringent internal security legislation.

title: Small-Town Gay America
description: A year ago, I moved out of the Dupont Circle neighborhood of Washington, the heart of the city's substantial ''gay ghetto,'' where I'd spent most of the past decade. In Dupont Circle -- a mile or so from the White House -- the sight of same-sex couples holding hands is a common one, and by the time I left, it no longer surprised me to see two men pushing a baby carriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHIFF, RICHARD L.
description: SCHIFF--Richard L., 83, of Boca Raton, FL. Died on November 14. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Cherished father of Mark, and Heidi. Proud grandfather of Evan, Vanessa, Kimberly, and Jennifer. Loving great-grandfather of Ethan. Devoted brother of Helen. An extraordinary man with a passion for living, who was ''loved the most.''

title: Hey, Mate, Get Your Mitts Off My Shepherd's Pie Mix
description: It all began with Heinz Baked Beans in tomato sauce. When customers at the Key Food supermarket in Park Slope, Brooklyn, saw that staple of British cuisine, they asked for more. Ribena black currant syrup. Shepherd's pie mix. Marmite yeast spread.

title: The Critic's Talk Back to Zagat; The Movie Guide: 'Sunny,' 'Distorting'
description: HAVING spent some time perusing the new Zagat Survey Movie Guide, I have reached a startling conclusion: people really like movies. More precisely, people -- as represented by the nearly 8,000 respondents whose anonymous opinions are synthesized in this slender silver-and-black volume -- really like the movies they like; the movies they don't like as much, they tend to like a little bit less. According to the guide's 30-point rating system, nearly every one of the 1,256 films falls somewhere between ''good'' (15) and ''perfection'' (30), with a substantial majority scoring higher than 20, which is where the climb from ''very good'' through ''excellent'' to ''extraordinary'' begins. Moreover, the ''uniform'' responses (represented by a solid black square) far outnumber the mixed responses (indicated by a black and white semaphore.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, LAURENCE
description: TISCH--Laurence. The Tisch Family Zoological Gardens in Jerusalem mourn the death of a true friend of the zoo, Laurence (Larry) Tisch.

title: Harassment Dismissed Against Parent of Dead Son
description: A Riverhead town judge has dismissed a harassment charge against a parent who angrily confronted a Riverhead school official he blamed in part for the death of his son.

title: 2 Israelis, 2 Palestinians Shot to Death
description: Gunmen on Saturday night shot and killed two Israeli security guards near Jerusalem as they were keeping watch near the West Bank barrier that Israel is building, Israeli security officials said.

title: Movies 2003
description: It's interesting that Rob Walker's article, ''Saving Oscar,'' ruefully shakes its head at all of those average Americans who don't bother to see any of the nominated films before the broadcast of the Academy Awards, when in fact several of the other articles in your Movies issue (Nov. 9) supply a number of plausible reasons why this is difficult for the average person, even one with discerning taste in film. Many ''contenders'' are released during a few short weeks in December, and many can be seen only in limited release (that is, in New York or Los Angeles). What option do those of us who live in the provinces have but to watch the Oscar broadcast for the pretty dresses?

title: Personal Business; New Rules May Set Off a Cellphone Scramble
description: FOR Omar Wasow, an Internet company executive who lectures about technology and has served as Oprah Winfrey's on-the-air technology expert, few things are as valuable as his cellphone number.

title: Introduction
description: Movies 2003 prompted critiques of Oscar -- and of a winner of the award, Steven Spielberg. And why not co-star Jack Nicholson with a woman his own age? some asked. The Lisa Belkin letters drew a strong response, extending the conversation about careers, children and the luxury of choice.

title: Fuentes's 'Don Quixote'

title: Late Kick Helps England Win Title at the World Cup
description: Australia knew exactly what was coming. There was less than 30 seconds to play in extra time in the final of the rugby World Cup on Saturday. The score was tied. The aging England pack made one last thrust at the opposition's line. Jonny Wilkinson, the England fly half, took up position.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALAIDJIAN, ELIZABETH B.
description: KALAIDJIAN--Elizabeth B., 81. Of Indian River Shores, Florida. Formerly of South Orange, New Jersey. A native of San Diego, CA. She worked during World War II at the U.S. Naval Hospital in that city. Beloved wife of 57 years of Edward C. Kalaidjian. Mother of Emma, Walter and Robert and proud grandmother of four. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to VNA & Hospice Foundation, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL. 32960.

title: M.L.S. Woos Hispanic Fans To the Game They Love
description: For Major League Soccer, a league that began in 1996 and that will play its championship game today at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., the nation's changing demographics offer a huge opportunity that it has often overlooked.

title: Business; When Nations Need A Little Marketing
description: SIMON ANHOLT, a British branding expert, spent a career developing international campaigns for Coca-Cola and Nestl. Now he is trying to put his image-making skills to work for a very different kind of client: countries with struggling economies, like Croatia and Slovenia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELLER, ROBERT SIMEON ISSAC
description: HELLER--Robert Simeon Issac, 79, on November 5. Devoted husband, beloved father and adored 'Poppa' and grandfather. We all miss you. Your Loving Family.

title: Business People; Henry's Take on Martha
description: It takes one to know one, or least that was Slate.com's theory when it hired Henry Blodget, the former Merrill Lynch securities analyst, to cover the trial of another white-collar headliner, Martha Stewart.

title: DEADLINE ON UNIVERSITY MERGER
description: Rutgers has until Jan. 1 to determine whether it will support the proposed merger of New Jersey's three research universities. Governor McGreevey, who set the deadline last Tuesday, said that a swift decision was necessary to get a $2 billion bond proposal for financing the merger on the ballot next November. The merger would integrate Rutgers, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the New Jersey Institute of Technology into one 67,000-student university with campuses in New Brunswick, Newark and Camden. A preliminary blueprint for the new system was disclosed earlier this month with the release of seven draft reports, which will be reviewed by a steering committee of university leaders on Dec. 10. Jessica Bruder

title: The World; Ahead of Any 9/11 Memorial, a Wall Bears Witness
description: THE gargantuan physical remnants of the World Trade Center often carried an emotional power beyond anything the original buildings could muster. Early on, the Gothic shard of the south tower's steel facade loomed darkly above the smoking ruins at ground zero. Then workers found the immense bronze globe by the sculptor Fritz Koenig, once perched 25-feet high in the center of the plaza, now horribly puckered and punctured by falling debris.

title: Sports of The Times; Clarett Casts a Shadow Over Fallen Ohio State
description: OHIO STATE will not repeat as national champion. Michigan saw to that yesterday with a convincing 35-21 victory at Michigan Stadium.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: AS COOL AS I AM

title: The Opt-Out Revolution
description: All of the published letters were from women, but I'd like to hear from the husbands: do they, perhaps, feel as if they've been victims of the old bait and switch?

title: Striped Bass Can Provide A Fish Story For Everyone In the Boat
description: With a nippy breeze blowing off Gerritsen Beach, the Flamingo III sliced through the misty waters near Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, in search of a big and noble fish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN DUUREN, BENJAMIN
description: van DUUREN--Benjamin, a pioneering cancer researcher who identified cancer-causing chemicals in cigarettes and was in part responsible for the warning label on cigarettes, died suddenly in Manhattan on Thursday, November 13. He was 77. van Duuren became a world-renowned cancer researcher during his 36-year career at New York University Medical Center in New York. Soon after scientists established cigarette smoking as a major cause of human lung cancer in the 50's, van Duuren began fractionating cigarette tars and isolated 21 arcmatic hydrocarbons, 6 of which were shown to cause cancer. In the 60's, with his research group, he elucidated many important ''structure activity relationships'' not only of chemicals found in cigarette tars but those found in many classes of cancer-causing chemicals used in industrial processes. His research made it possible to predict which chemicals might be carcinogens based on their molecular structure. Soon after the discovery of the structure of DNA he extended his studies to structure activity relationships with chemical carcinogens and animal DNA. Dr. van Duuren was born in South Africa and received his Sc.D. (Doctor of Natural Sciences) in chemistry from the University of South Africa. He did post-doctoral research with renowned chemist Roger Adams at the University of Illinois and then with Nobel Laureate Donald Cram at UCLA. In 1955 he joined Institute of Environmental Medicine of New York University Medical Center as an instructor and later became Professor and the Director of the Laboratory of Organic Chemistry in Carcinogenesis. He retired in 1991. van Duuren was a consultant and served numerous agencies engaged in cancer research including the National Institutes of Health, National Research Council, National Academy of Sciences, National Science Foundation, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Nutrition Foundation, the Department of Justice, and the World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer. van Duuren is survived by his wife, Satloo Gurbaxani. A memorial service will be held in 2004.

title: When Kennedy Came to the Bronx
description: To the Editor,

title: Spoiling (Carefully) for a Fight
description: In a green-and-beige hotel suite overlooking the Detroit River, John Edwards sits cross-legged, his back to the bleak Canadian vista, absently bouncing his stockinged foot. The day started so inspiringly, with Edwards, the North Carolina senator and presidential candidate, bounding up to the pulpits of two African-American churches and energizing crowds who'd never heard of him. (''The Lord is in this place!'' he shouted, to elated calls of ''Yes, sir!'') But now, a few hours later, here he is in Room 661 of the Renaissance Center Marriott, surrounded by a circle of half a dozen senior aides who are prepping him for tonight's Democratic debate. Nodding impatiently as he shifts in his chair, Edwards has the look of a man whose date has dragged him to a foreign film.

title: All About the Delicacy and Energy of the Line
description: 'Linear Investigations'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KIRKLAND, LINDA
description: KIRKLAND -- Linda. Pro foundly loved and deeply missed. Today we honor our mother's 54th birthday. Death arrived September 22nd. She was the best and gave the best. Our love will prevail. Our memories will abide. Zosera, Nikki, Chucky, Jenny

title: Page Two; One Book, Two Very Different Covers
description: PAUL KRUGMAN, the liberal economist and columnist for The New York Times Op-Ed Page, has recently urged his fellow liberals to be less civil toward their conservative foes. The British publisher of his latest book, ''The Great Unraveling,'' however, may have taken Mr. Krugman's advice further than he intended.

title: Schenectady Hits a New Low, And There's No Edison in Sight
description: Schenectady -- once so lively that Thomas Edison moved a company there and it grew into General Electric -- has experienced such a downhill slide that on Thursday, Moody's Investors Service gave the city the lowest credit rating of any municipality in New York State.

title: Spanish Option To Champagne
description: Jaume Serra's sleek, weightless, dry Cristalino Brut, a nonvintage Spanish cava (sparkling wine) with a floral bouquet, resembles expensive French Champagnes. This Catalonian white blend has fine bubbles and appetite-quickening green-apple flavor. It is economical for holiday buffets. K&D, 1366 Madison Avenue (96th Street), asks $8. A case purchase (with a 10 percent discount) is smart. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Tax-Free Accounts Drew Yeas From the Wary
description: For some conservative Republicans opposed to expanding a government entitlement program, the sweetener that allowed them to swallow the medicine and vote for the Medicare bill on Saturday morning was the inclusion of a new tax-free health savings account.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CONHEIM, SUE
description: CONHEIM--Sue. November 19, 1950. In ever loving memory. Marilyn

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE ending of ''An Unmarried Woman,'' when Jill Clayburgh proves her self-realization by refusing to commit to Alan Bates and carrying an enormous painting home by herself, has never rung quite true. But Judy Davis's speech when, as a simple country girl in 1890's Australia, she turns down Sam Neill's proposal in MY BRILLIANT CAREER (1979) does. ''Maybe I'm ambitious, selfish, but I can't lose myself in somebody else's life when I haven't lived my own yet,'' she says, adding that she has to at least try to be a writer. ''But I've got to do it now, and I've got to do it alone.'' Gillian Armstrong directed -- Thursday at noon on Oxygen.

title: A Not-So-Dutiful Daughter
description: THE OPPOSITE OF FATE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOVELL, DOUGLAS G.
description: LOVELL--Douglas G. Of Philadelphia, PA. Born August 17, 1927, died November 17, age 76. He is remembered for his travels to the world's great archaelogical sites, his avid interest in nature, and his infectious enthusiasm. Loving husband to wife Alida, and devoted father to his children; Douglas Lovell, Lexy Lovell, and stepchildren; Lylee Van Pelt, Ellen Jordan, and William Van Pelt, and grandfather to eight. His life will be honored with a celebration in May--in the tradition of the festivals he traveled so far to see--with music, color, and stories. Donations may be made in his name to the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology.

title: Giving Grazie
description: There's nothing wrong with Thanksgiving. It's the one holiday that doesn't inspire protests against trees and crches, stars and bushes or the rape of the country in 1492. There may be the tiniest whimper from vegetable-rights groups still angry at the way Chief Massasoit molested the maize in 1621, and the president does have to let the White House bird live every year (if you call that living), but basically Thanksgiving has warmly celebrated family and friends for well over 200 years.

title: International Datebook: Dec. 1 to 27
description: DEC. 1, KRAKOW, POLAND

title: Seeing San Francisco From On High
description: Sea gulls aren't the only ones with a bird's-eye view of San Francisco Bay. San Francisco Hang Gliding is offering rides on an aqua glider, a motorized, two-person hang glider that flies at about 2,000 feet. Equipped with propeller and pontoons, the ultralight craft takes off and lands on water while the pilot and passenger remain dry.

title: From Grit to Chic to Trs Chic
description: ON a typical weekday there is a bustle of activity at Chelsea Market, which occupies the ground floor of the old manufacturing building that covers the block between Ninth and 10th Avenues and 15th and 16th Streets. Shoppers browse the food stores to the sweet smell of baked goods, while others enjoy a snack at the tables spotted at strategic corners of the irregularly shaped main-floor corridor.

title: Fat Vehicles, Skinny Streets And a Bid to Avert Sideswipes
description: Ricky Pistone has watched the same harrowing scene over the past few years. On 95th Street in Ozone Park, Queens, two drivers in S.U.V.'s barrel toward each other but soon realize that they are closing in on an intractable problem of spatial relations: the 60-foot-wide two-way street can barely accommodate a row of parked cars on either side and the drivers' wide-bodied vehicles.

title: Claire Whittlesey, Brian Hochleutner
description: Claire Brown Whittlesey, a daughter of Linda Belding Whittlesey and Stephen Whittlesey of West Barnstable, Mass., on Cape Cod, was married yesterday to Brian Richard Hochleutner, a son of Mary and Richard L. Hochleutner of Del Mar, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Kristen L. Harper performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Barnstable.

title: Record Crowd Warmed By 2 Games Outdoors
description: It would have been understandable if Montreal Canadiens goaltender Jos Thodore was not thrilled about playing Saturday night in the N.H.L.'s first regular-season outdoor game.

title: Lessons From a Maverick Chief Executive
description: NOT many chief executives call themselves mavericks these days. But if you've lived to the age of 85 and have been involved in business for 60 years -- and if you knew Duke Ellington -- you may have earned the right to call yourself whatever you like.

title: Nassau Courts Get New Brooms
description: AFTER taking an elevator to the basement of the Nassau County Courthouse late last month, officials walked through a hallway narrowed by broken seats from jury boxes, an empty six-foot-tall tank that once held ammonia and piles of wooden chairs.

title: The Dodgers Weren't Enough: Now They Have Disney Hall
description: MOVIE stars, civic leaders and cultural administrators turned out in droves last month for the inaugural galas at Walt Disney Concert Hall, the spectacular new home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Among them was Zarin Mehta, the executive director of the New York Philharmonic, and it was hard not to feel a little sorry for him as he circulated through the elegant lobbies.

title: Business; It's Just a Game, but Hollywood Is Paying Attention
description: DAVE KILLINGSWORTH, 33 and a former disc jockey, is so immersed in pop culture that he has images of Spider-Man and Batman tattooed on his back. In his free time, he puts that passion to work betting in an online game, guessing which films will make it big. He is so good at forecasting the public's taste that he has reaped a windfall, at least in play dollars, turning $2 million into $460 million.

title: Michigan Ends Ohio State's Hopes of a Title Repeat
description: Running back Chris Perry scored two touchdowns in fifth-ranked Michigan's 35-21 victory over No. 4 Ohio State on Saturday, but he limped and winced on the field with what he said were hamstring and other injuries.

title: When College Savings Don't Go the Distance
description: I'VE been pretty smug over the years about letting everyone know that I've saved enough money to send my oldest child to almost any college she wants. But I'm less cocky about her three younger brothers, and less certain that there will be anything left for retirement. I keep telling my wife, Christine, that when we are older, we will probably end up living off the equity in our home.

title: CRIME
description: For a native Texan, Deborah Crombie always creates evocative settings for her British procedurals featuring the Scotland Yard detective Duncan Kincaid and his lover and partner, Gemma James, an inspector with the Metropolitan Police. So it's no slight to the intricately worked plot of NOW MAY YOU WEEP (Morrow, $23.95) to say that it pales beside its spectacular locale in the Scottish Highlands, where Gemma and her friend Hazel are spending the weekend. In a romantic multigenerational story about two feuding families of whiskey distillers, this land of natural beauty and historical violence is an overwhelming presence.

title: Republican Governors Voice Concerns on Iraq
description: Republicans at a governors' association meeting here raised concerns on Saturday about the Bush administration's ability to communicate its policies on Iraq, particularly as Americans continue to die.

title: Overcoming Graphomania
description: CAN we really keep blaming television and our image-driven culture for the decline of reading? In ''So Many Books: Reading and Publishing in an Age of Abundance'' (Paul Dry Books), Gabriel Zaid observes that since 1950, when television arrived on the culture scene, the world population has grown by 1.8 percent a year and the publication of books has grown by 2.8 percent a year.

title: The Prisoner Who's Happy Right Where He Is
description: ONE night last spring, Sandy Grushow, the chairman of Fox Entertainment, watched a rough cut of a pilot titled ''Arrested Development,'' chronicling the misadventures of a rich, goofily depraved family that suffers a reversal of fortune after its patriarch is arrested for Enron-like misbehavior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORDE, PHYLLIS EISEMAN
description: ORDE -- Phyllis Eiseman. Friends and family of Phyllis Eiseman Orde honor her memory by recalling her loyalty and friendship of many years. She was born in Cincinnati, OH on September 26, 1915, the daughter of Dr. Abraham and Ann Eiseman. She arrived in New York City in 1955 where she resided until November 4, 2003 at which time she passed away at Mount Sinai Hospital. Phyllis was devoted to the arts and subscribed to opera, concerts and theater. She was a tournament bridge player in New York City and on shipboard during her many travels abroad. An active alumna of the University of Michigan, she was a strong supporter of their library project. She was interred in the Eiseman family plot in the Clover Hill Park Cemetery, Royal Oak, MI. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a future date. We miss her.

title: 3 G.I.s Are Killed in Iraq, Including 2 With Slashed Throats
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 23  Three American soldiers were killed in Iraq today, including two whose throats were slashed, a military official said, after they came under attack in the northern city of Mosul with rocks and gunfire.

title: A New Boast for Dallas
description: AFTER living in Fort Worth for more than 20 years, I didn't have to think too much until recently about where to take out-of-town visitors -- or myself, for that matter -- to see the best art in northern Texas.

title: A Road Mystery (Clue: Think Detour)
description: IN Connecticut, Interstate 684 is a highway in name only. There is a stretch of road 1.4 miles long that is indeed in Connecticut, but it does not have a single entrance or exit in either direction anywhere in the state.

title: The Disability Gulag
description: 'My father died when I was 2, and I lost my mother when I was 5.'' Throughout my childhood, that's what Grandmother says. She's a fine storyteller with rare gifts for gross delicacy and folksy pomposity, but she doesn't give the details, and we don't ask. To me, it's enough knowing that she's an orphan, like Heidi -- like Tarzan even! What else is worth knowing?

title: Benefits of Vietnamese
description: WHEN new friends learn that I review restaurants in central New Jersey, we usually talk about the lack of reasonably priced restaurants that serve anything other than Italian, and then after a pause someone says, ''Any place around here to get a good bowl of pho?''

title: Sensory Stimuli
description: Thanksgiving is a time for glad gatherings and hearty indulgences. And as the official holiday shopping push begins, it is also a time to wander through stores and find a feast for the senses: gifts to see, touch, taste, smell and even hear. Below are some of this season's delicious temptations -- yet another reason to give thanks.

title: General Clark on the Hustings: Complexity and Contradiction
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark was losing his voice. He was whispering. It was also true that he was hungry and in a bakery. There was no chance he was leaving empty-handed.

title: Elizabeth Collins, Scott Ellard
description: Elizabeth Cannon Collins, a magazine executive, and Preston Scott Ellard, a real estate executive, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Mary E. Haddad performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

description: MYMAN--Ceil. Beloved wife of the late Israel, devoted mother of Robert and the late Martin, mother-in-law of Carmen and Barbara, and grandmother of Yelena, Marie and Francesca. We will remember, miss and love you forever.

title: In Northern Canada, the Land of the Inuit
description: FROM Ottawa, it's only a three-and-half-hour flight to Iqaluit, Nunavut. But what I could see from the window of the plane as we touched down made me feel as if I was visiting another planet: below was a cluster of low, boxy buildings set in a vast, treeless brown tundra. The otherworldly impression intensified when I took an exploratory walk outside my hotel and noticed a stop sign in which the English letters shared space with a script that I looked like nothing I'd seen before.

title: Don't Be Lulled: Interest Rates Could Be Poised to Leap
description: WHEN thinking of interest rates, think of a coiled spring. That tells you how quickly Treasury yields could rise, driving down prices across the fixed-income market.

title: U.N. Will Seek $300 Million For Reconstruction of Liberia
description: The United Nations, despite the drain on donors by Afghanistan and Iraq, hopes to raise at least $300 million in a conference early next year to help with the reconstruction of Liberia after years of civil conflict, officials here said this week.

title: The World: Car Culture; Like the U.S., China Favors Fuel Standards, Not Taxes
description: TO slow the swift rise in its consumption of oil, China could follow the European model: raise gasoline taxes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kid's 'R' Us Gives Notice: Prepare for Store Closings
description: Last week, Toys ''R'' Us Inc., which is based in Wayne, N.J., announced that it would be closing all 146 of its free-standing Kids ''R'' Us stores and 36 Imaginarium stores across the country, a decision that includes several locations in Connecticut.

title: Oxford, Take 2
description: To the Editor:

title: London Rentals
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Finding London Apartments'' (Q&A, Nov. 9), by Ray Cormier, our family of four has spent a week in London twice in the past three years, and I found apartments by using A Place Like Home, 1 Anhalt Road, London SW11 4NZ; telephone (44-207) 228 4668, fax (44-207) 738 1626, Web site www.aplacelikehomelondon.co.uk.

title: In Bustling Bangkok, An Exotic Allure
description: IT'S easy when you first visit a city to form a lasting impression on the basis of what you see on the way into town from the airport.

title: To the Rebuilt Station
description: IT was all eerily familiar, but different too, this PATH station for New Jersey commuters. Where there had been a solid wall of tiles separating the station from a parking garage, there was now a wall of thick glass, providing a view of a sunlit chasm at the base of what once was the World Trade Center. The stairways and escalators were just as steep as they rose to the street. The stairs even wound past a newsstand rising in the same place where the old one once stood. But the station felt a lot less hermetic than before, largely because of the light streaming into this new underground space through that wall of glass.

title: Bay Shore Made Offer As Home for Carousel
description: Re ''The First Ride, 20 Years Later'' [Nov. 2], about the Empire State Carousel: It wasn't Bay Shore's fault that the carousel ended up in Holtsville. In fact, the board of the carousel turned down Bay Shore's offer of assistance. The Town of Islip had offered the carousel a site in downtown Bay Shore, and community members stepped forward to lead the necessary fund-raising campaign. At the time, the carousel board decided that it had a better offer from the Village of Patchogue. Bay Shore was the rejected suitor.

title: How to Spread the Word When the Word Is 'Grim'
description: THE movie ''21 Grams'' is one of the best of the year, but go when you're in a good mood -- otherwise you might be tempted to leap out the window when it's over. There is no sugar-coating in its harsh, uncompromising view of the world. A potent immersion in the lives of three sets of characters eventually linked by death, the film offers some of the most viscerally absorbing performances on screen right now: Sean Penn is a dying man waiting for a heart transplant; Naomi Watts is a woman who suffers a devastating family loss; Benicio Del Toro is a former drug addict who has become a religious fanatic.

title: It Was Time To Cash In His Chips
description: Speaking of Atlantic City, who knew beating a casino could be so easy?

description: IN PRAISE OF NEPOTISM

title: A Milford Man Seeks To Use a Cart to Play Golf
description: City officials in Milford said they would look into a 78-year-old resident's claim that he was being denied proper handicapped access to a municipal golf course because he was not allowed to use a cart when playing.

title: Food for Holiday Thought: Eat Less, Live to 140?
description: IN his quest to reach the age of 143, Michael A. Sherman is making his peace with doughnuts. Renouncing potato skins and chocolate-chip pancakes was no problem, but he just hasn't found a substitute for a glazed, oven-warm bear claw oozing with apple filling. ''I love them, but the larger specimens of that species can approach 1,000 calories,'' he said a few weeks before Thanksgiving, a holiday he can't get overly excited about. ''That's almost as much as I allow myself in a whole day.''

title: Paroled Killer Met the Wrong Person at the Wrong Time, His Backers Say
description: The parole officer's entries about Thomas Trantino's new female companion were bland, with no hint that the officer knew of her convictions and prison sentences since the mid-1990's for forgery in Florida and bank robbery in Newark, as well as parole violations for drug abuse.

title: Saving New Jersey $10 Billion a Year
description: EFFORTS by Millburn, Montclair and Roseland to secede from Essex County are symptomatic of much larger problems New Jersey government continues to battle. This year, the state budget deficit was exceeded only by California's and New York's and is likely to repeat next year. But it is largely self-inflicted as a result of the state's structure of governance. New Jersey, the most urbanized state in the nation, has 1,635 units of local government -- counties, municipalities, school districts, local public authorities and special taxing districts. Per square mile, no other state has fractured itself into as many pieces.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the expansion of Arabic-language studies misstated the number of colleges and universities surveyed by the Modern Language Association last year about enrollment in language courses. It was 2,780, not 780.

title: A Potential Contender In a Post-Couric Derby
description: CAMPBELL BROWN'S awakening to the peculiarities of anchoring morning news television came a few weeks back when her producer uttered a single unnerving word: Rockettes.

The one I stumbled on most recently, ''America's Cornucopia: A Collector's View of American Botany and Horticulture,'' is at the LuEsther T. Mertz Library at the New York Botanical Garden, in the Bronx, through Feb. 16.

title: A Serra Sculpture Emerges From Its Tomb
description: THE art-world gods must have a strong sense of irony: how else to explain why our greatest living sculptor of walls would find his work behind one? That was the case from 1998 until last month, when Richard Serra's sculpture ''Gutter Corner Splash: Night Shift'' lay entombed behind a wall in the fourth-floor galleries of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art -- totally inaccessible, slowly collecting dust. This is ''permanent'' collection indeed.

title: Corrections

The sign, at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street for Louis Vuitton, was produced by a Manhattan company called Fuel Digital Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, RUTH B.
description: COHEN--Ruth B. Of Forest Hills, retired medical librarian at Bronx Lebanon Hospital, died Saturday, November 22, 2003. Loving mother of Barry R. Cohen, and the late Kenneth P. Cohen, and daughters-in-law Ruthie and Naomi, beloved grandmother of Dana, Samara and Daniel, darling aunt to Mel and Gail, Roberta, Karen, Ellen, Janice and Mona. Loving friend to many. She will be greatly missed and always remembered in our hearts. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, on Monday, November 24, at 12:45 PM.

description: A hiker came face to face with a grizzly bear in August while walking on the wooded trail to Crowfoot Glacier. Tiptoeing backward in a cautious retreat, the young man tripped on a tree root, and the bear pounced.

description: Tara Louise Gleason, a daughter of Dr. Mary Louise Gleason and James F. Gleason Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Jason Scott Chicirda, the son of Phyllis and Cyril Chicirda Jr. of Chalfont, Pa. The Rev. Robert B. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Joseph on the Brandywine Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del.

title: Labor Leaders Add Their Heft to Dean Rallies
description: Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor, had the chance over the weekend to bask in the rewards of his recent union endorsements when labor leaders accompanied him to noisy rallies in three states.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Cadillac SRX; A Station Wagon Rolls Into the Cadillac Revival Tent
description: IN eighth grade, I went on dates to school dances with my first real boyfriend. His mother was our chauffeur, in her pale yellow Cadillac Sedan deVille. I sat perched on the front seat between him and his mother, uncomfortable in more ways than one.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture of a house in this section last Sunday with an article about tax assessments was published in error. The house, in Yonkers, belonged to a neighbor of Julie and Michael F. Meyer, who challenged their property assessment. The Meyers' home is pictured here.

description: Michelle Elzay and Matthew E Brannon, artists, were married last evening in Manhattan. The Rev. Edward J. Coughlin performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier.

description: To the Editor: Two of your suggestions may be too far from central London to satisfy the average tourist.

title: Keeping Music's Many Worlds In One Volume
description: When it appeared in 1986, The New Harvard Dictionary of Music was hailed in many quarters as the most valuable single-volume reference work on classical music in English. Now, still unsurpassed in the classical field, it has become even more valuable, with a new edition -- the fourth -- to appear on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Nov. 2 about a Beatrix Potter exhibition at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto misstated the location and telephone number of a simultaneous exhibition of Potter's letters. It is at the Toronto Public Library's Osborne Collection of Early Children's Books at 239 College Street; telephone (416)393-7753.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Edgemont; Like Neighboring Scarsdale, but Different
description: EDGEMONT'S winding, tree-lined streets look much like those in the well-known neighboring town of Scarsdale. And most homes in the 2.76-square-mile unincorporated section of the town of Greenburgh even have Scarsdale ZIP codes. What is more, the two communities are often mentioned in the same breath when the subject of Westchester's top-performing schools comes up. So it may not be surprising that many people think Edgemont is part of Scarsdale.

title: In Need of a Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwelcome Guests at Wildlife Refuge
description: WILD animals thriving at the Morton Wildlife Refuge, near Sag Harbor? That's what wildlife refuges are for, right?

title: Driver Is Killed and Passenger Is Rescued After an S.U.V. Plunges Into the Hudson in Harlem
description: A sport utility vehicle plunged into the Hudson River early yesterday, killing the driver despite efforts by witnesses and police and fire workers to rescue him, the authorities said. A passenger was rescued by a man delivering groceries in the area, witnesses said.

title: Sensory Stimuli
description: Thanksgiving is a time for glad gatherings and hearty indulgences. And as the official holiday shopping push begins, it is also a time to wander through stores and find a feast for the senses: gifts to see, touch, taste, smell and even hear. Below are some of this season's delicious temptations -- yet another reason to give thanks.

title: Irina McCreery, Christopher MacGuire
description: Irina Flemming McCreery, a daughter of Irene McGrath McCreery and Charles Crompton McCreery of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Daniel MacGuire, a son of Dean Dasilva MacGuire and Schuyler MacGuire of Lawrence, N.Y. Msgr. Eugene Clark performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLAVITT, EARL BENTON
description: SLAVITT--Earl Benton. On November 20, in Los Angeles. Beloved husband of Amy;devoted father to Andrew, Lesley and Gabriel; longtime partner at KMZ Rosenman. Service today, 3 PM at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Louis Warschaw Prostate Cancer Center, 8631 West 3rd St, Suite 1001E, LA, CA 90048.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: JAY'S JOURNAL OF ANOMALIES: Conjurers, Cheats, Hustlers, Hoaxsters, Pranksters, Jokesters, Impostors, Pretenders, Sideshow Showmen, Armless Calligraphers, Mechanical Marvels, Popular Entertainments, by Ricky Jay. (Quantuck Lane, $25.) As the title suggests, there's plenty of weird lore stuffed into this collection of all 16 issues of Jay's erudite and lovingly researched quarterly of the same name about magicians and unusual performers. Among the showmen are an armless and legless bowler and a performance artist who specialized in self-crucifixion. The versatile author ''has pulled off yet another impressive trick,'' Francis Heaney wrote here in 2001. ''He has simultaneously written a work of popular entertainment and a work of serious history.''

title: Neeti Madan, Richard Safranek
description: Neeti Madan, a literary agent, and Richard Michael Safranek, a portfolio manager, were married yesterday at the Puck Building in Manhattan. The Rev. Joanna Rose Schaap, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Some Enchanted Evening
description: KUMMI Kim says she thinks a lot and drinks a lot, so that would make her a thoughtful bartender. Ms. Kim, 25, is also part of a vanguard in New York that is reinventing the vocabulary of cocktail-making.

title: Spotlight | N.B.A.; Despite Failure as Pro, He'll Forever Be Pearl
description: He never became the N.B.A. superstar many projected him to be, but Dwayne Washington, known as Pearl, is still a legend. Proof of that came last week when Adidas released a throwback jersey in his honor -- his No. 31 from Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn. Nike will release a replica of the jersey he wore at Syracuse University in January.

title: Sensory Stimuli
description: A feast for the senses: gifts to see, touch, taste, smell and even hear. Here are some of this season's delicious temptations  yet another reason to give thanks.

description: A new sculpture center helps turn Dallas into an art destination.

title: Clare Le Corbeiller, Curator At the Met, Is Dead at 71
description: Clare Le Corbeiller, a longtime curator of the decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71.

title: Gephardt Attacks Dean's Record as Governor of Vermont
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri sharply attacked Howard Dean's record as governor of Vermont on Sunday, accusing Dr. Dean of trying to balance the state budget by repeatedly slashing social programs for the poor and the disabled in the 1990's.

title: MediaTalk; Not Need to Know But Nice to Know
description: When Slate, the online magazine, hired Henry Blodget to cover the Martha Stewart trial, it found the rare aspiring journalist who could identify with running afoul of government securities regulators. Mr. Blodget, a former analyst for Merrill Lynch, paid $4 million in fines and accepted a ban on working in the securities industry after he came under investigation.

title: Bronfman Heir Plotting His Comeback, in Music
description: For the last three years, Edgar Bronfman Jr. has lived in the shadow of a monumentally bad decision. He sold his family's Seagram liquor empire for shares of Vivendi, a French utility-turned-media company, only to watch it nearly collapse and take with it his family's fortune.

title: Political Memo; For State's Democrats, Presidential Choice Inspires Hedging
description: One day this month, the Brooklyn Democratic Party put out word that its leaders would get together at the Park Plaza Diner, a hangout for the borough's politicians, to make a surprisingly early endorsement in the presidential contest.

title: Mount Vernon's Time of Trouble: A Divided City, Shocked by Crime
description: This fall will not be remembered as a high point in this community, which seems a world apart from the wealthy Westchester that is etched in the popular imagination.

title: Tony Thompson, 48, Drummer Who Helped to Define Disco
description: Tony Thompson, a drummer whose beat for Chic helped define both disco and hip-hop, died on Nov. 12 in Los Angeles. He was 48 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Risotto With Pancetta and Wild Mushrooms
description: Awonderfully hearty dish, perfect for an autumn evening. Pancetta is cured, rolled and unsmoked bacon available in most Italian specialty stores. Regular bacon is a good alternative if you cannot find it.

description: James Mosieur buys 50,000 cellphones a month, and now, with wireless number portability beginning today, he expects he will be acquiring even more.

title: About a Bird
description: When you sit down to your Thanksgiving meal on Thursday, waiting for the main attraction to be brought in on a platter, take a moment to think about where it came from and how it found its way to your table. After all, your turkey is not the same wily, energetic, tasty bird that struck our ancestors as the perfect centerpiece for an American holiday.

title: In War Over Spam, One Company Is Happily Arming Both Sides
description: As Congress heads toward passage of legislation meant to stanch the flood of junk e-mail messages, or spam, few companies are as involved in both the sending and receiving of spam as IronPort Systems.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Driver Hits Police Car
description: A Manhattan man was charged with drunken driving last night after striking a police patrol car and careering into a deli at the corner of 49th Street and First Avenue, according to the police. The police said Juan Pabey, of 635 East 21st Street, steered his 1992 Ford sedan around cars that had stopped in the path of the patrol car, which was traveling west on 49th Street with its lights and siren on. Two officers in the patrol car sustained minor injuries, and were treated and released from Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Cingular Is in Front in Promoting Portability
description: Cingular Wireless may be the only cellphone service provider addressing local number portability in any significant way in its advertising this week.

title: Dean's New Challenge: Reaching Out to Black Voters
description: Cynthia Williams showed up nearly an hour before Howard Dean's scheduled appearance at Mount Olivet Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday morning, eager to disappear among the women in feathered hats who filled the pews. For once, the only thing making Ms. Williams, an African-American computer technician from Nutley, N.J., stand out was the blue Dean button on her lapel.

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Collecting; Mazda's Rotary Sports Car: Going Round, Coming Around
description: FEW attributes will catapult a sports car from mediocre to memorable faster than a great engine. Taking that knowledge to heart, Mazda created its RX-7 around a very different engine -- its responsive and smooth-running rotary -- and won a following among enthusiasts who had rarely paid attention to its cars.

title: Search by Kaiser Is Narrowed to Three
description: Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, Calif., the health maintenance organization, has narrowed to three finalists its review for a large new assignment, national brand agency for advertising. Spending for 2004 is estimated at $40 million.

description: INVENTING is about catching the wave,'' said Ray Kurzweil, who addressed a national convention of inventors in Philadelphia last Monday. ''Most inventions fail not because the inventor can't get them to work but because the invention comes at the wrong time.''

title: New Attacks in Iraq
description: Three American soldiers were killed in Iraq, military officials said, including two who came under attack in the northern city of Mosul. In Baquba, north of Baghdad, where at least five people were killed in a suicide bombing on Saturday, a soldier from the Fourth Infantry Division was killed by a roadside bomb.

title: MediaTalk; Wagering on Who Will Land Celebrity Interviews
description: In media circles, there is plenty of friendly wagering about which big-name journalist will obtain the first interview with Michael Jackson, and on the Web, there is a place willing to take on such bets.

title: Chief of Delta Air Lines to Quit in Unexpected Move
description: In a surprise move, Delta Air Lines said that today that its chief executive, Leo F. Mullin, would retire on Jan. 1. Mr. Mullin, 60, will be replaced by Gerald Grinstein, a member of Delta's board and the former chief executive of both Western Airlines and Burlington Northern.

title: No Quick Rodriguez Deal, Agent Says
description: Besides the riches that came with his Texas Rangers contract, Alex Rodriguez acquired something else when he signed his 10-year, $252 million deal in December 2000: power. Because of Rodriguez's full no-trade clause, he has control over where he plays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONSON, HOWARD C.
description: BRONSON--Howard C. On November 21, 2003, at age 77. Beloved husband of Clara Bronson. Loving father of Valerie Bronson and stepfather of Louis Wirtz and his wife Diane Wirtz. Dear brother of Mickey Bronson. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday November 25th, 3 pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Lung Association of NY, Inc., 432 Park Ave South, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10016.

title: MediaTalk; Vanity Fair Editor Learns Smoking Ban Applies to Corner Offices, Too
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's ban on smoking in all public places save New York's streets has landed uncomfortably at 4 Times Square, the headquarters of Cond Nast Publications and one of the more privileged addresses in the city.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: BRIDGEPORT: MAYOR SWORN IN FOR FULL TERM Mayor John Fabrizi was sworn into office for a full term on Saturday and promised an administration that would not tolerate corruption. Mr. Fabrizi, who first took office after Mayor Joseph P. Ganim's conviction on federal corruption charges, was overwhelmingly elected in November. "The Fabrizi administration will not tolerate improper behavior of any kind," Mr. Fabrizi said. "I continue to urge anyone who suspects, or is aware of, such behavior to notify the proper authorities." Mr. Fabrizi, the former City Council president, delivered the same message in April, when he was sworn in after Mr. Ganim's conviction. In his address Saturday, Mr. Fabrizi said he would hire an executive director for the city's Ethics Commission who would carry out independent investigations.   (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a disputed Defense Department memorandum that listed points of intelligence linking the Iraqi leadership of Saddam Hussein to the Qaeda terrorist network misstated the timing of the Pentagon's establishment of the Office of Special Plans in preparation for a possible war in Iraq. It was in October 2002, less than six months before the war -- not a year or more.

title: In Medicare Fight, Frist Is Scrambling To Improve Record
description: For any Senate majority leader, the final hours of a Congressional session are the clearest measure of success or failure, and no one knows that better than the physician from Tennessee who spent the weekend frantically arm-twisting and trolling for votes.

Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Randall and Julia. Mayest Thou O God of Mercy, shelter her forever under the wings of Thy presence. May her soul be bound up in the bond of life eternal and grant that the memories of her life inspire us. Visitation Monday, 79 pm. Services Tuesday, 11:15 am at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: As Sgt. First Class Vernon Story's column of Humvees climbed a desolate ridge a mile from the Pakistan-Afghanistan border here on Sunday morning, the sergeant got the feeling that someone was watching. The five unexploded land mines he and his men had found along this same ridge in a firefight with Taliban rebels here less than two months ago lingered in his mind.

Loving father of Jessica (Tim) Kisling and Johnny & Katie. Loving brother of Barbara Geraghty and Joan Kral. Calling hours at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Monday 7-9 pm, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, NY, Wednesday 11 am. Interment at Ferncliff Crematory, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to T.J. Sullivan Cancer Foundation, PO Box 402, Bernardsville, NJ 07924.

title: Metro Matters; Gentle Waters, Reflecting This City?
description: THEY have light, air, water and greenery. What the eight designs for the World Trade Center memorial do not have is a feeling of New York.

title: White House Makes Offer to Save Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  The White House tried today to resurrect the energy bill by floating an offer to drop a controversial section about the gasoline additive MTBE.

title: A Troubled Past
description: Georgia, the birthplace of Stalin, endured centuries of foreign domination. The Red Army forcibly made it a republic in 1921.

title: GEORGIAN LEADER AGREES TO RESIGN, ENDING STANDOFF
description: President Eduard A. Shevardnadze of Georgia, once acclaimed for his role in helping to end the cold war, resigned Sunday in the face of huge public protests over the corruption and economic collapse that have marked his nearly 12-year rule.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz bassist Chubby Jackson on Oct. 4 misspelled the name of the city where he died. A recent e-mail message from a reader pointed out that it is Poway, Calif., not Paway.

title: Gutting Education Reform in Congress
description: The No Child Left Behind Act appeared on the national stage as a series of farsighted reforms that would raise standards, place a qualified teacher in every classroom -- and force schools to end the practice of trapping black and Latino students in substandard schools. But the Bush administration's decision to underfinance the act -- while soft-pedaling the teacher quality provisions and playing to the far right -- has emboldened groups like the National Education Association, the teachers' union that never liked an important aspect of the law, namely holding schools accountable by focusing on minority student performance. The N.E.A. is working partly through Democrats in both houses, who have introduced measures that would gut accountability standards, preserving the disastrous status quo.

title: 2 G.I.'s, Throats Slashed, Found Dead After Rock-Throwing Attack on Car in Northern City
description: Three American soldiers were killed in Iraq on Sunday, including two whose throats were slashed after they came under attack in the northern city of Mosul with rocks and gunfire, a military official said.

title: Public Campaign Financing Collapses
description: With not a vote yet cast, the election of 2004 is already notable for ushering in the collapse of Watergate-era restraints on special-interest money in presidential politics. The 29-year-old system of limiting spending by providing candidates with publicly financed subsidies has been brushed aside by President Bush. He became the first modern White House candidate to formally opt out and aim for prodigious amounts of private contributions to outspend competitors. Former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont and Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts are following suit in the Democratic primaries, fearing they could be outspent by four to one before their party even picks a nominee to challenge Mr. Bush.

title: The Bells Struggle to Survive A Changing Telephone Game
description: When the United States telecommunications industry imploded a few years ago, with upstart carriers disappearing by the dozens and investments vanishing by the billions, it looked as if the regional Bell companies had won the telecom wars.

title: Internet Users Shifting to Faster Services
description: Things are bleak, but not hopeless, for the companies that have been leading providers of dial-up Internet access, as the market shifts rapidly to faster broadband service, according to new research from ComScore Networks. In the third-quarter of the year, 24.5 million homes had broadband service, about one-third of the total homes with Internet access. Nearly all of them bought their access from their local telephone company or cable company, not America Online or Microsoft's MSN, the two leading dial-up providers. But Microsoft and AOL are having some success in persuading customers to use their services, in addition to cable or phone company broadband. SAUL HANSELL

title: Turks Say to Europe: Can't We Just Come as We Are?
description: Serra Bayburt raised her voice over the thumping strains of Gloria Gaynor's ''I Will Survive'' in a fashionable bar beside the Bosporus and expressed her views on Turkey's future.

title: Tremors From Rosie Trial Still Rattle Gruner & Jahr
description: There has not been an official decision in the court case between Rosie O'Donnell and Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing over the demise of Rosie magazine, but the fallout has already begun.

title: Sports of The Times; Empty Seats, No Noise, But Look Who's Talking
description: AS early as the kickoff, the empty seats at Giants Stadium were obvious. Red in both the upper stands and the lower stands, blue in the mezzanine. At least 7,000 or 8,000 empty seats, maybe more. The Jets would announce the attendance for yesterday's 57-minute yawn with the Jacksonville Jaguars as 77,614, a virtual sellout, but that was the number of tickets purchased, not the number of derrires in those red and blue seats, and behind the glass in the luxury suites.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY,

title: Amid Some Storms, CBS Finds a Surge; Despite Two High-Profile Problems, Network's Chief Has Had a Good Month
description: In all the ways television usually measures success, Leslie Moonves, the chairman of CBS, has enjoyed the best month of his network career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAVKEWITZ, HENRY, PHD
description: KAVKEWITZ--Henry, PhD, 90, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died November 22 at home in Chattanooga, TN.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Developing Nations Join Wireless World, U.N. Says

title: Risotto Recipes
description: Basic Risotto

title: Riyadh Journal; Seeing the Funny Side of Islamic Law, and Not Seeing It
description: The three women wake to the sound of a burglar rummaging downstairs.

title: E Pluribus Unwired
description: As wireless communications companies wait to see how customers will respond this week to new rules allowing subscribers to keep their phone numbers regardless of the carrier they use, the industry can find satisfaction in at least one fact: The cellphone is a part of everyday life for the majority of people in the nation's largest metropolitan areas.

title: A Building's Bold Spirit, Clad in Marble and Controversy
description: Let us now celebrate the aristocratic satisfaction of not pleasing. Huntington Hartford gave himself that pleasure when he commissioned Edward Durell Stone to design the Gallery of Modern Art (1964), the legendarily exotic building at 2 Columbus Circle.

title: Little Outcry From Viewers As Rates Rise For Cable
description: John Dunning figures that he spends several hours a weekend watching cable channels, mostly sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRATZ, DONALD
description: GRATZ--Donald. On November 21, after along battle with cancer. Beloved husband and helpmate of Roberta. Doting father of Laura and Rebecca. Loving brother of Bill. Loving father-in-law of Jon and Joe. Adoring grandfather of Halina, Frank, Stella and Isaac. The owner and guiding force of Gratz Industries. Donald was the consummate craftsman and so much more. His wit was like a shaft of light. With him around, you never needed to dust off the encyclopedia. He could fix anything. He zipped through the Times crossword puzzle. He shot pool like a shark and he mastered the arts of friendship and love. Funeral arrangements to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you make a contribution to the Eldridge Street Project, 12 Eldridge St, NYC 10002, or cancer research.

title: The Doctors and the Drug Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on Wednesday about the Johnny Mercer Foundation tribute to the songwriters Marilyn and Alan Bergman misstated a word in the title of a song performed by Christine Ebersole. It was ''The Lullaby of Broadway,'' not ''Melody.''

title: In Minneapolis, a New Work by Stephen Paulus
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 16 - The prophets, explorers and frontline combatants of new music might occasionally step back and examine the career of Stephen Paulus. Mr. Paulus writes music that opera companies and symphony orchestras want to pay for and that their audiences want to hear. If his colleagues seem to occupy a vast waiting room, competing for a ticket to immortality, Mr. Paulus has found his own train and is already aboard.

title: Voices of 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CIRKUS, PATRICIA (NEE ZARCHIN)
description: CIRKUS--Patricia (nee Zarchin), 58, of Boca Raton, FL died peacefully on November 23, 2003. Beloved mother of Michael & Jonathon Cirkus. Dear daughter of Sylvia Zarchin. Proud grandmother of Brandon, Ryan, Rebeka, Joshua & Samantha. Devoted sister of Gail Ehrens & Elizabeth Biddy Fein. Loving companion of Bernie Gold. Services Tuesday 1:15pm in Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial Floral Park Cemetery, South Brunswick, NJ. Contributions to The Progressive Charter School, c/o The ARC, 1201 Australian Avenue, Riviera Beach, FL 33404.

title: Bond Offerings Scheduled for the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Donovan's Goals Lead San Jose to Second M.L.S. Title
description: Landon Donovan scored a goal in each half as the San Jose Earthquakes beat the Chicago Fire, 4-2, to win the M.L.S. Cup for the second time in three seasons Sunday at the Home Depot Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENKE, ALEXANDER STUART
description: MENKE--Alexander Stuart. Died peacefully in his sleep at home in Pasadena, CA, on Saturday, November 22, 2003. He was an honorable and loving gentleman. He is survived by his devoted wife Virginia, and caring children John Milton, Laurie Zatkowski and Jason, a brother, John Roger, and a sister, Rosanne Menke Lustberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TESCHER, ROSE
description: TESCHER--Rose. On November 22, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Loving mother of Elliot and Arnold. Cherished grandmother of Todd, Erica, and Jeremy.

title: Counting CD Sales Isn't an Exact Science
description: Folks who walked into the more than 300 Hallmark Cards Inc. stores across the country earlier this month may have noticed ''Closer,'' the new CD by Josh Groban, amid all the greeting cards, Christmas ornaments and stuffed animals.

title: Dissatisfaction With the Guru of Customer Satisfaction
description: You would think that J. David Power had put a match to the American flag, judging from the outrage his comments about car dealers have generated in the auto industry.

title: For a Change, Offense Turns The Cowboys Into Winners
description: In the land of the never satisfied, where a winning record and a spot atop the National Football Conference East are not quite enough for the demanding masses, the Dallas Cowboys' offense has played the piata in recent weeks.

title: E-Commerce Report; Sensing economic opportunities, many developing nations are laying the groundwork for online commerce.
description: E-COMMERCE is starting to find a place in some of the world's emerging economies. Governments and businesses in a growing number of developing nations have begun building the infrastructure needed for online commerce, according to a report released Thursday by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, or Unctad.

title: Rays of Hope on Energy
description: There may be a chance to defeat the dreadful energy bill after all. On Friday, in a rebuff to President Bush and the Republican leadership, Senate opponents blocked a final vote on the bill by denying the White House and Bill Frist, the majority leader, the 60 votes they need to end a filibuster. The supporters of the bill are now two votes short, with time rapidly running out in the current Congressional session.

title: The Doctors and the Drug Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Mourning, Needing Kidney, Must Quit Basketball
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 24  Alonzo Mourning's comeback from kidney disease ended today when the New Jersey Nets announced that he needed a kidney transplant and could no longer play professional basketball.

title: Misery Loves Company
description: At the end of a practice last week, Giants Coach Jim Fassel gathered his players around him and shared his sense of confusion. They did not look like a 4-6 team, he told them. They did not practice like a 4-6 team.

title: A Paper Trail Follows Iraqi Merchants of Tyranny
description: In the end, after the secret investigations, the middle-of-the-night arrests, the obsequious genuflections to Saddam Hussein, a common passion drove these members of Iraq's Baath Party to excel at their special occupation. It was all about the money.

title: Missing Links Found
description: Two blockbuster magazine articles last week revealed evidence that Saddam's spy agency and top Qaeda operatives certainly were in frequent contact for a decade, and that there is renewed reason to suspect an Iraqi spymaster in Prague may have helped finance the 9/11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAKIM, TOUBA
description: HAKIM--Touba. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Goldberg Weprin & Ustin LLP express our deepest sympathy on the death of Touba Hakim, mother of our esteemed client, Kayvan Hakim, and our dear friend, Kamran Hakim. May her memory bring comfort and always be a blessing to her family and all who knew her.

title: Equity Offerings for Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section last Monday about businesses that sell to nonprofits referred incorrectly to TechRocks, a nonprofit organization that developed a software product called ebase. Ebase is now distributed by Groundspring.org, no longer TechRocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, ALICE GAHAGAN
description: MURPHY--Alice Gahagan. Of Sands Point, NY, on November 22, 2003, age 76. Beloved wife of the late William F. Jr., loving mother of William F. III (Colleen), cherished sister of Frederick Gahagan (Dolly), William Gahagan (Katherine) and Gerli Carotti (the late Giulio), proud grandmother of Daryn, William and Dane. Also survived by loving nieces and nephews. Visiting Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Monday, 7-9 pm. Mass Our Lady of Fatima R.C. Church, Manorhaven, NY, Tuesday, 10 am. Interment private.

title: Sharon Hints That Israel May Remove Some Settlers
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel has hinted that he will consider eventually evacuating civilians from some isolated settlements in the Gaza Strip, as he prepares to renew talks with the Palestinian leadership.

title: U.S. Finds New York Still Lags on Access to Food Stamp Program
description: New York City is still not making food stamps as accessible as the law requires, according to a new audit by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBIN, FRANKLIN ELLIS
description: ROBIN--Franklin Ellis, who served in the OSS in World War II, died in Ridgewood, NJ, on Tuesday, November 19, 2003. During his 30 year career at Dun and Bradstreet, Mr. Robin maintained homes in Manhattan and Brick Town, NJ, until recently. He was 88. Born in Rutherford, NJ, on September 8, 1915, as a young man he played a leading role in a literary circle in that town that included William Carlos Williams, Kathleen Hoagland, and other writers and artists. He graduated from Dartmouth College Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa in 1937. His longtime companion Howard Ross predeceased him. He is survived by his nieces Nancy Robin Jaicks of Ridgewood, NJ, and Diana Robin of Chicago, IL, four grandnieces and nephews, and five greatgrandnieces and nephews. Services will be held Monday, 12 noon, at Christ Episcopal Church in Ridgewood. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New Jersey Audubon Society of the American Red Cross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRBY, WILLIAM J.
description: KIRBY--William J. 78, November 22nd, Forest Hills, NY. Retired partner Sullivan & Cromwell. Survived by wife of 49 years, Ann Pfohl Kirby, children Dr. Mathis Powelson, Richmond, VA, William Jr., Brookline, MA, Andrew, Greenwich, CT, Peter, Tokyo, Paula McWhinnie, London, and Julia Vien, Bookline, MA, their spouses, 16 grandchildren and three sisters. Visiting hours at Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave, corner Metropolitan Ave, Monday, from 6-9 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 70-01 Kessel St, Forest Hills, at 10:30 am, Tuesday. Interment Lakeview Cemetery, Essex, NY, Wednesday. Donations to Harvard College, Harvard Law School or St. Mathias Educational Foundation Inc, 58-15 Catalpa Ave, Ridgewood, NY 11385.

title: Leo Burnett Wins A Wella Account
description: Wella, the German hair care company now controlled by Procter & Gamble, has shifted the creative assignment on its global account, with billings estimated at more than $100 million, to Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: The Doctors and the Drug Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Recapturing a Childhood In a Prerevolutionary Eden
description: For most of his adult life Carlos Eire had tried to run away from Cuba. The island was his only briefly, for 11 years, before the Cuban revolution ushered in a world of heartache in which he was separated from his parents and spent years of hardship in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARSHOWSKY, SOLOMON H.
description: WARSHOWSKY--Solomon H. On November 22, 2003. Beloved husband of Constance, devoted father of Cassandra and Nancy Ann. Cherished grandfather of Jacob Charles and Max George. Loving brother of Lou. Funeral service 10 am at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Candidates Plan Responses to G.O.P. Commercial on Terrorism
description: The campaigns of Senator John Kerry and Howard Dean said on Sunday that they would begin showing television commercials in Iowa heavily criticizing a new Republican Party advertisement that portrays the Democratic presidential candidates as undermining President Bush while he fights terrorism.

title: The Doctors and the Drug Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANNIS, HERBERT
description: ANNIS--Herbert, age 87, died peacefully at home in Oceanside, NY, on November 22, 2003. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Esther; children, Susan Beth (Hileman), Jeffrey, Jean Lee (Mishkin); grandchildren, Billy, Jennifer, Sarah, Rebecca, Naomi, Miriam and Benjamin and brother Martin. A real New Yorker, he was truly sui generis. Craftsman, kite flyer, and inveterate collector of facts, he loved Rembrandt, Mozart and most of all his grandchildren. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services Monday, 11:30 am, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Publisher Named for International Herald Tribune
description: Michael Golden, vice chairman and senior vice president of The New York Times Company , has been appointed publisher of The International Herald Tribune. The appointment, effective immediately, was announced today by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., chairman of the company.

title: An Inexpensive Remedy for a Sports Car Itch
description: SOME vintage-car collectors look down their noses at the RX-7, considering it Budweiser amid the Bordeaux. Yet the RX-7 is one of a very few rotary-powered vehicles in automotive history, is fun to drive and is quite affordable. So who needs snob appeal?

title: Scotts Chooses New Media Buyer
description: One of several reviews for large media accounts has been decided.

description: The following is the text of the Democratic candidates' debate in Iowa sponsored by MSNBC and the Democratic National Committee, as transcribed by FDCH e-Media, Inc.

description: IGNATOW -- Archie. So missed as our family grows. Remembered with love. Gene and Three Generation

title: U.S. Retracts Report of G.I.s Being Mutilated
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 24  Military officials retracted a report today that two American soldiers had been slashed in their throats in an attack Sunday in the northern city of Mosul.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Wednesday about the appointment of Howard Sherman to succeed Roy A. Somlyo as leader of the American Theater Wing referred imprecisely to their titles. While Mr. Sherman will be executive director, Mr. Somlyo was president and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, RUTH B.
description: COHEN--Ruth B. Of Forest Hills, retired medical librarian at Bronx Lebanon Hospital, died Saturday, November 22, 2003. Loving wife of the late Harvey W. Cohen and mother of Barry R. Cohen, and the late Kenneth P. Cohen, and daughters-in-law Ruthie and Naomi, beloved grandmother of Dana, Samara and Daniel, darling aunt to Mel and Gail, Roberta, Karen, Ellen, Janice and Mona. Loving friend to many. She will be greatly missed and always remembered in our hearts. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, on Monday, November 24, at 12:45 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREY, MARCIA YUSS
description: GREY--Marcia Yuss. On November 22. Beloved wife of Jerry. Mother of David, Carrie and Susan. Grandmother of Zachary, Molly and Grey. Sister of Irene and Shirley. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in Marcia's memory to the American Heart Association, c/o Anne Grey, 816 South Figueroa St, Los Angeles, CA 90017; or the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 17872 Mitchell North 100, Irvine, CA 92614.

title: Chaos in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Interactive Account In Review at AOL
description: America Online in Dulles, Va., has begun a review for the creative and media duties for its interactive advertising assignments. Billings are estimated at $55 million to $60 million.

title: Chinese-Filipinos Protest Ransom Kidnappings
description: Hundreds of people took to the streets here on Sunday, turning the funeral of a local Coca-Cola executive who was kidnapped and killed last week into a protest march against a series of kidnappings in the Philippines.

title: Jets Drive Non-Spike Into the Heart of the Jaguars
description: The Jets were 94 yards from the end zone, a long stretch that would hold either a comeback victory to restore some pride to a struggling team or a humbling defeat that would devastate it.

title: Again, Trains Put the World In Trade Center
description: And yesterday, the people returned to ground zero.

title: E-mail Messages From Beyond
description: Die-hard e-mail users take note: You can click ''send'' from the hereafter. Mylastemail.com, a British company, has introduced a service to hold a writer's farewell e-mail messages for three years, to be delivered after the writer's death. The service costs $10, and if the three-year period expires before the subscriber does, the customer can renew.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; A String Quartet? Philosophy? Whoa!
description: Nelly Furtado was never just the chirpy, conventional pop singer that her inescapable 2000 hit, ''I'm Like a Bird,'' made her seem. And selling two million copies of ''Whoa, Nelly!'' has emboldened her for her second album, ''Folklore'' (DreamWorks).

title: Rutgers Resists Deadline on McGreevey's Campus Merger Plan
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey's ambitious proposal to merge New Jersey's research universities is faltering because Rutgers, which has the power to veto the plan, is resisting a Jan. 1 deadline he set last week to endorse the merger.

title: 'No Child Left Behind'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheltering the Neediest
description: There seem as many acronyms as lost souls in the shelters where New York's homeless cycle through routinely desperate lives. Darlene, a 38-year-old ex-convict, is a MICA -- a mentally ill chemical abuser. An alcoholic as a young teenager, she lost prime years to drug addiction and dealing, then two prison terms across a downward spiral in which her two sons fended for themselves. ''This time, I'm ready,'' Darlene vows at one of the city's women's shelters, warily facing a fresh chance to move up and out to a group home. ''I want to see my sons and the grandchild that's coming,'' she says, admitting old addictive hungers vie with her mid-day dream of family stability.

title: Jaguars' Defense Lacks Finish
description: Jack Del Rio, the rookie coach of the Jacksonville Jaguars, was grim and caustic after Sunday's 13-10 loss to the Jets. He spoke in short sentences, with a dagger seemingly attached to every response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELBERG, FREDERICK
