description: GELBERG -- Frederick. 84. Beloved husband of Terie Gelberg (nee Isaacs) and the loving father of Barbara Freundlich (Richard), Jonathan Gelberg (Debra) and Steven Gelberg (Nilima). Adored grandfather of Amanda and Ali Angerman, and Michael and Robert Gelberg. Mr. Gelberg will be remembered by all who knew him for his brilliance, his love of life, compassion, inspiration and devotion to family and friends. He was a Partner at the law firm of Moses & Singer in NYC. Previously a Partner at Gelberg & Abrams, and at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hayes & Handler. He was a widely respected member of the New York Tax Bar and was honored by the New York Law Journal as one of the top tax attorneys in NYC. He was a graduate of the City College of New York and Columbia University School of Law, where was an editor of The Law Review. Mr. Gelberg was also an honored veteran of WWII. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday at 11am, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, at 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY (across from the train station). No flowers please. Donations can be made to Columbia University School of Law or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Liberia's Rape Survivors
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Letter; In Hour to Shine, an Envoy Instead Shuns the Spotlight
description: Lost in all the white ties and tails, cavalry parades and antiwar protests of President Bush's trip to London last week was a reticent multimillionaire American racehorse breeder, William S. Farish. His day job is the United States ambassador to Britain, and his credentials include very close ties to the Bush family.

title: Michael Jackson, In Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Paid Notice: Deaths   KIERAN, MARGARET FORD
description: KIERAN--Margaret Ford, of Rockport, MA, on November 22, 98. Mrs. Kieran was a former editor and feature writer for the Boston Globe, Boston Herald and New York Times. She was the wife of the late John Kieran. She is survived by her stepson, Dr. James Kieran of Morago, CA, a Past President of the American Lung Association and American Thoracic Society; 19 stepgrandchildren; 26 step greatgrandchildren; two step great - great - grandchildren; and cousin, Miss Margaret Raphael Sullivan of Quincy, MA. Her funeral mass will be celebrated on Wednesday, November 26, at 10am in St. Joachim's Church, Rockport, MA. The burial will be in Beech Grove Cemetery, Rockport. There are no visiting hours. Contributions may be made in Mrs. Kieran's name to a charity of one's choice. For information, contact the Burgess & Mackey Funeral Home, 201 Main St, Rockport.

title: Berlusconi ally is found guilty in corruption case
description: VENICE:  The Italian judicial system was thrust into the limelight on Sunday after a ruling that found an ally of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi guilty of corrupting judges, but found no evidence that he corrupted them in a case in which the prime minister was also accused.

title: Bucs' Title Dreams All but Vanish
description: Tampa Bay Buccaneers defensive end Simeon Rice understands the widespread perception about the Bucs this season: they haven't played with the hunger and aggressiveness they displayed when they won the Super Bowl. And he agrees.

title: Microsoft's Monopoly, in Europe
description: Just when Microsoft's antitrust woes seemed over, it is facing a tough inquiry from European regulators. The Europeans are concerned that Microsoft may use its Windows monopoly to control important new parts of the tech world, including online music and video. Just as American courts ruled that Microsoft cannot unfairly use its Windows monopoly against competitors, the European Union should press Microsoft for meaningful concessions, to ensure that the software market remains competitive and consumers have real choices.

title: The Doctors and the Drug Makers (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Charged in Murders of Man and 2 Women at Queens Home
description: The police arrested a 36-year-old woman on Friday in connection with the killing of three people in their home in a quiet Queens neighborhood this summer, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Retracts Report of Soldiers Bodies Being Mutilated
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 24  Military officials retracted a report today that two American soldiers had been slashed in their throats in an attack Sunday in the northern city of Mosul.

title: New Economy; Supercomputing has the momentum, judging by dueling conventions.
description: TWO seemingly unrelated indicators the fact that hotels in downtown Phoenix were sold out at the same time that there were no taxi lines in Las Vegas -- point to subtle but sweeping changes under way in the computer industry.

title: From Philippines, With Scrubs; How One Ethnic Group Came to Dominate the Nursing Field
description: When Arlene Aguirre arrived in New York from the Philippines in September for an extraordinary round of surgery -- the separation of her 18-month-old twins, who are conjoined at the tops of their heads -- she hardly knew a soul in this country.

title: Eagles Win Sixth Straight, but Show Assortment of Holes
description: EAGLES 33, SAINTS 20

title: Vesey Street Bridge Opens to Quiet, but Grateful, Crowd
description: With none of the fanfare that greeted the reopening of the nearby World Trade Center PATH station but with plenty of grateful travelers, the Vesey Street Bridge opened yesterday at the northwest corner of ground zero.

title: Solid Victory for a Mixed Pair In a Life Masters' Competition
description: Two major titles were decided here Saturday night at the American Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League. A mixed pair won the Life Master Open Pairs, a rare event: Jo Morse and Kyle Larsen, each of whom owns a world title, scored a clear victory.

title: Cable and satellite companies take their battle for television viewers into the mud.
description: THE mudslinging between cable and satellite companies has become messier of late. The EchoStar Communications Corporation's recent campaign for its Dish Network satellite television service depicts cable operators as money-hungry pigs.

title: Bison Roam in the Refuge, But That's on a Reservation
description: The air here is usually serene, a scene from the Old West, with hundreds of chocolate-brown buffalo grazing the hills of the National Bison Range, and the jagged, snow-covered Mission Mountains standing in the distance.

title: After a Long Road of Planning, a Few Companies Await Payoff
description: No one knows for sure which wireless carriers will thrive and which may suffer now that consumers can switch their cellphone numbers from one service to another. But no matter the outcome, several companies are poised to profit by playing integral behind-the-scenes roles.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He is not a coward and probably understood that the moment had come to make this step so that Georgia would not break up. I think he was right.''

title: Jury Sentences Muhammad to Death for Sniper Killings
description: Ajury in Virginia Beach sentenced John A. Muhammad to death today for the murder of a man at a Virginia gas station last fall as part of a plot to terrorize Washington and its suburbs.

title: Sis, Today The Village, Tomorrow The World
description: On your knees, citizens of Broadway. A superwoman walks among you. Having established herself as the first lady of musical tragedy -- with Tony-winning performances in Stephen Sondheim's ''Passion'' and a somber ''King and I'' -- Donna Murphy has now crossed to the sunny side of the street. She makes it very clear, thank you, that this, too, is unconditionally her turf.

title: MEDICARE DEBATE TURNS TO PRICING OF DRUG BENEFITS
description: With Congress poised for final action on a major Medicare bill this week, some of the fiercest debate is focused on a section of the bill that prohibits the government from negotiating lower drug prices for the 40 million people on Medicare.

title: Newborn Secret Is Nestled In the Frher's Household
description: SIEGFRIED

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a disputed Defense Department memorandum that listed points of intelligence linking the Iraqi leadership of Saddam Hussein to the Qaeda terrorist network misstated the timing of the Pentagon's establishment of the Office of Special Plans in preparation for a possible war in Iraq. It was in October 2002, less than six months before the war  not a year or more.

title: Green Pea Risotto With Fresh Vegetables
description: This spring-friendly recipe should serve as a guideline for any vegetable risotto; your favorite vegetables, sauteed to your liking, can be substituted.

title: New Lawmakers Tested by Job's Unpredictability
description: It is sometimes said that a session of Congress is like a Tchaikovsky symphony: just when you think it is about to end, it goes on a little longer. After a roller-coaster month that included an unexpected vacation and a marathon Medicare vote, Representatives Candice S. Miller and Ral M. Grijalva are discovering that painful truth.

title: Economic Calendar Expected
description: Today

title: In Croatian Parliament Election, Nationalists Reclaim Control
description: The Croatian Democratic Union, a hard-line nationalist party ousted from power four years ago, appeared set on Sunday to form Croatia's next government after preliminary results showed it had won a clear lead in parliamentary elections.

title: INSIDE
description: Divided on Gay Marriage

title: No Golden Years Yet for a 75-Year-Old Mouse
description: The Walt Disney Company celebrated the 75th anniversary of Mickey Mouse as a cultural icon and corporate totem last week, but some business analysts wondered whether it could have been a retirement party.

title: Amid Acceptance of Gays, A Split on Marriage Issue
description: As friends, work colleagues and lunch buddies, Niema Faulkner and Helene Hall never knew how differently they viewed gay marriages until a Massachusetts court ruled that same-sex couples have the right to marry under the state's Constitution.

title: About-Face for Jets' Red-Faced Defense
description: Ted Cottrell, the Jets' defensive coordinator, was at a small tailgate party with his family after the Jets' 13-10 victory over the Jacksonville Jaguars on Sunday, as he usually is after games. This one, though, was different. It was the first game after Cottrell's defense was shredded in a 38-31 loss to the Indianapolis Colts, a performance that started speculation that he might be made the scapegoat for the team's sorry play.

title: Putnam's Decisive Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: A Neat and Tidy Top Two, Then a Mess
description: This should have been a pretty definitive week for college football, right? The college presidents from the non-Bowl Championship Series conferences met with their six B.C.S. conference counterparts who hold the purse strings, and dtente was reached: both sides agreed that the system would be changed once the current contract runs out after the 2005 season.

title: Reinventing Seventeen With a View to Middle America
description: When Hearst Magazines bought Seventeen magazine last spring, it asked Atoosa Rubenstein, the frizzy-haired editor of CosmoGirl, a Hearst guide to girls' empowerment, to rejuvenate the fading teenage publication. But after looking in the mirror, Ms. Rubenstein decided that another kind of editor would be needed to remake Seventeen, a much more conventional magazine than CosmoGirl.

title: Basic Risotto
description: The most important part of any risotto is, of course, the rice. Arborio or, less commonly, vialone are the classic choices; they are short-grain varieties that will result in a creamy product that retains a slight bite to each grain. Using regular long-grain rice will produce a mushy, gummy mass.

title: Hezbollah, in Iraq, Refrains From Attacks on Americans
description: Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Shiite group, has established a significant presence in Iraq, but is not taking part in attacks on American forces inside the country, according to current and former United States officials and Arabs familiar with the organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POOLE, HENRY P.
description: POOLE--Henry P. 40 year resident of Malverne, suddenly on November 22, 2003. Beloved husband of 47 years to Jacqueline. Loving father of Margaret, Nancy Parker (Terrence), Jacqueline Zerilli (Steven), Patricia, Michael J. (Andrea), and Daniel P. (Tara). Dear grandfather of Ryan, Janine, Joseph, Brooke, Jacki, Jessica, James, Christopher and Kelly. Cherished brother of Sr. M. Julianna Poole S.S.N.D. Longtime parishioner of Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Henry was a graduate of St. John's University and St. John's School of Law (1957). He was the Vice-President of the Assembly of General Counsel of Merrill Lynch. He was the Executive Vice-President and General Counsel of the New York Stock Exchange, Inc. (1973-1993). Family will receive friends tonight, 7-9 pm, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc, 34 Hempstead Ave. (corner Peninsula Blvd), Lynbrook. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:30 am, Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEANE, MARJORIE ANGELE SCHLESINGER
description: DEANE -- Marjorie Angele Schlesinger. On November 22, 2003, at age 80. Loving mother of Marjorie Gregg Deane Swain, Kathryn Morgan Deane-Krantz, Disque D. Deane Jr. and Walter Longstreet Deane. Devoted grandmother of Ned, Tarara, Uki, Tucker, Titi and Tyler. Sister of Kathryn Michel. Services at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St., Tuesday, November 25th, 12:30 pm.

title: Seafood Risotto
description: This dish uses the resulting liquid from steaming the mussels and clams as the base of the cooking liquid for the risotto. An addition of saffron gives a beautiful orange color and an additional layer of flavor.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 2, Is Killed By School Bus, Police Say
description: A 2-year-old boy was struck and killed by a private school bus in Brooklyn yesterday after he wandered away from his mother, the police said.

title: Fun-House Proportions Turn Dominance Upside Down
description: The setting for ''A Doll's House,'' George Bernard Shaw said, was every suburb in Europe. We can now add the suburbs of every continent along with the high-rises. How many thousands of times since the play opened in 1879 has Nora Helmer slammed the door on her martinet husband and her child-bride self?

title: The Guthrie Ghost Smiled At Songs Demanding Truth
description: Tom Morello proudly told the audience for the Tell Us the Truth Tour on Saturday night that it was ''the only tour that will pass through Webster Hall that got tear-gassed.'' That was on a previous stop, in Miami during protests against the prospective Free Trade Area of the Americas. The tour, headlined by the songwriters Billy Bragg and Steve Earle, defines itself as ''raising a ruckus for media diversity, fair trade and democracy.'' There were banners on the balcony from Common Cause, the open-government organization, and from the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Laughing On the Links? That's Par For the Course
description: Gotta love a show that admits right up front that it's lame, superfluous and occasionally offensive, then goes about unabashedly proving that for the next two hours. Such is ''Golf: The Musical,'' a hilarious revue by Michael Roberts that turns mindlessness and predictability into art forms.

title: Study Links Higher Speed Limits to Deaths
description: A report from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety says increased speed limits on Interstate highways led to nearly 1,900 extra deaths in 22 states from 1996 to 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLEBERMAN, MIRIAM RIVKIN
description: GLEBERMAN--Miriam Rivkin, on November 22, 2003, at age 80. Beloved wife of J. Harvey (deceased). Loving mother of Joan, Ellen and Joseph. Grandmother of Matthew, Benjamin, Samantha, Sarah, Margaret and Charles. Also Linda Pyo Cavalier. Sister of Roslyn Attinson and Edith Susskind of Staten Island. Graduate of New York University. Founded J.H. Harvey retail furniture chain together with late husband. One of the first female directors of National Home Furnishing Association and founder, past president and chair of its Interior Design Society. Served on JCC of MidWestchester board. Funeral service Tuesday, November 25, 2003, 1:30 PM, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. For information, Hellman Garlick Memorial Chapels, 1300 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510, 914-762-5501.

title: Gains for Pro-Democracy Party in Hong Kong
description: Pro-democracy candidates mostly prevailed over pro-Beijing candidates on Sunday in the first elections here since three huge rallies last summer. Those rallies shook the political establishments here and in Beijing and forced the shelving of stringent internal security legislation.

title: Boeing Dismisses 2 in Hiring of Official Who Left Pentagon
description: The Boeing Company dismissed its chief financial officer and another executive yesterday for what it called ethical misconduct in the hiring of the executive, a former Pentagon official who was involved in contract negotiations with the company.

title: Where Were You?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 3 Arizona Killings Are Linked to 9 Others
description: Three men, believed to have been illegal immigrants from Mexico, were found slain execution-style in the Arizona desert over the weekend, the Maricopa County sheriff said on Monday.

title: Scrutinizing and Satirizing Hollywood's Tinsel Heaven
description: STILL HOLDING

title: Skakel's Defense Team Appeals Conviction in 1975 Murder
description: Lawyers for Michael C. Skakel, who was convicted in June 2002 of the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley, filed an appeal here on Monday in State Supreme Court.

title: How the Nets Won The Right to Move
description: If his $275 million bid to buy the Nets succeeds, the real estate developer Bruce C. Ratner will have a previous Nets ownership to thank for smoothing his way to taking the team to downtown Brooklyn.

title: Technological Dub Erases a Bush Flub for a Republican Ad
description: It may be called the Case of the Disappearing Pause.

title: NASA Seeks $220 Million For Shuttle Safety Measures
description: Returning the shuttle fleet to orbit will require at least $220 million for safety improvements in this fiscal year, on top of $60 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30, NASA said on Monday. And the agency acknowledged that those sums ''do not address the full spectrum'' of what will be needed.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New NASD proposals on initial public offerings aim to prevent excesses like those in the 90's.
description: NASD is considering whether to require underwriters to justify the prices they set for initial public offerings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, EUGENE D.
description: FRANK--Eugene D., President of Sidney Frank Importing and long time resident of New Rochelle passed on November 24, 2003. Former husband of Doris L. Frank. Loving father of John R. Frank and Linda F. Rodman and her husband Lawrence B. Rodman. Adoring grandfather of Tara, Max and Jesse. Dear brother of Sidney Frank and Edna Nowitz. Funeral Service today 1PM at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road Larchmont, NY 10538. Interment at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. Flowers or donations to White Plains Hospital Cardiology Program White Plains Hospital Center, Davis Avenue at East Post Road, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: 9/11 Memorial Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Ask U.N. For Resolution
description: The Iraqi Governing Council asked Monday for a Security Council resolution recognizing a new American-Iraqi agreement for a speedier transfer of power in Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Rare Gorilla Dead
description: Snowflake, a 40-year-old rare albino gorilla and the star of the Barcelona Zoo, was euthanized after he deteriorated with worsening skin cancer. He had been at the zoo since 1966 and was born in the former Spanish colony of Guinea. Snowflake -- Copito de Nieve in Spanish -- appeared on thousands of postcards throughout the city. In September, the zoo's president announced that Snowflake was dying, and City Hall waived zoo entrance fees for children who came to say goodbye. In his long captivity at the zoo, Snowflake sired 21 offspring. None was an albino. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Car Kills Queens Girl, 15
description: A 15-year-old girl was hit and killed by a car in Queens yesterday, the police said.

title: Superheroes in Snow, and Some Cold Blue Eyes
description: It wouldn't snow for the X-Men. Sergio Leone sees something in Henry Fonda, and Federico Fellini interests Walt Disney.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: DOCTOR WOUNDS CAPTOR, A MURDER SUSPECT A man wanted in a double killing in Oklahoma was captured near Lufkin, Tex., after a doctor he had taken hostage in Arkansas shot him four times, the police said. The fugitive, Scott J. Eizember, commandeered a car driven by Dr. Samuel Peebles of Nashville, Ark., and forced him at gunpoint to drive into Texas, the police said. Dr. Peebles, whose wife was also in the car, eventually used a pistol he had hidden to wound Mr. Eizember, who drove on alone in the hijacked car until he was stopped by the police. Mr. Eizember was wanted for the Oct. 18 killings of an elderly couple in Depew, Okla. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: HEALTHSOUTH EXECUTIVE PLEADS GUILTY IN FRAUD CASE
description: A former vice president of the HealthSouth Corporation became the 15th executive yesterday to plead guilty in a $2.7 billion accounting fraud that prosecutors assert was orchestrated by the company's founder, Richard M. Scrushy. The executive, Catherine Fowler, a former cash manager and vice president in the company's treasury department, admitted that in 2001 she helped hide the sale of $27 million in another public company's stock. Ms. Fowler, 36, admitted that she enhanced HealthSouth's balance sheet at the request of Malcolm McVay, then the chief financial officer, although she said she did not think that Mr. Scrushy knew of the transaction.

title: The Uncivil War
description: ''One of the problems with media coverage of this administration,'' wrote Eric Alterman in The Nation, ''is that it requires bad manners.''

title: NIKE RAISES QUARTERLY DIVIDEND 43%, TO 20 CENTS
description: Nike Inc., the world's biggest athletic-shoe maker, raised its quarterly cash dividend yesterday by 43 percent, to 20 cents a share. The dividend will be paid Jan. 5 to holders of Nike shares at the end of the day on Dec. 15, the company said in a statement. Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., set the earlier 14-cent dividend in November 2002. Nike had net income of $261.2 million, or 98 cents a share, in the first quarter ended Aug. 31 on revenue of $3.02 billion.

title: For Concussions, Bench Remedy
description: Two new studies of college football players add credence to the idea that athletes should stay on the sideline for a week after their concussion symptoms disappear.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: BURUNDI: REBELS JOIN GOVERNMENT President Domitien Ndayizeye appointed former Hutu rebels to four cabinet posts on Sunday in the clearest sign yet of the country's wish to heal the wounds of a decade-long civil war that killed 300,000 people. The appointments, intended to give Hutus more jobs in the Tutsi-dominated government before elections, are part of a three-year transition to democracy brokered in 2000.

title: New York Court Overturns Death Sentence
description: New York State's highest court overturned today the death sentence of a Syracuse-area man who poisoned his wife as she began to recover from being beaten by him with a baseball bat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENKE, ALEXANDER STUART
description: MENKE--Alexander Stuart. Died peacefully in his sleep at home in Pasadena, CA, on Saturday, November 22, 2003. He was an honorable and loving gentleman. He is survived by his devoted wife Virginia, and caring children John Milton, Laurie Zatkowski and Jason, a brother, John Roger, and a sister, Rosanne Menke Lustberg.

title: At Ground Zero, a Stream of Commuters and Tears
description: The PATH train lurched around a bend and emerged from the darkness of a cast-iron tube into the morning sun. Reaching for her husband's arm, Carol Webster, 60, turned to face the exposed guts of ground zero for the first time.

title: Thanksgiving Forecast: Potential Fireworks on the Sun
description: Snapping like rubber bands pulled too tightly, tangled magnetic fields on the surface of the Sun have been spewing waves of radiation and superheated particles at Earth.

title: U.S. Acquiesces to Allies on New Iran Nuclear Resolution
description: The United States, bowing to the wishes of its allies, agreed Monday to let the International Atomic Energy Agency adopt a resolution deploring Iran's nuclear program without referring the issue to the United Nations for possible sanctions, administration officials said.

title: Letters
description: The Need for Proxies

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Names New Executive
description: Nokia, the world's biggest maker of cellphones, has named Mary McDowell head of its enterprise solutions unit as it seeks to increase sales to corporate customers. Ms. McDowell, now a senior vice president for strategy and corporate development at Hewlett-Packard Company, will start Jan. 1, Nokia, which is based in Finland, said. Among Ms. McDowell's tasks will be to persuade companies to replace fixed-line phones with cellphones and substitute handsets for laptop computers.

title: Big Names Go Musical (What Rhymes With Oedipus?)
description: 'We're All Dead'

title: Standing Guard in the Kitchen As the Castro Revolution Arrives
description: Oddly missing from ''The Cook,'' Eduardo Machado's bittersweet slice of Cuban life in the time of Castro, is the lyricism that this interesting Cuban-born playwright generally delivers. The play, which takes place over four decades in the kitchen of a Havana mansion, is generally in line with the concerns of Mr. Machado: the personal consequences of political upheaval. But it's a programmatic treatment, a prosaic outline of a play that seems to be waiting for the shadings of poetry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, JUDITH
description: FRIEDMAN--Judith, on November 22, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Arnold D. Loving mother of Roger, Lisa and John. Mother-in-law of Pat and Kathy. Dear sister of Herbert Scheinberg. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Randall and Julia. Mayest Thou O God of Mercy, shelter her forever under the wings of Thy presence. May her soul be bound up in the bond of life eternal and grant that the memories of her life inspire us.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 13 about a study of the cholesterol-lowering drugs Lipitor and Pravachol referred imprecisely to the directness of the comparison between them. While the study was a head-to-head comparison -- that is, both drugs were given to heart patients at the maximum allowable dose -- the article omitted those dosages. Patients on Lipitor, or atorvastatin, were given 80 milligrams a day. Patients on Pravachol, or pravastatin, were given half that dose, 40 milligrams a day, because that was the maximum allowable dose at the time. (Bristol-Myers Squibb, the maker of Pravachol, has since received approval for an 80-milligram dose.) The research, conducted by the Cleveland Clinic and financed by Pfizer, the maker of Lipitor, was intended to test the effects of aggressive and moderate therapies on lowering cholesterol.

title: An Imperfect Compromise
description: Its passage was never going to be a sure thing, or even, at times, a likely one. For six years Congress had tried, and failed, to reach agreement on legislation overhauling Medicare and adding prescription drug benefits for the 40 million elderly and disabled Americans in the program.

title: It May Be a Long Season for St. John's
description: When a team is as young and inexperienced as St. John's, there are precious few Big East Conference games that it will be expected to win. Last night's home game against Fairfield, a team predicted to finish in the middle of the pack in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, was one of the early-season matchups that was supposed to balance the scales.

title: The Giants Sink While the Buccaneers Swim
description: It could have been dubbed the Disappointment Bowl, a matchup of Super Bowl hopefuls struggling for the last shred of hope for a playoff berth. The game itself, a Monday night matchup between Tampa Bay and the Giants, lived down to that billing with enough mistakes to sink the pirate ship that looms over one of its end zones in Raymond James Stadium.

title: SENATE REMOVES TWO ROADBLOCKS TO DRUG BENEFIT
description: The Senate beat back two major challenges on Monday to a bill that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare. The votes cleared the way for Congress to approve the biggest changes in the program since it was created in 1965 as a cornerstone of the Great Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHANANAU, ALEXANDER
description: CHANANAU--Alexander. On November 22, 2003 at the age of 88. His wife Adele of 65 years of marriage, his daughter Rosalind, granddaughters Sarah & Allison, his son-inlaw Gary Karlitz and his four step-grandchildren, remember him lovingly. Born in New York City in 1915, he worked his way through college and law school ultimately serving as a Justice of the Supreme Court of New York from 1974 through 1983 and previously as a member of the New York State legislature from 1958 through 1972. Alexander Chananau will be remembered as a selfless public servant who took pride in helping others. During his long and distinguished career, Judge Chananau had served as a director for many organizations including: Supreme Court Justices Association of the City of New York, Bronx County Bar Association, New York State Trial Lawyers Association and the New York University Law School Alumni Association among others. The family will sit Shiva at the Chananau home from Tuesday through Sunday morning. An extraordinary man, he will be sorely missed.

title: Alzheimer's Risk Identified
description: Changes in the size of a small part of the brain can be used to predict mental decline in older people, a study being released today suggests.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Claims It Has Doubled Chip Power
description: Intel said it had produced chips using the 65-nanometer manufacturing process, a strong sign the company would continue to keep pace with the so-called Moore's law, which posits a doubling of the number of transistors on a chip every 18 months. Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., announced yesterday that it would start to mass-produce the chips in 2005. The nanometer figure refers to the average size of features on chips produced by the process. Most PC microprocessors on the market are made on the 130-nanometer process; most manufacturers are just starting to produce 90-nanometer chips.

title: U.S. Presses Israel to Stop Work On New Settlements and Barrier
description: The Bush administration has sent new signals to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel demanding that his government stop its expansion of settlements and the construction of a barrier in the West Bank, administration officials said Monday.

title: Constructing a Comedy From Architects' Foibles
description: 'Private Jokes, Public Places'

title: Nielsen Offers More Details On Lost Viewers
description: Nielsen Media Research, whose data shows a puzzling decline in younger males watching broadcast network television since the fall season began, offered a more detailed explanation yesterday for the shift in viewing habits that has vexed the networks, advertisers and agencies.

title: Movie Stars Onstage: Big Daddy Speaks Out
description: They say you need sexy young movie stars to sell Broadway shows these days, particularly when it comes to long, literate plays like Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' The current revival of ''Cat'' meets this requirement with Jason Patric, in silk pajamas that reveal his hairy chest, and Ashley Judd in a form-fitting slip.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Gets Cellphone Complaints
description: Nearly 5,000 complaints about cellphone reception and other problems were recorded by the city in the last few weeks, according to a city report released yesterday. On Oct. 27, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg encouraged cellphone customers, as part of an effort to improve service, to register complaints by calling 311 or logging on to the city's Web site. The Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications said that six major carriers handled the city's nearly 10.5 million cellphones, and that Sprint and AT&T Wireless had received the most complaints. Lower Manhattan, Midtown and Inwood were the Manhattan areas with the most complaints about dropped calls and other problems. Sprint plans to use the data in its effort to install more cellphone transmission towers in areas where zoning laws restrict them. Nora Krug (NYT)

title: Colombia Begins Controversial Disarmament Program
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, Nov. 25  After a minute of silence in memory of the thousands killed in Colombia's conflict, 800 fighters from an urban band of Colombia's right-wing paramilitary group today laid down their weapons in a ceremony for a disarmament program the government says could bring Colombia closer to ending its 39-year-old war.

title: Economy Grew Even Faster Than First Thought in 3rd Quarter
description: The economy grew at an 8.2 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the government reported this morning, a much more torrid pace than the 7.2 percent that was the initial estimate.

title: Paul J. Haskins, 62, Editor at The Times
description: Paul J. Haskins, an editor at The New York Times who earlier directed The Kansas City Times's Pulitzer Prize-winning coverage of a disastrous hotel walkway collapse in 1981, died on Sunday in Cancn, Mexico. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POOLE, HENRY P.
description: POOLE--Henry P. 40 year resident of Malverne, suddenly on November 22, 2003. Beloved husband of 47 years to Jacqueline. Loving father of Margaret, Nancy Parker (Terrence), Jacqueline Zerilli (Steven), Patricia, Michael J. (Andrea), and Daniel P. (Tara). Dear grandfather of Ryan, Janine, Joseph, Brooke, Jacqueline, Jessica, James, Christopher and Kelly. Cherished brother of Sr. M. Julianna Poole, S.S.N.D. Longtime parishioner of Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Henry was the retired Executive Vice President and General Counsel of the New York Stock Exchange Inc. (1973-1993). Prior thereto he was Vice President and General Counsel of Merrill Lynch. He was a graduate of St. John's University and St. John's University School of Law (1957). Family will receive friends Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue (corner Peninsula Blvd), Lynbrook. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Embattled Chief Executive of Delta Air Lines to Step Down
description: Leo F. Mullin, the chief executive of Delta Air Lines who came under fire earlier this year from Congress and union officials over a pay package they deemed excessive and who has battled in vain for concessions from pilots, said unexpectedly yesterday that he would step aside Jan. 1.

title: Sahara Journal; Camel Crossing Ahead: A New Sahara Highway
description: Forget compass readings, camel caravans and disorienting, potentially deadly Jeep journeys through the world's most fabled and forbidding desert. Soon it will be possible to take a leisurely drive along a paved two-lane highway from the spot where Europe kisses the tip of this continent into the heart of sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Rivals Attack Dean at Debate, Focusing on Medicare
description: On a day when Congress moved toward final approval of a Medicare reform bill sought by President Bush, Howard Dean came under attack at a Democratic presidential debate here on Monday for suggesting he would reduce the growth of Medicare spending, and for social service cuts he made as governor of Vermont.

title: Accord on Iran Nuclear Issue
description: The United States agreed to an International Atomic Energy Agency resolution, avoiding referring Iran's nuclear program to the United Nations. Page A3.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Doctor Wounds Captor, A Murder Suspect
description: A man wanted in a double killing in Oklahoma was captured near Lufkin, Tex., after a doctor he had taken hostage in Arkansas shot him four times, the police said. The fugitive, Scott J. Eizember, commandeered a car driven by Dr. Samuel Peebles of Nashville, Ark., and forced him at gunpoint to drive into Texas, the police said. Dr. Peebles, whose wife was also in the car, eventually used a pistol he had hidden to wound Mr. Eizember, who drove on alone in the hijacked car until he was stopped by the police. Mr. Eizember was wanted for the Oct. 18 killings of an elderly couple in Depew, Okla. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Cease-Fire Offer Welcomed
description: Officials welcomed Pakistan's offer of a cease-fire along the line separating the countries, saying they would ''respond positively,'' the state-run media reported. India proposed a cease-fire on the Siachen Glacier, a high-altitude ice field where Indian and Pakistani forces have been skirmishing for years. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Pertussis, Conquered Yet a Threat
description: After 12 years as a public health nurse, I received my first report of pertussis, or whooping cough, last year. I knew very little about it then, but by the time I was finished with my investigations I knew the first names of all the communicable disease experts at the state level.

title: MEMO PAD
description: All signs indicate that travel will be up significantly over both 2002 and 2001 for the holiday period starting tomorrow and continuing through New Year's Day.

title: Young Ideas For Solemn Sites; Newcomers Dominate In Designs for Memorials
description: The unveiling last week of eight competing designs for a World Trade Center memorial has provoked an inevitable debate about whether any of the projects can properly honor those who died on Sept. 11, 2001. But nearly everyone has been struck by how many of these projects, plucked as they were from a pool of more than 5,000 anonymous submissions, are the work of young artists and not the architectural elite.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Thursday about Michael Arad, a New York City Housing Authority architect whose design is a finalist in the World Trade Center memorial competition, gave an erroneous example of his work. While he helped design two city police stations, Police Service Area 4 on the Lower East Side was not one of them.

title: Syphilis Cases Increase, Raising Fear of H.I.V. Rise
description: The rate of syphilis infections in the United States, which declined sharply from 1990 to 2000, shot up in 2002 for the second year in a row, according to new figures from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Goodbye Bush, Hello Chirac: Blair Nurtures European Ties
description: With President Bush barely out the door after his state visit last week, Prime Minister Tony Blair held meetings with the leaders of France and Spain on Monday, trying to demonstrate that he can have a special friendship with the United States while maintaining close relations with Europe.

title: U.S.C. Moves Up, But L.S.U. Is Lurking
description: Southern California retook the No. 2 slot in the Bowl Championship Series ranking yesterday, giving the Trojans a tenuous hold on the second berth in college football's national championship game, the Sugar Bowl.

title: 'Anti-American' Papers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column yesterday about gallery talks at the Frick Collection in Manhattan misstated the starting day. It is Dec. 5, not this Friday.

title: Of Fowl and Firemen
description: Forums highlights, including readers' Thanksgiving stories and food and wine tips.

title: Captain in Staten Island Ferry Crash Protests His Firing by the City
description: The captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed into a pier last month met yesterday with city officials to formally contest their decision to fire him.

title: Gay Marriage and Our Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Refuting The Cynics
description: The Economist magazine recently observed that in the 40 years following World War II, ''America and Europe seemed to be growing more like one another in almost every way that matters.'' Demographically, economically and politically, the United States and Europe seemed to be converging.

title: This Is Broadway? Alas, Not in My Book
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economy Expected To Surge
description: India's economy is expected to grow at an ''explosive'' pace as a government economic program encourages spending by consumers and leads to higher production, the finance minister, Jaswant Singh, said. ''The fundamentals in reality have not been better in the last 52 years,'' Mr. Singh, left, told executives in New Delhi over the weekend. The government expects the economy to expand more than 7 percent, the fastest pace in seven years, in the fiscal year that ends next March, as a heavier-than-normal monsoon increases farm production and lifts rural income. That will generate demand for products from televisions to tractors. Companies have also become more efficient by cutting costs and adopting technologies.

title: Gay Marriage and Our Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Anderson and Mutombo Get It Done for Knicks
description: Dikembe Mutombo was wagging again and Shandon Anderson was zigzagging, and together all of the healthy Knicks were weaving their patchwork lineup into a surprisingly artistic quilt.

title: Sports Briefing
description: HOCKEY

title: The Three-State Solution
description: President Bush's new strategy of transferring power quickly to Iraqis, and his critics' alternatives, share a fundamental flaw: all commit the United States to a unified Iraq, artificially and fatefully made whole from three distinct ethnic and sectarian communities. That has been possible in the past only by the application of overwhelming and brutal force.

title: THEFT OF COBALT IN IRAQ PROMPTS SECURITY INQUIRY
description: A seeming lapse in surveillance by American forces has led to the looting of dangerously radioactive capsules from Saddam Hussein's main battlefield testing site in the desert outside Baghdad and the identification of at least one 30-year-old Iraqi villager, and possibly a village boy, as suffering from radiation sickness.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: TEAMSTERS BACK GROCERY STRIKERS The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced that it would back supermarket workers in a six-week dispute with three Southern California supermarket chains by refusing to make deliveries to the 859 stores involved. The supermarket workers' union, the United Food and Commercial Workers, said the Teamsters' move, coming in Thanksgiving week, would pressure the three chains, Vons, Ralphs and Albertsons, to make compromises to settle the dispute. On Oct. 11, workers at Vons went on strike, and the next day the two other chains locked out their workers, meaning that 70,000 workers have been sidelined. Previously, the Teamsters made deliveries to the stores but refused to unload them, forcing workers at the supermarkets to do the unloading. Now the Teamsters will not even make deliveries.

title: Conductor In New Job Plays It Quite Cool
description: The Brazilian conductor Roberto Minczuk has been contributing at the New York Philharmonic since 1998, leading concerts in the parks, in the boroughs outside Manhattan and on tour. Last year Lorin Maazel made his role official by naming him the associate conductor.

title: Added Peril of Epilepsy
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Says State Law Violated Man's Rights
description: A federal judge has agreed that New York City violated the constitutional rights of a man who was arrested for sending an alarming letter last year to a candidate for lieutenant governor. Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of United States District Court in Manhattan, in a ruling yesterday, agreed with Carlos Vives, 66, who claimed that the state's antiharassment law violated his right to engage in protected speech. The question of damages, and whether or not the officers who arrested him are personally liable, must go to trial, she ruled. Noting that many courts were finding the law unconstitutional, she urged state and local law enforcement officials to stop enforcing it. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A Richness of Advisers, Most of Them Free
description: This is not a joke, but maybe it should be: How many bankers does it take to advise the buyers of Warner Music? The answer: At least seven.

title: Theater in Review
description: Constructing a Comedy From Architects' Foibles

title: TENET HEALTHCARE RECEIVES TWO MORE SUBPOENAS
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that the United States attorney's office in New Orleans had issued two additional subpoenas seeking documents and information from affiliates of the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tenet said the affiliates -- the People's Health Network, a provider of health plan management services based in New Orleans, and Memorial Medical Center, a New Orleans hospital owned by a Tenet unit -- received the subpoenas on Friday. The United States attorney's office previously issued two subpoenas to People's Health, which were disclosed in October. Tenet, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., is facing several lawsuits as well as government investigations into its billing practices and charges of unnecessary surgical procedures.

title: Yonkers Parents Turn Out To Protest School Budget
description: More than 200 people packed a public hearing at Yonkers Middle/High School late Monday afternoon to voice their frustration, disappointment and outright confusion about the state of the Yonkers school budget.

title: At Ahold, Past Errors Shadow The Future
description: Days ahead of a large equity issue, Royal Ahold's new management team said that the company's future partly depended on how it undid its past.

title: Soldiers' Paychecks
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the new marketing program for Mickey Mouse misstated the date of Walt Disney's death. It was Dec. 15, 1966, not in 1967.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMALL, MICHAEL LEWIS
description: SMALL--Michael Lewis, age 64, passed away surrounded by his loving family on November 24, 2003. He is survived by his adoring wife, Lynn, and his beloved children Jonathan and David. Michael wrote musical scores for over 50 feature films and TV programs, as well as hundreds of TV and radio commercials. His many credits as a film composer include the music for Alan Pakula's Klute and The Parallax View, Bob Rafelson's The Postman Al ways Rings Twice and Black Widow, and John Schlesinger's Marathon Man. All those who had the privilege of meeting him were touched by his playful humor and incredible talent. He will be greatly missed. Services Wednesday 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOWARD, BEVERLY RUTH (KAHAN)
description: HOWARD -- Beverly Ruth (Kahan), 66, of Westport, CT and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, beloved daughter, wife, mother and grandmother, died Saturday, November 22, 2003 at the Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center in Florida. She was born April 11, 1937 to Helen (Peiros) Cohen of Tamarac, FL and the late Barney Kahan and grew up in Fall River, MA. She was the beloved wife of Melvin Howard, to whom she had been married for 46 years. In addition to her husband and mother she leaves her children, Marjorie Evans and her husband Douglas, of Avon, CT and Brian Howard and his wife Melanie, of Newtown CT; her six grandchildren: Danielle, Samuel and Stephanie Evans, and Benjamin, Maxwell and Joshua Howard, as well as other family members and many dear friends. She was predeceased by her sister, Roberta Kevelson. Beverly was a lovely lady who touched everyone she met with her warmth and sweetness. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, November 26th at 1:00 PM at Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Road, Westport, CT. A memorial service will take place in Palm Beach Gardens, FL on Friday, December 5th. Memorial donations may be made to: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis Research, c/o The American Lung Association, 61 Broadway, NY, NY 10006.

title: Deal on Media Rules
description: President Bush and Senate Republicans settled a dispute over media ownership rules, eliminating a stumbling block to approval of a spending bill for a third of federal programs.

title: Front Row
description: A New York Debut

title: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Laurence Steinberg; Are Young Killers Evil, Or Works in Progress?
description: If the 12 jurors presiding over Lee Malvo's fate in a Chesapeake, Va., courtroom find him guilty, they will then have to decide if death is an appropriate punishment for crimes committed by a 17-year-old. Mr. Malvo, now 18, is accused of participating in the sniper attacks that terrorized the Washington area last fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAKIM, TOUBA
description: HAKIM--Touba. The Israel Cancer Research Fund expresses sincere condolences to Kamran Hakim, a member of our International Board of Trustees, and his wife, Ellen, on the passing of his beloved mother, Touba Hakim. Yashar Hirshaut, M.D., Pres. Leah Susskind, Chairperson Simon Kaminetsky, Director

title: Solving the Problem Of an Absent Polish Mother
description: 'My Big Gay Italian Wedding'

title: Sprint to Lay Off Another 2,000 As Sales Decline
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off 2,000 workers, or 2.9 percent of its employees, as it reorganizes operations to contend with falling long-distance sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTNAYER, YVONNE ROSA
description: GUTNAYER--Yvonne Rosa. Greatly loved and cherished wife of the late Henry R. Gutnayer. Devoted and loving mother of Joan C. Engel and Kathryn D. Gordon and doting and loving grandmother of Alex and Ken Rudd. We will deeply miss you through your love and caring and the memory of your eternal French charm will remain in our hearts forever. Anyone wanting to make a contribution please send to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisades Ave., Riverdale, NY 10471. Services Wednesday 1:30 PM, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In Their Own Words
description: In a debate yesterday in Des Moines, the Democratic presidential candidates all addressed the issue of prescription drug coverage for Medicare recipients. All the candidates except Senator Joseph I. Lieberman were present.

title: Bush Meets Families of 26 Killed in Iraq; Offers Prayers
description: President Bush offered personal condolences on Monday to the families of 26 soldiers killed in Iraq, meeting privately with 98 parents, spouses, children and other relatives of the dead at a time when his handling of war casualties has become a political issue.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: New Financial Regulator
description: The French finance minister, Francis Mer, inaugurated the new financial market regulator in Paris. The body, called Autorit de Marchs Financiers, will replace three organizations -- the Commission des Oprations de Bourses, which monitored market transactions; Conseil des Marchs Financiers, a filings agency; and the Conseil de Discipline de la Gestion Financire, the financial markets council. Michel Prada, former head of the C.O.B. and the C.M.F., was appointed director of the group. After the Enron scandal, the French government decided to simplify and reinforce control of financial markets by merging the three organizations. The commission will monitor the stock exchange, protect savings and try to ensure that investors have fair access to information. It will also have broader powers to ensure that companies comply with their corporate governance obligations and to supervise financial analysts. Helene Fouquet (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Lockerbie Bomber Must Serve 27 Years
description: Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, the Libyan intelligence officer sentenced to a life term in a Scottish prison for the 1988 downing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, must serve at least 27 years before he can apply for parole, a Scottish court ruled. Mr. Megrahi, 51, was convicted and sentenced in 2001 for the murders of the 270 people killed. He was before a court again because of a law that requires that prisoners sentenced to life be told how many years they must serve before they can apply for parole. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: PRO BASKETBALL: N.B.A. Analysis; The Nets Will Be the Same, With or Without Mourning
description: It had become evident, even before yesterday's sad news, that the Nets' version of Alonzo Mourning was not the fearsome, dominating Zo of five years ago.

title: ROUGE INDUSTRIES WINS APPROVAL FOR ASSET AUCTION
description: Rouge Industries Inc., the largest supplier of steel to Ford Motor, won a bankruptcy judge's permission yesterday to auction its assets; OAO Severstal of Russia has made an offer of about $215 million for them. Severstal's bid was given ''stalking horse'' status, which means other offers will have to beat the Russian company's price at a Dec. 19 auction. Judge Mary F. Walrath of United States Bankruptcy Court approved auction procedures yesterday. The U.S. Steel Corporation remains a competing bidder. Rouge filed Chapter 11 papers in October amid depressed steel prices and operating losses.

title: Gay Marriage and Our Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAGED, BETTY FOX
description: MAGED--Betty Fox. Of Hallandale, FL, on November 24, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Henry Fox, and then of the late Myron Maged. Cherished mother of the late Marcia Stern and Jerry Fox, and mother-in-law of Marcia Fox and the late Sandy Stern. Cherished stepmother of Barbara Weinger, Bonnie Goldstein, and Steve Maged, and the entire Maged family. Adored grandmother of six and great grandmother of four. The matriarch of a large, close family, she touched the lives of many. Her vivacious warmth filled the room with compassion and generosity of spirit for all. Her love and kindess spread beyond her family to all in need. Services Wednesday 11:15 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to your local UJA Federation.

title: The Need for Proxies
description: To the Editor:

title: Refusal by Purinton Puts Sather in a Bind
description: Rangers Coach Glen Sather confirmed Monday that last week he asked defenseman Dale Purinton to accept a two-week conditioning assignment with Hartford, the team's top minor league affiliate. Purinton has thus far declined to do so.

title: Schilling Now Has One Foot In Fenway
description: The Yankees began this off-season hoping to replace Roger Clemens in their starting rotation with Curt Schilling, another strapping right-hander with a dominant fastball and splitter. But trade talks with Arizona went nowhere, and now the Yankees are faced with a nightmare: the Diamondbacks have agreed to trade Schilling to Boston.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel Has Never Shaken Playoff Loss Against 49ers
description: SEPARATED by nine months, the two decision makers watched their fabled teams build indomitable playoff leads only to experience the false sense of security that dooms sand-castle kings.

title: Funk That Shows Off by Holding Back
description: Most jam bands live for the chance to mix up genres and charge off on improvisational tangents. Galactic, a band from New Orleans that played two sets at Roseland on Friday night, isn't one of them. Its songs have a more utilitarian goal: to get people dancing. A Galactic song that starts out as a funk tune stays that way all the way through, keeping the groove steady and the structure obvious. Galactic accepts the discipline of funk: the repetition and deliberate space that give the music its solidity and swing. The musicians show off by restraining themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BELL, NEIL ARMSTRONG
description: BELL--Neil Armstrong. 6/10/69 to 11/25/83. In loving memory of my dearest son. Since your eyes closed my eyes have never ceased to weep. You were a wonderful son, brother and friend. We thank you for the short 14 years and you will be in our hearts forever. Love, mother Lydia, Marlon & Deirdr

title: Gay Marriage and Our Society (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Marriage and Our Society
description: To the Editor:

title: More Mothers Are Breast-Feeding Longer, Survey Shows
description: The number of women who start breast-feeding in the hospital and who are still nursing six months later is at an all-time high, according to a survey released today. Yet 30 percent of new mothers never try breast-feeding, and 67 percent have quit by six months, the Ross Mothers Survey found.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Questioning Police Tactics At Protest
description: The United Steelworkers of America called for a Congressional investigation into whether the Miami police violated the rights of protesters last week during the Free Trade Area of the Americas meetings in Miami. The union, which sent members to participate in a march sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Thursday, said in a news release that the police had systematically intimidated marchers and other protesters. The free-speech rights of the protesters were ''blatantly violated, sometimes violently,'' by police officers using ''massive force, riot gear and armaments,'' the release said. Dozens of people were arrested at the protests, some accused of setting trash fires and throwing bottles, rocks and smoke bombs. At least one protester was hospitalized. The Miami Police Department did not return a call seeking comment. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Pennington Takes Page From Montana's Book
description: The drive against Jacksonville that is burnishing a nascent legend took Chad Pennington back to the 1999 Mid-American Conference championship game, when he rallied Marshall from a 23-point deficit against Western Michigan with four touchdowns in the second half.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Business School Exam Canceled
description: A countrywide admission test to enter the top business schools was canceled on Sunday after the police discovered that the questions had been leaked ahead of the exam. Following a tip, officers with the Central Bureau of Investigation raided a hotel and arrested four people selling the questions for the exam, the Common Admission Test. Hundreds of thousands of graduates appear each year for the competitive exam where top scores make students eligible for admission to the premier Indian Institute of Management as well as a few other top management schools. The leaked papers were sold for as much as 5,00,000 rupees ($11,000). A schedule for a new exam is expected to be announced. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Loans Keep Korean Credit Card Issuer Afloat
description: South Korea's largest credit card company, LG Card, resumed cash operations on Monday after barely averting bankruptcy.

title: The Lines Are Busy as Cellphone Clients Switch
description: After a long wait, new rules that allow people to change mobile phone companies while keeping their numbers sent a surge of customers into cellphone stores around the country yesterday, with some stores seeing more than a tripling of traffic.

title: History, Rescued From Dust; The Men Who Saved The Relics of 9/11
description: Three old friends gathered in the days before Thanksgiving amid a roomful of scattered artifacts, once-mundane objects that have been transformed by trauma. These are relics of the World Trade Center attack; they will be displayed in a new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society that opens today.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Dropping Push For an Energy Bill This Year
description: Congress abandoned its efforts to enact new energy legislation this year as Senate Republican leaders said Monday night that time had run out to resolve an impasse blocking a vote on the measure.

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend on Friday about a New York Philharmonic concert of 20th-century Russian works mistranslated the Roman numeral CD in the title of a Stravinsky piece. It is 400 (''CL'' would have been 150). The piece was written in 1961 for the 400th anniversary of the birth of Gesualdo di Venosa.

title: Corrections
description: ACongressional Memo article on Saturday about a frenzy of last-minute legislative activity misstated the number of votes needed in the Senate to cut off a filibuster. It is 60  that is, three-fifths of the Senate, not two-thirds.

title: Germany and France Win Time on Deficits
description: Germany and France won extra time on Tuesday to reduce their budget deficits, overriding objections from four smaller countries that the compromise risks the credibility of the euro by undermining European Union fiscal rules.

title: The Need for Proxies
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Court Is Holding 12 In Terror Acts
description: Turkey's State Security Court took custody of 12 people on Monday in connection with the four suicide bombings here in recent days, moving a step closer to bringing charges in the attacks. Authorities said they had identified a third bomber in the group of four.

title: A Course in Evolution, Taught by Chimps
description: Fossil bones record the history of the human form but they say little about behavior. A richer source on the way human social behavior evolved may come from chimpanzees, with whom people shared a common ancestor as recently as five or six million years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, JOAN RAHM
description: MILLER--Joan Rahm. Of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away on November 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Hy Miller and cherished spouse of Malvin Rahm. Loving mother of Sharon Rahm Sheen and Randi Rahm. Adoring grandmother to Mathew, Andrew and Mason Sheen and Michael and Jason Bressler. She will always be loved and will live on in our hearts.

title: Congressional Memo; Spending Discipline Proves Unfashionable This Year
description: The Medicare bill about to clear Congress is the latest example of how budget discipline is being given short shrift at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, critics here and on Wall Street say.

title: Time Warner Sells Music Unit for $2.6 Billion
description: Time Warner confirmed the sale of its Warner Music division yesterday for about $2.6 billion to an investor group led by the Seagram heir Edgar Bronfman Jr. and the investment firm Thomas H. Lee, ending an 18-month corporate garage sale to pay down debts.

title: XEROX EXPECTS PROFIT INCREASE NEXT YEAR
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that profit would rise next year and in 2005, helped by cost-cutting. Sales in 2004 will be little changed, the company said. Profit next year will rise to 67 cents to 72 cents a share, from the 50 cents to 55 cents expected this year, the chief executive, Anne M. Mulcahy, said in a Webcast from New York. The company is expected to earn 73 cents in 2004, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Ms. Mulcahy has reduced costs to try to reverse 14 consecutive quarters of declining sales and restore investor confidence after a financial scandal. Shares in Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., rose 8 cents, to $10.62.

title: Produce Is Vital. Is It Dangerous? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast-Food Nation Is Taking Its Toll on Black Bears, Too
description: It's no secret that America's adults are getting fat and sedentary. Its children are becoming couch mini-potatoes. Even its pets are overweight.

title: 20 Airport Workers Arrested in Drug-Smuggling Case
description: Federal agents arrested 20 airport baggage and cargo handlers yesterday and charged them with running a decade-long drug smuggling operation that brought hundreds of pounds of cocaine and marijuana a year through Kennedy International Airport under the noses of customs officials.

title: South Florida Freezes Are Linked to Draining of Wetlands
description: Draining the lush wetlands that once dominated South Florida's landscape was supposed to make the region more suitable for agriculture than the state's cooler areas up north.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle To Continue Pursuit Of Peoplesoft
description: Oracle executives reiterated the company's intent to acquire a rival software maker, PeopleSoft, for $7.3 billion, hoping to counter speculation that the merger was looking increasingly unlikely. ''We remain committed to acquiring PeopleSoft,'' Chuck Phillips, vice president of Oracle, said in a conference call yesterday with financial analysts. Oracle executives said that the company would comply with the Justice Department's second request for documents and information in the next few weeks, and that they expected approval sometime early next year. Oracle, which is based in Redwood Shores, Calif., is complying with a separate investigation by the European Commission. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: The Sixth Generation Corvette
description: The 2005 Chevrolet Corvette is to be unveiled at the 2004 Detroit auto show in January. However, a keen spy photographer caught a glimpse of the much-anticipated 6th generation sports car.

title: Trust Company Is Said to Be Facing Charges In Fund Inquiry
description: The New York attorney general is preparing to file criminal charges, possibly as early as today, against the Security Trust Company in Phoenix, an important corporate middleman serving the mutual fund industry, according to senior people briefed on the investigation.

title: Wild West And Boston As Partners In Morality
description: The 22nd floor of Fidelity Investments here is a sea of gray cubicles, unremarkably corporate in design, decor, feel. Even the corner office, where Thomas E. Eidson resides from 9 to 5, is hardly distinctive. Its major attraction, a view of Boston's renewed blue harbor, is partly sheathed by thick flaps of Venetian blind.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SYNGENTA CROP PROTECTION INC., the United States unit of Syngenta, Basel, Switzerland, the world's largest crop-chemical maker, said it had asked a federal judge to rule that it was not infringing on three herbicide patents of Monsanto Co., St. Louis, and that the patents were not enforceable.

title: Tyco Prosecutors Want to Show Tape Of Executive's Home
description: Prosecutors in the fraud trial of L. Dennis Kozlowski want to show a video of the New York apartment where, they say, Mr. Kozlowski, Tyco International's former chief executive, spent more than $30 million of company money on art and other furnishings, including a $15,000 umbrella stand.

title: Warren Spahn, 82, Dies; Left-Handed Craftsman of the Baseball Mound for 21 Seasons
description: Warren Spahn, who in a career spanning 21 seasons won 363 games, the major league record for a left-handed pitcher, died yesterday at his home in Broken Arrow, Okla. He was 82.

title: Lots of Beer Drinking On a Dead-End Front Porch
description: 'Where We're Born'

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Boeing Fires Executives For 'Ethical Misconduct'

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDELSON, JEFFRY
description: EDELSON--Jeffry. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Jeffry Edelson, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his parents, Ellen and Steven, and the entire family. Marc Goldberg, President Rabbi Stanley Platek

title: Abductions in Philippines spark death penalty debate
description: MANILA:  The rise in kidnappings in the Philippines has revived calls for lifting a moratorium on the death penalty in what some officials see as a reflection of growing public exasperation toward kidnappers and the government's inability to stop them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLINER, GEORGE
description: HOLINER--George, age 80, on November 23, 2003. Beloved husband of Lucille Holiner. Loving father of Tim and Hope; father-in-law of Linda and Michael. Doting grandfather of Sara, Max, Sharon and Diana. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, November 25, at 11 AM, Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELBERG, FREDERICK
description: GELBERG -- Frederick. 84. Beloved husband of Terie Gelberg (nee Isaacs) and the loving father of Barbara Freundlich (Richard), Jonathan Gelberg (Debra) and Steven Gelberg (Nilima). Adored grandfather of Amanda and Ali Angerman, and Michael and Robert Gelberg. Mr. Gelberg will be remembered by all who knew him for his brilliance, his love of life, compassion, inspiration and devotion to family and friends. He was a Partner at the law firm of Moses & Singer in NYC. Previously a Partner at Gelberg & Abrams, and at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hayes & Handler. He was a widely respected member of the New York Tax Bar and was honored by the New York Law Journal as one of the top tax attorneys in NYC. He was a graduate of the City College of New York and Columbia University School of Law, where he was an editor of The Law Review. Mr. Gelberg was also an honored veteran of WWII. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday at 11am, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, at 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY (across from the train station). No flowers please. Donations can be made to Columbia University School of Law or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank To Sell Some Properties
description: Germany's largest bank, Deutsche Bank, said yesterday that it would sell parts of its real estate holdings for 1.04 billion euros ($1.23 billion) to the Blackstone Group by the end of the year. The deal involves 51 properties across Europe. Most of the sites are occupied by the bank and will be leased back. Deutsche Bank said the transaction was part of its efforts to ''focus on core businesses and optimize the use of available capital.'' Since May 2002, the bank has sold industrial assets and noncore businesses worth more than 8 billion euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: The Sticker-Shock Congress
description: Congress nearly always engages in pork-barrel spending as it leaves town for the holidays, usually to feather the nests of special interest groups responsible for the perpetuation of careers on Capitol Hill. But this year's end-of-session binge has gone way beyond pork, saddling the country with long-term obligations of mammoth proportions and inviting censure not only from the usual good-government types but also from economists who genuinely fear for the future of the economy. The Wall Street investment bank Goldman Sachs, not given to hyperbole, warned in its most recent newsletter that the ''U.S. budget is out of control.'' This sentiment was echoed by the bipartisan Concord Coalition, which monitors federal spending, and which called 2003 ''the most irresponsible year ever'' in terms of fiscal discipline.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CITIGROUP BUYS WASHINGTON MUTUAL UNIT FOR $1.25 BILLION
description: Citigroup Inc. said yesterday that it had bought Washington Mutual Finance, the consumer finance unit of Washington Mutual, for $1.25 billion in cash. Washington Finance, based in Tampa, Fla., provides direct consumer and real estate loans through 409 offices in 25 states, mostly in the Southeast and Southwest. The company had more than 2,300 employees and total assets of $4.1 billion as of Sept. 30, according to a Citigroup statement. Citigroup said the transaction would add to the bank's earnings in 2004, was subject to customary regulatory approvals and was expected to close in the first quarter of 2004.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan Aims To Double China Sales
description: The Nissan Motor Company and its partner in China, the DongFeng Motor Corporation, said they hoped to more than double the number of cars sold by 2007. The companies, which started making cars in July, aim to sell 620,000 cars by 2007, up from an estimated 300,000 this year. Revenue from the sale is expected to be $9.6 billion, while operating profit margins are seen rising to 10 percent of sales, from 8 percent this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And This Was Before She Knew About the Reviews

title: Senator With Legislative Genes Is Elected New Minority Leader
description: Senator Leonard Lance, a Hunterdon County Republican whose father is the sole surviving framer of the state constitution, was unanimously elected yesterday to lead New Jersey's Senate Republican caucus.

title: Interim Leaders in Georgia Act Quickly to Establish Stability
description: A day after driving the country's longtime president from power, Georgia's interim leaders moved quickly on Monday to re-establish stability in a country torn by political divisions.

title: Panel Suggests Gas Tax Rise In New Jersey
description: A transportation commission appointed by Gov. James E. McGreevey recommended on Monday that New Jersey increase its gasoline tax by at least 12.5 cents per gallon, a move likely to ignite an angry political battle in a state where motorists love their cars nearly as much as they despise tax hikes.

title: Hugh Kenner, Commentator on Literary Modernism, Pound and Joyce, Is Dead at 80
description: Hugh Kenner, the critic, author and professor of literature regarded as America's foremost commentator on literary modernism, especially the work of Ezra Pound and James Joyce, died yesterday at his home in Athens, Ga. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARP, ABRAHAM J.
description: KARP--Abraham J., Rabbi, professor, scholar and bibliophile. Born April 5, 1921, Amdur (Indura) Poland. Arrived in New York 1930. Died November 24, 2003 in New York. Educated at Yeshiva University High School, Yeshiva College, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America and Columbia University. Rabbi in Swampscott, MA, Kansas City, MO and Rochester, NY. Professor of History and Religion at the University of Rochester, Adjunct Research Professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary. Author of many books, including The Jewish Way of Life, Haven and Home: A History of the Jews in America and From the Ends of the Earth: Judaic Treasures of the Library of Congress. Survived by his wife Deborah, two sons Hillel and David, daughtersin-law, Arlene and Barbara and six grandchildren, Joshua, Aaron, and Rachel; Sarah, Beth, and Benjamin. Contributions may be made to institutions of Jewish learning. Funeral 2 PM Tuesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. & Amsterdam Ave, New York.

title: Killing of Suspected Mob Figure Yields Few Clues for the Police
description: It was a Sunday night ritual for a man suspected of being a major player in the mob world in Hartford and other parts of New England.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: In New Hampshire, Lieberman Aims Ad at McCain Supporters
description: Struggling to break out of a cramped second tier of Democratic presidential candidates in New Hampshire, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman was set to broadcast a new commercial today that sought to appeal to the state's independent voters by casting him as the next John McCain.

title: Clark Campaign Puts A Veteran Manager At the Helm
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark's campaign for the Democratic nomination for president, which has gone for seven weeks without a campaign manager, announced on Monday that it had hired Paul Johnson, the manager of Senator Bob Graham's short presidential campaign, to fill that role.

title: Executive to Be Producer at Paramount
description: The president of Paramount Pictures, John Goldwyn, plans to step down to become a producer for the studio, Paramount said Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAWIL, IKE
description: TAWIL--Ike. We grieve with the family of Ike Tawil. We grieve with his dear Joy. We will miss his sweet, kind presence. Heartfelt, Alice and Louis Weiss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, JOHN HARRISON
description: FRANK--John Harrison, 83, of New York, N.Y., passed away on November 24, 2003 surrounded by his loving family. He is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, Gloria, his three loving daughters Penny, Rosemary and Terri and six grandchildren. John was a graduate of Yale University and owner of Atlantic Home Products. Memorial Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Tuesday, November 25th, 5:30PM.

title: After Big Victory, Cowboys Remembering What Spotlight Feels Like
description: This is not a juggernaut team like those of Troy Aikman and Emmitt Smith. There is no sense of domination, no Super Bowl talk, even in whispers. The Dallas Cowboys know they are not approaching greatness yet.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Beetles' Energy Booster

title: After Claim, S.I. Teacher Is Charged With Perjury
description: A Staten Island teacher was charged with perjury yesterday for having accused City Education Department investigator of assaulting her.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Electronic Arts Might Miss Sales Estimate
description: Electronic Arts, the largest maker of video games in the United States, may miss its sales estimate for this quarter because of increased competition from companies like Microsoft and Sony, said William J. Lennan Jr., an analyst for W.R. Hambrecht. ''The competitors who lost the most share last Christmas (Nintendo, Activision, Sony, Microsoft and Konami) are much stronger this year,'' Mr. Lennan wrote in a note to clients. The president of Electronic Arts, John Riccitello, has said his company will meet its revenue forecast. Electronic Arts usually makes as much as 50 percent of its annual sales during the holiday quarter.

title: People
description: Robert McKernan was named president, a vacant post, at Blue, part of the Edelman division of Daniel J. Edelman Inc. Mr. McKernan, based in the agency's Washington office, had been a partner at Smith & Harroff, Alexandria, Va.

title: Counselor Held In Sodomy Case Involving Stick At Youth Home
