description: On a tranquil, wooded campus in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., the nation's largest residential treatment center for troubled youths is struggling to cope with a case of sexual abuse in which a 14-year-old was said to have been sodomized with a broomstick by another resident while being held down by a counselor.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SCOTLAND: LOCKERBIE BOMBER MUST SERVE 27 YEARS Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, the Libyan intelligence officer sentenced to a life term in a Scottish prison for the 1988 downing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, must serve at least 27 years before he can apply for parole, a Scottish court ruled. Mr. Megrahi, 51, was convicted and sentenced in 2001 for the murders of 270 people on board. He was before a court again because of a law that requires that prisoners sentenced to life be told how many years they must serve before they can apply for parole.

title: JUDGE BACKS BOSTON SCIENTIFIC IN DEVICE DISPUTE
description: Shares of the Boston Scientific Corporation, the world's third-largest maker of heart stents, rose 5.3 percent yesterday after a judge denied Johnson & Johnson's bid to keep the company's newest device off the market in the United States. The Taxus drug-coated stent would compete with Johnson & Johnson's Cypher, which now has the United States market to itself. The devices are mesh tubes that prop open arteries cleared in angioplasty procedures. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., is moving closer to federal approval of Taxus after receiving the recommendation of a government advisory panel last week. Johnson & Johnson has not proved that the introduction of the product will cause ''irreparable harm,'' Judge Sue L. Robinson of Federal District Court in Delaware said. Boston Scientific shares rose $1.79, to $35.70. Shares of Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., rose 60 cents, to $51.48.

title: U.S. Should Be a Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Being Told It's Over, And Finally Listening
description: THE morning after feels like the mourning after, no pun intended, relative to yesterday's stunning but not entirely surprising news out of East Rutherford, N.J. A lifestyle measured by competitive ritual, by afternoon naps and pregame meals, concludes with a deflating medical report, one with all the subtlety of a door slammed on one's hand.

title: A Scrapbook of Songs That Adhere to a Life
description: At a time when most cabaret shows are organized around strict thematic concepts, it takes a certain courage to buck the trend and use one's own messy life as a subject. But Barbara Brussell, who grew up in Carmel, Calif., and now lives in New York, carries it off with aplomb.

title: Corrections
description: The diagramless puzzle in the magazine on Sunday provided an erroneous clue for 21 Down, seeking the answer ''Colin.'' Colin Powell is secretary of state, not defense.

title: Hungary's Memorable Victory
description: Fifty years ago today, the national team of Hungary walked onto the field at Wembley Stadium in London and two hours later walked off into history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, EUGENE
description: KLEINER--Eugene. Died November 20, 2003 in Los Altos Hills, California, at the age of 80. He was predeceased by his loving and beloved wife of 54 years, Rose Kleiner (2001). He is survived by his children Robert Kleiner and Lisa Kleiner Chanoff, grandchildren Jake Kleiner and Yael, Talia and Eli Chanoff. Eugene was one of the founding fathers of Silicon Valley, a journey that began with the German occupation of his birthplace Vienna in 1938, forcing his family to escape through France, Belgium and Portugal, and finally find passage to the United States where they settled in New York in 1941. At the end of World War II after serving in the United States Army, Eugene took advantage of the GI Bill and earned a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from Polytechnic University, New York, and a Master's of Industrial Engineering from New York University. In 1947 he was married to Rose Wassertheil, who had escaped the German invasion of Poland in 1939. In 1952 his son Robert was born, and four years later the family moved to California after Nobel Prize winner William Shockley recruited Eugene from Western Electric to join him and seven other scientists and engineers to start Shockley Laboratories in Palo Alto. In 1957, these eight men, who became known as the ''Fairchild Eight'', broke away from Shockley and founded Fairchild Semiconductor; the first successful company to manufacture the silicon based transistor. This effort spawned the industry which would eventually transform Santa Clara Valley into the Silicon Valley and was the basis for all of today's information technology. In 1959 his daughter Lisa was born, and two years later the family moved to a new house that they built in Los Altos Hills, in which Eugene and Rose would live for the rest of their lives. In 1962, he left Fairchild to start ventures of his own including Edex Teaching Machines which was bought by Raytheon. As a limited partner with Davis & Rock, and a first round investor in Intel, Eugene began a new interest in venture capital. In 1972 he joined with Tom Perkins to form the partnership now known as Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield and Byers which has spawned over 300 companies including Compaq, Genentech, Tandem Computers, Sun, and Amazon. Since becoming ''Partner Emeritus'' at KPCB, Eugene served on numerous corporate boards, advisory committees, and college boards. In 1989 he received an Honorary Doctorate of Engineering from Polytechnic University where he had served as a Trustee. Eugene was inducted into the Silicon Valley Business Hall of Fame, and in 2000 was named Outstanding Mechanical Engineer of the Century by Polytechnic University. Throughout his career he was a respected mentor and advisor to many. He died in his home that he built 42 years ago on a hill overlooking Silicon Valley. Memorial services will be held at Congregation Beth Am, 26790 Arastradero Rd., Los Altos Hills at 1:00PM, Friday, December 5, 2003. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Polytechnic University, 6 Metrotech Center, Brooklyn, NY 11201, Attn: Richard Thorsen.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ROOSEVELT: GIRL ABDUCTED AND ASSAULTED, POLICE SAY A 12-year-old girl was sexually assaulted Sunday after two men forced her into a black Mercedes, the Nassau County police said. After picking her up on Babylon Turnpike near Independence Avenue about 1:50 p.m., they drove to an isolated wooded area and assaulted her, then released her around 2:10 p.m. She went home and called the police, the police said. At 7:20 p.m., two masked men of the same physical description chased two 15-year-old girls who were walking a dog near East Clinton Avenue and Rose Street, the police said. The girls ran to a nearby house and the men fled.   Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Making A Small Stage Seem to Swell In Dimension
description: Jonathan Riedel attracted considerable attention last year with ''The Unsightful Nanny,'' a dance inspired by the work of Edward Gorey. On Thursday night Mr. Riedel and his new Riedel Dance Theater performed a full evening of his choreography at the Joyce SoHo. Several of the simpler dances were compelling, but the program as a whole seemed overly ambitious.

title: Bush, Fear and F.D.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: B.O.A.T. Publicity, Bratislava, Slovakia, joined the ComVort Group, Barcelona, Spain, an association of independent agencies.

title: Man Charged With Bias Crime for Girl's Killing in Newark
description: A Newark man accused in the stabbing death of a 15-year-old girl, who police said rebuffed his advances by telling him she was gay, was indicted on Monday by the Essex County prosecutor on a charge of murder ''with a purpose to intimidate an individual or group because of sexual orientation.''

title: Revising Report, Army Denies Throats of 2 G.I.'s Were Cut
description: Confusion swirled Monday as a United States military official retracted his earlier report that the throats of two American soldiers had been slashed during an attack on Sunday in the northern city of Mosul.

title: Congress Bows to Veto Threat on Spending Bill
description: President Bush and Senate Republicans on Monday night settled their long-running dispute over media ownership rules, eliminating a major stumbling block to Congressional approval of a $330 billion catch-all spending measure covering a third of all federal programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KYLE, ROBERT B.
description: KYLE--Robert B. Age 73, of Easthampton, NY. Formerly of New York City, on November 23, 2003. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Skidmore), loving father of Katherine Hope Kyle, of Croton-OnHudson, NY, Robert, of Ossining, NY, and Leigh Kyle, of San Diego, CA, and stepfather of Sandra McManus, of Bronxville, NY, and Tylor Tregellas, of New Canaan, CT. Dear brother of Frederick W., of Philadephia, PA, and Betsy Frost, of Saint Helena Island, NC. ALso survived by seven grandchildren, and five step grandchildren, and five nephews and nieces. Memorial donations to Swarthmore College, 500 College Avenue, Swarthmore, PA 19081 or The Retreat, 13 Goodfriend Drive, Easthampton, NY 11937.

title: Time Warner and Bronfman Leave EMI Out in the Cold
description: Time Warner's agreement to sell its music business to Edgar Bronfman Jr. and a group of investors prompted the EMI Group to withdraw its offer for part of the division on Monday, leaving EMI without a partner at a time when industry profits are shrinking and two of its largest competitors plan to join forces.

title: Miscellany
description: FCB HealthCare will close its San Francisco office and move about half of the dozen employees there to its New York headquarters, where the agency's accounts will be consolidated. FCB HealthCare is part of Foote Cone & Belding, a division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: The Delicate Balance Of Pain and Addiction
description: Over the past two decades, conflicting medical ideas have surfaced about narcotic painkillers, the drugs that Rush Limbaugh blames for his addiction while being treated for chronic back pain. And both of them, not surprisingly, have centered on the bottom-line question: just how great a risk of abuse and addiction do narcotics pose to pain patients?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a decision by the Pulitzer Prize Board against revoking the 1932 award to Walter Duranty of The New York Times for articles about the Soviet Union, which were later discredited, referred imprecisely to the scope of a report commissioned by The Times. The paper engaged Prof. Mark von Hagen of Columbia to assess Duranty's work about the Soviet Union in 1931, not just the 13 articles that were entered in the prize competition.

title: Twins and Allergies
description: Q. Are identical twins allergic to the same things?

title: Women's Concerns Push Hotels to Improve Security
description: In a 2002 survey by John Portman & Associates, a hotel-architecture firm in Atlanta, only one of five female executives described security as their most important consideration in choosing a hotel. Yet 75 percent wanted screens in their rooms showing who was outside the door and 84 percent said they would like to have panic buttons on the wall to alert the front desk.

title: Gay Marriage and Our Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Passes Spam Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  The Senate passed a bill today by voice vote to curb junk commercial e-mail, bringing national regulations on spam closer to reality.

title: Have Number, Will Travel Catches On
description: It was supposed to be easy. Beginning in July, French consumers were allowed to keep their mobile phone number even after switching to a new company. But of the 40,000 people who applied to do so in the weeks that followed, only 1,250 had their requests fulfilled by Sept. 26. That is because, under France's interpretation of a European law, consumers must wait at least two months to make the switch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CATANZARO, ROSARIO
description: CATANZARO--Rosario, 80, of Woodcliff Lake, NJ formerly of New Bern, NC on November 23, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Rose (nee Mistretta) (2003). Devoted father of Marisa McDonnell and her husband Gordon of Woodcliff Lake, NJ and Leonard Catanzaro and his wife Stephanie of Little River, South Carolina. Loving grandfather of Russell James and Patrick Catanzaro. Dear brother of Salvatore Catanzaro and the late Sebastian Catanzaro. Funeral service at 11:00 A.M. on Wednesday at Vander Plaat Memorial Home, S113 Farview Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Interment George Washington Memorial Park. Family will receive their friends Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Produce Is Vital. Is It Dangerous?
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran's Nuclear Menace
description: The board of the International Atomic Energy Agency failed to agree last week on how best to deter Iran from developing nuclear weapons. Britain, France and Germany favored a diplomatic approach that would encourage Iran to cooperate with the agency's inspectors while the United States pushed for a crackdown through the United Nations Security Council. Wisely, Washington has now backed down and will let the I.A.E.A. test how far Iran is willing to go. There is a struggle in Iran between those who want to cooperate with inspectors and hard-liners who seek a nuclear capability. It would be foolish to undercut the pragmatists.

title: World Hunger Increasing, New U.N. Report Finds
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 25  The number of hungry people worldwide swelled in recent years, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, thanks to war, drought, AIDS and trade barriers, according to a report released today by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a lecture at the New York Public Library by J. M. Coetzee, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature this year, at one point misspelled the surname of the man for whom the lecture series is named. He is Robert B. Silvers, not Silver.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Teamsters Back Grocery Strikers
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced that it would back supermarket workers in a six-week dispute with three Southern California supermarket chains by refusing to make deliveries to the 859 stores involved. The supermarket workers' union, the United Food and Commercial Workers, said the Teamsters' move, coming in Thanksgiving week, would pressure the three chains, Vons, Ralphs and Albertsons, to make compromises to settle the dispute. On Oct. 11, workers at Vons went on strike, and the next day the two other chains locked out their workers, meaning that 70,000 workers have been sidelined. Previously, the Teamsters made deliveries to the stores but refused to unload them, forcing workers at the supermarkets to do the unloading. Now the Teamsters will not even make deliveries. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: H.I.V. Secrecy Is Proving Deadly
description: With the progress in the medical treatment for H.I.V. over the past decade, unsafe sexual practices have risen and prevention efforts stalled.

title: Death Sentence for Muhammad; Sniper Jury Cites Lack of Sorrow
description: After deliberating for just over five hours, a jury here sentenced John A. Muhammad to death on Monday for directing the Washington-region sniper killings, expressing dismay with what jurors saw as his steely lack of remorse for the attacks last fall that left 10 people dead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HAKIM, TOUBA
description: HAKIM--Touba. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, November 26, 2003 at 6PM at Sephardic Society of Manhattan, Park East Synagogue, 164 E. 68 St, NY, NY. In Los Angeles, CA. on Wednesday, December 3, 2003 at 6PM at Sinai Temple, 10400 Wilshire Blvd, Los Angeles.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 431 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Give More Joy to Your World: Cut Holiday Stress
description: Few people would disagree with the observation that this is the most stressful time of the year for most people, men as well as women. Holiday preparations, planned vacations, gifts to buy and wrap and send, homes and yards to clean and decorate, bothersome relatives you ''must'' spend time with, kids home from school, end-of-the-year deadlines.

title: Plan Gives Farmers a Role in Fighting Global Warming
description: In an unlikely alliance, Kansas Republicans and the advocacy group Environmental Defense are supporting an effort here that seeks to use agriculture as a weapon against global warming.

title: Supersonic Jet Takes Slow Boat to New Home
description: The supersonic jet Concorde came to a halt today as part of a floating museum on a New York river, its last stop after a high-altitude career flying celebrities and other passengers at twice the speed of sound across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Some Members Propose Keeping Iraqi Council After Transition
description: Leaders of the Iraqi Governing Council, just days after vowing to dissolve the body when a new provisional Iraqi government is elected in June, are lobbying to stay in power and serve as a second legislative body, perhaps as a senate.

title: ImClone Drug Gets Fast Track in Canada
description: A Canadian regulatory body will speed up the review of ImClone Systems Inc.'s application to use its Erbitux cancer drug in combination with irinotechan, a chemotherapy drug, to treat colon cancer, ImClone said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRATZ, DONALD
description: GRATZ--Donald, on November 22, after a long battle with Cancer. Beloved husband and helpmate of Roberta. Doting father of Laura and Rebecca. Loving brother of Bill. Loving father-in-law of Jon and Joe. Adoring grandfather of Halina, Frank, Stella and Isaac. The owner and guiding force of Gratz Industries. Donald was the consummate craftsman and so much more. His wit was like a shaft of light. With him around, you never needed to dust off the encyclopedia. He could fix anything. He zipped through the Times crossword puzzle. He shot pool like a shark and he mastered the arts of friendship and love. Funeral will be held Tuesday at 12noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you make a contribution to the Eldridge Street Project, 12 Eldridge Street, NYC 10002, or Dr. David Nanus Research Fund 525 East 68th St. NY NY

title: Coca-Cola Dismisses Universal McCann
description: The Coca-Cola Company delivered a blow to the Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday by dismissing the Universal McCann agency owned by Interpublic from a significant assignment in North America. Coca-Cola consolidated media planning and buying for all soft drink and juice brands in North America, shifting them to a Universal McCann competitor, the Starcom MediaVest Group of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLEBERMAN, MIRIAM RIVKIN
description: GLEBERMAN--Miriam Rivkin, on November 22, 2003, at age 80. Beloved wife of J. Harvey (deceased). Loving mother of Joan, Ellen and Joseph. Grandmother of Matthew, Benjamin, Samantha, Sarah, Margaret and Charles. Also Linda Pyo Cavalier. Sister of Roslyn Attinson and Edith Susskind of Staten Island. Graduate of New York University. Founded J.H. Harvey retail furniture chain together with late husband. One of the first female directors of National Home Furnishing Association and founder, past president and chair of its Interior Design Society. Served on JCC of MidWestchester board. Funeral service Tuesday, November 25, 2003, 1:30 PM, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. For information, Hellman Garlick Memorial Chapels, 1300 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510, 914-762-5501.

title: Ignoring a Forest for the Tree Trimming
description: From an ill-timed lunch to some too-tall trees, the immediate causes of the Aug. 14 blackout were made clear in a report issued last week. But a variety of experts now say the findings were too narrow, ignoring the federal government's role in the recent reshaping of the power industry.

title: Ups and Downs of Newborn Test
description: The expanded medical screening of newborns put into effect by about half the states is catching an increasing number of genetic disorders and making it easier to prevent their most severe consequences, according to a study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Final Splash For Publicist
description: Few stories are more American than that of Eleanor Lambert, a circus advance man's daughter from Crawfordsville, Ind., who headed east to New York as soon as she could to reinvent herself doing advance for a different kind of circus, the world of fashion.

title: Judge Censured for Free Work by Accountant
description: A Manhattan judge has been censured by state authorities for letting her personal accountant prepare her taxes without pay during a period when she gave the accountant court-appointed jobs worth more than $21,000.

title: Big Step in Conductivity: More Sociable Particles
description: Eight years after physicists coaxed ultracold atoms into a new type of matter in which thousands of atoms slide into the perfect lock step behavior of a single superparticle, two research teams have now repeated the feat using small molecules.

title: Accounts
description: Pep Boys, Philadelphia, the automotive products and services retailer, dismissed its agency of nearly two years, the Richards Group, Dallas, and will handle its account internally. Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: The Need for Proxies
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Talking of Arson As Fire Toll Climbs to 36
description: The death toll climbed to 36 on Monday in an early-morning fire that raged through a five-story dormitory full of African and Asian students. The police said they were investigating the possibility of arson.

title: A Merger Maker Who Learned to Think Small
description: IF Roger C. Altman went in for that sort of thing, the soft putty of his life story would conform easily to the well-worn grooves of the self-adulatory business tycoon autobiography. Left fatherless at age 10 and raised by his librarian mother, he paid his way through college and business school, made a pile of money with financial derring-do and went on to serve two presidents a decade apart.

title: Promotion at Times Co.
description: R. Anthony Benten, treasurer of the New York Times Company, has been promoted to the additional corporate position of vice president. The appointment was announced yesterday by Leonard P. Forman, senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Michael Jackson Spectacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Lautenberg Voices His Opposition To Bear Hunt as the Debate Grows
description: With New Jersey's first bear hunt since 1970 scheduled to start in two weeks, the war of words between critics and advocates of the hunt mounted yesterday, and Senator Frank R. Lautenberg added his voice to those with misgivings.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Calgary; A Bit of the Wild West (but Farther North) and a Skyline to Boot
description: Calgary, Canada's energy and beef capital, is one of the country's fastest-growing cities -- with traffic congestion to match. But the benefits of surging oil and gas prices have been diluted by a slump in the cattle industry since the United States and other countries banned the import of Canadian beef in May after the discovery of a case of mad cow disease on a ranch in northern Alberta. An economic development commission, set up late last year, is looking for ways to diversify Calgary's economy by attracting more investment in areas like health care, tourism and filmmaking.

title: Mourning's Dedication Won Him Admiration
description: When Alonzo Mourning came to the bench midway through the fourth quarter Saturday afternoon, Nets Coach Byron Scott watched him carefully, noticing that the fatigue was worse than usual. With the game against Toronto in the balance, Scott could not help thinking about something more.

title: Banking Regulators Shut Down Security Trust Company
description: The mutual fund scandal claimed its first corporate casualty today, as banking regulators ordered the shutdown of the Security Trust Company, a key intermediary in the processing of mutual fund trades by pension plans.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Roosevelt: Girl Abducted And Assaulted, Police Say
description: A 12-year-old girl was sexually assaulted Sunday after two men forced her into a black Mercedes, the Nassau County police said. After picking her up on Babylon Turnpike near Independence Avenue about 1:50 p.m., they drove to an isolated wooded area and assaulted her, then released her around 2:10 p.m. She went home and called the police, the police said. At 7:20 p.m., two masked men of the same physical description chased two 15-year-old girls who were walking a dog near East Clinton Avenue and Rose Street, the police said. The girls ran to a nearby house and the men fled. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A Congressional Memo article on Saturday about a frenzy of last-minute legislative activity misstated the number of votes needed in the Senate to cut off a filibuster. It is 60 -- that is, three-fifths of the Senate, not two-thirds.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about preparations by New York Democrats for the presidential primary election referred imprecisely to the method of selecting state delegates to the national convention. Voters will choose both delegates and a presidential candidate, not just delegates. The results will be combined in a formula to select the delegates.

title: Surgery on Conjoined Twins Is Step Toward Separation
description: Clarence and Carl Aguirre, 19-month-old Filipino twins joined at the head, underwent a five-and-a-half-hour operation yesterday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, the second in a series of procedures expected to separate them.

title: Mayor on the Fly, Covering Lots of Ground
description: Monday morning found Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg blessing the bread in a Jerusalem synagogue beneath stained-glass windows by Chagall. Evening found him here, dancing the valle, a circle dance, with folkloric dancers in red headdresses at the Albanian National Theater.

title: Father of Sniper Suspect Testifies for Son's Defense
description: On the day the man he once considered his father was sentenced to die, Lee Malvo, 18, watched his biological father appear as the first witness on his behalf.

title: Mourning Forced To End Comeback
description: Alonzo Mourning, who developed a trademark for toughness, is saying a forced goodbye to the Nets and professional basketball because his chronic kidney disease had rapidly worsened to the point where he was in danger of suffering cardiac arrest and dying on the court, his doctor said yesterday.

title: Examining a Kaleidoscope Of Sound, All From Vienna
description: A limited space can contain an infinite variety of information. For the pianist Mitsuko Uchida the space is Vienna: the works of Schubert, Berg, Webern. And the information is a kaleidoscopic wealth of colors and sounds that were brilliantly illuminated in two concerts of Ms. Uchida's Perspectives series, subtitled Vienna Revisited, at Zankel Hall, the first on Nov. 17 and the latest on Friday night.

title: U.N. Report Calls Efforts Against AIDS Entirely Inadequate
description: While the pace of the battle against AIDS is picking up, current efforts to stem the epidemic are "entirely inadequate" for the health emergency that is "continuing to spiral out of control," the director of the United Nations AIDS program said today.

title: Lynn Tries to Become the Coach at Arizona
description: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 24  Having an 18-year-old son leaving home to play college football reminded the Giants' defensive coordinator, Johnnie Lynn, what being a college coach is all about. As he gets ready to send his son Chazz off to play at Rutgers next year, Lynn thinks about leaving for college again, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Sylvia. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Sylvia Goldstein, beloved mother of Burton Goldstein. We extend our condolences to Burton and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Produce Is Vital. Is It Dangerous?
description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing Dismisses 2 In Hiring of Official Who Left Pentagon
description: The Boeing Company dismissed its chief financial officer and a vice president yesterday for what it called ethical misconduct in the hiring of the vice president, a former Pentagon official who had been involved in contract negotiations with the company.

title: What's Your Phone Number?
description: Those 10 digits really do belong to you now, if you want them. As of yesterday, consumers are entitled to take their phone number with them when they switch wireless carriers, and to cut the cord at home and transfer the number onto a cellphone within the same service area.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Chile: Economy Gains 3% In Quarter
description: Chile, which has an economy that is growing at twice the average rate in Latin America, said the expansion quickened in the third quarter as sales of copper, its top export, climbed on stronger demand from China. Gross domestic product grew 3 percent, the central bank said, compared with 2.7 percent in the second quarter and 3.5 percent in the first quarter. Growth is expected to quicken through next year because of higher production and sales of copper, and as trade accords with the United States and the European Union bolster demand for Chile's goods.

title: Using Force Intelligently
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRBY, WILLIAM J.
description: KIRBY--William J., 78, November 22, Forest Hills, NY. Retired partner Sullivan & Cromwell. Survived by wife of 49 years, Ann Pfohl Kirby, children Dr. Mathis Powelson, Richmond, VA, William Jr., Brookline, MA, Andrew, Greenwich, CT, Brian, Newtown Square, PA, Peter, Tokyo, Paula McWhinnie, London, and Julia Vien, Brookline, MA, their spouses, 16 grandchildren and three sisters. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 70-01 Kessel St, Forest Hills, at 10:30 AM, Tuesday. Interment Lakeview Cemetery, Essex, NY, Wednesday. Donations to Harvard College, Harvard Law School or St. Mathias Educational Foundation Inc, 58-15 Catalpa Ave, Ridgewood, NY 11385.

title: Drug Makers Move Closer To Big Victory
description: As Congress edged closer to passing a Medicare drug benefit that prohibits the government from using its buying clout to win discounts, one thing was clear: the drug industry appeared on the cusp of an enormous victory, gained in part by millions in political donations and an expensive lobbying campaign.

title: Bronx Subway Stop Reopens to Sighs of Relief
description: Three long months ended yesterday on 174th Street in the Bronx.

title: Difficult Times for Coffee Industry
description: Surrounded by coffee-lovers from as far afield as Baltimore and Bulgaria, the coffee farmer Luiz Norberto Paschoal removes the frothy top off one last cup of espresso with a theatrical slurp. Savoring the taste and aroma for just a few seconds, he then expels the liquid in a thick brown jet into a bucket at his feet.

title: The Befuddled Respond To the Hotel Irritants' List
description: IN last week's column, I ridiculed those tragically hip boutique hotels where, I said, the employees dress like the Manson family. I heard from Manson family groupies, but also from more thoughtful readers like Michael van Eckhardt.

title: Lawyer for Church Says He Hid His Own Sexual Abuse by Priest
description: For five years, Robert P. Scamardo defended the Roman Catholic Diocese of Galveston-Houston against lawsuits by people who claimed to have been sexually abused by priests.

title: Rushing, With Dignity, for the Exit
description: However badly Eduard Shevardnadze ruled his mountain republic of Georgia, and however tardy his departure, he left with stature intact as one of the great statesmen in the ending of the cold war. Like Mikhail Gorbachev, his comrade in that saga, Mr. Shevardnadze recognized -- just in time -- that hanging on would only lead to violence. The Georgian opposition is equally wise to pledge that he will retire with respect so his forced exit is perceived as a legitimate transfer of power.

title: Weak at Box Office, 'Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks' Closes
description: ''Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks,'' the two-person comedy starring Mark Hamill and Polly Bergen, has become the latest Broadway show to close prematurely, surviving just four weeks. A producer said yesterday that the play's Sunday performance was its last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERMAN, NATHAN
description: SHERMAN--Nathan. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., mourns the passing of Nathan Sherman, beloved husband of Lydia, cherished father of Shelley Sherman and David Diamond. Nathan was a generous benfactor of Hadassah, devoted to Israel and the Jewish people. His legacy will live on through the projects he supported at the Hadassah Medical Organization. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. June Walker, National President

title: Vow to Rebuild Burned Holocaust Museum
description: An Auschwitz survivor has vowed to rebuild a Holocaust museum here that was destroyed by a suspicious fire early last Tuesday.

title: If Nothing Else, Bucs Are Always Believers
description: Using a college football analogy, Tampa Bay defensive tackle Warren Sapp says that until the Bowl Championship Series computer rejects the Buccaneers as a playoff hopeful, he is going to continue to believe it is possible.

title: Redrawn Districts Examined in Federal Trial
description: Senate District 34 in the Bronx has a notoriously odd shape, likened to that of a squashed doughnut. But is its figure unconstitutional, the result of gerrymandering designed to limit the voting strength of blacks and Hispanics?

title: Black Seminoles' Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Loses Tylenol Account
description: Days after Saatchi & Saatchi in New York lost its longtime assignment to create campaigns for Tylenol products, the Johnson & Johnson division that sells Tylenol dismissed the agency from its remaining creative assignments, for the Mylanta, Pepcid and St. Joseph brands. Total billings on those brands were estimated at $75 million.

title: 3 Teenage Boys Stabbed in Fight With Group of Youths on West Side
description: Three 16-year-old boys were stabbed yesterday afternoon during a melee that erupted outside Lincoln Center shortly after school let out at nearby Martin Luther King High School, the police said.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Young Man Gets a Future and His Mother Gets Rest
description: When he was a freshman at William E. Grady Vocational High School in Coney Island, James Manas rose at 6 a.m. to get ready and take a bus and a subway to make his first class at 8:30. The length of the trip did not bother him, but what did was the fear of what he might encounter along the way.

title: UNISOURCE AGREES TO $3 BILLION BUYOUT BY INVESTORS
description: The UniSource Energy Corporation, the owner of Tucson Electric Power, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a group of investors led by Frederick B. Rentschler, the former chief executive of the Beatrice Companies, for $3 billion in cash and assumed debt. The Saguaro Utility Group, which is managed by the Sage Mountain group controlled by Mr. Rentschler, has agreed to pay $25.25 a share, UniSource said in a statement. The offer values UniSource at approximately $850 million. Investors in Saguaro include funds run by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, J.P. Morgan Partners and Wachovia Capital Partners. Shares of UniSource, which is based in Tucson, surged $5.09, or 26 percent, to $24.49.

title: In Journalism, Only the Good Die Poor
description: LET'S start with a snap quiz.

title: Changes Announced For Herald Tribune
description: The New York Times Company announced a series of changes at The International Herald Tribune yesterday intended to strengthen the newspaper financially and journalistically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LONDON, EVELYN
description: LONDON--Evelyn, 52, died on November 24, 2003, in Weymouth, MA of renal failure. Daughter of Herbert London & Margery G. Kahn, sister of Susan London-Payne, sisterin-law of Michael Payne, and aunt of Kate Payne. Funeral services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONSON, HOWARD C.
description: BRONSON--Howard C. On November 21, 2003, at age 77. Beloved husband of Clara Bronson. Loving father of Valerie Bronson and stepfather of Louis Wirtz and his wife Diane Wirtz. Dear brother of Mickey Bronson. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday November 25th, 3 pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Lung Association of NY, Inc., 432 Park Ave South, 8th Floor, NY, NY 10016.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Charged In Triple Homicide
description: Prosecutors filed murder charges yesterday against a 36-year-old woman in connection with the killings of three family members in their home in Cambria Heights in June. The woman, Sandra Powell of Far Rockaway, was arrested on Friday and is accused of working with an unidentified attacker who shot and killed all three victims, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. The victims, Larie Barnes, 39; his wife, Carren Chambers, 34; and her sister, Tisha Chambers, 21, were all found shot in the head on June 9. Law enforcement officials have said that Ms. Powell and her male accomplice, who has not been arrested, were looking for drugs but did not find any. Ms. Powell was arraigned on Sunday in Queens County Criminal Court before Judge Seth L. Marvin, who ordered her held without bail. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Like 'Gladiator,' But With Couture
description: Though social anthropologists have failed to take note of the phenomenon, the weeks leading up to the end of the year provide men with a nearly unmatched occasion to understand the opposite sex. In late November and December, many women submit themselves to the Darwinian consumer experience known as the sample sale. It is here that a woman outwardly reticent and contained might reveal herself to be as pitbullish as a Marge Schott, the former owner of the Cincinnati Reds, when in close proximity to a pair of tweed culottes at 96 percent off and three dozen other women determined to own them.

title: INSIDE
description: G.I.'s Were Shot to Death

title: Japan and Russia Turn to Nature To Bridge Vast Chasm in the Sea
description: Cranes, eagles and puffins have no trouble crossing a 20-mile-wide finger of the Sea of Okhotsk that separates two national parks, one Russian and one Japanese. But the channel has long been a scary barrier for humans.

title: Hidden Arsenic in Older Play Sets
description: The Janak family's outdoor deck was looking more than a little worn two years ago, so they decided to sand and stain it. What the couple did not know was that sanding the pressure-treated lumber was not just creating sawdust, but also scattering particles of arsenic in the air.

title: Car Seizures In Nassau Are Stopped By State Court
description: A law that allows Nassau County to seize and sell drunken drivers' cars was struck down on Monday by the state's highest court, a ruling that now forces the county to give back 1,400 cars that have been sitting on impound lots.

title: Craving More Than Just Sugar?
description: College students whose fathers were alcoholics showed an unusually strong preference for sugary tastes, a new study says, suggesting that an extreme sweet tooth may be added to the list of risk factors for drinking problems.

title: Swiss to Announce Race Site
description: Tomorrow morning in a Geneva hotel, the sailing world will find out which southern European city will be host to Team Alinghi's party in 2007. Alinghi won the America's Cup nine months ago, overwhelming Team New Zealand in its own waters off Auckland, but the only home waters the Swiss-based winners possess are lakes, rivers and streams.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It would take a great leap of faith to think justice wasn't served today.''

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: 2 Charged In School Murder Plot
description: Two 16-year-olds, a boy and girl, were charged with conspiracy to commit capital murder and aggravated assault in what the police described as a plot against classmates and administrators at Vidor High School, 80 miles northeast of Houston. The two have been held in juvenile detention centers since Nov. 10, when school officials said they uncovered a plot to kill up to 24 people. Three other students were expelled. District attorneys said they had not decided whether to prosecute the two defendants as juveniles or adults. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Nexstar Joins Crowd of Initial Offerings
description: Nexstar Broadcasting Group raised $140 million in an initial public offering yesterday, the busiest day for initial public offerings in the United States in more than three years, with seven companies scheduled to sell shares to investors.

title: Philip Morris Wins Tobacco Death Suit
description: Philip Morris USA, the nation's largest cigarette maker, was cleared yesterday by a New Hampshire jury in a lawsuit by the widow of a longtime smoker of the company's Marlboro brand.

title: End-of-Life Decisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Barriers Toppling for Disabled Medical Students
description: As a fourth-year medical student, Jeffrey Lawler listens -- really listens -- as his patients run through their lists of physical complaints.

title: One Broken Deal After Another
description: EMI has been trying for years to merge with or acquire a major record company. Each time a deal seemed close, something went wrong, including last weekend when it lost out in the bidding for Warner Music. Analysts are questioning whether EMI is big enough to compete on its own.

title: Dead Man Walking
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pace of Ferry Crash Inquiry Angers Members of Council
description: Frustration that the cause of last month's fatal Staten Island ferry crash remains unexplained boiled over at a City Council hearing yesterday, as some council members complained that city and federal officials were keeping the public in the dark.

title: Interim Leaders in Georgia Back Presidential Candidate
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Nov. 26  The young and passionate leader of Georgia's popular revolt became the front-runner for the presidency today when the opposition united behind him as its sole candidate.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: California Twist: A Chocolate Cloak On Crystallized Ginger
description: In Colonial times, crystallized ginger was often served at the end of a dinner to aid digestion. It is an idea worth a modern twist, one provided by Scharffen Berger, the chocolate maker in Berkeley, Calif. The company dips crystallized ginger in unsweetened chocolate, which is used mostly in baking but becomes a marvelous foil for the spicy-sweet ginger. A box of 16 pieces of chocolate-dipped ginger is about $12 at Adriana's Caravan in the Grand Central Market in Grand Central Terminal, at Zabar's, at www.scharffenberger.com and at Citarella stores.

title: You Better Watch Out
description: According to legend, New York lore and two major Hollywood flicks, Macy's Santa is the real deal. And tomorrow, to the delight of millions of little children (not to mention the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court), the Santa in New York's great parade will be half of a same-sex couple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRICE, THOMAS E.
description: PRICE--Thomas E. Age 82, died November 23 in Cincinnati. Lifelong resident of Cincinnati. Business executive and tennis enthusiast. Graduate of the University of Texas, where he was a star of the tennis and basketball teams in the early '40s. Served as a lieutenant in the US Army Air Corps during World War II. Captain-Coach of the Junior Davis Cup Team in the postwar period where many tennis stars were developed, including Tony Trabert, Arthur Ashe, Clark Graebner, etc. Former President of the Cincinnati Tennis Club. Widely known as an official and umpire at countless tennis matches. The annual Cincinnati metropolitan tennis championships were named in his honor since 1991. Mr. Price was a member of the founding family of the Werk Soap Company. He is survived by his daughter Elizabeth Price of Chicago, his brother Edwin of Cincinnati, and his longstanding friend and companion Helen Dennis of Cincinnati. Contributions in his honor gratefully accepted at Greater Cincinnati Tennis Association, PO Box 42365, Cincinnati, OH 45242. Checks may be made to GCTA Thomas E. Price-Tennis Development Program.

title: A Badge, As License To Break The Law
description: There are no crusading moralists to clean up the mess in ''El Bonaerense,'' Pablo Trapero's grim, dispassionate drama of police corruption, set mostly in contemporary Buenos Aires. This powerful sweat-stained swatch of Argentine neo-realism, filmed in harsh high contrast that throws its characters' faces into deep shadow, follows the initiation of Zapa (Jorge Romn), a nave police recruit, into a labyrinth of sleaze.

title: Results Hint of a Turnaround for Japan's Banks
description: In a sign that Japan's biggest banks may have turned a corner, all four of the largest banking groups have returned to the black in the first half of their fiscal year, after posting record losses last year.

title: Roh vetoes bill, enraging opposition in Seoul
description: SEOUL:  President Roh Moo Hyun, who has already rattled domestic politics through his maverick style of leadership, set the stage Tuesday for heightened tension with South Korea's powerful opposition party.

title: Taking Beethoven's Cue, Even at His Wildest
description: If there are weaknesses in Mitsuko Uchida's repertory, they have not been apparent. She has moved easily through an expanding circle of specialties that has included Mozart and Schubert, with briefer stops to explore Schoenberg and Chopin, and when she has moved beyond her established specialties, the results have been so consistently illuminating that listeners unfamiliar with her ideas about a particular composer or work are likely to trust her.

title: Sniper Suspect's Life Recalled in Testimony
description: In a judicial version of the old television show ''This Is Your Life,'' Lee Malvo watched as a dozen witnesses described his first 17 years, from his boyhood in Jamaica to the months preceding the sniper attacks in the Washington area last fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, MARSHA
description: STEVENS--Marsha, died November 25, 2003. It is with inexpressible sadness we announce the sudden passing of the sweet, loving and vivacious woman with the warmest smile around, whose biggest joy in life was her family. Devoted wife of the late Henry P. Stevens, Marsha is survived by her loving children, Dr. Jeffrey Stevens of Aventura, FL, Mallory Stevens of New York City; daughter-inlaw Nancy Stevens and grandchildren Lilli and Harrison. Marsha was also the proud daughter of the late Rabbi Jacob Dubrow, founding rabbi of Kesher Israel Congregation in Washington, D.C. Funeral services today at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave/76th St in Manhattan at 11:45AM.

title: T-MOBILE USA IN ACCORD TO END OVERTIME SUIT
description: The T-Mobile USA unit of Deutsche Telekom agreed to pay $4.78 million to settle a suit accusing it of violating labor laws on overtime pay, the Labor Department said yesterday. The settlement averages about $233 an employee and covers three years of back pay for 20,546 workers at 13 customer call centers. T-Mobile, a wireless-telephone carrier based in Bellevue, Wash., did not admit liability in the agreement, filed with the United States District Court in Seattle, and in a statement denied any wrongdoing. The court must approve the settlement. An investigation at three call centers found the company did not pay employees for ''preparatory activities'' before shifts began, the department said. T-Mobile must pay the back wages by Feb. 22, according to the court filing.

title: Red, Intense and Consistently Impressive
description: SOMETIMES in our fascination with high-status wines from around the world we forget about regions that have not flocked to internationally popular grapes like cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay, merlot and pinot noir.

title: A Failed Energy Bill: What Went Wrong?
description: Lawmakers and lobbyists said the energy bill fizzled in the last days of Congress because it had too many benefits for industry, cost too much, was written without enough Democratic help and was overshadowed by the Medicare bill.

title: Accounts
description: The Coca-Cola Company, Atlanta, to the Shanghai office of the Starcom MediaVest Group, part of the Publicis Groupe, to handle media planning and buying in China. The assignment, with billings estimated at $30 million, had been handled by a Publicis sibling, ZenithOptimedia. The shift came after Coca-Cola consolidated media planning and buying for North American brands.

title: Harold Schonberg Memorial
description: A memorial service for Harold C. Schonberg, the longtime chief music critic of The New York Times, will be held at 5 p.m. next Wednesday at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Schonberg died on July 26 at 87.

title: Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
description: America's whole immigration policy is currently such a mess that communities are forced to try to regulate an irrational status quo. A perfect example is the current controversy over whether an illegal immigrant should have a driver's license. Obviously on one level it makes no sense for the government to be issuing documents -- documents that are frequently used as identification cards -- to people who should in theory be deported. But right now there are an estimated seven million people in the country illegally. Our law enforcement officials are not making any serious effort to find them, and our political leaders are not making any serious effort to come up with a system that would expand their ability to work here legally. So it is no wonder that many experts support the driver's license idea as a simple matter of highway safety.

title: Genentech's Cancer Drug Falls Short in a Second Round of Tests
description: Biotechnology's next potential star product has lost a bit of its glow.

title: Evidence Against Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, EUGENE
description: KLEINER -- Eugene. The Board of Directors, President Robert N. Butler, M.D., and the staff of the International Longevity Center -- U.S.A. mourn the loss of Eugene Kleiner. Lovingly remembered and admired. We extend our condolences and sympathy to the entire family upon its loss.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column yesterday about the brief life of the Steve Getz Music Hall in Brooklyn misstated its opening and closing dates. They were Oct. 17 and Nov. 17, not Sept. 17 and Oct. 17.

title: Offspring of Great Men, United Only in Disability
description: 'Our Fathers'

title: A Woman's Work? Don't Tell That to This Kindergarten Teacher
description: At Dennis Elementary School, Jill Davis has white ruffled curtains on the door of her classroom. It is just the sort of homey, feminine touch people expect from a kindergarten teacher.

title: Calendar
description: Smorgasbords Here and There

title: Blending Italy In a Pan
description: THREE classic flavors are often overlooked these days, so much so that when I prepared a dish combining them not long ago, I seemed to be tasting it for the first time. This combo is garlic, anchovies and capers, a natural southern Mediterranean team that is strong and distinctive.

title: INVENTION FOR 900 HANDS: 'Our Core Business'; At Steinway, It's Hammer Time
description: As grand piano No. K0862 was being wheeled from workbench to workbench at the Steinway & Sons factory in Queens in late September, the workers had two schedules in mind: the one that they did not talk about much, and the one that had them buzzing.

title: Mets Give Castillo Offer; Lee Traded by Marlins
description: The Florida Marlins lost one member of their World Series championship team yesterday, trading first baseman Derrek Lee to the Cubs to avoid paying him a raise in arbitration and receiving Hee Seop Choi and a minor leaguer in return. They may be days away from losing another.

title: Westchester Wins Fight for Reduced Electricity Bills, at New York City's Expense
description: The Public Service Commission agreed on Tuesday to reduce the rates residents of Westchester County pay for electricity, ending a three-year battle between local officials and the state commission that sets electricity rates.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: President Vetoes Inquiry
description: President Roh Moo Hyun vetoed a bill passed by the National Assembly that called for an independent counsel to handle an investigation into allegations of corruption involving former aides. Opposition lawmakers in turn staged a sit-in protest and vowed to refrain from parliamentary affairs. The head of the main opposition party, the Grand National Party, which controls a majority of the seats in the legislature, said he would begin a hunger strike today.

title: For '04 Cash, Edwards Will Show Up at Door, in Hardcover
description: When John Edwards, the Democratic senator from North Carolina, came out with a campaign autobiography to promote his presidential candidacy, he was following a long tradition.

title: Arroyo rejects calls to lift moratorium on death penalty
description: MANILA:  President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo on Tuesday rejected calls for the reimposition of the death penalty, saying it had not been proved to deter crime in the Philippines.

title: Southern Treats, by Way of Bedford-Stuyvesant
description: Shakoor and Marissa Watson, below, who own Shakoor's Sweet Tooth, 555 Throop Avenue (Halsey Street), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, have baked plenty of sweet potato cheesecakes (below right) and sweet potato pies, their signature desserts, for those who might be caught short for Thanksgiving. They are open today from noon to 6 p.m., but are closed on Thursday.

title: BERKSHIRE ACQUIRES A 2ND MOBILE HOME MAKER
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. agreed to buy the Oakwood Homes Corporation out of bankruptcy for $373 million yesterday and combine it with Clayton Homes Inc. to create the nation's biggest mobile home maker. Berkshire is controlled by Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor. Mr. Buffett, who bought Clayton Homes two months ago for $1.7 billion, had contributed to a $215 million program to finance Oakwood, which is based in Greensboro, N.C., during bankruptcy proceedings. The purchase signaled a shift in Mr. Buffett's thinking about Oakwood. In a July statement, Mr. Buffett said that Berkshire's purchase of Oakwood debt was a ''bad investment'' and that Berkshire ''learned the hard way of the dangers in mobile home finance.''

title: Dozens Offer A Kidney To Mourning
description: Alonzo Mourning's intensity on the basketball court has earned him fame and fortune, and now it may enhance his chances of receiving a new kidney. Since Monday's announcement that he is in need of a kidney transplant and must end his N.B.A. comeback with the Nets, dozens of people across the nation have offered to serve as his donor.

title: Carefully Plotted Noise as a Tool, Not Chaos
description: Noise was a disturbance and a catalyst when Broadcast and Manitoba shared a bill at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night. Without it, Broadcast might have been a cool-headed lounge band, and Manitoba could have been relentlessly bubbly and cloying. But blasts of distorted guitar, off-tuned analog keyboards and barreling drums made each band's music bristle as much as it soothed.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: CHILD ABUSE LINKED TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE At least one-third of all child-abuse cases in New Jersey involve a parent or care giver with a drug or alcohol problem, yet the state's child welfare employees receive no organized training in how to recognize or cope with families affected by substance abuse, according to a study released yesterday. A review of the Division of Youth and Family Services, part of a court settlement between the state and a child advocacy group, also found that case workers were ill-prepared to respond to families in which domestic violence accompanies child abuse. The study made 10 recommendations to improve the training of child welfare workers and to help the state's various social-service agencies work together more effectively. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAMMANO, SUZANNE (NEE PISTILLI)
description: MAMMANO--Suzanne (nee Pistilli). 61, on November 22, 2003 while traveling in Tibet. Beloved sister of Audrey Grieco; loving aunt of Regina, Matthew, Eric, Kevin, Craig and David; sister-in-law of Anthony, Marcia, Howard and Donald. Visiting hours, Friday, November 28, 6 to 9PM at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 Street. Mass of Christian Burial 11AM on Saturday, November 29 at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82 Street, New York, NY 10028

title: Chaplain Held in Espionage Case Is Freed
description: The military said on Tuesday that it was releasing Capt. James J. Yee, the former Muslim chaplain at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, after confining him for nearly three months on suspicion of espionage activities.

title: U.S. Adds to Detained Australians' Rights
description: The Australian government and the Bush administration said on Tuesday that they had reached a final agreement to let military commissions bring terrorism or war crimes charges against two Australians detained at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: To the Polls
description: Voters will select their representatives for the province's legislature today for the first time since 1998, when a landmark peace accord established a local government to share power between Protestant and Roman Catholic parties. The 108-seat assembly has been suspended for a year. Opinion polls have shown no clear front-runners on either side of sectarian divide, but the balance of power is expected to shift away from mainstream and moderate parties. More than 2,000 extra police officers are being deployed at polling places. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Electronics and Athletics Transform an Ancient Epic
description: 'Ramayana 2K3'

title: Preparing for the Feast? Read This First (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Teddy Randazzo, 68; Wrote Hundreds Of Popular Songs
description: Teddy Randazzo, who with Bobby Weinstein and others wrote hundreds of popular songs like ''Goin' Out of My Head'' and ''It's Gonna Take a Miracle,'' died on Friday at his home in Orlando. He was 68.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HAKIM, TOUBA
description: HAKIM--Touba. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, November 26, 2003 at 6PM at Sephardic Society of Manhattan, Park East Synagogue, 164 E. 68 St, NY, NY. In Los Angeles, CA. on Wednesday, December 3, 2003 at 6PM at Sinai Temple, 10400 Wilshire Blvd, Los Angeles.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Trade-Clearing Fees To Drop
description: The London Stock Exchange said Monday that fees to clear trades would drop 25 percent in January because of a new agreement with London Clearing House, the company that clears all of the exchange's trades. The exchange and clearinghouse have been in negotiations for months over fees, after Eurex, a subsidiary of Deutsche Boerse of Germany, offered to handle the London exchange's trades for less. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Stake In Hyundai Units
description: Prudential Financial said it had reached an agreement with the South Korean government to buy 80 percent of two Hyundai Group money-management units and become the nation's biggest foreign-controlled asset manager. Prudential originally said in March that it would pay 500 billion won ($415 million) for Hyundai Investment and Securities and its wholly owned unit, Hyundai Investment Trust Management. The announcement, which did not include the price, came as the government agreed to repay about $2 billion of debt at the two companies.

title: H&R BLOCK POSTS ITS FIRST PROFIT IN A 2ND QUARTER
description: H&R Block Inc., the tax preparation company, earned a second-quarter profit for the first time in its history after income from mortgage lending jumped 20 percent. Its shares rallied in after-hours trading to close at $51.05, up $1.65. Net income was $10.4 million, or 6 cents a share for the quarter that ended Oct. 31, in contrast to a loss of $37.3 million, or 21 cents, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had expected a 6-cent loss. H&R Block, which typically earns most of its profit in the three months ahead of the April 15 tax day, had never made a second-quarter profit in its 41-year history as a public company. It has focused on mortgages to provide year-round income.

title: Family Stuffing, Forged by Fire
description: WHEN I was a child, Thanksgiving brought with it a sudden awareness of relatives -- in our case absent relatives. Separated by thousands of miles from the Family, with its ever expanding and incomprehensible family tree and universal Mesa, Ariz., address, my brothers and sister and I always felt very left out.

title: This Santa Sobers Up, But Only For Greed
description: Somebody needed to make a comedy out of all the holiday season hostility that goes up this time of year along with the decorations, and the light-fingered director Terry Zwigoff and the screenwriters Glenn Ficarra and John Requa are just the guys for the task. Their new film, ''Bad Santa,'' takes all the Christmas season's bad vibes and converts them into an achingly funny and corrupt dark comedy.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Diebold Decides Not To Sue Over Internet Postings
description: Diebold Election Systems, which makes electronic voting machines, told a federal court in California in a filing that was made public yesterday that it would not sue people who had posted thousands of the company's internal e-mail messages to Web sites. The company had sent dozens of cease-and-desist letters to college students, Internet service providers and others who had posted its communications on the Internet to show that its voting system was flawed. ''We're not filing suit for copyright infringement,'' a Diebold spokesman, David Bear, said. He added that Diebold would try to settle a lawsuit by the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a high-tech civil liberties group, on behalf of two Swarthmore students and an Internet service provider. Judge Jeremy Fogel will hold a hearing on Monday in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., to consider the case in light of Diebold's statement. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Gold Rush May Continue, but With Tempered Expectations
description: Gold does not have to break $400 an ounce to prove that it is in a bull market. That has been clear for some time, as the price has surged 52 percent since gold hit bottom in April of 2001.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Next Time, Get a Box With Cable

title: A Garden Of Eden Where Luxury Is No Sin
description: A DINING table is a compact cosmos, as densely crossed with vectors of meaning as an astronomer's map of the sky. To set a table is to engage customs with origins as old as human habit, and with histories whose implications are almost as profound as the act of being fed. It is also a great pleasure, if you happen to be me.

title: Modesty Becomes A Songwriter
description: John Mayer got a pop star's welcome when he walked onstage for his sold-out concert at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. Hundreds of cameras flashed, and thousands of teenage girls squealed. They went on to sing along with every verse of every song. And for his adoring fans, Mr. Mayer had one request: ''You don't mind if I play a little guitar, do you?'' At a time when countless musicians wish they were pop stars, Mr. Mayer is a pop star aspiring to be a musician.

title: Russia Lists Charges in Oil Tycoon Case
description: Russian prosecutors said Tuesday that they had concluded a criminal fraud investigation of the imprisoned industrialist Mikhail Khodorkovsky, setting the stage for a trial.

title: A 9/11 Memorial For the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS--Sidney. Your love, laughter & caring are beside us always. Zenith and the family

title: Patented AIDS Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Haddonfield: Pursuit Ends In Fatal Crash
description: A driver who sped up to evade traffic officers crashed into another vehicle, killing himself and the other driver yesterday, the authorities said. Officers pursued the man, whom they identified as Gregory Ganski, 27, of Williamstown, N.J., in a chase that lasted for about five minutes, said William Shralow, the spokesman for the Camden County prosecutor's office. Mr. Ganski sped along Interstate 295, exited the highway, and crashed in Haddonfield, N.J., hitting Thomas R. Fitzgerald, 58, of Magnolia, in his car and killing him, Mr. Shralow said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAREL, EZRA
description: HAREL--Ezra. On November 24, 2003, at sea, age 53. Dearly beloved husband of Adina, loving father Naama, Lavi and Lee, and father-in-law of Eyal. Devoted brother of Boaz Harel, and Irit Denai. A more devoted father and husband did not exist. Burial later this week in Israel. He is gone but will always remain with us.

title: Arnold Creative Officer Leaves New York Office
description: In another sign of turmoil at Arnold Worldwide, Rochelle Klein, who has served for the last three years as vice chairwoman and chief creative officer at the agency's New York office, is leaving unexpectedly.

title: Holiday Tomorrow -- Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Met Opera Says Hiatus Will Help With Slump
description: The Metropolitan Opera's decision to take a midseason hiatus in January 2005 -- the only interruption in its 120-year history -- has been planned for three years, Joseph Volpe, the general manager, said yesterday. But he conceded that a break during a slow time of the year -- which was revealed Monday -- will be helpful, given the slump in tourism and in contributions to arts groups since Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Asterisk Settles Dewey Suit
description: The Library Hotel, whose rooms are numbered according to the Dewey decimal system, has settled a trademark-infringement lawsuit brought by the nonprofit library cooperative that holds the rights to the Dewey name. The hotel, at Madison Avenue and 41st Street, not far from the New York Public Library, has added an asterisk to its Web page saying that Dewey is a trademark of the cooperative, the Online Computer Library Center of Dublin, Ohio. The center filed suit in September after complaining to the hotel's owner, Henry Kallan. James Barron (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAMBERT, HOWARD A.
description: LAMBERT--Howard A. On November 25, 2003 (the 115th wedding anniversary of his parents). Beloved brother of nine. Survived by Mary E. Lambert and Grace L. Skoglund. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Formerly of Lambert & Skoglund Company, C.D. Mallory and Glander Intl. The family will receive friends on Friday at Chas. Peter Nagel, 352 East 87 Street, NY, NY from 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Monica's R.C. Church, on Saturday, 11 AM.

title: 'Steak and Shake' Takes On A Whole New Meaning
description: ADAM PERRY LANG looked distinctly uneasy sitting in the cocktail lounge, and who could blame him? It's tough trying to conduct an interview while at the next table a voluptuous woman in spangles has dropped her top and is treating one happy executive to a lap dance. It was even tougher, I soon discovered, trying to eat a steak dinner while another enterprising gal gyrated her bare buttocks just inches from the entree. But as they say here at the Penthouse Executive Club, that's entertainment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, JUDITH
description: FRIEDMAN--Judith, on November 22, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Arnold D. Loving mother of Roger, Lisa and John. Mother-in-law of Pat and Kathy. Dear sister of Herbert Scheinberg. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Randall and Julia. Mayest Thou O God of Mercy, shelter her forever under the wings of Thy presence. May her soul be bound up in the bond of life eternal and grant that the memories of her life inspire us.

title: A Nightclub Made Churchlike by Softness of Sound and Touch
description: You have to admire the Norwegian pianist Tord Gustavsen for a pleasingly disjunctive, conceptually airtight presentation. Young, fresh-faced and pinstripe-suited, he gets to the piano bench with his similarly sharp-looking bassist and drummer, and proceeds to play incredibly somber music.

title: Opposition in New York Area
description: Democratic lawmakers from the New York metropolitan area overwhelmingly opposed the prescription drug bill that Congress approved on Tuesday, while the region's Republicans backed the bill in a near-party-line vote.

title: A 9/11 Memorial For the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Tell the Pope
description: Pope John Paul II would be scandalized if he came to the Roman Catholic hospital here in the poor southwestern part of El Salvador.

title: Getting Roosevelt Into One Volume, a Trick in Itself
description: FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT

title: Rod Rodgers Remembered: Lyric and Vivid Choreography
description: Urban Dance Collective

title: How to Set the Table, and Why: The Short Course
description: WHEN I was growing up, a treat for me at Thanksgiving was setting the table. My mother spread out a thick white and gray damask cloth she said an aunt had brought from Germany (and which I now treasure). Then she would take down the special French dinnerware.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm worried about kids. Elite athletes know the side effects, and they can afford to pay for the real stuff. Kids don't have the knowledge, and they're buying it from some clown selling it at school. Who knows what they're getting?''

title: The Neediest Cases; Mother's Hope for Son: No More Wheelchair
description: It took four years and a leap of faith.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Semiconductor Maker Settles Claim
description: Cree Inc., which makes semiconductors that light cellphones and dashboards, settled a suit brought by its former chief executive, Eric Hunter, and his wife. The settlement ends all litigation with the couple, Eric and Jocelyn Hunter, who had accused Cree of defrauding shareholders and had filed a defamation suit seeking $3.21 billion. The settlement does not require any payments to the couple, and Cree, based in Durham, N.C., said it had accepted Mr. Hunter's resignation. The Hunters filed suit in June against Cree and its chairman, Neal Hunter, Eric Hunter's brother. The Hunter brothers founded Cree in 1987. Shares rose 36 cents to $18.49.

title: Preparing for the Feast? Read This First
description: To the Editor:

title: Gephardt Attacks Bush and Rivals on Affirmative Action
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt offered a vigorous defense of affirmative action on Tuesday before a crowd of cheering black ministers here, and criticized President Bush and three Democratic rivals as questioning the value of such programs.

title: Transit System Bond Sale
description: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which operates the nation's fifth-largest mass transit system, said yesterday that it planned to sell as much as $260 million of sales tax revenue bonds next week to refinance existing debt and save from $10 million to $11 million in interest.

title: On a Trail To Fixing A Broken Family
description: Apparently the only thing tougher than endurance on the frontier is sitting through a movie about endurance on the frontier -- at least that is the point ''The Missing'' seems determined to make. Amazingly, what it also seems to be saying is that nearly 50 years after John Ford's ''Searchers'' we have arrived at a point in film history when the movie industry can offer a less sophisticated version of the same material.

title: For Bottles of a Noble Sort, Big-Wheel Cheeses
description: WHEN wines and cheeses are matched, two conventions generally prevail. The first is to select a cheese from the same region as the wine. The second is that red wine is the most suitable partner for cheese.

title: Republicans Urge Inquiry On Head Start
description: Facing an increasingly raw fight over the future of Head Start, Congressional Republicans asked the General Accounting Office today to examine the federal government's financial oversight of the program, which serves almost one million preschoolers who live in poverty.

title: Schwarzenegger Aide Offers First List of Proposed Budget Cuts
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger's finance director asked lawmakers on Tuesday to approve a stark economic bailout package that includes sharp cuts in programs for the poor and the disabled while borrowing large amounts of money from transportation projects to cover other spending.

title: A Tiny Box, Sparkling With Seafood
description: JACK'S LUXURY OYSTER BAR is proof that a big idea can fit into a small restaurant. Jack Lamb scored a big hit a few years ago when he and his wife, Grace, opened Jewel Bako, a high-quality sushi restaurant with an East Village atmosphere. For an encore, he has struck out in an entirely different direction, although he did not travel far. Jack's, on two floors of a carriage house right across the street from Jewel Bako, is a New Orleans oyster bar that has been given a New York upgrade and a downtown twist or two. It's one of the most distinctive restaurants to come along in years.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: UConn Out To Prove No. 1 Spot Is Justified
description: In almost every preseason poll, the Connecticut women's basketball team was No. 1 in the nation. That is logical because the Huskies have won the last two N.C.A.A. championships and all the starters return from last season's 37-1 team.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: LIFE SENTENCES FOR 12 HINDUS A court sentenced 12 Hindus to life imprisonment for killing 14 Muslims during riots in Gujarat State last year. Three other Hindus received prison terms of two years. All the defendants were convicted a day earlier, the first convictions of Hindus in connection with the rioting, in which at least 1,000 Muslims were killed. Gujarat officials were accused of sanctioning the violence. Previous trials of Hindus accused of taking part resulted in acquittals, and the courts have been facing heavy criticism and reversals from the country's highest court, the Supreme Court. (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Construction Companies To Merge
description: The Kumagai Gumi Company and the Tobishima Corporation, two of the country's largest construction companies, said they would merge in April 2005. Sales at both companies fell more than 30 percent last year, and Kumagai Gumi reported a profit largely because its bank waived more than $2 billion in debts. The companies will combine their road-building subsidiaries six months before their full merger. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLEBERMAN, MIRIAM
description: GLEBERMAN--Miriam. The Board of Directors and staff of the JCC of Mid-Westchester mourns the passing of longtime Board member Mimi Gleberman. Mimi was a great supporter and friend of the JCC.

title: Theater in Review
description: Electronics and Athletics Transform an Ancient Epic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRATZ, DONALD
description: GRATZ--Donald. The Board and staff of the Noguchi Museum mourn the passing of our friend and neighbor, Donald Gratz. We extend our deepest condolences to the Gratz family.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Cutbacks At M.I.T.
description: Facing a $70 million budget gap and a shrinking endowment, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is undertaking a number of cost-cutting measures, including closing the school for nearly two weeks around Christmas and New Year's. The school also plans to eliminate up to 250 jobs to save money, and is asking employees to turn out lights and order supplies in bulk. The school's endowment, the nation's fifth largest, dropped to $5.4 billion in 2002 from $6.5 billion in 2000. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Hunger Worsens in Many Lands, U.N. Says
description: The number of hungry people worldwide has swelled in recent years, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, because of war, drought, AIDS and trade barriers, according to a report released Tuesday by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Seize Money And Steroids
description: The police seized $2 million in cash and a large quantity of steroids yesterday as part of an investigation by the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the New York Police Department, the authorities said. The police also charged a suspect, Richard Burack, 51, with second-degree criminal possession of a controlled substance. In all, authorities confiscated 1,100 vials of liquid steroids and 10,000 steroid pills, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Italian Exchange Offers Plan To Attract Wary Investors
description: In the heyday of the Internet, Italy's technology startups and other fast-growing companies ran to list shares on the Nuovo Mercato, often referred to as the country's Nasdaq. Investors greeted them with open arms. Then the bubble burst and share prices plunged, scaring investors away.

title: AARP Support Came as Group Grew 'Younger'
description: William D. Novelli, the chief executive of AARP, sat in his downtown Washington office on Tuesday, still glowing from the Senate's passage of prescription-drug legislation that his group had endorsed, and slid a copy of the glossy AARP magazine across a mahogany table. The actress Lauren Hutton was on the cover, along with blurbs for stories about ''where to find love'' and ''amazing new sex drugs.''

title: INSIDE
description: Guantnamo Chaplain Freed

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARP, ABRAHAM J.
