description: KARP -- Abraham J. The American Jewish Historical Society mourns the passing of Rabbi Abraham J. Karp, who served as President of The Society from 1972 to 1975. A distinguished scholar of American Jewish history and collector of rare books and original documents, Abe Karp helped shape the Society as an institution and the field of American Jewish history for generations of scholars. We extend our condolences to his wife, Deborah, and his entire family. Sidney Lapidus, President Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman Michael Feldberg, Ph.D., Executive Director

title: Once Again, Bond Market Finds Nassau Attractive
description: Nassau County government will go into the bond market next month under its own name for the first time in three years. Buoyed by the latest in a series of credit upgradings, the county plans to sell $120 million of tax-anticipation notes, temporary loans to cover operating expenses until property-tax payments come in.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Senate Passes Measure To Overhaul Medicare

title: 800 in Colombia Lay Down Arms, Kindling Peace Hopes
description: After a minute of silence in memory of the thousands killed in Colombia's conflict, 800 fighters from an urban band of a right-wing paramilitary group laid down their weapons on Tuesday in a disarmament ceremony the government says could bring the country closer to ending its 39-year-long war.

title: Boeing's Tawdry Deal
description: Senator John McCain and others have long portrayed a $20 billion Air Force commitment to lease and buy up to 100 Boeing 767 refueling planes as a poster child of wasteful government spending. It is now looking more like a poster child for the sheer corruption of the Pentagon's procurement process.

title: Antispam Bill Passes Senate By Voice Vote
description: The Senate passed a bill to curb junk commercial e-mail by voice vote on Tuesday, bringing national regulations on spam closer to reality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HASKINS, PAUL
description: HASKINS--Paul. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Paul Haskins, associated with The Times from August 1982.

title: Weighing Transit Possibilities, New Study Follows the Money
description: The wish list of mass transit projects that local, state and federal politicians have drawn up for the city is long and ambitious: the Second Avenue subway, Long Island Rail Road service to the East Side, the No. 7 subway extension, a relocated Pennsylvania Station, a transit hub for Lower Manhattan, and the list goes on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HABIG, JOSEPH BERNARD
description: HABIG--Joseph Bernard, died September 21, 2003 in Middletown, NJ of Parkinson's Disease. Mr. Habig worked as Artist and Repertoire Producer at RCA, Victor Red Seal for 19 years (1954-1973) and at Reader's Digest Music Division for 16 years (1973-1989) as Executive Producer. He worked with many classical, pop and jazz artists. He received a Grammy Award for producing Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms with Robert Shaw as conductor and The Robert Shaw Chorale and Orchestra. Prior to joining RCA he worked 10 years as a trombonist with Dean Dixon and The American Youth Symphony, Leon Barzin and the NYC Symphony, Benjamin Swali and the North Carolina Symphony and Morton Gould. Habig received a B.S. in Music Education at CCNY and also attended Juilliard and the Manhattan School of Music. Virginia Harlow Habig, his wife of 53 years is the only survivor. She lives in Tinton Falls, NJ.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: TO THE POLLS Voters will select their representatives for the province's legislature today for the first time since 1998, when a landmark peace accord established a local government to share power between Protestant and Roman Catholic parties. The 108-seat assembly has been suspended for a year. Opinion polls have shown no clear front-runners on either side of sectarian divide, but the balance of power is expected to shift away from mainstream and moderate parties. More than 2,000 extra police officers are being deployed at polling places. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Preparing for the Feast? Read This First
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Finds Meaning in Its Victory
description: Rutgers will have plenty of opportunities to prove that it can compete with capable opponents. This just was not one of them.

title: The Lesson of Somalia: Just a Humpty Dumpty Story?
description: The recent sight of Black Hawk helicopters falling from the sky in Iraq prompts comparisons with Somalia, where the downing of a Black Hawk in 1993 spelled the end of an earlier experiment in stabilizing a divided, violence-racked nation.

title: For Concorde, a Far Slower Ride At a Much Lower Altitude
description: A marvel of British and French aeronautical engineering was towed to Manhattan yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORREE, JEANNETTE
description: BORREE--Jeannette. On November 19. Passed away peacefully. Beloved grandmother of Yvonne and her two daughters Susan and Jeanine. She meant the world to us and gave from her heart always. Her wonderful, giving spirit will be missed very much.

title: Philip Morris USA Starts Its Move to a Historic Building
description: Michael J. Schewel, the secretary of commerce and trade for the commonwealth of Virginia, was driving to work one morning when a news report on the radio caught his attention: Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York, was proposing to further toughen his city's antismoking law.

title: A Poll Shows That the Mayor's Approval and Popularity Are Down Again
description: Fewer than a fourth of New York City voters want to see Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg re-elected, and two of his leading Democratic challengers would beat him handily if the election were held today, a new poll has found.

title: Dance in Review
description: Rod Rodgers Remembered: Lyric and Vivid Choreography

title: Midcentury Chinese-American in Riverdale
description: THE Chinese restaurant of my early childhood is stamped on my memory. For our family -- for almost anybody in the mid-1960's -- Chinese food was considered exotic dining, and for me, each visit to our local restaurant, Fong's, was a ritualistic joy.

title: A Holiday Ride From The Internet To the Table
description: SHOPPING for gifts of food online has become as sophisticated as catalog shopping and much more convenient. The pictures on Web sites have become more enticing than those on paper, even glossy paper. Browsing the sites is as easy as turning pages, and if you have questions, the best sites have someone at the other end of the phone.

title: In Keansburg, Bitter Political Fight Worsens
description: For two years, a bitter battle has been going on between Keansburg's mayor and the longtime police chief he has been trying to oust. It has pitted neighbor against neighbor in a town of 10,700, and on Tuesday the feud overflowed to the steps of the Monmouth County Courthouse as the mayor accused the county prosecutor of not investigating allegations of corruption against the chief and his aides.

title: Networks Criticize Report on Male Viewers
description: Network executives expressed strong reservations yesterday about a report from Nielsen Media Research that seeks to explain a puzzling drop in male viewers and continued to argue that changes in Nielsen's sample, and not any audience disaffection with their programming, is at the heart of the issue.

title: The Candidates and the Draft (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toshiba To Expand Production
description: The Toshiba Corporation will increase production of its memory chips in Japan to keep up with growing demand for semiconductors used in digital products. Toshiba, Japan's largest chip maker for consumer electronics, will spend another 12 billion yen ($110 million) this fiscal year, which runs through March 2004, to expand capacity. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: In Vast Numbers, Americans Hit the Thanksgiving Trail
description: More people are expected to travel this Thanksgiving holiday than at any time since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in 2001, according to the American Automobile Association.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Execution
description: New York State's highest court yesterday overturned the death sentence of a Syracuse-area man who was convicted of poisoning his wife while she was recovering from a baseball-bat beating he administered.

title: A Snug Cap for Leftovers, To Use Over and Over Again
description: Nifty little elastic-edged plastic caps, like shower caps for Muppets, are grandmotherly reusable covers for bowls, jars or tubs of leftovers. They are airtight, washable and environmentally friendly substitutes for plastic wrap or foil. These, made in Japan, come in sets of six in assorted sizes for $14 in the shop at Felissimo Design House, 10 West 56th Street.

title: Off the Menu
description: APRIL BLOOMFIELD, left, a 28-year-old English chef and alumna of the River Cafe in Hammersmith, just outside London, spent the summer in the kitchen of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., preparing for her new job in New York. She will be cooking at THE SPOTTED PIG, a gastropub at 314 West 11th Street, when it opens in a couple of weeks. It is owned by KEN FRIEDMAN, a music talent scout, who is outfitting it with pubby dark wood and a pressed-copper ceiling. It will serve a lot more than mere bangers and mash: Ms. Bloomfield plans hearty food like smoked haddock chowder with biscuits, a creamy veal stew and seasonal pasta made with pumpkin.

title: INDEPENDENCE COMMUNITY BUYS STATEN ISLAND BANCORP
description: The Independence Community Bank Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Staten Island Bancorp Inc. for $1.5 billion in stock and cash in a move to expand in the New York and New Jersey banking market. The deal will create a combined banking company with assets of about $17 billion and 116 full-service branches, 51 of those in New Jersey. Independence, based in Brooklyn, said it expected the merged company to have a loan portfolio of about $9 billion, 60 percent derived from commercial loans, and a deposit base of about $9 billion. Under the agreement, which is expected to close in the spring, Independence will pay $369 million in cash plus about 29 million shares for Staten Island Bancorp.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: PROSTATE DRUG WINS APPROVAL The Food and Drug Administration approved a new drug to treat the symptoms of advanced prostate cancer, including urinary obstruction and bone and nerve pain. The drug, Plenaxis, marketed by Praecis Pharmaceuticals of Waltham, Mass., temporarily shrinks tumors but does not prolong life. It is meant for men whose only other option would be castration  5 to 10 percent of men with prostate cancer, or 15,000 to 20,000 in the United States. The drug can cause dangerous allergic reactions and requires special monitoring. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: Former A.N.C. Bomber Becomes a Police Chief
description: An anti-apartheid fighter convicted in a 1986 bombing that killed three women was officially appointed police chief of a Johannesburg district on Tuesday, making him responsible for the safety of two million people.

title: Teachers' and Principals' Grievances Now Include, Well, You Guessed It
description: Unions for New York City teachers and principals have filed grievances over yet another issue: changes in the grievance process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTNAYER, YVONNE ROSA
description: GUTNAYER--Yvonne Rosa. Greatly loved and cherished wife of the late Henry R. Gutnayer. Devoted and loving mother of Joan C. Engel and Kathryn D. Gordon and doting and loving grandmother of Alex and Ken Rudd. We will deeply miss you though your love and caring and the memory of your eternal French charm will remain in our hearts forever. Anyone wanting to make a contribution please send to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisades Ave., Riverdale, NY 10471. Services Wednesday 1:30 PM, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Arithmetic of Pizza in a Made-to-Measure Pie
description: Matt Birnbaum, far left, and Todd Birnbaum, brothers who have just opened Pinch: Pizza by the Inch, 416 Park Avenue South (29th Street), think pizza lovers deserve a fresh slice, not a reheated one. So they bake swaths of thin crust that are 36 inches long and 4 inches wide and lightly painted with tomato sauce, then let customers choose among dozens of toppings like grilled eggplant, capers and hot sausage. More tomato sauce and the toppings are applied and baked to order for a crispy, fresh-tasting slice.

title: Publisher to Close 3 Magazines Aimed At Black Readers
description: Vanguarde Media Inc., publisher of Savoy, Honey and Heart & Soul, announced yesterday that it would close the magazines and seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Evidence Against Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Attacks on Americans Start to Ease, Bremer Says
description: Far fewer Americans have been killed in guerrilla attacks in recent days, L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator here, said Tuesday. Instead, he said, the insurgents have turned to killing other Iraqis.

title: The Magical Solution
description: It seems as if everyone is coming up with a surefire, can't-miss, ''comprehensive'' agreement to make peace once and for all between Palestinians and Israelis.

title: Before the Main Event You Still Have to Eat
description: ONE of the difficulties of an impending feast -- panic, the weight of expectation and family tensions aside -- is that everyone acts as if that is the only meal on the horizon. Before Thanksgiving it is natural that a certain focus should be on the dinner itself, but other meals do exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FURLONG, ROBERT GORDON
description: FURLONG--Robert Gordon. A marketing executive from Montclair, NJ, died at his home on November 23. He was 81. A graduate of Brown University, he served as a decorated gunnery officer in the Pacific Theater aboard the US Navy DestroyerMinesweeper, USS Chandler, and was a retired Lt. Commander in the US Navy Reserve. He held senior sales management positions with Philco, DuMont and RCA before founding Mil-Comm Products Company, serving as CEO until his death. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Mary Frances Johnson, children Robert, Jr., Pamela, Lucinda, and Joan of Montclair, Charles of Chilmark, MA, Frances Furlong-Riesenman of Charlottesville, VA, and eight grandchildren. A funeral mass will be celebrated at Immaculate Conception Church in Montclair on Saturday, November 29.

title: Schilling and the Red Sox Planning to Meet Today
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks ace Curt Schilling has considered what it will take for Boston to persuade him to waive his no-trade clause, and he will inform Red Sox officials of his requirements this afternoon in a meeting at his house in Paradise Valley, Ariz.

title: Force in Hewlett-Compaq Merger Resigns
description: Jeffrey J. Clarke, a leader of the management team that put the operations of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer together in the wake of their contentious merger, resigned unexpectedly yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Munich Re Posts Profit
description: Munich Re said that it had returned to a profit in the third quarter after five quarterly losses but warned of a full-year loss because of high tax provisions and write-downs on equity investment. The company, which is the world's largest reinsurer, posted a quarterly net profit of 152 million euros ($179 million) by the end of September, up from a loss of 859 million euros in the previous year. The result nevertheless disappointed analysts' expectations of higher pretax and net profit. The company said its forecast of a ''three-digit-million loss'' in 2003 was based on tax charges on write-downs and losses on asset sales. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBLEIN, FREDA
description: LIEBLEIN--Freda. A 55 year resident of Great Neck. Beloved wife for 63 years to the late George. Devoted mother of Skip Lieblein, Ellen Goldblatt and the late Eddie Lieblein. Cherished grandmother of Jill, Stuart and Corey Lieblein and Ariel, Laura and Aaron Goldblatt. Great-grandmother of Justin, Jesse and Sydney Lieblein. Loving sister of Lee Welner and Molly Pile. Services Wednesday, 11AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Sodomy Case Highlights a System's Problems
description: The crime was horrendous, a 14-year-old boy sodomized with a broomstick by a 16-year-old, while an adult supervisor held him down.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Swimming Spots Faulted
description: Spain must improve the quality of its lakes, swimming pools and other bathing waters by next summer or face a fine of $18 million, the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg ruled. The court said that 85 percent of Spain's inland bathing spots met European standards in the summer of 2002 but that the government has not taken measures to ensure 100 percent compliance. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERNBERG, MAURICE
description: STERNBERG -- Maurice, known more familiarly as ''Uncle Maurice'' of Knights Day Camp to some 35,000 children, parents, and staff, died November 9th at the age of 92. He will be sorely missed by his son, daughter and grandchildren. His unfailing sense of humor and kind demeanor we hope will be remembered by all those whose lives he touched. A memorial service will be held 1:00 PM, November 29th at the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. Those who remembered him are welcome.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nets' Play At Start of Trip Seems Inspired
description: Alonzo Mourning's last public plea, delivered shortly after what was probably his final N.B.A. game, was a call for the Nets to wake up and sweep the road trip they began here Tuesday night.

title: An Athlete's Dangerous Experiment
description: After recording one save last season, Taylor Hooton expected to join the starting rotation next spring for the baseball team at Plano West Senior High School.

title: Liberty, a Lady in Waiting, Gets Money for Reopening
description: Two years ago, the nation's leaders urged a panicky public to strike back against terrorism by embracing the normalcy of everyday life. But the failure to reopen the Statue of Liberty after the World Trade Center attack became a silent reminder that New York -- and the world -- had changed.

title: France and Germany Given More Time to Curb Deficits
description: Europe's finance ministers have agreed to suspend the fiscal rules that underpin the euro, eliciting sighs of relief from France and Germany, but driving a wedge through the 12-member monetary union and raising fears about the stability of the single currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMALL, MICHAEL
description: SMALL--Michael. There's a little less sparkle in the skies tonight; we've lost our lovable, whimsical, favorite MC. Loving condolences to Lynn, Jonathan and David. Emile & Diane Charlap

title: The G.O.P. Congress Fails at Closing
description: Congress has headed home for holiday feasting having failed to meet its most basic responsibility -- approving the bills that pay for another year's government. A murky $820 billion omnibus bill needed by a score of federal agencies is already two months overdue, mocking the Republican leaders' campaign vow to make Congress look more efficient.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL UNION OF ELECTRONIC-COMMUNICATIONS WORKERS said that 10,000 of its members working at Delphi Corp. in Troy, Mich., the world's largest maker of auto parts, had voted 94 percent in favor of a new four-year contract.

title: The Man Who Clears Kermit the Frog for Takeoff
description: The other 364 days a year, he is just another guy in town, another passing wisp of humanity in the above-average sustained wind and sometimes bitter cold front that is New York City.

title: U.S. Closes Mutual Fund Intermediary
description: The mutual fund scandal claimed its first corporate casualty yesterday when federal banking regulators ordered the shutdown of the Security Trust Company, an important intermediary in the processing of mutual fund trades by pension plans.

title: Muhammad May Face Additional Trials
description: The trials of John A. Muhammad, the convicted mastermind of the Washington-area sniper killings, may be far from over.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Millions In Taxi Fines Uncollected
description: Lax enforcement and poor record-keeping has prevented the city from collecting $97 million in fines from taxi owners and drivers, according to an audit released yesterday by the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., left. Mr. Thompson said that up to $8 million of the unpaid fines could still be collected, but that computer problems, poor coordination among agencies, inadequate records and poor procedures had contributed to the collection failure. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELBERG, FREDERICK
description: GELBERG--Frederick. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Frederick Gelberg, and we extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Terie and their family. Old Westbury Golf and Country Club Herbert Selzer, President Steven Tolman, Secretary

title: Eternal Conflict: Good vs. Medieval
description: The clumsy, wooden, screen adaptation of Michael Crichton's novel ''Timeline'' suggests a particularly wretched episode of ''Star Trek'' tricked out with fancy fireworks and weighed down with a score that grinds away like a cement mixer. The pyrotechnics, in which battling 14th-century soldiers catapult fireballs into each other's fortresses, may be diverting. But from the beginning, this fantasy of time travel, in which a group of contemporary archaeologists plunges through a wormhole in the time-space continuum to land in France in 1357, pounds you over the head with its noisy, ridiculous notions of medieval life.

title: Memorials Without a Memory
description: The Florentines of the 15th century did not trust Filippo Brunelleschi, who kept secret the details as he went about building the world's largest dome. They had good reason to be skeptical, actually, as Brunelleschi was a goldsmith and sculptor who had never before built a building. In one of the great mystery stories of art history, the people of Florence had to wait 16 years to see if the 37,000 metric tons of material would hold together.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about labor support for Howard Dean at three political rallies over the weekend misstated the given name of a New Hampshire state worker who said 90 members of his union group planned to work for the Dean campaign. He is Art Ellison, not Allan.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Democratic presidential debate in Des Moines referred incorrectly to advice once given by Gen. Wesley K. Clark in favor of the congressional resolution authorizing the war in Iraq, an incident he did not mention during the debate while trying to clarify his stand. The advice was given not to a member of Congress but to a New Hampshire candidate for Congress, Katrina Swett.

title: The Candidates and the Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: SWEEPING MEDICARE CHANGE WINS APPROVAL IN CONGRESS; PRESIDENT CLAIMS A VICTORY
description: Congress gave final approval on Tuesday to a bill that would help millions of older Americans buy prescription drugs, and President Bush immediately embraced the legislation, which promises the biggest changes in Medicare since its creation in 1965.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEANE, MARJORIE
description: DEANE--Marjorie. The Board and staff offer its deepest condolences to the family of Marjorie Deane. Marjorie epitomized the values inherent in Girl Scouting as a dedicated director for over 20 years. All who knew Marjorie enjoyed learning from her and working by her side. Susan Nitze, President Susan Greenbaum, CEO Girl Scout Council of Greater New York

title: N.Y.R.A. Hires Director of Security
description: The New York Racing Association, which has been accused of mismanagement and fraud by state officials, named a former deputy superintendent of the New York State Police as director of security yesterday.

title: Charming Illegal Aliens Facing Family Upheaval
description: At the start of ''In America,'' Sarah and Johnny Sullivan arrive at the United States-Canadian border in a swaybacked station wagon with their two daughters in the back seat. They are from Ireland, and they are coming to the United States illegally so Johnny can find work as an actor and they can start over after the death of their young son, Frankie.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Paul Haskins, an editor at The New York Times and earlier at The Kansas City Times, misstated his birthdate and the number of surviving grandchildren and omitted the maiden name of his wife. He was born on April 18, 1941, not April 8; he had 12 grandchildren, not 11; his wife is Judith Hyman Haskins.

title: R.P.I. Surprises St. Cloud
description: St. Cloud State rolled into Troy, N.Y., last weekend ranked No. 5 in the nation, sporting an 8-1-1 record and coming off its fourth straight trip to the N.C.A.A. tournament last spring. The Huskies' unranked host, Rensselaer, which was 12-25-3 last season, had failed to qualify for the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament and had not earned an N.C.A.A. bid since 1995.

title: U.S. Rescinds Part of Loan Guarantees to Israel
description: The Bush administration, in a rare rebuke to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, has decided to rescind $289.5 million in American-backed loan guarantees for Israel as a punishment for illegal construction activities in the West Bank, the Israeli Embassy announced Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WACHENHEIM, EDGAR, JR.
description: WACHENHEIM--Edgar, Jr. With great love and sadness, we mourn the passing of Edgar Wachenheim Jr., on November 25, 2003 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Marshall Wachenheim. Devoted father of Scott and Edgar III. He is also survived by a sister, Jessie Burack, seven grandchildren, and four great grandchildren. He loved his family, friends, and community--and he was a constant source of joy to all whose lives he touched. He devoted a good part of his life to helping those in need-and, as a result, he left the world a better place. His unselfish generosity, passion for life, and wise counsel will be greatly missed by all. A service to celebrate Ed's life will be held 10:30 A.M. on Sunday, December 14, 2003 at The Beach Point Club, 900 Rushmore Avenue, Mamaroneck, New York. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to The Edgar Wachenheim Jr Endowment Fund, The Guidance Center, 70 Grand St., New Rochelle, NY 10801.

title: The Candidates and the Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; A little-known player succumbs in the scandal as others worry that 'too big to fail' doesn't apply.
description: ELIOT SPITZER obviously meant what he said when he warned last week that some financial services companies might be shut as part of the latest round of scandal on Wall Street.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Off the Menu column on Nov. 5 about the restaurant Gaia in Greenwich, Conn., referred incorrectly to its owner. Marlon Abela is a man.

title: The Candidates and the Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Briefing
description: PRO FOOTBALL

title: Taking Cargo and People, Chilean Airline Flourishes
description: These are terrible times for airlines all over Latin America, as one carrier after another closes, staggers under huge losses, scales back routes or reluctantly merges with rivals. But at the shiny new glass headquarters of LanChile here, things have never been better.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Democratic presidential debate in Des Moines referred incorrectly to advice once given by Gen. Wesley K. Clark in favor of the Congressional resolution authorizing the war in Iraq, an incident he did not mention during the debate while trying to clarify his stand. The advice was given not to a member of Congress but to a New Hampshire candidate for Congress, Katrina Swett.

title: Rochester Utility Sells Nuclear Power Station
description: A Baltimore-based electric company said Tuesday that it would buy the Robert E. Ginna nuclear plant from Rochester Gas and Electric for $401 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPELKE, HENRY
description: SPELKE--Henry. Of Delray, FL, formerly of Stamford, CT. Died Monday, November 24, 2003 in his 95th year. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife, Judy, sons, Robert and Clifford, daughter-in-law Leslie, and grandchildren, Craig, Samantha, Jenna, and Brandon, who will remember him lovingly. Funeral services at Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford, CT 06902, Friday, November 28th at 11 A.M.

title: Indian and Pakistani Forces Agree to Cease-Fire in Kashmir
description: Indian and Pakistani military commanders agreed Tuesday to a cease-fire along their common border, including the volatile and heavily militarized front line in the disputed territory of Kashmir, officials in both countries said.

title: Second Suffolk Teenager Pleads Guilty in Fire at Mexicans' Home
description: The second of five teenagers accused of setting afire the Farmingville home of a Mexican family pleaded guilty on Monday and agreed to testify against the others in the case.

title: Preparing for the Feast? Read This First
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Americans on Winning Team At Fall Bridge Championship
description: Many of the top performers at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships here found on Tuesday night that good current results helped assuage sad recent episodes.

title: Army Says Troop Rotation Into Iraq Poses Increased Danger
description: Senior Army officers have told Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld that the rotation of more than 100,000 soldiers into Iraq early next year will present a great risk for American forces, with officials saying they must prepare for a surge in attacks on troops who may be more vulnerable during the transition.

title: Economy's Growth Is Revised Upward to 8.2%
description: The nation's growth was even more torrid in the third quarter than previously estimated, the government reported Tuesday, while a new survey of consumer confidence suggested that growth should remain strong next year.

title: Powerful Cleric Opposes U.S. Plan for Elections in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 26  The nation's most powerful cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, made public today his opposition to a new American plan for indirect elections of an Iraqi government, dealing a possibly fatal blow to the United States initiative to turn power over more quickly to Iraqis.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Government Contractors Swap Units
description: Affiliated Computer Services, the world's largest processor of student-loan payments, and Lockheed Martin Corporation, the biggest manager of computer networks for the United States government, completed a $658 million swap of business units. Affiliated sold most of its business that manages computer systems for federal agencies, including the Defense Department, to Lockheed for about $551 million, and in return acquired Lockheed's commercial computer services unit for about $107 million, a Lockheed spokesman, Jeff Adams, said. Lockheed, which has been divesting commercial operations and expanding services for the military and the federal government, said the transactions would increase its 2004 earnings by about $400 million. Affiliated, based in Dallas, will use proceeds from the sale to pay down debt. Affiliated shares fell 33 cents to $49.92. Lockheed, based in Bethesda, Md., fell 58 cents to $45.87.

title: Exposing the Cheat Sheet, With the Students' Aid
description: A Crystal Rock water bottle is Exhibit A in a campaign to reduce cheating here at Staples High School, a bastion of affluence, academic achievement and unrelenting pressure to succeed.

title: Even With Bush's Support, Wide-Ranging Legislation May Have Been Sunk by Excess
description: In the end, the energy bill that fizzled in the last days of Congress was undone by an overload.

title: Pilgrims, No Thanks In Mohawk Country
description: CECILIA KING'S first grade class had just finished a lesson on Thanksgiving and Ciara Skidders-White knew exactly why it was a big deal. ''We get three days off,'' she said.

title: Japan Says It Might Impose Tariffs on American Imports
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26  Japan said today that it planned to place tariffs on American imports for the first time if the Bush administration did not drop duties on some Japanese steel products that it imposed to protect American companies.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Putin Cancels Visit
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called off a visit to the tiny country of Moldova, a former Soviet state sandwiched between Romania and Ukraine, after a senior Kremlin official accused the country's president of caving in to pressure and backing out of an agreement that would have kept Russian troops in the country. The Moldovan president, Vladimir Voronin, a former K.G.B. official, refused to sign a Moscow-brokered plan to extend the stay of 2,000 Russian peacekeeping troops in the breakaway Dniester region in the east after protesters took to the streets of the capital, Chisinau, demanding that Russia withdraw its troops immediately. The demonstrators burned a Russian flag and a portrait of Mr. Putin outside the Russian Embassy, according to news agency reports. Russia had promised the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe that it would remove its contingent by year's end. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Who Put the Overdrive in Mr. Murphy's Mansion?
description: The Disney fright comedy ''The Haunted Mansion,'' starring Eddie Murphy in another of his put-upon dad roles, is an anomaly: no frights and no laughs. The price of the popcorn-and-drink combo at most theaters showing this film is scarier.

title: Firm Details Trades
description: Federated Investors Inc., a money manager, provided details yesterday about market-timing arrangements that its mutual funds had with some hedge funds. One of the arrangements involved Canary Capital Partners hedge funds, Federated said, adding that it did not include late trading of mutual funds. Two employees resigned over their role in setting up the arrangements and one was fired for deleting e-mail messages related to the investigations, a spokesman, J.T. Tuskan, said.

title: 20 Airport Workers Held in Smuggling Of Drugs for Decade
description: Federal agents arrested 20 airport baggage and cargo handlers yesterday and charged them with running a decade-long drug smuggling operation that brought hundreds of pounds of cocaine and marijuana a year through Kennedy International Airport under the noses of customs officials.

title: Turks Charge 9 in Bombings of British Sites
description: Turkey's State Security Court charged nine people on Tuesday in connection with the suicide bombings of British targets here last week as Britain warned that more attacks against Western interests in the country could be imminent.

title: Seeking a Menorah And Finding a Family
description: 'Broadway Sings ''The Odd Potato'' '

title: Edwards Using 'Sense' For Fourth-Down Calls
description: With almost every Jets game being excruciatingly close, extra attention has been paid to Coach Herman Edwards's unorthodox pattern of decisions on fourth down. He bristles at the suggestion that he is a gambler, because it suggests that he is not in control of a situation; perhaps aggressive is a better description.

title: Security Posts Filled
description: President Bush has appointed James R. Wilkinson, who served as the spokesman for Gen. Tommy R. Franks during the war in Iraq, as a new deputy national security adviser for communications, with primary responsibility for coordinating the administration's public messages about the Iraqi occupation, the White House said Tuesday.

title: The Candidates and the Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Hot, Dry Summer Leaves Truffles More Elusive and Costly
description: AS dusk engulfs the outskirts of this town in the Piedmont region of Italy, Giorgio Romagnolo is busy combing the woods with his dog Diana, who wildly sniffs every tree, as if she were hunting for treasure.

title: S.&P. 500 Gains for a 3rd Day, Led by Financial Shares
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose for a third day yesterday, led by financial shares. The Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley gained after an analyst recommended buying shares of the brokerage firms because of a rebound in mergers and acquisitions.

title: Boston U. Search
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing Valiant Battle With Menacing Thoughts
description: Julia Ritter Performance Group

title: Gays Respond: 'I Do,' 'I Might' And 'I Won't'
description: No sooner had Massachusetts' highest court ruled that same-sex couples should be allowed to marry than Mike Sullivan's sister was on the phone volunteering to be the flower girl at his wedding.

title: Gothic Treasures From an England of Chaos, Catholicism and Visual Splendor
description: To study late-medieval England through Shakespeare's history plays is to discover a land constantly at war with France or with itself, a chaotic period of squabbling nobles, pernicious prelates and usurping kings. Yet it was also an era of prosperity, with wealth enough to build fine churches and to fill them with stained-glass windows, paintings, elaborate tombs and other works of religious art.

title: Clothes That Are Colorful and TV's That Are Thin Make Many Lists
description: Americans are already out there, buying. And retailers are taking notes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man, 19, Fatally Stabbed
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man was stabbed to death yesterday in what a police official said was an argument with another man. The victim, Cody Knox, died from multiple stab wounds to the back after he and the other man quarreled in a busy shopping area on Flatbush Avenue near Nevins Street, the police said. The fight ''looks like a dispute between two people who knew each other,'' the official said. One witness, a retailer who works in an apparel store nearby, said: ''There was a big debate about who sells cigarettes on what corner. That's what this was about.'' The police said two men were seen running from the area after the stabbing. There had been no arrests as of last night. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Park Plans Rejected
description: County councilors for the north Dublin area rejected a proposal for Vega City, an amusement park on more than 3,000 acres on the outskirts of the city, by a vote of 19 to 1, after county planning officials described the plans as sloppy and vague. Its developers, a consortium called United Entertainment Partners, had claimed the project would cost 7 billion euros ($8.3 billion), create 40,000 jobs and attract 37 million tourists each year. The plan was rejected because the consortium refused to identify the American backers who it said had promised to invest 1.5 billion euros ($1.8 billion), and did not provide enough detail about Vega City. The managing director, Louis Maguire, said that the group would consider other sites in Europe. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECK, RUTH HARMON
description: BECK--Ruth Harmon. On November 22, 2003, beloved wife of the late Albert E. Beck, Jr., and the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. E. Paul Harmon, Jr., and cousin of John N. Harmon, Jr., of Boulder City, Nevada. A descendant of Peregrine White, who was born on the Mayflower as the ship lay at anchor in Cape Cod Bay, November 20, 1620, the first child born in New England of English parents. Mrs. Beck, Packer Collegiate Institute, Class of 1922, also attended Pratt Institute, and was active in many Brooklyn charitiesMethodist Hospital Auxillary, Colony House, Salvation Army, Brooklyn Botanic Garden Auxillary, Civitas, and belonged to The Montauk Club. Memorials services will be at The Montauk Club, 8th Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, at 11:30 A.M. December 3rd. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Packer Collegiate Institute, or your favorite charity.

title: To a Guy Who Banks on Bad Luck, Good Luck Can Be Bad
description: In ''The Cooler'' William H. Macy plays Bernie Lootz, a man who is not just prodigiously unlucky but also the cause of unluckiness in others. He is employed by a Las Vegas casino owner named Shelly (Alec Baldwin) to terminate the winning streaks of customers with too much good fortune, something he can do merely by showing his sad-sack face at a hot blackjack table or slot machine.

title: Debt Is Seen Taking Toll On Jackson's Lavish Style
description: When he surrendered to the Santa Barbara County sheriff last week, Michael Jackson resembled an aging Joan Crawford, pale, frail and weighing 120 pounds.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MEDICAL CENTER SAYS $1 MILLION IS LOST The Columbia University Medical Center said yesterday that $1 million of the dermatology department's funds had been misappropriated over at least three years and that the matter had been referred to the Manhattan district attorney's office. The center said that three department administrators and a clerical worker had either resigned or been dismissed, that no public money had been taken and that the misappropriation had not affected patient care. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Effort To Recall Mayor Falls Short
description: A drive by some black clergymen to recall Mayor Laura Miller of Dallas was aborted when they failed to submit the 73,000 signatures required to get the recall on the ballot by the Monday night deadline. The campaign began after Terrell Bolton, Dallas's first black police chief, was fired last summer by the Dallas city manager amid a high crime rate and accusations that fake drugs had been planted on suspects. Mr. Bolton blamed Ms. Miller for his dismissal and supported the recall effort. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: RIDING OFF INTO THE SUNSET Cleveland's mounted police unit, the second-oldest in the nation, will be disbanded as part of an effort to close the city's $61 million budget deficit. The unit's 13 horses will be given to farms and the seven officers will be assigned to other duties. The unit, once 100 horses strong, was established in 1905 and is the oldest continuing mounted police unit in the nation. Only New York's is older, but it was disbanded for a period. (AP)

title: Southern Treats, by Way of Bedford-Stuyvesant
description: Shakoor and Marissa Watson, who own Shakoor's Sweet Tooth, 555 Throop Avenue (Halsey Street), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, have baked plenty of sweet potato cheesecakes and sweet potato pies, their signature desserts, for those who might be caught short for Thanksgiving. They are open today from noon to 6 p.m., but are closed on Thursday.

title: G.O.P. Worries Face From Past Will Haunt Florida Senate Race
description: It would seem that the last thing President Bush needs as he seeks re-election next year is anything that reopens the profound wounds from the Florida presidential recount of 2000.

title: Congress Meets in December On Big Financing Measure
description: Senate leaders reluctantly agreed on Tuesday to a December session, in hopes of finishing a long-delayed spending bill that provides money for more than a third of the federal government. But the chance of passage even then remained slim.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Prostate Drug Wins Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new drug to treat the symptoms of advanced prostate cancer, including urinary obstruction and bone and nerve pain. The drug, Plenaxis, marketed by Praecis Pharmaceuticals of Waltham, Mass., temporarily shrinks tumors but does not prolong life. It is meant for men whose only other option would be castration -- 5 to 10 percent of men with prostate cancer, or 15,000 to 20,000 in the United States. The drug can cause dangerous allergic reactions and requires special monitoring. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 434 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Our Towns; Parish of Pain Sees Millstone As a Monument
description: THERE had been so many lives altered, so much pain caused by a pedophile priest at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here that Father Kenneth E. Lasch can only compare it to another horror.

title: Energy Bill Gives Special Focus to a Fuel Additive
description: The collapse of the Bush administration's efforts to enact energy legislation this year revealed a fierce dispute over proposed concessions to Texas companies that produce a gasoline additive that makes drinking water smell like turpentine.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Medical Center Says $1 Million Is Lost
description: The Columbia University Medical Center said yesterday that $1 million of the dermatology department's funds had been misappropriated over at least three years and that the matter had been referred to the Manhattan district attorney's office. The center said that three department administrators and a clerical worker had either resigned or been dismissed, that no public money had been taken and that the misappropriation had not affected patient care. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Some Experts Foresee Revolt by Elderly Over Drug Benefits
description: With good intentions and bright advisers, Congress overwhelming passed legislation in 1988 that would insure the elderly against catastrophic medical expenses, including crushing drug costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, EUGENE D.
description: FRANK--Eugene D. The Board of Directors and Members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Eugene D. Frank, whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Steven M. Slaven, President Thomas W. Brock, Secretary

title: Saudis Report Thwarting Car-Bomb Attack
description: Saudi security forces thwarted a car-bomb attack on Tuesday in the capital, Riyadh, and killed two suspected militants, the official Saudi news media reported.

title: Portrait of a Mother, Sloppy Hats and All
description: 'Moms: An Evening of Comedy

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Action Against Drug Makers
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich said he would decrease the state's use of pharmaceuticals from companies that he said were trying to derail his plan for the state to buy lower-cost drugs from Canada. Five companies, including Eli Lilly and Pfizer, have limited the amount of drugs they supply to Canada in an effort to halt the resale of medications to the United States, said Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat. He said he would ask state officials to buy drugs from other companies when possible. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASSMAN, NORMAN A.
description: GLASSMAN--Norman A. Age 65 on November 25, 2003. Resident of Edgemont, NY. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Strauss). Devoted father of Janice (Benjamin) Cohen and Jeremy Glassman. Loving brother of David (Mildred) Glassman. Cherished brother-in-law of David & Carol Strauss. A Bridge Life Master and a member of Temple Israel Center of White Plains. Graveside services Wednesday 1:30 PM at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. For info Hellman-Garlick Memorial Chapels, 1300 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 4 MILITARY CONTRACTORS TO STUDY HYPERSONIC WEAPONS
description: Four military contractors have received federal contracts to study hypersonic weapons, including an unmanned bomber. The Northrop Grumman Corporation said yesterday that its six-month contract, from the Air Force and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, calls for it to develop concepts for a ''hypersonic cruise vehicle'' capable of flying at eight times the speed of sound and striking targets 9,000 miles away in less than two hours. A Northrop spokesman, Brooks McKinney, said the contract was valued at about $1.5 million. Similar initial-study contracts went to Northrop's primary competitors, the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Boeing Company, and to the closely held Andrews Space in Seattle, a Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency spokeswoman, Jan Walker, said in an e-mail message.

title: Insurer Backs Off on Call For Refund of Therapy Fees
description: Oxford Health Plans said yesterday that it had dropped its demands that psychotherapists refund fees based on the company's claim that the therapists' notes of client sessions were inadequate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELSKY, SAMUEL
description: BELSKY--Samuel. On November 25th, 2003. Beloved husband of Harriet. Loving father of Ilene Gouldman. Adoring grandfather of Elyssa Tamra. Dear brother of Edith Gross and Stanley. President of Concord Lodge of the Free Sons of Israel. Past President of the 94th Infantry Division Association. Service Friday, 11:30AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: W. Fred Turner, 81; Defended Indigent in Key Trial
description: W. Fred Turner, the lawyer chosen to represent Clarence Earl Gideon after the Supreme Court said in a landmark case that the indigent Mr. Gideon had the right to such representation, died on Sunday at home in Panama City, Fla. He was 81.

title: Sprewell's Basis for Comparison Will Be on the Bench
description: There was shock at first in the summer, then arrows piercing paths in the fall.

title: MSNBC Is Clearing Out a Slot in Prime Time
description: MSNBC is reshuffling its lineup again to clear the way for a star, so far unidentified, it hopes to introduce in prime time in the coming weeks, according to a memorandum made available yesterday.

title: Atomic Agency Warns Iran for Secrecy on Nuclear Activities
description: VIENNA, Nov. 24  The International Atomic Energy Agency passed a much-debated resolution today that condemns Iran for covering up its nuclear program for nearly two decades.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bombardier Executive Resigns
description: Bom-bardier, the world's biggest maker of rail equipment, said Pierre Lortie, the transportation unit president, left, was resigning to pursue other interests. Mr. Lortie, 56, spent more than 12 years at Bombardier, the Montreal-based company said. The chief executive, Paul M. Tellier will lead the transportation unit's management committee until the company appoints a new president. Mr. Tellier said last month that he planned to cut executive jobs at the train unit to reduce costs. The business had sales of 2.32 billion Canadian dollars ($1.77 billion) in its second quarter and a profit margin of 4.5 percent.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Kodak To Buy Scitex Printing Unit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, making good on its promise to investors in September that it would bolster its commercial printing portfolio, said yesterday that it would buy Scitex Digital Printing, the inkjet printing division of the Scitex Corporation of Israel, for $250 million in cash. The deal is another step in Kodak's forced migration from its photography past to a hoped-for digital imaging future. It also further blurs the competitive distinctions in the digital imaging world, in which the copier giant Xerox now sells printers and the printer giant Hewlett-Packard sells cameras and copiers. Kodak said the Scitex unit would add $190 million to sales in its first full year as a Kodak subsidiary. More important, it gives Kodak a powerful entry into the growing market for variable-data printing on items like bills and credit card statements, which must be customized for each recipient. And it gives Kodak a vehicle to commercialize some of its own inkjet printing patents. Kodak already sells large printers through NexPress and Kodak Polychrome Graphics and through its Encad subsidiary, but the products are geared toward mass print runs. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: Giants' Offense Is Compromised by a Triple Bogey
description: Giants quarterback Kerry Collins managed a pained smile, even through his disappointment and exasperation after Monday night's game, when he realized just how many times this season he had repeated the same explanation after a loss. He even apologized for the repetition.

title: About New York; From an Alabama Sousaphone, a Fanfare for the City
description: THEY deserved New York. Those who have willingly donned the maroon-and-gold uniforms of the Pinson Valley High School marching band, who have lived to the tweets of their director's whistle, who have played so much upbeat music that they can bring pep to ''Ave Maria.'' Yes, these children of Alabama deserved to participate in that glorified commercial known as the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: Nigerian Says He May Return Liberia's Ex-Leader for Trial if Liberia Asks
description: Having offered asylum last August to Charles G. Taylor, Liberia's former president, who is wanted on war crimes charges, Nigeria said Tuesday that it would persuade Mr. Taylor to face trial in Liberia, should it seek to prosecute him.

title: DEERE REPORTS STRONG SALES AND 3.8% RISE IN PROFIT
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit climbed 3.8 percent, helped by cost cuts and new consumer products. Net income increased to $70.6 million, or 27 cents a share, from $68 million, or 28 cents, in the quarter ended Oct. 31. Sales rose 14 percent, to $3.94 billion from $3.47 billion, the company, based in Moline, Ill., said in a statement. Deere had been expected to earn 18 cents a share last quarter, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. The company's shares rose $1.24, to $61.44.

title: Pension Fund Relief Plan Fails to Clear The Senate
description: A measure that would have let the nation's businesses defer tens of billions of dollars in pension contributions over the next two years was beaten back in last-minute Senate maneuvering yesterday evening, disappointing companies that have been pushing all year for help with their depleted pension funds.

title: Evidence Against Iraq (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Rejects Bid for Extra Year for Sept. 11 Compensation
description: Congressional officials from the New York area conceded yesterday that their last-gasp attempt to extend the deadline for the federal government's extraordinary program to compensate the relatives of Sept. 11 victims had all but failed.

title: Honoring Eugene Istomin
description: A memorial service in honor of the pianist Eugene Istomin will be held on Tuesday at 5 p.m. at Zankel Hall at Carnegie Hall, 57th Street at Seventh Avenue. He died on Oct. 10 at 77.

title: The Shrinking Snows of Kilimanjaro
description: Give credit for bold thinking to Prof. Euan Nisbet, a Zimbabwean scientist now working at the University of London. While the rest of us have been wringing our hands at the accelerating disappearance of glaciers, Professor Nisbet has come up with a proposal to slow the melting of the famous glaciers atop Tanzania's Mount Kilimanjaro, the highest mountain in Africa and an iconic symbol of the continent's beauty. The crux of his plan is to drape huge tarpaulins over the edges of two glaciers to retard their melting and buy time for more lasting solutions. It would be a mammoth undertaking yielding dubious benefits.

title: Nostalgia For a Land That Twirls In Dreams
description: There are some works of animation that are notable for their realism, for conjuring imaginary worlds whose inhabitants -- the sea creatures in ''Finding Nemo,'' the witches and princesses in classic Disney fairy tales, the wide-eyed heroines of Japanese anime -- move in more or less plausible ways through fantastical settings. Others -- the cartoons of Tex Avery and Chuck Jones come to mind -- rewrite the laws of physics and the conventions of physiology to suit their own fanciful requirements.

title: No Difference Found In Clotting and Stents
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that the rate of blood clots found after implantation of a new drug-coated heart stent was no higher than with other stents.

title: Rangers and Markkanen Make Goals Stand Up
description: The Rangers figured to be ripe for a letdown Tuesday night. Their backup goaltender made sure it did not happen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAWER, GERTRUDE
description: FAWER--Gertrude. A woman of valor. We extend heartfelt condolences to her beloved son Martin, Chairman of our Board, a daughter-in-law Estanne and her extended family of grandchildren, stepgrandchildren, and greatgrandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Israel Heart Fund Dr. Morton Leibowitz, Pres. Emily Levy-Shochat, Executive Director

title: The Candidates and the Draft
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about the opening of ''Wonderful Town'' misstated the given name of the director Joshua Logan's wife, who gave a party at the couple's apartment after the show first opened on Broadway in 1953. It was Nedda, not Netta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURKIN, DOROTHEA
description: DURKIN--Dorothea. (Retired Teacher, NYC Board of Education). Beloved daughter of the late Thomas and Mary (nee Cross). Visiting Friday, 9AM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, 10AM, St. Anselm's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOCKOLOW, MURRAY
description: SOCKOLOW -- Murray, of Tenafly, New Jersey. Husband of Gertrude (nee Levy). Father of Nina, Gina, Paulina and Tina. Grandfather of Michael, Julia, Charlotte, Sheri, Aaron, Joshua and Hannah. Services Wednesday 9:15AM ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: Medicare Reform: Who Wins and Loses
description: Taxpayers

title: A 9/11 Memorial for the Living (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Spread of AIDS Fast Outpacing Response
description: While the pace of the battle against AIDS is picking up, efforts to stem the epidemic are ''entirely inadequate'' for the health emergency, which is ''continuing to spiral out of control,'' the director of the United Nations AIDS program said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Detecting a Lineage From Spahn to Schilling
description: IN the spring of 1942, a 20-year-old left-handed pitcher who wound up having no decisions in his four appearances with the Boston Braves that season was pitching in an exhibition game against the Brooklyn Dodgers. At one point Boston Manager Casey Stengel instructed the young pitcher to brush back the batter, Pee Wee Reese. He refused.

title: Preparing for the Feast? Read This First
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER LENDER SEEKS TO SETTLE BORROWERS' LAWSUIT
description: Household International Inc., an American unit of HSBC Holdings, one of the world's largest banking companies, said yesterday that it had proposed settling a lawsuit brought by borrowers and community groups over its lending practices in the United States. Household said the settlement included reducing interest rates and waiving penalty charges for borrowers who had missed payments and were in danger of losing their homes. Household, based in Prospect Heights, Ill., said in a statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would also finance programs to educate borrowers. Almost a year ago, Household agreed to a $484 million settlement of another case in which it was charged with misleading borrowers about their loan terms. The bank specializes in lending to people with a history of not repaying their debts.

title: Saving Animals Is Ex-Pastor's New Mission
description: A MILD allergy to cats does not keep Edward Boks from playing with kittens -- or from working with hundreds of them as the new executive director of the nonprofit organization that handles most animal care and control for New York City.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Queens; Industrial Hub Emerges in College Point
description: For 25 years, Gelmart Industries, a large lingerie company that manufactures its garments abroad, made its home and distribution headquarters in College Point, Queens.

title: New Ways to Defy Old Man Winter
description: Plugging in unseasonable warmth, indoors and out.

title: The Works of a Doomed Romantic
description: A selection of drawings from the Arshile Gorky show at the Whitney Museum.

title: It's Easier to Be Green
description: Residential architects in Los Angeles are experimenting with green design.

title: Defining Home
description: Around the South, a photographer found powerful portraits of pride and place: first-time homeowners and their families, to whom a house was truly home.

title: Turkey Soup for the Soul
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: BERNSTEIN -- Sylvia, in Washington, DC, on November 21. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Bernstein. Mother of Mary, Laura and Carl. We remember a friendship begun at Columbia Law School between Henry and Alfred that lasted through turbulent years with loyalty and understanding. We celebrate Sylvia's beautiful life devoted to human rights and give thanks for the warmth and love she brought into our lives even in the last sad weeks. Jacqueline Schneider & Family

title: Bush Makes Surprise Thanksgiving Visit to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 _ In a stunning mission conducted under enormous secrecy, President Bush flew into Baghdad today aboard Air Force One to have dinner with United States officials and a group of astonished American troops.

title: Valencia Named Host For '07 Cup
description: It has been clear since March that sailing's premier competition, the America's Cup, was returning to Europe for the first time since it began off the Isle of Wight in 1851.

title: Waiting, Unshorn, for a Record-Setting Barber's Return
description: Peter Vita likes to boast that he has cut hair from the days of Morse code to the dot-com era. He started in on the slicked-down scalps of the jazz age and was still at it when boys began showing up in his chair with pierced eyebrows and Mohawks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLON, JULIA
description: BALLON--Julia, on November 25, 2003, survived by daughter Lois and loving grandchildren Adam Granger and Stephanie Rabinowitz. No services. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Daytop.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: How to Obey Schools Ruling? Pataki and Bloomberg Differ
description: A ruling from New York's highest court hangs like a storm cloud over state government this year, putting the Republican administrations of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on a collision course.

title: Damien Hirst Makes a Strategic Purchase: His Own Work
description: Charles Saatchi, the advertising magnate who is one of Britain's largest contemporary-art collectors, has sold the bulk of his collection of works by the British artist Damien Hirst back to the artist and to his dealer, Jay Jopling.

title: Marjorie Deane, 80, Authority on Fashion
description: Marjorie Schlesinger Deane, who advised retail stores on fashion trends through an influential publication called the Tobe Report, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80.

title: Letter From Tikrit
description: Memo to: President Bush

title: House, Painting and Wife Join in Kerry Financing
description: For Senator John Kerry, the five-story red brick house in the exclusive Beacon Hill section of Boston, with its climbing wisteria, antique furnishings and rooftop deck, offers a place of respite from his frenetic campaigning for the Democratic nomination for president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BONDEROW, JACK C.
description: BONDEROW--Jack C. CPA for 50 years and Lieutenant in US Navy and served on USS Brooklyn in WW II. Beloved father of Amy and Selma. Loving grandfather of Alyssa and Dana. Dear father-in-law of Leon and Jim. Funeral services private.

title: CNF Retirees' Pension Suit Is Dismissed By U.S. Judge
description: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by a group of retirees from CNF and its spinoff company, Consolidated Freightways, who said their pensions had been improperly reduced. Judge James Ware of Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., said the retired workers first needed to see if the federal government would intervene in their case.

title: Donald Gratz, Metal Craftsman, Dies at 68
description: Donald Gratz, a craftsman in metal whose creative realizations transformed the renderings of artists and architects into objects of art, died on Nov. 22 at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: 2 HOME DEPOT DIRECTORS WILL NOT SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: Home Depot said yesterday that two directors, including Richard A. Grasso, the former New York Stock Exchange chairman and chief executive, will not stand for re-election next May. Home Depot said in a news release that Mr. Grasso confirmed his earlier decision in June not to stand for re-election to the company's board at the completion of his term in May. The company, the leading home improvement retailer, said the other board member, William S. Davila, 72, had reached the company's mandatory retirement age and would be completing his term next May.

title: Turkish Town's Despair Breeds Terrorists, Residents Fear
description: One of the men believed to be behind the Istanbul bombings of the past two weeks was just a toddler when his father was killed in political violence here. According to acquaintances, the boy grew up with a hurt and a confusion that never went away.

title: Another Listless Effort by the Islanders
description: Islanders Coach Steve Stirling stood behind the team bench Wednesday night, arms folded and tension creased on his face. His body language off the ice and his players' forlorn body language on it told the story of the Islanders' 2-0 loss to the Carolina Hurricanes.

title: Cable Network Unearths Classic Tie From the 60's
description: On Nov. 19, 1966, Notre Dame and Michigan State played to a 10-10 tie, a game remembered for the matchup of the top two college football teams in the nation and for the conservative play-calling of Ara Parseghian, the coach of the Fighting Irish, at the end.

title: Is the U.S. a Success, or a Work in Progress?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Drug Industry Trying To Roll Back Prices Abroad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUECHLER, LEONARD
description: BUECHLER--Leonard. The congregants and staff of Dix Hills Jewish Center are deeply saddened by the death of Leonard Buechler, beloved father of our Rabbi, Howard Buechler. May the family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: INSIDE
description: Atomic Agency Rebukes Iran

title: U.S. to Shift Some Experts From Arms To Antiterror
description: Dozens of the American intelligence experts and linguists sent to Iraq to search for illicit weapons have been reassigned to an expanding effort to learn more about the insurgents attacking United States troops, senior government officials said Wednesday.

title: Key to Ending Hunger
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Guns Fall Silent
description: India and Pakistan observed the first 24 hours of a new cease-fire agreement without any reported violations, military officials said, and villagers along the front line in the disputed territory of Kashmir celebrated the Muslim festival of Id al-Fitr without the daily machine-gun and artillery duels between the armies. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: 10,000 FLEE VIOLENCE At least 10,000 Hindi-speaking settlers in northeastern Assam State have been moved to makeshift government camps to protect them from attacks by Assamese mobs and rebels that have left 54 dead. A night curfew was in force in most parts of Assam with federal soldiers given the power to shoot troublemakers on sight. (Agence France-Presse)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm not saying Santa is gay.''

title: New Ways to Defy Old Man Winter
description: WITH winter less than a month away, mild autumn days will soon give way to chill. This season there are new heaters for every space, indoors and out. One makes serving drinks on the patio possible well into December. For renovators who like the look of tile but shiver at the thought of cold surfaces underfoot, a new radiant heating system provides warmth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAWYER, MICHELLE AN DREWS
description: SAWYER -- Michelle An drews. Of Sturgis, MI, died peacefully in her sleep on November 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Herb, and loving mother of Nina and Billy, cherished daughter of Randall and Winifred Andrews. Memorial service will be held on Tuesday, December 2nd at 4:30 at Grace Church in New York, 802 Broadway at 10th Street.

title: K2 TO BUY FOTOBALL USA FOR $17.2 MILLION
description: K2, the maker of Rawlings sporting goods and Shakespeare fishing equipment, agreed to acquire Fotoball USA yesterday for $17.2 million in stock, to add sports souvenirs like bobblehead dolls, balls and bats. Fotoball stockholders will receive 0.2757 share of K2 for each share of Fotoball they own, K2 said. The transaction values each Fotoball share at $4.37, or 9.8 percent more than the closing price of $3.98 on Tuesday. K2, which is based in Carlsbad, Calif., will also acquire an undetermined amount of Fotoball debt. Shares of K2 fell 43 cents, to $15.27, while Fotoball rose 17 cents, to $4.15.

title: Audio Clips: Vermont Coach Tom Brennan
description: The following are audio excerpts with Vermont basketball coach Tom Brennan, who co-hosts a popular morning radio show on a classic rock station, WCPV-FM, in Burlington (.mp3 format):

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Areva To Build Nuclear Plant
description: Areva, France's government-controlled maker of nuclear-reactor fuel, said it would spend 3 billion euros ($3.6 billion) on building a uranium-enrichment plant and acquiring the necessary technology. The investment includes the purchase of a 50 percent stake in the Enrichment Technology Company, owned by Urenco, a uranium-processing company established by Britain, Germany and the Netherlands in 1971. France relies on nuclear power for about three-quarters of its electricity, more than any other country in the world.

title: Hearing Aid and Cellphone Call a Truce
description: Wireless technology has not been kind to most people who wear hearing aids: because the older models lack internal shields to segregate digital frequencies, the devices are vulnerable to interference from cellphones. As a result, some 12 million people around the world are said to hear a buzz or static during cellphone conversations.

title: Duty, Honor, Country and Combat
description: Of course Graham White wanted to play in the National Football League, and he had the ability to make it. He averaged 44.1 yards a punt during his career, best in Army history, good enough to lure pro scouts to West Point and to be invited to the Blue-Gray Classic in his senior season. But though unique among the hundreds of potential N.F.L. players leaving college in the spring of 1999, White had something to do that was more important than playing football on Sunday afternoons.

title: Reports Indicate the Economy Is Continuing Its Expansion
description: The economy extended last quarter's momentum into October and November, with reports yesterday showing the biggest jump in durable goods orders in 15 months, the fewest weekly jobless claims in three years and higher consumer confidence.

title: Today's N.F.L. Matchups
description: 12:30 p.m. -- Green Bay Packers (6-5) at Detroit Lions (3-8)

title: BEST BUY NAMED IN SUIT OVER SAM GOODY PERFORMANCE
description: The Best Buy Company, the nation's largest electronics retailer, was sued by a shareholder who said the company misled investors last year about the prospects for its former Sam Goody unit. The suit filed last week in Minneapolis said a 36 percent fall in Best Buy shares on Aug. 8, 2002, resulted from revelations a day earlier that Sam Goody stores had performed worse than expected. The suit, which seeks to represent everybody holding Best Buy shares from Jan. 9 to Aug. 7, 2002, said the company issued falsely optimistic information. Best Buy's shares have risen more than 38 percent since the company sold the money-losing Musicland unit, which included Sam Goody, to Sun Capital Partners Inc. in June, and they have more than doubled in value in the last year. Best Buy shares rose 74 cents, to $61.10.

title: Romance, Comedy, Bathos: All Blended by Bollywood
description: Hollywood has Thanksgiving to unleash its end-of-the-year blockbusters; Bollywood has the end of Ramadan, when fasting filmgoers are allowed to return to the theaters. Such is the occasion for ''Kal Ho Naa Ho,'' a Bollywood musical extravaganza, which opens today to Indian audiences around the world.

title: On a Cheap Plastic Grid, Gigabytes Galore
description: IT'S just a humble plastic material, often used as an anti-static coating to keep fluff from clinging to computer screens.

title: Where Thanks Are Due
description: IF the technology industry were a traditional family tonight, sitting down to a Thanksgiving dinner, what would those gathered have to be thankful for? Three rotten post-bubble years? Rising public anger at the decline in customer service? The way viruses, spam and hackers are taking all the fun out of personal computers? Dear Lord, we thank thee for -- uh, the turkey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NESBITT, ELEANOR W.
description: NESBITT--Eleanor W., 81. Devoted mother of Ian and Annie and loving grandmother of Riley. Memorial service Friday 11AM, First Presbyterian Church, NYC. Contributions to YAI Gifts/Donation, 460 W. 34 St, NY, NY 10001.

title: British Authorities Hold Terror Suspects
description: LONDON, Nov. 27  British authorities arrested two suspected terrorists in separate raids today and said one of them was believed to be connected to "the network of Al Qaeda groups."

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Blamed For Legions Of Orphans In Africa
description: More than 11 million African children have lost at least one parent to AIDS, and that number is likely to rise to 20 million by the end of the decade, a report by the United Nations Children's Fund predicts.

title: New Jersey Weighs Ending Parkway Tolls to Raise the Gas Tax
description: As New Jersey Democrats try to muster support for a politically unpopular increase in the gasoline tax, they are considering a plan that would eliminate one of the most reviled features of New Jersey's transportation system, the tolls on the Garden State Parkway.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: 2 CAUSES OF COASTER ACCIDENT A fatal roller coaster accident at Disneyland was a result of improper maintenance and operators who had not been told to act if a ride made an unusual noise, state investigators said. The report, by the Occupational Safety and Health Division, said outside machinists did not understand or follow the park maintenance procedures and operators were not given correct guidelines. One rider, Marcelo Torres, 22, of Gardena, was killed on Sept. 5 on the Big Thunder Mountain Railroad coaster. On Tuesday, Disney officials said poor maintenance caused the accident. It is unclear when the ride will reopen. (AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: Transit Workers Sickened by Unknown Substance
description: Six city transit workers were overtaken by fumes yesterday morning while cleaning debris in the subway tunnel of the F line near 21st Street, Fire Department officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: MAN SENTENCED IN STABBING SPREE A man convicted of stabbing four members of a Queens family, killing two and seriously wounding the others, was sentenced yesterday to 39 years to life in prison. The man, Moo Chul Shin, 31, pleaded guilty last month to killing his former lover, Sook Kim, 34, and her daughter, Clara, 7. He also pleaded guilty to the attempted murder of Mrs. Kim's husband, Hyun Kim, 38, and their daughter Estelle, 8. In 2002, Mrs. Kim left her family for Mr. Shin, of Springfield, Va., but later returned to her family in Queens, the authorities said. In January, Mr. Shin tracked down and attacked Ms. Kim and her two daughters. He then attacked Mr. Kim at a nearby parking lot in Elmhurst. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; Aunt and Nephew Look Forward to a Healing Tradition
description: Markee Truesdale, 13, stood at an electronic keyboard in his East New York, Brooklyn, apartment and picked out the ''Ode to Joy'' theme from Beethoven's Symphony No. 9. He taught himself to play after playing the violin for five years.

title: Market Place; Hot Options in Cold Stock, for No Apparent Reason
description: Is it a sign of rampant speculation? Of market manipulation? Of a short squeeze? Or could someone possibly know something?

title: A Projector for Your Carry-On
description: Plus Vision, a maker of miniature projectors that have been sold under other companies' brands, has put its own name on a new line of mobile projectors.

title: Taiwan Passes Independence Referendum Law
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Nov. 28  Taiwan's legislature took a half-step back on Thursday night from an immediate confrontation with China, passing a bill that would allow national referendums on constitutional and sovereignty issues only under very narrow circumstances.

title: Arrests in Iraq
description: The wife and daughter of a close aide to Saddam Hussein, Izzat Ibrahim, are being held for questioning after being captured by soldiers, a military spokesman, Master Sgt. Robert Cargie of the Fourth Infantry Division, said Wednesday.

title: U.N. Atom Agency Gives Iran Both a Slap and a Pass
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency passed a much-debated resolution on Wednesday that condemns Iran for covering up its nuclear program for nearly two decades but stops short of urging action by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Listening to the Nation Through Latino Voices
description: The performance trio Culture Clash has been traveling the country much of the last seven years, creating city-specific shows from interviews with local citizens.
