The troupe members are Richard Montoya, who is Chicano, and Ric Salinas and Herbert Siguenza, who have Central American roots.

title: For a Republican Squabble, $25 Million Worth of Balm
description: It is no secret that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City is no fan of Representative Tom DeLay, the House's conservative majority leader. Recently, the mayor said New Yorkers might want to think twice before making any campaign donations to Mr. DeLay, a fellow Republican.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Arrested In Stabbing
description: Detectives have arrested two men suspected of stabbing three others in a gang-related attack on the Upper West Side, the police said yesterday. Jose Reyes, 19, and Lening Ponce, 18, both of Washington Heights, are charged with gang assault, a felony, which carries a sentence of up to 25 years, a spokesman for the Manhattan district attorney's office said. Around 3 a.m. on Monday, three boys, all 16, were stabbed at the corner of 66th Street and Broadway. Two have been released from New York Hospital, but the remaining victim, who was stabbed many times in the torso, remains in serious condition, the police said. The victims' names have not been released because of their age. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: A San Francisco Design Store That Offers the Right Touch
description: ''Great design in a friendly, open atmosphere,'' said Mark Lenox, a former product development and branding specialist, describing Friend, his new store in San Francisco. Shunning the ''look, don't touch'' aura of many design stores, Mr. Lenox turned to Fuseproject, a design firm in San Francisco, and its owner, Yves Bhar. (The men met when Mr. Lenox, who was at Birkenstock, hired Mr. Bhar to design a line of shoes.) The result blends natural and manufactured materials, like warm rough oak and recycled rubber. Well-known designers line the shelves, including Kartell, Alessi and Karim Rashid, whose lime green chair with chrome legs (made by Magis, $250) is shown, left, next to office products by Lexon ($15 to $100). The store also carries the work of emerging designers, including lighting by Pablo, a Bay Area company; bent-plywood furniture by Offi of San Francisco; and leather goods by Patch NYC of New York. Friend is at 401 Hayes Street (Gough Street; (415) 552-1717).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEWIS, GLYN
description: LEWIS--Glyn Always, Bett

title: If Nature Could, Nature Would: All-Purpose Synthetic Sisal
description: Floor coverings of synthetic sisal, a woven vinyl from Bolon, look natural but can be mopped or scrubbed. They are on sale from Dec. 3 through 17 for $29 a square yard from the Curran catalog, (800) 555-6653 or www.curranonline.com (password, banana). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the Giants' 19-13 loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Monday misstated the Buccaneers' scoring in some copies. They had two touchdowns, one field goal and a safety, not two touchdowns and two field goals. The article also misstated Tampa Bay's record of victories at home this season; this was the second, not the first.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Debt Rating Raised
description: Moody's Investors Service raised its crucial rating on Thailand's debt to reflect the country's improving economy. The agency raised its rating on Thailand's long-term foreign-currency denominated debts to Baa1 from Baa3, saying record foreign reserves, falling levels of foreign debt and rising exports had increased the country's creditworthiness. The upgrade, which placed Thailand on par with neighboring Malaysia, helped send Thailand's benchmark stock index up 4.3 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Captain Fired After Refusing To Aid Inquiry Of Ferry Crash
description: City officials yesterday fired the captain of the Staten Island ferry that plowed into a pier last month, killing 10 people, because they say he refused to cooperate with investigators.

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Maze: A Survival Guide
description: IT'S not hard to find the television department in a 60,000-square-foot cathedral of electronics. Just close your eyes and listen for the explosions.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Sad Sack, Unclothed

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: How Women Won the Holidays
description: More than the Pilgrims, Sarah Josepha Hale gave us Thanksgiving. Until she came along in the early 19th century, the only national holiday was Independence Day, and it involved things that were only done by men -- parading down the street, creating large explosions, consuming massive quantities of liquor. The women were relegated to the role of spectator, waving their handkerchiefs decorously from the front yard, or serving as decorations on the occasional float. Mrs. Hale wanted a holiday that took place on the women's home turf, with the kitchen holding center stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAURITANO, NATALIE FERAZZI
description: LAURITANO--Natalie Ferazzi. Died on November 25, 2003 at her home in Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Amedeo Lauritano, a former NYC judge. Sister of Dr. Pat Ferazzi. Cherished mother of Lois Lauritano and Natalie Wassong. Devoted grandmother of Fletcher, John and Chris Daly, adoring great grandmother of Emma Grace and Elizabeth Rose Daly. Beloved aunt of Marie Halloran, Frank and Peter Gudicello, and her nieces and nephews. A special woman cherished by all who knew her. She will remain in our hearts always. Memorial Mass at Sacred Heart of Mary & Jesus, 10am, December 2. Contributions may be made to Cabrini Hospice 227 E. 19th St, NYC.

title: Financial District Security Getting New Look, Welcomed by Businesses
description: As public space, the eight blocks around downtown's greatest crossroads -- Wall and Broad Streets, the front yard of the New York Stock Exchange, Federal Hall National Memorial and the original headquarters of J. P. Morgan & Company --never fully recovered from Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Beatrix Farrand's Secret Garden
description: THE last home and garden of the landscape gardener Beatrix Farrand, an intimate retreat she created here in 1955 at the age of 83, has long gone unnoticed, even by Farrand scholars. Tucked behind a farmhouse, the retreat, Garland Farm, has changed hands only twice since her death in 1959, both times to gardeners who knew enough not to change it.

title: Mistrial Is Declared in Tax Withholding Case
description: Jurors in Fort Worth failed to reach a verdict Tuesday in the trial of a Texas businessman who has not withheld taxes from his workers' paychecks since 2000, the second significant setback in four months for the federal government in tax cases.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about three officials who preserved the World Trade Center artifacts now on display at the New-York Historical Society gave their identifications out of order in some copies. Seated from the left were Special Agent Richard B. Marx of the F.B.I., wearing a light tie; Police Inspector James Luongo, in a red tie; and Assistant Chief Dennis Diggins of the Sanitation Department, in uniform.

title: It's Easier to Be Green, Thanks to a Utility Rebate
description: The Natural Resources Defense Council may have set high standards for environmentally aware design with its new building in Santa Monica, but its architects are not the only ones embracing solar power, nontoxic materials and energy efficiency. Walter Scott Perry, below, an architect and the founder of Ecotech, a practice he describes as melding ''ecology and technology in a harmonious way,'' did it the cheap and cheery way: he remodeled his 1950's tract house in the Hollywood Hills by reusing rather than replacing fittings and materials. He added solar panels to generate electricity and a sun screen supported by yellow powder-coated tubing, bottom left, which shades the house. He purchased his panels and screen off the shelf at local stores. With a rebate from the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, his out-of-pocket cost was around $12,000.

title: Is the U.S. a Success, or a Work in Progress?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Microwave Graduates From Sous-Chef to Star
description: THE pride of Delores Cole's kitchen in Lusby, Md., used to be the range. ''We got a gas stove because I hate electric stoves, I burn everything on them,'' Mrs. Cole said.

title: National Briefing | West: Texas: Reinstating Ex-Narcotics Detective
description: The Dallas Police Department will reinstate a narcotics detective who was acquitted by a federal jury on Tuesday of charges of concocting evidence and lying to F.B.I. agents. The trial of the detective, Mark De La Paz, was a result of a Justice Department investigation into the arrests of dozens of Hispanic immigrants in cases that collapsed when the drugs offered as evidence proved to be harmless substances. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Viennese Maverick
description: The pianist Alan Feinberg is most often heard playing American music of the early 20th century, most notably by Ives. But he set that repertory aside on Nov. 20 to play a program he called "Haydn Reconsidered" at the Miller Theater.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Convicted Officers Seek New Trial
description: Lawyers for a group of former Orange, N.J., police officers convicted of violating the civil rights of a fellow officer's suspected killer argued on Tuesday that the group deserved a new trial because a laboratory technician might have bungled blood evidence. Prosecutors argued, however, that the blood evidence was not crucial to the conviction for conspiring to violate the suspect's rights. The suspect, Earl Faison, died from an asthma attack after a beating, and blood from a sidewalk was identified as his. The judge, John C. Lifland, did not say when he would rule. Last March, an F.B.I. laboratory technician admitted mishandling the evidence from scores of cases, including the Faison case. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: The Blessings Of Having Just Enough
description: In the early 1990's, archaeologists from the University of Arizona examined samples of household garbage in Tucson on the Monday after Thanksgiving. Their purpose was to decipher the nature of the feast by deciphering the garbage, as a scholar might examine the kitchen middens in the remains of an ancient village. They broke each sample into a list of ingredients, from ''faunal material'' -- turkey bones -- to ''beverage related'' items, like the plastic ring from a six-pack. The hardest task these archaeologists faced was trying to draw conclusions only from the physical evidence, as if they were not members of the culture that produced it.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Changing Tastes

title: Once World Leader in Traffic Safety, U.S. Drops to No. 9
description: The United States, long the safest place in the world to drive and still much better than average among industrialized nations, is being surpassed by other countries.

title: Looking for the Perfect Mix? Create One of Your Own
description: If years of music lessons have proven that your child is not the next Mozart, take heart. With the Mixman DM2, there's still a chance for fame as a decomposer.

title: Drug Company Halts Trials Of Procrit
description: Several clinical trials of a widely used anemia drug have been halted in the last few weeks after patients developed a higher-than-expected number of blood clots, according to doctors and Johnson & Johnson, the seller of the drug.

title: Report cites stigma and discrimination : With fear's help, AIDS is spreading
description: MANILA:  The climate of fear surrounding AIDS is hampering efforts to curb the spread of the disease and creating the environment for the epidemic to worsen, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.

title: Audrey B. Love, 100, a Patron of the Arts
description: Audrey B. Love, a philanthropist and patron of the arts, died on Saturday at her home in Key Biscayne, Fla. She was 100.

title: Testimony Ends in Hearing for Hinckley
description: After four days of testimony, a federal hearing to determine whether John W. Hinckley Jr.'s mental condition has improved enough to permit him unsupervised visits with his parents concluded on Wednesday without a ruling. Witnesses included several mental health experts and Mr. Hinckley's mother.

title: St. John's Gains With Help From a Penalty-Kicks Specialist
description: This time, St. John's Coach Dave Masur was not playing a hunch; he was using a tested strategy.

title: Fate of Idle Ex-Fighters Poses Challenge for Liberia
description: Schooled in the jungle insurgency of Sierra Leone, drafted into one of this country's most dreaded fighting units, Tejan Fofanah now spends his days peddling cigarettes on street corners.

title: Backup's Backup Emerges for Ravens at Quarterback
description: Five days before the Ravens began their season, they gathered inside a hotel in downtown Baltimore for a banquet with a few fans and the United Way, which was honoring the team's owner, Art Modell. Each Raven walked across the stage and was introduced by Coach Brian Billick. When it was the turn of the third-string quarterback, Anthony Wright, Billick spoke of what a hard worker Wright was, how Wright helped set the right climate among the younger Ravens and how he was a valuable part of the team.

title: Is the U.S. a Success, or a Work in Progress? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, DORIS
description: SOLOMON--Doris. On November 26, 2003. At age 81 after a brief illness. Adored wife of Max, cherished mother of Steven, Susan and the late Cindy. Beloved mother-in-law of Bess Miller and devoted grandmother of David and Matthew. Services Friday at 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NASSETTA, ANTHONY F.
description: NASSETTA--Anthony F., 82 of North White Plains, NY. Died November 25, 2003. Structural Engineer with Weiskopf & Pickworth for 40 years, Partner for 26 years. Led engineering of NYC skyscrapers including The Lever House, One Liberty Plaza, Union Carbide Corporate Offices, and the Texaco Headquarters in Harrison, NY. Survived by devoted wife, Cecelia; son, Anthony P; grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Calling Hours Friday 2-4, 7-9 at Hawthorne Funeral Home, Hawthorne, NY 914-769-4404 www.hawthornefuneral home.com. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Name of Jesus Church, Valhalla, Saturday, November 29, 10AM.

title: U.S. Sending Officials to Georgia to Offer Help on Transition
description: The United States will send a team to Georgia next week to determine the needs of the transitional government that took power after the ouster of the country's president, officials said Wednesday.

title: A Place for the Weary Head With an Active Imagination
description: NotNeutral, a spinoff of the Los Angeles architecture and design firm Rios Associates, has introduced a line of striking pillows with silk-screened patterns in red, black and white cotton (14 by 18 inches; $48). ''We wanted to make the most graphic statement we could,'' said Julie Smith, the company's president. One, below, is an abstract apple. NotNeutral is at 6824 Melrose Avenue (Orange Drive); (323) 692-0015 or (800) 270-6511; www.notneutral.com.

title: Attacks on G.I.'s in Mosul Rise as Good Will Fades
description: Since the Americans came to town seven months ago, the firefighters in this northern Iraqi city have gotten new trucks and new uniforms, American training and salaries 10 times larger than they used to be.

title: How to Rule Georgia
description: To the Editor:

title: J.P. MORGAN CHASE TO PURCHASE CITIGROUP UNIT
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that it would buy Citicorp Electronic Financial Services, a unit of Citigroup, for $380 million in cash to expand its payment card services. The new unit, which sells prepaid payment cards used in place of food stamps, adds to J.P. Morgan's wholesale payment services operations, the bank said in a statement. The purchase follows J.P. Morgan's acquisition this month of the corporate trust unit of the Bank One Corporation for $720 million.

title: Georgian Opposition Unites Behind a Single Candidate
description: The young and passionate leader of Georgia's popular revolt became the front-runner for the presidency on Wednesday when the opposition united behind him as its sole candidate.

title: For Right Price, a Bit of the Moon, Perhaps
description: The desk set -- a few pieces of plastic amateurishly glued together -- is battered and scratched. The pen was snapped off years ago. On the left side is a yellowing blob of epoxy in the shape of a rock. On the right is a small plaque: ''Presented to Joe Healy from his friends at LRL.''

title: Hal Walker, 70, Television Correspondent
description: Hal Walker, one of the first African-American journalists on television news in the 1960's, died Tuesday in his home in Reston, Va. He was 70.

title: A Special Vision Of Contemporary And Classic
description: The Blackman Cruz furniture store in Los Angeles, which celebrates its 10th anniversary this week, is patronized by those seeking not a trademark style but the idiosyncratic taste of the store's owners, Adam Blackman and David Cruz. Annie Leibovitz, Jorge Silvetti and Megan Mullally are among customers tempted by a range of pieces including furniture by Frank Lloyd Wright and Gio Ponti and limited-edition bronze hearts by a contemporary sculptor, Jeff Price. The wrought-iron Octopus lamp (left; 78 inches high, $2,800) was created for the store by Kathleen O'Keefe, a designer in Anchorage, Alaska. Blackman Cruz is at 800 North La Cienega Boulevard (Waring Street); (310) 657-9228.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Another Roaring Farewell
description: A Concorde jet took off, broke the sound barrier and landed for what British Airways said would definitely be the last time after a series of farewells to supersonic flying. The 95-minute spin from London to Bristol in southwestern England via the Bay of Biscay carried 100 British Airways staff members back to Filton Airfield, from which Concorde first flew in Britain in 1969. It was the fifth commemorative occasion since Concorde's last commercial flight from New York to London on Oct. 24. Air France retired its Concorde fleet last May. British Concordes are to be displayed in several places around the world, including New York. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: $10.5 MILLION IN THE GARBAGE A garbage strike in the Chicago region is proving sweet to two lottery winners who had mistakenly thrown their $10.5 million ticket in the trash. The two, Ezekiel Garnett, 27, and his sister Karen, 24, bought an Illinois Lotto ticket on Oct. 4 in Niles but threw it out without checking the numbers. Their mother heard that a ticket sold in Niles was a winner, and she checked the trash with her daughter. Thanks to the nine-day garbage strike last month, the winning ticket was in a bag waiting to be picked up. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 23 about Richard George, who is leading an effort to preserve beachside bungalows in Rockaway, Queens, misidentified the newspaper that publishes the columnist Jimmy Breslin, who made a comment about Rockaway that Mr. George recalled. It is Newsday, not The Daily News. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Asbestos Workers Set Strike Deadline
description: The union representing 2,500 asbestos, hazardous-waste and lead-removal workers in New York City and on Long Island said its workers would go on strike on Monday unless a contract was reached. The union, Local 78 of the Laborers' International Union of North America, said in a statement on Tuesday that the main issues were wage increases and the prevention of any reduction in health coverage. The union is negotiating with the Environmental Contractors Association, which represents more than 30 companies. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Job Transformed: Paper-Pusher to Junkyard Dog
description: William Francis Galvin acquired the nickname ''Prince of Darkness'' during his 16 years as a state representative, when he was known for covertly cutting deals and drawing up legislation well into the night.

title: School Is Haven When Children Have No Home
description: The public school system helps Mariah Miller, a first-grade pupil at Park Elementary here, survive homelessness.

title: Johnny Cash's Legacy Of Emotions, on CD's
description: ''I'll play you one song,'' the record producer Rick Rubin said over the telephone. Two clicking sounds could be heard in the background. Then a voice, singing, came through the earpiece: ''I never thought I needed help before/Thought that I could get by by myself.''

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Special Note of Thanks Goes to the THG Tipster
description: UNTIL now, familiar names have always been the recipients of these Thanksgiving Day thank-you notes to the good people in sports' little corner of the world. But this year there's a mystery guest:

title: Downtown Hospital Plans Expanded Emergency Room
description: The central courtyard at NYU Downtown Hospital -- which served briefly as an open-air ward on Sept. 11, 2001, after the emergency room and cafeteria filled beyond capacity with the injured -- will become the site of an expanded emergency room.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about ''In America'' misstated the given name of the actress who plays Christy. As shown in the credit listing and in a picture caption, she is Sarah Bolger, not Elizabeth. In summarizing the plot, the review reversed details about Christy and her sister, Ariel (played by Ms. Bolger's real sister, Emma). Ariel is the chirpy sister; Christy is the watchful, reserved one. And it is Christy, not Ariel, who composes a child's diary with her video camera.

title: Decoding the New Cues In Online Society
description: A SOCIOLOGIST among geeks and a geek among sociologists, Danah Boyd has 278 friends who link her to 1.1 million others.

title: Is the U.S. a Success, or a Work in Progress?
description: To the Editor:

title: Activists Call for a Reptile Museum to Close
description: Animal activists said on Wednesday that they were outraged by a history of problems at the Long Island Reptile Museum and called for the gallery of snakes, lizards and turtles to be shut down.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the relative emphasis of foreign and domestic policy in the presidential campaign of Gen. Wesley K. Clark misidentified the political figure who said that while foreign policy mattered little in elections in the 1980's and 1990's, that might change in 2004. He was Tony Podesta, a Democratic strategist, not his brother, John Podesta, President Bill Clinton's last chief of staff.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 435 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Fruit of the Vine Beckons From Afar
description: SOON after I moved to California last year, I went to a supermarket on a Sunday morning at 9. At first, all seemed normal. Inside the store, I untangled a cart, headed resolutely past the cheese case and consulted my list.

title: Brazil Posts Growth, but Is Short of Goal
description: Brazil has dragged itself out of recession, posting 0.4 percent growth in the third quarter over the previous three-month period, according to data released on Wednesday. But the anemic recovery is still a far cry from the ''spectacular growth'' promised for this year by President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the finances of Michael Jackson, who was arrested on charges of child molesting, misstated his characterization of the accusations in some copies. He has called them ''a big lie,'' not ''big lies.''

title: Pass the Sour Grapes, Not Sweet Potatoes
description: Congress broke for Thanksgiving with a final burst of partisan recriminations over the conduct of a session that produced Medicare changes, tax cuts and hard feelings certain to spill over into the 2004 campaign.

title: 'Portable' Number, Just Out of Reach
description: THE warnings were clear. When Cellphone Number Liberation Day arrived on Monday, there was to have been chaos as millions rushed to be among the first to take their old cellphone numbers with them to new carriers. AT&T Wireless cautioned on its Web site that ''you may want to wait for the dust to settle before you consider making a move.''

title: Corrections
description: A review and a picture caption yesterday about the animated film ''The Triplets of Belleville'' misspelled the given name of the writer and director. As shown in the credit listing, he is Sylvain Chomet, not Sylvan. The review also misspelled the name of a character cited as an example of cultural stereotypes in past cartoons. It is Pep Le Pew, not Le Peu.

title: Ahold Says U.S. Inquiry Involves Suppliers
description: Besides reporting disappointing third-quarter results, Royal Ahold said on Wednesday that regulators in the United States are investigating some suppliers of its U.S. Foodservice subsidiary in relation to a $1.1 billion accounting scandal earlier this year.

title: Four Walls That Change the World
description: ''I picked this house because of a dream,'' Pearlie Mae Seals of Orchard Village, Tenn., told Bill Bamberger, a photographer, in 1994.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mets Showing Little Urgency Over Bullpen
description: As the Mets continued negotiating with the free-agent second baseman Luis Castillo, they made little progress in filling two holes in their bullpen yesterday. They are not one of the teams that have made an offer to the free-agent closer Keith Foulke, and they were waiting to respond to reliever John Franco's latest contract request.

title: Former Boeing Official Denies Misconduct
description: The Boeing Company's former chief financial officer, Michael M. Sears, who was dismissed on Monday, denied yesterday that he violated company policy after Boeing said he improperly had a meeting with an Air Force official to discuss hiring her.

title: These Days, It's Good to Be Gold
description: Gold briefly passed $400 an ounce yesterday and that might make many investors finally take notice, although gold has been in a bull market since April 2001, rising more than 50 percent in that time.

title: Forecast for Global Growth Is Raised Slightly
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has predicted that an increase in global trade in the next two years will bolster a United States-led economic recovery and reduce unemployment across the 30 industrialized nations that are its members.

title: Economic Scene; Does Medicare or private insurance do a better job of controlling health care costs?
description: GIVEN the passage this week of Medicare legislation, which would privatize much more of this vast program than anyone expected, you might think there would be plenty of evidence that such a shift would reduce the growth of health care costs over time. After all, that is the main reason the bitterly fought bill passed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTLIEB, DAVID L.
description: GOTLIEB--David L. on November 26. Beloved husband of Bernice, loving father of Peter and Diane, James, and Judith and Neal. Grandfather of Nina, Daniel and Iris, Naomi, Bigi, and Hannah. Brother of Enid and Lee Blaymore. A wonderful man. Services Friday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Members Criticize Eminem
description: City Council members denounced lyrics by the rap performer Eminem as racist and misogynist, and called upon the music industry to make reparations to communities they say are hurt by rap-inspired violence. The Source magazine recently released a recording of a decade-old song by Eminem, who is white. Eminem is quoted as rapping, ''Black girls are dumb, and white girls are good chicks.'' At City Hall yesterday, Councilwoman Yvette D. Clarke, above, of Brooklyn and Councilman Leroy Comrie of Queens singled out Eminem's lyrics. ''Who made it acceptable for hip-hop to be a forum for the denigration of black women?'' Ms. Clarke said. ''Who profits from this madness?'' Eminem said last week that the recording was ''something I made out of anger, stupidity and frustration when I was a teenager.'' Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Apology For Abuse Victims
description: The Christian Brothers, a Roman Catholic order that ran many Irish schools throughout the 20th century, apologized for the actions of a brother convicted Tuesday of sexually abusing boys from 1959 to 1974, at St. Joseph's Reformatory outside Galway. The brother, Maurice Tobin, 71, is the first Christian Brother to be imprisoned for sexual abuse. He received a 12-year sentence for raping 25 boys. He initially faced 140 separate charges. ''The Christian Brothers deeply regret the hurt and pain caused to those who were abused,'' the order said in a statement. More of its members are expected to be charged. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: The Hate Right Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEFF, RUTH
description: SHEFF--Ruth, 76, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Mrs. Sheff is survived by her beloved companion of 28 years Joseph Ehrlich, loving sons, Michael (Honey), Andrew (Danielle), and Dr. Jonathan (Cathy), and grandchildren. Service will be held 1:00PM Friday, November 28, 2003 at Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck.

title: Jets Prepare as if McNair Will Play
description: The Jets had seen the videotape of Tennessee Titans quarterback Steve McNair clutching his right calf in pain, and they shrugged. Opponents have seen McNair sustain injuries before. They have read the injury reports, only to watch McNair, one of the N.F.L.'s toughest players, emerge from the tunnel before a game and beat them after spending days in the trainer's room.

title: The Cartoon Renegades
description: Mainstays of independent animation for half a century, John and Faith Hubley are no longer with us. (John died in 1977, Faith in 2001.) But their presence continues to be felt through a series of retrospectives and tributes, of which the documentary "Independent Spirits: Faith Hubley/John Hubley" is the latest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORWIN, ALLAN ROY
description: CORWIN--Allan Roy. Of New York City, passed away on November 19, 2003. Beloved husband of Gladys, loving son of Irving, of Great Neck, and brother Jules of New York City. He will be lovingly remembered by family and friends. Services private. We will miss you forever. Your friends and family

title: Ramping Up the Suburbs
description: ALL you could hear on Patrick and Sara Price's forested block last Saturday was the drift of autumn leaves and the thunder of seven skateboards on plywood.

title: GARDEN Q.&A.
description: Why Joe-Pye?

title: Op-Art
JOHNSON SHIFTS AD AGENCIES ON 4 BRANDS
description: A division of Johnson & Johnson is changing advertising agencies on four big drug brands with total spending estimated at $200 million. The new agencies replace Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, which was dismissed this month. Campaigns for the Tylenol and St. Joseph brands of analgesics will be created by Deutsch in New York, Marc Monseau, a spokesman for the division, McNeil Consumer and Specialty Pharmaceuticals in Fort Washington, Pa., said yesterday. Deutsch is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies. Alchemy in New York, part of the Lowe & Partners division of Interpublic, which creates campaigns for McNeil brands like Motrin and Imodium, will also create ads for the Mylanta and Pepcid brands of antacids.

title: London Journal; Palace Snoop Reveals All, Down to (Gasp!) Tupperware
description: If no man is a hero to his valet, the same might be said of a family and its footman, particularly if it is the royal family.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: For Short, Just Lady Louise
description: After almost three weeks of pondering, Prince Edward and his wife, Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, have finally decided on a name for their first child, Buckingham Palace said. The girl, born prematurely by emergency Caesarean section on Nov. 8, will be called Louise Alice Elizabeth Mary Mountbatten-Windsor and will be known as Lady Louise Windsor. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: German Concern Catering to Readers' Thirst For Knowledge
description: Taschen, the German publisher, has opened its first bookstore in America, in an enclave of fashion stores in Beverly Hills.

title: Broad Bills Stuffed With Lawmakers' Pet Items
description: In public, members of Congress have spent hundreds of hours debating the future of Medicare and the need for a national energy policy. Behind the scenes, they have spent even more time working on little-known provisions of the legislation that would benefit specific health care providers and energy companies.

title: Seeking the Sublime in the Simple to Mark 9/11
description: THE eight memorial designs being considered for the World Trade Center site seem to have done almost everything they were supposed to do. Except resonate in the public imagination.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on Tuesday about the opening night of the Broadway musical ''Wonderful Town'' misstated the surname of the show's lead actress at one point. She is Donna Murphy, not Marshall.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Choice Of France For Reactor Draws Anger
description: Experimental physics does not usually rouse passions, but the European Union's decision to back a French site as the European candidate for a $5 billion nuclear fusion reactor has left Spanish opposition leaders fuming. Socialist Party leaders cast the decision, which passed over a less costly Spanish proposal, as punishment for Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar's support of the American-led war in Iraq. France, Spain, Japan and Canada have proposed sites for the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor, which would produce the first sustained fusion reactions. The plant would generate thousands of jobs. An international consortium that includes China, the United States, Russia, South Korea and Japan, is expected to decide next month which country will build the reactor. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXEL P.L.C., Bracknell, England, which transports and stores goods for companies, said it would have a one-time gain of $50 million from the sale of shares in an initial public offering by Sirva Inc., Westmont, Ill., owner of North American Van Lines Inc., which Exel kept a stake in after selling it in 1999.

title: The Keyboard as Pencil Box And All-Around Clutter Buster
description: In developing a computer pointing device, Victor Lazzaro and Dean DeVolpi dismantled a number of keyboards. That led to an interesting discovery.

title: For Fassel and Mitchell, Not Many Happy Returns
description: In the wake of the Giants' third consecutive loss, Coach Jim Fassel has not only seen his team tumble to 4-7, but he has also been forced to deal with the disgruntled Brian Mitchell, once one of the best kick returners in football but this season one of the worst.

title: Give Thanks and Life
description: Maybe it's so touching because Alonzo Mourning seemed so tough.

title: The Founding Fathers: For All Their Faults, Gore Vidal Loves Them Still
description: INVENTING A NATION

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lenders Criticize Lead-Paint Bill
description: A coalition of private lenders and nonprofit groups has urged the City Council to oppose provisions in a new lead-paint bill. In a letter sent to the Council this week, they say the bill, which governs the city's removal of lead-paint hazards, would make it more difficult for owners to obtain property liability insurance, thereby discouraging investment in low- and middle-income neighborhoods. Supporters have argued that the bill would provide tax breaks for investors and encourage rehabilitation of buildings. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Sharon Says Palestinians Risk Losing Land Permanently
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 27  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel warned Palestinians today to become more conciliatory or risk losing permanently some of the land they want for a state.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the AIDS activist and educator Evan Ruderman on Friday gave an incorrect surname for her surviving stepmother. She is Vicki Sufian, not Fian.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: G.O.P. Turmoil
description: Reta Hamilton of Bella Vista was reaffirmed as acting chairwoman of the Arkansas Republican Party. The party's Rules Committee rejected a claim to the post by Gunner DeLay of Fort Smith, a former state senator. Mr. DeLay stepped down on Saturday but tried to withdraw his resignation after Ms. Hamilton, who succeeded him, replaced a committee created to examine the party's chaotic finances. Its debt exceeds $250,000, it has laid off five of its six employees, and it expects fines by the Federal Election Commission for campaign finance violations. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Hillary Clinton Visits Soldiers in Afghanistan
description: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan, Nov. 27  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for the deployment of additional foreign soldiers in Afghanistan today in a Thanksgiving visit to American troops here. Senator Clinton, citing recent attacks on aid workers, said reinforcements from the United States or NATO were needed to increase security.

title: For the Moviemaker and Portraitist, a Double-Duty Shooter
description: Most digital still cameras can shoot short videos, and most digital video cameras can shoot low-resolution stills. Fisher's tiny FVD-C1 pocket camcorder outdoes both, shooting 3.2-megapixel stills and full-motion VGA video with stereo sound -- simultaneously, if need be.

title: City Hall Pushes for Savings In Health Costs From Unions
description: The Bloomberg administration is pressing New York City's unions to agree to hundreds of millions of dollars in savings in health care costs to help hold down the city's health insurance premiums and to help finance possible raises for city workers.

title: U.S. PLAN IN IRAQ TO SHIFT CONTROL HITS MAJOR SNAG
description: The American plan to turn over power in Iraq more quickly was thrown into disarray on Wednesday when the country's most powerful cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, made public his opposition to a proposal for indirect elections.

title: H.I.V. Infections Continue Rise, Study Says
description: The number of new H.I.V. cases diagnosed in the United States is continuing to climb, and the most significant rise has been among Hispanics and gay and bisexual men, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPEAR, IRMA
description: SPEAR--Irma. June 12, 1922November 20, 2003. A longtime resident of Redwood City, CA passed away due to complications from diabetes. She is survived by her husband Julius, children Joan and Larry, and grandchildren Katie, Julia, and Andrew. Irma will be deeply missed by friends and family. She touched many lives. She earned her Masters degree in education at New York City College in 1943 at age 21. She taught elementary school and worked in the high school system in Palo Alto, CA for over three decades. She married Julius in 1948 in New York and they moved shortly thereafter to Redwood City, CA enjoying over 54 years of wonderful marriage. Irma enjoyed cooking, entertaining her many friends, playing Mah Jong, and travelling. She was an avid reader and enjoyed/supported local theatre. Memorial services were held on November 24, 2003 at Temple Beth Jacob in Redwood City, CA at 2PM. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, November 30, 2003 at 1:00PM at Hills of Eternity, 1301 El Camino Real, Colma, CA.

title: On Secret Iraq Trip, Bush Pays Holiday Visit to G.I.s
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27  In a stunning mission conducted under enormous secrecy, President Bush flew into Baghdad today aboard Air Force One to share Thanksgiving dinner with United States officials and several hundred astonished American troops.

title: 4 Officers Hurt at School
description: Four Nassau County police officers were injured Wednesday afternoon as they tried to break up a disturbance involving roughly 100 people outside Uniondale High School, the police said.

title: Subway Chain Chooses Coke, Displacing Pepsi
description: In the latest volley of the cola wars, the Coca-Cola Company announced a deal yesterday to become the exclusive supplier of fountain drinks to Subway Restaurants, wooing the chain away from its partnership with the Pepsi unit of PepsiCo.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Sentenced In Stabbing Spree
description: A man convicted of stabbing four members of a Queens family, killing two and seriously wounding the others, was sentenced yesterday to 39 years to life in prison. The man, Moo Chul Shin, 31, pleaded guilty last month to killing his former lover, Sook Kim, 34, and her daughter, Clara, 7. He also pleaded guilty to the attempted murder of Mrs. Kim's husband, Hyun Kim, 38, and their daughter Estelle, 8. In 2002, Mrs. Kim left her family for Mr. Shin, of Springfield, Va., but later returned to her family in Queens, the authorities said. In January, Mr. Shin tracked down and attacked Ms. Kim and her two daughters. He then attacked Mr. Kim at a nearby parking lot in Elmhurst. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: A $400 Cake Wasn't Served, but the Band Played On
description: A bit of show-business disaster surrounded the subdued music of a new quartet led by the alto saxophonist Lee Konitz on Tuesday night at Iridium. Elvis Costello was to make a brief appearance to give Mr. Konitz a cake for his 76th birthday and to sing ''Someone Took the Words Away.''

title: On Acknowledgments, the Inquisition Was Easier
description: Last time, it was the dedication. My book was already at the printer when the editor called to say I had forgotten to dedicate it to anyone. So without thinking I dedicated the book to my 82-year-old mother. When I ceremoniously presented her with the bound galleys, she cried. So did my wife, not so much because she hadn't been chosen but because she wasn't consulted. She has never read the book.

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Are Stymied By Florida's Luongo
description: Roberto Luongo snatched what would have been the Rangers' first three-game winning streak this season out of thin air Wednesday night.

title: Drug Industry Seeks to Sway Prices Overseas
description: Having beaten back price controls on prescription drugs in the United States, the American pharmaceutical industry is trying to roll them back overseas, with help from the administration and Congress.

title: Is the U.S. a Success, or a Work in Progress?
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITH & WESSON SAYS S.E.C. IS EXAMINING 2002 STATEMENTS
description: The Smith & Wesson Holding Corporation, the nation's oldest maker of handguns, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the company's fiscal 2002 financial statements and restatement of earnings. Smith & Wesson intends to cooperate fully with the investigation, the company said. The company, the maker of products that include the .357-caliber Magnum and the .38- and .44-caliber S&W Specials, said in August that it planned to restate earnings for the year ended April 30, 2002. Smith & Wesson hired PricewaterhouseCoopers in March 2003 to replace Stonefield Josephson Inc. as the auditor of its financial statements.

title: Group Wants Investigation of Police Tactics at Miami Trade Talks
description: Amnesty International called on Wednesday for an investigation into police tactics during last week's Free Trade Area of the Americas meetings here, joining a swelling chorus of complaints that the police used unwarranted violence to stifle mostly peaceful demonstrators.

title: Citigroup Bids to Buy a Portion of Hynix
description: SEOUL, Nov. 27  Citigroup has submitted an offer to buy the non-memory-chip operations of Hynix Semiconductor, ending weeks of speculation over a looming bid, Hynix's main creditor, Korea Exchange Bank, said today.

title: Houston And Knicks Win Round 1 Vs. Sprewell
description: Latrell Sprewell's eyes danced circles around this date soon after the Knicks traded him to Minnesota last summer, but Wednesday night at the Target Center, it was Allan Houston who seized the moment.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: G.O.P. TURMOIL Reta Hamilton of Bella Vista was reaffirmed as acting chairwoman of the Arkansas Republican Party. The party's Rules Committee rejected a claim to the post by Gunner DeLay of Fort Smith, a former state senator. Mr. DeLay stepped down on Saturday but tried to withdraw his resignation after Ms. Hamilton, who succeeded him, replaced a committee created to examine the party's chaotic finances. Its debt exceeds $250,000, it has laid off five of its six employees, and it expects fines by the Federal Election Commission for campaign finance violations. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Sprewell Admits It Was Long Night
description: As a disappointing outing neared its end, a glum Latrell Sprewell stood with hands on hips near the top of the circle as Charlie Ward of the Knicks took the game's final free throws. Sprewell chewed gum with his front teeth in a manner that squared his jaw. Even if he tried to smile, he couldn't.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkwagen Expects U.S. Sales To Fall
description: Volkswagen's sales in the United States will fall significantly next year as the company, Europe's largest carmaker, is hurt by two aging models, the strength of the euro and competitors' discounts, the chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, said. Demand for the compact Jetta and midsize Passat cars will decline before the introduction of new versions in 2005, Mr. Pischetsrieder, above, said in a broadcast interview with Bloomberg News. Volkswagen will not increase its sales incentives, now a third of those of competitors. Overall profit should rise next year, helped by growing demand in Western Europe and China, he said. Volkswagen's nine-month operating profit fell 99 percent, to 9 million euros ($10.6 million) in North America, which accounted for 17 percent of revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, JOHN H.
description: FRANK--John H. The Board of Directors and Members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, John H. Frank, whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Steven M. Slaven, President Thomas W. Brock, Secretary

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Granada Reports Year-End Profit
description: The broadcasting company Granada reported its first year-end profit since 2000, and said that its merger with Carlton Communications would save almost twice as much as previously reported. Granada's year-end profit was 53 million ($93 million) before taxes, up from a net loss of 156.2 million a year earlier. The company expects to save 100 million a year by cutting costs after it merges with Carlton in 2004, up from earlier predictions of 55 million a year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: NORDSTROM FAMILY WILL SELL UP TO 5.4 MILLION SHARES
description: Nordstrom, a 102-year-old department store chain, said yesterday that a partnership run by members of the founder's family planned to sell as much as two-thirds of its shares to diversify its holdings. The partnership, the Elmer and Katharine Nordstrom Family Interests, will sell as many as 5.4 million of its 8.2 million shares, the company said in a statement. The partnership holds about 6 percent of Nordstrom's shares. Nordstrom shares have risen 86 percent this year as profit and sales surged.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tech Data Beats Sales Estimates
description: Shares of Tech Data Corporation, one of the largest computer distributors in the world, rose more than 11 percent after the company predicted an increase in sales this quarter higher than analysts had expected. Tech Data gained $3.60, to $36.13, after rising as high as $37.50. The stock had risen 21 percent this year after dropping 38 percent last year. Tech Data's chief executive, Steven A. Raymund, said in a conference call on Tuesday that United States companies are starting to spend more on information technology. Tech Data, based in Clearwater, Fla., will have sales for the fourth quarter, ending in January, as much as 15 percent higher than a year earlier, Mr. Raymund said. He added that spending for information technology ''will grow at a rate somewhat faster than the overall economy, maybe as much as twice as fast in real terms.'' Tech Data is the second-largest computer distributor, behind Ingram Micro Inc.

title: Harris Fills Nets' Need for an Outside Shot
description: As N.B.A. transactions go, Alonzo Mourning for Lucious Harris may not sound like the fairest trade. But the Nets, who must swallow Mourning's four-year, $23 million contract, will take whatever they can get in return.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEITNER, SYLVIA (TZIPPY)
description: LEITNER--Sylvia (Tzippy). In 1940, I was blessed with a beautiful bride. Children and grandchildren made us thrive. In 1989, came the accident and you did not survive. Today, only precious memories remain like an antidote for my loss and pain. With love, Nat

title: Mrs. Claus and Cross-Dressing: A Holiday Tale From New York
description: Gather round, my lovelies. 'Tis that very special season. The turkey is roasting. The family is here. And a flamboyant, guttural-voiced openly gay male cross-dresser is having it out with a unit of a corporate retail conglomerate capitalized at more than $8 billion.

title: Ailing Coach's Removal Roils Holy Cross
description: The verdant, brick-lined campus of the College of the Holy Cross is behind iron gates atop one of seven hills in this dreary central Massachusetts city.

title: Dean Pauses to Reflect on a Brother's Long Trip Home
description: Howard Dean's eyes followed the flag-draped container on Wednesday as four servicemen slowly marched it from a mammoth cargo plane past a military color guard onto the back of a school bus. Dr. Dean did not cry, nor reach for his mother's hand, but simply swallowed hard, once, during the 15-minute ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUTNAM, RUTH ALDRIDGE
description: PUTNAM--Ruth Aldridge on Tuesday, November 25, 2003. Beloved daughter of the late Marguerite A. and John B. Putnam; sister of Sarah P. Lawson and Marion P. Kouns; aunt of seven nephews and nieces, six greatnephews and nieces and four great-great nephews and nieces. Services will be held on Friday, November 28, 2003, 10A.M. at the Church of St. Barnabas, Irvington, New York. Interment Oak Lawn Cemetery, Fairfield, CT.

title: The Terrorists' Bait
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLENGER, MARIE ELI ZABETH ''BETTY'' (NEE DALEY)
description: BALLENGER -- Marie Eli zabeth ''Betty'' (nee Daley) of Flint, MI, age 94, died Sunday, November 23, at her home in Flint. Burial will be in Glenwood Cemetery, Flint. A memorial service will be held in a few months. Mrs. Ballenger was born in New York City on December 5, 1908, and grew up in Manhattan. She was the daughter of a physician who later became the first medical director of the Equitable Life Insurance Company. She later attended Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Class of 1930. Throughout her life, she maintained a family summer home that her father had built in 1900 in eastern Long Island, N.Y. near the Town of Southold. She married William S. Ballenger, Jr., the son of an auto pioneer, a co-founder of General Motors, who was the first treasurer of Chevrolet and Buick. She is survived by four children and two grandchildren.

title: Congress in Review
description: Before heading home for Thanksgiving break, Congress wrapped up most of its business for the year. Here is a look at some of the major items it completed and some of those that were left undone. FINISHED

title: Scrushy Ordered to Repay Loan
description: The former chief executive of HealthSouth, Richard M. Scrushy, must reimburse the company in cash for a $25.2 million loan he paid back with inflated HealthSouth shares that later fell in value, a Delaware judge ruled in an opinion made public by the court yesterday.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill 3 Palestinians in Gaza Strip
description: Israeli troops shot dead three Palestinians on Wednesday night after they were spotted near a road leading to a Jewish settlement in the southern Gaza Strip, according to Israeli military officials and Palestinian medical workers.

title: A Bulge in Misses 8? Digital Scanners Resize America
description: ANN ULRICH knows that her days as a model could end soon. A national survey has just finished taking electronic measurements of a cross section of Americans, the apparel industry is eagerly awaiting the results, and she may find that she's no longer their perfect size 1X.

title: Being Chased by the Big Boys
description: If an entrepreneur has a hot new product, it is a good bet that the big boys will come calling, either to buy him out or drive him out. And they have deep pockets.

title: Astronauts Reporting Odd Noise
description: The two astronauts aboard the International Space Station heard a mysterious metallic sound early Wednesday and reported it to mission control, but NASA officials said there was no indication of a problem.

title: Celebrating Balanchine, From Kinky To Classic
description: The New York City Ballet opened its season on Tuesday night with a low-key prelude to a high-octane celebration that begins in earnest in January.

title: The Un-Pilgrims
description: Three hundred and eighty years ago, a huddled band of Europeans set out across the Atlantic to seek a new life in wilderness America. They survived hardship, gave thanks, ate turkeys and eventually flourished. And every year at Thanksgiving we ignore them.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CHOICE OF FRANCE FOR REACTOR DRAWS ANGER Experimental physics does not usually rouse passions, but the European Union's decision to back a French site as the European candidate for a $5 billion nuclear fusion reactor has left Spanish opposition leaders fuming. Socialist Party leaders cast the decision, which passed over a less costly Spanish proposal, as punishment for Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar's support of the American-led war in Iraq. France, Spain, Japan and Canada have proposed sites for the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor, which would produce the first sustained fusion reactions. The plant would generate thousands of jobs. An international consortium that includes China, the United States, Russia, South Korea and Japan, is expected to decide next month which country will build the reactor. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAWER, GERTRUDE
description: FAWER--Gertrude. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Gertrude Fawer, beloved mother of Martin Fawer. Martin, his wife, Estanne, and his sons, David, Mark, and Andrew, are cherished friends and devoted supporters of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Fawer family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Lottery Numbers
Soldiers Have Thanksgiving Dinner at Abandoned Palace
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 27  Between the previous night's house raid and tonight's street patrol, Specialist Chris Owen found time to cram his mouth full of turkey on the grounds of Qusay Hussein's old palace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTNER, LEONARD BERYL
description: GUTNER -- Leonard Beryl, M.D., 86, died on November 26 from complications due to Alzheimer's Disease. Dr. Gutner received his undergraduate degree from Dartmouth College, a Master's degree from Columbia University and his medical degree from New York University. He is survived by his most beloved and devoted wife, Gloria (Friedman) Gutner. Loving father to his five children, Roger Gutner, Rodney Gutner, Merri Rubin, Nancy Clark and James Gutner. Adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Michael & Samuel Gutner; Tristan & Cassidy Gutner; Spencer & Carly Rubin and Ian Clark. He was predeceased by his brother, Monroe Gutner. Dr. Gutner is also survived by his loving brother-inlaw, Evan Friedman and sisters-in-law, Susan Friedman and Lillian Gutner. A memorial service will be held Friday at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester, Rye, New York at 1:30PM; 914-967-4382. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the relative emphasis of foreign and domestic policy in the presidential campaign of Gen. Wesley K. Clark misidentified the political figure who said that while foreign policy mattered little in elections in the 1980's and 1990's, that might change in 2004. He was Tony Podesta, a Democratic strategist, not his brother, John Podesta, President Bill Clinton's last chief of staff.

title: Bolshoi Ballet Told to Rehire The Ballerina It Dismissed
description: A court here ruled on Wednesday that the Bolshoi Theater must reinstate Anastasia Volochkova, the glamorous ballerina who was fired in September on grounds that she was too heavy.

title: Sweep With a Scanner, Vacuum a Printed Page
description: Q. I do a lot of my research by reading old newspaper articles. Is there a way to scan the text and transfer the content to my computer?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Workers Strike Bombardier Unit
description: All 4,500 workers at Shorts, the Northern Irish subsidiary of the Canadian aerospace manufacturer Bombardier, went on strike to protest low wages and job cuts. The escalation of the six-month-old dispute is the first full walkout at the company since the 1970's, and took place on the day of elections to Ulster's local parliament. Bombardier, which has four plants in the province, says that 1,000 jobs will be lost if a new four-year contract is not put in place, but workers say they deserve a better deal because Irish operations generate greater earnings than its other locations. Unions and management began negotiating hours after the strike began. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: 3 Marine Battalions Are Called to Iraq
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has approved the deployment of three more battalions of marines to Iraq next year and has alerted about 7,900 National Guard and Reserve forces that they may be called up for the mission, the Pentagon announced Wednesday.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Next, Riverdance Will Be Doing It

title: A Celebration With Darker Currents
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt spent most of the Thanksgivings of his presidency at the polio rehabilitation center he founded in Warm Springs, Ga. He carved the turkey while seated beside children in leg braces, and talked about the battle against a dreaded disease. His audience, which grew over the years into the hundreds, was full of what he called the ''Warm Springs spirit'' of pluck and determination, but there was also biting humor and pathos. The holiday menu had politically incorrect offerings like ''Potato Crips,'' and the entertainment included girls in wheelchairs singing ''I won't dance, don't ask me.''

title: Jay-Z Raps On the Fly Like a Man Set to Die
description: Tupac Shakur was shot to death in 1996, but it didn't much hurt his career: he is revered now more than ever, lionized in the new documentary ''Resurrection.'' The Notorious B.I.G. was killed in 1997, but no hip-hop club night or radio show is complete without one of his songs. And 50 Cent reminds everyone how he cheated death: an assassination attempt left him with an appealingly slurred voice and a great back story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISRAEL, JEROME
description: ISRAEL--Jerome, on November 26, 2003. Beloved husband for 56 years of Rosalind, the devoted father of Marilynn Potter and Sandra Testani. Cherished grandfather of Neil. Loving brother of Lillian Durschlag and Doris Kaplan. Services Friday, 1:15PM at ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WACHENHEIM, EDGAR, JR.
description: WACHENHEIM--Edgar, Jr. With great love and sadness, we mourn the passing of Edgar Wachenheim Jr., on November 25, 2003 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Marshall Wachenheim. Devoted father of Scott and Edgar III. He is also survived by a sister, Jessie Burack, seven grandchildren, and four great grandchildren. He loved his family, friends, and community--and he was a constant source of joy to all whose lives he touched. He devoted a good part of his life to helping those in need-and, as a result, he left the world a better place. His unselfish generosity, passion for life, and wise counsel will be greatly missed by all. A service to celebrate Ed's life will be held 10:30 A.M. on Sunday, December 14, 2003 at The Beach Point Club, 900 Rushmore Avenue, Mamaroneck, New York. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to The Edgar Wachenheim Jr Endowment Fund, The Guidance Center, 70 Grand St., New Rochelle, NY 10801.

title: Finding Screen Time for American Indian Voices
description: ELIZABETH WEATHERFORD is speaking in her soft Tennessean voice about the Native American Film and Video Festival that she directs at the National Museum of the American Indian in Lower Manhattan. She founded the festival in 1979.

title: TENET SAYS COURT CUTS EXECUTIVE'S DAMAGES AWARD
description: The Tenet Health Corporation, the giant hospital chain, said a court lowered a $253 million judgment against it by $100 million after reconsidering how to calculate damages for a former executive who sued to receive unpaid promised benefits. An appeals court in California ruled Tuesday that interest owed to John C. Bedrosian on his damages should be calculated from Oct. 3, 2002, instead of April 1995, Tenet said in a statement. That reduced the court's Oct. 30 award to $148 million, after prejudgment interest was cut to about $7 million from $112 million. Shares of Tenet rose 18 cents, to $14.58.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Wounded Woman May Sue Authorities
description: The way has been cleared for a woman who said she had sought police help against her abusive ex-boyfriend, who later shot her and killed himself, to sue the Westchester County district attorney's office and the Mount Vernon Police Department. Justice Nicholas Colabella of State Supreme Court ruled last week that a jury could decide whether the two agencies acted negligently. The woman, Joy Thomas, said she had obtained a temporary restraining order against her ex-boyfriend, Olonzo Davis, but the police denied having a record of such an order, said her attorney, Randolph M. McLaughlin. Yesterday, the county district attorney's office said, ''Ultimately, Olonzo Davis, and Olonzo Davis alone, is responsible for shooting Joy Thomas.'' Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Faith in Charities Still Below Pre-9/11 Level
description: A new survey shows that the number of people expressing strong confidence in charities has risen recently but remains below where it was before the Sept. 11 attacks, which inspired record charitable giving but also new scrutiny of how donations are used.

title: Carter and Cowboys Riding High
description: He was called a loser, a whiny loser at that, and it was almost inevitable that the short tenure of Dallas Cowboys quarterback Quincy Carter would come to a mercifully quick end.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about men who teach in the lower elementary grades misstated the affiliation of Paul Sargent, who has studied male elementary-school teachers. He is an associate professor at San Diego State, not the University of San Diego.

title: Legislature May Restore Cuts in Jobs and Services
description: The budget committee of the Westchester County Legislature plans to recommend that the county restore 236 jobs cut from the county budget and roll back planned service cuts in exchange for an additional increase in property taxes.

title: Standings in Blue Ribbon Pairs
description: A surprising cosmopolitan partnership led the Blue Ribbon Pairs Championship here Wednesday at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Suit Cites Building Flaws in Garage Collapse
description: A lawyer representing the families of two ironworkers killed in the recent collapse of a casino parking garage under construction in Atlantic City filed a negligence lawsuit yesterday contending that improper construction practices doomed the building and the workers.

title: The Perfect Fit of a Marching Band; An American Riddle Leads to a Pennsylvania Shoe Factory
description: The perfect marching band shoe pitches the toe forward to foster the seamless, balletlike movement called the roll step. It might be black if your band is prone to sloppy footwork, because dark colors can mask many a mistake, or white if you have the chops. For marching under the lights on a Friday night, glossy with a patent-leather sheen is best.

title: N.Y.R.A. Hires Director of Security
description: The New York Racing Association, which has been accused of mismanagement and fraud by state officials, named a former deputy superintendent of the New York State Police as director of security yesterday.

title: Is the U.S. a Success, or a Work in Progress?
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Officials Woo Schilling Face to Face
description: Red Sox officials spent yesterday in talks with Arizona Diamondbacks pitcher Curt Schilling, trying to persuade him to waive a no-trade clause and approve a trade to Boston.

title: Defendants In Drug Ring And Still Behind in Rent
description: One of them was chronically behind on his $1,150-a-month rent. Another lived with a girlfriend who has been on welfare for six years. At least one lived with his parents, and most of the others rented unadorned middle-class apartments in outer Queens or Brooklyn.

title: Ford Chairman, Now Confident Of Turnaround, Expects a Profit
description: Despite billions in losses over the last few years, a shrinking market share worldwide and falling credit ratings, the Ford Motor Company is meeting its turnaround targets and is poised to return to profitability and make a run at environmental leadership, Ford's chairman and chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., says.

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTERPRISE PRODUCTS PARTNERS DEBT IS DOWNGRADED
description: The debt ratings of Enterprise Products Partners were cut to the lowest investment grade by Standard & Poor's on concern about the partnership's weaker financial performance. Ratings on about $1.8 billion in debt at the Houston-based pipeline partnership were lowered one level to BBB- from BBB and may be cut again, S.&P. said in a statement yesterday The credit rating company said the outlook was negative for Enterprise Products Partners. The partnership said it planned to sell $100 million of Class B nonvoting limited units to an affiliate of the Enterprise Products Company in December, with the proceeds to be used to reduce debt.

title: Japan Warns Of Tariffs Against U.S.
description: Japan said on Wednesday that it would place tariffs on American imports if the Bush administration did not drop duties that it imposed on some Japanese steel products in an effort to protect American companies.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ban On Net Tax Dead Till 2004
description: A federal ban on Internet access taxes that expired last month cannot be renewed until January. ''Nothing by the end of this year,'' said Carol Guthrie, a spokeswoman for Senator Ron Wyden, a Democrat of Oregon and a sponsor of the bill to make the ban permanent. State and local governments say the law would ban taxes on telecommunications services provided online. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Medicare Transformed: The Policy and the Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Teddy Wilburn, 71, Nashville Music Star
description: Teddy Wilburn, who with his older brother Doyle formed one of the most popular country-music duos in the 1950's and 1960's and later played a vital role in the careers of Loretta Lynn and Patty Loveless as song publisher and manager, died on Monday in Nashville. He was 71.

title: A New York Tradition
description: The Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade featured the usual floats and a controversy over Harvey Fierstein's portrayal of Mrs. Claus.

title: Home Fitness
description:
By SUZANNE HAMLIN
With Thanksgiving over, it's time to recover and start strength training for the continuing holiday marathon.

title: Veterans of Science Laboratories, Chimps Will Soon Get Own Retirement Haven
description: Somewhere beyond the Crawfish Palace, beyond the roadside shops selling horse blankets and twisted alligator claws, beyond the towering casino with the $1 million wall, the future residents will build their homes, or more specifically, their nests.

title: The U.S. And China Test Bounds Of Trade
description: Washington and Beijing are talking these days as if they are in the midst of a trade war. But the words are harsher than the actions on each side, and the two governments seem more intent on keeping domestic constituencies happy than actually picking a fight.

title: John Wesley; Kelley Walker; Shirin Neshat
description: John Wesley

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, November 26, 2003. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: To All of You Who Make Art for Its Own Sake: A Toast
description: Following the trails of friendship, either for young performers or their parents, I found myself recently at two events stocked with aspiring musicians and actors. One was a program of Spanish music by Spanish students at the Manhattan School of Music; the other was an evening of three one-act plays by Horton Foote by second-year students at the Atlantic Theater Company Acting School.

title: Stuck in the Present Tense, Pointing to the Twin Towers
description: While ''World Trade Center'' signs around the new PATH station startled commuters and visitors this week, a smaller but even more poignant graphic remnant of the past was hiding in plain sight across Church Street.

title: A Year of Looking Under Rocks
description: Early in the last century, New York's reformers decided that there was too much politics in public works projects. So they established a new kind of government entity -- called a public authority -- to work at arm's length from the state's grasping politicians. These authorities were supposed to be like private corporations, but with the power to slide around local condemnation or zoning laws to get things built more quickly. And they were allowed to do most of their work in secret.

title: Presidential TV Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Smorgasbord Of Books

title: Guccis President to Stay Despite Top-Level Departures
description: PARIS, Nov. 28  Giacomo Santucci has said he will stay on as president of the Gucci brand within the Gucci Group despite the departure of Gucci's chief executive and star designer, an executive familiar with the company said today.

title: Putting the Bulls Behind Him
description: The joint was dripping with drama. A banner was to be raised at the United Center in honor of a retired Bulls employee, and many wondered what exactly the response from the crowd would be. After all, it was not unusual for him to be booed, even in the midst of phenomenal success. Many remembered how lustily he was reviled by the fans in November 1994 when Michael Jordan's jersey was retired.

title: Residential Real Estate; Building a Home for Artists in Jersey City
description: In the shadow of this city's bustling Hudson River waterfront is an enclave of early-20th-century warehouses, one of them beginning its transformation to 59 condominiums, six of which are reserved for low- and moderate-income artists. The conversion is in anticipation of a proposed designation of a cultural district, which backers argue will not only provide artists a place to live and work, but also link Jersey City's old neighborhoods with its new riverfront.

title: White House Memo; When Foreign Policy Aims and Campaign Needs Clash
description: After spending months trying to recast President Bush as a man devoted to building international coalitions rather than the gun-slinging cowboy of European political cartoons, Mr. Bush's foreign policy team was stunned by the Republican National Committee's new advertising campaign. The spot hailed the president as a man who pre-empts first and asks questions later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPELKE, HENRY
description: SPELKE--Henry. Of Delray, FL, formerly of Stamford, CT. Died Monday, November 24, 2003 in his 95th year. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife, Judy, sons, Robert and Clifford, daughter-in-law Leslie, and grandchildren, Craig, Samantha, Jenna, and Brandon, who will remember him lovingly. Funeral services at Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford, CT 06902, Friday, November 28th at 11 A.M.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Some Like Medals, Some Don't
description: Queen Elizabeth II presented David Beckham, the captain of the England soccer team, with the Order of the British Empire. Mr. Beckham said the award was ''probably the best I have received so far.'' Benjamin Zephaniah, a Rastafarian poet, said he had rejected the same award to protest British imperialism. ''Stick it, Mr. Blair and Mrs. Queen,'' he said. ''Stop going on about the empire.'' Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: China's Hazy Battle With a Scourge
description: To the Editor:

title: Report cites stigma and discrimination as bars to prevention: Fear fuels the spread of AIDS
description: MANILA:  The climate of fear surrounding AIDS is hampering efforts to curb its spread and creating the environment for the epidemic to worsen, the World Health Organization said.

title: 'Independent Spirits' -- 'Faith Hubley/John Hubley'
description: Directed by Sybil DelGaudio

title: Profit Up at Daily Mail
description: Daily Mail and General Trust, the British newspaper company, said yesterday that it had a 1 percent increase in pretax profits for the year ended Sept. 28, to 108 million ($185 million). Circulation revenues were up 2.4 percent, but advertising revenues remained weak, dropping 1.7 percent.

title: Nikki S. Lee -- 'Parts'
description: Leslie Tonkonow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEPAOLA, ANNA VIRGINIA
description: DePAOLA--Anna Virginia, 88, of Boca Raton passed away on Thursday, November 27, 2003 at her residence. Mrs. DePaola worked at Doubleday Publishing House prior to her marriage. She moved to Boca Raton 30 years ago from Valley Stream, NY. She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Joseph, president of Dic-Underhill Construction & Certified Industries, four children: Dennis, Donald, Joanne, & Kathy, 12 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Sinatra Memorial Home, 601 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, 10704 (914) 963-5263. The family requests expressions of sympathy be made to the Putnam-Northern Westchester Women's Resource Center, 935 South Lake Blvd, Mahopac, NY 10541. For information, contact the Babione Funeral Home, (East Chapel).

title: Government Case Shifts Its Focus To Fraud
description: It has been five years since the Olympic bribery scandal broke and there may finally be an answer to the question: Did Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson conduct excessive bid efforts for the 2002 Winter Olympics in secret, or did community leaders know more than they have admitted?

title: FINANCING MOVES BY 2 DEMOCRATS RECAST CAMPAIGN
description: The decisions by Howard Dean and Senator John Kerry to withdraw from the campaign finance system are sharply altering the early Democratic presidential nominating battles in Iowa and New Hampshire, as both candidates pump large sums into those small states in search of a decisive early victory.

title: 900 Taxis? That Won't Fix the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Algerian Bomber's Conviction Upheld
description: A French court upheld the life sentence of an Algerian convicted of involvement in a deadly wave of bombings that shook Paris in 1995. Proclaiming his innocence, Boualem Bensaid, 35, had appealed his 2002 conviction for attempted murder and destruction by explosives. The bombings, which included attacks on subway stops, killed 8 people and injured more than 200. A radical Algerian movement, the Armed Islamic Group, claimed responsibility for some of the bombings, saying it was punishing France for supporting Algeria's military-backed government. Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: Overseas Players Ahead in Bridge Pairs
description: Players from the other side of the Atlantic are showing the way in the American Contract Bridge League's Blue Ribbon Pair Championship here.

title: Three Arrested as Part of European Terror Investigation
description: LONDON, Nov. 28  Italian and German police arrested three north Africans in an investigation of a European-based network, linked to al Qaeda, that has been recruiting extremists to fight in Iraq, according to police.

title: 900 Taxis? That Won't Fix the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Hypocrisy on the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: DaimlerChrysler Heads to Court Over '98 Merger
description: Five years after Daimler-Benz acquired Chrysler to create DaimlerChrysler AG, the deal will go on trial, beginning Monday, in a Wilmington, Del., federal courtroom.

title: A Cornucopia of Cultural Exchange, Beginning With a Martial Arts Hero
description: Looking at ''Black Belt'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem is like watching whiplash in slow motion. The head is moving all over the place, but the body is left behind.
