title: Dolphins Shoot Holes In Dallas Defense
description: The Miami Dolphins and the Dallas Cowboys wore retro uniforms in honor of the Thanksgiving Day game at Texas Stadium. They seemed to have brought retro games as well, with Miami the image of the Dan Marino Dolphins and the Cowboys looking much like the Dave Campo version of last year.

title: No Tinsel, No Santa: Holiday Ads for the Jaded
description: HOPING to avoid a Christmas as blue as the past few, retailers and marketers are experimenting with ambitiously novel ways to woo consumers. Along with traditional trappings like Santa's workshops, decorated store windows and teddy bears as gifts with purchases, shoppers will see an assortment of unconventional campaigns, all intended to encourage the impulse to buy among those bored with or tired of holiday chestnuts (literal and figurative).

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Rise In Tobacco Prices May Ease
description: The Senate approved a government-backed amendment to the 2004 budget draft that would lower the proposed price increase on tobacco, after thousands of tobacconists protested a much steeper tax increase. Under the revised proposal, prices would be raised 8 to 10 percent on Jan. 5, instead of the planned 20 percent that was approved by the lower house a month ago. The amended bill now goes back to the lower house for a vote.

title: Sharon Warns Palestinians: Make Peace or Risk Losing Land
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel warned Palestinians on Thursday to become more conciliatory or risk losing permanently some of the land they want for a state.

title: A 1970's Farm Union Struggle Leaves a Broken Town Today
description: With ''Valley of Tears,'' the director and cinematographer Hart Perry returns to 16-millimeter film he shot in 1979 while working for the Texas Farm Workers Union. The material concerns a strike in Raymondville in South Texas that broke out when union pickers, most if not all of them Mexican-Americans, decided that 25 cents a bushel, the going rate for more than 20 years, was no longer enough to live on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, DORIS
description: SOLOMON--Doris. On November 26, 2003. At age 81 after a brief illness. Adored wife of Max, cherished mother of Steven, Susan and the late Cindy. Beloved mother-in-law of Bess Miller and devoted grandmother of David and Matthew. Services Friday at 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: At Least, Strengthen the Grid
description: We were happy when Republican leaders abandoned an awful, pork-laden energy bill before the holiday recess. The bill did, however, contain a few useful provisions, one of which deserves to be resurrected the moment Congress returns to work. It would require the federal government and the utility industry to write mandatory rules for the operation of the power grid. The goal is to make America's electrical transmission system more reliable and fix some of the things that may have contributed to the August blackout.

title: Kelley Walker
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Howard Dean's support among black voters misstated his age. He is 55, not 54.

title: Brooklyn Tire Slashings May Be Bias Crime, Police Say
description: For the second time in less than a week, scores of tires in the largely Jewish neighborhood of Borough Park, Brooklyn, were slashed before dawn yesterday, leaving residents frightened that the vandalism may portend a rise in anti-Semitism. The police vowed to step up patrols in the area to try to prevent the problem from growing.

title: Islands in the Desert
description: IN the southern Arizona desert, some two dozen mountain ranges stand between the Sierra Madre Occidental in Mexico and the Galiuros northeast of Tucson. These high, massive arcs of ancient rock, with peaks up to 11,000 feet, are the sky islands of Arizona, and a hike into their upper regions can take you through six different climate regions, each marked by a sharp contrast in vegetation. Page 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARZ, MARIE (KLAUBER)
description: SCHWARZ--Marie (Klauber), died on November 24, 2003. Widow of Dr. William A. Schwarz. Interment Sunday at Linden Hills Cemetery, Queens, NY. Larson Funeral Home, Bridgeport, CT.

title: The Barefoot Doctor Fights AIDS
description: Debate about helping the world's 40 million people with the AIDS virus has focused on how to make expensive antiretroviral drugs accessible in poor countries. But even more costly and challenging to supply than medicines is people. Trained workers are needed to make diagnoses, treat patients, provide testing and counseling, and manage labs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRUPP, A. PHILIP
description: KRUPP--A. Philip of Chestnut Hill, MA and Palm Beach, FL, entered into rest November 26, 2003. He was the beloved husband of Bernice (Carlin). Dear son of the late Gussie and Joseph Krupp. Devoted father of George and Lizbeth Krupp (Rickles), Douglas and Judith Krupp (Hurwitz) and Joanne Krupp. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Richard, Daniel and Alex Krupp and Justin Sacks-Wilner. Loving brother of William Krupp, and the late Henry, Frederick and Maxwell Krupp. Brother in-law of Doris Krupp, Selma Krupp, Evelyn Medoff, Charlotte Sokoloff, Helen Rubin. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Services will be held Sunday, November 30, at 12:00 Noon at Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1668 Beacon St, Brookline, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Krupp's memory may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 40 Court Street, Boston, MA 02108, or to Ben Gurion University, 2150 Washington St., Newton, MA. 02162.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Two Children Wounded By Bullet
description: Two 11-year-old children playing tag in the playground of an apartment complex were hit by a bullet yesterday afternoon, the police and family members said. The boy and girl, Dashawn Wallace and Nakia Jones, were among a dozen children playing outside about 4:30 p.m. at the Booker T. Washington Apartments when a single gunshot rang out, family members said. A bullet grazed Dashawn's right arm, then struck Nakia in the calf and lodged in her ankle, the police and family said. The children were taken to the New Jersey Medical Center. The boy was treated and released, and the girl was expected to be kept at the hospital overnight. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: 'No One May Ever Have This Knowledge Again' -- 'Letters to Mount Wilson Observatory, 1915-1935'
description: Christine Burgin Gallery

title: Red, White And Creepy? Could Be Santa
description: NOW that Macy's has assured everyone this Thanksgiving that Santa Claus is a straight guy with no eye for same-sex marriage, it may be time to face another issue squarely.

title: Rare Work Drenched in Gore With a Stalker as Protagonist
description: Set in a dreary Scottish castle in the 1820's, Heinrich Heine's ''William Ratcliff'' is a macabre tale of a beautiful daughter who can't marry because all her fiancs keep getting murdered by her crazy stalker ex-boyfriend, the title character. There's plenty of steamy romance and high drama, including visits from ghosts, deadly sword fights and a final blood bath so gory it could pass for a Quentin Tarantino period piece.

title: An Archipelago in the Arizona Sky
description: SOMETIMES the trail down into the canyon is recognizable -- a winding footpath worn into the hard desert rock. Sometimes it's even marked by piles of stones. (These are cairns, left as guideposts by other hikers.) But once in the canyon, we're either bushwhacking through tangles of scrub or scrambling with our packs over the boulders that fill the streambed between the narrow canyon walls.

title: Suzanne Valadon
description: Frost & Reed

title: In Feinstein's Parody Hit Parade, Holiday Favorites Gain Wit
description: Although Michael Feinstein calls this year's version of his annual Christmas show ''The Great American Holiday Songbook,'' the program goes out of its way not to clog your ears with the usual seasonal hit parade. Even when the songs are familiar, Mr. Feinstein, accompanied by a trio under the direction of the pianist John Oddo, comes up with a fresh, witty take.

title: Scholars of Twang Track All the 'Y'Alls' in Texas
description: ''Are yew jus' tryin' to git me to talk, is that the ah-deah?''

title: Bloomberg and 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Latino Essence, Remixed and Redistilled
description: In art, as in fashion, old ideas rarely die. They just change shape and labels. Identity politics, a big feature of American art of the 1990's, is very over in the 2000's. Except that it isn't. It may look and sound different, less insistent and reductive, but for better and for worse it is still in operation.

title: To the Collector, The Spoils
description: THERE is an adage in collecting that ''you should always buy what you like.'' Jacques Littlefield really likes tanks.

title: Lloyd Webber Seeks Piece Of Time Warner Deal
description: If Andrew Lloyd Webber has his way, the battle for Time Warner's music division is not over yet.

title: Quiet Town Wants To Stay That Way
description: POPULATION 3,645

title: For the Classical Saxophone, A Chance at Last to Show Off
description: It's easy to feel sorry for the classical saxophone, that orchestral Cinderella, brought in to join the symphonic fun when a little exotic color is needed but mostly left at home to practice watered-down arrangements of violin showpieces and transcriptions of Bach cello suites.

title: Sports Briefing
description: HOCKEY

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means tickets were at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

title: Jeremy Blake -- 'Autumn Almanac'
description: Feigen Contemporary

title: Amid Tight Secrecy, a Tip: Bush Is Going to Baghdad
description: On Wednesday afternoon, Mike Allen, a White House correspondent for The Washington Post, was talking on his cellphone outside a school in Crawford, Tex., not far from President Bush's ranch, when an aide to the president motioned him toward the passenger seat of a rented Dodge pickup truck.

title: Giving Voice to Last Words From the Holocaust
description: AS Kathleen Chalfant moved across her rehearsal space, she was followed by shadows. Some loomed large and menacing behind her, some shrank in pain, some multiplied to give a sense of crowds and movement, and some floated faintly on the curtain like ghosts.

title: Old Songs Revisited By Voices Of Today
description: ONE way to draw the map of popular music in the new millennium would be to divide the world into two volatile, interacting territories. One, the world of pop for grown-ups, is a land of song where the sunsets are dramatic and the pace is leisurely. The other, younger world is a defiant nation under a groove, a fast-food franchise in which tornado watches are announced daily.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LANGER, BERNICE C.
description: LANGER--Bernice C. November 28th, 2001. Each day an emptiness is felt. Each day I miss our conversations, your knowledge, strength, kindness & love. I am truly blessed to have had you as my mother. Your loving daughter, Louise

title: We Are Where We Shop
description: Today, according to ancient American custom, thousands of moms and dads will wake before dawn, jump into their cars and drive to the mall. There they will wait patiently in the parking lot for the doors to open. Then they will race their shopping carts through the broad, familiar aisles of our nation's most popular discount stores, filling them with DVD players, wide-screen TV's, Hokey Pokey Elmos -- something's always on sale. Before noon, if they're lucky, they will emerge triumphant from behind the cash registers with the trophies of their early-morning hunt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIBINGA, MAARTEN SMIT, M.D.
description: SIBINGA--Maarten Smit, M.D. Age 76 of Media, PA on November 16, 2003 from respiratory failure after a long illness. Dr. Sibinga, born in the Netherlands, was a pediatrician who specialized in gastroenterology and practiced for many years at St. Christopher's Hospital for Children in Philadelphia. He was also a dedicated amateur violinist and chamber musician. He is survived by his loving family, wife of 47 years, Cecilia (nee Bradbeer) children, Michael, Nicholas, Erica Sibinga, six grandchildren, twin brother, Joost and sister, Marijke both of the Netherlands. There will be a memorial meeting, Saturday, November 29, 2003 at Media Friends Meeting, 125 West Third St, Media, 11AM. Followed by a reception. The family will also be available prior to the meeting from 10:30AM at the Meetinghouse. Burial private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Pendle Hill, Wallingford, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWER, MARY FRANCIS
description: BROWER--Mary Francis. Saint John's Church. Cold Spring Harbor, LI. Saturday November 29th, 11AM.

title: Maria Elena Gonzlez -- 'U.N. Real Estates'
description: Art in General

title: Injury Silences Shockey (For a Practice, at Least)
description: The lower volume at Giants practice Thursday had something to do with the Thanksgiving lull in traffic around Giants Stadium, with no horse racing crowd, no flea market and fewer planes overhead. Well, that and no Jeremy Shockey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAINE, SYDONIA
description: RAINE--SYDONIA-11/28/99 Loving thoughts of you are always in our hearts and minds. Your ever lovin Murray, Caren, Joshua, Bonnie, Alan and Colin

title: Guarding the Gaudy, G.I.'s Gorge Near a Hussein Palace
description: Between the previous night's house raid and Thursday night's street patrol, Specialist Chris Owen found time to cram his mouth full of turkey on the grounds of Qusay Hussein's old palace.

title: An Orphan in a Funny Suit, In Search of a Family Tree
description: Elf

title: European Union Agrees to Rules on Mergers
description: After 14 years and several false starts, European Union lawmakers finally agreed Thursday to pass a law intended to ease cross-border takeovers.

title: Cedar Houses: A Natural Look, a Natural Fragrance
description: WHO -- J. B. Davies, 43, commercial real estate developer

title: Surprise Guest Makes the Meal Worth the Wait
description: About 600 soldiers from the First Armored Division and the 82nd Airborne were getting restless waiting for Thanksgiving dinner in the Bob Hope mess hall at Baghdad International Airport. They were eager for their special guests, L. Paul Bremer III and Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, to start the feast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERLING, ANNE
description: SILBERLING--Anne, on November 26, 2003. Cherished sister to Diane and beloved aunt, great-aunt and greatgreat-aunt to so many in the Silberling family who mourn her passing. She loved her life in Greenwich Village, her fierce independence and her pursuit of all New York's cultural riches. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends. She was preceded in death by sisters Lillian, Sam, Suche, Fannie, Belle and brothers Lou, Shim and Meyer. Services today, November 28, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The World Is Volatile, So Why Should Earnings Show Smooth Gains?
description: TO far too many executives in corporate America, the right to report steadily rising quarterly earnings is fundamental, ranking right up there with life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. If that belief is not changed, the current wave of corporate reform will ultimately fail.

title: Beware the Worm In Your Handset
description: As more consumers begin surfing the Web and sending e-mail messages on cellphone and hand-held devices, along comes a new worry: worms and viruses spread via Internet-enabled handsets.

title: Cleo Athenos Stark, 95, Modern Dancer
description: Cleo Athenos Stark, who performed with the modern-dance companies of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman in the 1920's and 30's, died on Nov. 9 in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 95.

title: The Neediest Cases; Bad Times, But a Family Makes Room For One More
description: Last Fourth of July, Lavadar Campbell, 39, went to a barbecue. One of eight children, she knew that in addition to tons of tasty food, there was sure to be a lot of family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHENBERG, MYRON, DR.
description: ROTHENBERG--Myron, Dr. 88, on November 26, 2003. Husband of the late Sylvia. Father of Shelli and Elaine, grandfather of Rebecca and Shana. Brother of Joseph, sister of Lillian Hellman. Services Sunday 11:30 AM, I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, BENJAMIN, 87, MD, F.A.C.S.
description: HOFFMAN -- Benjamin, 87, MD, F.A.C.S. Beloved husband of Irma. Adored father of Andrea (Michael) Harrison and Dr. Ian Hoffman. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Rachel and Jessica. Dear brother of the late Sidney Hoffman. Devoted uncle of Dr. Allan (Sue) Hoffman. Brilliant and prominent surgeon, respected and loved by his patients and friends, he will be sorely missed by all. Services 1 PM today, I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Why We Need Gays in the Military
description: Ten years ago Sunday, President Bill Clinton signed into law the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy on gays in the military. The law, which has resulted in nearly 10,000 discharges to date, bans openly gay people from serving in the armed forces, requires those who do serve to conceal their sexual orientation and avoid homosexual conduct, and prohibits military personnel from being asked about their sexual orientation. With American soldiers, gay and straight, fighting for their country in Iraq, the wisdom of this policy is increasingly suspect.

title: Shopping List | Home Fitness
description: ENOUGH now with the mega-eating, drinking and passive quarterbacking. It's time to recover and start strength training for the continuing holiday marathon. Weekends are a great time to do some free-form moving on your own -- and don't hesitate to encourage family participation: you may be training your future coach. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAMMANO, SUZANNE (NEE PISTILLI)
description: MAMMANO--Suzanne (nee Pistilli). 61, on November 22, 2003 while traveling in Tibet. Beloved sister of Audrey Grieco; loving aunt of Regina, Matthew, Eric, Kevin, Craig and David; sister-in-law of Anthony, Marcia, Howard and Donald. Visiting hours, Friday, November 28, 6 to 9PM at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 Street. Mass of Christian Burial 11AM on Saturday, November 29 at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82 Street, New York, NY 10028

title: French Unions Ask Diplomats To Strike Against Fund Cuts
description: In a country where workers' strikes are considered a way of life, do French diplomats have the right and the duty to walk out?

title: 900 Taxis? That Won't Fix the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISRAEL, JEROME
description: ISRAEL--Jerome, on November 26, 2003. Beloved husband for 56 years of Rosalind, the devoted father of Marilynn Potter and Sandra Testani. Cherished grandfather of Neil. Loving brother of Lillian Durschlag and Doris Kaplan. Services Friday, 1:15PM at ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Small town in south wins a reprieve : Italy delays decision on nuclear waste site
description: MILAN:  After two weeks of protests, the government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Thursday was forced to backtrack from a decision to make the small southern town of Scanzano Jonico the site of the main nuclear waste repository in Italy.

title: 'Crack Baby' Syndrome?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard-Liners Gain in Northern Ireland Voting
description: Hard-line parties appeared to make strong gains Thursday in elections for the Legislature in Northern Ireland. The results, while still preliminary, pointed to a polarized outcome that many fear will make it difficult to resuscitate the local government that shares power between Protestants and Roman Catholics.

title: China Again Warns Taiwan About Seeking Independence
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 28  Beijing shifted its response today to new Taiwanese legislation on national referendums, expressing concern about the law and repeating warnings to this island against seeking formal independence, but stopping short of any threats.

title: Holding Down Drug Prices
description: Now that Congress has passed a costly prescription drug benefit for older Americans -- a bill that we endorsed to close a glaring gap in Medicare -- it is imperative to find strong tools for restraining drug costs. The drug benefit is projected to cost $400 billion over the first 10 years and perhaps $1.5 trillion or more over the following decade. Without cost restraint, it will impose huge financial burdens on future generations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGLER, SYLVIA HOPKINS
description: SIEGLER--Sylvia Hopkins of Darien, CT. on November 24, 2003. Wife of the late Edouard H. Siegler. Mother of Ted Siegler, Lucinda Brown and Nancy Stanesco. Sister of Bob Hopkins. Grandmother of four. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, November 29, 2003 at 11:00 AM at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, CT. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Dola de Jong, a mystery novelist, misspelled the name of a mystery writing award she won in 1964. It is the Edgar Allan Poe Award, not Allen.

title: Who-o-o-o-o Is That Moaning In the Cellar?
description: EDDIE MURPHY'S character, an ambitious real estate broker, faces the supernatural in Disney's horror comedy ''The Haunted Mansion,'' which opened on Wednesday. He takes his family along to inspect an antebellum Louisiana estate he hopes to be asked to sell. When a sudden thunderstorm leaves them stranded in this once grand, now crumbling home, they learn that it's also haunted by hundreds of ghosts who reside in a backyard cemetery where they enjoy bicycling, archery and tea parties. This house is the latest in an illustrious line of movie homes and hostels that come equipped with scary creatures or phenomena (or at least seem to). All are visitable on video or DVD. ANITA GATES

title: Taiwan Legislators Step Back From Confronting China
description: Taiwan's legislature took a half-step back on Thursday night from an immediate confrontation with China, passing a bill that would allow national referendums on constitutional and sovereignty issues only under very narrow circumstances.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 30 about Jack Meador and his sister Jane Meador Cook, both figures in a scheme to sell stolen medieval German artworks, misstated the title of Constance Lowenthal, who commented on their case. She is a former director of the Commission for Art Recovery, a unit of the World Jewish Congress, not the current director.

title: Jane Evans, 59, Executive And Women's Advocate, Dies
description: Jane Evans, a former top executive of several large companies and most recently the managing partner of the Directors' Council, a company she helped form this year to help companies find women and members of minorities to serve as directors, died Nov. 16 in Buenos Aires, where she was attending a business conference.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGDON, HOMER
description: LANGDON--Homer. On November 26. Devoted husband of the late Victoria. Father of Peter. Adored stepfather of Candace and Robin. Now you are with your beloved soulmate Vicki but we shall carry you in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held Saturday, November 29, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, NYC, 12 noon.

title: 'Hukkle'
description: Directed by Gyorgy Palfi

description: HILFER--Jack, 89, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of New York. Beloved husband of Julia (nee Tarlow). Loving father of Alan (Elena) Hilfer and Myra (Marc) Cohen. Adored grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel, Ilene and Mitchell. Funeral services Sunday, November 30, 2003, 10:15 AM at the Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York 800-446-0406.

description: Sean Kelly Gallery

title: A Coach Becomes the Talk of Vermont
description: When Tom Brennan pulled into an old general store in the tiny town of Hancock, Vt., the man wearing bib overalls behind the counter blurted, ''Whoa, hey, hey.''

title: Mining Company Set to Buy Majority of Harry Winston
description: Aber Diamond Corporation, a diamond mining and exploration company based in Toronto, said it intended to buy a majority interest in luxury jeweler Harry Winston Inc.

title: Russian Oil Companies Suspend $11 Billion Merger
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 28  In a fresh blow to Russia's financial markets, Sibneft, a major Russian oil producer, today suspended its merger with Yukos, freezing a deal that would have created the world's fourth-largest oil producer.

title: Holik Finally Knows His Role, and It Shows in His Play
description: It took more than one full season, but the Rangers are finally getting the production they expected from Bobby Holik when they lured him from the Devils with a five-year, $45 million contract in the summer of 2002.

title: On Kashmir Border, Soldiers Trade Gifts, Not Shots
description: Children laughed as they played cricket. Men and women worked peacefully in rice fields. Indian and Pakistani border guards exchanged festive gifts and friendly chats instead of gunfire.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Howard Dean's support among black voters misstated his age. He is 55, not 54.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was just looking for a warm meal somewhere.''

title: Made In America, Before 1776
description: The first Buy American campaign began even before there was a United States of America. In 1767 a council of elected colonial leaders, upset with new British duties on paper, tea, lead and glass, banned the import of certain British goods. That policy benefited colonial artisans, who suddenly saw increased demand for their furniture and other wares.

title: Proposal on Italian Media Appears Headed for Passage
description: A proposed Italian law that would give Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi ample space to expand his media empire and increase his power to shape public opinion is likely to move one step closer to becoming law when the Senate votes Tuesday.

title: Thomas Finds Comfort In Contributing to the Jets
description: Jets defensive end Bryan Thomas spent Thanksgiving alone last year, eating dinner in front of the television, another unremarkable day in a forgettable rookie season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMSON, JACK
description: WILLIAMSON--Jack, 76, died November 20, Hilton Head, SC. Founder and president, DiFranza Williamson, NYC 1955-1989. An award-winning artist and graduate of Parsons School of Design. Mr. Williamson is survived by his wife Irene, six children Arthur Williamson, Jacqueline Piro, John A. Williamson, Jennifer DeMeo, Gregory and James Williamson; sister Ruby Martin and three grandchildren.

title: A Man Who Invented Himself and Helped Invent an Era
description: With the recent opening of the Broadway show ''Taboo,'' the reputation of Leigh Bowery, the Australian-born, London-based performance artist, fashion designer and drag provocateur has finally crossed the Atlantic. In the 1980's Bowery was the toast of the London club scene, where he elevated dressing outrageously into a kind of mad performance art.

title: How Code-Breakers Alter a War
description: INTELLIGENCE IN WAR

title: Losing Himself to Find Himself
description: Once he was L. T., the Giants' lethal linebacker and sometime cocaine addict with a dangling ''LT'' diamond earring. Now he's Lawrence Taylor, actor, author and occasional drug counselor, without the earring.

title: Who-o-o-o-o Is That Moaning in the Cellar?
description: EDDIE MURPHYS character, an ambitious real estate broker, faces the supernatural in Disneys horror comedy The Haunted Mansion, which opened on Wednesday. He takes his family along to inspect an antebellum Louisiana estate he hopes to be asked to sell. When a sudden thunderstorm leaves them stranded in this once grand, now crumbling home, they learn that its also haunted by hundreds of ghosts who reside in a backyard cemetery where they enjoy bicycling, archery and tea parties. This house is the latest in an illustrious line of movie homes and hostels that come equipped with scary creatures or phenomena (or at least seem to). All are visitable on video or DVD. -- ANITA GATES

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: History in the Making

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Passenger Killed In Car Crash
description: A car with three people in it veered off Roosevelt Avenue in Elmhurst about 2 a.m. yesterday and crashed into a divider, killing one passenger and severely injuring another, the police said. The driver, Santos Arqueta, 24, of Harmony, N.C., was charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said. The injured man is his brother, Edgar, 21, and the dead passenger, Ever Arqueta, 21, was their cousin. Edgar Arqueta was listed in critical condition yesterday. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Vicious World Inflicts Bruises, But the Humor Is Optional
description: When Rufus Wainwright sings, he sustains every word, using a vibrato that's both vulnerable and obstinate. He's not exactly a crooner: his voice is too nasal to be soothing. But he savors and clings to his melodies as if they're the only thing that will carry him through what one song calls a ''Vicious World.''

title: Democrats Temper Praise For Bush Visit With Criticism
description: With his Thanksgiving Day excursion to Baghdad, President Bush moved to regain control of an issue that Democrats have increasingly viewed as a political liability, reinforcing his commitment to the war while displaying solidarity with troops his rivals had accused him of neglecting, Democratic officials said yesterday.

title: Joni Mitchell Slept Here
description: ''LISTEN!'' commanded Jono Hart, sitting up with a jerk from the lounge chair on his back deck. His ears turned toward the eucalyptus grove behind his Laurel Canyon cottage. The wind rustled through the leaves, a few dogs barked, and then, faintly, the sound of a bass guitar and a drum echoed off the hills. ''That's live, from a recording studio owned by the Doors' former manager,'' Mr. Hart said.

description: DANIELS -- Mary Edmond son. Died November 25, 2003 in Hightstown, NJ. Formerly of Bronxville, NY. Widow of Freeman J. Daniels. She is survived by her daughter Mary Daniels Lowry of New Canaan, CT, grandchildren Jane Lowry Miller and John Lowry III, and great-grandsons Sumner and Preston Miller. Funeral services will be private. Donations may be made to The Reformed Church, Box 397, Bronxville, NY 10708.

description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 28  The barrier that Israel is building in the West Bank is causing "serious socio-economic harm" to the Palestinian people and is undermining the Middle East peace process, Secretary General Kofi Annan declared in a report today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, ANDREW M.
description: FISHER--Andrew M. We mourn the death of our bright, shining star who at 22 years of age, was tragically taken from us on Thursday November 27, 2003. Andrew was a budding artist who floated above this earth with his sunny disposition and happy view of life. He was the light of our lives. He leaves behind his mother Laura; his father Richard; his two brothers Hadley and Winston; and his sister Alexandra. Funeral services will be private.

title: Lausanne Journal; For a Medieval Cathedral, A Made-in-America Organ
description: Jean-Christophe Geiser is not taking any chances. When he inaugurates a new pipe organ at the cathedral here next week, his first piece will be a prelude by Bach, who is to organ music what Verdi is to opera.

title: Under a Baton in a Younger Hand
description: When the New York Philharmonic was searching for a successor to Kurt Masur as music director a few years ago, the conductor David Robertson could not even be considered. Why not? He was one of several accomplished younger conductors who had yet to make their Philharmonic debuts. Obviously, the orchestra could not hire someone, however talented, who had never worked with the musicians. That Mr. Masur did not make it a priority to get the most promising conductors of the new generation into the Philharmonic's roster was a major shortcoming of his tenure.

description: Fredericks Freiser Gallery

title: In Hawaii, Recipes for Thanksgiving Include Blending Customs
description: The lava rocks came from a stream in west Oahu, the firewood from that side, too, the ti leaves from a man up the road, the banana tree stumps from local farmers. The labor setting up a huge fire pit, lining it with wood and rocks, filling it with food, sealing and tending it overnight? That was provided by dozens of volunteers.

title: Dangers in Iraq? For Lincoln, Richmond Was Scarier
description: President Bush's trip to Iraq on Thursday was hardly the first by a president to a war zone. But it was unusual in the extraordinary secrecy with which it was carried out and, as a result, in the considerable amount of surprise it generated.

title: Prison Officers Are Taking Longer Leaves
description: The rate of inmate assaults on New York State correction officers has dropped by half since 1991, but that has not stopped the amount of workers' compensation leave taken by correction officers from growing by more than 40 percent in recent years, according to a recent audit.

title: One Able Quarterback Is Usually Not Enough
description: It is a given that the starting quarterback is the most crucial player on a football team. But who finishes second in that vote?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Tuesday with an article about young artists and architects whose designs are among the final contenders for the World Trade Center memorial misstated the affiliations of two of them. Sean Corriel is a student at Cornell, and Jessica Kmetovic at the California College of Arts and Crafts. (They took part in a Columbia program for architects and planners with Prof. Pierre David, their collaborator on the plan for a memorial called ''Garden of Lights.'')

title: Telling the Truth, Facing the Whip
description: A week ago yesterday I was supposed to appear at the Sahafa police station to receive 75 lashes on my back. I had been sentenced by a religious court because of articles I had written calling for freedom of speech and criticizing Wahhabism, Saudi Arabia's official religious doctrine. At the last minute, I decided not to go to the police station and undergo this most humiliating punishment. With the nation at a virtual standstill for the holiday Id al-Fitr, the sentence remains pending. I will leave this matter to fate.

title: Senator Clinton, in Afghanistan, Calls for More Foreign Troops
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for the deployment of additional foreign soldiers in Afghanistan Thursday during a Thanksgiving visit to American troops here. Senator Clinton, citing recent attacks on aid workers, said reinforcements from the United States or NATO were needed to increase security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEINER, EUGENE
description: KLEINER -- Eugene. The Board of Trustees, administration, faculty and students of Polytechnic University mourn the passing of Eugene Kleiner, an alumnus, trustee and a 1989 Honorary Doctorate of Engineering recipient of the University. As a founder of Fairchild Semiconductor, the first successful company to manufacture the silicon-based transistor, and later a founder of the venture capital firm of Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield and Byers, which launched over 300 companies, Eugene Kleiner's enormous contributions to the field of information technology are legendary. Among the many honors bestowed upon him, Eugene was inducted into the Silicon Valley Business Hall of Fame, and in 2000 was named Outstanding Mechanical Engineer of the Century by Polytechnic University. His gentle humor and generous spirit will be very much missed. Our sympathies are with his son, Robert, and daughter Lisa Kleiner Chanoff and their families. Stewart G. Nagler, Chairman David C. Chang, President Polytechnic University

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Wednesday about Santa Claus and gay marriage misspelled the name of a gay American composer. It is Virgil Thomson, not Thompson.

title: So Sad It's Funny, And Getting Sadder
description: Like the sun and the moon in a solar eclipse, every now and then an actor and a role align in a way that makes them seem perfect complements, together producing a startling and memorable light. You may remember that ''Butley,'' Simon Gray's painfully astringent comedy about the emotional and psychic disintegration of an English literature professor, provided such a role for Alan Bates, who originated the title character on a London stage in 1971, did a reprise on Broadway in 1972 and played it again on screen in a 1974 film.

title: Nets Find Drive to Win, But Road Isn't Smooth
description: In a rare and revealing show of frustration, Jason Kidd pulled up at half-court, called timeout and fired the ball against the backboard Thursday night.

title: 'East Wind'
description: Queens Museum of Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURKAN, MR. THOMAS R., SR.
description: DURKAN--Mr. Thomas R., Sr., of New York City and Dalton, GA, passed away on Tuesday evening, November 25, 2003 at his home in Georgia. Mr. Durkan was the founder of Durkan Patterned Carpet, Inc. Mr. Durkan was born in New York City on October 18, 1925, the son of Irish immigrants Thomas R. Durkan and Beatrice Joynt Durkan. He served with the 8th Army Air Corps in the European Theater during WWII, and graduated from Fordham University in 1949. After founding the company that would become Durkan Patterned Carpet, Inc. in 1971, Mr Durkan introduced new technologies that revolutionized the carpet industry. He retired in 1996 after selling Durkan Patterned Carpet, Inc. to Mohawk Industries, Inc., where he had begun his career 45 years earlier. Mr. Durkan often said that the secret of his success was that he had discovered the power of women in business. He was active in many business, philanthropic and community endeavors in Manhattan and Dalton. Mr. Durkan is survived by a sister, Mary Durkan Knizie of Belle Harbor, NY; his children, Tara E. Durkan of Redondo Beach, CA; Thomas R. Durkan, III , of Dalton, GA; Patricia A. Durkan of New York City; James P. Durkan of Chattanooga, TN; and Charles W. Durkan of Dalton, GA; and seven grandchildren. Services will be held Monday, December 1, 2003 at 12:00 noon from Saint Joseph's Catholic in Dalton, GA, with Father Daniel Stack officiating. The family will receive friends at the Church after 10:00AM Monday morning. There will also be a memorial service for Mr. Durkan in New York City on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the Durkan family requests that donations be made to (Covenant House, 346 West 17th Street, New York NY 10011, the United Way). Condolences may be sent to durkanfamily@ pondersfuneralhome.com. For information, Locally Owned and Operated, Ponders Funeral Home and Crematory, 138 Melrose Drive, Dalton GA, 706-226-4002.

title: Corrections
description: A hip-hop review yesterday about Jay-Z misstated the month in some copies for his release of ''The Black Album.'' It was this month, not last.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: FOR BLAIR, JUST A PAIN IN THE STOMACH Prime Minister Tony Blair, 50, said he was fine after complaining of stomach pains. Doctors examined him twice but a spokesman for Mr. Blair said they had no plans to treat him further. The episode was the second in a month. Last month, Mr. Blair was taken to the hospital with an irregular heart-beat. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POMERANTZ, RACHEL
description: POMERANTZ -- Rachel. On November 25, 2003, at age 72. Loving daughter of the late Pauline and Samuel Pomerantz and loving sister of the late Howard E. Pomerantz. She is survived and cherished by her brother Mike and his wife Ruth and her devoted nieces and nephews Jan Wilcox, Susan Pomerantz, Alan Pomerantz, Drucie and Gerald Isenberg, and their children Sarah, Halie, Jennifer, Rebecca, Matthew, Stephen and Lindsey. She was a thoughtful and kindly woman who will be remembered with affection.

description: Asia Society

title: Sexual Abuse And the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Alumni Return, Juxtaposing Past and Present
description: One of the best places in New York to discover the players of tomorrow's art world is White Columns, a nonprofit gallery that for two decades has been assembling consistently interesting group shows by emerging artists. The gallery has also given 284 artists their first solo shows under the aegis of its White Rooms program, which offers these exhibitions to artists who have not previously shown alone in New York and have no official commercial gallery affiliation.

title: Faster Justice for the Balkans
description: In its nearly 10 years, the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia has been fair and thorough. But it has also been expensive and lumbering. Now, at the urging of the Bush administration, the Hague-based tribunal is speeding up proceedings by allowing those accused to plead guilty to lesser charges. Plea bargains are controversial for Europeans unfamiliar with the practice. But they make swifter justice possible. Moreover, the confessions required for a deal are finally helping the tribunal to fulfill one of its central missions: persuading Balkan nations accustomed to considering themselves victims that their forces committed terrible crimes.

title: A Dancer Shows How Rhythm Can Set Fire to a Flirtation
description: Mara Bentez Teatro Flamenco approaches this Spanish dance form with taste, tact and a sure sense of theater. But the company, founded in 1970 and based in Santa Fe, N.M., appears to have less respect for flamenco music. The amplification in the troupe's opening performance at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night had the crushing loudness and synthetic quality of a stadium rock concert, and the sight of a singer sprouting a microphone was distracting.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by Times critics of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Bush pays surprise visit to Iraq to spend Thanksgiving with GI's
description: WASHINGTON:  In a stunning mission conducted under enormous secrecy, President George W. Bush flew into Baghdad on Thursday aboard Air Force One to share Thanksgiving dinner with U.S. officials and several hundred astonished American troops.

title: Abused Mothers Keep Children In a Test of Rights and Safety
description: In September 2002, child welfare workers, acting on a tip from a schoolteacher, arrived at a Bronx home to investigate a suspicious bruise on a 4-year-old boy. They quickly learned that the child's mother was entwined in a deeply abusive marriage, that she was living with her husband in violation of a court order to remain separate, and that the boy had been bruised before.

title: 36 Hours | Corpus Christi, Tex.
description: IN the late 1800's, developers from New York announced plans to make Corpus Christi a ''Chicago of the Southwest'' with the construction of a deep-water port connected to the rest of Texas and neighboring states by an elaborate network of rail lines. Fortunately, their idea failed. Corpus Christi, which means ''Body of Christ'' in Latin, eventually expanded into a city of 270,000 but has remained a laid-back playground destination on the Gulf Coast. Bathed in sunlight (winter temperatures in the 70's and 80's) and lined with palm trees, Corpus Christi is where the varied cultures and subcultures of South Texas -- Tejano, Anglo, rancher, wildcatter, beach bum, entrepreneur, seaman and many others -- come together next to the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Even though a port was eventually built -- and remains among the busiest in the nation, ferrying cotton, sorghum, petroleum and shrimp -- Corpus Christi retains the feeling of a place that prefers to be far from the hustle of bigger cities. SIMON ROMERO

title: A Player's Perseverance Is Rewarded
description: Darting and sprinting up the block, the little boy with the miniature football was as familiar a sight as the cabs that zoomed through Park Hill Avenue, the main artery of the Park Hill housing projects on Staten Island. Immaculately attired in charcoal gray slacks, a silk shirt and navy blue Buster Brown shoes, 4-year-old Gary Ham Jr. was playing with friends outside his apartment building on a humid summer morning in 1987. He was waiting for a church van to take his family to a Sunday service.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Washington, Conn.
description: WASHINGTON is the kind of place where you strike up a conversation with a retired gent at the library only to find out that he has lived in four countries and helped build a well-known hotel in the Bahamas. Or where the couple you meet at the local bar turn out to be best friends with a famous film director.

title: Bar Mitzvah Time: Drivers Wanted
description: AT about 5:45 on a recent Saturday afternoon, Zach Orenstein and a quartet of his friends jumped out of his family's S.U.V. in a dark corner of the parking lot at Temple Beth El in Cherry Hill, N.J. Moving fast, the boys threw off their jeans and T-shirts, wriggled into suits, then stood under a streetlight so that Zach's father, Jonathan, could make the final adjustments to their ties. By 6 p.m. the boys were inside at the second of their three bar mitzvah commitments of the weekend, ready to pray and party. Only one more to go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAUL, ROBERT DAVID
description: PAUL--Robert David. On November 27, 2003 at age 75 of a brain tumor. Retired President and Chairman of The Segal Company; Founder and former Chairman of the Employee Benefit Research Institute; Board member of WellChoice, Inc.; and former Board member of Wiss, Janney, Elstner Associates, Inc. Beloved husband of Eve for 51 years. Devoted father of Jeremy (Laurel Leff) and Sarah (Dr. Mark Nachamie) and grandfather of Jason and Russell Paul and Eli Nachamie. Loving brother of Norma Benisch. His passion for getting things right, doing one's best and treating others with dignity and respect will forever remain an inspiration to all who knew him. Services Sunday, November 30 at 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to the MFA Program in Creative Writing, University of Michigan, Department of English Language and Literature.

title: A Crook Blunders Into Christmas Redemption
description: ''Stealing Christmas'' wears its heart on its fur-trimmed red sleeve. This holiday fable, Sunday night on the USA Network, tugs at all the expected strings. The tugs are gentle, though. And while its plot is as familiar as Aunt Bertha's eggnog, this little film is surprisingly satisfying.

title: The Good News
description: I've heard it said that I should try, just once, to write something upbeat. Honestly, on the domestic front it's hard. Yes, the business cycle is looking up -- but with the budget out of control, pork-stuffed legislation making its way through Congress and the extractive industries making environmental policy, we seem to have lost the ability to govern ourselves. Did I mention civil liberties?

title: Sales Rise in Japan
description: Retail sales in Japan grew a better-than-expected 0.8 percent in October from September because of deep discounting and strong car sales. The growth was twice as fast as economists expected, suggesting that consumer spending was recovering after a slow third quarter. Added to improving exports and capital spending, the numbers also signal that the economy could pick up steam this quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: In politically charged Venezuela, when President Hugo Chvez takes over the airwaves to deliver one of his rambling speeches, Gloria Villamizar leaves her apartment in a huff.

title: Day Later, Nothing Is the Same For Knicks
description: It took only 10 seconds for Reggie Miller to flail and flop and get the first foul called on Allan Houston. Houston picked up his second foul with what seemed like barely a bump on Miller just a minute later.

title: Medicare Plan For Competition Faces Hurdles
description: The most politically charged feature of the Medicare legislation passed by Congress -- its attempt to make the federal Medicare program compete with private managed-care plans -- is also the least likely to come to fruition on the seven-year schedule set in the bill, according to health policy experts.

title: A Mother's Expandable and Embracing Heart
description: Susan Tom, the indefatigably caring and devoted adoptive mother of a large brood of severely disabled children, is the kind of selfless person who, once encountered, could prompt you to re-evaluate your definition of love.

title: Arshile Gorky, Poet of Line and Color
description: THE drawings in the Arshile Gorky show at the Whitney Museum are, as you would expect, heartbreakingly beautiful. How could they be otherwise? It's only a pity that the show is too big. The narrative bogs down. Gorky's works need to be appreciated slowly, one at a time. After perusing the 30th or so of them from around 1946, you can begin to feel drained, notwithstanding an admiration for Gorky's enterprise.

title: With Cross-Sound Rivals, Waters Are Rarely Calm
description: It is a rivalry that has gone overlooked by headlines and history, and will never be as famous as the battles of the Axis versus the Allies, the Yankees versus the Red Sox and Liza Minnelli versus David Gest.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: GOUGING NOT AT FAULT IN GAS PRICE RISE A sudden rise in gasoline prices last summer was not a result of price gouging, but of "external market forces," an official with the State Department of Consumer Protection said. Gov. John G. Rowland, left, requested the inquiry in August, after some parts of the state reported sudden hikes by as much as 21 cents in a matter of hours. The department surveyed gas stations and local suppliers and distributors, and said it found that profits had not risen significantly during the summer months. The hike was the result of the complexities of the gasoline market, the department said. "All the data points to external market forces at work," said the consumer protection commissioner, Edwin R. Rodriguez.   (AP)

description: Judge Jane Marum Roush, who is presiding over the trial of the younger defendant in last fall's sniper shootings, has a quick wit. She has used it sparingly but to great effect in the first weeks of the trial, in which Lee Malvo, 18, is accused of killing an F.B.I. analyst and others.

title: On Secret Iraq Trip, Bush Pays Holiday Visit to G.I.'s
description: In one of the most secretive presidential trips in American history, George W. Bush flew to Baghdad under intense security on Wednesday to spend Thanksgiving with United States troops and to thank them for standing up against the ''band of thugs and assassins'' they are fighting in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TALTON, KAREN W.
description: TALTON--Karen W., of Altadena, CA, and formerly of NY, died November 24 in Pasadena, CA. She was 57 and had been undergoing treatment for cancer. Survived by her husband, the Rt. Rev. Chester L. Talton, bishop suffragan of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles; by their four children, Kathy, Linda, Frederick, and Benjamin; by four grandchildren; and her father, Mr. Bennie Warren of Alhambra, CA. Requiem Eucharist is set for 10am on Saturday, November 29 at the Cathedral Center of St. Paul, 840 Echo Park Ave., Los Angeles. The Rev. Betsy Hooper-Rosebrook of Altadena, CA will be celebrant, and the Rt. Rev. J. Jon Bruno, Bishop of Los Angeles, will preside. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Karen W. Talton Scholarship Fund for black seminarians. Contributions may be sent to the Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, PO Box 512164, Los Angeles, CA 90051. Mrs. Talton was born April 7, 1946, in Oakland, CA. A poet and potter, she held a degree in nursing from the City University of New York, where she resided during her husband's tenure as rector of St. Philip's Church, Harlem, and as an associate of the Parish of Trinity Church, Wall Street. For further information Angeleno Pasadena Mortuary, 626-449-2121.

title: Refighting the Battles of Recent History
description: WHEN Bob Lawrence plays army, he doesn't fool around. He has a complete captain's uniform from the German Panzer Grenadiers of World War II and an MP-40 Schmeisser machine pistol. Then there is his 1944 Kbelwagen, the German equivalent of the Willys Jeep, which he drives in re-enactments of conflicts like the Battle of the Bulge and the Battle of Kursk.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It's once more unto the breach at ABC Carpet and Home. The store is now on its third attempt to create a restaurant in the area once occupied by Colina, which begat Chicama, which now gives way to Lucy Mexican Barbecue. The third time may be the charm. Phil Suarez, a longtime partner of Jean Georges Vongerichten, has put Andrew DiCataldo, his chef at Patria, in charge of the kitchen.

title: Division Over Death Penalty
description: On March 7, 1995, New York's newly elected governor, George E. Pataki, fulfilled one of his main campaign promises by signing the state's death penalty into law. He called the law ''the most effective of its kind in the nation.''

description: State and city officials say they are inching toward a tentative agreement with the owners of the New York Jets to split the $1.5 billion cost of building a new football stadium over Manhattan's West Side rail yards.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Economy Grows 1.1%
description: The nation's gross domestic product grew by an annualized 1.1 percent, adjusted for inflation, in the third quarter after shrinking by 0.7 percent in the previous three months, the national statistics agency reported. The latest number was about half of what analysts had expected, and reflected a sharp drop in inventories, weak exports to the United States and shrinking factory output. Exports fell for the fourth consecutive quarter, partly because of the strong Canadian dollar. In spite of the weak growth report, analysts expect the Bank of Canada to leave its base interest rate unchanged at 2.75 percent when it reviews monetary policy on Dec. 2. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: B. S. Cohn, Expert on Culture Of Modern India, Dies at 75
description: Bernard S. Cohn, who spent his life studying and writing about British influence on modern Indian culture and society, died here on Tuesday after a long illness. He was 75.

title: Plaques for Nazi Victims Offer a Personal Impact

''Leopold Schwarzschild, year of birth 1924, deported in 1941 to Riga, ???,'' one plaque read, the question marks indicating the unknown circumstances of the young man's death.
