description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; For Family That Fled War, Safety, and Some Help, Too
description: ''There is no place like America,'' Mohamed Zawril says. ''People here are helpful; we are lucky.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, GUS W.
description: WEISS--Gus W. Of Washington, D.C. on November 25, 2003 at age 72. Beloved son of the late Gus and Natalie Weiss. Loving nephew of Lillian Weiss and dear cousin of Joan Poorvu and Claire Weisman. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Monday, December 1st at 1 PM. Interment Beth El Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Upping the Campaign Ante
description: Political sanctimoniousness surprises no one, least of all candidates competing tooth and claw for the presidency. But let the record show that the decision by former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont and Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts to abandon publicly subsidized campaign spending limits -- so tinged with high-minded regret -- was really all about outspending and annihilating each other in the opening Democratic nomination rounds in Iowa and New Hampshire. The announced rationale for resorting to open-ended private campaign funds was that President Bush's plan for a $200 million war chest of private donations forced their abandonment of public financing in fear of being outspent next year.

title: From Discordant Notes, Reformers Hear One Song
description: This time, the revolution may be telecast on premium cable.

title: MBNA'S FOUNDER AND CHIEF WILL RETIRE AT YEAR'S END
description: The MBNA Corporation, one of the world's largest issuers of credit cards, said yesterday that its founder and chief executive, Charles M. Cawley, would retire at the end of the year. Mr. Cawley, 63, will be succeeded by Bruce L. Hammonds, the company, based in Wilmington, Del., said in a statement. Mr. Hammonds is senior executive vice president and chairman of MBNA America Bank, the company's main subsidiary. The bank's president, John R. Cochran III, will take Mr. Hammonds's position. The three men were working together even before the company was founded in 1982, Mr. Cawley said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Talk Of Ashikaga Bailout
description: Japan's banking czar, Heizo Takenaka, disputed local news media reports that the government was on the verge of nationalizing the troubled regional lender Ashikaga Financial Group. Regulators completed an inspection recently of 10 regional banks including Ashikaga. According to the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading business daily, the inspection revealed that the bank was short of capital at the end of the last fiscal year. Regulators are considering whether to use taxpayer money to help the bank, the paper said. Bank officials called the report ''speculation.'' Mr. Takenaka said he was not considering taking any action against the bank because he had not seen its most recent half-year results. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLATTERY, REV. MAURICE (BUD)
description: SLATTERY--Rev. Maurice (Bud), on November 25th. CDR. USN, Ret. Survived by his sister Eileen Murphy, six nieces and nephews, five grand-nieces and a grandnephew. Calling hours Sunday, November 30th, 3-5 and 7-9 PM at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, 288 Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY. Mass Monday, December 1st, 11AM. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Georgia Tech Races to Preseason N.I.T. Title
description: Georgia Tech is quickly converting those who thought it was going to be an ordinary team this season. Last night the Yellow Jackets earned praise from one of the game's toughest critics, Bob Knight, who complimented Georgia Tech on its toughness after it dismantled his Texas Tech team, 85-65, in the final of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Norsk Hydro Gives Spinoff Details
description: Norsk Hydro, a leading Norwegian oil, natural gas and aluminum company, said it would spin off Hydro Agri, the world's biggest fertilizer company, next March 25 by giving 80 percent of the new stock to existing shareholders and selling the remaining 20 percent in an offering. Shareholders in Norsk Hydro will receive one share in the fertilizer business for each existing share they own in Norsk Hydro, the company said. The Norwegian government, which owns 44 percent of Norsk Hydro, said it would hold at least 33.4 percent of the new company. The spinoff was announced in June. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRITISH COLUMBIA HYDRO AND POWER AUTHORITY, Vancouver, the second-largest exporter of electricity to the United States, said profit in the second fiscal quarter fell to about $28.5 million, from $77.8 million a year ago.

title: Mayor's Failed Effort To End Party Primaries Cost Him $7.5 Million
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent more than $7 million of his own money to promote his proposal for nonpartisan elections, a ballot initiative that New Yorkers soundly defeated at the polls earlier this month.

title: Australia Leads Davis Cup on Strength of Doubles
description: Australia took a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup final Saturday when the experienced team of Todd Woodbridge and Wayne Arthurs dismissed Spain's untried pairing of Alex Corretja and Feliciano Lopez, 6- 3, 6-1, 6-2.

title: Having Reshaped Broadway, Disney Readies a Second Act
description: The Walt Disney Company, with three hits already on Broadway, is preparing a second, even more ambitious assault.

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Computers as Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Building a crche set, one figurine at a time
description: VIENNA  Two years ago, I was hurrying through Vienna's cheerful, kitschy Christkindl Markt looking for something worth buying when I noticed a little wooden stall right under the giant Christmas tree in front of the Rathaus. The storefront was full of tiny wooden figures, angels, saints and creche figurines. When I asked the price, I was startled by how expensive they were  until I took another look at the detailed, expressive faces, the soft, glowing colors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRACY, ROSEMARY P.
description: TRACY--Rosemary P. nee Guiney. She was a former long time resident of Rye, NY. She died of natural causes on Wednesday, November 26th at The Village of Vestavia Hills in Birmingham, AL. She was 76. She was born on July 5, 1927 on the Staten Island Ferry to Timothy and May Guiney. She graduated from Mount St. Vincent in Riverdale, NY in 1949. She was married to the late Joseph Aloysius Tracy, Sr. She is survived by her children Regina Semmes of Greenwich, CT, Emie Barnes of Chappaqua, NY, William Tracy of Colorado Springs, CO, Joseph A. Tracy, Jr of Birmingham, AL, Rosemary Maxfield of Stamford, CT, Michael Tracy of Huntington, NY and Marguerite Tracy of Boston, MA and 12 grandchildren. Calling hours 5-8PM on Sunday, November 30th at The Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY. Funeral Monday, December 1st, 11:00 AM at Resurrection Church.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rents Decline Across U.S. As Families Buy Homes

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a decision by Vanguarde Media Inc., the publisher of Savoy, Honey and Heart & Soul, to close the magazines and seek bankruptcy protection misstated the title of a former executive who commented. Roy S. Johnson, now an assistant managing editor at Sports Illustrated, was editorial director of Vanguarde and editor in chief of Savoy, not editorial director.

title: Caviar: knowing your sevruga from beluga
description: PARIS  Gastronomically, the holiday season suggests luxury, and France's traditional lineup of end-of-year splurges include silken foie gras, earthy black truffles, bittersweet chocolates and ethereal caviar. Of the four, caviar is without doubt the priciest, the most exotic, the rarest and one of the most difficult for the average consumer to evaluate. Yet few gastronomic joys can compete with the intense, momentary pleasure of the sparkling, silken, mouth-popping eggs of the rare sturgeon from the Caspian Sea.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Bangladeshi's Autobiography Is Banned
description: West Bengal State banned an autobiography by the Bangladeshi writer Taslima Nasreen on the ground that it could offend Muslims. More than 2,500 copies of the book, ''Dwikhandito,'' or ''Split in Two,'' were seized by the police. Chief Minister Budhadev Bhattacharjee said that he had read the book and that his government had decided to ''proscribe'' it. Ms. Nasreen said in an interview with the PTI news agency from New York, ''In my personal opinion, 'Amar Myebela' ('My Girlhood') was far more anti-Islamic than this one.'' The book was also banned in Bangladesh. P.J. Anthony (NYT)

title: A Lead Paint Law We Can Live With
description: The way to a meaningful lead paint bill looks clearer now that the City Council has produced responsible legislation and the Bloomberg administration seems ready to work with it. Still, there is much to be done if the city is serious about helping to protect young children from lead poisoning.

title: Cross-Dressing for Thanksgiving (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: A RECORD YEAR FOR WILDFIRES The wildfires last month burned more acreage than any others in California history, state officials said. The Cedar fire in San Diego County scorched about 273,000 acres, eclipsing the 1932 record of 220,000 acres burned by a single blaze. The Cedar fire also destroyed 2,820 buildings. About 989,000 acres across California have burned this year. That tops the previous record year, 1987, when fires charred 780,000 acres.   (AP)

title: Yesterday, Hail to the Chief; Today, Hail to the Senator
description: The first surprise waiting for Dr. Raja Habib Khuzai, a member of the Iraqi Governing Council, was President Bush in the flesh, telling her and other politicians that even his mother did not know he had come to Iraq for Thanksgiving. Then, on Friday, she was summoned by American officials again.

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about ''Broadway Sings 'The Odd Potato': A Concert Musical for Hanukkah'' misspelled the surname of a cast member. She is Charlotte Rae, not Rea.

title: Quiet Time In the Bronx; In Fall, After the Yankees Go Home, The Streets Show a New Character
description: Famous places have secret lives. Like famous people, they reveal their private faces only when the lights go out and when the crowds have gone away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, BRUNI
description: ALLEN--Bruni. On November 26, 2003 at age 64.

title: Conjoined Filipino Twins Return to Rehab After Third Operation
description: Carl and Clarence Aguirre, Filipino twins joined at the head, were playful, hungry and showing no signs of neurological damage, doctors said yesterday, four days after the boys had surgery to divide shared blood vessels in their brains.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Circuits on Thursday with an article about shopping for television sets referred incorrectly to those pictured, which owe their slim profile to plasma or liquid crystal displays. They are known as flat-panel sets, not merely flat-screen.

title: Keeping an Architectural Oddity Alive (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cross-Dressing For Thanksgiving
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida's Late Basket Nips Arizona
description: When Dr. James Naismith invented basketball by hanging a peach basket during a physical education class at Springfield College here in 1891, he probably did not envision a game like this.

title: Some People Didn't Spend the Day Shopping. Maybe Even on Purpose.
description: Calling all cars: be advised of an all-points bulletin for individuals wanted for questioning in connection with crimes against consumerism perpetrated in the New York region yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMYTH, LILA HARKINS
description: SMYTH--Lila Harkins, of Bronxville, NY. Died at home of a recurring brain tumor on November 26, 2003, in her eighth year of life. Cherished daughter of Dr. James and Clare Hollensteiner Smyth. Beloved sister of Luke and William Smyth. Granddaughter of Joseph and Patricia Smyth and of Robert and Letitia Baldrige Hollensteiner. Great-niece of Robert Baldridge and of the late Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige and of Margaret Baldrige, and of Louise Van der Vort. Niece of Malcolm Baldrige and Carey Hollensteiner, and of Joseph K. Smyth, Una Smyth and Kathleen Smyth Daunais. Mass of Christian burial services private. Contributions may be made to ''Making Headway Foundation Inc.'', dedicated to the care of children with brain and spinal cord tumors, 115 King Street, Chappaqua, New York 10514.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: U.S. SAYS POPPY CROP DOUBLED IN YEAR Poppy acreage in Afghanistan nearly doubled from 2002 to 2003, to a level 36 times higher than in the last year of rule by the Taliban, White House figures show. The area planted with poppies, used to make heroin and morphine, was 152,000 acres in 2003, compared with 76,900 in 2002 and 4,210 in 2001, the Office of National Drug Control Policy said. These figures differ significantly from those of the United Nations, which said poppy cultivation rose 8 percent in 2003, to 200,000 acres, from 185,000 in 2002. The White House said the United Nations used a different calculation based on ground surveys and satellite images. The American estimates are based on a sample survey of agricultural regions conducted with specialized satellite imaging systems. (Reuters)

title: U.S. IS WORRIED FOE IS TRACKING TARGETS IN IRAQ
description: Bush administration officials are increasingly concerned that anti-American forces in Iraq are using simple but effective means to monitor activities and coordinate attacks against the American military, civilian administrators and visiting dignitaries.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices increased for the first time in five and a half years as a result of several one-time factors including tax increases and a surge in rice prices, the government reported. Prices rose 0.1 percent in October from a year ago. The increase was widely forecast and is not expected to persuade the Bank of Japan to abandon its zero-interest-rate policy because the financial system and economy are still considered too fragile. The government also said that Japan's unemployment rate increased for the first time since March, rising to 5.2 percent from 5.1 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Japan's gift-giving generation gap
description: TOKYO  'To give a gift to someone is to reveal who you are to that person." So said an 18th-century Japanese poet. Actually, I just made that attribution up. The person who did say it is an editor at a Tokyo fashion magazine called Spring who used that as a blurb for an article about gifts.

title: Giants Try to End Funk; Fans Will Bring In Noise
description: The last time the Giants played in their stadium, they left the field to a chorus of boos. Their coach was being chanted out of town. The Giants had just lost to a woeful Atlanta Falcons team and their fans were less than shy about their view of the Giants' fourth loss in five home games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANHOFF, MILDRED
description: MANHOFF--Mildred. Born in Brooklyn, died Monday, November 24, 2003. Renowned dancer, winner of many awards, she taught dance in Jamaica, WI, appearing in a couple of films dancing with the likes of Sean Connery. Mildred was partner with her husband, Harold, in Manhoff Studios decorating the Copacabana, the Savoy Ballroom, Helena Rubinstein's penthouse, and Billy Rose's Horseshoe Club. Survivors include a son, Ira, & a daughter, Helen Cuccaro of Boulder.

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Remnants of Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: They're Off and Shopping, but Seeking Sales
description: Holiday shoppers, intent on bargains, descended on America's malls yesterday, but spent only slightly more than they did last year, according to reports from retailers and analysts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the rise in H.I.V. infections in the United States from 1999 to 2002 misstated non-Hispanic whites' share of new diagnoses in that period. It was 31.3 percent. (The 8 percent figure was the increase in diagnoses among non-Hispanic whites from 1999 to 2002.)

title: America's Sugar Daddies
description: Sugar growers in this country, long protected from global competition, have had a great run at the expense of just about everyone else -- refineries, candy manufacturers, other food companies, individual consumers and farmers in the developing world. But now the nation's sugar program, which guarantees a domestic price for raw sugar that can be as much as three times the world price, needs to be terminated. It has become far too costly to America's global economic and strategic interests.

title: From elegant German ceramics to Polish pottery
description: BERLIN  The work of the German ceramicist Hedwig Bollhagen has gained increasing international attention since the fall of the Berlin Wall. Her distinctive designs for tea, coffee and dinner service, garden pots and decorative plates range from delicate to lyrical to formalist. The most popular pattern is a simple dark blue, dusty blue, and white vertical stripe. More daring are abstractions in deep greens, oranges and black. All bear the HB signature.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about a lawsuit brought by Kirk Kerkorian in connection with Daimler-Benz's acquisition of Chrysler reversed the identities of two executives. Robert J. Eaton, chief executive of Chrysler at the time of the merger in 1998, was at the left and Jrgen E. Schrempp, chairman of Daimler-Benz, at the right.

title: Islanders Leave Snow Defenseless at Detroit
description: Garth Snow, the Islanders' backup goaltender, must have known there would be no mercy Friday night.

title: An Act of Courage and Love
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Chief Denounces West Bank Barrier
description: The barrier that Israel is building in the West Bank is causing serious harm to the Palestinian people and undermining the Middle East peace effort, Secretary General Kofi Annan declared in a report on Friday.

title: Beijing Softens Stance Against Taiwanese Law
description: Beijing shifted its response on Friday to new Taiwanese legislation on national referendums, expressing concern about the law and repeating previous warnings to this island against seeking formal independence but stopping short of any threats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERTEL, ANN (NEE PORTNOY)
description: FERTEL--Ann (nee Portnoy) passed on November 27th at the age of 95 following a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Irving Fertel, devoted mother of Bernice and the late Bernard Metz, Diane Fertel, Maxine and Elliot Simon. Cherished Nana of Charlene Metz, Lewis and Caroline Lilla, Beth Lilla and Dominic Piscitelli, Gerry and JoanMarie delle Badia, and Joy Simon. Adored greatgrandmother of JoAnn, Anthony, Richard, David, Amanda, Jessica, Alexa, Juliana and Bianca. Caring sister of Hy Portnoy. Her legacy is the strength her family will find in love and sharing. Services will be held on Sunday 2PM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, Forest Hills. Donations in her memory may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: HORMEL REPORTS 3.5% HIGHER PROFIT IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Hormel Foods Corporation, the nation's largest turkey processor, said this week that profit rose 3.5 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter on improved sales of its beef, pork and poultry Fully Cooked Entrees and other refrigerated products. Net income rose to $70.4 million, or 50 cents a share, in the three months ended Oct. 25, from $68 million, or 49 cents, a year earlier, the company, which is based in Austin, Minn., said in a statement. Sales rose 13 percent, to $1.2 billion. Hormel had been expected to earn 49 cents a share, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

title: Name That War
description: A drum roll, please: It's time to announce the results of the Name That War Contest.

title: Cross-Dressing For Thanksgiving
description: To the Editor:

title: No Easy Road to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Ulster Peace Pact in Peril

title: 3 Arrested in Europe Are Tied to Recruitment of Iraq Fighters
description: The Italian and German police arrested three North Africans on Friday as part of an investigation into a European-based network that the police said had been recruiting fighters for Iraq.

title: Networking on TV: A Feminine Touch
description: Back in the 1950's, Lucille Ball of ''I Love Lucy'' delighted television audiences with her screwball attempts to escape domesticity for her husband Ricky's glittery entertainment world. The comedy played off the reality of those years when being mothers and wives defined many women.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 436 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Corrections
description: Illustrations in Circuits on Thursday with the Online Diary column carried an erroneous credit in some copies. They were by Ron Barrett.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a film review on Wednesday about ''Bad Santa'' misstated the year of the movie ''Scrooged,'' with which it was compared. It was 1988, not 1998.

title: Sadegh Khalkhali, 77, a Judge In Iran Who Executed Hundreds
description: Sadegh Khalkhali, the first leader of the Islamic Revolutionary Courts in Iran after the 1979 revolution, who ordered the execution of hundreds of people, died Wednesday. He was 77.

title: Rural Haitians Are Vanguard in AIDS Battle
description: CANGE, Haiti  In the cool mist of daybreak, hundreds of villagers fanned out across the forsaken reaches of this nation's remote interior, fording rivers swollen by torrential rains, slogging through muddy cornfields and clambering up slippery mountainsides to reach people sickened by AIDS.

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: As Obesity Rises, Health Care Indignities Multiply
description: When Mark Rosenthal suffered a stroke, he was too heavy and wide for a stretcher, so he made the jarring, bouncing dash to the hospital lying on an ambulance floor. The ride injured his back, and he felt as if his own weight would suffocate him. At the hospital, doctors wanted to give him an M.R.I. scan, but he could not fit into the machine.

title: Flights of fancy from California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On the cutting edge of the Western world, not every export is virtual. Cottage industries are alive and well in the greater San Francisco Bay area, blotting up crazy amounts of time and dogged patience.

title: Helping an Old French Art to Rise
description: Steven L. Kaplan stared through the window of a Paris bakery one Sunday morning, looking like an osprey ready to swoop.

title: Religion Journal; For Missionaries With Children, the Calling vs. the Danger
description: In 1956, Jean Phillips and her husband took their 2-year-old son on a mission trip to Southern Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe). Working for the Southern Baptist International Mission Board, they stayed for 40 years, through a guerrilla war and the births of three children more.

title: A Surface vs. Substance Fight for Edwards
description: The hair is a bit shorter and tamer these days, the better to keep him from constantly sweeping the boyish tuft out of his eyes and with a side effect of making him look older than he did when he entered the race for the Democratic presidential nomination a year ago.

title: The Promised Land
description: The history of American conservatism is an exodus tale. It begins in the wilderness, in the early 1950's, with Russell Kirk, Milton Friedman and William F. Buckley Jr. writing tracts for small bands of true believers.

title: Hugo Wolf Songs in Two Styles
description: The best-known Wolf in classical music is not big and bad but small and intricate. Hugo Wolf, the Austrian composer, specialized in beautifully concise lieder that immerse themselves in their poetry with nuanced vocal lines and rich, articulate piano ones.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If a name brand is on sale, I hop on it.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about a request by prosecutors in the fraud trial of L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, to show jurors a video of his New York apartment referred incorrectly to the assistant district attorney who made the request. The attorney, Consuelo Fernandez, is a woman.

title: Nuclear Agency Changes Its Stance on a Fire Safety Proposal
description: After 10 years of struggling to make reactor owners modify their plants to protect electrical cables from fire, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is now proposing to amend its own rules, retroactively legalizing an alternate strategy used by many plants but never formally approved.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.B.A.

title: Gephardt Pushes His Health Care Plan With a Personal Story
description: This 30-second advertisement, the latest from Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, began running in Iowa on Wednesday. Its personal tone is similar to that of an advertisement for Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, which also addresses health care.

title: Long Strike at a Nestl Plant In Korea Comes to an End
description: A long strike at a Nestl plant in South Korea came to an end on Friday, but the fear of labor unrest continues to loom over the South Korean economy.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: SCHOOLS TO BAN SCARVES The government plans to ban head scarves from public schools to protect Muslim girls from "fundamentalist pressures" to wear them, Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin said. The issue pits fiercely secular France against some of its five million Muslims. Female politicians have been especially eager for a ban, saying conservative Muslim families press girls into wearing scarves in violation of the principle of sexual equality. "This is not about religion," Mr. Raffarin said. "It's about lifting a constraint on women." (Reuters)

title: Politics Rescue Euro From Stability Agreement
description: When the European Union suspended the fiscal rules that underpin the euro this week, some political leaders here warned that it would undermine the stability of the currency.

title: Ohio Police Say 2 Highway Shootings Are Related
description: At least 2 of 10 recent shootings on or near Interstate 270 near Columbus, Ohio, are related, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Houston Urges McDyess Not to Rush His Return
description: Antonio McDyess has missed the last 116 games of his career, dating from March 20, 2002, when he was with the Denver Nuggets. He will miss his 117th this afternoon when the Knicks play host to the New Orleans Hornets at Madison Square Garden.

title: Keeping an Architectural Oddity Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping an Architectural Oddity Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Is Accused of Taking Welfare Despite Lucrative Job
description: She earned as much as six figures as a computer consultant, lived in an affluent Connecticut suburb and shopped at J. Crew, but a Darien woman, the police say, also represented herself as a welfare case and collected $70,000 in state payments and federal assistance.

title: Coerced or Not, Palestinians Who Assist Israel Face Death
description: For a Palestinian accused of cooperating with Israel's security forces, confession can amount to a death sentence. But Muhammad Hilal apparently felt he had no choice.

title: Move Over Starbucks, Juan Valdez Is Coming
description: How about a nice large cup of coffee, light on the guilt?

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Two State Agencies Become Embroiled in a Dust-Up Over Lobbying Rules
description: The head of the state lobbying commission and Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's office are at odds over the interpretation of state lobbying rules, with each side trying to circumvent the other over several issues involving Russell Simmons, the hip-hop impresario.

title: Vision vs. Symbols and Politics at Ground Zero
description: Although it failed to produce a work of genius, the competition to design a memorial to the victims of 9/11 was well worth undertaking. It threw into sharp relief three problems that have plagued the ground zero design process. Too much symbolism. Not enough time. A breakdown of cultural authority.

title: Edwards Not Far Removed From Fassel's Troubles
description: During the bleakest of football seasons in New York, the echoes of two teams gone awry bounce off each other. Jets Coach Herman Edwards observes Giants Coach Jim Fassel's excruciating season and empathizes.

title: SUNY Seeks A Tuition Rise For 2nd Time In Two Years
description: The State University of New York, which raised undergraduate tuition $950 this year to $4,350, is proposing a tuition increase for next year, though it does not plan to seek any increase in state aid.

title: Briefly, in the Beginning There Was a Farmer
description: ''As a vantage point for writing the history of the human race,'' writes Michael Cook with a bit of defiance, ''the present has very little to be said for it.'' )

title: A stockingful of fun, for kids from one to 92
description: From movie-influenced board games to variations on old favorites, children's games still top many a Christmas list. New games are always being introduced, but "Chutes and Ladders," "Old Maid," "Connect Four" and "Monopoly" continue to be favorite choices. A wide range of games are available internationally at toy stores or online at www.ToysRUs.com, www.KBToys.com or www.Imaginarium.com.

title: CHIEF OF SCHERING-PLOUGH BUYS 303,500 OF ITS SHARES
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, the pharmaceutical maker, said yesterday that Fred Hassan, the chairman and chief executive, has purchased almost $4.7 million worth of the company's common stock. The announcement pushed shares of Schering-Plough up 69 cents, to close at $16.07, on the New York Stock Exchange Mr. Hassan, who took over in April as chief executive of the company, based in Kenilworth, N.J., bought 303,500 shares. In August, he said in a regulatory filing that he wanted to acquire Schering-Plough stock because of his ''long-term confidence in the company.''

title: Laundry in Queens Agrees to Raise Pay After 9-Hour Strike
description: A large industrial laundry in Queens, Jung Sun, agreed to a tentative contract yesterday, just nine hours after more than 100 of its workers went on strike.

title: Sports of The Times; Rutgers and UConn Are the Big East's Future
description: IF ever there was a ray of hope for a tortured college football program and, by extension, the future of the besieged conference it plays in, it was in East Hartford, Conn., on Nov. 8 when Rutgers and Connecticut battled deep into the fourth quarter, 31-31, and the Huskies punted with little more than a minute to play.

title: Oil Producer In Russia Puts Halt to Merger
description: Sibneft, a major Russian oil producer, said on Friday that it had suspended its $13 billion merger with Russia's biggest oil company, Yukos, taking its embattled partner by surprise and roiling markets here.

title: Youth Killed and 2 Officers Are Hurt in Robbery Attempt in Queens Subway
description: A 17-year-old was fatally shot yesterday in a midafternoon robbery attempt on a subway platform in Queens, and two police officers who ran toward the sound of the gunfire were injured scuffling with the suspects, the authorities said.

title: Bank Delaying Move on Fund
description: Bank of Montreal, Canada's fifth-largest bank, has postponed the appointment of Alliance Capital Management as adviser for two of its mutual funds.

title: A Critic Whose Scholarship Gleamed With His Writing
description: Hugh Kenner, who died at 80 at his home in Athens, Ga., this week, was among the finest writers of critical prose in America. He was one of the few commentators whose books and articles cause delight and stand as literary achievements in their own right, including ''Gnomon: Essays in Contemporary Literature'' (1958); ''Dublin's Joyce'' (1955); ''The Stoic Comedians: Flaubert, Joyce and Beckett'' (1964); ''The Counterfeiters: An Historical Comedy'' (1968), the latter two illustrated by the writer and artist Guy Davenport; ''The Pound Era'' (1971).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about John Edwards's use of his autobiography to raise money for his presidential candidacy referred incorrectly in some copies to the book's $150,000 advance. Although $15,000 went to a charity named for Mr. Edwards's late son, Wade, the rest went to researchers and writing assistants, not to the co-author, John Auchard.

title: Ostracized by Commonwealth, Zimbabwe Says It May Pull Out
description: On the eve of a summit meeting of the 54-nation Commonwealth, Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, said Friday that he was prepared to desert the group if its members continued to ostracize Zimbabwe because of its human rights and economic policies.

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Crowds May Not Help Travel Industry
description: Heading into the busiest travel day of the year -- the Sunday of the Thanksgiving weekend -- there was evidence that the long-troubled travel industry was finally enjoying a boomlet in demand.

title: Giving the Solo Viola Its Due In Sounds Seductive and Raw
description: Music lovers should spare some pity for violists. Firmly lodged in orchestras and chamber groups, few have made solid solo careers over the last century. And they don't get much respect: these days, violists are the hapless subjects of a huge repertory of musical jokes. (How can you tell a violist is playing out of tune? The bow is moving.) Still, in the right hands the viola can sing like a tenor. It was the instrument that Bach most enjoyed playing, and Mozart and Beethoven were partial to it as well.

title: Op-Art
Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies on Thursday about the victory of St. John's University over the University of Connecticut in the National College Athletic Association soccer tournament misstated the date of St. John's next game. It is tomorrow, not today.

title: Red Sox Ace Out the Yankees And Get Schilling for 3 Years
description: Curt Schilling and the Red Sox agreed on a contract extension yesterday afternoon, completing a trade that sent him from the Arizona Diamondbacks to Boston and suddenly gave the Red Sox one of baseball's most formidable starting rotations. Schilling will team with Pedro Martnez and Derek Lowe in Boston's quest to beat the Yankees, although acquiring him was a victory in itself.

title: American and Norwegian Win the Blue Ribbon Pair Title in New Orleans
description: A trans-Atlantic partnership won the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here on Thursday night. Michael Seamon of Miami Beach, Fla., a member of a famous bridge family, scored a runaway victory with Geir Helgemo, a Norwegian expert who has twice been second in the world championship for the Bermuda Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, HILDA R.
description: ROSENTHAL--Hilda R. Died on Thanksgiving Day, surrounded by her loving family. She was a very special lady who will be missed by all who were lucky enough to know her. Beloved and devoted wife of Louis. Mother of Bernice and Adella. Sister of Helen Zirilstein and aunt of Joan Zirilstein. Services Sunday, November 30th at 10:15 AM at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woodsbridge Road, Katonah, NY. Contributions may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art.

title: Contemporary style with Hong Kong twist
description: HONG KONG  For a long time, most new Chinese household designs in Hong Kong belonged to one of two extremes. There was the nouveau aesthetic favored by fresh arrivals from the mainland. (Think mass-produced plastic plates made to look like blue-and-white porcelain or gold-trimmed, garishly colored ceramic figurines of traditional deities.) And there was the "exotic" Chinoiserie created for expatriates. (Think dragon-carved rosewood furniture and factory-made table linens embroidered with tacky pagodas.)

title: Trade Sanctions Against U.S. to Be Delayed
description: The World Trade Organization has agreed to a 10-day delay before Europe can impose $2.2 billion in sanctions against the United States in response to steel tariffs imposed by President Bush last year, an administration official said on Friday.

title: Devils Fail to Achieve Record Unbeaten Streak
description: The Devils brought a franchise-record-tying 13- game unbeaten streak into the American Airlines Center on Friday night, an accomplishment that had inspired little more than a collective ''whatever'' before their game against the Dallas Stars.

title: Following a Different Drum to the Ends of the Earth
description: USING his breakfast knife to demonstrate, Sir Ranulph Fiennes was explaining why he took it upon himself to saw the tops off the fingers and thumb of his left hand three years ago.

title: Airport Security for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning to Like the Image in the Mirror
description: Dressed in curve-hugging low-rise jeans, flip-flops and a faded black sweatshirt, Pink strutted into a downtown Manhattan hotel room, plopped herself on a sleek leather couch and immediately lighted a Newport cigarette, her first of many during an interview.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODSKY, GRACE ANN (NEE DUFFY)
description: BRODSKY--Grace Ann (nee Duffy) of River Edge, NJ formerly of Manhattan on November 26, 2003. Mrs. Brodsky was a Registered Nurse with a Master's Degree from Georgetown University. She was Chief Executive and Owner of Medical Arts Center Hospital in New York City before retiring. She was formerly a parishioner of St. Peter's RC Church in River Edge. Beloved wife of the late William Brodsky (1959), daughter of the late William and Elizabeth Duffy, she is survived by her children, Barbara Lynn Brodsky of San Francisco, CA, Deborah Ann Brodsky of Montville, NJ and Paul Frances Brodsky of River Edge, NJ. Dear sister of Romayne Fialk of Pittstown, NJ, Paul Duffy of Archbald, PA, Eugene ''Oney'' Duffy of Rockaway Township, NJ and the late Francis Duffy, Jerome Duffy, Ronald Duffy and William Duffy, Jr. She also leaves behind many beloved nieces and nephews and especially Arthur Fialk of Pittstown, NJ. Dearly beloved friend of Rebecca Capabianca and family of North Caldwell, NJ. The Funeral service will be held Monday, December 1, 2003 at 11:30 AM from Vander Plaat Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes, NJ and Funeral Mass will be performed at 12:00 PM at Most Blessed Sacrament RC Church, Franklin Lakes. The interment will take place at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. Family will receive their friends Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Donations to Sacred Heart RC Church, 4 Richards Avenue, Dover, NJ 07801 or to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105 would be appreciated, in lieu of flowers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shinsei Profit Rises 28%
description: Shinsei Bank Ltd., Japan's first foreign-owned lender, said profit grew 28 percent in the first six months of the fiscal year, in line with forecasts. The bank, which is owned by the investment group Ripplewood Holdings, earned 34 billion yen ($310 million), while its revenue grew 20 percent. The bank's chief executive, Masamoto Yashiro, also said the bank would have an initial public offering between January and March as planned. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Halliburton Subsidiary Is Accused of Bias
description: Five black veterans have accused Kellogg Brown & Root, a subsidiary of Halliburton, of engaging in racial discrimination.

title: Head of Gucci Brand to Stay Despite Recent Departures
description: Giacomo Santucci, the president of the Gucci brand within the Gucci Group, has said he will stay on despite the departure of Gucci's chief executive and star designer, an executive close to the company said on Friday.

title: Colombia Sets Range for Curbed Inflation
description: Colombia's central bank board said yesterday that it would try to limit inflation to 5 percent to 6 percent next year, seeking to keep it in the single digits for a sixth consecutive year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: No Escaping The Red Ink As Bush Pens '04 Agenda
description: President Bush is heading into 2004 facing a growing budget deficit, frustration among some Republicans about what they see as a lack of fiscal discipline and a challenge in putting together an election-year agenda that will not plunge the government all the deeper into debt, lawmakers, analysts and administration officials say.

title: Portland Drama Brings Nets an Unhappy Ending
description: The Nets might have run into the one opponent Friday that has had to deal with more distractions recently and had to cope with more traumatic times.

title: Guess Who Wants to Be Governor
description: As a campaign slogan, it leaves something to be desired: ''Why the hell not?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAUL, ROBERT DAVID
description: PAUL--Robert David. On November 27, 2003 at age 75 of a brain tumor. Retired President and Chairman of The Segal Company; Founder and former Chairman of the Employee Benefit Research Institute; Board member of WellChoice, Inc.; and former Board member of Wiss, Janney, Elstner Associates, Inc. Beloved husband of Eve for 51 years. Devoted father of Jeremy (Laurel Leff) and Sarah (Dr. Mark Nachamie) and grandfather of Jason and Russell Paul and Eli Nachamie. Loving brother of Norma Benisch. His passion for getting things right, doing one's best and treating others with dignity and respect will forever remain an inspiration to all who knew him. Services Sunday, November 30 at 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to the MFA Program in Creative Writing, University of Michigan, Department of English Language and Literature.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: New Planes For Aer Lingus
description: Aer Lingus, Ireland's state-owned airline, said it would buy seven new Airbus planes and lease another 10, giving its European fleet 27 of the single-aisle A320 and A321 aircraft. The deal will allow Aer Lingus to start serving 15 new continental routes by 2005. Financial terms were not disclosed. ''It reinforces the transformation of Aer Lingus into a low-fares airline that offers a way better service,'' the chief executive, Willie Walsh, said in a statement. Mr. Walsh has made changes at Aer Lingus to compete with Ryanair, the Irish low-budget carrier. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MAXIM, LESLIE M.
description: MAXIM--Leslie M. Nov. 29, 1917--June 23, 1996 Happy Birthday! Happy Thanksgiving! Remembrances of your life and deeds. Missing you. Love, Pear

title: Persistent New Leaks Fuel Coverage of Jackson Case
description: Michael Jackson has yet to be officially charged in the child molesting case against him, but the trial before the trial is off and running, fueled by leaks from both sides.

title: About New York; Unforgiven For the Passions Of His Youth
description: MALACHY McALLISTER sits at a corner table in a Manhattan restaurant, his back again to the wall. He has not been to his home in New Jersey for more than a week, because he knows that federal agents have been there, looking to detain and deport him. Eyes down, he is a man out of place.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN TO BUY EDUCATIONAL TESTING COMPANY
description: The Houghton Mifflin Company has agreed to acquire Edusoft, which helps school districts track test results, according to a regulatory filing made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The acquisition by Houghton, based in Boston, is expected to close before Jan. 15. Edusoft, based in San Francisco, helps school districts, administrators and teachers track student performance on state standards through state exams, district benchmarks and in-class teacher tests, the filing said.

title: Shaw Is Suspended By St. John's Again
description: Willie Shaw, a senior guard on the St. John's basketball team, has been suspended indefinitely for violating team policy, Coach Mike Jarvis said in a statement yesterday. Jarvis and the university had no further comment, the statement said.

title: Ballot Victory by Unionists Widens the Divide in Ulster
description: The hard-line Protestant Democratic Unionist Party, led by the Rev. Ian Paisley, emerged Friday as the dominant political group in Northern Ireland after elections that deepened the province's sectarian divide and cast doubt over the future of its power-sharing government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, WILLIAM J.
description: GORDON--William J. Of Baldwin on November 28, 2003. Age 74 years. Devoted husband of Evelyn (nee Pedersen) for almost 51 years. They met at Wagner College where they both sang and toured with the Wagner College choir. They became college sweethearts and were engaged on graduation day. Beloved father of Suzannah Barranco (Joseph), Laura Jane Conlon (Peter) and Diana Halle Gordon. Dear grandfather of Meredith and David Barranco and Emma and Samuel Conlon. William was very devoted to the Baldwin School District, where he served for 47 years. William loved teaching partly for the theatrics it encompassed. For the 1976 Bicentennial, he paraded as Benjamin Franklin, much to the children's delight. He was an amateur Egyptologist and had an intense love of poetry. He memorized many lengthy passages and could still quote them flawlessly before his hospitalization. One of the family's most vivid memories is him teaching them to recite Robert Frost's ''Stopping By The Woods On A Snowy Evening.'' He will be dearly missed. The family will receive friends Sunday 2-5 PM only at Weigand - Pensa Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave., Baldwin, NY. Religious service Monday, 10:30 AM at Bethlehem Lutheran Church. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Bethlehem Lutheran Church, 1375 Grand Avenue, Baldwin, NY, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, ANDREW M.
description: FISHER--Andrew M. We mourn the death of our bright, shining star who at 22 years of age, was tragically taken from us on Thursday November 27, 2003. Andrew was a budding artist who floated above this earth with his sunny disposition and happy view of life. He was the light of our lives. He leaves behind his mother Laura; his father Richard; his two brothers Hadley and Winston; and his sister Alexandra. Funeral services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ALLEN, ALLEN S.
description: ALLEN--Allen S. Happy 75th Birthday from everyone who loved you and misses you. Fay

description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BENDER, IRENE.
description: BENDER--Irene. 11/29/07 -11/28/95. Happy Birthday Dearest Auntie. Thank you for everything you did for me. Forever loved, never forgotten. Linda.

title: HEWLETT WINS $600 MILLION CONTRACT IN IRELAND
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, which in April said it was in exclusive talks to win a computer services contract from the Bank of Ireland Group, said yesterday that the agreement was completed and valued at about $600 million. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., will manage computers, printers and networks for the bank, which is based in Dublin and is Ireland's biggest lender by assets. Hewlett-Packard, which bought Compaq Computer last year to increase sales of services, this year landed its largest services order, a 10-year, $3 billion contract from Procter & Gamble, as well as orders from Ericsson and the U.S. Army. Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell 16 cents, to $21.70. Bank of Ireland rose 0.08 euro, to 10.40 euros ($12.39) in London.

title: Bush in Iraq: A November Surprise (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Montclair State Puts Streak on Line Against Ithaca
description: In 21 seasons as the football coach at Montclair State, Rick Giancola has guided the Red Hawks to seven New Jersey Athletic Conference titles, two E.C.A.C. championships and six trips to the N.C.A.A. Division III playoffs. Still, he insists that he has never seen anything like his team's run this season.

title: Iraq Exit Plan: New Obstacles
description: Two weeks ago, the Bush administration settled on an ''exit strategy'' for Iraq in which the United States committed itself to establishing self-rule there by next summer -- well ahead of its previous schedule and just as the American presidential election season will be getting under way.

title: 1996: A Watershed Draft for Underclassmen
description: In 1996, 29 college players declared for early entry, a bumper crop that included Allen Iverson, Marcus Camby, Stephon Marbury, Ray Allen and Antoine Walker.

title: At the Pierre Hotel
description: The Pierre is one of the few quasi-public domains of true wealth in New York City.

title: What Would Jeannie Do?
description: The endless rerun capacity of cable TV has switched on the lights in the attic of American design. The deep trouser pleats on ''Thirtysomething,'' the Moroccan flourishes inside Jeannie's bottle -- who knows what will inspire the next retro trend? To help us rummage through all this junk (and find a keeper or two), we sat down with three designers at the Museum of Television and Radio to watch clips of old shows. Participants were the interior designer Miles Redd, the fashion and housewares designer Cynthia Rowley and the ceramics and furniture designer Jonathan Adler.

title: A Possible Holiday Bonus: The AirTrain to Kennedy Airport May Soon Be Running
description: The much anticipated AirTrain at Kennedy International Airport was set to open last year, but a crash during testing in September 2002 killed a train driver and dashed the hopes of airport officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OWCZAR, DANIEL M.
description: OWCZAR--Daniel M. Of San Antonio, TX, died Friday, November 21, 2003 in San Antonio. The cause of death was lung cancer. Mr. Owczar was with Citibank for 34 years. Starting in 1969 as a teller, he rose to become a Vice President and Senior Director at Citibank's United States Service Center in San Antonio. He was preceded in death by his father, Daniel M. Owczar. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen Mansmann; three children from a previous marriage, Daniel III, Stefanie, and Keith; his mother, Wanda (nee Arominski); his sister, Susan; two grandchildren, Daniel IV and Emery; and a cousin, Michael Owczar. The family will receive friends on Monday evening, December 1st, from 6 o'clock to 9 o'clock as well as on Tuesday morning, December 2nd, from 9 o'clock to 11 o'clock. Service Tuesday, December 2nd, 11:00 AM, at Porter Loring Chapel, 1101 McCullough Avenue, San Antonio, TX. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to the Cancer Therapy and Research Center, P.O. Box 1657, San Antonio, TX 78296. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.porterloring.com.

title: Corrections
description: A Soapbox essay on Nov. 23 about New Jersey's structure of local governance misstated the number of boroughs in the state. It is 255, not 265.

title: A Smoother Commute Across the Sikorsky
description: Drivers no longer feel their cars vibrating and shimmying on the steel grid of the Sikorsky Memorial Bridge. Monday morning's commute was the first during which traffic between the Merritt and Wilbur Cross parkways flowed above the Housatonic River on a new bridge.

title: A Presidential Mien
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheeling and Dealing, Epstein Got His Man
description: Theo Epstein was dejected as he left Nicaragua last December, a little more than a month into his job with Boston. The youngest general manager in baseball history, Epstein had failed to land the Cuban pitcher Jos Contreras for the Red Sox.

title: No Headline
description: Bishop Robert L. DeWitt, who helped change the face of the Episcopal Church in America with the ordination of women, died on Nov. 21 in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 87.

title: The Gemtlich World Schoenberg Left Behind
description: IF Vienna at the turn of the 20th century had had a soundtrack, it would have been Schoenberg's ravishing string sextet, ''Verklrte Nacht.'' Almost everything about the piece -- its birth date, its poetic inspiration and its melting harmonies -- suggests the febrile, overripe aesthetic of that time and place, where the old was disintegrating but the new had not yet been born.

title: The Real Loss In the Elevators
description: To the Editor:

title: Tweed Upgraded
description: Men who favor finery that extends considerably beyond the blue blazer can now slip into something a little more dramatic: velvet sports coats in neutrals and earthy hues. With simple slim cuts, they can be worn with jeans or dress pants to spice up humdrum holiday dressing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALKER, TOMMY RAY
description: WALKER--Tommy Ray. Beloved husband of Eunice Salton. Father of Dallas Walker Pender. Father-in-law of John Pender IV and grandfather of Ellen Van Horn Pender. Died in Costa Rica on November 21, 2003, victim of a tragic drowning accident. Born on November 28, 1941, to Euphie and Frank Walker, he was proud to be a 5th generation Texan and native of Ft. Worth. He was a graduate of the University of Texas and a U.S. Army veteran. Professionally, he enjoyed much success as an innovative and enthusiastic advocate for futures and options markets. He served as a Vice President for Dean Witter, General Manager of Clayton Brokerage and Vice President of Marketing for two major commodities exchanges (COMEX and NYBOT), as well as a teacher and a term as a small town mayor in Texas. On a personal level, his life and work touched many people. Tom's talent and creative energy joined with his endless store of generosity, warmth, and kindness could lighten the heaviest heart and illuminate the darkest of days. He loved his family, his friends and his work without qualification. And those who had the good fortune to share his days loved him dearly in return. His loss is great; his life--a treasure. A memorial service will be held at 10 AM, Wednesday, December 3, 2003, at Trinity Church located at Broadway and Wall Street in New York City. Donations can be sent in lieu of flowers to the Tommy Walker Memorial Fund at ''Plays for Living'' (a non-profit organization that benefits at-risk youth through the arts) at 505 Eighth Ave., Suite 1202, NY, NY 10018.

title: 46 Iraqis Die in Fierce Fight Between Rebels and G.I.s
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 30 - American soldiers killed 46 guerrilla attackers in a shootout on Sunday afternoon in central Iraq, which military officials called the largest battle in the country since coalition forces toppled Saddam Hussein's government last spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CIVALE, BENJAMIN J.
description: CIVALE--Benjamin J. On November 29, 2003. Loving husband of Doris (nee Regan). Dear father of Cathleen, Christopher and Kevin. Also survived by six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Reposing Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany R.C. Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment at St. Raymond Cemetery.

title: As Stimulus, Tax Cuts May Soon Go Awry
description: LAUDING the Bush tax cuts isn't easy. They have turned a comfortable budget surplus into a constraining deficit, and they are enriching the wealthy far more than families with only five-figure incomes.

title: The World: The Talk of Iraq; A Conversation on Tiptoes, Wary of Mines
description: KNOWING what ordinary Iraqis thought was never easy for Western reporters when Saddam Hussein bestrode the land. Now his secret police and information ministry minders are gone, but not Mr. Hussein himself. So his terror still radiates among Iraqis, many of whom condition their words and actions against the possibility he may return.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Franklin Square, N.Y.; A Stable, Low-Key, Middle-Class Hamlet
description: IT seems appropriate that the water tower rising above densely residential Franklin Square bears the initials of the water district, but not the name of this nearly three-square-mile Long Island hamlet in western Nassau County.

title: Made in Connecticut, Eaten There, Too
description: THERE are now enough delicious goodies made, grown and produced in Connecticut to make holiday shopping easy. No hassle, no traffic jams, no jostling crowds, no frustration. Just a telephone call for a catalog or quick check of a Web site and you can order a wide array of edible gifts and items for the holidays. There is also the added pleasure of giving ''made-in-Connecticut'' products.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you create the most beautiful and evocative memorial that lasts 10 years, you have not truly met your objective. You must build a memorial that will last through the generations.''

description: IN the cold light of defeat, Eduard A. Shevardnadze knows what he did wrong as the failed president of Georgia, and he is prepared to acknowledge his mistake openly: too much democracy.

title: Take the Lead Out, Or at Least the Titanium
description: Governor McGreevey is an avid runner, but he won't be joining in any turkey trots this year. The governor spent the Thanksgiving holiday on crutches after having a titanium rod surgically removed from his left thigh on Tuesday.

title: Page Two; It's Beginning To Look Less Like Christmas
description: FOR those Americans who celebrate Christmas, the holiday's winsome accouterments -- mistletoe and garland, chestnuts and open fires, and of course, decorated trees -- can offer the cozy embrace of tradition in an otherwise rootless world. But then there's all that messy cleanup.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about federal energy legislation misstated a provision for uranium enrichment projects. The bill would have streamlined regulations for a plant proposed for New Mexico and shifted responsibility for its waste to the federal government, but did not authorize any federal money for it.

description: SINCE the demise of the Berlin Wall in 1989, visitors to Berlin have had a chance to explore the picturesque villages and characteristic tree-lined alleys of the city's rural hinterland, particularly the surrounding Mark Brandenburg, which encompasses most of the current state of Brandenburg.

While Mr. Jonze is related to the family that founded the Spiegel catalog (his real name is Adam Spiegel), he is not an heir.

description: Scotland's baby bust is echoing noisily in the political system.

title: Saratoga Springs Sophomore Returning to the National Finals
description: Nicole Blood, an undefeated 15-year-old sophomore from Saratoga Springs High School in New York, raced to a 32-second victory yesterday in the Northeast Regional High School Cross-Country Championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Her time was 17 minutes 45 seconds on the hilly 5,000-meter (3.1-mile) course.

title: A Dog's Gotta Bark, And Tenants Gotta Fuss
description: Sharon Klein remembers the pitiful, raspy noises that Eddie Vecchione's dog made years ago when the animal had its vocal cords removed. The goal was to appease Mr. Vecchione's barking-weary neighbors on the 14th floor of the Regency East Apartments, a co-op on East 64th Street near Second Avenue.

title: It's Trade School, But With a New Focus
description: ELIZABETH JANSON is a senior at Yorktown High School with a 93 percent average, a competitive volleyball player and the state president of a national student leadership organization. As she makes plans to attend a good college next year, Miss Janson knows that she will graduate from high school with a skill that she can use to pay for a sizeable chunk of her education.

title: Revamping Stables With Eye on the Past
description: IN refurbishing horse stalls and making plans to hang brass chandeliers in the high-ceilinged foyer, which opens into the cavernous indoor riding ring, David K. Boley is trying to restore the lost glory of a horse club that was a center of local society life and sporting life in the early and middle 20th century.

title: 'Saturday Night' Campaign Fever
description: This Saturday, presidential hopeful Rev. Al Sharpton will host ''Saturday Night Live'' -- the 10th politician to take the stage. Though hardly a front-runner, he'll fulfill what has become a perverse ritual for office-seekers: demonstrating a sense of humor by any means necessary. For someone like Mr. Sharpton -- who spent years known as the the big-haired activist tainted by the Tawana Brawley case -- the appearance seems like an odd choice. Why wreck years of slow gravitas-building with one flippant night?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOER, MICHELE TORTOMASI AKA PEGGY
description: BOER -- Michele Tortomasi aka Peggy. Devoted and beloved sister, aunt, cousin and friend. Cherished wife of the late John Boer. Peggy was born December 16, 1912. She passed November 22, 2003. Business representative in the education department of ILGWU. Retired in 1975. Lifelong union activist. Cat lover extraordinaire. Involved in animal rights and an outstanding gourmet cook. Will be remembered with love and dearly missed. Funeral services on Monday, December 1st, 12 PM at Trinity Cemetery located at 153 Street and Riverside Drive.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Nov. 9, about Stowe, Vt., included a ski center erroneously, and omitted another, in a grouping of cross-country ski areas that make up a 93-mile trail system that honors a $15 adult day ticket. Topnotch at Stowe Resort and Spa, not Stoweflake Resort, should have been included. •

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 9 about adaptations of works by Saul Bellow, Philip Roth and John Updike misspelled the surname of an actress in the film of Mr. Roth's ''Goodbye, Columbus.'' She is Ali MacGraw, not McGraw.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 30, 2003
description: Weeks

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Trying to Keep a House She Signed Away
description: The four-family red brick house on 96th Street in East Flatbush where Mae Ruth Little has lived for more than three decades seems worn and frail these days, just like its 76-year-old owner. Paint is peeling off the walls, tiles are missing from the kitchen ceiling and the linoleum is cracked and faded.

title: 7 SPANISH AGENTS AND 2 JAPANESE ARE SLAIN IN IRAQ
description: Seven Spanish intelligence officers and two Japanese diplomats were killed Saturday in separate ambushes in Iraq, the latest in a series of attacks against America's allies that seemed intended to drive a wedge between them.

title: In a Homeland Far From Home
description: The United States bears some burden of responsibility for the well-being of Cambodian refugees, even if it is simplistic to blame the United States alone for drawing Cambodia into the Vietnam War 30 years ago. We also need to think of the larger costs to American society of the deportations of men and women who are leaving children, spouses and elderly parents behind. We will bear a significant portion of the burden of these domestic disruptions through increased dependence on public assistance and other publicly funded social services.

title: Reform Is Needed on Field, in Class
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, SIDNEY O.
description: THOMPSON--Sidney O. Died peacefully at age 83 November 28, 2003, in Litchfield Park, AZ. Former resident of Pound Ridge, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Mercedes (Huppeler) Thompson and three children, Pamela G. Thompson of Falmouth, MA, Gretchen T. Goodwillie of Geneva, IL, and Craig S. Thompson of New Canaan, CT, a sister, Ardis Mathis of Carpenteria, CA, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A former banking and insurance executive, Sidney was a founder of Hudson Valley Bank in Yonkers, NY, and served as chairman from 1976 to 1982. He was the Flagship producer for the New England Life Insurance Co. for nearly two decades. Contributions in Sidney's memory may be sent to the Hudson Valley Foundation, 21 Scarsdale Rd., Yonkers, NY 10701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANKUS, SEYMOUR
description: YANKUS--Seymour. Dearest dad, love is a precious gift and it will keep us together always. You are in our hearts forever. Lauren, George, Emily Landress and Marc Yankus

title: Page Two: Nov. 23-29; RE-OPENED FOR BUSINESS
description: In the most tangible way yet, the site of the former World Trade Center began its slow metamorphosis into something more than a place of loss: commuters returned aboard the PATH train. Last Sunday, the ceremonial reopening of the rebuilt World Trade Center station was mostly attended by the important and the curious. But by Monday, the station was filled with the suited, workaday crowds of Lower Manhattan. A few cried as they gripped the station's latticework walls and stared at ground zero, but others just charged up the escalators to get to work.

title: Investing; For Benefits Managers, a Very Good Year
description: FOR small businesses, hiring employees and administering benefits can be big headaches. Gevity HR and Administaff are companies that take on these burdens for other businesses.

title: Sex-Ed Night School
description: Those Hollywood writers Walter Kirn refers to (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 16) are misleading today's young people into believing that young adults in New York City cruise effortlessly through life, swapping sexual partners with greater ease than they would a latte.

title: In an Uncertain World
description: ON THE EVENING OF January 10, 1995, I stood on the Great Seal woven into the carpet of the Oval Office and swore to uphold the Constitution of the United States as Secretary of the Treasury. Confirmed earlier that day, I had been waiting all afternoon for the official document that would allow me to take the oath of office. Once the papers arrived from Capitol Hill, a small group of family, friends, and colleagues assembled at the White House for a hasty ceremony.

title: Price Is Right
description: I occasionally traffic in Persian carpets. A fellow came over about one I'd advertised for $130. He offered $160 -- evidently he remembered the $175 price of another carpet and was trying to bargain. I accepted, and we each felt we got a great deal. My housemate, Dave, says, ''No harm, no foul.'' My wife thinks I ripped the guy off. Counsel? J. C., California

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VERDERY, SUZANNE (ALD RICH)
description: VERDERY -- Suzanne (Ald rich). 83, died November 20, 2003, in her home, Camden, ME. Born on November 8, 1920, Fall River, MA, the daughter of The Right Rev. Donald B. Aldrich and Frances (Learned) Aldrich. A graduate from Wellesley College (BA in History), and the wife of The Rev. John D. Verdery (1917-1985), Headmaster of The Wooster School (1943-1976), Danbury, CT. Few women are as liberated from the bounds of their sex, the restrictions of motherhood, the etiquette of table and parlor, the confusions of the church, and the will of God as Suzanne Verdery was; and few-men or women-are as specifically proud of their sex, mindful of their parenthood, devoted to the common sense of courtesy, meaningful in their worship and obedient to The Word as she was. Suzanne Verdery is survived by her four children-Joan, Daniel, Donald, Benjamin--and six grandchildren. Memorial service: James Marshall Chapel, Wooster School, Danbury, CT, 2PM, March 27, 2004. Instead of flowers, donations may be made to PALS, P.O. Box 309, Camden, ME 04843 or to The John D. Verdery Library at The Wooster School, Ridgebury Rd, Danbury, CT 06810.

title: Them Against the World, Part 2
description: Austin Bunn's article (Nov. 16) offers a look into the workings of anarchists, hellbent on chaos for its own sake, inspired by that latter-day flower child Lisa Fithian, who thrives on mob unrest but who has no vision for a better world. She wants us to live in a ''Mad Max'' desert of nihilism, in which we all somehow grow vegetables. Her only aim in life is to create crisis so that change can take place. Change? How? Where? The police should put her and her co-conspirators in a cooling pen for a while, until they can learn to live among others.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Needs Work, but It Shows Well
description: KATHARINE HEPBURN'S house needs a little work, but it is still ''Kate's house,'' so the $12 million asking price isn't scaring off prospective buyers.

title: Vote Getters
description: Back in the days when people happily hunkered down to listen to two- and three-hour perorations from their local Congressman, American politics was all about words. (Were speakers better back then, or was it just that nobody had anything better to do?) We began shifting to the era of images after photography was invented and people began noticing that Franklin Pierce was a good-looking son of a gun and that William Howard Taft was kind of fat. More than half a century ago, Dwight Eisenhower hired the actor Robert Montgomery to make sure he looked good on the new medium of television, and these days a presidential campaign isn't much more than one long, fast-moving photo op. But for all of politicians' obsession with the way things look, modern campaigns have been amazingly short of memorable images. Next year, in commercials all over the country, candidates will be paying their media experts to make their opponents' faces morph into Saddam Hussein -- or if it's Chicago, the guy who grabbed the ball at that Cubs game.

title: Do-Good Marketing
description: IT is tough to come up with fresh ideas for raising funds, even for the best of causes. But two New Jerseyans, working separately and in different ways, are helping to plow new ground. Their tack is casual get-togethers held in ordinary homes or in bars, with a decided emphasis on socializing, much like Tupperware or Mary Kay cosmetics parties. Yet they are raising real money, even as the sour economy and scandals in the industry have made fund-raising increasingly competitive.

title: Horse of Year Contender Strengthens His Case
description: No Pan Intended was virtually assured the Horse of the Year honor in harness racing by winning his event in the Breeders Crown on Saturday night at the Meadowlands. He withstood a strong challenge at the end and captured the $542,500 event for 3-year-old pacers on a night of eight Breeders Crown races.

title: Corrections
description: The diagramless puzzle in The Times Magazine last Sunday provided an erroneous clue for 21 Down, seeking the answer ''Colin.'' Colin Powell is secretary of state, not defense.

title: For Sale: Town Hall, Officials Not Included
description: Perusing the real estate ads in the lower Connecticut River Valley, an unusual offering sticks out. Officials in Chester are taking bids for its former town hall, a brick building built in 1940. It is 3,600 square feet, has an outdoor bulletin board and a vault. The minimum bid is $365,000.

title: India Announces Plans to Expand AIDS Therapy Programs
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 30  India has decided to expand substantially its program to provide antiretroviral therapy to people with H.I.V. and AIDS, government officials say.

title: Recycling Difficulties Must Be Overcome
description: We all understand that garbage disposal is a necessity. But we now have the ability to transform waste matter into usable, productive materials, creating a double home run for the environment and community at large. Recycling clearly reduces the amount of garbage with which we must deal.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions
