title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NIXON, HELEN (MCGRAW)
description: NIXON--Helen (McGraw), of Laguna Woods, CA; formerly of Wantagh, NY, on November 25. Beloved wife of the late Richard J. Nixon; devoted mother of Claire N. Ryan of Rockville Centre, NY, Richard T. Nixon, Esq. of San Diego, CA., Nora N. Derenze of Mission Viejo, CA, Daniel V. Nixon, Esq. of San Marino, CA and John T. Nixon of Alexandria, VA; loving mother-in-law of James B. Ryan, Maureen R. Nixon, Thomas P. Derenze, Diana M. Nixon and Barbara Brogan; cherished grandmother of Ted, Paul, Madeline, Joseph, Caroline and Paige; sister-in-law of the late Anne Nixon; daughter of the late Anna and James E. McGraw; sister of Lorraine Moore, Dolores McGraw, Dorothea McGraw, Margaret Murphy and the late James McGraw. The success and happiness her family has achieved is a result of her selfless love and devotion. She was a wonderful mother, we loved her and will always miss her. Our sorrow is endless. May God love her and keep her. ''May flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.'' There will be a private family service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, 341 West 38 St, 10th floor, NY NY 10018.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENS, EDITH
description: STEVENS--Edith, age 89, on November 28, 2003. Mourned by her sons Howard (Diana) and Robert (Rhonda), grandchildren Rebecca (Dan Broden), Elizabeth and Mara Stevens, great-grandchildren Lila and Isabella Broden, and nieces, nephews and friends. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: The Chant Not Heard
description: I stood on the sidewalk in London the other day and watched thousands of antiwar, anti-George Bush, anti-Tony Blair protesters pass by. They chanted every antiwar slogan you could imagine and many you couldn't print. It was entertaining -- but also depressing, because it was so disconnected from the day's other news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAILICK, SIDNEY
description: MAILICK--Sidney. Age 80, of Forest Hills, NY, on November 28, 2003, in New York City. Beloved husband of Mildred for 56 years. Devoted father of Daniel and Marsha. Father-in-law of Lydia Read and Gary Seltzer. Cherished grandfather of Beth, Rebecca, Adina and Rachel. Loving brother of Belle and Helen. He was Professor of Public Administration at New York University from 1958 through 1993 and consultant to the Government of Israel, the United Nations and the U.S. Department of State. His passion for Israel and the Jewish people knew no bounds. Services will be held today, 12 noon, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to a charity of your choice.

title: Capt. Charlton Heston
description: To the Editor:

title: Get Credit Where Credit Is Due
description: Time is running out to collect your child tax credit checks.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; FILM
description: Historic movie epics seem to be all the rage this holiday season. But Hollywood has a keen eye on ''The Last Samurai,'' the fictional story of a Civil War veteran who travels to Japan in the 1870's, which opens on Friday. The movie, which stars Tom Cruise, is generating early Oscar buzz for its costumes and cinematography. But many people are wondering whether Mr. Cruise, who has been nominated three times but never won, will earn another nomination. Laura M. Holson

title: A Partial List of Tony Kushners Current Political Preoccupations
description: ebt reduction for developing nations."

title: That Pudgy Pooch Is an Industry's Best Friend
description: UNLIKE their diet-crazed owners, America's pets don't care a whit about rock-hard abs. Most dogs and cats have yet to meet a buttery table scrap they didn't like, no matter how much kibble they have consumed.

title: Those Who Serve, Those Who Are Served
description: ON a recent Monday afternoon, men gathered like crows around a black Lamborghini parked outside the Pierre Hotel. Tucked into their dark suits, they all had the conspicuous sheen that comes from a lifetime of elliptical training, beef cheeks and Chteau Margaux.

title: Iraqi Governing Council Voices Support for June Elections
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 30  The Iraqi Governing Council, responding to demands from senior Shiite clergy, agreed by a unanimous vote today that full, national elections would be the best way to choose an interim government next June.

title: Corrections
description: The Photographer's Journal caption last Sunday, with a picture showing a poster with a disembodied face and hands in a trash can, misstated the location. It was Third Avenue in Manhattan, not Fourth Avenue.

title: Lauren DiSavino, Stephen Olefson
description: Lauren Jodie DiSavino, a daughter of Eileen B. and Leonard P. DiSavino of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday on the island of St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, to Stephen Mathew Olefson, a son of Dr. Arnold Olefson of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Dr. Ruth Spiegel Olefson. Rabbi Sarah H. Reines officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Charlotte Amalie.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about federal energy legislation misstated a provision for uranium enrichment projects. The bill would have streamlined regulations for a plant proposed for New Mexico and shifted responsibility for its waste to the federal government, but did not authorize any federal money for it.

title: On Indian Point, Quieter Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Greening Of Suburbia
description: TOYOTA, which did not become big by thinking small, has grander plans for its Lexus RX sport utility wagon. The RX, already a generation ahead of the competition, will take another leap next fall with a hybrid gasoline-electric version that will test the willingness of the upper-middle class to vote for greener vehicles with their monthly payments.

title: Antidotes For Blues Of Winter
description: THE sooner you start growing houseplants, the better you'll feel about winter. Nothing keeps a gardener from going stir crazy like a house full of green things sending up new shoots, groping for the best spot of sun, maybe even blooming. Of course, the antidote only works if those houseplants thrive.

description: Laureen Connelly Rowland and John Leonard Mutuski were married on Friday at the Crestwood Chapel and Pavilion, a bed-and-breakfast in Ashuelot, N.H. The Rev. Bonnie McCarthy, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

description: To the Editor:

description: THE switch is on.

title: Hamming It Down in Japan
description: The Nippon-Ham Fighters are the ''Fighters,'' not the ''Ham Fighters.'' That is, Nippon-Ham is the owner of the team, which plays in the Nippon Professional Baseball league in Japan. It's simply a bit of misfortune that the organization's full name suggests lunch-meat gladiators.

title: The Beast Of Queens
description: The Van Wyck Expressway is a legendary traffic hazard, but it has probably never inspired the sense of imperial doom that it does now. Right down the middle of the highway stands a line of gigantic concrete columns, one after the other, holding up some sort of track. When I first saw it, I suspected a boondoggle, a private highway for those who pay extra on their E-Z Pass. But actually, it's AirTrain, a highly touted monorail system that is soon supposed to whisk riders from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport and thrust the whole prehistoric city toward a gleamingly efficient future.

title: Never Again?
description: In some ways today's reemergence of anti-Semitism in a time of turmoil is predictable and unsurprising - although it's profoundly disappointing to realize how quickly millions of people seem to have forgotten the lessons of the Holocaust. What's most troubling is the way today's new anti-Semitism combines traditional bigotry and hatred with modern resentments in a way that is unprecedented and particularly virulent. The process is furthest advanced and most visible in the Middle East and on the continent of Europe, but it can be observed also in the United States, in Latin America, and in other countries around the world - even those, like Japan, in which very few Jews can be found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAVER, ALICE CRAFTS
description: SHAVER--Alice Crafts. Died peacefully November 26 in Oberlin, Ohio, age 89. Loved for her trenchant wit, her curiosity and her gift for friendship, she was a model of imaginative service to others. Wife of the late Chester Linn Shaver. Survived by a son, Phillip A. Shaver of Princeton, and daughter Annie ShaverCrandell of New York City, three grandchildren and eight nieces and nephews.

description: Florida's Elderly Skeptical Of Medicare Drug Benefit

title: At 72, a Dogged Rather Is Not Yet Ready to Yield
description: At lunchtime in a hotel dining room here the other day, Dan Rather stood before a group of car dealers, jewelry store owners and furniture wholesalers, sounding more like a politician on the hustings than the network news anchor he is every weekday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRATA, HERBERT CHARLES
description: KRATA -- Herbert Charles. Died November 26, 2003, at age 68, after a courageous battle with lung cancer. Beloved husband, devoted father, adoring grandfather.

title: Babylon Feels Republic Has Become Land Hungry
description: Claiming that Republic Airport in Farmingdale is seeking to expand by swallowing up adjacent property under the guise of safety, the supervisor of Babylon Town is striking back.

title: Tiny Bubbles, Subtle Taste
description: Loire vintners call local sparkling wines fines bulles (fine bubbles). Domaine Champalou's nonvintage Vouvray Brut, one of the finest, emulates Champagne. Kermit Lynch, a Berkeley, Calif., merchant whose name symbolizes excellence, imports it. Beautifully balanced, tantalizing, Champalou is a carousel of subtle flavors like anise and orange zest.

title: Mini-Series; Golda Meir; Movie Piracy; Wheres Charley?
description: MINI-SERIES

title: In the Beginning, There Was Leather. . . .
description: If you dream of a handbag, chances are you dream of Herms. In the last decade, the Kelly and its sister, the Birkin, have become symbols of taste and class. But when the Kelly was introduced in 1930, no one showed much interest. Not until 1956, when Grace Kelly used the purse to shield her pregnant belly from a photographer, was the bag elevated to celebrity status. To understand why a Kelly costs $5,500 (or more) and requires a year's wait (or more), we requested an Herms bag in red box leather, 35 centimeters long. Instead, we received the bag in a smaller size (32 centimeters), and the more rigid leather was replaced by a soft, pebbly skin they call ''fjord.'' So the dream is deferred, but the process still dazzles.

title: Inexperience Catches Up With Brazilian Appointees
description: The country's leading newsmagazine calls it ''the most radical and voracious partisanization of the state bureaucratic structure'' in Brazilian history. Since taking office at the start of the year, President Luiz Incio da Silva has stuffed government ministries and agencies with political appointees, many of them unseasoned, and the country is now feeling the effect of their efforts to learn on the job.

title: Less Charity, Please
description: ALL right, enough with school charity. I'm all for helping the needy and for teaching children to help those who need it. But it seems my son's school is constantly asking for handouts.

title: The Nation; The High Costs of Rising Incivility on Capitol Hill
description: EVER since Thomas Jefferson presided over the United States Senate as vice president, the chamber has had not only a tradition of civility but rules requiring it. So there were more than a few raised eyebrows earlier this month when the Senate's No. 2 Democrat, Harry Reid of Nevada, marched up to the crowded press gallery and, in a fit of pique at Senate Majority Leader Bill Frist of Tennessee, declared, ''I've never seen such amateur leadership in all the time I've been in Congress, 21 years.''

title: Aladdin As Customer Service Genie
description: WHERE will you find classes of young people painstakingly learning the names of America's state capitals, earnestly watching episodes of ''Friends'' and doggedly trying to distinguish between ''unh-unh,'' meaning no, and ''uh-huh,'' meaning yes?

title: Editorial Observer; Living in Minas Tirith: New Zealand Becomes the Land of 'The Making of . . .'
description: When I was growing up in New Zealand, I used to read J. R. R. Tolkien's ''Rings'' trilogy on the way to school each day as I rode the train past a quarry full of earth-moving equipment. Twenty-five years later, the quarry became part of that same story. After New Zealand was chosen as the place where ''The Fellowship of the Ring'' and its two sequels were to be filmed, the quarry was re-imagined by cinematic set makers as Helm's Deep and Minas Tirith, two evocative locales in the saga.

title: Kings And Nets In a Tale Of 2 Arenas
description: The two places where Byron Scott has coached basketball are separated by a few thousand miles, a few thousand fans and a few hundred decibels.

title: Diagnosis
description: Your headline should have read: ''Diagnosis: Ugly.'' Lisa Sanders's article (Nov. 16) conveys, far more clearly than its intended point, that for women to be attractive, they must be small, light-voiced, thin and hairless. If they fail in these points, even their doctors will notice. Although Sanders's conclusion that too much insulin can alter appearance is relevant, her narrative reads like a horror story from a 1950's magazine: ''Help me, Doctor! I look like a MAN!''

title: Repairing the System Of Local Governance

description: Mary Susannah Shay and Michael Thomas Millea were married last evening in New York. The Rev. Park Bodie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: A Promise, and a Future, Left to Die on the A Train
description: Shamel Garrett awoke early on the morning after Thanksgiving at his girlfriend's home. They had not dated or seen each other in about two years, but it was coming back fast on this whirlwind week. They even spoke quietly of marriage, she said, a secret they were keeping from their families.

title: Taxes, Town and Gown
description: MAYOR MARVIN REED is hardly sympathetic to a financial plea from the Cottage Club, one of a dozen Princeton University eating clubs along Prospect Avenue on the northern edge of the campus.

description: The Medicare bill passed by Congress last week includes sizable increases in payments to hospitals, but under formulas intended mostly to help small-town hospitals, little of that money will go to the New York metropolitan area.

title: Drawing With Scissors
description: Romare Bearden was ''probably the most saintly person I have ever known,'' recalled the owner of Books & Company on Madison Avenue near the Whitney Museum; the artist spent almost every Saturday afternoon at Books until his death in 1988. Bearden sliced up many of his beloved books for the sake of his collages, in which he always stayed close to black American culture in subject matter while stylistically roaming the lexicon of modern art. Yet we are given these vivid details only on the last page of Ruth Fine's studious text in THE ART OF ROMARE BEARDEN (National Gallery of Art/Abrams, $50), which, disappointingly, does not make the man leap off the page as palpably as his images -- pieced together with the sensibility of jazz or quilting from photocopies, sandpaper, fabric, foil and his own paintings. (''The skill with which he wielded his scissors transformed that implement into a refined drawing tool,'' Fine observes.) She does an admirable job bridging the numerous gaps in Bearden scholarship (even the year of his birth is questionable, but she settles on 1911). As a young man Bearden was molded both by the work of George Grosz at the Art Students League and the intellectual community in Harlem. His art would always straddle the two realms above and below 110th Street; one reviewer wrote in 1971, Bearden ''explores his culture and our culture with the delicate sensuality of a good physician feeling for broken bones.'' Whether this ''double consciousness'' posed internal conflict for Bearden -- Fine refers to an emotional breakdown in 1956 -- remains elliptical, even in his own words: ''There are roads out of the secret places within us along which we all must move as we go to touch others.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Necessity Is the Mother of Invention
description: Striding down a hallway at M.I.T., Amy Smith has a bucket in one hand and a length of string in the other. The brain behind such creations as the phase-change incubator, she is on her way to the Charles River to retrieve some dirty water for her next class. As she lopes along, Smith describes the ordeals of testing water in remote villages. Her words spurt out. She's a woman on fast-forward, and she does not so much talk as download information.

title: Business; Are Late Nights the Answer for a U.S. Gateway?
description: AS Americans begin their holiday buying binge, the odds are strong that they will eventually bring home something that arrived in this country through the giant port complex at Los Angeles and Long Beach.

title: Monterey Celebrates Its Spanish Heritage
description: Santas are sprouting across the land, heralding the approach of Christmas. But in several communities near Monterey Bay, Calif., the season will also be marked by annual events evoking the state's Spanish and Mexican heritage.

title: Sea of Glory
description: Most sailors did not refer to it as the Pacific Ocean. They called it the South Sea, a name that dated back to 1513 when Vasco Nunez de Balboa ventured across the sliver of mountainous, jungle-choked terrain known as the Isthmus of Panama. The isthmus runs west to east so that when Balboa first glimpsed water, it appeared to extend to the south. Quite sensibly, he dubbed his discovery the Great South Sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLYNN, BRYCE (BUZ) JR.
description: BLYNN--Bryce (Buz) Jr. 79, Vero Beach, FL, and Riverside, CT died Thursday, November 27th, at home in Riverside. The son of Mabel Howard Post Reid and Bryce Blynn, he was born in Philadelphia, PA. He grew up in Chestnut Hill, and graduated in 1942 from Chestnut Hill Academy, where he was captain of the football team. In 2003, he and his undefeated team were inducted into the Chestnut Hill Academy Hall of Fame. He attended Princeton University class of 1946. During World War II he served as a pilot in the Army Air Corps. He joined Time, Inc. in 1947, working in advertising sales for LIFE magazine from its inception through 1970. He then joined Sports Illustrated, where he became Assistant Sales Director until his retirement in 1979. In late 1979, Blynn created a publishers' representative firm in Coral Gables, FL which he sold in 1990. Blynn was married in 1946 to Dorothy Nash of Lincoln, NE, who died in 1987. They are survived by their children, Larry Blynn, Sandra Staniar, and Bryce Blynn III; his brother Harry, and his sister-in-law Sydney. Blynn married Mary Frances Gulliver of Riverside, CT, in 1988. She survives him along with Joseph and Pamela (Maffei) McCarthy, Mary Frances Maffei, John and Susan (Maffei) Plowden, Allan and Jenny Gulliver, David and Tina Gulliver, John and Lynne Erkkinen, Peter and Susan Carlson, seven grandchildren, eleven stepgrandchildren, nine greatgrandchildren, and his beloved dog Foxy. Blynn was a member of Hawk's Nest Golf Club, The Moorings Club, and the Princeton Club, all of Vero Beach. In Greenwich, CT, he was also a member of Greenwich Country Club, and the Riverside Yacht Club. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM on Monday, December 1st, at the Greenwich Country Club, 19 Doubling Road, Greenwich, CT. There will also be a memorial service in Vero Beach, FL at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Greenwich Hospital Home Care Hospice, 25 Valley Drive, Greenwich, CT 06830, and to AlcoHope of the Treasure Coast, Inc., 5925 37 St., Vero Beach, FL 32966.

They had somehow made it through the troubled amateur basketball landscape in the United States with a grasp of the fundamentals, a solid understanding of the game and a readiness for the N.B.A.

title: Four Seasons' Nod to Island
description: Julian Niccolini, an owner of the Four Seasons in Manhattan, admits that it was only last February that he fully learned about the potential of East End wines. That month, the Long Island Wine Council and his restaurant jointly sponsored a dinner to celebrate the local industry's 30th anniversary.

title: Immersed In Baden-Baden
description: HERE'S the drill at the Friedrichsbad in Baden-Baden. First you take off all your clothes, men in one room, women in the other. Then, stark naked, you proceed from one stage to another of what might be called the ultimate hot spring process. Stage 1: a nice hot shower; Stages 2 and 3: warm air baths in vaulted chambers of hand-painted tiles, the second hotter than the first. Then, after another shower, and if you've paid the extra 10 bucks, you do Stage 4, a vigorous soap and brush rubdown by a trained professional (of the same sex as the client).

title: The Cacophony of Life in America

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: RETIREMENT is depressing for Warren Schmidt (Jack Nicholson). Leaving the office for the last time is depressing, the farewell dinner is depressing, and finding his wife (June Squibb) dead on the kitchen floor soon afterward is the last straw. So Warren fires up the gigantic Winnebago his wife persuaded him to buy and goes on a road trip in Alexander Payne's ABOUT SCHMIDT (2002). The journey will end at the wedding of his daughter (Hope Davis), an event he hopes she'll cancel. Mr. Nicholson gives an ennobling, typically brilliant performance, but Kathy Bates, as his white-trash in-law-to-be, is mesmerizing, and when the two of them are on screen together, it's almost too much fun -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4 a.m. on Starz.

title: A Record-Setting Day For Bailey at Aqueduct
description: Easily the top jockey in the country, Jerry Bailey has had plenty of spectacular afternoons at the track during his career, but few quite like this. In a span of less than an hour at Aqueduct yesterday, Bailey set two records, won three stakes races and firmed up the mount on a contender for next year's Kentucky Derby.

description: A more conventional Rhodes Scholarship recipient could, perhaps, take it easy before heading off to Oxford University in the fall for that ultimate academic honor.

title: Most Popular Travel Vehicle: a Whim
description: FOR travelers who have put off making holiday reservations, there's some early cheer: as late as the week before Thanksgiving, rooms were still available at popular winter resorts -- on the ski slopes and on the beaches. At a time when most hotels are usually booked solid, late planners could even find bargains on the Web. ''There are still plenty of opportunities for any number of cruises and resorts,'' said Karen Crager, public relations manager for 11thHourVacations.com, a site serving late bookers. ''But if you are looking at a specific travel date, I would advise you to book soon to get the maximum amount of choice.''

title: Laugh Lines Where You Most Expect Them
description: Chuck Lorre may be the award-winning writer and producer of several hit sitcoms, but he still gets upset at the term ''canned laughs.'' ''There are microphones hanging over 250 people, and we record what they do,'' he said, referring to audiences at the tapings of his new CBS series, ''Two and a Half Men.'' ''And they'll let you know when the material doesn't work -- by the career-sucking silence.''

title: The Intern as Hipster
description: THE first time Tim Grant saw the Strokes play live, it was cool. He was still in high school, and he got to see them play an intimate show at a tiny club in St. Louis, near his hometown in southern Illinois.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRUPP, A. PHILIP
description: KRUPP--A. Philip. Ben-Gurion University of the Negev and The American Associates family mourn the loss of Philip Krupp, a dear friend who helped establish American Associates, Ben-Gurion University in 1972. Philip served on the AABGU National Board and as a past president for the New England region. Many of the University's successes can be attributed to his generosity and vision. We are forever grateful. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Bernice, George and Lizbeth, Douglas and Judith, Joanne and the entire Krupp family. Lord Weidenfeld, Chairman, Board of Governors, BGU Prof. Avishay Braverman, President, BGU Lis Gaines, Pres, AABGU

title: The Index of Missing Economic Indicators; The Productivity Paradox

But there is one aspect of the economy on which agreement is nearly unanimous: America's miraculous productivity. In the third quarter, productivity grew by 8.1 percent in the nonfarm business sector -- a figure likely to be revised upwards -- and it has grown at an average rate of 5.4 percent in the last two years.

title: Is This Child a Threat to His School?

After all, Dylan's mother, Beth, recalled that she started enjoying that genre of scary movie when she was about Dylan's age.

title: 'Oracle Night'
description: I began with small outings, no more than a block or two from my apartment and then home again. I was only thirty-four, but for all intents and purposes the illness had turned me into an old man-one of those palsied, shuffling geezers who can't put one foot in front of the other without first looking down to see which foot is which. Even at the slow pace I could manage then, walking produced an odd, airy lightness in my head, a free-for-all of mixed-up signals and crossed mental wires. The world would bounce and swim before my eyes, undulating like reflections in a wavy mirror, and whenever I tried to look at just one thing, to isolate a single object from the onrush of whirling colors-a blue scarf wrapped around a woman's head, say, or the red taillight of a passing delivery truck-it would immediately begin to break apart and dissolve, disappearing like a drop of dye in a glass of water. Everything shimmied and wobbled, kept darting off in different directions, and for the first several weeks I had trouble telling where my body stopped and the rest of the world began. I bumped into walls and trash bins, got tangled up in dog leashes and scraps of floating paper, stumbled on the smoothest sidewalks. I had lived in New York all my life, but I didn't understand the streets and crowds anymore, and every time I went out on one of my little excursions, I felt like a man who had lost his way in a foreign city.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

description: Pointing a Finger Toward Safer Subways

title: America Tunes In For the Money Shot
description: THERE'S not much meat left on Michael Jackson's bones. He is 5 foot 11 and weighs 120 pounds. His face is falling off. But that doesn't mean we can't feast on him for what could be at least a year of what TV calls ''celebrity justice.'' In that time there will be a presidential campaign, an election and war. But it's possible that nothing, the red meat of Kobe included, will upstage the thriller from Neverland -- nothing, that is, short of the kind of domestic terrorist attack that forced us to wrench our attention away from Gary Condit and rampaging sharks two autumns ago.

title: The Good Fortune of One Man's Fork in the Road
description: MIDWAY through autumn, I drove through an area so beautiful it took my breath away. It was Seven Lakes Drive in Harriman State Park, and I was there to celebrate the birthday of William J. Myles, author of the indispensable ''Harriman Trails, A Guide and History.''

description: There is no reason Showtime's version of ''The Reagans'' could not have been broadcast on CBS earlier this month.

title: Two? Two Museums For Children?
description: TWO separate plans for children's museums have surfaced in Westchester, one in White Plains that is on a developer's drawing boards and one in Rye that is a gleam in the eye of a young nonprofit group. Both have a kind of official backing, and one -- or even both -- could be realized, taking Westchester from a county with no children's museums to a county with two of them.

title: The Democratic Majority Shouldn't Get Comfortable

The victory has put the Democrats in total control of the State House for the first time since 1991.

title: Salvagers Say a Shipwreck Trove Is Worth Millions
description: It lay in darkness at the bottom of the Atlantic for more than a century, guarded only by the occasional shark. Now, the 150-year-old steamship has a visitor: a robot bristling with lights, cameras and mechanical arms that is picking its way through the wreckage, hauling up a fortune in gold and silver coins, eventually perhaps 30,000 of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WACHENHEIM, EDGAR, JR.
description: WACHENHEIM--Edgar, Jr. The Board of Directors and staff of The Guidance Center mourn the passing of Edgar Wachenheim, Jr., Honorary Chairman of the Board, gracious philanthropist, passionate advocate for social action and beloved friend. Generous with his time, wisdom and good counsel, he was a tireless volunteer who was admired for his leadership and adored for his warmth and down to earth manner. His love for all humanity was inspirational and will endure as a role model for all to emulate. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Elizabeth and their family. A memorial service will be held at Beach Point Club, Mamaroneck at 10.30 AM on December 14, 2003.

title: Habitats/Sullivan County; A Couple Refashions City Lives Into Country
description: SANDRA JETTON and David Picker's new house sits just above a knob of land on the Toronto Reservoir in Bethel, N.Y., in Sullivan County, two and a half hours from Manhattan. The other day, a snow squall blew down the reservoir from the west and rounded the peninsula with such speed that for a moment the sky was neatly divided into two weather systems: the storm to the west, brilliant blue to the east.

title: Old School on the Slopes
description: Ski enthusiasts looking for an alternative to the parka-princess look of Aspen 2003 can now transport themselves sartorially back to Grenoble 1968 via Vintage Alpine, a company that sells never-worn vintage ski wear from the late 1960's and early 70's. Rife with nostalgia-inducing brands like Gerry, Montant and Hoggs of Hawick, selections include pompommed knit hats ($5 to $15), striped stretch ski pants by Sport Hauser ($50), patterned turtlenecks ($10 to $30) and long-haired lamb fur boots by Killy ($400). About 1,500 pieces of the collection will make their first retail appearance at the Manhattan Vintage Clothing Show on Dec. 1 and 2 (www.manhattanvintage.com). The rest will be available in the middle of December at www.vintagealpine.com (207-772-7842).

title: Executive Life; The Holiday Party as a Leading Indicator

title: Business; To Save Factories, Owners Diversify
description: THE 1,200 workers at the streamlined, automated plant here that makes Polartec, the popular cold-weather fabric, are having to live with the possibility that their jobs will be exported to China. If that happens, their chances of finding other work that pays as well are slim.

title: Oracle Night
description: Ihad been sick for a long time. When the day came for me to leave the hospital, I barely knew how to walk anymore, could barely remember who I was supposed to be. Make an effort, the doctor said, and in three or four months you'll be back in the swing of things. I didn't believe him, but I followed his advice anyway. They had given me up for dead, and now that I had confounded their predictions and mysteriously failed to die, what choice did I have but to live as though a future life were waiting for me?

title: Ideas & Trends; Well, It Seemed Like a Good Idea At the Time
description: ''BUT what are the worst accomplishments?'' the interviewer asked. We had been discussing great accomplishments in the arts and sciences, a subject on which I've written. The question stopped me cold. Art and science that are simply bad have no ''worst'' -- all of it is equally unimportant. But the unintended consequences of great art and science are another question. Einstein did not have nuclear weapons in mind when he discovered that E=mc2, and Lenoir did not envision smog when he invented the internal combustion engine.

title: Survival of the Fittest
description: MY mother was the main influence in my life. She was a great sportswoman who loved hunting, fly-fishing and playing polo. From the time I was about 9 years old, I was her main fishing companion. Her greatest ambition for me was that I become a pointing-dog trainer. She didn't see any reason why I ought to go to school beyond high school.

description: THE night before the pinnacle of his National Football League career, Roy Simmons was already a wreck. Among the posse of some 20 family members and friends he had invited to Tampa to watch him play in the 1984 Super Bowl were his three current lovers -- two women and one man. They were all staying at the same hotel, and each required attention that even Mr. Simmons, a 290-pound offensive lineman for the Washington Redskins known for his speed, found exhausting.

title: Them Against the World, Part 2

Admittedly, careful thought and reasoned discussion aren't as thrilling as sloganeering and shouting epithets at television cameras. But if she would think less of herself and her escapades, and more about the issues that set her raving, she would learn that global capitalism generates widespread prosperity, cleanliness, cultural richness and liberty.

title: Page Two: Nov. 23-29; NO SANCTIONS, FOR NOW

For now, though, it ducked the threat of sanctions by the United Nations Security Council. The White House had pushed for Security Council involvement, but was rebuffed by Britain, France and Germany, which believe that Iran should be allowed to show its better intentions. With nuclear inspectors returning to Iran this week, that test could come soon. Mark Landler

"To me, school clothes are happy clothes," she said. "They're clothes that are worn by people in motion."

title: Mr. Bodacious
description: John Currin's approach and attitude are entirely consistent with the forebears he reveres (Deborah Solomon, Nov. 16). When a prodigiously talented Raphael swaggered into Rome in 1508, he surely said: ''Michelangelo. He's the guy to knock off.''

title: The Seeds of Inspiration: A Design Portfolio
description: Selfridges Department Store

title: A Scene That Lives in Infamy
description: IN Fred Zinnemann's ''From Here to Eternity,'' which swept the 1953 Academy Awards and which opens at Film Forum on Friday in a restored, 50th-anniversary print, there's a shot so famous that people tend to think they've seen the movie even when they haven't. It features Deborah Kerr and Burt Lancaster lying in the Hawaiian surf and making out like hormone-crazed teenagers. If this was the uptight 50's, could the sexual revolution be far behind?

title: Rita Starritt and Ted Shafer
description: SHE seems more like a country singer than the Denver internist she really is. Dr. Rita Elaine Starritt has auburn hair, speeds around in a much-dented truck and swears freely in a strong Texas accent. When she gardens, she does it in a bikini, in her front yard.

title: Hollywood's New Toy: 19th-Century Action Figures
description: THIS is shaping up as a big year for the 19th century, at least at the movies. No fewer than four studios -- Fox, Columbia, Miramax and Warner Brothers -- are staking their holiday box office and Oscar ambitions on long, expensive, wide-screen epics featuring elaborate period costumes and bloody, in some cases half-forgotten, military conflicts.

title: Following in Fred and Ginger's Steps
description: ''DON'T let your skirt fly up too high,'' the choreographer Jerry Mitchell called out to a cast member during a recent rehearsal of ''Never Gonna Dance,'' a new Broadway musical based on the 1936 film ''Swing Time,'' starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. ''No panties on view. This is all about romantic elegance. I want to bring back that beautiful choreography and that way of telling a story in dance.''

title: Masters of War
description: A TIME OF OUR CHOOSING

title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF
description: GOUVERNEUR MORRIS: An Independent Life

title: Them Against the World, Part 2
description: Austin Bunn asks, ''Given the reality of heavily prepared security forces, how do activists do something that doesn't end up merely highlighting their own powerlessness?'' Activists are always up against often brutal forces. That is nothing new. Such a question presumes falsely that it is futile to act in the face of such overwhelming odds.

title: MORE FOR GAS?
description: A gas tax increase of at least 12.5 cents a gallon may be necessary to raise the $750 million that will be needed each year to repair New Jersey's roads, bridges and mass transit lines, a transportation commission appointed by Governor McGreevey said last week.

title: The Men
description: NATIONAL CHAMPION

title: In a Homeland Far From Home
description: Thank you for Deborah Sontag's sensitive and considered article (Nov. 16). It highlights an unintended consequence of the stringent 1996 legislation: thousands of children who are United States citizens have been left fatherless by draconian removal policies.

title: Naming Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Steakhouse Tries Italian Row
description: RESTAURANTS cluster. Think of the string of big-beef places that form steakhouse row on Route 25A in northern Nassau. Motor Parkway in Hauppauge could double as a tour of Italy. Mario, San Marco, Sempre Vivolo and Pomodorino have dominated the road for more than a decade.

title: Tony Kushners List of Projects
description: An original screenplay about Eugene O'Neill for the producer Scott Rudin.

title: Kristen Hoeschler, Terence O'Brien Jr.
description: Kristen Bowe Hoeschler, an executive for public radio, and Terence Garner O'Brien Jr., a lawyer, were married yesterday in St. Paul. The Rev. Kevin M. McDonough, the vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of St. Thomas Aquinas on the campus of the University of St. Thomas.

title: On the Subway, Sept. 11
description: To the Editor:

title: Must Iraq Be Whole to Be Free?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Checking In

title: Business People; Spending His Money On Something That Matters
description: Robert F.X. Sillerman hopes to get a nonfinancial return -- an improved golf game -- from his latest investment.

title: Clouds in Her Coffee
description: Tara Donovan's apartment in Bushwick doubles as her studio, and because space is tight, she generally likes to work there with only one sculptural material at a time. Projects are bound to overlap, however. In the course of a supermarket run to buy paper plates for one project, Donovan saw a large package of foam cups and threw them in her cart. She'd been in the midst of sculpturing the plates into intricate ruffled balls, but back at home her attention wandered. She began to shape the cups instead. Later in the day she returned to the store to buy 10 more packages. She had seen something curious when she attached the cups in a certain manner and hung the assemblage near an overhead light.

title: Suffolk Receives New Administrative Judge
description: Justice H. Patrick Leis III, who headed up the State Supreme Court's matrimonial parts in Suffolk County and its Integrated Domestic Violence Court, has been named Suffolk's administrative judge. He replaces Justice Alan D. Oshrin, who died in August.

title: After Attacks, Turkey Braces for Fallout
description: THE sudden outbreak of suicide terrorism in Istanbul, which during a five-day period this month took dozens of lives and left hundreds injured in four attacks, cast a pall on that country's flourishing tourist industry. ''Is tourism to Istanbul dead as well as those Muslim Turks who died in the four attacks within one week?'' asked the English-language Turkish Daily News on Nov. 21.

title: When the Saints March In, Will Father Varela Be There?
description: Msgr. Octavio Cisneros is desperate for a miracle. Preferably two. That is because the monsignor, a chatty, sunny priest born in Cuba who works for the Diocese of Brooklyn, is leading a campaign to make another Cuban-born priest, the Rev. Felix Varela, a saint of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: More to Flutter
description: In a season that is mad for mod, a new generation of false-eyelash kits is allowing women to access their inner Brigitte Bardot with a range of options -- from extension tips to decadent full-length fringe. Vincent Longo's La Dolce Vita Lash Tips ($45 at Barneys New York) holds two sets of tapered tips, glue, a mini lash-curler, liquid liner and mascara. Sephora's Fake-It Lash Duo ($6, at www.sephora.com) comes with two full-size lash strips and two half-strips, while pared-down kits from Daphne Snodgrass ($4.99, at Ricky's stores in New York, 877-447-4259), hold two full-size strips that can be trimmed. In a test trial, Vincent Longo's entry provided the easiest application and the most natural-looking results. However, the most valuable tools by far were a steady hand and a good pair of tweezers. STEPHANIE HUSZAR

title: Sources of Paranoia
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; He Goes From G.M. To Delta, but First A Stop at the Deli
description: When he retired as chairman of General Motors last spring, John F. Smith Jr. made it clear that one of his new duties would be to help his son Brian run the Smithfield Market, an upscale deli in East Orleans, Mass. But on Monday, Delta Air Lines said Mr. Smith would become its new chairman, assuming some of the responsibilities held by Leo F. Mullin, who in a surprise move announced his retirement as chief executive and chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECK, RUTH HARMON
description: BECK--Ruth Harmon. On November 22, 2003, beloved wife of the late Albert E. Beck, Jr., and the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. E. Paul Harmon, Jr., and cousin of John N. Harmon, Jr., of Boulder City, Nevada. A descendant of Peregrine White, who was born on the Mayflower as the ship lay at anchor in Cape Cod Bay, November 20, 1620, the first child born in New England of English parents. Mrs. Beck, Packer Collegiate Institute, Class of 1922, also attended Pratt Institute, and was active in many Brooklyn charitiesMethodist Hospital Auxillary, Colony House, Salvation Army, Brooklyn Botanic Garden Auxillary, Civitas, and belonged to The Montauk Club. Memorials services will be at The Montauk Club, 8th Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, at 11:30 A.M. December 3rd. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Packer Collegiate Institute, or your favorite charity.

title: Gem of an Inn Warmed by Banked Fires
description: DINING recently at the Bird and Bottle Inn, a pedigreed hostelry with enormous physical charm, I felt as if I had been unwillingly cast in a restoration comedy, the sort of farcical drama in which characters with names like Mistress Flummery and Mr. Botchit conspire to make a mockery of propriety.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: When His Tail's in the Closet, His Snout's Out the Window
description: Anthony Costa was standing, as he often does, outside Four Paws, an upscale dog accessory store in the West Village, with Wilson, his Great Dane. Four Paws is where Mr. Costa has bought all of Wilson's 75 collars, not to mention the sheared rabbit coat that Wilson wears on trips to the country in the winter.

title: Page Two: Nov. 23-29; FILIBUSTERED
description: Republican leaders in the Senate needed just two votes to break a bipartisan filibuster, but they could not find them. So Republicans pulled the plug on energy legislation, which had been a top priority of the White House.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about Phipps Houses, which was established to improve housing for the poor, misstated the location of its first development. It was at 321-337 East 31st Street, between First and Second Avenues, not Second and Third.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN NOSTRAND, BRAD
description: VAN NOSTRAND--Brad. The entire Forbidden Broadway family mourns the tragic death of this unique and extraordinary man. Our hearts go out to his family. One of the funniest and kindest people to walk the earth; a light has gone out in the world.

title: Corrections
description: A sports highlight entry and a picture caption in the Television section on Nov. 16 for the Houston Masters Tennis Cup that day were outdated. Lleyton Hewitt, last year's winner, did not compete, and a correction in this space last Sunday misstated the reason. Hewitt did not qualify; the decision against competing was not his.

title: Cat Car: Oh, the Places You'd Go!
description: THE star car on movie screens this season may not have the staying power of James Bond's Aston Martin, Steve McQueen's Mustang or even the customized pocket rockets in ''The Fast and the Furious,'' but it does have exposed gears and three steering wheels. The car belongs to the Cat in the Hat, and it would surely receive a higher rating on the Cat's ''phunometer'' than the film has received from reviewers.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Principal Pam Newell Bradley is shown sweeping her school's entrance while at least a dozen students idly stand by (Nov. 16). While I admire her can-do spirit, she sets the wrong example, showing that even in the face of financial chaos, someone else will clean up your mess. In Japan, schoolchildren happily join one another and their teachers in policing their classrooms for debris and disorder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLENGER, MARIE ELI ZABETH ''BETTY'' (NEE DALEY)
description: BALLENGER -- Marie Eli zabeth ''Betty'' (nee Daley) of Flint, MI, age 94, died Sunday, November 23, at her home in Flint. Burial will be in Glenwood Cemetery, Flint. A memorial service will be held in a few months. Mrs. Ballenger was born in New York City on December 5, 1908, and grew up in Manhattan. She was the daughter of a physician who later became the first medical director of the Equitable Life Insurance Company. She later attended Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Class of 1930. Throughout her life, she maintained a family summer home that her father had built in 1900 in eastern Long Island, N.Y. near the Town of Southold. She married William S. Ballenger, Jr., the son of an auto pioneer, a co-founder of General Motors, who was the first treasurer of Chevrolet and Buick. She is survived by four children and two grandchildren.

title: 52-Yard Pass Caps Florida State's Final Rally
description: FLORIDA STATE 38, FLORIDA 34

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKOWITZ, DOROTHY
description: BERKOWITZ--Dorothy. On November 28, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Moe. Loving mother of Mort and Gene. Cherished grandmother of Cami, Sloane, Michael and Stacey. Great-grandmother of Cole. Dear mother-in-law of Judy and Lydia. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: First Hip-Hop, Now Cholo Style
description: PATRICIO GASIA, 20, flaunts his own brand of street cred, one part hip-hop two parts cholo, which is slang for the Mexican-American gangster style that originated in East Los Angeles. His street-tough look, a composite of oversize T-shirt, visored cap and pastel-tinted rosary, was enhanced by his bicycle, a low and streamlined trick bike, customized with baroque metallic flourishes. Mr. Gasia, a busboy who works in Spanish Harlem, spoke last week through a friend and interpreter. His style ''comes from people of color but with a Latino twist,'' he said. The idea is to look, he said, ''chingaso -- ready to fight, like a gangster.''

title: State Debates Massachusetts Ruling
description: ANNE STANBACK stepped to the lectern at a room in the Legislative Office Building in Hartford on Nov. 18, ostensibly to announce the results of a poll her organization, Love Makes a Family, had commissioned on same-sex marriage. But the Massachusetts Supreme Court had upstaged Ms. Stanback only moments earlier, declaring same-sex marriage legal in that state.

title: Reading X-Rays From Afar
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Proginet Corp. Posts Loss Of $202,695 for Quarter

title: Jen Maxfield, Scott Ostfeld
description: Jen Maxfield, a television news reporter, and Scott David Ostfeld, an investment banking associate, are to be married this afternoon at the Pleasantdale Chateau, a caterer in West Orange, N.J. The Rev. Craig W. Rule, a Presbyterian minister, will officiate with Rabbi Nathaniel Benjamin.

title: Making the Dead Count, Literally
description: AT first glance, the eight finalists in the competition to design the memorial at ground zero appear sleek and minimal. There are no statues, no elaborate filigree and few images.

title: Now Entering The California State of Mind
description: OF all the places we've lived over the years -- Kansas City, Philadelphia, New York, Johannesburg, Houston -- Los Angeles was the one where we found that friends who said, ''Oh yes, we'll come visit,'' actually did.

title: L.I. Charter Schools Still Lagging in Tests
description: WHEN Reginald Brinson of Roosevelt first learned that a charter school would be opening in his school district, he immediately sent in an application for his daughter, Regine.

title: Books on Tony Kushners Bedside Table
description: etting Mother's Body" by Suzan-Lori Parks

title: Dreams and Realities About That Inheritance
description: Baby boomers who are counting on a big inheritance to sustain them through their golden years may be disappointed, a recent study suggests. In 2001, the median value of inheritances received by baby boomers, most of whom are now in their 40's and 50's, was $47,909, according to AARP, which conducted the study.

title: Giants Hoping They Still Have Something Left As Motivation
description: Running back Tiki Barber stood in front of his locker on Friday, explaining why he thought the Giants had not given up on their 4-7 season. He said he still saw the spark necessary in a team that wants to win. He said the mood at practice and in meetings had not been gloomy or depressed.

title: The Pugilist
description: NIGHT JOURNEY

title: Terry Zwigoff's Santa: He's Making a List And Checking His Escape Routes Twice
description: ''BAD SANTA,'' directed by Terry Zwigoff and starring Billy Bob Thornton, tells the story of Willie T. Stokes, a department store Santa with a miserable childhood, a foul mouth, a drinking problem and criminal intentions who ends up bonding, almost against his will, with an 8-year-old sad sack. The movie offers an all-star comedy ensemble -- the late John Ritter as the department store's manager, Bernie Mac as the mall detective, Cloris Leachman as the child's barely present guardian and grandmother, and Tony Cox as the bad Santa's elf and partner in crime.

title: The World: A Thousand Words; Good as a Gun: When Cameras Define a War
description: MODERN war has given us iconic images that both shape and reflect our views of conflict.

title: I'm a Native New Yorker, And You, Buddy, Are Not
description: As a student at the University of Michigan, Zo Schneider had no trouble meeting fellow New Yorkers.

title: This City Is Skin Deep
description: New York is wonderful. Especially when you're cute. That's the recurring joke in Broadway's new hit revival of ''Wonderful Town.'' Watch as Eileen, the harmless and pretty blonde, cows her smart but plain-looking sister, Ruth, by getting the star treatment from a smitten store manager, an editor, the cops and eventually the tabloids, all for doing nothing special. She could be the Tara Reid of her day. Or maybe Edie Sedgwick.

title: A Matter of Education About Mutual Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Ice And Snow Melt Away
description: IF this winter is anything like the last one, metropolitan area residents will make good use of shovels and snow blowers. Wouldn't it be wonderful if you could flip a switch and make all that snow on your sidewalk and driveway go away?

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: Urban Studies
description: I SAILED WITH MAGELLAN

title: Behind Beauty of 9/11 Designs, Devil May Be in Nuts and Bolts
description: One of the eight finalists in the design competition for the World Trade Center memorial wants to incorporate three dozen or so ''beautifully tall'' Eastern white pines that would recall the intensely vertical spirit of the twin towers. Elegant trees, to be sure, but they are particularly vulnerable to air pollution and tend to break apart in heavy winds or ice, creating a potentially serious hazard.

title: The Issues of the Day, With a Liberal Slant
description: YOU'RE on the way to the hardware store, or washing the dishes, and you're listening to a talk show on the local public radio station. At first, it sounds as if two smart girlfriends are chatting over a cup of tea. The voices are a little sassy, a bit skeptical, and occasionally outright provocative. And they're both expressing seriously liberal views.

title: More Are Grabbing for Piece of Real Estate Pie
description: LIKE any number of people in the corporate world, Peter Olsen of Cortlandt Manor had a soaring career that hit a patch of turbulence two years ago. He was forced into early retirement from his job as a vice president at Deutsche Bank in Manhattan after the company bought Bankers Trust. He tried consulting, but work dried up after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. So Mr. Olsen decided to turn his gaze from the misfortunes of the city he had worked in for more than 20 years to the booming housing market in his own backyard.

title: When Breathing Is Believing; New Yorkers Doubt E.P.A. Credibility on Air Safety, but Truth Is Complex
description: From the first days after Sept. 11, 2001, the fears and unknowns about health and air quality in Lower Manhattan were compounded by the politics that swirl, as always, around the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: On the Market
description: 3-bedroom, 1-bath colonial at 41 Catherine Avenue, $279,000.

title: A Blend of Cuisines With a Hint of Thai
description: THE Papaya Thai and Asian BBQ restaurant in South Norwalk -- directly across from the Maritime Center -- resembles a W. Somerset Maugham version of Asia: three intimate and festive dining rooms, with bamboo bird cages as hanging lamps, a thatched nipa hut roof over the bar and the ornately carved wooden wall plaques of Southeast Asian scenes.

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: In Seussland, Rhyme Without Reason, You See, Sir, Is Treason

title: A Matter of Education About Mutual Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: At Rutgers, Weathering An Ordeal
description: RICHARD McCORMICK was in trouble.

title: As Spain Absorbs Deaths in Iraq, Support for U.S. Is Questioned
description: MADRID, Nov. 30  Jose Maria Aznar, the Spanish prime minister, said today that his government's course was unchanged and its determination unbroken and that Spain would stay in Iraq `'with loyalty and serenity," despite the killing Saturday of seven Spanish intelligence agents.

title: Boxing Matches for Violin and Piano
description: BEETHOVEN'S ''Spring'' Sonata was published in 1801, his ''Kreutzer'' in 1805, both as works ''for piano with violin accompaniment.'' A century and a half later, either might have been presented as a work for ''solo violin'' -- no mention of a piano. What they are, in fact, is superbly balanced duos, in which the piano happily dukes it out with the smaller but feisty violin.

title: The Best and the Brightest
description: HUMAN ACCOMPLISHMENT

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: NONFICTION | FICTION

title: Hooters Air Adds Routes to Beaches
description: Starting Dec. 18, Hooters Girls, clad in hot pants and tank tops, will be welcoming passengers on nonstop flights between Columbus, Ohio, and Atlanta and between Myrtle Beach, S.C., and Fort Myers, Fla., and Myrtle Beach and Nassau on Sunday, Monday, Thursday and Friday.

title: Game 2: Machine Bites Man. Game 3: Kasparov Bites Back.
description: Just pitiful, absolutely awful -- that was the computer X3D Fritz's play in Game 3 of its match with Garry Kasparov in New York two weeks ago. When Kasparov confronted the machine with a radically closed pawn formation, it went into a state of suspended animation, wandering back and forth and losing without even making a show of a battle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, HELENE J. (NEE COHN)
description: ROSENBERG -- Helene J. (nee Cohn). Of Brooklyn and Chestnut Ridge, NY, died peacefully on November 27, after a courageous battle against esophageal cancer. A deep void will be felt in the lives of her family and friends. She is survived by her beloved husband Paul, loving son Edward (Estelle), and grandson Michael of Brooklyn, NY, devoted daughter Lisa and life partner Mary Shanley of NYC. They are forever grateful to have been graced by her joy of life, her laughter and her love. Thank you to all the good people who made her smile. Donations in Helene's honor can be made to United Hospice of Rockland, 11 Stokum Lane, New City, NY 10956-3505.

title: Mr. Bodacious
description: We've always known that great artists don't necessarily make great men; Caravaggio was a murderer and Jackson Pollock an ornery drunk. John Currin seems to be holding up his end of the deal as far as his personality goes.

title: Dance Listings
description: A.B.T. STUDIO COMPANY  Works by Antony Tudor, Scott Rink, William Forsythe and Peter Quanz. Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, 566 LaGuardia Pl., at Washington Square S. (212) 992-8484. Sat., Thur., Fri., 8; Sat., 2 and 8.

title: Storied Past, Golden Rsum, But Mixed Reviews for Kerry
description: In 1971, when most of his rivals for the presidency were in college, in graduate school or just beginning ambitious but still anonymous careers, John Forbes Kerry was already a decorated combat veteran of two tours in Vietnam and such a prominent leader of the antiwar movement that ''60 Minutes'' profiled him and the correspondent Morley Safer asked, ''Do you want to be president?''

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, Nov. 17, 2003

title: City's Bad Luck Takes Another Spin
description: This city, with its sputtering smokestacks that line Lake Michigan and its shuttered, boarded, barred downtown, has tried everything to save itself -- a theme park, a beauty pageant, murals, baseball, basketball, gambling.

title: Special Delivery
description: Over on the far West Side of Manhattan, down where the cabs sleep and art geeks wander, there is a restaurant called the Red Cat, which a fellow named Jimmy Bradley opened in 1999. It is a laconic, successful and welcoming place, popular far beyond the confines of its immediate neighborhood.

title: At Ole Miss, It's Give Me a T-A-I-L-G-A-T-E
description: IF Heisman trophies were awarded for tailgating, the University of Mississippi would be the favorite.

title: Must Iraq Be Whole to Be Free? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Machine for Sitting
description: In your 50 years as a designer, what have you wanted to accomplish?

title: Iraqis Learn Bureaucracy At Town Hall Meetings
description: They are the vanguard of democracy in Iraq, and they like to say they are a most unhappy lot.

title: Richard Mohr, Robert Switzer
description: Prof. Richard Drake Mohr and Robert William Switzer were married on Monday in the wedding chambers at City Hall in Toronto by Cynthia Scott, who is licensed by the province of Ontario to perform weddings.

title: Oil Experts See Long-Term Risk To Iraqi Underground Reserves
description: As the Bush administration spends hundreds of millions of dollars to repair the pipes and pumps above ground that carry Iraq's oil, it has not addressed serious problems with Iraq's underground oil reservoirs, which American and Iraqi experts say could severely limit the amount of oil those fields produce.

title: Needing Its Best Game, Montclair St. Can't Deliver
description: ITHACA 33, MONTCLAIR STATE 13

title: Mr. Bodacious
description: Solomon described Thanksgiving as ''celebrating neither religion nor ethnic identity but the singularly American devotion to enormous helpings of bland food.'' The importance and meaning of Thanksgiving to America is underscored by the fact that it has remarkably remained a family-centered holiday without being significantly commercialized. People travel for hours to join other family members or close friends to observe the holiday, without even the promise of receiving gifts as an inducement. Does Solomon really think that the day before Thanksgiving is the busiest travel day of the year because all those Americans just can't wait to dig into that bland food? I think not.

title: No Need to Tip, But What if He Crashes?
description: Don't expect to see green-and-gold epaulets in the lobbies of certain new high-end Manhattan residential buildings. Some owners are betting that video monitors, public address systems, digital recorders and high-speed Internet cables can do as good a job as any doorman, at a fraction of the cost.

title: Must Iraq Be Whole to Be Free?
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; Uptown Mansions, Houston St. Families, Terra Cotta
description: Riverside Drive Mansions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRATZ, DONALD
description: GRATZ--Donald. The Writers Room extends its sympathy to Board Member Roberta Brandes Gratz and to the friends and family of her husband, Donald Gratz.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Grandparents As Caregivers
description: Across the country, growing numbers of older adults are filling the child-care gap as the children's parents wrestle with problems like substance abuse, jail time and divorce. When they do, money can be scarce.

title: For the Eyes, Bubble Gum
description: RICHARD AND MONICA SEGAL, who live in Rye, have devoted more than two decades to collecting contemporary realist paintings. Their collection, which tops 750 pictures, is the basis for ''Facing Reality: The Seavest Collection of Contemporary Realism,'' an exhibition of some 40 works now on display here at the Neuberger Museum of Art on the campus of Purchase College.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; POLITICS
description: For those looking ahead to the next presidential election -- not to mention, looking back at the last one -- there may be no more critical state than Florida. And so it is that when the state Democratic Party invited the candidates to swing by for a state convention, they all jumped at the invitation. The big event begins on Friday; watch Democrats invoke a certain disputed election in a preview of one of next year's big Democratic themes. Adam Nagourney

title: Not Slowing, Still Helping
description: AT 75, Stanley Schear is not even thinking about retirement, let alone slowing down. Instead, he is spending his later years providing aid to the elderly of Westchester County.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE DREAM LIFE

title: Assertiveness on the Slopes
description: The trickiest part of an encounter with Edith Rosenberg is figuring out what to ask first: How did she come by the nickname Chickie (her given name is Edith)? Why, as a 64-year-old grandmother, has she written a book on snowboarding?

title: Suspected Mob Figure Is Murdered in Springfield
description: A man Federal authorities said handled business for the Genovese organized crime family in Connecticut was murdered last Sunday night in Springfield, Mass.

title: FEATURED MATCHUP -- COMPARING QUARTERBACKS
description: Kerry Collins and Drew Bledsoe could form an empathy group: tall, strong-armed, pocket quarterbacks without much in the way of pockets to protect them this season. Behind questionable offensive lines, they have compiled stats that are eerily similar, including leading their teams to identical 4-7 records. Collins has thrown for more yards, touchdowns and interceptions. Bledsoe has been sacked more often. The biggest difference: Buffalo fans have started calling for the backup Alex Van Pelt. Giants fans are not exactly eager to see Jesse Palmer. LYNN ZINSER

title: Two-Way Starter Leads Tottenville to the Title
description: Sparked by the two-way star Diego Oquendo, Tottenville sneaked past Canarsie, 28-24, yesterday in front of 2,000 fans to win the Public Schools Athletic League football title at Midwood High School in Brooklyn.

title: Questions for Roberta Combs
description: Roberta Combs joins a growing list of conservative scolds who consider themselves exempt from the ''correct'' lifestyle choices they want to impose on others (Deborah Solomon, Nov. 16). She takes a nasty swipe at working mothers by commenting that shows like ''The Osbournes'' ''wouldn't exist if mothers stayed home with their kids and supervised what they watched.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DECICCO, ANNE L.
description: DeCICCO--Anne L. Longtime trade association executive for the travel goods and healthcare industries, died at her home, November 26, after a long battle with cancer. She was 53. Contact Kimble Funeral Home, Princeton, for memorial service arrangements.

title: Woman Says She Put Swastikas on Her Door to Get Help
description: A woman who had reported finding swastikas and anti-Semitic remarks scrawled on her door on three separate occasions earlier this month admitted that she was responsible for one of those episodes, and said she acted to spur the investigation of the others.

title: Downtown Freddie Brown Is Still a Man to Bank On
description: Fred Brown had a successful and fulfilling career as a guard with the Seattle SuperSonics, serving as captain of the 1979 N.B.A. championship team, playing in one All-Star Game and scoring more points than anyone in franchise history besides Gary Payton. So Brown never felt compelled to return to the court or pictured himself playing in today's game.

title: Frank Talk About Abortion
description: The current debate about so-called partial birth abortion has produced some strange and unfortunate consequences. Among the most disheartening is the widespread impression that the pro-choice movement does not regard abortion as a serious matter, and that women seeking to terminate a pregnancy require a condescending reminder from Congress to understand that the fetus they are carrying is a potential life.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE ART OF ROMARE BEARDEN

title: There's a Sucker Born in Every Medial Prefrontal Cortex
description: Are we now seeing the next step leading to the creation of a ''Stepford'' consumer society? An insidious movement to program people to better the bottom line of business, irrespective of any redeeming value of the goods and services?

title: Deals and Discounts
description: Travel bargains can help preserve the budget for holiday shopping. Here are some possibilities.

title: In a Homeland Far From Home
description: Our country is proud of its immigration tradition but insists on deporting men and women who violate, even slightly, the criminal laws. I lost one client for a $15 shoplifting conviction. Another is headed back to Afghanistan for a white-collar crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLENBACH, DR. BURTON
description: WELLENBACH--Dr. Burton. I have lost my best friend. We've been in such tune for 62 years, despite separated by almost 3,000 miles for half that time. Rest in the peace, dear Burt, that you have so deservedly won. I join with your beloved family in bidding you adieu. Steve Reiss

title: Introduction
description: Our account of the deportation of a Cambodian refugee drew mail saying that the man deserved a second chance. Not so John Hinckley: readers insisted he belonged in custody. An antiglobalist activist was labeled all anarchy, no answers. Others said there's little that's educational in sitcom sex.

title: Headshots That Don't Guarantee The Agent Will Call Back
description: A CENTURY from now when celebrity waywardness emerges as its own academic discipline, students of the unseemly adulthood of Michael Jackson might unearth all the research they need with a single image.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Nov. 9, about Stowe, Vt., included a ski center erroneously, and omitted another, in a grouping of cross-country ski areas that make up a 93-mile trail system that honors a $15 adult day ticket. Topnotch at Stowe Resort and Spa, not Stoweflake Resort, should have been included.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLSON, REV. JOHN ANTHONY, S.J.
description: NICHOLSON--Rev. John Anthony, S.J. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road., Bronx on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial in Murray-Weigel Chapel on Tuesday, 11:30AM. For information contact Farenga Bros., Inc. Directors, phone 718-654-0500.

title: Wim Wenders and the Landscape of Desire
description: WIM WENDERS says he is the only filmmaker in history to have been awarded an honorary doctorate in theology, a doctorate that had to be approved by the pope himself. The Catholic Church decided (agreeing with some critics) that films like ''Wings of Desire'' (1987), ''Paris, Texas'' (1984), ''The American Friend'' (1977), ''Kings of the Road'' (1976) and ''Alice in the Cities'' (1974), movies that deal with alienation, disengagement and a lack of identity, represented a spiritual quest. (In a recent interview at his New York gallery, he said he owes this to a conspiracy of monks who were movie freaks.) Though his films of the 1990's continued to win awards internationally, none measured up to the work that had made him a great hero of art-film audiences everywhere, nor did they attract much attention in America until ''Buena Vista Social Club'' in 1999.

title: Katz, Katz And More Katz
description: To the Editor:

title: Nice Place to Live, But I Need Sidewalks
description: Re ''Wide Island'' [Nov. 23]: My family and I moved to Dix Hills from Providence, R.I., about three years ago. While I miss my best friends and beautiful old house the most, I find myself desperately missing Providence's sidewalks. Taking a walk in Dix Hills could be considered a suicidal gesture! There are no safe places on our streets for pedestrians. Having lived with sidewalks for most of my life, I can say in all sincerity that they dramatically improve the quality of one's life. It is a joy and a pleasure to be able to safely walk or jog around one's neighborhood. It's a great way to meet and talk to neighbors, spend time with family or enjoy one's solitude. Frankly, I feel trapped and claustrophobic without this option.

title: Sugar Plums, Bach and Handel
description: A welcome tradition for the holidays in Westchester, the performance of all six of J.S. Bach's Brandenburg Concertos, has become a much-anticipated part of the season. And for 20 years, Philharmonia Virtuosi, with Richard Kapp leading the ensemble, and a number of guest soloists, has been carrying this banner heralding the instrumental Bach. Its 2003 edition arrives next Sunday at 3 p.m. in Recital Hall of the Performing Arts Center at Purchase, featuring the soloists Edward Brewer at the harpsichord, Robert Bush on flute, Matt Peterson on trumpet and Mela Tenenbaum on the violin. Got kids? If they're under 18, they get in free. Toll-free reservations: (800)973-7729.

title: Stacey Sayetta, Jeffrey Goldstein
description: Stacey Lynn Sayetta, the daughter of Barbara J. Sayetta and Steven A. Sayetta of Manhattan, was married last evening to Dr. Jeffrey Lawrence Goldstein, a son of Adrienne N. Goldstein and Leonard M. Goldstein of Oakland Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Scott M. Corngold officiated at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, ARTHUR
description: WEISS--Arthur. Devoted husband of 66 years to Belle. Loving father to Carol and Martin. Adoring grandfather to Jay and Laura and Mindy and Todd. Proud and affectionate great-grandfather to Emily, Josh, Eli, Drew, Charley and Julia. Gramps will be missed more than words can say. He loved us all as we loved him with passion and joy. Services will be held on Monday, December 1, at the Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, New Jersey.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: FRIENDS ALONG THE WAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFRAM, HAROLD W.
description: WOLFRAM--Harold W. On November 26, 2003, in his 97th year in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Loving husband of the late Frances. Devoted father of Neil and father-in-law of Marianne. Cherished grandfather of Bruce J. Wolfram and Nicole W. Kerr (Russell). Adoring great-grandfather of Nathaniel W. Kerr. We miss him.

title: The Guts of a New Machine
description: Two years ago this month, Apple Computer released a small, sleek-looking device it called the iPod. A digital music player, it weighed just 6.5 ounces and held about 1,000 songs. There were small MP3 players around at the time, and there were players that could hold a lot of music. But if the crucial equation is ''largest number of songs'' divided by ''smallest physical space,'' the iPod seemed untouchable. And yet the initial reaction was mixed: the thing cost $400, so much more than existing digital players that it prompted one online skeptic to suggest that the name might be an acronym for ''Idiots Price Our Devices.'' This line of complaint called to mind the Newton, Apple's pen-based personal organizer that was ahead of its time but carried a bloated price tag to its doom.

title: Page Two; BUZZWORDS
description: The compiler of the item you are now reading got in touch with his inner annoying-buzzword detector and, after a computer database search, came up with scads of references, from just this month alone.
