description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Carol Pursley, Donald McGuire
description: Carol Roberts Pursley, a teacher, was married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., to Donald Michael McGuire, a pharmaceuticals executive. Janet K. Lockton, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated at St. Bedes Chapel at the Greenwich Japanese School.

title: The Week Ahead
description: POLITICS: For those looking ahead to the next presidential election  not to mention, looking back at the last one  there may be no more critical state than Florida. And so it is that when the state Democratic Party invited the candidates to swing by for a state convention, they all jumped at the invitation. The big event begins on Friday; watch Democrats invoke a certain disputed election in a preview of one of next year's big Democratic themes.

title: Lifes Solution
description: Iam a bipedal hominid, of average cranial capacity, write my manuscripts with a fountain pen, and loathe jogging. Thanks to years of work by innumerable biologists I, or anyone else, can tell you to a fair degree of accuracy when the ability to walk upright began, the rate at which our brain increased to its present and seemingly astonishing size, and the origin of the five-fingered forelimb whose present versatility allows me to hold a pen, not to mention the fishy origin of those lungs that make such a noise as the joggers pass me early in the morning on Cambridge's Midsummer Common.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAUL, ROBERT DAVID
description: PAUL--Robert David. On November 27, 2003 at age 75 of a brain tumor. Retired President and Chairman of The Segal Company; Founder and former Chairman of the Employee Benefit Research Institute; Board member of WellChoice, Inc.; and former Board member of Wiss, Janney, Elstner Associates, Inc. Beloved husband of Eve for 51 years. Devoted father of Jeremy (Laurel Leff) and Sarah (Dr. Mark Nachamie) and grandfather of Jason and Russell Paul and Eli Nachamie. Loving brother of Norma Benisch. His passion for getting things right, doing one's best and treating others with dignity and respect will forever remain an inspiration to all who knew him. Services Sunday, November 30 at 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to the MFA Program in Creative Writing, University of Michigan, Department of English Language and Literature.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; TELEVISION
description: Tonight, viewers can see what the fuss was about. ''The Reagans'' will be shown at 8 p.m. on the pay-cable station Showtime. CBS originally planned to broadcast the film, but canceled after protests from Reagan supporters, who charged that it was unfair to the former president.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Homeless, but Hardly Friendless
description: MURIEL DENTON stood in her beauty salon on Eastern Parkway cradling a snapshot of a man with a white beard who smiled and squinted into the winter sun.

title: Page Two; The Bawler in Chief: Real Men Can Cry
description: LAST week George W. Bush became not just the first American president to visit Iraq, but the first American president to weep in Iraq. Reporters with Mr. Bush on his top-secret trip all noted that a very visible tear dripped down his cheek when he was greeted by whooping American soldiers waiting for their Thanksgiving turkey at a mess hall in Baghdad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBINI, REICHLIN, CLARICE
description: RUBINI - REICHLIN -- Clarice. On November 28, 2003. Born in Vienna, Austria, March 1, 1912. Long time resident of New York City and Westchester; living in New Jersey for the last twelve years. Left Austria in the early 1930's to follow a theatrical career, which took her all over Europe. While working in cabaret in Czechoslovakia, met and married Albert Wolf, a bridge master, and thereafter immigrated to the U.S. in 1937. When the Nazis invaded Austria in the Spring of 1938 she immediately started to find sponsors to facilitate the immigration of her family to the U.S. Thanks to her efforts most of them escaped the Nazi terror. Her father, aunt, and many others in the family were killed by the Nazis. In the early 1950's she was divorced and thereafter married Mario Rubini-Reichlin, a prominent New York voice teacher which brought her in contact with the world of opera, theater and cantorial music. They resided at Carney Hall (where he maintained his studio) and had a home in Tanglewood. Until his death in 1968 she and Mario were active in the music entertainment scene in New York and Tanglewood and had contacts with Leonard Bernstein, Isaac Stern and many other entertainment figures. Mrs. Rubini-Reichlin was a member of the Cavendish Club, Champions Bridge Club. Her nieces, Jessica Hurley and Allison Ross, as well as a grandniece and two grandnephews, survive her. Services Sunday November 30th, 11:15am ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Japan Takes Control of Big Regional Bank
description: Financial regulators took control on Saturday of one of the nation's largest regional lenders, Ashikaga Bank, after tighter inspections showed that the bank was insolvent.

title: Teaching Germany to Grin and Bear Cheerleading
description: The Olympic Stadium, which Hitler built for the 1936 Berlin Olympics, is now home to another spectacle. It is the home field of the Berlin Thunder, a football team affiliated with N.F.L. Europe, and its cheerleaders.

description: OTTOLENGHI--Donna Franca. March 17, 1951 to November 21, 2003, beloved daughter of Anna and the late Paolo Ottolenghi. Rest in peace. ''In the end is my beginning''.

title: Inspiration: Where Does It Come From?
description: Raymond Loewy, the industrial designer, once said that ''simplicity is the deciding factor in the aesthetic equation.'' So, in the spirit of good design, let's begin with a radical simplification. Artists are influenced primarily by other artists, which means that standard art history can sound like a baseball broadcast of an infield play: Velzquez to Goya to Picasso. And designers? To be sure, they are aware of the products of other designers, but their attention is not so narrowly focused. When, near the end of his life, Isamu Noguchi, who straddled the boundary between art and design, created a sculpture garden in Costa Mesa, Calif., he was unquestionably recalling the manipulations of space and perspective in the Zen gardens of Kyoto and the geometric sculptures in the observatory in Jaipur. At the same time, he was thinking of the ways in which the sets he designed as a young man for theatrical stages had, through clever lighting and placement, made a constricted space seem vast. And he was acutely conscious of the function of this sculpture garden in Orange County as the centerpiece of a commercial real-estate development.

title: After Georgia's Revolution, the Watchdogs Remain Vigilant
description: It just seemed the natural thing to do. As discredited officials from the old government began leaving their posts this week, the victors in Georgia's popular uprising began appointing friends and relatives to their positions.

title: The High Road in Sikkim
description: THE herders sauntered down the trail toward us, a single black yak lumbering in front of them. They wore faded jackets and grimy rubber boots. Daggers in leather sheaths dangled from their belts.

title: Corrections

The AtomShockwave Corporation, which owns the site, says it does not have contracts with spyware makers and does not include such technology with software available on its site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, GUS W.
description: WEISS--Gus W. Of Washington, D.C. on November 25, 2003 at age 72. Beloved son of the late Gus and Natalie Weiss. Loving nephew of Lillian Weiss and dear cousin of Joan Poorvu and Claire Weisman. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Monday, December 1st at 1 PM. Interment Beth El Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Necessity Is the Mother Of Invention
description: Striding down a hallway at M.I.T., Amy Smith has a bucket in one hand and a length of string in the other. The brain behind such creations as the phase-change incubator, she is on her way to the Charles River to retrieve some dirty water for her next class. As she lopes along, Smith describes the ordeals of testing water in remote villages. Her words spurt out. She's a woman on fast-forward, and she does not so much talk as download information.

title: Audrey Brashich, Christopher Sjoholm
description: Audrey Deyan Brashich, a daughter of Catherine Sidor Brashich and Deyan Ranko Brashich, both of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Johan Gunnar Sjoholm, a son of Ann-Charlotte Sjoholm and Leif G. Sjoholm of London. The Rev. P. Kimberleigh Jordan performed the Reformed Church of America ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: Page Two: Nov. 23-29; THE 2000 DIVIDE
description: She was the face of Florida's 2000 presidential recount, cheered on by fellow Republicans and despised by Democrats as she ultimately certified George W. Bush's razor-thin victory. No doubt, Katherine Harris, then Florida's secretary of state, was a polarizing figure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAPOSNIK, IRVING
description: SAPOSNIK--Irving. Friends & family honor the memory of a loving and compassionate Jewish scholar, friend, father, grandfather and teacher. Died at age 67 November 20, Madison, Wisconsin surrounded by his wife Francie, his children & grandchildren.

title: For Home Loans, A Steady Market
description: THE residential mortgage market continues to be, by historic standards, exceptionally welcoming to borrowers, despite having poked above the 6 percent mark in the benchmark 30-year fixed-rate loan during the summer. It has fluctuated around that level since then, and last week it was at 5.89 percent.

title: Marion Abrams, David Kessler
description: Marion Keren Abrams, a daughter of Marsha Abrams and Dr. Albert Abrams of Macungie, Pa., was married last evening to Dr. David Alexander Kessler, a son of Hope Kessler and Dr. Lawrence Kessler of Manhattan. Rabbi Eugene Wernick officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Web Merchants Go Global
description: UNTIL recently, online travel companies competed most heavily in the travel industry's huge markets, like domestic air travel, vacation packages and hotel reservations. But that reality can be frustrating for those looking for less than common travel help.

title: A Proud Mussolini Refuses To Let 'Il Duce' Be Vilified
description: Alessandra Mussolini never minded the occasional small dig against Fascism, which certainly had its problems, or a little gibe about her grandfather Benito, who had his flaws.

title: A Chance For Plants In Home
description: THE sooner you start growing houseplants, the better you'll feel about winter. Nothing keeps a gardener from going stir crazy like a house full of green things sending up new shoots, groping for the best spot of sun, maybe even blooming. Of course, the antidote only works if those houseplants thrive.

title: A Change in the Weather
description: In the documentary film ''The Weather Underground,'' Mark Rudd, now teaching at a community college, describes what happens when his students ask him what he did during the Vietnam era: ''I tell them I helped found an organization whose goal was the violent overthrow of the U.S. government, and they look at me like I'm from another planet.'' Rudd's past -- which includes leading the 1968 student occupation of Columbia University and several years in the bomb-planting revolutionary cadre called the Weather Underground -- may seem alien to his students, but they keep on looking. A portion of the audience for the film (directed by Sam Green and Bill Siegel) and for a rash of recent books about the underground radicals of the 60's and 70's consists of people who were there then. But a generation of writers and artists who are too young to remember, or who can barely remember, the Days of Rage protest, the Weather Underground's bombings of the Capitol and the Pentagon, or the increasingly lethal activities of various splinter groups, also finds the subject alluring.

title: Greenburgh Votes to Pay Share in Open Space Parcel
description: In a unanimous vote on Monday, Greenburgh approved the acquisition of 183 acres of open space, the largest such purchase in the town's history. The town board voted to authorize the issuance of $3.8 million in bonds to pay the town's one-third share of the cost of the property, off Taxter Ridge, which is owned by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, with the other two-thirds being paid by the state and the county.

title: Word for Word / Stay Loose; How to Succeed in Business Without Really Dressing
description: YOU think dress-down Friday is laid back? Hah! It's got nothing on the weeklong sartorial informality of people who work at home. To judge from the zillions of work-at-home come-ons choking the Internet, these aspiring kitch-en-table success stories could be taking work dress codes to new levels -- if not heights of fashion. You bet your housecoat and fuzzy pink slippers they are. Here is a sampling. TOM KUNTZ

title: Interest Surges in Voodoo, and Its Queen
description: Last year, doctors told a 41-year-old New York woman who had been bedridden with meningitis and other ailments that she should prepare for the worst. Rather than resign herself to her fate, she boarded a train to New Orleans -- her illness does not permit her to fly -- and made an offering at the tomb of Marie Laveau, the ''voodoo queen'' who died in 1881 but has re-emerged as the center of a far-reaching religious movement.

title: Connecticut Is Conditioned To Go All-Out All the Time
description: It is not easy being a freshman on the University of Connecticut women's basketball team. The most bountiful collection of high school trophies and summer camp ribbons must seem inadequate credentials walking into the first practice of a team that has lost only five games in the past four seasons -- and won three national championships.

Platt of United States District Court in Central Islip has ordered all sides in the legal dispute over the Shinnecock Indians' proposed casino to be ready to go to trial by January. He also joined separate suits filed against the tribe by the state attorney general's office and Southampton Town, each seeking to stop construction of the casino.

title: Atmospheric

The bearded gentleman, belly straining against his silk cummerbund, is wheezing his way up the grand staircase of Rod's Steak and Seafood Grille, calling something to his companions, as the hum of conversation and the clink of glasses and a whiff of cigar smoke drift upward to the tables in the balcony.

title: Investing; A Wider Door to Hedging, With Fees Attached
description: WALL STREET firms are eagerly marketing hedge funds to investors of more moderate wealth, on the theory that many people who have been burned in the stock market are hungry for strategies that can profit even if the market declines.

title: Iraqi Leaders Say U.S. Was Warned of Disorder After Hussein, but Little Was Done
description: In the months before the Iraq invasion, Iraqi exile leaders trooped through the White House, the Pentagon and the State Department carrying a message about the future of their homeland: without a strong plan for managing Iraq after toppling Saddam Hussein, widespread looting and violence would erupt.

title: Florida Elderly Feel Let Down By Medicare Drug Benefit
description: In the condominiums and on the palm-shaded beaches here, where Medicare is a frequent topic of conversation, few people expect to get much help from the new drug benefit just approved by Congress.

title: Should John Hinckley Go Free?
description: From a strictly pragmatic viewpoint, to what would St. Elizabeths Hospital be liberating John Hinckley (Michael Sokolove, Nov. 16)? Indeed, your article makes it clear that, before his life in an asylum, Hinckley failed to attain basic essentials of independent adult existence. Furthermore, despite only attaining a ''bright normal'' score on his I.Q. tests, Hinckley consistently has been able to hide his very evident admiration for individuals even more antisocial than himself. Psychiatrists have seen only a John Hinckley kept safe from the exigencies and stressors of normal life, and even then, he shows them only a very attenuated part of his psyche. The past is prologue -- and Hinckley should remain safe from society, so society can be safe from him.

To Mr. Sherman's great credit, his students, who include many adventurous and important pianists, have turned out to be quite different from one another. There is no Russell Sherman mold.

title: Ideas & Trends: Iran and Guatemala, 1953-54; Revisiting Cold War Coups and Finding Them Costly
description: SOON after the C.I.A. installed him as president of Guatemala in 1954, Col. Carlos Castillo Armas visited Washington. He was unusually forthright with Vice President Richard M. Nixon. ''Tell me what you want me to do,'' he said, ''and I will do it.''

title: Overdose Suspected In Death of Inmate
description: The authorities in Orange County, N.Y., are investigating the death of a female inmate at the county jail in an apparent heroin overdose, officials at the jail said yesterday.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Lexus RX330; Low-Fat S.U.V. Substitute, Now in Extra Creamy
description: IN the 14 years since Lexus sprang from an upscale gleam in Toyota's eye, it has done as much to spruce up the better suburbs as Sherwin-Williams or the Lawn Doctor. Nearly 2 million Lexii have been sold, and by most accounts the owners are a pampered and satisfied -- though hardly overstimulated -- bunch.

description: NOW that investors realize that their interests do not always come first with their mutual fund managers, perhaps they will focus on the sky-high fees they have been forking over for years.

title: The Index of Missing Economic Indicators; The Unemployment Myth
description: The government's announcement on Tuesday that the economy grew even faster than expected makes the current ''jobless recovery'' even more puzzling. To give some perspective, unemployment normally falls significantly in such economic boom times. The last time growth was this good, in 1983, unemployment fell 2.5 percentage points and another full percentage point the next year. That's what happens in a typical recovery. So why not this time? Because we have more to recover from than we've been told.

description: Page 71: Main photograph of Selfridges by Norbert Schoerner. NatWest: Richard Davies. Rabanne dress: Orban Thierry/Corbis Sygma. Snakeskin: Corbis. Church facade from Future Systems. Small exterior detail photographs of Selfridges: Soren Aagaard/Future Systems. Sketch by Future Systems.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; New Offices, a 12 Mile Move, a $40 Million Tax Break
description: Plans by the developer of an office and residential complex on Route 7 in Norwalk to lure a large tenant away from its present quarters in Stamford to one of two new office buildings he is building have brought criticism of the state economic development program that underpins the move.

title: Reynolds and St. John's Overcome Distractions
description: Grady Reynolds, a senior forward for St. John's, knows about performing when off-court matters take precedence. He played all of last season while facing an assault charge before the matter was resolved over the summer.

title: Mr. Timothy
description: Not so tiny any more, that's a fact. Nearly five-eight, last I was measured, and closing in on eleven stone. To this day, people find it hard to reckon with. My sister Martha, by way of example, wouldn't even meet my eye last time I saw her, had to fuss at my shirt buttons and stare at my chest, as though there were two dew-lashed orbs blinking out of my breastbone. Didn't matter I've half a foot on her now, she still wanted to be mothering me, and her with a full brood of her own - six, last I counted - and a well-oiled husband gone two nights for every night he's home, why would she want more bodies to tend? But she does, and old habits, and let the woman have what she wants, so on this last occasion, I dropped to my knees and looked straight at the sky with that look I used to have, it comes back in an instant, and I sang "Annie Laurie." And Martha laughed and boxed my ear and said Out with you, but I think it pleased her, remembering me smaller, everything else smaller, too.

title: A Pianistic Quarterback Passes To a Younger Generation
description: AMERICAN football is hardly the first thing that springs to mind when you talk to the pianist and pedagogue Menahem Pressler. For one thing, the diminutive Mr. Pressler, despite his physical prowess at the keyboard, is not an athletic type. (''In my mind, I'm 5 foot 3,'' he is fond of saying, ''but deep down I know I'm only 5 foot 2.'') For another, at 79 he retains the accent of his upbringing in Germany and Israel.

description: The Canadian government is suspending the use of thermal scanners at the Toronto and Vancouver airports. The scanners, which detect elevated body temperatures, were introduced last spring in the hope of preventing passengers infected with SARS from entering or leaving Canada.

description: THE only problem with ''Angels in America'' is the angels.

title: Flying in the Face Of Mediocrity
description: Airplane travel is one of the black holes of American design. Walk 10 steps into any airport, and you feel yourself sucked into a kind of placelessness, a modular nightmare of function over form that ends only with your subsequent ejection into a different city. So heavy is the air of stylistic enervation that it has overcome the travelers themselves; the faces around the average airport gate resemble a Walker Evans photograph, in the shabby, heroic stoicism of those whom experience has taught to expect nothing.

description: In the early years of the 21st Century, consumers have accounted for more than two-thirds of spending in this country, their greatest share in more than half a century.

And the players all seem to have one thing on their minds: How and when do I make it to the N.B.A.?

description: RESIDENTS in Huntington and Smithtown are raising strong objections to plans by the Long Island Rail Road to build a storage yard at one or possibly two of six sites along the Port Jefferson line.

description: FOR seven months, the United States has tried to finesse two crucial questions about the future of Iraq: How much control will the country's Shiite majority have over the drafting of a constitution? And how Islamic will that constitution be?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAMBRIOLA, VINCENT JAMES
description: LAMBRIOLA -- Vincent James. On November 28, 2003, in Middletown, CT. Formerly of Bellmore, NY, and Montauk, NY. He was a 22 year retired veteran of the NYC Police Department and former Vice President of Feature Ring, Inc. Devoted husband of Angela, loving father of Vincent, Linda and James. Father-in-law of Bill and Diane. Cherished grandfather of Jenny and Emily, brother of Millie, the late Joseph and the late Helen. We will miss you always. For information, Clayton Funeral Home, Kings Park, NY.

title: Tina Antonakakis, Peter Metis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, ANDREW M.
description: FISHER--Andrew M. We mourn the death of our bright, shining star who at 22 years of age, was tragically taken from us on Thursday November 27, 2003. Andrew was a budding artist who floated above this earth with his sunny disposition and happy view of life. He was the light of our lives. He leaves behind his mother Laura; his father Richard; his two brothers Hadley and Winston; and his sister Alexandra. Funeral services will be private.

title: Corrections

title: Susan Burger, Michael Ranis
description: Susan Burger and Michael Bruce Ranis were married last evening by Rabbi Yael B. Ridberg at the Pratt Mansion in New York.

title: At Finish, Mutombo Listens And Likes What He Hears
description: With the Knicks trying to hang on to the lead in the final minutes at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the New Orleans Hornets twice brought the ball upcourt and called out their offensive sets. Dikembe Mutombo was all ears.

title: LaGuardia College Gets Its Due In a City of Academic Heavy Hitters
description: The City University of New York has six community colleges, all of them dwarfed by the city's two skyscrapers of higher education, Columbia University and New York University. While those two powerhouses compete for star faculty members, real estate, news media attention and millions in endowments, the community colleges humbly take in the academically tempest-tossed, many of whom are the first in their family to set foot in a college classroom.

title: Mom's Last Trip to Jones Beach
description: A YEAR ago I had summoned up the courage to ask, ''What kind of funeral arrangements would you prefer?''

title: Taking the Memorial Designs for a Test Drive
description: AMID the fanfare and controversy over the release of the eight finalists' designs for the World Trade Center memorial, one of the most transformative aspects of the event has gone all but unremarked. In addition to presenting their designs through conventional architectural drawings and models, the finalists used sophisticated computer animation to show what the memorials might look like as visitors approached them, walked around them, moved through them. (The animated segments are online at www .wtcsitememorial.org/finalists.html.) With the chance to view the designs in this dynamic, strikingly ''cinematic'' way, the public was given its first glimpse of a revolution that has been under way for the past few years. Indeed, the memorial competition itself accelerated that revolution, harnessing the explosion in broadband Internet access to allow millions of people around the world to view the animated presentations, more or less at once -- something that was never before possible.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Following Up column on Nov. 16 about the future of the Coney Island parachute jump gave an incorrect year from the Landmarks Preservation Commission for the shutdown of the ride. It occurred in 1964, when the rest of Steeplechase Park closed, not in 1968.

title: Kazumi Terada, Omar Ovalle
description: Kazumi Terada and Omar Ricardo Ovalle Caro, graphic designers in New York, are to be married in New York today. The Rev. T. Kenjitsu Nakagaki, a Buddhist priest, will perform the ceremony at the New York Buddhist Church.

title: Letters
description: Our account of the deportation of a Cambodian refugee drew mail saying that the man deserved a second chance. Not so John Hinckley: readers insisted he belonged in custody. An antiglobalist activist was labeled all anarchy, no answers. Others said there's little that's educational in sitcom sex.

title: There's a Sucker Born in Every Medial Prefrontal Cortex
description: The commercial world has caught on to what ''neuromarketers'' can offer. Politicians, the state, even the military, will surely follow and recognize the vast potential for not only probing into the human mind but also manipulating it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISEN, SYLVIA KLINGON
description: EISEN--Sylvia Klingon. Age 80, of Great Neck, NY, on November 29, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Charles J. Eisen. Devoted mother of Amy Eisen Krupsky, Elizabeth H. Eisen and Claudia Eisen Flack. Cherished grandmother of Rachel and Lydia Krupsky, Samuel and Natalie Dworkin, and Nathaniel and Caleb Flack. Also survived by her brothers, Dr. Gerald Klingon and Richard Klingon. Services Sunday, 1 pm, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: In a Land of Plenty, Plenty in Need
description: THE week before Thanksgiving, about 20 Hispanic women gathered in a church basement here to celebrate the holiday early with a potluck lunch -- not of turkey, but of rice, chicken, empanadas and tamales. At gatherings like this one, these women, most of them immigrants who are unemployed, get together to learn the basics of everyday life in their new land and to share their stories of need, as well as their strategies for the balancing act that is their lives: making do for their families on their husbands' paychecks, typically the wages of a laborer, with perhaps a small supplement of a few dollars a week from the wives.

title: Technology Group Gets Help in Expanding
description: Westchester County's technology companies now have a full-time booster. Dorothy T. Forcina, a former senior technology executive at Fleet Securities, is now managing director of the Westchester Information Technology Cluster, a county-sponsored organization representing small and midsize companies.

title: To Draw a Bridge
description: When he can't sleep, the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava draws pictures. Birds, bodies, bulls -- the fluid, figural images repeat themselves in sketch after sketch. The drawings fill his notebooks, and the notebooks -- elegant Japanese ledgers with pages that open out like a room-length accordion -- fill the offices and homes he keeps in Zurich, Paris, Valencia and Manhattan.

title: A Pot for Good Looks, If Not for Good Cooks
description: IT'S safe to say that the words ''Marcia, Marcia, Marcia'' do not prompt knowing laughs among the Finnish members of Generation X -- not the way they do among their cousins in the United States. The words, famously uttered by a petulant Jan Brady about her older sister's unflagging popularity, are now a shorthand of sorts for 30-somethings' arch adoration for all things retro.

title: Human Accomplishment
description: Before human accomplishment could begin, we had first of all to become human. It took a long time. Bipedality came first, somewhere in the vicinity of five million years ago. After bipedality, about two and a half million years passed before the animal that walked on two legs learned to make crude tools. The taming of fire required another one and a half million years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERGAMENT, ELMER M.
description: PERGAMENT--Elmer M. Of Savannah, GA. passed away on November 5, 2003. He was born in New York City on May 11, 1918. He graduated from CCNY in 1938. He is survived by his wife Cleta; two daughters; two grandchildren; and two step-daughters.

title: Delhi
description: New Delhi lives vigorously with a past that remains evocatively present. Some 12 million people maneuver amid the stunning relics of the city's thousand-year history.

title: The World: Engineering Change; Rebuilding Iraq Takes Courage, Cash and Improvisation
description: IN the pounding heat last August, near ancient Babylon, a group of American and Iraqi engineers and local Shiite workers gathered to flip the switch on a refurbished irrigation system for 200,000 acres of land that had become parched during years of neglect under Saddam Hussein's rule. All seemed ready, but the Iraqis refused to try the switch before improving their luck.

title: There's a Sucker Born in Every Medial Prefrontal Cortex
description: While it is certainly not illegal for neuroscientists to help corporations market their wares, it is unseemly and, in my view, unethical (Clive Thompson, Oct. 26). Neuroscientists are professionals whose training and basic research is largely financed by public sources. They receive ample compensation and prestige because of their presumed service to society: a better understanding of the brain, with eventual applications to health and education. When they focus on enriching themselves and their sponsor corporations, they abandon their calling; they enter the ranks of advertising and marketing, and come close to joining the oldest profession: prostitution.

title: China Releases 3 Cyber Dissidents
description: BEIJING, Dec. 1  The Chinese government released today three jailed "cyber dissidents." Among the three was a young college student nicknamed "Stainless Steel Mouse," whose arrest a year ago had brought international condemnation, a Hong Kong human rights group said.

title: The Height of Ingenuity
description: One of the less glamorous tasks builders face is designing things that people don't want to have around -- electrical substations, tunnel exhaust vents, sewage treatment plants. Or cellphone antennas, one of the most difficult design challenges of contemporary life. Since the mid-80's, almost 150,000 of these unlovely radio transmitters have sprung up around the country on poles along roadways and on the facades of buildings. The construction of new antennas grows at a steady rate of 12 percent a year; meanwhile, communities have become even less willing to have them placed on their streets and in their backyards.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CANNON, VICTOR, JR.
description: CANNON--Victor, Jr. Oct. 24, 1931 -- Nov 24, 1991 David and Ellen

title: The Neediest Cases; When Grandparents Step Into the Child Care Gap, Money Can Be Scarce
description: Vaughn Bennett, 17, practices his lyrical poetry with a friend on the steps of his grandmother's three-bedroom duplex apartment in Brooklyn. They aspire to be like the many rap artists whose skills have lifted them from poor neighborhoods to luxury lifestyles.

title: Great Expectations
description: MR. TIMOTHY

description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Blitz, Louis Sobol
description: Dr. Jennifer Leigh Blitz, the daughter of Roberta Blitz and Dr. Donald Blitz of West Bloomfield, Mich., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Louis Leonard Sobol, a son of Evelyn Sobol and Dr. Bernard Sobol of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Daniel Nevins performed the ceremony at the Adat Shalom Synagogue in Farmington Hills, Mich.

title: For Real or Not
description: It isn't even winter and the wearing of fur is in full force. Cloth and leather coats and jackets are lavishly trimmed with long-hair furs, along with the split hems of blue jeans. This nonchalant, supple look can be seen in knitted furs. A long fur boa achieves its elasticity through cutting of the pelt in the manner of fishnet. The big revivals are ranch-raised silver and red fox, often worn with black leather. For some, this dress-down look means pastel-colored fake furs.

title: Now for a Word From Whomever You're Calling
description: CALL the reservation desk at the Lodge at Keyah Grande on nights or weekends when the call volume is at its peak, and you can expect a little wait. Operators are busy helping other customers. (Surely you've heard that before.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAURWEIN, PAUL G.
description: SAURWEIN--Paul G. Of Cambridge, MA, on November 25, 2003. Former husband of Margaret (Hammond) of Nashua, NH. Father of Margot Powell of Lincoln, RI, George Saurwein of Riverside, RI, and the late Lisa Pajeski and Eric Saurwein. Brother of Jean Saurwein of Brockton, MA, Carol Sullivan of Worcester, MA, and Martha Saurwein of Chicago, IL. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Memorial services will be announced at a later date. Gifts in his memory may be sent to the American Diabetes Association, P.O. Box 2680, North Canton, OH 44720.

title: BENEFITS
description: Saving Neighborhoods

title: NEW REPUBLICAN LEADERS
description: State Senator Leonard Lance, a Hunterdon County Republican whose father is the sole surviving framer of the state constitution, was unanimously elected last week to lead the Senate Republican caucus. Mr. Lance's elevation to minority leader, the state's highest-ranking Republican post, comes three weeks after the Senate president, John O. Bennett, lost his bid for re-election. A fiscal conservative whose moderate views on social issues place him comfortably within the state's traditionally centrist Republican Party, Mr. Lance, 51, vowed that his priorities when he assumes his post in January would be ethical integrity and financial reform. The Republican caucus also elected Senators Peter A. Inverso and Martha W. Bark to serve as deputy leaders and Senator Thomas Kean Jr. to be the minority whip. Jessica Bruder

title: Color Cognition
description: Roses are red; violets are blue. But if we called a violet red, what color would it be? This is not a rhetorical question. How we label things can affect how we perceive them. Naming can impose meaning. And though science and anthropology have provided significant support for the proposition that color perception is basically identical across societies, recent studies have found evidence that we also see our rainbows through cultural lenses.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 12, about seasickness, referred incorrectly to acupressure, which is one remedy. Acupressure, which treats symptoms by applying pressure to specific parts of the body, is not an example of homeopathy, which treats disease with small amounts of drugs.

title: Business People; A Challenge for the Speaker: Make Bankers Look Colorful
description: Diana L. Taylor, the New York State superintendent of banks, will be the opening speaker at this year's Banker of the Year awards dinner, to be held on Wednesday in Manhattan.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share

Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Commercial Property/Newark; Developers Plan to Repopulate the Downtown Area
description: FOR more than 17 years, the old Hahne & Company department store has sat vacant on two blocks of prime real estate on Broad Street in downtown Newark, defying multiple attempts to convert it to another use. But lately, a new owner, the Cogswell Realty Group, has cleaned up the exterior and installed new windows, planning to convert it and the adjacent Griffith Building into 223 rental apartment units.

title: Not Under the Tree This Year
description: What does it take to make a successful toy? A graveyard. Every year, Meyer/Glass, a toy-invention company based in Chicago, pitches 200 concepts to manufacturers. They get contracts for about five, and ''we need at least one hit every year to keep going,'' says the company president, Steve Meyer. But even with recent winners like Catch Phrase, Gooey Louie and Silly 6 Pins, misfires are a necessary part of the design learning process. Here, the Meyer/Glass team -- Meyer; Randy Klimpert, the creative director; and Dianne Lauble, a designer -- analyze five toys that died so that others might live.

title: Drop That Skateboard. Uh, Nevermind.
description: No doubt soothing the hearts of X-Game types everywhere, Cape May officials are apparently reconsidering a proposal that would ban the mere carrying of skateboards in public places.

title: The Sound of Footsteps From Above
description: Q. I own a condominium unit in SoHo. Recently, a new unit owner directly above me did major renovations that involved adding a new bathroom, moving the kitchen and basically changing the floor plan. The owner made the changes without approval of our board and without permits or inspections from the city. Because of these alterations, I suffer from extreme amplification of footsteps that has completely disturbed my peace and quiet. I have appealed to the board to make the unit owner comply with our bylaws and properly insulate the floor, but the board refuses to act. They claim that the noise is my problem, not a condominium matter. What is my recourse? . . . Rochelle Gurstein, Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about spyware, software that allows pop-up ads or monitors computer users' activities, referred incorrectly to Shockwave.com, which offers games and other software online. The AtomShockwave Corporation, which owns the site, says it does not have contracts with spyware makers and does not include such technology with software available on its site.

title: Vidhya Rangaiah, Robert Kelly
description: Vidhya Rangaiah, a daughter of Rathna Rangaiah and Dr. Govindappa Rangaiah of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married on Wednesday to Robert Winston Kelly, a son of Ingrid and Jack Kelly of Pottersville, N.J. Sri Shrutipriya, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Raj Mahal Villas, a wedding hall in Bangalore, India. On Thursday, the couple had a Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral, also in Bangalore, which was led by the Rev. Prathap Ignacious.

title: Rural Haitians Are Vanguard In AIDS Battle
description: In the cool mist of daybreak, hundreds of villagers fanned out across the forsaken reaches of this nation's remote interior, fording rivers swollen by torrential rains, slogging through muddy cornfields and clambering up slippery mountainsides to reach people sickened by AIDS.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: COLLECTED STORIES, by David Leavitt. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) This volume reprints David Leavitt's three short-story collections, ''Family Dancing'' (1984), ''A Place I've Never Been'' (1990) and ''The Marble Quilt'' (2001) -- the last one for the first time in paperback. Leavitt's subject, Wendy Martin wrote in her review in these pages of ''A Place I've Never Been,'' is ''the complexities of love -- platonic, erotic and electronic,'' and his prose ''is often spare and carefully honed.'' Michael Pye found that some of the stories in ''The Marble Quilt'' do not ''feel rooted in a solidly imagined world,'' but noted that others are a reminder of how good Leavitt -- whom he called ''an elegant and sexy and clever writer'' -- can be.

title: Slightly Slimmer Gift Budgets
description: American households plan to spend an average of $455 on holiday gifts this season, about 6 percent less than the average last year of $483, according to the Conference Board, a private research group.

title: INVESTING WITH: W. Whitfield Gardner; Chesapeake Core Growth Fund
description: SMALL companies help W. Whitfield Gardner find big companies for the $75 million Chesapeake Core Growth fund.

title: When All Numbers Are In, Do Hedge Funds Shine?
description: HEDGE funds use many strategies to try to produce extraordinary returns in any market. But a new study suggests that, on average, hedge funds may perform worse than mutual funds.

title: The Missing Beer
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Celebrating a Schoolhouse

title: It May be Minimal, but It Challenges the Intellect
description: ''ART isn't easy,'' runs a line in ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' Stephen Sondheim's Broadway musical about the trials of artistic creation. Nowhere is this more apparent than at Real Art Ways, in Hartford, where two difficult exhibitions remind us that, for viewers as much as artists, good art challenges the intellect.

title: Miami Grabs A B.C.S. Berth, And Fitzgerald Catches Little
description: The fans who had not retreated to the warmth of their cars began to roar. It sounded a lot like a mock cheer. Pittsburgh wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald, the Heisman Trophy contender, had finally caught his first pass of the game.

title: The Year in Boxes: CD's and DVD's Learn to Share
description: FOR the 21st-century boxed set, music isn't always enough. It's a multimedia music business now, and as video-era bands amass box-worthy archives, DVD's with video clips are beginning to take their place alongside hits, outtakes, rarities and live cuts. Here, the pop music critics of The New York Times review this year's boxed sets of three discs or more that include previously unreleased material. Sets that have already been reviewed in The Times, including Led Zeppelin's ''How the West Was Won'' and Miles Davis's ''In Person Friday and Saturday Nights at the Blackhawk Complete,'' are not included. Prices are suggested retail.

title: Hurricane Kushner Hits The Heartland
description: WITH two Tony Awards, a Pulitzer Prize and a stack of once-in-a-lifetime reviews, Tony Kushner admits, ''I don't need any earthquakes in my life.''

title: Sports of The Times; Spurrier Smirk Vanished With Move to Redskins
description: HEY, let go of my ego! At one time, Steve Superior had an unapologetic vise grip on the horn he tooted as he publicly indulged in his own genius, wearing a visor like a belt to hold his vast knowledge in place.

title: On Indian Point, Quieter Debate; On Nurturing Squirrels And Other Creatures
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report on Oct. 26 about the commitment ceremony of Sandra Contreras and Elizabeth Cullen DeHaas included a credit incorrectly for Ms. Contreras, a freelance video editor. She never worked on the animated Fox network series ''King of the Hill.''

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Looking for a State Song

title: Just Saying No To the Dating Industry
description: BY her own admission, Sara Cambridge was ''totally cruising.''

title: QUICK BITE/Hamilton; Going by the Book
description: As Rat's, the restaurant in Hamilton that is named for a character in ''The Wind in the Willows,'' has expanded, so has its theme. Witness the opening two months ago of a retail bakery operation with five tables and comfortable upholstered chairs tucked away in a quaint old building across from the railway station in Hopewell. Its name? The Badger Bread Company.

title: Hilary Rogers, Davis King
description: Hilary Franklin Rogers and William Davis King Jr. were married yesterday in Atlanta, where the Rev. John Mark Wiggers performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Philip.

title: Big Wheels Keep On Turning Up
description: THEY have been used as garden steps and lawn decorations. Houses have been built with them. Some have even followed their owners to the grave.

title: On Indian Point, Quieter Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Guerrillas Shift Tactics
description: BAGHDAD, Nov. 30  Three foreign contractors were killed in two separate incidents today north of Baghdad, further marking a dangerous strategic shift by guerrillas toward attacking non-military targets, American military officials said today.

title: Necking It Down
description: Alexander Haig was the last four-star general to run for a presidential nomination. His campaign introduced two military locutions to political discourse: one was nuancal, ''subtly shaded,'' which did not last. But I still hear the useful phrasal verb to snake-check, which many veterans know means ''to examine closely.'' Before closing down his campaign headquarters, Al explained its origin: when awakening from a night out on bivouac, a soldier must snake-check his boots, which may have provided a warm home for a small snake during the night. To this day, candidates with military backgrounds like to say to aides, ''Have you snake-checked this speech?''

title: The Women
description: NATIONAL CHAMPION

title: Boston Fans Buzzing Over Schilling Trade
description: Just six weeks after Boston's crushing loss to the Yankees in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, a sense of optimism has returned to Red Sox fans.

title: The Shape of Jackets to Come
description: Olivier Theyskens, a 26-year-old Belgian designer, is renowned for a kind of High Goth, Marie Antoinette meets Morticia Addams sensibility, and when he received a call from the house of Rochas in early 2002, he was a little surprised. Rochas was a lost fashion name, a company known mostly for the creation of the gupire (a long-line girdle that smoothed the curves of women like Marlene Dietrich) and, more enduringly, for creating perfume that arrived in a pale pink box decorated in black lace. Although Rochas had made clothes since 1990, they were not distinctive. ''When they phoned to ask me if I was interested in the job,'' Theyskens (pronounced THIGH-skins) said, calling from his atelier in Paris, ''I remembered the perfume and its box. I have a passionate relationship with black lace. My grandmother, who is French, would collect black lace for me as a child. I would save it. And now I wonder if my interest started with her Rochas box. I think I have that box in my distant memory.''

title: Edgar Bronfman Jr.'s Backup Band
description: THOMAS H. LEE, the buyout maven, was slouching in an oversized chair in his Manhattan penthouse last Monday. It had been a long day. His firm, Thomas H. Lee Partners, had just wrapped up the final details of its most prominent and perhaps riskiest deal ever: a stunning $2.6 billion buyout of Warner Music led by Wall Street's favorite whipping boy, Edgar Bronfman Jr.

title: Liquor Has Day Off, But Maybe Not For Much Longer
description: WHEN the new budget bill finally passed last August, lawmakers changed the closing time for alcohol sales to 9 p.m. from 8 p.m. in the hope of generating more tax revenue for the state. It was a change that has started a battle over liquor and beer sales that is expected to intensify this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VADALA, LOUIS R.
description: VADALA--Louis R. Beloved father of Candice Vadala of NY and Cinthea Vadala of Napa, CA. Loving grandfather of Thoren Vadala of Brooklyn, NY, fond uncle of Charles Vadala family, cousins, nieces and nephews. Louis, a jazz drummer who played with Louie Prima, Raymond Scott, Orrin Tucker, Paul Lavalle, Lester Lanin and Emil Coleman. A regular band member at the Central Park Casino, Waldorf Astoria and Tavern on the Green. A WWII veteran of four and a half years. Family and friends may attend chapel services at Raccuglia and Son, 321-323 Court St, Brooklyn, 718-855-7737, December 2nd, 7-9 PM, Tuesday.

title: A Spanish City Looks to the Cup for a Lift
description: VALENCIA, Spain, Nov. 27  Anybody who doubts this city's can-do spirit need only take a look at the sinuous strip of open space running through the middle of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMYTH, LILA HARKINS
description: SMYTH--Lila Harkins, of Bronxville, NY. Died at home of a recurring brain tumor on November 26, 2003, in her eighth year of life. Cherished daughter of Dr. James and Clare Hollensteiner Smyth. Beloved sister of Luke and William Smyth. Granddaughter of Joseph and Patricia Smyth and of Robert and Letitia Baldrige Hollensteiner. Great-niece of Robert Baldridge and of the late Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige and of Margaret Baldrige, and of Louise Van der Vort. Niece of Malcolm Baldrige and Carey Hollensteiner, and of Joseph K. Smyth, Una Smyth and Kathleen Smyth Daunais. Mass of Christian burial services private. Contributions may be made to ''Making Headway Foundation Inc.'', dedicated to the care of children with brain and spinal cord tumors, 115 King Street, Chappaqua, New York 10514.

title: How to Be a Pop Star Using the Missy Method
description: WHEN Missy Elliott released ''Supa Dupa Fly,'' in 1997, it seemed like a fluke: an unskinny woman from an unhip state (Virginia) sang and rapped and giggled and whispered her way through an hour of space-age hip-hop and R & B.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, JAY M.
description: COHEN--Jay M. Mar 10, 1937 to Jan 17, 2003 In honor of your unveiling ceremony November 30, 2003. You are alive in our hearts & thoughts constantly. You left us way too soon but your fighting spirit lives within us. We miss you and love you more than words can say. Love always, Helen, Larry, Andy, Martha, Donna and Teddy

title: Roy Disney Resigns and Urges Eisner to Follow Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30  Roy E. Disney, a nephew of the founder of the Walt Disney Company , said on Sunday that he was leaving the board of directors and called for the resignation of the chairman and chief executive, Michael D. Eisner.

title: Unjustified Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Auldbrass Wasn't Rebuilt In a Day
description: When Joel Silver talks about Auldbrass, the Frank Lloyd Wright house in Yemassee, S.C., which he bought in 1986 and has been restoring for the last 15 years, filmmaking metaphors are often close at hand. Silver, Hollywood's top-grossing producer, likens the work on Auldbrass to one of his big-budget action pictures (''Lethal Weapon,'' ''Die Hard,'' ''The Matrix'' and their many offspring). Like a movie, a restoration begins with an idea set to paper, and after ''a process fraught with negotiation, problems, compromise and tremendous budget and cost issues, becomes something that lasts forever.''

title: Anton Burg, 99, Expert on Boron Who Led Way to New Materials, Dies
description: Anton Burg, an expert on the nonmetallic element boron who developed compounds used as building blocks in the creation of synthetic materials, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 99.

title: Was the Island Pre-Fab From the Start?
description: A SLENDER sliver of wood painstakingly extracted by a coring drill from a rafter of this town's best-preserved 17th-century building could prove that it was an early prefabricated residence, designed and cut in Massachusetts and then shipped to the South Fork.

title: A Plan for Five Vacant Lots Gets Plenty of Vacant Stares
description: It has taken the city more than 35 years to develop five city-owned plots, acquired as part of a 1965 urban renewal plan, near Delancey and Grand Streets. But now that Lower East Side residents have heard what's planned for the area, some wouldn't mind delaying it for another 35 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-26

title: The Name-Brand Game
description: NOW that product placement is routine in movies, television and rap songs, it is only fitting for nightspots to be next on the branding frontier. That seems to be the thinking behind Play, a new lounge in Greenwich Village, which opened in the small basement space that used to be Halo. On a Friday night, guests sat at reserved tables and played PlayStation2, donated by Sony, on plasma television screens supplied by Gateway. The waitresses, who looked like Hamptons versions of the Hooters Girls in Ugg boots and tight white tank tops, sported denim miniskirts courtesy of Paper Denim & Cloth.

title: Still Recording Music as Edison Did
description: PETER DILG wound the handle on his 1890 Edison phonograph, making a wax cylinder spin. Music crackled out of a large horn. As the slightly muffled, scratchy strains of a turn-of-the-century Ada Jones recording of ''By the Light of the Silvery Moon'' wafted from the antique machine, time seemed to slip back through the decades.

title: A Secret In the Garden
Europeans Reach Deal On Defense
description: Britain, France and Germany have struck a deal on a common European defense, including a guarantee of mutual assistance and a scaled-back plan for a headquarters, officials said.

title: Etched Into Memory
description: Modern war has given us iconic images that both shape and reflect our views of conflict.

title: The Seeds of Inspiration
description: Illuminating the mysteries of the creative process.

title: Campaign Posters Designers Would Like to See
description: In posters and buttons, leading designers make a visual statement for each of the major Democratic presidential candidates.

title: Inside Auldbrass
description: When the Hollywood producer Joel Silver stumbled on a forgotten Frank Lloyd Wright masterpiece in South Carolina, he found an obsession to consume a lifetime.
